column2: Syracuse, N.Y. The city of Syracuse, N.Y., borrowed $4,040,000 yesterday through the sale of an issue of long term bonds at an interest cost to it of 3.3396 per cent a year. The award was made to a syndicate headed by Lehman Brothers which named a price of 100.025 for the bonds to bear interest at the rate of 3.40 per cent.

In a charity polo program held at the 101st Cavalry Armory in Brooklyn last night for the benefit of the School Settlement Association, the First Division and Law Ridge trios triumphed in two fast, well-played games.

Edward Lee of the New York Athletic Club advanced to the threshold of his third consecutive national amateur three-cushion billiard championship at the New York A.C. last night by defeating Charles Gill, 50 to 39, in a fast game of fifty-one innings.

Perhaps it was because a feature of the waterway creations of 1933 is the noise eliminator, such as the submerged exhaust, but there wasn't a "put-put" last night at the opening of the National Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Five men, described by the police as a $2,000,000 arson gang, were accused of first-degree murder today in the burning of the downtown Ellington Apartment Hotel in which thirteen persons perished on June 9.
MADRID, Jan. 20. -- Reorganization of Roman Catholic non-religious activities in Spain will be undertaken soon.
The University of Pennsylvania swimming team defeated Columbia, 38 -- 33, last night in the Columbia pool in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet.

Robert Love Whitley, 28 years old, a college instructor and the son of Dr. Samuel H. Whitley, Texas educator, committed suicide by shooting himself yesterday in the bathroom of his apartment at 41-42 Forty-fourth Street, Sunny-side, Queens.
Several leases for expansion and moves to different trade centres featured the business rentals reported yesterday.

Acting in accordance with emergency messages from Mayor O'Brien, the Board of Estimate approved yesterday the abolition of the Bill Drafting Department, the Department of City Planning, and the Board of Taxicab Control. The functions of the taxi board will be restored to the Police Department, which formerly exercised them.

DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Lieutenant Irvin A. Woodring, 31, last of the army's "Three Musketeers of Aviation." noted for their daring, was killed instantly today when an experimental type attack plane which he was testing crashed near here.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In one of his cables Mr. Duranty said that "When Soviet statistics speak of pre-war production they mean pre-war factory production whereas fully half, if not more, of the goods consumed by the pre-war Russian population was produced by artisans or local handicraft labor, which has now virtually disappeared."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Farm relief advocates in Congress were noticeably encouraged by Governor Roosevelt's conversations on the subject during his brief stay here and claimed today that he had taken considerable pains to make clear that he was desirous of seeing a four-commodity relief measure passed at this session of Congress.
Albert H. Wiggin, retiring chairman of the board of directors of the Chase National Bank is sailing tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by Mrs. Wiggin.

PARIS, Jan. 20. -- The struggle between the Radical Socialists, representing the government, and the Socialists over how the 10,000,000,000-franc (about $390,000,000 at current exchange) budget deficit is going to be balanced went on all day without either side emerging victorious or the budget project getting much further on the way toward adoption.

Offering's of new bond issues this week, aggregating $16,373,086, were well received despite the somewhat irregular trend of the general bond market. Most of this week's new financing consisted of a single public utility issue, $11,250,000 of 4 1/2s of the Union Electric Light and Power Company of Missouri, due in 1957, marketed in connection with a maturity of about the same amount on May 1, next.

MONTREAL, Jan. 20. -- An unofficial boycott of all Canadian amateur hockey teams by amateur sextets in the Eastern section of the United States, with the exception of those in the Boston district, was reported today by G.T. Ogilvie, manager of the Montreal Royals.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20. -- The Soviet government today published a decree signed by Viacheslav M. Molotoff, president of the Union Council of People's Commissars, and Joseph Stalin, replacing grain collections with a fixed tax in kind on a sliding scale from an average of forty kilograms [about eighty-eight pounds] an acre in the chief grain-producing regions to twenty-five kilograms in the medium-production regions and ten in the lowest.

The New York Athletic Club's hockey team tied the Bronx H.C. for second position in the New York Amateur League by battling to an overtime 4-to-4 tie with the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton sextet at the New York Coliseum last night before 2,500 persons.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- Returning from a meeting of the board of directors of the Westchester Title and Trust Company in New York this afternoon, Reginald P. Ray, vice president in charge of the mortgage department, said the directors had expressed "sympathy" toward the efforts of the Lawyers Westchester Mortgage and Title Company to reduce the interest rates on mortgages.

It would be ungracious and needless to debate whether the President or Governor ROOSEVELT prevailed in the White House agreement of yesterday. Roughly it may be said that the original idea of Mr. HOOVER was retained, but that the methods insisted upon by Mr. ROOSEVELT were accepted.

Don Collins, Internationally known confidence man with a long record of convictions, who faces a possible life term as a habitual criminal if he again Is convicted, was one of four men indicted by the grand jury yesterday on felonious assault charges growing out of an attack on Detective Louis Raskin of the West Sixty-eighth Street station last New Year's Eve in the West End Club in West Seventy-second Street.

For the first time since the award was instituted in 1920, the prize to the New York Athletic Club athlete who made the greatest progress in his sport during the past year will have joint ownership when the Veterans' Association of the N.Y. A.C. honors both Leo Sexton, the Olympic shot-putting champion, and Angelo Trulio, national handball titleholder and the winner of ten crowns, at its annual dinner at the Winged Foot clubhouse tonight.

The value of a well-planned conservation program has been brought home to sportsmen, in New Jersey through the recent announcement of the State Game and Fish Commission that it would be forced to curtail expenditures for restocking purposes.

In Kansas, prohibition has had its long and perfect work. It must be for less fortunate States that The Emporia Gazette is moved and grieved as it sees mischief conceived and iniquity brought forth at Washington:

Twenty men were saved yesterday from eviction from "Hudson City," a shanty colony they had built on the dumps west of River-side Drive, by the intervention of Mayor O'Brien and an unidentified man, well dressed and of middle age, who has befriended them on other occasions.
At the request of Mayor O'Brien the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to appropriate $5,000,000 for unemployment relief in the city during February.

ST. PAUL, Minn., Jan. 20. -- Warning that taxpayers were about to go on strike, more than 500 farmers and business men marched into the Minnesota capital today and demanded a 25 per cent reduction in State expenditures.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- German business, though not definitely optimistic, is reflecting the belief that the low point has been passed the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of world economic conditions.
When the trustee of Mary C. Tompkins sold to Agnes L. Rodgers, 215 West 101th Street for $34,463. Mrs. Rodgers gave back a purchase money mortgage for $31,000 payable five years hence, at 5 per cent.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Vice Chancellor Bigelow today ordered permanent receivership for the Pressed Steel Car Company of Jersey City, manufacturers of railroad cars, with plants in Pittsburgh and Chicago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20 (AP). -- It cost Hawthorne Bissell, 24-year-old nephew of the late Charles W. Hawthorne, artist, $74,84 today for his unsuccessful attempt to persuade his wife to return with him to his Summer home at Province-town, Mass., after a separation of six months.

John W. Neal of Houston, Texas, an officer of the Cheek-Neal Coffee Company, lost yesterday an application to strike out the defense in a suit against the National City Bank for 5587,978 when Justice Dore of the Supreme Court held that the defense was proper.

Production figures of forty-four life insurance companies for 1932 disclose that 17.9 per cent less new life insurance was purchased than in 1931. These figures are contained in a statement forwarded to the United States Department of Commerce by the Association of Life Insurance Presidents.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The cause and cure of war conference called by Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt unanimously endorsed today the administration's Far Eastern policy, the disarmament proposals of President Hoover and the Senate resolution empowering the President to prohibit the export of arms and munitions to nations at war.

Old inventions come to life again in these days of broadcasting. Fifty years ago, when the telephone was the world's latest wonder, ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL showed that it was possible for a beam of light to transmit speech and music.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated Jan. 18:

WOLF ISLAND, Mo., Jan. 20. -- Two full-grown lions refused to take Denver M. Wright and his score of hunters seriously today when they were released from their cage as prey for an "African" lion hunt.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Circuit Court Judge Rulif V. Lawrence filed today with the Supreme Court here a decision holding that William C. Durant of Deal, automobile manufacturer, was entitled to recover a part of his losses sustained in the stock market.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 20 (AP). -- With Monte Parke in the saddle, Benny Creech's Whipper Cracker came home from behind to win the mile feature at Jefferson Park today.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- It was denied today in The City that any gold at all had been earmarked by the Bank of England in favor of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York on Dec. 15 as part of the process by which England paid the war debt instalment of $95,500,000, due on that day to the United States.

THE runners are pounding the indoor tracks again and it promises to be a lively season on the turns. The program or prospectus of the Jefferson Club meet at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn this evening features events at "Olympic distances." a gentle method of hinting that the hated meter will be the unit of measurement.

William B. Ward, president of the Ward Baking Corporation, who died on Feb. 6, 1929, left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,023,788 gross and $3,770,421 net. The bulk of the estate consisted of $3,696,871 as the value of six trust funds comprised of stock of the Ward Foundation Corporation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 20. -- A denial that the doctrine of a life after death finds support in biological science was voiced tonight by Professor Herbert S. Jennings, zoologist and geneticist of Johns Hopkins University, in the final Dwight H. Terry lecture at Yale University.

What education should give, from the standpoint of the needs of business, was described last night by Percy S. Straus, vice president of R.H. Macy Co., as a grammar school course related to life and chiefly vocational; a high school curriculum stressing cultural values even in vocational courses, and a college training that is primarily cultural.

LONDON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The agreement between President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt to discuss the war debts with Great Britain without delay was described in political quarters here this evening as the best news in weeks.

Members of the casts of "Autumn Crocus," at the Morosco; "Dangerous Corner," Fat the Fulton, and "20th Century" at the Broadhurst, have volunteered to donate 1 per cent of their salaries to the Stage Relief Fund.

Old inventions come to life again in these days of broadcasting. Fifty years ago, when the telephone was the world's latest wonder, ALEXANDER GRAHAM BELL showed that it was possible for a beam of light to transmit speech and music.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 20. -- Alfred G. Kay is chairman of the committee sponsoring the exhibition tennis matches to be played on the Everglades Club courts Sunday night. Among the players who will take part are William T. Tilden 2d, Bruce Barnes 2d, former intercollegiate doubles champion; Hans Nusslein, champion of Germany, and Emmett Pare of Chicago.

Considering the number of developments that might have been expected ordinarily to drive prices sharply upward, the slow advance in the security markets yesterday was somewhat disappointing to Wall Street. It was remarked in commission house circles, in explanation of the comparatively sluggish movement, that the markets have not been accustomed of late to give effect to such news as quickly as they did in the past.

ON BOARD ROOSEVELT SPECIAL TRAIN, Lynchburg, Va., Jan. 20. -- The way for an approach by France and other debtor nations for further revision of their war debts to this country was cleared today by the conference between President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt, at which the latter agreed to receive British representative to discuss the war debt situation soon after his inauguration on March 4.
NEW YORK. Charles A. Davila, the Rumanian Ambassador, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 20. -- The lightly campaigned colt Chief John, owned by J.A. Marsch and a starter only four times in 1932, scored for the first time since September, 1931, when he drove to a neck victory in the Arcadia Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today.

The Board of Elections voted yesterday to make an independent Investigation of the failure of many election inspectors to file proper returns on the written-in vote for Joseph V. McKee. Eighteen more inspectors surrendered to indictments charging fraud and were held in $1,000 bail each.

St. Ann's Academy moved into fourth place in the Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. basketball tournament by defeating De La Salle Institute, 24 to 21, yesterday at the West Twenty-eighth Street gymnasium.

Repeal of laws prohibiting railroads from engaging in water transportation, discontinuance of the government owned and operated Inland Waterways Corporation, and regulation of all water carriers under the supervision of the Inter-state Commerce Commission, were among the measures for a new national transportation policy, to be developed by Congress, advocated last night at a meeting of the New York Railroad Club by Milton W. Harrison, president of the Security Owners Association.

More than 5,000 persons, including many prominent in the political life of city and State, attended the annual reception and entertainment of the Thomas M. Farley Association, regular Tammany organization of the Fourteenth Assembly District, last night at the Central Opera House, Sixty-seventh Street and Third Avenue.
PEIPING, Jan. 20. -- The Japanese claimed today that they had cleared out the volunteer Chinese forces that had been harassing their lines of communication into Jehol from South Manchuria.

Impressed by the kind and courteous treatment given to women prisoners in the house of detention for women at West Tenth Street, "and the splendid and humane construction of the building," Miss Joan Poole, daughter of Sir Reginald Poole and secretary of the Thirteen-County Scheme of the Holloway Discharged Prisoner's Aid, in London, declared yesterday that "she would carry on a vigorous campaign for the erection of a similiar penal institution in England.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- President Hoover today took to the country his contest with Congress over budget-balancing legislation. He called attention particularly to the action of the House yesterday in rejecting a reorganization program, which, the President asserted, would have been "a contribution to lessening taxation in the forthcoming fiscal year."

An opposition slate of directors presented by supporters of John T. Austin, suspended last Fall as president of the United States Bond end Mortgage Corporation, was defeated yesterday by a vote of more than 7 to 1 at the annual meeting of stockholders of the corporation in the auditorium of the Chanin Building, 122 East Forty-second Street.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The Chicago Stadium Corporation, owner of America's biggest indoor-sports arena, today surrendered its four-year fight to beat general economic conditions when Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson placed it in equity receivership.

GENEVA, Jan. 20. -- The League of Nations released today the second part of the report of the Preparatory Economic Commission containing the annotated agenda, a 13,000-word commentary on the six agenda points contained in the first part published yesterday.

More than 200 representatives of power and light companies, State rate-making bodies and other organizations met yesterday at the first session of the Public Engineering Institute, in the Hotel Pennsylvania, to discuss problems expected to have a wide bearing on the future of electric light and power rates.

Tributes to Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, novelist and missionary, for her portrayal of the life of the Chinese people were paid by fellow-authors yesterday at a luncheon given in her honor by the League for Political Education at the Hotel Astor. Almost 1,000 members of the league and their quests attended.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- The steering committee of the Reichstag today voted to postpone the next session of the Legislature for another week, fixing the date as Jan. 31 instead of Tuesday as originally scheduled.

Currency inflation and all inflationary measures proposed in and out of Congress to end the depression were condemned as illusory and likely to lead to destructive consequences by Francis H. Sisson, president of the American Bankers Association, in an address yesterday before the New York State Bankers Association at its midwinter meeting at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney endorsed proposed bills to require defense counsel to notify the prosecution of an alibi defense in advance of trial, and against slot machines, in an address yesterday at the luncheon given by the Association of Grand Jurors of New York County at the Hotel McAlpin.

The Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital treated 25,949 dogs, cats, horses, parrots, monkeys and other animals during the last year, it was reported yesterday by Miss Rosa Anne Grosvenor, chairman of the executive committee of the New York Women's League for Animals, Inc., at its annual meeting at the home of Mrs. Orme Wilson, 3 East Sixty-fourth Street.

The New York University football team will engage in seven contests next Fall, according to the schedule announced yesterday by Philip O. Badger, chairman of the university's board of athletic control. Last season eight games were played.

World Rescue Groups. America is to contribute six members to a committee made up Groups of the twenty - five greatest minds in the world, which Professor EINSTEIN is said to be getting ready to select.
PARIS, Jan. 20. -- France's interest in the Roosevelt-Hoover conversations on the war debt question resembles somewhat that of the holder of dummy in a bridge game.

HAVANA, Jan. 20. -- With all indications pointing to a successful meeting, the fifty-one session of the Cuban-American Jockey Club at Oriental Park will get under way tomorrow. Elaborate plans have been made to maintain racing of the highest grade.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The estimated cost of building construction, including alterations and repairs, declined 19.5 per cent in December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today on the basis of reports from 348 cities with populations of 25,000 and over.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 20. -- The first use in litigation of the theories of technocracy was disclosed here today in an answer to a civil suit filed in the County Clerk's office by Herbert Bruce Brougham of 117 Ralph Avenue.

Antonio Scotti, seasoned veteran of the world's stage during forty-three years, from Malta and Milan to London, Buenos Aires and New York, can look back today on a third of a century among the stars of the Metropolitan Opera Company.

Not the least of those being trained in sales promotion in the department store organization of William Filene's Sons Company, Boston, are store executives, according to William H. McLeod, advertising manager for that store, who so told the National Retail Dry Goods Association at the closing session of its twenty-second annual convention at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- The casualness with which this city accepts the unusual was never more strikingly manifested than today when the President and the man who in a short time will be his successor sat in the Red Room of the White House while Washington calmly went about its business.

Led by United States Government issues the prices of bonds on the New York Stock Exchange advanced appreciably yesterday in active dealings. Federal obligations gained 2-32 to 14-32 point for the day, sending most of the long-term loans close to the peak prices for more than a year, which were established a few days ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- The powerful Democratic leadership in Congress tonight threw the full force of its support behind a mammoth plan for adjusting the debts of the nation's farmers on a basis of their ability to pay.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The outstanding fact of the present day is that our economic machinery is out of order because we did not believe the warnings of those who foresaw that the economic consequences of the war would be of an almost revolutionary character.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- The Boerse was firmer today, despite a small turnover and lack of clarification of the political outlook. Stocks as well as bonds showed an upward tendency, with Farben and several steel and coal stocks of special market interest.

Urging the investor for his own advantage to accept for a few years a lower rate of interest on his guaranteed mortgages. Richard M. Hurd, president of the Lawyers Mortgage Company, in his report to stockholders, said that when the vast amount of mortgage debt was realized it became apparent that the owners of New York real estate and the guaranteed mortgage companies must have the cooperation of the mortgage investor.

While the great figures of the lyric stage of the past and the present sat out in front at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon for Scotti's farewell, felicitations poured in on the distinguished baritone by telephone, letter, telegram and cable from all parts of the United States and from points overseas.

The New York Giants brought their fourth member of the year into the fold with the announcement yesterday that Hughie Critz, regular second baseman, had sent in his signed contract. Accompanying the document was a letter, the contents of which Secretary Jim Tierney was more than pleased to reveal.

Helen Canasta and her husband, Melvyn Douglas, are planning a joint appearance next Summer in a new play by Dan Totheron called "Mother Load," which will be presented by Belasco Curran, Coast producers, according to word received here.

The organization of a strong minority of thinking persons throughout the United States and the elimination of "hypocritical platitudes" in education were urged last night by educators as the means by which our economic and social structure can be reorganized.

The "good ship Ile de France" steamed into the grand ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria last night, took on board more than 3,000 fancifully costumed members of society and the artistic world and bore them off on a fantastic "cruise" to seven remote corners of the globe.

Believed to have been injured by a hit-and-run automobile driver, William Van Houten, 10 years old, of 133-09 115th Avenue, South Ozone Park, Queens, was found in a dying condition last evening in a vacant lot not far from his home at 115th and Lincoln Avenues

Holcombe Ward, president of the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association, is slated to be re-elected to office for another year when the annual meeting and elections of the organization are held next Saturday at the Hotel Vanderbilt.

A resolution calling for State legislation at the present session of the Legislature to make possible revision of the city charter was adopted last night at a meeting of representatives of about thirty-five civic organizations at the Bar Association Building, held at the invitation of the recently formed City party.
The substitution of a heavyweight battle for a canceled welterweight struggle last night in Madison Square Garden proved to be neither a competitive, financial nor an artistic success.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best name. Thursday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best name. The quotations are for tnree-four months' paper.

The annual report of the Ameriean Superpower Corporation for 1932 shows total assets at the end of the year amounting to $113,848,1322, with a market value of $58,656,374 on last Saturday. Deducting accrued first preferred and preference dividends and miscellaneous liabilities, the market value was equal to $99.75 a share on combined 334,991 first preferred and 235,207 preference shares. There are 8,293,005 common shares outstanding.

Far East Developments TOKYO -- Foreign Minister Uchida in an address to the Peers today issues a warning to China of "unfortunate eventualities" if she continues her warlike preparations; also that Japan will regard an increase of Communist activities along the Yangtse as a "serious menace."

TOKYO, Jan. 20. -- Throughout Japan, army recruits began reporting to their stations today in obedience to a War Office decision which is expected to increase by 50 per cent Japan's manpower in Manchuria.

A performance long to be remembered, and watched by some with eyes that blurred, took place yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, when Antonio Scotti made his last appearance on the lyric stage, as Chim-Fen in Leone's "L'Oracolo," and thus took leave of the Metropolitan Opera Association and the public he has served with such distinguished art for thirty-three years.

The production of zinc throughout the world in December amounted to 73,803 short tons, compared with 70,285 tons in November and 80,617 tons in December, 1931, according to the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. The production of zinc in the United States in December was 18,489 tons, against 15,958 tons in November.

Hans Kempinski and his cousin, Dr. F.W. Unger Kempinski, partners in M. Kempinski Co., wine dealers and wine producers of Berlin, arrived yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen to survey the possible market for their products in New York and other large cities of the United States in the event of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

Albert H. Wiggin, chairman of the American committee on German standstill credits, and F. Abbot Goodhue, president of the Bank of the Manhattan Company, who is chairman of the junior standstill committee, will leave this city today on the Bremen for Berlin, where a meeting of international bankers has been called for Jan. 30 to draw up an agreement to replace the current German standstill agreement.

They have cast Jack Pearl as the Dresden police commissioner in "Pardon My English," which opened at the Majestic last night. But underneath all those scarlet and rococo costumes the Hester Street influence still tells. That is the essential thing about Jack.

Governor LEHMAN will need the support given to a leader in an ancient battle, that his hands may be upheld in his effort to prevent impairment of the school system of the State and the increase of the burden upon local taxpayers. He has consented, after consultation with the Board of Regents, to the reduction of $9,000,000, which is the estimated amount of the salary increments for 1933 under the present law.

Reflecting the lower prices for securities which prevailed during the year, the annual reports of four large investment companies in the Harrison Williams group showed smaller net assets at the end of 1932 than a year earlier. The companies are the Shenandoah Corporation, the Blue Ridge Corporation, the American Cities Power and Light Corporation and the Electric Shareholdings Corporation.

An ill woman and Mittens, her pet cat, who were overcome by smoke in a fire at a boarding house at 315 West Thirty-third Street, were rescued yesterday by Captain Joseph B. Martin of Hook and Ladder 24, son of "Smoky Joe" Martin.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Behind the strongest police guard mobilized in Berlin in months. Adolf Hitler, in a fiery address at the crowded Sportspalast, tonight assailed the "system of defeatism enforced since 1918."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20 (AP). -- A concentrated attack on France's default on her war debt to America was loosed in the Senate today after Senator Robinson, Republican, of Indiana, had called that country a "thorough ingrate" and urged prompt passage of the Johnson bill to bar financial dealings with nations failing to pay.

Residents of New York who bought investment certificates of the Investors Syndicate of Minneapolis, a Minnesota corporation, are entitled to demand the return of money paid, on the ground that the concern had no license from the State Banking Department to make the sales in this State and had not deposited $100,000 as the law requires of a foreign investment company.

An appropriation of $1,462,925 to enable the Board of Transportation to complete and place in operation, within the next six months, twenty-two additional route miles of new city subways was voted yesterday by the Board of Estimate. The board also authorized the issuance of city securities sufficient to raise the money.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 20. -- Old-time cricketers here are quietiv smiling at the news from Australia that English players are alleged to be practicing what is known in baseball as "dusting 'em off."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Following is the text of the address on Japan's foreign relations to be delivered by Count Uchida, Foreign Minister, before the House of Peers tomorrow, as given out by the Japanese Embassy:
Although business was smaller than usual, prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday and ended 4 to 5 points higher than on Thursday.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Count Uchida in his address to the Diet in Tokyo replied to members of the Continued on Page Six.

The season's first performance of "Siegfried" at the Metropolitan last night brought entirely new characterizations in three roles, in addition to returning to the repertoire this music-drama of youth and love and overwhelming beauty. And for all these favors, and chiefly the favor of an integral and moving performance a large audience was enthusiastically grateful.

Providence College outlasted Manhattan in a hard-fought basketball game, 30-27, and gave the Jasper team its fourth successive setback at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. A near-capacity crowd of 1,100 looked on.

GENEVA, Jan. 20. -- Manoeuvring continued today between the League of Nations and Japan with the view either to put conciliation of the Chino-Japanese conflict on a basis of compromise or to end the League's conciliation procedure or the most favorable moral ground.

American holders of German Government "revaluation bonds," which were issued to replace "pre-inflation bonds" outstanding before 1923, when money was being printed without stint, have failed generally to present their bonds for payment when the issues have been drawn by lot for redemption, according to the New York and Hanseatic Corporation, which points out that these drawings have taken place annually since 1926.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Plans for bankruptcy reform, intended to prevent widespread involuntary liquidation, were embodied in two bills completed today by the House Judiciary Committee. They will be introduced tomorrow or on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- President-elect Roosevelt has offered the position of Secretary of the Treasury in his administration to Senator Glass of Virginia and that of Attorney General to Senator Walsh of Montana, according to those close to Mr. Roosevelt.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 20. -- Harvard University announced today the award of grants to twenty-two members of the faculty from appropriations made by the General Board of Education for studies in the humanities.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Following is the text of Governor Lehman's statement announcing that he had applied to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for an allotment of $45,000,000 to aid the State in unemployment relief, and the text of his application:

The Board of Estimate has done well to approve an appropriation of $1,462,925 to advance the city's Independent Subway System. Chairman DELANEY gave some illuminating figures in his recent letter to the board on which its action yesterday was based.

In a howling wind and dangerous seas the American Merchant liner American Merchant saved twenty-two members of the crew of the British freighter Exeter City in mid-Atlantic yesterday, and left the little vessel foundering, broken and torn apart by the fury of the seas.
PARIS. Jan. 20. -- The fate of the Bank for International Settlements at Basle will be determined at the World Economic Conference, French financial opinion is now suggesting.

Mrs. Alice Scribner, 24-year-old Yonkers mother, who loaded her unemployed husband's rusty army revolver with soap and held up a Brooklyn bakery shop, received a suspended sentence from County Judge Algeron I. Nova In Brooklyn yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20 (AP). -- J. N. Bozeman Jr., young cue master from Vallejo, Cal., tonight went into the lead in the struggle for the world's championship in three-cushion billiards by defeating Allen Hall of Chicago, 50 to 34, in forty-three innings.

DUBLIN, Jan. 20. -- The Free State Senate, which has held up most of the Fianna Fail's radical legislation, will be abolished or, if retained, its numbers will be much reduced, should President Eamon de Valera win the election.

The F.W. Dodge Corporation reports that contracts awarded for new construction in thirty-seven States east of the Rocky Mountains during the period from Jan. 1 to Jan. 15, this year, totaled $43,261,300. During the corresponding period of 1932 the total reported was $37,312,000.

Removal of the three receivers appointed by Supreme Court Justice Salvatore A. Cotillo for Local 306, Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, wag demanded in the Appellate Division yesterday by former United States Attorney Charles H. Tuttle, counsel for the parent union, on the ground that the receivership placed the Supreme Court in the position of controlling strikes and posting pickets.

At the end of 1932 The Annalist index of business activity in the United States stood "at about 40 per cent below estimated normal." But it is pointed out in the Annual Review and Forecast Number, published yesterday, that the figure for the year's end showed a gain of about 15 per cent from the low point reached last July.

FLORENCE, Italy, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Miss Grace Cleveland Porter, the daughter of the late William Porter of Summit, N.J., a relative of President Grover Cleveland, was married today to Riccardo Nobili, a former officer of the grenadiers and a painter who has exhibited at Venice, Paris and at the Chicago Fair of 1893.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Montagu Norman, governor of the Bank of England, is engaged to marry Mrs. Priscilla Cecilia Maria Worsthorne it is revealed by marriage intentions filed at the Chelsea Registry Office.

MANILA, Jan. 20 (AP). -- Manuel Quezon, President of the Philippine Senate and for many years leader of Filipino agitation for immediate independence, was reported today to favor a vote with little delay on the acceptance or rejection of insular freedom in about twelve years, as provided in a bill passed by Congress Tuesday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 20 -- The issuance immediately of $5,555,000 in tax revenue notes of various denominations, based on $8,000,000 delinquent taxes, to be used to pay salaries of school teachers and city employes is being considered by Mayor Harry Bacharach and members of the City Commission.

MANILA, Jan. 20. -- It is reliably reported Manual Quezon has abandoned his trip to the United States and will go only as far as Shanghai, where he will meet the Philippine independence mission, which, it is said, will be recalled.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- Notes recently exchanged by Secretary Stimson and W.D. Herridge, the Canadian Minister, concerning water diversion at the Massena Canal and Grass River in connection with development of the St. Lawrence Deepwater Way were made public by the State Department today to show that the United States and New York State would not be restricted in dealing with the power question there as a domestic problem.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- Traders in wheat on the Board of Trade here bought early today on the strength in stocks and talk of inflation in Canadian currency, besides an official report placing the acreage in the Punjab district in India at about 2,000,000 acres under that of last year.

With more than 700 athletes entered, the Jefferson Club will stage its third annual charity track and field meet at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn tonight. The leading attraction is Leo Sexton of the New York A.C., the Olympic shot-putting champion and one of six members of the American Olympic team, who will compete in the games.

Effective next Wednesday, the rates of interest paid by clearing house banks on deposits will be cut in half, making the return to depositors the smallest on record. The new rates are one-quarter of 1 per cent on demand deposits, except those deposited by mutual savings banks, which will receive one-half of 1 per cent, and one-half of 1 per cent on time deposits.

A commission headed by Herbert Hoover during the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt, if Mr. Roosevelt is "big enough" to appoint Mr. Hoover, to find a solution of the country's industrial problems and seek to prevent recurring depressions, was proposed yesterday by Elon H. Hooker, industrialist, at a meeting of the Woman's Forum in the Hotel Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. -- Prices of hogs advanced 5 to 15 cents a hundred pounds today to the best levels since Nov. 28, the top being raised 10 cents to $3.50, while the day's average was up 10 cents at $3.30. Light hogs led the upturn and gained 10 to 15 cents, while heavy kinds were up 5 to 10 cents and sows were steady to 5 cents higher.

With his back turned on them on the witness stand, ignoring their presence, Giuseppi Leonti, 40 years old, heard yesterday his wife, Sadie, and their 16-year-old son, Joseph, testify against him in his General Sessions trial on a first-degree murder indictment in the stabbing of his 19-year-old daughter, Anna, a bride of eleven days, in their home, then at 248 Broome Street, on April 3 last.

Stocks and bonds advanced again yesterday as the financial focus shifted to Washington, where President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt, in a harmonious meeting, gave assent to British suggestions that the foreign debt situation and "world economic problems" be explored at a conference of representatives of the American and British Governments.

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Declaring that the State's relief funds are at the point of exhaustion, Governor Lehman applied today to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for a Federal advance of $45,000,000. Of this amount, he asked that $34,600,000 be made available in the next six months, $6,100.000 for February, $7,100,000 for March, $6,600,000 for April, $5,600,000 for May and $4,600,000 each for June and July.

To the Editor of The New York Times: On Jan. 11 in an editorial you told us how to save $400,000,000 by repealing the law now giving pensions to old and disabled soldiers, and wound up with: "To this program the Democrats in Congress and the incoming President are pledged by their platform."

ALBANY, Jan. 20. -- Governor Lehman expressed his confidence in District Attorney Crain's investigation of election frauds in New York City today when W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, and other members of a group of city officials and political leaders urged Governor Lehman to start new and sweeping inquiries.

Paulist priests from all parts of the country will come to attend the celebration here next week of the diamond jubilee of the Missionary Society of St. Paul the Apostle, commonly known as the Paulist Fathers. All the services will be in the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, the "mother church" of the community, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

After having expounded in a radio address last night her belief in the right of a married woman to her own career, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt plans a practical demonstration of her thesis today. She is scheduled to fly to Chicago, where she is to deliver a lecture tonight under the auspices of the Illinois League of Women Voters.

Automobile Finance Company (Pittsburgh, Pa.) -- Year ended Dec. 31: Net income after Federal taxes, expenses and other charges, $26,521, equal to $1.13 a share on 23,552 7 per cent preferred shares, against $61,624, equivalent after preferred requirements, to $1.87 a share on 10,888 common shares, in 1931.

Balance sheets of the insurance companies in the America Fore group, as of Jan. 1, issued yesterday, show that the two largest increased their total assets last year. Of the remaining five companies, four showed slight declines, while the fifth, the smallest in the group, gained.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 20. -- Two of the four top seeded players were forced to withdraw as the annual New Jersey squash tennis championship got under way at the Short Hills Club today.

Dock Commissioner John McKenzie defended his proposal for the establishment of a free zone in the port of New York where foreign cargoes would be transferred from one ship to another or prepared for transshipment in an address last night before the annual meeting of the Propeller Club, at the Down-town Athletic Club building.

A purse-snatcher who yesterday at noon followed Mrs. Mary Rhatigan, an elderly widow, into her doorway at 111 Congress Street, Brooklyn, stole her pocketbook and ran down the street, was stopped a block away by an energetic Boy Scout who checked the thief's flight with a flying tackle.

The deportation of Kid Chocolate, recognized here as the world's champion, cost him his chance to box Seaman Tom Watson, Great Britain's titleholder, in Madison Square Garden next Friday. James J. Johnston, the Garden's boxing director, announced yesterday he had abandoned plans for the fight, temporarily at least.

Four men were burned, one critically, when the gasoline tank of the thirty-foot fishing trawler C2734 exploded early last evening while the craft was being refueled in Sheepshead Bay off Exeter Street and Shore Boulevard, Brooklyn. Flames caused by the explosion burned to the waterline, menacing other boats anchored near by.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- After a day of futile debate and no progress on his banking reform bill, Senator Glass rose late this afternoon to describe as valueless the unanimous consent agreement reached yesterday and to give notice that beginning Monday he would insist on night sessions.

Four men were burned, one critically, when the gasoline tank of the thirty-foot fishing trawler C2734 exploded early last evening while the craft was being refueled in Sheepshead Bay off Exeter Street and Shore Boulevard, Brooklyn. Flames caused by the explosion burned to the waterline, menacing other boats anchored near by.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 20. -- After a day of futile debate and no progress on his banking reform bill, Senator Glass rose late this afternoon to describe as valueless the unanimous consent agreement reached yesterday and to give notice that beginning Monday he would insist on night sessions.

Announcement that $152,000 par value of Mobile Ohio Railroad general 4 per cent bonds of 1938 had been called for redemption at par caused an advance of 2 1/2 points yesterday in the price of Southern Railway Mobile Ohio collateral 4 per cent bonds of 1938.

TULSA. Okla., Jan. 20 (AP). -- Charges flew about the oil industry today as petroleum prices in the midcontinent field fell generally from a peak of 77 cents a barrel to a 52-cent top. Senator Elmer Thomas. Oklahoma Democrat, asserted in Washington "the price was cut because the big companies are getting all the oil they want -- stolen oil."

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- Adolf Hitler's Berlin storm troops will line up in the Buelowplatz tomorrow afternoon "with their front to Karl Liebknecht Haus," the headquarters of the Communist party, before marching to near-by Nicolai Cemetery for the commemoration of the death of Horst Wessel, the young trooper who was killed by Communists two years ago and has become a glorified hero of the National Socialist party.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 21. -- The Foreign Ministers of Argentina, Brazil and Chile have begun a keen diplomatic contest for leadership in terminating the Chaco hostilities and for the international prestige that would accompany success in accomplishing what the commission of neutrals at Washington failed to accomplish.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 21. -- George Douglas Debevoise and Perry R. Pease of the Racquet and Tennis Club, the metropolitan squash racquets doubles champions, led the field into the semi-final round today in the first annual handicap tournament of the Piping Rock Club, which started this morning with sixteen teams from clubs all over the metropolitan area entered.

FIRST the old-fashioned saloon, then the newfangled speakeasy, then what? This is the question which bobs up these days like the ghost of Banquo at Macbeth's feast to trouble both the moderates and the wringing wets.

Fifteen Roman Catholic institutions and clergymen will share in the $18,000 estate of Margaret Sullivan, who died on Dec. 28 at St. Joseph's Home for the Aged at 209 West Fifteenth Street, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate.

A wholesale reduction in the funded indebtedness of railroads would adversely affect their credit, it is asserted in an editorial in the current issue of Railway Age, although lowering of totals may be necessary in some cases, it is added. The St. Louis-San Francisco Railway is furthering a plan to decrease its funded debt through a voluntary recapitalization.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Adoption of shorter working schedules by industries throughout the country has supplied jobs for about 5,000,000 men and women who otherwise would be unemployed, according to a preliminary survey made by the share-the-work committee of which Walter C. Teagle is chairman.
ALBANY, Jan. 21. -- In an effort to slash personal service expenditures, a policy of retiring State employes over 60 years of age and abolishing the positions has been started in several departments.

POMPTON LAKES, N.J., Jan. 21. -- This little village made its bid today for a share of the fame which technocracy has brought to Howard Scott, its chief exponent. Here in a little two-story brick building, the villagers say, was the birthplace, or at any rate the nursery, of the great idea.
Optimism is returning to the real estate and building field, said Benjamin Winter yesterday.

Revision of the tax system to make the mass of citizens instead of a small portion bear the burden was described by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in a speech last night as the one sure road to government economy and a general public interest in the workings of government.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- During the stay here this week of the President-elect some persons who were admitted to the inner circle of Mr. Roosevelt's advisers were convinced that they saw unmistakable evidences of friction between two of his most prominent counselors on foreign affairs, Norman H. Davis and Professor Raymond Moley.

The New York Giants advanced another important notch yesterday in bringing their athletes into the fold for 1933 with the announcement by Secretary Jim Tierney that the signed contract of Carl Hubbell, the long, lean and expert left-hander, had just been received.

The individual who in 1932 was outstanding in the sport of motor boating will be honored at the Motor Boat Show by the Regatta Circuit Riders' Club, national organization of motor boat racing enthusiasts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Despite the depression the nations of the world are spending $4,000,000,000 this year on armaments. If these billions and the millions of men now engaged in the unproductive services of preparing for war were used instead in productive services, what progress might the world not make in the elimination of poverty and disease.

A 7-year-old girl and her uncle were seriously injured and another uncle was slightly hurt last evening when their automobile was in collision with a B.M.T. bus at East Thirty-fifth Street and Kings Highway, Brooklyn. About a dozen passengers in the bus were shaken up but none was hurt.

A "sell American" campaign, in which merchants and producers would strive to build a better consumer appreciation of the products of American factories, would be more appropriate at this time than the "Buy American" movement now under way, Louis Blumenstock, advertising counselor of Hartman's, Chicago, points out in a statement to THE TIMES.

PARIS. I DO not know whether many American girls read the books of Mme. de Segur in their childhood. But I would willingly believe that many of them have, for it so happened, during certain conferences in New York, that when I mentioned the "Malheurs de Sophie" I saw a smile of comprehension pass over more than one face.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., Jan. 21. -- In a speech on the portico of the Alabama State Canitol here tonight, Franklin D. Roosevelt, President-elect, declared that he would take steps to put in operation the government-owned power and nitrate plants at Muscle Shoals soon after his inauguration.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 21. -- A wide police search for Michael Legdon, 18 years old, who had been indicted in connection with two murders in Passaic County, appeared ended tonight when detectives returning from Goshen, N.Y., declared that a youth held in the Orange County jail, who had given the name of John Miller, had been "positively identified" as Legdon.

NOW it develops that Pauline Lord, the actress, has purchased two paintings by Alexander Geiss, included in an exhibition for needy artists at the Seventh Avenue Roxy's. This development scintillates with potential drama.

Senator Borah's influence on American foreign policy will be little diminished when he is superseded as chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee after March 4, Professor Allan Nevins of Columbia University predicts in an article in February Current History, entitled "Borah and World Affairs."

BERLIN, Jan. 7. THE supernatural, the magical, was always one of the most resonant strings in the theatre's lyre -- and I don't need to wrap myself in the robes of the prophet to foretell that it always will be. For the more mechanical and prosaic our life becomes, the happier we are to fly to the freedom of the theatre, where spirits wander and a poodle can turn into a devil.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 21. -- The Bolivian Government, according to reliable information received here today, has ordered the Bolivian delegation to the League of Nations to inform it that Paraguay is maufacturing asphyxiating war gas in the botanical park at Asuncion under the direction of a "European chemist."
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 21. -- A large dinner was given by Joseph E. Widener and Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d at their residence this evening.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The St. Valentine's golf tournament, which annually attracts leading amateurs of the North and the South, will begin tomorrow. A system of play never before used in the twenty-nine years' history of this event will be inaugurated.

THE chief purpose of Mr. Looker's volume is to weave together into a single complete narrative the story of Colonel Roosevelt's desire to raise and command a division of troops for service in France at the beginning of our entrance into the World War and to exonerate him in that matter from any but single-minded and patriotic motives.

The police and immigration and customs authorities of the entire nation, especially those in seaports and border points, received a general alarm late yesterday notifying them to be on the lookout for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer-runner, and two of his lieutenants, Henry (Sailor) Stevens and Frank Ahearn, wanted here for income-tax evasion.

THERE is a war going on, a war so insidious that most of the inhabitants of this planet are unaware of it, yet of so vital a character that its effects upon posterity may be considered of far greater importance than those of the politico-economic wars that feature the daily news.

Continued weakness in butter and eggs stood out as the most significant development in commodity markets yesterday. Butter and eggs staged a fresh decline to levels unequaled in a good many years. Else- where, the grains were irregularly lower, while cotton firmed up. Coffee, sugar and cocoa were higher; rubber lower, silk and hides steady.

The steel industry has passed the lowest level of the depression and has started to retrace its steps, according to a study of the probable five-year future of steel by Robert E. Baker and Harold R. Moorhouse, to appear in tomorrow's issue of The Harvard Business Review.

Mrs. Emile Vatable, a quiet and effective worker in several Catholic charities in this city for the last forty years, died yesterday morning at her home, 124 East Ninety-first Street, after an illness of two months of a complication of ailments in which heart disease predominated.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 19. -- When Judge Guy B. Park stumped the State last Fall in quest of votes for Governor, he promised sweeping economies in office if he were elected. He is now the Governor of Missouri and scarcely had the General Assembly settled down to work after the inauguration caremonies last week than he started to make good his pledges.
WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Jan. 21. -- Yale defeated the Williams basketball team decisively in La Salle gym tonight, the largest crowd of the year seing the Elis triumph by 44 to 19.

THE professor of the history of religions in Union Theological Seminary here has drawn upon his profound acquaintance with the religions of the world to set before readers interested in their messages to humanity the choicest selections from their teachings.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- A protest against the reduction of the retirement pay of Justice Oliver Wendell Holmes by $10,000 a year was made during hearings on the Department of Justice appropriation bill by Attorney General Mitchell.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 21. -- Notable additions to the Harvard Law Library's collection of early records of American State government, already the largest in the world, were disclosed today by Dean Roscoe Pound of the law school in his annual report to Presidet Lowell.

Early American furniture, pottery, porcelain, pewter, silver, glassware and other objects from the collection of the late Charles Hitchcock Tyler of Boston will be offered at auction at the American Art Association-Anderson Galleries, Inc., on Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday and Saturday afternoons.

Business conditions were moderately improved last week in the New York Federal Reserve District, with the clothing industry showing a larger share of the gains than other pursuits, whether in the manufacturing, wholesale or retail divisions.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 21. -- The decision for immediate action looking to indictments in the election frauds here, announced today in Washington, is the result of an investigation made by Federal agents which began a few days after the election.
The rubber industry supplies a notable evidence of the advanced industrial development of Canada. In this industry the Dominion ranks with the most industrially advanced countries of the world.

A reviving interest in the plantation areas of coastal South Carolina, where many of the fine Winter homes of wealthy residents of New York and other northern cities are located, has been evidenced by reports of realty transactions of recent weeks in that dis trict.

HAD a biography with this title appeared fourteen years ago, when the world had presumably been made safe for democracy with a new destiny, the title would have connoted much more than it can now in the days of technocratic nationalism.

The principal factors in the distribution costs of electricity are the number of customers in a given territory and the average customer usage in such an area, according to Samuel Ferguson, president of the Hartford (Conn.) Electric Light Company.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 7. -- The commission of neutrals at Washington left Paraguay with no alternative except to retire from the Chaco negotiations and recall its representative, Dr. Soler, according to a long statement given to the newspapers here by the Paraguayan Minister, Dr. Vicente Rivarola.

SILVIA FOX was a kind of social reagent. Her presence never failed to effect a positive reaction from those about her. As Gracie, her sister-in-law, put it, "Terrible, terrible party, and then I mentioned Silvia and everything went off like firecrackers."

FISK UNIVERSITY is being brought to the attention of New York this week by the appearance of its choir in a concert in Carnegie Hall on Thursday evening. Those who attend will not only hear beautiful music but see sixty very interesting young Negro men and women.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Bank debits outside New York City receded to December levels during the week ended Jan. 14, following the usual year-end rise, and were 20 per cent under a year ago, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

W.B. Ogden captured the high Scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the shoot by breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets. The second trophy was annexed by A.L. Burns, who finished with a card of 96.

AIR EXPRESS INCORPORATED has now operated its overnight express service between Los Angeles and New York for one month. Philip K. Philbin, president of the line, reports that the company is convinced that the service is going to fill a definite need in the commercial field.

VATICAN CITY, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Three Cardinals who will open the holy doors of three of Rome's basilicas at the inauguration of the Holy Year April 1 will be designated at a consistory that Pope Pius XI convoked today for March 13, and it is possible that many of the seventeen vacancies in the Sacred College of Cardinals will be filled at the same time.

One hundred Chinese students marched in an anti-Japanese parade yesterday afternoon from Riverside Drive at 122d Street through the Morningside Heights section to the Carl Schurz monument at 116th Street and Morningside Drive, where speakers representing Chinese patriotic societies denounced the activities of Japan in Manchuria and Jehol and called for an American boycott on Japanese goods.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- As the four-department bill was reported to the House today. Chairman Byrns of the Appropriations Committee reiterated a previous hope that the money bills can be cut $100,000,000 under budget estimates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 14 amounted to 506,322 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was an increase of 70,670 cars, or 16.2 per cent, over the preceding week, but 66,327 cars, or 11.6 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week last year and 218,890 cars, or 30.2 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

ALTHOUGH the author offers this book called "Hot Places" as the fruit of a recent South American excursion, be might just as well have stayed at home to write it, for the countries about which he tells are illuminated more by his vivid talents than by their particular atmosphere.

Some fifty years ago the imaginary travels of a group of school- boys and their teacher were set down by Hezekiah Butterwortn under the title. "Zigzag Journeys in Europe, Vacation Rambles in Historic Lands by H.B.," and at about the same time the Bodley family set forth on their travels in "The Bodleys on Wheels," "The Bodleys Afoot" and other volumes by Horace E. Scudder.

GEORGE MOORE'S best novel has come to an end. He dramatized himself. He nourished his legend. From Ebury Street he talked to the world. He invented his father's suicide. In spite of his early plunges into realism he invested himself with a romance. His quarrels, his indiscretions, his absurd appraisals of his more illustrious English literary contemporaries, were all parts of the play which he enjoyed intensely.

Influenced by favorable developments in Washington and an advance in sterling exchange, prices on the Cotton Exchange rose at one time yesterday to the previous high levels of the week. At 6.36 a pound for May contracts, quotations were up $1 a bale from the recent low level, but the market met contracts at the advance and closed at the bottom with losses of 2 to 7 points.

In behalf of the pre-opening performance of "Evensong" on the night of Jan. 30 at the Selwyn Theatre for the benefit of the Maternity Centre Association, Mrs. John Sloane, president of that organization, will give a reception this afternoon at her home, 48 East Ninety-second Street, for the members of the cast of the play and the board of directors of the association.

THIS year's first motor vehicle inspection in Pennsylvania, which began earlier this month, will continue until March 31, it is reported. The same regulations effective in the 1932 inspections will be in force. Official inspection stations will function for the adjustment and repair of safety equipment on motor vehicles.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Four falls helped the Columbia University varsity wrestling team to defeat Pennsylvania at the Palestra today, 20 to 12, in the latter's opening meet.

WOLF ISLAND, Mo., Jan. 21 (AP) -- The playful lions of Denver M. Wright, St. Louis manufacturer, were killed ignominiously on a Missisippi River island eight miles south of here today, after the animals had resolutely refused to leave the vicinity of Wright's "African hunting camp."

THIS is a delectable volume. It is full of folk-wisdom and folkways, of whimsy and humor and drama, with occasional tragedy to hearten the reader. The title (derived from a Negro spiritual included in the book) suggests to the editor the serene and gracious acceptance of life, a magic bell that "tones only where folks are natural in the way that grass and sunshine are natural."

OMAHA, Jan. 21. -- Economic conditions are rapidly approaching a crisis in farming affairs in the "bread basket" States of Nebraska, Iowa, the Dakotas and others, and what will finally develop not even the experts can foresee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Withdrawal of the Daughters of the American Revolution from the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense, to be held here Jan. 30, has thrown into a turmoil of talk the whole forefront of women's "peace" and "defense" causes.

Conversations are being carried but that look to the General Aviation Corporation, which is affiliated with the General Motors Corporation, acquiring North American Aviation, Inc., and, if successful they will result in the merger of holding companies with total assets of $25,000,000.

THIS first novel moves along with considerable sweep and the story might be described as one that "holds the interest." It is a tragedy, but there seems to be little of integrated development of either character or events to sustain its gloomy conclusion.

MUKDEN, Dec. 21. -- After even a abort trip through Manchuria has served to reveal strikingly the real progress which Japan has made toward stabilizing the country, any sojourner in Mukden must agree, at least to some extent, with the arguments of Japan's delegates at Geneva to the effect that China will almost certainly continue in a condition of turmoil and disunity for the next ten or twenty years.

BOSTON, Jan. 19. -- When more than a thousand petitions for legislation were entered, "on the Hill" three years ago it was said that an intolerable situation was developing from the guarantee in the Bill of Rights of the State Constitution which insures to any person the right "to request of the legislative body, by the way of addresses, petitions, or remonstrances, redress of the wrongs done them or of the grievances they may suffer."

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19. -- There was a wind and sandstorm in Los Angeles a day or two ago, and grizzled desert prospectors were pretty mad when they found out that householders had been sweeping gold dust off their porches and sidewalks.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES reports of preparations for the next season's performances at Beireuth remind us that on Feb. 13 it will be exactly fifty years since Richard Wagner breathed his last in the VendraminCalergi Palace at Venice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The thirty-hour-week advocates who are now excitedly agitating for legislation are merely repeating history-but it is evident that they regard history as just a fairy tale. It is a sad commentary on the twentieth century that, in spite of the wonderful advancement we have made in industry and social communication, progress in social thought has lagged so painfully behind.

TOKYO, Jan. 21. -- Consul Charles Devault and other officials of the United States Consulate in Yokohama spent an anxious evening tonight after the local Chief of Police had informed them that 1,000 Singer Sewing Machine Company strikers, with their Labor Federation allies, were preparing to march, on the consulate.

ONE of the problems facing Mayor O'Brien is the reorganization of New York City's system of purchasing supplies. In his inaugural address the new Mayor urged that the powers of the Department of Purchase be extended go that all purchases for every department should be made through this central agency.

Coordinated groups of buildings covering several blocks and replacing other buildings as these become obsolete are visioned by three architects, L. Andrew Reinhard, Henry Hofmeister and Wallace K. Harrison, as a possible means of insuring beauty and harmony of design, ample sunlight, safety and greater convenience for office and residential tenants.

Continued supremacy by Ed Siegel of the Swedish-American A.C. in the sprints and by Joe McCluskey of Fordham in the distance events featured the third annual charity track and field games of the Jefferson Club at the Thirteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn last night before a gathering of 4,000.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 21. -- The Shandon Farm entry of At Top and Ennis ran one-two at Jefferson Park today in the Jefferson Derby, a mile test for 3-year-olds. The race carried $2,500 in added money, and there was little surprise at the result, since the entry had been made favorite at $5.20 for $2.

Rose-colored glasses were missing at the convention of the National Retail Dry Goods Association held here during the week. Nor were blue-tinted spectacles used by many of the 4,000 merchants who listened to the authorities in their field expound their views on the greatest array of problems facing retailers in many years.

SINGAPORE. AFTER twenty-seven days on the Atlantic Ocean, the Mediterranean Sea, the Suez Canal and the Indian Ocean, the Fox Film Corporation's "Man Eater" company, headed by Clyde E. Elliott, debarked at Singapore to make an adventure film in the Malayan jungle.

Two bills designed to set up minimum wage standards for women and children and to shorten the present hours of labor permitted for such groups have been drafted by the Consumers League of New York. Steps to bring them before the State Legislature are scheduled for next week.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Jan. 21. -- The first concert of the Nassau Philharmonic Society, Inc., was presented tonight at the Hempstead Theatre before an audience of nearly 2,000. Many persons prominent in society, as well as members of musical organizations and choral clubs in various parts of Long Island, attended.

MIAMI BEACH. -- Providing a fitting climax to the social activities of January will be the formal opening of the Surf Club on Saturday night, which is also introductory to the annual series of gala dinner dances to be sponsored by the club this Winter.

Figures published last week show that transatlantic steamship lines carried 744,000 passengers in 1932 on their established routes between the United States and Europe. This is a two-way figure -- it includes travelers bound both east and west. It compares with 818,000 in 1931 and 1,113,000 in 1930.

EVERY shave-tall Second Lieutenant joining the army hears a great deal about the "old army" and what was done in the "old days." The new subaltern is likely to take these fantastic tales of his elders with several grains of salt and to conclude that time has so mellowed and magnified the events of the past and so worked upon and so embellished the imagination of his superiors that much fiction has supplanted little fact.

PARIS, Jan. 21. -- Rightly or wrongly there is a strong French opinion that it is American preoccupation with the gold standard and the effects of its abandonment by Britain and others that led President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt to get together to begin the debt discussion at the earliest possible moment.

LONDON. SOME one has lately expressed the wish that a fairy might wave a wand and for a year turn all booksellers into publishers and all publishers into booksellers. There would be great surprises for each party when it found itself faced with the difficulties and problems of the other.

Although a capricious stock market failed to register enthusiasm, Wall Street, judging by the flood of week-end comment, appears confident that the inter-governmental debt problem will be forced to some sort of a solution in the negotiations which are to be reopened after the Presidential inauguration in Washington.

Although boys' club organizations last year found themselves with much less money to spend on service to their members, numerical increases over 1931 are reported in nearly every organization affiliated with the Boys' Clubs of America, it was said yesterday in the news bulletin published monthly at the headquarters, 381 Fourth Avenue.

Observations made in recent weeks in an effort to obtain as definite an idea as possible regarding the number of wild water fowl which are wintering within the borders of the country lead many authorities to believe that conditions which, two years ago, threatened seriously either to wipe out many species or to extirpate many others, have been greatly relieved.

STRESSING the tendency of recent designs for transport airplanes to emphasize comfort as well as speed, the first of the new fifteen-passenger, eight-ton Curtiss Condors, of which five have been ordered by Eastern Air Transport and four by Transamerican Airlines, a division of American Airways, will take the air in test flight at St. Louis this week.

Motor boat drivers of various colleges, undaunted by the curtailment of rowing, met yesterday at the Motor Boat Show in a gathering of the Eastern Intercollegiate Outboard Association and made plans for carrying on their activities next Summer.

The American Merchant liner American Merchant is steaming through stormy weather slowly today, bound for New York with the twenty-two seamen of the lost British freighter Exeter City, which went down Friday night after losing her captain and four men.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- The promised invitation from the United States Government to the British to come to Washington to discuss the war debts has not yet been received here, but it is expected within a few days.

YEAR-END figures relating to aeronautics are beginning to show some interesting trends. The Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce announces that on Jan. 1 there were 18,594 pilots and 7,330 aircraft holding active license.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Declines of 0.4 per cent in employmen and 0.9 per cent in payrolls during December were reported today by the Labor Department.
HAVANA, Jan. 21. -- Havana's nineteenth annual racing season opened today at Oriental Park with a surprisingly large attendance that equaled previous inaugurals.

In another section of today's NEW YORK TIMES there appears an official reply by the Technocracy group to criticisms expressed in an article in our Magazine two weeks ago. Amazing has been the speed with which the Technocracy vogue spread over the country.

THE extension of branch banking has become an important issue in the country. The proposal has come from various sources, and in different forms, out was not dramatically brought before the public mind until Senator Huey P. Long began his filibuster against the branch-banking provisions of the Glass bill.

American standards in decorative design are low, was the statement made last week by Ely Jacques Kahn of this city, chairman of the committee on allied arts of the American Institute of Architects. He urged the development of American schools in the minor arts modeled on those of Europe, to alleviate overcrowding in architecture and allied fields.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Obstruction in the Senate to the Glass banking reform bill appeared likely to fade away today as that body agreed to a compromise on branch banking, the principal point of contention.

A spirit of good will and helpfulness by Republicans during the forthcoming Democratic administration was urged yesterday by Under Secretary of the State William R. Castle Jr. at the twelfth annual luncheon of the Women's National Republican Club in the Waldorf-Astoria.

Prices on the New York Cotton Exchange held within narrow limits last week and closed the week at net declines of two to six points. The influences which produced a moderate upward movement during December had apparently spent their force for the time being at least and were offset by reports that the new crop acreage may be increased and by unfavorable conditions in the domestic mill situation.

MRS. BEALE'S title is to be taken literally. She plunged into America's far past by flying in an airplane to the scenes of the ancient Inca civilization and then to the jungles of Central America, where the relics of the Mayas are being dug out of the wilderness.

MOSCOW, Jan. 20. -- A strange and peculiar Bolshevist ceremony occurred at a recent meeting of the Central Committee of the Communist party in the shape of formal "peccavi" speeches by three leaders of the former Right Opposition, Nicolai Bucharin, Alex Reiykov and M. Tomski, which subsequently were pupblished in the Pravda.

Cardinal Hayes will sail tomorrow night for a brief visit to the Bahama Islands on the Augustus of the Italian Line. He will be the guest of the Right Rev. Bernard Kevenhoerster, Prefect-Apostolic of the Bahamas, at the Benedictine Priory, Nassau.

ATLANTA, Jan. 19. -- Georgia's Legislature has completed its short meeting of ten days and started on the regular sixty-day session. Until this year, the incoming Governor has been inaugurated in June, at which time the legislators foregathered, but hereafter the new Executive will be inducted biennially early in January.
BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- There is a widespread belief in Germany that general military service is coming back in some form.

THOUGH a whale in New York Harbor is hardly a common occurrence, the one recently sighted by a Sandy Hook pilot is far from being unique. Three years ago the Moamouth reported a collision with a whale in the harbor, and two years before that a baby sperm whale was captured in the Gowanus Canal in Brooklyn.

ON Christmas Day there appeared in this department what purported to be a review of recording and allied activities during 1932. At the end of this attention was drawn to what in our opinion were the most notable releases of the year, foreign and domestic.
DAYTON, Ohio, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Ex-Governor James M. Cox, one-time Presidential candidate, in a signed statement in his newspapers tomorrow on the subject of international debts, says:

DUBLIN, Jan. 21. -- The Irish Free State election, campaign is drawing to a close almost tamely. Serious trouble had been feared because of the rival armed bodies supporting the major parties, yet no grave collision has resulted.

CHICAGO, Jan. 20. REPORTS from the Opera House front, where musical shows for the masses are being offered at Spanish War prices, are favorable. "Show Boat" is in its second week at the reconditioned Auditorium, with another fortnight to go, and large throngs are repairing to this ancient shrine every night.

THIS little volume of essays has an inescapable feeling of yesteryear. Both the subject matter and the way it is handled suggest the literary essays of a generation ago. when cultivated gentlemen still wrote politely of polite subjects.

The port of New York has lost several sources of freight as a result of rate structures and rail differentials, according to a report prepared for the Foreign Commerce Club by James Young, of the Barber Steamship Lines. Much of the divergence of freight from New York is due to the activity of trade bodies in other Atlantic ports, said Mr. Young.

Maurice Benedict of 2,068 East Twenty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, returned yesterday noon to explain to his wife why he took a trip to Havana instead of taking her to the theatre last Saturday as he had promised, and also why he had failed to be in his place as foreman of the jury sitting in a trial in Federal court of two men charged with using the mails to defraud.

PARIS, Jan. 19. -- The new textiles offer interesting sidelights on the forthcoming couture showings. It is forecast that Rodier's group of natural flax fabrics, called lynic, will repeat the success of his smellic group. Especially notable are mouslinic, a fine flax crepe which comes in all colors for Summer evening gowns, and creplynic for heavy topcoats and suits.

Our public men, however adroit, suffer from the infirmities of the English language. It has, for example, no simple word or phrase to express the thought: "I have heard you, and "I think you're a splendid fellow, but "I don't care to commit myself on "your proposal."

The domestic program of the Roosevelt auministration "will end in futility" unless the new administration reshapes its foreign policy with "a bold and realistic spirit." according to a warning given by Dr. Glenn Frank, president of the University of Wisconsin, in an address last evening at the thirtysecond annual dinner dance of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Banking at the Waldorf- Astoria.
