To the Music Editor: The passing of De Pachmann recalls an incident in the life of that famous musician in which I happened to be a participant.

DURING the last ten days two outstanding developments have again focused attention on the interests of the United States in the Orient. The first is the reiteration of the nonrecognition doctrine laid down in the American note of Jan. 7, 1932 the second is the passage over a Presidential veto of a Philippine independence bill.

WHAT happened after this planet congealed from a mass of gas into a world with a solid crust is written in mountains, oceans, continents and islands. It is a story which goes back several hundred million years and which must be read in shifting poles, in fossils, in mighty pressures, in masses of rock that are still being molded like putty.

LONDON, Jan. 11. -- Day after day news comes in from Manchuria about a further Japanese advance, and the situation there is being discussed unceasingly in its bearing upon the state of affairs in China. The Chino-Japanese quarrel at the present time is the problem at Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The allotment plan farm relief bill was subjected today in the Senate Agricultural Committee to a cross-fire of emasculating suggestions, one of which would strike out the acre-age redaction provision, considered by its advocates to be the principal justification of the experiment.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The approach to Great Britain for debt revision developed at the outset differences of opinion between representatives of President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt as to the details of the procedure to be followed.

"ALL aboard for New York." A raucous voice speaks from the amplifier in the waiting room and ten of us get up and crowd into a canopied walk leading to the plane, the midnight mail for New York. Across the Chicago Municipal Airport a beacon blinks and turns rhythmically, flashing its message in Morse to fliers aloft.

TOKYO. THE present-day Japanese lives a double life in a peculiarly literal sense. He Has one foot in the vividly colored but narrow life of old Japan, which is still so near, the other in the twentieth-century life of travel, cable news, international trade and capitalist economy.

MONTREAL, -- Visitors in unusually large numbers are expected here this week, as the program reveals a variety of events, with the Snowshoe Congress, the indoor tennis championship and the charity ball as the highlights.

IN THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine of Jan. 8, there was published "A Challenge to Technocracy," written by Simeon Strunsky. On this page appear Technocracy's official reply to Mr. Strunsky, prepared under the supervision of Howard Scott, director of Technocracy, and Mr. Strunsky's rejoinder.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Reports that Everett Sanders is ready to resign as chairman, of the Republican National Committee were described at the White House today as being without foundation.

THE Printing House of Leo Hart, Rochester, N.Y., will issue in February a volume entitled "Eibliotheca Typographical A List of Books about Books." compiled by Horace Hart. All Use important reference works and classic texts in the history of printing and its allied industries are recorded and arranged by subjects.

The number of buyers in the wholesale markets increased considerably during the week and Spring buying is getting under way activey, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

Following are the fourteen statements and two formulas cited by Mr. Strunsky in his article of Jan. 8 as among those which "sum up Technocracy to the public," and commented upon in the accompanying article:

HANOVER, N.H., Jan. 21. -- Princeton easily defeated Dartmouth in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight, the Tigers gaining a 40-25 victory by virtue of uncanny shooting. Dartmouth was outclassed in the second half, in which the Tiger forwards went on a scoring rampage.

VIENNA, Jan. 20. -- Except in Rumania, where King Carol's struggle against democracy resulted in another change of government, and Bulgaria, where orthodoxy claimed Queen Joanna's first child in defiance of the Vatican, economic developments claimed the major attention in Southeastern Europe this week.

Although squash racquets is a sport in which women have made tremendous strides during the last five years in this country, the game has enjoyed a longer reign, of popularity in England. Just what the comparison may be between the calibre of competition in this country and abroad will soon be disclosed, for on Wednesday a team of British stars will sail for New York on the first expedition of its kind.

With a larger entry list than was received a year ago, the American Spaniel Club will stage its sixteenth specialty show tomorrow in the ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt, the exhibition opening at 9 A.M. and continuing until 7 o'clock in the evening.

THE Victorian period is at last recognized by interior decorators as an important feature of the American background. As interpreted by the modern decorator, the Victorian style loses much of the contusion and bad taste of the later phases; the spirit is sought rather than a literal reconstruction of interiors with all their details.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Governors of many States have advised the American Legislators' Association of their readiness to coperate in making the interstate conference of legislators, to be held in Washington Feb. 3 and 4, a "significant and successful event."

Interest rates on real estate loans will fall first through involuntary reduction, and second by voluntary reduction, points out Edwin J. Rosenbaum, a realty owner, who adds that amortization is a misguided policy of national defeatism. He considers that amortization has led to inflated costs, unsound valuations, inflated loans, inflated tax assessments and vast overbuilding.

HOLLYWOOD. THE BIRTH OF A NATION" may reach the screen this year in a talking version. Thomas Dixon, the author, has been negotiating for all the outstanding rights for some time, and, according to word reaching Hollywood, he is now ready to approach producers.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 19. -- The first major failure of a financial institution of Louisiana since the depression has left the State quiet and somewhat surprised. The surprise arises from the slight public reaction to the collapse of the Union Indemnity group, one of the largest institutions in the State.
BERLIN. TWO years ago Josef Ponten began a great trilogy. "Volk auf dem Wege, der Roman der deutschen Unrube" (Deutsche Verlagsanstalt, Stuttgart). The second volume has now been brought out.
DUBLIN, Jan. 21 (AP). -- The Irish Free State Censorship Board last night banned "A Story Teller's Holiday," one of George Moore's books.

LONDON, Jan. 5. NO man has by luck written a great work of art; no man has made a work of art at all without elaborately taking pains to which he may directly trace an important part of his achievement. But widespread popularity, whether it be of an artist's work or a charlatan's, springs from a source that none can certainly trace.

PARIS, Jan. 10, 1933. THE Opera has just put on a new ballet of Prokofieff's which, adds nothing to the reputation of the creator of "Chout," "Pas d'Acier" and "L'Enfant Prodigue." Nothing less plastic or less applicable to choreography than the heavy music of "Sur le Borsythene" can be imagined.

CAIRO, Jan. 20. -- Vehement protests were raised by the opposition and independent press this week against Egypt's participation in the conference at Addis Abeba, Abyssinia, to discuss construction of a dam on Lake Tsana.

An instance of an industry which, by careful regulation of production escaped the burden of surplus stocks throughout the depression, is deliberately building up stocks in order to furnish employment for its workers, was revealed here yesterday by R.M. Roosevelt, president of the American Zinc Institute.

Under the patronage of Juan Francisco de Cardenas, the Spanish Ambassador, Senora de Cardenas, and many other prominent Spaniards in this country, a Spanish charity ball will be given on Feb. 3 in the main ballroom of Sherry's. Sponsored by the Comite de Socorro Espanol, of which Benito C. Collada is president, proceeds from the ball will be used to aid needy Spaniards in New York.
CHATTANOOGA, Jan. 19. -- Governor Hill McAlister made good this week his promise of a complete clean-up in the State's executive staff which served under his predecessor, Henry Horton.

PARIS. YANTORNY, the bootmaker, gazed down from his workshop window on the Place Vendome. He was abstracted and he did not see how in that lovely square Napoleon's big cannon-made column was out of place or how the disrepair of the chimney pots was like a wrinkle on it perfect brow.

THE article in THE TIMES of Jan. 8 to which Technocracy formally replies addressed itself entirely to Technocracy's figures for current or imminent industrial production. The article listed fourteen allegations and proceeded to ask questions about them.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Fog which delayed the coming, sped the parting tonight of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt on a "hail and farewell" visit to Chicago. At 7:25 o'clock she arrived by train, her airplane flight westward from Newark, N. J., having been halted at Cleveland by what aviators call thick weather.

ROME, Jan. 20. -- Since the destruction by Yugoslav mobs of the winged lions of St. Mary relations between Italy and Yugoslavia have steadily been growing worse and it is felt here that Yugoslavia must definitely be set down as pursuing a policy hostile to Italy.

The assertion, frequently heard that the "big bankers" secretly desire inflation of the nation's money is completely false, men in this class declare, if by inflation is meant any of the schemes for tinkering with the currency that have lately been under discussion in Washington and around the fringes of Wall Street.
The real estate promotion business is dead for several years to come, while the real estate development business is under way, points out F.J. Dolan Jr. of Gleeson Dolan, Long Island developers.

A NEW development in the study of evolution began with the opening years of the present century, says the Professor of Biology in the California Institute of Technology, formerly Professor of Experimental Zoology at Columbia University and one of the most eminent of American biologists.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The efficacy of any movement designed to relieve the present economic situation must lie in its power to solve the problem, and the "Buy American" movement does not seem to possess that power.

What happier and more delightful way of spending your spare time on week-ends and during your annual vacation period can you suggest than a vacation afloat? There was a time when the family outings were made in the automobile and when it was possible to find shady nooks in the countryside which were not yet occupied by other picnickers.

A daily nation-wide auction of perishable farm products, in which bids and sales will be transmitted from city to city by a teletype network, has been planned by a corporation which is registered in Nevada as the Farmers Market System.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Playing even more brilliantly than in his first two matches, Clarence Jackson of Detroit, veteran of many years in billiards, today moved back into a tie with J.N. Bozeman Jr. of Vallejo, Cal., for first place in the world's championship threecushion billiard tournament.

UNEMPLOYMENT relief will suffer unless Congress continues Federal-aid appropriations on the present basis of $125,000,000 a year, according to a statement issued by the American Road Builders Association from its headquarters in Washington.

Moses Koenigsberg of 160 Riverside Drive, former head of a group of Hearst news and feature services, has sent back to Ambassador Claudel of France his decoration as a Chevalier of the Legion of Honor because the French Government defaulted in its debt payments to the United States, it was disclosed here last night.

Price movements on local commodity exchanges last week were irregular, with downward trends continuing in some markets and reversals of these trends in others. Sugar, coffee and silver futures advanced, while cocoa, rubber, hides, silk and wool tops were lower.

BOSTON, Jan. 21. -- Harvard's hockey team staged a great comeback against the Princeton Tigers at the Garden tonight, beating the Tigers, 5 to 4, in a thrilling see-saw battle. The Crimson's triumph followed the Tigers' 6-to-2 victory over Harvard at Princeton a week ago and tied the series at one game each.

A starting point for economic planning as outlined in the report of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends is found in the Federal Home Loan Bank system, points out I. Friedlander of Houston, Texas, vice president of the United States Building and Loan League.

IN its title this book of Mr. Simonds, a companion to the political and racial study "Can Europe Keep the Peace?" asks a question which he answers in the last chapter. He does not believe that the United States will ever be able to stay at home in the sense that it can live to itself and avoid involvement in European affairs.
Ed Logan, popular young boxer from the Holy Name Club, gained the New York State amateur heavyweight championship by stopping Walter Brennan of Buffalo at Madison Square Garden last night.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- Three knockouts were features of today's international intercollegiate boxing meet, the first ever staged at Syracuse University. The Orangemen defeated Toronto, 5 1/2 to 3 1/2.

The following table compares results in the foreign trade of the United States as reported by the Department of Commerce last week, with the results in a long series of preceding years. In the accompanying table, plus indicates excess of imports, minus indicates excess of exports.

The painting by Whistler, "Portrait of the Artist's Mother," one of the most celebrated canvases by an American artist, which has been lent by the Louvre in Paris to the current exhibition of American painting and sculpture at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West Fifty-third Street, will not be returned to France at the close of the show here early next month.

LONDON. DURING 1932 the small car of from 8 to 10 horsepower enjoyed a considerable vogue in Europe, due in part, at least, to the general economic situation. A gain in the popularity of these "baby" cars is also reported from France, Italy and Germany.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- The action of the wheat market of late is said to have greatly discouraged some of the local bulls. Scattered early buying on the Board of Trade here today advanced the May 1/2 cent to 48 cents a bushel, but the buying was not sufficient to carry the price through the offers and selling against the latter put an effective stop to the bulge.

SIMEON STRUNSKY'S article, "A Challenge to Technocracy," in THE NEW YORK TIMES Magazine for Jan. 8, necessitates the following brief rejoinder from the research organization of whose work he there writes with so little comprehension.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

There is no longer any room for doubt as to what Japan intends to do about Jehol. Foreign Minister Uchida, addressing the House of Peers, said yesterday that the province would be annexed to Manchukuo.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- The Army varsity indoor polo team defeated Cornell today, 12 -- 7 before a large crowd in the riding hall of the military academy.

THE cool, hard-headed brain specialist who is the narrator of this weird tale tries his best to find a rational explanation of the horribly fantastic events with which the story deals, but science offers no satisfactory solution.

WILLMAR, Minn., Jan. 21 (AP). -- One thousand farmers who thronged the court house left today believing they had prevented foreclosure of a mortgage on land tilled by its occupant for fifty-seven years, but whether they had done so was uncertain tonight.

Describing the present as "this terrible age" Dr. Mather A. Abbott, a headmaster at the Lawrenceville School, told the members of the Lawrenceville School Fathers Association at its annual dinner last night at the Waldorf that the boys of today were in danger of being overwhelmed by the machine.

IF S.N. Behrman wrote with more fever and crackle, his comedies of manners would no doubt arouse more excitement in the theatre. For pace and hilarity his first comedy, "The Second Man," is still his most successful. But in the last six years Mr. Behrman has been steadily refining his gifts for writing and observation, and his current play, "Biography," is in every respect his best.

Prayers for the reunion of Christendom will be offered today in all Roman Catholic churches. It will be the Sunday in the annual church unity octave which began last Wednesday. The special prayer for today will be "for the return of all Christians in America."
PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 21. -- Princeton's swimming team swept every first place to swamp Lafayette, 62 -- 9, in Brokawa pool tonight. The victory was the Tigers' second straight.

THE Admirable Aldous has compiled an anthology and enriched it with running commentary. He has divided it, after the manner at such books, into compartments, each with its name. It would be hard for him to do anything badly.

Preparations have begun already for the reception of hundreds of thousands of pilgrims expected in Vatican City beginning April 2, dur- ing the Holy Year proclaimed by Pope Pius to commemorate the 1900th anniversary of the passion, death and resurrection of Jesus Christ.

BERLIN, it seems, did not take ardently to its bosom the concert entitled "New American Music," when Howard Hanson presented recently through the Berlin Philharmonic Orchestra. Robert Russell Bennett's "Four Sketches for the Theatre"; works by Leo Sowerby, William Grant Still and John Powell were bracketed together as pleasant trifles cleverly turned.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Legislation to strengthen the protective features of the tariff against the competitive influence of imports from countries with depreciated currencies will be discussed at a meeting of House Republicans on Jan. 25, President Hoover was told today by Representative Snell of New York, minority leader.
ISTANBUL, Jan. 7. -- This year will be the tenth of Kemalism-a decade in which Turkey has, on the surface anyway, been changed out of all recognition.
ONE of the week's exhibitions evolved an idea that, although not freshly minted, ought still to be serviceable to some landscape painters in these uncertain times.

A DISPATCH recently appeared in THE NEW YORK TIMES to the effect that an ingenious inventor, Rudolf Pfenninger of Munich, had produced the necessary music for a sound film not by playing and recording it but by drawing it on paper with a pen and brush and then transferring it photographically to the film.

Retailers visiting trade exhibitions here last week evidenced an entirely different attitude toward merchandise and showed sympathy for manufacturers' efforts to stabilize wholesale markets, according to executives of furniture, rug and curtain and drapery companies which opened Spring, 1933, lines Monday.

FIVE more years in the life of Boswell are recorded in these two new volumes of his Journal, which form the fifteenth and sixteenth of the Malahide Castle Papers. The conviction grows with each successive volume of this diary that no record more remarkable, more fascinating to the student of human nature, exists in the literature of autobiography.

HELSINGFORS, Jan. 21. -- The Soviet Union is carrying out an extensive scheme of highway and railroad construction in the territory adjoining Finland -- a most important section from a military point of view.

To the Edtior of The New York Times: It would help in the solution of many of our national problems if we thought less exclusively of the Constitution of the United States and gave more consideration to that other fundamental embodiment of law, the constitution of nature.

LONDON. AFTER six months of silent grinding pressure the socalled tariff war with England goes to a virtual referendum in next Tuesday's general election in the Irish Free State. If President de Valera gets a majority the tariff war apparently will have to be ended by England, if ended at all, and any English attempt to end it will probably find de Valera a more intractable negotiator than ever.

THOUGH Winter winds are still blowing and March is yet to come, one cannot be unmindful of the fact that Spring is lurking somewhere around the corner -- at least, if one is dealing with fashions. The new ones are going to whet the appetite for clothes.

MOST of us are dullards who like to have our reading experiences, particularly if they be emotional, cast into familiar forms. We are inclined to regard innovation with an eye wary for trickery. The novel is open to great stylization, but its substance and force derive from long knowledge of a limited group of characters and from the timed, inevitable unfolding of its episodes.

TOKYO, Jan. 21. -- In a statement to the Diet today Korekiyo Takahashi, the Finance Minister, declared Japan's economic position was inherently sound and cited in evidence a 23 per cent increase in exports and 15 per cent increase in imports in the last year and said the adverse balance was reduced 50 per cent.

OMAHA, Jan. 19. -- The stoppage of farm mortgage foreclosure sales by massed groups of farmers has been occurring with increased frequency during the past fortnight. The practice began last Fall, but was rarely resorted to then. Now hardly a day passes without one or more reports of such mass action.

Few spectators, except those intimately connected with the sport of motor-boat racing, realize the patient upbuilding, the careful thought and many months of hard work that have gone before the actual start of a regatta.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21. -- Yale's swimming team, which has not lost a meet to an outside rival in eight years, defeated the Wesleyan squad today, 59 to 25.

THAT ingratiating comedienne, Alison Skipworth, is one of the principals in "Tonight Is Ours," this week's feature at the Paramount. Miss Skipworth is a veteran of the stage and screen, and her thirty-three years of theatrical trouping have borne their share of ups and downs.

PARIS. COTTON (and by this I include such whilom unsophisticated fabrics as linen, hemp, string, flax and the like) will be smarter than ever this year. Probably we shall not be quite so smugly ostentatious about the economy of our little cambric evening gown, which, if signed by a Chanel or an Augustabernard, will turn out to be about as costly as the most luxurious satin or lame.
PARIS, Jan. 13. -- The building which houses the Legion of Honor in Paris is, for more than one reason, of interest to Americans.

PEOPLE without jobs or money are banding together in local groups in various parts of the land to combat the depression by resorting to the ancient system of barter, and in some cases are supplementing barter by issuing script to pass as money among themselves and their neighbors.

LITTLE change was noted in the course of retail trade during the week. The weather continued to hold down volume on seasonal lines of merchandise. However, there was a more active response to certain clearances, particularly in shoes, women's coats and men's shirts.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- In the role of benignant shadow of a coining event, Franklin D. Roosevelt once more appeared in the capital this week and spread a layer of happiness over Washington.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Unanimity of sentiment in Legislatures from coast to coast tonight had swept to the verge of ratification a twentieth amendment to the Constitution, the one that will abolish "lame ducks."

BALTIMORE, Jan. 20. -- The new Roman Catholic cathedral to be constructed in the northern part of this city, near the new St. Mary's Seminary, will be in the Romanesque style of architecture and will bear the name of the present edifice, the Cathedral of the Assumption of the Blessed Virgin Mary.

CHICAGO, Jan. 19. -- Citizens of Illinois are encouraged in the hope that waning faith in representative institutions and political leadership is to be revived. Not Congress in its "lame-duck" limping but their own State administration and General Assembly is responsible for that feeling, and more especially the attitude and acts of their new Democratic Chief Executive, Governor Horner.

MILAN, Dec. 27, 1932. THE Scala season was opened yesterday evening with its usual pomp and circumstance when the customary gala first-night audience, bristling with notables, assembled in Italy's major lyric sanctuary to hear "The Dusk of the Gods."
TWENTY pictures, with locales scattered all over the globe, are in work or ready to start at Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, marking the company's heaviest production schedule in twelve months.

MEN may come and men may go but the Empire Theatre, secure in all its fin-de-siecle glory, seems to be one of those things which just go on forever. It was forty years ago to the day, come Wednesday evening, at a half after eight o'clock, that the curtain rose upon the first public performance in the house which still covers the plot of ground on the southeast corner of Broadway and Fortieth Street.

In the January issue of L'Esprit International is an article seeking to explain to Europeans the complexities of our form of government. Written by Mr. WALTER MILLIS, as an after-comment upon our Presidential election of last year, and translated into French, it seeks to explain to the foreign mind our historic system of "checks and balances," embedded in the Federal Constitution.

The board of directors of the Clarion River Power Company, which operates in Western Pennsylvania, has issued to stockholders a statement reviewing the company operations and financial transactions since acquisition of control by Associated Gas and Electric interests and outlining the investigation of the company by the Federal Trade Commission and the Federal Power Commission.

In spite of the heavy losses suffered by Swedish investors for the failure of the Ivar Kreuger enterprises and from the general business depression, the financial position of Sweden is not alarming, Kurt Belfrage, president of the Stockholm Stock Exchange, said last night in a radio address over a National Broadcasting Company network.

James J. Sexton, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, predicted a fairly substantial reduction in the basic tax rate for all boroughs yesterday after announcing that his department had completed hearings on more than 75,000 protests on assessed valuations of real estate.

HAVANA, Jan. 18. -- An attempt the form a Socialist Labor party will be made by the labor unions of Cuba, according to resolution passed by the Second Labor Conference, which has just been held in the city of Cienfuegos and at which some seventy-five unions were represented.

The program adopted last week for the Economic World Conference is altogether practical. This Is notably true as regards the gold standard. It was at least conceivable that the conference would be asked to discuss the merits of a so-called "managed currency." No such proposal is made.

THE east coast of South America has been joined to Africa by a flight that endured only fourteen hours. A mail pilot, flying a plane built for commercial duty, established the record last week between St. Louis in the Senegal and Port Natal, Brazil.

Valentim F. Boucas, general technical director of the committee on State finance and economics of the Brazilian Government's Ministry of Finance and manager in Brazil of the International Business Machines Corporation, arrived here last week to discuss the financial situation in Brazil with bankers who marketed bonds of the Brazilian federal, State and municipal governments in recent years.

Uncertainty as to the outlook for new legislation affecting railroads is a factor in Wall Street's consideration of bond maturities in the early part of this year. Brokers see little chance of such legislation at this session of Congress, although a relaxation of the terms on which the Reconstruction Finance Corporation extends loans to railroads and an amendment to the bankruptcy law to facilitate railroad reorganizations have been urged by the railroad managements.

The National Association of Real Estate Boards will open its annual business meeting in Washington, D.C., on Wednesday with Federal housing loans and methods of fostering home ownership as the chief topics of the four-day conference.

The 279-foot seagoing yacht Caroline, temporarily converted into a floating laboratory, slipped out of Tebo Yacht Basin in Brooklyn yesterday morning and headed south for the five-mile ocean deep off Puerto Rico, where scientists connected with the Smithsonian Institution will spend two months in deep-sea exploration.

Betrayed by the visit of a girl friend who for three months had been under police surveillance, Michael (Dynamite Mike) Miller, 32 years old, hold-up man and escaped convict, was captured last night by detectives of the East Thirty-fifth Street Station in a chase over roofs at Eightieth Street and First Avenue.

When he told his hearers at Yale last week that "biological material is running up "although the universe is running down, Professor JENNINGS must have astonished even biologists. To be sure, there is an ascent in life that finds no counterpart in the nonliving, but it is an ascent of the spirit and not of matter.

GREENVILLE, S.C., Jan. 21 (AP). -- The Greenville Piedmont today quotes Charles Johnson, former textile operator here, as saying that he was "brutally" treated and whipped eleven times while serving a three-year sentence on a South Carolina chain gang for involuntary manslaughter.

LOUISVILLE, Jan. 19. -- Firm belief that Kentucky is ready to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was expressed by Jouett Shouse, former Kentuckian and president of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, speaking at the dinner of the Kentucky branch, Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, here this week.

THE steady accumulation of contributions to the Stage Relief Fund has continued and, during the past week, donations aggregating $5,025.80 were added to make a grand total of $15,330.30 received. The new contributions listed were as follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The Adjutant General of New York is the highest paid military officer in the world when he is on active duty, Representative LaGuardia of New York told the House today. He said that the Adjutant General, when serving at Summer camps, drew the pay of a Major General of the United States Army and the pay of a Major General of the State.

FLORENCE, Ala., Jan. 21 (AP). -- The communities around the government's $150,000,000 nitrate and power plants at Muscle Shoals blossomed with flags and smiled with optimism over President-elect Roosevelt's visit to inspect the project today.

A long, arching goal from nearly half the length of the floor by Len Hartman in the last four seconds of play gave Columbia a 37-36 victory over Cornell last night in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game in the Morningside gymnasium.

GENEVA, Jan. 21. -- The League of Nations published today a long memorandum dated Jan. 18, giving the Persian Government's reply to Great Britain, which laid their dispute over the Anglo-Persian oil lease before the Council under Article XV of the covenant as one likely to lead to a rupture.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 19. -- A twenty-year fight to compel the three transcontinental railroads with Los Angeles terminals to build a union station on a site long since designated by the California Railroad Commission apparently has reached an impasse.

Wider use of new materials and new construction methods is likely to bring changes in the designs of various types of buildings, from commercial structures to private homes, in the opinion of the group of architects participating in the exhibition of modern architecture, now being held at the New School, for Social Research.

Virtually all sections of the bond list on the Stock Exchange participated in a general rise yesterday, many issues advancing 1 to 3 points. United States Government bonds extended their gains of the preceding few days, and in the foreign group strength in German loans was a feature.

Reminiscences of Imperial Russia will be revived on Friday night when the fifth annual Russian Students' Ball will take place in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton in the interests of the cultural, educational and welfare work of the National Russian Students' Christian Association and the Alumni Association of the Russian Students' Fund.

Well-known poets and novelists have volunteered their services for the annual authors' matinee in behalf of the Mary Fisher Home in Tenafly, N.J., which will take place tomorrow afternoon in the main ballroom of the Astor. Among the authors who will read selections from their writings are Leonora Speyer, Kathleen Norris, Grace Hoffman White, Lucy Lowe, Harold Vinal, Veronica Rosaio, Erwin Howland and Betty Hannon.

ALL who are interested in Victorian poetry and poets must be greatly interested in this admirably edited and complete collection of letters from the critic and poet. Matthew Arnold, to his friend and fellow-poet, Arthur Hugh Clough.

MR. VILLARD'S book may be divided into two uneven parts: one containing at admirable appraisal of "the actual achievements of the German Republic," "its many substantial accomplishments": the other dealing with "the events which led up to the great change in 1932."

Four masked gunmen who had robbed Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Braunstein and their twelve guests at a card party early this morning in the Braunstein apartment on the second floor of 2,101 Morris Avenue, the Bronx, of $2,000 in cash and jewels, trained their pistols at the door of the apartment as the arrival of police in radio cars blocked escape.

Recent intimations from the political supporters in the city of President-elect Roosevelt have been that Tammany Hall will have to content itself with an extremely modest share of the Federal patronage to be dispensed by the Demo- cratic national administration after March 4.

The attendance was large but bidding was not brisk at the final session yesterday of Thomas L. Elder's sale of various coin collections, autographs and other curiosities at 8 West Thirty-seventh Street.

To the Dramatic Editor: In your Sunday section of Jan. 15 Brock Pemberton remarks that "designers of scenery are asked by their union to demand minimum fees that are ruinous." It may therefore be in order for me to remind your readers that this "ruinous" minimum consists of the tow- ering sum of $250 per set and an additional superintendence fee of $250 per production (not per set).

LONDON, Jan. 19. -- With a Cabinet meeting this week for the first time since before Christmas, the British Government is beginning to resume activity. Not only has there been no formal work but, for the most part, Ministers left their departments to run themselves.

Esmond P. O'Brien, son of Morgan J. O'Brien, former Supreme Court Justice, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court. The petitioner, who lives at 67 West Fiftysecond Street, is president of the Brady Brass Corporation, a secretary of the North and South Corporation, and a prominent club member.

THE chief item of news for what should be a nice, crisp January morning is that Arthur Hopkins has written a play. He has done that before, of course, although the last of which he could claim full authorship was "The Fatted Calf," of years back.

The United States Power Squadrons, which organization has an educational exhibit at the Motor Boat Show and win hold its annual meeting at the New York Athletic Club on Saturday, is a novel body among boating circles.

NASSAU, Bahamas -- With the opening of Nassau's two largest hotels -- the New Colonial Hotel and the Fort Montagu Beachthe 1933 season will be in full swing, although an increasing number of Winter residents have already established themselves in recently completed homes or in waterfront cottages rented for the Winter.

Accused of having defrauded residents of Larchmont, Mount Kisco and other Westchester communities out of at least $200,000 through the sale of stock, Harry E. Armstrong, 45 years old, of Bedford, Va., was arrested at 11 o'clock last night after a stormy hearing which had been going on for nine hours in the office of the Attorney General at 80 Centre Street.

WHEN the radio curtain went up for another week's variety performance this morning it was a signal for hundreds of entertainers and educators to begin another seven-day trek across the ethereal stage.

LAKE PLACID. -- Welcome brisk winds have made ice boating, ski and skate sailing popular on the frozen lakes surrounding Lake Placid. Usually impossible on account of the depth of snow, sportsmen are taking advantage of these sports, which dot Lakes Mirror and Placid with towering white sails.

ROME, Jan. 21. -- With the object of giving "a valid and vigorous impulse to the technical, economic and financial reorganization of industrial enterprises that have been depressed but not ruined by the crisis in order that they may find themselves in the best condition of efficiency at the moment of economic recovery," the Cabinet Council today approved the foundation of the Institute of Industrial Reconstruction.

COLOGNE, Jan. 21. -- American and other foreign students, especially of the medical faculty, will henceforth be more carefully examined as to their preparatory qualifications before they are admitted to the University of Cologne, in order not to take limited accommodations in laboratories away from German students, it was learned today.

COMPARED to the drama, many playgoers found Louis Gruenberg's opera after Eugene O'Neill, "The Emperor Jones," an anticlimax. For operagoers-operagoers, at least, of the younger generation and modern tastes -- the work had very exciting novelty, swiftness, originality of method and dramatic effect.

CREATIVE ART, of which, succeeding Henry McBride, Dr. Frederick A. Blossom is now the editor, offers in its January issue some very interesting material, "packaged" -- to borrow an art term from the commercial field -- with much ingenuity and taste.

WAGNER'S great "Nibelungenlied," together with "Tannhauser" and "Tristan und Isolde," will be broadcast when the Metropolitan Opera Company begins its special Wagrner matinee cycle this year with "Das Rheingold" next Friday afternoon.

IT Is given to few to suggest new ideas in constitutional jurisprudence. The Constitution has now been in operation for 145 years and during that period each of its provisions has been subjected to meticulous examina- tion by the microscope of the judiciary.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- A cut of $5,284,742, or about 5 per cent, in the budget estimates and a reduction of $14,079,931 below the 1932-33 outlay were shown in the $103,282,039 appropriation bill for the Departments of State, Justice and Labor, introduced today in the House.

The committee on business conduct of the New York Stock Exchange has requested members of the Exchange to furnish by noon on Wednesday a list of all transactions made from Sept. 27, 1932, to Jan. 16, 1933, inclusive, in ten-year 5 per cent convertible bonds of the Pressed Steel Car Company, due on Jan. 1, 1933.

Budget balancing by means of a sales tax instead of other indirect levies is overwhelmingly favored by the economic credit council of the National Association of Credit Men, it was revealed yesterday in a survey of more than 100 treasurers and credit executives of wholesaling and manufacturing companies and bankers throughout the country who compose the council.
The American Power Boat Association was founded in 1903 to promote the use of power boats, improve their design and formulate rules for contests of speed and ensurance.

In an effort to provide property owners with suggestions for the orderly development and beautification of the land along the new Queens Boulevard, the Chamber of Commerce of the Borough of Queens is sponsoring a competition out of which it is hoped a feasible program for the territory may be evolved.

THOUGH recent proposals for raising the income-tax rate have now been shelved, the possibility of a change still remains, for Congress may fall back on income-tax receipts as a last resort to balance the budget. The suggested, tax rate -- 6 and 12 per cent on normal incomes -- would equal the highest rate ever imposed in this country.

Guy Hodgens Buchanan of Westfield, N.J., chemical engineer and chief technologist of the American Cyanamid Company, 535 Fifth Avenue, died yesterday in the Doctors Hospital of pneumonia after an operation. He was born on May 27, 1868, in Taylorsville, Pa.

Some form of sales tax toward raising additional revenue to balance the State budget is suggested by the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards as one of the most equitable means for obtaining necessary funds.

Except for two lots of public utility bonds and part of one railroad issue, calls issued last week for bonds to be paid before their dates of maturity were mainly for small amounts of State and municipal issues. The total for January is now $44,613,700, compared with $20,453,000 last month and $70,631,000 in January, 1932.

MRS. DELAFIELD'S provincial lady, who in an earlier book aroused our sympathy by seeming doomed to surroundings to which she was so patently superior, comes more into her own in this second volume of her adventures when a book she writes achieves success and the success in turn enables her to take a London flat and move among more interesting people.

GLANCING backward at New York's recent motor exhibition, Automotive Daily News calls it "a successful show" and pauses for a bit of editorial analysis. "There is no point in denying that the automobile industry entered upon the 1933 national show in New York with considerable trepidation," it remarks.

The new United Fruit liner Peten, last of six ships built by the line during the last two years, will leave the yard of the Newport News Shipbuilding Company on Feb. 15 to undergo her sea trials off the Virginia Capes and will sail from New York March 2 on her maiden voyage to Havana, Panama and Costa Rica, it was announced yesterday.

You never know quite what Henry Billings is going to do next. He is not a very frequent exhibitor, and when he does bring forward new work it usually represents exploration in a new field -- or, at any rate, one more or less new to the artist.

Intensive sales and advertising campaigns, in which quality will be the major talking point, are contemplated for this year by leading manufacturers of mechanical refrigerators. Convinced that price-slashing was responsible for the sudden drastic decline in dollar volume which set in during the last six months of 1932, producers feel that any further reductions in price will only aggravate their present difficulties.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- Farmers of the agrarian States are fighting two of their ancient foes, mortgages and taxes, with a desperate determination this Winter, and State Legislatures are their battleground.

LONDON, Jan. 20. -- Sir Albert Kitson, who has just returned from Kenya, with a report to Sir Philip Cunliffe-Lister, Secretary of State for the Colonies, on the recently discovered gold in that region, said at a luncheon of the East Africa Club that the field is now in a state of transition from the alluvial to the reef stage.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. George B. Post will give a dinner tomorrow at their home, 45 East 78th Street.

Questions of taxation, municipal finances and existing mortgage conditions will be the chief topics discussed by the speakers at the forthcoming annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York to be held Saturday evening, Feb. 4, at the Hotel Commodore.

THE publisher's notice tells us that this novel won the first Danish, as Sigurd Christiansen's "Two Living and One Dead" won the first Norwegian, prize in the Inter-Scandinavian Novel Contest -- whatever that may be. It is a good and readable story, which seems a bit undecided where to take a stand, whether as serions realism or as social comedy.

Chinese wall helps The way things are shaping up in the Far East it is fortunate for China that she has a Great Wall. It is not that the Great Wall can stop the Japanese armies from driving right through the wall or over the wall to any point in China Proper, if they see fit.

ANY one in search of dance criticism, pungent and penetrating, would do well to drop in upon the Teatro dei Piccoli, which has just gone into its second edition at the Lyric Theatre. Here the dance is forced into a rather astonishing self-revelation, for its practitioners, being constructed of wood, wire, cloth and string, have neither any theories nor any passion with which to justify them.

With its first full day's session the National Motor Boat Show, off under full throttle on Friday night, chugged ahead yesterday. A constant stream of people poured in and out of Grand Central Palace.

IT is perhaps an act of supererogation to dwell upon the career of H.G. Wells, of how he began as a prolific creator of fantasy, and a humorist of type, of how he added a most effective satire in "Tono-Bungay," that first important deflation of the spirit of our modern publicity-nursed industry, of how he has continually battled for the scientific method and world view.

Most of the barter schemes now current in the United States grew spontaneously from small deals. A man with more potatoes than he could personally use found it advantageous to swap some of them for a cow, or for his neighbor's services in repairing a barn.

GENEVA, Jan. 20. -- The extremes to which Japan has gone this week in opposing the proposal to invite the United States and Soviet Russia to participate in its efforts to conciliate the Manchurian conflict have deeply impressed diplomats here.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Recommendations calling for increased revenues from lower income and estate tax exemptions are contained in a resolution dispatched to Washington today by 101 university economists. They represent seventeen universities in the United States.

GENERAL MOTORS Truck Company announces the introduction of a new valve-in-head engine built specially for truck service. According to the company the new engine provides more sustained torque per cubic inch of piston displacement than any other light-duty truck engine built.

The annual net loss of population on the lower east side appears to be slackening, although the exodus continues at the rate of more than 3,000 families yearly, according to tenement-occupancy figures compiled by Joseph Platzker of the East Side Chamber of Commerce for the period from Dec. 15, 1931, to Dec. 15, 1932.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One cannot fail to note the many decisions of the United States Supreme Court which have recently been decided by a closely divided bench, very often five to four. The newly elected President of the United States is a liberal.

CLOTHES, according to that cryptic saw, do not make the man. No more, according to Arthur Shields, who is the actor-manager of the touring company of Abbey Theatre Irish Players, do stage props and scenery make a play.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Pennsylvania shattered the Navy's long winning streak tonight by winning in a sensational basketball game at the Palestra, 38 to 34.

In the outburst of stories for young people about the Civil War this year there has been so much variety in the emphasis, the period of time covered, the section of country used as a background, that the books do not duplicate one another; taken together they make a very complete and many-sided picture.

The United States Intercoastal Conference, whose membership includes the principal ship lines operating between the Atlantic and Pacific coast ports, has notified the Senate Commerce Committee that it is opposed to any extension of powers of the Shipping Board to regulate the services of the intercoastal lines to so-called "inland" ports.

LONDON, Jan. 21. -- Montagu Norman, Governor of the Bank of England, whose engagement was announced only yesterday, was married today to Mrs. Priscilla Cecilia Maria Worsthorne, a granddaughter of the seventh Earl of Abingdon and a niece of Viscount Fitz Alan.

Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenhieimer is a product of the street corner gangs of the Mott Haven district of the Bronx. Before he was 16 -- about twenty years ago -- he was a good hand with the pool cue, both, in billiard games and in poolroom scraps.

THE beginning of the Wagner cycle series with the season's first "Das Rheingold," the return of Lily Pons after a lengthy absence due to illness, and the first performance of "Manon" this season feature the tenth week of the Metropolitan Opera season.

THIS book, designed as an interpretation of the life and work of two geniuses of Spain's Golden Age, is a disappointment in its present form. Conceivably the original appealed more strongly to the student of art and letters and the casual reader than will this translation, which, unhappily, is an inept piece of writing marked by unpleasant and disturbing locutions, ill-fitting adjectives, artless use of transitional words and a general lack of precision of tone.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- Close competition marked the open jumping event at the informal indoor horse show which the Boulder Brook Club gave today for its members in the riding ring on Old Mamaroneck Road. Nine took the jumps and two tied for first and second with clean performances, while two more were scored with only a slight touch each.

GEORGE ARLISS and his new film, "The King's Vacation," have taken over the screen at the Radio City Music Hall this week. The story, written for the English actor by Ernest Pascal, presents Mr. Arliss as a Prince Philip who marries a commoner, has a baby daughter and then to his own surprise finds himself on the throne of his country.

Edward Lee of the New York A. C., national amateur three-cushion billiard champion, retained his title when he defeated Alfredo De Oro Jr. in the final game yesterday at the Winged Foot Club, 50 to 25, in fifty-nine innings.
MADRID, Jan. 20. -- Some philosopher has pointed out that while it is comparatively easy to grab a bull by his tail, it is a decidedly delicate job to let go.

SO encouraging has been the response to Edna St. Vincent Millay's poetic broadcast that arrangements have been made for two extra programs. Her broadcasts were to have ended last week, but she has agreed to speak over the air twice more before leaving on a trip to Africa.

Myra Hess, who gave her first piano recital of the season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, again revealed the distinguished talents which we associate with her. They are many, and so well known by now that to talk of her rich palette of tone-color, her firm and singing line, her exquisite pianissimo, is almost redundant.

THOUGH it is cluttered up with the usual sentimental extravagances of the Dell romances, this novel evolves in its conclusion a father-son situation which unwontedly moved our cynical and flinty heart. Young Beresford, the hero, has been reared in the belief that his father, a famous forger, had died valorously in the World War, but the true fact is that he has just been released from serving a fifteen-year term in prison.

The first "Pelleas et Melisande" of the season, yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, fell with a special glamour and benevolence upon the ear. This was partly because of certain operas of more exterior and realistic nature which had immediately preceded it in the same theatre.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Jan. 21. -- Ellis H. Parker, chief of detectives of Burlington County, declared tonight that in his opinion Bradway Brown, who was found shot dead under mysterious circumstances last Monday night at his home in Palmyra, did not commit suicide but was murdered.
PITTSBURGH, Jan. 21. -- President William Benswanger of the Pittsburgh Pirates baseball club today announced the signing of Waite Hoyt to bolster the pitching staff.

"Success is not an accident. It comes to a man who does his work better than the other fellow." That motto on the walls of the office of the Jackson Shoe Manufacturing Company, at 692 Broadway, at the corner of Fourth Street, attracted the attention of the leader of three hold-up men yesterday morning.

GENEVA, Jan. 21. -- The Committee of Nineteen of the League of Nations decided this afternoon at a secret session that conciliation efforts in the Chino-Japanese conflict "have, so far as it is concerned, failed for the time being."

EMERSON round the Englishman to be of all men he who stood firmest in his shoes, and one hardly can fail to agree with him in the presence of an exhibition -- any exhibition -- of English art. Royal Academician, Impressionist, Cubist, even Dadaist, the English artist must remain an Englishman.

TOKYO, Sunday, Jan. 22 (AP). -- While newspaper extras this morning carried the news that the League of Nations Assembly Committee of Nineteen had virtually abandoned efforts to conciliate the Chino-Japanese problem, official quarters indicated that Japan, likewise, considered that phase of the question closed.
PARIS, Jan. 21. -- Strict measures for the repression of tax evasions were approved today by the Chamber of Deputies finance commission in three long sittings.

VANDALIA, Ohio, Jan. 21. -- A.J. Stauber of Los Angeles established a new world's record on registered trapshooting targets for a season by winning the high average title of North America during 1932 with a mark of .9940 on 1,000 clays.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 17. -- A new archaeological centre has been found in Mexico, surrounding the city of Achiutla, the great Mixtec capital in the northern and western parts of the State of Oaxaca.

ENGLAND'S poet laureate is visiting this country. He conies not as a stranger, for some of his formative years were spent here when, as a boy, he worked in a bakery, a livery stable, a carpet factory and a saloon. Yet, in manner at least, John Masefield apparently has been unaffected by his early experiences.
WHILE four desperate bandits were crying "Stick 'em up!" police voices in the Michigan air were calling "Bid 'em welcome!"

According to yesterday's classified statement of the Department of Commerce, this country's imports of gold during December, which amounted to $100,872,133 (the second largest Import showing for any month in the country's history), included consignments from thirty-three separate countries.
The Babylon section of Long Island has shown a steady expansion in recent years, due in part to improved traffic and transit facilities, according to realty men active in that territory.

THE railroads of the country, hard hit by declines in revenue, have resorted to one expedient after another to build up their passenger business. They have improved their cars, they have in some instances speeded up their schedules, they have extended special week-end and excursion rates, and some have issued scrip books entitling passengers to $108 worth of transportation for $81.

The great problem in Europe is not war or peace, it is whether to maintain existing conditions and suffer complete collapse or changer an intolerable situation and enable the return of prosperity, Count Eberhard Westarp, member of the German Army General Staff during the World War, declared yesterday at a luncheon of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor.
ANNAPOLIS, Md., Jan. 21 (AP). -- Reginald Bassett, Princeton University wrestler, went to the hospital tonight after assuring his team a 16-to-14 triumph over the Naval Academy matmen.
The population of Queens Borough increased by 12,100 during the past year and now totals 1,142,100, according to the annual estimate made by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce.

WHEN the Fisk University Choir, which is to be heard here Thursday night, Jan. 26, at Carnegie Hall in a concert of Negro spirituals and other choral music, opened its first concert tour in Cincinnati last Sunday afternoon the newspapers there reminded their readers of another concert of Fisk singers in that city some sixty years before in which a dramatic chapter in American musical history was begun.

The American Institute of Electrical Engineers will begin its annual five-day convention here tomorrow at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street. About 1,200 electrical engineers from all parts of the country are expected to attend.

NOW that I am growing accustomed to your barbaric habit of not serving champagne with every meal (a queer people, you Americans), I shall endeavor to pull myself together long enough to set down a few random notes about matters theatrical in London -- London as I used to know it, long, long ago.

Relief activities chargeable to the $15,000,000 fund of which the completion was announced last week by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, have already resulted in the expenditure of about one-fourth of the total, it was announced yesterday by the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau.

CHICAGO, Jan. 21. -- In place of the effort to create a vague piety which gives unreal answers to the real problems of youth, an attitude often laid to Protestant churches, Dr. Herbert W. Gates of Boston demands that the churches face youth problems as real things.

BERLIN, Jan. 20. -- A slow revolution of wheels within wheels of the Versailles treaty produced last July a convention regulating navigation of the Oder River drawn up by an international commission which, thirteen years before, the treaty's Article 341 created for governance of that river.

IT is a little more than seventyfive years since tbe Sepoy Rebellion, and the horror of it loses some of its poignancy as it fades into the past. But it is still one of the most dramatic incidents, the most horrifying, the most vividly moving in its sheer emotional appeal in all the history of the English-speaking race.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- The leaders of the Senate Democrats and Independent Republicans, Senators Robinson of Arkansas and Senator Borah joined today in strongly commending President-elect Roosevelt's decision to discuss the British debt in conjunction with other economic problems.

DOES college destroy religious faith? If the consensus of opinion among 1,500 Jewish students at fifty-seven colleges of all types and in all parts of the country may be trusted, religious belief is apt to be weakened at college, but college itself is not responsible.

Prominent women of society and well-known stars of the stage are aiding in the sale of boxes and seats for the special performance of "We, the People," the new play by Elmer Rice, which will be given tonight at the Empire Theatre under the auspices of the Actors' Fund Matinee Club for the benefit of the Actors' Fund.

MEDITERRANEAN voyagers may be lured by the island of Sardinia, its natural beauties, the primitive customs of its inhabitants, and many, no doubt, have sojourned there for a longer or shorter period in answer to that lure.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday involved a total of only 366,000 shares, which was barely, sufficient to keep the languishing market alive. From the viewpoint of the commission houses, this meant merely another addition to the long list of unprofitable days.
The population of Queens Borough increased by 12,100 during the past year and now totals 1,142,100, according to the annual estimate made by the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce.

WHEN the Fisk University Choir, which is to be heard here Thursday night, Jan. 26, at Carnegie Hall in a concert of Negro spirituals and other choral music, opened its first concert tour in Cincinnati last Sunday afternoon the newspapers there reminded their readers of another concert of Fisk singers in that city some sixty years before in which a dramatic chapter in American musical history was begun.

Relief activities chargeable to the $15,000,000 fund of which the completion was announced last week by Harvey D. Gibson, chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, have already resulted in the expenditure of about one-fourth of the total, it was announced yesterday by the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- Al- though the marines who returned from Nicaragua a few days ago after four years of warfare against Sandino bandits tell many tales of heroism, the entire brigade agrees upon two acts of bravery that top all others during the long series of bandit fights.

IT is the time of the year when every woman wants something new to wear. She wants to look different, and yet it is not the opportune moment for supplying herself with an entirely new wardrobe unless she is fortunate enough to be bound for other climes.

FROM a cabinet of curiosities and a place where rare objects might be preserved the museum has developed into an educational and therefore a social institution. How its social purpose is best to be fulfilled has never been clearly defined.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 21. -- A nose finish in the Palm Beach Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today, electrified a crowd of 6,000 persons who turned out for the first Saturday card of the meeting. Helios, recently acquired by the Anall Stable of Allan Ryan, just lasted under a hustling ride by Jockey Charles Kurtsinger to win by the scantiest of margins from Bolilee, now bearing the colors of G.C. Winfrey.

A list of the fifty largest savings banks in New York State published in the current bulletin of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York shows twelve institutions with deposits of more than $100,000,000 each and four with deposits exceeding $200,000,000. The largest one is the Bowery Savings Bank, which held on Jan. 1 deposits of $536,798,776.

LILIAN HARVEY, who is trilingual, diminutive and blonde, is off to Hollywood to make her first American picture, "His Majesty's Car." Fox's latest importation from beyond the seas presented herself to the advance agents of her prospective American public at the Waldorf last Monday and discussed a variety at subjects with a Mayfair accent.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 21. -- Ontario's, gold harvest increased $4,035,878 in 1932, or approximately 9.4 per cent, exclusive of exchange compensation, according to the official report of the Ontario Department of Mines. For December the output was $201,353 greater than in November.
WASHINGTON. NO other Congressional proceeding attracts quite as much attention as a filibuster such as that which Senator Huey Long has been conducting against the Glass banking bill.

HOLLYWOOD. A FANTASTIC film which has been one and one-half years in the making will soon be released. It is "King Kong," made by those two adventurer-producers, Ernest B. Schoedsack and Merian C. Cooper.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Extension of the currency expansion provision of the Glass-Steagall law for another year was approved by the Senate today and prospects of House sanction were described as favorable.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 21. -- Gene Venzke, the long-legged Pottstown, (Pa.) runner, who rose to fame a year ago, today shattered the University of Pennsylvania three-quarter-mile outdoor board track mark by nearly five seconds.

In a modest dwelling house in Changchun, which is completely enclosed in a high barbed-wire barricade, which is closely patrolled day and night by Japanese soldiers, lives General Nobuyoshi Muto, the man in whose hands is concentrated all of Japan's power in Manchuria.

ELECTRICAL magic has worked revolutionary changes in radio since an urgent CQD caused excitement all along the New England coast twenty-four years ago tonight. It was at 4 o'clock on the morning of Jan. 23, 1909, that the steamship Florida collided with the White Star liner Republic in a dense fog off Nantucket.

HONOLULU, Jan. 21. -- George Norton Wilcox, one of the wealthiest residents in the Territory of Hawaii, who was well-known for his philanthropy, died here early today at the age of 93, after a prolonged illness. His body will be cremated and the ashes will be taken for burial to the island of Kauai, where he had made his home for nearly seventy years.

President John W. Blodgett of the National Lumber Manufacturers Association, has appointed the original eight members of the committee to consider the merchandising and distributing methods of the lumber industry, author- ized at the annual meeting of the directors in Chicago in December.

Because one of the "home town boys" played football at Franklin Field, Philadelphia, Dec. 3 or sat on the Army or Navy bench there, charity in seventy-three cities and towns in the limited States will benefit by $100 each this Winter.

The motor boat clan has gathered from the far corners of the country and the near corners as well, for the twenty-eighth session of the National Motor Boat Show. This is a brand new show, glittering with variety and temptations for the growing family of those who seek their sport and recreation on the water.

An appeal to the women of America to stem the tide of demoralization in the cloak industry which has resulted in an extraordinary increase in sweat-shops was made yesterday to Mrs. Grace Morrison Poole, president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs by Samuel Klein, executive director of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 21. -- To permit his successor to have a brief period of Senatorial training before taking over his duties in his own right, Senator Harry B. Hawes, Democrat of Missouri, will step out of the Senate on Feb. 3.

BERLIN, Jan. 21. -- The Boerse closed the week with a more active market and with a majority of stocks rising 1 to 5 points. Shares of key industries were the centre of interest. Public utilities and motors also were in good demand. The bond market was inactive but also strong, even small purchases sending up prices.

MOSCOW, Jan. 21 (AP). -- Owing to the forthcoming issuance of passports to those engaged in "socially useful" work, which will mean the exclusion of others from the centres where the passports are issued, an exodus on a small scale has already begun from Moscow.

With stocks displaying quiet strength in trading of a routine Saturday pattern, interest yesterday was centred largely in the bond market, in which there were many fairly substantial advances and a few that ran to 3 and 4 points or more.

BUFFALO, Jan. 19. -- This is the time of year when public attention centres more on plans and outlook than on anything that has happened. The habit of taking stock and looking to the future during the opening month of a new year applies alike to business and politics, as well as to other activities which later become the subject of specialized effort.

PALM BEACH -- With increased momentum from earlier weeks, when tentative plans for cultural affairs were being made and preliminary play in golf, tennis and other sports comprised weekly programs. Palm Beach this week will receive announcements of completely formulated schedules and witness the first real tournament play.

THE will of Calvin Coolidge, a simple document bequeathing his estate to his widow, has called forth estimates of its value at approximately $500,000. The will also serves to call attention to the fact that few Presidents of the United States could be classed as wealthy men and that, while most of them might be regarded as being in "comfortable circumstances," some Presidents died practically penniless.

Judging from the large number of boxes and seats that already have been sold for the double bill at the Metropolitan Opera House on the afternoon of Feb. 3, a substantial sum will be realized by Vassar Club for its scholarship fund. "Elektra" and "Pagliacci" will be sung.

Meeting in executive session at the School of Business on the Columbia University campus, the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools yesterday afternoon discussed the interpretation of the resolution adopted by the body last year calling for the abolition of athletic scholarships by member colleges and schools.
RYE, N.Y., Jan. 21. -- Breaking 94 targets, P.M. McHugh carried off high scratch honors at the traps of the Westchester Country Club today.

Developments in the oil industry in the last few weeks, including severe price cuts in both gasoline and crude oil, point to a weakening sentiment for proration as it is now being enforced. Because of the large production of crude oil in excess of the prescribed allowable amounts, many former advocates of proration are said to have become disgusted and now are about ready to abandon any further efforts along this line.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 21. -- The Yale wrestling team today outscored Lafayette, 24 to 8, securing three falls to one and three time advantages or referee's decisions to one for Lafayette.

THE substance of Miss Patrick's later novels seldom varies -- she is overwhelmingly preoccupied with young love's pains and raptures -- and in these books there is apparent a steady dimunition of the more intelligent qualities manifested in her earlier works, such as "Dreaming Spires" and "Firefly."

SAD to say, boxing failed in a national emergency. But, perhaps, baseball will do better. When the eminent Senator from Louisiana, Huey P. Long, put on his filibustering act, the Republican cohorts clustered around the Hon. Warren Barbour, former amateur heavyweight champion, and said in effect:

The St. Cecilia Club, which has occupied a high place in society and musical circles since its organization in 1906, will give its first concert of the season on Tuesday night at the Town Hall. The concert will inaugurate the twenty-seventh season of the unit which originally was called the Tuesday Morning Singing Club.

LONDON. THE day will come when the intergovernmental war debts will be a closed account. It probably will not be in the year 1984, when the final British payment to America is officially scheduled to be made.
DES MOINES, Jan. 20. -- The domestic allotment plan is part of a greater plan to help the United States relate herself properly to changed conditions growing out of the World War.

MADISON, Wis., Jan. 21 -- Wisconsin will be made safer for the investor who buys without consulting earning sheets and operating re- ports if the Legislature passes the administration bill now before it to strengthen the State securities law.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 21. -- J. Earle and T.B. Pettit Jr. tied for the High Scratch Cup at the traps or the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. Each finished with a perfect string of 50 targets. In the shoot-off Earl won by breaking 25 straight. Pettit had 24.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 21. -- Following the failure of the East Tennessee National Bank to open for business yesterday, the Fidelity Bankers Trust Company, a real estate investment concern, sent a re-financing statement tonight to all its bondholders proposing immediate payment of 50 per cent on all of its $8,000,000 bonds, regardless of maturity.

DUBLIN, Jan. 20. -- Just before the polling of one of the hardest-fought elections since the Irish Free State was established, all indications point to a position of virtual stalemate in the new Dail Eireann.

BOSTON, Jan. 19. -- For the first time in its variegated history covering eighty-seven years the Old Howard is "dark." Not for thirty days will it be possible for the management to renew its standing advertisement, "Always Something Doing From 1 to 11."

IN his introductory note Mr. Odum, who is Professor of Sociology in the University of North Carolina and general editor of the series to which this book is a recent addition, explains that for some years before his death, now almost two years ago, Franklin H. Giddings had been planning this work.

PRODUCERS here and abroad have recently issued motion pictures with stories culled from newspaper files and biographies. In several instances they came as a relief from the many stereotyped romances. There was the "Warner Brothers' worthy contribution, "Silver Dollar," based on the meteoric career of Haw Tabor of Denver, and also the not so successful film on Ivar Kreuger.

LONDON. THE day will come when the intergovernmental war debts will be a closed account. It probably will not be in the year 1984, when the final British payment to America is officially scheduled to be made.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A storm of discussion has of late been raging on the form of art which is called modernism, provoked by architects, sculptors and painters voicing their bombastic views, inspired by the phantasmagoria of their nightmares.

Knowing and Seeing. Mr. ROOSEVELT was greatly impressed by the size of Muscle Shoals. "It was at least twice as large as I had any conception." Yet it is not to be supposed that he really made up his mind about Muscle Shoals on the basis of his brief study on the spot.

A well-dressed, middle-aged man, who, according to the police, seems to have mastered the technique of hotel robberies, held up his third Brooklyn hotel in a month early yesterday morning and escaped with $275 in cash. The hotel was the Clarendon in Washington Street, in the shadow of the Brooklyn Federal Building.

Among those who have observed the phenomenon of Yehudi Menuhin since his first appearance in public nearly a decade ago there are some who have turned anxious eyes on the passing years and wondered what time would do to him. Remarkable virtuoso talent in early childhood, even rare artistic insight, has been seen to attach itself orchid-like to children occasionally, flowering strangely into brief beauty and fading with adolescence.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The industrial employment situation changed little during December although in some lines, operations were expanded and working forces increased, the United States Employment Service's monthly review said today.

AMSTERDAM, Jan. 20 -- It cannot be said that industrial developments in Europe since the turn of the year have been much changed. There are, however, certain signs of improvement. Here in Holland, shipping activity has somewhat increased, and in Germany, there has been a pretty distinct recovery in some principal industries, especially shown by such companies as the Vereinigte Stahlwerke and the Farbenindustrie.

Waning religion, lawlessness and public apathy toward government are outstanding dangers which threaten the national life of the United States, the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod, pastor of the Collegiate Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, said yesterday in a sermon which formed part of the fifteenth annual services of the New York State membership of the National Society of Colonial Dames.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Has it occurred to others what a significant relation there is between the asinine performance represented by Huey Long's filibuster in the Senate and technocracy?

With a view to framing legislation to increase the age jurisdiction of the Children's Courts in New York State, the National Probation Association, 450 Seventh Avenue, has appointed a committee to confer with the Welfare Council and other agencies regarding a proposed bill, it was announced yesterday.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 22 (AP). -- Lighthorse Harry Cooper, Chicago professional, won the second annual Phoenix open golf tournament today with 281 for the 72 holes. He shot 71 and 72 on his last two rounds.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 22 -- A nation-wide retrenchment in State and municipal expenditures is indicated in a report submitted by E.F. Dunstan of the Bankers Trust Company, New York, before the Winter meeting of the board of governors of the Investment Bankers Association of America, which closed a three-day session at the Sea View Golf Club at Absecon today.

Amid all these jangling voices of planners and panaceists, patter of economic jugglers, predictions of cock-sure prophets, shouting of miracle men and "yarb doctors," it is refreshing to hear a quiet philosopher of the old school. In The Forum ex-President HIBBEN, writing about the depression, restates with unshaken calm some of the essential values that have been pushed out of sight by newer, temporarily more fashionable systems.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Cattle interests did not do so well last week as they did four to six months ago. Some have fed their steers too long. The dressed beef market was overloaded, resulting in unevenly lower prices.

PARIS, Jan. 20 -- After various fluctuations, caused by anxiety concerning home political developments, the Paris Bourse became more hopeful this week, prices taking a turn for the better. The feeling has gained ground that the worst of the depression is over and that the only impediments to real recovery are no longer of a strictly economic nature.

The minding of other people's business was described as the moral duty of good Christians in a sermon preached yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Raymond L. Forman, pastor of St. Paul's Methodist Church, West End Avenue and Eighty-sixth Street.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Jan. 23 -- China's reply to the increasing Japanese threat in North China and to the warning uttered Saturday by Count Uchida, Japanese Foreign Minister, has assumed the form of an intensified national effort. There is to be a hurried assembly of military leaders at Nanking where a policy of resistance is likely to be formulated and support assured to Chang Hsiao-liang in his defense of Jehol and Hopei.
SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 22 -- Only three of the original eight seeded players in the New Jersey State squash tennis championship had survived at the close of today's play at the Short Hills Club.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- Although definite consideration of the Washington invitation to discuss war debts cannot begin before tomorrow's special meeting of the Cabinet, there already are two views as to what the British point of departure for the negotiations should be.

A sharp increase in the number of buyers here for Spring merchandise produced increased activity in the wholesale markets last week. Style tendencies for the new season definitely crystallized, with tailored versions predominating in practically all types of ready-to-wear.
Reports sent out over the weekend by brokers and managing agents of properties in Manhattan indicate a good demand for business space.

Before the close of its present session the State Legislature will be asked to extend the existing eight-hour law so that it will include the thousands of nurses, attendants and other employes in State hospitals for the insane. A measure embodying this provision may be added to the pending bill extending the eight-hour law to prison employes.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Marine investigations in the Central American seas, which were started by the Yale oceanographic expedition to the Gulf of Mexico on the schooner Mabel Taylor, will be continued this year as a result of arrangements announced today between Yale University and the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution.
