Fearing a panic might result as smoke seeped into the Royal Theatre, a motion-picture house at Westchester and Bergen Avenues, the Bronx, from a blaze sweeping a two-story department store adjoining it, fire officials last night ordered the theatre emptied of 2,000 persons in the audience.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Ever since South Africa abandoned the gold standard at the end of last year there has been steady depreciation in the external value of the South African currency. Before the gold standard was suspended the rate of exchange between London and South Africa was u70 South Africa for u100 sterling.

The national rate of steel production expanded one point to 18 per cent of capacity last week, according to the magazine Steel. Generally, the rise of the first half of January ceased, and this, with re- ductions in sheet and wire quotations, the publication says, caused a feeling of uncertainty to spread over the industry.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Progressive Republicans considered for Cabinet places by President-elect Roosevelt are represented in some quarters here as having graciously declined to surrender their positions in Congress to become members of his official family.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- The Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies worked all day because it has only tea days to settle budget details so the government can carry on during February. When the members adjourned they had passed many measures but had so reduced Finance Minister Cheron's proposals that the negotiations obviously are going to end with far less than the $400,000,000 needed to meet the deficit unless new resources are found.

What New York thinks of a daring and gallant rescue at sea was shown when Captain GEORGE FRIED of the liner America came into port with the crew of the Florida on board in January, 1929. Broadway gave the officers of the America the same kind of welcome that is accorded famous polar explorers and aviators who have greatly distinguished themselves.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 22 -- Professor James Harvey Rogers, Sterling Professor of Political Economy at Yale University and author of "America Weighs Her Gold," tonight gave out a statement in which he declared an unfortunate emphasis had been placed on re-establishment of the gold standard by Great Britain in discussion of war-debt negotiations.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Heavy mists, light showers and fair rains fell last week over the greater part of Kansas, Oklahoma, Texas and Southern Colorado, the last section also getting good snows. The moisture will do a little good to the Winter wheat crop, but more is needed, particularly in Western Nebraska, Western Kansas, and Southern Colorado.

After being closed over Sunday, the National Motor Boat Show will open again this morning, to resume all-day sessions for the rest of the week. The exhibition invariably hits its full stride on its rebound.

"The Dubarry," starring Grace Moore, will begin the last week of its engagement at the George M. Cohan Theatre this evening. On Jan. 12 the top price was reduced from $4.40 to $2.75. The operetta, which opened here on Nov. 22, represents Mrs. Tillie Leblang's second theatrical venture this season.

DETROIT, Jan. 22 -- The Detroit Red Wings smashed through the vaunted defense of the New York Americans tonight to score a 2-to-0 National League hockey victory. It was the sixth shutout this season for Goalie John Ross Roach.

Uncle Robert and his Radio Pals who are heard every Saturday evening between 6:30 and 7:30 over station WPAP, gave a performance yesterday afternoon for the 348 inmates of the Home for Aged and Infirm Hebrews, 121 West 105th Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- An issue of $250,000,000 in five-year 2 5/8 per cent Treasury notes will be offered by the Treasury Department for subscription tomorrow, Secretary Mills announced tonight. The notes will be dated Feb. 1, 1933, on which date $144,372,000 in 3 3/4 per cent certificates will mature.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Leaders in the grain trade, in the main, express themselves as looking for an advance in the price of wheat. They say there is an abundance of idle money awaiting investment and that as soon as policies in Washington are determined business in the country will improve and a restoration of confidence should carry prices for agricultural products and commodities to higher levels.

Miss Elisabeth Marbury, noted leader in theatrical, literary, political and civic life, died of a heart attack at 5:33 A.M. yesterday at her home, 13 Sutton Place. On Thursday she had undergone a minor operation on a leg, from which she was supposed to have suffered no ill effects.
The Bronx Hockey Club scored a one-sided victory over Westchester, 10 to 4, in an exhibition game at the New York Coliseum yesterday before 2,500 fans.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Thirty-five Nazis, Communists and police-men were injured and eighty persons were arrested today when crowds tried to interfere with the demonstration by thousands of National Socialists in the Buelowplatz.

Although available statistics fail to show any increase in Insanity because of the suffering brought about by the depression, suicide has become unmistakably more frequent and a great many lesser departures from normal mental health are being observed, according to a report on the mental hygiene of unemployment which has been prepared for the National Committee on Mental Hygiene by Dr. George K. Pratt, psychiatrist.

Contracts for all classes of construction in this city and vicinity amounted to $190,678,200 last year, as compared with an aggregate of $725,061,400 for the year 1931, according to a summary of new construction awards just announced by the F.W. Dodge Corporation.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week were as follows:

The operation of test trains through the Brooklyn extension of the Eighth Avenue subway, from Chambers Street to Borough Hall, has been started and will be continued this week on a larger scale. Engineers of the Board of Transportation's operating force are drawing up schedules for the passenger service, which is expected to start about Feb. 1.
ALBANY, Jan. 22 -- Governor Lehman will set in motion the work to devise a State liquor-control system when he confers with his special commission at an organization meeting here Tuesday.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 22 -- The award of sixty-five insignia to Princeton men in recognition of their work in minor sports during the Fall was announced today by Asa S. Bushnell, graduate manager of athletics.

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., Jan. 22 -- With both teams playing from scratch, George Douglas Debevoise and Perry R. Pease of the Racquet and Tennis Club defeated Junius Richards and E.M. Miller of the Rockaway Hunting Club this afternoon to win the first annual handicap squash racquets doubles tournament of the Piping Rock Club.

In diplomacy, said Lord PALMERSTON, "it is the tone which makes the song." This is what we have now got with respect to the question of intergovernmental debts. It is a new tone, a different pitch and rhythm. That accounts for the general cheering up of public opinion, both here and abroad, as a result of the agreement between President HOOVER and Governor ROOSEVELT announced on Friday.

Whatever fears the Giants might have entertained on the score of salaries for 1933 were virtually dispelled yesterday when Secretary Jim Tierney, wearing his broadest smile, announced the receipt of Master Melvin Ott's signed contract.

SHREVEPORT, La., Jan. 22 (AP). -- Plans for revamping the credit system of the country "to make all banks safe," necessity for legislation to avert foreclosures of farm and home mortgages and farm relief were discussed here today by Senator-elect William G. McAdoo, who is en route to his California home by airplane.

The Group Theatre, whose last offering was the short-lived "Big Night" -- which closed Saturday after seven performances -- has written the end to its season. It could not be learned definitely last evening whether or not it had also ended its career.

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- After digging two years into the black lime soil of Persepolis, ancient capital of Persia, University of Chicago archaeologists have uncovered two rich chapters of the story of man's rise from savagery. Dr. James Henry Breasted, director of the Oriental Institute at the university, made public today reports of "great and important" discoveries prepared by Dr. Ernest Herzfeld, field director of the institute's Persian Expedition.

In the college year beginning Sept. 1, 1933, the members of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools must dispense with all forms of athletic scholarships, or subject themselves to removal from the approved list of institutions maintained by that organization.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 22 -- The Frostbite Yacht Club skippers had to bow to the elements today.

The North American Game Breeders Association officially has adopted the "model game law" which its committee has been working upon for several weeks. At a meeting of the board of directors on Saturday it was voted to accept the measure as it now is written.

The Society of Missionary Priests of St. Paul the Apostle, generally known, as the Paulist Fathers, began yesterday a four-day celebration of the diamond jubilee of the organization, which was the first American order of priests established in the Roman Catholic church, all the services being held in, the "mother church," the Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 22 -- One of the fiercest battles in the Chaco war has been raging since Friday at dawn in the vicinity of the Paraguayan Fort President Ayala, which the Bolivians know as Port Nanawa.

The two easy victories scored by Princeton, defending champion, featured the week in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race. The Tigers, who lost their opening game to Pennsylvania, returned to form and advanced into a tie for second place with Columbia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Actual cash loans of $1,648,622,393 to prevent the forced liquidation of assets of financial institutions, forestall railrcad receiverships and provide relief for the destitute were made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation from its establishment last February to the close of business Dec. 31.

Although the roadster in which they were riding on the west side express highway crashed last night into an electric light post in the centre of the road and overturned. Stephen Berenowsky of 53 Monroe Street, the driver, and his companion, Miss Jean Corner, 20, of 40 Washington Street, escaped unhurt.

As a result of a substantial reduction in the value of stock dividends from affiliated and subsidiary companies, the gross income of the Central States Electric Corporation was insufficient to cover interest, discount, taxes and expenses in 1932, according to the annual report issued yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Ginsburgh's article in THE TIMES, telling us that motors are to take the place of the cavalry horse in order to maintain the cavalry as the fastest-moving fighting force, was read with a great deal of interest.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 22 -- Concerted action by Nassau County taxpayers, whose tax bills in some instances are 100 per cent more than the levies of a year ago, is under way with economy in government as the objective.

Pierre Matisse is offering something of a novelty in an exhibition of paintings by Andre Masson. Several canvases by this French artist have been seen here before, but this is his first one-man show. To those who are interested in new departures in painting the exhibition will prove of interest.

William Butler Yeats, Irish poet and playwright, sailed on the liner Bremen early yesterday for Southampton, with words of praise for George Moore, the Irish novelist, who in life had been one of Mr. Yeats's most distinguished adversaries.

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 22 -- The most important event last week in the steel trade, in the opinion of both manufacturers and consumers, was a decline in the open market prices of wire products. There was no formal marking down of quotations, producers taking pains to assert that "official" prices were unchanged.

Mrs. Charles Cary Rumsey has given the use of her studio at 152 East Fortieth Street for an exhibition of handicraft articles made by members of the Metropolitan Junior Achievement, to be held on Thursday and Friday afternoons. On Thursday Mrs. Sidney C. Borg will speak of the organization's work, and on Friday Harold A. Ley, president of the New York City branch of the national body will speak.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES recently there appeared a quotation from a speech made by William Guggenhieim at the University of Pennsylvania clubhouse the evening before. In advocating the cessation of the policy of "soaking the rich,' Mr. Guggenheim remarked:

CHICAGO, Jan. 22 -- Farmers are not selling their corn freely and outside interests are indifferent about buying futures or even cash grain. A small business for export was done last week, part for nearby shipment from the Gulf and for May shipment from Montreal to Sweden.

No one this side of the Riviera will have reason to disapprove Mayor O'BRIEN'S proposal to reorganize the Department of Sanitation in such a way as to permit the elimination of Dr. SCHROEDER as its directing head. It is also in the interest of efficiency as well as economy that one commissioner be substituted for the present three.

The intimations that Tammany would be coolly treated in the matter of Federal patronage under the Roosevelt administration were followed yesterday by information that Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City, leader of the New Jersey Democratic organization, is to receive a full share of recognition after March 4 from President Roosevelt and his advisers.

A world's heavyweight wrestling championship match under the direction of Promoter Jack Curley will be offered tonight in Madison Square Garden at marked-down prices. Ed (Strangler) Lewis, who is the State Athletic Commission's recognized title-holder, is to defend his crown against Jim Browning, husky Boston Irishman, in a match to a finish.
A dense fog covered New York harbor late yesterday afternoon, delaying ferryboats from five to twenty minutes on their regular runs and causing two accidents.

Edwin Gruhl, president of the North American Company, one of the largest public-utility holding companies in the United States, died suddenly at 9 o'clock last night of coronary thrombosis at his residence, 975 Park Avenue. Services will be held in the Funeral Church, Broadway and Sixty-sixth Street at 11 o'clock tomorrow morning.

Let us hope that Tammany is acquiring, or is having forced upon it, a new sensitiveness in the matter of judicial nominations and appointments. At the time of naming a Surrogate, Governor LEHMAN is understood to have taken the position that he would accept no judge who did not first have the approval of the Bar Association.

The American Society of Miniature Painters opens its annual exhibition tomorrow afternoon with a private view at the Grand Central Galleries. On the same day the Brooklyn Museum will offer to the public an international exhibition of water-colors.

Using the Olympic Games, the national championships and seasonal performances as his background, Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the Amateur Athletic Union, yesterday named his annual All-America track and field team. This list, together with his All-College and All-Scholastic selections, appears in the Spalding Athletic Almanac, which is just off the press.

In the fourteen months ended Jan. 1, $37,374,976 was spent jointly by the State and counties and cities for work relief for the unemployed, it was revealed yesterday in a report of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration. The funds spent through 100 county emergency work bureaus, financed jointly by the State and local governments, helped about 177,500 families and, in addition, 17,500 individuals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- A petition to the people and to members of the Senate to bring about negotiations with other governments to detegalize war was made public today by a group of men and women, embracing many professions, headed by Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, who commanded the Twenty-seventh Division during the World War.

"The Depression Gaieties" will have its single, solitary performance at the Imperial Theatre on Sunday night, Feb. 5. At the moment authors are writing small pieces to form its skits, and song writers are pounding their pianos in the search for tunes.

Stability in the petroleum industry, according to C.B. Ames, president of the American Petroleum Institute, could be brought about by the cooperation of only three or four States and the industry by the adoption of sound conservation principles.

MUKDEN, Jan. 22 -- The American consular authorities today were Investigating the circumstances of an alleged unauthorized and illegal trespass on American property here by the Japanese consular police after an altercation between the American owner and a Japanese subject.

Charles Fertig of the Tappen Post of the American Legion, aided by a handicap of 1:00, romped home first in the time of 23:47 in the weekly 4 1/2 mile road race held by the St. Anselm's Athletic Club through the streets of the southeastern section of the Bronx yesterday.

Because of a breakdown, in the traditional methods of supplying funds for education, more than a third of the school children in the United States are being deprived of essential instruction, it was declared yesterday by Dr. Paul R. Mort, head of the National Survey of School Finance, in making public the report of the survey.

PARIS, Jan. 22 -- French opinion has become quite alarmed in the last few days over the turn events have taken at Geneva with the inability of the Committee of Nineteen to reach a satisfactory formula of conciliation regarding Manchuria.

MOSCOW, Jan. 22 -- The ninth anniversary of Lenin's death, commemorated today at the end of the Five-Year Plan and the beginning of a second, is being used to emphasize, first, the essential continuity of Bolshevist aims and policy, and, second, Joseph Stalin's place as "the prolonger of Lenin's work," to use his own correction of your correspondent's phrase of two years ago that he was "the inheritor of Lenin's mantle."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Conversion of the outstanding $8,201,000,000 of Liberty bonds and the $5,350,000,000 of short-term public debt into long-term bonds at a saving in interest apparently is to be left entirely up to the incoming Democratic administration.

Bernard S. Deutsch, attorney and Jewish leader, who received almost 300,000 votes as independent candidate for the Supreme Court bench in the fight against, the HofstadterSteuer candidacy last November, was the guest of honor last night at a dinner attended by more than 1,000 of his friends at the Hotel Commodore.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Veterans of the war, more particularly those who served in the 107th Infantry of the 27th Division in France and Belgium, must have read with sorrow the account in THE TIMES this morning of the death of their former commander, Brig. Gen. Mortimer Drake Bryant.
Merely Metrical. Gather fleet or even fleeter for the battle of the meter In our country where the yardstick is the measure.

Pynson Printers, in their little gallery on the seventh floor of The Times Annex, Have opened an exhibition of original drawings and early woodcuts, which will remain through February, to be followed by another instalment in the selfportrait series.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 22 -- The first callers on President-elect Roosevelt after his arrival at Warm Springs this morning were Senators Robert M. La Follette of Wisconsin and Bronson Cutting of New Mexico, two of the leading members of the Progressive Republican group who supported him for election. Step that appealed to the Progressives of both parties.

In one way the twenty-eighth annual national motor boat show, which opened Friday night with a magnificent and varied display of the newest developments in boats, engines and marine equipment, is the most important of all the motor boat shows which have been held during the entire three decades of this fast-growing sport.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Arguing for reflationary adjustment of the currency to meet advantages held by countries off the gold standard, Senator Borah today assailed proposals for imposition of a sales tax.

Three of the leading investigators of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends discussed Technocracy in the light of their own three-year study of the state of the nation, and all three agreed yesterday In a public dialogue, broadcast through Station WEVD, that Technocracy is "a trade name for a special interpretation of the effect of the machine."

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- Although there has been marked improvement in Great Britain's overseas balance on merchandise trade account, according to the published figures for 1932, it is not generally thought that Great Britain's actual balance on all foreign payments, visible and invisible, is again on the right side.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan. 22 -- Eight thoroughbreds of 3 years and upward, including last year's Louisiana Derby winner, Lucky Tom, have been named for the Inaugural Handicap, opening-day feature tomorrow at the old Fair Grounds course. Formerly under the control of E.R. Bradley, the famous track will be under the new management of the Crescent City Jockey Club, which has John C. Schank of Chicago as president.

But for the general adoption of shorter working schedules by industries, there are 5,000,000 men and women who would be unemployed. This is the statement made by the Teagle Share-the-Work Committee as the result of a survey made by it in cooperation with the Departments of Commerce and Labor.

The self-effacing west side resident who enlisted the sympathy of Mayor John P. O'Brien in behalf of the twenty men living in their own shanty colony along the Hudson north of Ninety-sixth Street was George Willard Bronte, illustrator and former art editor, of 330 West Ninety-fifth Street, it became known yesterday.

Having the dramatic courage of his private convictions Elmer Rice has written a bristling indictment of the American political system in "We, the people," which was put on at the patrician Empire Theatre on Saturday evening. If It comes to a question of choices, Mr. Rice is a revolutionary.

LONDON, Jan. 22 -- London's bus strikers, who have disregarded union orders and tied up about three-fourths of the city's chief transportation system, threatened tonight to extend their rebel influence into other means of travel and to paralyze the city.

The successful culmination of the 1932 drive of the Federation for the Support of Jewish Philanthropic Societies was hailed yesterday by Joseph M. Proskauer, president of the federation, at its annual meeting in the community house of Temple Emanu-El, 1 East Sixty-fifth Street.

A program of staggered ship construction has been prepared by the Postoffice Department for bidders on contracts to transport mails on two ocean routes. The contracts on both routes will run for ten years, starting at a time optional with the ship lines but not later than eighteen months from the date of award.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 22 (AP). -- Ernie Nevers's Pacific Coast All-Stars, a team assembled and coached the last two weeks, furnished a surprising upset today by defeating the Green Bay Packers, formidable professional football eleven, 13-6.

Albert Firmin, Brooklyn Postmaster, who celebrated his fiftieth anniversary in the postal service on Jan. 8, will retire on March 4, although under his appointment his term would not expire until 1936, he announced yesterday. He was appointed as Postmaster in 1924 by President Coolidge.

An organization known as the Guild of American Festivals has been organized to undertake a nationally coordinated campaign for a ten-year program to stimulate concerts, festivals and opera in every State, and particularly in the national capital.

A bronze plaque in memory of the Rev. Dr. George Alexander, for many years minister of the First Presbyterian Church, Fifth Avenue and Eleventh Street, was unveiled at the church yesterday morning after a memorial sermon by the Rev. Dr. J.V. Moldenhawer who succeeded to the pulpit after Dr. Alexander's death on Dec. 12, 1930.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- Hope has been expressed la some financial and diplomatics circles that negotiations between Great Britain and the United States for revision of the war-time debt agreement will lead to a solution which will call for application of the lump sum payment principle or a short-term arrangement which will wipe out the pact which funded the British debt to this country over a period of sixty-two years.

Deploring the prevalence of "easy-time faith" and "cluttered faith that rests upon a sort of magic Bible and a magic, wonderworking God," the Rev. Dr. Finis S. Idleman in his sermon at the Central Church of Disciples of Christ, 142 West Eighty-first Street, declared yesterday that "the faith of Moses deeply rooted in eternity and in the invisible God is the only kind of faith with which to meet life."

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- The pick of Berlin's police forces, mobilized with full riot equipment, today prevented the Communists from interfering with the much-heralded demonstration by the National Socialist storm troops in the Buelowplatz, in the east end of Berlin, the Reds' citadel and the location of their party headquarters.

Although endorsing the discontinuance of the City Planning Commission, the Bill Drafting Commission and the Board of Taxicab control as part of the city's retrenchment plan, the Real Estate Board of New York expresses disapproval of the proposed change in tax payment dates, in a letter addressed to Mayor O'Brien by Anton L. Trunk, president of the Real Estate Board.

BERLIN, Jan. 20 -- Developments in home politics this week discouraged business initiative and led to sharp reaction on the Boerse. In that decline, however, not only home politics but also the heaviness in Wall Street and the reaction, in German bonds abroad played their part.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 22 -- President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt, on hearing today of the death of Miss Elisabeth Marbury, said: "I am greatly shocked to hear of the death of my old friend, Miss Marbury. Mrs. Roosevelt and I will miss her very much."

RYE, N.Y., Jan. 22 -- Several of the leading dinghy sailors from the Westchester shore of Long Island Sound, who, for one reason or another, found it impracticable to cross over to Manhasset Bay for the regularly scheduled regatta of the Frostbite Yacht Club, gathered at the American Yacht Club today and held a series of informal races off Milton Point.

Detractors of Christianity who contend that the teaching's of modern science are inconsistent with religious belief are "thirty or forty years behind the times," Bishop William T. Manning declared yesterday in his sermon at St. Paul's Chapel, Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- The constitutionality of the Federal waterpower act and the right of the Federal Government to regulate rates, charges and security issues of waterpower concerns will go before the courts tomorrow with the reopening of the case of the Appalachian Electric Power Company against the Federal Power Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your correspondent A.G. Hatcher deplores the liberties taken at the Memphis convention with the standards of correct English, and argues for uniformity in such matters by all English-speaking peoples. His point is well taken, but he does not explain why these ever-shifting standards must necessarily originate in England.

LONDON, Jan. 20 -- The fact that only minor movements are now occurring in the sterling exchange market is taken here to indicate that official control of rates has created something approaching stability. At one time this week sterling seemed inclined to relapse, owing to unfavorable comments on the home budget outlook and some fears abroad of a possible railway strike in Great Britain.

The Montreal Maroons duplicated the feat of the Detroit Red Wings by blanking the New York Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The rugged Canadian sextet, after a scoreless first period, crashed into the speedy New York aggregation with a barrage of shots in the last two sessions and subdued the blue-jerseyed stick-wielders by the score of 5 to 0.

PINEHURST, N.C., Jan. 22 -- The 8-inch cup recently proposed by Gene Sarazen to give golf an added thrill was tried today at the Pinehurst Country Club, and failed to find favor with a representative group of golfers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 22 -- An attendance of nearly 300 persons marked the exhibition tennis matches, both singles and doubles played tonight on the flood-lighted courts of the Everglades Club by William T. Tilden 2d, Bruce Barnes, Hans Nusslein and Emmet Pare.

Leading for the entire game and pressing the attack all the way, the Hershey (Pa.) sextet turned back the New York A.C. combination, 4 to 1, in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon before a crowd of 8,000. Excellent pokechecking by the brown-shirted Pennsylvanians repeatedly broke up the Winged Foot attack before it could gain any impetus, and the visitors were never in serious danger throughout the contest.

DUBLIN, Jan. 22 -- At least ninety persons have been injured; some seriously, in clashes between political factions and the police in the closing hours of the bitter electoral campaign precipitated by President Eamon de Valera's sudden decision to test his strength at this crucial juncture in Irish affairs.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 22 (AP) -- The climax of nearly a half-century of searching for definite proof of the existence of the "ether," that all-pervading substance in space through which light waves once were supposed to move, is in slight, according to Dr. Dayton C. Miller, Cleveland physicist.

Policemen of the Parkville station in Brooklyn were mystified early yesterday morning when they investigated a collision between two automobiles and found one of the cars with all its windows and doors locked on the inside and no one at the controls. They were forced to break a side window to shut off the motor.

The expression of religion in terms of our own day so that men will see again that religion is a necessity is the greatest need this distraught world has, the Rev. Dr. Sydney B. Snow, president of the Meadville Theological School of the University of Chicago, declared yesterday morning in his sermon at the Universalist Church, of the Divine Paternity, Central Park West at Seventy-sixth Street.

City officials have used the taxicab business as a political football and have displayed either complete ignorance of its problems or callous indifference to its claim to proper regulation, according to a statement issued yesterday by H.A. Inness Brown, secretary of the Taxicab Chamber of Commerce.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 22 -- Unofficial news from the disputed Chaco region indicates that fighting in the Nanawa sector is very active.

PRAGUE, Jan. 22 -- Fifty armed Fascists attempted to seize the army barracks at Brno last night, being turned back only after an hour of stiff fighting with nine casualties, including one Fascist killed.

Breaking 98 out of a possible 100 targets, P. Garino captured the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. The second scratch prize went to E.S.S. Carroll, who finished with 97. L.F. Sanman prevailed in the handicap contest, J. Nida taking the second and last cup.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Elisha C. Tower will give a dinner tomorrow at the Savoy-Plaza for Mrs. Henry Symes Lehr of Paris.

BERLIN, Jan. 22 -- Germany has her own technocratic movement in the Technokratische Union, with headquarters in Berlin. Although it has taken its name from its American counterpart, it is not an offshoot of the latter but an indigenous growth.

The agreement at Friday's White House conference between the outgoing and incoming Executives, that the question of England's intergovernmental debts and other world-economic problems affecting both nations will be discussed with Great Britain by our government at Washington in March, was the week's occurrence of paramount importance.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Jan 22 -- Trading in cotton on the Cotton Exchange here last week was quieter than it was during the Christmas holidays. There was a little trade buying and price fixing by the mills, but little hedge selling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 22 -- National policies must undergo fundamental modification if an international agreement is to be reached by the general disarmament conference at Geneva on a general disarmament treaty, according to a report issued by the Foreign Policy Association today in anticipation of the resumption of the conference on Jan. 31.

A patrolman thwarted the escape of five young men, all of whom are held on charges of robbery, when they were about to drive off in a taxicab after having robbed an alleged speakeasy at 1,750 Westchester Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon.

Something different in cross-word puzzle books, "The Crossword Tracer," will be brought out by William Morrow Co., on Feb. 15. Each book will contain a pad of thin, strong, transparent sheets. The puzzle words are put down on these sheets rather than in the book itself, and time competitions will be possible.

Bedrich Smetana's opera, "Prodana Nevesta," in which the Czechoslovak composer brought to the stage a wealth of melody, folk-dance and simple life of Bohemia, will be revived at the Metropolitan on Saturday afternoon, Feb. 4, it was announced by General Manager Giulio Gatti-Casazza yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 16 (by Mail). -- Ignace Paderewski, pianist, who has been in England to fulfill musical engagements, sees the machine destroying beauty and culture.

The Most Rev. Dr. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, preaching yesterday morning at St. Thomas Episcopal Church, Fifth Avenue and Fifty-third Street, predicted a bright future for mankind, declaring "we are now standing at the dawn, of the revelation of the word of Jesus Christ."

MADRID, Spain, Jan. 22 -- Fifty-nine Monarchists, exiled to the African penal colony at Villa Cisneros, were being hurried to Madrid tonight to stand trial in connection with the rebellion of last August.

GENEVA, Jan. 22 -- The Japanese delegation to the League of Nations is understood to have strongly urged Tokyo to give it a free hand politically here with a view of saving the conciliation procedure in the Chino-Japanese conflict by last-minute concessions.

The Baldwin Locomotive Works reports for 1932 a consolidated net loss after all charges including depreciation reserves and deduction of loss accruing to minority stockholders, of $4,078,131. This compares with a loss of $4,122,759 for the previous year.

BALBOA, C.Z., Jan. 22 -- The Peruvian cruiser Coronel Bolognesi is expected here this week to go into dry dock for overhauling, which may create a problem in international law for the United States if hostilities break out between Colombia and Peru over possession of the Amazon River port of Leticia.

Cutlery in the Navy, Our old friend Representative BLANTON of Texas never wearies in defense of the People. The other day he uncovered another sore spot of hideous Government waste and flagrant betrayal.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last Thanksgiving, through the beneficence of fourteen old Villagers, like Barney Gallant, C.O. Bigelow, Dr. Brooks, Dr. May Mayers, and myself, there were served 135 turkey dinners to needy Greenwich Village artists and writers.

JEFFERSON CITY, Mo., Jan. 23 -- The "lame-duck" amendment to the Constitution was ratified by the Missouri Legislature at 10:06 o'clock this morning, following a hastily called session to insure Missouri's being the thirty-sixth State to ratify.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- An appeal to the hearts of striking bus drivers brought relief today to hundreds of thousands of Londoners who had suffered from lack of transportation on the coldest day in four years and at the height of an influenza epidemic.

Confidence in the American business system and opposition to technocracy were expressed last night by Lee J. Eastman, president of the Packard Motor Company of New York, in a talk to the advertising and selling class of the Advertising Club of New York at the Alexander Hamilton Institute, 13 Astor Place.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23. -- A method for the control of cancerous growth, based on the knowledge of the electrical currents present in all living tissue, is presented in hypothetical form in the current issue of the Yale Journal of Biology and Medicine by Dr. Raymond Dodge, Professor of Psychology and a member of the Institute of Human Relations at Yale University.

The Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers opened here yesterday at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, with the presentation of the Alfred Nobel Prize to Frank M. Starr, 28-year-old electrical engineer of the General Electric Company.

Dr. Alfred N. Goldsmith, vice president and general engineer of the Radio Corporation of America, who has been an executive of that organization since its formation in 1919, has resigned to form a private consulting engineering practice in radio, electrical entertainment, sound-film and allied fields.

DUBLIN, Jan. 23 -- The Free State election campaign closed tonight at a high pitch of fervor when President Eamon de Valera spoke at a huge meeting on College Green, Dublin, and former President William T. Cosgrave addressed a great gathering in Cork.
Southern Pacific. The Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday for 1932 a net operating income of $5,606,157, against $21,964,454 in 1931. Its statement follows:
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Fitz Hugh Whitehouse of the Savoy-Plaza and Newport, who sailed on Saturday for London and Paris, will return early in March.

The Appellate Division, by unanimous decision, removed yesterday receivers appointed by Supreme Court Justice Cotillo for Motion Picture Machine Operators' Union 306 and gave the parent body the right to supervise the local's affairs on condition that it post a $500,000 bond within five days as security for the union's funds.

BOGOTA, Jan. 23 -- The Foreign Office released tonight the text of Colombia's note delivered today to the governments of the United States and other signatories of the Briand-Kellogg pact, requesting them to call Peru's attention to its obligation to renounce war as an instrument of national policy and to urge Peru not to violate the pact.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- An agreement was initialed here tonight between the League of Nations Finance Committee and the Rumanian Government whereby the League gives Rumania "technical anal consultative cooperation" for four fiscal years beginning in April.

GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- With a discussion of three hours today the Committee of Nineteen of the League of Nations began its work of passing judgment on the Chino-Japanese conflict. The report to the League Assembly which it is to draft is called "the gravest State paper the League has ever been called on to write."

Bethlehem, Pa. A new issue of $1,088,000 city of Bethlehem (Pa.) water works refunding bonds dated Feb. 1, 1933, and due from 1934 to 1949, was awarded yesterday to a syndicate beaded by the Guaranty Company of New York, and including W.H. Newbold's Son Co. and E.W. Clark Co.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Anglo-American treaty of 1924 providing that British rum-runners may be searched only when within an hour's sailing distance from the United States coast was sustained by the Supreme Court today in a decision holding that the 1930 tariff act, which set a twelve-mile limit, did not invalidate the treaty.

Alphonse Demarce, 70 years old, a retired real estate dealer, was run down and killed yesterday by an automobile owned and operated by Peter J. Catotasto of 27 Fort Place, St. George, S.I. The accident occurred at the corner of Hannah and Van Deuzer Streets in Tompkinsville when, according to the police, Demarce stepped from behind a parked car into the path of the approaching machine.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Final ratification of the Twentieth Amendment today came exactly 327 days after it was submitted to the States on March 2. Eighteen States ratified within ten days, each trying to be ahead in this race to approval of a constitutional amendment.

Newspaper readers, contrary to the general belief of advertising men, advertisers and others interested in the subject, have a definite and natural impulse to turn to the left-hand pages of their favorite dailies before they give their attention to. the right-hand pages, according to a report made public yesterday by Professor Howard E Nixon of the School of Business Columbia University.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Governor Lehman rejected today the demand of W. Kingsland Macy, Chairman of the Republican State Committee, and a group of prominent New York City Republicans for an investigation under the Moreland act of the official conduct of Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. in connection with frauds in the New York elections.

After attacking the Blaine repeal amendment because it specifies ratification by Legislatures rather than by conventions, also because it leaves Congress "the sole judge" in dealing with liquor regulation, Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, founder and national chairman of the Women's Organization for National Prohibition Reform, warned a meeting of that organization's advisory council at the Hotel Plaza yesterday morning that the drys' strategy would be to block ratification.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The Senate met in executive session after Attorney General William A. Stevens ruled tonight that a bill designed to relieve municipalities of making mandatory appropriations was unconstitutional because of the delegation of legislative authority to the State House Commission.

A committee of nine railway traffic officials met in the offices of the New York Central Railroad yesterday and drew up an answer to a recent letter of inquiry sent by the Interstate Commerce Commisision to railroad managements which raised the question of reducing the basic passenger fare rate.

Magistrate Goldstein in Night Court suspended sentence last night upon 81 men who pleaded guilty to peddling without a license, refusing to accede to a request of the Thirty-fourth Street Midtown Association that he and other magistrates impose severe penalties in such, cases.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., Jan. 23 (AP) -- Luke Lea and his son were in Nashville, Tenn., today when called to surrender in court here under convictims of bank-law violation, and capiases for their arrests were ordered while extradition machinery was set in motion.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- The market for hogs recovered today from Saturday's decline, with prices steady to 10 cents higher. Little change was shown as compared with Friday. Receipts were small and shipping demand was fair. Arrivals at the eleven Western markets fell 41 per cent below the total of a year ago, which helped to sustain the market in the face of a relatively slow cash demand.

The Columbia University and Dartmouth Clubs scored sweeping victories in the Class C squash racquets matches in Group One of the Metropolitan League last night, defeating their opponents, each by 5 to 0.

Two of the world's most famous figures in aeronautics -- Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh and Professor Auguste Piccard, who in his ascents into the stratosphere in his balloon attained the greatest altitude ever reached by man have just met and compared notes.

The election of Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, president of the University of Illinois and former president of the University of North Carolina, as the eighth chancellor of New York University was announced yesterday by Dr. Fred I. Kent, president of the University Council.

HAVANA, Jan. 23 (AP) -- With fillies and mares holding the place of honor on the Oriental Park card, James Arthur's Bokie B. showed the way home to five of her sex in the five-and-a-half-furlong feature today.

With the principal foreign exchanges rising sharply against the dollar, It became apparent again yesterday that, however unresponsive our own financial community may be to Senator Borah's clamor for "adjustment of the money problem," he has an attentive audience abroad.

PARIS, Jan. 23 -- Those who are following closely here the question of a possible resumption of French debt payments have reached the conclusion that if there is to be any progress in the conversations between Washington and London and subsequently between Washington and other debtors there must be revision of the terms of the old formula, "capacity to pay."

BRESLAU, Germany, Jan. 23 -- University circles here are looking forward with divided minds but unanimous curiosity to tomorrow when, it is understood, Ernst Cohn, young law professor who is objectionable to National Socialist students, will resume his lectures.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 -- For bespectacled little Eddie Tolan, whose short legs swept him to triumph as sprint king of the 1932 Olympiad, the heady wine of victory has turned, over night, to vinegar.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, Kentuckian, snatched victory from defeat last night in Madison Square Garden and saved his laurels as the State Athletic Commission's holder of the world's heavyweight wrestling championship.

Elimination of unsound and uneconomic procedure in the building industry is the aim of a code of bidding just drafted by the joint committee on building practices, representing the Associated General Contractors of America and the American Institute of Architects, the institute announced yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 23 -- The attack on Shanghai and the invasion of Manchuria and Jehol by Japan have done more to consolidate forces in China and stimulate unity among the Chinese people than any other thing, said David A. Brown of New York, chairman of the American committees for flood and famine relief in China, when he arrived here today from China.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 23 -- Paraguayan troops defending Fort Ayala (Nanawa) have been forced to draw back from their right-wing trenches by the intensity of the Bolivian artillery fire, according to unofficial information here. The informant's news is understood to come direct from Bolivian aviators who flew over the Paraguayan positions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- In its new capacity as the "bridge" between the outgoing and incoming administrations, over which "arrangements" for the debt and economic conferences with the British in March may be transported, President Hoover's State Department is emitting creaks and groans.

The first in a series of receptions in behalf of the forthcoming West Indies cruise for the benefit of the Frontier Nursing Service will be given this afternoon by Miss Julia W.C. Carroll and Mrs. Kenneth S. Kirkland at the home of Miss Carroll, 105 East Fifty-third Street.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Senate Judiciary Committee today reported for passage its own substitute for the Collier beer bill, proposing the legalization of a brew of 3.05 per cent by weight and wine of the same alcoholic content.

Marking the conclusion of the ten-year administration of Supreme Court Justice James C. Cropsey as president of the Crescent AthleticHamilton Club, Alexander B. Gale unanimously was picked for that office at the annual election in the club's city house last night.

The cry "The Persians are coming!" is now heard with acclaim rather than alarm or dismay by the Western World. XERXES and DARIUS are welcomed because they have a new glory to put into the story of mankind. Even the Greeks would offer XERXES a bridge of ships to bring Persia's treasures across the Hellespont.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- President Hoover was represented today as having under consideration a veto of the first deficiency bill, which carries appropriations of $35,000,000, of which $28,000,000 is apportioned to tax refunds.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 23 -- Bolivia is driving a hard offensive against Paraguay along the ninety-five-mile front embracing the entire Chaco war area from Fort Corrales in the Puerto Casado sector to Cuatro Vientos in the Pilcomayo sector.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Prospective applicants for Federal jobs under the new administration face the necessity of paying the government 40 cents each for lists of available positions, if they wish to study them.

BERLIN, Jan. 23 -- After a rather bullish opening today the Boerse sagged on a small turnover, but Without notable declines, and the general list closed near Saturday's levels, a few stocks even higher. Outstanding features were the electricals in which Siemens Halske, after rising 4 1/2 points, declined to 1/2 point above Saturday's closing, and A.E.G., which netted 1/2 point above Saturday's final price.

PASADENA, Cal., Jan. 23 -- Declaring that the world-wide depression was not caused by the war debt situation but by new machinery and more efficient industrial organization which had brought about the displacement of labor and lowered purchasing power, Dr. Albert Einstein delivered an address in English here tonight in a symposium on "America and the World Situation."

MOSCOW, Jan. 23 -- The Soviet Central Executive Committee, which is the Soviet Parliament, opened its session here tonight and heard a three-hour speech by Vyacheslaf Molotoff, President of the Council of People's Commissars.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The House revolted today against the plan of Chairman Collins of the appropriations subcommittee to eliminate the Citizens Military Training Camps in the 1933-34 supply bill, and voted, 117 to 46, to restore the training camps item with an appropriation of $2,500,000.

The Joint Committee of Railways and Highway Users plans to file a report with the National Transportation Committee within about two days, Dr. W.J. Cunningham, Professor of Transportation at Harvard University and executive secretary of the joint committee, said yesterday.

CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Jan. 23 -- Counting on time as an ally, the Japanese are proceeding with preparations to sweep through Jehol in leisurely fashion. Pointing out that cold weather and dissension among the Jehol generals are disrupting Chinese morale, Japanese military circles intimate that, barring an emergency, the Jehol drive will follow the original schedule, probably not less than three weeks off and possibly more.

Ever alert to new possibilities, smugglers have turned to a modern means of bringing contraband liquor into the county, but Customs authorities were only a single jump behind them yesterday and seized a liquor cargo for the public stores valued at more than $50,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Coincident with ratification of the "lame duck" amendment, Senator Norris, its author, issued a formal statement giving the history of the struggle for the amendment and the evils which finally led to its adoption. His statement read:

"Design for Living," the Noel Coward comedy, in which he will appear with Alfred Lunt and Lynn Fontanne, win have its Broad-way premiere this evening at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre. Because the play has a running time of two hours and fifty minutes, the curtain will rise promptly at 8:15 P.M.

PRAGUE, Jan. 23 -- The Czechoslovak authorities are taking the attempted Fascist revolt at Brno more seriously than at first appeared. General Gajda, famous commander of the Czech Legionaries, who fought with Ruasian Whites against the Bolsheviki and who is now head of the Czechoslovak Fascist party, was arrested today in Slovakia.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Supreme Court today sent back to the Federal Court for the Southern District of New York a suit, in which Richard Held Rogers, minority stockholder of the American Tobacco Company, sought to upset an employes' stock subscription plan by which President George W. Hill and five vice presidents are alleged to have received $2,620,000 in bonuses.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Pari-Mutuel, the 5-year-old son of Fair Play-Quelle Chance, today gave Joseph E. "Widener, chairman of the board of the Miami Jockey Club, his first victory of the meeting at Hialeah Park.
GARY, Ind., Jan. 23 -- A 40-yearold housewife who tried to keep her husband out of politics took over the office Sheriff of Lake County today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Thousands of persons are playing bridge in this city every day. Other thousands are wondering where their next meal is coming from. The first-named group, by and large, probably is sincerely concerned over the plight of the less fortunate thousands in the streets.

With the receipt yesterday of word from A.M. Reld, secretary of the United States Golf Association, that the playing dates for the national amateur championship have been fixed, the ruling body now has its 1933 schedule in complete order.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- A move to prevent hasty currency inflation at the "lame duck" session and to keep control of this and other efforts to change the economic system in conservative hands in the new Congress, was seen in the favorable report today of a resolution, of Senator Harrison, proposing an expert study of plans to correct conditions growing out of the depression.

A biography called "Andrew Jackson: The Border Captain," on which Marquis James has been at work since he finished his Pulitzer Prize book, "The Raven," early in 1929, will be published on March 15, the 166th anniversary of Jackson's birth, by the Bobbs-Merrill Company.

MUKDEN, Dec. 15 -- The fact that enormous progress has been made by Japan in the matter of restoration of normal conditions In South Manchuria during the last seven months becomes evident after even a most superficial survey of the area between the seaport of Dairen and Mukden, the former Manchurian capital.

A shake-up yesterday by Police Commissioner Mulrooney banished the gun squads set up during the regime of Grover Whalen and sent back to the street one sergeant and fifty-three patrolmen who had been attached for years to various civil offices and public buildings throughout the city.

On the last day of 1932 General PERSHING led off with an article in The Army and Navy Journal which was to be the first of a series entitled "The Maintenance of National Defense." "If disarmament "negotiations now in progress "should fail," said General PERSHING, "it may become necessary "to build our navy up to the limits "fixed by treaty and to increase "our army."
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Speaker Garner said today the La-Guardia-McKeown bankruptcy bill would probably be taken up by the House for consideration at an early date.

MONTREAL, Jan. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Laurence Northcott, Maroons left wing, acquired two points in the Montreal sextet's victory over the Rangers on Sunday night to break the tie that existed between himself and Bill Cook, veteran Ranger right wing, for the point-making lead in the National Hockey League.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- The Court of Errors and Appeals directed today that receivers named recently by Vice Chancellor Bigelow for the Pressed Steel Car Company are not to take charge of the concern "until further orders, provided officers declare no dividends and make no disbursements except those necessary to current business."

Four gunmen, members of a band of robbers that in the last four years has held up banks in several Eastern cities, including Newark, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Washington, unexpectedly pleaded guilty to third-degree robbery in Judge Rosalsky's part of General Sessions yesterday.

The Twentieth (or "lame duck") Amendment was ratified by the necessary three-fourths of the States more quickly than any other since the period just following the Civil War. It was submitted by Congress on March 3, 1932 and hence slightly less than eleven months elapsed before ratification was effected.

The League Year-Book for 1932, the first of a series to be issued annually for the benefit of those interested in the work of the League of Nations, has just been published by the Macmillan Company. The work, covering nearly 600 pages, sketches the organization of the League and summarizes its work and proceedings up to July, 1932.

A reduction of $2,375,000 in its bank loans was accomplished by the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation last year, according to the report for the year ended Dec. 31, mailed yesterday to stockholders. The company's reserves rose from $2,304,034 to $4,219,024, an increase of $1,914,990.

Buyers Settle Down to Orders. Buyers are settling down to quite active purchasing of Spring merchandise, reports in the market here yesterday indicated. The concentrated lines being shown have put number taking at a minimum and the absence of style uncertainty has paved the way for the writing of actual business.

The rejection of the entry of Sol Furth of the Millrose A.A., former intercollegiate hurdles champion and a member of the American Olympic team, was the unexpected action of the track and field committee of the Metropolitan Association of the A.A.U. in session at A.A.U. headquarters last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: You have recently reported that two of the great commercial organizations have submitted to the United States District Court protests against any action in conformance to the resolution adopted by the New York County Lawyers Association which condemned the monopoly of the Irving Trust Company as receiver in bankruptcy and appealed to the court to abolish the rule establishing it.

Captains and higher ranking officials of the Police Department were notified yesterday by Commissioner Mulrooney to appear at headquarters at 10 o'clock this morning to attend a conference for discussion of crime prevention among children in the city.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The thirty-nine States which have ratified the Twentieth Amendment and the dates of their respective action are:

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 23 (Canadian Press) -- Canada will not inflate her currency, but will maintain her sound money position and meet her obligations in the terms of the contracts, Prime Minister R.B. Bennett told the Toronto Board of Trade today.

Eight police radio cars, an emergency squad and its truck, an ambulance and more than a score of policemen responded to a riot call from the Times Square subway station at theatre time last night and found nothing to do but sympathize with Interborough guards discussing the waywardness of youth.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Franklin D. Roosevelt will lose almost $9,000 as a result of the "lame duck" amendment.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club made a successful start in the defense of his national amateur pocket-billiard championship last night, when he triumphed over Henry C. Craft of Brooklyn, 125 to 62, In twenty-two innings at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy.

BURLINGTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- A giant oil-burning turbine engine in the power plant of the Public Service Corporation in "West Burlington exploded today and wrecked part of the building. Fire, which followed the explosion, caused damage estimated at $250,000. Engineers and plant officials who made an investigation were unable to determine the cause of the explosion.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- While Congress was preparing today for action on a new general bankruptcy bill, Representative Kleberg of Texas introduced a joint resolution asking Governors to request the State courts to hold up farm foreclosure proceedings until Congress and the Legislatures can pass the necessary mitigating legislation.

A call for a mobilization of public opinion in the cause of reducing the State budget for 1933-34 was sounded yesterday by G. William Magly of Jamaica, chairman of the New York State Budget Advisory Committee, which reported to former Governor Roosevelt last December and recommended savings of $75,000,000 and offered a detailed plan designed to save $51,694,468.

A fresh wave of reductions of rates of interest appeared yesterday to have been set in motion by the announcement on last Friday that, effective tomorrow, interest paid by clearing house banks on domestic deposits was to be cut in half to the lowest levels on record.

A steady decrease since the middle of 1932 in demands by policy holders for loans on their policies was reported yesterday by the Provident Mutual Life Insurance Company of Philadelphia and the New England Mutual Life Insurance Company.

The Yankees made their first substantial advance yesterday in rounding up their athletes for the 1933 season with the announcement by Secretary Ed Barrow that four more or less distinguished members of their world's championship cast had returned their signed contracts.

The liner American Merchant bound for New York with twentytwo of the crew saved, from the wrecked freighter Exeter City, received another call for help yesterday when the Ellerman freighter City of Delhi reported trouble 1,120-miles east of New York.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Bureau of Investigation Issued the following orders today, dated Jan. 20:

The annual campaign to defray the budget expenditures of fifteen branches and other agencies of the Young Men's Christian Association of the city was opened yesterday at a luncheon, attended by more than 200 officials and secretaries of the organization, in the campaign headquarters at 44 Wall Street.

The symbolism of the subconscious is likely to gain an added significance in the life of Secrese Lee, a 23-year-old Negro, whose apparent inability to distinguish imagery from reality late yesterday afternoon led to his being locked up in the East 104th Street police station charged with, violation of the Sullivan law.

Representatives of the transatlantic steamship lines will meet in Brussels on Feb. 1 to discuss Several problems that were left unsettled at the last meeting of the Utlantic Passenger Conference last November in London. The most important items on the agenda are the reclassification of cabin ships as first-class liners and the fixing of a surcharge on passenger tickets bought in Great Britain.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 23 -- All seeded players came through successfully in the first round of the all-South singles tennis championship on the Miami-Biltmore courts here today.

TOKYO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Hitoshi Ashida, spokesman for one of Japan's principal political parties, declared in the Diet today that unless relations between Japan and the United States were improved they would produce renewed armaments competition and possibly a world war.

Inflation measures proposed in Congress as means of coping with the depression were condemned as "ill-advised nostrums" in a resolution adopted last night by members of the Society of the Genesee at the society's thirty-fourth annual dinner at the Hotel Commodore.

January, 1932, was one of the mildest Winter months of which there is a record in the Weather Bureau, but the January of this year has so far been even more Springlike. Atlantic City never hides its light under a bushel, and it will be glad to have the world know that for twenty-one consecutive days, including yesterday, its mean temperature registered above normal.
Several flats and taxpayers were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

With only one more league encounter to play, the City A.C. Class C squash tennis team took undisputed possession of first place in the metropolitan league race last night by defeating one of its chief rivals, the New York Athletic Club, 7 to 0.

The American Legion, more than 1,000,000 strong, will take a definite stand on immigration and will take a more active part in political matters in the future, Louis A. Johnson, national commander of the Legion, declared yesterday at a luncheon in his honor at the Brooklyn Elks Club.

Six men and five women, accused by the police of attempting to create dissatisfaction among relief seekers at a Home Relief Bureau in Public School 231, at Benson and Twenty-fifth Avenues, Brooklyn, were arrested yesterday morning charged with disorderly conduct.

ALBANY, Jan. 23 -- Mrs. Herbert H. Lehman, wife of the Governor, this afternoon cut the Silk ribbon stretched across the roadway of the new Albany-Rensselaer Bridge. A few minutes later Governor Lehman, Mayor John Boyd Thacher of Albany and Mayor James E. Johnstone of Rensselaer made the first trip across the bridge, followed by hundreds of pedestrains and private cars.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 23 -- The Colombian armada which has been assembling at Manaos, on the Upper Amazon River, sailed today for Teffe, on the way to retake the river port of Leticia from Peruvians who seized it last Sept. 1.

A large water-color exhibition opened with a reception last evening at the Brooklyn Museum. This show puts in its appearance every two years. While water-color is the medium chiefly encountered, pastels and drawings also are included.

While poverty will be on the increase for several years the longtime trend is for a nation without poverty, with less disease, but with more crime, Dr. William F. Ogburn of the University of Chicago told the National Social Work Council yesterday.

Herbert Fuchs, 16-year-old Brooklyn high school student whose heroic eighteen-month fight for life after he contracted infantile paralysis in the Summer of 1931 attracted nation-wide attention, died late Sunday night, of pneumonia at the Long Island College Hospital.

Gradual liquidation of the American Community Power Company was foreshadowed by the purchase yesterday on behalf of the holders of the company's 5 1/2 per cent notes of the $2,250,000 face amount of General Public Utilities Company first-mortgage and collateral trust 6 1/2 per cent sold bonds, Series A, for $225,000.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Today was a bad one for leaders in the world's championship three-cushion billiard tournament, J.N. Bozeman of Vallejo, Cal., and Clarence Jackson of Detroit suffering their first defeats, leaving Welker Cochran of Hollywood, Cal., in undisputed possession of the leadership, with three victories and no defeats.

Kathleen Norris explained in an interview yesterday how she manages to write three fast-selling novels and fifty-two weekly articles a year. The explanation is that writing never has been work for her, that it steadily becomes easier the more she does of it, and that she can sit down almost anywhere and under any circumstances and turn out an average of about 1,000 words an hour.

An embarrassed youth, John B. Maypole Jr., a high school student just turned 15 years, was signally honored last night at the Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace. He topped all the other drivers in the country last year in a scoring competition in outboard racing.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 23 -- President-elect Roosevelt, during his stay here of two weeks, will take up the study of economic problems, both domestic and foreign, as well as appointments to the Cabinet and other important posts.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 (AP) -- The century-old boundary dispute between Honduras and Guatemala was settled amicably today when Chief Justice Charles Evans Hughes, as chairman of the special boundary tribunal, handed down at the Pan American Union an award dividing the controverted area essentially on a basis of the status quo of actual occupation.

The mutual savings banks in Greater New York plan to reduce their interest rate on deposits to 3 per cent, it was announced last night by Paul W. Albright, general secretary of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.

Secretary MILLS keeps on giving useful elementary instruction in public finance. His broadcasts, his statements, his testimony before committees of Congress continue to teach the A B C of Treasury operations. As he pungently said yesterday to the Ways and Means Committee of the House, Congress has by its action, or failure to act, virtually forced the Government to go on "mopping up a Treasury deficit year after year" by borrowing.

Winter wilted off the calendar again yesterday under another wave of warm Spring weather that sent the mercury up to 62 degrees at 2:15 P.M., one degree below the all-time record established for the date in 1906. The average temperature for the day was 55 degrees, 25 degrees above normal.

The new Treasury financing, consisting of an issue of $250,000,000 of five-year 2 5/8 percent notes dated Feb. 1, was well received yesterday in Wall Street, and the usual heavy over-subscription was indicated. At the close of business the market on the new issue was quoted at 100 17-32 bid and 100 19-32 asked.

The disruption of the official technocracy group and virtual dismissal of Howard Scott, chief protagonist of the movement, was announced yesterday at Columbia University, which has been host to the group of more than one hundred unemployed architects and engineers who under Scott's direction have been carrying on an "energy survey of North America."

A referendum on the proposal to appropriate $250,000 from the union's defense fund for unemployment relief will be voted upon Thursday by the members of Typographical Union 6, it was announced yesterday by Austin Hewson, the president, who issued an appeal urging affirmative action.

Maurice Benedict of 2,068 East Thirty-seventh Street, Brooklyn, jury foreman, who caused a mistrial in Federal court in his home borough last week by taking a swift cruise to Havana before the case was finished, was fined $200 by Judge Moscowitz yesterday for contempt of court.

There is in France one of those associations that "without hope live in desire" -- a Federation of Taxpayers. It has just sent an extraordinary notice to the President of the Council. The federation read in the newspapers that the Government had consulted the Syndicate of Officeholders in regard to certain measures of retrenchment to be proposed in the Senate and the Chamber of Deputies.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Two amendments to the Glass banking bill providing for the revalorization of silver, introduced late today by Senators Long and Wheeler, promised to force a vote on this long-dormant question tomorrow.
LONDON, Jan. 23 -- Great Britain's elder statesmen of golf today expressed indignation over Gene Sarazen's advocacy of a larger golf hole.

LONDON, Jan. 23 -- The Marylebone Cricket Club, governing body of the sport, tonight met Australian charges of unsportsmanlike conduct on the part of the English team now in Australia with a flat statement of full confidence in the English cricketers.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 23 -- William R. Castle, Under-Secretary of State, speaking tonight at a dinner of the Presbyterian Union of Philadelphia, declared that the newspapers and the Department of State had a mutual obligation in the matter of helping the nation keep the peace.

Federal authorities who have looked in vain for Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer runner, ever since last Wednesday, when a warrant was issued for his arrest on a charge of evading the income-tax law, were informed yesterday that $18,600 of the racketteer's money, against which they had filed a lien, had slipped out of their hands.

CHICAGO, Jan. 23 -- Under conflicting influences and a further curtailment of speculative interests, the active futures of wheat on the Board of Trade here held today until noon within a range of around 1/4 cent a bushel. Then a minor selling movement carried prices off about 3/8 cent from the top and below Saturday's finish.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 23 -- In an opinion written by Justice Joseph L. Bodine, the Court of Errors and Appeals unanimously denied today the use of funds of the Courts of Chancery for the financing of the investigation of receivership practices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Difficulties of formulating a program for the apparently inevitable special session of Congress appeared to Democratic leaders to be multiplying today when, taking stock, they found the legislative demands upon the new administration larger than for the last several years combined.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- Internal revenue collections for the July-December half-year amounted to $744,437,495, a decrease of $137,660,448 from the corresponding period of last year, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

At the Metropolitan Opera Assosociation's performance of "Rigoletto" last night, the third of the season, Richard Bonelli made his first appearance in the title role and Lily Pons returned to the Metropolitan stage as Gilda after an Illness of two weeks; two facts undoutbedly not unrelated to the large and brilliant audience that filled the house and gave the artists a warm welcome.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Pulitzer entertained tonight with a dinner followed by motion pictures at Louwana, the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Gurnee Munn, which has been unoccupied since Mrs. Munn's departure soon after the holidays, at which time Mr. Munn joined his brother, Charles A. Munn.

Net assets of the Standard Investing Corporation declined in 1932 from $8,374,000 to $7,094,000, according to the company's annual report to stockholders. As of Dec. 31, the net assets applicable to its debentures were equivalent to $1,013 for each $1,000 principal amount, and, after deducting debentures, to $1.75 a share for the preferred stock.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 23 -- Tommy Goodwin, 19-year-old holder of the New York State amateur crown, annexed medal honors today in the twenty-second annual Lake Worth tournament at the Palm Beach Golf Club. The youngster's card of 36, 35 -- 71 gave him the prize by a one-stroke margin.
PASADENA., Cal., Jan. 23 -- The speech of Dr. Albert Einstein on "America and the World Situation," delivered as part of a public symposium program here tonight, was as follows:

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 23 -- Taking advantage of her light weight of ninety-four pounds, F.P. Letellier's Marie Jean handed the form players a setback today, when she came from off the pace to win the Inaugural Handicap at the opening of the historic Fair Grounds.

Four indictments naming twenty-three inspectors and others for violation of the Congressional elections law were handed up yesterday by a Federal grand Jury here soon after Governor Lehman announced in Albany that he had decided to disregard pleas for his intervention.

The Greater City Surety and Indemnity Company filed an answer in the Supreme Court yesterday to an application by George S. Van Schaick, Insurance Superintendent, to liquidate the company on the ground that its capital is impaired to the extent of $143,143, and that it is unsafe for the company to continue writing bonds.

Two men deftly removed a banging showcase, containing cameras and lenses worth $500, from the wall of 127 West Forty-second Street yesterday afternoon as scurrying thousands passed by without noticing. The building is about 100 feet from the Northeast corner of Broadway and Forty-second Street, a heavily policed section of the city.

Exponents of technocracy have been unwise in presenting the partial results of their studies at this time because "it has introduced a disturbing element in an already sorely distressed world," Cardinal Hayes said in an interview last night.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The time has come for more than just the politicians of this country to interest themselves in this business of government.

BOSTON, Jan. 23 -- Dr. Joao Frederico Normano, a visiting lecturer on economics at Harvard College, was identified today by Dr. Fritz Driesen, a Berlin merchant, as Isaak Lewin, Berlin banker, wanted in an alleged $750,000 swindle in Germany perpetrated in 1928 and 1929.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange held within a narrow range in limited trading yesterday and ended with gains of 2 to 4 points.

The appointment of an equity receiver for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation was asked yesterday by Alfred West of 32 East Thirtyfifth Street in a petition filed in Federal court. West declared that he was the holder of $5,000 in the corporation's bonds.

Whitey took his seat yesterday afternoon beside Magistrate Benjamin Greenspan in ancient Jefferson Market Court, cast a bored look around at assembled photographers, attendants and court clerks and made a pass or two at his whiskers. He winked at the presiding officer.
DETROIT, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Henry Ford, always reluctant to appear in court, was threatened today with a bench, warrant to compel him to testify in litigation involving his motor company.

Conservation hits many snags. Connecticut, for instance, officially is discouraging the establishment of sanctuaries because the Board of Fisheries and Game has found it impossible to control predatory animals within the sanctuaries.
ALBANY, Jan. 24 -- A bill to give the Public Service Commission wide powers of regulation over trucks and buses in the State was introduced in the Assembly tonight by William L. Marcy Jr. of Buffalo.

DUBLIN, Jan. 23 (AP) -- Followers of former President William T. Cosgrave in Cork clashed with rival factions tonight. The combatants had to be separated by Civil Guards, who used clubs. Several persons were treated in a hospital for slight injuries.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 23 -- The award of sixty-nine sports insignia was announced today by the board of control of the Yale Athletic Association, which acted upon the recommendation of the Undergraduate Athletic Association.

ELYRIA, Ohio, Jan. 23 -- Arthur L Garford, industrialist, financier and politician, died early this evening of heart disease at his home here, soon after his return from a meeting of bank directors. He had been apparently in good health. His age was 74.

Informal negotiations with a view to effecting an affiliation of Eastern Air Transport, a subsidiary of North American Aviation, with Ludington Airlines, Inc., an independent and privately owned unit, have been carried on for several months, an officer of one of the companies said yesterday.

Dr. Terry M. Townsend, in his inaugural address as president of the Medical Society of the County of New York, declared at the Academy of Medicine last night that there was danger to the public health in the present deranged medical economy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 23 -- The Roosevelt administration will be confronted by debt negotiations with virtually all the debtor governments -- if the debtors' wishes are followed -- and well before the British case has been concluded, it appeared certain today from the reactions in foreign circles to the Hoover-Roosevelt debt communique of last Friday and the invitation immediately extended for discussions with the British.

Members of the Board of Estimate studied yesterday the relative importance of city projects estimated to cost a total of $50,116,363 without reaching any decision on the items that should be advanced immediately.

Magistrate David Hirshfield disposed of about 400 cases in Bedford Avenue Traffic Court in Brooklyn yesterday, and was driving his sedan up Delancey Street, over in Manhattan, toward his home at the Hotel Pennsylvania, when, at the Norfolk Street intersection, he met Patrolman Ttmmas Conroy of Traffic D.

RYE, N.T., Jan. 23 -- Mamaroneck High, defending champion in the Westchester County high and prep schools hockey league, remained in a tie for first place today with Hackley Prep when the teams battled to a 1-1 deadlock at Play-land Casino.
