GENEVA, Jan. 23 -- On the request of Peru that the League "in order to safeguard its jurisdictional powers and pending the adoption of a decision to order the suspension of all measures of force" in the Leticia dispute with Colombia. It it was decided tonight to add this conflict to the agenda of the Council opening its seventieth session tomorrow.

Morris L. Ernst, attorney, of 285 Madison Avenue, and the American Civil Liberties Union have joined the legal forces of the Rev. Robert P. (Fighting Bob) Shuler, storm centre in Los Angeles politics, in the fight to win tack his license to operate his radio station KGEF in Los Angeles, it was revealed here yesterday by Mr. Ernst.

Champion the Great My Own, the grand black cocker spaniel owned by Leonard J. Buck of New York City, last night captured the higest honors in the sixteenth speciality show of the American Spaniel Club held in the ballroom of the Hotel Roosevelt.

Prices of bonds on the Stock Exchange held steady to firm yesterday in quiet trading. United States Government issues were strong, leading foreign loans averaged some improvement and domestic corporation issues were inclined to be slightly lower.

LONDON. Jan. 23 -- Members of the British Cabinet today received President-elect Roosevelt's plan for a Washington conference on war debts and world economic problems and indicated the government would accept.

The rising discussions of inflationary proposals in Wall Street and Washington, coupled with Senator Borah's assertion that the budget could not be balanced in the present conditions, provoked yesterday another Hurry of speculative selling of the dollar in the foreign exchange market.

THE scoring record of the Rangers has received a compound fracture and, with two shutouts coming so close together, Lester Patrick is worried lest the boys in the blue shirts shift from the scoring habit to the non-scoring habit.
ATLANTA, Jan. 23 (AP) --Chase S. Osborn, former Governor of Michigan, in a letter to Governor William A. Comstock, the present Governor, has said:

SHANGHAI, Tuesday, Jan. 24 -- Reports that Chino-Japanese relations may be considerably altered by important negotiations now going on between representatives of the two nations are reaching here from Peiping today.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 23 -- Financial losses resulting from the collapse of the Mid-West Utilities Company, with its alleged overcapitalization, were cited as proof of the need for Federal regulation of water power developments at the opening of re-argument of the case of the Appalachian Electric Power Company vs. the Federal Power Commission today before Judge Luther B. Way of the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia.

LONDON. Jan. 23 -- Members of the British Cabinet today received President-elect Roosevelt's plan for a Washington conference on war debts and world economic problems and indicated the government would accept.

The rising discussions of inflationary proposals in Wall Street and Washington, coupled with Senator Borah's assertion that the budget could not be balanced in the present conditions, provoked yesterday another Hurry of speculative selling of the dollar in the foreign exchange market.

THE scoring record of the Rangers has received a compound fracture and, with two shutouts coming so close together, Lester Patrick is worried lest the boys in the blue shirts shift from the scoring habit to the non-scoring habit.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 23 -- Financial losses resulting from the collapse of the Mid-West Utilities Company, with its alleged overcapitalization, were cited as proof of the need for Federal regulation of water power developments at the opening of re-argument of the case of the Appalachian Electric Power Company vs. the Federal Power Commission today before Judge Luther B. Way of the United States District Court for the Western District of Virginia.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- A constitutional amendment extending the terms of Presidents to six years and stipulating that Presidents should not be-elected appeared today as a topic to be seriously considered by the incoming administration.

If the Twentieth Amendment had teen ratified a year ago Mr. ROOSEVELT would have had to select his Cabinet before this date. Having had, like his predecessors, a longer interval after his election, he has taken his time about the task.

PARIS, Jan. 24. -- Henri Guilbeaux, a Frenchman who had been condemned to death in absentia for treason in the war and who had returned to France last August voluntarily to meet whatever fate awaited him, went on trial today before a military tribunal.

Charged with abandoning his infant daughter on Jan. 15 when she was only 2 weeks old and with failing to give his correct name and age in obtaining a license to drive a taxicab, Frank De Costa, 20 years old, of 511 West 145th Street, was held in $1,500 bail yesterday by Magistrate August Dreyer in the Yorkville court for a nearing Friday.

LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The underlying policy of the British Government in its prospective war-debt negotiations at Washington was indicated tonight by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, speaking at a dinner of the Leeds Chamber of Commerce.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 24. -- The breach between the two branches of the Roosevelt families, which has existed since 1920, is apparently in process of being healed.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Senator Arthur H. Wicks, Ulster Republican, and Irwin Steingut, Democratic leader in the Assembly, introduced companion measures today to appropriate the remaining $15,000,000 of the $30,000,000 bond issue voted last Fall for emergency unemployment relief.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Again the crew of an American ship has distinguished itself in effecting a rescue under the most hazardous conditions of a severe Winter on the North Atlantic. To Captain Giles C. Stedman, master of the American Merchant, goes the credit for his skill and courage as a seaman in saving the lives of the twenty-two men of the ill-fated British freighter Exeter City.
LONDON, Jan. 24. -- The text of the part of the speech made in Leeds tonight by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, dealing with debt revision follows:

The Board of Estimate committed itself yesterday to the immediate advancement of city projects costing $20,306,001 and decided to defer action on less important improvements whose estimated cost is about $30,000,000.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 24. -- The entire field of governmental and economic problems, including war debts, rehabilitation of the railroads, reorganization of the government to bring about economies and the refunding of Treasury obligations, was discussed today by President-elect Roosevelt in an all-day conference with Bernard M. Baruch, New York financier and acting chairman of the National Transportation Committee, of which former President Coolidge was the head until his death.

Less than a decade ago the leading authorities on conservation, including such as Seth Gordon, president of the American Game Association; Aldo Leopold, noted student of ornithology; Colonel A.F. Foran, vice president of the More Game Birds Foundation; Herbert L. Stoddard, author of many widely-read volumes on game, advocated the cooperation of America's more than 6,000,000 farmers in the gigantic effort to restore to this country some semblance of its once vast game resources.

KETCHIKAN, Alaska, Jan. 24. -- The plans of American salmon canners for Alaska and the Pacific Coast this season depend largely upon a bill in Congress designed to equalize exchange values of currency as a curb on Japanese imports, according to Eigil Buschmann, an official of the Nakat Packing Corporation, who has just arrived here from Seattle.

Agreeing with opinions expressed by other leaders in the mortgage field, the Bond and Mortgage Guarantee Company in its annual statement urges a reduction of rates for those who borrow on mortgages. Clinton D. Burdick was re-elected president yesterday at the annual meeting of stockholders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Consultations with diplomatic representatives of the signatories of the Kellogg-Briand anti-war pact were instituted by Secretary Stimson at his home tonight over charges made by Colombia that Peru had been guilty of aggression at Leticia, contrary to its obligations under the treaty.

The Chase National Bank, as trustee, and plaintiff In a foreclosure action, yesterday bought in the fifteen-story Havemeyer Building, occupying the blockfront on the east side of Church Street, between Cortlandt and Dey Streets, at a foreclosure auction.

LONDON, Jan 24 (Canadian Press) -- The Earl of Chesterfield, former Lord Steward of his Majesty's household, was the tenth Earl of that name. He was a descendant of the fourth Earl of Chesterfield, whose famous letters written to his son are the most noted examples of eighteenth century epistolary elegance preserved to this day.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- A sharp curtailment in the representation of Tammany Hall in the Federal House of Representatives, the State Senate and Assembly, and the Aldermanic Board in New York City will result if projects for a larger allotment of Representatives in these legislative bodies, asked here by the Queens County Democratic organization, are realized.

"Ann Vickers," a new novel by Sinclair Lewis, is published today in sixteen countries and thirteen languages. The author is the only Amerlcan who ever won the Nobel Prize in literature, and he has beet a conspicuous national figure since the publication in 1920 of his novel "Main Street," whicn sold more than 700,000 copies.

Justice William Harman Black of the Supreme Court, First Department, protested against the reduction of his alary in letters submitted yesterday to the Board of Aldermen and the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate.

Commander George M. Dyott returned on the liner Santa Clara yesterday from an exploration into the forest country of Ecuador to survey the possibilities of colonization. On familiar ground, Commander Dyott spent considerable time with tribes of Shuaros Indians, an ancient race with many strange customs and beliefs.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Legislation which, it is hoped, will go a long way toward solving the bankruptcy problem was reported to the House and its early enactment urged by the Judiciary Committee today.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- The Japanese delegation published today the text of Japan's final amendments to the resolutions and the Presidential declaration which the Committee of Nineteen of the League of Nations rejected Saturday.

Manhattan Prep moved into a tie for second place with La Salle Academy, and Cathedral Boys High, C.H.S.A.A. champion last year, advanced to fourth place in the Manhattan division of the C.H.S. A.A. basketball tournament as the result of games played yesterday.

The adjusted index of steel mill activity is practically unchanged at the level of the two preceding weeks. There is general agreement that the recent rise in actual output has been largely seasonal in character, although there is some divergence of opinion as to just what percentage of ingot capacity is at present engaged.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The whole question of currency Inflation, which has been stalking the Capitol for weeks and so, far has been held behind cloak-room doors, boiled out on the floor of the Senate today, and precipitated the most serious debate which has held the attention of that body in a long time.

The names of 232 graduates of Hunter College were announced yesterday by Mrs. Mary Belden James Lena, registrar of the college. The list includes twenty-three seniors of the evening and extension divisions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24. -- Sparkling performances by Tommy Goodwin and Albert R. Hakes of New York featured the first round of match play today in the twenty-second annual Lake Worth tournament on the links of the Palm Beach Golf Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The New York City Y.M.C.A. has just started its annual financial canvass for subscriptions for its 1933 budget. The total estimated budget is $2,758,278, over 90 per cent of which is taken care of by the members and from other sources, so that the public is asked for less than 10 per cent, or only $252,106.

Mrs. Georgia McDonald, 30 years old, who lives at the Hotel Taft, was critically wounded by her husband, Ronald J. McDonald, in the crowded tea room of the Hotel Victoria, Fifty-first Street and Seventh Avenue, during the luncheon hour yesterday.

Further diversion of westbound traffic from the railroads to motor trucks and water lines will result if tail rates to Western trunk-line territory are increased by the Interstate Commerce Commission, according to spokesmen of several manufacturing companies in Connecticut who testified here yesterday at the opening of the hearing of the commission on the application of the Eastern and Western railroads for a revision of the rates upward.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- The Council of the League of Nations opened its seventeenth session this morning by adopting the Mandates Commission's report without comment on the denial by Japan that she was violating the mandate for Pacific islands by building a naval base there between Hawaii and the Philippines.

MOSCOW, Jan. 24 -- A decree was signed today by Joseph Stalin and Premier Molotoff empowering local authorities of the North Caucasus to "mobilize" peasants for the grain campaign and appointing a special commission of six, with "all authoritative rights," to conduct the campaign and enjoining the severest repression of all hostile forces.

A tuition charge of $100 a year in all of the publicly supported schools in the city above the grade of high school was urged last night by Dr. Alonzo P. Myers of New York University, president of the Eastern States Association of Professional Schools for Teachers, as a means of balancing the school budget.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- The grain trade here is concentrating its attention on developments in Washington, especially the progress of measures for inflation of the currency. The talk there today and a sharp upturn in silver early started a heavy buying movement in wheat on the Board of Trade here, which carried prices up about 1/2 cent a bushel from yesterday's finish.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 24. -- Gustavo Volltner, Cuban champion and Davis Cup star, was the only seeded player to be eliminated in the second round of the All-South singles tennis championship on the Miami-Biltmore courts today. He succumbed to Carroll Turner, outstanding player in the Miami district, in the only three-set match of the day, the score being 6-4, 3-6, 7-5.

Drt John Myers Furman, head-master and owner of the Irving School for Boys, a college preparatory boarding school at North Tarrytown, N.Y., priest of the Protestant Episcopal Church and church organist, died yesterday in Flower Hospital after undergoing an abdominal operation.

A sharp decline in retail failures, together with an increase in the number of banking and financial suspensions, featured business defaults for the week ended Jan. 19, according to Bradstreet's. The retail failures numbered 404, against 475 in the preceding week.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,015,300 barrels, compared with 2,011,050 in the preceding week, an increase of 4,250 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 26,650 barrels in East Texas was virtually offset by a decline of 26,600 barrels in Oklahoma.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 24. -- The B.B. Stable's consistent 3-year-old gelding Character scored a driving length-and-a-half victory over the Anall Stable's Helios in the featured Lake George Purse at Hialeah Park today. E. R. Bradley's Blessed Event, which ran coupled with Boy Crazy, finished third, two lengths behind Helios.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- A proposal for a broad "luxury" excise tax, applied on the principle of a manufacturers' sales levy, was gaining favor today with Democratic leaders who are to bear the brunt of budget-balancing efforts in the new Congress.

Lewis Luckenbach, vice president of the Luckenbach Steamship Lines, in a statement yesterday urged that the government undertake a survey of the merchant shipping situation so that privately owned lines may be aided in preparing for a revival of traffic when the economic situation is improved.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The House, by a viva voce vote early tonight, passed and sent to the Senate the War Department appropriation bill for the 1933-34 fiscal year, after more than six hours of wrangling which taxed parliamentary ingenuity and caused heated debate over national defense.

Keen to annex the only team championship to escape it last year, the metropolitan senior indoor crown, the New York Athletic Club has entered a team of thirty-one for the annual title tests at the 102d Engineers Armory on Saturday, it was announced yesterday.

Indications that the speculative foray against the dollar had collapsed were seen yesterday in the cancellation of almost all of the gain shown by the franc on the day before. At the same time that the franc was falling, sterling improved its position in the foreign exchange "market by nearly 3 1/4 cents.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 24. -- The Right Rev. FranK W. Creighton, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Missionary District of Mexico, was elected on the second ballot as the second Suffragan Bishop of the Long Island Diocese at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here this afternoon.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 24. -- Robert Rives Lamonte, former national organizer of the Socialist party in the United States, lawyer and author, was nominated today as Judge of the New Canaan Town Court.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24. -- Yale's basketball team sprang a surprise tonight by defeating Penn's quintet. 35 to 23, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game. A crowd of 1,400 attended the contest.

DUBLIN, Jan. 24 (AP). -- When the polls closed tonight in the Irish free State election it appeared there had been less violence reported than instances of fraudulent voting. The balloting was for the selection of a Dail Eireann, which in turn will elect a President.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The House, by a viva voce vote early tonight, passed and sent to the Senate the War Department appropriation bill for the 1933-34 fiscal year, after more than six hours of wrangling which taxed parliamentary ingenuity and caused heated debate over national defense.

Keen to annex the only team championship to escape it last year, the metropolitan senior indoor crown, the New York Athletic Club has entered a team of thirty-one for the annual title tests at the 102d Engineers Armory on Saturday, it was announced yesterday.
George Puccinelli of the Rochester Red Wings won the batting championship of the International League for the 1932 season with a mark of .391, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

DUBLIN, Jan. 24. -- With the heaviest vote in the history of the Irish Free State cast today, it was not expected that definite returns over any wide area would be announced before Friday or Saturday. The count of the ballots will start tomorrow and it may be Thursday before even the general trend will be known on account of the system of proportional representation.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 24. -- Telephoning from the Santa Monica Hospital, where he is recovering from an influenza attack, Gene Sarazen today told The Associated Press he was not "spoofing" when he recently suggested the enlargement of the golf cup to eight inches.

Indications that the speculative foray against the dollar had collapsed were seen yesterday in the cancellation of almost all of the gain shown by the franc on the day before. At the same time that the franc was falling, sterling improved its position in the foreign exchange "market by nearly 3 1/4 cents.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., Jan. 24. -- The Right Rev. FranK W. Creighton, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of the Missionary District of Mexico, was elected on the second ballot as the second Suffragan Bishop of the Long Island Diocese at the Cathedral of the Incarnation here this afternoon.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., Jan. 24. -- Robert Rives Lamonte, former national organizer of the Socialist party in the United States, lawyer and author, was nominated today as Judge of the New Canaan Town Court.

DUBLIN, Jan. 24. -- With the heaviest vote in the history of the Irish Free State cast today, it was not expected that definite returns over any wide area would be announced before Friday or Saturday. The count of the ballots will start tomorrow and it may be Thursday before even the general trend will be known on account of the system of proportional representation.

Horace E. Dodge of Detroit yesterday was selected by the Regatta Circuit Riders' Club as the outstanding figure in the sport of motor boating last year. The club, a national one composed of drivers of speed boats, officials and others interested in the craft, held its annual meeting at the Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace and voted its merit medal to him.

PARIS, Jan. 24. -- Notice of Washing's readiness to receive representatives of Italy to discuss the war debts was received today at the Foreign Office where, contrary to what might be expected, the news was regarded with considerable satisfaction.
Exceedingly Strange Interlude There is a way of taking too seriously Strange the collapse of the Interlude. Technocracy bubble, just as there was obviously a way of taking its claims too seriously.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Authoritative studies of the eariy history of the white race were cited here today by Dr. Dlnshah Pestanji Framji Ghadiali of Malaga, N.J., in an answer to a move by the naturalization authorities to cancel his citizenship on the contention that he is a Hindu and not of the white race.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The finance committee of the Chamber of Deputies today completed its discussions of the proposed budget, which must meet a 10,000,000,000-franc [$390,000,000] deficit, and the Chamber will publicly debate the measure Thursday afternoon.

A three months' search for Herman B. Becker, 40 years old, formerly of 2,805 University Avenue, the Bronx, on a perjury indictment growing out of an alleged fake service of a summons and complaint last May in a Municipal Court suit, in which a default judgment was returned, led late yesterday afternoon to Becker's arraignment before Judge Freschi in General Sessions.
DUBLIN, Jan. 24 (Canadian Press). -- Explaining the system of proportional representation which will show the count of the huge vote cast in today's Free State election, The Irish Times says:

To the Editor of The New York Times: I nearly fell backward in my chair this morning when I read in your editorial that Representative Wood was "about to retire into the lame duckery." The lame duckery! That struck me. I got down my Trench, but got no help; and my Skeat, but no light.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Prices of farm products since the middle of January have lost some of the gains made early in the month, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Department of Agriculture, said today in its weekly survey of the markets.

Mary Antonia, 3 years old, and her 2-year-old sister, Ethel, like most children of their age, are fond of their bath, and that, together with the fact that Edward Block-linger, who lives in the apartment below that of their parents at 512 West Forty-sixth Street, is not fond of having a shower while eating his dinner, saved the lives of the two youngsters last night.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- Dictatorial powers for the President of the United States, beginning with the authorization to eliminate budget deficits, were predicted by former Foreign Minister Julius Curtius in an address today at a luncheon of the American Chamber of Commerce here.

Referring to himself as "director" of technocracy, Howard Scott repiled yesterday to his critics at Columbia University, saying the he accepted the resignation of the group of his former associates who on Monday disavowed him and withdrew from the Committee on Technocracy.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- First efforts of the Legislature to afford relief to local governments from mandatory appropriations by setting up the State House Commission, as an appeal agency having been halted by Attorney General Stevens's opinion that such action would be unconstitutional, a special committee of the Senate and Assembly evolved today a plan to give to the counties and municipalities unrestricted power to reduce salaries.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 24. -- Backed by the State of Virginia and an opinion of Attorney General Mitchell, counsel for the Appalachian Power Company, operating subsidiary of the American Gas and Electric Company, went before Federal Judge Luther B. Way today and demanded the right to construct a $10,000,000 power plant on New River without submitting to regulation of the Federal Power Commission.

To the Editor of The New York Tims: We Americans have the deplorable and irrational custom of doing our loving and hating by wholesale. No mediate and reasoned-out position for us-all hate, all love, ornothing.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report in THE TIMES by Dr. C. Luther Fry on his religious survey of "Who's Who in America" is exceedingly interesting and encouraging. The suspicion he seems to feel, however, that the listing of religious affiliation is not altogether genuine, but due in many cases to social pressure, is disquieting.

Extraordinary demands upon the Henry Street Settlement nurses, many of whom are breaking down from overwork, make it imperative that the Visiting Nurse Service give up its "silent campaign" for $200,000 and appeal to the public for the $114,000 still to be raised, it was announced yesterday by Marguerite Wales, General Director of the service.

After quiet trading for several hours yesterday, prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced to the best figures in the last ten days, only to meet contracts and end unchanged to 3 points higher than on Monday.

The Glass till, now nearing a final vote in the Senate, is an attempt to repair at certain points a banking system with the disgraceful record of more than 10,000 failures in the last twelve years. No attempt is made to bringall of the commercial banks of the country, small as well as large, under the Federal Reserve System.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Jan. 24. -- Although General Jan C. Smuts, head of the South African party, in presenting a motion in the Assembly today calling on the government to resign and help form a national coalition government, spoke in gravest terms, declaring a state of emergency existed, debate was adjourned tonight with little prospect of the government's defeat.

Twenty-one foils stars participated in the preliminary round of the junior national championship tournament last night at the New York Athletic Club, and after an evening of brisk competition, featured by the closeness of most of the bouts, six qualified for the final.

The man to whom Thomas O'Connell, property clerk at Police Headquarters, turned over $18,600 seized in June, 1931, from Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, when the latter was arrested on charges of assault and carrying a concealed weapon, was revealed yesterday by Police Commissioner Mulrooney, as Lawrence Carney, who is said at the Federal Building, where Schultz is wanted for income tax evasion, to have been one of the latter's lieutenants.

Mr. Coward, who has a way of his own with musical romance and historical pageantry, has a way of his own with the familiar triangle. "Design for Living," which came to the Ethel Barrymore Theatre last evening, is the proof. It is a decadent way, if you feel obliged to pull a long moral face over his breezy fandango.

The American Society of Miniature Painters, organized in 1899, opened its thirty-fourth annual exhibition with a reception yesterday afternoon at the Grand Central Galleries. The work will be on public view, beginning today, through Feb. 11.

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May of Brooklyn signed a petition yesterday for an order to show cause in a taxpayer's suit brought by the Jamaica Central Railways, Inc., against the City of New York and others, asking for a temporary injunction to restrain three corporations from further operating their bus lines in Queens.

VANCOUVER, B.C., Jan. 24 (Canadian Press) -- Robert (Klondike Bob) Henderson, whose sensational discoveries at Gold Creek in 1896 started thousands of adventurers on the trail of '98 to the Klondike, has passed along his last trail.

The story of how 600,000 barrels of flour by the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross were bartered through many channels of industry before they finally resulted in the 1,500,000 packages of relief food now being distributed by that organization was unfolded last night by General Robert C. Davis to the Overseas Service League at its twelfth annual dinner in the American Women's Association clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.

The practical applicability of Catholic social teaching to present-day problems of living was stressed by the Rev. Wilfrid Parsons, editor of The Catholic periodical America, in addressing a meeting at the Hotel Astor yesterday of the sponsoring committee of the twenty-eighth regional meeting of the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems.

BRESLAU, Jan. 24. -- Giant firecrackers, tear gas bombs and bombs that emitted choking fumes -- plus a noisy interpolation of National Socialist marching songs and "Deutschland Ueber Alles" -- greeted Professor Ernst Cohn this morning when he resumed his law courses at the University of Breslau after several weeks' interruption.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 24. -- President-elect Roosevelt does not intend to close the door in the face of any debtor nation seeking readjustment of its war debt to the United States. This became known here today, following announcement in Washington that Secretary of State Stimson had notified Italy that the United States would welcome representatives to take up the question of readjustment with Mr. Roosevelt after he becomes President.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 24. -- Concha Marina, the villa of Mrs. Dodge Sloane, was the setting tonight for a dinner with which she entertained in compliment to her house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Livingston Clarkson and Mrs. H. Nelson Slater.

PATERSON, N.J., Jan. 24. -- Dominick Spinelli, an engineer of the Lido Piece Dyeworks, 90 Second Avenue, was injured today by the explosion of a bomb which he had pulled from a boiler in the plant shortly after two armed men had entered the engine room by force and had tossed the bomb on the fire.

Secretary Jim Tierney, who is collecting signed contracts at the Giant offices these days with the avidity of a stamp collector, had another one to report yesterday on receiving the duly approved document of Johnny Vergez, who is slated to play third base once more at the Polo Grounds this year.

A will is not a will until the person who made it is dead, Surrogate George A. Wingate ruled in Brooklyn yesterday. Proceeding a step further, the court held that since a will has no legal existence during the maker's lifetime, a written agreement or "understanding" concerning his will is "meaningless" as far as the law is concerned.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just finished reading Voltaire's "Candida" for the second time. One would expect a story, no matter what its qualities or merits are, to lose effectiveness upon a second reading. But in this case it was not so.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan. 24. -- With receivership applications pending in New York City and Baltimore, Vice Chancellor Alfred A. Stein appointed temporary custodial receivers today for the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation's properties and interests in New Jersey.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24. -- A preliminary report was made to the United States District Court today by Charles A. McCulloch and Edward N. Hurley, receivers, of their stewardship of the Middle West Utilities Company, the largest of the Insull holding companies.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP). -- After eleven hours of debate, the Senate adjourned at 10 o'clock tonight with a final vote on the Glass banking reform bill still to come.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Declaring that it is difficult to explain why "ruinously low prices have not contributed to a reduction of farm output," Senator Wagner of New York discussed the farm parity bill in a raido talk over the Columbia Broadcasting System this morning.

Wendell L. Willkie was elected president of the Commonwealth and Southern Corporation at a meeting of the directors yesterday, it was announced by B.C. Cobb, chairman of the board. Mr. Cobb, who has been acting as president as well as chairman of the company, will remain chairman and chief executive of the company.

GENEVA, Jan. 24. -- The disarmament conference's bureau today adopted the remainder of the articles of the proposed treaty establishing a permanent disarmament commission. The discussion was notable for Germany's consistent efforts to weaken the supervision of disarmament.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- President Hoover today vetoed the first deficiency bill on the ground that a provision relative to supervision by Congress of tax refunds was unconstitutional, and the House promptly sustained the veto, 193 to 158.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Convict industries at Sing Sing prison produced a net profit of $258,593 in the fiscal year 1931-32, according to a report filed today with the State Commission of Correction by Commissioners John S. Kennedy and Sam A. Lewisohn, and Clifford D. Young, chief inspector.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- A threat of delay in action on the beer bill by the Finance Committee brought a warning from Senator Harrison today that dilatory tactics would result in a move to take the measure from the committee and bring it to the floor of the Senate.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 24. -- Reginald D. Root, who became head football coach at Yale University last month, today issued the call for a meeting tomorrow to organize the candidates for Spring practice. He will meet aspirants for all elevens, including the varsity, freshman, class league and 150-pound teams, and outline his plans.

Leasing of a new plant in Long Island City by the J.K. Welding Company, Inc., was reported yesterday. The company, established nineteen years ago, intends to continue its Manhattan plant at 138-40 Centre Street. The 10,000 square feet of space taken in 43-19 Thirty-seventh Street, Queens, practically doubles the facilities of the firm.

ERIE, Pa., Jan. 24 (AP). -- Tom Mix's hair-raising stunts in the movies are the result of trick photography, Johnny Agee, veteran circus horseman who worked with Mix in many films, testified today in Zack T. Miller's damage suit.

By a special resolution adopted yesterday by the Board of Estimate, meeting in committee of the whole, the functions and duties of the extinct City Planning Department are transferred to Herman H. Smith, chief engineer of the board, whose powers were widened to include his new duties.

Fireman John J. Logan of Engine Company 37 died last night at Sydenham Hospital of injuries received when he and four other firemen were flung to the street from the company's engine as it was in collision with a Fifth Avenue bus carrying about twenty-five passengers at St. Nicholas Avenue and 127th Street yesterday morning.

The squash racquets team of the Junior League defeated the Heights Casino, 4 to 1, at the former's courts on East Seventy-first Street yesterday and thereby became assured of finishing in at least a tie for first place in the New York group of the tournament conducted by the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

Ernest Schoenig, wealthy bootlegger of Pleasantville, N.J., who charges he was kidnapped on last Dec. 27 in the Federal Building in Brooklyn by Patrolmen John Nevins and John. Graef, appeared again yesterday in Federal court in Brooklyn at an adjourned hearing on an indictment charging him and three others with connection with a rum-running ring.

Numerous apartment leases were reported yesterday, with the largest volume of rentals in the midtown section of Manhattan. Activity was apparent also in the uptown and downtown areas and in various suburban districts.
The fortieth anniversary of the opening of the Empire Theatre will be celebrated today by the cast of "We, The People," the Elmer Rice , play now showing in that theatre.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- Acting on the heels of a challenge by Governor Lehman, Assemblyman Hamilton F. Potter, from the home district in Suffolk of W. Kingsland Macy. Republican State Chairman, announced today that he was drafting a bill for an investigation of New York City election frauds by a legislative commission.

Conforming to its recent practice, the share market slackened its pace yesterday as sporadic weakness cropped out in a handful of issues. The pressure was never aggressive at any point and where heaviness appeared it was short-lived.

In an unusually long game, Edwin Apfelbaum of the Newark Lodge of Elks last night defeated Thomas L. Corcoran of the Montclair Athletic Club, 125 to 98, in the third game of the national amateur pocket billiard tournament being held at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy.

BERLIN, Jan. 24. -- While bonds were firm at today's session of the Boerse, stocks, on the whole, lost a little upon relatively small sales, owing to the general stagnation of the market. Weakness in the dollar caused some nervousness, although opinion in financial circles as to what importance should be attached to Senator Borah's statements regarding inflationary measures in the United States was distinctly divided.

BOSTON, Jan. 24. -- Charles (King) Solomon, reputed leader of the most lucrative liquor, vice and narcotic syndicates in New England and proprietor of several night clubs, was shot while he was in the washroom of the Cotton Club in Roxbury early this morning and died at the City Hospital a few hours later, cursing "those dirty rats" who killed him.

The first report of the state of the books and business of the United Cigai Stores Company of America when it was adjudged bankrupt on Aug 29, 1932 was filed with Referee Irwin Kurtz at 15 Park Row yesterday.

Seven girls who said they were taking a post-graduate course at the Todhunter School were admitted with a teacher to the hearing before Supreme Court Justice Cotillo yesterday in the proceeding involving the custody of the two children of Mr. and Mrs. Walter L. Richard, although the general public was excluded on the ground that testimony involving the moral fitness of Mrs. Oroville Wooster Richard was being brought out.

Business and governmental leaders will be compelled within the next six months to answer an "irresistible demand" for some form of currency inflation, Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, told 250 delegates to the convention of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association, which opened yesterday in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

A temporary Martin act injunction and receivership order sought by Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr. against the United States Bond and Mortgage Corporation and two of its subsidiaries was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in Brooklyn.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 24. -- Since early this morning hundreds of persons have fairly mobbed the general staff headquarters building for news of the battle of Nanawa.

Direct radio-telegraph service between the United States and Vatican City was inaugurated yesterday by the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation with the exchange of a series of congratulatory messages between Catholic dignitaries in this country and at the Vatican.

Magistrate David Hirshfield's encounter with Patrolman Thomas Conroy of Traffic D at Delancey and Norfolk Streets on Monday afternoon, which resulted in the jurist's getting a summons accusing him of obstructing traffic, became the subject of a Police Department investigation yesterday.

L.M. Castle Co. -- Year ended Dec. 31. Net loss after taxes, depreciation and other charges, $161,197, against $107,696 loss for 1931 after all charges, including $72,448 to cover market decline in securities. In addition to $15,000 charged out of current earnings in 1932, company set up out of surplus an additional $50.000 reserve to provide for doubtful notes and accounts receivable.

Helen Young, who won the Anna Hyatt Huntington prize of $100 for water-color painting at the current exhibition of the National Association of Women Painters and Sculptors, is having a one-man exhibition of oils and waters-colors at the Morton Grallery.

ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- In welcoming members of his liquor study commission, which met here today to effect organization. Governor Lehman set before the commission the task of developing a plan for future regulation of liquor traffic by the State which on one hand would put an end to the evils of prohibition and on the other prevent a return of "scandalous conditions" surrounding that traffic in pre-prohibition days.
ALBANY, Jan. 24. -- In a surprise move today the Democratic majority in the Senate stripped the O'Connell brothers of Albany of their former control over Senate patronage.

Consolidated operating income of the Marine Midland Corporation and its twenty-two constituent banks and trust companies and their affiliates amounted in 1932 to $6,740,934 before appropriations to general reserves, according to the annual report, issued to shareholders yesterday by George F. Rand, president of the corporation.

Lord Dudley Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords and chairman of the Parliamentary Council of the British Art Federation, is due today from England on the Cunarder Berengaria. Ignace Paderewski, the pianist, is also arriving on the ship for his nineteenth concert tour in the United States.
BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 24. -- The battle for possession of Fort Nanawa, also called Ayala, continued through the fifth day today, with Bolivia and Paraguay both stoutly claiming advantage.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Stamped with the final approval of House and Senate, a bill carrying $90,000,000 in Federal credit for the farmer was dispatched tonight to the White House.

Following early weakness, the bond market on the Stock Exchange steadied and closed irregularly higher yesterday. Continued strength in United States Government bonds was again a feature of the dealings. Active issues of the government group moved up 1-32 to 7-32 point, with the exception of the Liberty 3 1/2 s and the Treasury 4 1/4 s, which were down 1-32.
A detailed list of investments in the portfolio of the Utility Equities Corporation was made public for the first time by the directors in their statement for 1932, mailed to stockholders yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Friendly dissension among friends of Senator Glass over whether he should be the next Secretary of the Treasury became apparent today at about the same time that Senator Long opened a campaign against Mr. Glass as a Cabinet member.

The trend toward more complete and informative annual reports to stockholders has resulted in great improvement in the quality of corporations' statements of earnings, according to a pamphlet issued by the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, which is based on the reports of 500 business organizations.

Two robbers had just taken $195 in cash and a $100 check from twenty members of Our Lady of Mount Carmel Society in a restaurant at 221 Union Avenue, Brooklyn, last night when a policeman, summoned by radio, entered with pistol drawn and capture one of them.

Amendment of the State law on railroad grade crossing elimination to lessen the financial burden on railroads and governmental units alike is recommended in the annual report to be submitted soon to the Legislature by the Public Service Commission.

BERLIN, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Goaded by a Nationalist attack, Chancellor Kurt von Schleicher, whose lone game has been mystifying observers, revealed his hand tonight, showing that he intends to force political issues with the greatest celerity.

Stimulated by strength in outside markets and by arguments being presented in Congress, the silver market on the National Metal Exchange was more active yesterday than on any previous day this year, and prices at one time moved up to levels more than a cent an ounce above those on Monday. Before the market opened, bar
NEW YORK. General and Mrs. Emile-Adolphe Taufflieb, who have been at the Pierre for some time, will sail tonight to return to their home in Paris.
A goal in the closing stages of the final period by Frank Boucher gave the New York Hangers a 3-to-2 victory over the Americans in a National Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden last night.

MINEOLA, Jan. 24. -- Two youths, arrested as the thugs who, armed with pistols, had forced young women into their automobiles, and then had robbed them after driving them to Nassau County, were indicted today by the Nassau County grand jury, less than twelve hours after their capture.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- The following table, prepared from Treasury records, indicates the present status of foreign debts owed to the United States:

A survey of conditions in Harlem Hospital, the centre of several political and social controversies during recent years, will be made by a group of prominent physicians within the next few months, it was announced yesterday by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- An appeal to French parties to drop the conflict over the financial situation and unite for the general interests of the country was contained in a letter published in L'Intransigeant today under the signature of former President Gaston Doumergue, whom many here consider likely soon to be called upon to take the leadership in a non-party government.

By a section of the tariff act of 1922 officers of the Coast Guard were authorized to stop and board, examine and search any vessel within twelve miles of the United States coast; and, if any law of the United States seemed to have been violated which would subject the vessel and its cargo to forfeiture, it was made their duty to seize the same.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., Jan. 24. -- H.E. Meeker, who was named receiver of the First National Bank in Mamaroneek last Friday, announced tonight that within two or three days he would reopen the doors of the institution for liquidation purposes.

New York University trustees are to be congratulated on the selection of Dr. HARRY W. CHASE as successor to Chancellor BROWN. He has made full demonstration of his ability as a university president. Before his experience for years in North Carolina and later in Illinois, he had preparation as a scholar and a successful record as a teacher.

A rider has been added to the bill making appropriations for the Treasury and Postoffice Departments, now pending in the Senate, which would go a long way to destroy the usefulness of the United States Civil Service Commission. Its effect is to repeal the existing laws and regulations relating to the personnel records now kept by the commission, and to require that such records shall be kept by the several executive departments and independent establishments.

The gentlemen of the Philadelphia Orchestra, which played last night in Carnegie Hall, with Issay Dobrowen conducting, gave that leader much better service than the gentlemen of the Philharmonic-Symphony when Mr. Dohrowen was their guest.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- When the incoming President and his aides have completed their discussions on war debts and related economic questions with the representatives of Great Britain, the new administration will be willing to proceed to similar negotiations with other debtors in an order to be determined later.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 24. -- Led by a substantial increase in the output of automobiles in connection with the introduction of new models, industrial activity as a whole showed less than the usual seasonal decline in December, the Federal Reserve Board announced today in its monthly review of business conditions.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 24 (AP). -- Dr. Parrish, which figured in the money in twenty of his twenty-five starts last year, won his first race as a 7-year-old today when he led home a classy field in the one-and-one-sixteenth mile feature at the Fair Grounds.

A plan of reorganization for the Pittsburgh, Shawmut Northern Railroad, which has been in receivership since 1905, has been adopted by committees representing interested security holders. The outstanding securities involved comprise $2,044,350 of receiver's certificates, $733,000 first mortgage 5s, dated 1892, and $164,000 first mortgage 5s, dated 1899, of the Central New Tork Western Railroad, and $14,491,600 refunding 4s, dated 1902, of the Pittsburgh, Shawmut Northern.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 24. -- The nation's banking system is in a "splendid position" to finance business recovery, but lack of confidence is retarding a return to normal conditions, Francis H. Sisson of New York, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and president of the American Bankers Association, told the Bond Club of Philadelphia in an address today.

CHICAGO, Jan. 24 (AP). -- The tie for second place in the world's three-cushion billiard championship tournament was reduced to two players today as Clarence Jackson of Detroit and Tiff Denton of Kansas City suffered their second defeats.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The substitute for the Collier been bill which was reported from the Senate Judiciary Committee places the supporters of legalized beer in a dilemma; and no matter which way they turn they are impaled on one of its horns.

Fresh water fishing in New York State will be better this year than last and probably will surpass that of any recent periods, in the opinion of Sumner M. Cowden, superintendent of Fish Culture of the New York Conservation Department. In making this prophecy, Mr. Cowden bases his belief on the improvements that have been made within the last few months looking toward increased production of game fish for restocking purposes.

Ignace Jan Paderewski, the pianist and first Premier of Poland, arrived yesterday on the Berengaria to make his nineteenth concert tour in the United States. He will stay in this country two months and will travel as far West as Milwaukee.

A biting northeasterly wind which attained a velocity of fifty miles an hour kicked up an unusually heavy surf along the New Jersey and Long Island coasts last night, flooding seaside resorts and widening breaches in bulkheads made by the November storm.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Two vacancies have reduced the Federal Reserve Board to only four regular members and it therefore was not qualified today to make advances to member banks on their promissory notes, since the Glass-Steagall act, which bestows such power, requires the consent of not less than five members of the board to such advances.

The Boston Hockey Club, instead of the Montreal Royals, will play the St. Nicks in Madison Square Garden on Sunday afternoon. Substitution of the Boston sextet for the Montreal team was announced yesterday by Metropolitan A.A.U. officials, although they declined to admit that a ban existed against Canadian amateur hockey teams playing in this part of the United States.
The advance sale for "Ann Vickers," by Sinclair Lewis, had reached 54,732 copies yesterday, the day of publication, Doubleday, Doran, publishers of the book here and in Canada, said yesterday.

Senator WAGNER has pointed out one of the fundamental defects in the "domestic allotment" plan, in the form recently approved by the House of Representatives. Consumers are to be taxed from $750,000,000 to $900,000,000 a year in-order to raise money to be distributed in bounties to the farmers.

Sentiment in Wall Street Improved yesterday as the share market broke away from reactionary influences and moved moderately higher in trading that was 50 per cent more active than that of the previous day. The volume on the Stock Exchange was 750,000 shares, compared with 493,000 on the day before.

GENEVA, Jan. 25. -- The committee charged by the League of Nations with the task of preparing for the World Economic Conference decided today that the conference would not meet for at least three months. The committee will meet again before May to fix a definite date for the conference or postpone that duty again, for, as today's decision shows, the tendency is still toward delay.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25. -- Argentina's foreign trade decreased 19.2 per cent last year from the total in 1931, amounting to 934,323,000 gold pesos ($546,578,955), compared with 1,157,043,000 gold pesos ($676,870,155), according to the National Statistical Bureau's report to Finance Minister Hneyo, published tonight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Jan. 24 was published an item under the heading "Pink and Hilly Clash on R.F.C. Home Aid." There Can be no doubt in the mind of any one close to the situation that the views expressed by Mr. Pink are right.
Before an audience that crowded Town Hall, Professor Auguste Piccard, visiting Belgian scientist, delivered his first lecture in this country last night, under the auspices of the Civic Forum.

A plan to provide employment for unappointed school teachers, without additional cost to the city, will be presented to Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools, on Saturday morning, according to an agreement reached yesterday by representatives of the unemployed teachers with the Board of Education at a meeting of the board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Plans to discontinue air mail routes from Phoenix to San Diego; from Chicago to Indianapolis; from Big Spring, Texas, to San Antonio, and one of the services between Kansas City and St. Louis were outlined by Postmaster General Brown today to the House Postoffice Committee.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- Governor Lehman's executive budget bill has been completed and will go to the Senate and Assembly at the session Monday evening. It will be accompanied by a message in which the Governor will recommend new or additional taxation sufficient to balance the 1933-34 budget.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The machine might speak for itself thus:

A plan to purchase a home for retired circus performers near Richmond, Va., by the Circus Saints and Sinners Club of America was announced yesterday by F. Darius Benham, originator of the project, at the monthly luncheon of the Dexter Fellows Tent of tanbark fans, at which Dr. William Beebe, undersea explorer, was initiated into membership as "fall guy."

Good-Natured Gossip. In connection with SINCLAIR LEWIS'S new book it is stated that the author has been the victim of many unfounded newspaper reports. He has been spoken of as ill with bronchitis in Vienna and with pneumonia in London, whereas he is enjoying the very best of health in the Austrian mountains.

George W. Wickersham, former United States Attorney General, sails tonight for Europe on the Cunarder Berengaria, accompanied by Mrs. Wickersham and their daughter, Clive. Others booked to sail are Mrs. G.B. Holdsworth, novelist; the Countess of Dudley, Count Enrico de Zogheb, Professor Albert A. Cook, Mrs. Frank J. Egan, Miss Marjorie Holme-Sumner, Harry S. Black, L. Seton Lindsay, J.D. Robertson and Wilson Somerville.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 25. -- Dark Polish, 114 to 1, one of the longest shots in the history of Florida racing, made her first start at Hialeah Park today and annexed the two-furlong Kissimmee Purse for juvenile fillies.

The building at 1,443 Third Avenue was leased by Sarah Rosenblatt to Guy Giovinco from Han. 1, 1933, to April 30, 1943, at a yearly rent of $2,700 until April 30, 1938, and $3,000 for the last five years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The satisfaction shown by Senators who were with President-elect Roosevelt at Muscle Shoals Saturday is interpreted as indicating that Mr. Roosevelt plans to undertake development of the Tennessee River on a greater scale than ever before projected.

For the second time in the life of this Congress the Citizens' Military Training Camps have been restored to an army appropriation bill, despite the opposition of Chairman COLLINS. Last May, as in this January, that sometimes misguided friend of economy succeeded in eliminating the appropriation, only to fail to carry the House with him.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 25. -- At a meeting of directors of the Dominion Bank today, after the annual meeting of stockholders, A.W. Austin retired from the presidency to become chairman of the board of directors, and C.A. Bogert, who had been vice president and general manager, was elected president.
NEW YORK. Mrs. Charles A. Cartwright, who has been for several weeks at the Waldorf-Astoria, will leave on Feb. 18 to return to her home in London.

Former Mayor James J. Walker lost yesterday his application to Supreme Court Justice Lydon to vacate two orders in which papers were served on him in suits brought against him and his wife. Mrs, Janet Allen Walker, for a balance due on wearing apparel furnished to Mrs. Walker.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Great Britain's note conditionally accepting the proposal to discuss the war debts was delivered today to Secretary Stimson by Ambassador Lindsay.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 25. -- The formation of a permanent organization to represent township governments was announced here today at a meeting of more than 100 township officials from virtually every county in New York State. The meeting had been called by Supervisor J. Russell Sprague of Nassau County to consider proposed amendments to the new Kirkland law, designed to modernize the governmental machinery of townships.

Immediately after the Federal grand jury had voted a sealed indictment yesterday, Thomas E. Dewey, Chief Assistant United States Attorney, appeared before Federal Judge John C. Knox and obtained warrants for the arrest of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer runner, and Henry (Sailor) Stevens and Frank Ahearn, his lieutenants, all wanted for violation of the income tax law.
LOS ANGELES, Jan. 25. -- The Olympic Games last Summer returned a net profit of approximately $150,000.

Fanned by a strong northeast wind, fire swept almost the entire block bounded by East 137th and 138th Streets, Madison Avenue and the Harlem River, last night. The flames raged for an hour and a half before firemen with more than forty pieces of apparatus, summoned on four alarms, brought them under control, about 11:15 o'clock.

Maintaining their even pace, even to the size of their respective scores, the squash tennis teams of the Columbia University Club and the New York Athletic Club continued in the lead of Class A in the Metropolitan League last night.

MONTREAL, Jan. 25. -- Paced by the defending champion, J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., and Frank Shields, Davis Cup player from New York, three players from the United States and five from Montreal advanced to the quarter-final round of the Canadian indoor tennis championships today.

After an eight-hour search for Helen Sterler, 6 years old, missing from in front of her home at 1,003 De Kalk Avenue, Brooklyn, since 4 o'clock yesterday afternoon, the police early today found the child slain in the cellar of a three-story dwelling five doors away at 1,013, where she had been strangled by a clothesline left knotted about her throat.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Down through the stretch bursts a flying youth, arms driving rhythmically, slender legs eating up distance, spikes biting into the track.

The unexpected action of the State Senate in taking control of its patronage from the O'Connell brothers of Albany was regarded here yesterday as a decisive victory for the so-called Roosevelt wing of the Democratic party in the State in its battle with the leadership of Tammany Hall and its up-State allies.

Prices of bonds moved generally higher again on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Many domestic corporation issues showed strength, and United States Government bonds climbed 1-32 to 6-32 point. Five issues of the government group, the Liberty 3 1/2s, first Liberty 4 1/4s, Treasury 3 3/4s and two of the three issues of 3 3/8s reached the highest levels in more than a year.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The first major move for a general cut in railroad freight rates to correspond with the sharp decline of commodity prices since October, 1929, was launched today with the filing of a joint petition to the Interstate Commerce Commission by five organizations representing agricultural leaders and the coal and lumber industries.

The fourth festival concert for the benefit of the Musicians Emergency Fund, Inc., took place last night at Madison Square Garden under the direction of Walter Damrosch before an audience estimated at 12,000. The all-Beethoven program included the "Leonore Overture No. 3," the "Agnus Dei" from the "Missa Solemnis" and the Ninth Symphony.

Baseball fans in the metropolitan area, eager to see what Connie Mack's revamped Athletics will look like this year, will not have to wait until the American League schedule brings them to the Yankee Stadium.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Warm weather has curtailed the demand for hogs as well as fresh pork, and the former were quoted here today as 5 to 15 cents lower on lights, while other kinds -were steady to 5 cents lower. The extreme top was off 15 cents at $3.30, with the day's average 5 cents lower at $3.15.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- By a vote of 54 to 9, the Senate late this evening passed the Glass banking reform bill, around which has raged the most persistent filibuster in recent years.

Bleakness hid the sunshine even from Park Slope yesterday, no sign of sprouting buds could be seen on the trees that shade the section's brownstone fronts and scarcely a peep could be heard from the sparrows and starlings that perch upon them.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- War debts held the centre of the Senate stage for a time today as Senator Robinson of Indiana, Republican, and Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader, hotly argued over whether William C. Bullitt had been sent to Europe as an unofficial representative of President-elect Roosevelt on the debts, and Senator Johnson, denounced the speech made in Leeds, England, last night by Neville Chamberlain, British Chancellor of the Exchequer.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Rumors in Bolivia and other Latin-American countries that the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey was aiding Bolivia financially and otherwise in its war with Paraguay were brought to Washington's notice today by a denial from the New Jersey company that there was any truth in the rumors.

DETROIT, Jan. 25. -- Herbert Chase, a New York consulting engineer, speaking before members of the Society of Automotive Engineers today, visualized a lighter, roomier automobile, stream-lined to the point of having no fenders.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- A bipartisan movement to raise tariffs to compensate for depreciated currencies abroad took definite form in the House today coincident with disclosures that President Hoover felt the necessity for this course or for international action to stabilize the moneys of the world.

A new ruling, made yesterday by the Treasury Department, eliminates from the scope of the excise levy on furs practically all furtrimmed cloth coats retailing at $25 or under, it was announced by the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.

Moderate declines in quiet trading were the rule in local commodity markets yesterday. An exception appeared in the market for coffee futures, where prices advanced as a result of the sale at auction of part of the February allotment of the Federal Farm Board's coffee by the Grain Stabilization Corporation.

The Delaware Hudson Company, controller of the 870-mile railroad of the same name, announced yesterday that it had acquired approximately 10 per cent of the capital stock of the New York Central Railroad, one of the country's major systems, with a total of 11,000 miles of track.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Jan. 23:

An important collection of Assyrian sculpture as been given to the Metropolitan Museum of Art by John D. Rockefeller Jr. Most of the objects included in the gift came from the palace of King Ashur-nasir-apal II of Assyria at Nimrud.

The Pennsylvania Railroad maintained yesterday the continuity of dividend payments which dates from 1847 by declaring a dividend of 50 cents on its $50 par stock, but at the same time the Delaware Hudson Company ended the record maintained since 1880 by omitting the quarterly dividend of $1.50 due at this time.

Operations in the steel Industry continue to increase at the rate of about one percentage point weekly, according to The Iron Age, which estimates current production at 17 per cent of ingot capacity. This compares with 16 per cent in the previous week.

The fate of the Soviet regime depends essentially upon whether or not other countries will have revolutions and join Russia in a Socialist program, declares Leon Trotsky, fallen Soviet leader, in his "History of the Russian Revolution," the last two volumes of which are published today by Simon Schuster.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 25. -- Despite a drop of $316,000 in last season's football revenue and a reduction of $260,000 in the athletic budget, William J. Bingham, Harvard's athletic director, today announced that no Crimson sport team will be forced to cancel any of its contests.

A plea for solidarity among English-speaking races to protect their fundamental principles of liberty against "the challenge" of dictatorship and communism was made yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler at the annual luncheon meeting of the Pilgrims, of which he is president, in the Bankers Club.

Imports of $14,192,300 gold, including $7,494,300 from England which was part of the gold ear-marked in London for the account of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York in connection with the 15, were announced yesterday by the Reserve Bank.

Developments that touch the Wall Street community intimately held the attention of the financial markets yesterday. On the Stock Exchange there were a partial recovery in share prices and a continuance of the deliberate upward movement in bonds.
ALBANY, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Up-State counties will receive today more than $9,000,000 from the State into their local education funds for 1933, Controller Morris S. Tremaine said today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan, 25 (AP). -- At home in the heavy going, A. Pelleteri's Sizzling splashed her way to her third victory of the Winter season today, winning the mile and a sixteenth feature at the Fair Grounds.

BRESLAU, Jan. 25. -- As the University of Breslau schedule today included no lectures by Professor Ernst Cohn the national Socialist agitation against him took a recess. The malcontents confined themselves to an outdoor parade -- which though led by the president of the National Socialist students organization in a Hitler uniform was a skimpy affair -- and distributing handbills calling a protest meeting against Professor Cohn for tomorrow when he is to lecture again.

Ratification of the lame duck amendment leads Senator PITTMAN to revive the proposal for a constitutional amendment making the President's term of office six years. The matter has been discussed on and off ever since the debates on it in the Constitutional Convention of 1787.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- The answer to the New York State citizen's plaint. "How many times am I going to pay this tax?" is found in the recent report of a House subcommittee on double taxation."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Senator Norbeck, the chairman, said today that the Senate's stock market investigating committee would present several important cases involving stock mannipulation at this session of Congress, in addition to its inquiry into the Insullutilities collapse.

A FRENCH staff officer of the Napoleonic era once sagely observed that when the old women of the towns began throwing dishwater on the troops from second-story windows, the campaign was as good as lost. On the other hand, when hockey fans gather in the streets to throw punches at a referee alter a game, the campaign is as good as won. Hockey has made the grade.

The general Impression of the Franco-American debt situation which was carried back to France yesterday by General Emile Adolphe Taufflieb, former commander of the Thirty-seventh French Army Corps and divisional commander in the defense of Verdun, was that considerable bad feeling existed in the United States and that it was regretted by thoughtful Americans.

Floyd B. Odium, president of the Atlas Corporation, has been elected to the executive committee of American Investors, Inc., and Oswald L. Johnston, secretary of Atlas and a director of many of its subsidiaries, has been elected a member of the board of directors within the last year, it was revealed yesterday in the annual report to stockholders.

The debate in the Senate on the "silver amendments" to the Glass banking bill was of interest chiefly as showing how the ghosts of a dead and buried past may walk again. After interment for a third of a century, we heard again the old-time propaganda.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- J.N. Bozeman gained undisputed possession of first place in the world's championship three-cushion billiard tournament today as Welker Cochran of Hollywood, Cal., met with his first reversal in four starts.

Lord Marley, former Lord-in-Waiting to King George V, Under-secretary of State for War in 1930 and 1931 and now Deputy Speaker in the House of Lords, and chairman of the Parliamentary Council of the British Ort Federation, arrived yesterday on the Cunarder Berengaria for a three weeks' visit

Air Reduction Company, Inc., reports for the year ended on Dec. 31 last, consolidated net Income of $2,293,760 after depreciation and other operating reserves, including Federal taxes, equal to $2.72 a share on 841,288 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $3,815,409 in the previous year, or $4.53 a share.

Eastern shippers resumed their attack on the proposal of the Eastern and Western railroads for revision of freight rates to the Western trunk-line territory yesterday at the second of a series of hearings by the Interstate "Commerce Commission at the Hotel New Yorker.

As the audience at the New Yorker Theatre last night clearly Indicated, it is good to have Harald Kreutzberg back again, freed from the entanglements of elaborate production, independent of an assisting group and dancing in top form in a first rate solo program.

Suspension of the city-owned ferry line between Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, and South Street, Manhattan, was ordered yesterday by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund. A three months' "trial period" was agreed upon to determine if the suspension would be effective in wiping out operation deficits and if the districts served by the line could do without it.

Changes in the executive personnel of the National Biscuit Company were revealed yesterday when its pamphlet report to stockholders was made public. Roy E. Tomlinson, chairman of the board, was elected president of the company, succeeding Frank C. Lowry, who became a vice president.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- A $1,500,000,000 program for farm relief was launched in the Senate today by the Democratic leaders.

Five corporations and an individual were fined yesterday by Magistrate Farrell in the Bronx for violating the section of the State labor law requiring employers to adhere to posted work schedules for female employes. In each case an inspector for the Department of Labor testified that he had found a woman working either earlier or later than the legal schedule.

By defeating the Cosmopolitan Club yesterday, 4 to 1, the Nassau Country Club remained in the running for the crown in the New York group of the tournament conducted by the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 25 (AP). -- Two companies of the National Guard were held in readiness for mobilization tonight as the after-math of demonstrations by 300 unemployed men and women at the State Capitol.

Newspaper office color and atmosphere, recently introduced on stage, screen and radio, were interpreted in terms of music last night at the premiere of Ferde Grofe's "Tabloid," a suite in four movements, in Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Regulations pertaining to the gift tax which was written to the 1932 revenue act were issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.
The schism in the ranks of technocracy resulted yesterday in two groups working independently of each other on an "energy survey of North America."

Proposals for currency inflation were attacked in speeches yesterday by Francis H. Sisson, president of the American Bankers Association and vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company, and by George Bassett Roberts, vice president of the National City Bank.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 25. -- Playing at the top of his game, George Lott of Chicago, three times national doubles champion and member of four United States Davis Cup teams, scored an easy victory in the third round of the all-South singles tennis championship on the Miami-Biltmore courts today.

The Department of Public Markets is conducting a city-wide drive against infractions of the kosher food law, it was disclosed yesterday, after Mayor John P. O'Brien had issued orders for the campaign.

Reference in the 1932 football rules committee report to the fear that something might have to be done eventually about the forward pass has brought forth from prominent coaches at least three suggestions that something be done immediately.

HAVANA, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Arthur Hullcoat's Proteus, once considered a promising candidate for 1932 3-year-old honors, won his first race in thirteen starts today when he accounted for the six-furlong feature at Oriental Park.

The trial of the suit of Sam Kaplan, ousted president of Local 301 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators Union, to compel his reinstatement by William C. Elliott, president of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes and Moving Picture Machine Operators, began yesterday before Supreme Court Justice Miller.

TOKYO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- The Japanese Cabinet is delaying decision on whether Japan shall withdraw from the League of Nations until the government learns the exact nature of the recommendations for settling the Chino-Japanese conflict which will be made by the League Assembly's Committee of Nineteen.

Our monthly foreign trade figures during 1932 sufficiently indicated the kind of comparison with other years the full twelvemonth's record would make. In money value the country's total foreign trade decreased 34 7/8 per cent from 1931 and 57 3/8 per cent from 1930.

District Attorney Geoghan or Kings County moved yesterday for a speedy opening of a grand jury investigation of alleged vote frauds in his borough, obtaining a court order requiring the Board of Elections to turn over to him documents and "write-in" rolls of twenty-three election districts in which evidence of fraud has been indicated.

Antonio Scotti celebrated his sixty-seventh birthday yesterday in rooms filled with flowers, high up in the Hotel Vanderbilt, that had been his home for nearly half the thirty-three years he has spent in America. At his desk amid the bouquets, he opened telegrams and letters, then laid them in neat packets between portraits of Caruso before the war and of Gatti in the opera director's present jubilee year.

George Reith, chairman of the card committee of the Knickerbocker Whist Club, has been elected executive vice president of the United States Bridge Association, it was announced yesterday. At the same time he announced his intention of resigning from the executive committee of the American Bridge League.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 25. -- President-elect Roosevelt devoted himself today to study of how to cut down government expenses to help balance the budget and conferred tonight with Walker D. Hines, former Director General of Railroads, whom he is likely to ask to become Budget Director.

The Montclair A.C. carried off the Class C New Jersey group team squash tennis championship when it turned back the Essex Club players, 6 to 1, on its own courts in a Metropolitan Squash Tennis League encounter yesterday.

The Edison Medal for 1932 was presented last night at the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirty-ninth Street, to Bancroft Gherardi, vice president of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, for "his contributions to the art of telephone engineering and the development of electrical communication."

A program of unemployment reserves for American industry is to be proposed shortly in a report of the National Industrial Conference Board, it was announced yesterday. The board, whose policy has hitherto been to permit industry an opportunity voluntarily to set aside reserves for unemployment, now indicates that legislation of a compulsory character is in the offing.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- In an effort to discover whether there had been any change in the French position since the Chamber of Deputies refused to make the Dec. 15 debt payment to the United States, Ambassador Edge visited Premier Paul-Boncour at the Foreign Office this evening.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 25. -- Considerable thought was given to a "depression wardrobe" today as more than one hundred of the nation's fashion dictators sat behind closed doors to decide what men shall wear next Fall and Winter.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The text of the note from Secretary Stimson to the Foreign Minister of Peru on the Leticia situation, in the light of the Kellogg-Briand anti-war pact, follows:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 (AP). -- The formulation of a broad program of Federal relief for unemployed men and women and for communities in difficulties will be begun tomorrow by the Senate Manufactures Committee in the light of views its members have obtained from President-elect Roosevelt and in a vast amount of testimony taken in public hearings.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- Henri Guilbeaux, who is standing trial before a military tribunal on a wartime charge of treason for which he faces the death penalty, showed today as the questioning got under way that he intended to address his appeal to the whole nation.

Renewal of the five-year contract of the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company for refuse disposal in that borough will be opposed before the Board of Estimate next Tuesday by the Community Councils of the City of New York, Frank Peer Beal, executive secretary, said yesterday.
The Princeton Club and the Harvard Club scored clean sweeps in yesterday's squash racquets matches in the first group of the New York Division of the Metropolitan Class B League.

Total admitted assets of the Travelers Insurance Company, revealed at the annual meeting of stockholders yesterday in Hartford, were $674,492,525 on Dec. 31, while those of the Travelers Indemnity Company were $20,120,434 and those of the Travelers Fire Insurance Company were $16,054,586 -- a combined total of $710,667,545.
