PARIS, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Feminine frills were more evident in the fashion world in the second day's style shows today, which displayed the most feminine clothes Paris has produced in a decade.

When it was known that the great mathematician and physical astronomer was to speak on world economic conditions, everybody got his ears ready. Now we should hear something worth while. It might be hard to understand, but we could count on something absolutely new and highly scientific.

A "duel" between chain stores and their landlords which already has resulted in two injunctions temporarily restraining the Louis K. Liggrett Company, operators of 555 drug stores, and the Melville Shoe Corporation, which operates 502 stores, from going into bankruptcy, is being fought out in Philadelphia courts, Morris Wolf, Philadelphia attorney, said here yesterday in an interview.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., Jan. 25 (AP). -- With mattresses stuffed into a fifteen-foot rip in her side, the destroyer Dahlgren arrived afely in San Diego Bay today after a collision 300 miles at sea with the Tarbell, another vessel of the United States Navy scouting force.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The case of the Fir-Tex Insulating Board Company against the Lucken-bach Steamship Company, involving freight rates on Fir-Tex from Portland, Ore., to Atlantic Coast ports, was dismissed by the Shipping Board today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 25. -- Mrs. Peyton J. Van Rensselaer entertained tonight with the largest event of the season, a bal masque at Casa Rosada del Lago. Fairy lamps, clusters of rose and green glass grapes lighted from within by tapers, illumined the grounds and patio.
Flats and dwellings comprised the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

A pontifical mass celebrated by the Most Rev. John J. Dunn, Auxiliary Bishop of New York and administrator of the Archdiocese in the absence of Cardinal Hayes, marked the conclusion yesterday morning of the four-day celebration of the Diamond Jubilee of the founding of the Paulist Fathers and the Church of St. Paul the Apostle.

JERUSALEM, Jan. 25. -- Submitting to the pressure of the Palestine Government and Arab leaders, Emir Abdullah of Trans-Jordan today announced the cancellation of an agreement to lease 17,500 acres of his personal domain for a Jewish settlement.

Complete revision of the State of New Jersey's uniform bond act, popularly known as the Pierson model bond law, and drastic changes in existing laws of the State relating to municipal finance are undertaken in bills introduced this week in the Legislature.
LONDON, Jan. 25. -- The British hope their note, delivered to "Washington today, will end all talk of bargaining in connection with the impending war-debt discussions.

The Federal Government is undermining the confidence of the majority of the citizens through its operations in the business field in direct competition with private enterprise. Joseph B. Shannon, Representative at Large from Missouri and chairman of the House committee to investigate government competition with private enterprise, declared last night.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The future looked brighter today for the woman who gave Herbert Hoover his early schooling in the little town of West Branch, Iowa.

The summons charging obstruction of traffic that was handed to Magistrate David Hirshfield by Patrolman Thomas Conroy of Traffic B at Delancey and Norfolk Streets last Monday was voided yesterday at Police Headquarters.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Chairman T.V. O'Connor of the Shipping Board today appointed a committee of steamship owners, operators, builders and members of allied interests to consider the recommendations made at the recent national conference on the merchant marine.

ONEIDA, N.Y., Jan. 25 (AP). -- Fifty ice fishermen were swept out into treacherous Oneida Lake today when wind, whipping across the lake in a northwestern direction, broke up the ice that had been weakened by Springlike sunshine. Quick work by rescuers using almost every available small craft on that end of the lake made possible the rescue of most of the men within two hours after the ice had gone out.

All relief agencies in New York City, public and private, spent $7,726,000 for outdoor relief in December, as compared to $6,433,000 in November, an increase of $1,293,000 for the month, according to the Welfare Council's Coordinating Committee on Unemployment, which received the report yesterday from the research bureau of the council.
BERLIN, Jan. 25 (AP) -- The Rechsbank's statement as of Jan. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:
The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad refused yesterday to consider a voluntary reduction of commutation rates between Grand Central Terminal and points in Westchester County.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club, defending champion, and Edward Fagan of the Engineers Club continued in a tie for first place in the national amateur pocket billiard tourney in progress at the Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy yesterday.

After trailing throughout the first quarter and during the greater part of the second, the Union Temple basketball team rallied to defeat the New York Athletic Club, 37 to 28, in the Union Temple gymnasium last night. The victory was the fourth in a row for the winners and their eighth triumph in nine starts this season.

The 6,000-seat Roxy Theatre on Seventh Avenue at Fiftieth Street has slashed its admission prices to a 25 and 35-cent scale as part of a reorganized policy, which becomes effective tomorrow, according to an announcement made yesterday by Howard S. Cullman, representing the Roxy Theatres Corporation.

After rejecting an offer from Otto B. Shulhoff and his associates yesterday to lease the seven-block Chrystie-Forsyth Street area as a site for modern elevator apartments, the Sinking Fund Commission directed Board of Estimate engineers to prepare plans for the best development of the tract as a basis for competitive bids.

Documents filed here yesterday with Oscar W. Ehrhorn, as referee in bankruptcy, revealed that the Irving Trust Company, as trustee in bankruptcy for Ivar Kreuger's International Match Company, had Investigated the rumors that Kreuger was still alive and that a wax dummy had been sent to Stockholm for burial.

Almost no great novel of China stands alone and separate as a creation in itself, each being a collection of stories from history, story-tellers, court intrigue and drama. Mrs. Pearl S. Buck, novelist and missionary, declared in an address at a dinner given in her honor last night by the Women's University Club, 106 East Fifty-second Street, in cooperation with the New York branch of the American Association of University Women.

The performance of Wagner's Gotterdammerung last night in the Metropolitan Opera House must be accounted one of the best that New York audiences have seen in recent seasons. The presence of Frieda Leider and Maria Olszewska, especially Mme.
MONTE CARLO, Jan. 25. -- Cars of American make made a relatively good showing in the twelfth annual automobile rally, which ended today.

Ike Boone, who up to recently was the property of the Brooklyn Dodgers, turned in the best fielding average among the regular outfielders of the International League during the 1932 season, according to the official averages announced yesterday.

ALEXANDRIA, Va., Jan. 25. -- The constitutional authority of the Federal Power Commission to regulate and recapture without due compensation hydroelectric power projects was challenged today by Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson administration.

All the universities of the United States, even in the midst of their own financial troubles, must have special sympathy for the University of North Carolina, the oldest State university in the United States. It was chartered in the first year of WASHINGTON'S first Administration.

A Chinese celestial calendar year ended at 12:01 o'clock this morning as the head of a papier-mache dragon glided to the door of 41 Mott Street. The tail of the symbolical creature reached to the brownstone stairs of 33 Mott Street and slowly twisted as Willie Lee, who was once the laundryman of Mayor O'Brien, smiled benignly at voting Chinese Democrats.

The 1933 edition of the Directory of Directors of the City of New York, which was issued yesterday, contains the names and addresses of 40,000 directors. The numbers is slightly under that in last year's edition, it was announced. "In their search for economy, a number of corporations have reduced the size of their boards of directors."

Formation of protective committees for holders of two issues of dollar bonds of Colombian States was announced yesterday. The issues involved are Department of Cundinamarca secured 6 1/2s, due in 1959, outstanding in an amount of about $11,500,000, and Department of Cauca Valley secured 7 1/2s, due in 1946, outstanding in an amount of approximately $3,400,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- Senator Borah, who a few days ago stated that some inflationary measure was necessary to meet existing international and domestic trade conditions, told the Senate today in the midst of another debate on currency that something must be done to restore an "honest dollar" which will be fair to both debtor and creditor.

Rehearsals for "Both Your Houses," the Maxwell Anderson play which the Theatre Guild recently announced for production, are scheduled to start within a few days with Theresa Helburn and Lee Simonson constituting the production committee.

Mayor O'Brien warned the heads of city, county and borough government yesterday that unless they saved an additional $20,000,000 in the 1933 budget by Saturday he would slash the budget by that amount himself.
ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- The O'Connell brother of Albany today openly defied James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, by shutting him off from distribution of any of the State Senate patronage.
The Engineers Country Club at Roslyn, Long Island, scene of the national amateur championship in 1920 and one of the country's outstanding links, came to the end of its career last night.

DUBLIN, Thursday, Jan. 26. -- Returns from Tuesday's general election available at an early hour this morning indicate that President Eamon de Valera's Fianna Fail party will have a small majority in the Dail Eireann. With the support of the Laborites, Mr. de-Valera was regarded as virtually certain of control.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.

Christian B. Clark, former organist and choirmaster of the Church of the Transfiguration, "the Little Church Around the Corner," died Tuesday night of a heart attack at his home, 44 West Ninetieth Street, after a long illness. He was born in Brooklyn sixty-seven years ago.

ALBANY, Jan. 25. -- A Senate Finance Committee investigation of the use of unemployment relief funds in New York City was ordered today by the upper house of the Legislature. The committee at once made ready to hear next Wednesday officials of the Temporary Emergency Relief Administration and New York City organizations joining in relief.

The Chicago World's Fair will get the national outboard championships this year. That was decided yesterday at a meeting of the National Outboard Commission at the Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace. The title races will be held on Sept. 23, 24 and 25.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In dealing with technocracy is not THE TIMES becoming slightly ridiculous? Almost every one of your news items on the subject has seemed by choice of words and general tone to be either defensive or depreciatory.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25 -- A move by Chairman Smoot to extend the Senate Finance Committee's consideration of the 3.05 per cent beer and wine bill beyond the question of taxation was challenged tonight by Democratic members who are anxious to avoid delay on the measure.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation sent to the House late today, for presentation when that body convenes tomorrow, a report of all loans made from the time the agency began work on Feb. 2, 1932, to July 20, when publication of regular reports became a monthly custom.

CHICAGO, Jan. 25. -- Spreading operations in wheat between here and Winnipeg, as well as between the various deliveries, furnished a good part of the trade in that grain today. The bulls had unfavorable crop comments on "Winter wheat in their favor, but the news had little effect.

The New York Stock Exchange will strike from its list at the close of business on Monday the American certificates for Kreuger Toll Company participating debentures, it was announced yesterday. Counsel for the depository advised that the transfer books would be closed at the end of business on Tuesday.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 25. -- Both Bolivian and Paraguayan communiques assert the battle for possession of Fort Nanawa, or Ayala, is the most sanguinary in the entire Chaco war, far surpassing eithar Boqueron or Saavedra in casualties to the other side.

To the Editor of The New York Times: From time to time we hear protests against cruelty or cowardice in sports. It may be against bull-fighting, fox-hunting or some other such diversion of interest to an element of society.

The Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies and the advisory and consultative work it is doing for seventy-nine affiliated agencies were praised yesterday afternoon by Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President-elect, at the twelfth annual meeting of the federation at the home of Miss Louise G. Zabriskie, 1,185 Park Avenue.

The monthly average of copper shipments to consumers for the last three months in all foreign countries except Canada is placed at 62,524 short tons by the American Bureau of Metal Statistics. One month ago the average for the three preceding months was 61,649 tons, two months ago 62,619 and three months ago 61,539.

DRESDEN, Germany, Jan. 25. -- Nine Communists were slain and eleven seriously wounded by police attempting to disperse a Communist indoor meeting here today. The gathering was one of scores conducted throughout the Reich in connection with the huge Red demonstration in Berlin.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange moved little in either direction yesterday and ended with losses of 1 to 4 points. For the first time in many months, quotations in Liverpool finished unchanged on the day. Similar quiet trading marked other commodity markets here.

Unable to attend his neighborhood public school because of a rheumatic heart, Sidney Bandklader, 14 years old, nevertheless expected to receive his diploma as a public school graduate yesterday in the children's ward of the Hospital for Joint Diseases.
An increased demand for space in the garment centre district was indicated by the large number of new rentals in that section yesterday.

The return to the Metropolitan repertoire of Smetana's "Bartered Bride" after an absence of five years, the second performance in the Wagner matinee cycle and the return of Lauri-Volpi after his recent illness will mark the eleventh week of the opera season next week.

PARIS, Jan. 25. -- Paris today was in a state verging on unofficial siege while various groups were demonstrating or attempting to demonstrate against the budget proposals that will come before the Chamber of Deputies tomorrow.

Sandy Somerville was In town yesterday, not as the United States amateur golf champion, not as the man who beat Johnny Goodman in a spectacular up-hill final round battle at Five Farms last Fall, nor as the second foreign golfer in history to win the American crown, but as plain C. Ross Somerville, young London (Ont.), business man.

BOSTON, Jan. 25. -- Dr. William Phillips Graves, Professor Emeritus of Gynecology at the Harvard Medical School and famous surgeon, died here today of pneumonia at his home, 244 Marlboro Street. He had practiced here for many years, was the author of several important medical books and had received honors from medical societies here and abroad because of his surgical skill and knowledge of medicine.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Jan. 25. -- Mrs. Alice Grantham, a widow, of New York City, filed suit in Superior Court here today against Harold L. Knapp of Greenwich, administrator of the estate of Harry Van Ness of Greenwich, asking specific performance of a $100,000 trust deed or damages of $100,000 for alleged breach of a "companionship" agreement with Mr. Van Ness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- The President-elect has decided to form an advisory committee, composed of Democratic members of the next Congress, to keep him informed daily of sentiment in that body as to war-debt revision in general and the details of revision as they develop.

BUFFALO, Jan. 25 (AP). -- Buffalo Democratic leaders want the widow of Norman E. Mack, Mrs. Harriet Mack, named Democratic National Committeewoman for New York State, filling the vacancy caused by Elisabeth Marbury's death.

John Graham was not his name to begin with. The artist now exhibiting at the Eighth Street Gallery, whose work has long been familiar to New Yorkers, was born in Russia in 1891 and, the catalogue relates, was educated at the University of Kiev, where he polished off with an LL.D.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 25. -- An audience representative of official, diplomatic and social circles welcomed today Miss Myra Hess, English pianist, and Hans Kindler, 'cellist, at Mrs. Lawrence Townsend's Musical Morning at the May-flower.

The Rev. Dr. Frederic Sydney Fleming was instituted yesterday morning in Trinity Church, Broad way at Wall Street, as the twelfth rector of Trinity Parish, the oldest Protestant Episcopal church in the city. It was organized by royal charter 236 years ago. A few weeks ago Dr. Fleming was inducted at a civic ceremony as the rector.
PROVIDENCE, R.I., Jan. 25. -- Yale's hockey forces routed Brown University to score an overwhelming 11-to-0 victory over the Bruins at the Rhode Island Auditorium tonight.

LITTLE ROCK, Ark., Jan. 25 (AP). -- A treasure hunt in which the American Red Cross had the charts and did the digging today had netted some $6,000 in gold and currency from hiding places on the North Arkansas farm of R.F. Leigh, aged recluse, who suffered torture and hanging rather than reveal his secret to any one else.

The foreclosure auction of the twenty-two-story Victoria Hotel, at the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Fifty-first Street, was adjourned yesterday to Feb. 24. The hotel was listed for sale at the stand of Joseph P. Day as a result of proceedings brought by the Chase National Bank, as trustee, against the Max Kurzrock Realty Company.
Twelve Manhattan and Bronx properties were listed for sale at foreclosure auctions yesterday. All were struck down to the plaintiffs except two, which will be offered at later dates.

Chief Justice WILLIAM S. GUMMERE of the Supreme Court of New Jersey, who died at Newark yesterday, was a great lawyer, who made law from the bench in leading cases, fearless in the discharge of his duty, original and independent in reasoning.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 26 (AP). -- William J. Bingham, director of Harvard athletics, tonight said he would sound out Eastern rowing colleges on the Los Angeles proposal to stage a national championship regatta on the Olympic course at Long Beach.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 26. -- Week-end conversation at Nanking, in which Chiang Kais-shek, Chang Hsiaoliang Tuan Chi-jui, Lo Wen-kan, Dr. T.V. Soong and other prominent leaders participated, resulted in a decision that China should adhere to its policy of trusting the League of Nations.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 26. -- Delegates of the Argentine Agrarian Union, meeting at La Rosa in Santa Fe Province, voted today for a nation-wide farmers' strike beginning next Wednesday, including the suspending of all work connected with plowing or harvesting until the national and provincial governments accept the relief program drawn up at today's meeting.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- France was "very unwise and foolish not to pay the United States the small sum of $19,000,000 last Dec. 15," said Raymond Recouly, author and former French diplomat, in an address at the weekly luncheon of the American Club today.

It is very pleasant, in the midst of the Wagnerian splendors which the Metropolitan has been revealing to us, to be reminded that much delightful music lies in the vales below these august peaks, and that Jules Massenet could contrive garden plots and nosegays of song which we would be very loath to do without.

Into the board room of the United States Steel Corporation, where the policies governing an annual production of more than $700,000,000 of steel and cement are decided, an attentive secretary yesterday conducted the Mayor of Cleveland, the pastor of a Roman Catholic Church in the Newburg section of that city and three of its municipal Councilmen to oppose a dollar-and-cents decision of the corporation with arguments based upon humanity and sentiment.

Gerhard M. Dahl, chairman of the Brooklyn-Manhattan Transit Corporation, filed an answer in the Supreme Court yesterday in the suit of Paul Blanshard, as owner of one share of stock, to compel him and William S. Menden, president of the company, to return to the corporation money voted to them as additional compensation between 1928 and 1931.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- A virtual demand on behalf of the New York Central Railroad that the State declare a "substantial moratorium" on its $350,000,000 program for the elimination of dangerous grade-crossings was voiced today at a hearing before Governor Lehman on the huge project involving removal of the New York Central tracks from a Syracuse street.

GENEVA, Jan. 26. -- The League Council spent this afternoon trying to prevent oil from causing a rupture between Great Britain and Persia. It grot no further than hearing thousands of words and arguments, in which both sides demonstrated to their own satisfaction the inaccuracy of the other's figures in regard to the Anglo-Persian Oil Company concession.

American sportsmen would find it difficult to believe stories of the tremendous abundance of native upland game birds of other years were it not for the writings of sportsmen and ornithologists of an earlier period. In our pioneer days, America had a greater number and variety of such birds than any country in the world.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Tobacco tax collections in 1932 amounted to $387,271,269, as compared with $424,532,735 in 1931 and the peak of $449,016,098 in 1929, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 26. -- In a bold move to save intercollegiate rowing from the tidal wave of sports curtailment, action was started today to stage a national championship over the Olympic course at Long Beach early in June.
MEXICO CITY, Jan. 24. -- As from Feb. 1 all money sent to Mexico in contravention of local legislation will be confiscated. The previous procedure was to return the money to the point of dispatch.

Combining squash racquets with their cross-country cruising flight, seven aviators from March Field in Riverside, Cal., defeated a seven-man New York A.C. team, 6 to 1, yesterday at the New York A.C. for their sixth squash racquets victory in as many matches during their transcontinental air journey.

Eric Ny, Sweden's great middle-distance runner, arrived yesterday on the United States liner Leviathan completely fortified for an American track and field campaign by "scrimmage" workouts in Stockholm before his departure.

Retail Statements Are Issued. With the flood of year-end statements from retailers reaching their peak, the financial data revealed about measures up to expectations, reports here yesterday indicated. Last year's operations resulted in operating loss for many stores and this loss is shown in a reduction of capital.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Forbra, surprise winner of the Grand National last year, today paid the price of victory with the announcement of the weights for the steeplechase classic, which will be renewed over the treacherous four-mile Aintree course on March 24.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Jan. 25, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,080,000,000, a decrease of $24,000,000 compared with the preceding week and an increase of $267,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- The Boerse turnover shrunk today to such small dimensions that little significance attached to price changes. These kept within relatively narrow limits, and although the tendency was rather weak, numerous stocks closed at or above yesterday's final levels.
PARIS, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

Interrupted in the midst of his supper last evening by the cries of neighboring barber's two daughters, Patrolman Leopold Colantuono of 451 Union Street, Brooklyn, ran outdoors with his service pistol, turned into Bond Street, and, after a brief chase, shot and seriously wounded one of two men who allegedly had just held up the barber's shop, taking $5 from the cash register and $25 from five customers.
Detailed plans for a public dinner in honor of Dr. Albert Einstein in the Hotel Commodore on March 15 are to be made at a luncheon of the American Friends of the Hebrew University today.

Regardless of the plea of his lawyer that a sentence to a State's prison would be tantamount to his assassination by other convicts as a "squealer," Alexander Munro, 46 years old, an ex-convict, received a five-year term in Sing Sing yesterday from Judge Koenig in General Sessions on his plea of guilty to forgery.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26. -- The Mary- land Jockey Club, which conducts racing at Pimlico, will schedule eight races each day at the coming Spring meeting. There will be $117,900 available in stake and purse money, despite the reduction of the Preakness value by $25,000, according to an announcement made today by Secretary M.L. Daiger.

In a sweeping gesture which indicated unrelenting firmness in respect to its restrictions on gratuities, the New York Stock Exchange yesterday imposed suspensions ranging from one month to three years on six of its members. Not in many years has the Exchange at one time deprived so many members of their trading privileges.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As a student of government, with a twenty-four years' background as Mayor of a medium-sized city, I have watched with interest the new movement for a change in the government of the City of New York, which, if carried to a successful conclusion, would have a great influence elsewhere.

Don Brennan, right-handed hurler of the Newark Bears, who is expected to make a strong bid for a regular berth with the New York Yankees this Spring, was the outstanding pitcher in the International League for the 1932 season, according to the official averages released for publication today.
The Leticia dispute threatens the peace of all South America, according to John Barrett, former United States Minister to Colombia and former director general of the Pan American Union.

A plan for refunding the $14,250,000 outstanding unmatured bonds of the Imperial Irrigation District, California, all of which went into total interest default on Jan. 1, was made public here yesterday by the bondholders' protective committee headed by Charles J. Lick.
MONTREAL, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Two players from the United States and two from Canada reached the semifinal round of the Canadian indoor tennis championships today.

The State Education Department is considering a complete revision of the syllabus for citizenship and patriotism in public schools and colleges, according to a report of the State Board of Regents in answer to an inquiry from the National Self-Government Committee as to what the board was doing "in the line of more direct and efficient attention to training citizens to secure a people's government able to meet economic and political problems more satisfactorily."

Paul R. Heyl, a physicist since 1920 in the United States Bureau of Standards, is the author of "The Philosophy of a Scientific Man," published today by Vanguard. He surveys religious and philosophical thought and gives his own conclusions.
A mortgage for $7,000 held by the Citizens' Savings Bank from Samuel Strom on 36 Catharine St. has been extended to Nov. 15, 1937, at 5 1/2 per cent.

Australia's success in economic readjustment under the "Premiers' Plan" suggests that a "Governors' Plan" along similar lines might be helpful to the United States, David M. Dow, Official Secretary for Australia in this country, proposed yesterday, "with no intention of impertinence," in addressing the British Luncheon Club of New York at 53 Broadway, during a celebration of Australia Day.

Verdict for $1,090,095 damages against the City of New York and $4,340 against the Interborough Rapid Transit Company was returned by a jury before Supreme Court Justice Henry G. Wenzel Jr. in Brooklyn yesterday in favor of the Newman Carey Company, subway contractors.

Twenty-five fencers competed last night at the New York A.C. in the qualifying matches for the national junior epee championship tournament. At the end of a lively evening of competition, eight survived for the final round.
LONDON, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- An assault on prohibition enforcement by curtailing its appropriation by 50 per cent or more, and limiting the use of the remaining supply funds for the fiscal year 1934, was being planned today by the wet organizations of the House.

S. Howard Cohen, president of the Board of Elections, was one of three witnesses questioned before the New York County grand jury yesterday in its investigation of frauds and irregularities at the polls in the elections last November.

The Committee on Character and Fitness of the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court made public yesterday a list of 141 applicants for admission to the bar, including five women, who have been directed to appear before the committee.

Jumping far ahead of the schedule which he originally had set for himself, Secretary Tierney of the Giants, who appears to be about the only baseball secretary who is not loaded down with woes and cares these days, bobbed up with no fewer than three signed contracts yesterday.

A plan whereby property owners may help unemployed men and at the same time obtain the professional services of landscape architects has been worked out by the New York Chapter, American Society of Landscape Artists, 101 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Annette Hoyt Flanders, chairman of the society's unemployment relief committee.

Renting of stores for selling to the retail trade was reported on a large scale yesterday. Shops were taken in scattered sections of the city, and this form of renting was supplemented by many other business leases, including some entire floors.

A plan whereby property owners may help unemployed men and at the same time obtain the professional services of landscape architects has been worked out by the New York Chapter, American Society of Landscape Artists, 101 Park Avenue, it was announced yesterday by Annette Hoyt Flanders, chairman of the society's unemployment relief committee.

Renting of stores for selling to the retail trade was reported on a large scale yesterday. Shops were taken in scattered sections of the city, and this form of renting was supplemented by many other business leases, including some entire floors.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Great Britain's $95,550,000 payment on her war debt to the United States in December, made in gold, marked the principal change in the European gold reserves for that month, the Federal Reserve Board said in its monthly bulletin today.
HARTFORD, Conn., Jan. 26. -- Dr. Ansel Granville Cook, noted orthopedic surgeon and inventor of several surgical appliances, died last night of heart disease.

HAVANA, Jan. 26. -- Eighteen boats, four of which were American craft and two British, sailed today in the first race of the Bacardi Trophy series for Star Class yachts over a ten-mile triangular course off the Havana Yacht Club. The Cuban yacht Mara, sailed by F.S. Bru. was the victor.

A further unseasonable advance of $9,000,000 in the volume of money in circulation occurred this week, following a rise of $13,000,000 last week, the report of the Federal Reserve System, covering the week ended on Wednesday, showed yesterday.

Jumping far ahead of the schedule which he originally had set for himself, Secretary Tierney of the Giants, who appears to be about the only baseball secretary who is not loaded down with woes and cares these days, bobbed up with no fewer than three signed contracts yesterday.

DETROIT, Jan. 26. -- Because of a strike in the Briggs Manufacturing Company's plant here, which with the Murray Corporation of America has been supplying bodies for Ford cars, the Ford Motor Company shut down completely this afternoon.

Robert Cole scored his initial vic- tory in the national amateur pocket-billiard tournament in progress at Lawler Brothers' Manhat- tan Academy by administering a third defeat to Edward A. Widt- man. New York, 125 to 43, in fifty innings last night.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- Municipalities would be authorized to issue ten-year emergency unemployment relief bonds under a bill introduced today by Assemblyman Steingut, Democratic leader of the lower house. At present these bonds are payable within five years.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Whenever the subject of proper English conies up and you give space to some very learned men as to how she should be spoken, there appears to be a great deal of cynicism attempted by these wise grammarians, and many of them are adepts at sarcasm.

Seaman Tom Watson, holder of the British featherweight championship, will make a bid for a chance at the world's title in the 126-pound class tonight when he opposes Fidel La Barba of California in the feature bout of twelve rounds at Madison Square Garden.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 26. -- The Russian project of expanding and improving communications in the northern districts, particularly near Finland, is much more extensive than has been previously realized.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Re-establishment of the world monetary system on a gold basis and progressive abolition of trade barriers through concerted international action were advocated as the chief requisites to economic recovery by Clement Moret, governor of the Bank of France, in his annual report to stockholders today.

Shortly before 3 o'clock this morning Assistant District Attorney William S. McGuiness of Kings County announced at the Gates Avenue police station in Brooklyn that Lloyd Price, a 22-year-old Negro, had confessed to the murder of Helen Sterler, 6-year-old girl, whose strangled body was found early Wednesday morning in the basement of a tenement house at 1,013 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn.

The dragons of good omen writhed through Chinatown yesterday, taking the tribute that is theirs by tradition on the first day of the ancient Celustial new year. Drums sounded, there were feasting and fasting, debts were settled and the Kitchen God, with its mouth sealed, went to heaven to report to the Ruler of the World.

Henry W. Taft, former president of the State Bar Association, declared yesterday that irresponsible political leaders had rendered unsatisfactory the popular election of high judicial officers and suggested that the power of appointment be restored to the Governor.
PARIS, Jan. 26. -- In two long sessions the Chamber of Deputies today debated with considerable political heat the tangled problem of French finances.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Representative Hamilton Fish Sr., high ranking Republican member of the House Foreign Affairs Committee, received a letter today from Secretary Stimson observing that the Platt amendment placed no obligation upon the United States to intervene in Cuba and citing former War Secretary Root's assurance that the amendment did not give this government the right to interfere in the affairs of Cuba.

Forty-two minutes after Judge Levine had placed the case in its hands last evening, a jury in General Sessions returned a verdict of first degree murder against Giuseppi Leonti, 40 years old, for the stabbing of his 19-year-old daughter, Anna, a bride of eleven days, in their home at 248 Broome Street last April 3.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- The despatch from Warm Springs, Ga., giving an authoritative denial of reports that President-elect Roosevelt has a representative in Europe was supplemented today in London by the reiteration of the official statement to the effect that neither Prime Minister MacDonald nor any other member of the British Government has seen or received a communication from any emissary of Mr. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Welker Cochran, the balkline wizard from California, smothered Clarence Jackson of Detroit, 50 to 26, in forty innings tonight to go back into a tie with J.N. Bozeman Jr. of Vallejo, Cal., for first place in the world's championship three-cushion billiard tournament.

"D.S.," a cheery little magazine described as the official organ of the Sanitation Department, made its bow yesterday replete with, inspirational verse to guide the struggling street sweeper on his arduous rounds and many gossipy "personals" designed to improve the personal relations of the employes.

Senator Huey Long leaned back in a red leather easy chair in a suite in the New Yorker Hotel yesterday and told how easy it was, with the aid of the Bible and a little Negro philosophy, to rearrange the economic structure of the nation and banish depression forever.

The next metal age for our civilization, which began with the iron age and evolved to the present chrome-alloy era, will be the aluminum age, the annual Winter convention of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers was told yesterday by Professor Colin G. Fink, head of the division of electro-chemistry, Columbia University.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Stop Gap, a 6-year-old gelding from F.P. Letellier's barns which started forty-nine times last year, outstepped a band of platers in the mile and a sixteenth test which featured the card of claiming races at the Fair Grounds today.

Deaths Under Suspicion. Testimony was read into court proceedings here the other day to the effect that IVAR KREUGER did indeed die by his own hand in Paris and that a wax dummy was not sent to Stockholm with the connivance of the French police.

Speaking last night over the radio from Station WJZ, Baron Richard von Kuehlmann, former Foreign Minister of Germany, declared that the most striking observation for any one who comes to the United States from Germany is the great difference between the moderate and confident optimism which, for the time being, is pervading large parts of Germany and the comparative gloom and discouragement which seems to overshadow the United States.

DUBLIN, Friday, Jan. 27. -- At 1 o'clock this morning Eamon de Valera's Kianna Fail party had definitely captured fifty-two seats in the Dail Eireann, William T. Cosgrave's Cumann na nGaedheal party had won thirty-one, and the new Centre party had obtained six, the Independents eight and the Labor party six.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A bill providing $500,000,000 for outright unemployment relief grants to States, instead of relief loans such as have been authorized heretofore, went on the Senate calendar today, backed by the votes of a majority of the Manufacturers Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Over the protests of organized business, prominent banking authorities and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, that agency's complete record of financial assistance to 4,704 institutions in every State in the Union from the time of its establishment on Feb. 2, 1932, to July 21, 1932, was laid before the American public today by the House of Representatives.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Important changes in the territory operated by the Baltimore Ohio Railroad, including consolidation of divisions, were announced today by C.W. Galloway, vice president in charge of operation and maintenance.

BERLIN, Jan. 26. -- Chancellor Kurt von Schleicher today demanded the submission of full evidence on last night's clash in Dresden in which the police, breaking up a Communist mass meeting, shot and killed nine Reds and wounded eight, including three women.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- The military tribunal that la trying Henri Guilbeaux on a charge of trafficking with the enemy during the World War heard a remarkable series of tributes to the prisoner from many French Intellectuals today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Farmers of the country will have an opportunity to express their views before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee on the $1,500,000,000 "emergency farm credit" program introduced yesterday by Senator Robinson, Democratic leader.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a spirit of pleasantry but nevertheless seriously, may I refer to the press dispatch in this morning's TIMES to the effect that "Franklin D. Roosevelt will lose almost $9,000 as a result of the Twentieth Amendment."

Compulsory healh insurance, as outlined in the majority report of the Committee on the Costs of Medical Care, was warmly debated by two prominent members of the committee last night at the closing session of the Regional Conference on Social Hygiene at the George Washington Hotel, Twenty-third Street and Lexington Avenue.

By contrast with the inaction in the stock market, domestic corporation bonds gave a confident exhibition of firmness yesterday. Reactionary influences were at work, however, in most of the other markets.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 26. -- Governor A. Harry Moore and several jurists paid tribute today to the memory of Chief Justice Gummere, as follows:

THE British stone is equivalent to fourteen pounds, and thereby hangs a tale. Every time an English fighter comes over here the old story comes up. Seaman Watson is the latest pretext for finding sermons in stones. As far as boxing is concerned, either there is some peculiar property in English stones or some old racial trait in English fighters.

The commission named by Governor Lehman, as authorized by the Legislature, to formulate a State plan for liquor control in the event of the repeal or modification of prohibition, began its study of the problems involved yesterday at the Hotel Park Lane.

TROY, N.Y., Jan. 26 (AP). -- Professor William Lispenard Robb, head of the Department of Electrical Engineering at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute since 1902, died here early today from congestion of the lungs at the age of 71.

Boston, Mass. The City of Boston announced yesterday its initial financing in anticipation of 1933 taxes and revenues. Bids are to be opened at noon on Monday for an issue of $2,000,000 of notes dated Feb. 1 and due on Oct. 2.
"Marathon," a play by Isabel Dawn and Boyce DeGaw, will open tonight at the Mansfield Theatre. "The Taming of the Shrew" will also be added this evening to the repertory of the Shakespeare Theatre.

With American foreign trade already at the lowest level since 1905, most of the Republicans and some of the Democrats in the House of Representatives are clamoring for still higher tariffs. They are disturbed by the circumstance of which Mr. HOOVER made much in the last days of his campaign -- the possibility that countries with depreciated currencies may "flood" our markets with their goods.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Seventeen boats finished today's opening race in the Bacardi Trophy series. The craft, in the order of finish, the club or fleet each represents, the skipper and the elapsed time follow:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Democrats, in control of Congress and determined to await Franklin D. Roosevelt's direction on all matters affecting foreign trade, stood impervious tonight to a concerted Republican drive for higher tariff protection and gave it no chance for enactment.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Table VIII of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's report gives the statement of condition during December:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- "No note tonight," said Secretary Stimson as he hurried away from the State Department late today after having spent an hour with Professor Raymond Holey, war debts representative of President-elect Roosevelt, in drafting a reply to the British memorandum received yesterday with reference to the debt and economic discussions scheduled for early in March in Washington.

A sixty-mile-an-hour gale that roared in from the ocean hammered the coast from New York to North Carolina early yesterday, stranding several vessels, tossing small pleasure boats about like chips, pounding jetties, piers and boardwalks into twisted wreckage and sweeping three New York pilots to death in the surf off Long Branch, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Faced with what appeared tonight to be an even more stubborn resistance than it encountered during the last few stormy weeks in the Senate, the Glass banking reform bill, according to some Republican members, seemed destined to die in the House Banking and Currency Committee unless President-elect Roosevelt himself takes an active part in attempting to force action in the next five weeks.

CHICAGO, Jan. 26. -- Sufficient selling of wheat developed today at 48 1/2 cents a bushel and above for the May future to check any tendency to advance on the Board of Trade here except for a brief period at the start, when prices were fractionally higher and at the best figures since the middle of the month.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 26. -- The first four seeded players won their quarter-final round matches in the all-South singles tennis championship on the Miami-Biltmore courts today. George Lott of Chicago, three times national doubles champion and member of four United States Davis Cup teams, was the only participant compelled to play three sets in order to emerge triumphant.

George O. Arkin, Assistant Corporation Counsel, appeared yesterday under a subpoena before a Federal grand jury to explain why he authorized the Police Department last October to surrender $18,645, against which the government had filed a lien, to a lieutenant of Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer runner, wanted for income-tax evasion.
Among the passengers arriving today from Hamburg and Channel ports on the Hamburg-American liner Albert Ballin are:

Although the list of those who will try for North American figure skating championships at the Ice Club and at Madison Square Garden on Feb. 10 and 11 is not yet complete, it is certain that the leading men and women skaters from the United States and Canada will be at hand.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- There were more bank failures in the United States in 1932 than in any similar period in history, except in 1931, according to figures made public today by the Federal Reserve Board.

Taxpayers' strikes may result from failure to reduce the cost of government and taxation, according to warnings sounded by speakers at yesterday's sessions of the annual Eastern Regional Savings Conference of the American Bankers Association, Savings Division, at the Waldorf-Astoria.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt disclosed yesterday that she has received thousands of letters advising her to disassociate herself from all the organizations with which she now is connected.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Tributes to Mrs. Oliver H.P. Belmont on behalf of the National Woman's party, of which she had been president and to which she devoted much of her energy and contributed a large share of her fortune, was voiced here today by Mrs. Florence Bayard Hilles, chairman, and Doris Stevens, member of the advisory council.

The death of Mrs. OLIVER BELMONT, following so closely upon that of Miss ELISABETH MARBURY, will recall to many the successive phases of the fight for woman's suffrage in this country. To that movement both gave an impetus through their personal energy, their indomitable hopefulness, their social position and their political skill.
Paul V. Coletti has been appointed manager of the insurance department in the office of Edward A. Kelly, 14 West Kingsbridge Rd.

COMSTOCK, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Knives flashed in the yard of Great Meadow prison here this morning in a flare-up between two groups of New York gangsters serving long sentences and, before keepers could stop the brawl, three of the six participants were wounded, one fatally.

The Fisk University Choir of sixty voices made its first New York appearance last night in Car negie Hall. This choir is a descendant of the smaller body from Fisk University which began its career in 1871 and quickly gained international reputation, especially for its performance of Negro spirituals, under the title of the Fish Jubilee Singers.

Announcement that the Delaware Hudson has purchased a tenth interest in the stock of the New York Central has various implications. Its bearing on the question of future railway combination and railway control is problematical; its bearing on recent railway history and on the possible railway future is interesting.

HAVANA, Jan. 26 (AP). -- S.S. Friedlein's Quorum, making his first start of the Winter turf season, came through with a head victory over Indicative in the five and one-half furlong feature at Oriental Park today.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 26. -- Establishment of two governmental bureaus, one of transportation and the other of communications, is being considered by President-elect Roosevelt as part of his consolidation and economy program. will probably be set up as independent agencies instead of being placed in one of the existing governmental departments.

Eastern shippers completed their case in opposition to the proposal of the Eastern and Western railroads for a revision of freight rates to Western trunk line territory yesterday before examiners of the Interstate Commerce Commission at the Hotel New Yorker.

PARIS, Jan. 26. -- Some light was thrown today on the causes of successive burnings of French liners at sea, by the publication in the newspaper Paris Midi of what it alleges to be the text of the report of the committee of inquiry into the destruction of the Georges Philippar in the Gulf of Aden last May.
PARIS, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Little girl styles for sophisticated debutantes were featured today in the Spring fashion shows of some of the smaller houses.
Sugar and silk futures were irregularly higher yesterday, but the other commodities traded on local exchanges continued to fall. Trading in nearly all cases was quiet.

HAMBURG, Jan. 26. -- At a joint session today of the governing boards of the Hamburg-American and North German Lloyd Steamship Companies, Marius Boeger, vice chairman of the former line since 1926, was appointed its chairman to succeed the late Dr. Wilhelm Cuno.

A decrease of $1,982,400 in the monetary gold stocks of the country was indicated in yesterday's daily gold report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which showed a loss of $2,001,100 through the net increase of that amount in the gold earmarked for foreign account and an import of $18,700 from Mexico.

BOWLING GREEN, Ohio, Jan. 26 (AP). -- Eight hundred grim-faced Wood County farmers silenced a finance company bidder by their numbers today, bought about $800 worth of a neighbor's property at auction for $14, and told him to keep it.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Jan. 26. -- Arthur I. Vorys, 76 years old, attorney, who as Jake Vorys organized sentiment more than twenty years ago for William Howard Taft in his campaign for the Presidency, died in his home here today.

The so-called "buy-American" idea was criticized yesterday by Professors Edmund E. Day and John H. Williams, United States delegates to the preparatory commission of experts for the international Monetary and Economic Conference, who returned on the United States liner Leviathan.

BOSTON, Jan. 26. -- Dr. George Howard Monks, former surgeon-in-chief of the Boston City Hospital, one-time lecturer on surgery at the Harvard Medical School and a noted writer on medical subjects, died today at his home here. He was 79 years old.

Charles Hovey Pepper, like some other members of the public, has been disillusioned about statesmen, as his one-man exhibition at the Fifteen Gallery amply proves. The chief difference between this artist and his fellow-sufferers is that while their disenchantment is often mute, his is eloquent.

The proposed merger of the General Aviation Corporation, an affiliate of the General Motors Corporation, and North American Aviation, Inc., holding companies with assets of more than $25,000,000, calls for the acquisition of General Aviation's assets by North American, officers of the companies said yesterday.

Elsie de Wolfe Mendl, wife of Sir Charles Mendl of Paris, was named chief beneficiary of the will of Elisabeth Marbury, noted leader in theatrical, literary and political life of this city, who died last Sunday in her seventy-seventh year, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogates Court.

SPRING VALLEY, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Wisps of smoke rising from behind a boulder seventy-five feet east of the new Nyack Turnpike-Saddle River crossroad in Viola disclosed today the murder of an unidentified woman whose body, concealed behind the rock, had been set afire and partly destroyed.

Radical departures in airplane design with emphasis on the study of rotating wings, the application of present designs to planes for seven and eight miles a minute speeds in the stratosphere and the charting of ocean flying weather were among the topics which occupied 100 leading designers and engineers in American aviation yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 26. -- Jockey Buddy Hanford and Trainer Hirsch Jacobs scored triples at Hialeah Park today, Hanford winning with Miss Corinne, Bank Shot and Wishing Star. The two last named were saddled by Jacobs, who made it three in a row by sending out Recede in the nightcap.

Winning the approval of the Interstate Commerce Commission for him to join the New York Central Railroad's board is the next problem that L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, must solve in making concrete the 10 per cent share of control which his company has purchased in the trunk line, it was asserted in railroad circles yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The Harrison resolution proposing an exhaustive study of economic ills and remedies by the Senate Finance Committee as a basis for legislative action by the next Congress was adopted by the Senate today without a dissenting vote.

Much of the romance of deep water and much of the seamanlike efficiency of the age of sail has gone with the passing of the square-riggers, Felix Riesenberg, master mariner in sail and steam, writes in "Log of the Sea" -- saltwater sketches of fifty years of storm and calm, which was published yesterday by Harcourt, Brace Co.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 26. -- Specific Federal measures to relieve the railroads of three of their "burdens" were advocated today in a talk with newspaper men by Walker D. Hines, war-time director general of railroads and reported to be President-elect Roosevelt's choice for Director of the Budget.

The preventive measures of the pre-school clinic of the BellevueYorkville Health Demonstration were described yesterday by its medical director, Dr. Margaret Witter Barnard, at the sixtieth annual meeting of the New York Diet Kitchen Association in the National Society of Colonial Dames, 215 East Seventy-first Street.

Increases in total mileage flown, miles of routes operated, passengers and express carried and other gains in commercial aviation were reported yesterday to the members of the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America, representing 95 per cent of the aircraft and aircraft-engine manufacturers and 99 per cent of the air transport operators of the United States, at their annual meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

GENEVA, Jan. 26. -- The Council of the League of Nations threw its weight this morning on the side of Colombia in the Leticia conflict, debated before it on the request of Peru. The president of the Council, in telegrams sent to both States, implicitly took Colombia's view that its Amazonian military-naval expedition was a legitimate move to restore domestic order.

When Mr. CURRY sought his up-State allies in his war, so sagaciously begun and planned, against the nomination of Mr. ROOSEVELT as President and Mr. LEHMAN as Governor, it was clear to all observers that he had found cooperators worthy of himself.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Holiday demands on the Federal Reserve Banks for currency during December amounted to only about $120,000,000, as compared with totals ranging in recent years from $225,000,000 to $275,000,000. This was attributed by the board in its monthly bulletin, issued today to a continued return of money from hoarding, to gold imports and to lower prices of merchandise.

Mayor O'Brien moved last night to block passage of the bankruptcy and currency bill now pending in the House of Representatives on the ground that it would reduce the value of city tax liens on real estate if passed.

ALBANY, Jan. 26. -- James A. Farley arrived here today prepared to compel the ousting of twenty-two Senate employes selected by the O'Connell brothers, up-State allies of Tammany. In their place, choices of the national and State chairmen are to be substituted.

New Jersey and Long Island have in the past been rivals for the favors of Manhattan. Hoboken and Newark are accustomed to compete with Brooklyn and Jamaica Bay for the commerce, actual and potential, that overflows the Manhattan waterfront.

Modification of the prohibition law, with the national government retaining control of liquor, was favored last night by George W. Wickersham, chairman of President Hoover's Law Enforcement Commission, in an interview before he sailed on the Cunard liner Berengaria for a two months' business trip abroad.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Challenging members of the Senate, particularly of his own party, to stand up and be counted for the economies they have been preaching since the Chicago conventions, Senator Tydings presented a resolution today calling for immediate steps toward bringing the appropriations to be voted by this Congress within the government's income for the fiscal year 1934.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., Jan. 26. -- Summarized financial statements of the Glens Falls Insurance Company, the Commerce Insurance Company and the Glens Falls Indemnity Company, as of Jan. 1, were announced tonight.

An effort to establish a uniform arrangement whereby the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would advance funds to mortgage companies in New York City to enable them to refund maturing mortgages instead of, as at present, leaving it to individual companies to seek assistance as their needs arise on the basis of individual borrowings, has been undertaken by local title and mortgage companies.

HAVANA, Jan. 26. -- John T. Wilford, American publisher of The Havana American News, who filed a protest at the United States Embassy on Jan. 13 against the military censorship, was advised today by Ambassador Guggenheim that the United States Government was unable to entertain his complaint until he had exhausted all legal recourse.
Fighting off a spirited New York drive in the final session, the Chicago Black Hawks registered a 3 to 1 triumph over the Rangers in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

DULUTH, Minn., Jan. 26. -- Watson S. Moore, for several decades a leader in Duluth business, civic and religious activities and a nationally known grain trader, died here today from a stroke which he suffered three weeks ago. His age was 65.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 26. -- George H. Snowden of Milford, Conn., instructor in sculpture in the Yale School of Fine Arts, was announced today the winner of the competition for the design of the bronze tablet to be placed by Yale University on the wall of Pershing Hall in Paris, in memory of the Yale men who gave their lives in the World War.

MONTREAL, Jan. 26. -- Overtime play failed to break a 1-1 deadlock between New York Americans and the Canadiens tonight and the visitors, as a result, tied the idle Montreal Maroons for second place in the international group of the National Hockey league.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Members of the Senate during the fiscal year ending June 30 consumed, at the expense of taxpayers, 500 aspirin tablets, one bottle of bromoseltzer, one package of soda-mint tablets, three pounds of bicarbonate of soda, two bottles of mouth wash, three pints of medicated alcohol and five gallons of witch hazel, the annual report of the Secretary of the Senate reveals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26 (AP). -- The possibility of a Senate inquiry hung tonight in the background of charges by a labor leader that New York banks have obtained a "stranglehold" on American industry which has brought it to a condition "bordering upon servitude."

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 26. -- Death has ended the remarkable career of a Pittsburgh scientist, Dr. Victor Sterki, who transformed his own affliction into the means of making him the world's foremost authority in his own field.

Safely moored in Grand Central Palace, the cruisers, runabouts and racing craft in the Motor Boat Show survived the fifty-mile-an-hour nor'easter yesterday morning and for the sixth day were on exhibition, still looking spick and span.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A total of $5,523,709.18 in loans to banks and trust companies in receivership was authorized by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during December, bringing the total to $56,113,587.05, of which $4,412,845.91 has been canceled.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 26. -- In compliment to Mrs. Henri P.W. van Heukelom of Paris, who is her house guest for the season, Mrs. Henry Seligman entertained today with a luncheon. Those present were:

Through the din of welcoming harbor traffic and the three-whistle salutes of tugs and liners, Captain Giles C. Stedman, youthful master of the American Merchant liner American Merchant, brought his ship to her dock yesterday with twfenty-two seamen, saved from death in mid-Atlantic when their ship, the Exeter City, was disabled by a furious Winter sea.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A guarded announcement by the War Department of an award of a $2,080,890 contract for thirty-eight bombing planes of a new type to the Glenn L. Martin Company of Baltimore, confirmed today reports recently circulated in aviation circles of the development of what is believed to be the most powerful military weapon produced by any nation since the World War.

"Railroad propagandists" are using the State Legislatures "to drive the motor bus and truck from the public roads," according to statements in a special edition of Bus Transportation, a magazine published by the McGraw-Hill Company.

Unless Samuel S. Koenig announces in the near future his intention to retire next Fall from the county leadership he has held for twenty-one years, the young Republicans of the city will stage a primary battle to unseat him at the party primary in September.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday was in slightly larger volume than on the day before, but Kreuger Toll, selling close to the lowest quotable figure, accounted for about one-fifth of the turnover. Trading in the more important issues was slow.

"The revolt in the dress industry has just begun and it will not run its course in the trade until the workers are given a square deal," declared Julius Hochman, general manager of the Joint Board of Dressmakers, following a meeting yesterday which had been called to seek a method of ending chaotic conditions.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Andrew Carnegie will give a small dinner dance tonight at her home, 2 East Ninety-first Street, for Miss Dorothy Adams Dunn, whose marriage to Andrew I. Peterson will take place tomorrow in the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- Another large oversubscription to the Treasury's latest offering of securities brought the statement from Secretary Mills today that in the interests of the public and the Treasury steps should be taken to prevent such heavy padding of subscriptions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 26. -- A bill to authorize immediate payment of the face value of adjusted service certificates held by unemployed veterans, at an estimated cost of $10,000,000 the first six months and less thereafter, was introduced today by Representative Fish of New York.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- While predicting that the British pound eventually would be linked to grold, Sir Harry Goschen, chairman of the National Provincial Bank, told the shareholders today that there could be no stabilization until a repetition of the 1931 panic had been made impossible.

For the third successive session the heaviest trading on the Cotton Exchange yesterday occurred in the last hour, and the pressure was sufficient to close quotations at the bottom at losses of 4 to 6 points. Routine price fixing for mill account was adequate most of the day to absorb the limited selling and maintain quotations, but toward the close spot interests put through hedging operations in substantial quantity the first time this week.

Railroad bonds displayed yesterday about the best strength in the bond market on the Stock Exchange, which as a whole moved irregularly higher. The improvement in the rail liens came as the aftermath of the announcement of purchase of a large interest in New York Central by the Delaware Hudson, declaration of a dividend by the Pennsylvania, and the continued shortening of the amount of decline in car loadings as compared with last year.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 26. -- Miss Grace Brinkley, who plays Diana Devereaux, the second feminine lead in "Of Thee I Sing," the musical satire now playing at Ford's Theatre here, was married here yesterday to Joseph T.P. Sullivan, New York attorney.

Art joins hands with music in the exhibition of lithographs by Henri Fantin-Latour at the C.W. Kraushaar Art Galleries. For a number of the prints in this exhibition music served as the inspiration. Wagner especially, for whom Fantin-Latour became an advocate in Paris in 1864, moved the artist to graphic expression.

A continuation in the week ended on Wednesday of the gradual improvement recently developed in bank clearings was indicated yesterday in the report issued by R. G. Dun Co. Clearings were only $43,391,000 less than the week before, while in 1932 the decline in the corresponding period was $1,015,258,000.

The Paramount-Publix Corporation, a motion picture producing and distributing firm with assets of $166,000,000, was placed in equity receivership last night by Federal Judge William Bondy. Charles D. Hilles, Republican National Committeeman, and Adolph Zukor, president of the corporation, were appointed receivers.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Jan. 26 (AP). -- Seven thousand women from the Illinois coal fields -- old and young mothers, and school girls -- marched today under a banner that bore the word: "Peace." The parade was arranged to bring public attention to the plight of miners and their families in the war-torn coal mining districts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Most "depression cures" I read seem one-sided and faddish. Thrift, industry and courage are already slowly drawing the United States away from the brink of economic disaster; but several desirable general public policies are not, I think, emphasized enough.
BOSTON, Jan. 27. -- The two favored combinations advanced into the semi-final round of the national doubles racquets championship which opened on the courts of the Tennis and Racquet Club today.

Iredoll W. Iglehart was appointed receiver for the Central Gas and Electric Company by Judge Coleman of the United States District Court in Maryland yesterday on a bill of complaint filed in the morning. The assets of the company consist entirely of securities of public utility companies.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, warns against rushing to "ridiculous and extreme conclusions" regarding the study and consideration which must be given to such facts as technocracy is assembling In an article, "Appraising Technocracy," published today in The Woman Republican.

Half a dozen well-known architects, interior decorators and painters disagreed amicably, if a trifle caustically, last night about the function of "The Picture in the American Home," when an exhibition of paintings and other works by unemployed draftsmen was opened in the galleries of W. J. Sloane, 575 Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the Architects Emergency Committee.

With all indications pointing to a bitter struggle between the New York Athletic Club and New York University for the team championship, the annual Metropolitan A.A. U. Indoor track and field championships will be conducted at the 102d Engineers Armory tonight under the joint auspices of the German-American A.C. and the Ninth German Masonic District.

Urging that college publicity writers pay more attention to the work of scientists in the laboratories of their institutions, Waldemar Kaempffert, science editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said yesterday afternoon that news was being made constantly in every college and university laboratory in the country.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 27. -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, said today In The Yale Daily News that Britons did not say "Uncle Shylock" when they referred to the United States, a boast which Ambassadors of some countries to Washington could not make.

The city planning resolution adopted by the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate this week is a welcome indication that the new Administration has decided not to abandon completely that vital municipal function. The City Planning Department had recently been abolished, on the recommendation of Mayor O'BRIEN.

PARIS, Jan. 27. -- With dramaitc suddenness, the trial of Henri Guilbeaux ended this evening with his acquittal when the prosecuting officer before the military tribunal which was trying him on a war-time treason charge withdrew the accusation.

Several hundred members of society, including many prominent native Southerners now living here, thronged the main ballroom of the Plaza last night for the Blue Ridge Ball, a dance given annually to aid the work of the Blue Ridge Industrial School among the mountaineer children of Greene County, Va.

Having had its stamina tested by a selling movement which at times threatened to get out of hand, the share market turned sharply about yesterday afternoon and retraced all of the lost ground. The movement of bonds was irregular.

Hearings before a referee in the Workmen's Compensation Bureau on death claims growing out of the steamship Observation disaster in the East River on Sept. 9, 1932, were prevented yesterday by a restraining order from the United States District Court, pending a decision as to jurisdiction.

BALTIMORE, Jan. 27. -- Figures issued today by the Maryland Racing Commission reveal that there was a drop of approximately $10,000,000 in the amount bet through the pari-mutuel machines during 1932 at the State's four major tracks.

NEW CITY, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- James and Joseph Canora, 21 and 19 years old, respectively, identified today the body of their mother, Mrs. Lena Canora, 53 years old, of 227 Church Street, Lodi, N.J., which was found last night, burned almost beyond recognition, in the shadow of Spook Rock, a tremendous boulder off the Viola Road, near Spring Valley, N.Y.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 27 -- A battle is in progress at Fort Fernandez, also called Fort Herrera, which apparently is turning out to be of more importance and on a more extensive scale than has been indicated by the brief references to it in the general staff communiques.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- At the request of the British Cabinet, Ambassador Sir Ronald Lindsay will sail for England from New York on the Europa next Tuesday to lay the Anglo-American debt situation before the government. The idea of the visit may have originated with President Hoover or President-elect Roosevelt.

The State Bar Association went on record yesterday as favoring retention of the elective system of selecting judges after a spirited debate in which up-State lawyers charged that if high judicial office is a pawn of politicians in New York City, it is the fault of the electorate and not of the system.

The annual report of the American Brake Shoe and Foundry Company and subsidiaries shows a net profit of $257,379 after depreciation. Federal taxes and adjustments. This is equivalent to $2.70 a share on 95,385 shares of 7 per cent preferred stock and compares with a net profit of $1,386,138, equal after the payment of preferred dividends to $1.14 a share on 627,776 no-par common shares, for 1931.

The Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, the amusement company affiliated with the Radio Corporation of America, with assets of about $133,000,000, was placed in equity receivership late yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- With the maturity of $750,000,000 in New York City mortgages impending this year, the Reconstruction Finance Corporation has thrown its influence behind the establishment of a central mortgage bank for that area.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- A concurrent resolution was laid before the Senate today by Senator Couzens under which further loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to any railroad would be barred until Congress ordered otherwise.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, spent an hour and twenty minutes on the witness stand yesterday before the December term of the Bronx grand jury. Although the purpose of calling Mr. Macy was not revealed, it was reported that the grand jury wished to learn his attitude toward legislation for seven new judgeships which the grand jury, on Jan. 19, asserted were needed in the borough's county, city and municipal courts.

TORONTO, Jan. 27. -- A surprise move today by the State of Illinois in its effort to obtain extradition of Martin J. Insull had the effect of changing the scene of the impending extradition battle from the little town of Barrie, sixty miles north, to Toronto.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 27. -- The "bust-up" among the technocrats at Columbia University was bailed as "taking a weight off the shoulds of technocracy" by M. King Hulbert, lieutenant of Howard Scott, in an address here today before the convention of the New York State Publishers Association, the Associated Dailies and the New York Press Association.

Fordham Prep strengthened its lead in the Manhattan Division C. H.S.A.A. basketball tournament by defeating La Salle Academy, 24 to 12, at Goddard gymnasium yesterday, and Cathedral Boys High, defending C.H.S.A.A. champion, moved into second place in the race by vanquishing Manhattan Prep, 22 to 13, in the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium.
NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 27 (AP). -- Winning his third consecutive race, E.E. Major's Bill Orange today led a high-class field of platers over a mile and a sixteenth route at the Fair Grounds.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will call on Mrs. Hoover at the White House tomorrow and, after an informal chat over a tea table, the next First Lady will look over the big Presidential mansion which is to be her home for four years.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 -- Japanese politicians, being human, refrain from attacking the government's relief expenditure, and consequently financial criticisms are chiefly directed against naval and military expenditure.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- A movement to coordinate applications by New York State communities for Federal loans for self-liquidating projects was begun today by Governor Lehman. The Governor announced that he would appoint a committee next week to handle all applications to speed construction on self-liquidating projects so as to provide jobs, to lighten the present burden on home and work relief and to stimulate the construction industry.

Beethoven and Wagner were drafted last night at Carnegie Hall for the second time this season by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra for a concert for the benefit of its pension fund. Bruno Walter conducted and Lotte Lehmann was the soloist.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Words that once would have seemed strange continue to pour out of the financial centre of London. At the annual meeting of the Midland Bank today its chairman, Reginald McKenna, former Chancellor of the Exchequer, spoke a good word for inflation and said that various things were far more important to Great Britain than the rate of exchange.

A slight increase in hedging operations carried prices off 5 points in yesterday's early trading on the Cotton Exchange, but a setback of $1 a bale brought in trade buying and the list closed unchanged to 5 points higher than on Thursday.

Jose de Capriles, New York University's fencing captain, gained a place among the six qualifiers for the national junior saber championship in the preliminary round at the New York Athletic Club last night to add to the laurels he had grained in other elimination tests during the week.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday work and home relief projects for which $5,000,000 was appropriated on Jan. 20. The money will be spent in February under the supervision of the Emergency Work and Relief Administration. At the same time the board postponed decision on the administration's request to control the allocation of work and home relief expenditures.

The reaction in sterling, after its recent sharp rally, continued yesterday with the official control active in the market to "cushion" the fall but not attempting to turn quotations up. The closing quotation, which was the lowest for the day, was $3.37 1/2, down 1 1/4 cents on the day and 2 5/8 cents below the high for the recent recovery, reached on Tuesday.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- England's comparatively new tariffs were advanced today as available to the British commission for bargaining purposes when that body presents its appeal for revision of the war debts to the United States.

Builders and sellers of boats had their annual get-together yesterday at the Motor Boat Show in Grand Central Palace. The National As sociation of Engine and Boat Man ufacturers held its meeting. Henry R. Sutphen of this city was re elected president and Charles A. Criqui of Buffalo again was named first vice president.

Never Felt Better. Governor LEHMAN used to smoke eight cigars a day and many cigarettes, but gave up tobacco the night after his election. His victory had nothing to do with it, the Governor has stated.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 27 (AP). -- L.B. Palmer, general manager of the American Newspaper Publishers Association, said in an address here today that the passage of a tariff bill, now pending before Congress not only would "increase the cost of newspaper production," but also would "legislate two-thirds of an industry out of existence for the benefit of the other third."

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Operations laid to several local professionals were largely responsible for an early break in the wheat market today.
