The selling started soon after the opening of the Board of Trade, and, with light outside buying, prices dropped almost 1 cent from Thursday's finish before the break was checked.

Of the first thirty-two railroads to report for December, seventeen showed increased net operating incomes for the month, compared with the same month a year previously. In November, fifteen members of the group recorded increases in this account.

The creation of a new Cabinet post, a secretaryship of "public morale," was urged yesterday by Kenneth Goode, economist, before the fourth annual convention of the Eastern division. National Association of Direct Selling Companies, in the Hotel Roosevelt.

Two good reasons for going to the Capitol now are the presence of Mary Garden on the stage and a splendid pictorial adaptation of the play, "Whistling in the Dark," in which Ernest Truex makes his talking film debut in the same role he played in the parent work.

FRANKFURT, Germany, Jan. 27. -- The I.G. Farbenindustrie, Germany's dye and chemical concern, records in its report for the last quarter of 1932 improvement In production, sales and employment. It parallels the showing of Germany's biggest steel concern for the same quarter, published earlier this month, apparently indicating that the German key industries have begun climbing upward.

The two buildings at the north-west corner of Eighth Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, after having been held in the same ownership for thirty-nine years, were reported sold yesterday by the Wood-Dolson Company for Frank Goodman.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Representative La Guardia today wired Mayor O'Brien an explanation of the bankruptcy bill pending in the House and said the Mayor's protest against it was based on misinformation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Acting under the broad authority which the Senate holds over its members, a committee of five will leave within a few days to investigate Senator Huey Long's strongly intrenched political organization in Louisiana.
MADRID, Jan. 27. -- A cold wave that brought heavy snowfalls to many cities from the northern to the southern coast continued to hold Spain in its grip tonight.

HIGHTSTOWN, N.J., Jan. 27. -- A dispute at the breakfast table led today to the shooting of Kelton Pierce, 30 years old, at the home of his mother-in-law, Mrs. Thomas H. Everett, at 444 South Main Street here. James Fischer, 79, an uncle of Mrs. Everett who also lived at the house, was charged with the shooting.

The eviction of seven tenants from Paradise Alley, a so-called artists' colony at the northeast corner of Avenue A and East Eleventh Street, resulted yesterday in two clashes between the police and Communist sympathizers, the arrest of three persons on disorderly conduct charges and the sending of a fourth to Bellevue with a possible fractured skull.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday made up a total of 972,000 shares, as compared with 808,000 on the previous day. The volume was the heaviest in more than two weeks, which encouraged the expectation in Wall Street that the market may be preparing to work out of the narrow area in which it has been moving for some time.

PHILADELPHIA, Saturday, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Four members of the family of John M. Di Silvestro, prominent banker and Supreme Master of the Sons of Italy, were seriously injured early today in an explosion which demolished their three-story home in South Philadelphia.

Led by a man in a patrolman's uniform, four armed robbers invaded the office of the Woodside branch of the Prudential Life. Insurance Company yesterday forenoon and took an envelope containing $3,527 from the safe. The money, intended for the payroll of the office, had been placed in the safe fifteen minutes earlier, a patrolman having accompanied a girl from the office to and from the bank to get the money.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- When President-elect Roosevelt takes office in a little more than five weeks he will find a swimming pool and probably a yacht added to the existing safeguards to the health of the Chief Executive. Both facilities will furnish forms of recreation to which Governor Roosevelt is known to be partial.

Mayor O'Brien expects to receive by noon today final reports from all agencies of the city, county and borough governments showing what success they have had in the effort to cut 520,000,000 in other than personal service accounts from the 1933 city budget.

Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black brought suit yesterday to compel the Board of Estimate to maintain the salary of the Supreme Court justices of Manhattan and the Bronx at $25,000 a year. He maintained that the enabling act passed by the December extraordinary session of the Legislature and also the State Constitution bar a reduction in judges' salaries.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- Barring upsets, Chancellor Kurt von Schleicher should make his Reichstag debut next Tuesday in accordance with today's resolution of its steering committee. The official agenda prescribed for that day provide only for the reception of the government's statement.

Robert McCormack, 60 years old, of 708 West 177th Street, one of the oldest confidence men in the business, was held without bail in Yorkville Court yesterday for hearing next Tuesday on a charge of having stolen a $2,500 brooch from the home of Mrs. Mary Topping, 827 Park Avenue, on Sept. 19.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas gave a dinner tonight at the Beach Club in honor of Mr. and Mrs. Barclay Kountze Douglas, their son and daughter-in-law, who have taken Pelican Lodge, adjoining their own residence, and their house guest, Mrs. J. Henry Alexandre.

By acquiring 10 per cent control of the New York Central Railroad, the Delaware Hudson Company has acted to protect itself in future consolidation negotiations, Leonor F. Loree, president of the last-named railroad, said yesterday. He Indicated, however, that the move did not mean the D. H. would oppose the four-system plan approved by the Eastern trunk lines by remarking that "much had been done to stabilize" this alignment.

MANILA, Jan. 27 -- Filipino action for independence daily becomes more confused, with local politics, apparently preliminary skirmishes for control, providing the principal topic of discussion in all quarters, but with little clarified.

A successful reorganization of the McCrory Stores Corporation, now in receivership, is possible, according to H.P. Reader of the Cannon Mills, chairman of the protective committee of the merchandise creditors, after an examination of the preliminary figures by the receiver.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Ernest J. Stevens, former president of the Stevens and La Salle Hotels, and former vice president and director of the Illinois Life Insurance Company, was arrested in his home at 8:15 o'clock tonight on a bench warrant charging conspiracy to defraud the insurance company of $1,000,000.

In an effort to permit American holders of foreign dollar bonds on which the interest is not being paid in terms of United States currency to realize something on the unpaid coupons, the committee on securities of the New York Stock Exchange ruled yesterday that henceforth such defaulted bonds may be traded on the Exchange with the over-due coupons detached, as well as by the present method of requiring all unpaid coupons to be attached.

Developments in the last week were largely constructive, even though they were somewhat hampered by lack of settled governmental policies, according to the weekly survey of economic conditions by Dun's Review. The report reads in part:

Wall Street's interest in the meeting next Tuesday of the directors of the United States Steel Corporation was heightened yesterday when it was intimated at an authoritative source that public sentiment should be prepared for a change in the $7 preferred dividend, which will be acted upon at that time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Every sensible American must wonder if the earnest admonition of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, published in the Nation's Business, will finally arouse our business leaders, financiers and legislators to the increasing seriousness of our present economic situation, especially as it affects our vast army of unemployed and those other millions who, while classed as employed, are earning barely enough to prevent starvation.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 27 -- It was learned on reliable authority tonight that strong international diplomatic pressure, directed at Peru as her four-day truce with Colombia regarding border difficulties ended, has resulted in Peru's virtual acceptance of a Brazilian peace formula.
DETROIT, Jan. 27 -- Notices of increases in pay rates of the Briggs Manufacturing Company which will probably be accepted by the striking workers were posted at all employment offices today.

Hasty and fragmentary reports were published on Thursday afternoon of some of the loans made by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation during the first five months of its functioning. As a result, the fears expressed try Banking Superintendent BRODERICK were verified.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 27. -- Shaker Lady, a daughter of Dis Donc, racing for D.B. Midkiff, won the Suwanee Purse in a thrilling finish at Hialeah Park today, defeating C.V. Whitney's Moon Shy, a former stablemate, by a nose. A length and a half further back Fervid crossed the line to gain the show by a head from Memories Dear.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Henry Ford, interviewed by transatlantic telephone, was quoted in The Evening Standard tonight as saying that bankers had brought about the closing of Ford factories in Detroit and elsewhere.

Plans to promote organized yacht racing in the waters of Eastern Connecticut gained momentum yesterday at the second annual meeting of the race committee of the new Eastern Connecticut Yacht Racing Association held at the Yale Club.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The drive of Senator Tydings, Democrat, of Maryland, to force drastic cuts in all of the appropriation bills to be voted by this Congress to the end that the government live within its income for the next fiscal year, was halted this morning by the Democratic organization, which decided that the Senate had better suffice for the present with a simple declaration of policy toward that objective.

Communism, both Left and Right wings; policemen, a city marshal, the Democratic party, slashed automobile tires and a general lack of brotherly love all contributed yesterday to the eviction of Sam Silberberg and his family from their apartment in the Communist cooperative colony at 2,800 Bronx Park East.

Dispatches to THE TIMES from Warm Springs state that Mr. ROOSEVELT is considering plans for two new departments in Washington. One would be a bureau of communications, consolidating various Federal agencies now having regulatory powers over telegraph companies, radio and electric power.

HAVANA, Jan. 27. -- The Cuban yacht Jibaro, sailed by Cesar Fuentes, today captured the first race of the International Star Class Series for the Cuba Cup. This victory followed that of another Cuban craft, the Mara, in the opening contest yesterday of the Bacardi Trophy series, the other event of the mid-Winter regatta.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- President Hoover plans to deliver his farewell address to the nation before the National Republican Club of New York, Feb. 13, at a celebration of Lincoln's birthday. Political and industrial leaders will be present.

The control of enemies of bird life is important, but far too often the killing of innocent birds and animals is resorted to by those who consider all hawks and owls destructive. It has been estimated by authorities that fully 75 per cent of the hawks and owls commonly found in this country are more beneficial than destructive in that their food supply consists principally of rodents.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated Jan. 25:

In the event that satisfactory script revisions are made in "A Story of Love," the play will be presented at the Biltmore Theatre on Thursday night of next week. The production, the cast of which is headed by Dorothy Hall and Kenneth MacKenna, will close a week's preparatory engagement in Philadelphia this evening.

Three of the city's most extensive series of mural paintings were seen yesterday by guests in the first unit of the new office building of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, 25 East Twenty-fourth Street. Size and number, however, do not constitute the claim of these murals to the attention of art lovers.

What to do to make the sale of beer not only legal, but also possible and popular, engaged twenty of the city's better known restaurateurs at Luchow's Restaurant in East Fourteenth Street yesterday. The gathering was prompted by recent developments in the prohibition situation, which they described as "alarming."

HAVANA, Jan. 27 (AP) . -- Keeping intact her perfect record on the Winter turf, Bokie B, a 3-year-old filly from James Arthur's stable, today won her second consecutive race at Oriental Park in accounting for the mile-and-fifty-yard feature.
Seaman Tom Watson made an auspicious debut in an American ring last night. Before 10,000 fans he hammered his way to a twelve-round decision over Fidel LaBarba in Madison Square Garden.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27 (AP). -- Welker Cochran of San Francisco shot his way into undisputed possession of the lead in the world's championship three-cushion billiard tournament tonight by outpointing Tiff Denton, Kansas City veteran, 50 to 30, in forty-one innings.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP). -- From grain dealers and cotton spinners the Senate Agriculture Committee heard outspoken objections today to the domestic allotment farm relief bill.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Assertions that a small group of New York banks controlled through Interlocking directorates the policies of insurance companies, railroads, utilities and manufacturers were the start today of a Senate Judiciary subcommittee's investigation in a new and broad field.

The money market was feature-less. No business worthy of the term was reported in any section, resulting in an unchanged array for quotations. Stock Exchange call loans continued at 1 per cent and Street loans at 1/2.

The spacious silences of the old Roxy on Seventh Avenue were torn into streaming ribbons of laughter and sound yesterday by the largest crowds that have visited the 6,000-seat theatre in months. The incentive was the sharp reduction in admission prices and the object was amusement.

Three members of President Hoover's committee on social trends discussed the recent report of the committee last night at a meeting in the Cooperative School for Student Teachers, 69 Bank Street. The speakers were Dr. Wesley C. Mitchell of Columbia University, chairman of the committee; Professor Robert S. Lynd of Columbia and Professor Hornell Hart of Bryn Mawr.

VIENNA, Jan. 27. -- A taxicab drivers' strike blocked all traffic in the centre of Vienna today and turned St. Stephen's Square into a river of automobiles in which islands were represented by entangled trucks and buses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent news items indicate that some light is needed on the subject of retired pay in the military services, to disabuse the public mind of the idea that it is a gratuity. Such a classification is neither accurate nor fair, as a consideration of any typical case will show.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Within less than five minutes today the House today passed a modified first deficiency bill, carrying a total of $3,756,535.72.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The story is told of a party of amateur fishermen who put out to sea in a small vessel, having had the forethought to lay in a generous supply of canned goods. Several hours later, after exercise and fresh air had developed vigorous appetites, the disturbing discovery visas made that no can-opener was available.

The merger of the National Committee Against the Pre-payment of the Bonus, organized last Fall, with the National Economy League, headed by Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, was announced yesterday jointly by the two organizations. The merger was described as an endeavor to practice the economy preached by both groups, by eliminating the duplication of aims and efforts.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The causes of Eamon de Valera's success in the Irish election are being debated in the British press without acrimony and full credit is being given for the shrewdness with which he appealed to the country before his opponents were ready.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Republican administration strategy to use the powerful lever of higher tariffs to force world exchange stabilization received a boost today from James A. Farrell, former president of the United States Steel Corporation.

Resplendent with its regimental colors and guidons awarded during the year, the historic Seventh Regiment was reviewed last night in its armory, 633 Park Avenue, by Major Gen. George E. Leach, chief of staff of the militia bureau of the War Department.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27. -- The board of control of the Yale Athletic Association, on recommendation of the undergraduate body, authorized the award of thirty insignia to athletic team members today.

Mrs. Carrie Guggenheim, widow of Isaac Guggenheim, New York copper producer, who died in her seventy-fourth year on Jan. 5 last in her home at Beverly Hills, Cal., left $25,000 to institutions for the prevention of cruelty to animals and divided $81,000 equally among nine philanthropic institutions in New York and California, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 27 -- Nanking officially claimed today that 1,000 volunteers under General Keng Chi-chow had captured Chaoyang, important Jehol gateway, last Monday after several months' occupation of the town by the Japanese.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- With about 1,000 cases now under consideration by the Federal Trade Commission, interest in the prospective appointment of members to fill the two vacancies on the commission is increasing among business associations throughout the country having member firms which are concerned with pending decisions.

Mathematical proof that the cosmic rays consist largely of electrons, protons, or alpha particles, corroborating the experimental findings of Professor Arthur H. Compton and his collaborators, is presented in the current issue of The Physical Review, publication of the American Institute of Physics, by Abbe George LeMaitre, famous Belgian scientist, and M.S. Vallarta of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology.

Miss Joan McSheehy, Olympic swimming star, won the metropolitan 100-yard back-stroke crown, and Miss Susan Robertson successfully defended her 500-yard free-style title in the open A.A.U. meet held in the Downtown Athletic Club pool last night.

J. Richard Hughes, attorney, of 1,450 Broadway, whose negotiations with the Corporation Counsel's office are said to have led up to the surrender of $18,645, which the police seized in June, 1931, from Arthur (Dutch Schultz) Flegenheimer, Bronx beer runner wanted now for violation of the income tax law, was forced yesterday under threat of citation for contempt of court to answer questions before a Federal grand jury.

ALBANY, Jan. 27. -- The O'Connell brothers. Democratic leaders of Albany, will attempt to strike back at the Republican forces in the Legislature for their aid to supporters of Chairman James A. Farley of the Democratic National Committee in patronage matters.

A resolution objecting to the recent attack by two Irish organizations in New York on the theatrical presentations of the Abbey Theatre Irish Players of Dublin was sent yesterday to Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Executive Council, through the Consul General, William J. Macaulay.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Favorable action was taken today on Governor Lehman's application for Federal relief funds for New York State by the relief directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation and their recommendations will be submitted for the final approval of the board of directors of the corporation tomorrow.

Captain Giles C. Stedman, master of the American Merchant liner American Merchant, who rescued twenty-two of the crew of the British freighter Exeter City, modestly received the plaudits of the city and the official thanks of Great Britain yesterday, and put to sea again after just twenty-five hours in port.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 27. -- Francis P. Garvan of New York City, who established the Mabel Brady Garvan Institute of American Arts and Crafts in the Tale School of the Fine Arts, has donated to the Yale University library a collection of more than 2,000 books on Ireland.

Joe Judge, veteran first baseman who has been campaigning with the Washington Senators for the last seventeen seasons, became the property of the Brooklyn Dodgers yesterday by affixing his signature to a one-year contract. Judge had received his unconditional release from the Senators several weeks ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP). -- Under Secretary. Castle of the State Department today urged Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee to expedite action on the Hoover arms embargo proposal.

GENEVA, Jan. 27 -- Blame for events in Manchuria after Sept. 18, 1931, when the Japanese opened military action there, is placed by implication on Japan by the subcommittee of the League of Nations Committee of Nineteen in the first part of its report on the dispute, which was adopted today.

Local option, extended to areas as small as incorporated villages, was decided upon yesterday as a feature of any liquor-control plan that might be recommended to the State Legislature by the commission named to study the problems connected with the modification or repeal of prohibition.

VILLANOVA, Pa., Jan. 27. -- St. John's College of Brooklyn, with twelve straight victories to its credit, was dealt a surprising set-back by Villanova tonight, 38 to 32, before a crowd of 2,000 basketball fans.

The decision of the French Chamber of Deputies on Dec. 14 to refuse to pay the $19,261,432 due the United States the following day was directly responsible for the formation of a new Cabinet three days later by Senator Joseph Paul-Boncour.

Henry C. Craft of Brooklyn took undisputed possession of first place in the national amateur pocket billiard tournament at the Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy last night by defeating Edward Fagan of the Engineers Club after Thomas L. Corcoran had scored an upset victory over the defending champion, J. Howard Shoemaker, in the night's first game.

TOKYO, Jan. 27 (AP). -- The War Office today expressed the opinion that the clash between Chinese and Japanese at Chumen Pass was a minor action. It was pointed out that the Japanese garrison there was small. The War Office had not received details of the battle.

It is getting to be time for a new definition of the word "spokesman" in politics. Sometimes it comes perilously near meaning a man who "puts a spoke" in the wheel of the one he professes to represent. This is getting to be true in some cases with those who set out to speak for President-elect ROOSEVELT.

Along the Eastern naval front yesterday the response was quick and in some instances distinctly favorable to the proposal for a national intercollegiate championship regatta over the famous Olympic rowing course at Long Beach, California, next June.

CHICAGO, Jan. 27. -- Retirement of several operating executives from the board of directors of the Commonwealth Edison Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois was forecast tonight by James Simpson, chairman of both concerns.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 (AP).-- Representative Crump of Tennessee has protested to Attorney General Mitchell "against the delay and apparent dillydallying which has characterized the handling of the government's prosecution of Luke Lea."

DUBLIN, Jan. 27. -- President Eamon de Valera has won out in the surprise general election that he sprang on the Free State. His tactical action in dissolving the Dail Eireann before Lord Mayor Alfred Byrne's projected national party had time to form brings him back to the Dail with increased strength and a bigger voting majority.

An emergency in the city's efforts to care for maternity cases among the poor has caused the Department of Hospitals to appeal to the Board of Estimate, through Mayor O'Brien, to relax the regulations governing the city's payment to private hospitals for the care of indigent maternity patients, it was revealed yesterday.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 27. -- The Chelsea-Second National Bank and Trust Company and its two branches, one of the largest institutions here and having about 22,000 depositors, did not open for business today.

Although "Quo Vadis" still leads as the most popular novel published in this country since 1895, Pearl S. Buck's "The Good Earth" has edged into second place, displacing "David Harum," by Edward Noyes Westcott, according to Irving Harlow Hart, director of the extension division of Iowa State Teachers College, in the Publishers' Weekly, issued today.

In the exchange of radio messages between The American Merchant and The Exeter City the word that gave cheer, to the remaining officers and men of the sinking ship was that the other hoped to be "alongside" soon. She changed her course on the instant and started to give such help as the law of the sea requires of those who venture upon it.

Although price levels in the general bond market rose moderately this week, no new corporation bond financing was done publicly, and new municipal financing was limited to $7,699,000, which included all new bond and note offerings for the week.

In the most important match of the Class B season to date, the Bayside Tennis Club defeated the City A.C. on the latter's courts last night and thereby definitely established itself as the favorite to win the honors in the New York group of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 27 -- A three-point economy program, calling for a reduction in the number of government employes, consolidation of governmental agencies and abandonment of certain governmental functions, is being prepared by President-elect Roosevelt to be put through with the aid of Congress at the coming special session, it was learned from him today.

S. Howard Cohen, President of the Board of Elections, revealed yesterday that his board next week planned to recanvass the entire city vote, including that written in on the paper ballot rolls for Joseph V. McKee for Mayor.

The Academy of Political Science now has 6,520 members, including a foreign membership of 798 distributed in sixty-five countries, Alanson B. Houghton, former Ambassador to Great Britain and president of the academy, announced yesterday afternoon at the academy's annual corporation meeting in Fayerweather Hall, Columbia University.
The Dance Centre, which opens its second production of the season tonight at the Barbizon-Plaza, gave an official preview there last night, the bill being a revival of Stravinsky's "Petrushka."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- The United States will have to build 135 ships, with a total tonnage of 316,530, between now and Dec. 31, 1936, to bring its navy up to the strength permitted under the terms of the London naval treaty, according to the latest comparison of navies prepared by the Navy Department for the Senate Naval Affairs Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana, who exposed the Teapot Dome scandals in the Harding administration, will become Attorney General in the Roosevelt Cabinet, it became known definitely today.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's recently appointed committee of eighteen to study economic problems held its first meeting yesterday at Columbia University. The members of the commission assembled at 10 o'clock and were received by Dr. Butler in the trustees' room in the university library.

TWO large golf clubs in the metropolitan area have gone on the financial rocks, and that's only a minor part of a sad situation. As a result of building single golf holes that cost as much as $25,000 and palatial clubhouses that ran as high as half a million, dear old Colonel Bogey (of Caledonian ancestry, too!) is standing bewildered on a bitter tee.

New York University's swimming team recorded a 39-to-32 triumph over Amherst in the London Terrace 75-foot pool yesterday. It was the losers' first defeat in three meets and the winners' first victory in a similar number of meets.

Mail contracts to American shin lines were defended as an aid to the development of American business in foreign countries as well as to the ship lines carrying the mails, in a statement issued yesterday by Kraser A. Bailey, vice president of the Matson Navigation Company.

UTICA, N.Y., Jan. 27 -- Asa K. Jennings was about 55 years old. His parents lived in Cleveland, N. Y. He was educated at Syracuse University and was admitted to the Northern New York Conference of the Methodist Episcopal Church in 1908.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- Today's turn-over on the Boerse was the smallest in several weeks. It is expected that the stagnation will last until the political situation is clarified, especially the question whether the Reichstag will be dissolved again and the elections held in due time.

GENEVA, Jan. 27. -- An arms memorandum proposing the work for the disarmament conference to follow once it has finished general discussion of the French plan was handed to President Arthur Henderson today by Anthony Eden of Great Britain.

Newark Farmers Market, Inc., has taken title to the remainder of its tract comprising three and one-half blocks in Newark, it was announced yesterday. The property had been leased in February, 1931, from the Essex and Hudson Land Improvement Company and William B. Glacken, with whom the present deal was arranged.

Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts heads a large delegation from Boston sailing today on the Cunarder Franconia for her first cruise of the season to Havana and Nassau. Also sailing are Representative D. Lane Powers of Trenton and Mrs. Powers.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- Following its recent sudden rise, sterling was lower today in the foreign exchange market, with the New York rate $3.38 1/8%, against last night's closing quotation of $3.39 3/8. The stock markets generally were cheerful, a feature being almost boomlike conditions in South African gold shares, prices rising sharply on buying orders from the Cape.

Mr. DB VALERA skillfully dissolved the Dail and ordered a new election at the moment when his adversaries were least prepared; but, irrespective of political strategy, he seems to have been sustained by the country to an extent which might have been even considerably greater were it not for proportional representation.

Every effort has been made bi the Department of Justice during the depression to administer the anti-trust laws with the least injury to business, Attorney General Mitchell declared last night before the annual meeting of the State Bar Association at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- The government-financed Senate barber shop, which costs between $8,000 and $10,000 a year to operate, does not serve Senator James Hamilton Lewis of Illinois, the only member of the Senate with, a beard. Senator Lewis said today that he does not permit the government to finance his "personal demands."

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27 -- Drastic restrictions to prohibition enforcement, as well as a cut of about 10 per cent in the appropriation for it, were voted by the House this afternoon in a series of amendments to the Department of Justice supply bill.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months paper.

Contracts for raw sugar, coffee and silk futures advanced in price yesterday on local commodity exchanges. Other commodities continued their downward trend, with virtually no improvement over the low levels of trading which have prevailed recently.

PARIS, Saturday, Jan. 28 -- The Paul-Boncour government was defeated at 6 o'clock this morning after a valiant struggle of twenty-two hours to get its budget proposals through the Chamber of Deputies.

PARIS, Jan. 27. -- Former Premier Andre Tardieu, In his first public address in eight months, proposed today four reforms in the French Government to correct the abuses of "vain liberalism and materialism."

Lloyd Price, 22 years old, of 556 Myrtle Avenue, Brooklyn, a Negro with a psychopathic history and a police record, was held without ball in the Flatbush Homicide Court yesterday after he had confessed, according to detectives, that he killed Helen Sterler, 6 years old, whose body was found late Wednesday night in the cellar of 1,013 De Kalb Avenue, Brooklyn.

One man was killed and three others were seriously wounded in a free-for-all fight which took place about 2 o'clock this morning in the rooms of the Beldon Social Club at 2,418 Second Avenue, at the cornea of 124th Street. Two of the wounded are expected to die.

Fourteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure sales yesterday. Among them was the twelve-story office buliding at 507 Fifth Avenue, near Forty-second Street, which wag acquired on a bid of $50,000 by the New York Life Insurance Company, plaintiff, against the Rayon Holding Corporation.

The brilliance of military pageantry which has characterized the Old Guard Ball since it was first held in the old Academy of Music in East Fourteenth Street, when women wore crinoline and bustles and military men boasted "handle-bar" mustaches, came to life again last night when the veteran organization celebrated its 107th anniversary at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- All Industries in Japan are less active, warehouse stocks have increased and security prices have fallen substantially, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of world economic conditions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In answer to Bernhard Ragner's letter, I might add that the American people may be a bit "irrational," but they are honest. They show on the surface what they feel in their hearts. It may not be diplomatic, but it is an old American trait.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 27. -- President-elect Roosevelt has promised to use his influence in trying to force the Glass banking bill through the House, one of the most influential Senators interested in financial legislation said tonight.

The season s series or special Wagner matinees at the Metropolitan Opera House began yesterday afternoon with "Rheingold." The cast had features of novelty for confirmed Wagnerians of this city, though it must be said that the general level of ensemble and coordinated interpretation, was higher than that of the contributions of individual singers.

The wisdom of the economies required of New York City before the banks would extend financial aid was questioned by Professor Joseph D. McGoldrick of Columbia University, in an address yesterday afternoon at the closing session of the annual Eastern Regional Savings Conference of the American Bankers' Association, savings division, at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Although twenty-seven communities throughout the country will seek sealed bids next week on new bond and note issues, the total will be only 55,157,870, compared with this week's revised aggregate of $9,622,600 and a weekly average of $15,658,640 for 1933 thus far.

Bonds turned irregular on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with trading totaling $10.627,500, compared with $9,180,000 on the previous day. Railroad loans averaged again the best gains in the domestic corporation group.

Two more contract signers hopped upon the Giants' bandwagon yesterday when Secretary Jim Tierney announced that LeRoy Parmelee, right-handed pitcher, and Francis Healey, promising young backstop and sole survivor of last year's catching staff, had come into the fold.

LOS ANGELES, Jan. 28. -- Murray W. Garsson, assistant to Secretary of Labor Doak, began today the Immigration Bureau's campaign to drive out of the Hollywood film colony all foreign actresses and actors who cannot prove beyond doubt that their residence in the United States is legal.

CONTINUING the survey of Wagner recordings, we now turn back from the "Ring" to the three better known dramas which preceded it. With these we are on rather different ground and classification becomes easier.

We are hearing a great deal in this country about "regulated inflation." Nobody favors an unlimited issue of fiat money. Not even Senator BORAH would have the depreciation of the currency go beyond a certain point. The calamitous experience of Germany in printing marks until a billion or two of them were worth only a dime stands as a continuing reminder and warning before the eyes of even our extreme inflationists.

PIERRE, S.D., Jan. 26. -- South Dakota having just passed through one of the most critical periods in its history is looking for an upward swing in 1933, but business leaders and State officials are taking this view with guarded optimism, chiefly because they realize a return of good times must be preceded by an advance in agricultural prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Arguing that "convincing evidence of the intention of Congress to reduce government expenditures would give the stimulant that industry and commerce need to start on the upgrade," Henry I. Harriman, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the United States, appealed today to Senator Hale and Representative Byrns, chairman of the respective Appropriations Committees, to reduce expenditures to the level of expected revenues during the next fiscal year.

Science Service reports that the Smithsonian Institution has almost a dozen canes of the sort used by medicine men of a Panama tribe of Indians. Each is carved "with the unmistakable features" of a Dr. William Patterson, who, it is said, was "a leader of a Scottish colony" which went to the coast of Panama in 1698.

THOSE Jules Vernes of space who anticipate interplanetary communication are likely to find a new ray of hope now that words, music and even pictures can be transmitted across a beam of light, as over a radio wave.

The annual convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of the United States opened last night in the Ohab Zedek Synagogue, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street, and will continue today and tomorrow, with about 1,000 delegates from throughout the nation, at the Hotel Edison.

ETHEL BARRYMORE has -- with one gesture -- recovered from her illness and found another play. That would be the encore to "Encore," the one in which she was touring early in the Winter. She confided to this department a few days ago that she is holding it, but she would tell nothing of the name, the author or the management.

Z.G. Simmons led a field of twenty-eight gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the high scratch cup by breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets. The second trophy went to T.H. Lewis, who finished with 95.

With divorces obtainable in thirty-two days and with lawyers' fees down as low as $100 a divorce, New York's first matrimonial court disposed of 1,893 matrimonial actions in 206 trial days during 1932.

The Spanish Ambassador, Juan Francisco de Cardenas, and Senora de Cardenas will be guests of honor at the Spanish Charity Ball to be given on Friday at Sherry's under the auspices of the Comite de Socorro Espanol. The dance is to further the work of the Comite among destitute Spaniards in this city.
CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- George Lott Jr. of Chicago and Mrs. Dorothy Weisel Hack of Los Angeles, wife of the Chicago Cubs' young infielder, are the Western tennis leaders.

Every building and loan association thus far admitted to membership in the Federal Home Loan Bank system is in a strong financial position, points out Ward B. Whitlock, president of the United States Building and Loan League, which originally sponsored the home loan bank law.

Four men, who were alleged to have been present at the shooting and killing of one man and the wounding of three others in a so-called social club at Second Avenue and 124th Street at 2:30 A.M. yesterday, were sent to the House of Detention as material witnesses yesterday by Judge Freschi in General Sessions, due to lack of bail.

DETROIT, Jan. 26. -- Has the district school, after more than a century of trial in Michigan, justified its existence or must the one-room schoolhouse in which fancy delights to picture the future leaders of the country forming their simple, sturdy backgrounds, disappear before modern conditions?

To the Editor of The New York Times: No sufficient emphasis is being placed by thinking men in this country upon the fact that any step in the direction of removal of the so-called Polish Corridor means another and a much more disastrous war than the last.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Jan. 28. -- An urgent patriotic appeal to the nation to strengthen its defense forces was issued today on the occasion of the fifteenth anniversary of the outbreak of the civil war of 1918 by General Justus Mannerheim.

THE Paramount announces its attractions for the new month of February. Following "Luxury Liner," which, with a cast headed by George Brent, Zita Johann and Vivienne Osborne, will make its bow on Friday, there will come successively "She Done Him Wrong."

MONTREAL, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Frank Shields, young star from New York, carried the Canadian indoor tennis championship back to the United States as he overwhelmed the 1932 champion, J. Gilbert Hall of South Orange, N.J., 6 -- 2, 6 -- 4, 6 -- 2, today.

ASSURED by meteorologists that at a height of about 1,500 feet there is always a steady breeze, Honnef, a German builder of radio towers, steps forward with a grandiose windmill of radically new design. He would rear a steel frame 400 meters (1,312 feet) high and mount upon it a frame carrying several windwheels, each 160 meters (524.8 feet) in diameter.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Resorting to the drastic discharge petition after Democrats had bottled up the plan in committee, House Republicans today insured a vote Feb. 13 on legislation to increase import duties against nations with depreciated currencies.

DIANA WYNYARD, the leading actress in "Cavalcade," who recently signed a contract with Metro, has postponed her trip to Europe to play the feminine lead opposite John Barrymore in "Reunion in Vienna," which is scheduled for early production.

CAIRO, Jan. 27. -- Ever since the Mixed Tribunal rendered the judgment last Saturday that the Egyptian Government must pay the coupons and capital of the Egyptian unified privileged guaranteed debt bonds in gold the predominant topic of conversation throughout the country has been "gold or paper."
With an entry even larger than at the preceding exhibition, last week's specialty show proved decidedly satisfactory to members of the American Spaniel Club.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP). -- Wizardry with a tennis racket that carried George M. Lott of Chicago to a place on four United States Davis Cup teams was his again today as he conquered the intercollegiate star, Clifford Sutter of New Orleans, to win the singles championship of the all-South tennis tournament.
JANUARY'S broadcast finale presents Mary Garden from the operatic realm; Giovanni Martinelli singing melodies of Italy, and Lotte Lehmann, from Vienna opera, in her debut on the American air.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- Truck freight and express companies of the country are watching with interest for the outcome of a decision handed down by the Illinois Commerce Commission, barring two truck companies from using the State highways and hailed as a victory for the railroads.

TORONTO, Jan. 28 (Canadian Press). -- Canada defeated the United States today for the Lapham Trophy, offered for international squash racquets team competition, winning eleven out of fifteen events. It was Canada's third victory in twelve years of competition, against eight for the United States and one for England.

MUSIC has long been recognized as the spinal column of broadcasting. But the broadcasters lament that they must pay so much for the backbone of their invisible channels. With the appointment of Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in the Wilson Cabinet, as counselor, the National Association of Broadcasters assert that "this is but the first gun in the campaign for lower rates for melodies."

Improvement of trade relations in manufacturing lines which have gone "sour" because of conditions during the last two years is a major objective of an intensive program of retailer-manufacturer cooperation which is being sponsored for the coming year by the merchandising division of the National Retail Dry Goods Association.

LARGE expenditures for harbor improvements by Japan in her mandated islands in the Pacific Ocean recently brought down upon her the suspicion that she was secretly building a naval base in the South Seas. When the question was raised at the recent meetings of the League of Nation's Mandates Commission, the Japanese delegate denied that there were any grounds for such an accusation.

IF possible, even thinner and sillier them the author's previous novel, this yarn tells at the adventures which befell an ex-Marine Corps aviator after he had completed six years' service and enrolled as bodyguard of a metropolitan bootleg czar whose secret racket is dope smuggling.

Freight rates proposed by the railroads are attacked as both too low and too high in protests made by Western and Eastern shippers to the Interstate Commerce Commission. The Western shippers oppose the plans of the railroads to meet the competition of Western inland waterways with low rates and complain that the rates which they propose would tend to offset the development of the waterways.

Adoption of a broad program of public works holds out the only prospect of jobs for millions of unemployed, Robert D. Kohn, architect and executive chairman of the National Committee for Trade Recovery, said yesterday. "Despite the fact that many millions throughout the United States are in distress," he asserted, "there is no scarcity of investment money if the security is sound, as demonstrated by the recent oversubscription of low-interest, short-term Treasury issues.

Bonds called for payment last week before their dates of maturity were mostly for small amounts. Additions to the January list consisted of small lots of municipals, while the principal calls posted for future months were two public utility issues, called in their entirety.

DUBLIN. TWO distinguished Irishmen, both members of the new Academy of Letters, are at present lecturing in the United States. W.B. Teats, founder of the academy, is returning to Ireland in a few days, while Dr. Oliver St. John Gogarty is just beginning his tour.

ERNEST TRUEX is the most recent of the theatrical old guard to celebrate his cinematic debut. He is to be seen at the Capitol in "Whistling in the Dark," in the role which he played in the Broadway stage production last year.

THE romantic note was sounded lightly last week, without providing any proof that romance is to serve as the theme of the next movement in art. It is interesting that the Kraushaar Galleries thought the time ripe to exhibit a score of the romantic lithographs of Henri Fantin-Latour, and that from the upper rim of Greenwich.

URBANA, Ill. THE functions of a university should be directed "to help people to be the sort who can keep on growing with their world," in the opinion of Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, who, it has just been announced, will become chancellor of New York University on July 1.

NEWLLANO, La., Jan. 20. -- Five hundred men, women, and children here know the depression only by hearsay. They are the citizens of the Llano Cooperative Colony, and since their land is just as fertile as it was in 1929 and since there is just as much power to be extracted from a cord of wood in their boilers, they expect to continue to eat heartily and sleep warmly.

HOLLTWOOD. THE return of Greta Garbo to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer on April 1 became a generally accepted fact this week when, in the face of refusals of studio heads to discuss the matter, under-executives on the lot admitted that a story has been prepared for the Swedish star and that shooting should begin early in April.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- House members may not be able to get shaves and haircuts free as do Senators, but they did spend $3,238,000 on a payroll last year, and that does not include the more than $4,000,000 which they got themselves.

Sixty-three business and professional men living at the West Twenty-third Street Y.M.C.A., whose employment with the Emergency Work Bureau will be discontinued after March 15, have worked out a plan of self-rehabilitation which consists in the establishment of a cooperative store for the handling of well-advertised merchandise on consignment.

WHEN Professor Einstein was speaking about the world situation at Pasadena the other day he felt obliged to make two preliminary reservations. Only one of them concerns us here. "The first of these is the obstacle of the black dress suit," he said.

TOKYO. NEW ideas of the weakness and importance of the news reel have been brought back from a tour of the world's cinema theatres by Kiyohito Ushiwara, a director of the Shochiku, one of the principal producing companies in Japan.

Tomorrow will be the last day for receiving entries for the fifty-seventh annual Westminster Kennel Club show to be held in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 13, 14 and 15. The lists have been held open as long as possible to give fanciers throughout the country every opportunity to get their entries in.

Contracts for coffee futures continued their steady advance in price yesterday, and silver futures turned about after several days of declines to make small gains. Otherwise, the trend of prices in local commodity markets continued downward.

ANN VICKERS" will surely take its place with the major creations of Sinclair Lewis. It is a book fully representative of the qualities for which he has come to stand in American literature, and it could not be the work of any other author.

A DISTINCTIVE viewpoint in the study of Mormonism is taken by Arbaugh in this volume of scholarly and extensive research. In his youth the author lived in Carthage, Ill., next door to the old jail where Joseph Smith met his death, and there he saw and talked with young missionary Mormons on pilgrimage to the Mormon Mecca.

In spite of its great concentration of industry, trade and finance, Manhattan is predominantly a residential community; it will probably continue to be a predominantly residential community for a long, long time.

Members of the Order of Americans of Armorial Ancestry visited the Cathedral of St. John the Divine in a body yesterday afternoon, after the annual luncheon and meeting of the order at the Waldorf-Astoria, and presented a check for $800 to Bishop William T. Manning for the historic and patriotic bay.

OTTAWA, Jan. 28. -- The New York Rangers ran wild tonight, scoring a 9 -- 2 victory over the Ottawa Senators in a National Hockey League game. It was the largest total any league team has posted this season. Cecil Dillon led the Rangers' scoring with four counters.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 28. -- Twenty-two classmates of Franklin D. Roosevelt at Columbia Law School came here tonight for a reunion, having selected Warm Springs as their place of meeting in honor of the President-elect.

PARIS. LAST year for the first time in its seventy years of existence the Societe des Bains de Mer et du Cercle des Etrangers a Monaco, which is the official title of the Monte Carlo Casino and its associate activities, did not pay a dividend.

The fact that railroad bonds held their ground well yesterday in the brief trading period on the Stock Exchange, following Senator Couzens's resolution to make all further loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the carriers subject to Congressional approval, was an outstanding feature of the day's bond transactions.

The opening of the annual city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship basketball tournament is the principal event scheduled this week for New York City's schoolboy athletes. Since the late stages of last Fall's football campaign, the public high school court squads have been preparing for the tourney.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- General Kurt von Schleicher's mission as "the Chancellor of peace" came to an end at noon today after fifty-seven days when President von Hindenburg refused him authority to dissolve the Reichstag in the event that it denied his Cabinet its confidence next week.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- The assumption in London is that Sir Ronald Lindsay, Ambassador to Washington, is returning next week with a detailed account of how President-elect Roosevelt intends to deal with the debts problem.

A SWEEPING indictment of vast commercial interests in this country and a caustic criticism of the Department of Agriculture of the United States Government are contained in this book, whose authors style themselves as engineers and technicians.

MADISON, Minn., Jan. 28 (AP). -- Three thousand farmers, protesting evictions from land for non-payment of debts, prevented foreclosure sales of five farms in three contiguous western Minnesota counties today.

Although the gusty weather prevented any attempt to take him and his friends for a ride over New York in a dirigible, as had been planned, Professor Auguste Piccard, the Swiss scientist who in his studies of the stratosphere has ascended higher than any other man, did have a birthday party yesterday at the Hotel St. Moritz.

JOHN C. VAN DYKE'S introduction to the American edition of Sir Charles Holmes's book has a touch of poignancy added to its interest by the fact that it must have been among the last things that be wrote, since it is dated so recently as last July.

IN this volume has been collected together prose pieces, several of them addresses before intellectual bodies, written by John Masefield during recent years. The first piece in the book, and by far the longest, is the narrative. "The Taking of Helen," published independently some seasons ago.

Young men and women who recently have been appointed foreign missionaries by the United Lutheran Church in America but are not yet on the way to their fields will be kept at home until financial conditions improve, the Rev. Dr. Frederick H. Knubel, president of the national body, announced yesterday at his office in the Lutheran Church House, 39 East Thirty-fifth Street.

THE system of Federal-aid roads today criss-crosses the entire country, connecting every city of more than 5,000 population with through interstate highways. It was not always so. The program, involving financial assistance by the national government to the States in the construction and maintenance of highways, was initiated in 1916.

OSLO, Norway, Jan. 28. -- Eddie Schroeder of Chicago, American Olympic speed skater last year, showed the way to Norway's best speedsters in the 5,000-meter race today as the international ice meet between the United States and Norway opened before a crowd of 15,000.

Riding hard through the best played game the season has yet produced, Los Nanduces moved to the front of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo Circuit last night, turning back Allenhurst, 13 1/2 to 9, in the ring of Squadron A Armory.

The importance of America's participation in the settlement of international affairs is emphasized by Count Carlo Sforza, former Italian Foreign Minister, who is in this country to lecture at several American universities on the invitation of the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace.

A BOOK that has the unmistakable ring of truth and that has caught in its pages something of the vastness of the Hungarian plains, magically haunted by the Fata Morgana. At 9 years of age Sandor is given his choice between becoming a shoemaker's apprentice or a cowboy.

A balanced budget and a thoroughly solvent organization with a full schedule of play ahead for 1933 was the accounting that President Holcombe Ward gave yesterday of his first year of stewardship over the Eastern Lawn Tennis Association.

ROME. THE success of previous Italian group flights has emboldened General Italo Balbo, Air Minister, to attempt his more ambitious plan for this year -- to fly the North Atlantic and to lead twenty Italian seaplanes to Chicago.

FOLLOWING its long-established custom, the Smithsonian Institution includes in its last annual report not merely an account of its own scientific activities, but a series of articles, reprinted from other sources, to reveal the progress made in physics, chemistry, biology, geology and anthropology.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Reorganization and consolidation of local governments and school districts today was recommended as a method of adjusting present-day educational needs with economic conditions bred by the depression.

LONDON. MANY Englishmen seem to hold that Sir John Simon has been only a qualified success as Foreign Secretary. On Issues which range from Manchuria to disarmament, they describe him as a great lawyer in a post which calls for a great statesman.

PANAMA CITY, Jan. 24. -- The influence of Mexico in Central American politics may be expected to increase as a result of the withdrawal of the United States Marines from Nicaragua and the denunciation of the Central American peace treaty, which for almost ten years has prevented recognition of governments that have come into power by force and revolution.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28. -- A few minutes after he had been notified of his discharge as a clerk in the office of the Nassau County Emergency Work Bureau here, Adolph Lux, 52 years old, of 69 Lent Avenue, Hempstead, fell dead on Mineola Boulevard.

The Appellate Term of the Supreme Court has reversed a judgment for $1,544 obtained by Abercrombie Fitch Company against the Fokker Aircraft Corporation of America for a complete outfit of wearing apparel furnished on June 26, 1930, to Air Commodore Sir Charles Kingsford-Smith, Captain J.P. Saul and two other members of the crew of the Fokker plane Southern Cross on the day it arrived here after crossing the Atlantic, it was learned yesterday.

Prominent women who are active in behalf of Greenwich House have taken over the performance of "The Late Christopher Bean" on the night of Feb. 16 at the Henry Miller Theatre to raise funds for carrying on the activities of the Health Centre maintained at the settlement at 27 Barrow Street.

Just one hundred years ago the citizens of New York were deeply interested in the provision made by the city to provide a reasonable water supply for a large area of Manhattan Island, and the completion in 1833 of the splendid city reservoir in Thirteenth Street, near the Bowery, was hailed as a noteworthy public improvement.

Women interested in many of the well-known private schools in the city are acting as sponsors for a series of Sunday afternoon musicales by young musicians of the Music School Settlement. The first musicale in the series will take place next Sunday afternoon in the auditorium of the Spence School.

To the Dramatic Editor: A news item can hardly be expected to convey the truth of any situation. When the closing of the Group Theatre was announced last week no light was shed on the reasons for this sudden decision. It must have been assumed that, discouraged by the failure of its latest production, it had decided to abandon its venture.

THE reader approaching Trotsky's bulky volumes faces a task more complicated than in the usual historical work. What we have before us is a personal account of events in which Trotsky played a leading and decisive part.

SAN FRANCISCO, Jan. 26. -- Democratic leadership in California is faced with two problems growing out of the recrudescence of the party in this State as a result of the Roosevelt sweep in the November election.

DETROIT. THE annual meeting of the Society of Automotive Engineers held here last week made it apparent why the public constantly gets better automobiles. It is because the vehicle's designer never is satisfied.
DUBLIN, Jan. 28. -- Latest returns indicated today that President Eamon de Valera's Fianna Fail would have a clear majority of one in the Dail Eireann.

The problems created by inability of many property owners to meet "unusually high fixes charges of interest and taxes" are receiving legislative attention, points out Ray Hofford, executive vice president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards, in a review of some of the measures introduced at Albany for the purpose of aiding real estate.

IN this little book Mr. Weekley, British etymologist well known to American readers by halt a score of volumes, offers a sequel to his two works on "Words Ancient and Modern," although he apologetically explains that it isn't the sequel he hoped to write and had promised in the preface to his Etymological Dictionary that he would write.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 28 (AP). -- An orgy of price-cutting during which tires were marked down 56 per cent in a single sweep was at an end today, halted by a command from factory headquarters in Akron, Ohio.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A plan for the guarantee of industry on an insurance basis was considered by the Commerce and Marine Commission of the American Bankers Association last year. It was devised by Fred I. Kent, a director of the Bankers Trust Company of New York City and chairman of the commission.
SUMTER, S.C., Jan. 26. -- The people back home have been generally pleased with the temper of the new Legislature, but experience has taught them to reserve judgment until the session is over.

LONDON. QUEEN MART of England, who is almost an expert in ner knowledge of antiques, is a generous patron of English museums. She visits them often, knows what each of them wants and keeps them in mind while traveling.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Bank debits outside New York City were higher during the week ended Jan. 21 than in the preceding week, according to the weekly survey of domestic conditions made public today by the Commerce Department.

IT is common, in every generation, to complain of the degeneracy of the age. Whenever we feel, as we so frequently do, that the world in which we live is far from satisfactory, we take refuge in an imaginary picture of the past.

THE Tuskegee Choir of 100 voices, under the direction of William L. Dawson, will make its first New York appearance in Carnegie Hall Wednesday evening, Feb. 8. The choir, composed entirely of students from Tuskegee Institute, Alabama, came to New York a month ago for the opening of Radio City Music Hall.

LONDON, Jan. 13. DINNER AT EIGHT," written by Mr. George S. Kaufman and Miss Edna Ferber, is already so familiar to American readers that I shall not discuss it at length. Its violence and variety have pleased the London public and Mr. Cochran has an entertainment which will fill the Palace Theatre for many weeks.

ATLANTA, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, tonight said the information that President-elect Roosevelt proposed to reopen the discussion of War Debts was "the best news that England and the world have had for a long time."

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Chancellor of the Exchequer Neville Chamberlain, announced flatly tonight that Britain would not stabilize her currency until she was certain the gold standard would work and until there had been "an international agreement as to conditions under which it shall be worked."

PHOENIX, Ariz., Jan. 26. -- With the inauguration of Governor B.B. Moeur and the convening of the Legislature, the new Democratic administration enters on what will be the most important and probably the stormiest session since Arizona won statehood.

LONDON, Jan. 26. -- Equipment for a flight to the summit of Mount Everest must be similar in many respects to that needed for an attempt for an altitude record, and yet in some important particulars it is very different.

The American Irish Historical Society will seek to raise $1,000,000 during 1933 to carry on the work of research in Irish contributions to American history, it was decided yesterday at the annual meeting of the society at the headquarters at 132 East Sixteenth Street.

FOR the twentieth time -- or, if the Bill of Rights is regarded as a unit, the eleventh time -- the American people have amended the rules and by-laws for the government of the nation drawn up at Philadelphia in 1787.

PARIS, Jan. 28. -- Taxpayers trying to march on the Chamber of Deputies and the Senate clashed with mounted Republican Guards and the police in the streets of Paris today as France, without a government for the second time in six weeks, tackled the hard task of trying to find a new one.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28. -- Surrounded by flooded swamps in which are thousands of poisonous jungle snakes, the Bolivian and Paraguayan armies have apparently settled down to wait for the drying up of the roads, which may not come until April.
Revealing an abundance of offensive power, the Colgate University basketball team vanquished Fordham, 38 to 33, last night in the Fordham gymnasium before 1,500 spectators.

THE ferocious demand for orchestral conductors of the highest possible rank and the most sensational attractiveness to the public is exhausting the available supply. What is to be done about it? Where are we in America going for new lions of the baton?
Following is the text of Peru's reply to Secretary of State Stimson's note asking the Lima Government to withdraw its forces from the Leticia district:

One of the novel entertainments of the Winter is in prospect in plans for the Five-Star Supper Dance to be given on Saturday in the Starlight Roof Garden of the Waldorf-Astoria to aid the work of the women's committee of the Emergency Unemployment Relief.

THE Spring fashion cruise will take the smart woman from cape to cape-even though she does not set foot on a gangplank. Capes will shelter tier wanderings from morn till midnight. If she chooses, they will travel with her to Palm Beach, accompany her on her shopping tours and to luncheon or tea, motor with her to her country club.

NEW materials for furniture and decorative accessories are adding to their charm and widening their field of usefulness. A synthetic plastic substance invades the reaim of glass, forming unbreakable goblets whose stems are of metal.

BOSTON, Jan. 27. -- The Board of Tax Appeals is under fire. Several bills have been filed with the General Court calling for its modification or abolition, and lively hearings have been held, especially that of last Monday on the abolition bill introduced at the behest of Mayor Curley of Boston.
Early steps to promote suits and blouses are urged by Tobe, fashion and merchandise counselor to retail stores, in a report especially prepared for THE TIMES.

The Constitution of the United States has been amended twenty times since the establishment of the present Federal Government in 1789. The first ten in the following list were proposed on Sept. 25, 1789, at the first session of Congress, and were declared in force on Dec. 15, 1791. The dates of submission and adoption of the other ten are given below. The complete list follows:

DIKES are usually built to keep water out, not to hold it in. But in the case of the huge dike -- the largest in Holland -- which separates the North Sea from the Zuider Zee, both purposes are served. It prevents the salt water of the sea from entering the Zuider Zee, and when necessary it keeps the fresh water of the Yssel and Amstel Rivers from pouring into the ocean.

The research being carried on at Columbia University by the group that withdrew from Technocracy is something more than what is generally understood by the term "scholarly enterprise" and aims at finding a comprehensive social plan for permanent reconstruction, it was intimated in an address by Professor Walter Rautenstrauch at a luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Hotel Woodstock yesterday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28. -- Yale's polo trio overwhelmed the Chicago Riding and Driving Club, 22 1/2 to 3, today. The visitors, with Earle A.S. Hopping, international polo star, in their line-up at No. 2, failed to get any scoring ac- tion until the final period, when they tallied three goals.

The appointment of receivers last week for the Paramount Publix Corporation and the Radio-KeithOrpheum Corporation, two of the country's five principal owners of motion-picture theatre chains, was attributed to the failing attendance throughout the country and to the inability of the companies to readjust propportionately the charges due on the theatres bought, built or rented in the boom years.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The Senate bowed before the President today and, on second consideration, passed the deficiency bill without the provision for Congressional approval of income tax refunds which caused Mr. Hoover to veto the original measure.

The break between Columbia University and Howard Scott, leader of technocracy, brought to a climax last week a movement, which, in its swift rise, seemed for a time to be leading to a new socio-economic cult or religion.

Manhattan College broke its losing streak in emphatic fashion, defeating a courageous Cathedral College quintet, 32-18, in a hard-fought game at the Manhattan gymnasium last night. Taking the floor with a new combination, the Jaspers flashed their best basketball of the season in the opening half to amass a 21-6 lead.

THERE is the tale of the American tourists who, some years ago, bought, in the course of their European travels, a very fine piece of period furniture -- only to discover, upon turning it upside down, that the chair had been manufactured in Grand Rapids.

HARTFORD, Jan. 26. -- A Republican party that does not seem to be aware of its minority status and a Democratic party suffering from lack of experience and an inferiority complex have resulted in the production of little more patronage for the Democrats than in the years when they were hopelessly in the minority.

Fred Berry, president of the Bronx Board of Trade, in outlining the main program of that organization for the coming year, states that the two improvements most essential for the borough's welfare are the completion of the Triborough Bridge and the opening of the Concourse subway.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- John B. Robinson, lawyer and former member of Congress, who for many years was a picturesque figure in the Republican party of Delaware County, died at his home here today after an illness of several weeks.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Jan. 28. -- Marion Talley, retired operatic singer, slipped quietly into Superior Court here last night, and on her plea that she had become a bride through the influence of fraudulent promises obtained a decree of annulment of her marriage to Michael Raucheisen, 43-year-old German concert pianist.

Several proposed changes in the law regulating hunting in this State will be presented to the legislators at Albany and their chances to pass generally are assumed to be very good. All of the new laws have been written with the hope that they would add greater strength to the present code, which has been beneficial in keeping the stock of game in this State up to a high standard.

RESORTING to the business of Providing brothers for her principal characters, Mrs. Glyn here tells of the ghastly predicament which arises when one of these two brothers becomes mixed up in the marriage plans of the elder.

BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- The sixth successive flood tide of the wild northeast storm which has lashed the Massachusetts coast for the last three days without cease early this afternoon broke all previous records and sent the property loss to well over $1,000,000, with the damage estimates mounting hourly and relief in sight.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Former Governor Smith of New York today took himself out of all consideration for a post in the Roosevelt Cabinet with a flat "No, sir," to queries regarding his acceptance of a place in the new official family.

Various organizations that minister to the welfare of children or youths have taken over performances of "Design for Living," a new play by Noel Coward, to raise funds for carrying on their philanthropic activities. Their performance on Tuesday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre will aid the Boys' Bureau, sponsored by the Charity Organization Society and the Association for Improving the Condition of the Poor.

BEING a lecturer for the Theatre Guild and a publicity or general manager for Herman Shumlin, Allan Scott and George Haight got together one rainy afternoon in Chicago, where "Mourning Becomes Electra" and "Grand Hotel" were doing nicely, thanks to Eugene O'Neill and Vicki Baum.

The Montclair Athletic Club defeated the New York A.C. quintet in an Eastern Athletic Club League game on the losers' court last night, 41 to 28. The Winged Foot players led several times in the early moments, but the visitors spurted before half-time, and started the final session on the long end of an 18-to-12 score.

THOSE who like their cowboy lingo spread thick will find rich entertainment in this very talky new book by the prolific author of the "Bar 20" -- "Hopalong Cassidy" series. The tale gets off to a slow start, but later on among the talk is interspersed plenty of action -- swift, sure-footed, sure-handed and deadly.

Today. Convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America at the Ohab Zedek Synagogue, 118 West Ninety-fifth Street, and at the Hotel Edison, 228 West Forty-seventh Street, today and tomorrow. Dinner at Hotel Edison tonight.

In all the discussion of the Twentieth Amendment, changing from March 4 to Jan. 20 the date at which the Presidential term ends, little has been said about how the older date came originally to be fixed. The reason for the present change is the long and awkward interval, sometimes of virtual "interregnum," which separates the inauguration of March 4 from the November election day.

Poker Under Difficulties. Washington dispatches now speak of the war-debt talks with London as a game of poker. England is playing poker when she declares that it must be a drastic revision of debts without any economic stipulations or reservations.

Passenger service on the Eighth Avenue subway will be extended under the East River to Borough Hall, Brooklyn, early next Wednesday morning, the Board of Transportation announced yesterday. The first train will leave Borough Hall station at 6:12 A.M. for its thirtyseven minute express run to 207th, Street, Manhattan.

LA PAZ, Jan. 28. -- A communique issued by the general staff at 10 P.M. stated Paraguayan counterattacks in the Nanawa sector on Thursday was repulsed. The casualties among the attackers were put at 300 dead and many wounded. The Bolivians lost six dead and twenty-nine wounded, it was stated.

Marking the opening of a drive for 10,000 free hospital beds for the unemployed, the Broad Street Hospital will stage a ball and carnival aboard the United States liner Leviathan on Thursday night, Dr. Mary Walton, chairman of the campaign committee, announced yesterday.

HAVANA, Jan. 28. -- The 8-year-old Hollister gelding, Pigeon Hole, which last year descended to competition on the half-mile tracks when it was thought that he was through with racing, proved an easy winner at Oriental Park today in the Jose Marti Handicap.

THAT the way of opera in the Soviet Union is far from smooth, and that attempts to link art, economics and politics are as hazardous in the land of the Bolsheviki as elsewhere, are freely admitted by A. Kobylinsky in an article printed in a recent number of the Moskauer Rundschau, the German weekly published in the Russian capital.

The Ellsworth transantarctic flight, planned for next Winter will be the "last big geographical discovery it is possible to make," Sir Hubert Wilkins said last night in describing the expedition's plans to an address at the annual dinner of the Explorers Club.

ALL through this Autumn and Winter of our discontent exhibitions of prints have been increasing, not by the elusive method of "leaps and bounds," but with a steady reassuring progress making something of headway against the discouragement invading art circles.

The disabled veterans' preference that places policemen and firemen with war injuries at the head of civil service promotion lists was attacked yesterday by H. Eliot Kaplan, chairman of the executive council of the Committee for Modification of Veterans' Preference.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Attorney General William A. Stevens, commenting today on the Interstate Commerce Commission examiner's report on New York Harbor lighterage, said:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Plans for the Roosevelt inaugural parade on March 4 have progressed to the point where all the marshals but one have been appointed, and it is known that the parade will be limited to about 10,000 persons. Thus the procession should require about two hours to pass the reviewing stand.

CONTRIBUTIONS totaling $471.20 to the Stage Relief Fund, Inc., were announced during the past week at the headquarters of that organization in the Hotel Algonquin. Added to the total of previous contributions, this brings the grand total of funds which have passed into the exchequer of the organization to $15,801.50.

PARIS, Jan. 27. -- The French travel, hotel and luxury industries have become seriously concerned over reports from the United States of an alleged boycott against touring in France and against the purchase of French-made goods, which is said to have arisen out of the war-debt controversy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Asserting that reductions from last year in the War Department appropriation bill, passed by the House this week, threatened the very fabric of national defense. The Army and Navy Journal, in an editorial today, calls upon all officers to enlist help to defeat the cuts.

An unidentified woman about 60 years old, whose skull had been fractured, apparently by a blow from a hammer, was found unconscious early yesterday morning in a lot near Old Mill Road and 102d Street, Elmhurst, Queens. A bloodstained hammer was found near by.

Leaders of the Roosevelt-Farley-Flynn section of the Democratic party of the State, in line with their policy of assuring control of the State organization, have decided to name men of proved loyalty as Federal attorneys in the two districts which include New York City.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 28 (AP). -- Mystery surrounded the whereabouts tonight of Colonel Luke Lea, who is facing a prison sentence in North Carolina.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Harold A. Clark, 39 years old, assistant general sales manager of the McGraw-Hill Publishing Company of New York and former football captain at Pennsylvania State College, was killed instantly early today in Woodbridge, N.J., when an automobile he was driving was in collision with the rear of a truck trailer on Route 25 near Lafayette Road.

To facilitate the exchange of goods through barter on the widest scale possible, a national plan of barter through cooperatives of unemployed was proposed here yesterday by Paul P. Gourrich, economist and originator of the tax and allotment scheme, on which the present farm parity plan is based.
