Conditions for the ocean race of the Gibson Island yacht squadron, which will be this year's offshore thrash alternate to the Bermuda contest, were sent out yesterday to yacht clubs and cruising craft owners. Unofficial advices have been received of a dozen entries, although the event will not be held until June 24.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The State Federation of Labor announced today its support of Senator William T. Byrne's bill to create a system of compulsory unemployment insurance.

BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- Urging "the greater protection of our workers and further reduction of the working day" as a basis for stabilizing the American social order, the intelstate conference on labor laws adopted an extensive program today of "humane" labor measures to be submitted to the Governors and Legislatures of nine industrial States.

GENEVA, Jan. 28. -- Another peace-making role probably will be offered to Major Gen. Frank R. McCoy by the League of Nations if Bolivia and Paraguay accept a commission of inquiry into their Chaco dispute, as the Council's committee of three semi-officially proposed to them yesterday.

SIMULTANEOUSLY with the celebration of the 400th anniversary of the birth of Montaigne, Alfred A. Knopf will publish on March 1 a new and definitive edition in English of "The Essays of Michel de Montaigne," translated and edited by Jacob Zeitlin, Professor of English Literature in the University of Illinois.

PALM BEACH. -- The rosters of the large hotels are almost filled and the number of Winter residents have increased greatly, the majority of them entertaining extensively with house parties. Hence the social and sports barometer of Palm Beach is rising high.
PARIS, Jan. 27. -- There is much weary effort being made in Paris these days to try to understand just why France and the French are momentarily so unpopular in the United States.

A NEW German process for making the sound strip on a piece of film without actually recording sounds by electrical processes has been developed in the preparation of a film for public exhibition, according to an account published recently in The London Times.

THE CATHEDRAL OF ST. JOHN THE DIVINE was born in dreams one hundred and odd Winters ago. Since 1892, when the cornerstone was laid, it has been building on Morningside Heights -- that is to say, through twoscore years.

FROM whatever viewpoint considered, Maria Theresa of Austria was an amazing person. Either as Queen for many years of one of the great nations of her day or as biologic function incarnate and active, her achievements stir the student of her career to wonder.

Recent developments in the war debt situation, which include the beginning of negotiations with the debtor nations for further readjustments, represent an interesting historical analogy with the debts arising from the Napoleonic wars and the manner in which settlement was made between Great Britain, the creditor country, and her Continental allies, including Austria, Russia, Prussia and Portugal, the debtor countries.

WASHINGTON. THE veterans' lobby, one of the best-organized and most influential in Washington, is preparing for another big legislative battle over the effort to reduce the sums paid out annually by the government in benefits to ex-soldiers and their families.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- A move looking to perpetuation of the Progressive organization set up in the 1932 campaign primarily to elect Roosevelt and to work for liberal legislation was undertaken here today by nine Senators. After a conference at the Capitol they appointed a subcommittee to investigate the prospects of a permanent and active group.
TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Taking five first places to two, the Rider College swimming team scored a 33 -- 26 victory over Fordham University today.

HERE is an item of some sort, the exact classification being a bit vague. It costs Sam H. Harris just exactly $15 each week for the crockery broken during the philosophical course of "Dinner at Eight." It seems that several of Mr. Harris's myrmidons, wise in the ways of the world, wanted to purchase the dishes and other items in Woolworth's estimable stores.

IN this compact volume by the author of "The Revolt of the Masses." Jose Ortega y Gasset, the philosophy which underlay the earlier book, but was adumbrated therein rather than made specific, is now expounded in a far more particularized fashion.

The business depression and increased taxation are reducing the number of corportaions capitalized with no par value and $100 par value stock, it is indicated in a survey of companies listed on the New York Stock Exchange. In former years stocks with these par values far outnumbered all other groups.

Jove hurled his thunderbolts when he was angry, but could be placated by sacrifice. Luck in the chase depended on the favor of Diana. It was at the pleasure of Neptune that a voyage ended happily or disastrously. They were as temperamental as tenors and prima donnas, these vanished gods.
French and English furniture and decorations, Oriental arms, pewter, glass, porcelains, prints and other objects will be offered at auction here this week.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Jan. 14. -- The plan for conversion of the entire foreign debt of the States and municipalities of Brazil has been adopted. The measure which was recommended by the States Financial and Studies Commission had been under consideration by the government for some time.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Varied arguments against the domestic allotment farm relief bill were presented to the Senate Agricultural Committee by witnesses from the West and South.

American shippers pay nearly $600,000,000 annually on ocean freight, and American ship lines get about one-third of the total, according to R.J. Baker, secretary of the American Steamship Owners Association. In an address before Detroit industrialists last week, Mr. Baker said $300,000,000 was saved to American farmers in 1926 by the fact that American ships were available as replacements for British ships withdrawn from American ports by the British coal strike.

BOSTON, Jan. 27. TO report upon the Boston stage in summary -- the present is good, while the future might be more promising. On Saturday at the Shubert, "Counsellorat-Law" ends three weeks of prosperous stay, one of the longest runs, as runs go in Boston, of the season.

The creation of a Federal Trade System to regulate profits among capital, management and labor is proposed by Samuel S. Fels, president of Fels Co., soap manufacturers of Philadelphia, in the current issue of The Survey Graphic.

OTTAWA, Jan. 26. -- Canada's export business in liquor has held up fairly well in spite of the depression and the absence of direct and legal channels for shipment into the United States which existed until the middle of 1930. The Dominion's exports in 1930 amounted to 3,313,272 gallons of whisky; in 1931 to 2,554,625 gallons and last year to 2,347,177 gallons.

THIS novel by Thornton Wilder's sister is written in a style which one meets but rarely nowadays. It appears to have no tricks or affectations of any kind, perhaps because the tricks are so well hidden that they fulfill perfectly their function of giving the reader the illusion of complete reality.

LONDON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Five outstanding teams of the first division, including the mighty Aston Villa eleven, today were eliminated from the English Soccer Cup play as fourteen teams qualified for the fifth round of play. Two matches ended in ties.

How the average expenditures of school districts in many States compare with what Professor Paul R. Mort, director of the National Survey of School Finance, thinks they should be, is shown in the following table. The "minimum defensible standard" in any State, he says, should be what the districts of average wealth in that State provide.

A move to substitute the quota system of import restrictions for the depreciated currency legislation now under consideration in Congress was started here yesterday by protective tariff advocates. Proponents of the new plan, who are identified with high-tariff interests, suggest that the United States invoke a quota system similar to those used by France, Czechoslovakia and a number of other European countries.

MONTREAL, Jan. 28 (AP). -- The Montreal Maroons smashed Detroit's record of thirteen games without a defeat by beating the Red Wings, 4 to 1, tonight in a National Hockey League game before a crowd of 12,000.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Jan. 27. -- Like a mild-mannered dog that turns and shows its teeth when somebody steps on its tail, culture and education in Rochester have answered a welter of financial blows with such ferocity that they appear to have saved, for a time at least, a reputation that has been a community tradition for nearly a century.

PARIS. MOST women have a decided weakness for prints, inspired by their obviously practical qualities. They do not spot easily; they clean well, and they depend on their own gayety of color or design, thus obviating complication in cut or trimmine.

GENEVA, Jan. 27. -- There has been nothing but good news for League of Nations circles from Washington lately. President-elect Roosevelt's Manchurian statement, President Hoover's move against the arms traffic, the resumption of the Roosevelt-Hoover talks and the hastening of serious debt and economic negotiations have all cheered League quarters.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- St. John's College of Brooklyn suffered its second straight reverse tonight when an inspired Temple quintet registered a 42-33 victory over the Redmen at Mitten Hall as 3,500 looked on.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Free lighterage in New York Harbor was condemned as wasteful and unwarranted and prejudicial to the interests of New Jersey and the Port of Boston in a tentative report to the Interstate Commerce Commission today by Examiner Earl M. Steer, urging abolition of the practice.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 28. -- Mr. and Mrs. John R. Clawson entertained at their villa this afternoon with a tea for:

LAKELAND, Fla., Jan. 26 -- Any doubts that there would be a good tourist crop this Winter have proved groundless, for, despite the stringency of the times, visitors are here in numbers apparently equal to last year's total.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Jan. 26. -- Whether Puerto Rico Democrats are to endorse a woman for Governor probably will be decided within a week. The executive committee of the National Democratic party of Puerto Rico, corresponding to a State committee, is to meet soon at the convenience of Mrs. Jean Shipstead Whittemore, national committeewoman for the island, who is a candidate for the Governorship.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- City Manager John F. Donovan will celebrate the end of the first year of this city's city manager regime on Monday night by submitting to the city council a budget for 1933 which he says will be about $1,000,000 net less than that of last year.

THE destinies of three nations today are bound up, as rarely before in history, with the lives of three men -- Paul von Hindenburg. Benito Mussolini and Joseph Stalin. How did they attain power? What have they achieved?

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 28. -- For the first time in more than a decade the veteran New York combination of Clarence C. Pell and Stanley G. Mortimer will not be in the final round of the National Doubles Racquets Championship as a result of the upset victory recorded by W. Palmer Dixon and Herbert N. Rawlins Jr., also of New York, today.

A reduction in notes payable from $3,314,000 to $1,500,000 and the elimination from the asset side of the balance sheet of an item of $8,400,000 of long-term notes receivable are the principal changes reflected in the annual report of the Niagara Share Corporation.
WONDERLAND, to which a little girl named Alice was transported many, many years ago by a higher mathematician who called himself Lewis Carroll, was a place which, after a fashion, was cockeyed.

TOKYO, Jan. 28 (AP). -- The Navy Minister, Vice Admiral Mineo Osumi, revealed today that in its grand manoeuvres this year the Japanese Navy would operate in the seas "southward of the islands composing the territory of the empire," but he would not say whether the operations were to extend to the mandated islands in the South Seas.

The New York University's chorus and orchestra last night gave a benefit performance of Handel's "The Messiah" in Carnegie Hall. Hollis Dann conducted. The soloists were Ruth Rodgers, Amy Ellerman, Ernest Davis and Chase Baromeo. J. Thurston Noe was organist.

In a recent issue of the Harvard Alumni Bulletin, RAPHAEL DEMOS, Lecturer on Philosophy at that haven of intellect, discusses "Some Aspects of a Liberal Education." Since he is striving after clarification rather than novelty, his maxims, isolated in italic type, have a familiar ring.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- Harnessing the energy locked up in the atom for doing work is a long way off and unlikely to be attained by methods hitherto developed for distributing the atom, Dr. Arno Brasch of the University of Berlin declared in a popular lecture last night.

NOT much change in the trend of retail trade was noted during the week. Sales were somewhat lower in the earlier part, but cooler weather brought increased volume toward the close. Excellent values in furniture brought response to such promotions.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The situation in Europe is viewed with grave concern by informed observers here, as they feel a crisis may be nearer than the public imagines. Germany's approaching liberation from the restraint of the last restrictions imposed by the Versailles Treaty provokes ominous subterranean rumblings in several directions.

LONDON, Jan. 18. -- Feeling has been growing for a long time that Westminster Abbey is uncomfortably crowded with monuments. For some years there has been no room to erect new memorials however famous the recently departed may have been.

Directors of the United States Steel Corporation at their meeting on Tuesday will reach a decision whether the established rate of 7 per cent on the preferred stock, of which there are 3,602,811 shares outstanding, may properly be continued in the face of a steadily mounting deficit from operations.

John D. Rockefeller 3d, son of John D. Rockefeller Jr., builder of Rockefeller Center, will be the chief speaker at the craftsmanship exercises to be held in the seventy-story RAC Building, main unit in the midtown development, on Wednesday at 11:45 A.M.

With speculative impulses suppressed, the share market was more inert than usual yesterday and interest was centred largely in bonds. The foreign exchanges were irregular and the more important agricultural commodities moved slightly lower.

LONDON. THE census of book production, compiled annually by the Publishers' Circular, shows that in 1932 there were published in Great Britain 9,251 new books (excluding translations and pamphlets) and 4,320 new editions, as against 9,197 and 4,125 respectively in 1931.
Mrs. Frank A. Vanderlip heads a group of members of the Altrusa Club of New York that has arranged a dinner for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt on Feb. 8 in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Business on the Stock Exchange yesterday approximated 300,000 shares, the smallest volume for any day since July 9, 1932. The shrinkage in volume surprised Wall Street after the sharp pick-up the day before. Yesterday's market was without any distinguishing incident.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Garvin P. Taylor, son of W. Hetherington Taylor, said today that about ten days ago his father suffered an attack in his Winter home at St. Petersburg, Fla., which impaired his speech. Since then he had shown improvement, but at times appeared despondent.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Evidence of a State and nationwide development of interest in the barter and exchange plan for unemployment relief has been shown by the volume of letters from interested persons and organizations received by the industrial relations section of Princeton University, which has been doing advisorial work on this program, it was disclosed today by Professor J. Douglas Brown, the director of the section.

The filing of a bill of complaint against the American Tobacco Company and seven officers and directors, who are charged with having conspired to gain control of 56,712 shares of common stock of the company which had been set aside as an offering to employes, was announced yesterday by William Stuhr, a lawyer of Hoboken.

Two resolutions suggesting changes respectively in the laws governing the Home Loan Bank act and the Reconstruction Finance Corporation act were presented at the midwinter meeting last week in Washington, D.C., of the National Association of Real Estate Boards by Edward A. MacDougall, chairman of the housing committee of the national association.

Displaying the power that earned it national indoor and outdoor team championships a year ago, the New York Athletic Club came slamming back to the top in local track and field competition last night.

Asserting that the United States Government in its efforts to balance the Federal budget must adopt the methods long used by private business, which separates current expenses from capital outlays, Harvey S. Chase, chief statistician of the Massachusetts branch of the National Economy League, holds that operation and maintenance expenses must be balanced against income, with whatever surplus remains to be used for capital outlay and expansion of facilities.

Taking advantage of the lull in building activity, the First Avenue Association has begun a movement to extend zoning restrictions in several sections of Manhattan upper far east side, where it is believed such changes in zoning will foster future development along harmonious lines.

WASHINGTON. IF you are a left-handed writer, says Bert C. Farrar, handwriting expert for the Treasury Department, do not go in for forgery. Left-hand writing can be easily detected. The left-hand writer, with his pen above his work, shades the up-stroke.

Failure of wildcat speculation to pay, the fact that mortgages do become due and the value of proper building management are some of the lessons which owners and agents of realty properties have learned during the recent years of financial depression, points out William J. Demorest of the firm of Wm. A. White Sons.

HOW fast were the wheels of the Machine Age actually turning around before the depression hit us? Obviously, faster than ever before in the 150-year history of the Industrial Revolution. But that is not the real problem. It is not a question of the absolute machine tempo but of the rate of acceleration.

Proposals for licensing and supervising real estate bondholders' protective committees by the State Banking Department were taken under advisement yesterday by the joint legislative committee that is investigating the mortgage bond situation under the chairmanship of Nelson W. Cheney, State Senator.

MADRID, Jan. 27. -- Forcible seizure of land by peasants in South-western Spain has reached alarming proportions and if it continues to spread may well be comparable with that in Russia during the early days of Soviet rule.

AT intervals this column is the recipient of monographs, or "separates," exploiting special features of the great libraries of the country, such as the Huntingdon, the Pierpont Morgan, the New York Public, the John Carter Brown, the Annmary Brown Memorial, the William Clements, the Yale or the Harvard Of their existence and general nature we are all more or less familiar.

IN all but a few States the actual minimum status of education is determined by the economic ability of local districts to support schools rather than by social needs for education. This fact has resulted in vast areas in American education where the educational offering is distinctly inferior.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- Edgar Gould's brown mare Betty won the open jumping event at the amateur horse show held today in the big ring of the Saxon Woods Hunt Club, jumping twelve fences without an error. Samuel Abernathy had the mount and was one of ten in the big field that turned in clean performances the first time around.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Inserting new and binding restrictions on prohibition-enforcement activities, the House today passed and sent to the Senate a bill allowing only $8,440,000 for these activities next year.

THE Winter issue of The Bridge, published by Evander Childs High School, in New York, is a beautiful example of periodical making. From the attractive red and yellow cover and end papers down to the least detail of type arrangement and spacing, it indicates not only the taking of infinite pains but also creative intelligence of no mean order.

Probably one of the best ways to cultivate interest in a sport is to bring the potential competitor to the field, court or rink and allow the person to become an eye-witness. That is virtually what those in authority at Georgian Court College, Lakewood, N.J., intend to do on Saturday.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Setting the pace from the rise of the barrier, the Southland Stable's Playtime was the surprise winner of the Ponchartrain Handicap, desided over a mile and a sixteenth route at the Fair Grounds today. The time was 1:46 1-5.

SEA ISLAND BEACH, Ga. -- Elaborate plans are being formulated for participation of the colonists of Sea Island Beach and near-by neighbors in the celebration this year of the bicentennial of the founding of Georgia, many events of historic importance in Colonial history having taken place in this vicinity.

The House bill to amend the bankruptcy law, which, among its clauses, would provide for the expedition of railroad reorganizations, aroused mixed comment in banking circles last week. It was conceded that passage of the act would help operations like the readjustment being pushed by the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway.

IT does not seem possible to write a fresh and original life of Marie Antoinette, the subject of so much writing, but Katharine Anthony has done it. It is her own Marie Antoinette who stands out vividly in these pages, and a convincing one.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Frank Hanson of the Columbia University Club, returning to competition after being inactive for a season, defeated Edward G. McLaughlin, a clubmate, runner-up last year and seeded third in the present tourney, in the semi-finals of the New Jersey State squash tennis championship at the Short Hills Club today.

The members of the Police Department were lauded for their charitable works and for their willingness to cooperate with the city administration in the interests of economy by Mayor O'Srien last night in an address at the nineteenth annual entertainment and reception of the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association in Madison Square Garden, at which more than 20,000 were present.
NEW YORK. Dr. Preston Pope Satterwhite will give a dinner on Feb. 9 at his home, 960 Fifth Avenue.

GENEVA, Jan. 28 (AP). -- Premier Jose Manzanilla of Peru informed the League of Nations in a telegram today that his government regarded Colombia's expedition up the Amazon River as a threat to Peruvian inhabitants of the disputed port city of Leticia and that Peru purposed to "uphold the established rights of minorities and defend our nationals."

THE lull in construction work of all types is giving architects, engineers and builders an opportunity to develop a vast number and variety of plans for possible future building projects, or to set down in blue prints and models their ideas of how new materials, new equipment and changing commercial and residential requirements will affect the design of structures of the future.

GENEVA, Jan. 28. -- A new method of international financial cooperation, agreed upon between Rumania and the League of Nations' financial committee, was put into effect today by the Council. It is notable as marking the extension of the League's influence from vanquished countries off the gold standard, as previously, to victorious countries on the gold standard but financially backward, of which Rumania is only one example.

Recommendations to the Legislature to make more effective several of the criminal statutes were adopted yesterday at the annual meeting of the District Attorneys Association of the State of New York held in the Ear Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: George Foster Peabody in his letter to THE TIMES reaches the conclusion that the Federal Government has "back of its obligations all the wealth of the country," but the real question is, What are these obligations?

In Arthur Sampson, who is leaving the Harvard football coaching staff this year, according to dispatches from Cambridge, the Crimson staff is losing one of the most interesting men in football, perhaps to the gain of another college, for Sampson is being talked of as a possible head coach.

THIS book, which is as much about Dreiser's background as about the man himself, has most of the characteristics of a Dreiser novel. It is born of as thorough an immersion in the subject-material as "The Financier" or "The Titan."
ONE of the dominant questions before Congress is the problem of public and private debts contracted on a vanished scale of prices.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 28. -- The Minister of Agriculture gave out a statement today saying the National Government would extend necessary relief to farmers in Entre Rios and food sufficient to keep families and Northern Santa Fe province and in parts of Cordoba which were suffering from destruction of crops by locusts and drought.

ITHACA, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- Stellar goal shooting by Captain Bob O'Connell and Nikkel gave Tale a 31 to 24 victory over Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game in the drill hall tonight. The victory put Yale in a four-way tie for first place.

THEY say that men from Mars are all heads and hands and no body: if so, "Ye Drunken Damozel" is a novel from Mars. Certainly it is a strange creation -- terse, elliptical, obscure, peculiary foreshortened. Mr. Simon Jesty, as the author is pleased to call himself, piles his fantastic events so closely upon one another that, though he avoids the common fault of diffusion, he falls into the more dangerous one of mystification.

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- An imaginative canvas entitled "Pool at Ilk," painted by S. Walter Norris of this city, was announced as winner of the Temple Gold Medal, awarded for the best oil painting shown at the 128th annual exhibition of the Pennsylvania Academy of Fine Arts, which opened tonight with a private view.

Criticism from various quarters of the growing movement to write down fixed asset valuations of large companies, on the grounds that it may adversely affect insurance recoveries in case of fire or other destruction, reduce the measure of tax deduction and, in some instances, mislead stockholders and the investing public, was answered here yesterday by Dr. Joseph J. Klein of Klein, Hinds Finke, certified public accountants.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 28. -- President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt announced today that he had invited Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, here for a conference tomorrow so that Sir Ronald might know at first hand his views on the procedure in the coming war-debt negotiations. Sir Ronald leaves for England next Tuesday.

SYRACUSE, Jan. 28. -- "Newspapers have been and are a major and essential part of retail promotion," John Wood, vice president in charge of merchandising and advertising of B. Altman Co. of New York, said in a business talk at the closing session of New York State Publishers' Association here today.

BERLIN, Jan. 14, 1933. THE new year has gotten away to a languid start. Matters these past weeks have been only a little less stagnant than they were all through December. The opera houses, for one reason or another, have permitted several important pledges to fall by the wayside and have contented themselves with a few half-hearted revivals instead.

New trends in investment-trust accountancy have developed extensively in the last year as a result of a continued depreciation in security values, constituting nearly all their assets. Some of the practices represent steps beyond the requirements of the Stock Exchange in attempting to set forth the financial condition, and operating results of the trusts.
With the sounding of a ship's bell, the National Motor Boat Show came to a conclusion last night in Grand Central Palace.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- The word of Henry Ford, as to causes of the strike in another plant which is tying up his operations was seized upon today by Senator Black of Alabama to launch a drive for investigating the charge that a few banks have a strangle-hold on American industry through interlocking directorates.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In connection with the TIMES article "Spinning Tops on Ships," may I bring to your attention the fact that the Hamburg-American Line was the first steamship company to install a device intended to banish that dreaded sea terror "mal de mer" from its vessels?

THERE have been half a dozen cheerful item's in the sports news of the past week or so. One of them, for instance, was the announcement by Bill Carr, Pennsylvania undergraduate track star and Olympic 400-meter hero, that he would retire from track competition at the end of the Summer. Carr expects to be graduated in June and to compete abroad this Summer in what might be considered a post-graduate vacation trip.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- By all accounts there was waged in Albany this week a political battle of implications almost as wide as those involved in the recent Presidential campaign.

FATHER HUBBARD, as an army of readers knows, is the "Glacier Priest," who for many years has been working in and traveling over Alaska, as missionary priest to the Eskimos and, for his own interest, as photographer, scientific observer, teller of tales of the marvels he has seen.

IF comment hare regarding the new opera house for the Metropolitan has practically died of inanition, it is not so overseas. At least, the news of the opening of Radio City Music Hall brought the following discussion in The Radio Times, the journal of the British Broadcasting Corporation:

DESPITE a year of depression, Long Island drew a great volume of traffic during 1932. To meet the needs of visiting motorists, the highway departments of counties, cities and townships engaged in a broad program involving the construction of highways, widening and repairing of old ones and the elimination of dangerous grade crossings.

At Washington last week the spokesmen of certain farm associations sought to impress the Senate Committee on Agriculture by declaring that there would be a "revolution" unless the farmers got relief. This is the sort of loose talk that is heard in times of extreme depression.

BIDDEFORD, Me., Jan. 28 (AP). -- A section of an amusement pier at Old Orchard Beach was washed away, stone bulkheads and waterfront cottages were undermined and roadways were under water along the southern Maine coast today as the storm which struck yesterday continued with little abatement.

CANTON, Dec. 29. -- Kwangtung and Kwangsi provinces are now cooperating in an attempt to do away with public gambling, and both provincial administrations have decided gradually to end existing gambling monopolies.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- The arrangement whereby Edwin Krenn, chief heir to the estate of Mrs. Edith Rockefeller McCormick, was to receive a lifetime annuity of $24,000 in return for waiving his fivetwelfths share in the estate has been canceled.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange remained abnormally narrow in light trading yesterday, prices ending at losses of 1 to 5 points. Considering outside markets, political news from Europe and unfavorable week-end statistics, prices displayed resistance and a closing figure of 6.23 cents for the May showed a loss of only 2 points from the preceding Saturday.

In the main ballroom of the RitzCarlton last night, the annual interfraternity ball of Violet Skull, the official interfraternity council of Washington Square College, New York University, was held. Some of the 500 or more guests came from San Francisco, Charleston, S. C., and Rapid City, S.D.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The British feeling concerning war debts is more grim than a week ago, when the parley proposal first came from Washington. An awkward fact in the situation is that the expectation of the United States to be compensated for revision conflicts absolutely with the British view.

Eight election officials of the Fourth Assembly District, all Democrats, began suit yesterday in United States District Court to restrain George Z. Medalie, Federal attorney, from prosecuting them on indictments alleging violation of the Federal election law, on the ground that the prosecutor, having been defeated in his candidacy for United States Senator, was not a disinterested official.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Completion by February of a comprehensive report on the transportation situation in which, many believe, will be included recommendations for radical reorganization of the railway system, was predicted here today by Alfred E. Smith, member of the National Transportation Committee.
WHEN Orville Wright tossed and turned and was unable to sleep on the night of Dec. 16, 1903, there was just one thought in his mind.

BUCHAREST, Jan. 28. -- The Rumanian secret police today unearthed a widespread Communist espionage organization and simultaneously found leads to a terrorist band believed to be connected with the notorious anti-Semitic "Iron Guard."

CHICAGO, Jan. 28 (AP). -- J.N. Bozeman Jr. of Vallejo, Cal., bounced back into a tie with Welker Cochran of San Francisco for the leadership in the world's three-cushion billiards championship tournament tonight by overwhelming Clarence Jackson of Detroit, 50 to 21, in thirty-eight innings.
THE fad for viewing broadcasts has flourished surprisingly during the past year. Every week an avalanche of requests for admission to the studios descends upon the radio showmen.

THE Radio City Music Hall is showing the Fox film version of Phil Stong's novel, "State Fair." The cast is headed by Janet Gaynor, Lew Ayres, Norman Foster, Frank Craven. Will Rogers, Sally Eilers, Louise Dresser and Victor Jory.

BERLIN, Jan. 14, 1933. AT the Winter's second session of the Berlin section of the International Society for New Music, the program was played by the Berlin Broadcasting Orchestra and conducted by Eugene Jochum. Life is exceedingly full of Herr Jochum these days.

To the Editor of The New York Times. When prohibition first fell upon us there was a great ado made about the determination of the alcohol percentage in beverages which are "intoxicating in fact." Now that prohibition has collapsed, the same ritual phrase has been revived to the confusion of the process of readjustment.

THE radio industry has several hopes for 1933. First, opportunity lurks in an "unlimited replacement market." Second, new instruments with up-to-date improvements to be introduced this Spring are expected to attract new buyers and to encourage replacement of obsolete receivers, estimated at 7,350,000.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Out of losses of $400,595,000 written off by member banks of the United States in the first half of 1932, the writeoff by New York Federal Reserve district institutions amounted to $200,858,000, according to Federal Reserve Board figures today.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- The coming Anglo-American debt parleys already present themselves to thoughtful and informed opinion in Germany as a crucial event in world developments, since it is believed their outcome will decide what may be hoped for from the World Economic Conference.
The State Bar Association closed its fifty-sixth annual meeting yesterday by re-electing Samuel Seabury president and adopting three resolutions dealing with the selection of judicial officers.

We "can get out of the mess we are in only as the vast resources of our nation are socialized, only as this wealth is so distributed as to give to the whole public the earning and buying power essential to prosperity," Clyde R. Miller, director of the educational service bureau of Teachers College, Columbia University, declares in a study of the economic aspects of education, made public yesterday.

ONLY YESTERDAY," Mr. F. L. Allen's description of the United States after the war, became a best-seller. For an imitation that is the sincerest form of flattery be cannot have been, therefore, wholly unprepared. It is the hope of Mr. Lang and Mr. Col- lier that the English landscape also may prove to be lucrative to literature, and their gratitude to Mr. Allen for a "brilliant idea" is "filial."

PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 28. -- A powerful explosive bomb apparently "planted" in the South Philadelphia home of John Di Silvestro, national head of the Patriotic Order of Sons of Italy and a personal friend of Premier Mussolini, reduced the three-story house to ruins early today, killing Mr. Di Silvesrtro's wife injuring his secretary, four of his seven children and several neighbors and causing property damage over an area of several blocks.

THE Henry Street Settlement is presenting a series of Sunday evening programs at the Grand Street Playhouse, under the direction of Eva M. Fry. The enterprise is worthy of the attention of the dance field whether on the bright side of the footlights or the dim side.

Morristown School's hockey teams of Morristown, N.J., conquered the previously unbeaten Hackley School sextet of Tarrytown, N.Y., 3 to 1, in the feature contest of a four-game scholastic hockey program at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

PARIS, Jan. 13. THERE being in Paris no tradition of plays of a specifically Christmas or New Year's character, the festive season always brings a lull in theatrical productions and there is only one for me to talk about.

GEORGE ARLISS, who toils amid the scenic glories of California, plays in the vicinity of England's moors, and is the author of "Up the Years From Bloomsbury," is King of somewhere in the Balkans in his latest film, which is known as "The King's Vacation."

CARACAS, Jan. 23. -- In Keeping with his policy of rigid governmental economy, by which he has been able to balance the national budget without imposing new taxes on the country, President General Juan Vicente Gomez has put all the army airplanes to work.

LONDON, Jan. 28. -- Miss Diana Fishwick, former women's British golf champion, and five other women golfers sailed for America today on an unofficial tour involving four tournaments, the first to be at Palm Beach on Feb. 13.

Class I railroads earned about 75 per cent of their fixed charges in the first eleven months of 1932, according to reports already issued, which would compare with a coverage of 1.19 times in 1931 and 2.25 times in 1929. The Bangor Aroostook, the Illinois Central, the New York, Ontario Western, the Reading and the Wabash increased their earnings available for charges in the eleven months compared with the 1931 period.

Legalization of the sale of beer would have little or no effect on crime in the opinion of several Police Department heads who visited this city yesterday to attend subcommittee meetings of the International Police Commissioners Association and of the International Association of Police Chiefs.

LITTLE international significance was attached to the Five-Year Plan when it was first brought before the world. On the contrary, many believed that the Five-Year Plan was a private undertaking of the Soviet Union, an important and serious undertaking but none the less the private concern of the Soviet Union.

THE twentieth century is still the nineteenth, says Mr. Eliot, remarking (in his essay on Dryden) on the persistence of Victorian misjudgments, "although it may in time acquire its own character." What that character will be and what the correspondences in literature, we can only guess.

WE have been told that our depression is one with a qualitative difference. The hard times of the second Cleveland administration, comparable in magnitude and often invoked for purposes of parallel, came to an end, so far as the United States was concerned, because of a combination of circumstances that may or may not be repeated.

LITTLE ROCK, Jan. 26. -- Something new in legislative programs is being conducted by Governor J. Marion Futrell. He has pointed out the emergencies which in some way must be provided for, and left the problem up to the General Assembly.

IF the hairs on the respective heads of Philip Dunning and George Abbott seem markedly grayer than a month ago, set it down not to domestic calamities or financial ills but rather to the agony and travail and heartache they endured in two weeks spent trying to tame and discipline a refractory Pullman car.

LAKE PLACID. -- House party groups of young sportsmen have been popular at Lake Placid since the opening of the Winter season, but the gala houseparty week-end promises to be that starting on Thursday, when the students of Northwood School for Boys at the Lake Placid Club will be hosts to young women guests.

CHICAGO, Jan. 28. -- Wheat developed an easier undertone today on the Board of Trade, due more to lack of support than to material pressure. The forecast indicated rain or snow in the eastern sections of Kansas and Nebraska, and some traders thought they saw evidence of the dry sections of the two States receiving moisture over the week-end.

WARSAW, Jan. 27. -- What is left of political life in Poland is now concentrated in the Sejm's budget committee, which is reviewing the government's work in the course of its examination of the estimates for the next fiscal year, beginning April 1.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- The national death rate in 1931 fell to 1,107.5 per 100,000 of estimated population as compared with 1,133.1 in 1930, despite the economic depression, according to a survey made public by the Bureau of Census of the Department of Commerce.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Amendment of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation act to permit the corporation to make loans on and to purchase first mortgages and removal of restrictive features of the Home Loan Bank act, so that the system could "properly serve all of the home owners," were among the recommendations adopted by the National Association of Real Estate Boards at the closing session of its annual meeting here today.

CHEYENNE Wyo., Jan. 26. -- With a Democratic House and Governor, but with a Republican majority of three in the Senate, Wyoming's Legislature has begun its twenty-second biennial forty-day session. This session will be an especially busy one, with economy in public expenditures as a principal objective.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28. -- The will of Louis Comfort Tiffany, who died in New York City on Jan. 17 at the age of 84 years, was filed for probate in the office of Surrogate Leone D. Howell here today. Although a petition filed with the will evaluates the real estate and personal effects disposed of at more than $10,000 each, it is estimated that the entire estate will come to more than $500,000.
INTEREST at the Metropolitan Opera this week centres around the revival of Smetana's "Die Verkaufte Braut" ("The Bartered Bride") after an absence of five years.

WASHINGTON. THE Capitol is trying to main up its mind about Huey Long of Louisiana, bad boy of the Senate, and welkin-ringer for the hill and farm people of his native South. Is he demagogue, boor and buffoon, or the apostle of a new freedom, ahead of his time -- a preacher of strange doctrines that sound stranger still because of his lack of the social and the intellectual graces?

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Jan. 28 (AP). -- William H. Taylor, 74, publisher of The Montclair (N.J.) Times, and for many years president of the Iron Age Publishing Company, disappeared Thursday after leaving his Winter home here supposedly for a theatre, and has not since been seen.

THERE is a strong movement at Washington to have the United States resume active participation in the world's great agricultural clearing house, the International Institute of Agriculture at Rome. Democratic leaders have interested themselves in this idea, adding their influence to that exerted in its behalf by President Hoover.

DETROIT, Jan. 28. -- From Henry Ford there came today a new intimation that the labor trouble at the Briggs body plants which has forced him to halt production of his new cars was instigated by business rivals.

BERLIN, Jan. 28. -- The Boerse continued extremely quiet today. As speculators had mostly cleared their engagements several days ago, no large offers disturb the market. The resignation of the von Schleicher Cabinet became known only after the closing of the market, but unofficial postsession trading produced no price movements either way.
The splendidly mounted Aknusti team defeated Squadron C, 13 1/2 to 6, in a metropolitan indoor polo circuit contest at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night after giving away two goals.

THESE two authors are both connected with Harvard University, the former as Henry Lee Professor of Economics and the latter as instructor and tutor in sociology, and their book, theretore, presents the fusing together of results obtained by approaching the subjects from the different viewpoints of the economist and the sociologist.

PARIS. PROFESSOR RIVET chose the ancient Kingdom of Benin as subject for the opening exhibition at the Ethnographical Museum -- the first of a series intended to give a systematic study of primitive arts.

BERLIN, Jan. 16. -- Traveling by rail at 100 miles an hour sounds exciting, but on the new Diesel-electric car, with which the German State Railway has broken new ground in rail transportation, one barely becomes sensible of moving at a speed greater than that of a very fast train -- so the newspaper men agreed who rode from Berlin to Hamburg as the Reichsbahn's guests.

To the Music Editor: As one who heard Antonio Scotti sing in London before he came to New York and repeatedly during his first ten years at the Metropolitan, I feel compelled to dispute the statement of Mr. Olin Downes, who, I feel sure, has formed his opinions from hearing Scotti later in his career, to the effect that the beloved baritone never had a beautiful voice.

PRAGUE, Jan. 26. -- Although the Czechoslovak Government insisted on taking it seriously, it is still uncertain whether the fantastic local Fascist "putsch" in Brno Saturday night deserved the description of the War Minister as "a crime which might have shattered the foundations of the State."

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

Many clergymen will preach today on technocracy or refer to it in their sermons, not a few quoting Cardinal Hayes, who, as he sailed for the Bahamas last Monday night, questioned whether this was the time to present such theories to "an already sorely tried world."

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hesitate to inject myself into a discussion of such bitterness as that at present being waged by Captain Ashley McKinley over the coming flight around Mount Everest, especially as I know only what I have gleaned from the published newspaper reports.

Reindeer and northern lights, glittering snow fields, a night that lasts for weeks in Winter and a sun that shines all night lone during a Summer that seems magical in its swift and sudden beauty, make the northern countries a land of charm and mystery to readers of any age.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 28. -- Yale today scored its sixtieth con- secutive Intercollegiate Swimming Association dual meet victory since 1924, turning back Penn, 53 to 18, before a crowd of 1,000. It was the 102d triumph in a row in meets with all outside rivals.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Debt negotiations and related economic discussions with Great Britain were transferred to Warm Springs, Ga., with the departure by airplane this afternoon of Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, for a conference with President-elect Roosevelt before the envoy sails for London on Tuesday to report on the situation to the MacDonald Government.

PEIPING, Dec. 31. -- A new note regarding the attitude of the people in Manchuria toward the Manchukuo regime was sounded here in an interview with this correspondent by Major Gen. R. Banzai, Imperial Japanese Army, retired. General Banzai, now a member of the Japanese House of Peers, believes that Manchukuo in its pretensions to sovereign statehood can represent only a transitory device.

The assistance of women in the adjustment of motion picture programs to fit the needs of children is growing rapidly, Carl E. Milliken, secretary of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America, told members of the Woman's Press Club of New York City, meeting yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- For the first time in several weeks the sportsman here looks forward to a week devoid of a tournament of some kind. With the conclusion of the twenty-ninth annual St. Valentine's golf tournament for men last week there will be a respite until Feb. 6, when the twenty-eighth, annual St. Valentine's competition for women will commence.

IN the midst of the interminable and all-absorbing discussions of such great world issues as the war debts, Manchuria and disarmament, Secretary Stimson and the Ambassadors of half a dozen great powers have turned their attention to a plea of Colombia for support in resisting an alleged aggression by Peru against Colombian territory.

WHATEVER one may say about this first novel, he can scarcely complain that it does not cover enough ground. It opens at the old homestead in Northern New York back in the '90s, the house that Adam and Sari Burdette established and where their thirteen children were brought up.

GENEVA, Jan. 14. -- President Hoover's recommendation, that the Senate ratify the League's convention for the supervision of the traffic in arms which we signed in 1925 calls attention here to the anomalies in the makeshift Yearbook on the Trade in Arms which the League issues while awaiting the application, of this convention.

PROVIDENCE, Jan. 26. -- Governor Theodore Francis Green announces that he plans to declare an emergency exists in Rhode Island in order that unemployment relief may have the right of way over all business before the State Legislature.
MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 28. -- F.C. Chapman did the best work in the weekly competition at the Nassau Trapshooting Club tracks today. He took the regular shoot by breaking 48 out of 50 targets.

MACON, Ga., Jan. 26. -- Some local thief with a ghoulish fancy for committing larceny with the Macaber touch chilled the spines of the good members of the Women's Missionary Society of Ingleside Methodist Church a few days ago.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 28. -- The Carlaris gelding Character, an eligible for the $10,000 added Florida Derby, made it five in a row at Hialeah Park today when he ran on top from start to finish of the featured Hialeah Stakes and won easily by a length and a half.

That there should not have been any recovery of real estate prices in 1932 was a foregone conclusion. But like unemployment and general business depression, economic conditions usually impress themselves upon the public mind only by existing circumstances, and these are grossly exaggerated.

Among the works of Russian composers past and contemporary which constituted the program of the League of Composers Quartet and Sergei Radamsky, Russian tenor, given last night at the New School, were two string quartets not hitherto played in America, according to a program note.

MIAMI. -- Entries will close on Wednesday in all open classes for the Miami-Biltmore National Horse Show, which will take place at Tropical Park race track, Coral Gables, on Feb. 15, 16, 17 and 18. There will be afternoon and evening events at the show, the latter being shown under floodlights.

BOSTON, Jan. 28. -- The same runners who last year won the three feature distance events repeated their victories tonight in the twelfth annual Prout Memorial Games in the Boston Garden before 8,000 spectators.
OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Jan. 28 -- Skaters from Detroit led both the men's and women's divisions in the first day's racing for the national amateur speed championship on Fowler Lake today.

In recognition of intelligence, executive ability, willingness to accept responsibility and responsible action, 218 high school students who will become graduates in a few days were honored yesterday by the Cooperation-in-Government movement with the semi-annual awards of medals and diplomas at exercises in the hall of the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28 (AP). -- A third phase in the anthracite industry's drive to meet stiffening competition developed today when the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Coal Company asked the Interstate Commerce Commission for a general revision of railroad rates on hard coal.

The sentiments expressed in England during the past week on the issue of war debts indicate that there exists a considerable distance between what may be now described as the British and American views. Fortunately, the distance is not necessarily one that cannot be covered in a fair compromise, but it is sufficient to supply considerable room for work on the part of the statesmen of the two countries.

THE action of this slender little novel -- if, indeed, it can be said to have any action -- takes place in the space of twenty-four hours. A young Englishwoman, who remains nameless throughout the story, wakes in the morning and lies in bed thinking, as young women in novels almost invariably do, of love.

THE time is the nineties, and Mrs. Van Kleek runs "The Hotel" on one of those islands of the South Pacific or Indian Ocean, one of those outposts of empire, which aid in thwarting the sun in its efforts to set on the British flag.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Jan. 23 Secretary of the Treasury Ogden Mills opposes strongly any attempt to interfere with the haphazard workings of our present antiquated currency and price system. Several of his arguments seem worthy of comment.

Giving a splendid exhibition that was marked by his renowned cannonball service, William T. Tilden, in what was scheduled as his closing professional tennis match in Manhattan, vanquished Hans Nusslein at the Seventh Regiment Armory courts in two sets yesterday.
TOKYO, Jan. 28. -- Japan's attitude in regard to League of Nations action on the Manchurian dispute has become entirely passive.

AN intellectual stirring among our population "geographically and temperamentally remote from academic halls" is noted by the People's Institute, United Neighborhood Guild of Brooklyn, in a recent report. People who would never think of enrolling in evening school classes or university extension courses are applying to the institute in increasing numbers for aid in forming discussion groups in philosophy, economics and history.

ONCE more Ernest Peixotto returns to the pen he had laid aside for ten years while he devoted himself to mural painting. The succession of books in which he long ago began to prove his ability to write as charmingly as be can illustrate is here taken up again with an account of a journey through some of the wine-making regions of France.

The investing public in New York State lost $48,352,465 through the purchase of worthless securities in 1932, according to Attorney General John J. Bennett Jr., who made public yesterday the annual report of the State Bureau of Securities. This loss from stock frauds was $11,000,000 less than in 1931.

HAVANA, Jan. 28. -- The explosion of a bomb early this morning at a street intersection of the city subdivision of Jesus del Monte ruptured the water main and cut off the water supply of the downtown district of Havana.

Two plans enabling customers to save for Christmas shopping and re- sulting in additional business and concentrated purchasing for the store have been adopted by Sanger Brothers, Inc., Dallas. One of the plans, designated "Thrift and Christmas Savings Club," pays customers from 2 to 5 per cent on cash purchases and charge account payments.

Presenting what is undoubtedly the finest and most impressive array of talent ever assembled in its history the Millrose A.A. will stage its twenty-sixth annual indoor track and field games at Madison Square Garden on Saturday night. The roster of entries reads like a compendium of the great athletes of cinder path and board floor.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- In a last-ditch battle to restore to the Prohibition Bureau the right to tap telephone and telegraph wires, employ "stool pigeons" and other informers, and purchase liquor in order to get evidence of violations, the prohibitionists in the House were defeated all along the line this afternoon.

Not so friendly to Harry Herman, manufacturing jeweler, of 105 Canal Street, were three men who personated Samuel H. Friend, a San Francisco friend of the jeweler, in the Hotel Victoria, 781 Seventh Avenue, on Friday. The fact that Herman had been robbed of $12,500 in jewelry and $45 in cash on Friday was revealed yesterday at Police Headquarters.

Reporting that there is a definite shift away from the trade association as a price protection agency to the association as an instrument to plan budgets for an industry, Edgar L. Heermance, industrial engineer and author of several books, estimated yesterday that about 50 out of the present 500 trade groups are ready for industrial planning.

The time-honored Charity Ball, which for more than three-quarters of a century has been an institution in New York society, will he held on Wednesday night in the ballroom suite of the Waldorf-Astoria and for the first time in its history will have features in addition to the grand march.

"La Traviata," which was Verdi's word for a coloratura-singing "Camille," was presented to a packed house at the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon. It was the tuneful opera's fourth time in the current bills, but the first with Bori and Tokatyan as Dumas's lovers, and the second for Tibbett as the lady's unwilling father-inlaw.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived by train from New York this morning, spent an hour at the White House with Mrs. Hoover, lunched with Mrs. Adolph Caspar Miller, and left by plane soon afterward for Warm Springs, Ga., to join the Presidentelect and other members of her family assembled there.

TORONTO, Ont., Jan. 28. -- Teck-Hughes Gold Mines, Ltd., which has reported an estimated surplus of $774,749 for the first quarter of its fiscal year, ended on Nov. 30, or $19,599 more than in the corresponding three months of 1931, is expected to lose no time in making a test of the Quebec Gold Belt and Reed-Authier properties recently placed under option in Louviscourt Township, Que.

WHAT with the splendid system of Federal airways, with their radio directional beams, their marked fields and their flashing beacons by night, the way of the air traveler has been made comparatively easy. He who flies often and far, however, must place much reliance still upon his air maps.

MOSCOW. SOVIET Russia is a land of shocks and surprises; one surprise is that toward foreigners there is no hostility. In Italy at various times foreigners have been glowered upon; at one time in France some American tourists were booed and even stoned by irritated citizens who thought the Americans had something to do with the depreciation of their franc.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 28. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Jan. 21 amounted to 496,434 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was a decline of 9,888 cars, or 2 per cent, from the total in the preceding week, 65,667 cars, or 11.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 219,040 cars, or 30.6 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

WAGNER is still on the gold standard, according to commodity ratings on the Broadway curb. "Rheingold," posted as an "only performance this season," promptly sold out the Metropolitan so that latecomers last Friday had only the far corners of the Opera House to choose from.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday that $2,190,800 of gold from Holland had been received here, that $813,000 from China had reached San Francisco and that $1,910,500 had been earmarked here for foreign account.

IRVINGTON, N.Y., Jan. 28. -- The first of two musicales will be held tomorrow afternoon at the home here of Mrs. Adam K. Luke to further the Hudson River Music School. The artists will include Winifred Cecil, soprano; Walter Scott, violinist, and Benjamin King, pianist.

A CHALLENGING sentence opens this book by Leal A. Headley, Professor of Education in Carieton College, Minnesota. "The work of a college or university," be asserts, "is best judged by its library," and then adds that be holds his statement "to be literally true."

HACKENSACK, N.J., Jan. 28. -- Frank Canora, 53 years old, proprietor of a garage, service station and lunchroom at 299 Summit Avenue, Hackensack, surrendered this morning to the Bergen County police and confessed that he had killed his wife, Lena, 51, at Spring Valley, N.Y., on Thursday morning, poured gasoline on her body and set fire to it.

With Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens flatly refusing to make any further cuts in his departmental budget for other than personal service, the deadline set by Mayor O'Brien at noon yesterday for a final budget cut of $20,000,000 passed by, leaving the Mayor doubtful whether the goal he sought had been accomplished by his subordinates.

More than 75 per cent of the exporters responding to a questionnaire sent out two weeks ago by the National Foreign Trade Council are in sympathy with a plan for amending the Reconstruction Finance Corporation law to permit the governmental agency to guarantee, without recourse to the exporter, up to 75 per cent of bills of exchange drawn for exports, according to executives of the foreign trade group yesterday.

A DRAFTING subcommittee of the League of Nations is now attempting to set forth the facts in the dispute between China and Japan, in accordance with Section 4 of Article XV of the Covenant. Under the same section, unless an amicable settlement is reached in the meantime, the subcommittee will later proceed to draft recommendations "deemed just and proper."

HAVING read what Arthur Hopkins had to say about the lost theatre, and then on top of that having read what Percy Hammond had to say about what Arthur Hopkins had to say, it appears now that the two boys have had their say, leaving little more to be said.

ZOLTAN KODALY, whose opera "Filanda Magiara" is the first Hungarian work to be presented on the stage of La Scala in Milan, sat down the other day after a rehearsal of the work and told an interviewer of the Corrierre della Sera about some of the experiences that had influenced his development.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Jan. 29. -- The new $50,000 administration, and and farm mechanics building erected at the National Farm School a year ago was named today the Herbert D. Allman Building in honor of the school's president, Herbert D. Allman of Philadelphia.

Warning his hearers not to be "fooled by any economic system that leaves God out of the reckoning." the Rev. Thomas L. Graham, preaching yesterday at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral, assailed technocracy on the ground that the system, if put in force, would leave the world "even more sinful than it is now."
Bronx Purges Enemy. When a Communist apartment colony in the Bronx evicts a member-tenant for being behind in his rent it is not a lapse into capitalist ideology, as might appear at first.

Problems affecting the functioning of the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League next Spring were ironed out yesterday at a meeting of the league's executive committee at the Columbia University Club. Representatives of the six universities in the league -- Columbia, Princeton, Yale, Pennsylvania, Cornell and Dartmouth -- were present.

A plan for refunding the $5,000,000 of General Refractories Company two year 5 per cent gold notes, due on March 1, 1933, by issuing $6,000,000 of five year 6 per cent first mortgage cumulative income bonds carrying stock warrants, is being mailed today to noteholders by a committee representing holders of nearly one-third of the present issue.

In a bitterly fought amateur hockey contest that kept a crowd of 9,000 excited for its entire duration, the powerful Boston Hockey Club turned back the St. Nicks, 7 to 5, in Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon.

The Giants made another notable addition to their collection of 1933 autographs yesterday by announcing the receipt of a contract duly signed and approved by one Augustus Rodney Mancuso, more commonly known as Gus, a rather stocky little fellow who will assume a job of a rather large order.

PARIS Jan. 27. -- The weakness on the Bourse throughout the present week was clearly due to the uncertainties regarding the Cabinet situation and the attitude of the Chamber of Deputies toward the budget. Under all existing circumstances, it was felt that the fate of the budget was undecided, and the decline in rentes followed.

NEW HAVEN, Jan. 29. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55.5, which compares with 56.4 a week ago, 57.3 two weeks ago, 57.4 three weeks ago and 57.6 four weeks ago. The highest average of 1932 was 66.3, in the first week in January; the average of the last week of December, 57.6, was the lowest.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Leaders of the automotive industry joined today at the National Automobile Show here in expressing confidence for improved business during 1933.
OSLO, Norway, Jan. 29 -- Eddie Schroeder of Chicago outskated Norway's best at 10,000 meters today and hung up his second victory of the international ice tournament.

Restoration of the taxicab business to the exclusive control of the Police Department will mean the continuance of a liability insurance system under which claims for damage to persons and property often went unsatisfied, according to a letter sent to Mayor O'Brien yesterday by H.A. Inness Brown, editor of a taxicab trade publication.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 -- Nine days' fighting at Fort Nanawa [also called Ayala] has caused 6,000 casualties, including dead, wounded and missing, according to Bolivian and Paraguayan official estimates.

Four armed men who early yesterday morning robbed ninety persons of $3,500 in two lower east side hold-ups continued their activities last night in the vicinity of Police Headquarters, holding up Jacob Hausman, grocer, of 275 Broome Street, and escaping with $150 after striking Hausman on the head with the butt of a revolver.

Drastic cuts in State expenditures and a careful scrutiny of State-aid items are urged in a report of the committee on taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, made public yesterday. The report says, in part:
HAVANA, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Haymaker's Ima Queen led home a smart band of platers in the fifth and featured race at Oriental Park today and chalked up her third successive victory of the season.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29. -- Commencement exercises at Harvard also will be held the week following the regatta, and the usual gayety of New London during the Harvard-Yale race may be missing.

An appeal for departure from the policy of using churches only as "auditoriums" during certain hours each Sunday was voiced yesterday by the Very Rev. Dr. Milo H. Gates, dean, in his sermon at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker in the House of Lords and former Lord-in-Waiting to King George V, appealed for generous support of the campaign for funds by the Peoples' Ort Federation which was launched last night with a dinner in the Hotel Commodore.

Only two games were played In the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League last week and both resulted in victories for Yale. After scoring a startling upset by defeating Penn, 35 to 23, at New Haven on Tuesday for the Quakers' first defeat of the season, the Elis also conquered Cornell, 31 to 24, on Saturday.

Modernization of the transportation system of the Port of New York and a reduction of millions of dollars annually in the cost of distributing food products alone would result from the adoption by the Interstate Commerce Commission of the report of Earl M. Steer, examiner, recommending the abolition of free lighterage charges, according to Norman F. Titus, president of the New Jersey Business Associates.

With the peak of the Winter cruise trade approaching, ship lines have remarked several new developments in the traffic this Winter, notably the popularity of the more expensive accommodations. Officials of transatlantic lines operating to the West Indies report that several days before the sailing dates staterooms and suites in the higher brackets have been sold out and applicants obliged to accept less expensive rooms.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29. -- A confident prediction that atomic energy may soon be harnessed and utilized is made in an article written by Dr. Karl Taylor Compton, president of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, in the current issue of The Technology Review, published tomorrow.

The church, shaken by its "failure" in the World War, is doomed unless it immediately assumes its neglected role of leadership to make men understand the causes and implications of the world's present economic plight, the Rev. Dr. Edmund B. Chaffee of the Presbyterian Labor Temple asserted yesterday morning in a sermon at the Park Avenue Presbyterian Church, Park Avenue and Eighty-fifth Street.

SHORT HILLS, N.J., Jan. 29 -- Harry F. Wolf of Montclair and the New York A.C., the national champion, overwhelmed Frank R. Hanson of the Columbia University Club in the final of the New Jersey State championship squash tennis tournament at the Short Hills Club today, 15 -- 1, 15 -- 4, 15 -- 9, gaining his second leg on the challenge cup.

Led by the sharp-shooting George Patterson, who rattled two shots into the net, the New York Americans repulsed the invasion of the Chicago Black Hawks in a National Hookey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. The Americans, showing a dashing attack coupled with a sturdy resistance, blanked the visiting skaters, 4 to 0.

The 3,500-ton freighter Malchace, bound in from Portland, Me., with a cargo of potatoes, went aground on a rock just south of Execution Light, near Sands Point, yesterday morning in clear weather. A thirty-five-mile wind was blowing from the northwest and a choppy sea running at the time.

It is expected that the Maternity Centre Association will benefit greatly from the pre-opening performance of "Evensong," to be held tonight at the Selwyn Theatre. The Centre, which is at 1 East Fifty-seventh Street, provides care and treatment for mothers and their children.

The independence act by which Congress proposed to establish the independence of the Philippine Islands was branded as absolutely unacceptable yesterday by Manuel Quezon, president of the Philippine Senate, in a radio speech broadcast over the Columbia system.

PARIS, Jan. 29 -- Edouard Daladier, Minister of War in Joseph Paul-Boncour's Cabinet, has been asked by President Lebrun to undertake the task of forming a Cabinet and finding a parliamentary majority. Almost all those whom the President consulted yesterday and this morning advised him that M. Daladier was the best choice at the moment.

ROME, Jan. 27 -- No excessive hopes are being based on results of the coming World Economic Conference. To the new protective duties, quota systems and prohibition against purchase of foreign currency which, together with the decision of the Ottawa Conference were expected to be among the topics discussed, there has now been added in each country a mass of private interests artificially bred through restrictions to the free flow of commerce.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- The debt talks between Ambassador Sir Ronald Lindsay and President-elect Roosevelt have aroused keen speculation here regarding the exact purport of the invitation which resulted in the Ambassador's flying visit.

The Freeport Texas Company reports for the year ended Dec. 31 a net income of $2,005,098 after reserves, Federal taxes, depreciation and contingencies, equal to $2.75 a share on 729,844 capital shares outstanding. This compares with $2,376,873, or $3.26 a share, in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Coming on the heels of the recent declaration of William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, that the working men of America intend to take matters into their own hands to force amelioration of present conditions, Mr. Green today reiterated that the federation is still uncompromisingly opposed to recognition of the Soviet Government until it shall have made plain that it will undertake no communistic activities in this country.

An appeal in the form of a letter to forty-two Legislatures now in session and to the Governors of these States to speed and extend State funds for relief of the unemployed was addressed yesterday by Newton D. Baker, chairman of the National Citizens Committee of the Welfare and Relief Mobilization, in an effort to maintain and expand relief work in the face of rapid exhaustion of private and communal relief sources.

The concert of the Manhattan Symphony under David Mannes set before the audience at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night two new works by American composers: Burrill phillips's "Grotesque Dane," given its premiere in Rochester last October and first New York performance last night, and William H. Woodin's suite, "Covered Wagon Days."

BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Jan. 29. -- The Irish News, Belfast Nationalist, newspaper, in a special Sunday edition, prints an interview with Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State Executive Council, dealing with the partition of Ireland. Mr. de Valera said:
To the Editor of The New York Times: I recently had occasion to attend a hearing under the workmen's compensation law and must report that there is room for a great deal of improvement there.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Owen D. Young, who has been prominently mentioned for Secretary of State in the Roosevelt Cabinet, has written a letter to the President-elect at Warm Springs, Ga., informing him that he cannot be considered for a Cabinet position.

BERLIN, Jan. 27. -- The continued improvement in the Reichsbank's position, shown again by this week's return as of Jan. 23, has revived discussion of the possibility of speedy reduction in the official discount rate. The Reichsbank approaches the January month-end not only with all credits repaid Which had been granted in the last week of December, but with the total volume of credits further reduced by 292,000,000 marks.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Jan. 29. -- Terming the inflation of currency "the road to ruin for America." Senator David A. Reed in an address before the Northeast Philadelphia Chamber of Commerce last night, said that the "vast body of common sense" in Washington would resist the importunities to take that "foolish" step.

A petition to President-elect Roosevelt urging the recognition of Soviet Russia by the United States was addressed yesterday by 800 college professors, including a number of college presidents. Two hundred and sixty-eight colleges in forty-five States are represented in the petition, which was initiated by the Fellowship of Reconciliation.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The most notable development of the London security markets this week has been the marked revival of activity and strength in securities of the British Government and other giltedged stocks. The reasons assigned for this movement were the rise in sterling, the Bank of England's substantial addition to its gold reserve and the favorable impression made by America's invitation for early discussion of the war debts.

"Our Christianity has not cost us enough; it has been so comfortable, so respectable and even so fashionable," the Rev. Dr. Stewart W. Herman of Harrisburg, Pa., president of the Board of Foreign Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America, declared in a sermon last evening at a mass meeting in the interest of foreign missions in Holy Trinity Lutheran Church, Central Park West and Sixty-fifth Street.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Jan. 29. -- In a tail of the northerly blows that have swept the entire Atlantic seaboard for several days, six dinghies of the Frostbite Yacht Club were put under sail on Manbasset Bay today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- A whistling wind from the northwest, blowing between thirty-five and forty knots an hour, almost defeated the dinghy sailors from the Westchester shore of Long Island Sound who gathered at the Larchmont Yacht Club today for a series of races.

For several reasons the policy of the Democrats in Congress on veterans' relief has been a matter of special interest. Their party platform pledged them to "an immediate and drastic reduction" of expenditures in Washington, "to ac"complish a saving of not less "than 25 per cent in the cost of "Federal Government."

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 29 -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt Whitney of New York, who arrived last night to be their house guests for a few days, Miss Sarah Jane Sanford and John Sanford gave a dinner tonight at Villa Marina.

MONTREAL, Jan. 29 (Canadian Press). -- Formal, official notice was served over the week-end by the Canadian National and Canadian Pacific Railways to their engineers, firemen, conductors, trainmen, yardmen and telegraphers, constituting the "running trades," of a 20 per cent reduction in the basic rate of wages.

The propagation of bob-white quail has been greatly increased in recent years, due mainly to a scientific study of conditions affecting this game bird and through the rearing of quail in captivity. The artificial breeding and rearing of game birds has been a subject which has required a great deal of research.

Prominent members of society, ambassadors from foreign nations, artists and art patrons are interested in International-1933, an exhibition of contemporary art representative of more than twenty countries, which will open under the auspices of the College Art Association with a private showing next Saturday night at Rockefeller Center.

Objections to those provisions of proposed amendments to the bankruptcy law that relate to the reorganization of corporations will be registered with members of the House of Representatives this morning by the Federal Bar Association of New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, over the signature of its president, Henry Ward Beer.

BERLIN, Jan. 29. -- President von Hindenburg is expected to receive Adolf Hitler and Dr. Ludwig Kaas, the Centrist leader, tomorrow to discuss the formation of a Parliamentary Cabinet by the National Socialist chieftain.

The committee Governor LEHMAN plans to appoint to serve as a clearing house for applications to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for public works loans will fill a real need. There has been a lot of confusion about these "self-liquidating" projects, with State and local officials often working at cross-purposes.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 -- Wheat and flaxseed were weak and unsteady last week, prices fluctuating on news from abroad.
