Wheat closed at 5.10 pesos a quintal, equivalent to 35 3/4 cents a bushel, 1/4 cent below the previous Saturday's close. Flaxseed closed at 9 pesos a quintal, or 58 3/4 cents a bushel, which was 1 1/4 cents down.

BOSTON, Jan. 29 -- W. Palmer Dixon and Herbert N. Rawlins Jr. of New York today dethroned Stanley G. Pearson and William C. Wright of Philadelphia as the national doubles racquets champions at the Tennis and Racquet Club. The score of the final was 10 -- 15, 15 -- 10, 9 -- 15, 15 -- 8, 15 -- 7.

John McCormack gave his first Carnegie Hall recital of the season yesterday afternoon, said to be the first time in many years that the tenor has given an afternoon concert in New York. This change was made for the benefit of followers from the suburbs and from towns and cities near by.

For the benefit of those, perhaps; who were anxldus to be informed that Cinderella had certain fraternal connections, a company of peregrinating actors and actresses assembled on the abbreviated stage of the Sutton Theatre -- in a way down East Fifty-sixth. Street apartment hotel -- on Saturday evening and presented a drama entitled "Cinderella's Brothers."

Because the recent Laymen's Foreign Mission Inquiry report "makes Christianity only one of the worthy religions of the world," it is condemned severely in a pronouncement of the Board of Foreign Missions of the United Lutheran Church in America.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29. -- Improved demand for farm products awaits the recovery of heavy industries where a large part of American unemployment exists, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics of the Department of Agriculture asserted in its annual farm outlook report, issued today after a week's conference with extension farm economists representing thirty-two States.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Betterment in sentiment and trade buying is more general, and increased output and sales by manufacturers and distributers of all kinds of merchandise are apparent. Report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation's loans and the fact that they have been largely repaid in many instances tend to create cheer among all lines of business and industry, and there is an increased disposition to look further ahead for improvement as the year advances.

The County Holding Company has leased for a term of years a fourstory building at 302 West Seventy-second Street through John F. Gowlan. The lessee intends to remodel the building into one and two room apartments.

LONDON, Jan. 29 -- There is common ground between Sir Robert Horne's radio broadcast to the United States today and Neville Chamberlain's Birmingham declaration Saturday, in the opinion of The London Times, in that they agreed wholesale prices should be raised, that there should be no return to the gold standard or any standard without guarantees against breakdown, and that taxation should be reduced.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Jan. 29. -- With three horses jumping brilliantly and giving faultless performances over the long and testing course, the individual jumping championship of the West Point Horse Show Association's midwinter exhibition was finally decided by lot today, the highest honors falling to the black gelding Geronimo of the Second Squadron, Tenth Cavalry, which was ridden by Captain F.L. Carr.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- Prices of hogs have surprised farmers and consumers by advancing 4O cents a hundredweight in two weeks, the best lot moving up from $3.25 to $3.65 at the close of the market last week, while the average price, Which was $2.85 four weeks ago, was 53.40 on Friday.

The fifty-first annual benefit for the Actors' Fund took place last evening at the Imperial Theatre with a fair percentage of the actors of the area participating. A fair percentage of the best actors, that is. Call it a full percentage, it was Daniel Frohman's last appearance as the manager of that particular show, or so he announced before the evening started.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Jan. 29 -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City tied for medal honors in the annual Miami-Biltmore women's golf championship today, the Western titleholder finishing with a score of 44, 44-88, which was matched by Mrs. Estelle Drennan of Tulsa, Okla.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Mrs. Robert Low Bacon, wife of Representative Bacon of New York, gave a musicale this afternoon in their home, presenting Guila Bustabo, violinist, a pupil of M. Louis Persinger of the Juilliard Foundation, who accompanied her on the piano.

MEXICO CITY, Jan. 29 -- Hitherto unknown marvelous archaeologic ruins are reported to have been discovered on the San Felipe Ranch, about twenty miles from the celebrated centre at Chichen Itza, in the State of Yucatan, according to a reliable source.

CHICAGO, Jan 29. -- Absence of general outside speculative interest, as well as that of leading professional operators here and in New York, due largely to lack of a definite price trend in the speculative grain markets and particularly in futures, keeps price movements on the Board of Trade confined within narrow limits, and no change is in sight.
NEW YORK. The commercial attache of the French Embassy and Mme. Maurice Garreau-Dombasle will give a reception tonight at the Plaza for Mme. Paul Claudel.

Only by a close vote did the House adopt the amendment to the Department of Justice supply bill, forbidding the use by the Prohibition Bureau of what Mr. Justice HOLMES called "the dirty business" of Wire-tapping. By more than 2 to 1 it approved the amendment shutting off prohibition agents from their wonted supplies of liquor bought as "evidence" and interdicting the use of paid informers.

TOKYO, Jan. 29 -- Hopes of building a bridge between Japan and the League of Nations in the controversy over Manchuria have been revived by the newest friendly intervention of Britain both here and at Geneva.

So far as markets are a witness, the financial attitude of the moment indicates composure, but also such absence of initiative in either direction as suggests the awaiting of developments. Perhaps it may be objected that there have been, such developments - recurrent talk in Congress, for instance, about debasing the currency, and talk in Wall Street about the resultant "movement of foreign exchange against the dollar."
WARSAW, Jan. 29 -- Charges that Soviet Russia is taking advantage of the Vatican's missionary work are being made in some sections of the Polish press.
ALBANY, Jan. 29 -- A program of new taxes and drastic cuts in State expenditures will be set forth tomorrow night by Governor Lehman when he submits his annual budget to the Legislature.

Missionary enterprise offers the only safeguard for the Protestant Episcopal Church against "self-centred denominationalism," Martin S. Firth, candidate for mission service in Brazil, asserted at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street, yesterday morning.

OSSINING, N.Y., Jan. 29 -- Thomas Fennelly, 25 years old, an inmate of Sing Sing prison, became so absorbed today in a painstaking preparation for escape from his cell that he forgot to attend the mid-day roll-call of prisoners. The report of a missing man sent guards scurrying to inspect every cell.

Active buying characterized trade in the wholesale markets last week, as stores showed a desire for new Spring styles. Piece goods and dress accessories were in greatest demand, but a brisk business was done in all lines to replenish low stock.

The best recital of dances which Ruth Page has presented hereabout in many a long day took place last night at the John Golden Theatre, where an audience consisting in large part of the dancer's colleagues, great and small, assembled in gratifying numbers.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Jan. 29 (AP). -- Tearfully, a frail little woman today released her husband, who claims to be suffering from a twenty-two year lapse of memory, to a wife and two grown sons in New Jersey, whom he mysteriously left years ago.

NEW HAVEN, Conn.. Jan. 29. -- George Pierce Baker, Professor of the History and Technique of the Drama and chairman of the Department of Drama In the School of Fine Arts of Yale University, will retire from teaching at the end of the academic year, it was announced today.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 29 -- A satisfactory agreement on arrangements for discussion of the British war debts at Washington early in March was reached today by President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt and Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, at a conference in Mr. Roosevelt's cottage on the slope of Pine Mountain.

Creation of a permanent foundation to rehabilitate and insure the future of Jewish religious and educational endeavors was urged yesterday by Rabbi Herbert S. Goldstein, retiring president of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America.

Modern decorative art will revive tapestry weaving before long, according to Dr. Rudolf H. Riefstahl, lecturer in the New York University College of Fine Arts, who foresees the use of modern tapestries as a logical outgrowth of recent endencies in painting and changes in social conditions.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- With, two former presidents general of the Daughters of the American Revolution prominently to the fore, but without the official support of that 170,000-member group, the eighth women's patriotic conference of national defense today began assembling here.

The directors of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation have voted to utilize a part of the corporation's large cash holdings to retire all of its outstanding 7 per cent and 6 1/3 per cent preferred stock as of April 1 at $110 a share, plus the usual quarterly dividends then due.

Thirty-four committees which will supervise all the sports under the jurisdiction of the Amateur Athletic Union were named yesterday by President Avery Brundage. More than 600 men and women from all sections of the United States have been named on these committees.

After waiting for a year to present the findings of twenty-one industries in the building trades, a delegation of New York City subcontractors, most of them in the metal and ornamental iron division, returned from Washington on Saturday after testifying before a Congress committee on the Goss bill, a measure designed to correct unethical practices in bidding on Federal construction projects.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I was interested in the report of Professor Nixon of Columbia on the preference of readers for left-hand pages, thus presumably making those pages of greater value for advertisers.

Representatives of more than fifty foreign language groups and fraternal associations, many of them nation-wide, met yesterday afternoon at the Engineering Societies Building in West Thirty-ninth Street to hear William N. Doak, Secretary of Labor, and to form a permanent committee.

ST. LOUIS, Jan. 29 (AP). -- A band of about a dozen robbers, some of them armed with machine guns, was frustrated today in an attempt to rob wealthy guests at a pre-wedding luncheon party for Miss Lily Busch Magnus, great-granddaughter of Adolphus Busch, founder of the Busch Brewery interests.
OCONOMOWOC, Wis., Jan. 29 -- Melvin Johnson of Detroit and Miss Kit Klein of Buffalo, N.Y., outraced the best of America's amateur skaters and emerged today with national championships.

"Bad Manners," a comedy by Dana Burnet and William B. Jutte, opens tonight at the Playhouse. Bert Lytell and Margaret Sullavan are in the cast. Also opening is "Oliver Twist," which has not been seen here for a dozen or more years. This one will be put on at the Ritz, the inaugural offering of Chamberlain Brown's ' dollar top" theatre.

The Maritime Association of the Port of New York announced yesterday that it had filed a protest with the Board of Estimate against any official endorsement by the the city of the "buy American" movement or the putting into effect of such a policy in the management of city affairs.

A card of sixteen bouts is scheduled for Madison Square Garden tonight in an intercity amateur boxing tournament under the auspices of the Metropolian A.A.U. The tourney is expected to furnish a line on the chances of the local group of amateur boxers in the A.A.U.'s national title tournament this year.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Jan. 29. -- A great mound on the Ards Peninsula, in Northeastern Ireland, believed to contain the body of a Viking pirate burled with his wife and household animals in his ship, will be the chief objective of the Harvard archaeological expedition, which will leave in April on the second year's investigation of the cultural history of Erin In the five-year survey being conducted under the general direction of Professor Earnest A. Hooten.

The French Government was voted out by the Chamber because it proposed to reduce the pay of civil employes by 5 per cent. The vigorous old Minister of Finance, M. CHERON, had insisted upon a balanced budget, and declared that retrenchment was necessary as well as new taxes.

A plea for widespread action by State Legislatures on the recommendations made public last week by the National School Finance Survey was contained yesterday in a statement issued on behalf of the survey group, of which the director is Dr. William John Cooper, Federal Commissioner of Education.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- A drive to put three important pieces of emergency legislation through the House in a single day will be undertaken by the Democratic leadership tomorrow.

The annual statements of the Aetna Life Insurance Company and affiliated companies, filed in Connecticut, show a combined premium income for the last year of $120,132,161 made up as follows: Aetna Life, $98,886,180; Aetna Casualty, $13,914,167; Automobile Insurance Company, $5,867,462, and Standard Fire Insurance Company, $1,464,352.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 29. -- Watchful waiting appeared to be the main feature in the cotton market on the exchange here last week While there were occasional spurts of activity, trading was as a rule rather slack, with operators disposed patiently to wait on the action of Congress in the matter of the allotment bill, the attempts to balance the budget, and the probable course of the government in the European war debts.

The paths of classic tradition in literature have been blocked in England and France, and if there is to be another major work in the old tradition must come from America, John Strachey writes in "The Coming Struggle for Power," published today by Covici, Friede.

Substantial gains in the early part of the week, were largely wiped out by later trading in futures contracts for commodities traded locally during the last week. Coffee and silver prices were higher and those for hides while the others were irregular, with gains in some contracts and losses in others.

A nation-wide campaign is being waged to repeal all social and labor legislation, according to Abraham Epstein, executive secretary of the American Association for Old-Age Security, who issued an appeal yesterday to friends of old-age pension legislation to organize to fight "the nullification of all that has been built up in the United States through a generation of effort."

FRAMINGHAM, Mass., Jan. 29 -- From the door of his home, Charles Ellsworth Rice, 43, a recluse, today shot three men, two of whom may die, before he surrendered to a posse of State Troopers and police when they threatened to demolish his house with hand grenades.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In surveying the report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which appeared in THE TIMES, I noted with surprise that up to July 21, 1932, no loans were paid out for self-liquidating projects, whereas loans to the amount of $948,570,198 were paid out to banks, insurance companies and other credit organizations, with railroads receiving $223,412,109.

DETROIT, Jan. 29 -- While the Briggs Manufacturing Company and its 6,000 striking workmen awaited tomorrow noon as the crucial point in the strike which forced the Ford plants to shut down, both officials and strikers kept their lines firm today.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Democratic members of the Senate Finance Committee today served definite notice on Chairman Smoot that they would oppose to their utmost hearings on the beer bill which would further delay possible enactment.

Members of more than fifty Ukrainian organizations of the metropolitan area adopted resolutions at a mass meeting in Cooper Union yesterday afternoon protesting against "pacification of western Ukraine" by Poland. The resolutions, addressed to the State Department and the League of Nations, call on each "to use its good offices and influence to prevail on Poland to carry out her international obligations under the Versailles treaty and other pacts."

MOSCOW, Jan. 29 -- With the introduction this month of two measures of action to win the villages to real socialization -- the formation of a political department in the machine-tractor stations and the "mobilization" decree in the North Caucasus -- the coming Spring will witness a decisive struggle on the agrarian front.
HAVANA, Jan. 29. -- American yachtsmen today won their first race of the midwinter International Star Class regatta by capturing the sepond race of the series for the Cuba Cup.
CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Accidental deaths in the United States were 9,500 fewer in 1932 than in 1931, a decline of more than 9 per cent, the National Safety Council estimated today.

LONDON, Jan. 27. -- The complets secrecy surrounding the operations of the government's exchange equalization fund accounts for the absence of any official explanation as to how the Bank of England was enabled to buy 3,820,000 gold this week.

Those seasoned playgoers who are beginning to find even the smarter revues dilute in wit and other theatric flavors are not likely to be interested in the old-fashioned type of musical comedy. "A Honeymoon for Three," by William Siegel and Herman Wohl, which was mounted in Yiddish at the Second Avenue Theatre over the week-end, is not for them.

Williamson S. Howell, First Secretary of the United States Embassy in Paris, and North Winship, Counselor of the United States Legation at Copenhagen, are among the passengers due today from Channel ports on the North German Lloyd liner Europa.

A suggestion that the economic situation of the country should be considered by a national conference of delegates representing all phases of American life was advanced yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Daniel A. Poling in a radio address over WJZ.

"We have got beyond the question whether or not there is a God," the Rev. Dr. Malcolm James MacLeod declared yesterday morning in the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street, of which he is the pastor.

BERLIN, Jan. 27 -- The reports of the German Railroad Corporation and of the Postal and Telegraph Department of the Reich state that the decline in their revenue has definitely ceased. The report on German unemployment is also favorable.

Sara Teasdale, whose lyric poetry had won her widespread recognition, was found dead yesterday morning in her apartment at 1 Fifth Avenue. She was lying in a bathtub filled with warm water, but whether her death was caused by drowning, a stroke or heart disease will not be known until today, when an autopsy will be performed by the Medical Examiner.

The Board of Regents contemplates a complete revision of the syllabus for citizenship and patriotism now in use in the schools of this State. The new one will be based upon "the fundamental philosophy" that a child "learns by doing."

Following three months of argument which at times threatened to split the group, the Joint Committee of Railroads and Highway Users issued for publication today a report in which agreement is shown on principles for the taxation of highway vehicles, reciprocity policies between States for the licensing of commercial motor vehicles, the elimination of grade crossings and the right of railroads to operate motor vehicles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- More business was handled in lard and dry-Falted clear bellies for future delivery on Saturday than on the combined transactions of the five previous days of the week. One provision distributer sold 1,500,000 pounds of May and July lard, and there was liquidation by other interests, also selling of January and buying of May and July by speculators and distributers.

The Board of Regents contemplates a complete revision of the syllabus for citizenship and patriotism now in use in the schools of this State. The new one will be based upon "the fundamental philosophy" that a child "learns by doing."

Following three months of argument which at times threatened to split the group, the Joint Committee of Railroads and Highway Users issued for publication today a report in which agreement is shown on principles for the taxation of highway vehicles, reciprocity policies between States for the licensing of commercial motor vehicles, the elimination of grade crossings and the right of railroads to operate motor vehicles.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29. -- More business was handled in lard and dry-Falted clear bellies for future delivery on Saturday than on the combined transactions of the five previous days of the week. One provision distributer sold 1,500,000 pounds of May and July lard, and there was liquidation by other interests, also selling of January and buying of May and July by speculators and distributers.

A conference called by the Public Education Association to consider the crisis in the schools will be held the evening of Feb. 7 at the home of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, Jan. 29 -- Experiments in cancer treatment, carried out with X-rays shot from the highest voltage machine of its kind in the world, will soon be undertaken in a special building at Michael Reese Hospital, which is protected from ray seeping by 90,000 pounds of lead in its construction.
The full amount of the budget economies effected as the result of Mayor O'Brien's order to his department heads will not be known until Wednesday or Thursday of this week, the Mayor said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- One of the first decisions which the Roosevelt administration must make is whether it will take immediate steps after March 4 to refund at lower interest rates outstanding long-term bonds which are callable during the present calendar year.

HONOLULU, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Guns on Honolulu fortifications pointed seaward tonight in readiness for an "attack." An expected air raid from the "black" fleet, steaming from San Diego, will demonstrate as definitely as can be established with unloaded guns whether an enemy advancing on the Pacific Coast could first silence and destroy America's mid-Pacific outpost.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Jan. 29. -- One of the largest shoots of the season was held over the traps of the Lido Country Club today. The high-over-all gunner was Tom Potter, who broke 95 out of 100 targets. It was the only scratch cup of the day.

It is hard to discover the rationale -- if there be any -- of the latest political upset in Germany. It appears that Chancellor VON SCHLEICHER had provisionally demanded from President HINDENBURG a decree dissolving the Reichstag in case it refused to sustain the Cabinet.

Police radio cars surrounded the Hotel Dauphin, 126 West Sixty-seventh Street, at 1:30 A.M. yesterday while Joseph Temple was sauntering down the stairs from the sixth floor, where he had left Robert McDowell, hotel elevator operator, bound with twine and gagged with strips torn from pillow cases.

In the presence of distress caused by the economic crisis, it is folly to suggest that men should drown their sorrows either by beer or jazz, declared the Rev. Dr. Harold Cook Phillips of the First Baptist Church, Cleveland, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Riverside Church, Riverside Drive and 122d Street.

Stone walls and iron bars separated Salvatore Spitale and Irving Bitz from their enemies yesterday. The two "square-shooting gangsters," chosen by Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh to negotiate with the kidnappers of his infant son, were prisoners in the Tombs, seemingly for their own good.

BERLIN, Jan. 29 (AP). -- Loudly acclaiming assurances by speakers that "the working class is ready to mount barricades to defend its constitutional rights," at least 100,000 persons took part today in an anti-Fascist demonstration in the Lustgarten, the square before the former imperial palace.

Many Britons believe the larger use of sliver as a supplementary currency to gold will aid stabilization in many parts of the world, said Sir Robert Horne, former British Chancellor of the Exchequer, in a talk from London yesterday which was rebroadcast in the United States over a National Broadcasting Company network.
Dr. William P. Healy grave a reception yesterday afternoon at his home, 14 East Ninetieth Street, to introduce his daughter, Miss Dorothy Anne Healy. Spring flowers were used in the decorations.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 (AP) . -- The feminine desire for a woman in the Cabinet, long a conversation topic, was crystallized today in a memorial to President-elect Roosevelt, signed by the presidents of six women's organizations.

Dozens of pieces of old silverware, ranging from ornate fruit dishes to worn napkin rings, in addition to gold-plated ware and jewelry made years ago, were donated by the congregation of Trinity Church, Broadway and Wall Street, yesterday morning to be converted into funds for unemployed Episcopalians in the New York diocese.

The New York County Lawyers' Association made public yesterday its stand on six pending bills to amend the civil practice act. Acting on reports of its committee on legislation, the association favored three and opposed three.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 29 -- It is understood in usually well informed circles that the Argentine and Chilean Foreign Ministers, when they meet in Mendoza, Argentina, Wednesday, will study a plan for settlement of the Leticia, Chaco and other South American conflicts in South America, without the intervention of the United States or other outside nations.

All trains on the Pennsylvania Railroad between New York and Philadelphia, will be operated by electricity beginning Wednesday, according to an announcement issued for publication today. At the same time it was disclosed that on Jan. 13 a test train ran between the cities in eighty-two minutes.

PARIS, Jan. 29. -- Lyolene opens the Summer fashion offensive with mannish Oxford trouser suits having double-breasted jackets and sleeved striped shirts for country wear and superfeminine small-dot or quaint flower-print dress and plain coat ensembles for afternoon.

The proposal to set forward by one month the dates for payment of real estate taxes in this city is opposed by the Citizens Union in a letter just sent to Senator Samuel Mandelbaum and Assemblyman Richard B. Smith, chairman of Senate and Assembly Committees on Cities.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

PITTSBURGH, Jan. 29 -- Production of steel ingots at the beginning of last week was at about 16 per cent of plant capacity, but there was a rise in the week and the average is estimated at nearer 17 per cent. It is regarded as certain that the January average will exceed the 15.02 per cent of December, but perhaps by no more than 1 point.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 29 -- Reviewing the divergent views of A. Mitchell Palmer, former Attorney General, and James M. Beck, former Solicitor General, upon the control of State conventions for dealing with the proposed constitutional amendment for prohibition repeal, Ralph M. Shaw, Chicago lawyer, has come to the conclusion that conventions initiated by Congress are preferable to those set up by State Legislatures.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 29. -- Harvard and Yale, as an economy measure, have agreed to a change in the date for their annual regatta on the Thames and announced today that the crew races would be held on June 16 instead of June 23, as originally scheduled.

The need for a technological program to protect workers against being thrown out of jobs by the machine is recommended by Professor Elizabeth F. Baker of the Department of Economics, Columbia University, in her findings following a four-year study of the printing trades.

The northeast gale which had battered the North Atlantic seaboard for two days with terrific seas, doing damage to coastal communities that is expected to run into millions, blew itself out yesterday. But it was supplanted almost immediately by an icy gale from the northwest.

"Evensong," a dramatization by Edward Knoblock of the similarly named novel by Beverley Nichols, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the Selwyn Theatre. Edith Evans, who played in the London production, will have the leading role.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The bankruptcy reform bill was passed late today by the House under suspension of rules and now goes to the Senate, where a virtually identical measure sponsored by Senator Hastings is pending before the Judiciary Committee.

PEIPING, Jan. 30. -- China, battling diplomatically to solve the Chino-Japanese dispute, has decided that means of permitting independent Tokyo-Nanking conversations leading toward settlement could be worked out if a third party, such as the United States or Great Britain, offered to act as go-between in bringing representatives of the disputant governments together.

Edward A. Widtman of New York scored his first victory in four starts in the national amateur pocket billiard tournament at the Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy last night when he defeated Henry C. Craft of Brooklyn, 125 to 86, in forty-five innings.

The current proposals to inflate currency were condemned last night by Arthur A. Ballantine, Under-Secretary of the Treasury, and by Charles S. McCain, chairman of the board of the Chase National Bank and president of the American Acceptance Council, at a meeting of the council to discuss the fiscal policies of the nation and the prospects of business during the coming year.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Another investors' suit growing out of the crash of the Insull utilities empire, in which hope of recovery lies in the directors rather than the now empty shell they once managed, was filed in Federal court today. The suit seeks $23,233,000 from Corporation Securities Company, a $150,000,000 Insull investment trust.

To the Editor of The New York Times: News reports from Albany continue week after week to express confidence in the enactment this Winter of some kind of unemployment insurance legislation. This expectancy is apparently based upon public pledges and recommendations which, when analyzed, disclose a remarkable sequence in the following order:
Eugene F. Moran last night began his tenth year as leader of the Fox Hills Golf Club on Staten Island.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Since the visit of Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, to President-elect Roosevelt at Warm Springs, President Hoover has necessarily taken a back seat in the making of arrangements for the coming of the representatives of Great Britain to Washington after Mr. Roosevelt takes office.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Louisiana's Senators, who have maintained a cold silence toward each other throughout this session of Congress, this afternoon began to recount publicly their versions of a political controversy soon to be studied by a select committee of the Senate.

The National Transportation Committee wound up a busy week-end by holding here yesterday one of its final meetings preparatory to issuing a report on the railroads and transportation generally on or about Feb. 15. About one hundred briefs have been submitted to it, exclusive of the expressions of "happy-thought" writers, in consequence of which the committee had more material to digest than had originally been expected.

LIMA, Peru, Jan. 30. -- The best way for Colombia and Peru to reach an agreement in the controversy over the city of Leticia is by direct negotiation between these countries, having in mind the national honor and dignity of each.

HAVANA, Jan. 30. -- President Machado, in an interview at the Presidential Palace today, denied that his government is a dictatorship and insisted that a majority of the Cuban people are supporting him. He promised to hold an honest Presidential election next year, at which, he said, he would not be a candidate for a third term.

Gwen Lux, one of the three sculptors whose work, commissioned for the Radio City Music Hall, met with Roxy's disapproval, opened an exhibition yesterday at the Delphic Studios, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street. "Spirit of the Dance" and "The Goose Girl," by the other two sculptors, William Zorach and Robert Laurent, have ere this been seen and discussed.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Jan. 25 shows a decrease for the week of $75,000,000 in loans, partly offset by an increase of $39,000,000 in investments; decreases of $46,000,000 in time deposits, $23,000,000 in government deposits and $12,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve banks, and increases of $29,000,000 in net demand deposits and $17,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve banks.
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 30. -- President-elect Roosevelt intends to draw heavily on the Senate for members of his Cabinet.
Alice Moves North. "And so," said the White Rabbit to Miss LE GALLIENNE'S Alice as they emerged from the Subway, "here we are, moved up all the way from Fourteenth Street to Times Square."

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The standstill conference of the foreign creditors' committees and the German debtors' committee to work out a new agreement for the maintenance of short-term banking credits to Germany got under way at the Reichsbank this morning.

The Department of Labor assigned a staff of men yesterday to act as boards of inquiry into the status of 206 Chinese coolies who arrived in New York Saturday on the Dollar liner President Lincoln with the intention of shipping out in the crews of American-flag ships.
NEW YORK. Lady Faith Montagu, daughter of the Earl and Countess of Sandwich, has come from Washington and is with Mrs. Ryder Breed at 812 Park Avenue.

The neighborhood block of 300 East Sixty-fifth Street was saddened yesterday by the suicide of Dr. Michael Roache, who for many years had given free treatments to poor patients in his home at 307, where he had lived virtually a recluse for the last twenty years.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- President Hoover joined Ohioans in Washington tonight in honoring the memory of President William McKinley.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Senatorial interest in agricultural relief was shown in two other directions today, the chief development being the introduction of a bill to refinance farm mortgages at a low rate of interest coincident with the complete revamping of the Federal structure for extending farm credits.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Those who have watched the response which the community has made to the various appeals for the relief of the unemployed must have been deeply stirred by the readiness with which people of all kinds have shared their seriously depleted resources with their destitute neighbors.

RIDGEWOOD, N.J., Jan. 30 (AP). -- Edgar G. Allen, who lived in Knoxville, Tenn., for twenty-two years as "Ted Morris," returned tonight to Ridgewood, home of his wife and two sons who had believed him dead.
Two northward moves in the midtown section of Manhattan's east side were reported among the business leases yesterday, in addition to two expansion rentals.

The adjusted index of automobile production has risen sharply to 48.1 for the week ended Jan. 28 from 42.0 (revised) for the preceding week and 39.0 for the corresponding week last year. Actual output, according to Cram's Automotive Reports, was about 39,330 cars and trucks, as against 33,616 cars and trucks (revised) in the preceding week and 26,200 cars and trucks in the corresponding week last year.

BERLIN, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Presiding over the first session of his Cabinet of "national concentration," Chancellor Hitler tonight put through unanimous motions against all policies of suppression, economic adventures or financial experimentation.

Another sharp break occurred yesterday in the Danish krone, arising from the suspension of foriegn exchange business in Copenhagen, because of the politico-economic crisis there. The Danish unit was swept down more than 1 cent to 15.62 cents, the lowest price since March, 1924.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Crowded galleries listened tonight as Governor Lehman's first annual budget message with its recommendations for heavy tax increases was being read in the Senate and Assembly, with the budget bill. It was referred without debate in the Senate to the Finance Committee and in the Assembly to the Committee on Ways and Means.

Resolutions urging early and final sion of war debts and condemning the allotment plan for stabilizing farm prices will be presented to the Chamber of Commerce of the ate of New York at its meeting Feb. 2, it became known yesterday when committee reports were stributed to members.

Reflecting the generally improved conditions in the oil industry last year, the Petroleum Corporation of America reveals a gain in the net asset value of its capital stock in its annual report, issued yesterday. In the year, the board of directors was reduced from thirty-seven to fourteen members.

OMAHA, Neb., Jan. 30. -- Governor Charles W. Bryan today moved to bring farmers and mortgage holders together and end the farmers' holiday movement in Nebraska by appointing a conciliatory board of seven, composed of farm leaders, business men and others who are to act without pay and whose duty it will be to bring about fair and equitable settlements between debtors and creditors.

LOS ANGEEES, Jan. 30. -- Balky motor cars, carrying scores of shivering passengers who went into the San Bernardino Mountains over the week-end for a taste of Winter and ran into a raging blizzard, began a parade late today down the snow-drifted mountainsides to the green valleys of Southern California.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 30. -- Senator Howell reiterated in the Senate today a statement made on Jan. 20 that "all that France has paid us since the settlement of the war debt" is not equivalent to the sum that country received from the sale of war supplies purchased from the United States and charged against an account grouped with the war debts.

MONTREAL, Jan. 30. -- The announcement of the British Government that an empire content of 50 per cent will be required for imperial preference on a long list of commodities, including motor cars, is regarded as good news for Canadian manufacturers, particularly the makers of automobiles.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Jan. 30. -- The touring United States tennis team today climaxed its Australian invasion by winning the Australian doubles championship. However, it failed in its quest for the singles title, which was retained by Jack Crawford.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Police in Berlin were forced to use clubs to disperse crowds in the working class districts, which were flooded with Communist handbills urging that a general strike begin at 7 A.M. today in protest against the Hitler Cabinet.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Johnny Layton, billiard star from Sedalia, Mo., tonight remained in the race for the world's three-cushion championship by defeating the defending champion, Augie Kieckhefer, of Chicago, 50 to 33, in forty-seven inning's. The setback wrecked Kieckhefer's chances of retaining the title he won a year ago.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- After a day of wrangling over items in the first big supply measure to come before it -- the billion-dollar Treasury-Postoffice bill -- the Senate heard a bipartisan demand for abandonment of its customary five-hour day in favor of night sessions, beginning tomorrow.

The Province of Buenos Aires, Argentina, through its Minister of Finance, Carlos I. Gomez, formally announced yesterday its inability to continue the debt service on its external loans, which include four bond issues marketed here and now outstanding in an amount of about $70,000,000.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 30. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt today celebrated his fifty-first birthday anniversary by cutting an eighty-pound birthday cake in the presence of 150 patients and staff members of the Warm Springs Foundation and by a dinner at his cottage, which was attended by members of his family and James A. Farley, Frank C. Walker, Edward J. Flynn and Henry Morgenthau Jr.

Executing a sort of flank movement in their efforts to round up their athletes for the 1933 campaign, the Yankees yesterday announced the signing of six players, a majority of whom are reasonably certain to take part in the next pennant fight.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Larger receipts of hogs depressed the market here today and prices were 20 cents a hundredweight lower than on Saturday and 15 to 30 cents lower than on Friday. The demand was relatively slow, although packers received more than half of the shipments directly.
These orders were issued yesterday:

Between 300 and 400 Communist sympathizers were routed from East Sixth Street late yesterday afternoon after an all-day demonstration in behalf of six tenants who had been evicted from a row of four-story houses at 418, 418 1/2 and 420 Sixth Street for non-payment of rent.

A gift of $150,000 from J.P. Morgan Co. to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee was announced yesterday. The gift was included in the $15,026,000 raised in the recent campaign but the contributor's name had not been reported.

The preliminary report of the Consolidated Gas, Electric Light and Power company of Baltimore for 1932 shows gross operating revenue of $27,506,531, against $28,499,247 for 1931, a decrease of $992,716. Net operating revenue after depreciation was $8,791,323, against $9,652,158, a decrease of $860,835.

With the endorsement of Health Commissioner Wynne and other speakers, the women's auxiliary of the Broad Street Hospital formally began last night its campaign for funds to endow 10,000 beds for the unemployed in hospitals throughout the country.

The Mexican Government won yesterday its application to oust the Supreme Court of jurisdiction to hear the accounting suit by the international committee of bankers on Mexico, of which Thomas W. Lamont is chairman, for a court ruling as to the manner in which $6,952,148 remaining from the customs receipts turned over by the government of Mexico is to be applied on defaulted bonds.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I note in THE TIMES today an account of a special edition of Bus Transportation, wherein several writers discuss motor taxation, asserting that such taxation totaled $1,085,000,000 in 1932, whereas that of the railroads was but $275,000,000.

Charles B. McLaughlin, District Attorney of the Bronx, announced yesterday that he had ordered Sylvester Ryan, one of his Assistant District Attorneys, to begin a grand jury investigation today into frauds and irregularities in last November's elections.

Edna Ferber, novelist and playwright, arrived yesterday from abroad in the North German Lloyd liner Europa, with her mother. She said that an attack of influenza, from which she has not yet wholly recovered, had prevented her from seeing the London production of "Dinner at Eight," which she wrote with George S. Kaufman.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Jan. 28 unless specified:

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The amazing life of luxury lived by John (Jake, the Barber) Factor, the Chicagoan who is fighting extradition from the United States to answer charges of defrauding English investors of $7,000,000, was revealed in Old Bailey Criminal Court today by Harry Geen, former personal secretary to Factor.
Having already announced its dates for the coming year, the United States Golf Association, golf's ruling body, has now made its final move toward getting ready for the 1933 season.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 30. -- Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas gave but a statement today that "exploration" in Asuncion and La Paz by confidential diplomatic agents has provided Argentina with concrete points which it believes acceptable to both Bolivia and Paraguay as a asis for the cessation of hostilities in the Chaco, which is one of the principal objects of the conference e will have with Foreign Minister Cruchaga of Chile at Mendoza, Argentina, Wednesday.

To prevent information from being circulated concerning the liquidation of assets of insolvent national banks, David Burnett, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, has approved a plan to be followed in effecting transfers of stocks and bonds without payment of stamp taxes by the institutions concerned.

Bail bonds totaling more than $150,000, which had been furnished by the Greater City Surety and Indemnity Corporation for twenty-five defendants indicted in recent years by the New York County grand jury, were voided yesterday in General Sessions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am interested in the discussion among your correspondents of pronunciation, as it offers another example of the somewhat amusing-habit of generalization. All over Europe one hears frequently that Americans do or say this or that.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- State Senator Nelson W. Cheney of New York, chairman of the Joint Legislative Committee on Banking, appointed by former Governor Roosevelt, called upon Senator Wagner today and urged that steps be taken by Congress to curb publicity on loans granted by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- While dry leaders stood outside waiting to be heard, the Senate Finance Committee today brushed aside all proposals for further hearings on the Collier-Blaine beer bill and ordered it sent to the Senate with a favorable report.

Adolf Hitler's acceptance of the German Chancellorship in a coalition with conservatives and non-partisans marks a radical departure from his former demand that he be made "the Mussolini of Germany" as a condition to his assumption of government responsibility.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Recommendations for tightening up the regulation and licensing of real estate brokers and salesmen were made tonight by Edward J. Flynn, Secretary of State, in his annual report to the Governor and to the Legislature.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- A bill to create a Federal Communications and Power Commission, which would combine the Radio and Federal Power Commissions and take over from the Interstate Commerce Commission the supervision of all interstate communications lines, was introduced in the House today by Chairman Rayburn of the Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Labor and industry united today in pleas for tariff increases, which they described as needed immediately because of depreciated foreign currencies and falling scales of foreign wages.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It would be a stupid and inhumane parent who refused to take his child to a doctor when the child was critically ill just because he could not see his way to pay the bill. It would be an unspeakably cruel and inhumane doctor who would refuse his aid because he did not see the parent's cash on hand.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- The Boerse was extremely irregular today. Conflicting reports in connection with the appointment of the new Cabinet created considerable nervousness and the final list of the new Ministers came as a complete surprise.

The campaign now being conducted by the State Conservation Department in Connecticut against predatory animals and birds is meeting with considerable success, according to a report made by Superintendent Arthur L. Clark yesterday.

The death of Sara Teasdale, poet, whose body was found Sunday morning in a partially filled bathtub in her apartment at 1 Fifth Avenue, was the result of accident and not suicide. Chief Medical Examiner Charles Norris reported after an autopsy yesterday.
ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Spurred by Governor Lehman, the Legislature took action tonight to pass at tomorrow's session the bill appropriating $15,000,000 additional for unemployment relief.

DETROIT, Jan. 30. -- Henry Ford sent an ultimatum today to the Briggs Manufacturing Company, where a strike has forced a shutdown of the Ford plants, warning that if the Briggs company did not quickly resume delivery of automobile bodies he would begin manufacturing his own.

Five bills to amend the Penal Law and the Code of Criminal Procedure were forwarded yesterday by District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin of the Bronx to Senator Harry G. Schackno, chairman of the Judiciary Committee, and Assemblyman Nicholas J. Eberhardt, both of the Bronx.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- Traders in wheat see in the dullness of the market the first real sign of approaching activity and probably a higher level of prices. Some leading operators several months ago expressed the belief that sooner or later the market would stabilize around some level and would remain there regardless of the news.

Edna V. O'Brien, well-known here and in other cities as an investment counselor to women, was arrested yesterday afternoon in her seven-room office suite on the thirty-fourth floor of the French Building, 551 Fifth Avenue, on a charge of grand larceny.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Invoking suspension of the rules, which requires a two-thirds majority of members voting, the House today passed the Ways and Means Committee bill continuing the 1-cent-a-gallon gasoline tax until June 30, 1934.

An attentive but cautious share market refused yesterday to give Wall Street any definite intimation as to the course which may be pursued when some overhanging uncertainties have been removed. Business on the Stock Exchange was of small proportions, the day's transactions involving 476,000 shares, compared with 972,000 on Friday, the last five-hour day of the previous week.

PARIS, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Mrs. Carter, who was 67 years old, had a slight cold on Friday when she left Paris to spend the week-end at Senlis, near the forest of Chantilly. This developed into influenza.

The City A.C. annexed the title in the New York division of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League Class C tournament last night, scoring a clean sweep in its match with the Harvard Club at the City A.C. courts. The score was 7-0. The City A.C. will now meet the winner of the New Jersey division play for the championship.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Amid applause from both sides of the aisle just before the House adjourned this afternoon, Representative Ludlow of Indiana called attention to the fact that today was the birthday of President-elect Roosevelt.

BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- Next to Chancellor Adolf Hitler, the most sensational member of the new Cabinet is Alfred Hugenberg, who holds the portfolios of Economy and Food. Consolidation of these Ministries has been his pet scheme. He is an arch-capitalist -- though with leanings toward antarchy -- financier, industrialist and newspaper publisher, and has been called the German Northcliffe.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 30. -- The Supremus colt Cathop, at one time last Spring considered a formidable Kentucky Derby eligible, was a driving winner of the Panama City Purse, feature today at Hialeah Park.
PARIS, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Telephone wire, glass and wood joined the 1933 style pageant as the last word in trimmings and economy in Spring clothes today.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Winning her second race of the Winter season over a sloppy track, Little Marcelle surprised the talent today when she romped home three lengths in front of Prometheus in the six-furlong feature of the all-claiming program at the Fair Grounds.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- Secretary of State Flynn urged tonight in his annual report that amateur boxing and wrestling be taken away from the A.A.U. and sent back under the jurisdiction of the State Athletic Commission.

If President COMPTON speaks hopefully of atomic energy, it is because of the remarkable discoveries made in the last two years. To release the energy of the atom, the nucleus, hitherto an impregnable citadel, must be shattered. Protons, electrons, alpha particles must be made to stream forth and to recombine in a process of transmutation which is highly energetic.

The F.W. Woolworth Company yesterday reported for 1932 a net income of $22,101,005, equal after all charges, including deductions for depreciation, amortization and Federal taxes and a reduction in market value of securities and unrealized foreign exchange losses, to $2.27 a share on 9,750,000 capital shares outstanding.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- The creation of an interstate sanitation commission to curb pollution of coastal and tidal waters adjacent to New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, was proposed today in bills introduced in the Senate. The proposed commission would be effective for New York and New Jersey as soon as approved by those two States, according to the bills.

The Chase National Bank will announce today the sale at auction here on next Tuesday of virtually all collateral securing its loan to the National Electric Power Company, principal Eastern holding unit of the Insull Middle West Utilities System.

While violins wailed and bagpipes played merrily, 250 members of the New York Scottish Society met last night in the Grand Opera House, Eighth Avenue and Twenty-third Street, to celebrate the 174th anniversary of the birth of Robert Burns and the twenty-fourth anniversary of the founding of their society.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, Ambassador of Great Britain, is sailing for London tonight on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. Others leaving on the ship for the Channel ports include J.D. Mooney, president of General Motors Export Company; Lord Decies, Sam Park, United States Vice Consul at Biarritz, France; Princess Eugenia Ruspoli de Nemi and her daughter, Miss Maria Theresa Berry; Nelson Doubleday, publisher, and Mrs. Doubleday, and Hans Kempinski, German wine merchant and restaurateur.

Led by five of its ring champions, a team of sixteen amateur boxers of the Metropolitan A.A.U. routed invaders from Cleveland, Philadelphia, Pittsburgh and Baltimore last night in the intercity tournament in Madison Square Garden.
Paul Boepple, director of the American Dalcroze Institute, will conduct a course in improvization both for beginners and advanced students at the New School. The course will commence Feb. 14.

ROME, Jan. 30. -- The National Socialist movement in Germany has given so many indications of sympathy for the Italian Fascist regime that the appointment of Adolf Hitler to the Chancellorship of Germany could not but produce sentiments akin to joy throughout Italy.

LONDON, Jan. 30. -- United States manufacturers who apply minor finishing touches on their goods in Canada and then send them to Great Britain under imperial tariff preferences as "empire goods" will lose that privilege under an order issued by the Board of Trade tonight.

GENEVA, Jan. 30. -- Agreeing with the German and French delegates that gas might play a much greater part in any future wars than in the World War, Captain Anthony Eden of Great Britain in the Disarmament Bureau this afternoon reached a different conclusion from them.

A report published yesterday summarized certain important conclusions reached by a joint committee representing the railways and their new rivals, the motor carriers. The two groups "agreed to disagree" on the much-disputed question of rate regulation for trucks and buses.

Supreme Court Justice Julius Miller upheld yesterday the action of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes in removing Sam Kaplan, president of Moving Picture Operators Union Local 306 and in barring him from running for office for five years.

Resolutions calling for an immediate drive throughout the country for $1,200,000 to aid Orthodox Jewish Congregations facing financial difficulties, and for the creation of a group of leading rabbis and laymen who would perpetuate Jewish customs, were adopted yesterday at the closing of the annual convention of the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America at the Hotel Edison.

There was confusion at Quarantine yesterday forenoon when the high wind caused the North German Lloyd liner Europa to drag her anchor and Captain Oscar Scharf ordered her to be hove up and the engines started to keep her in position to prevent a collision with the freighter Aachen, moored near by.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Jan. 31. -- Developments of the greatest importance are occurring in connection with Japan's decisive answer to the League of Nations' latest communication on the Manchurian dispute.

With a field of fifty-five competing, the seventh annual De Witt Clinton interscholastie tennis tournament got under way yesterday at the 369th Regiment Armory. The opening competition found all the eight seeded players automatically advancing to the second round by means of byes and no upsets of any sort were recorded.

BERKELEY, Cal., Jan. 30 (AP). -- Life from the great voids of space between the stars in the form of living bacteria found in meteors was reported here today by Professor Charles B. Lipman, dean of the graduate division of the University of California.

CLEVELAND, Jan. 30 (AP). -- Gorilla Jones, Akron (Ohio) fighter, knocked out Sammy Slaughter of Terre Haute, Ind., in the seventh round of a scheduled twelve-round bout tonight, thereby gaining the American middleweight championship as recognized by the National Boxing Association.
The amateur rider G.H. (Pete) Bostwick and the 7-year-old gelding Kellsboro Jack will be a formidable combination in the Liverpool Grand National.

Mrs. Constance Wilson Samuels and her brother, Montgomery Wilson of Toronto, who hold the three North American figure-skating championships, will make a determined bid to retain their laurels at the 1933 title meet next month. Receipt of their entries for the competition, which will be held Feb. 10 and 11, was announced yesterday.

Trading on local commodity exchanges continued yesterday to be dull and price movements were listless. Coffee retained its upward price trend, and silver and hide futures also made moderate gains. Contracts for all others, however, continued to fall slightly lower.

BOSTON, Mass., Jan. 30. -- Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd, retired, will start in October on his second exploration trip to the South polar regions with an expedition of forty men aboard the old Coast Guard cutter Bear.

It is to be feared that Dana Burnet and William B. Jutte have squired their play in a madcap mood. "Bad Manners," which was tossed around at the Playhouse last evening, is fundamentally superficial. As nearly as this reporter could tell by stopping, looking and listening throughout the performance, "Bad Manners" proves that abstemiousness makes the heart grow fonder.

GEORGE SAINTSBURY should have lived to be 100. Probably he would have done so if he had not weaned himself from those divine vintages of which he wrote so engagingly. Still, to stick to this planet till one is "going on" 88 is in itself no small performance.

The North German Lloyd liner Europa arrived yesterday with the story of a herring that was washed on board over the starboard bow in the middle watch, near 4 A.M., yesterday, on top of a sea estimated to be at least forty feet high.
LONDON, Jan. 30. -- The Cabinet spent an hour and a half considering the war debts today in its first formal discussion of the problem since before Christmas.

Earlier Promotions Help Orders. The shaping of plans by an increased number of stores to feature Spring lines earlier than was anticipated proved a stimulating factor upon orders placed in this market yesterday. Indications were said to be that the week generally will see brisk purchasing of both ready-to-wear and accessories.

CHICAGO, Jan. 30. -- James W. Stevens and his sons, Ernest J. and Raymond W., were reported named in three true bills voted by the Cook County Grand Jury today charging conspiracy and embezzlement in connection with the failure of the $150,000,000 Illinois Life Insurance Company.

PRINCETON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Miss Marguerite Anderson of Plainfield, seeded fourth, was the victim of the only major upset today as the third annual women's New Jersey squash racquets championship got under way at the Pretty Brook Tennis Club.

PRAGUE, Jan. 30. -- Czechoslovak opinion accepts the nomination of Adolf Hitler to the German Chancellorship without special excitement, considering that he has been made a prisoner of the so-called Harzburg front by President von Hindenburg through the President's appointment of Franz von Papen and Lieut. Gen. Werner von Blomberg to important posts with him.
The original bathysphere in which Dr. William Beebe descended almost half a mile into the ocean on the recent Bermuda expedition has been placed on exhibit at the American Museum of Natural History.

HAVANA, Jan. 30. -- Sailing over a smooth sea with a strong wind that steadily improved, the American yacht, Ace, of the Western Long Island Sound fleet, skippered by Adrian Iselin 2d today, won the second race of the international regatta for Star Class yachts competing for the Bacardi Cup.

It would be useless to try to disguise the qualms which the news from Berlin must cause to all friends of Germany. At the head of the Government of the German Republic has been placed a man who has openly scorned it and vowed that he would destroy it as soon as he could set up the personal dictatorship which was his boasted aim.
Five Manhattan properties and six in the Bronx passed at auctions yesterday to plaintiffs in foreclosure. One scheduled sale was adjourned to next week.

Turning in a brilliant display of fencing at the Salle d'Armes Vince last night, Miss Muriel Guggolz of the home organization swept through both the preliminaries and the final round-robin without losing a bout to win the Vince medal in the women's individual foils competition.

The Board of Education approved yesterday a $2,638,010 reduction in its 1933 budget. This is $130,000 more than the proposed cuts announced on Jan. 17 when Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the board, gave a detailed list of the items affected.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Jan. 30. -- The Atlantic City National Bank and its two branches, having about 15,000 depositors, did not open for business today. It was the second financial institution in this city to close within the last four days.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- Governor Moore accepted today the resignation of James Kerney of Trenton as a lay judge of the Court of Errors and Appeals and sent to the Senate at once the nomination of William L. Dill of Paterson to fill the vacancy.

ALBANY, Jan. 30. -- New or additional taxes, of an aggregate of $84,000,000, were recommended by Governor Lehman in his annual budget message, which was transmitted to the Legislature this evening with his constitutional budget bill, calling for total appropriations for the next fiscal year from all funds and for all purposes of $234,998,531, a decrease of 23.7 per cent.

Ferdinand Pecora, former chief assistant district attorney of New York County, began his work yesterday as counsel for the subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency, investigating Stock Exchange practices, by subpoenaing Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, and Gordon Rentschler, president of that bank, together with Horace Sylvester, vice president of its investment affiliate, the National City Company.

Events in Germany appeared to be moving too rapidly yesterday for Wall Street bankers concerned with German credits to appraise the significance of the appointment of the leader of the Nazis as Chancellor of the Reich, but the financial markets, on the whole, took the news calmly.

Several activities of E.I. du Pont e Nemours Co. shared in the general improvement that some important industries have shown since July 1, Lammont du Pont, president, asserted yesterday in issuing the company's pamphlet report for 1932.

For his work in saving the Metropolitan Opera in the present critical years, which has been the climax of a quarter of a century unmatched in operatic history here or abroad, all the artists of the association and those retired and still within reach of New York will unite in celebrating the twenty-fifth anniversary of Giulio Gatti-Casazza as general manager.

To augment the budgets of forty of its member agencies, the Protestant Foundation of the Federation of Protestant Welfare Agencies has voted an extra dividend, effective today, out of its trust funds.

NEWTON D. BAKER'S appeal to Governors and Legislatures of forty-two States to increase State funds for the relief of the unemployed in 1933 was made necessary by the straits of municipalities unable to take care of their needy. To obtain loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, States must show that they have given as much as they could.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- Glenn S. (Pop) Warner sees big things for Temple University in the football wars of the next few years.

Preliminary figures indicate that in December the railroads increased their net operating income over that of a year before for the first time since August, 1929. Net operating income of the first forty-eight roads to report for December was $22,884,000, against $21,726,000 in December, 1931, an increase of 5.3 per cent, and against $44,351,000 in December, 1930, a decrease of 48.4 per cent.

Physicians would make more money and patients would pay less under a guild system of medical practice, Evans Clark, director of the Twentieth Century Fund, says in "How to Budget Health," a book published yesterday by Harpers.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Complete destruction of the American merchant marine with resultant losses of millions to industry, agriculture and labor was pictured as a likely outcome of legislative proposals now pending in Congress, in a statement issued today by the National Committee on the Merchant Marine after a conference at the Shipping Board with Chairman T.V. O'Connor.

The bulk of the estate of William Fitz-Randolph of 135 West Eighty-fifth Street, a retired broker, who died on April 29, was left to Columbia University and the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the appraisal showed yesterday. The gross estate was put at $601,073 and the net at $561,368, of which $378,365 was in securities.

DUBLIN, Jan. 30. -- President Eamon de Valera is making several changes in his Cabinet. Vice President Sean T. O'Kelly, who has been Minister of Local Government, is to be Minister without portfolio so that he can assist the President in dealing with external affairs.

Despite charges by their lawyers that they were being held on trumped-up charges, Salvatore Spitale and Irvingr Bitz remained prisoners in the Tombs yesterday while the police sought evidence to justify holding them indefinitely.

A new issue of $12,000,000 Cincinnati Union Terminal Company first mortgage 5 per cent bonds, due in 195, held by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as collateral for a loan, will be placed on the market today by a syndicate composed of J.P. Morgan Co., Kuhn, Loeb Co., the First National Bank New York and the National City Company.

Mayor O'Brien took the first definite step yesterday toward building up new revenues for the city when he approved suggestions for increasing old fees charged by the Police Department and for adding new charges. The changes will provide altogether an increased revenue of $791,404.

Innocente Baiguera, Italian heavy-weight, scored his second successive knockout triumph in this country by stopping Frank Montagna of Newark at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 1,000 persons saw the Italian boxer deal a steady stream of punishment to his rival before Referee Jack Britton stopped the bout in 1:25 of the fifth session.
Adverse influences yesterday dropped prices on the Cotton Exchange 9 to 12 points.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 30. -- The State Highway Commission was advised today by O.H. Ammann, chief engineer of the Port of New York Authority, that toll collection on the Newark-Jersey City viaduct, as proposed by the Legislature, would cost the motoring public twice as much as the State would obtain in revenue.

PARIS, Tuesday, Jan. 31. -- France this morning was moving rapidly toward a new governmental alignment. Balked by the demands of the Socialists in forming a Cabinet with a Left orientation, Edouard Daladier, the Radical Premier-designate, turned with greater success to the Centre parties for collaboration.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Jan. 30. -- Legislation directing immediate bonus payments would "destroy morale and hinder recovery," according to a report of a "prosperity survey" made by Dr. Clyde William Phelps, head of the department of economics at the University of Chattanooga and author of numerous textbooks.
BERLIN, Jan. 30. -- Adolf Hitler, leader of the National Socialist party, today was appointed Chancellor of Germany after being twice rejected last year for that office.

BELFAST, Tuesday, Jan. 31. -- The strike on the railways of Northern Ireland and on the whole Great Northern Railway of Ireland, which is partly in the Free State and partly in Northern Ireland, began last midnight. The men are resisting a reduction in wages recommended by the Irish Railway Wages Board.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Our exports of chemical fertilizers, nitrogen compounds, exclusive of ammonium sulphate, increased to 167,000 long tons in 1932, a gain of 250 per cent over 1931, while our imports were about 50,000 long tons, the Commerce Department announced today.

By the margin of a single point, Ralph A. Powers of the Harvard Club, one of the ranking players of this section, escaped defeat at the hands of a comparative newcomer last night as the metropolitan squash racquets championship got under way at the University Club with an entry that included the national titleholder and two former wearers of the crown.

A new "father of the symphony" was proclaimed in Town Hall last night when Quinto Maganini, conductor of the Sinfonietta of New York, explained that Johann Stamitz's "Pastoral Symphony," given its first American performance, had been written nearly a decade before poor Haydn essayed the symphonic form.

An attitude of extreme listlessness was reflected in yesterday's dull and pointless dealings on the Stock Exchange. Price fluctuations were highly irregular in the share market, although the late movement was in the direction of higher prices.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The domestic allotment plan for farm relief was vigorously defended before the Senate Agriculture Committee today by W.R. Ronald, newspaper editor of Mitchell, S.D., and denounced by representatives of the meat packers.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Setting the pace for the best-balanced field that has ever competed in the classic, John B. Ryerson, former Yale star, of the Cooperstown (N.Y.) Country Club, won the qualifying medal today in the sixth annual national championship of golf club champions.

CORAL, GABLES, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Favorites came through without exception in the first round of match play today in the Miami-Biltmore Golf Championship for Women. The co-medalists, Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, and Mrs. Estelle Drennan, Tulsa, Okla., romped to easy victories, while another favorite, Miss Bea Gottlieb of New York overwhelmed her opponent, Mrs. Evelyn Reeve, Cincinnati, by 9 and 7.
LINCOLN, Neb., Jan. 30 (AP). -- Several leaders of the Nebraska Legislature, now in session expressed hope that the conciliation plan would bring relief, but others were somewhat doubtful.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Expressing dissatisfaction with the delay in action on the question in the Senate, Chairman McReynolds of the House Foreign Affairs Committee today introduced a resolution to confer upon the President authority to declare an arms embargo, in cooperation with other nations, against countries at war.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30. -- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Carnegie Phipps entertained tonight with a dinner at their villa. Among the guests were:...

Governor LEHMAN is too modest. He speaks of his budget as "generally conforming" with established custom. It does, but the message accompanying it transcends in power of analysis and exposition much that has gone before.

HAVANA, Jan. 30 (AP). -- The Ace's time today, 2:45:52, was the slowest registered in the four races hold thus far in the annual regatta for the Cuba and Bacardi trophies. Competition is under the auspices of the International Star Class Yachting Association.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30 (AP). -- An unusual alignment of Northern and Southern coal operators on the same side in a lake cargo rate fight came to light today when the Interstate Commerce Commission disclosed that the Southern bituminous mine owners were supporting Western Pennsylvania and Ohio mine owners in their opposition to a proposed 30 cents a ton increase in rates.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Maintenance of the army, navy and Marine Corps at the standards provided for in the National Defense act of 1920 was urged as a "necessity" superior to the demands for economy at the opening tonight of a three-day session of the Women's Patriotic Conference on National Defense.
PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 30. -- Colonel Henry D. Paxson, lawyer, historian and antiquarian, died of pneumonia today at his home here, after a week's illness.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 30. -- Congress was criticized today in a White House statement which asserted that bills thus far reported out of committee exceed budget estimates by $163,319,642. The statement read:

Deposits in mutual savings banks in the United States amounted on Jan. 1 to $9,970,947,424, a decline of $59,066,961, or slightly more than one-half of 1 per cent, from the beginning of 1932, according to the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks.

Unless the city's financial condition shows early and unexpected improvement, sufficient to assure the floating of a large issue of fifty-year bonds, there is little hope that the Board of Estimate will authorize any further expenditures for new subway construction this year, it was indicated yesterday.
ALBANY, N.Y., Jan. 30. -- The text of Governor Lehman's budget message, sent to the Legislature today, is as follows:

MOST actors are ardent baseball fans and consequently Mr. Eddie Brannick, who has been with the Giants for something more than a quarter of a century, man and boy, knew he had an appreciative audience when he settled himself in a cozy corner of the Lambs Club and remarked cheerfully that Gus Mancuso, late of the Cardinals, would fill J. Francis Hogan's shoes at the Polo Grounds.

The sixth performance of "The Emperor Jones," including one each in Brooklyn and Philadelphia, wag presented last night at the Metropolitan Opera House. Lawrence Tibbett was again in the title role, with Marek Windheim, Pearl Besuner and Hemsley Winfield also in the cast and Tullio Serafin conducting.

In the most extensive private effort to cooperate with the owners of mortgaged farms ever made, a number of the leading Eastern life insurance companies, with nearly $200,000,000 invested in Iowa farms, have decided to suspend foreclosure activities throughout that State until the Legislature can enact its program to improve the position of the debtors.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 -- Prices for wheat held within a range of 1/2 cent a bushel today on the Board of Trade here and finished unchanged to 1/8 cent higher than on Monday, the distant futures showing the most strength.

FRANK WYKOFF was in the grand stand while Eddie Tolan and Ralph Metcalfe were fighting it out for sprint supremacy in the Olympic Games at Los Angeles, and yet, according to the record book, Frank ran the fastest 100 yards that track fans had ever seen, the time being 9.4 seconds.

Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador at Washington, sailed for home last night on the North German Lloyd liner Europa. To newspapermen who interview him in his suite he announced that he intended to be away "just about as long as it takes to squeeze a lemon" and that he expected to be back at his post by March 1.

After hearing argument for more than two hours yesterday on the renewal of a contract to the Brooklyn Ash Removal Company for final disposition of refuse in Brooklyn, the Board of Estimate's committee of the whole deferred decision for a week.

Total income of the Metropolitan life Insurance Company for 1932 was nearly $1,000,000,000, or the largest ever recorded by any life insurance company, it was shown yesterday in the annual report made public by Frederick H. Ecker, president.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Jan. 31 -- Yale defeated New York University's basketball team tonight in their seventh basketball meeting, 37 -- 27. The Elis staged a drive near the close of the first half which overcame a 11-to-6 lead.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The White House today made public an analysis of budget estimates acted upon by the House or its Committee on Appropriations up to last Friday. The figures showed that bills already reported to the House or passed exceed the President's estimates by $163,319,642.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Members of the New York Power Authority argued at two conferences today with Brig. Gen. George P. Pillsbury, Assistant Chief of Army Engineers, and his assistants for reduction in the share of the cost which it is proposed to allocate to New York State for development of the St. Lawrence deeper waterway and power project.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Millions of individuals will be required to file income tax returns under the revenue act of 1932 who were not required to file returns under the prior revenue act.

The New York Stock Exchange has received from the Freeport Texas Company a notice of a proposed change in capital stock so that there will be authorized 52,500,000 of 6 per cent cumulative convertible preferred stock and 850,000 shares of common stock with a par value of $10.

Interest charges for call money remained unchanged in January from those obtaining at the close of the previous month on both stock exchanges here. Time loans, with the exception of a fractionally lower quotation for half-yearly accommodations, were also unchanged from December.

Gold received at New York in January made the largest total for a month in more than six years, but because most of the shipments were occasioned by releases of earmarked holdings abroad, the gain to the nation's sold stocks was smaller than in December.

New York's most famous philanthropic entertainment -- The Charity Ball -- will take place tonight in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Following the custom maintained since the first Charity Ball in 1856, it will be for the benefit of the Nursery and Child's Hospital.

Commodity futures traded on local exchanges were generally weak yesterday. Closing prices were lower in sugar, cocoa, rubber, hides, silk and silver, while coffee was irregular. In the cash markets, price trends were uneven.

Operation of the Eighth Avenue subway to Borough Hall, Brooklyn, by way of the Cranberry Street tubes under the East River, Trill start at 6:05 A.M. today. At that hour the express train arriving at the Chambers Street station in Manhattan will make the first passenger run over the new link.

The National Lead Company reported yesterday for 1932 a net Income of $3,301,612 after taxes and reserves, equal, after preferred diivdends, to $3.15 a share on the 309,831 shares of common stock.
