These figures include a non-recurring item of $557,980 received from the Federal Government last year as a tax refund and $332,456 because of a bookkeeping adjustment due to the acquisition of the minority interest in the Titanium Pigment Company.

Yeas and Nays. HITLER'S rise to power, we read in a Rome dispatch, has been received with great satisfaction by the "entire Italian press." That is the enormous advantage of having the press function as it does in Italy or in Soviet Russia.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Jan. 31 -- John D. Pettet, 57 years old, a Spanish War veteran and former Mount Vernon electrical appliance merchant, was released for two months this afternoon from the Westchester County jail at East View, where he has been confined since Aug. 7 on a series of commitments resulting from his failure to make alimony payments to his wife.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York A.C., defending champion, last night moved back into a first-place tie with Edward Fagan of the Engineers Club in the national amateur pocket billiard tourney in progress at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP) -- The building of the Insull utility empire was traced today by Federal Trade Commission investigators, who read into their testimony losses running into millions of dollars.

Renewed accumulation of member-bank reserves in excess of requirements marked the early part of January, says the current monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The review relates that with the passing of the crest of the seasonal demand for funds incident to Autumn and holiday trade the usual return flow of currency to the banks followed, and in addition there was a substantial inflow of gold from foreign countries.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Jan. 31 -- Senator Cordell Hull, of Tennessee, will arrive tomorrow night for a conference with President-elect Roosevelt. Professor Raymond Moley, of Columbia University, Mr. Roosevelt's economic adviser, also will come here tomorrow night to remain until Friday, when the President-elect will depart for Jacksonville to start his ten-day cruise.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I have read with some disappointment the editorial "Engineers and Drama."
HUNTINGTON, Ind., Jan. 31 -- This community of 14,000 is excited over a struggle between a local editor and the town's banks.

The cumulative effect of more than two years of dividend readjustments was reflected strikingly in the total of payments declared in January. They amounted to $178,839,359 for 739 corporations, compared with $349,571,195 for 1,183 corporations in the corresponding month of 1931.

American universities must train leaders and raise the general level of "social enlightenment in this complex age" if they are to perform their full function, Dr. Harry W. Chase, president of the University of Illinois and chancellor-elect of New York University, declares in a letter to The University Daily News, undergraduate publication, to be published today.

State Controller Morris S. Tremaine discussed means of building up the credit of New York City and other communities of the State at a conference of bankers here yesterday. He made the prediction that "recent economies will put New York City's credit on an enviable basis," adding that as the city's credit approached normal It would automatically result in lower rates on real estate mortgages covering property in the city.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Fiscal leaders in the Legislature, who will soon be engaged on the big job of whipping the 1933-34 budget into shape, are looking anxiously but with some hope, to Washington for Congressional action to legalize the sale of beer as a means of enabling them to revise downward Governor Lehman's estimate of needed revenues from the sources which he recommended in his budget message last night.
NEW YORK. The Marquess of Lothian will return from Boston today and will be with Mr. and Mrs. Thomas W. Lamont at 107 East Seventieth Street.

The Mayfair Yacht Club, exclusive night club with a nautically decorated porch on the East River to serve as a dock for entertainment-seeking yachtsmen as well as a private entrance and elevator at 450 East Fifty-second Street, in the Beekman Place section; was raided by federal agents last night.

TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 1 -- The Foreign Minister, Count Yasuya Uchida, returned last night from his mission to Prince Kimmochi Saionji, the last of the Elder Statesmen, and will report to the Cabinet today on their conversations regarding the status of the Manchurian issue in the League of Nations.

Banks holding mortgages on defaulted properties in Manhattan and the Bronx were among the successful bidders on several of eighteen parcels put up at foreclosure sales yesterday. Although tenement houses dominated the list of sales, bids were also asked on some vacant and business properties.

The danger that thousands of farm owners throughout the country might lose the properties on which they work for a livelihood was virtually removed yesterday when it became known that the suspension of foreclosure activities by life insurance companies, originally limited to Iowa, had been extended to cover the entire country and Canada.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

The outlook for municipal bonds is for higher prices as a result of the urgent demand for high-grade tax-exempt securities and the desire for safety at a time coinciding with a minimum of offerings, according to A. Edward Scherr Jr., assistant treasurer of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn, in the leading article in the current issue of the bulletin of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.

TORONTO, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press). -- Forced to open their famed defensive style by a first-minute goal, the New York Americans tonight met their most crushing defeat of the season, 7 -- 1, at the hands of the international group leaders the Toronto Maple Leafs.
BERLIN, Jan. 31 (AP). -- A policeman and a Nazi were killed, twelve persons were injured and fifty were arrested in political clashes in Berlin today.

GENEVA, Jan. 31 -- The disarmament conference bureau today reached a significant aspect of the problem of overcoming the prevailing distrust in enforcement of the disarmament treaty, which is a major obstacle to the reduction of armaments.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was the slowest of any month since October, 1924, and the smallest for a January in eleven years. The heaviest day's business was 1,617,454 shares on Jan. 11, and the lightest, 476,955 shares, on Jan. 30.

Bernard S. Deutsch, independent candidate for Supreme Court Justice at the last election, was named chairman of the Bronx committee of the City party at an organization meeting and dinner last night in the Concourse Plaza Hotel, Grand Concourse and 161st Street, the Bronx.
Among the apartment rentals reported yesterday were two for suites in the Sutton Place district and several others for quarters in the east side residential section.
"Marathon" was withdrawn after last night's performance from the Mansfield Theatre, where it opened on Friday.
Pictures of New York of the past and present and portraits of a number of its citizens made up an exhibition of recent accessions by the Museum of the City of New York which will go on view today.
Mrs. Daniel Bacon gave a luncheon yesterday in the north balcony of the Georgian Room of the Pierre for Mme. Paul Dupuy of Paris. The other guests were:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Sesotris Sidarouss Pasha, retiring Minister of Egypt, was the honor guest and speaker at a reception given for him this afternoon at his residence by the Most Rev. Pietro Fumasoni-Biondi, Apostolic Delegate to the United States.

Bond prices moved generally higher yesterday on the Stock Exchange under the leadership of the railroad issues, some of which advanced a point or more for the day. United States Government bonds gained ground slightly, and mild rallies occurred in leading foreign loans which were under pressure on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Peru has been asked by Secretary Stimson, in a note sent to Lima last night, to accept "without modification" the Brazilian proposal for solving the dispute with Colombia over Leticia.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Governor Lehman joined with both branches of the Legislature today to make available at once $15,000,000 more for unemployment relief.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The National Retail Dry Goods Association, in a letter to the Tariff Commission today, opposed proposals for changing the basis of valuation for levying tariff duties from foreign to American valuation.

Six of the eight seeded players triumphed and De Witt Clinton High School strengthened its commanding lead in the race for the team trophy as the second round of play was completed yesterday in the annual De Witt Clinton High School interscholastic indoor tennis tournament at the 369th Regiment Armory.

Several leading insurance companies, with nearly $200,000,000 invested in Iowa farms, have decided to suspend foreclosure actions in that State until the Legislature has had time to enact measures to improve the position of the debtors. The insurance companies have a double responsibility.

NEWARK, N.J., Jan 31 -- Albert Gould, 27 years old, of 52 Smull Avenue. Caldwell, and Fred Hyer, 26, of 128 Westover Avenue. West Caldwell, were held for the Federal grand jury in default of $10,000 bail by United States Commissioner A. L. Friedman here today on charges of using the mails in an attempt to extort money by threats of bodily harm.

NEW ORLEANS, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Carrying the light weight of 101 pounds over a muddy six furlongs in 1:15 1-5, M. Allen's Anne Arundel, once a top notch performer for S.W. Labrot of Baltimore, won the feature race for fillies and mares today at the Fair Grounds.

As the Board of Estimate, sitting in committee of the whole yesterday, approved a suggestion that all city contracts in future go to New York City contractors, who must hire laborers residing here, Mayor John P. O'Brien brought up the possibility that persons working in the city but living beyond its limits might be subjected to a special tax.

RIVERHEAD, L.I., Jan. 31 -- The will of the late Walter Jennings of Cold Spring Harbor, who was identified with the Standard Oil Company for many years, has been filed for probate in the Suffolk County Surrogate's Court here. Mr. Jennings died in Georgia on Jan. 9.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Heim inaugurates his new Champs Elysees premises with a varied collection featuring unusual fabric combinations for all hours. Spring capelet suits of wool weave or checked cotton are worn with knitted wool tops or blouses and cotton-cuffed suede gloves. Simple flax or knitted or woven wool afternoon ensembles are outstanding.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 31 (AP). -- A group of Nationalist Government leaders at Nanking announced today that they were considering introduction of legislation providing for purchase by the government of 1,700 fighting airplanes in "the shortest possible time."
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- France is watching with closest attention the first moves of the Hitler Cabinet in Germany.

Julian Huxley, whose major reputation has been earned as a biologist, is the author of "The Captive Shrew and Other Poems of Biologist," published today by Harpers. He describes beauty and mystery seen through a micro scope.

An increase in retail failures from 404 to 417 featured business defaults for the week ended Jan. 26, according to Bradstreet's. Each of the other classifications showed a decline. The total number of failures for the week was 605, against 618 in the preceding week.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The Weather Bureau tonight issued the following aviation route forecast for the twelve hours ending noon, Feb. 1:

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- New York received its first allotment of Federal relief funds today in a decision of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation which awarded $6,100,000 to the State for February requirements on Governor Lehman's application for $45,000,000 covering the entire year.

MIAMI, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The B.B. Stable's Idle Stefan, a 3-year-old son of Stefan the Great, captured the Clearwater Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today and completed a double for Hirsch Jacobs, leading trainer of the meeting with fourteen winners.

Adverse factors exerted yesterday an increasingly depressing influence on the Cotton Exchange, and prices touched the lowest levels reached in January. After starting the year at 6.09 cents a pound, May advanced to 6.56 cents and then slowly receded to within 4 points of 6 cents.

The thirty-two-year record of the United States Steel Corporation of uninterrupted dividend payments at a quarterly rate of $1.75 a share on its preferred stock was ended yesterday, when the directors reduced the dividend to 50 cents a share because of the large draft on the cash, and working resources of the company.

The Chase National Bank as successor trustee has asked tenders of Free State of Bavaria external twenty-year 6 1/2 per cent sinking fund gold bonds due on Aug. 1, 1945, at prices not exceeding their principal amount and accrued interest in an amount sufficient to exhaust $129,185 available in the sinking fund.

PARIS, Jan. 31 -- Apparently spurred on by the possibility that the Davis Cup may be wrested from France, where it has been held for six years, the record-equaling total of thirty-three nations today was entered for the 1933 international tennis play.

TRENTON, N.J., Jan. 31 -- Reversing a decree by Vice Chancellor Bigelow, the Court of Errors and Appeals set aside today the appointment of receivers for the Pressed Steel Car Company. The opinion, written by Justice Joseph L. Bodine, held that the receivership was "not in the best interests of the public, the creditors and the stockholders."

George Hirsch, 41 years old, of 645 West End Avenue, one of sixteen lawyers recommended to the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court for disbarment by Samuel Seabury in the Summer of 1931 as a result of the investigation of the magistrates' courts, was indicted by the grand jury yesterday for the alleged theft of $550 last November from a client.
WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The War Department issued these orders, dated Jan. 30:

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Although four persons were killed and at least forty-nine injured in outbursts of political violence in Germany today, the clashes attendant upon the installation of Adolf Hitler as Chancellor were fewer and less sanguinary than had been anticipated.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 31 -- Honoring her house guest, Mrs. Clarence W. Dolan of Philadelphia, Mrs. Edward Roberts was hostess today to a luncheon at The Reef, her residence. Those present included:

National Bellas Hess, Inc., reported yesterday for the first quarter of Its actual operations, which ended 6n Dec. 31, a net profit of $20,055 after operating, administrative and selling expenses but before provision for State or Federal taxes. This is equal to about 3 cents a share on 728,405 shares outstanding.

Largely because of substantial improvements shown by the Atchison, Topeka Santa Fe and the Louisville Nashville for the month, the first sixty-four railroads to report for December showed net operating income of about $28,749,000, against $25,264,000 in December, 1931, an increase of 13.7 per cent.

A bill to reform present court procedure, which has been in preparation since last May, will be introduced in the Legislature within the next three weeks. Presiding Justice Edward R. Finch of the Appellate Division, First Department, revealed last night in an address at the forty-eighth annual dinner of the Alumni Association of New York University Law School at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Sir Malcolm Campbell, holder of the world's land speed record, arrived yesterday from England on the Cunarder Aquitania to endeavor to beat his own record of 253.9 miles an hour made at Daytona Beach, Fla., last year. His car, the Bluebird, arrived a week ago on the Berengaria with four mechanics and is now awaiting him at Daytona.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 (AP). -- A charge that President Hoover employed a "phantom budget" in stating that the Appropriations Committee had increased his recommendations by $163.000,000 was made in the House today by Representative Boylan of New York.

On Monday the House passed, Under suspension of the rules, the bankruptcy reform bill, the bill continuing the cent-a-gallon gasoline tax and, by a viva voce vote, the bill extending the operation of the Glass-Steagall credit expansion act.

The polarograph, a new Instrument for chemical analysis of substances, liquid or solid, which, by the mere pressing of an electric switch, automatically registers on a paper in four or five minutes both the kind and the amount of chemical substances present, was described here yesterday by the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, at 342 Madison Avenue.

Most of the United States manufacturers with branch plants in Canada have anticipated the British Board of Trade order, issued Monday, for a 50 per cent "empire content of labor and material" to qualify for the imperial preferences agreed upon at the Ottawa imperial conference.

Just before leaving Washington yesterday the British Ambassador explained why he had been unable to make definite commitments with Mr. ROOSEVELT. The Ambassador himself could not pledge his own Government. Mr. ROOSEVELT has not yet any government of his own to obligate.

Bonds called for payment in January before their dates of maturity were in smaller volume than one and two years ago, although larger than those retired in December. The total bonds called for last month was $44,725,700, compared with $21,309,000 in December, and $70,718,000 in January, 1932.

DETROIT, Jan. 31 -- Nearly 1,300 men and women, mostly former employes who had gone on strike, have gone to work in the two main plants of the Briggs Manufacturing Company here, according to a company announcement this evening, and the production of automobile bodies, halted for a week by the strike, has been resumed on a small scale.

In 1893, while on a cruise in the South Seas aboard the sailing vessel Torrens, John Galsworthy, then a young lawyer with a decided distaste for his profession, became acquainted with the first officer of that ship and the two became close friends.
ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- The State Senate, with only one dissenting vote, today stripped Clerk Patrick H. O'Connell of his power to appoint petty Senate patronage.

Legend says that General Israel Putnam defied a wolf in his cave, and Miss Grace L. Putnam, whose grandfather was a cousin of the Revolutionary War hero, last night defied a similar menace in her modest drug store at 602 Marcy Avenue, Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The feud that has long existed between the House Postoffice Committee and Postmaster General Brown over the methods used by the Postoffice Department in handling air mail contracts drew toward a climax today when the committee, after a hurried executive session, adopted and sent to Mr. Brown a resolution calling upon him to rescind orders for sweeping changes in schedules effective tomorrow.

WASHINGTON. Jan. 31 -- A 10 per cent cut in every item in the independent office appropriations bill 1/8 which carries the appropriation for veterans' benefits, was asked by Representative Woodrum of Virginia, chairman of the Appropriations subcommittee in charge of the bill, when the bill came before the House today.

The statement issued yesterday by Mayor O'Brien setting forth reductions made in the budget and further cuts now ready to be put before the Board of Estimate bringing the total reduction to $40,690,485 follows:

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- The Boerse recovered today from its weakness yesterday when it learned of Adolf Hitler's appointment, an outright boom extending over the greater part of the stocks. The demonstration by Nazi students in front of the Boerse against "exploiters" had no influence on the market.

The birth-control movement received yesterday the support of the Federation of Jewish Women's Organizations, which includes almost 200 constituent groups with a total membership of more than 100,000. The action was taken at the thirteenth annual convention of the federation at the Hotel Astor.

After acting on 156,125 applications for reduction of assessed valuation on real estate in the city, the Department of Taxes and Assessments closed its hearing yesterday and began work on the final assessed valuations for 1933, which will be an important factor in determining the tax rate for the year.
"Hard to Handle," James Cagney'e new picture, will be presented at the Strand at 8 o'clock tonight.

GENEVA, Jan. 31 -- After a long fight, which the British lost today to the small powers led by Sweden, the Committee of Nineteen's subcommittee of nine reached a tentative agreement on the remaining two of the twelve findings on the Chino-Japanese conflict it is now drafting for the League of Nations Assembly.

These orders were issued yesterday: Death Announced. Retired Engineer of steamer Leon Meyer, formerly a member or Engine 156, residing at 45 Central Av., St. George, Richmond, died Jan. 29. Funeral will take place from his late residence, at 2 P.M., Wednesday, Feb. 1.
Arriving on a novel expedition, a team of British women squash racquets players reached here yesterday.

Legislation which would restrict the hours of women workers in mercantile establishments is opposed by a group of organizations of women wage earners who, in a communication to Governor Lehman and members of the Legislature yesterday, asked that the proposed forty-four-hour week and minimum wage legislation, as well as any other special restrictive wage legislation for women, should apply to all workers, men and women alike.

New securities offered publicly here in January were less than half the amount offered a year ago and the fewest for any month in the last year. They aggregated $90,457,000, compared with $97,441,000 in December and $171,903,000 in January, 1932.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The Layman's Missionary Inquiry has aroused new interest in church unity. It will have its repercussions here at home.

While trading on the Stock Exchange was somewhat more active yesterday than on the day before, the market again gave an appearance of suspended animation. Uncertainty surrounding the preferred dividend action of the United States Steel Corporation, which has chilled speculative interest recently, was not removed until after the close of business.

MINEOLA, L.I., Jan. 31 -- The Nassau County Grand Jury handed up a presentment to Supreme Court Justice Meier Steinbrink here today, exonerating Victor H. Franklin, secretary of the Phoenix Mills, Inc., of 8 Leonard Street, New York, from charges made by Mrs. Margaret Kummer, a servant in the home of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Frankel of Hewlett Manor Apartments, Hewlett, L.I.

Fordham Prep strengthened its lead in the Manhattan division C. H.S.A.A. basketball tournament and St. James High regained first place, in the Brooklny division race as six C.H.S.A.A. contests were played yesterday, three in eacho division.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Manufacturers' excise taxes and other new levies written into the 1932 revenue act are now believed to have reached a normal level, on the basis of the present productivity of commerce and industry, at from $31,000,000 to $33,000,000 a month.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan. 31 -- Nearly 100,000 farmers in Argentina's four principal grain-producing provinces are expected to lay down their tools tomorrow and refuse to harvest the corn crop or make preparations for sowing a new wheat crop as a result of the general agrarian strike voted by the Argentine Agrarian Federation.

The dollar volume of sales of reporting department stores in this Federal Reserve district in December was 23 per cent smaller than a year before; of reporting chain store systems 13 per cent down and of reporting wholesale firms 23 1/2 per cent off, according to reports to the Federal Reserve Bank to be published in its Feb. 1 review.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Jan. 31 -- The elimination of two former holders of the title and a sub-par round of 68 by Tommy Goodwin, youthful New York State amateur king, featured the first round of match play in the sixth annual national championship of club champions today.

At least $1,065,000 will be needed to insure continuation of Salvation Army activities this year in New York City, according to a statement made yesterday to the advisory board by Commissioner John McMillan, commanding officer of the Eastern Territory, at a meeting held at the Downtown Association.
Small housing parcels constituted the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

The British Army is more highly mechanized than the armies of other countries, in the opinion of Captain Liddell Hart, an English military critic, whose book, "The British Way in Warfare," was published by Macmillan yesterday. Not only will mechanized weapons be used in the next war, he says, but "mechanized" propaganda will be used as well.

Mischa Levitzki, who gave a piano recital last night in Carnegie Hall, fought free for at least half his program of the stereotyped succession of pieces. He began with the charming and characteristic A major sonata of Scarlatti and ended the first part of his concert with the incomparable "Chromatic Fantasia and Fugue" of J.S. Bach.

ALBANY. Jan. 31 -- With Speaker Joseph A. McGinnies of the Assembly serving notice on Minority Leader Irwin Steingut that any minority report on New York City charter revision would have to be presented by tomorrow when the life of the Hofstadter Committee expires, it was indicated tonight after conferences among leaders that the Democratic members of the committee would probably refrain from offering such a report.

OTTAWA, Jan. 31 (Canadian Press). -- The Canadian Government was asked to guarantee Russian 7 per cent bonds to a maximum of $4,000,000 to swing the $8,000,000-barter of Cananadian cattle for Russian oil and coal, the House of Commons was told today by Premier Bennett.

The best health record among the industrial population was established last year, according to a statement yesterday by Dr. Louis I. Dublin, third vice president and statistician of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company.
Exports and imports into the United States during 1932, classified by groups of articles, compare as follows with 1931 and 1930 (000 omitted):

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Surprise and regret were expressed here today alike by Red Cross officials and distinguished Catholic educators at what they characterized as a "misunderstanding" of an article in The Junior Red Cross News, which is reported to have given offense to the residents and school authorities of Somerville, Mass.

COPENHAGEN, Jan. 31 -- Danish employers today canceled lockout notices in many industries scheduled for tomorrow after a law prohibiting all strikes and lockouts for a year had been passed by the upper chamber of Parliament, with the Left abstaining from voting.

Francis Frederick Leman. president of the Staten Island Civic League, and widely-known attorney who was active in behalf of civic improvements in Richmond, died yesterday at his home, 112 Taylor Street, West New Brighton, Staten Island, at the age of 72. He had been ill three months with pleurisy.
One angle of upland game-bird shooting has developed a serious situation, in the opinion of conservation officials in this part of the United States.

The proposed new infantry drill regulations which, if put into effect by the War Department, will take away much of the color of dress parades in the United States Army, were demonstrated last night in the Seventh Regiment Armory before a board of officers appointed by the War Department.

Activity on the Stock Exchange was sharply restricted yesterday in advance of the dividend meeting of the United States Steel Corporation. The same uncertainty tended to curtail operations in other markets. The final quotations on the Stock Exchange represented a standoff, so far as the general list was concerned.

Salvatore Spitale was cleared by Magistrate Erwin in the Tombs Court yesterday of illegally possessing a pistol when, with Irving Bitz. his fellow emissary for Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh in the kidnaping of the colonel's son, he was arraigned following their arrest last Saturday night In a Broome Street restaurant as suspects in a nearby murder last Summer.

MOSCOW, Jan. 31 -- The urgency of the need for a new political department to take charge of machine and tractor repair stations is shown by the report of the commander of the first North Caucasus detachment which began work Jan. 15.

Recent newspaper reports that many alumni of the University of Notre Dame had protested the retention of certain athletic officials by their imiversiry were denied last night by the Very Rev. Charles L. O'Donnell. C.S.C., president of Notre Dame, speaking at the annual meeting of the Notre Dame Club of New York at the New York Althletic Club, Seventh Avenue and Fifty-ninth Street.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, veteran Kentucky grappler, who is recognized by the New York State Athletic Commission as the world's heavyweight champion, retained his title last night in an exciting match with Sammy Stein, capable Newark wrestler, at the New York Coliseum.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Jan. 30 -- Krum Elbow as the name of a promontory jutting into the Hudson is the point in question, and Mrs. Walter Graeme Elliott's interesting mention of a creek by that name on the east bank shows that the creek took its name because it flowed into the Hudson opposite Krum Elbow.

Equipoise, acknowledged the standout horse of 1932, and largest money winner last season in C.W Whitney's string, has been assigned top weight of 128 pounds for the famous Metropolitan Handicap, to be run at Belmont Park during the forthcoming Spring meeting, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, Jan. 31 -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, Ambassador to Washington, loomed tonight as Great Britain's probable spokesman during a large part of the coming debt negotiations in the United States.

BERLIN, Jan. 31 -- Adolf Hitler, Germany's new Chancellor, today conferred with Centrist leaders on the question of winning the Catholic party's toleration, since he needs its seventy votes for a comfortable majority in the Reichstag.

BUENOS AIRES, Jan 31 -- Paraguayan dispatches report the Bolivian offensive in the Chaco is being directed by German officers, apparently brought to Bolivia by General Hans Kundt, the Bolivian Commander. General Kundt is said to have been personally directing the drive against Nanawa until his trip to La Paz to confer with President Salamanca, whence he re- turned to the Chaco today.

W. Palmer Dixon of the Racquet and Tennis Club, national amateur squash racquets champion in 1925 as an undergraduate at Harvard and again in 1926, was eliminated from the metropolitan championship in the first round yesterday at the University Club.

A fine talent, a humane and generous spirit, and an enormous capacity for literary labor constituted the equipment with which GALSWORTHY applied himself to the task of depicting English life. He was Britain's contribution to the novel of chronology, of reminiscence and of nostalgia which began to be cultivated everywhere in Europe just after the turn of the century.

New regulations to eliminate unfair trade practices in the livepoultry industry, particularly "unscrupulous" methods of feeding and "unjust and unsatisfactory" prices, for which commission merchants and shippers were held responsible, were adopted yesterday by buyers and sellers at a conference held under the auspices of the Federal Trade Commission in the Hotel New Yorker.

Some persons who profess to be Christians have become so apologetic that they "hesitate to mention the church or its teachings," Bishop William T. Manning said last night at the forty-sixth annual dinner of the Church Club of New York at the Hotel Roosevelt.

In view of the progress made in working out the $700,000,000 tangle revealed by the suicide of Ivar Kreuger last March, Gordon Auchincloss filed yesterday his resignation as American trustee in bankruptcy of the Kreuger Toll Company, effective when a successor is appointed, so that he may represent only Kreuger's Swedish Match Company, which controls 90 per cent of the stock of the International Match Company.

A number of witnesses, among them Royal J. Davis, editorial writer, and Sidney Howard, playwright, testifying yesterday in the Court of Claims here, characterized as "bad" the reputation of Boris Brasol, Russian monarchist leader, who is appearing as an expert witness for the United States Government in the case of the Russian Volunteer Fleet Corporation, which is trying to recover $1,500,000 compensation for two vessels taken over by the Emergency Fleet Corporation during the war.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Drawing a comparison between President Wilson's participation in the Versailles Peace Conferences and President-elect Roosevelt's conversation with Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, Senator Lewis of Illinois warned Mr. Roosevelt today of the "danger" of acting as his own Ambassador in debt discussions.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Jan. 31 -- John R. Mitchell, Federal Reserve agent In Minneapolis and chairman of the board of directors of the Ninth Federal Reserve Bank since 1923, died of a heart attack this afternoon at his home here. He was 65 years old.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Unification of the Union Pacific Railroad with four subsidiary lines it already controls was conditionally approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. The condition was that the road certify its agreement within sixty days to abide by any future finding of the commission with respect to its acquisition of two other short lines.

An exhibition of "Fifty Modern Prints" has just opened at the Weyha Gallery. It is particularly welcome in view of the fact that the "Fifty Prints of the Year," hitherto an important annual event at the Art Centre, has had to be abandoned this season.
PARIS, Jan. 31 -- France tonight has another new government. Most people do not expect it will last long, but it would be an exception in France if it did.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York sold yesterday to the Bank of England $13,588,900 of gold, consisting of the remaining portion of the $95,550,000 of bullion earmarked in London for the account of the local Reserve Bank on Dec. 15 in connection with Great Britain's payment of her war-debt instalment.

HAVANA, Jan. 31 -- For the second consecutive year the United States yacht Harkness Edwards's Winsome, representing the fleet of Peconic and Gardners Bays, captured the Cuba Cup by finishing third in today's third and final race of the series.

Federal Judge Bondy refused yesterday to issue an injunction restraining George Z. Medalie, United States District Attorney, from participating in the forthcoming prosecution of eight men whose indictment he caused recently by the Federal grand jury in connection with alleged frauds and irregularities at the polls last November in the elections in which he and other Republican nominees for Federal office were defeated.

CHICAGO, Jan. 31 (AP). -- Johnny Layton of Sedalia, Mo., stopped the title march of young Jay Bozeman of Vallejo, Cal., in the world's three-cushion billiard tournament tonight by defeating him in a great match, 50 to 49, in fifty-four innings.

If "Evensong," which was put on at the Selwyn last evening, accomplishes nothing else, it reaffirms the great impression Edith Evans made here two seasons ago. Then she was playing Florence Nightingale in "The Lady With a Lamp," land playing it with spiritual beauty.

ALBANY, Jan. 31 -- Increases in the personal income tax, payable next year on 1933 incomes, under recommendations contained in Governor Lehman's budget message, as compared with payments due on 1932 incomes at existing rates on April 15 this year, are shown in the following tables:

DETROIT, Mich., Jan. 31 -- While Henry Ford's vast plants still lay idle today because of the strike in the Briggs company's factories, Mr. Ford himself discussed industrial problems in a leisurely interview. He declared that these were not bad times but good ones, and that we were on the threshold of an inconceivably bright future.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Jan. 31 -- Bolivian troops advanced several kilometers in the Fort Nanawa sector today, with the aid of a prairie fire started by the Paraguayans which turned against them, according to a General Staff communique.

Neither by an attempted policy of economic isolation nor by competitive depreciation of its currency can the United States hope to overcome the adverse effects upon world trade of the present unstable condition in the foreign exchanges, says the National City Bank in its current bulletin.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Immediate enactment of legislation to relieve the farm mortgage situation and relegation of agricultural relief in more substantial form to the new Congress, which will have more time to study the problem, was suggested today by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic leader of the Senate.

The Union League Club scored its third consecutive victory in the Class C competition of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League yesterday by turning back the Columbia University Club, 5 to 0, on the winner's court. The other three matches contested were bitterly fought, all three being decided by 3-to-2 scores.

MELBOURNE, Jan. 31 (AP). -- The Australian Cricket Board of Control today made public its answer to the Marylebone Cricket Club in which it reiterated its declaration that the "body line" bowling of the English test match team was opposed to the spirit of cricket and dangerous to the players.
Frank Wykoff, the fastest human of them all through 100 yards, has raced against many a speed demon in eight spectacular years on the cinder paths.

John and Jean, 8-month-old twins, who have been under the care of the child placing and adoption committee of the State Charities Aid Association, 105 East Twenty-second Street, since their birth in a city hospital, have found a home at last the committee announced yesterday.

Three Japanese university students, "ambassadors of good-will," will arrive here today and remain until Monday, Kensuke Horinouchi, Japanese Consul General, announced yesterday. The youths, whose American tour began in Seattle in November and is a return of the Japanese visit in 1932 of three University of Oregon students, will at once begin a busy schedule of activities here upon their arrival in the Grand Central Terminal from New Haven.

The Hartford Electric Light Company reported yesterday net Income for 1932 of $2,399,834, after taxes, charges, depreciation and customers' dividend, equal to $2.85 a share earned on 840,000 common shares of $25 par value, against $2,621,466, or $3.12 a share in 1931.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,008,700 barrels, compared with 2,015,300 barrels in the previous week, a decline of 6,600 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decline of 9,000 barrels in the daily output of California and one of 4,450 in Oklahoma and an increase of 5,000 in New Mexico were the most important changes for the week.

Balancing the budget and preservation of sound currency together with the credit of the government were emphasized as essential to economic recovery and stability by Ogden L. Mills, Secretary of the Treasury, in an address last night before the Columbia Institute of Arts and Sciences in the McMillin Academic Theatre.

Paul R. Richards, who began his baseball career as an ambidextrous pitcher, firing right-handed and left-handed to the consternation of batters and catchers alike until forced to take up catching himself just to end the general confusion, became the eighteenth Giant yesterday to come into the fold for the 1933 season.

Foreign nations are actively working toward the elimination of the American merchant marine from the high seas, it was declared yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Bureau of Shipping. The bureau went on recond as favoring the continuation of the government shipping subsidy through postal mail contracts and deplored recent attacks made upon the subsidy.

Ferdinand Pecora, former Chief Assistant District Attorney of New York County, said last night that the investigation into stock market practices which a subcommittee of the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency has been conducting intermitttently for more than a year and for which he became counsel a week ago, will be completed "as a fact-finding, not a head-hunting exploration."

James A. Kenny, a son of the late Battalion Chief Thomas A. Kenny and a boyhood friend of former Governor Smith, was buried yesterday in Calvary Cemetery after a solemn requiem mass at St. Augustine's Church, Sixth Avenue and Park Place, Brooklyn. Mr. Kenny, who was 53 years old, died at his home in Essex Fells, N.J.
Strong opposition to the recommendation of Governor Lehman for a tax of three-fourths of 1 per cent on retail sales was expressed yesterday by merchants here.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Representative Ruth Bryan Owen of Florida, daughter of William Jennings Bryan, read an original poem at a luncheon here today in which, as a "lame duck," she bequeathed to "members of the coming session all that is left of the depression."

BELFAST, Jan. 31 -- The first day of the railway strike in Northern Ireland passed in comparative quiet, with less disturbance to normal traffic arrangements than expected, although considerable inconvenience was caused to business men both by the delay of the mails and the absence of trains.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- Democratic leaders of the House created confusion in their ranks today and brought jibes from the Republicans when a decision to hold a caucus tomorrow afternoon, supposedly to line up opposition to the Hill depreciated currency tariff bill, was reversed before the notice of the caucus could be sent out.

Governor LEHMAN has in effect directed the New York Central to continue the work of eliminating the grade crossings which have for so many years vexed the business men of Syracuse. However, the Central's plea for a "substantial moratorium" on this kind of enterprise is not likely to go altogether unheeded.

WASHINGTON, Jan. 31 -- The action of the grain, cotton and live stock markets as a group was rather firm at the end of January, but the long and severe decline of eggs and dairy products gave the farm list a weak appearance during the past week, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics, Department of Agriculture, said today in its weekly review of the markets.

Two long shots, each from their rivals' blue line, enabled the Detroit Red Wings to defeat the New York Rangers in Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 14,000 watched, the alert Detroit sextet, after trying to break a tie that existed since the first period, crashed through for a tally with two minutes of play remaining and registered a 2-to-1 triumph over the New York skaters.

PASADENA, Cal., Jan. 31 (AP) -- Professor Albert Einstein disclosed tonight that he was mastering the English language sufficiently to deliver lectures on relativity, and has made progress toward thinking out his unified field theory, upon which he has been engaged for seventeen years.

LIVERPOOL, Eng., Feb. 1 (Canadian Press) -- Fifty-six steeplechasers of greater or less renown are listed among the first acceptances of the weights for the famous Grand National Steeplechase at Aintree, published tonight.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- The League of Nations published today a 529-page volume on prostitution in Asia, representing the report of its commission of inquiry which has spent the last eighteen months investigating the traffic in women and children in the East.

Miss Helen Keller, whose contact with the world is through the tips of her sensitive fingers, felt her way through the Radio City Music Hall yesteiday and was impressed by the sense of magnitude which she received.

SARANAC LAKE, N.Y., Feb. 1 -- Two women and a man were drowned In upper Saranac Lake today when an automobile broke through the ice a half mile off shore from Saranac Inn and sank in thirty-five feet of water.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler closed his proclamation tonight with an appeal for divine guidance for the men called to bead the German State and asked the indulgence of the nation for four years before judging his government.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 1 -- The Colony Club celebrated tonight the opening of its fifth season with a dinner dance attended by more than 400, and at El Mirasol, the residence of Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury, the first of the current events series took place followed by tea.

CAPE TOWN, South Africa, Feb. 1(Canadian Press) -- After weeks of intense political manoeuvring to oust it, the government of Premier J.B.M. Hertzog won a complete victory in the House of Assembly today. A motion of non-confidence in it was defeated, 83 to 63, following five days of heated debate.

Tipping the Scale? EINSTEIN, according to a Pasadena dispatch, is now engaged in mastering the English language so that he can deliver lectures on relativity. But the same dispatch would imply that either the great physicist knows enough English already or else he will never know enough.

MOSCOW, Feb. 1 -- It is significant that not a single word of comment on the Hitler Cabinet has appeared in the Soviet press. The only headline containing a germ of comment appears in the newspaper Economic Life -- "German Revolutionary Crisis Grows More Acute."
WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Feb. 1 -- The conference today between President-elect Roosevelt and Senator Hull is believed to have brought the Cabinet situation to a head.

Starting on West Thirty-sixth Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenue. 2,000 Communist members of the Needle Trades Workers Industrial Union paraded through the garment area yesterday as a protest against "miserable conditions." presided.

The Association of Unemployed College Alumni and Professional Men held its first barter-and-auction meeting last night. After a tumultuous two-hour session a Southern girl, who had "always wanted to ice-skate," had a pair of skates; a newspaperman present on business had a copy of "Timidity land How to Overcome It"; the association had $4.91 to finance further activities and almost every one present' had a piece of cake.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- On the assumption that Senator Hull will be chosen for the Roosevelt Cabinet, rumors spread here today that Representative Ewin L. Davis, "lame-duck" member of the House, would be chosen by Governor McAlister of Tennessee to succeed Mr. Hull in the Senate.
"All right," said the Cat; and this time it vanished quite slowly, beginning with the end of the tail, and ending with the grin, which remained some time after the rest of it had gone.

A summary of a suppressed government report on veterans' relief is given in Talcott Powell's "Tattered Banners," published today by Harcourt, Brace. The report was made at the request of Representative John M. Nelson of Wisconsin, chairman of the House Committee on Invalid Pensions in 1931, by "a score of experts, most of whom were actively connected with the Veterans' Administration."
The New York A.C. basketball team last night defeated the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club, 33 to 32, in an Eastern Athletic Club League contest played on the Winged Foot court.
The 1933 crop of St. Valentine's Day sentiments available for the modern swain, who has no native flair for poetry, was made public yesterday by the Western Union Telegraph Company.

Passenger service on the Eighth Avenue subway line was extended yesterday to Borough Hall, Brooklyn, with an intermediate stop in the financial district in Manhattan. At 6:12 A. M. Commissioner Daniel L. Ryan of the Board of Transportation gave the hand signal which sent the first train out of the Borough Hall station on its thirty-seven-minute express run to the northerly terminal of the line at 207th Street in Manhattan.

The Department of Labor, acting through special boards of inquiry at Ellis Island, ruled yesterday that 206 Chinese coolies who arrived in New York last Saturday on the Dollar liner President Lincoln to accept employment on other American ships should be deported, and this decision will stand unless the operators who brought them here with offers of employment appeal to higher officials of the department in Washington.

Organization under government supervision of a movement that has already given employment to more than 200,000 in placer mining has been proposed to President-elect Frank D. Roosevelt by Randolph Walker of 160 East Forty-eighth Street, former president of the United Filters Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Women's Patriotic Conference went on record today in opposition to cancellation or reduction of the war debts due the United States, to the further limitation of the merchant marine or of the chemical warfare service of the army, and to recognition of the Soviet Union.

David Maier, 63 years old, a witness in the Seabury investigation and companion of ex-Mayor Walker on his European trip in 1931, died suddenly of a heart attack in the Hotel Commodore yesterday afternoon.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 1 -- Valuable scientific papers and a collection of books and tracts on geological subjects were destroyed today in a fire that damaged the home of Dr. A.C. Veatch, a geologist, at 5 Central Drive here. The fire started in the basement when a bucket of tar which Dr. Veatch and his chauffeur had been heating for use In repairing a roadway boiled over.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The British Government does not regard the coming debt discussions with the United States as an occasion for bargaining, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told the American correspondents in London today.
Leases of space for business use in buildings in the Times Square and garment areas were announced yesterday in large numbers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1. -- As March 4 draws nearer many changes are in the air about the White House at 1,600 Pennsylvania Avenue, where the framework of an inaugural parade reviewing stand is already rising.

Three armed racketeers who forced their way into the Carlyle Garage, 354 East Seventy-sixth Street, early yesterday morning, held up two employes, and slashed upholstery and threw acid searing the paint of twenty-seven expensive automobiles stored there, were wreaking vengeance on the owner for refusing to force his employes to join a racket union, it became known last night.

The shipyards of the world launched 726,591 tons of merchant ships in 1932, a reduction of 890,534 from the total of 1,617,115 tons in 1931, according to Lloyd's Register of Shipping, whose annual compilation was published yesterday.

Led by Larry Christiansen, who scored four goals, the Baltimore Orioles blanked the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in the feature game of a hockey double-header at Madison Square Garden last night, 7 to 0.
Craftsmanship challenged technocracy and the machine age yesterday In ceremonies honoring building mechanics who did outstanding work on the seventy-story RCA Building in Rockefeller Center.

The city's nine ferry lines showed a further drop in traffic and revenues in 1932 amounting to 14 per cent in passenger traffic, 18 per cent in vehicles carried and 20 per cent in receipts, according to annual figures made public yesterday by Albert Goldman, Commissioner of the Department of Plant and Structures.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1 -- Well-informed Bolivian sources here are authority for the statement that if Chile interferes with the free transit of Bolivian war supplies through Chilean ports, Bolivia will consider the treaty of 1904 rescinded by Chile's action.
Mayor of Charleston, S.C., Corrects Unfounded Criticism.

J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York Athletic Club, defending champion in the national amateur pocket billiard tourney at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy, last night took a firmer hold upon first place when he defeated Edwin Apfelbaum of the Newark Elks, 125 to 36, in eiehteen innings.

The Canadian dollar, which has been falling slowly for several weeks, passed yesterday through a cycle of acute weakness and subsequent recovery which carried it to a discount of 20 per cent in London and back to within 1/8 cent of its previous close here at 16 1/8 per cent discount.

German bonds of all descriptions were weak on the Stock Exchange yesterday as a result of the dissolution of the Reichstag, and the entire bond market, foreign and domestic, except United States Government issues, closed generally slightly higher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The address on war debts of Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, before American correspondents in London today was regarded here as another effort to build up the British case for presentation to Washington.

Trading on the Stock Exchange was almost twice as active yesterday as on the day before. The transactions footed up to a total of 1,190,000 shares, compared with 656,000 on Tuesday. The decline in the combined averages amounted to $1-60: in twenty-five industrials it was $2.72.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- While agreements to halt foreclosures on mortgaged farms were under negotiation today throughout the Middle West, sympathetic neighbors of farmers whose property was sold to satisfy legal claims took steps to restrict bids to nickels and dimes, or, at most, a few dollars.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- The Max Schmeling-Max Baer heavyweight fight was virtually assured for Chicago today when Promoter Jack Dempsey informed officials of the Century of Progress that fulfillment of two conditions would decide his plans to hold the battle here, probably during the second week in June.

The New York Curb Exchange announced yesterday that until further notice it had suspended dealings in the common stock of Metal and Mining Shares, Inc. An investigation is being made into the affairs of the company, it is understood. Charles V. Bob was formerly identified with the concern, which is an investment trust.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Governor Hill McAlister will hold a hearing tomorrow morning on the request of North Carolina for Colonel Luke Lea and his eldest son, Luke Lea Jr., under conviction in that State for conspiracy to violate banking laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A charge that the House Appropriations Committee had unwittingly become the "tool of dishonest and dirty business" when it more than cut in half the Federal Trade Commission's appropriation in the independent offices bill led to a warm debate this afternoon which eventually ran into criticism of the foreign affairs policies of President-elect Roosevelt.

Support for the Young Men's Christian Association's drive for $252,356 on the ground that the association was the best medium to aid unemployed single men was urged yesterday by Bayard F. Pope, executive vice chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee and vice president of the Marine Midland Trust Company.
It Is Held Superior to Making Silver Part of Metallic Reserve.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee studying the plight of agriculture today confronted a heretofore untouched problem, the plight of "hundreds of thousands" of investors in joint stock land bank bonds who were represented as having thought they were buying government securities, but whose bonds in some cases have shrunk to one-fifth their face value.

Although the steel business was curtailed some by the suspension of operations in the plants of the Ford Motor Company, the rate of activity last week is estimated by The Iron Age at 19 per cent of the national ingot capacity. This represents an increase of about 2 points over the publication's estimate for the week before.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Thousands of letters are going out from Senator Long opposing the appointment of Senator Glass as Secretary of the Treasury in the Roosevelt Cabinet and urging1 that those of the same view ask President-elect Roosevelt to name instead Chairman Steagall of the House Banking and Currency Committee.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the beat names.

Differences between members of the Order of the Eastern Star in the State of New York, which have been aired in the courts for several years, took a new turn in the Supreme Court yesterday when Mrs. Mildred V. Everson, former Grand Matron and later treasurer, applied for an order directing her reinstatement on the ground that a trial last April leading to her suspension for a year beginning June 1 was unfair.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 1 -- Favorites toppled by the wayside in the second match round of the sixth annual national championship of golf club champions today. Tommy Goodwin, 19-year-old New York State amateur titleholder, and D. Clarke Corkran, Philadelphia, a top-flight player for nearly two decades, were the victims of brilliant performances by their opponents.

The New York Stock Exchange, which has been conducting a campaign for more complete and fully authenticated corporation reports and audits, has sent a letter to all companies whose securities are listed on the Exchange asking for confidential information concerning details of their statements of earnings and balance sheets.

A 32-calibre automatic pistol, found on his way to school yesterday morning by Thomas Fitzpatrick, 11 years old, of 1,262 Stadium Avenue, the Bronx, was accidentally discharged while Thomas was giving his schoolmates a surreptitious look at the weapon in his classroom, at Public School 71, Hobart and Roberts Avenues.

No uniformed employe of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad was complete yesterday without his copy of "Standard of Appearance," a new book of regulations put out by H.E. Baily, superintendent, in an earnest effort to combat with sartorial perfection the inroads of bus, air and private automobile competition.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The fight between James A. Farley, national chairman, and the O'Connell brothers of Albany over petty Senate patronage, entered its closing phase tonight as Governor Lehman signed the bill stripping Patrick H. O'Connell, Senate clerk, of his appointive power.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 (AP) -- J.N. Bozeman of Vallejo, Cal., Kept in the running for the world's three-cushion billiard championship tonight by defeating Augie Kieckhefer of Chicago. 50 to 30, in twenty-eight fast innings.
BERLIN, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Between now and the day of the Reichstag elections the government will go to the people in an intensive campaign on the slogan "Hindenburg and Hitler."

Steadiness increased yesterday in the local commodity markets, but none of the staples made clear gains in all positions. Small advances were recorded in many individual contracts, while the losses in others were not large. Cash prices, on the other hand, were soft.

DUBLIN, Feb. 1 -- The railway men's strike on the Great Northern system linking Northern Ireland and the Irish Free State led today to the derailment of a train manned by volunteers and the killing of two persons. At least one other person was seriously injured, while others suffered less serious injuries.
Prince Potenziani, former Governor of Rome, is arriving today on the Italian liner Conte Di Savoia. Others coming from Mediterranean ports on the ship are:

Twenty-eight organizations said to represent a total membership of nearly 500,000 have endorsed the program of the New York Labor Standards Committee for a minimum wage and forty-four-hour week for women and children in this State, it was announced yesterday by the Consumers League of New York, original sponsor of the program.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Details of the memorial services for Calvin Coolidge to be held in a joint session of Congress Monday were made public today in a program prepared by a joint committee.

Senator LEWIS of Illinois was almost tearful when he begged Mr. ROOSEVELT to give up all idea of matching his wits with British negotiators. They are always too astute and unscrupulous for inexperienced and simple-minded Americans.

GETTING scratched up a Bit In an auto collision didn't stop Bill Dickey of the Yankees on his hunting expedition. He hauled his gun out of the wreckage and went on. When the Yankees arrive at St. Petersburg Bill will have some fresh hunting stories to tell them. He is a tall fellow and he tells tall stories.
PLOESTI, Rumania, Feb. 1 -- Fifteen gendarmes and twenty workmen were badly wounded today following riots at the refining plant of the Romano-Americana Oil Company in Ploesti.

More than 40,000 families are receiving virtually their entire weekly supply of food from the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was announced yesterday by Frank Kidde, chairman of the committee's food and clothing division. The food was obtained through a conversion of Federal Farm Board wheat into flour, obtained from the Red Cross, which was exchanged for specific food-stuffs.

To the Editor of The New Yorh Times: As one who knew Franklin Petersen for many years, may I express my deepest regret at his early death. I joined the staff of The Melbourne Argus almost on the same day that Petersen became a member.

With Manager Bill Terry slated to return to New York today, Secretary Jim Tierney redoubled his efforts to put the Giant pilot in the very best of spirits and bobbed up yesterday with three more signed contracts. They were from Arthur McLarney and Gilbert English, recruit infielders, and Harry Banning, young catcher coming up for another trial, giving the Giants a total of twenty-one players in the fold.

HAVANA, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Yachts-men from the United States made a clean sweep in the international Star Class regatta when they won the four-boat competition against Cuba late today, after capturing both the Cup and Bacardi Cups.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 1 -- E.R. Bradley, who recently became a part owner of Hialeah Park, scored a double today, his Algeria winning the featured Mount Dora Purse, while Broad Meadows was first in the Fernandina. Algeria is the John P. Grier -- Jyntee miss which Mr. Bradley acquired from Joseph E. Widener.

No small part of the common complaints against courts and lawyers should be directed against Legislatures. The rigid statutes regulating procedure have to be followed by the judges, often against their will and sense of justice, and a lot of time is wasted over the construction of these statutes.

Salvatore Spitale and Irving Bitz, the two racketeers who gained world-wide notoriety about a year ago when Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh appealed to them to help find the kidnappers of his baby, were freed yesterday by Magistrate Renaud in Homicide Court as suspects in the slaying of another racketeer last Summer in front of a Mott Street tenement house.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- An increase in the duties on rubber footwear, to be obtained by assessing the duty against the American selling price instead of the foreign value, was ordered today in a proclamation by President Hoover.
A gift of $250 to the Hundred Neediest Cases "In loving memory of B.R.H." was received yesterday by THE NEW YORK TIMES from Pau, France. The gift brought this year's fund to $264,934.53.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Conversations with German bankers indicate that the Hitler Government is far from considering any measures that would ignore existing agreements and obligations in regulating the matter of Germany's foreign private debts.

Investigation of all gas and electric rates In New York City by a joint legislative committee will be asked in a resolution to be submitted in the State Senate today by Senator Philip M. Kleinfeld of Brooklyn, it was announced yesterday.

The fifteen-story apartment house at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Ninety-fourth Street was one of fourteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx put up at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The Park Avenue structure, as well as all the others, went to the plaintiff.

The College Art Association will open today at the Grand Central Galleries an exhibition called "The Background of American Painting." Audrey McMahon, in her catalogue foreword, expresses the belief that "every one who is stirred by the vigorous growth of American art will be interested in the sources from which it springs and the background from which it has developed."

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- The committee named by Governor Moore in December to study the farm mortgage problem in New Jersey recommended today establishment of a strong, unified Federal farm mortgage agency to replace the numerous small agencies now in the field; reduction of the farm mortgage interest rate and a scaling down of mortgage debts to a level more in line with present farm values.

The Guaranty Trust Company, as trustee of first and refunding mortgage 5 per cent gold bonds of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, due in 1966, has asked for written offers for the sale to it of as many of the bonds as may be purchased with $1,255,822 now in the sinking fund.

The Brentano publishing list, minus its brightest star, George Bernard Shaw, will be sold this week to Coward, McCann, Inc., according to information made available yesterday. The sale has been expected since three years ago, when the Brentano stores were financially reorganized with the aid of long-term credits arranged with book publishers.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A conference agreement providing for the formation of the Association of Regulated Lake Carriers was approved today by the Shipping Board. The carriers forming the conference are the Cleveland and Buffalo Transit Company, Detroit and Cleveland Navigation Company, Great Lakes Transit Corporation and Minnesota - Atlantic Transit Company.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- Lucien Lelong offers a striking Summer fashion collection featuring simple-looking flowing silhouettes, interestingly cut. Waist lines are normal and the skirt length unchanged. Sleeves are plainer and shoulders narrower.

Senator ROBINSON of Arkansas, Democratic leader in the Senate, has been urging the Banking and Currency Committee to put aside for this session proposed measures for "farm relief." This would include the allotment bill, passed by the House but under severe criticism in the Senate.

De Witt Clinton High clinched the team honors in its own annual interscholastic indoor tennis tournament at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday for the seventh successive time when Joseph Abrams, seeded No. 1; Phil Lautkin, No. 2, and Sid Weinstein, No. 4, scored in their respective encounters.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Robert Moses, chairman of the Council of Parks and president of the Long Island State Park Commission, will be chairman of a committee of nine created by Governor Lehman to expedite any advances of funds from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to public agencies and subdivisions of the State for relief projects of a self-liquidating character.
Thirty-two years ago, at Lakewood, N.J., one of the most famous amateur champions in the history of American sport started out on his career as a boy of 12.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A Winter of unprecedented need for family relief and aid to transients and homeless began last November, according to the Children's Bureau of the Department of Labor, which made public today reports from 993 agencies in 125 cities showing a total expenditure during that month of $27,705,934, an increase of 16.2 per cent over October, 1932, and of 80.3 per cent over November, 1931.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 1 -- Confidence that the railroad industry would be "well on the way to recovery by the middle of next Summer" was voiced today by Leonor F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Railroad.

Intimation on the part of Frederick H. Prince of Boston that he would not send the sloop Weetamoe abroad for racing against the large English yachts next Summer was followed yesterday by serious talk among yachtsmen of the likelihood of an America's Cup challenge next Fall or an international match next year.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- The questions the Centrist party asked Adolf Hitler, which contributed largely to the decision by his Cabinet to dissolve the Reichstag without waiting for it to meet, were as follows:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Can it be that Franklin D. Roosevelt and fewer than a dozen other men in the United States have completely kept the Cabinet secrets?

A new adjustment service for the unemployed of New York, to be directed by John Ersklne, president of the Juilliard School of Music, will begin functioning next Monday at 17 East Forty-second Street in offices donated by the National City Bank, It was announced yesterday by Morse A. Cartright, director of the American Association for Adult Education, 60 East Forty-second Street.

Reductions in assessed valuation of real estate In Staten Island amounting to $11,695,935 were announced yesterday by Tax Commissioner Thomas J. Kenny of Richmond, and in Manhattan the taxable value of some of the largest skyscrapers was cut substantially.

Colonel Thomas W. Miller, former Alien Property Custodian, who was released from the Atlanta Penitentiary in May, 1929, after serving thirteen months for defrauding the government of his "unbiased and unprejudiced services," has applied for the restoration of his citizenship rights, it was revealed here yesterday.

Ten of the thirteen teams in the Brooklyn division of the city P.S.A.L. championship senior high school hasketball tournament opened their league schedules yesterday, with Erasmus Hall, Boys High, New Utrecht, Bushwick and James Madison High the victorious quintets.
NEW YORK. Mme. Paul Dupuy, her son, Jean Dupuy, and Mile. Emilie Tznaga, who have been at the Waldorf-Astoria, will sail on Feb. 11 on the Paris to return to their home in Paris.

HAVANA, Feb. 1 -- The American yacht Ace of the Western Long Island Sound fleet today captured the Bacardi Cup in the International Star Class midwinter regatta. The craft, sailed by Adrian Iselin 2d, won the third and final race of the series and finished ahead of its American.
The downward movement in prices on the Cotton Exchange gained headway yesterday when both near deliveries sold below 6 cents a pound, while July changed hands within 5 points of the even figure.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A large audience attended this morning the last of the season's series of musicales given at the Mayflower by Mrs. Lawrence Townsend.

Arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Marvin in Flushing court, charged with attempting to bribe a motorcycle policeman who was about to give him a summons for speeding. John T. Pratt, son of Representative Ruth Pratt, admitted he had handed a ten-dollar bill to the policeman, but said he had done so "inadvertently."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- A bill to declare a national emergency and give the President power to fix prices for farm products behind an impenetrable but flexible tariff wall will be introduced by William G. McAdoo of California soon after he takes his seat in the Senate, according to Senator Brookhart, who said today he had discussed the details of the proposed farmrelief plan when Mr. McAdoo was in Washington recently.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- The State Tax Commission announced today the special franchise tax valuations for the five boroughs of New York City that had been determined upon. The 1933 valuations, with few exceptions, are higher than last year.

Mrs. Sara Pennoyer, advertising manager of Jay Thorpe, Inc., gave a talk last evening in THE NEW YORK TIMES Annex on "The Theory and Practice of Department Store Advertising." She outlined the fundamental principles governing the advertising of most exclusive specialty shops.

Definite action by the government to start the process of re-employment if the tide of the depression is to be reversed was urged as "a national must" by Professor Felix Frankfurter of Harvard University yesterday in an address at the New School of Social Research.

Moving within a narrower area than in either of the two previous months and in dull trading, stocks in January made a small gain in values for the second consecutive month. The appreciation was, however, the smallest for any month since August, 1931, in which an advance was made.

FRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 1 -- Miss Anne Page and Miss Anne Townsend, both of Philadelphia, reached the final round of the women's New Jersey State squash racquets championship today on the courts of the Pretty Brook Tennis Club.

Two Jersey City corners were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday. The F.E. Summers Coal and Lumber Company, Nathan Feld, president, sold to Louis F. Mesmer of Garden City, N.Y., the two-story brick building covering a plot 153 by 118 feet at 163-73 Carlton Avenue, southeast corner of Tonnele Avenue, and four vacant lota, 100 by 118 feet, at the northeast corner of Tonnele and Carlton Avenues, Jersey City.

The proof of a budget is in the spending. Whether some of the savings anticipated by Mayor O'BRIEN in his deflation, program, are actually realized will depend not only on its approval by the Board of Estimate but on the way it works out.

CHICAGO, Feb. 1 -- George W. Weatherby, president of W.D. Boyce Co., a large Chicago publishing house, and two other officials of the corporation were named today in a Federal Grand Jury indictment charging use of the mails in a scheme to defraud.

Except that the outside rate for call loans hardened in the late trading, rising to 3/4 from 1/2, which had prevailed right along, there were no other changes of importance reported in the day's money market. Shortage of funds usually employed in the street market because of the month-end demands was ascribed as the reason for firmness.

With the completion of a committee of fifteen, composed of representatives of national advertisers, advertising agents and publishers, a plan to have a review board consider cases regarded as violating sound advertising practices and standards has been adopted tentatively, it was announced here yesterday by the Association of National Advertisers.

Groundhogs -- like Eugenie hats -- are out. Definitely passe Dr. William Reid Blair of the Bronx Zoo, Dr. James H. Scarr of the Weather Bureau and Scoutmaster Harold K. Whitford, in charge of nature study for the Boy Scouts, exposed them yesterday as arrant fakers.

The Rialto Theatre at Forty-second Street and Seventh Avenue, went dark last night with the conclusion of the "Island of Lost Souls" engagement. The Paramount-Publix Corporation, which has operated the theatre since 1918, has decided to relinquish control of the theatre because of the continued slump in admissions along Broadway.

Sportsmen of this State are hopeful that one of the two conservation fund amendments, recently Introduced at Albany, will be passed by the Legislature, thus assuring that license fee money will be used exclusively for the work of the Division of Fish and Game.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Coincident with the beginning of a strike in which 35,000 to 50,000 farmers have pledged themselves not to plant crops during the coming season unless their grievances have been removed, the government moved today to assist agrarians in Santa Fe and Cordoba Provinces, where the strike is most widespread, as well as in Entre Rios, which already had been promised relief needed as the result of locusts and drought.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Between nations, as between men, one is apt to be fair only when one puts one's self in the position of the other. There has been a remarkable absence of that spirit among those who have judged France harshly in connection with the non-payment of the Dec. 15 instalment of the war debt.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- On the motion of Assemblyman Louis A. Cuvillier, who fought to prevent Its creation, the life of the Hofstadter committee which investigated former Mayor Walker and his administration was prolonged today for a month.

FRANKFORT, Ky., Feb. 1 (AP) -- Abolishing a county to end slayings which he attributed to feuds was recommended today by Nat B. Sewell, State Inspector and Examiner, in a report to Governor Ruby Laffoon.
Transactions Involving apartment houses in which savings banks figured as the sellers were announced yesterday.
The Princeton and Tale clubs were victors yesterday in their squash racquets matches in the first group of the New York division of the metropolitan Class B league.

Quarter-final brackets were filled last night in the Metropolitan squash racquets singles championship tourney on the courts of the University Club, with form holding through eight well - played and closely fought matches.

Detroit, Mich. Validity of an issue of $20,000,000 city of Detroit (Mich.) tax-anticipation bonds authorized at a special session of the State Legislature late in December, was upheld yesterday by the State Supreme Court in disposing of a taxpayer's suit brought to test the city's right to market the bonds, according to advices received here yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 1 -- "Lindbergh is needed in Paris now as a good-will Ambassador from the United States more than he was in 1927, because Franco-American friendship is in greater danger at present than it was then."

Led by Miss Florence Kiedleman, brilliant forward, the New York University girls' basketball team triumphed over Brooklyn College, 31 to 5, at the Judson Memorial Church gym yesterday. It was the Violet team's first victory in three starts.

Speakers, both lay and clerical, emphasized last night what they conceived to be the important functions of higher Catholic education in America at the first dinner meeting of the recently formed pontifical society, the Friends of the Catholic University of America, at the Knights of Columbus Club Hotel, Fiftieth Street and Eighth Avenue.

"Luxury Liner," with George Brent, Frank Morgan and Zita Johann, will open at the Paramount this morning. The stage will be occupied by an eighty-minute version of "The Desert Song," the Schwab and Mandel operetta, with a cast headed by Vivienne Segal, Gus Shy and Perry Askam.

Promising the same policy of cooperation for urban home owners who are having difficulty in meeting mortgage payments as he had previously pledged to farmers, Frederic H. Ecker, president of the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company, warned yesterday in a copyrighted interview with The Associated Press that the whole question of leniency for borrowers was "a difficult and complex question."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Continuation of loans to railroads by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was urged by Joseph B. Eastman, Interstate Commerce Commissioner, and Daniel Willard, president of the Baltimore Ohio, at a hearing today before a Senate banking and currency subcommittee on Senator Couzens's resolution to stop such advances.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- President von Hindenburg today decreed the dissolution of the Reichstag elected Nov. 6 on the ground that it had failed to return a competent working majority, and fixed March 5 as the date for new balloting. It is to afford the electorate an opportunity to express its mind on his newly installed government of national concentration headed by Adolf Hitler.
