Following up one phase of his budget-reduction program, Mayor O'Brien sent personal letters yesterday to the homes of 900 city employes who are 70 years of age or over, pointing out the advantages of retirement now. He stressed the statement that he had no desire to force employes of long service into retirement and offered to give any employe full information about the benefits to be had in his particular case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Democrats of the Senate today embarked upon a program of holding up all extraordinary appropriations involving questions of policy until the Roosevelt administration has come into power. They began by striking from the Treasury-Postoffice supply bill the $19,000,000 subsidy for domestic air mail.

The program for the fourteenth annual midwinter conference of the trust division of the American Bankers Association, which will be held on Feb. 14, 15 and 16 in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel, is announced by R.M. Sims, vice president of the American Trust Company of San Francisco, who is president of the division.

BELGRADE, Feb. 1 -- Dr. Vladko Matchek, who had been arrested last night in a restaurant at Zagreb and rushed to Belgrade without having been allowed to bid farewell to his wife and family, was taken today before the Chief of Police of Belgrade and informed he would be Interned for an Indefinite time without trial in the village of Cajnica, near Sarajevo.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- The Boerse today did not continue yesterday's advance. Stock prices declined slowly, with periodic rallies. Business at times was large. The downward movement was attributed to nervousness over the political situation, especially news of the forthcoming dissolution of the Reichstag.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Three-fourths of the new Democratic members of the next Congress have informed Representative Arnold of Illinois that they will be present at the inauguration and will be glad to attend a caucus of the Democratic members before March 4 to select a nominee for Speaker and other House officers.

From its foundation in 1900 to the close of the last fiscal year, the Jewish Agricultural Society, Inc., granted 10,703 farm loans aggregating $6,901,122.16 to Jewish farmers in forty States, Gabriel Davidson, general manager, reveals in the society's thirty-third annual report, made public yesterday.

The charge certainly cannot be brought against the members of the John Reed Club that they are interested in art for art's sake. The current exhibition at their club affords ample evidence to the contrary. To them art is rather a means of expressing their resentment at current social ills.

HARRISBURG, Feb. 1 -- Governor and Mrs. Pinchot gave a dinner at the Executive Mansion tonight in honor of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President-elect, from materials purchased from a commissary of the unemployed. The total cost of the meal, exclusive of a dessert of ice cream, was $2.72 for the fifty diners, or 5.5 cents for each diner.

Traders in New York City bonds were feverishly active in the first hour or two of business yesterday, with the prices showing an overnight gain of about 1 to 3 points as a result of Mayor O'Brien's reduction in the budget. Trading fell off subsequently and prices eased from their peaks.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 1 -- One of the well-known landmarks of the Vatican is to disappear as a consequence of Pope Pius's decision to demolish the tabernacle and campanille now standing of the reproduction of the Grotto of Lourdes in the Vatican gardens.

MENDOZA, Argentina, Feb. 1 -- Foreign Ministers Saavedra Lamas of Argentina and Cruchaga of Chile embraced in traditional South American fashion in a cold, drizzling rain at Los Tamarindos Airfield at 9:45 o'clock this morning as Senor Cruchaga stepped from a plane which, by the narrowest of margins, had just brought him across the cloud-hung Andes.

HAVANA, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Pancho Lopez, a speedy 4-year-old from Mrs. W.E. Schmidt's barns, today reeled off six furlongs in the fast time of 1:113-5 to capture the feature at Oriental Park. The track record is 1:11 flat.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, and other officials of that bank have been subpoenaed to testify on Feb. 21 in the Senate stock market Investigation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Eleven-hour daily sessions of the Senate with the time divided definitely between consideration of appropriations for government departments and other necessary legislation were proposed today by Senator La Follette.

GENEVA, Feb. 1 -- The drafting group of the League of Nations committee of nineteen practically concluded work on the first part of its report on the Chino-Japanese conflict in a secret meeting today.

BERLIN, Feb. 1 -- Dr. Thomas Stockham Baker, president of Carnegie Institute of Technology, in addressing the English-speaking branch of the German Society of Engineers today said that American men of affairs in the main had been forced to adopt the point of view long since reached by German business men that development in many industries was dependent on scientific laboratories.

DETROIT, Feb. 1 -- Early resumptiom of production by the Ford Motor Company and consequent rehiring of 100,000 Ford workmen here and in other cities are forecast tonight when the Briggs Manufacturing Company began delivering bodies to tha Ford plant.

No discrepancies from the official tally were found in a check-up of forty-six voting machines used in forty-three election districts of the Third Assembly District in the Bronx, Assistant United States Attorney William Jay Hoff reported yesterday after examining the vote cast on the machines for Senator, Representatives and Representatives at large.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Herbert Hoover has a plan for retiring from the public eye for a nine months period after March 4, but he will leave an unofficial observer behind him in Washington.

Six men and a woman were arrested yesterday in a police raid on a third-floor apartment at 56 Spring Street, a few blocks from Police Headquarters and locked up as alleged counterfeiters. According to the police, plates, molds and a quantity of counterfeit currency were found in the place.

Seven iron steamboats, relics of a half-century ago, were "sold down the river" yesterday at public auction for less than 1 per cent of their original cost to satisfy the creditors of the Iron Steamboat Company of New Jersey, which went into receivership on Nov. 29.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Colonel Hatfield, which performed with more than the ordinary success over mid-Western tracks last fall, came through with his third victory of the Winter season when he outmudded a classy field of 3-year-olds in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

The grant of $100,000 by the Carnegie Corporation to the Emergency Unemployment Committee for the specific purpose of aiding individuals in making personal readjustment to conditions which confront them in these difficult times is a type of relief worth attempting.

The sudden decision to dissolve the Reichstag and elect a new one on March 5 makes it clear that Chancellor HITLER found it impossible to obtain a coalition giving him a working majority in the present body. The powerful Centre party refused to give him even contingent support.
SHANGHAI, Feb. 1 -- Dispatches from Nanking announce that deplorable conditions exist among both the Chinese volunteers and regulars who are expected to defend Jehol against the Japanese soon.

The directors or the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey omitted yesterday the usual extra dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock, but declared the regular quarterly payment of 25 cents. The omission was unexpected and the announcement, made around noon, unsettled the stock market generally as well as the New Jersey stock, which closed at a net decline of 3 7/8 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- Legislation to prevent the banks from dominating railroad reorganizations was urged today by the legislative committee of the Interstate Commerce Commission as one means of helping the carriers. The proposal was made to a Senate judiciary subcommittee studying bankruptcy reform.

Members of the Japan Good-Will Tour, composed of three students from Japanese universities, who were chosen by the Oriental Culture Society of Tokyo to visit the principal cities and seats of learning of the United States, arrived from New Haven yesterday for a week's stay in this city.

If New York City adopts Mayor O'Brien's proposal to tax commuters, every automobile bearing New York City license plates should be compelled to pay a tax for using the Westchester parkways, declared Wells Wise, secretary of the White Plains Chamber of Commerce, yesterday.

Twelve Eastern college basketball teams, including six metropolitan rivals, will compete in a charity tournament in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 22, afternoon and evening. this series will be conducted under the auspices of the Mayor's official committee for the benefit of the unemployed and needy, which completed arrangements and announced the schedule of games yesterday.

Legislation fixing maximum hours of work and minimum wages in industry and public pressure upon courts and juries to enforce labor laws are needed to rescue industry from a "vicious downward spiral," in the opinion of Dr. Evelyn M. Burns, Professor of Economics at Columbia University.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Feb. 1 -- Bobby Jones had just finished an effortless round of golf over a hard Hollywood course, shaving a stroke from par and exhibiting a beautiful putting stroke. The champion of champions in the past has been known to encounter trouble putting in California.

TOKYO, Feb. 1 -- After the Cabinet had heard today the report of the Foreign Minister, Count Yasuya Uchida, on his visit with Prince Kimmochi Saionji, the Elder Statesman, with whom he discussed the situation in the League of Nations as regards the Chino-Japanese dispute, final instructions were reported to the throne and then cabled to Geneva.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 -- Denying that the Treasury would benefit through a tariff levy on wood pulp and insisting that the paper-mill industry on the other hand, would suffer irreparable loss and large numbers of workmen would be thrown out of work if the Hill depreciated currency bill was enacted into law.
PARIS, Feb. 1 -- A manifesto from the Duc de Guise, Royalist leader and pretender to the French throne, tonight called for the formation of a dictatorship in France under a monarchy.

There are encouraging evidences that educators are beginning to recognize the helpful possibilities of radio, Owen D. Young reported at the sixth annual meeting of the National Broadcasting Company's Advisory Council, held yesterday afternoon in the radio headquarters at 711 Fifth Avenue.

Nine religious or public Institutions will receive bequests totaling $250,000 under the will of Mrs. Lucy W. Denny, widow of Thomas Denny, member of the New York Stock Exchange, who died at her home, 30 East Sixtieth Street on Jan. 16.

The right of restaurants to serve wine and beer with food if the Volstead act is modified was asserted yesterday in a series of resolutions approved by members of the New York State Society of Restaurateurs at a special meeting at the Hotel Bradford, 210 West Seventieth Street.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 1 (AP) -- After having arrived at the amount of net income to be reported, Individual taxpayers are entitled to certain exemptions as follows:

The Union Pacific Railroad was expected yesterday to appeal to the full membership of the Interstate Commerce Commission against conditions laid down by Division 4 of the commission in approving the company's plan for consolidating certain subsidiaries.

Worthington Miner has been engaged by the Theatre Guild to direct its forthcoming production of Maxwell Anderson's new play, "Both Your Houses." which may begin a preparatory tour in Pittsburgh on Feb. 27. Mr. Miner directed the Guild's production of "Reunion in Vienna" last season.

ALBANY, Feb. 1 -- Governor Lehman has informed the legislative leaders that he is not disposed to call an extraordinary session of the Legislature to enact measures for the regulation, licensing and taxing of a traffic in beer, should Congress modify the Volstead law.

BRUSSELS, Feb. 1 -- Plans to resume the old practice of raising the minimum passenger fares for all classes during the Summer, when ocean travel is at its peak, were revealed today in an announcement of the postponement of the general meeting of the North Atlantic Shipping Conference, which was to have begun here today.

LONDON, Feb. 1 -- The Stock Exchange again was cheerful today, with the market featured by a sharp recovery in South African gold shares on cessation of profittaking. The tone on the Exchange also was strengthened by excellent reports by corporations for January.

Contingency reserves of the Aetna Insurance Company were increased by $2,124,053 to $5,893,053 last year, according to the 114th annual report of the company. Reports of other companies in the group, including World Fire Marine Insurance, Century Indemnity and Piedmont Fire Insurance, also were mailed yesterday to stockholders.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 1 -- The Mexican Foreign Minister, Dr. Jose Manual Puig Casauranc and the United States Ambassador J. Reuben Clark Jr., signed a convention today for controlling the currents and rectifying the course of the Rio Grande in the section between Juarez and EI Paso.

Reduction in the dividend rate on United States Steel preferred stock is an incident of the period that will be remembered hereafter as a landmark. So far as concerned dividends on the common stock, the Steel Corporation's shareholders have had, during the company's thirty-two years' history, a somewhat checkered experience.

TRENTON. N.J., Feb. 1 -- Eigth bills and one resolution designed to carry out a program for relieving county and municipal governing bodies from mandatory appropriations, and enabling them to put salaries previously fixed by law, were passed in both houses of the New Jersey Legislature and will be sent to Governor Moore for his signature tomorrow.

Season by season the violin playing of Josef Szigeti appears to grow in significance and communicative power. His recital last night in Carnegie Hall was one of the most interesting performances that the writer has heard from this violinist.

A showing of the "Arts of the Theatre" will, it is announced, be a feature of the forty-eighth annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York, which opens at the Fine Arts Building Feb. 18. The committee in charge of the theatre section is composed of Joseph Urban, Robert Edmond Jones, Lee Simonson and Edith J.R. Isaacs.

The State of Connecticut for several years has been carrying out a most extensive program of re-stocking the woods and fields with game-birds, but despite its best efforts it has found it difficult to keep pace with the demands of hunters and so has decided to broaden its program by introducing a supplementary plan.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Determined to give the incoming President the broadest possible authority to effect reorganization of the Federal Government, Democratic leaders of the Senate today evolved a plan that would make it even harder for Congress to thwart the purposes of the new Executive and one calculated to meet every legal objection that could be raised.

GENEVA, Feb. 2. -- With its general commission resuming work by opening a discussion of the French plans for disarmament, the disarmament conference today quietly celebrated its first anniversary. Arthur Henderson, the president, reminded it that nobody had wished it "many happy returns."

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 2. -- The Princeton sports program for the year ending June 30, 1932, resulted in a deficit of $98,952.96, it "was revealed in the financial report of the Princeton University Athletic Association published today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 2. -- By refusing to sanction the early return of Leticia to Colombia, Peru has in essence rejected the Brazilian formula for peace in the Upper Amazon Valley, in the opinion of observers here.

A general Federal turnover tax on all sales, rather than a manufacturers' sales tax, was advocated here yesterday by Hugh Satterlee, chairman of the tax committee of the New York Bar Association, former chairman of the committee on taxes of the American Bar Association and legal tax expert of the United States Treasury Department during the World War.
LONDON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- The battle over Senate patronage is at an end. The finish of warfare over page boys' and doorkeepers' jobs in the Senate came this evening when Senate Leader Dunnigan certified to the State Controller a list of eighteen new appointees.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, and Professor Raymond Moley of Barnard College, political adviser to President-elect Roosevelt, will be among the speakers at the twenty-sixth annual Columbia University Alumni Day luncheon in John Jay Hall at Columbia on Monday, Feb. 13, it was announced yesterday by Clarence E. Lovejoy, alumni secretary.

James F. Fogarty was elected yesterday president of the North American Edison Company to succeed the late Edwin Gruhl. He is vice president of the North American Company, and has been for ten years. Frank L. Dame remains chairman of the board, a post which he has held since the organization of the holding company in 1922.

The three Japanese university students who have been making a good-will tour of the United States brought a busy day to a close last night when they were guests of honor of the Young Men's Board of Trade at a dinner in the Princeton Club, 39 East Thirty-ninth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The normal tax rate is at the rate of 4 per cent on the first $4,000 of net income in excess of the personal exemption, credit for dependents, , and at the rate of 8 per cent of the remainder of such excess amounts.
Few changes of control affecting Manhattan properties were an nounced yesterday. Leases and sur renders of leases constituted most of the day's activity, which also included the sale of two houses.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- A warning against making a tentative or temporary debt settlement at Washington is published in this week's News Letter, the journal of the little National Laborite group in Parliament and the personal mouthpiece of Prime Minister MacDonald.

The New York Americans turned back the Canadiens of Montreal in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 5 to 0. The sprightly star-spangled aggregation, taking the aggressive at the outset and maintaining it for the greater part of the first two periods, overwhelmed their rivals with a dazzling passing attack.

Textile High, defending city P.S. A.L. champion, and Stuyvesant scored victories on their home courts yesterday as play opened in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division of the annual city P.S. A.L. senior high school championship basketball tournament.

Charles D. Hilles, Republican National Committeeman, and Adolph Zukor, were continued yesterday by Federal Judge William Bondy as temporary equity receivers for the Paramount Publix Corporation. Mr. Zukor is president of the corporation.

Hyper-sensitiveness to tobacco on the part of a small percentage of the population was reported last night as the principal cause of a certain disease of the blood vessels, technically known as thromboangiitis obliterans, at a symposium on "recent studies on the effects of tobacco in man," held at the New York Academy of Medicine.

Two bills involving amendments to the workmen's compensation act and four measures designed to amend the banking law were approved yesterday by the County Lawyers Association on the basis of a report submitted by its committee on legislation.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- The automobile tire "price war" that flared up again in Akron early today had shifted to Chicago by nightfall, with both Sears, Roebuck Co. and Montgomery Ward Co. announcing further reductions to meet the cuts made by Firestone and threatened by other Ohio companies.

The debut of Eide Norena, Norwegian soprano, and the first performance this season of Bellini's "La Sonnambula," with Lily Pons in the title role, will mark the twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera season. "Lohengrin" will open on Monday with Mmes. Ljungberg and Olszewska and Messrs, Melchior, Schorr, Tappolet and Cehanovsky, and Mr. Bodanzky conducting.

PARIS, Feb. 2. -- Still at a loss to interpret the exact significance of Adolf Hitler's elevation to the Chancellorship of Germany and the calling of new German elections, French observers are following attentively the political evolution across the Rhine.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Thirteen proposals calling for reorganization of the defunct Illinois Life Insurance Company or for reinsurance of its $150,000,000 in policies were submitted today to Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.

A fresh decline of 1.1 points carried The Annalist weekly index of wholesale commodity prices to a new post-war low of 80.3 on Jan. 31, from 81.4 (revised) the week previous, 83.9 on Jan. 10 and 93.1 a year ago. The monthly average for January fell to a new post-war low of 82.4 from 85.7 in December and 94.0 a year ago, the month's loss reflecting the sharp decline in the recent weekly figures.

Professional jealousy of dog-show rivals is blamed in the poisoning early Wednesday morning of fifteen pedigreed dachshunds, two of them champions, at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick A. Vodegel, 285 Johnson Avenue, Hackensack, N.J.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Thirty-two States will be represented by about one hundred delegates at the first interstate conference of legislators convening here tomorrow under auspices of the American Legislators Association.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- After fighting for five hours over items totaling less than $57,447,397 of a total carried in the independent office bill of $1,003,192,195, the House late this afternoon completed consideration of the bill and was ready to pass it when Representative Patman of Texas demanded a record vote on an amendment which added $301,000 to the Federal Trade Commission item.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

De Witt Clinton High, assured of the team honors in its own annual indoor interscholastic tennis tournament at the 369th Regiment Armory, yesterday clinched the individual supremacy as well when its top-seeded players, Joseph Abrams, No. 1, and Phil Lautkin, No. 2, gained the final.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some three billion dollars of guaranteed mortgage bonds and certificates issued by reputable title companies are held by investors in Greater New York. The problem of paying these bonds and certificates in cash as they mature has engaged the title companies for some time.

The Canadian dollar recovered further yesterday after its acute weakness in London on Wednesday. The exchange rose in this market to 15 1/8 per cent discount, a cent above the previous day's close, and finished at 15 3/4 per cent discount, up 3/8 cent net.

Brandishing two knives, a deranged patient of Dr. Andrew P. Porrazzo attempted to attack the physician in his office at 366 Clinton Street, Brooklyn, yesterday morning. The man was routed after a short struggle and was captured by a policeman answering a radio alarm sent out by the physician's wife, who had heard the commotion.

Because of the large number of adjustments to be made before final assessed valuations on city real estate for 1933 can be completed, James J. Sexton, president of the Department of Taxes and Assessments, said yesterday that he would not make the final figures public until Feb. 14, when he will report them to Controller Charles W. Berry.

Any nation that today has not a Plan must confess itself lacking one of the greatest modern conveniences. The plan may be for years -- Four-Year (HITLER), Five-Year (STALIN), Twenty-Year (HOOVER ) -- or it may be forever (meaning never), but high as it may come, we must have it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending Feb. 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,079,000,000, practically the same as during the preceding week, and an increase of $249,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1932.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler today disavowed speedy cures for Germany's ills as he renewed his plea for four years of power.

The House Ways and Means Committee has held hearings on several bills designed to increase existing tariffs in order to "compensate" for depreciated currencies in England and other countries. Among the witnesses who have appeared before it are producers of steel, iron, paper, silk and butter.

Tony Canzoneri, holder of the world's lightweight championship, will engage Billy Townsend of Vancouver, B.C., in the feature bout of ten rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The former's title will not be at stake, inasmuch as the boxers have agreed to weigh in at 140 pounds.

Thursday, Feb. 2, 1933. A return to a rate of 1/2 for street loans, after 3/4, had prevailed on Wednesday, and a fractional shading in four months' money to 1/2, with a few trades at that figure, turned out to be the only changes of significance recorded in the day's money market.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The plans of life insurance companies and other large holders of farm mortgages to suspend farm foreclosures during the period of severe depression are being studied with great interest in administration circles and in Congress in an effort to determine just how effective voluntary action of this kind will become.

A proposal that the City Administration build model tenements to replace the city slums was laid before Mayor O'Brien yesterday by Mrs. Mary M. Simkhovitch and Mrs. Helen L. Alfred, representing the Public Housing Conference.

Charges that the Fidelity Mortgage and Title Guarantee Company of Ridgewood, N.J., was forced into insolvency by the neglect of its directors were made in a complaint filed with Vice Chancellor Fallen in Jersey City yesterday as the first step in a suit by the trustees of the company to force an accounting from the directors.

The decreasing child population of the United States, along with other effects of recent social changes on the educational system of the country, is creating new problems in education, Dr. Wesley C. Mitchell, Professor of Economics at Columbia University, declared last evening in an address, "Social Trends and Education," at the Lincoln School of Teachers College, 425 West 123d Street.

Completion of the reorganization plan for the thirty-two-story Squibb Building, at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, will mean a sharp reduction in fixed charges and should put the property on a sound basis again, in the opinion of officials of E.R. Squibb Sons, now in control of the property.

A novice burglar, according to the police, made the mistake yesterday of setting forth on his first job on his motorcycle, and also erred by picking a home near that of Joseph Meeks, a motorcycle patrolman, who believes that cyclists generally stick to their machines.

Loans on securities to member firms as reported yesterday by the New York Stock Exchange increased $12,536,400 in January, or from $346,804,658 at the close of December to $359,341,058 at the close of business on Jan. 31. Loans as reported by the Federal Reserve Board for the four weeks ended on Feb. 1, the nearest comparable period, showed a net pain of $60,000,000, while the increase in the week ended on Feb. 1 was $76,000,000.

ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Because of an insufficient supply of water at the large new building of the New York City Reformatory at New Hampton, that structure cannot be fully used at present, according to the report of Cecilia D. Patton, Commissioner of Correction, and Philip G. Roosa, assistant secretary.

Total admitted assets of the Mutual Benefit Life Insurance Company at the end of 1932 stood at $587,952,985, according to the annual report made to stockholders yesterday. This compares with $589,980,371 reported at the end of 1931.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Democratic members of Congress today declared they do not credit reports from Warm Springs, Ga., that President-elect Roosevelt intends to hold the patronage club over Congress until the administration's legislative program is enacted.

The abolition of tariff restrictions, the substitution therefor of planned international trade and complete world-wide disarmament were advocated as relief measures for present economic conditions by Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, in an address on war debts and reparations broadcast last night over Station WEVD.

Further indications that the recent speculative stalemate may have been broken were seen yesterday as aggressive selling operations were continued with unsettling effect upon all departments of the share market. The general weakness reflected not only the renewal of speculation for the decline but fresh liquidation as well.

Price movements were small yesterday in the local commodity future markets. A sharp increase in trading in the sugar futures market was a feature, sales being about 20,000 tons. The cocoa market recovered slightly and the price for tin was marked up for all months, the quotations, however, being nominal.

The report of the Interstate Commerce Commission's examiner in the lighterage case contains serious implications for the future trade of this port. But before getting too wrought up over them it would be well for local commercial interests to understand exactly what alterations in the existing regime Examiner STEER favors -- and what ones he does not favor.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 2 (AP). -- Crowding two receptions, a convention, a luncheon and a "nickel-a-plate" dinner into less than twenty-four hours, Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt left the State capital today tired but smiling.

Engineers for two private water companies serving sections of Brooklyn and Queens testified yesterday at a hearing before the State Water Power and Control Commission that too much water was now being withdrawn from the underground sources in the two boroughs.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 (AP) -- Playing without Ebbie Goodfellow and Frank Carson, both first-string forwards, the Detroit Red Wings tonight put up an airtight defense to hold the burly Boston Bruins to a 1-1 overtime tie.
PARIS, Feb. 2. -- The United States will start its Davis Cup play this year on June 13 against Mexico as a result of today's draw at the Presidential Palace.

Many luncheons will be given in advance of the double bill this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House which will benefit the scholarship fund of the Vassar Club of New York. The operas to be sung are "Elektra" and "Pagliacci."

The Chicago North Western Railway is expected soon to offer to holders of its $6,355,000 of sinking-fund 5 per cent debentures, which will be due May 1, one-half cash and one-half new securities, the latter probably to bear a higher coupon rate.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 2. -- Bolivia has notified Argentina and Chile that it will not entertain any peace proposal emanating from the ABC-Peru group unless presented in collaboration with the commission of neutrals in Washington. It informed the Argentine and Chilean foreign offices that it would gladly receive and carefully study any proposal from neighboring republics provided it was presented also in the name of the neutrals.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Robert O'Brien, Republican chairman of the Tariff Commission, today attacked the plans of his party in the House to vote the tariff wall higher, but left undiminished the determination of party leaders to go ahead with their project.

Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate subcommittee on banking and currency investigating the stock market, announced yesterday that he had received from Vice President Curtis a special grant of authority which permitted him to examine under oath all witnesses summoned for private examination.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The cry "price war" sounded in the automobile tire industry of the United States today when the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company announced reductions ranging around 5 per cent.

The Pool brothers of the Harvard Club, both winners of the national amateur championship, stand in the semi-final round of the metropolitan squash racquets championship with Robert A. Goodwin of the Yale Club and William Coyle of the Montclair A.C.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The domestic allotment farm bill will be reported to the Senate soon, but the hopes of its sponsors for enactment at this session are fast diminishing.

Governor LEHMAN'S budget message recommends State aid to schools on substantially the same basis for 1934 as for 1933. "On "the average, cities and school dis"tricts may expect to receive in "1934 about the same amount of "State aid as they did receive in "1932 and as they will receive in "1933."

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 2. -- The Brook- meade Stable of Mrs. Isabel Sloan extended its triumphs today, Jubi- late, a 5-year-old son of Lucky Hour and June Flower, leading from start to finish of the Port St. Joe Purse, feature at Hialeah Park, and Potentate completing a double in the sixth race.

WORCESTER, Mass., Feb. 2. -- Another McDonald may be dominating the weight events for the United States when the 1936 Olympics roll around -- for here at Holy Cross a 235-pound freshman is making progress with the 35-pound ball.

The acquisition by Barnard College of a ten-acre tract in Yorktown, Westchester County, as a site for a permanent camp to be used by students and faculty members during week-ends or vacations, was announced yesterday by Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve.
ALBANY, Feb. 2. -- Two bills to carry out the broadened State unemployment relief program were passed by the Legislature today and sent to Governor Lehman.

FLORENCE, Ala., Feb. 2 (AP). -- Waking of the slumbering Wilson Dam giant in making the Tennessee Valley the Ruhr of America was seen today as the outgrowth of President-elect Roosevelt's plan for development of the region.

MANAGUA, Feb. 2. -- General Augusto Sandino who has been a Nicaraguan outlaw for more than five years, arrived here by plane today unannounced for negotiations with President Juan B. Sacasa, at the end of which he indicated he had made peace.
NEW YORK. Willard V. King will give a reception with music this afternoon at the Savoy-Plaza.

With money in circulation up $41,000,000, monetary gold stocks of the country down $8,000,000 and member-bank reserve balances decreased $75,000,000, the Federal Reserve System refrained from disposing of any of its holdings of United States Government securities in the week ended on Wednesday, the statement of the system, published yesterday, showed.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- Dissolution of the Reichstag and the prospect of the election campaign marked the stock market today and prices went down generally. Business was relatively quiet, with the exception of A.E.G., which lost 1 per cent.

Another team of 6-meter racing sloops is to be sent to Bermuda next month to compete against the best in the Coral Islands. The local boats that are slated to compete are R.B. Meyer's Bob-Kat II and J.S. Johnson's Jill, both of which were on the team that was sent to England last Summer, and which won the British-American Cup.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to express my appreciation of your editorial on training camps.

Joseph P. Martin, Assistant District Attorney, began yesterday an investigation of the damaging of twenty-seven expensive automibiles by three racketeers early Wednesday morning in the Carlyle Garage at 354 East Seventy-sixth Street in suspected retaliation at the owner's refusal to employ union help.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 2. -- Judge Frederick A. Hubbard, dean of the Greenwich bar, historian of the town and for three-quarters of a century a resident, died at the home here of his son, Carleton W. Hubbard, this afternoon, after an illness of several months.
MONTREAL, Feb. 2. -- An overtime period failed to settle a National Hockey League battle between the New York Rangers and the Montreal Maroons tonight and the score was tied at 2-2 when play ended.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 2. -- Close, hard-fought matches and the elimination of the medalist were the high lights of the third round of play today in the sixth annual national championship of club champions at the St. Augustine links for the Walter J. Travis Memorial Trophy.

T.V. O'Connor, chairman of the United States Shipping Board, outlined the government's policies with respect to its merchant marine yesterday at a luncheon meeting of the Advertising Club of New York at 23 Park Avenue and in turn received the praise of leaders in several branches of the shipping industry for his work during the last ten years in directing the government's maritime activities.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Feb. 2. -- The body of Mary Helen O'Connor, the 15-year-old schoolgirl who disappeared last Friday after she left her home in Rockaway Park to visit a friend, was found in a pile of underbrush here this afternoon by Alfred Abnenman of Wantagh, a woodcutter.

Members of the Stock Exchange, their partners, employes and investment bankers have contributed $1,002,000 to the Unemployment Emergency Relief Committee, it was announced yesterday. Of this total, $650,000 has been reported by the committee's New York Stock Exchange group of which Bernon S. Prentice is chairman and $252,000 by the Investment Bankers Division of which John W. Cutler is chairman.
To the Editor of The New York Times: You are to be congratulated for your editorial "Mr. de Valera Wins," and for your broad-mindedness in printing the news of the recent election in Ireland.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The Roosevelt proposal for developing the Tennessee Valley was hailed with delight today by Senator Norris, who said the President-elect had even gone a step beyond his own ideas.

The silks of another member of the Whitney family will be seen in action during the coming season, it became known yesterday when Mrs. Joan Whitney Payson signified her intention of racing and registered colors with the Jockey Club. Mrs. Payson is the daughter of Mrs. Payne Whitney and the sister of John Hay Whitney.
PEIPING, Feb. 2 (AP). -- New engagements between Japanese and Chinese for the control of Jehol Province were revealed in an official bulletin issued today at North China headquarters here.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Long shots monopolized the running of the six furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today, Mutual Friend, a 17 to 1 shot, taking the decision by a nose from One Long Hop, which paid $19.20 to run second.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- United States exports during December were larger to twenty-one principal foreign markets and declined to the remaining nineteen, while imports were less than for the preceding month from twenty-one countries and larger from nineteen, according to detailed foreign trade figures issued today by the Department of Commerce.
PARIS, Feb. 2. -- American fashion buyers now visiting Paris style openings found many couturiers demanding a deposit of the equivalent of $100 before admitting the buyer to a style showing.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The $90,000,000 loan to the Dawes bank of Chicago was defended today by Charles A. Miller, president of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, as "one of the bravest and most necessary things ever done in this country."

Harry Wolf of the New York Athletic Club and Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club, each a three-time winner of the national squash tennis crown, gained the final round of the Clyde Martin memorial tournament at the Yale Club yesterday.

Declaring that Japan's position in Manchuria "cannot be disputed," the Japanese Minister, Katsuji Debuchi, pronounced yesterday his country's intention to remain as a stabilizing force in the Orient, and said that of all Western nations "America will derive the greatest benefit from the economic regeneration of Manchuria."

American Admirals sometimes come from the farm or first see the light in country places to which the Gazetteer gives only a line. Rear Admiral SCHOFIELD, who was retired on Monday for age, was born on a farm near Jerusalem on Keuka Lake, New York.

What might be described as "family dinner" pictures of Theodore Roosevelt building for a political future, of William Howard Taft in his first quiet realization of his defeat as candidate for a second term as President and of Nicholas Longworth from childhood on are given by Clara Longworth de Chambrun in "The Making of Nicholas Longworth," published today by Ray Long and Richard R. Smith.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The Democratic "job list," which is being sold by the Government Printing Office at the rate of several thousand daily for 40 cents apiece, is being studied more assiduously by members of Congress these days than any other publication in recent years.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed total bills discounted and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole to be at the highest point of the year to date. The ratio of reserve at the New York bank also reached a high figure for the year.

While the hearts of the able actors in "Mon Coeur Balance," the latest production of the Paramount studios at Joinville to reach the screen of the Fifth Avenue Playhouse, may be hesitating so far as their love affairs are concerned, there was no hesitation in the outbursts of laughter with which their efforts were greeted by the audience at the first showing yesterday.

MONTREAL, Feb. 2 (Canadian Press). -- Peter Verigin, leader of the fanatical Russian sect of Doukhobors in Western Canada, was hustled through Montreal by government officials today en route to Halifax, where he is to be deported to Russia, despite his assertion that this would be tantamount to a sentence of death.
MANAGUA, Feb. 2. -- General Augusto Sandino announced after a surprise conference at the Presidential palace tonight that "peace is now a fact."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:
BELFAST, Northern Ireland, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Troops went on guard today as the railway strike in protest against a wage cut continued.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 2. -- Brazil could be entrusted with the provisional administration of Leticia for a limited time to avoid a tragedy, in the opinion of El Espectador tonight, but it would not be admissible for Peru to continue to exercise even theoretically any act of sovereignty over Leticia, which "must be freed immediately and unconditionally of any domination by Loreto or Lima."

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 2 (AP). -- North Carolina's demand for the extradition of Colonel Luke Lea and Luke Lea Jr. was taken under advisement late today by Governor Hill McAlister after a hearing during which, insinuations of bad faith were exchanged by opposing counsel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Fifty-five outstanding men were invited today to appear before the Senate Finance Committee week after next to present their views on the causes of the economic depression and such legislative remedies as may be needed from Congress.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- The wildest speculation in gold-mining shares in almost forty years rocked the London Stock Exchange today. In the streets behind the Bank of England brokers scrambled to buy at rapidly rising prices half an hour before the opening of the Stock Exchange.

MENDOZA, Argentina, Feb. 2. -- The Argentine and Chilean Foreign Ministers agreed today to take steps to make the ABC-Peru group a permanent organization for South American peace and to broaden the pact signed on Aug. 6 to enable the group to intervene in any political conflict threatening peace anywhere on the South American Continent.
Housing property conveyances comprised the bulk of the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

A pontifical mass for all the Orders of Religious Communities of the Protestant Episcopal Church in the New York area was celebrated yesterday morning in the Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street. These priests, brothers and sisters take vows as do monks and nuns in the Roman Catholic Church.
BERLIN, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Jan. 31 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

Among the passengers arriving today on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg is Dr. Paul Schwarz, German consul, with Mrs. Schwarz; Stefan Jancsy, industrialist, of Vienna, and G.J. Droste, manufacturer of Haarlem, Holland. Others on the Hamburg are:

The bright lights of Broadway seemed much dimmer than usual to an old-timer of the amusement district who stood last night in Forty-second Street, where Seventh Avenue merges with the "Great White Way."
Transfer of this year's national indoor polo championships to Chicago, to be held in conjunction with the World's Pair there, is being considered by the Indoor Polo Association of America.

A 20 per cent decrease in revenue from the sale of Christmas seals last year was reported yesterday at a conference of Eastern representatives of the associations affiliated with the National Tuberculosis Association. The conference was held in the Hotel New Yorker.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 2. -- A group of young technical men graduated from college into a world of depression, who are "all-fired sick of sitting around and doing nothing," have designated Richard M. Stewart of 126 Essex Avenue, Montclair, as their spokesman in a plan to offer their services, brawn and brain alike, to business men, builders or manufacturers who might find that a little help at no cost would come in handy at present.

Once again higher than in the preceding week, bank clearings throughout the country also continued in the week ended on Wednesday to keep the gaps between the totals of last year and this relatively smaller than those which prevailed in 1932, according to reports received by R.G. Dun Co.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 (AP). -- The wedding celebration of John Coyne, 66, and his 20-year-old bride, Irene Carbert, was interrupted tonight by the aged man's 22-year-old son, who shot and killed the bride and beat his father unconscious with a hammer.

Continued pressure against the share market was ascribed yesterday to the same influence that had produced the weakness of the previous day. Business on the Stock Exchange was slightly more active and the net losses were smaller on the average.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 2. -- Newspapers commenting on Paraguay's reported rejection of the League of Nations proposal to send a peace commission to the Chaco assert that Asuncion endeavored to break up the Washington neutrals and other international bodies with intention of removing the parleys to Buenos Aires, where it expected to find an atmosphere more favorable to the Paraguayan thesis, due to the important Argentine interests in the disputed area, granted by Paraguay.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Feb. 2. -- President-elect Roosevelt's yachting cruise, which he had hoped would afford him a complete rest, will not be entirely a period of relaxation. Consideration of some of his more important selections of office holders will occupy part of his attention at sea.

A recent decision by the Interstate Commerce Commission permitting Walter S. Franklin, president and receiver of the Wabash Railway, to sit on the Lehigh Valley Railroad's board was understood yesterday to have been d by L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson Company, in sounding out the commission's attitude toward his assuming a place on the New York Central Railroad's board.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2. -- Traders in wheat showed an inclination today to keep in the middle of the road. Higher Canadian exchange rates, which lifted the Winnipeg market about 3/4 cent compared with Chicago; strength in Liverpool and reports of liberal amounts of Manitobas being taken for export fell almost flat as influences on prices.

In his Whitney Museum monograph on Allen Tucker, published a few weeks ago, Forbes Watson allots to this artist a place among those "who have been granted the power to immerse themselves so completely in their visual experiences and efforts that, through the bitterest battles of theories and jealousies, they have not swerved from their appointed course of development."

The net loss of 165 Class I railroads, including seventeen switching and terminal companies, was $9,075,520 in November last, against $5,212,095 in November, 1931, ac cording to the Interstate Commerce Commission. This brought the net loss for the eleven months to $156,188,907, against a net income of $104,915,409.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- A flat denial by Senator Robinson of Arkansas, Democratic floor leader, that William C. Bullitt had any authority to negotiate debt settlements abroad on behalf of President-elect Roosevelt today climaxed debate during which Senator Robinson of Indiana demanded an investigation of Mr. Bullitt.

BERLIN, Feb. 2. -- The Hitler government today forbade the Communists to hold outdoor demonstrations in any part of Germany and instructed the police to keep their indoor meetings under the closest supervision.

Two mortgages held by the Bowery Savings Bank from the Parnell Holding Corporation, George A. Parnell, president, have been consolidated as one first lien for $30,000 on 58 W. 83d St. and extended to Feb. 1, 1938, at 5 per cent.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- The government deficit stood at $1,271,721,030 at the end of January as compared with $1,159,286,502 a month earlier, Treasury figures showed today.

Miss Sarah Schuyler Butler, leader of the Republican women in the State by virtue of her position as vice chairman of the Republican State Committee, forced W. Kingsland Macy, the chairman, yesterday to accept her resignation. The move came after Mr. Macy had declined to appoint Mrs. Rosalie Loew Whitney to the vice chairmanship, which Miss Butler had planned to vacate after the adjournment of the legislative session.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange lost ground again yesterday, but the market developed resistance on the basis of 6 cents a pound for July contracts and then fluctuated within the narrowest range in a year or more. All trading was within limits of four points, with buying orders sufficient to close the list a point higher to two points lower than on Wednesday.

GENEVA, Feb. 2. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's senior delegate, today apprised Sir Eric Drummond, the League of Nation's Secretary General, of Tokyo's desire to resume negotiations for settling the conflict with China by conciliation and revealed the concessions Japan was willing to make to this end.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Feb. 2. -- Development of the entire Tennessee River watershed on a gigantic scale to link water power, flood control, reforestation, agriculture and industry in one vast experiment was proposed today by President-elect Roosevelt as a way to relieve unemployment and restore the balance between urban and rural populations.

Walter Gieseking was soloist at the concert given by the Philharmonic-Symphony Society, Bruno Walter conductor, last night in Carnegie Hall. Mr. Gieseking played Honegger's "Concertino" and Richard Strauss's "Burlesque" for piano and orchestra.

PEIPING, Feb. 2. -- A new case of friction between a Japanese guard and an Occidental -- one of many recent ones -- caused Colonel L. M. Gulick, commandant of the United States Legation guard, to study tonight detailed reports of the incident to determine whether to make diplomatic representations or to protest direct to Colonel Ibara, commandant of the Japanese Legation guard.

Captain A. Graham Miles, army reserve officer and former polo player, who was committed to Craig House at Beacon, N.Y., as incompetent in May, 1932, after several hotels had caused his arrest because of disturbances he created, is being maintained by the income from two trust funds created for him by his former wife, now Mrs. Clover Boldt-Johansen, daughter of the late George C. Boldt, who was proprietor of the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

"Champagne Supper" is the new title of the Elizabeth Schauffler play. "A Story of Love," which Peggy Fears is producing and which closed for revision on Saturday night after a week's engagement in Philadelphia. It is scheduled to open on Broadway within the next three or four weeks.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 2. -- Kenlewinai, Mrs. James H. Kennedy's villa, was the setting tonight for a dinner followed by contract bridge. Mrs. Kennedy's guests were:

BERLIN, Feb. 2 (AP). -- Eleven Socialists were wounded, four of them seriously, at Witten in the Ruhr tonight as a huge parade passed a cafe frequented by National-Socialists, who shot into the throng.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Openly ignoring the pleadings of their leaders against voting a new "embargo tariff," nearly a score of Democratic Senators tonight were lining up with a strange alliance of administration and insurgent Republicans to force a "Buy-American" clause into the Treasury-Post-office appropriation bill.

Humiliated by published statements that all groundhogs are nature fakers and have been for a few centuries, two of the species committed suicide yesterday in the metropolitan area. One chose death in Second Avenue rather than suffer disgrace in the Empire State Building.

NOW the situation is really serious. It was just a cricket war at first, but the flame from the Ashes has fired jolly old England to a move that may have fearful consequences all over the world in all fields of sport. The bad news from London is quoted directly as follows:

The New York Athletic Club retained its national senior team saber championship last night at the Saltus Fencing Club when the Winged Foot representatives defeated the Fencers Club, 6 -- 3, and the Salle d'Armes Vince, 5 -- 0, in the final round.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 2. -- Independent confirmation of the existence of the neutron has been accomplished in the high voltage laboratory of the Department of Terrestrial Magnetism of the Carnegie Institution at Washington, Dr. M.A. Tuve declared tonight in a lecture on the atomic nucleus and high voltages before the Franklin Institute.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- Alfred E. Smith will head a delegation of New Yorkers to Washington Thursday for a conference and general hearing before the board of directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on actual and prospective applications from their State for loans to finance self-liquidating projects.

The Journal of Commerce, forced to vacate its present plant at 46 Barclay Street, on the site chosen for the projected Federal Building, signed a lease yesterday for four floors in the Pulitzer Building, formerly the home of The New York World, at 63 Park Row.

With an estimated deficit of about $350,000 for the current season, despite economies which have cut its budget by half, the Metropolitan Opera Association is faced with a financial crisis which threatens its future.

Mr. LLOYD GEORGE has been making some lively speeches in Wales. He was 70 last month, but has no thought of retiring. He is going, to keep on "plowing and sowing, with "a little useful harrowing now and "again." So he harrows RAMSAY MACDONALD and Mr. BALDWIN and Whiggery.
LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Anxieties over Great Britain's new tariff policy were expressed today by the Hon. Rupert Beckett, chairman of the Westminster Bank.

The first annual Prix Femina Americain was awarded yesterday to Willa Gather for "Shadows on the Rock," her plotless story of Quebec in the days of Frontenac, which was the most popular novel in America in 1931.

Joseph Castaldo, reputed successor of Ciro Terranova as "artichoke king," had gross receipts totaling $1,000,000 from his artichoke business and his dance halls in the three years 1929, 1930 and 1931, Assistant United States Attorney Thomas E. Dewey told Federal Judge Harry B. Anderson and a jury yesterday in his opening address in Castaldo's trial for violation of the Federal income tax laws.

WILMINGTON, Del., Feb. 2 (AP). -- Thirty-two mid-Western and Eastern railroads have petitioned the Federal District Court to hold up the Interstate Commerce Commission order fixing rail-barge-rail and barge-rail rates on cotton from Mississippi River points to certain Eastern States.

Additional indictments were returned by the Federal and New York County grand juries yesterday in their investigations of frauds and irregularities at the polls in Manhattan. The local grand jury also handed up a presentment to Judge Freschi in General Sessions urging Mayor O'Brien and the other members of the Board of Estimate to appropriate funds for a borough-wide recount.
"The Secret of Madame Blanche," with Irene Dunne, Lionel Atwill and Phillips Holmes, will open at the Capitol this morning and at Loew's Metropolitan in Brooklyn.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May one who is anxious to see the new administration succeed express that measure of apprehension which for him recent circumstances surrounding the debt question have produced? A recent Washington dispatch to THE TIMES and a declaration of Senator David B. Reed sufficiently indicate the present disturbing drift.

The question whether "the curtailment of expenditures of a social character" in the city budget for the current year had been wisely made was discussed yesterday by Professor Joseph D. McGoldrick of Columbia University in a lecture at the Women's City Club, 22 Park Avenue.

LONDON, Feb. 2. -- A situation unprecedented in the history of British diplomacy developed today between Great Britain and Australia as a result of an Australian charge that an English cricket team now playing a series of matches in Australia had been guilty of "unsportsmanlike" tactics.

A judgment for $101,478 against Julius H. Barnes, former chairman of the board of the United States Chamber of Commerce, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday on a decision by Justice Ingraham striking out his answer in a suit by the Beta Corporation on notes for $100,000.
LONDON, Feb. 2. -- Lord Waver-tree, great Edwardian sportsman died today at the age of 76. He leaves no heir and the title becomes extinct.

After several weeks of industrious repertory the Shakespeare Theatre players have come round to "Romeo and Juliet," which had one of its two opening performances at the south of Central Park last evening. Since tickets were sent to this reviewing-stand it is assumed that comment is invited.

All Will Be Aliens. A touch of the inspiration that possessed former Mayor HYLAN when he denounced foreign teachers living in Mount Vernon and foreign experts living in Long Island must have descended the other day upon Mayor O'BRIEN.

Railroads serving this city have under consideration a proposal submitted by elevator interests in Buffalo for 6 reduction next Summer in the freight rate for grain for export through this port. The Trunk Line Association, clearing house for rate matters in the East, is studying the proposal.

Proposed legislation affecting real estate will be considered tomorrow afternoon at a special meeting of the State-wide legislative committee and directors of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards to be held in Albany at the call of Ulysses G. Stockwell, president.

Net assets of International Carriers, Inc., on Dec. 31 were equivalent to $4.80 a share, comparing with $6.29 at the end of the preceding year, according to the annual report issued yesterday. Unrealized depreciation was reduced by $865,677 during the year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2. -- One of the most important sections of the Democratic plan, formulated at the request of the President-elect, to give him the broadest and most direct powers to effect great governmental economies has been abandoned in the face of legal decisions and the objections of partisans of the Anglo-Saxon Parliamentary system.

Severe pressure was exerted yesterday against virtually all German bonds on the Stock Exchange, with losses in the group ranging from fractions to more than 8 points. Domestic corporation loans ended lower, particularly the rails, but United States Government obligations continued steady with minor variations in prices.

Looking in excellent trim and quite ready for the stupendous task he has set for himself, Memphis Bill Terry, manager of the Giants, arrived in town yesterday to attend to a number of matters prior to embarking upon his first full season as successor to John J. McGraw.

The New York Adult Educational Council, designed to coordinate the activities of the adult education organizations of the city, public and private, was set up last night at a meeting in the American Museum of Natural History attended by more than 200 men and women, many of them representatives of existing agencies.

Robert E. Dowling has been elected a director of the New York Life Insurance Company to fill the vacancy caused by the death of former President Calvin Coolidge, it was revealed yesterday in the annual statement of the company's condition.

A class of ninety-eight young women was graduated by the Mount Sinai Hospital Training School of Nursing last night at its fiftieth commencement, in the Blumenthal Auditorium, Ninety-ninth Street east of Fifth Avenue. A reception in the Nurses' Home followed the graduation.

CAMBRIDGE, England, Feb. 2. -- The new Royal Society Mond Laboratory, one of the most advanced experimental physics laboratories in the world, will be opened tomorrow by Stanley Baldwin as Chancellor of the University.

Denying that there was any reason for impounding the receipts of the Manhattan Elevated Railway Company for the benefit of Manhattan security holders and creditors, Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr., receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, filed an answer in Federal court yesterday to the suit brought by the Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company making the demand.

The resolution of our economic problems should and will come from a gradual improvement of our existing system rather than from any violent change in our social order, Warren Nissley, member of the firm of Arthur Young Co., accountants and auditors, told the New York chapter of the National Institute of Credit, which met at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

A readjustment of the whole economic system will have to be made if the depression is to be successfully overcome, Professor Robert M. Maclver of Barnard College, chairman of the Columbia University Commission of Eighteen, recently appointed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler to investigate the economic crisis, declared yesterday in a statement dealing with the purposes of the commission.

MONTREAL, Feb. 3 -- Unsettlement of Canadian newsprint prices is reported here to have reached an acute stage. Contracts have been closed, it is said, at as low as $38 a ton, as against the $42.50 a ton that was supposed to be the Canadian price.

BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., Feb. 3. -- More than 200 delegates, representing practically every college in the Middle Atlantic States, were gathered here tonight for the annual midwinter conference of the student Y.M.C.A.'s of the Middle Atlantic Field Council, which opened this evening.

A taxpayer's suit to compel the Board of Estimate to strike from the 1933 budget approximately $12,000,000, representing interest and sinking fund charges on bonds issued to finance construction and equipment of the Eighth Avenue subway line, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by William Church Osborn and the Anahma Corporation.

More than 600 men and women attended last night the funeral services for David Maier, friend of former Mayor James J. Walker and a prominent leader in German-American and Democratic political circles, held in the Liederkranz Club, 111 East Fifty-eighth Street.
CHICAGO, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Welker Cochran, 37-year-old billiard star of San Francisco, is the new world's three-cushion champion.

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- With indications multiplying that Japan's present effort to restore conciliation procedure in her dispute with China without necessary concessions will prove fruitless, interest is revived in what will happen to the mandated Pacific islands if Japan executes her threat to quit the League of Nations.

The world's production of gold last year was the greatest on record, 23,911,000 fine ounces valued at $494,240,370 having been mined. In addition, the unlocking of hoards in India, Great Britain and Russia released an almost equally large supply of monetary gold in the year.

A plea for more effective participation by women in efforts to remedy unemployment and other "pressing questions" was made yesterday by Miss Lena Madesin Phillips, president of the National Council of Women, at the ninetieth convention of the New York City Federation of Women's Clubs in the Hotel Astor.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- Stocks and bonds continued to decline today. The public seemed to have become extremely nervous with the result that speculators also stayed off the market. Stock prices put up some resistance early in the day but when Reichsbank shares dropped 4 points a general downward movement began.

California, like KIPLING'S sailor, is of "infinite resources and capacity." When her climate fails her, and her boosters sink up to their ears in the depression, and her coffers are empty, and even Hollywood loses its tinsel of vitality and high salaries, she is fortunately still able to appeal to her rich uncle at Washington.
Six Manhattan properties and two in the Bronx were auctioned In foreclosure proceedings yesterday. They were knocked down to the plaintiff in each case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- In protest against the Senate's elimination of all air mail appropriations for next year, Postmaster General Brown today told Senator Robinson of Arkansas, sponsor of that move, that it would "practically destroy the aeronautical industry."

DETROIT, Feb. 3. -- Operations were resumed on a minor scale today in the Ford Motor Company's main plant at River Rouge, near here, which has been idle for more than a week because the strike against the Briggs Manufacturing Company cut off its supply of automobile bodies.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- The Admiralty is building ships to the maximum of Great Britain's allowance under the Washington treaty, Lord Stanley, Parliamentary Secretary of the Admiralty, told a shipbuilding deputation at the Admiralty today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- A total of $7,802,843,600 was subscribed for the Treasury's $250,000,000 offering of five-year 2 5/8 per cent notes, dated Feb. 1, Secretary Mills announced today. Subscriptions to the amount of $277,516,600 were accepted.

Major Gen. James G. Harbord, chairman of the Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation for the Second Federal Reserve District, announced yesterday following a meeting of its executive committee at the Engineers Club that Grover A. Whalen has been named chairman of the committee for Greater New York.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The appeal of 206 Chinese from an order if immigration authorities at Ellis Island, denying them entry into the country, as dismissed today by the Department of Labor.
A factory purchase, several taxpayer deals and a variety of residential conveyances were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

Cornell University eventually will receive half the residuary estate and a share in funds under the will of Albert Charles Murphy of Miami, Fla., who died at Beverly Hills, Cal., on Jan. 25 last, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

A shrinkage in incomes resulting from a drop in dividends was revealed yesterday as threatening curtailment of activity to institutions and memorials endowed with stock shares and dependent upon the income from them.

A recent address by Professor FIELD of Princeton University calls fresh attention to the uneven distribution by countries of minerals essential to civilization. It gives warning that until the geographical location of important metals -- coal, oil, nitrates, phosphates and potash -- is seriously considered from an international point of view, there "never can be a reasonable amity among nations."

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- Today's issue of the newspaper Vorwarts, the official organ of the Socialist party, which carried an election appeal, was confiscated by the police and the paper has been barred from publication for three days.

Many prominent members of the Spanish colony here and the Spanish Ambassador, Juan Francisco de Cardenas, and Senora de Cardenas were in the throng that filled the large ballroom of Sherry's last night for the annual Charity Ball of the Comite de Socorro Espanol, an association for the relief of needy Spaniards in New York.

How to Watch Roosevelt. Mr. HOOVER, according to one report, will live quietly at Palo Alto from the time he leaves the White House to the end of the year. "During this period he will be able to watch the turning of the wheels of government under the direction of his successor through the eyes of LAWRENCE RICHEY, his secretary and intimate aide for many years, who already has engaged a suite of offices here."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- Urging upon the House today the passage of a resolution for a Congressional investigation of organizations expending money for the "denationalization" of the United States, Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts violently assailed Dr. Nicholas Murra Butler, the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace and the Rockefeller Foundation.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3. -- The political situation in Cuba is a very ugly one, and no one can predict whether it can be resolved peaceably or whether it must inevitably drag on to a tragic and disastrous end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Saying he was unable longer to execute "absurd superior orders bent to persecute our nationals who have fled Cuba to avoid death," Orestes Garcia, Cuban Consul, third class, made public here today his letter of resignation from the Cuban Diplomatic Service addressed to Dr. Orestes Ferrara, Cuban Secretary of State.

In a suit by the N.P. Nelson Iron Works, Inc., against Controller Berry to compel the payment of $23,250 for thirty snow loaders delivered to the Sanitary Commission, the Appellate Division reversed yesterday a mandamus order directing the payment.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As to the new income tax proposed by Governor Lehman in his message to the Legislature, it should be emphasized that it is a tax of 1 per cent upon net incomes, excluding therefrom profits or losses on the sale of securities and without any deduction of exemptions.

George C. Warren Jr. of Summit, recently elected president of the New Jersey Board of Fish and Game Commissioners, yesterday announced a four-point program in behalf of his department which is one of the most comprehensive conservation plans ever presented.

The New York County grand jury handed up to Judge Freschi in General Sessions yesterday sixteen more indictments against election inspectors. The indictments, which named three women, made a total of sixty-four returned since the start of the inquiry.

The United States has a responsibility to make effective the Kellogg peace pact by the use of force in the event of its violation, it was declared yesterday by Frederic R. Coudert, international lawyer, who has been mentioned for the post of Secretary of State in the Roosevelt Cabinet, at a luncheon of the Greater New York Chapter of the League of Nations Association in the Hotel Woodstock.

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- In the disarmament conference's general commission today Captain Anthony Eden of Great Britain answered Italy's objection to the French plan's omission of Britain from the proposed Continental European security pact.

Arturo Toscanini, sailing for this country again on Feb. 17, is to conduct a cycle of Beethoven's works, including eight symphonies or all but the choral Ninth, in regular concerts of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall on five consecutives Sundays, it was announced last night.

Heavy construction contracts for the week ended Jan. 30 totaled $21,291,000, a sharp increase for the second consecutive week, according to figures compiled by Engineering News-Record. The previous week's total was $17,517,000 and two weeks ago the total was $12,265,000.

By winning from the Princeton Club players, 5 to 2, last night, the Bayside Tennis Club team clinched the Metropolitan League Class B squash tennis championship. With eight victories and no defeats and only one more match to play, the Bayside players also have a chance to end their season with a clean slate.

Having already been considerably reduced by force of circumstance, the city budget for 1933 may be still further curtailed by force of law. It now contains an appropriation of $17,000,000 to meet interest on corporate stock and corporate stock notes issued and to be issued for the construction of the Independent Subway System.

Yale boxers, past and present, gathered at the Yale Club last night and entertained a crowd of 700 with six three-round bouts. No official decisions were given, but the youth of the varsity boxers predominated in most instances over Eli alumni.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza, director of the Metropolitan Opera for twenty-five years, observed his sixty-fourth birthday yesterday. But a birthday was no festive occasion, Mr. Gatti said. One was not inclined to celebrate growing old as one would rather be 30 again, he reflected.

New Yorkers sailing today for Mediterranean ports on the Conte di Savoia include Mrs. Marshall Field, Mr. and Mrs. W.R. Batcheller, Mr. and Mrs. Douglas Burden, Mr. and Mrs. G.W. Crawford, Mr. and Mrs. G.A. Carruthers, Mr. and Mrs. T.F. Davies, Mrs. F.W. Hollander, Mr. and Mrs. H.G. Scott and Mrs. R.N. War mack.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Following its action of yesterday in voting without debate and without a rollcall $966,000,000 for the veterans' administration, the House today, amid pleadings for economy, eliminated by 181 to 165 the Bankhead amendment adopted yesterday, which added $301,000 to the Federal Trade Commission's allotment for the fiscal year 1934.

Cathedral Boys High, defending C.H.S.A.A. champion, and Manhattan Prep remained tied for second place in the Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. standing by winning games yesterday. Cathedral Boys High defeated La Salle Academy, 20 to 19, at the East Fifty-fourth Street Gymnasium and Manhattan Prep downed De La Salle Institute, 29 to 17, at the Manhattan College gymnasium.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Representative Boylan of New York, a life member of the Society of Tammany, asked THE NEW YORK TIMES today to amplify the story of his argument on the floor of the House Saturday with Representative Blanton of Texas.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, headed by Serge Koussevitzky, gave its third evening concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. As is the custom of Mr. Koussevitzky and the Boston, they came bearing a gift of a new work, Conrad Beck's "Innominata," a gift neither to be feared nor revered.

Two of the leading Protestant Episcopal churches will have tomorrow the unusual experience of having a woman preach in their pulpits. Mrs. Harper Sibley of Rochester, N.Y., will deliver the sermon in the morning at St. George's, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street, and tomorrow evening in Grace Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

The rift between W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, and some of the women leaders of the party, which culminated on Thursday in Mr. Macy's acceptance of the resignation of Miss Sarah Schuyler Butler as vice chairman of the State committee, was regarded yesterday as having further weakened Mr. Macy's Influence in the party.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3.m -- Bitter feeling, which at times seemed likely to lead to blows, was shown at the first day's hearing of the resumed Senatorial inquiry into the Louisiana primary of last August, in which John Holmes Overton, candidate of Senator Long, defeated Senator Broussard.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Feb. 3 (AP) -- A document written in Spanish, purportedly stolen from the wallet of the slain Captain Walter Wanderwell, was described to a Jury here today by his widow in her testimony against William James Guy, 23-year-old Welsh adventurer on trial for the killing.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Frank A. Hayes will give a small dance tonight in the white and gold room of the Plaza, to introduce to society their daughter, Miss Marie Van V. Hayes. The party was postponed from Dec. 22 last.

WARM SPRINGS, Ga., Feb. 3. -- Invigorated by his stay of nearly two weeks and showing no indication of the strain which might be expected to affect the man who is to assume the Presidency in a month, Franklin D. Roosevelt left Warm Springs at 8:15 o'clock this evening for Jacksonville, Fla.
Honor Guests of Theatre Will Be the Program Feature at Waldorf.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 3. -- Jungle King, by St. Germans, the sire of Twenty Grand, and a candidate for the $10,000 Florida Derby, was a decisive winner of the Haines City Purse at Hialeah Park today, scoring by two lengths over E.R. Bradley's Bubbler, which saved the place by a neck from Pre War.

Whatever fears the Giants might have entertained of being forced to come to grips with at least one holdout of the first class this Spring faded yesterday. Secretary Jim Tierney received the signed contract of Freddy Fitzsimmons, chubby knuckle-ball manipulator and, between seasons, a well-to-do chicken farmer in Arcadia, Cal.

Tony Canzoneri, world's lightweight champion, knocked out Billy Townsend, Vancouver (B.C.) welterweight, last night in 1 minute 5 seconds of what was to have been the ten-round feature bout at, Madison Square Garden.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Champ Clark's son began a Senatorial career today with lower tariffs as his principal and immediate aim.

Edward Fagan defeated J. Howard Shoemaker of the New York A.C., the defending champion, in the final game of the national amateur pocket billiard championship tournament at Lawler Brothers' Manhattan Academy last night and thereby caused a three-way tie for the crown.

Theatre owners and business interests of the Broadway district met yesterday to organize a protest against the theatre-hour traffic and parking restrictions. A petition will be presented to Police Commissioner Mulrooney and Deputy Police Commissioner Hoyt, in charge of traffic, asking that the restrictions be lifted.

The New York University girls' basketball team repulsed the Upsala College girls' sextet, 14 to 8, at the N.Y.U. School of Education gym yesterday. It was the Violet team's second consecutive victory this week. Seven field goals by Miss Jacqueline Corrigan, star forward, accounted for all of the winner's points.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Declaring, as an indication that Great Britain had passed the worst of the depression, that December was the best month British automobile exporters had ever experienced, Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, told a Birmingham audience tonight that any increase in taxation "would be a disaster of the first magnitude."

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 3. -- Chattanooga friends of Nathan L. Bachman, former Justice of the Supreme Court of Tennessee, have begun a campaign to obtain his appointment to a seat in the United States Senate if Senator Hull becomes a member of the Roosevelt Cabinet.
