NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 3 (AP). -- J.L. Cleveland's Ricciardo, a winner the last time out but an outsider today, came from behind to win the mile and a sixteenth claiming feature at the Fair Grounds. The time was 1:53.

Yesterday at Albany saw a glorious victory for FARLEY and principle. On Thursday Governor LEHMAN signed the bill depriving Senate Clerk O'CONNELL, brother of The O'CONNELL, of his power to appoint petty officers of the Senate.
About $250,000 worth of art has been bought here recently by the William Rockhill Nelson Trust of Kansas City, Mo., according to reports in art circles yesterday.

VIENNA, Feb. 3. -- The Austrian Chancellor was told in Parliament today that he had given false answers to the Britisn and French Ministers in regard to the arms smuggling affair at Hirtenberg, and he was accused of allowing constant transportation of arms to Hungary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The joint Congressional Committee on Veterans Affairs today heard a veterans' organiaztion oppose payment of the bonus and recommend extensive cuts in present payments to ex-soldiers.

Three players from Westchester and two from the New Jersey group of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association were selected yesterday to represent New York in the national Class A team championship starting Monday at the Merion Cricket Club, Haverford, Pa.

The British Empire is one of the "dominant circumstances" of modern civilization, Lord Snell of Plumstead, Labor peer, said yesterday at a luncheon in the City Club, 55 West Forty-fourth Street. Lord Snell, who was introduced by his confrere, Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, spoke on the topic "Is the British Empire Breaking Up?" which he emphatically denied, asserting that dominion self-government would be extended and the dole maintained.

It is not only the way of the transgressor that is hard, William Kennedy, a Federal prohibition agent, testified last night. He made the observation while, immaculately groomed and escorted by two policemen, he was pushing a peddler's wagon down Broadway through crowds of theatregoers.

The Board of Estimate voted yesterday to accept the offer of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to give the city a plot of land on the west side of Broadway between Bennett Avenue and West 196th Street, which will extend the boundaries of Fort Tryon Park.

BALTIMORE, Md., Feb. 3. -- With the largest first day's attendance in its long show-giving history, the Maryland Kennel Club opened its twentieth annual two-day dog show today in the Mar-Del Building, nearly 600 dogs being on the benches.

Wall Street came out of its fit of despondency yesterday afternoon, and the resultant market improvement was of sufficient scope to cancel a small part of the previous day's losses. However, the volume of business on the Stock Exchange indicated some diminution of interest.

Analysis of the reorganization plan recently made effective for the thirty-two-story Squibb Building at the southeast corner of Fifth Avenue and Fifty-eighth Street, reveals that the building, now assessed at $3,800,000, has been used to support the acquisition for the new corporation of the ownership of the site formerly occupied on lease and assessed at $3,900,000, making a property with a total valuation of $7,700,000.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 3. -- Asserting that the influence of gangland on high school students was helping to undermine modern Civilization, Dr. Harold Rugg of Teachers College, Columbia University, told a regional conference of the Progressive Education Association here today that thousands of such students in New York City were "actually organizing for racketeering."

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- The ability of the Central Republic Trust Company to repay the $66,423,762 balance which the report from Washington shows that it owes to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation would depend, it was said tonight, upon its success in liquidating about $70,000,000 of loans which were still outstanding.

ALBANY, Feb. 3. -- Imposition of a 2 per cent retail sales tax to replace the major levies recommended by Governor Lehman was under consideration today by legislators preparing the budget for passage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some of the points emphasized by Yandell Henderson and Knight Dunlap in recent letters to your columns on the unsolved liquor problem deserve, and may require, continued emphasis until they stand out in full relief as factors essential to a solution.

Plans are being discussed by the management of the Palace Theatre, once the leading vaudeville house in the country, to present a Broadway revue at that playhouse, it was reported yesterday. The musical show mentioned was "Billy Rose's Revue," which has been on the verge of rehearsal for several months.

If Mr. ROOSEVELT manages to achieve a balanced budget during his first year in office it will be almost entirely in consequence of such leadership as he may display at the forthcoming special session. Democrats in the House of Representatives are giving him no help at present.

The Treasury Department's full monthly report of the stocks of all kinds of money in the United States as of Jan. 1 shows the following principal changes during 1932. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

Following the recent decline of more than $3 a bale, prices on the Cotton Exchange steadied yesterday and recovered 15 points from the low levels of the week, leaving quotations 10 to 12 points higher than on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Urgent pleas for more Federal help to care for the increasing millions of unemployed won such support today in the Senate Banking subcommittee that quick approval there was in sight for Senator Wagner's bill to open all resources of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation for relief.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 3. -- Dispatches from official foreign military observers at Mukden, Manchuria, report nineteen Japanese troop trains en route to Chinchow and Suichung, near the border of Jehol Province, and forecast early issuance of a declaration in connection with the coming Jehol campaign.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has explained that all he sought to work out in his conference with the British Ambassador was the "set-up" of the conference on war debts to be held early in March. But that set-up has already been a good deal upset.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 3 (Canadian Press). -- Seventeen mining men and capitalists, most of them from New York, left this city tonight for the North, accompanied by Charles McCrea, Minister of Mines for Ontario, on a tour of Ontario's chief gold producers.

The Board of Estimate denied yesterday the application of the Tompkins Bus Corporation for a franchise to operate on five new routes on Staten Island. The company now operates routes there under a franchise granted in the first administration of former Mayor Walker.

Unless reports are revised greatly net operating income of the Class I railroads in December will be set at about $33,000,000 in the final reports, or an increase of 55 per cent from the $21,263,000 shown for December, 1931. A year ago there were drastic revisions in the totals, the preliminary figures showing net operating income of $27,000,000 in December, 1931, for the first seventy-two railroads alone.

M.S. Szymczak, Controller of the City of Chicago, issued yesterday a statement advocating a change in the Federal Reserve act to permit central banks to increase their holdings of municipal tax-anticipation warrants. Under section 14 of the act, purchases are limited to warrants of maturities not exceeding six months.
The Samuel J. Tilden High School quintet, defending champion, inaugurated its Brooklyn P.S.A.L. campaign by dropping a 25-13 decision to the Abraham Lincoln team Yesterday at Lincoln.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- The Senate tonight voted a modified restriction on imports by confining all government departments to the purchase of American-made materials and supplies wherever practicable. The vote was 41 to 12.

The Poly Prep and Erasmus Hall sextets were the victors in scholastic hockey games at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night. Poly Prep defeated St. John's High, 3 to 0, in a playoff of their early season 1-1 tie, while Erasmus conquered Lynbrook, 1 to 0. Neither game was a league encounter.

MANILA, Feb. 3. -- Philippine sentiment appears to be swinging toward acceptance of the Hawes independence law. As long as the Legislature was in session, it was firmly held in the grip of Senator Manuel Quezon, leader of the opposition to the measure, but since the adjournment his hold has been loosening.

The present-day revaluation of Thomas Eakins continues apace and the esteem in which this stalwart nineteenth century American painter is held seems to be steadily deepening. In 1930 his work was honored by the Museum of Modern Art, which presented him in exhibition as one of a trio of "independents," the other two artists being Albert P. Ryder and Winslow Homer.

LONDON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The "big-five" of the British Cabinet dispersed to their country homes today to spend a long British weekend after nearly a fortnight of work in formulating the government's policy toward the March debt negotiations in Washington.
BUCHAREST, Rumania, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The government was empowered tonight by Parliament to declare martial law in Rumania to curb unrest and agitation "of perilous dimensions."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- In an unprecedented action, the Senate today openly accused, tried and suspended David S. Barry, Sergeant-at-Arms, for writing a magazine article in which he stated that "there are not many Senators or Representatives who sell their vote for money, and it is pretty well known who these few are."

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Federal Judge George A. Carpenter decided today to, open up the entire Insull bankruptcy situation to determine the merit of charges brought by Samuel Ettelson, former Chicago Corporation Counsel, to the effect that Samuel Insull and his former bankers had "framed" the receivership of the various Insull investment companies to benefit themselves.

Major Gen. Sir Ernest D. Swinton, who developed the tank as a war weapon, despite Lord Kitchener's skepticism, tells the story in "Eye-Witness and the Origin of the Tanks," which will be published on Feb. 15 by Doubleday, Doran. General Swinton was "Eye-Witness," the only correspondent allowed on the British front during the first ten months of the war.

With a capacity crowd of 17,000 anticipated, the Millrose A.A. will stage the twenty-sixth of its annual track and field extravaganzas tonight in Madison Square Garden. Always one of the most scintillating of all indoor games, this year's meet is expected to be the best of a brilliant series.

LONDON, Feb. 3. -- Retorting to intimations from the United States that Great Britain is purposely keeping the pound unstabilized as a threat to compel the United States to revise war debts, The Economist will say tomorrow:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Republican plans for higher tariffs against depreciated currency countries appear to be blockaded by the nearness of the end of the Congressional session.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 3. -- Newspapers, diplomats and official and unofficial observers attribute tremendous importance to the Mendoza conference between the Foreign Ministers of Argentina and Chile, especially that part whicn sets up the ABC-Peru group as a permanent organization claiming exclusive jurisdiction over future conflicts on the South American continent.

The report of Standard Brands, Inc., for 1932, issued yesterday, shows a larger net profit than for, 1931, although gross profit last year was only $44,904,239, against $47,915,906 in 1931. The improvement was made possible by a reduction of expenses from $30,069,685 to $28,049,762, a curtailment of losses on foreign exchange from $524,691 to $222,072 and the absence of an inventory adjustment of $1,100,000, such as had been made in 1931.

Richard Strauss's "Elektra," which is one of the supreme achievements of the present Metropolitan Opera season, was given its sixth and last performance of the present Winter yesterday afternoon with three important alterations in the cast. Goeta Ljungberg, who had had some anticipations of earlier appearances in the role, was the Elektra; Maria Olszewska the Klytemnestra.

Commodity markets here were firm yesterday. Sugar, cocoa, rubber, silk, hide and silver futures all made moderate gains, but some of the coffee contracts fell to lower ground. Trading generally was quiet. In the cash markets, on the contrary, declines in prices outnumbered gains:

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

GENEVA, Feb. 3. -- The League of Nations Council today rather reluctantly withheld the project of sending a commission of inquiry to the Gran Chaco until, as requested by Bolivia and Paraguay, more time is allowed for the peace efforts already begun by Chile and Argentina.

German loans were again heavy losers in a generally weak bond market on the Stock Exchange yesterday. All classifications of domestic corporation bonds lost ground, and United States Government bonds, which had held steady during the last few days in the face of the lower trend of the bond market as a whole, moved irregularly lower yesterday.

The third and last for this season of the Junior Assemblies held last night in the Ritz-Carlton brought out an unusually large gathering. It was in the main ballroom suite in a setting of Spring flowers, jonquils, forsythia, tulips and snap-dragons, combined with ferns and gilded palms.

Stocks were confined yesterday to a small market area, but they showed the first determined resistance to selling pressure in four days. Bonds were weak again, the foreign exchanges were steady and agricultural commodities, irregular.

PARIS, Feb. 3. -- Uniting once more, though "without enthusiasm and without promise" on the part of the Socialists, the combined Left parties of the Chamber of Deputies voted confidence in Premier Edouard Daladier's government today by 370 to 200.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Some Democratic friends close to the President-elect -- there are several in Washington -- are convinced that, after piecing together several scraps of information that have come from Warm Springs, Ga., they know the broad outlines of the conversation last week between Mr. Roosevelt and Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States.
The University of Pittsburgh basketball quintet overwhelmed the Fordham University five, 47 to 16, in the Maroon gymnasium last night. Centre Cribbs led the Panthers in scoring with 14 points.
The actual condition of business is better than sentiment, reversing the situation of a year ago, according to the weekly survey of economic conditions by Dun's Review, which says in part:
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday-1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday-1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

MANAGUA, Feb. 3. -- Church bells spread the news of peace throughout Nicaragua this morning while the erstwhile rebel, General Augusto C. Sandino, slept in a chamber of the Presidential palace after having signed a truce in which he pledged his followers to lay down their arms in return for amnesty and a grant of land on which they might settle as farmers.

Immortality occupied the thoughts of an audience of about 100 men and women last night in the Community Church Centre, 550 West 110th Street. It was the topic for general discussion after a lecture by Dr. Gustav F. Beck, director of the Labor Temple School, on "A Philosopher's View of Immortality."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Housewives and persons of "no occupation" continued to rank highest among the various classes of Americans traveling abroad during 1932, according to the State Department's annual report of the passport division.

The rules committee of the Eastern Association of Intercollegiate Football Officials at its meeting here yesterday proposed one of the most radical changes of recent years in an effort to adjust the balance between the offense and defense.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 3. -- The investigation of the poisoning two days ago of fifteen pedigreed dachshunds on the "dog farm" of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Vodegel at 285 Johnson Avenue, North Hackensack, extended today to New York City.

Four young thugs bound and gagged the night watchman in a Brooklyn garage yesterday and damaged the upholstery of ten privately owned cars to an extent estimated at from $8,000 to $15,000. Afterward William McGuinness, Assistant District Attorney of Kings County, charged that the vandalism was part of a campaign of intimidation of independent garage owners by racketeers.

General SANDINO, whether he be regarded as a bandit, or as a patriot according to his lights, must have credit for going to Managua as a peacemaker and as a supporter of President SACASA of Nicaragua. He had doubtless been assured that his draft of terms, negotiated by the Nicaraguan Minister of Agriculture, would have SACASA'S approval.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 (AP) -- The death of three anti-Fascists in clashes with Nazis tonight raised the death toll since the accession of Chancellor Hitler Monday to twenty.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- Arthur Reynolds, former chairman of the Continental Illinois National Bank and Trust Company, has accepted an offer to become vice chairman and chief executive officer of the Bank of America National Trust and Savings Association, which has headquarters in San Francisco.

The Railroad Credit Corporation reported yesterday to the Interstate Commerce Commission that it had made or authorized loans of $53,259,918 to Jan. 31 to assist railroads in meeting fixed interest obligations. Of this total $48,163,052 is outstanding and $1,236,647 has been repaid, leaving a balance of $3,860,219 to which the corporation is committed.

LONDON, Feb, 3 (AP). -- The Orient Steam Navigation Company, Ltd., is attempting to solve the mysterious disappearance from the liner Oronsay of a passenger registered as Captain W. Messenger, who it was believed may be an American and a man of importance.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- A request for Shipping Board aid in restoring Philadelphia to the list of transatlantic passenger ports was placed before the board today by Philadelphia shipping interests.

The Communist movement in the United States, which has been split into three factions -- Right, Left and Centre, with the latter representing the official party approved by Joseph Stalin, Soviet dictator -- suffered another fissure yesterday with the announcement by Ben Gitlow of a schism in the faction led by Jay Lovestone, which hitherto had been supposed to represent the Right wing opposition to the Stalin group.

THE Millrose meet, with its list of distinguished entries, will draw the track fans of this vicinity to the Garden this evening. Any discussion of coming events in track meets should be guarded with the warning that the performers are amateurs and occasionally exercise what they consider the privilege of an amateur by not showing up at the starting mark.

BERLIN, Feb. 3. -- Rumors that President von Hindenburg dismissed General Kurt von Schleicher as Chancellor and hurriedly appointed Adolf Hitler as his successor to prevent the General from seizing power through a "putsch" were promptly discounted today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- An immediate upward tendency in the living standards of silver-using countries and a general increase in purchasing power throughout the world would follow enactment of the Wheeler bill for the remonetization of silver, Senator Wheeler told the House Committee on Coinage, Weights and Measures today.

Loans for self-liquidating projects which may cost more than $150,000,000 and supply jobs for many thousands of unemployed will be sought from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by the committee of nine appointed by Governor Lehman to expedite applications for such loans.

PARIS, Feb. 3. -- Maggy Rouff's Summer collection shows a wide, rather flat silhouette with large armholes and loose three-quarter sleeves. For afternoon and evening a six-inch waistline has drapery extending a little above and below normal.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 3. -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. George R. Blodgett of Boston, who arrived today to be their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. John Shepard Jr. gave a dinner tonight at Casa del Pastor. During dinner and later a group of Romanies entertained with a program of songs and dances.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The writer of the letter signed "Retired Naval Officer" appears to be confused as to the facts in regard to the bill in Congress relating to retired pay. The bill, as reported in The Army and Navy Journal, is much worse than he represents it, and as yet it applies only to the army, although it may be extended to the navy and Marine Corps.

The Metropolitan Opera offered a rare performance of almost wholly American singers in its presentation last evening, when "Romeo et Juliette" was repeated with only two changes from a previous hearing this year. Where three foreign stars had sung on that occasion, the cast of a dozen last night had only one, the versatile player of many parts during twenty-five New York seasons, who had retained citizenship abroad.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 3 -- President Hoover declared in a speech today before State legislators and tax experts meeting here that the people must have relief from tax burdens imposed by the "perfect maze of overlapping, conflicting tax systems," resulting from what he said had been the "haphazard development of sources of taxation" to support the functions of government.

The comparative dearth of new State and municipal financing is reflected in next week's calendar of loans listed for award through competitive bidding. The total is only $3,361,518, made up of thirty-one issues, the largest of which is $1,200,000 city of Newark (N.J.) park bonds on Monday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 3. -- A steady reduction in the open interest in May wheat on the Board of Trade here, particularly since Jan. 19, has attracted attention from the trade. At the close of business yesterday the open interest was 91,767,000 bushels, 4,208,000 bushels less than two weeks ago.

The trial of Albert Grossman, also known as Al Gross, for conspiracy to violate the prohibition laws at the Breakfast Club, which was in the Hotel Delmonico, 502 Park Avenue, until prohibition agents raided it more than a year ago, opened yesterday before Federal Judge Harry B. Anderson and a jury.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES editorial covering election frauds in the City of New York represents a careful analysis of the real facts. There is every indication that the perpetrators of these frauds will be prosecuted, and such action will certainly have a purging influence so far as future elections are concerned.

SIOUX CITY, Iowa, Feb. 3. -- Four men, three of them South Dakota farmers and the other an Iowa picket, were wounded late today in a clash between milk truckers and picketers four miles north of Riverside, a suburb of Sioux City

HAVANA, Feb. 3 (AP). -- Wrigley Field, winner of three of his six starts at Jefferson Park, made It two in a row at Oriental Park today when he captured the mile and a sixteenth feature at the surprisingly long odds of 5 to 1. The time was 1:46.

Joseph Castaldo, called by the government the "artichoke king" of New York City, pleaded gruilty in Federal court yesterday as his trial for violation of Federal income-tax laws was about to enter its third day. He was immediately sentenced by Judge Harry B. Anderson to a term of eleven months in the Federal House of Detention here.

Complete revision of Federal naturalization laws because of changing social conditions and changing attitudes toward aliens in the United States was urged yesterday afternoon at the fourth annual meeting of the National Council on Naturalization and Citizenship at the Russell Sage Foundation, 130 East Twenty-second Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today announced its approval of a further $5,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the Baltimore Ohio Railroad for meeting equipment trust obligations due in the first half of the year.

The women's field hockey team that will represent the United States in the international tourney at Copenhagen next September was named last night at an executive committee meeting of the United States Field Hockey Association.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It is one of the idiosyncrasies of the bar that it is fluent in criticism but somewhat inarticulate in commendation.

Surrogate Frank I. Smith of Richmond informed Mayor O'Brien by letter yesterday that he would take a reduction of 10 per cent in his $15,000 salary rather than have his salary cut to $10,000 by new legislation.

Despite disturbed business conditions in the amusement field which resulted in the closing of the Rialto Theatre this week, realty interests pointed out yesterday that assessed value of the theatre property today is more than fifteen times the figure set down by tax authorities in 1900.

Exchange of checks at the principal clearing houses of the country for last month totaled $20,147,380,892. This was a loss of 3.8 per cent from the December turnover and of 23.8 per cent from that in January of last year. Beyond the loss with December, last month's clearings were the largest since last September.

The annual report of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company for 1932 shows a net income of $8,999,876 after taxes, depreciation and charges, equal to $6.75 a share earned on 1,333,458 shares outstanding at the end of the year This compares with $11,675,225, or $8.76 a share, earned in the previous year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3. -- Cash disbursements of $330,145,572 were made in the last three months of 1932 to 2,088 applicants for loans, according to the quarterly report of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, made public today. The disbursements were made on authorizations of $388,746,283.

A meeting of the American creditors of the Kreuger Toll Company was set yesterday by Henry K. Davis, referee, for Saturday, Feb. 18, at 10:30 A.M. in Room 235 of the Federal Building on Park Row, for the election of a bankruptcy trustee to succeed Gordon Auchincloss.

TOKYO, Feb. 3. -- The open question in Japanese politics as to whether or not the Cabinet controls the fighting forces is raised by a petition presented in the House of Peers today requesting an authoritative interpretation of the Constitution.

A plan for the regulation of interstate transmission of electricity and gas by compacts between the States, under Federal sanction, was approved yesterday, after an all-day conference at the Hotel Commodore between representatives of New York State and five adjoining States.

Abandoning its previously announced plan for public hearings, the State commission which is studying the problem of liquor control in anticipation of the modification or repeal of the prohibition laws began its gathering of expert opinion yesterday, calling former Governor Alfred E. Smith for examination in private.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- A bill to relieve owners of heavily mortgaged farms by setting up over the nation twelve farm mortgage adjustment districts, backed by an appropriation of $250,000,000 that would be expanded eventually to $1,000,000,000 through sale of debentures was introduced today by Representative Buchanan of Texas.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 3 (AP) -- After having been led to safety, nine frenzied women patients ran back into a blazing cottage in the Ridgecliff Sanitarium grounds today and perished.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 3. -- The management of the Hotel St. Francis reported today that it was bringing suit against former Mayor Walker of New York for a $2,079 hotel bill he contracted when he was here to plead for a pardon for Tom Mooney two years ago.

A more rigid enforcement of the highest standards of advertising, to prevent the loss of public confidence, was urged yesterday by Benjamin H. Namm, president of the Namm store in Brooklyn, in an address to the members of the Advertising Club of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

The social values of radio broadcasting, growing every day in volume and intensity, cannot fail to affect profoundly the trend of life in this country, said M.H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company, in an address last night at the annual meeting of the National Institute of Social Sciences at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The Regional Planning Association of America, with offices at 56 West Forty-fifth Street, made public yesterday a letter to Presidentelect Roosevelt which said the organization "heartily backs your proposal for the comprehensive regional development of the Tennessee River Valley."

Additional economies which would result in a saving of at least $500,000 of the cost of this year's operatic season must be found if the Metropolitan Opera Association is to reopen next Winter, it was said yesterday as an unofficial budget figure revealed the discrepancy between expectation and reality.

MOSCOW, Feb. 3. -- Joseph V. Stalin, secretary-general of the Communist party, made his third speech of the year last night before the all-Union conference of the Communist Youth organization, which is discussing the Spring sowing campaign.

Although sales representatives of two of the smaller Canadian manufacturers of newsprint are offering newsprint for as little as $40 a ton here against a prevailing price of $45, spokesmen for the larger manufacturers said yesterday that they hoped to avert a price war or market disturbances.

The expected clash between Beekman Pool and J. Lawrence Pool, both of the Harvard Club, for the metropolitan squash racquets championship will not take place, as the result of the elimination of the latter in one of the two semi-final matches yesterday at the University Club.

Miss Emily T. Janeway, member of an old American family and sister of the late Dr. Edward G. Janeway, died yesterday at her residence, 12 East Ninety-seventh Street, at the age of 89. She had been in failing health for the last two years and had been confined to her bed for six months.

Declaring that "the honest and competent property owner has carried on to the limit of his ability and must have Immediate relief," the New York Title and Mortgage Company appealed yesterday to holders of its guaranteed mortgage certificates to cooperate in the rehabilitation of real estate by accepting a voluntary reduction of interest to 4 per cent instead of the 5 1/2 per cent called for by their securities.

Aside from the fact that this week's aggregate of new bond financing, $15,947,000, was approximately double that of last week, considerable interest centred in the offering of an issue of $12,000,000 of long-term railroad bonds, marking the first railroad financing of this magnitude in more than fourteen months.

A search for a Brooklyn taxicab driver who, the police believe, may have information important to the investigation of the brutal murder of Mary Helen O'Connor, 15-year-old Rockaway Park high school student, whose body was found in Massapequa Thursday, was begun last night on the basis of information given by a newly discovered witness and other clues.

To talk of a "cure" for crime is "folly, naivete or charlatanism," Dr. Sheldon Glueek, Professor of Criminology at Harvard Law School, writes in "Probation and Criminal Justice," just published by Macmillan. He believes, however, that probation -- the oversight of selected offenders by trained probation officers -- is the most promising modern means of dealing with the criminal.

BOSTON, Feb. 3 (AP) -- Mrs. Florence Hascall, widow of a former business manager and trustee of Boston University, surrendered today to police on a warrant charging her with larceny in an alleged fraud which, police said, might have victimized prominent women to the aggregate extent of $1,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 3 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Feb. 1:

A NEW season of ballet to be given Feb. 14-March 4 at the Municipal Theatre of San Remo, Italy, has been undertaken by Anita Colombo, formerly general manager of La Scala. The project is of particular interest in that it is an experimental attempt to evolve a new dance form in which writers, musicians, choreographers and designers are participating.
BRACEVILLE, Ill., Feb. 2 -- The ghost of a one-time flourishing community beckons hard-pressed families here.

A FLUTTERING string of signal flags-scarlet and saffron and deep blue against the slate background of the sea -- whips to the flagship's yardarm. The lively music of bugles and the skirling notes of bosuns' pipes sound about the decks. Gongs clang.

To the Music Editor: We radio fans, victims of crooning, third-rate jazz and other rubbish and piffle of all kinds, are glad, of course, to have symphony concerts over the air. But, alas! our early expectations have been dashed and our disappointment is keen.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Judge William F. Kenyon of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals said today it was preferable to permit some evasions of the income tax laws rather than to set aside constitutional rights, in an opinion which reversed the action of the Commissioner of Internal Revenue and Board of Tax Appeals in the case of deficiency assessments against Frederick B. Wells, Minneapolis investment broker.

BARCELONA. THE revival of the Mediterranean question brings once more into relief the strategic position of Minorca, the most northerly of the Balearic Islands, especially in view of the recent announcement that the port of Mahon is to be dredged and its fortifications augmented.

RETAIL trade showed some improvement in the week, mainly toward the close when the weather turned cooler. The demand continued rather spotty, however, and merchandise values were shopped very closely. For this reason furniture volume in the aggregate was not altogether satisfactory, but centred on a few outstanding promotions.

Conflicting factors were evident In the general economic situation In this country during the last week. Outside of the automobile industry and the steel fabricators, which continued to show improvement, general industrial conditions remained little changed.

BEIRUT, Jan. 19 -- Times are very hard in Syria just now. The sun shines, "the skies are blue and the weather is so perfect that tourists think it heavenly, but natives believe it has been sent by the Evil One. The Syrian Winter should be rainy, but the weeks are slipping sunnily by with only an occasional evening sprinkle.

An analysis of contracts between the Postoffice Department and merchant snip lines for the transportation of foreign mails indicates that the basis of payments is not the actual volume of mail anticipated for transportation, says the National Committee on the Merchant Marine.

Shipping interests have been asked to express their views of the proposed government policy toward the Erie and Oswego Canals, as drafted by a special board appointed by the chief of army engineers. It has been proposed that the government improve, maintain and operate the canals without taking title to them.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 4 -- The Yale junior varsity polo team barely won over Boulder Brook of Scarsdale, N.Y., today, 13 to 12 1/2. Because of personal ratings the visitors were given a two-goal handicap.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Frederic A. Delano of Washington are at the Gladstone.

The directors of the Utah Copper Company, which is about 98 1/2 per cent owned by the Kennecott Copper Corporation, decided yesterday to distribute to its stockholders all the stock in the Nevada Consolidated Copper Corporation which the Utah company holds.

RICHMOND, Feb. 2 -- The University of North Carolina, already seriously handicaped by drastic cuts in appropriations in the past few years, is threatened with such additional reductions in the budget now before the State Legislature as to endanger its standing as an institution of the first rank.

OTTAWA, Feb. 4 (AP) -- The Ottawa Senators took a 3-2 decision from the Boston Bruins tonight in a fast National Hockey League game marked by the threat of Manager Art Ross of the Bruins to take his team from the ice in the closing minutes of play.

BY producing "We, the People," which is a lurid panorama of all the current American complaints, Elmer Rice has raised again the unsettled problem of the propaganda play. Like most revolutionaries, and like a good many of us who are not, Mr. Rice believes that the stage should be used in part for the blunt statement of political and economic views.

While the farm mortgage problem and the increasing leniency being granted to farmers throughout the country by insurance companies and other mortgage holders has been drawn to the attention of the public recently, there also has been an increasing agitation for similar consideration of the owners of homes within urban limits.

Mrs. S. Hinman Bird heads a group of prominent women who are active in behalf of the forth-coming series of Sunday afternoon musicales by young students of the Music School Settlement to be held at various private schools in the city for the benefit of that organization and the Women's Division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

SLIPSHOD work on airplanes, with its corollary, hazard in flight, obviously cannot be tolerated. In consequence, the bulletin made public last week, "Vocational Training for Aviation Mechanics," in the preparation of which air transport organizations, aircraft manufacturers, aeronautical associations and engineers and the Aeronautics Branch of the Department of Commerce collaborated, is particularly timely.

Continuing its policy of the last few years of issuing postage stamps commemorative of important historical events, the Postoffice Department will place on sale on Monday, Feb. 13, in Savannah and other offices in Georgia a new 3-cent stamp commemorative of the founding of the Colony of Georgia in 1733 by General James Edward Oglethorpe.

The poetry of Frederick Dellus's "Brigg Fair," and one of the greatest of the symphonies -- the Fifth -- of Jean Sibelius; a new work by Frederick S. Converse of Boston, "Prophecy," for soprano and orchestra, and Richard Strauss's "Death and Transfiguration," made the engrossing program given by the Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall.

IN his introduction to this autobiographical story of the surprising career of Bruce Lockhart Hugh Walpole mentions the author's voice -- "an odd voice, assertive and modest, arrogant and humorously depreciative, all at the same time."

TOKYO, Jan. 20 -- Expeditions to dive for sunken treasure and reports of the discovery of gold deposits of fabulous richness are providing Japanese newspaper readers with relief from the drab monotony of depression.

WESTWARD the path of impresario goes. Max Gordon left this unhappy shore last Monday, and Gilbert Miller a day later. The one may or may not have something to do with the movies, and the other certainly will.

WHAT is the American musical public thinking of Richard Wagner on the eve of a world-wide observance, by opera houses, concert halls and broadcasting stations both here and abroad, commemorating the death of the great German composer fifty years ago, on Feb. 13, 1883.

Today will mark the close of a week's celebration of the anniversary of the first Christian Endeavor Society, which was organized in Portland, Me., on Feb. 2, 1881, by the late Rev. Dr. Francis E. Clark. Pastors here will retell the story in their sermons this morning.
A campaign to raise $3,000,000 for a permanent endowment fund to maintain the Yeshiva and Yeshiva College was started last week at a meeting of the board of directors of the organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The total vote cast for Democratic members of the Assembly at the November election exceeded by 582,436 that polled for their Republican opponents. The Democratic total was 2,344,118 and the Republican 1,761,682.
To the Admissions Committee, Psychopathic Ward, Bellevue Hospital.

More wood products are likely to be used in the small houses of the future than ever before, C. Stanley Taylor of this city told the delegates at the convention last week in the Hotel Pennsylvania of the Northeastern Retail Lumbermen's Association.
Returning for another golfing visit, Miss Diana Fishwick, erstwhile British golf champion and present holder of the women's French title, will reach here this week for a six weeks' sojourn.

THOSE who wonder how film producers manage to persuade millionaires to permit them the use of their magnificent homes, estates, gardens and yachts will be interested to learn that this is accomplished through the agency of the Assistance League of Southern California, a charitable organization which has raised a considerable sum for the needy by working with, the film industry during the past seven years.

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- Following investigations into riots in two Canadian penitentiaries new rules of conduct have gone into effect which alter considerably the conditions under which 4,200 prisoners live in these institutions. They get some new privileges, but discipline generally has been tightened.

Dr. David S. Muzzey's list of forty-nine Americans who, he believed, would figure prominently in histories written fifty years hence was prepared in less than twenty minutes and contains the names of several not worthy of inclusion, while it omits those of others meriting it, he said yesterday.
PARIS. FOR a year or so now they have been dusting off the little Arc de Triomphe du Carrousel -- that other triumphal arch at the lower end of one of the world's most magnificent vistas.

"YOU are all a lost generation." said Gertrude Stein to Ernest Hemingway, and the phrase became the motif for his first novel and a sort of label for the disillusioned and cynical youth that emerged from the World War years.

It is ancient wisdom that the mind of man is less vividly stirred by what finds entrance through the ears than by what is brought before the eyes. This is a common experience. "The "eyes believe themselves, the ears be "lieve others." Yet hearing does bring satisfactions to the mind which the eyes cannot offer.
MOSCOW, Feb. 2 -- Moscow's children certainly contradict reports abroad that the Five-Year Plan and the collective farm campaign have materially reduced the living standards of the Soviet masses.

THIS, the third, volume of the diaries of Tolstoy's wife is no less interesting than the preceding instalments of this absorbing human document. Like the earlier volumes, it will shock the general public that remembers Tolstoy as the Grand Old Man of Russia, give food for thought to the student of human nature, and thrust a prickly problem upon the novelist's future biographer.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- By overwhelming majorities the House of Representatives today voted down amendment after amendment to cut items from the legislative appropriation bill, including efforts to reduce the salaries of Senators and Representatives to $7,500.

The ninth annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures will open a three-day session at the Hotel Pennsylvania on Thursday in which representatives of motion-picture groups from various parts of the country will participate.

A visit of considerable Interest was made to Harvard over the past week-end by one of the most interesting of recent mid-Western athletes, Wesley E. Fesler of Ohio State. Fesler spent a day at the Cambridge institution, conferred with William J. Bingham, director of athletics, and was taken on an inspection of the athletic plant by Eskie Clark, Mr. Eingham's assistant, and then departedd, leaving a trail of rumors in his wake.

While business conditions in the New York area showed little change last week, sentiment, particularly in the financial district, underwent further deterioration under the influence of declining security markets. There were no quotable changes in money rates and, although excess reserves of New York City banks were substantially reduced, no evidence appeared of a change from the prevailing ease in credit.

MILWAUKEE, Feb. 2 -- Wisconsin has in Governor A.G. Schmedeman a Democrat who talks like an old-fashioned Jeffersonian and backs up his remarks with a program of economy and simplified government. In his budget message he recommended a reduction of $14,000,000, or 25.09 per cent in appropriations.
DUBLIN, Feb. 3 -- Eamon de Valera's party will enter upon its second term of office when the Dail Eireann meets Wednesday and Mr. de Valera is re-elected to the Presidency.

RADIO has always cherished the University of the Air idea. The broadcasters consider that they can do three things with invisible waves -- entertain, educate and inform. The tools are spoken words and music.

OMAHA, Feb. 2 -- Movements to deal with the farm mortgage emergency in the Corn Belt have gone forward encouragingly during the past fortnight. Outstanding developments toward easing the situation include these:

Warning real estate interests to fight shy of the bugaboo of moratorium talk, Benjamin Winter said yesterday: "The less tinkering we have by legislative bodies in real esstate the better off we will be. With real help in sight from proposed cuts in interest rate schedules, let us incur no risks by loose talk.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 4 (AP) -- While W.R. Coe's colt Ladysman is the only nomination, for the 1933 Kentucky Derby so far announced, more than a score of the season's leading 3-year-olds are regarded as certain to be in the list which will be announced in two weeks.
New York again will be the centre of a figure-skating carnival with the staging of the North American championships on Friday and Saturday.

WASHINGTON. DESPITE the precedent set by George Washington to his Farewell Address. the President delivers an inaugural but never a valedictory. It is a pity, because if there is one time more than another when the Chief Executive might utter words it would profit his countrymen to hear, it is at the end of his administration.

A program recommending to the Senate extensive changes in the bill to amend the bankruptcy law, H.R. 14358, passed by the House of Representatives, was formulated during the week at a conference of credit men, bankers, lawyers and referees, it was learned yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is true that we have assembled in the Department of Agriculture at Washington the best body of experts found anywhere in the world, which could suggest and advise any number of agricultural business opportunities, but being a government body they cannot lead; they can only advise on inquiries.

The author of this article has been a member of the Council of the University of Adelaide since 1926, is an associate member of the Australian National Research Council, and was chairman of the Emergency Committee of South Australia, during the crisis.

What are the chances for a clear majority for the Hitler Cabinet in the election, next month? The Reichstag just dissolved was elected on Nov. 6 last. The distribution of approximately 35,000,000 votes was about as follows: For the parties sow represented in the Hitler Cabinet, Nazis and Hugenbergvon Papen Nationalists, 14,500,000 votes; for the Weimar coalition Socialists, Centrists and Bavarian People, 12,500,000 votes; for the Communists, 6,000,000 votes; scattering, 2,000,000 votes.

ROME, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Italy today denounced the customs, or preferential duties, section of the 1924 commercial treaty with Soviet Russia. The main section of the pact, under which Italy recognized the U.S.S.R. and agreed to establish diplomatic and consular relations, was untouched and remains in force.

With the time limit for such action due tomorrow, the Irving Trust Company, as trustee, and creditors of the bankrupt Kreuger Toll Company presented claims against the defunct corporation in a volume which reached rush proportions yesterday at the office of Henry K. Davis, 140 Nassau Street, Federal referee.

OF paramount significance in the week's art panorama is the College Art Association's 1933 International, which opened last evening and will be found commented upon in today's news columns. Some twenty nations figure in this ambitious enterprise.

TWO different views of the future of industry have been put forward. Mr. Gandhi is a wholehearted supporter of the movement for a return to primitive conditions; he would suppress the machine and reinstate the old hand processes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Loadings of revenue freight in the week ended on Jan. 28 totaled 472,088 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was 24,346 cars, or 4.9 per cent, fewer than in the preceding week; 88,255 cars, or 15.8 per cent, under the corresponding week last year and 247,309 cars, or 34.4 per cent, below the week two years ago.

PHILLIPS RUSSELL, biographer of Emerson and Franklin, has gathered together between the covers of this book seven figures in the history of the last seven hundred years of the world and has bound them together with one idea. To him they are men who, as he puts it, "began, furthered or completed a harvest of thought or deed, or both, in a way to Influence human destinies."
Dr. Paul Schwarz, German Consul in New York, has just returned from a vacation in Europe, accompanied by Mrs. Schwarz.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The fight against double taxation will be carried to Congress at the expected special session, it was decided today by the Interstate Assembly of the Legislators' Association. The association, at its convention here, voted for creation of a continuing committee to study the problem of conflicting and overlapping taxation and to draft a solution for presentation to the Ways and Means Committee.

TORONTO, Feb. 4 (Canadian Press) -- The Standard Mining Market today had its moat exciting Saturday session in the last five years. Quotations on gold shares bobbed about like a leaf in a gale, variations of 10 and 15 points showing between sales in some cases.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The essential feature of the gold standard is the unrestricted interconvertibility of gold and the various forms of currency and credit at a fixed ratio; for example, in the United States 23.22 grains of gold to $1.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Pedro, Cal., Feb. 4 -- Anchored in the lee of the green headlands of the California coast and swinging to the tide-rips off Hawailan beaches, 140 ships of the United States fleet prepared today for participation in a two-weeks' test of American sea power, the navy's annual mimic war.

Philanthropic organizations will benefit in the near future from "Alien Corn," opening at the Belasco Theatre on Feb. 20. The Neighborhood Playhouse Studios will be aided by the performance on the night of Feb. 21, the net proceeds being devoted to the scholarship fund of that organization.

IN this book T.F. Powys has grouped three stories, of which the last is the title piece. In all three Mr. Powys displays anew the deftness of structure, the uncanny penetration into the deeper recesses of the human mind, the rich satirical reading of life, which made his "Mr. Weston's Good Wine" and "Unclay" as well as others of his books so unforgetable.

THE American theme was ascendent in art exhibitions opened recently and on view this week. Perhaps the depression may be held responsible for the fact that most American artists seem to have spent their time at home lately, contenting themselves for subject matter with the New England coast instead of the Mediterranean littoral, and the American countryside instead of the Hill Towns of Italy.

New fees and increases in existing fees in the City Court were suggested yesterday by Chief Justice Edward B. La Fetra to Mayor O'Brien as a means of increasing the court's revenue by $772,374.50 this year.

Fifteen police radio cars, seven police launches and a number of patrolmen were guarding several miles of the Brooklyn waterfront yesterday in a search for a prisoner who escaped early in the day from the Atlantic branch of the United States Army Disciplinary Barracks on Governors Island.

Hackley School, Carteret Academy and Roosevelt High of Yonkers triumphed in the scholastic hockey games at the New York Coliseum yesterday morning. Hackley defeated Riverdale Country School, 7 to 1, Carteret downed Millburn High, 5 to 1, and Roosevelt vanquished Montclair Academy, 3 to 1.

Joseph Abrams of De Witt Clinton High, seeded No. 1, won the annual Clinton indoor interscholastic tennis tournament at the 369th Regiment Armory yesterday, turning back Phil Lautkin, a teammate, the second seeded player, by 6 -- 4, 6 -- 3, 4 -- 6, 6-1, in the final.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index shows a decrease to the lowest level since the week ended Sept. 17. The index for the week ended Jan. 28 is 54.0, as against 54.6 for the preceding week. It now stands only slightly less than two points above the record low level of last Summer.

PALM BEACH -- This week brings two of the leading golf tournaments of the Palm Beach season, the twenty-first annual South Florida championship and the fifth artists' and writers' tournaments, the former at the Palm Beach Golf Club and the latter over the greens of the Palm Beach Country Club.

A FEW Winters ago some Harvard graduates of Baker's 47 Workshop looked with seeing eyes upon the Charles Townsend Copeland Association and bestirred themselves to organize a more selective replica in George Pierce Baker's honor.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Yale took undisputed possession of first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League by beating Penn at the Palestra, 33 to 26, before a crowd of 6,500 tonight. This was the Elis' fifth straight conquest on the court.

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- The Government of Canada has nailed its flag to the mast of sound money and there will be no retreat unless, as Prime Minister R.B. Bennett expressed it in a recent speech, "something abnormal happens; something that cannot be foreseen."

SINCLAIR LEWIS. who is spending the Winter In Austria., has been reading so many contradictory things about himself that he scarcely knows whether he is afoot or on horseback, as they used to say "In the pre-motor era.

IN his day dreams Adolf Hitler's father, a petty Austrian customs official, saw his son as a customs officer; but Adolf had other ambitions. He wanted to become an architect, and would have become one if the director of the Vienna Art School had had a better opinion of his drawings.

THE decision in favor of local option by Governor Lehman's commission brings that system of liquor regulation to the fore again. The commission was recently appointed on the assumption that the Eighteenth Amendment would be repealed or modified.

IN the face of limited activity In business which caused declines in all other forms of transportation except domestic airlines, the International airlines of the United States, embraced almost In their entirety by the 25,500-mile system of airways of the Pan-American network, showed increases In every phase of their activity in 1932, a summary of the year's operations by this company made public last week indicated.

LONDON, Jan. 20 IVOR NOVELLO'S new piece, which has appeared at the Criterion Theatre under the name of "Fresh Fields," is an object-lesson in the uses and abuses of theatrical situation. Mr. Novello is an actor and has a very accurate sense of the stage.

EUREKA, Nev., Feb. 2 -- Not since Nevada became the "Battleborn State" to uphold the hands of Lincoln in the Senate in the critical days of 1864, have issues of larger moment confronted the Legislature than those facing the biennial session which is now under way.

DONALD OGDEN STEWART, Frank Sullivan, James Thurber, Ogden Nash, Ring (or, as he is called here, in the collected edition manner, Ring W.) Lardner, Dorothy Parker and a number of other people who can be very funny, too, have pieces in this book.

In adopting practical measures for the relief of distressed property owners, many of the major institutional lenders have publicly recognized that a new phase of the readjustment period has been reached. With the appeal by the New York Title and Mortgage Company to holders of its guarantee certificates to accept a lower rate of interest, a far-reaching move has been made toward solution of a problem which mortgage interests generally have recognized for some time.

To The Editor of The New York Times: Termination of steamboat service on Lake Champlain, announced in THE TIMES recent Albany dispatch, marks the end of a tourist route of extraordinary attraction. This line formed a water link in one of America's most famous pathways.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The State Society of Professional Engineers at its Winter meeting here today registered disavowal of "any responsibility for the findings of statements of technocracy" and also criticized, opponents of technocracy who "without justification are seeking to discredit engineering as a social factor in civilization through condemnation of technocracy.
CHICAGO, Feb. 2. BOX-OFFICE prices have been deflated to the $2 level, but only five theatres are in action. And so Chicago's ghastly stage season drags itself along in the dust like a wounded snake.

A FEW weeks ago there was an item of news from Persia which stated that the Shah had decided to take over the British oil concessions there. There was a time when such an act of arbitrary power, disregarding British rights and interests, would have called forth military action by the British Government.

Former Governor Smith, in a radio appeal last night over Station WEAF on behalf of "as many as 100,000 children who are hungary," urged consumers of bottled milk to subscribe for an extra quart each day to be delivered to the School Relief Committee.
The preliminary report of the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad for 1932 shows a net loss of $3,410,486, against $2,963,231 in 1931. The statement follows.

LONDON, Jan. 20, 1933. THE great majority of the carol recitals which ushered in the new year, and continued till they looked like ushering it out, had little to distinguish them from similar events of other years -- with one exception.

In accordance with the plans announced on Jan. 23 by the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York, trustees of several important savings banks in this city will take action this week to reduce the rate of interest paid on deposits from 3 1/2 to 3 per cent.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Playtime, veteran campaigner from the Southland Stable, today led four younger rivals over a heavy racing strip to win the Jack L. Dempsey Memorial Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

BORDEAUX, Jan. 26 -- A pre-historic tomb, dating from the neolithic age and containing the remains of a priestess-chieftian of that faraway epoch, has been discovered on the property of Count Hermann Wrangell, former Minister of Foreign Affairs for Sweden, twenty-five miles from this city.

A BOLD experiment, when compared with current experiments on Broadway, and one which should arouse the intellectual curiosity, at least, of local theatregoers, will be attempted this evening and next Sunday evening by the newly formed Stage Alliance when it presents at the Guild Theatre a program of six medieval miracle plays.

RENO, Nev., Feb. 4 (AP) -- Plans for a consolidated bank to replace the twelve closed banks in the Wingfield group were discussed here today following an announcement that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation had aproved a loan of $1,500,000 with which to finance the new institution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The economy axe, which the Senate started out to wield right and left on the appropriation bills in the "Lame Duck" session, was with-held today from the $35,500,000 grant of the government for ocean mail contracts.
BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Germany is passing through a period of inflation. I do not mean financial inflation but inflation of the nationalistic spirit.

Items which automobile owners and operators may deduct from gross income in their Federal tax returns were listed yesterday by the Automobile Club of New York, from information said to have been obtained from the United States Bureau of Internal Revenue.

THE suggestion from Warm Springs, Ga., that Presidentelect Roosevelt Is seriously considering the broadening of the powers of the Interstate Commerce Commission to include all forms of transport, or, rather, the making of the present I.C.C. a unit in a three-division Bureau of Transportation, air, water and land, has aroused hoth interest and speculation among air transport operators.

A suit in behalf of Charlton Co., Inc. jewelers, against Alfred Severin Bourne, son of the late Commodore Frederick G. Bourne, to recover a balance of $37,166 for fifty-six items of jewelry aggregating $364,666 sold between August, 1926, and Dec. 17, 1931, was disclosed in the Supreme Court yesterday when Justice Dore struck out three of four defenses, including counterclaims for $73,500.

The Squadron A Armory at Ninety-fourth Street and Madison Avenue will be the scene of a championship polo and military tournament on Feb. 15. Members of the Squadron have arranged the various events on the program which is being given for the benefit of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

The titles that will make up the "Fifty Books of the Tear" exhibition sponsored by the American Institute of Graphic Arts were announced yesterday. The books are selected annually not for their literary content but as good examples of American bookmaking.

GENEVA, Feb. 4 -- The League of Nations Committee of Nineteen rejected Japan's conciliation offer this morning as falling far short of the basis deemed necessary for a friendly settlement of the Chino-Japanese conflict.

ON the next to the last page of this volume the author makes the disquieting statement that in the situation in which our generation finds itseif "all the highest ideals and tenderest emotions which men have felt all through the ages o o o will seem from our perspective to be something of a luxury."

Overcoming a 3-point first half deficit, Manhattan's basketball team downed Scton Hall College of South Orange, N.J., 36 to 21, tonight. Captain John Hassett, left guard of Manhattan, led the scoring with a total of 14 points. Zdanewizz of Seton Hall took second honors with 12 markers.

MILAN, Jan. 20, 1933. AS the first absolute novelty of the season, Riccardo Zandonai's one-act opera, "Una Partita" (a card game), upon the libretto of Arturo Rossato, had its world premiere at La Scala last night.

BANFF -- The stage is set for Banff's annual Winter carnival, which will commence on Wednesday. Flanked by mountain peaks whose rugged sides are glistening with snow and dotted with great patches of evergreens, the carnival queen's ice palace is ready to receive its ruler, Margaret II, who will reign over one of the most colorful Winter events on the continent.

CHARLESTON, S.C., Feb. 4 -- Mrs. James W. White of 279 West Twelfth Street, New York City, suffered a fractured thigh today when the automobile in which she was riding plunged off a bridge down an eighteen-foot embankment and turned over in a shallow creek near Yemassee, a out seventy-five miles from Charleston.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- In a hotly contested hockey game in Army's skating arena tonight, the Cadets defeated the University of New Hampshire by a score of 4 to 3.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 4 -- In honor of Mrs. Harold Wilson Sweatt and her house guest, Mrs. William Eastman, a luncheon bridge was given by Mrs. Bernard Henry Kroger today at the Gulf Stream Club. Others present were:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Yale scored a 40-to-31 victory over Rutgers in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet in the Payne Whitney gymnasium pool tonight. A crowd of 1,600 persons, the largest gathering ever to witness a swimming meet at Yale, attended.

Squadron C granted six goals handicap to the Crusaders and then came through to win, 17 1/2 to 15 1/2, in the Class A exhibition that featured the program of indoor polo at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night.

To the Music Editor: I have read with great interest your article regarding the career of Signer Antonio Scotti, reprinted here by the Border Cities Star, local paper of my home town of Windsor, Ont. I used to live fortytwo years ago in Newark, N.J., and very often went to New York to hear the operas.

FREDERICK Allen's "Only Yesterday" was a book of palpable happenings. Beauty contests could be seen; the Younger Generation could be heard; flagpole sitters vied with gulls and crows as tangible objects thrown against the sky; William Jennings Bryan, sitting on a raft in a Florida lagoon and calling down blessings on the real estate market, was indubitably a phenomenon of the flesh.

Retailers here began, during the week to gird themselves for a strong fight against the enactment of a retail sales tax in this State. Although threatened for some time, the issue assumed major importance with the recommendation, to the Legislature by Governor Lehman of a levy of three-quarters of 1 per cent upon retail sales.

CASTEL GANDOLFO, Italy, Jan. 23 -- A second Vatican is in the course of preparation in this quaint old town, one side of which overhangs Lake Albano, fifteen miles south of Rome, while the other offers that famous view over the vast sweep of the Roman Campagna and far out to sea.

PARIS, Jan. 24 -- The city government of Paris apparently isn't any more popular with its apartment tenants than are a lot of individual landlords. More than 200 occupants of apartment houses recently constructed by the municipality in order to relieve the housing problem are on strike.

WE have not yet done with the age whose fashions were immortalized by the distinguished American llustrators A.B. Wenzell and Charles Dana Gibson. The period covered the last years of the reign of Queen Victoria, when nineteenth-century femininity armed itself against the attack of twentieth-century emancipation.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Yale's hockey team, apparently none the worse for a ten-day layoff, came back tonight and pinned an impressive 5-to-2 defeat on the St. Nicholas Club of New York. George Robson, Yale sophomore, led the Eli scoring with two goals.

The story of a "charming and lovable dragon," who composes poetry and is too tired to employ the devastating attributes of his fire-breathing forebears, has been chosen by the Junior League Players as the theme for their second production of the season.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Rutgers University fraternities terminated a four-day initiation period today with the formal induction of 122 men into twenty Greek letter organizations. Ninety-two of the initiates were members of the freshman class and all but three of the remainder were sophomores.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- A bill which has been urged by its Congressional sponsors as the only credit resource for many a hardpressed farmer because law today by President Hoover's signature.

ITHACA, N.Y. AT attempt to humanize the engineer while he is being educated is under way at Cornell University. The man of technology, it is believed, is being called into administrative and executive positions, and the hope is to supply him.

WHILE Mr. Kenyon's book has its distinctive values for students and specialists, for the ordinary lover of books and for those interested in the ancient civilizations it will have an eerie sort of fascination because it brings so near and makes so real the booklover of twenty, thirty, forty centuries ago and makes the booklover of today feel own brother to him, dead and turned to dust though he has been for so many generations.

The first art exhibition to be held in Rockefeller Center opened with appropriate gestures and flourishes last evening on the twenty-seventh, floor of the R.K.O. Building, where the College Art Association has installed its 1933 International. This exhibition, representing some twenty-three nations, is distinctly alive, despite various handicaps under which it was assembled.

Mayor John P. O'Brien predicted last night that the city not only would live within its 1933 budget of $518,000,000, but would have a surplus left over to apply to expenses for 1934. He spoke at the thirty-seventh annual dinner of the Real Estate Board of New York at the Hotel Commodore.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- House Democrats drove another nail today into the lid under which they plan to smother Republican efforts for tariff boosts at this session.

VIENNA, Jan. 12, 1933 STEPS are being taken to found an Institution here for the assistance and encouragement of music students from the United States which, under the name of the American Musical Association of Vienna, shall be a sister body to the well-known American Medical Association of Vienna.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 4 -- A "voluntary, temporary suspension of foreclosures" was urged by Governor Horner today in an appeal to all holders of mortgages involving farmers and small home-owners.

NEAR Carmel, on the California coast, about 130 miles in a southerly direction from San Francisco, are two rocky headlands -- Cypress Point and Point Lobos -- forming respectively the northern and southern arms of Carmel Bay.

ARTISTS who have been associated with Giulio Gatti-Casazza in his twenty-five years at the Metropolitan continued all last week to forward their acceptances to the committee which is making plans for the "gala" concert and "surprise party" to be held at the Metropolitan on Sunday evening, Feb. 26, in commemoration of Mr. Gatti's quarter of a century as the director of New York's opera.

THE author of that prodigious, World War spy thriller, "The W Plan," has here produced a tale equally steep and sanguinary, one which involves no less a catastrophe than the outbreak of hostilities between England and Soviet Russia.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Featured by a sensational match between Rowland B. Haines, three-time national squash tennis champion, and P.W. Bunnell, former Yale football star, the first annual Invitation squash racquets tournament of the Round Hill Club got under way today and reached the semi-final stage.

THE growing use of murals as a unifying and significant part of a room's ensemble is rapidly reuniting the fine arts with interior decoration. Paintings for overmantel and overdoor spaces, special niches and recessed panels are often planned when a house is buit or an interior decorated.

The forthcoming publication of a ten-volume history of the State of New York, edited by Dr. Alexander C. Flick, State historian, was announced yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the trustees of the New York State Historical Association, held in the Times Annex, 229 West Forty-third Street.

More than 3,000 men, women and children, including a few Japanese, paraded yesterday noon through Wall Street from the East River to Broad Street and then down to the Battery to demonstrate against the Japanese actions in Manchuria and China and against the wars in South America.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Great Britain was accused in the Senate today of undertaking by "secret diplomacy" in advance of the World Economic Conference to reach international agreements detrimental to American shipping.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 4 -- In the first scholastic sailing dinghy regatta ever held, the Port Washington High School today emerged the winning salt water aggregation. Its young windjamming navigators scored 33 points, to 29 for Manhasset High School and 21 for Great Neck High School in a triangular event on Manhasset Bay.

LONDON, Feb 3 -- From widely separated sources have come indications this week that British foreign policy was suddenly swerving in the direction in which the United States has long wanted it to move.

BERLIN. THE present German Government has been going in strong for the system of permits (Kontingente) for the importation of foreign products. But in the film world it doesn't seem to be able to keep out the American talker.

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 4 -- The Greenwich Citizens Committee, headed by Deputy Sheriff Charles W. Carvette, is raising a fund to start mandamus proceedings in the Superior Court at Bridgeport on the refusal of the Board of Selectmen to call a special town meeting to take action on a change in the method of distributing funds by the emergency relief committee and town Charity Department.
WASHINGTON. TWO amendments in the War Department bill, passed by the House and now being considered by the Senate Military Affairs Committee, are being fought bitterly by the service men.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 4 -- Dr. Alleyne M. Baldwin. 64 years old, leader in Ohio Masonic circles and a noted surgeon, died today at his home here after an illness of more than a year.

ECONOMIC upheaval has not halted the development of new materials and process in industry. Recently Dr. H. C. Parmele, vice president and editorial director of the McGraw. Hill engineering periodicals, presented a list of what he called "depression inventions" to the science forum of the New York Electrical Society.

On the whole, it was a simple and comfortable sort of globe on which we lived until the close of the last century. Although it was cold, deep down there was molten magma that aided the sun and the atmosphere in keeping us warm. When the internal pressure became too great the magma rushed out through safety-valves which we called volcanoes.

CHICAGO, Feb. 2 -- Chicagoans are gradually becoming conscious of a new importance attaching to their city as the centre of a metropolitan region. The first comprehensive study of problems involved in that point of view was published the other day as the result of research by the Political Science Department of the University of Chicago, under the direction of Professor Charles H. Merriam.

There has been quite a flurry of questions asked all over, not alone the city, but the whole country -- "What about a suspension of amortization? Some prominent life insurance companies have come out and said what they are doing in connection with farm mortgages.

In the absence of any special incentive to speculative enterprise, the share market continued yesterday its idle and meaningless movement. The maximum scope of the fluctuations was not wide and the net changes, even in the small group of active stocks, were confined to small fractions as a rule.

The abolition of intercollegiate athletics is opposed by Dr. Edward S. Elliott, director of athletics at Columbia University, in his annual report, submitted yesterday to President Nicholas Murray Butler.

IT was somewhat of a surprise to find Victor releasing the Elgar violin concerto (B minor Op. 61) and "In the South" overture so soon after their first issue in London. Incidentally, it is strange that it took the English companies so long to get round to doing the right and proper thing by the outstanding living native composer.

Chancellor Luther A. Campbell of New Jersey was honored last night at a dinner in the Hotel Pennsylvania attended by more than 600 representatives of the New Jersey bench, bar and Legislature. Chancellor Campbell, formerly a Supreme Court Justice, was appointed to his State's highest judicial office by Governor Moore on Oct. 15.
Ernest T. Weir, president of the National Steel Company, said yesterday that a further reduction in wages in that industry would be unfair to labor, according to The Associated Press.

A 10,000,000-acre irrigation project is one of the Soviet plans in preparation for which Russian agronomists have been making world-wide studies for the last two years, according to Professor N.I. Vavilov, director of the Soviet Institute of Plant Industry, who sailed for home last week.

To all publishers and politicians, to all lobbyists and librarians, to all authors, orators and proofreaders, we commend the annual report of that Great Panjandrum of the Pressmen, the Public Printer:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Bank debits outside New York City declined during the week ended Jan. 28 to about the December weekly average, according to the weekly survey of domestic business conditions made public today by the Commerce Department, but it was explained that this indicated "no particular change in the turnover of bank credit."

Z.G. Simmons and J.H. Wantling tied for the high scratch honors at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot with a card of 97 out of 100 targets. In the shoot-off, Simmons broke 25 straight to annex the cup.

LONDON, Sunday, Feb. 5 -- Ships of a new type which may revolutionize the world's trade at sea have been designed by Sir Joseph Isherwood, noted naval architect, and will be built within the next six months.

Discussing some of the realty problems of the present day and future possibilities, Stewart Forshay, vice president of the firm of Byrne Bowman, says that during that firm's thirty years of experience in the real estate field there has never been a better opportunity to invest in well-located, well-planned and properly managed apartment houses than the present time.

BISHOP LEETE defends his subtitle description of Palestine as the "Land of Light" with the argument that, aside from its religious significance, "this tiny, stony, impoverished strip of the earth's surface" has produced "more seers, heroes and saints than a vast continent."

GENEVA, Feb. 3 -- There is hope, not to say expectation, in international circles here that Franklin D. Roosevelt's inauguration as President of the United States will mark an important development in the evolution of American policy toward abandoning the doctrine of neutral rights.

HELSINGFORS, Finland, Feb. 4 -- Deportations from the Leningrad area of Soviet Russia, in consequence of the new policy of evacuating undesirable sections of the population, are beginning to assume the proportions of a wholesale exodus, according to news received here.

Firing point blank from amidst a crowd in a subway car in the 181st Street station of the I.R.T. subway, an unemployed and homeless plumber shot and fatally wounded Sergeant Eugene Monahan of the Wadsworth Avenue station, last night, slightly wounded a woman bystander and threw the train and the station into an uproar.

Some of the earliest history of Chicago, or at least of the site upon which the city stands, is contained in an article in the February Issue of Field Museum News, the monthly bulletin published for the members of Field Museum of Natural History.

The Spring term of the city's public schools will begin tomorrow with a record enrolment in the senior high schools which will require members of the supervisory staff and administrative assistants to supplement the regular teaching staff.

OTTAWA, Feb. 2 -- Liquor sales by the Quebec Liquor Commission as reported for the last fiscal year, were $17,979,782, as compared with $22,711,639 for the preceding year and $27,539,966 two years earlier.

Senator HAHRISON, who will be chairman of the Finance Committee in the next Congress, is the author of the resolution under which the present chairman, Senator SMOOT, has asked fifty-five persons, most of them of national distinction, to give their views, privately or publicly, to the committee I on the causes of the depression and on remedies for it.
