Price trends in yesterday's local commodity trading were uneven, although the sum total of changes indicates a continuation of the firm undertone. Rubber, hides and silver recorded minor gains, while others were steady and unchanged or slightly lower.

With the combined specialty shows of the Associated Terrier Clubs as its objective, the vanguard of the great gathering of dog lovers that annually comes to New York during the month of February will crowd the Grand Central Palace next Saturday.

HAVING decided to visit the Orient and take "Old Bill" of blessed wartime memory with him as valet or batman, Bruce Bairnsfather determined that he would go through Asia in an Asiatic spirit and that he would see to it that Old Bill did likewise.

After having been defeated in its past two games, St. John's College regained its winning stride and repulsed N.Y.U.'s basketball team, 26 to 19, in a stirring battle at the 102d Engineers' Armory last night. A crowd of more than 3,000 saw the contest.

YEOVIL, England, Feb. 4 -- The Houston-Westland airplane, which will be used to fly over Mount Everest, has reached 35,000 feet in a test flight. The temperature at that height over England was considerably lower than it probably will be over Mount Everest.

CHICAGO. THE Hoosier Salon, the ninth of the series, current in the galleries of Marshall Field's huge department store, demonstrates that I have been too modest heretofore in regarding it as a psychological penomenon rather than as an art manifestation.

IN "The Imitation of Life" Fannie Hurst shows clearly the wear and tear of her determination to become the story-teller of the millions. Rarely has a book by a novelist who has accomplished fine things in the past been so stamped with the resolve to have it enormously read.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 4 -- Ch. Heather Reveller of Sporran, the famous Scotch terrier owned by S.S. Van Dine of New York City and handled in the ring by William Prentice, tonight was named best of nearly 600 dogs that have been competing for two days in the twentieth annual show of the Maryland Kennel Club.

Complete control of the Democratic organization in the State by the Roosevelt forces under the direction of State and National Chairman James A. Farley has been achieved, according to trust worthy information, to the extent that even a re-formation of the Tammany alliance with up-State organizations would fall far short of the influence it wielded a year ago.

ITEMS of interest of the twelfth week of the Metropolitan Opera season will be the debut of Eide Norena, Norwegian soprano, as Mimi, in "La Boheme," and the first performance this season of "La Sonnambula," with Lily Pons.

MEXICO CITY, Mexico, Feb. 3 -- Fernando Gonzales Roa, Mexico's new Ambassador to the United States, follows some brilliant men in that post. There was Don Manuel Tallez, who represented this country for eleven years and became dean of the diplomatic corps, and the most recent incumbent, Dr. Manuel Puig Casauranc, who is now Minister of Foreign Affairs.

Need for stricter control over the floating of local bond issues and the provision of proper facilities for appeal by the taxpayers are urged by Ulysses G. Stock-well of Albany, president of the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards. "The ease with which local bond issues may be passed has reacted to the detriment of the taxpayer," Mr. Stockwell says.

Two men believed by the police to be members of a gang that has been possing thousands of dollars' worth of spurious travelers checks of the North German Lloyd Line were held in Yorkville Court yesterday for hearings on Feb. 10 on charges of conspiracy.

IN these days when Sunday articles and daily reviews of concerts appear, discoursing high aspects of the art of music, many musicians suffer and starve, and even distinguished representatives find it difficult to sell very many seats for their recitals.

The Noel Coward play, "Design for Living," the current attraction at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre, at several of its prospective performances, will further the work of various philanthropic endeavors. The show tomorrow night will aid the Professional Children's School, which provides an education for youngsters who are engaged in various professional occupations connected with the stage and who, because of their work, are unable to attend public schools.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The Cabinet's gain will be the Senate's heavy, perhaps irreparable, loss, if Carter Glass, Cordell Hull and Thomas J. Walsh accept invitations to head Federal departments under Franklin D. Roosevelt.

A NEW pantomime-ballet with singing parts included was recently given in Zagreb, the Croatian city of Yugoslavia. The work is called "Gold," with text and choreography by Bela Pecic and music by Boris Papandopulo. This seems to make it a Yugoslav-Russian-Hungarian-Greek collaboration, as Gerhard Krause points out in a review in Die Signale, wherein he highly praises the joint endeavors of the young authors.
Washington, D.C., Feb. 3 R.S. Hecht, Hibernia Bank and Trust Company, New Orleans.

A survey of the situation by Seidman Seidman, public accountants of this city, in the current issue of Buildings and Building Management, indicates that, while the volume of business has generally been seriously curtailed, the taxation business has materially increased.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 4 -- The Naval Academy swimmers, in their season's opening meet today, defeated the University of Virginia, 62 to 9 and gave promise of brilliant performances in the coming Intercollegiate Association matches.
BERLIN, Jan. 20 WHAT is the Deutsches Theater? An antiquated old box of a house, looking out on a gloomy courtyard. Its exterior has no architectural beauties except those of Spartan simplicity.

AMERICAN readers will be glad to find various "New Phases of American Art" illustrated in the February number of The London Studio, just at hand -- reproductions, these prove to be, of paintings and sculpture in the 1862-1932 exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.

LONDON. BEFORE long somebody in England, or possibly in America, may be going about wearing proudly a woolen scarf that was knitted by the Prince of Wales. For the heir to the British throne knits and crochets, too, enjoys doing both and does both unusually well.

Many boxes and seats have been purchased for the special performance of "Parsifal" on the afternoon of Feb. 13 at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance. The occasion will mark the tenth anniversary of the founding of the New York chapter of the alliance by Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson and the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Richard Wagner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- President-elect Roosevelt's decision to consult with Congressional committees during the coming British debt negotiations attracted particular interest among Democratic members of both houses today. Most conversation concerned the personnel of such a committee, which it was believed would not be one of the standing committees but a carefully selected group.

DETROIT, Feb. 4 -- Henry Ford is now well along in the development of a radically new industrial process which may prove to be as significant as was his introduction of modern methods of mass production a generation ago.

WHAT'S the matter with Congress? Why doesn't it function? These queries are the daily utterances of hundreds of thousands: they are found in thousands of letters now pouring into Washington. And candor compels the admission that the expressed impatience and displeasure on the part of the people with the Congress are not infrequently justified.
Following Friday's rally, prices on the Cotton Exchange worked back yesterday to previous low levels of the week, recovered part of the decline and closed with net losses of 5 to 6 points.

ONCE upon a time, when rows were hard to hoe and there was poverty in the homeland, people set sail for frontier countries. Either they arrived at their proper destinations or they were cast ashore on desert islands. In the latter case, the Swiss Family Robinsons proceeded to rescue cheeses from the holds of ships, caught lobsters at low tide, snared animals and generally lived more easily than the inhabitants of the Hoovervilles.

PARIS. TO judge by one's first impression of the Spring and Summer millinery openings, every one is about to burst out in a straw sailor, and it is certain that we shall see a great many of them in the early Spring.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Rudolph Spreckels, New York and California sugar refiner, in a letter today to Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, protested against the impending debt negotiations between President-elect Roosevelt and foreign governments and said if Europe could afford to default America could refuse to pay the bonds behind the loans.

Experts in the transportation problems of the port of New York find in the report of Examiner Earl M. Steers to the Interstate Commerce Commission, in which elimination of free lighterage of freight is recommend, prospects of a development of traffic at the contract terminals of the port, which are in South Brooklyn.

PARIS. IN THE Chamber of Commerce of Marseilles there hangs the Swiss flag that flew from the stern of the river boat Helvetia which, manned by fifty Swiss athletes, was piloted through the shoals and rapids of the Rhone last year from the Swiss border to the Mediterranean.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- The London Stock Exchange witnessed today what was described as easily the biggest Saturday since the war, with the Kaffir boom the highest since the recent gold rush began. When the Exchange closed at 12:30 hundreds of brokers started the biggest street market the London financial district has ever seen.

THERE is some sort of magic in ships," says Mr. Philip Hone, under the date of Dec. 16, 1846, in the version of his diary provided by Mr. Laing for the purposes of this narrative, "and in this ship (the Sea Witch) more than in any other I ever saw."

The applications of officials of the Union Pacific and the Delaware Hudson railroads to serve on the New York Central Railroad's board are expected to show whether the Interstate Commerce Commission intends to uphold policies discouraging interlocking directorships outlined in its plan of consolidation drawn up in 1929.

The current week brings with it one of the unique college events, the Dartmouth Winter carnival, which each Winter, for a day or two, transforms the little town of Hanover in the New Hampshire hills into a replica of a Swiss mountain resort.

Dr. Samuel Marshall, 45 years old, a dentist of 414 West 120th Street, was instantly killed last night shortly after 9 o'clock.

The difficult problem of farm mortgages, brought into the news last week by protest meetings in several States and the decision of a number of leading insurance companies to suspend foreclosures, is discussed in an article in the Feature Section of THE TIMES today.

Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, president of the Society for the Prevention of Crime, informed Police Commissioner Mulrooney yesterday that the organization had offered a $1,000 reward to anybody who would furnish information that would lead to the arrest and conviction of the three gunmen who held up two employes last Wednesday and damaged twenty-seven privately owned automobiles with acid and knives in the Carlyle Garage at 354 East Seventy-sixth Street.

HAYS, Kan., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A romance of politics today led to the marriage of Miss Kathryn O'Loughlin, Representative - in - Congress-elect, and State Senator Daniel M. McCarthy, a lawyer of Mankato, Kan.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 2 -- Until a few days ago it looked as if the direct primary system in Pennsylvania might be doomed. In the special session of the Legislature last Summer a primary repeal bill was put through the Senate, 26 to 20, just as a "feeler."

January retail business responded where extraordinary efforts were put forth in order to obtain it, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Stores making such endeavors had decreases smaller than the general average.

THROUGHOUT the world the Scot has stood for generations in the full glare of the limelight. As soldier and statesman, as scientist, explorer and merchant, he is found everywhere a maker of history. His proverbial solicitude for the bawbees, as he calls his ha pennies, has inspired a wealth of anecdote as abundant as stories of fishing.

BERLIN, Feb. 4 -- In a tumultuous session that was repeatedly adjourned to restore order, the Prussian Diet, elected in April, 1932, refused to declare itself dissolved today, the Communists supporting the Socialists, Centrists and Democrats in rejecting the National Socialists' motion by a vote of 214 to 196.

When the doors of Madison Square Garden are opened at 9 o'clock on Monday morning, Feb. 13, for the forty-seventh annual three-day dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club there will be just 2,236 dogs of seventy-five distinct breeds barking a welcome from the benches in the exhibition hall.

VIENNA, Feb. 3 -- The appointment of Adolf Hitler as Chancellor of Germany redoubled the anxieties of the Little Entente States and raised correspondingly the hopes of the revisionist bloc headed by Italy, which is now openly committed to upsetting peace treaties which France and the Little Entente are committed to upholding to the last.

ISTANBUL, Feb. 3 -- Progress as the watchword of the new Turkey is not an easy one to live up to in the present state of the world, but Turkey is suffering less than most other countries from the depression and is ready to make sacrifices to achieve the social and economic development that are near her heart.

Uncertainty over the course of tax legislation at Washington is restricting national advertising schedules, according to comment here yesterday, and large companies are keeping their budgets as flexible as possible. Contrary to general forecasts made in the last quarter of 1932, the volume of linage being bought is somewhat under that of last year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 2 -- The ghost of one of the tragedies of the World War walks abroad with, the filing for probate of the will of Dr. Theodor Holm, Danish-American, botanist and explorer. The scientist bequeathed his unparalleled collections and library to the Belgian Government for the University of Louvain.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Southern Californians who like their college football watched in amazement today as the Green Bay Packers professional team put on a remarkable exhibition of passing to defeat an all-star eleven, 19 to 6.

THE eleventh annual exhibition of "Fifty Books of the Year." conducted by the American institute of Graphic Arts, will be held in Room 112 of the New York Public Library from Feb. 9 to March 5, daily from 9 A.M. to 6 P.M., Sundays from 1 to 5 P.M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Representative Rainey, taking a hand in a plan to build the navy quickly up to London Treaty strength, received today from Secretary Adams a communication showing that, if no other construction were carried on before the fiscal year 1936 ends, the United States would have 156 over-age vessels out of a total of 225 vessels of all types.

Hopes of a quick recovery in commodity prices to former "normal" levels are not borne out by previous economic history and should not be permitted to stand in the way of needed revaluation of capital assets, according to Philip M. Davis of the engineering firm of Ford, Bacon Davis.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Secretary Mills's recent tedious and rather involved diatribe on the dangers of inflation is most unconvincing. Let us consider for a moment the fundamental facts underlying the present deplorable situation.

AT the international civil aeronautics conference in Washington five years ago General Electric engineers described a series of experiments on sonic altimeters and landing instruments based on the success of the sonic depth finders which have been in use all over the world for fifteen or twenty years.

Endowed with millions and a domineering personality. Goddard is the Grand Mogul of Barchester, Pa. The press, schools and the church do his bidding with the alacrity of Tammany ward-heelers tipped off by the Big Boss.
LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Communists threaten to make trouble tomorrow when more than 100,000 trade unionists march on Hyde Park for a mass protest against the government's unemployment policy.

LIKE a white light thrust down into the depths of Irish politics, the recent historic election in the Free State threw up the grim and gigantic shadows of three distinct Irish armies -- the official army of the Free State: the invisible army of the Irish Republic; and the White Army, without military weapons, which was formed to resist the "intimidatory practices" of the Republican Army.

THE Secret of Madame Blanche," which is at the Capitol, is a tale of mother love which begins back in the '90s. Irene Dunne, who learned to age gracefully in "Cimarron." spans a period of thirty years in this chronicle. Opposite her is Phillips Holmes, and otherwise prominent in the cast are Lionel Atwill, Una Merkel. C. Henry Gordon and Jean Parker.

LAKE PLACID -- Winter Sports at Lake Placid will reach their height this month, with colorful national and international events listed on the program. Ideal weather has prevailed recently and several inches of soft snow have blanketed elopes and mountain trails, improving "all sports facilities.

Purchases of rolling stock by railroads in 1932 reached the lowest levels recorded since 1901. This decline reflected mostly the great drop in traffic that followed the ending of the 1929 inflation, although to a lesser extent it was a result of a trend in the last decade toward the installation of smaller numbers of more powerful locomotives and larger freight cars.

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 2 -- Farm relief seems to be as important an issue in Kentucky this year as in any Western commonwealth. Despite the fact that a fair price was obtained for the 1932 tobacco crop, the sale of thousands of farms for taxes has been advertised.

LONDON, Feb. 4 -- Some British editors are discussing whether Neville Chamberlain was right in speaking so bluntly to the United States as he did last Wednesday. Tomorrow's Observer, for example, says he "grimly, but of necessity, paraded facts and resisted sentiment," but adds:

Members of the Maplehurst Alumnae will hold their annual card party for the benefit of their charitable fund on Thursday afternoon at the River Club. The proceeds will be devoted to the philanthropic activities of the organization.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Reports in THE NEW YORK TIMES of a revolt by terror in Cuba were read today with deepest interest by officials with a feeling that the situation might before long come to a head, but without any indication that President Hoover, with only four weeks left to his administration, would do anything about it.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Jan. 10 -- What brought about this wholesale desertion of the Republican standard in Alaska where that party normally musters safe majorities is clearly not so plain as the Democratic victories in the States. The depression has manifested itself in Alaska but by no means to the extent that prevailed in most other parts of the Union.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 4 -- Invitations were issued today to 39,000 Yale alumni to visit the university on Alumni University Day, Feb. 22. A prograrn, which includes a morning meeting, a luncheon, followed by brief addresses, visits to classrooms and laboratories, a special performance of "Passee," by Marion Morgan, in the University Theatre, the annual de Forest prize speaking, several athletic events, and several unusual exhibitions has been arranged.

PASADENA, Cal., Feb. 4 (AP) -- The stratosphere above equatorial regions of the earth should be the next scene of exploration in the quest of the secrets of the cosmic ray, Dr. Robert A. Millikan said here today.

PARIS. A NEW picture by Rene Clair has just been shown in Paris and of course, it is the talk of the town, so far as films are concerned. His pictures are, indeed, worthy of world-wide attention, for certainly no producer anywhere, except Charles Chaplin, whom he so closely resembles, has brought to the cinema a genius so original, or so great, as Rene Clair.

THE average vehicle In active service is four and one-half years old, in the opinion of George L. Brunner, president of the Motor and Equipment Manufacturers Association, who points out that of a total of 24,536,000 cars and trucks registered on Dec. 31, 1932, at least 11,370,000 are in their fifth year of active service, 6,568,000 in their fourth year, 2,510,000 in their third year and 2,472.000 in their second year.

Bond prices on the Stock Exchange moved irregularly lower in quiet trading yesterday. German loans continued under pressure, although, part of the group recovered a little of the ground lost in the last few days. The German Government issues were among the weakest, the 7s losing 2 points and the 5 1/2s 1 1/8 points for the day.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Representative Hamilton Fish of New York was charged today with starting a run on the Hibernia Bank and Trust Company here by Rudolph S. Hecht, president of the bank, by his recent criticism of Mr. Hecht before the House Banking Committee in connection with Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to the defunct Union Indemnity Company of New Orleans.

NUREMBERG, Bavaria. THE magic surrounding the name of Hans Sachs has had a curious effect here. In these hard times, when nobody buys shoes who does not have to do so -- save tourists wishing to take home something with a local flavor -- there has arisen a strong desire among the Nuremberg shoemakers to appropriate to themselves some echo of the fame of the Meistersinger of the sixteenth century whom Wagner immortalized.

GILBERT MILLER is off for Hollywood to direct pictures for Columbia under that contract which the company announced while the producer was in London. Mr. Miller will remain in California for ten weeks, returning thereafter to his familiar haunts in New York and possibly London again.

Before the United States can settle its growing pension problem the magnitude of the obligations which any pension system, governmental or private, will place upon the present and future generations must be thoroughly investigated and understood, the Metropolitan Life Insurance Company's latest monograph on social insurance, made public yesterday, declares.

DALLAS, Feb. 7 -- The insurance lobbies set up in Austin for this session of the Legislature have almost crowded all others out of the capital. More strenuous than ever are this year's efforts to repeal the Robertson insurance law that since 1907 has compelled life insurance companies doing business here to invest 75 per cent of their Texas reserves in Texas securities.

LONDON, Jan. 27 -- Like a periscope of a submarine, a thing sticks out from the reply sent from London to the invitation which has come from Washington to open the discussion of war debts in conjunction with other economic problems.

BURLINGTON, Vt., Feb. 2 -- Did Vermont or New Hampshire win the boundary line suit, according to the findings of Special Master in Chancery Edmund F. Trabue of Louisville, Ky., filed with the Supreme Court of the United States about a week ago?

PARIS. VERY seldom has a centenary exhibition attracted so much attention as that recently opened in the Orangerie in the Tuileries, of souvenirs of the tragic life of the King of Rome -- the son of the Emperor Napoleon Bonaparte.

MOUNT CARMEL, Ill., Feb 4 (AP) -- A business holiday of a week and two days ended here today with all business places opening and the town's only bank, the American-First National, resuming business on a limited basis.

MASSAPEQUA, L.I., Feb. 4 -- Nassau County authorities investigating the murder of Mary Helen O'Connor, 15-year-old Rockaway Park high school student, whose body was found last Thursday in a pile of underbrush here, are now virtually convinced that the girl was murdered on Jan. 27, the day she disappeared from her home.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition for the first time a rare collection of prints, lithographs, wood-cuts, etchings, photographs, advertisements, pamphlets, books and newspapers dealing with the early history of stage coach days and those of the pony express in California between 1847 and 1860.

Charging that depreciated currency tariff bills now before Congress are full of pitfalls for American business and will increase the bad blood already existing among nations, Hubert Deplanche, president of the Mercantile Import and Export Corporation, yesterday appealed to the New York State delegation in Congress to vote against the measures.

LONDON, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Aston Villa and Sheffield Wednesday today whittled down Arsenal's lead in the English League, first division, as they won while the Gunners were being held to a 1-1 draw by Everton. The Villans defeated Portsmouth, 4-1, and the Wednesday won from its town rival, United, 3 -- 2.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- Army won handily from the New York University swimming team today by a score of 48 to 23. The cadets took six first places in the eight events contested. Frank, in the 440-yard event, and Altschuler, in the century swim, were the Violets' only winners.

Leiter (1834-1904), who began his career as a clerk in a country store and ended it as one of the nation's leading capitalists. To the Editor of The New York Times: In a recent address over the radio Mme. Paul Dupuy, owner of several Paris publications, expressed amazement at the amount of news from Europe that your better newspapers print.

WASHINGTON. WHEN President Hoover asked the Tariff Commission last October to inquire into the effect of depreciated currencies of foreign nations on the activities of American industry he set in motion an agitation which has now become an important factor in national and international politics.
WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- A fast moving University of Pittsburgh five vanquished Army's basketball quintet today in a wellplayed contest, 42 to 25.

"Moor Born," one of the many recently written plays baaed on the lives of the Bronte sisters, will be tested on Tuesday, Feb. 14, under the auspices of the University of Iowa, Iowa City. It is the work of Dan Totheroh, who was last represented on the Broadway stage a year ago by "Distant Drums."

PARIS, Feb. 2 -- The few Summer collections shown up to the present permit no definite conclusions to be formed as lo general style movements. Beltless loose straight coats and jackets prevail, but some belted above-the-knee-length suit coats indicate a possible trend in this direction.

PARIS, Jan. 25 -- Attendance at charitable functions and lectures by well-known men of letters constitute a considerable part of the fashionable round during the pre-Lenten season. Several of the outstanding litterateurs can always count upon a mundane audience, when their talks deal with French literature and history, or other subjects which are closely related to the intellectual and spiritual interests of France.

A New York shopper who put $1,000,000 into his bill case and went out to purchase precious articles would have to come back for more money before he reached the end of his list.

THIS is a book to be placed near the top of one's list of Spring reading. Sponsored by the Japan Society of New York on the occasion of its twenty-fifth anniversary and based on a series of lectures given by Professor Anesaki at the Fogg Museum of Harvard University, it is authentically -- though quietly -- important and ranks among the better books of the month.
AIKEN -- Aiken's season 13 taking on greater liveliness as the month of February advances, and outdoor sports of many kinds are attracting large followings in the Winter colony.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 4 -- President-elect Roosevelt pushed off "to unknown seas" today for an eleven-day fishing trip, the last vacation he will have before he enters the White House on March 4.

IN these days when some American school doors are swinging ominously near to closing, many an anxious citizen is becoming acutely conscious that there is no one central educational authority to whom general appeal can be made. The school's fate rests with a vast scattered amateur government, composed of half a million laymen -- butchers, bakers, candlestick makers -- sitting on 150,000 school boards.

Douglas Fairbanks was among the passengers sailing yesterday for the South of France and for Italy on the Conte Di Savoia which had 250 in the first class and 850 passengers altogether. The actor sailed for Genoa. He will meet his wife, Mary Pickford, in Rome.

THIS book is supposed to present -- or at least the publisher's blurb is sure that it does present -- an authoritative view of "what the youth of today is seeing and thinking in a world still dominated by the old and middle-aged."

CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- A local professional trader who had been long on May wheat went out of his holding early today on the Board of Trade here and, with selling by smaller traders, this caused a break of 3/4 cent a bushel to the lowest level since Jan. 5 and with in 2 3/4 cents of the lowest prices of the crop year.
The fourteenth annual Aviators Ball will be given on Saturday night at Essex House in an effort to replenish the welfare and relief fund of the Aviators' Post of the American Legion.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Geneva's reception to the French security-disarmament plan at the reopening of the disarmament conference has served to show how great is the opposition to the plan in France. From the first it was obvious that Edouard Herriot and Joseph Paul-Boncour had put forward a suggestion which was certain to be combated with the utmost vigor at home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- In response to the demand of Senator Robinson of Indiana that the State Department curb the alleged diplomatic activities of William C. Bullitt in Europe, the department is inquiring of its embassies and legations in London and on the Continent whether they have any information concerning Mr. Bullitt's present activities.

IF listeners observe a stronger signal from KYW, Chicago, it is because the engineers have developed what they call a "concentrator aerial." They contend this is the first major radio achievement in 1933.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Enactment of a law making all prison sentences really indeterminate, investing the State Board of Parole with full authority to consider the cases of convicts after they have served one year and supervision by the board until the expiration of the maximum sentence is urged by Commissioner Bernard J. Fagan, in charge of the New York area.

Sweeping changes in the form of our government within the next few years were predicted last night by Edward R. Finch, presiding justice of the Appellate Division, at a testimonial dinner to former Supreme Court Justice Thomas W. Churchill, in the Hotel Roosevelt.

A question frequently asked by foreign visitors here is "When are you "going to have a dictator in the United "States?" This is not so ludicrous a misreading of our political unrest as it might seem. Few Americans are ready to give up their existing form of government as a dead failure, but many are saying, or sighing, that it ought to be supplemented or reinvigorated and directed by some great personality.

The frequent assertion that the present period of depression is "the worst in the world's history" is one of those generalizations which needs a more accurate test than is commonly applied. Some phenomena of the day have undoubtedly taken more formidable shape than in other periods of the kind -- the scope of the three-year decline in prices, for instance, and the dislocation of many foreign currencies.

Moscow. IN the lurid scenes of Russia's history her peasants have been a dark background, unknown yet ominous by sheer weight of numbers. From the Middle Apes, when Russia threw off the yoke of Tartar invaders only to begin another struggle against Western enemies, until the end of the nineteenth century the peasants played for the most part a passive role quite out of keeping with their numerical importance.

Aknusti and Los Nanduces maintained their tie at the head of the Metropolitan Indoor Polo League last night, Los Nanduces taking a hard fought extra period match from Squadron A, 7 to 6, and Aknusti defeating Fort Hamilton, 17 1/2 to 9.

A fighting Rutgers basketball team, which rallied strongly in the second half after being held to 8 points in the first period, made City College travel fast at the C.C.N. Y. gymnasium last night before the Lavender could win, 35 -- 21, for its ninth victory of the season in ten starts.

PARIS. IT is a superb compliment for a French work to be recognized by English historians as the best that has been written on "The History of England During the Nineteenth Century." The work is by Elie Halevy (Hachette publisher); the compliment has been paid to him by nearly all of his English critics.

The gayety and color of Smetana's "Bartered Bride," with its uproarious humor, its endless succession of lovely Bohemian folk melodies, came romping back to the Metropolitan yesterday afternoon after an absence of five years with a gusto that dissolved the solemnity wont to settle upon operatic audiences.

Taking the offensive in their battle against private label competitors, manufacturers of national advertised grocery products claimed yesterday that they had won an important victory in persuading a number of corporate chains to feature advertised goods more extensively this Spring.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- Broadening the scope of the Donnelly antimonopoly act to strike at racketeering was urged by Attorney General Bennett today in submitting a series of recommendations for new legislation at the present session.
CHICAGO, Feb. 4 -- Too young to quit at 71, Amos Alonzo Stagg is going West to carry on in the football world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- A bill providing for the remonetization of silver, probably along the general lines of the Pittman bill, which has already been reported favorably by a Senate committee, is expected to be completed and ready for introduction in the House about Feb. 11, Chairman Somers of the Coinage, Weights and Measures Committee announced today.

CONTINUED safety education, a stronger license laws and stricter enforcement contributed to the 13 per cent decrease in motor vehicle fatalities during 1932 in the opinion of National Safety Council officials. The council last week estimated the number of deaths for the year at 29,500, against 33,740 in 1931.

WHEN you run in debt," said Benjamin Franklin, "you give to another power over your liberty." In these times this maxim of Poor Richard has a serious meaning. To the farmer it epitomizes grim reality because his gross income is hardly more than three-fourths of what it was in 1910, while his debt is nearly three times as high as in that year.

GENUINE humor is the rarest thing in literature. The author who can make us chuckle to ourselves and perhaps occasionally even laugh out loud, without at the same time lowering our opinion of a large proportion of our fellow-beings, is a real benefactor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- When the Nourmahal steamed past Fort George into the Atlantic today, Franklin D. Roosevelt had not yet been informed whether Senator Carter Glass of Virginia will accept or reject his offer of the Treasury portfolio.

MATERNAL domination is the theme of this interesting character study. Familiar as that theme has become in fictional and stage presentations, Miss Zastrow has handled it in an original manner with logic in the motivation than have many of her predecessors.

WHEN one considers that thousands of musical pieces, ranging from simple folksongs to lengthy oratorios must be fed to the insatiable microphone annually, some idea may be had of the gigantic task that confronts radio's music librarians.

UNTIL within very recent years the science of law had undisputed sway over all matters concerned with crime and criminals. But its competence is now being disputed with ever-increasing frequency and confidence by the science of medicine.

RADIO'S bill this week presents a variety of entertainment featuring John McCormack, Irish tenor; Nathan Milstein, Russian violinist; Maria Kurenko, soprano; Lawrence Tibbett, baritone, and Helen Corbin Heinl, pianist. The Lopez and Waring orchestras open new programs, and as a novelty Paul Whiteman's orchestra will broadcast Grofe's latest melody.

The Vassar Club of New York yesterday gave its annual luncheon in the gold room of Sherry's. The event marked the tenth anniversary of the society. Dr. Henry Noble MacCracken, president of Vassar College, and Mrs. MacCracken, Professor Lucy Textor and the members of the board of trustees were the principal guests.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 4. -- A new stage in the evolution of the all-night lunch wagon was indicated here today with announcement of the formation of the Association of Dining Car Owners. The association plans to consolidate on a cooperative marketing basis the operations of individual lunch-wagon owners throughout the Greater New York area.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- W. Palmer Dixon and Herbert N. Rawlins, holders of the national racquets doubles championship, were beaten by Stanley W. Pearson and William C. Wright, former American titleholders, in the feature match of the intercity series at the Racquet Club today, but New York managed to gain an even break in the four matches.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Cuba's economic outlook for the immediate future is distinctly unfavorable, but for the long pull it is just as distinctly favorable, according to Americans in Havana best qualified to discuss such questions.

HOLLYWOOD. LILIAN HARVEY arrived this week and the town, usually suspicious of, if not antagonistic to, foreign stars, clasped her in its arms. Strange stories had preceded her. She was to have her own director, her own designer, her own orchestra leader, her own leading man -- in fact, in Hollywood's eyes she was going to be rather difficult to handle.

The natural propagation of game birds has been the dream of every conservation official in this country, but the difficulties encountered have discouraged most efforts. Thus it has happened that States have been forced to turn to the rearing of birds in captivity or to importation in order to provide a sufficient number to satisfy the demands of the public.

KANSAS CITY, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Society, aroused to feverish anxiety by the kidnapping and slaying of Charles A. Lindbergh Jr., is slowly but surely increasing penalties against the evil so drastically revealed.

A nation-wide colonization of unemployed men in work camps, such as the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration has established at Blauvelt in Rockland County, would "defeat the depression," Brig. Gen. Pelham D. Glassford, former head of the Washington police, declared yesterday on a visit to the camp.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- By the margin of one and thirteen-hundredths of a second, the Lake Placid Club Sno Birds, with Raymond F. Stevens at the wheel, today captured the national A.A.U. junior 4-man bobsled title on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Bankruptcy reform legislation to give debtors more lenient treatment than is possible under the generations-old procedure must, in the opinion of well-informed Senators, go over to the agenda of the special session of Congress expected to be called by President-elect Roosevelt.

Mrs. Ethel Keller, 43 years old, of Summit, N.J., was fatally injured yesterday when an automobile in which she was riding was in collision with a Public Service bus on the elevated highway across the Jersey meadows, at a point about 200 feet east of the bridge over the Passaic River.

GALLERY visitors belong to the reflective type, and quite a number are now asking themselves why we are suddenly so interested in the history of American art, why we are digging up beautiful old "primitives," giving memorial exhibitions of men long dead, showing the sequence of art since our beginning as a nation, and, most recently, trying, to trace connection between the different phases of our art and the influences that played upon their origin.

"We fear that the creation at the present time of a single central board responsible for the administration of the foreign missionary work of American Protestantism is not possible, however desirable it might be," says a pronouncement made by the prudential committee of the American Board of Commissioners for Foreign Missions.
LONDON, Feb. 4 (Canadian Press) -- A flight from England to Brazil, a distance of 4,800 miles, is to be the next effort of Captain J.A. Mollison, British transatlantic flier.

ROME, Feb. 4 -- A special military tribunal for the defense of the State, after a trial lasting only a few hours, found Professor Charles Eydoux, director of a polytechnic school in Paris, guilty of procuring information of a military character. He was sentenced to five years' imprisonment, of which three years were remitted by reason of the recent amnesty decree.

A picture of the Southern college professor, overworked and underpaid as compared with his more prosperous Northern colleagues, emerges from an investigation of the lack of research in Southern universities recently made by the Social Science Research Council.

AUGUSTA, Ga. AN event unusual in American history will occur here this week when Southern white people join with colored people in celebrating the fiftieth anniversary of Paine College, a Negro college conducted by members of the two racial groups.

WHEN Grete Wiesenthal makes her bow at the Biltmore Theatre next Sunday night the New York dance world will have what is practically, though not literally, its first opportunity to see the work of a dancer who played a prominent role In the history of the dance during that formative period just after Isadora Duncan had hurled her challenge into the face of traditionalism, and has occupied a prominent position in it ever since.

What is described as a new discovery for the early diagnosis of cancer, which, if corroborated by further investigation, may become one of the most important weapons found so far in the world-wide fight to reduce the enormous death-rate from the disease, is reported in Krasnaya Gazetta, official daily newspaper of the Leningrad Soviet.

MIAMI -- Numerous parties, both public and private, are on the program for this week in the Miami area. In many the St. Valentine theme will be predominant. In fact, it pervades even the field of sports. The St. Valentine's Day Championship will start on Saturday and continue through Feb. 14.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Most of the financiers, economists and industrialists who have been invited by the Senate Finance Committee to appear before it at hearings beginning Feb. 13 to discuss the causes of the economic depression and legislative remedies, have sent messages accepting the invitation, Senator Smoot, the committee chairman, said today.

One of the greatest collection of football minds to sit in on a clinical consideration of the rules of the game labored from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. at the New York A.C. yesterday. At the end of that long session the American Football Coaches Association brought forth a formal statement of its findings, giving the playing code a clean bill of health as it stands in the books.

Economic distress has become so acute in Vienna that several people are playing with the idea of renting their comfortable flats and moving into cheaper quarters, but practically no one has embraced the horrible idea seriously as yet, says The Associated Press.

The President's Research Committee on Social Trends finds that even after the coming of the slump the people of the United States were spending more than $10,000,000,000 yearly on recreation and amusement, it was announced yesterday at its headquarters, 230 Park Avenue.

The three public libraries in New York City are considering the question of participating in the retirement plan for librarians adopted recently by the American Library Association, Milton J. Ferguson, Chief librarian of the Brooklyn Public Library, said yesterday.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Golf again comes to the fore this week, with two of the leading tournaments of the Winter scheduled to start. The twenty-eighth annual St. Valentine's tournament for women, which annually attracts leading golfers of the North and South, will commence tomorrow and the thirteenth annual seniors' tournament, for men more than 55, will get under way on Saturday.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- In his sixty-eighth year Dr. Alfred Hugenberg has entered the German Cabinet for the first time. His inclusion brings to it not only one of the most resolute fighting personalities in Germany but also a man whose political, economic and financial views are so diametrically opposed to Chancellor Adolf Hitler's that it is difficult to see how they can work together.

IT is always distinctly interesting to read a novel which has nothing in common with other novels, which has a sense of life all its own and a personality wholly is author's, "God's Little Acre" is surely such a book. Leaving all other questions momentarily aside, no more original novel has appeared in America for a long while.

LONDON. THE early history of Virginia will soon become a familiar tale to a large number of English people who have hitherto known little or nothing about it. For David Garnett's "Pocahontas" is the book of the hour.

Due largely to his powerful hitting and the terrific speed he was able to muster and control when needed, Beekman Pool of the Harvard Club gained the metropolitan squash racquets championship yesterday at the University Club when he defeated William Coyle of the Montclair A.C.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Senator Watson, Republican floor leader, who was defeated for re-election, in a radio address over the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight, challenged the sincerity of campaign pledges made by the Democratic party, predicted that the incoming Congress would include mote Democratic "pork barrel" advocates and enemies of sound currency than now hold office, and called upon the Republican "minority" party to band together to uphold sound principles of government.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 4 -- With the Speakership race between Representatives Rainey, Byrns and McDuffie growing more heated as the time nears for the Democratic caucus to select a successor to Speaker Garner, friends of Mr. Rainey pointed out today that Southern States have predominated during the past fifty years, with only Missouri breaking the "solid South" in one instance -- that of Speaker Champ Clark from the Sixty-first to the Sixty-sixth Congress.

Following an extraordinary growth after the war, golf has now reached a point where its expansion will be slower, says Dr. Jesse F. Steiner, author of one of the chapters of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends entitled "Recreation and Leisure Time Activities."

Before more than 3,000 co-linguists, the Ukrainian Art Theatre presented last night at Mecca Temple what the singing actors announced as a first performance in America of their historic epic, "Mazeppa." The composer, Tchaikovsky, had himself, in 1891, stood near by to dedicate Carnegie Hall.

Before more than 3,000 co-linguists, the Ukrainian Art Theatre presented last night at Mecca Temple what the singing actors announced as a first performance in America of their historic epic, "Mazeppa." The composer, Tchaikovsky, had himself, in 1891, stood near by to dedicate Carnegie Hall.

BETHLEHEM, Pa., Feb. 4 -- The good and the bad in the machine age were discussed today in an address by Representative James M. Beck of Philadelphia at the homecoming alumni convocation of the Moravian College, from which he was graduated fifty-three years ago.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Mrs. Margaret Chesney, 33 years old, of 808 Warren Street, Harrlson, was killed and four persons were injured today when an automobile crashed Into a stalled bus on the main highway near Newark Airport. The police were unable to learn the identity of Mrs. Chesney until her husband, an unemployed special policeman, learned of the accident.

PARIS, Jan. 26 -- Statistics issued by the Prefecture of Police show a steady increase in the number of suicides in Paris during the past six years. "While the population of the city has remained practically stationary during that period suicides have increased from 1,341 to 1,935.

LONDON. CONTEMPORARY interior decoration is very much now what it was two or three years ago. Good style in chairs should be more enduring than style in hats and must not change every season. I have paid visits to two or three flats furnished as an advertisement for the decorator and an aid toward renting.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange increased 48,071 shares to 1,845,047 shares in the four weeks from Jan. 3 to Jan. 30, it was announced yesterday. The gain was the largest for any month since last July, but was small in comparison with monthly fluctuations a year or two ago.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- The announcement of Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas in Buenos Aires of the formation of an ABC-Peru group claiming executive jurisdiction over the Chaco controversy between Bolivia and Paraguay and future South American conflicts, without the assistance of the United States, aroused no objection in official circles here, judging from reactions today to the Buenos Aires reports in THE NEW YORK TIMES.

BOSTON, Feb. 2 -- What Mains did a few years ago New Hampshire now has done. An outside agency has spent a year in a detailed examination of the executive or administrative operations of the government of the State itself and of its 10 counties and 228 towns, and submitted an elaborate report.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

ARCHANGEL, U.S.S.R., Feb. 4 (AP) -- A vast campaign to speed up production of lumber, involving the conscription of all peasants in the Northern region, has been launched by the Soviet Government as a safeguard against failure to comply with the demands of the 1933-34 timber export plan.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 4 -- Educators are willing to sacrifice certain "hard-won advances" in order to contribute to the general welfare during the depression but they resent "the demands of financiers and industrialists" for slashes in educational budgets which would injure society and create additional difficult problems, according to Dr. Stephen Duggan, director of the Institute for International Education.

Strong resentment against the slashing of next year's appropriations for the Federal Trade Commission by nearly two-thirds by the House of Representatives was expressed here yesterday by leading trade association counsels, who saw in the move the end' of the trade practice conference.

TROY, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- All proposals for currency inflation were opposed by Dean John Thomas Madden of the New York University School of Commerce, addressing Group V of the New York State Bankers Association at its annual dinner here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Immediate removal from office of David S. Barry, veteran Sergeant-at-Arms, will be urged upon the Senate by the Judiciary Committee on Monday, Chairman Norris of the committee predicted today. Mr. Barry, suspended yesterday for writing a magazine article charging that a "few" members of Congress "sell their votes," remained silent at home.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 4 -- Comparing Delaware corporation laws to the easy divorce laws and commercialized gambling laws of some other States, David E. Lilienthal, Wisconsin Public Service Commissioner, demanded in a speech here this week that Delaware corporations be barred from operating or selling securities in Wisconsin until they come up to the standards required of home corporations.

PARIS, Feb. 4 -- Bruyers continues the natural waistline with, medium width separate belts, often of patent leathers. Pleated skirts predominates. The most practical of which has pleated apron-front panels.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- With Adolf Hitler as Chancellor of Germany, and France changing government every few weeks, there is much talk both privately and publicly in this country just now of the need for a change in the present governmental form.

LAKEWOOD, N.J., Feb. 4 -- Another cycle in the history of the famous Casino court tennis court was marked today as an exhibition match was staged in the court that had not resounded to play in over a decade.

Directors of the Metropolitan Opera it became known yesterday are giving serious consideration to a proposal to reorganize the company on a national scale as a means of meeting the financial crisis In its affairs.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 4 -- Curacao, owned by Mrs. Payne Whitney and the favorite in a field of ten, won the Miami Beach Handicap, feature today at Hialeah Park. A crowd of more than 6,000, including Mrs. James Roosevelt, viewed the racing, which was conducted over a fast track, under sunny skies.

WE may look forward with confidence to a new era in broadcasting," said M. H. Aylesworth, president of the National Broadcasting Company, in his annual report to the organization's advisory council. He observed that the pace of radio activity slowed up a bit in 1932, when only two stations were added to the networks of WEAF-WJZ, raising the membership to eighty-seven transmitters.

The Students' Concert or the Philharmonic-Symphony concert last night in Carnegie Hall offered Mozart's "Heffner" symphony in D major; Debussy's beautiful and too infrequently played "Iberia," Carl Goldmark's A minor concerto for violin with Nathan Milstein as soloist, and Strauss's "Till Eulenspiegel."
The subject of "Modern Property Briefs" was discussed by M. Morenthau Jr., president of the company bearing his name, before the real estate class of the West Side Y.M.C.A. recently.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 4 -- The experienced swordsmen of the New York Fencers Club defeated the Naval Academy, in the latter's opening match today, 11 to 6. The visitors won the foils 6 to 3 and with sabers 3 to 1, each team taking two of the bouts with the epee.

PHOENIX, Ariz., Feb. 2 -- Arizona has interests more potent, and concerns more basic than the hanging or the failure to hang Winnie Ruth Judd, a young woman convicted of killing two girl friends. This has been a dramatic affair involving some well-known persons in Phoenix and developing a political angle, but politics, this Winter are meat and drink to this youngest member of the sisterhood of States.

Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Napoleon Bonaparte gave a luncheon yesterday at the Central Park Casino. Their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Martin Dehn, Mr. and Mrs. Walton Oakley, Mr. and Mrs. Hokan B. Steffanson, Mr. and Mrs. Griswold A. Thompson, Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Schumacher, Mr. and Mrs. George Fitz-Chandler, Mrs. Henry Symes Lehr and Edward Fisher.

WARRENTON, Va. -- Much hunting is promised for the rest of February. Amory S. Carbart and William Almy, masters of the Warrenton Fox Hounds, have announced the following fixtures: Tomorrow, Clovelly Farm; Wednesday, Wateroo; Saturday, Whitehall Farm; Feb. 13, Ball's Cross Roads; Feb. 15, Oak Shade Church; Feb. 18, St. Leonard's Gate; Feb. 20, Fauquier Springs; Feb. 22, Lake's Corner; Feb. 25, W.H. Emory's, and Feb. 27, Farley Gate.

Swapping of stocks among market professionals accounted for the bulk of yesterday's 419,000-share turnover on the Stock Exchange. The market was irregularly lower at the opening, but it turned firm at the beginning of the second hour, only to develop fresh weakness just before the close.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 4 -- Ontario's gold production enabled Canada to maintain its favorable position among the nations of the world and prevented the Canadian dollar from dropping in value to possibly 50 cents, Charles McCrea, Minister of Mines for Ontario, said this week in an address to the Women's Conservative Association in Hamilton on the gold industry of the Province.

WASHINGTON. WHEN President-elect Roosevelt takes office he will be immediately confronted by one major problem of government, to the solution of which both he and President Hoover were committed by their party platforms.

Ferdinand Veverka, Czechoslovak Minister at Washington, spoke from the capital yesterday over the NBC network to "the radio audience of America," preceding a broadcast here of the Metropolitan's revival of Smetana's "Bartered Bride."

WHEAT WOMEN represents a considerable advance over Nard Jones's previous work. It is wider in scope and more mature in purpose than his youthful story, "Oregon Detour," and it is immeasurably superior in technique to "The Petlands."

When the parrot dealer was a young boy in Greece his desire to see strange lands made him run away to sea. After a stormy voyage he found himself landing in Bahia. where an old dealer in parrots, monkeys and other small animals, recognizing in Carlos a fellow-countryman and pleased with the boy's enthusiasm, persuaded Carlos to stay with him as his partner.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The difficulties which have appeared in Congress in connection with the consideration of the proposed repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment afford occasion for a fuller examination of the provisions for amending the Constitution.

A move is being made by leading steel-producing companies to reduce losses caused by an overaccumulation of unmined reserves of iron ore and bituminous coal, it is indicated in the financial statements of them, and by the remarks of leaders of the industry.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 4 -- D.T. Murray, 80 years old, one of the most colorful railroad figures of the old school in this section, died today. He was known to hundreds of railroad men and steel company officials throughout the country as Duke.

More than two-thirds of all exchanges of securities proposed in the plan for reorganizing the former Central Public Service System had been effected by the close of last week. In the opinion of bankers, this virtually clinches success of the plan, and deposits of an overwhelming majority of securities are expected before the time limits expire.

HAVANA, Feb. 4 (AP) -- Jaz Age, second in his previous three starts at Oriental Park and in his last two races at Jefferson Park, finally got home first today, winning the sixfurlong feature at the Havana course.

Prominent men and women of the social, professional and business worlds are taking an active interest in the dinner which has been arranged under the auspices of the Altrusa Club of New York for Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President-elect, to be held on Wednesday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria.

Women's suits, neckwear, home furnishings and novel jewelry were outstanding in retail trade during the week, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer-Both Retail Reporting Bureau. Blouses, convertible pillows and jig-saw puzzles also drew marked response from consumers.

HAD the announcement of Professor Charles B. Lipman that he has found living micro-organisms in meteorites come from one less conspicuous in biology it would have received scant attention. Professor Lipman is a member of the faculty of the University of California and a bacteriologist of international authority and repute.

With the Higher Vegetables. An artichoke is still a mysterious vegetable to a great many people. But it apparently has peculiarities which even the adepts hardly suspect. Day before yesterday in the local Federal court an Artichoke King pleaded guilty to evading his income tax over a period of three years.

A thousand unemployed men will be put to work tomorrow on the construction and development of the Grand Central Parkway in Queens, Robert Moses, chairman of the Emergency Public Works, appointed by Governor Lehman to expedite self-liquidating projects in the State, announced yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 4 -- The name of a regular party nominee could appear a second time on the voting machine, in the separate row set aside for independent candidates, under a bill to be introduced Monday by Assemblyman Herbert Brownell Jr., of the Tenth New York district, as an aid to the fusion forces in the municipal campaign this year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 4 -- Dissension in the ranks of the Navy League came to light today with the announcement that three of its most prominent and long-standing members had resigned as the result of policies adopted at a recent meeting of the board of directors in New York.

UNA MERKEL, which happens to be her right name is contributing her amusing drawl to "The Secret o Madame Blanche" at the Capitol She was born in Covington, Ky., taught Sunday school, sang in the choir and when she grew up traveled extensively with her parents.

The accomplishments of the industrialization plan of Soviet Russia were praised and its further success was predicted yesterday by speakers at the luncheon held under the auspices of the Foreign Policy Association in the Hotel Astor.

A London woman clearing up her garret found a "two-a-penny" pamphlet contaniing thirteen pictures in color showing London street scenes with legends attached. She was about to send it out as rubbish but, on the advice of a friend, sent it to Sotheby's auction room instead, "to bring what it could."

IRVINGTON-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 4 -- A bridge tea will be held on Monday at the Irvington House for Cardiac Children. Mrs. Arthur T. Ellsworth will serve as hostess. The players will pause at 3 o'clock to listen to a radio talk by Health Commissioner Shirley W. Wynne of New York and Mrs. Irma B. Levy, president of the home.

"Depression Be Dashed!" was the theme of a supper dance given last night at Essex House by young women of society in the interests of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Fund. The various features of the carnival-like entertainment included fortune-telling booths, rapid sketch artists, soda refreshments and a midnight cabaret.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, wife of the President-elect, does not intend to continue her broadcasting on commercial programs over the radio after she enters the White House, according to reliable information yesterday.
Currier Ives prints, English American and French etchings, old English silver, antique furniture, tapestries and textiles are among the articles which will be offered at auction here this week.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb 4 -- Army won a hard and closely fought polo game from Yale today by the score of 7 to 6. The Eli horsemen, with Baldwin leading the attack, got away to an early lead, the score at the end of the third period favoring the visitors, 5 to 3.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 4 -- Foreign Minister Saavedra Lamas this morning mailed to Brazil and Peru certified copies of the Mendoza agreements and then went to Mar del Plata to spend the week-end.

Curtis High has high hopes of continuing its city P.S.A.L. crosscountry championship reign next Fall, for five of the ten runners who received block "C's" at the recent athletic awards assembly are expected to return to the Staten Island school next September.

The sudden fall and subsequent recovery of the Canadian dollar last week focused attention upon the debate over inflation now raging in Canada. For some time there has existed in Canada, as in the United States, a body of opinion favoring a devaluation of the currency.

BATAVIA, Dutch Java, Feb. 5 -- The Dutch battleship De Zeven Provincien, 5,644 tons, is running wild in the hands of mutineers somewhere along the coast of Sumatra and no one knows where she is headed.

After almost fifty years of conducting an undergraduate school of nursing, the New York Post-Graduate Medical School and Hospital, 303 East Twentieth Street, is to retire from that field and has under consideration a plan to teach post-graduate nursing, according to an announcement yesterday.

In normal times the sum of $75,000,000 is expended yearly for public and private welfare work (exclusive of hospitals) in New York City. The agencies disbursing these funds organized eight years ago the Welfare Council which now includes 650 organizations "encompassing the entire range of social welfare activity."

Under Martha Graham's Gothic style of direction-six medieval miracle plays were performed at the Guild Theatre last evening. They represent the enterprise of Natalie Hays Hammond, who selected and arranged the manuscripts and designed the costumes, and Alice Laughlin, who designed the settings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Representatives of a dozen national organizations interested in peace will present to Congress and the administration tomorrow a petition urging control of the international traffic in arms.

With a hundred different denominations sending missionaries to China to labor for the conversion of that country, it is questionable whether the Christian forces have any right to be there at all, Mrs. Harper Sibley of Rochester, N.Y., declared in a sermon yesterday morning in St. George's Protestant Episcopal Church, Stuyvesant Square and East Sixteenth Street.

For all his Russo-German-Jewish composition, there has always been a Gallic quality about Ossip Dymov's work, and last night, at the auditorium of the College of the City of New York, it came out in the form of a series of sort of one-acters, a sort of revue, a little suite of lunacy -- in short divertissement in Yiddish called "Town Lunatics."

Considering the nature of the emergency and the heroic measures proposed to meet it, Governor LEHMAN'S budget got, on the whole, a " good press." There is almost universal praise for his insight into State finances and the way in which the somewhat complicated facts and figures were presented, while a number of editors approve substance as well as form.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- A speed of forty knots for Atlantic liners is foreshadowed by the new revolutionary hull design worked out by Sir Joseph Isherwood, noted naval architect.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Not unnaturally, the week's political developments in Germany have had a seriously depressing effect on financial and business sentiment. This has extended even to manufacturing circles, where intense nervousness prevailed.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Marie Elianoff, alias Marie Graff, young Soviet secret agent, has been kidnapped and taken back to Russia, according to a story that has now belatedly come out in Berne. Details of it are printed here.

Suggestions for recommendations by Governor Lehman'a Emergency Public Works Commission of self-liquidating projects for unemployment relief to be financed by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will be discussed at a hearing today in the office of Robert Moses, chairman of the commission, in the State Office Building.

Jobs for 25,000 more unemployed persons and direct relief to 75,000 more families will be supplied in February by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration as a result of an appropriation of $7,500,000 for the month, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the administration.

Three young men, admittedly guilty of too much concentration, were locked up at Police Headquarters yesterday, while detectives worked to establish whether they were guilty of a series of recent payroll robberies.
BOSTON, Feb. 5 -- "Biocracy," the application of simple biological laws to economic and social problems, has been offered as a substitute for technocracy in the treatment of the ills of mankind.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on Important roll-calls of the past week are given in the appended tabulation:

Until there is a drastic redistribution of wealth from the hands of the few into the hands of the many there will be no recovery from the depression, Senator Gerald P. Nye of North Dakota told a meeting held last night in the Labor Temple, 242 East Fourteenth Street.

If no stowaways turn up on the yacht, for a short, blessed interval Mr. ROOSEVELT is free from office-seekers, recommenders, advice-givers, planners, professors. He is with a little knot of friends. He can enjoy himself, sure that nobody is trying to wheedle or "work " him, stuff him with wisdom, bore him with folly.
Adolf Hitler's rise to the Chancellorship of Germany and his attitude toward the Jews of that nation were the subject of sermons in several synagogues in this city yesterday morning.

Denver favors Experts. Colorado is the first Commonwealth, so far as any records exist, to have an official State Liar. A resident of Denver has just been appointed to that post by Governor JOHNSON, who has long entertained the conviction that too much lying was being done around the State Capitol in a miscellaneous and uncoordinated fashion.

The Rev. Granville Mercer Williams, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street, cautioned would-be reformers of the church in his sermon yesterday morning by telling them that drastic changes toward excessive goodness often lead to greater evils than those now apparent.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 5 -- A dinghy was capsized and the auxiliary sloop Longonot, which acted as patrol boat, was blown aground as Long Island sailors today tried to resume the races started last Sunday at the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club in the face of extremely adverse conditions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- One-third of the income-tax collections of the United States in the calendar year 1932 were paid by residents of New York State, and the bulk of the State receipts came from corporations and individuals filing returns in the Second or Custom House District of New York City, according to figures issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

New Yorkers shivered last night as a fifty-seven mile an hour north-west wind howled down upon the city, driving the temperature down to 15 above zero at 10 o'clock. The Weather Bureau predicted last night that today would be not quite so cold, but that the cold wave would again strike the city and its environs tomorrow.

Despite the handicap of a high wind, excellent scores were returned in the shoot of the New York Athletic Club at Travers Island yesterday. Tracy H. Lewis won the High Scratch Cup by breaking 96 out of a possible 100 targets.

ALBANY, Feb. 5 -- New stock corporations in January showed an increase of eight over a year ago, according to the report of the Secretary of State Flynn, made public today, with an increase of 350 over December. The January total was 2,365, and of this number 2,106 concerns were located in Greater New York, with 259 scattered over thirty-six up-State counties.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Before today's State funeral for Eberhard Maikowski, Nazi storm troop leader, and Joseph Zauritz, a policeman, only two persons had been buried at the expense of the State since the founding of the Republic -- President Frledrich Ebert and Dr. Gustav Stresemann.

Buying continued active in the wholesale markets here last week, indicating a prolongation of the season over previous years. Stocks are being gauged by retailers in accordance with local conditions. Although consumers are interested mainly in needed items, sales are heavy in new and novelty merchandise.
ROME, Feb. 5 -- Adolf Hitler's appointment to the Chancellorship in Germany is regarded here as heralding a totally new phase of Italo-German relations and collaboration.

Mayor John P. O'Brien said last night that the "very foundations of the republic were endangered" by the drifting of youth from the orthodox religions of their parents toward atheism. He spoke at a testimonial dinner to Isadore Apfel, Grand Master of the Independent Order B'rith Abraham, in the ball-room of the Hotel Astor.

Some decision in the war debt situation which would put an end to international political controversy was advocated yesterday by a group of oil company executives in a statement made public by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation and chairman of the Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts at 330 West Forty-second Street.

PARIS, Feb. 3 -- The week's reduction of 139,000,000 francs, or $5,400,000, in the gold reserve of the Bank of France for the week reported on last Thursday makes the entire reduction in eight weeks 1,055,000,000 francs, or $41,350,000. Gold holdings as compared with a year ago, however, are still larger by 10,541,000,000 francs, or $413,100,000.
SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 5. (AP) -- Addison Mizner was born in Benicia, Cal., up the bay from San Francisco -- the son of a forty-niner.
LONDON, Feb. 5 -- The biggest Labor demonstration London has ever seen was held peacefully in Hyde Park today without any attempt by Communists to break it up by force.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 5 -- The development of a national park at Morristown moved a step nearer realization today when, after a tour of the entire area, Representatives Dennis Chavez of New Mexico, Don B. Colton of Utah and Scott Leavitt of Montana declared that they were deeply impressed by the historical significance of the vicinity and its suitability as a site for a national shrine.

With many of the Millrose games stars listed to compete, the seventh annual Seton Hall track and field meet will be held at the Newark Armory tonight. The feature is likely to be the Waldron 600 in which Bernie McCafferty of the Newark A.C. will be the favorite.

The non-fiction best seller published in the last twelve years was "Diet and Health," by Mrs. Lillian Hunt Peters, with the "Outline of History," by H.G. Wells, second, and "The Story of Philosophy," by Will Durant, third, according to a new table by Irving Harlow Hart of Iowa State Teachers College published in the current Publishers' Weekly.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 5 -- Sarazen II, a 6-year-old gelding owned and trained by Bruce Johnson, sprinted to victory in the six-furlong dash that featured a program of eight claiming races at the Agua Caliente track today.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Success of the forthcoming conversations on war debts and world economic problems between the United States and Great Britain will depend in a large measure upon both parties entering the conference free from commitments made by statesmen beforehand in public speeches.

"Pageant," a novel About Tasmania, which is the Literary Guild choice for February, is published today by Century as the headliner of that company's Spring list. The author is Edith J. Lyttleton, whose pen name is "G.B. Lancaster." She was born in Tasmania and gathered much of the material for her novel from the old records of her family there.

In the due course of routine at the Midtown Galleries, it has fallen to the lot of Ethel Katz to hold a one-man show this month, while the other members of the organization join in a new group exhibition of oils and water-colors. Miss Katz confines her show to water-colors, which she paints with spontaneity and fresh color.

The practice of criticizing the faults of others was decried yesterday by the Rev. Francis Kenny, a Redemptorist, in his sermon in the Actors' Chapel of St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church, Forty-ninth Street, west of Broadway.
The rising curve of steel-making operations flattened last week and the average of 19 per cent of capacity attained in the week ended Jan. 28 was barely maintained, according to the magazine Steel.
NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Freezing cold and a snowstorm did not deter the sheepskin-coated dinghy sailors who gathered today at the New Rochelle Yacht Club for a Frostbite Yacht Club regatta.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Prices of hogs fluctuate so fast now that farmers and packers are busy keeping track of the market. Leading packers are buying about 50 per cent of the hogs in the country, shipping them to Chicago. By using a packing house outside of the stockyards for unloading from cars they are able to truck them through the regular stockyards to the packing houses without paying yardage.

The Atlantic City Sea Gulls, holders of the national amateur hockey championship, turned back the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club of Brooklyn in the feature game of the weekly double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday. A crowd of 7,000 persons saw the New Jersey skaters break through the stubborn resistance offered by the Crescent Gerense men to capture the verdict by the score of 4 to 1.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- Germany today entered upon four weeks of campaigning for an election that has all the earmarks of being crucial for her future, and the future of Germany affects the future of the world, not excluding distant America.

Prominent women and debutantes of this and recent seasons who are active in behalf of many wellknown philanthropic organizations ministering to the health of mothers and children of this city, will act as hostesses today at the International Art Exhibition, held under the auspices of the College Art Association at Rockefeller Center.

PARIS, Feb. 5 -- Mainbocher shows an enormous variety of silhouettes, skirt lengths, collars and details. Low and normal waistlines and wide and narrow shoulders are offered. Pleated skirts are prominent for all hours, many with short pleated apron day fronts.

The devil is the personification of evil and those who say he does not exist should realize that there is no evasion of his reality in the Bible, from the first page to the last, the Rev. A.B. Moldenke, pastor of St. Peter's Lutheran Church. 597 Lexington Avenue, declared in his sermon yesterday morning.

GREENSBURG, Pa., Feb. 5 (AP) -- The story of a thrilling battle with a snowstorm by Richard du Pont, 24-year-old Wilmington (Del.) society man, in an open airplane above the Alleghanies, ending with a blind landing on the side of a ridge, was told tonight.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Western Conference basketball comes out of hiding this week with six games on the championship slate, flanked by five contests against non-conference foes.

William Dixon, 35 years old, who shot and killed Sergeant Eugene Monohan of the Wadsworth Avenue Precinct when the policeman tried to arrest him for carrying a pistol, was held without bail on a charge of homicide yesterday in Washington Heights Court, and was lodged in the Tombs.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- One hundred and fifty-nine schools in New York State are included on the 1933 accredited list of the commission on secondary schools of the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools. Dr. E. Duncan Grizzell, chairman of the commission, which has headquarters at the University of Pennsylvania, made the announcement.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Objection to the selection of four Senators for his Cabinet on the ground that their appointment would remove too many of his supporters from key positions has been made to President-elect Roosevelt, it was learned today.

The Port of New York is threatened with a loss of trade which probably never would be won back, according to the report of Examiner Earl M. Steer, to the Interstate Commerce Commission, recommending the abolition of free lighterage of freight between the railroad terminals in New Jersey and other parts of the port, it was said yesterday by William H. Chandler, manager of the traffic bureau of the Merchants' Association of New York.
