GENE SARAZEN'S suggestion that the golf cup be enlarged to an 8-inch diameter has been discussed far and wide, sometimes placidly and sometimes acrimoniously. Almost all golfers have had moments when they wished that the cup had been a little bit larger on one side, at least.

London Terrace Food Stores, Inc., has leased for a Royal Scarlet food market two stores at the southwest corner of Ninth Avenue and Twenty-fourth Street, in the London Terrace apartment block. The rental is based upon a percentage of the gross sales, with a minimum rental of $21,850 for a five-year term, James N. Wells's Sons, Inc., the broker reports.

MANILA, Feb. 5 -- The address by General Emilio Aguinaldo today on the Hawes - Cutting independence act, in the opinion of political observers here, was calculated to suit both sides without committing the

The cast for the performance of "Parsifal" at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday afternoon. Feb. 13, was announced yesterday. It will be headed by Frida Leider as Kundry, Lauritz Melchior as Parsifal. Friedrich Schorr as Amfortas and Ludwig Hofmann as Gurnemanz.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- The creation of one long-term amortization fund for Germany's private debts was urged by Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Economy and Food Minister in the Hitler Cabinet, in a memorandum prepared some months ago and published recently.

KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 5 (AP) -- City-issued scrip money, development of man's age-old custom of bartering goods for services, has come into extensive use in many, Southern cities, having in gome instances attained a greater turnover than cash.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Henry Homburger and his Red Devils of Saranac Lake won first honors in the Adirondack Bobsled Club's four-man championship event on the Olympic slide today, but saw their record for one heat on the run, 1:52, smashed by J. Hubert Stevens and his crew, who flashed down the mountainside in 1:50.23 on their first trial.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Fedro, Cal., Feb. 5 -- Rolling gently to the slow groundswell of the open ocean, the battleships and cruisers of the Blue force lay at anchor in San Pedro Harbor today, while their crews, in tailored blues and white hats set at rakish angles, sauntered along Los Angeles streets on their last week-end liberty before the opening of the "Battle of the Pacific."

With the assertion that sweeping reforms are necessary to tighten up on the safety of compensation insurance, State Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick recommends drastic changes in the workmen's compensation law in his annual report, which will be submitted to the Legislature at Albany this evening.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 5 -- Honoring Maria Jeritza, former Metropolitan Opera diva, who will appear tomorrow night in the first of the Society of Arts concerts at the Everglades Club, and Baron von Popper, her husband, Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman gave a luncheon today at the Cafe Marguery at the Bath and Tennis Club.

The education of Jewish youth in the faith and traditions of their fathers was urged as essential to the continued strength of the race by Jewish civic leaders last night at the opening of a campaign for $35,000 to meet the deficit of the Jacob H. Schiff Centre, 2,510 Valentine Avenue, the Bronx.

When the six-story tenement at 124 Lewis St. was sold by the Emigrant Industrial Savings Bank to the East End Housing Corp., Joseph Hoffman president, the bank took back a purchase money mortgage for $9.500, payable in five years at 5 per cent.

Overcrowding said to be unprecedented in the city's hospitals is disclosed in the annual report of the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association, made public yesterday at the association's headquarters, 105 East Twenty-second Street.

A report of motor vehicle casualties in 1932, issued by the Travelers Insurance Company of Hartford, carries the title "They Call Us Civilized." The 300,000 Americans who were killed hi action or died of wounds in all our wars are compared with 325,000 fatal casualties incurred hi the operation of motor vehicles during the last fifteenyears.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 5 -- Cash payment now of the soldiers' bonus would not only be unfair to all other citizens, but to veterans themselves, Roger Babson says in a statement made public here today. He denied that prepayment would aid business.

The best revue of the season opened last night at the Imperial Theatre, played about a performance and a half and then closed some time early this morning. It was "The Depression Gaieties," in honor of the depression and a half. Marc Connelly was impresario -- assisted by a large cast -- and the money went to the Authors League and the Stage Relief Funds.

The National Committee on Industrial Rehabilitation has received reports Showing that rehabilitation projects totaling $155,049,702 have been undertaken to date by plants and retail business establishments all over the country.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- A warning that private charity might collapse because of high income taxes was given here today by I. Montefiore Levy in addressing the annual meeting of the New York Guild for the Jewish Blind, of which he is president, at the guild home here.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- A scheduled two-day curling event for the Gordon and Emmett Medals was brought to a close tonight on the local rinks, only one day being required to complete the program. The Caledonians of New York took the Gordon Medal and Utica won the Emmett Medal from the St. Andrews' curlers of New York.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- With additional orders signed today, the total of motor cars sold at the thirty-third national automobile show here last week was raised to 2,512 with an aggregate value of $1,808,649. This was double the volume of last year's show business and also greater than that of 1931 or 1930.

Baseball men from far and wide, making up a gathering of more than 600, parked their feet and their troubles under the tables of the grand ballroom in the Hotel Commodore last night to attend the tenth annual dinner and frolic of the New York Baseball Writers' Association and also pay tribute to John J. McGraw, the evening's guest of honor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Atlee Pomerene, chairman of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and Charles A. Miller, president, do not intend to serve in the next administration, according to information in administration circles.

Mr. ROOSEVELT made an interesting announcement before leaving Jacksonville. As if to forestall any moaning at the bar of Congress as he put out to sea, he said that he hoped to keep a committee of Senators and Representatives fully advised of the progres; of his Executive discussion of th war debts with Great Britain and other countries.

Considerably upset over a charge that he was responsible for starting a run on the Hibernia Bank and Trust Company of New Orleans, Representative Hamilton Fish announced yesterday that he would not press his demand for an investigation of certain business corporations which failed after receiving loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

The Bronx Hockey Club approached within two points of the New York Amateur League leaders, the St. Nicks, by defeating the New York A.C. sextet, 5 to 3, at the New York Coliseum yesterday in a rough game. The rough tactics reached a climax in the third period when Wink Foulis and Don Grimason came to blows and received major penalties.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 5 -- Miguel Cruchaga, Minister of Foreign Affairs, and Gustavo Ross, Minister of Finance, continued today consideration of the position of American Interests in Chile after their conference yesterday with United States Ambassador William S. Culbertson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A militant drive to reclaim the country from, the Democratic party, through the formation of the National Republican League headed by Vice President Curtis, was announced by John A. Campbell of White Plains, N.Y., national director of the new organization.

Humanity must take care lest it fall into a dark modern age as society did in the Middle Ages, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, warned yesterday morning in his sermon in the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, Madison Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

George V. Sheridan of Columbus, director of the Ohio Council of Retail Merchants, warned the heads of New York department stores and members of the taxation committee of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York yesterday that the proposed State sales tax would mean ruin to many merchants unless some feasible basis for passing on the tax directly to the consumer is devised.
Approval of four bills now pending in the State Legislature was announced yesterday by the New York County Lawyers Association.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Miss Vera Hayburn, a 25-year-old stenographer, leaped to her death from the thirty-third floor of the Medinah Athletic Club early today following a party at a night club at which she was the guest of Albert Russell Erskine Jr., son of the president of the Studebaker Corporation and the Pierce Arrow Co.

NOME, Alaska, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Pilot Robert Reeves said that a "howling blizzard" and trouble with his plane compasses explained his two-day delay in arriving here yesterday with four passengers from McGrath while a widespread search was under way.
NEW YORK. Lady Colefax of London, now at the Waldorf-Astoria, will sail for England Feb. 18.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- A number of State governments are extending a protective hand to bank depositors, some offering, in effect, to act as respositories in which citizens can place their savings with confidence.

A new method of curing facial paralysis by surgery, which has been used successfully to restore emotional expression to the face -- a problem that has long challenged the medical profession here and abroad -- was announced yesterday in the quarterly bulletin of the Milbank Memorial Fund.

A marked decrease in loans to policy holders at their demand was recorded in the last half of 1932 by the Mutual Life Insurance Company, according to the company's annual report, which is being sent to policy holders. In the first six months of the year cash payments on policy loans aggregated $34,501,199 and in the last six months they dropped to $23,736,402.

Personal Kind Is a Myth; What We Have Is Social Variety. To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of last Sunday you reported an address by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler in which he said that liberty consisted in the right of every man to do what he thought was right, and that it also implied the right of any man to be wrong.

CHICAGO, Feb. 5 -- Politics, financial legislation, uncertainty about the course of the Federal Farm Board, lack of export demand for wheat and erratic action of the British and Canadian exchanges combined last week to create the most unsatisfactory speculative conditions known to the grain trade.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 5 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55.3, which compares with 55.5 a week ago, 56.4 two weeks ago, 57.3 three weeks ago and 57.4 four weeks ago.The highest average of 1932 was 66.3, in the first week in January; the average of the last week of December, 57.6, was the lowest.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- The Bank of England's further gold purchase this week raises its gold reserve to just over u127,000,000, which compares with u120,600,000 immediately after last month's American debt payment. It Is also u5,800,000 larger than in this week a year ago.

A drive to raise a $100,000 relief fund to care for unemployed architects and draughtsmen of the metropolitan area will open today under the auspices of the Women's Division of the Architect's Emergency Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- Asserting that the time had come to "use national resources and save human lives," the American Federation of Labor, in its monthly survey of business for January, advocated today large government borrowings for emergency needs to stimulate business activity.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Warnings that dairymen's strikes and violence would take place if the Legislature did not act this session to stabilize milk prices were voiced yesterday to Senator Perley A. Pitcher, chairman of the Legislative Milk Investigating Committee, at a conference with nine representatives of Northern New York farmers.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 5 -- Inspector Harold R. King of the Nassau County police, in charge of the investigation into the murder of Miss Mary Helen O'Connor of Rockaway Park, Queens, intimated today that his men had turned up something important In the case.

With an increasing number of new projects and a rising volume of alteration work coming out for bids, the building trades in this city and vicinity continue to concentrate their attention on the present tightness of the mortgage loan market and the new building code, according to Alien E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

LONDON, Feb. 5 -- Parliament will resume its sessions Tuesday after a seven-week recess in which nothing happened to disturb the political status quo that has prevailed ever since the government took office in October, 1931.

The Racquet and Swimming Club of Ardsley clinched the Group I honors in the Westchester division of the Metropolitan League Class C squash racquets tournament by defeating the Sleepy Hollow Country Club team, 3 to 2, yesterday at the Racquet and Swimming Club courts.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Implication is increasingly made that bankers are at least partly responsible for the business depression through having acted "ignorantly," "short-sightedly," selfishly."

ISTANBUL, Feb. 5 -- A religious uprising which was almost tantamount to an insurrection today took President Mustapha Kemal Pasha to Broussa, where orthodox citizens attacked a muezzin (public crier), who, in giving his call to prayer, used Turkish instead of Arabic.
The New York Rangers once more asserted their superiority over the New York Americans by defeating the spangled sextet, 4 to 1, in a National Hockey League game in Madison Square Garden last night.

TOKYO, Feb. 5 -- The possibility of Japan's leaving the League of Nations is causing officials and jurists to study the question of her right to retain control of the Marshall and Caroline Islands, now held under the League mandates. As a result of their investigations, it is their belief that Japan's right to retain the islands is juridically unassailable.

The Jewel Tea Company, Inc., reported yesterday for 1932 a net income of $1,053,626 after charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after a loss of $210,442 from operation of the Jewel Food Stores, Inc., to $3 a share on the 280,000 shares of capital stock outstanding.

A net average loss of 4.94 per cent on their capital stock and surplus combined shown by the national banks of the United States in the fiscal year ended on June 30 last, was the first loss for such a period to be reported in the sixty-three years that the system has been in operation, says David Friday, writing in The Rand McNally Bankers Monthly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Vice President Curtis, upon retiring to private life March 4, will become chairman of the National Republican League, an organization formed to keep alive Republican principles and work for Republican success in the Congressional elections in 1934 and the Presidential election of 1936.

HAVANA, Feb. 5 -- J.E. Smallman's Feudal Lord accounted for his second stake of the Oriental Park meeting today, winning the Marianao Handicap, for 3-year-olds and upward, in a hard drive from Mrs. Emil Denemark's Pigeon Hole.

Yale continued its winning streak on Saturday night by defeating Penn at Philadelphia, 33 to 26, in the only Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game played last week. By this victory, its second scored over the Quakers, Yale advanced to the league leadership, breaking a four-cornered tie which had existed for first place.

LONDON, Feb. 3 -- In the London stock market, all eyes are at present turned to South African goldmining shares. In that market a boom resembling the famous rise of 1895 is in progress. It is this time based ostensibly on the abandonment of the gold standard in South Africa, which has enabled the companies to obtain the full market price in sterling for their output.

Plans for a new jury system for the Supreme Court in Brooklyn have been completed and will be put into effect on Feb. 15 with an estimated annual saving to the city of more than $100,000, it was learned yesterday.
To the Editor of The New York Times: How much longer must the United States be shamed by our despicable foreign policy in Cuba?
DUBLIN, Feb. 5 -- After the fever of election oratory and high-sounding patriotic speeches the Irish people are now turning to the hard facts of the economic situation.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 5 -- There was surprise in some quarters in the steel trade at the United States Steel Corporation's dividend action on Tuesday, a payment of 75 cents or $1 on the preferred shares instead of 50 cents having been expected. The general view Is that the directors were very cautious, and the belief previously held, that reductions of salaries and wages would follow a cut in the dividend, was strengthened.

Norman Lewis, Evander Childs fencing captain, captured first place in the invitation interscholastic foils competition yesterday at the Salle d'Armes Vince. The victor swept through seven bouts without defeat and was touched only seven times.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 5 -- Uruguay, the only South American country that has not had a revolution in a quarter of a century, now presents the spectacle of the President, Dr. Gabriel Terra, leading bitter opposition against the executive branch of the government, with the Senate openly charging him with conducting subversive propaganda and the newspapers openly discussing the possibilities of a revolt.

Cities that have maintained their water systems as separate entities and have issued water bonds payable from water revenues instead of as general obligations find now that uncollected water taxes are small compared with general tax collections, according to official reports received here by bankers who have handled the water bonds.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 5 -- Realizing that they must become reconciled to the loss of most of their former trade with the 30,000,000 Manchurians, and apprehensive that North China may come under the away of Manchukuo and Japan, American business men in Shanghai are attempting to effect a great expansion of American trade in the Yangtse Valley.

HIGHLAND FALLS, N.Y., Feb. 5 -- Two children of Lieutenant Godwin Ordway Jr. of West Point drowned here today in a small pond near their home, Margaret, 4 years old, apparently having lost her life in an effort to save Albert, 7.
ALBANY, N.T., Feb. 5 -- A drive for readjustment of Governor Lehman's recommendations for new and increased taxation was in prospect tonight as legislators began to reassemble for another week.

MANILA, Feb. 5 -- Gen. Emilio Aguinaldo, who led the Philippine insurrection against the United States in 1899-1901, today attacked provisions of the Hawes-Cutting independence act in a speech before the annual convention of veterans of the Philippine insurrection.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 5 -- A Canadian sloop, laden with 1,000 sacks of assorted liquors and commanded by a French citizen, was tied up here tonight under guard of a Coast Guard cutter and a customs cutter while Francois Riou, the master, prepared to bring formal charges against the United States Coast Guard with Marcel de Verneuil, the French Consul in this city, tomorrow.

"One Wife or Another," a comedy by Percy Shaw and T. Wigney Percyval, will be presented this evening as the first production of Authors and Actors, Associated, at the Provincetown Playhouse, 133 Macdougal Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The assertion is frequently made that the United States is being flooded with imports from countries which have abandoned the gold standard. It is pointed out that costs of production and wages in those countries have decreased with the depreciation of the currency.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- With twenty-three legislative days remaining of the present session of Congress the opinion of Republican and Democratic leaders is that no constructive legislation will be enacted before March 4, and that this will force Franklin D. Roosevelt as President to present a vast economic and reconstruction problem to the coming special session.

Real estate transactions announced in New Jersey over the week-end showed a good demand for housing properties. Trading consisted of sales of small flats and dwellings to investors, with some activity in business holdings.

Prices for commodities on local Exchanges fluctuated erratically last week. During the first few days nearly all quotations went lower, but later an undertone of firmness developed. Coffee, however, moved opposite to the general trends, going higher at the outset and then falling off.

Slowly but surely conservationists, especially the scientists and officials among their ranks, are coming to know how it is possible to restore game to America which once boasted the greatest abundance of wild life known anywhere in the civilized world.
The Class B squash tennis team of the Short Hills Club defeated the Montclair A.C. yesterday on the latter's courts, 3 -- 2, in the New Jersey group of the Metropolitan Squash Tennis League.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Officials of the Hibernia Bank Trust Company announced tonight that directors of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, at a session in Washington today, had approved a $20,000,000 loan to the bank provided the bank raised $4,000,000 and depositors of $10,000 or more agreed to "freeze" 50 per cent of their deposits until the corporation's loan was repaid.

The lowering of the 7 per cent dividend on United States Steel preferred stock, for the first time in the company's thirty-two years' history, undoubtedly came as a shock to minds which had learned to look on "Steel preferred's 7 per cent" as impregnable.

New public financing, excluding municipal issues, in the United States in January was $50,425,000, or $9,255,000 more than in the opening month of 1932, according to a compilation by Otto P. Schwarzschiid, president of the National Statistical Service, Inc. Of this year's financing, $47,175,000, or more than 93 per cent, consisted of bond and note issues, the remainder, $3,250,000, consisting of stock.

Richard Washburn Child, former Ambassador to Italy, issued a formal denial yesterday, in behalf of Colonel Edward M. House, that William C. Bullitt, American journalist now traveling in Europe, was in any way representing Colonel House or President-elect Roosevelt to the point of discussing foreign affairs with foreign officials.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 (AP) -- The passage by the House and approval by two Senate committees of the Collier-Blaine beer bill was described tonight by the Board of Temperance and Social Service of the Methodist Episcopal Church, South, in a statement as a "wet rebellion" against the Constitution.

BERLIN, Feb. 3 -- Although manufacturing activity seems to be temporarily checked in Germany by the political situation, reports show that the retail turnover, including that of the "cooperatives," is increasing everywhere. The Institute for the Study of Trade Statistics reports that monthly industrial production in Rhenish Westphalia is 12 per cent above the lowest of 1932.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 5 -- Trading in the cotton market here last week was greater than in either of the two preceding weeks, particularly in the second half of the period. The increase in business was, however, at the expense of prices, which gradually worked lower until at the low points on the closing day of the week the active trading months showed declines of 40 to 41 points, or $2 a bale.

GENEVA, Feb. 5 -- The Presidency of the League of Nations Council, now held by Italy, will, by the established system of alphabetical rotation, pass in May to Japan, unless she quits the League in the meanwhile because of the condemnation of her which the Committee of Nineteen will continue to draft tomorrow.

Social conditions in Cuba today are deplorable when judged by American standards, and are bad enough in relation to the lower scale of living sufficient to provide food, clothing and shelter in a tropical country.
The letter arrived last week. It came from Bill Hargiss, coach at the University of Kansas, and it contained a polite request.

Religious certitude can be attained in only two ways, by belief in the infallibility of some external authority such as the Pope, or by having a personal awareness of God, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick said yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church.

The successful assumption by a detective of the role of a Western Union messenger resulted yesterday morning in the apprehension of a young man who, it is charged, attempted to extort $780 from Harold Stern, orchestra leader, under threat of killing Stern, his wife and his child.

The Port of New York Authority yesterday announced a program of retrenchment for 1933 which is expected to result in a reduction of $360,072 in operating expenses. Of this sum, $158,878 represents salary reductions and $205,194 savings through reduction of the size of the operating force.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 5 -- The "married persons" section of the economy act was denounced and its repeal demanded at a mass meeting held today by the Government workers council of the National Woman's party to defend "women's right to paid employment.
The tendency to acquire Manhattan real estate by leasehold was emphasized in transactions made over the week-end.

PHILADELPHIA, Pa., Feb. 5 -- President Hoover is asked to instruct the American delegates to the Geneva conference "to proposea multilateral treaty for immediate total disarmament" in a joint message sent to him today by five peace organizations and made public here by the Pennsylvania Committee for Total Disarmament.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 5 -- The evils of mass production methods, superficial instruction and handicaps for the exceptional student are ailments which result in the lowering of standards in American education, in the opinion of four European educators writing in the current issue of The Harvard Teachers' Record, quarterly publication of the Harvard Graduate School of Education.

MOSCOW, Feb. 5 -- "Albatross survivors rescued," runs a radio message received in Moscow today as the laconic climax of a story of Arctic adventure that would have driven any other country frantic with excitement.
CHICAGO, Feb. 5 (AP) -- Winter, with accompanying snow and zero temperatures, was an unwelcome week-end guest of the midwest.

The champion Marshall Chess Club team and those of the Manhattan, Empire City, West Side and City College were victorious in the opening round of the annual competition for the championship of the Metropolitan Chess League yesterday. Headed by Frank J. Marshall, United States titleholder, and Reuben Fine, Western champion, the Marshall Club made a sweep on seven boards, to score over N.Y.U. by 7-0.

BERLIN, Feb. 5 -- The Hitler Government and the bloc supporting it -- the National Socialists and Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's Nationalists -- are going into the campaign for the Reichstag elections March 5 on the platform once formulated by the former Kaiser:

Failure to settle the war debts problem in the forthcoming negotiations because of "unreasonable demands on either side" will intensify international bitterness where international cooperation is necessary, and will aggravate the depression, according to Parker T. Moon, Professor of International Relations at Columbia University, who spoke before the Catholic Conference on Industrial Problems at the Hotel Astor last night.

Maritime and trucking interests started yesterday a campaign for resumption of service on the ferry line between the Battery and Atlantic Avenue, Brooklyn, which the Board of Estimate ordered discontinued last week. Petitions were circulated in the downtown shipping district and they will be distributed among the various industries related to shipping, to be presented to Mayor O'Brien and the board, urging reconsideration.

After presiding at a meeting of the executive committee of the Citizens Union which voted to ask District Attorney Crain and the grand jury to investigate garage racketeering, Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, head of the Committee of One Thousand and of the City party, addressed a meeting of the Protestant Episcopal clergy of Long Island in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon and received the endorsement of the meeting for the fight he is leading against racketeers.

GENEVA, Feb. 6. -- The French security plan received a body blow this afternoon at the Disarmament Commission session when Poland, France's closest ally, opposed it. On the other hand, Soviet Russia gave the plan the friendliest reception it has had yet from any of the great powers and the only substantial support it had gained from the East.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Sir Herbert Samuel, leader of the Liberal party in the House of Commons, made his long expected statement of policy today at a luncheon given for him by the party whips. He declared the Liberals were no longer under any obligation to support the National Government as it is now constituted or its policy as now declared.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 6. -- Three flying boats, a cruiser, two submarines, two destroyers and a minelayer are now pursuing the Dutch battleship De Zeven Provincien, which is on the Indian Sea in the hands of mutineers. The flying boat squadron left Batavia, Dutch Java, at daybreak under sealed orders.

Higher grain prices and the expectation that the General Motors Corporation would maintain the dividend rate on its common stock furnished the inspiration yesterday, in the judgment of Wall Street, for the partial recovery on the Stock Exchange.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- A resolution announcing the legislators as "strenuously and unqualifiedly opposed" to the proposal of Mayor John P. O'Brien of New York to tax New Jersey business commuters to that city was adopted tonight by the Senate within an hour after it had been introduced and adopted in the Assembly.

An Interesting trophy will be a stake for the event that is new to American competition -- the fours -- during the North American figure skating championships to be held here Friday and Saturday. The prize, the Duke of Connaught Trophy, will be on view in Madison Square Garden Saturday evening when the finals are held.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- The Argentine trade mission, headed by Dr. Julio A. Roca, Vice President of the republic, is arriving in London tomorrow in an attempt to offset the serious effects of the Ottawa agreements on Anglo-Argentine trade.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- American diplomatic missions in Paris, London, Vienna and Berlin have informed the State Department that they have not discovered that William C. Bullitt, is conducting diplomatic negotiations in Europe or is more than a correspondent, although he has been seen at 10 Downing Streeet in London and has talked with Joseph Paul-Boncour at present French Foreign Minister.

Declaring that the killing and maiming of firemen and destruction of their apparatus in accidents must stop, Fire Commissioner John J. Derman issued general orders yesterday designed to reduce the number of accidents in which fire apparatus is involved.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- Democrats in the Legislature will present a solid front in support of the plan for new and additional taxes, embodied in Governor Lehman's executive budget bill, with only minor changes. This became known following a conference this afternoon of the Governor with legislative leaders of the party.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (Canadian Press). -- Bill Cook of the Rangers and Laurence Northcott of the Maroons are tied in the race for National Hockey League point-scoring honors, according to the statistics issued tonight from the office of President Frank Calder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The quartet touring the country to chase away the blues and the gloom, by music and jokes, brought their funny stunts and a score of jokes to the White House today. The self-constituted chasers of gloom -- former Senator James MacFarlane of West Virginia, Major Charles Brinkerhoff, Pierce L. Reynolds and Joseph B. Dubreull, departed on their joke-making tour from New York last Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A Republican proposal to apply to Roosevelt progressives treatment somewhat similar to that which Southern Democrats applied to those who voted against Smith in 1928 has been going the rounds of the cloakrooms of the Senate for the last few days and only awaits leadership to become a definite movement.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- After a nervous and weak opening, the Boerse rallied in the course of the day, both in the stock and bond markets. The statement by Dr. Hugenberg, Economy and Food Minister in the Hitler Cabinet, that the government did not intend a compulsory adjustment of interest rates, went a long way toward reassuring the public.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Admiral Richard H. Leigh, commander-in-chief, reported to the Navy Department today that the United States fleet would get under way at the "zero hour," midnight tonight, to engage in manoeuvres in the Pacific off the west coast.

Net income of the Household Finance Corporation, according to the report for 1932 mailed yesterday to stockholders, was $3,645,280 after all charges including $2,245,684 of instalment notes written off as uncollectable. This was equivalent, after allowing the maximum participation for preference stock, to $4.29 a share on 600,499 common shares.

A family of five may eat and maintain health in New York City today on a food budget of $7.50 a week, through economy in buying, proper selection of food and care in its preparation, according to a demonstration conducted yesterday by pupils of the Washington Irving High School in the auditorium of the school.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) . -- A broad program for expanding the Federal Government's aid to the unemployed emerged from a Senate Banking subcommittee today with strong Democratic support.

Reflecting the firmness in security prices, the aggregate market value of all listed stocks on the New York Stock Exchange rose $305,557,373 in January, according to a compilation issued yesterday by the Exchange. In December, 1932, the market value of stocks on the Exchange increased $508,499,544, while in November it declined $1,181,524,654.

One lesson learned by 6-year-old Angelina Ruzzilina on her first day at school yesterday probably will stay in her mind longer than anything her teacher taught her. That is that elevated trains run on Fulton Street but not on Herkimer Street.

Vigorously protesting against the diversion of funds set aside in pesos for service on American dollar bonds of departments and municipalities of the Republic of Colombia, former Senator Robert L. Owen of Oklahoma, as chairman of the Independent Bondholders Committee of the Departments and Municipalities of Colombia, sent a letter yesterday to Secretary of State Stimson asking that the State Department take steps to safeguard the bondholders.

Exactly the same flaws, only worse in each particular, would be found in the Protestant churches in the United States as those found by the fifteen investigators for the recent Laymen's Foreign Missions' Inquiry Commission, in India, Japan and China, the Rev. Dr. William P. Merrill, pastor of the Brick Presbyterian Church, declared yesterday morning at the annual public meeting of the Greater New York Federation of Churches.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- A plan proposed by Georges Bonnet, Finance Minister, and Lucien Lamoureux, Budget Minister, for balancing the French budget for 1933, which is the third to be submitted to the French Chamber, was approved at today's Council of Ministers.

Reports on the valuations of properties that the Southern Pacific and Chicago, Rock Island Pacific plan to consolidate are expected to be issued by the Interstate Commerce Commission within thirty days. The valuation procedures are required under the section of the transportation act which requires that the capitalization of consolidated railroads shall not exceed their value as determined by the commission.

Although trade was on a substantially smaller scale than in 1931, Latin America's balance of payments will show a credit of $120,000,000 in 1932, against $92,000,000 in 1931, according to preliminary estimates by the Committee on Inter-American Relations.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A prisoner whose sentence has been suspended may be placed in jail by another judge sitting at another term of court, the Supreme Court decided today.

DETROIT, Feb. 6. -- Although about 300 strikers were on picket duty at the Briggs auto body plants this morning despite near zero weather, the factories opened at the usual hour with a force of about 3,000 workers. There was no disorder.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- In the campaign now in progress preparatory to the German election on March 5 it is already obvious that all the trump cards will be in one hand and it will be strange, indeed, if that hand is not the winner.
BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- The provisions of the decree issued by President von Hindenburg today for the control of the press and public assemblies follow:
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Opinions involving the authority of the Federal Tariff and Trade Commissions and the rights of States to levy special taxes were handed down in the Supreme Court today.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 6 (AP). -- Opposition to Governor Lehman's proposed sales tax, designed to assist the State to balance its budget, was sounded at a meeting here today of representative retail merchants from nearly every part of the Commonwealth.

With the Senate far behind schedule, caught in the jam of its own unrestrained loquacity, there is small chance that the "domestic allotment" plan of farm relief will be approved before March 4. Even if approved, it would doubtless be vetoed by the President, and there is no evidence of a two-thirds majority in either branch of Congres ready to override him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I am away from home and now in this country, I feel that the members of the British Society of Authors, Dramatists and Composers, whose chairman I have had the privilege of being for the past six years, would wish me to express appreciation of the editorial in your issue of yesterday on the loss literature has sustained by the death of John Galsworthy.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, Inc., attacked Governor Lehman's budget message as "not adequate," because "it does not meet the needs of the taxpayers," at a meeting at the Fox Meadow School here tonight.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- About $2,500,000 in Federal taxes will be collected, through a decision, announced by the Supreme Court today, under which the gift tax was held applicable to a transfer of trusts made seven years ago by Murry Guggenheim, capitalist, to his children.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- An impressive memorial service for Calvin Coolidge took place today, the President, Congress, the Supreme Court, the Cabinet, the army, the navy, the Marine Corps, the Coast Guard, Ambassadors and Ministers of foreign countries joining in solemn tribute to the "life, character and public service" of the former President.

SOME of the baseball magnates were discussing the schedule yesterday, but Sam Breadon, owner of the Cardinals, was off in a corner giving a little talk that was not on the schedule. It seems that Branch Kickey had said something about the Cardinals winning a world's series this year and making it possible for National Leaguers to face the world with a smile again.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Following is the address in full of Chief Justice Rugg of the Massachusetts Supreme Court at the Congressional exercises in memory of former President Coolidge.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 6. -- In one of the fastest 600-yard races ever run on an unbanked track, Bernie McCafferty of the Ne-wark A.C. held steadfast to his blazing pace right up to the tape to win the Waldron 600 in the brilliant figures of 1:13.8 at the Newark Armory tonight.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 6 (AP) -- Legal disapproval today was given to violence and intimidation by farmers at mortgage foreclosure auctions.

Nothing looks quite so homeless in the old Provincetown Playhouse as a sophisticated comedy that illuminates the domestic problems of the upper classes. Able seamen, stokers, poets, ploughboys and plantation Negroes have found that reformed barn a tidy haven, and no doubt that is why we still collect down there when a new venture is started.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 6. -- The Senate committee hearing on fraud charges in this State's Senatorial primary resolved itself for a time today into a verbal duel on campaign fund levies between Chairman Robert B. Howell and Senator Huey P. Long, counsel for John H. Overton, whom he backed to defeat Senator Edwin S. Broussard for the Democratic renomination.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- Attempting to extricate itself from a two-month legislative jam, the Senate spent two hours today trying to fix the blame for its present inactivity and decided after a record vote that no party now controlled the body.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- With the appearance tonight of Maria Jeritza, the Society of Arts inaugurated the series of three concerts for members only, to be given during February at the Everglades Club. Mme. Jeritza who, with Baron Leopold von Popper, her husband, is staying at the club, was received with unusual enthusiasm.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Released by kidnappers who had held her captive since last night, Mrs. Walter F. Skeele, 65 years old, wife of the music dean of the University of Southern California, returned to her home in a hysterical condition at 8 o'clock tonight.

MONTREAL, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Discovery that vitamins apparently are helpless in improving health without the aid of a "silent partner" in the stomach was reported today before the American College of Physicians.

Safe-robbers looted Oetjen's Restaurant, 2,210 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, of $5,000 early yesterday morning shortly after another group was captured while attempting to force the door of a safe at the Rugby Theatre, 823 Utica Avenue. Police, answering a radio alarm, arrested three men in the manager's office of the theatre after firing a shot into the ceiling as a warning to surrender.

The importance of preserving the traditional friendliness of Franco-American relations, and some aspects of the war-debt problem, were stressed last night by speakers at a dinner at the Waldorf to commemorate the 155th anniversary of the signing of the treaty of alliance and commerce between the two countries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A proclamation certifying that the Twentieth, or "lame duck," Amendment is now a part of the Constitution was issued by Secretary Stimson today. It will take practical effect next Oct. 15. After that Congress will meet on Jan. 3 and the President and Vice President will be in-augurated on Jan. 20.

The opening date for "One Sunday Afternoon," the new play by James Hagan which Leo Bulgakov and Leslie J. Spiller are producing, has been definitely set for Friday evening, Feb. 10, at the Little Theatre.

Strength in German loans contrasted with general weakness in virtually all other groups of the listed bond market yesterday. Despite the disquieting news from Germany over the week-end, holders of American dollar bonds found a basis for fresh hope in the remarks of Theodore Duesterberg, Presidential candidate at the last election, that he did not favor forcible interference with existing agreements regarding interest rates.

Certified milk is the most vital factor in lowering the community Infant death rate, Dr. Shirley W. Wynne, Health Commission, declared yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Metropolitan Certified Milk Dealers, Inc., who held a joint meeting with the Certified Milk Producers Association of America, Inc., at the Hotel Commodore.

Tammany has never been weaker than it is today, William Ziegrler Jr. declared last night in an address before the members of the Republican Club of the Twelfth Assembly District (middle), at the clubhouse, 230 East Thirty-sixth Street. Mr. Ziegler, who is treasurer of the Republican State Committee, was speaking in his capacity as chairman of the Aldermanic campaign committee of the Republican Mayoralty committee.

The pamphlet report of the Bell Telephone Company of Pennsylvania for 1932 shows a net income of $6,886,570 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after $1,300,000 of preferred dividends, to $5.08 a share earned on 1,100,000 common shares, compared with $10,912,822, or $8.73 a share, earned in 1931.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, SAN PEDRO, Cal., Feb. 6. -- The calm waters of San Pedro Harbor were streaked with the white waves of small boats today and naval observation planes roared across the sky as the Blue fleet began final preparations for the "Battle of the Pacific."
Ten canvases from the brush of Mrs. Irying T. Bush, wife of the financier, startied visitors to the Knoedler Galleries in East Fiftyseventh Street yesterday. They were spirit paintings.

Two artists -- Carla Wellendorf and Simeon Braguin -- are holding one-man shows at the Marie Harriman Gallery, 61 East Fifty-seventh Street. Mme. Wellendorf, whose oils occupy the larger of the two exhibition rooms, is a Danish artist who has apparently spent some time in Paris.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Grantland Rice, perennial titleholder, started in his customary auspicious manner today by winning the medal in the sixth annual Winter championship tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association, at the Palm Beach Country Club.
Two Brooklyn deals and several Manhattan transactions were included in the city realty market activity reported yesterday.

Club owners of the National League will spring something striking today when they hold their annual schedule meeting, which in recent years has never really involved the schedule to any greater extent than to see it ratified officially as a matter of form.

Trapped in the darkened hallway of a house at 436 Union Street, Brooklyn, where they had gone in search of a murder suspect, two detectives shot their way out of the place last night in a furious rough and tumble battle with at least a dozen men and women.
While recovery was the rule in all the markets yesterday, the incident of greatest interest, aside from the sharp advance in German bonds, was a rise of 3 5/8 cents in sterling exchange.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- A 300-pound iron safe, containing about $150,000 worth of stocks and bonds, was stolen from the Overbrook home of George K. Bartle, a director and assistant merchandise manager of a store here, early Friday morning, it was revealed today when Mr. Bartle returned from Florida.

Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, returned from a three weeks' trip through the Middle West yesterday and reported what he characterized as a distinct trend toward an American brand of Fascist dictatorship and toward war. He said that no improvement in the economic situation was to observed.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Horace Annesley Vachell, as chairman, told the Dickens Fellowship birthday dinner tonight that "The Mystery of Edwin Drood" was about to be published in the form Dickens apparently intended it to have.

Adoption in the United States of the English practice of levying a penny a ton on all coal mined for to benefit of the miners would raise $3,000,000 a year and might well be the beginning of a movement, to help rehabilitate surplus miners and to further research in coal, according to Malcolm Ross, whose book on "Machine Age in the Hills" was published yesterday by Macmillan.

Fire starting in the "Tunnels of Love," a water ride at West Twelfth Street and the Bowery, Coney Island, about an hour before dawn yesterday, swept the entire south side of the Bowery one block east to Jones Walk, doing damage estimated at $250,000.

Combining an alert defensive with a powerful attack, the Textile High School quintet, defending City P.S. A.L. champion, routed Townsend Harris, 55 -- 11, yesterday at the Textile gymnasium for its second victory in as many starts in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond Division of the P.S.A.L.
Columbia's varsity rowing squad officially started its campaign yesterday when thirty candidates reported for workouts on the machines in the Morningside gymnasium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The statements made by President Gerardo Machado in an interview granted to your paper are widely at variance with the true facts of the case. If his intention has been to prevent the country's falling into a state of anarchy or military dictatorship, his system has proved most unfortunate as shown by the actual result, because such is precisely the situation in Cuba today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6.-- While House Republicans chided the Democratic leaders with being afraid to call a caucus to attempt to bind the majority to fight a depreciated currency tariff, the Ways and Means Committee planned an executive session tomorrow to act upon a subcommittee report rejecting the measure.

The grouse family is one of the most interesting among our game birds. It is a large family, sending species to the far corners of the North American Continent. There was a time when the ruffed grouse was very plentiful along the Atlantic seaboard, but this species has decreased so rapidly that it seldom is seen in its former habitat.

The trustee for bonds of the Allephany Corporation, top company in the railroad holding structure controlled by the Van Sweringen interests, held impounded cash of $1,714,778 on Wednesday, the last date on which collateral for the bonds was appraised.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 6 (AP). -- Governor McAlister today postponed until 3 P.M. tomorrow his decision on the request of North Carolina for the extradition of Colonel Luke Lea and Luke Lea Jr.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) -- Senate committees consider farm relief measures tonight put an end to a torrent of testimony and began the actual task of preparing legislation for submission to the Senate.
Industrial and business properties comprised a large part of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
NEW YORK. James H.R. Cromwell is returning to the Waldorf-Astoria tomorrow from Palm Beach, where he has been with his mother, Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury.

F.S. Yantis, who until Feb. 1, was vice president of Chandler Co., Inc., has organised F.S. Yantis Co., Inc., with offices at 61 Broadway, to do a general investment business. Prior to his association with Chandler Co., he was vice president of Folds, Buck Co. of Chicago.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- The last remnants of Prussia's autonomous rights as a Federated State were decreed away by President von Hindenburg today when he vested Vice Chancellor von Papen, as Reich Commissioner for Prussia, with complete ministerial powers.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Playing in defense of his title, Albert R. Hakes, youthful star of Dunkirk, N.Y., won the qualifying medal today in the twenty-first annual South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club. The Empire State representative scored 34 -- 36 -- 70, one over par, to lead the field by two strokes.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 6. -- E.R. Plunkett's I Pass, a 4-year-old son of Thunderer and Two No Trumps, trumped several equine aces and passed everything in the St. Augustine Purse at Hialeah Park today to win amid general surprise at $37.90 for $2.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 6. -- The Nassau County police sent out an alarm today for a man known only as "Blackie," a resident of Jamaica, Queens, who is wanted for questioning in connection with the killing of Mary Helen O'Connor, 15-year-old high school student, of 116 Beach 113th Street, Rockaway Park, Queens, whose body was found in Massapequa, L.I., last Thursday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- David S. Barry, suspended sergeant-at-arms of the Senate, appeared before the Senate Judiciary Committee today with a defense of his motives in writing the magazine article for which he faces dismissal from his post.
Four women fencers, who will represent this city in the national junior foils championship competition on Feb. 15, gained the right to compete for the titular honors last night at the Fencers Club.

The Board of Estimate voted unanimously at a special meeting yesterday to appropriate $5,000 through the sale of revenue bonds to finance a recanvass of the votes cast in the general election last November, which resulted in the election of John P. O'Brien as Mayor.

State of Mississippi. In an effort to refund certificates of indebtedness due on March 1, the State of Mississippi will offer on next Monday, which will be Lincoln's Birthday holiday here, new bonds for $6,657,000, according to word received yesterday.

The National Bureau of Casualty and Surety Underwriters announced yesterday increases of slightly more than 12 per cent in liability insurance rates for pleasure cars in the Jersey City area, which includes all municipalities in Hudson County east of the Hackensack River.

Consumption of all kinds of cotton throughout the world is estimated at 2,042,000 bales for December by the New York Cotton Exchange Service. This compares with 2,039,000 bales in November, 1,931,000 in December, 1931, and 1,908,000 in December. 1930.

Prices moved irregularly yesterday on the local commodity exchanges. Trading was quiet. Sugar and silk made gains while coffee, cocoa, hides and silver were slightly lower. Cash prices were generally higher.

Statement showing the budget for 1933 as adopted by the Board of Estimate and Apportionment on Oct. 31, 1932, in comparison with the budget for 1933, as proposed by the Mayor, reflecting recommended decreases in tax-levy appropriations. And in addition, reductions payable from funds not contained in the 1933 tax-levy budget.

New York Alone! It was bound to come. The people of this State are now invited in the matter of vegetables to "Buy New York." They must not stand idly by and see the canning industries of the State driven out of business by "out-of-State cheaply canned, inferior quality fruits and vegetables."

The Oxford University Press says that "the increased influence of American thought and speech" on the English language is particularly noticeable in the Shorter Oxford English Dictionary, now being brought out here. The book is an edited revision of the many volumes of the Oxford English Dictionary, of which the first part appeared in 1884 and the last in 1928.

Representative William F. Brunner of Queens called on the Long Island Real Estate Board and other groups in Queens yesterday to protest to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation against the appropriation of funds for new housing projects in Manhattan or for the construction of a new tunnel to New Jersey.

ALBANY, Feb. 6. -- A resolution seeking a legislative investigation into the method of rendering bills by the telephone companies of the State was introduced in the upper house tonight by Senator Julius S. Berg, Democrat, of the Bronx.

Hans Birkle, the stolid German heavyweight, received the decision over Donald (Red) Barry of Washington at the St. Nicholas Arena last night. A crowd of 1,500 persons saw the 10-round battle, which was fought at a furious pace all the way.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 6. -- At the request of the Lower Hudson River Association, Jay Downer, county engineer, was appointed by the Westchester Board bf Supervisors today to sit with a committee of the association which is making a survey of a proposal to construct a toll highway along the Hudson River from Yonkers to Tarry town.

After receiving a revised budget yesterday from Mayor John P. O'Brien showing reductions of $38,775,228.74 in expenses financed through the tax levy, the Board of Estimate by resolution set tomorrow for a public hearing.

MIAMI, Feb. 6 -- News of President-elect Roosevelt's departure for Nassau was contained in the following radiogram today from Vincent Astor to Colonel Marvin H. McIntyre, Mr. Roosevelt's personal press representative, received at 2:31 P.M.:

Harry A. Cronk, president of the New York Milk Conference Board and head of the Borden Farm Products Company, announced last night that a petition would be presented to Governor Lehman in Albany today asking the repeal of the 1932 laws imposing higher license fees on motor trucks, tractors and trailers, and charging that these laws "impose a heavy and unfair burden upon agricultural enterprise within the State."

Conflict between the religion that accepts the present competitive order and the social idealism that condemns it is keener today than that between religion and science, Mordecai M. Kaplan, Professor of Homiletics and dean of Teacher's Institute of the Jewish Theological Seminary of America, declared yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- A further loan of $11,127,700 to the Chicago North Western Railway Company from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.

The heaviest selling pressure in recent sessions carried prices at the opening of the Cotton Exchange yesterday to the lowest quotations since the day after the annual crop estimate was issued in December. All active deliveries of the 1932 crop sold below 6 cents a pound.

The Associated Telephone Utilities Company has written to holders of its $3,858,000 6 per cent secured gold notes due on April 1, 1933, asking them to join in an extension of the due date until April 1, 1935, to avert a receivership for the company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- A special board of army engineers has recommended Federal expenditures totaling $27,500,000 for improvement of the New York State barge canal from the Hudson River to Three Rivers Point and from there to Lake Ontario.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Friday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

DOORN, Feb. 6. -- A continuous stream of the "Imperial household's" baggage, passing on the way to Germany through one of the railway stations near Doorn, causes this little town to believe former Kaiser Wilhelm is preparing to regain his throne in Berlin.

The Inquiry into the assets of the bankrupt United Cigar Stores Company of America, which were transferred at various stages of the financing of subsidiaries, was continued yesterday at a hearing of creditors before Irwin Kurtz, referee in bankruptcy, in his offices at 15 Park Row.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Members of the Women's Guild of the Empire participated in a demonstration outside Bow Street Court today because Miss Winifred James, formerly Mrs. Henry de Jan, had been accused of a violation of the aliens act.

Months have been spent in preparations in India and England for the flight over Mount Everest. The climb of the first plane, piloted by Lord CLYDESDALE, with an observer, from the southern base, a tract unexplored, will take only a very few hours.

The Levys had an unexpected get-together in Judge Collins's part of General Sessions yesterday when twelve of them, strangers to one another, were among fifty talesmen called in a special panel from which to select twenty-three members each for the regular and additional county grand juries.
DUBLIN, Feb. 6. -- Striking developments in connection with Ireland's White Army, which is opposed to the Irish Republican Army, may provide President Eamon de Valera with a thorny problem.

GENEVA, Feb. 6. -- With the French and British showing unusual firmness, the League of Nations Committee of Nineteen unanimously decided this morning to recommend not merely non-recognition of Manchukuo in law, but non-cooperation with it in practice.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has remarkable gifts of persuasion. They must be almost supernormal if the persistent rumors are correct that he has "tentatively selected" four Senators as members of his Cabinet and that three, Mr. GLASS, Mr. WALSH of Montana and Mr. HULL, have consented.

HAVANA, Feb. 6. -- An appeal to save her son from death at the hands of the police was made this morning by Senora Eulalia Guzman to the Spanish Embassy here following his arrest late last night. This student, Luis Fuentes Guzman, was arrested with a student companion, Jose Manuel Aleman, when the automobile in which the youths were riding collided with that of Representative Felipe Gonzales Sarrain.

Facing possible sentences of from twenty to fifty years in Sing Sing, two suspended New York City patrolmen and their three alleged accomplices went on trial in Brooklyn yesterday on charges of kidnapping Ernest Schoenig, a New Jersey bootlegger.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., Feb. 6. -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., women's Western champion, won medal honors today in the qualifying test of the Bay Shore-La Gorce women's title tournament on the Bay Shore golf course.

BERLIN, Feb. 6. -- Contemporaneously with the sessions here of the Wiggin standstill committee on German private debts there came out today an Interesting personal statement from Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Minister of Economics and Agriculture and so-called "economic dictator" in the Hitler Cabinet, modifying to some degree his recent declaration in favor of action to reduce the burden of the German private debt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- While Senator Norris, an active Progressive supporter of President-elect Roosevelt, would regret "stripping" the Senate to fill Cabinet positions, he said today that he had not protested and would not protest such an action by Mr. Roosevelt.

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Upon authorization of the French Ministry of Marine a complaint was filed today in the Bordeaux courts charging persons unknown with deliberate arson in connection with the burning of the French steamer Atlantique.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Regal Flag, a speedy son of Sun Flag, from the Pine Tree Farm, today won his second consecutive race at the Fair Grounds, coming from behind to defeat a band of sprinters at six furlongs. The time was 1:13 3-5.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- Links between Persian and European architecture were described today by Arthur Upham Pope, director of the American Institute of Persian Art and Archeology. The institute's exhibition of photographs of Islamic architecture in Persia was opened by Ambassador Mellon of the United States at the Royal Institute of British Architects today.

The policy of the State Department at Washington toward the Machado Government in Cuba -- a policy that has been widely criticized as keeping President Machado in power against the will of the Cuban people -- is based upon the Root interpretation of the Platt amendment.

HAVANA, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The lightly weighted Bea M., from the stable of J.D. Weil, today won the feature race, a five-and-one-half-furlong claiming affair for 3-year-olds, at Oriental Park, in a driving finish with A. Pelleteri's La Contessa.

Armed robbers held up rent collectors in two widely separated sections of the city yesterday and escaped with money that had just been collected from tenants. In the Bronx three thugs got away with $2,000, while in the Astoria section of Queens two hold-up men made off with $400.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 6 (AP). -- The will of William Halls Jr., banker and philanthropist, of Summit, who died of pneumonia in Philadelphia Jan. 26, was filed for probate today in the Union County Surrogate's office. It disposes of an estate valued at more than $1,000,000.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 6. -- Columbia University's basketball team tomorrow will be greeted by the first overflow crowd that has thronged Payne Whitney Gymnasium, which seats 1,600. To meet the ticket demand the Yale Athletic Association will erect 200 emergency bleacher seats for what is expected to be the largest crowd ever to witness a basketball game at Yale.

DENVER, Feb. 6 (AP). -- The fortune left by Frederick G. Bonfils, publisher of The Denver Post, will be devoted to charitable, educational and scientific purposes, through the Frederick G. Bonfils Foundation, after annuities and bequests have been paid.

Acting to check the boom in gold stocks on the London stock market, the official control yesterday stepped out of the sterling market and allowed the pound to rise to the best price since Oct. 17, at $3.44 1/4, up 4 3/8 cents from Saturday's final price.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The statement by Viscount Snowden of Ickornshaw, published in THE NEW YORK TIMES today, that the granting of compensation in the form of freer access to British markets of American commodities could with advantage be considered in connection with revision of the British war-debt problem, was viewed in official circles here as a move to offset declarations by Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, that there should be no such trading.

Labor troubles at Detroit resulted in a sharp decrease in motor car production last week. Not only was Ford closed throughout the week, but operations at several other plants were slackened as a direct or indirect result of the strike.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, world's heavyweight wrestling champion, had no difficulty defending his crown last night against the assault of Dr. Fred Meyers, Chicago's grappler-dentist, in Madison Square Garden.

After touching a low for 1933 at 6 o'clock yesterday morning, when a temperature of 13 degrees above zero was registered, the cold that gripped the city over the week-end moderated, thanks to a shift of the wind to the south, and last night the temperature was slowly rising.

England seems to be waking up to the fact that Americans have a viewpoint of their own about the war debts. There are pleasing signs that the British Government perceives the need of finding out more fully and accurately what people in this country think and want and are prepared to do.

Club owners of the International League made another determined effort to solve their vexing problem involving the Jersey City franchise at a meeting in the Hotel New Yorker yesterday. Although they again failed of their objective, nevertheless they completed a number of other important accomplishments.

Senator Elmer Thomas of Oklahoma, Democrat, last night told a gathering of partners of firms in the New York security and commodity exchanges and officers and directors of financial institutions in this city, that the depression had been ingineered here and that "you and you alone can give the order and set in motion the machinery which will pull us out of the mire."

PARIS, Feb. 6. -- Lanvin combines wide, square shoulders with extremely loose cuts, creating an individual silhouette. Square flaps, beginning as incrustations, prolong the shoulders of suit jackets or capes. Square back capes and travelcoats carry out the same motifs, extra wide sailor collars are used on frocks and jackets.
The ten principles laid down by the Lytton report as a basis for permanent peace between Japan and China are as follows:

Joseph P.A. Hart, president of the general contracting firm of Hart Early, which held contracts of more than $7,000,000 for work on the new Eighth Avenue subway, died on Sunday at the Johns Hopkins University Hospital, Baltimore, after a long illness.

The mysterious disappearances of sums of money belonging to persons who had consulted gypsy fortune tellers led yesterday to the arraignment of "King" Bimbo and two other gypsies in magistrates' courts.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Feb. 6. -- His two dogs put to death in accordance with an agreement with the Associated Humane Societies, Robert Lichtenfels, 78 years old, who was found dead yesterday in the house at 74 Fortieth Street in which he had lived alone here for thirty years, will be buried tomorrow without services or witnesses by Charles F. Hausmann, Irvington undertaker, who was his only friend.

If New York's example in organizing a community dental service to provide dentistry for the needy is universally adopted, dental service would be made available to the public without taxes or insurance, Dr. Herman J. Kauffer, president of the First District Dental Society, declared in an address at the monthly meeting of the organization at the New York Academy of Medicine last night.

LONDON, Feb. 6. -- When Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, arrived in London today and had his first talk with Cabinet Ministers one recommendation he brought from President-elect Roosevelt, it is understood, was that a lump-sum settlement would be the best solution of the debt problem.

Supreme Court Justice Lydon signed an order yesterday permitting James A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banks, as liquidator of the Bank of United States, to join in the settlement of suits against five former directors of the bank and to release all claims against them.

In a last-minute rush American investors who put $130,000,000 into the debentures of the Kreuger Toll Company four years ago filled the office of Henry K. Davis, referee, at 140 Nassau Street, all day yesterday until midnight. Yesterday was the last day under the bankruptcy law to file proof of claim to share in such assets as may be salvaged eventually from the wreck of Ivar Kreuger's worldwide organization.

Charged with splitting $216,000 fees in workmen's compensation cases in the last four years, and with conspiracy to defraud the City, Dr. William H. Walker, brother of former Mayor James J. Walker, and four other physicians went on trial yesterday before a subcommittee of the medical research grievance committee of the State Board of Education, in the State Building, 80 Centre Street.

CHICAGO, Feb. 6. -- A severe cold wave sweeping the Winter wheat belt and skies dark with dust over parts of Kansas and Nebraska started today a buying movement on the Board of Trade here, headed by professional operators, that carried prices up 1 3/4 cents a bushel from Saturday's finish.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Feb. 1 shows an increase for the week of $126,000,000 in loans, offset in part by a decrease of $20,000,000 in investments, also decreases of $87,000,000 in reserve balances with Federal Reserve Banks and $37,000,000 in net demand deposits, and increases of $57,000,000 in government deposits and $5,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

Forty-three hours after he was alleged to have shot Sergeant Eugene Monohan of the Wadsworth Avenue Station in a subway train in the 181st Street station of the west side I.R.T. line last Saturday night, Floyd Whitman, 27 years old, an unemployed plumber, was indicted yesterday by the grand jury under the name of William Henry Dickson on a first-degree murder charge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP). -- On the motion of Pennsylvania the Supreme Court today dismissed the suit brought by the State against New Jersey arising out of the construction of the new Delaware River Bridge. The case was begun about seven years ago.

Publication of the detailed figures of the vote cast for members of the Assembly by the two leading parties last November affords an opportunity for interesting comparisons. Even in Democratic years up-State Republicans have a way of standing by their local candidates.

A substantial reduction in the unrealized depreciation on the investment portfolio of the Massachusetts Investors Trust was effected in 1932 through the realization of losses, according to the annual report, mailed yesterday to shareholders.
The directors of the General Motors Corporation declared yesterday the regular quarterly dividends of 25 cents a share on the common stock and $1.25 a share on the $5 preferred stock.

More than 633,000 persons among the families of unemployed are badly in need of clothing and bedding, according to an announcement yesterday by the Welfare Council, based on a partial survey of clothing needs.

There has been a progressive decrease in the number of fatalities among children from traffic accidents during the past ten years. Philip D. Hoyt, First Deputy Police Commissioner, told about 250 school teachers yesterday afternoon at the first of a series of twenty lectures being sponsored jointly by the Police Department and the Board of Education to reduce further the number of street accidents.
LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 7. -- British airmen are engaged in two great flying adventures and they reported good progress.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 6. -- It will be virtually an all-Warner aggregation of football coaches at Temple University this Fall.
Two knockouts scored by Pat Robertson of the Unionport A.C. featured the bi-monthly amateur boxing show held last night at the New York Athletic Club.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 6. -- While the ABC-Peru group is exchanging notes to decide on a formula for solution of the Chaco war, with which they expect to show the commission of neutrals in Washington how it should have been done. French and German war methods agraln are struggling for supremacy at the Verdun of the Chaco, as Fort Nanawa has come to be known in South America.

A charge that Albert Grossman, or Al Gross, alleged proprietor of the Breakfast Club, which occupied quarters in the Hotel Delmonico before it was raided, threatened to put her "on the spot" if she testified against him, was made in Federal Court yesterday by Mrs. Julia S. Reardon, formerly in charge of personnel and filing at the club.

The formation of the Victor Herbert Memorial, Inc., to perpetuate the name of the late composer by assisting needy musicians and composers, was announced yesterday after Supreme Court Justice Hatting had approved a certificate of incorporation for the memorial.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 -- Mrs. Margaret Sanger today characterized as "a new book on a repudiated theory" a compilation by Dr. Leo J. Latz of the Loyola School of Medicine of theories advanced in behalf of the contention that women are naturally sterile eighteen to twenty days in each month.

Three players yesterday advanced to the third round of the 1933 veterans' squash tennis tournament at the Coulmbia Club. They were F.A. Sieverman of the New York Athletic Club, A.J. Cameron of the Shelton Club and R.H. Reutter of the home club.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 6. -- Marking their first tournament appearance in America, as well as the initial bid of any English player in quest of the title, the members of the British women's squash racquets team all survived the opening round of the national championship today as play got under way on the courts of the Merion Cricket Club before crowded galleries.

Six self-liquidating projects, including the proposed Thirty-eighth Street-Weehawken vehicular tunnel and involving a total of $98,250,000, were approved by Governor Lehman's Emergency Public Works Commission yesterday as the basis for immediate applications for loans to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

OKLAHOMA CITY, Feb. 8 (AP). -- After fourteen of the more than fifty defendants threw themselves on the mercy of the court, the government today postponed the Julian mail fraud trial until June, because C.C. Julian, the principal defendant, carried out his threat not to appear.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 6 (AP). -- Challenging the public to test their strength, New Orleans banks threw banking hours into the discard today and kept their doors open from dawn until dusk, notifying, through full-page newspaper advertisements, depositors who might be nervous about false rumors of local difficulties to withdraw if they so desired.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Debts Across the Sea" is evidently intended as a piece of timely advice to those of us who have been disturbed by the recent turn events relative to the war debts have taken. Its message is admirable, and in so far as it urges us to suspend judgement it is excellent; but, alas, it is so unconvincing!

WASHINGTON, Feb. 6 (AP) --As he prepares to leave the White House after four strenuous years of residence, Herbert Hoover is enjoying -- in the words of his physician -- "excellent health" and trim physical condition.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- The 201 members of the Senate and Assembly have voluntarily accepted a $155 cut in their annual salaries of $2,500. This is in accord with a policy set down by Governor Lehman in his annual message, in which he recommended graduated reductions in the pay of all State officials and employes whose salaries were not fixed by the Constitution and who were receiving from $2,000 upward.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- The permanent committee of the Prussian Diet decided today that the State election should be held March 5, the same day as the Reichstag balloting, as proposed by the federal government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Harvey S. Firestone, chairman of the board of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company, after discussing economic conditions with President Hoover today made public a statement in which he asserted that "vicious price cutting" was "gradually driving industry into insolvency."

The Protestant churches in New York are suffering from an inferiority complex, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared last evening at the annual dinner of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, which was held in the Riverside Church, 122d Street and Riverside Drive, of which he is pastor.

James Orr Elton of Salt Lake City has been named as recipient of the James Douglas Medal for 1933, it was announced yesterday by A. B. Parsons, secretary of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers. The award, the highest in the metallurgical field in the United States, was established in memory of Dr. James Douglas, who was largely responsible for the development of copper metallurgy in Arizona.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Unable to find Republican member of the Legisilature from New York City to act as sponsor for the measure, the citizens Union has asked Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange County to introduce its bill embodying a new charter for the city, as recommended by Samuel Seabury in his report as counsel to the Mofstadter committee.

COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 7. -- Acting on the petition of Louis Mansbach of New York, Federal Judge J. Lyles Glenn has ordered the Lexington Water Company of South Carolina to show cause at Columbia on Feb. 15 why a receiver should not be appointed for the company.

Yasuo Kuniyoshi's first one-man show in several years opened yesterday at the Downtown Gallery. It is not a large exhibition, containing only eleven canvases, but the progress this artist has been making of late is illustrated so forcefully as to leave little room for argument on that score.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- After ten years of controversy and discussion, the London County Council today accepted the government's plan for reconstruction of Waterloo Bridge, which has lately become one of London's major engineering problems.

Further cuts in the school budget may result in "thoughtlessly sacrificing the greater good and the lasting good for a lesser and more immediate good," according to a warning sounded by Chancellor Elmer Elsworth Brown of New York University at a conference of educators last evening at the home of Adolph Lewisohn, 881 Fifth Avenue, under the auspices of the Public Education Association.
