DETROIT, Feb. 7 -- Three thousand automobile body workers at the Hudson Motor Car Company's plant went on strike today as officials of the Briggs Automobile Body Manufacturing Company, where a strike resulted in a shutdown of the Ford works, were announcing that 5,000 men had been employed for their plants.

The listed bond market showed a better degree of steadiness yesterday than at any time in nearly a week. Domestic corporation bonds, especially, showed rallying tendencies, with a number of representative issues recovering a point or more for the day.

The Senate Subcommittee on Banking and Currency, which is conducting the stock, market inquiry, will hold a hearing in Washington on Friday at 10 A.M., Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the committee, announced here yesterday.

Soon after President Machado and his highly efficient army put down the revolution led by former President Menocal in August, 1931, President Machado took the position, according to most reliable American sources of information in Havana, that he could put an end to all the unrest in Cuba by means which he knew how to use, except that he did not wish to antagonize public opinion in the United States.
Leonora Corona, soprano of the Metropolitan, was a guest of the Music Society last evening at the Hotel Gotham.

Production of crude oil throughout the world in 1932 amounted to 1,293,829,801 barrels, according to an estimate made by World Petroleum. This was a reduction of 61,555,711 barrels, or about 4.75 per cent, from the 1,355,385,512 barrels produced in 1931.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- The roll of Britain's jobless is creeping up to the 3,000,000 mark. The government's returns for Jan. 23, just issued, report an increase of 179,778 over the previous month, bringing the total unemployed to 2,903,065.

A court partition sale of the six tenement houses at 508-518 East Eighty-fourth Street yesterday resulted in the purchase of the buildings by six heirs of John Schreiner Sr. The sale was conducted by Joseph P. Day in settlement of the Schreiner estate and the partition action was brought by John Schreiner and others, plaintiffs, against Helena Bardes and others, defendants.
A noticeable tinge of anxiety in the otherwise professional plea of Miss Madeline De Fina, Brooklyn lawyer, excited the curiosity of County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: House Bill No. 14,131 may have been drawn in the interests of stamp collectors, as is stated by Stephen G. Rich in a letter to THE TIMES, but the makers of that bill certainly overlooked a few important facts -- probably in their zeal to make stamp-collecting easier for many of the novices of the hobby.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, Feb. 7. -- About 1,800 Sandinistas have already gathered in San Rafael del Norte to lay down their arms in accordance with the peace terms reached with their leader, General Agusto Sandino, it is reported here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Senate by a vote of 53 to 17 ousted its sergeant-at-arms, David S. Barry, this evening, for writing an article in which he said that "not many" members of Congress took money for their votes.

Babe Ruth quietly celebrated his thirty-ninth birthday yesterday in his west side apartment and professed to see no reason why the passing of another milestone should prevent him from contributing another substantial batch of home runs to the cause of the New York Yankees.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- New York will be asked to pay $89,000,000 as it share in the development of the St. Lawrence waterway, it was understood from a reliable source today.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- J. J. Robinson's Eisenberg merely cantered along in front of a clever 3-year-old band to win the feature race at the Fair Grounds today. Mrs. R.T. Flippen's Harold Jr. finished second after forcing the pace all the way, while Doris B. was a distanced third.

Reports by way of London that Mr. ROOSEVELT would favor accepting a lump sum in payment of the "present value" of the war debts seem rather tenuous. They can elicit no denial from him while he is at sea. It is highly probable that he has considered this proposal, among others that may be made to him.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your Madrid correspondent has confused the philosopher Jose Ortega Gasset with his brother, Eduardo Ortega Gasset. Since the former's books are at last becoming known in America, it might be worth while to point out the difference between them for the benefit of those interested.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- A thorough investigation of lobbying as it affects members of Congress was demanded today by Representative Patman of Texas. His joint resolution was a more or less direct result of the charges contained in an article written for The New Outlook by David S. Barry, suspended Sergeant-at-Arms of the Senate, and of utterances of Senators Glass and Thomas of Oklahoma regarding lobbyists.

At a meeting of the board of directors of the American Kennel Club, held yesterday in connection with the annual meeting of the delegates to the governing body in this country, officers were elected as follows: President, Russell H. Johnson Jr. of Philadelphia; executive vice president, Charles T. Inglee of Plainfield, N.J. Secretary and Treasurer Perry B. Rice was re-elected.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The number of New York youths who have been designated to take the March 7 entrance examination for the United States Military Academy at West Point have been increased by the selection of a number of enlisted men from the ranks of the army.

GENEVA, Feb. 7. -- The United States gave its view on the French security-disarmament plan today in the disarmament conference and was the last great power to do so. Its view, which Hugh S. Gibson expressed in a 200-word statement, was non-committal, as the "interregnum" at Washington, had led most persons to expect.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Assurance that several of the leading munitions manufacturing nations of the world had expressed a desire to cooperate with the United States in the movement to ban shipment of arms and munitions of war to nations in conflict was given to the House Foreign Relations Committee today by under-Secretary Castle and Joseph Green of the Western European Division of the State Department.

The County Lawyers Association and the committee on State legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York announced their disapproval yesterday of several bills pending in the Legislature.

Robert J. Byers, department adjutant and welfare officer of the American Legion, department of Michigan, and George S. Krieger, a New York merchant, were indicted yesterday by the Federal grand jury here on a charge of conspiracy to defraud the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- In recognition of their efforts in connection with the colonial exposition in Paris in 1931 fourteen American citizens will receive decorations from the French and French Colonial Governments tomorrow. The presentations will be made by Ambassador Claudel at the French Embassy here at a tea in honor of the eight recipients.

Four persons narrowly escaped death last night when a coupe in which they were riding crashed through a gate guarding the approach to the Long Island Railroad tracks at 119th Avenue, Queens, and into the side of a speeding Long Beach express.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 7. -- An injunction to silence any discussion of a Coolidge-for-President movement in 1936 was framed by the late Calvin Coolidge only a few days before his death last month. This was revealed here tonight by Edward T. Clark, Mr. Coolidge's attache at the White House.
After having dropped on Monday to the lowest level in about two months, prices on the Cotton Exchange continued yesterday the recovery begun on the previous day and made net gains of 5 to 9 points.

The fine spirit of friendly camaraderie and mutual cooperation which existed between Patrick Danaher, manager of a chain grocery store at 2,032 Fulton Street, Brooklyn, and the 20-year-old robber who held him up and took his receipts on Monday, Wednesday and Friday of last week, were temporarily interrupted yesterday when David Failor, the dapper young desperado, fell into the hands of the law.

According to Professor WILLCOX of Cornell, who may be said to be our chief demographer, the population of the globe has nearly quadrupled in less than three centuries. He estimates the earth's population (as of 1929) at 1,820,000,000. Thus nearly two billion persons are carried by this planet in its daily rotation and in its yearly revolution -- for when one falls back into the dust another springs to take his place.

Unable to ratify a complete schedule due to the possibility of Sunday baseball becoming legalized in Pennsylvania, club owners of the National League nevertheless occupied themselves for more than five hours at their annual schedule meeting in the Hotel Commodore yesterday.

Inflation, Loose or Wrapped. Mr. NORMAN THOMAS has a vision of the nearer future which cannot be called exactly cheerful, but which does show a brighter side. It is some consolation to know that the end of things is not around the corner.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- Worth maintains the straight, slender silhouette without circular cut or godets for day and evening. Some low-pleated skirts are more plain. Day skirts are slightly longer, waistlines normal and wide belts often buckled in back.

A feature of investment buying of Manhattan real estate yesterday in the most active day of trading in many weeks was the purchase by owners of sites adjoining their present holdings. Two of these deals involved properties in residential sections of the city.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Clarence A. Edwards of the Garden City Country Club recorded an upset victory today in the first-match round of the South Florida championship by defeating one of the young favorites, Celeste A. Durand Jr. of the Lido Club at Long Beach, L.I. Edwards, a veteran campaigner, scored over his 19-year-old opponent by 3 and 1.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Linking a remarkable series of facts, The London Daily Express tonight suggests that Buckingham Palace may become a hotel in the near future and the royal family may move to Kensington.

A long shot by Hooley Smith that bounced off Roy Worters's left arm and fell into the net gave the Montreal Maroons a 1-to-0 victory over the New York Americans in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The commodity markets had a draggy trend during the first week of February, and this was shared by many of the staple farm products, but price declines were generally small, the Bureau of Agricultural Economics said today in its weekly survey.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP). -- One more bit of evidence favoring Einstein's relativity theory that space is curved near the sun developed today in a report from the Dearborn Observatory of Northwestern University.

Two men, arrested in the Motor Vehicle Bureau's campaign against automobiles that carry passengers on a "share-expense" basis without being properly registered, were arraigned yesterday in Traffic Court before Magistrate Francis J. Erwin.

Albert Grossman, known as Al Gross, was found guilty by a jury in Federal court yesterday on all three counts in an indictment charging violations of the prohibition law at the Breakfast Club, located at the Hotel Delmonico until Federal agents raided it.

A suit to prohibit the Board of Estimate from cutting the salaries of the justices of Special Sessions more than 10 per cent, and that only with their consent, was filed yesterday in the Supreme Court by Justice Lawrence T. Gresser of Queens.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- The suggested agenda for the World Monetary and Economic Conference, submitted to the Preparatory Commission by a special committee of the Council of the International Chamber of Commerce, follow:

Vincent Astor, now acting as host to President-elect Roosevelt on a cruise in Southern waters aboard his yacht Nourmahal, has sold his country place at Sands Point, L.I., to Allan J. McIntosh, a member of the Stock Exchange firm of Davis McIntosh.

BASLE, Switzerland, Feb. 7. -- Following is the balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements, giving its condition as of Jan. 31, as made public here yesterday. Figures are in Swiss francs at par.

If the nation can be saved by delay, the Senate will save it, as it has so long been engaged in doing. Its fritterings have again stirred the wrath of the House. Leaders of the other body are said to have threatened to make public proclamation of the dillydallying, everlasting palavering and time-wasting of the Chamber of Snails.
Numerous leases by textile and garment firms were reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Senator Hull introduced a joint resolution today to reduce the rate of Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans to 4 per cent during the year after the measure becomes law. While the resolution specifically applies to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, it would, the Senator explained, start a "governmental policy" of lowered interest.

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 7. -- The suggestion that legalized beer would create a greater market for the farmer's grain was characterized as "an insult to intelligence" by Fred B. Freestone, master of the State Grange, in his address at the opening of the annual meeting here today.

In observance of its eightieth anniversary the Corn Exchange Bank Trust Company sent yesterday to stockholders a statement of its condition as of Feb. 1, the date of the anniversary, together with a full list of its investments.

Suit to recover $15,000,000 from more than 15,000 stockholders in the closed Bank of United States, representing assessments of $25 a share, was begun yesterday by State Superintendent of Banks Joseph A. Broderick in the Supreme Court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Crude petroleum production for the United States in December totaled 58,044,000 barrels, a daily average of 1,872,000, the Commerce Department announced today. It was the first time since March, 1926, that the daily average output for one month fell below 2,000,000 barrels.

The Chase National Bank purchased for $4,068,000 at public auction yesterday the collateral securing a defaulted loan of $5,485,051 which it had made to the National Electric Power Company, now in bankruptcy. No other bidders appeared, and no effort was made to restrain the sale.
THE wind whipped briskly around the corner, and, as he buttoned up his brown overcoat, Johnny Farrell said:

American manufacturers of automotive equipment have failed to recognize the potential market in China, David A. Brown, chairman of China Famine Relief, U.S.A., declared yesterday, while reporting his recent survey of relief activities in the Far East at a luncheon in the Hotel Woodstock.

BOSTON, Feb. 7. -- The Boston Bruins, after turning back one of the most determined drives launched here this season, won their first victory of the campaign from the speedy New York Rangers before 15,000 tonight in the Boston Garden, by 2 to 1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Following the two weeks of public hearings on the domestic allotment plan for relief of agriculture the Senate Committee on Agriculture prepared today to rewrite the House Jones bill.

Edgar F. Luckenbach, president of the Luckenbach Steamship Lines, in a statement yesterday attacked the proposal advanced by advisers of President-elect Roosevelt that the interstate commerce act be changed to permit railroads to compete with traffic moving through the Panama Canal.

Stocks continued to feel their way cautiously yesterday, but the general movement was in the direction of higher prices. Other markets pursued an uneven course, with only one emphatic result, and that, a further lively recovery in German bonds.

George Leone, 119, Jackson Heights bantamweight, received the decision over Johnny Ladao, 116 3/4, Philippines, in the main six-round bout before 2,000 persons at the New Lenox S.C. last night. Ladao, who substituted for Augie Ruggiero, floored Leone for no count in the fourth round, but the latter's aggressiveness enabled him to win on points.

The body of a man burned beyond recognition was found last night in an automobile in a one-car garage on Arthur Place, West New York, N.J., after firemen had been notified by a passerby that he had seen smoke curling from the garage.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, OFF SAN PEDRO, Cal., Feb. 7. -- A powerful "enemy" raiding force carrying 175 fighting, bombing and observations planes aboard some of the fastest ships in the world, was somewhere in mid-Pacific today with radios stilled and decks cleared for action.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 7. -- Winding through a fog of hazy memories and "recollections that couldn't be searched," the Senate committee investigating the Overton-Broussard Senatorial primary in Louisiana today suddenly brought up sharply against the blunt defiance of "the Kingfish of Louisiana."

Harvey Stephens and Bernice Elliott have been added to the cast of "Conquest," Arthur Hopkins's new play, which he plans to open at the Plymouth Theatre on Feb. 18, with Judith Anderson in the leading role.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 7. -- Colonel Luke Lea and his son, Luke Lea Jr., convicted of conspiracy to defraud the Central Bank and Trust Company of Asheville, N.C., of more than $1,000,000, tonight were under the surveillance of Sheriff J.M. Peavyhouse in Jamestown, Fentress County, Tenn., a few hours after Governor Hill McAlister, at Nashville, had granted their extradition and issued fugitive warrants for their arrest.

President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt has invited the Governors of the forty-eight States to confer with him at the White House on March 6, two days after his inauguration, to discuss ways and means of solving national problems in which the governments of the States and the nation have a common vital interest.

Relief expenditures in New York City amounted to more than $80,000,000 in 1932, of which about 72 per cent were disbursed by public agencies out of tax funds, according to an analysis of expenditures made public yesterday by the Welfare Council of New York City.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Algeria, the 3-year-old filly which E.R. Bradley acquired from Joseph E. Widener, won the Indian River Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today, defeating Mr. Widener's The Pelican. The margin of victory was a head with Idle Stefan two lengths away in third place.

With the worst blizzard in years creating havoc in the Middle West and temperatures as low as 55 degrees below zero recorded in its wake, local Weather Bureau officials said last night that the storm probably would strike New York and its surrounding territory tonight.

The Museum of the City of New York at Fifth Avenue and 103d Street, which was opened on Jan. 11 last year, has proved its value to the community and won wide public approval during its first year, Phoenix Ingraham, president, declared in his annual report, made public yesterday.

A 20-year-old girl has thrown, a bombshell into that exclusive company of fifty gentlemen, most of whom are well past the half-century mark, and who guide the destinies of the Jockey Club. The Jockey Club is the governing body of the turf in New York State, and yesterday there came into its offices the first application in its history from a woman for a license as a trainer.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- Compulsory unemployment insurance is coming, Sam A. Lewisohn of New York, vice president of the Miami Copper Company, declared today in an address at the annual meeting of the American Management Association.

NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. J. Macy Willets will give a dinner tomorrow in the Seaglade of the St. Regis for their daughter, Miss Julia K. Willets, and Robert R. Comly, who will be married on Saturday in the Church of the Heavenly Rest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 -- The blizzard conditions over a wide area in the Winter wheat belt, with temperatures in many sections far below zero, failed to have much effect today on prices of that grain on the Board of Trade here. The local element was inclined to be bullish, but buying was not so aggressive as on Monday, and all bulges ran into persistent selling by commission houses.

BERLIN, Feb. 7. -- Bonds advanced materially at today's session of the Boerse as a further reaction to Dr. Alfred Hugenberg's statement against governmental interference with interest rates. Stocks also improved, but in the course of the day trading became extremely quiet, with the result that part of the early advances were lost.

Daily average gross production of crude oil in the United States last week was 2,028,250 barrels, compared with 2,008,700 in the previous week, an increase of 19,550, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A rise of 16,900 barrels in the average daily output of Oklahoma and a decline of 6,100 in California were the most important changes.

Two mishaps occurring fifteen minutes apart on Central Park lakes yesterday ended with the rescue of four persons. The accidents were caused in both cases by school boys who disregarded the absence of the red ball, the traditional safety sign for skaters, and ventured onto thin ice.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, parried questions put in the House of Commons today concerning the war debt to the United States and thereby indicated that the Government was determined to adhere to President-elect Roosevelt's suggestion that silence is golden in the present phase of the debt question.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Readjustment of international public and private indebtedness and the setting up of "economic groupings" of countries for tariff reciprocity outside the scope of most-favored-nation treatment are among recommendations in a report of a special committee of the International Chamber of Commerce, which it proposes as a basis for negotiation at the World Monetary and Economic Conference.

Issay Dobrowen, who is a romantic rather than a classic interpreter, chose for the concert of the Philadelphia Orchestra, which he conducted last night in Carnegie Hall, a program calculated to display to the best advantage his characteristics as an orchestral leader.

A theory that "the only way to write a really popular song is to put one's self first in the state of mind of a less than average person, with a less than average vocabulary, range of thought, experience and sense for grammar" was offered yesterday by Dr. Sigmund Spaeth.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Senate tonight voted practically dictatorial power to President-elect Roosevelt to reorganize the entire executive branch of the Federal government in the interest of public economy.

William Driscoll, 60 years old, of 205-20 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Bayside, Queens, trudged through the rain last night, pulling a soap-box wagon to the local police station, where he was to get his family's weekly allotment of coal. Justin, his 12-year-old son, walked with him.

The estate of Major Louis Livingston Seaman, civil and military surgeon, who provided in his will for experiments at Cornell University to ascertain the value of various foods as rations for American soldiers in peace and war, was appraised yesterday at $197,736 gross and $194,176 net.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Lenore Ulric spent $11,129 while she was starring in "Lulu Belle" and "Mima" to entertain newspaper critics and others, but the Board of Tax Appeals ruled today that she could not deduct that amount from income of 1927 and 1928 for tax purposes.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 7. -- A conference of the leaders of the Parliamentary parties was held as soon as the news of the death of Count Apponyi in Geneva reached here. It was decided to accord national honors to the statesman and bury his body at State expense.

LONDON, Feb. 7 -- A glitter of gold lace and a flash of uniforms greeted Dr. Julio A. Roca, Vice President of Argentina, when he arrived today at the head of a mission to negotiate a reciprocal tariff agreement with the British Government.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7. -- Dr. and Mrs. Leland Eggleston Cofer entertained sixteen guests with a dinner tonight at their villa.

The Amtorg Trading Corporation, official Soviet commercial agency in America, confirmed yesterday reports that a Canadian syndicate in Winnipeg is negotiating with the Soviet Government for the barter of Dominion cattle for Russian products.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Lord Sydenham died today of a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in London. His age was 84. He collapsed while dressing and his wife rushed to his side. He was dead before a physician arrived. He took a walk yesterday and apparently was in good health.

Culminating an improvement that began in June, the Class I railroads have reported to the Bureau of Railway Economics for December an increase of 19 per cent in net operating income compared with December, 1931. This was the first increase in net operating income on the basis of comparison with the same month of the preceding year shown by the railroads since August, 1929.

Reviving an old custom of holding informal gatherings with committees, Commodore Junius S. Morgan, new senior flag officer of the New York Yacht Club, gave a dinner last night in the clubhouse in Forty-fourth Street to the members of the race and racing appeals committees of the organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 7. -- Governor Lehman was warned by milk producers today that a milk strike impends in the State if something is not done to relieve the widespread distress among them. The Governor received a group of up-State farmers, after they had testified before the Pitcher milk committee.

Although activity was somewhat increased, the price ranges on local commodity markets were narrow yesterday. Sugar continued higher, as did cocoa, while other staples were irregular. In the cash markets, price changes were relatively few.

Meeting for the twentieth time in the past fourteen months, with the tangled affairs of the Jersey City club being the chief inspiration for their conclaves, the directors of the International League concluded their latest gathering yesterday at the Hotel New Yorker wlth the problem apparently no nearer clarification.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7 -- Intimations from London that the British Government may propose a lumpsum settlement of the war debt owed to the United States received a noncommittal reception here today on the Lusis of opinions formed by Senators and Representatives on the spur of the moment.

The annual report of the Shawinigan Water and Power Company for 1932 shows a net profit of $2,534,472 after all charges and depreciation reserve but before income tax for the year, compared with $4,150,438 in 1931. Gross earnings were $12,635,279, against $13,693,195 in 1931.

Ralph Pulitzer, former publisher of The World, has been appointed to direct the Spring membership campaign in New York for the National Economy League, it was announced last night by George C. Clark, city chairman of the organization.

With a clean sweep of its matches against the Yale Club, the Class C squash racquets team of the Harvard Club won its match in Group I of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets League last night on the Yale Club courts.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 7. -- The Dutch Minister of Defense announced today that no negotiations would be held with the mutineers aboard the battleship De Zeven Provincien. If the mutineers did not surrender unconditionally and immediately, he stated, force would be used.

The Citizens Union, through its secretary, R.E. McGahen, sent a letter to District Attorney Crain yesterday, demanding a grand jury investigation into the vandalism of three men last week in damaging twenty-seven automobiles in the Carlyle Garage, in East Seventy-sixth Street, in what the police believed was a racket by certain labor union leaders.

DETROIT, Mich., Feb. 7. -- Earl J. Davis, counsel for Robert J. Byers, an officer in the American Legion here, accused of getting army supplies at low rates under promise of distributing them free to the poor, then selling them at high prices, termed the indictment "an outrageous miscarriage of jusice."
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Monday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The session of the Reichstag's Parliamentary Rights Committee was broken up by the Nazi members today when Hans Frank, a Nazi, declared Chancellor Adolf Hitler had been described as "Adolf the Slovak" in a campaign speech by Paul Loebe, the committee's chairman.

Racketeering exists in New York County on a scale ten times greater than in the Bronx, in the belief of Dr. William Jay Schieffelin, chairman of the Committee of One Thousand, who spoke last night at the Community Church Centre, 546 West 110th Street.

Twelve more election inspectors were indicted late yesterday afternoon by the New York County grand jury investigating frauds and irregularities at the polls, bringing the number indicted by this grand jury since the opening of the inquiry on Jan. 11 to seventy-six.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7 (AP). -- A general moratorium on farm debts in Iowa approached ratification today as from a dozen sources came new suggestions for saving farms worth billions of dollars from forced sales.
Two savings banks in Brooklyn announced yesterday that they would reduce interest rates on loans on real estate by one-half of 1 per cent, bringing the number to six.

LONDON, Wednesday, Feb. 8.-- Britain's great flying adventure is nearing success. The Royal Air Force monoplane which is flying toward Cape Town, South Africa, was making fast time last night, and if the flight is successfully continued the world's distance record will be broken by about 7 o'clock this morning (2 A.M. in New York), when the plane will be some 1,000 miles away from its goal.

Commending the city's present program of economy as genuine and expressing the expectation that it will continue, the Citizens Budget Commission issued yesterday an analysis of the proposed budget for 1933 as compared with that for 1932.

On Monday evening Senator THOMAS of Oklahoma repeated before a Wall Street audience his argument for "controlled expansion of currency." It rests on the assumption of a direct and decisive relationship between the amount of money in circulation and the general level of prices.

PARIS, Feb. 7. -- For the third time in three months a new set of budget proposals was laid before the Chamber of Deputies today. These do not pretend to deal conclusively with the whole budget problem. They only incorporate in a provisional bill covering the month of March some economies and new taxation measures that the government feels are necessary.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Approval of a three-year loan of $8,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was sought today by the Chicago. Rock Island Pacific Railway Company in an application to the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Board of Tax Appeals today ordered a redetermination of a deficiency of $1,496 for the year 1923 levied against Mrs. Bula E. Croker, widow of Richard Croker, the Tammany boss.

Eugene Garguilo, 21-year-old butcher, of 203 Prospect Place, Brooklyn, failed yesterday in two attempts to battle his way to freedom after he had been frustrated in an attempt to hold up a passenger on the southbound platform of the Fulton and William Street station of the Interborough subway during the noon hour.

In an exhaustive report on the funds of Local 125, International Union of Operating Engineers, Carroll Hayes, referee for the local, which was placed in receivership last June 3, recommended yesterday to Supreme Court Justice Ernest E.L. Hammer that former officers of the local, including Patrick J. Commerford, should be made to return more than $15,500 in cash and bonds to the organization.

MONTREAL, Feb. 7 (AP). -- The pick-and-shovel laborer is mistaken in supposing that the boss who sits and thinks behind a desk is taking it easy, for a hard-thinking brain uses energy as fast as a hardworking muscle, the American College of Physicians was told today.

With Shakespeare excluded because "his presence may be taken for granted," Barrett H. Clark's two-volume anthology, ''World Drama," has just been published by Appleton. There are several plays translated from the Greek, one from the Chinese, another from the Japanese, and several written by Shakespeare's con1temporaries.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Tariff Commission's investigation of the sugar industry to determine whether import prices warrant readjustment of tariff rates is nearing a conclusion, but whether the recommendations will be made to President Hoover or his successor remains in doubt.

In their efforts toward raising a $200,000 emergency fund for the Visiting Nurse Service of the Henry Street Settlement, Mrs. Joseph L. Lilienthal, Mrs. Grover C. Loening and members of their committee have arranged an entertainment to be given the evening of Feb. 26 at the River Club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 7. -- What was construed as a move to throw the Middle West Utilities Company into bankruptcy was made today before Judge Walter C. Lindley in Federal Court when attorneys for the petitioning creditors of the company joined hands with attorneys representing holders of Middle West "gold" notes of $40,000,000 par value, asking Judge Lindley to authorize and set a date for a hearing to discover assets under the Federal bankruptcy act.

BERLIN, Feb. 7 -- One of the contradictions of this new political campaign in Germany is that the National Socialists, while endlessly vilifying their opponents and going to the extreme lengths of a press gag law to prevent them from answering in kind, are appealing for cooperation and unity to attain the victory they so ardently seek.

Sentences imposed upon first offenders in New York State are often "fiendish" and stimulate the desire to break jail, Dr. Walter N. Thayer Jr., State Commissioner of Correction, told the Osborne Association at 114 East Thirtieth Street yesterday.

Our dispatches from Geneva published yesterday indicate that the Committee of Nineteen, preparing its recommendations for the League of Nations, have grown tired of the delays and evasions of the Japanese Government. Even France and England, which have been showing a great deal of consideration for the Japanese point of view, have now stiffened their tone.

The long-awaited new Ford models probably will be introduced to the public throughout the country on Saturday, it was revealed yesterday after a meeting at which the cars were shown to dealers at the Ford Motor Company's plant in Long Island City.

The Boy Scout awards fostered by President Hoover for high achievement in the ten-year citizenship growth program of the Boy Scouts of America, which was started last year, have been won in the New York City area by the Queens and Staten Island Councils of Boy Scouts, it was announced yesterday.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 7. -- The official list of entries for the Dartmouth Winter carnival, which will be held this week-end, was released today by the Dartmouth Outing Club. Thus far there are sixty-five entries for the intercollegiate, interscholastic and invitation events.

French artists have not yet exhausted "that field of discovery and useful lessons" in which they have been engaged many years, Paul Claudel, French Ambassador, told visitors yesterday afternoon at the international art exhibition arranged by the College Art Association in the RKO Building, Rockefeller Center.

Al Jolson's new film, "Hallelujah, I'm a Bum," will be presented at the Rivoli tonight at 8.45 o'clock. The cast includes Madge Evans, Harry Langdon and Frank Morgan. Ben Hecht wrote the story, Rodgers and Hart the lyrics, S.N. Behrman the scenario and Lewis Milestone was the director.
BOSTON, Feb. 7. -- Judge Charles N. Harris of the Middlesex County Probate Court, died today at his home in Westchester after an illness of several months. He was 72 years old.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 7. -- Yale strengthened its hold on first place in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League tonight by defeating the speedy Columbia five, 23 to 20, in a thrilling encounter.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Irked by the talk of Republicans that the Democrats were afraid to call a caucus to attempt to bind members for a fight against the depreciated currency bill, Representative Rainey issued a call today for a party caucus tomorrow.

The gold medal for the prize-winning design in the small-house architectural competition for 1932 has been awarded to Royal Barry Wills, a Boston architect, it was announced here yesterday by the American Institute of Architects. President Hoover, as honorary chairman of Better Homes in America, which sponsored the contest, will present the medal to Mr. Wills at the White House next Wednesday.

Production of steel ingots in January showed the first increase since October, it was announced yesterday by the American Iron and Steel Institute. The output last month totaled 1,006,297 tons, against 844,618 in December, and 1,459,450 in January, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission today gave the railroads subject to its jurisdiction eighteen days to reply to the petition of three basic industries that it begin proceedings, requiring the roads to show cause why they should not drastically reduce existing freight rates.

LA GRANDE, Ore., Feb. 7 (AP). -- State Police Captain Lee Noe said tonight that William J. Moore, 30, arrested here yesterday, confessed to being implicated in the slaying of Harold O'Connor, 30, Brooklyn (N.Y.) motorist, whose body was found at Coopey Falls, thirty-five miles east of Portland on Sept. 11.

A marble bust of Samuel J. Tilden, lawyer and statesman, which disappeared under mysterious circumstances nearly twenty years ago from his library and was discovered a few months ago on the grounds of a country estate in New Jersey, was restored to its place last night at ceremonies in commemoration of the 119th anniversary of Tilden's birthday at the National Arts Club.
The following statement was issued last night by Francis Walton, managing editor of New Outlook, in connection with the United States Senate's dismissal of David S. Barry, its Sergeant-at-Arms:

PARIS, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Attorneys for Baroness Dorothy de Graffenried de Villars, daughter of Frank Jay Gould, announced today that she had recently filed suit for divorce from Baron Roland Graffenried de Villars.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 7. -- The general staff called to the colors today all able-bodied youths who reached the age of 19 years in 1932. They must report to the nearest military commandants between March 6 and March 12. In the ordinary course of events this class would have been called in December, but, it is explained, this was postponed, as the army was too busy to train them.

Rabbit-hunting is a sport that is enjoyed in almost every State in the country. Until a few years ago it was believed generally that the stock of rabbits would never be depleted, so abundant was the supply.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 7. -- Authorities investigating the murder of Mary Helen O'Connor, the 15-year-old Rockaway Park schoolgirl whose body was found last Thursday in the Massapequa woods, seemed to be at a standstill today.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 7. -- Following an attack by City Commissioner Charles P. Gillen of Newark on the Port of New York Authority because of its attitude on the lighterage case, the City Commission voted today to request Governor Moore to call a conference here to inquire why the Port Authority had condemned the examiner's report in the lighterage case.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- With the dinner given tonight in honor of Vice President Curtis, the President and Mrs. Hoover resumed the White House social program interrupted by the official mourning for former President Coolidge.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith declared last night that the United States must have a Director General of Public Works, with power to cut through red tape and scrap hampering statutes, if the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was to be an effective weapon against depression.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Representatives of groups advocating 44-hour week and minimum wage laws for women have attacked the right of ten organizations of women wage earners to speak for working women in opposition to these proposals, on the ground that many of them are business women's groups, the members of which, they say, would not be affected by the laws.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Reaction obtainable here tonight to the Governors' conference called by President-elect Roosevelt was apparently divided, with the conference being supported by Democrats but looked on with some doubt by Republicans.

Creation of the Hackensack River ewerage District to include Hudson and Bergen Counties, New Jersey, which will involve the issuance of approximately $24,000,000 in county bonds, is provided for in a measure, known as Assembly bill 50, introduced in the New Jersey legislature in Trenton late on Monday night.

LONDON, Feb. 7. -- Sinclair Lewis arrived here from Vienna today and celebrated his forty-ninth birthday by posing for news photographers and reading American reviews of his latest novel, "Ann Vickers," which had been just received.

AKRON, Ohio, Feb. 7 (AP). -- Hal P. Denton, former war correspondent and confidant of President Theodore Roosevelt, died today of a heart attack at the age of 60. He was editor of The Weekly Summit County Democrat.

While the share market continued its lazy recovery yesterday, less business was done on the Stock Exchange than the day before, and Wall Street showed little interest. Transactions aggregated 584,000 shares, compared with 670,000.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Referring to the present "Buy American" agitation which is being so prominently compared to the "Buy British" movement that was launched in England some years ago, I would like to point out that the fundamental ideas that prompted the campaign in England were entirely different from those back of the movement here.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 7. -- Postal receipts at New York City in January amounted to $5,095,413, a decrease of $33,951, or .66 per cent, under January, 1932, 14.23 per cent under the corresponding month of 1931 and 8.58 per cent lower than in January, 1930, the Postoffice Department announced today.

Mrs. Lucy Cotton Thomas, widow of Edward Russell Thomas, wealthy sportsman, banker and publisher of the old New York Morning Telegraph, will receive an allowance of $3,000 a month for the "support, education and maintenance" of her 7-year-old daughter, Lucy Cotton Thomas of 995 Fifth Avenue, under an order signed by Surrogate James A. Delehanty.

Using canned goods in lieu of more effective weapons, a 73-year-old woman fought two hold-up men in her grocery store at 1,092 Hegeman Avenue. Brooklyn, yesterday. The thugs beat her into unconsciousness, bound her and left her lying on the floor, but fled without getting any money.
Professing a desire to take a place in Florida's sunshine as soon as possible. Miss Diana Fishwick, erstwhile British champion, reached New York yesterday on her second Winter golf visit.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 7 -- Eight election officials of Newark's Fourteenth Ward, including two women, were named today in two indictments returned by the Federal grand jury as a result of its investigation of alleged voting frauds last November.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 7 -- Democrats who supported Franklin D. Roosevelt for the nomination for President will have the preference in appointments under the incoming administration.

After a day of Spring-like warmth -- the mildest Feb. 8 ever recorded here and in many other Northeastern cities -- the temperature dropped precipitately last night as the heralded cold wave swept in from the Northwest accompanied by a forty-mile gale.

Neglect of the American, directors who were elected to represent the American participation of about $100,000,000 in Ivar Kreuger's International Match Corporation was scored repeatedly in a report filed here yesterday in the Federal district court by the Irving Trust Company, setting out its operations during the last eight months as bankruptcy trustee for that corporation.
PINEHURST, N.C., Feb. 8 -- A stiff breeze today hampered the play in the twenty-eighth annual women's St. Valentine's golf tournament over the No. 1 course, but all the favorites advanced handily.

That mob rule and the sword may be an effective means to thrust a writer into the best-seller class was pointed out by implication yesterday by Dr. Lion Feuchtwanger, German novelist, in a talk ridiculing Adolf Hitler as a writer.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Bob Stupple, unassuming young professional from the Skokie Country Club at Glencoe, Ill., played the ''dark horse" role in the third annual St. Petersburg open championship today, putting together cards of 73 and 71, for a total of 144, to take first money.
PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Two splendid white diamonds, sufficiently celebrated to bear special names and to be catalogued, were sold here today by the municipal pawnshop for 1,600,000 francs (about $62,500).
The Eastern States Power Corporation reports for 1932 an asset value of $34.42 a share on 40,000 Series A and 60,000 Series B preferred shares, comparing wijth $43.49 the year before.

MOSCOW, Feb. 8 -- Conclusions of unusual interest are drawn from Foreign Commissar Litvinoff's Geneva speech in the newspaper Izvestia today in an editorial entitled, "Charter of Peoples' Rights to Security and Independence."

BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- The idea of an internationalized army to keep the peace among the turbulent nations and enforce the League of Nations' decrees finds no favor with General Hans von Seeckt, former commander-in-chief of the German republican army.

The Brunswick School sextet of Greenwich, Conn., triumphed over Boys High, 6 -- 1, and Lynbrook High battled to a 2-2 tie with La Salle Military Academy in a scholastic hockey double-header at the Brooklyn Ice Palace last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- With the Senate Finance Committee ready to begin hearing's Monday in a search for remedies for the depression, more than fifty leaders in business, finance and education have already accepted invitations to give an analysis of our economic ills and to offer constructive plans for their cure.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. William Fahnestock have left the Savoy-Plaza and gone to St. Augustine, Fla.

Bishop John J. Dunn, Vicar General of the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, testified yesterday in Federal court that he had not known that a letter he had written to Conde B. Pallen, Catholic layman who has since died, would be used as a basis for selling stock of the National Diversified Corporation.

Legislative action to eliminate multiple job-holding by teachers in the city's public schools will be sought by Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education, it was announced yesterday following a meeting of the board. The practice of one person holding two positions, particularly at the present time, has been the object of much criticism recently.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The arms-embargo resolution, once passed by the Senate, today encountered a fresh obstacle when Senator Bingham with considerable sharpness refused to comply with a request by Senator Borah that he withdraw his motion to reconsider the vote on the resolution.
The Class C squash tennis team of the City A.C. carried off the Metropolitan League championship by vanquishing the Montclair A.C. representatives in the league playoff, 5 to 2, last night.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Unemployment in cities would be increased and farmers would also be seriously affected by application of the increased taxes on trucks, witnesses today told the Motor Vehicle Committee of the Assembly.

"Before Morning," a melodrama by Edna and Edward P. Riley, will open tonight at the Ritz Theatre. "The Monster" will be revived this evening at the Waldorf Theatre, with De Wolf Hopper heading the cast.

The Brown University Club in New York is planning to affiliate with the Princeton Club here, it became known last night at the sixtyfifth annual dinner of the Brown Club, held at the Hotel Shelton. The affiliation is contingent upon the success of a membership campaign in the Brown Club to increase its enrolment to 300.

The Real Estate Bondholders Protective Committee, of which George E. Roosevelt is chairman,has sentout a call for deposit of the $3,555,000 in bonds outstanding against the Westinghouse Building, at 150 Broadway, in order that a plan of reorganization may be worked out.
MUNICH, Feb. 8 -- The Catholic Bavarian People's party, the ruling force in the State, and its considerable number of Protestant allies do not have a high opinion of Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

A Republican election inspector, one of twelve defendants, all of whom had entered pleas in bar to void indictments returned against them for vote fraud, admitted yesterday, on the witness stand before Federal Judge Alfred C. Coxe that he had served ninety days in the Federal House of Detention for stealing from the mails.
ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Bills to ban movies picturing the life and works of politicians in a manner held to reflect on their standing in the community were introduced in the Legislature today.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The government's action in removing natives from their lands in Kenya on which gold has been discovered was denounced today by Opposition member of both the Lords and Commons on the ground that equivalent allotments had not been provided for the refugees.

The sharpest increase In nearly two years in sales by dealers was announced yesterday by the General Motors Corporation in its report for January. Sales of dealers to consumers totaled 50,653 cars, against 19,992 in December and 47,942 in January, 1932.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 8 -- Notice that Universal Studio too will shut down on Saturday was received today by more than 400 employes of the motion picture concern. It is considered unlikely that production will be renewed before six or eight weeks.

The Hunt Club season of race meetings will begin on March 25 with the running for the Carolina Cup at Camden, S.C., and conclude on Nov. 4 with the Pickering Hunt session at Phoenixville, Pa., according to an announcement made yesterday of action taken at the annual meeting of the hunts committee of the National Steeplechase and Hunt Association.

An application for the listing of the new stock issues of the Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Company, created through the recent reorganization of the company, has been approved by the New York Stock Exchange. The issues, which will be listed on notice of issuance, are 290,285 shares of Class A convertible stock with a par value of $1, and 720,566 shares of Class B stock with a par value of $1.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The second "treaty cruiser" to be completed since the London Naval, Treaty, the Portland, will be delivered to the navy next Wednesday, the Navy Department announced today. The new 10,000-ton cruiser, which is one of a class of eight authorized by Congress in 1929, will have a maximum speed of thirty-three knots and will carry four planes.

With foreign, bonds in high, favor again, the moderate improvement yesterday in the speculative markets was more or less obscured. There was, however, a more interested movement in stocks and an increased demand for agricultural commodities.

MONTREAL, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Long life Is becoming a curse instead of a blessing to many old people, the American College of Physicians was told today by Dr. Francis M. Pottenger of Monrovia, Cal., because after doctors have prolonged their lives business gives them no chance to earn a living.

ALBANY, Feb. 8. -- The State commission to revise tax laws, headed by Senator Mastick, which for some years has been studying the State's taxation problems, made a report to the Legislature today in which it suggested several new revenue sources if the Senate and Assembly should be unwilling to accept Governor Lehman's program of taxation as defined in his budget message.

Another overwhelming victory was registered last night by Metropolitan A.A.U. boxers in intercity ring warfare. Competing against stalwart representatives of Montreal, Detroit, Washington and Newark before a crowd of about 6,000 in Madison Square Garden, the New York fighters won nine of the sixteen bouts.

While the slow recovery on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the more favorable sentiment to which Wall Street has given expression in the last few days, the net results were only a trifle more impressive than on the day before. The total volume was 723,000 shares, against 584,000 on Tuesday.
VIENNA, Feb. 8 -- The Benes statement that 180,000 rifles had been smuggled from Austria into Hungary puts the figure higher than any yet estimated here.

An unidentified well - dressed , woman about 60 years old was fatally injured about 9:15 o'clock last night by a taxicab while crossing Park Avenue between Fifty-seventh and Fifty-eighth Streets. According to the police, Milton Cohen of 272 Crown Street, Brooklyn, admitted his cab struck the woman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Governor Lehman's Emergency Public Works Commission, headed by Alfred E. Smith, arrived here tonight to seek loans of $93,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation as the latter disclosed that it is giving consideration to construction loan applications from New York State of $146,522,950.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In your issue of Feb. 6 Commissioner George S. Van Schaick, in his annual report, recommends drastic changes in the workmen's compensation law, which will be submitted to the Legislature at Albany.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Prospects of a larger movement of snow-bound hogs to market in a day or so took the edge off the soaring market today, but not until prices had advanced 15 cents early to a top of $4.15 a hundredweight, equaling the best price since Oct. 5 and 15 cents above yesterday.

Colonel Leopold Philipp, executive chairman of the George Washington Bicentennial Commission, set at rest yesterday all speculation over the fate of Federal Hall by announcing the building would be demolished within two weeks. Colonel Philipp said he had so informed Park Commissioner Walter R. Herrick.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Tribute to the progress made in recent years in the Philippines, Alaska and Puerto Rico "under American leadership" was paid by Ambassador Claudel here today in presenting decorations from the French and French colonial governments to American citizens who cooperated in the Colonial Exposition at Paris in 1931.

The New School for Social Research is at the moment well stocked with exhibitions. On the fifth floor may be seen groups of oils by two artists, Paul Mommer and Vincent Spagna, work by both of whom has been increasingly in evidence about town this season.

Adding another startling chapter to a long series of player transactions that have assumed record proportions during baseball's current off-season, the Brooklyn Dodgers last night traded Dazzy Vance, famous speedball pitcher, to the St. Louis Cardinals in a deal that involved three other players.

In a letter sent to Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, F.J. Carr, president of the Controllers Institute of America, announced yesterday that it would cooperate with the program of the Exchange for safe-guarding investors by obtaining more complete and properly presented financial reports.

Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr., Federal receivers for the Interborough Rapid Transit Company, filed with Federal Judge Martin T. Mantcn yesterday an application for compensation for services at the rate of $5,000 a month each for the period between Feb. 1 and the dates of their qualification, and for payment "on account" at the same rate from Feb. 1 on.
Several flats were included In the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 8. -- An improved outlook in the iron and steel industry was emphasized today by an unexpected upturn in mill operations and the receipt of a large order for rolling mill machinery by a Salem manufacturer. The order will give work for six months to 100 employes of the E. W. Bliss Company.

After reading a book, It all seemed so simple to 11-year-old Leonard Rudy of 54 Hemlock Street, Brooklyn, that he set forth yesterday on a career as a criminal investigator. He would be the terror of the underworld, against whose adventures those of Sherlock Holmes, M. Lecoq, Nick Carter and Hawkshaw would pale, he determined.

Eugene Doane, veteran newspaper man and a member of the news staff of The New York Sun, was found dead in a rooming house at 25 Frankfort Street yesterday morning. According to the police, he had committed suicide by turning on a gas jet and slashing both wrists.

Most of the ninety-seven trade groups comprising the Commerce and Industry Division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee will continue their fund-raising efforts, it was announced yesterday by Myron C. Taylor, chairman, and H.B. Lamy Jr., executive chairman of the division.

JAMESTOWN, Tenn., Feb. 8 (AP) -- Driven back at every turn for a year and a half, Colonel Luke Lea prepared tonight to use his last remaining legal weapon, habeas corpus proceedings, in an effort to halt his forced retreat toward a North Carolina prison cell.

Pierce H. Power, for twelve years a member of the Community Councils of the City of New York and one of the group's charter members, resigned yesterday, charging that Frank Peer Beal, executive secretary of the councils, misstated the position of civic organizations on the proposed ash removal waste disposal contract in Brooklyn, the Queens Civic Economy League announced.

With political, economic and social conditions in Cuba progressively going from bad to worse, and with an impasse reached in the underground warfare between President Machado's secret police and the terrorists, the Cuban situation seems likely to require early attention by Franklin D. Roosevelt when his administration takes office on March 4, if it does not come to a head before that time.

Election of Harold V. Coes, manager of the industrial department of Ford, Bacon Davies, as president of the Engineering Trustees, Inc., was announced yesterday. Mr. Coes succeeds Harry A. Kidder, superintendent of motive power of the Interborough Rapid Transit Company.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Sir Frederick Whyte discussed "Asia of the Twentieth Century" at the second of the current events series this afternoon at Lagomar, Mrs. Henry R. Rea's residence. Sir Frederick, a native of Scotland, was a member of Parliament for nine years.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Army was victorious in two sports today, the hockey team capturing a fast encounter with Hamilton College, 2 to 1, and the basketball quintet turning back Lehigh, 37 to 30, by means of a second-half rally.
The Columbia varsity rowing squad was increased to forty aspirants yesterday when ten more candidates were added to the group of thirty that reported on Monday.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8. -- Yale's hockey team defeated Boston University tonignt, 5 to 2. Coach Holcomb York used regulars and reserves alternately until the long list was exhausted. Practically three full sets of players were employed.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 8 -- Dr. Earl D. Bond was announced tonight as winner of the $10,000 Philadelphia award, established by Edward W. Bok to be presented annually to the resident of this city or its suburbs "who, daring the preceding calendar year, shall have performed, or brought to its culmination, an act or contributed a service calculated to advance the best and largest interests of the community of which Philadelphia is the centre."

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Sir Ronald Lindsay's daily debt talks with the Cabinet committee continued this afternoon and they have been scheduled up to and including Monday, on which day the last session may be held. If the Ambassador to the United States can finish his mission by then he will sail on the Majestic Tuesday, arriving in New York on Feb. 20.

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 8 -- Deflation through liquidation of real estate or "reflation" through reduction of the value of the dollar were suggested as the two chief ways out of the economic depression today by G.F. Warren, Professor of Agricultural Economics and Farm Management at Cornell University in adressing 3,000 delegates to the convention of the New York State Grange.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Feb. 6:

The report of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company for 1932 shows net income of $6,839,695 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal to $5.68 a share earned on 1,203,952 shares of stock, compared with $8,464,158, or $7.03 a share, earned in 1931.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- A "model" pistol regulating bill was reported favorably by the Assembly Codes Committee today and is said to be due for passage. Sponsors of the measure have asserted that it follows the lines of statutes which are in effect in many States.

LIMA, Ohio, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A mild-mannered, gray-haired county judge explained tonight why his conscience made him challenge the United States Supreme Court in creating an American citizen by court action. He said he expected to do it again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Mrs. Hoover attended the annual meeting and luncheon today of the Travers' Aid Society, of which she is honorary president, and promised to be its "walking delegate" after March 4.
COMMERCIAL, PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

Mayor O'Brien regards as as "a sacred duty" the maintenance of the city's credit structure, and he thinks that taxes should bear so lightly on property that there would be no difficulty in meeting them, he told the New York Board of Trade, to an accompaniment of applause, at its monthly meeting at the Hotel Pennsylvania yesterday.

For the second consecutive year the Kips Bay Neighborhood Association, at 794 Second Avenue, has won a trophy for having conducted the best organized clean-up campaign in New York during 1932, Miss Sara C. Clapp, executive secretary of the association, announced yesterday after receiving a letter from Ralph W. Emerson, director of the National Clean-Up and Paint-Up Campaign Bureau, in Washington, D.C., which donated the award.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Arrivals in the capital from points in the South where President-elect Roosevelt has been sojourning or embarking have brought the report that he is not trusting wholly to Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador to the United States, to convey to London his ideas of how the British debt review should be approached.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 (AP) -- Ten well-known Chicagoans have been subpoenaed to testify before the Senate subcommittee investigating collapse of the lnsull utility holding companies it was revealed tonight by James B. McDonough Jr., assistant to Ferdinand Pecora, the subcommittee's counsel.

Complete reorganization of welfare work in Brooklyn and the establishment of social planning on a community-wide basis along the lines of the Welfare Council of New York, was urged by Douglas P. Falconer, general secretary of the Brooklyn Bureau of Charities, in an address last night before 100 men prominent in the business, social and religious life of the borough.

Crete Stuckgold, Metropolitan Opera soprano, replaced Lotte Lehmann as the recitallst at the Town Hall for its endowment fund at short notice last night, and gave one of the season's notable recitals. In her return to the concert stage several months ago, Mme.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Width of vision in government and greater liberalism were argued by Paul Reynaud, former Finance Minister of France and student of American developments, as the only cure for the present world depression.
For the first time in local experience a squash tennis match has had to be postponed on account of bad weather.

THE hockey campaign has now reached the stage where the points begin to count. In the early season nobody bothers much about it. It's a long race and fast starters have been known to tire and drop back to join the crowd. But it won't be long now and teams like Ottawa, the Black Hawks and the Canadiens know they can't linger longer if they plan to get into the play-offs.

On a rooftop two blocks north of where Francis Crowley was besieged by an impenetrable ring of bluecoats, another "outlaw" cringed yesterday and hurled defiance at another cordon of policemen. For four hours he fought for his freedom while thousands of residents of West End Avenue in the neighborhood of Ninety-second Street watched with bated breath.

Herbert M. Harriman, youngest son of the late Oliver Harriman, who died on Jan. 2 at Aghadowey, Londonderry, Ireland, left his entire estate of not more than 55,000, according to the petition for the probate of his will, to his wife, Sarah J. Hunter Harriman of Londonderry, it was disclosed yesterday when the testament was offered for probate here.
RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 8 -- A new formula for peace with Colombia over the seizure of the upper Amazon town of Leticia is reported here to have developed from internal and external pressure on Peru.

Impressed by the fine showing that Carl Coan of Penn made in the Wanamaker Mile on Saturday, the New York Athletic Club yesterday added the former intercollegiate mile champion to the field for the Baxter Mile that will be one of the features of the Winged Foot games at the Garden a week from Saturday.

Continuing its fight against the appointment of a corporation as receiver in bankruptcy cases the Federal Bar Association adopted a resolution last night calling for a drive against the "unlawful practice of the law" as carried on by trust companies, banks, financial institutions and collection agencies.

The list drawn up by the special committee of the International Chamber of Commerce of the particular problems to which in its judgment the coming World Economic Conference must give attention begins by recognizing clearly the extent to which our present troubles are an inheritance from war.

Mr. ROOSEVELT has long had a sneaking fondness for Governors. Not simply because he was one himself for four years,but out of unfeigned interest in the affairs of the separate States; and also because he likes to hear men talk and believes in the free exchange of ideas, he regularly attended the annual meetings of Governors.

On Tuesday Senator REED sought to have the army and navy exempted from the general but In pay of eight and a third per cent. His proposal was voted down. The reduction has been in operation for a year, and there is no reason why an exception should be made in favor of the army and the navy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: David Barry, sergreant-at-arms of the Senate, may be a martyr in a good cause. Congressional corruption is talked about in every thoughtful household and patriotic group today, so that it fills one with rather bitter humor when Mr. Barry puts it only upon students.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- President Hoover's support of plans to revise tariff rates on imports from countries with depreciated currencies received new impetus today from a report by Secretary Chapin which said that serious concern over the situation was being expressed by business interests.

The revival of Italo Montemezzi's "The Love of Three Kings" will be presented at the Metropolitan Opera House Friday evening, Feb. 17, it is announced by Giulio Gatti-Casazza. In the leading female role, that of Fiora, will be Lucrezia Bori, who appeared in this opera in its American premiere at the Metropolitan Jan. 2, 1914, which was Miss Bori's second season at New York's opera.

Details of the corporation that is being organized by local banks and mortgage companies to assist in the refinancing of maturing guaranteed mortgages will be announced tonight by bankers who have been working on the project for nearly two months.

While steel operations this week are estimated at a shade less than 19 per cent of ingot capacity, which represents a negligible decrease from the previous week, "an increase in miscellaneous business is taking up some of the slack caused by a decline in automobile tonnage," says The Iron Age in its weekly review.

William A. Eagle, assistant superintendent of the Polyclinic Hospital, and Drs. Francis Creighton and Jerome Van Ness of the hospital staff, were accused yesterday of contempt of court by J. A. Doherty, attorney for the Yellow Taxi Corporation, because the physicians failed to appear in time to testify in a personal injury suit against the taxicab company.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 -- The Hudson Motor Company, which was closed by a strike yesterday, issued a general call today for all employes of record to return to work tomorrow, assuring them that the situation would be adjusted to their satisfaction.
Lower Manhattan business properties and upper west side houses were in demand by investors yesterday, when trading was confined roughly to these two areas.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent comments and criticisms in Congress of banking and railroad officials indicate such failure to understand the moral obligations Involved in such enterprises that It seems important to call attention to the danger that may result from a public opinion based on a serious lack of understanding.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8 -- Yale baseball teams will play forty-five games this Spring, it was announced today. The program, includes twenty-five varsity, ten junior varsity and ten freshman contests. While the list is practically the same as that scheduled for several years, competition for the varsity has been cut slightly.

BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- A subcommittee has been appointed at the Standstill conference to work out a proposed provision for extension of the Swiss clause of the Standstill agreement, which would permit creditors to transfer part of their short-term credits from the present debtor to the Reichsbank for loneterm investment.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Jubilation swept the Air Ministry and aviation circles in England today at the news that the giant Royal Air Force monoplane had smashed the world's distance record established by Russell Boardman and John Polando in 1931.

The Shippers' Conference of Greater New York lent its support to the project for the deepening of the State Barge Canal with Federal funds under continued State ownership and declared its opposition to legislation before the Legislature which would place motor trucks under the control of the Public Service Commission, at its monthly meeting yesterday at the Merchants' Association rooms.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The advisability of seeking libel action against David S. Barry and The New Outlook of which Alfred E. Smith is editor, tonight became a question of importance in Senatorial minds.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8. -- The votes of the Electoral College were counted today at a joint meeting of the Senate and House and it was discovered that Franklin Delano Roosevelt of New York and John N. Garner of Texas had been elected President and Vice President, respectively, of the United States of America.

MELBOURNE, Australia, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Australian board of cricket control today notified the Marylebone Cricket Club, ruling body in England, that it meant no reflection on the English test match team players when it charged that the "body line" bowling of Harold Larwood was unsportsmanlike.

To have been reared in the family of a minister was LAWRENCE ABBOTT'S fortunate lot, for his father, LYMAN ABBOTT, early abandoned the law in which he was gaining a reputation in New York City and prepared himself to preach.
DUBLIN, Feb. 8. -- In the presence of a packed chamber in Leinster House today, Eamon de Valera was re-elected President of the Free State Executive Council. The vote was 82 to 54.

The mild weather has a way of sending strange, tingling sensations up and down the spine of every salt-water fisherman, and even though it is only February the old-timers are thinking about the advent of pollack and flounders and other edible creatures of the sea.
Eide Norena, Norwegian soprano, who will make her debut tonight with the Metropolitan Opera Company as Mimi in "La Boheme," spoke hopefully of the future of opera when interviewed at her hotel.

Ferdinand Pecora, counsel to the Senate banking and currency subcommittee which is investigating the stock market, announced last night that the National City Bank and affiliated companies agreed to give the committee complete access to its books and records.

A story of adventure on the high seas, with a hint of murder and a melodramatic kidnapping plot, was unfolded through the usually taciturn lips of a New Jersey rum-runner yesterday in the trial of two suspended policemen charged with kidnapping Ernest Schoening.

Nearly 1,000 holders of leasehold bonds sold by S.W. Straus Co., Inc., in the Hotel Pierre, Inc., appeared before Supreme Court Justice Levy yesterday to oppose confirmation of the sale recently of the hotel property to a committee representing 96 per cent of the holders of the $6,500,000 issue of bonds, and particularly to object to the expenses of the committee, which also is before the court for approval.

Bank clearings in New York City showed their first improvement in thirty-one months during the week that ended yesterday. The improvement was so substantial, amounting to almost 10 per cent, that it lifted the total for the entire country above the corresponding week in 1932.

A resolution, commending Congressman John J. O'Connor for his efforts to bring about remedial fur tax legislation was passed yesterday by the board of governors of the Industrial Council of Cloak, Suit and Skirt Manufacturers, Inc.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The war Department issued the following orders today:

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 (AP). -- Jimmy Sutro, unable to win a race since the 1932 Winter season, finally crashed through today, defeating a small but classy field in the mile and one-sixteenth handicap at the Fair Grounds.
APPLETON, Wis., Feb. 8 -- The Wisconsin Cooperative Milk Pool today committed itself to a milk strike which it hopes will spread throughout the Middle West.

Appeals to New York City's welfare agencies by destitute unemployed or others needing help in 1932 were greater than ever in their history, and in the rendering of this service there was less duplication and more coordination than ever before, according to Dr. Solomon Lowenstein, chairman of the Welfare Council's committee on the Social Service Exchange, which made its annual report yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8. -- More than half the States are considering a general sales tax to provide funds for unemployment relief or to reduce the burden on property. Sales tax bills have been introduced in these twenty State Legislatures:

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 8. -- Yale baseball teams will play forty-five games this Spring, it was announced today. The program, includes twenty-five varsity, ten junior varsity and ten freshman contests. While the list is practically the same as that scheduled for several years, competition for the varsity has been cut slightly.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- "As an editor I am not so hot," Alfred E. Smith, editor of The New Outlook, said tonight when asked about the possibility of being called before the Senate Judiciary Committee in connection with the article by David S. Barry, which caused the latter's dismissal as sergeant-at-arms of the Senate.

An article urging immediate action against the authors and publishers of certain popular novels which are held to contain obscene material appears in the current issue of America: A Catholic Review of the Week.

That Belated Blizzard. For every wrong there is a remedy, except as against the Weather Man. A sergeant-at-arms of the United States Senate can be dismissed. A President of the United States can be impeached.
The New York University basket-ball team snapped its two-game losing streak by repulsing West Virginia, 44 to 30, at the University Heights gym last night. A crowd of more than 500 saw the game.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 8 (AP) -- The Senate committee investigating the Overton-Broussard primary was surprised today when General Samuel T. Ansell, committee counsel, asked Robert S. Maestri, former president of the Louisiana Democratic Association, if he did not know there was a $75,000 deficit from the Overton campaign.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 8 -- The prospect of the women's national squash racquets championship being carried out of the country for the first time became all the more ominous today as four members of the British team gained the quarter-final round of the tournament in progress at the Merion Cricket Club.

Somerset Maugham says that his habit of stammering was one of his main reasons for starting to write. In an interview in John O'London's Weekly he advances the theory that "a physical, defect can be of the utmost value to any one who is striving to succeed in the arts."

The League Loans Committee of London, which, with the sanction of the League of Nations, started last year on formulating a policy regarding loans sponsored by the League of Nations that are now in default, has held a series of meetings in the last fortnight, according to word received here yesterday by interested bankers.

The bond market on the Stock Exchange manifested considerable strength yesterday, all sections of the list moving higher, with the exception of United States Government bonds, which closed unchanged to 10-32 point net lower. Railroad bonds led the advance in domestic corporation issues, and German loans in the foreign bond group.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- The favorites continued their winning tactics in the second round of the sixth annual Winter championship of the Artists and Writers Golf Association at the Palm Beach Country Club today. Leading the march again was Grantland Rice, the defending champion and medalist, who scored over Frank Crowninshield, 5 and 4.

Marion Talley will return to the concert stage in the early Autumn under a contract that includes radio engagements, she announced yesterday at the office of George Engles, managing director of NBC Artists Service, under whose auspices the former opera singer will resume her singing.

John (Zacci) Savino, who was arrested and subsequently freed following the hold-up at the dinner to Albert H. Vitale, then a magistrate, in December, 1929, has received a full and unconditional pardon from President Hoover freeing him from a conviction for counterfeiting, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, was informed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- Sweeping changes in twenty-nine government departments and agencies to remove them from competition with private business were recommended to the House today by the special committee appointed last Summer to study charges that such competition was retarding private business enterprises in various parts of the country.

WINNIPEG, Feb. 8 (Canadian Press) -- Foreshadowing a partnership arrangement between the people of Canada as owners of the Canadian National Railways and the shareholders of the Canadian Pacific, E.W. Beatty, chairman and president of the latter, carried his argument for unification of the two railways for management purposes another step forward in an address before the Canadian Club today.
