BERLIN, Feb. 8 -- Stocks and bonds continued today to recover the losses which were recorded upon the appointment of the new Cabinet. The average rise of leading stocks on the Boerse was 2 per cent, although A.K.U. Rayon and Reichsbank shares advanced about 5 per cent.

A further recovery in prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday carried May within 3 points of 6 1/4 cents at one time, but a setback in the last hour left the list a point higher to a point lower than Tuesday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Fears of damage to the growing Winter wheat crop by temperatures as low as 24 degrees below zero without adequate snow covering over part of the belt dominated the wheat market on the Board of Trade here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- An agreement between the Leyland, Harrison and Dixie U.K. Lines to apportion sailings and pool the earnings on traffic from designated Gulf ports to ports of the United Kingdom was approved today by the Shipping Board.

A net gain of $2,910,000 in this country's monetary grold stocks was indicated in yesterday's gold statement of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. Imports of $1,204,500 from England and $135,500 from Peru were received here and $1,670,000 arrived in San Francisco from China.

Trading in the principal commodities here was dull yesterday, except in sugar and cocoa. Price changes were small. Sugar, hides and silver made moderate gains, while the other staples were irregular. Cash markets were firmer with cotton and wheat.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8 -- The policy of the Roosevelt administration of rewarding friends with patronage will be followed in making Federal appointments in New York City, it was learned today following conversations by James A. Farley, Democratic National Chairman, with New York State Democrats both in person and by telephone.

CHICAGO, Feb. 8 -- Clark Shaughnessy, now coach at Loyola University of New Orleans, is the choice of Thomas Nelson Metcalf, incoming athletic director at the University of Chicago, to succeed Amos Alonzo Stagg as football coach on the Mid-way.

The Majestic Theatre will house "Strike Me Pink," the forthcoming Lew Brown-Ray Henderson revue co-starring Jimmie Durante, Hope Williams and Lupe Velez. "Pardon My English," the current attraction at the Majestic, will be transferred to another theatre not yet selected.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb, 8 -- John J. Bernet returned today to the presidency of the Nickel Plats Railroad, succeeding W.L. Ross, who retired because of ill health Already president of the prosperous Chesapeake Ohio Railroad, and the Pere Marquette, Mr. Bernet is now in a position to weld the three Van Swingeren railroads Into a single entity.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- Following the publication this morning of a statement that an officer of the famous Seaforth Highlanders had been arrested on charges of espionage, the War Office this afternoon issued the following statement:

"Burglars" that come all the way from the interstellar spaces, penetrating steel doors as though they did not exist, will be made to walk into a cunning trap devised especially for them by modern science, and, while caught in the act of entering a huge steel vault, to tell of their capture over a nation-wide radio hook-up, when everyday men and women can listen in on them for the first time.

"They may say that O'BRIEN is vague on the budget," the Mayor remarked in the course of his campaign, "but the answer is going to "come later when I am in office "and put into effect a real scheme "to reduce the budget and help "property owners."

WALFISH BAY, South Africa, Feb. 8 -- Squadron Leader O.R. Gayford and Flight Lieutenant G. E. Nicholetts of the British Royal Air Force set a new world's distance record of 5,341 miles when they landed here at 4:40 P. M., Greenwich Time, today. Rain, headwinds and darkness prevented their reaching their goal, Cape Town, 780 miles further on.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The stock markets were cheerful today. British funds were higher, but there was not much business. German loans recovered further on better political news. Industrial issues displayed general firmness and the international shares were strong on the improvement in Wall Street yesterday.

The Tuskegee Institute Choir, which gave a concert in Carnegie Hall last night under the direction of William L. Dawson, showed its good technical drilling in the precision of its attacks, its tonal unity, its excellent balance and the beauty of one of its solo voices.

Sincerity, good taste and honesty are, or should be, the "big three" in advertising, William H. Howard, publicity director of Gimbel Brothers, told 500 members of THE NEW YORK TIMES class in retail newspaper advertising in The Times Annex yesterday.

Members of the New York County Republican Advisory Committee who are opposed to the leadership of Samuel S. Koenig characterized yesterday the resolution adopted at the meeting of the committee Tuesday night as a "milksop" resolution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- The House leadership today planned the speediest possible action on the grant of broad and sweeping authority to reorganize the executive branch of the Federal Government which the Senate voted last night to the incoming President.

Declaring that the Public Service Commission had no more jurisdiction over the labor policies of the Brooklyn Edison Company than it had over a department store or a hotel, Chauncey B. Garver, representing Shearman Sterling, attorneys for the company, at a hearing yesterday in the State Building, 80 Centre Street, asked that a complaint alleging "arbitrary, unjust, unreasonable and unlawful methods and practices" which "endanger the adequacy and continuity of electric service" be dismissed.

Amid decorative effects of silver and blue, "A Night in Budapest," the eleventh in a series of entertainments aiding several New York philanthropic organizations, took place last night at the St. Regis.

Vittoro Grillo, 72 years old, of 1,676 Eighty-third Street, told Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in Federal Court, Brooklyn, yesterday that he stole a letter from the mails, a crime for which his son. Angelo Grillo, 32 years old, was convicted last Oct. 6 and sentenced to two and a half years in prison.

The marriage of Miss Caroline Sutherland of Washington, D.C., daughter of the late Daniel J. Sutherland of Philadelphia, to John Quincy Adams Johnson of Yonkers, N.Y., took place at noon yesterday in the Church of the Transfuguration ("The Little Church Around the Corner"), marking the culmination of a friendship that began when they played together as children.

LONDON, Feb. 8 -- The Federation of British Industries sent a memorandum today to Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, declaring no steps should be taken to return to the gold standard at least until there is full assurance the action will serve the needs of the empire and the rules will be observed by other countries.

GENEVA, Feb. 8 -- The Japanese Government's latest formula for conciliation of her dispute with China over Manchuria was submitted today to Sir Eric Drummond, the Secretary General of the League of Nations.

A committee for the protection of the debentures and the extended gold notes of Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation has been formed. This committee, which consists of George N. Armsby, chairman; Edward C. Delafield and Arthur Lehman, is asking the holders to deposit their securities promptly.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 8 -- Albert R. Hakes of Dunkirk, N. Y., defending titleholder and medalist, was eliminated in the second round of match play today in the South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club. The young star finished 1 down to William H. Hyde of Ridgway, Pa., after a seesaw tussle that was not decided until the final green.

BERLIN, Feb. 8. -- The widespread criticism that Chancellor Adolf Hitler's press gag law evoked in the German press induced him to receive the editors of some of the leading papers today to appease their apprehensions that no more criticism regarding Cabinet measures would be permitted.

PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Augustabernard closes the Summer fashion showings with a distinguished, wearable collection featuring the straight daytime silhouette, subnormal waistlines and wide leather belts or draped silk hip sashes.

Chancellor Wolcott of Wilmington, Del., approved yesterday the plan of reorganization of the General Water Works and Electric Corporation and set March 7 for the sale of the assets of the company and of its receivership estate, at a public auction to be held at Wilmington.
PARIS, Feb. 8 -- Even the reduced demands upon taxpayers and public employes in the budget proposals of the Daladier government are raising protests.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 8. -- The native mutineers aboard the Dutch battleship De Zeven Provincien are now in the Indian Ocean southeast of Benkulen, Sumatra, but the squadron dispatched to recapture the battleship thus far has not reached it.

Prominent women who are active in behalf of the Lots for Little Shop, a permanent thrift shop maintained at 902 Third Avenue for the benefit of several charitable organizations, met yesterday afternoon at the Convent of the Helpers of the Holy Souls, 112 East Eightysixth Street.
NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 8. -- Rutgers defeated Fordham in a well-played basketball game tonight, 28 to 18. The defense of both teams was unusually good, especially in the first half.

DETROIT, Feb. 8 (AP) -- A dispatch from Lansing, Mich., last night that the General Motors Corporation had filed notice with the Corporation Division of the Department of State of Michigan of a decrease in authorized capital stock from $1,253,333,000 to $750,000,000 was described today at the corporation's offices here as in error.

MADRID, Feb. 8 -- Charging that the republic's 200,000,000 gold pesetas petroleum contract with the Russian Nafta is unfair to Spain and demanding that the Cortes investigate it, the Radical minority in the Cortes continues its violent crusade against the Socialists in the Azana government.

LANSING, Mich., Feb. 8 -- About 1,000 irate farmers, many of them armed with axe-handles, took charge of a farm mortgage sale near Ithaca, north of here this afternoon, manhandled and Imprisoned the representative of the bank which ordered the sale and bid in an automobile and a cow and other items at prices ranging from 10 to 25 cents.

BOSTON, Feb. 8. -- Playing its first game in almost three weeks, Harvard's hockey team overwhelmed the Brae Burn Hockey Club, 13 to 4, in the Boston Garden tonight. The Brae Burn team, made up of former players at Yale, Dartmouth and Harvard, offered the Crimson skaters weak opposition.

Of the wild and tumultuary proceedings, not unworthy of an old-fashioned spirited ward meeting, in the Senate on Tuesday, which ended, fortunately without actual battery, in the expulsion of the erring sergeant-at-arms, Senator REED probably expressed the general opinion when he called them "a holy show."

Pig iron production last month, according to The Iron Age, amounted to 568,785 gross tons against 546,080 tons in December, or a daily rate of 18,348 tons compared with 17,615 tons in the preceding month. Merchant iron output declined last month, but the gain in steel-making iron amounted to almost 13 percent.

Almost 2,000 guests. Including men and women prominent in many walks of life, paid warm tribute to Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt last night at a dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria given in her honor by the Altrusa Club of New York, an organization of business women of which Mrs. Roosevelt is a member.
GENEVA, Feb. 8 -- Joseph Paul-Boncour, chief author of the French plan, ended the general discussion upon it in the disarmament conference this afternoon by a long defense that added little new.
THE NEW YORK TIMES has received the following cable message from Dr. Orestes Ferrara, Cuban Secretary of State and former Ambassador to the United States:

The Commercial Investment Trust Corporation, a finance company, earned more than enough to cover its common dividend in 1932, according to the annual report issued yesterday, which showed a net profit of $5,719,775, equivalent to $2.04 a share on the average number of common shares outstanding in the year.

A large attendance of Governors at the conference called by President-elect Roosevelt at Washington for March 6 was assured yesterday as replies poured in from State Executives all over the country, most of them hailing the meeting as a valuable step toward recovery.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 8. -- The Supremus colt Cathop, bearing the colors of the estate of R.M. Eastman, was a surprise winner of the Wildwood Purse, mile feature at Hialeah Park today. Under 106 pounds he sped the distance in 1:36 4-5, the fastest time of the meeting and only two-fifths of a second behind the track record, scoring by a length at $14.60 for $2.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, San Pedro, Feb. 8 -- A cordon of ships and shore-based planes will be flung across the 1,200-mile Western coast of the United States tomorrow, when the Blue forces of Admiral Luke McNamee, the defending fleet in the navy's annual mimic war, steam out to sea to do battle with an "enemy" raiding force.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 8 -- Despite its extremely serious probabilities, the Uruguayan situation is taking on many aspects not present in other recent South American internal disputes. It is not the traditional Latin-American conflict between the outs and the ins, but a struggle of one section of the ins to oust other regularly elected ins and quit sharing with them the affairs of government, especially patronage.

After a series of attacks on young women in the Bedford and Stuyvesant sections of Brooklyn in the preceding twenty-four hours, a search of those areas was begun yesterday by more than fifty detectives. A suspect arrested in connection with one of the attacks was held in $2,500 bail.

ALBANY, Feb. 8 -- Frank P. Walsh, chairman of the State Power Authority, calling upon Governor Lehman this evening to submit the text of the agreement reached With Washington on a division of the cost of the St. Lawrence power project, said it meant that the cost of production per horsepower per year would be only $8.50, possibly less.

To the Editor of The New York Times : Why, in the truly beautiful auditorium of the Radio City Music Hall, architecturally leading us forward into a realm of dignity, repose and beauty, are we compelled by its management to revert to the manners of a hoodlum by dropping our ashes and matches on the floors of the smoking-galleries?

Cleveland, Ohio. With the quick sale yesterday morning of the issue of $2,000,000 city of Cleveland (Ohio) 5 1/2 per cent waterworks bonds, due on Nov. 1, 1934 to 1973, at prices to yield 5 to 5.10 per cent, the New York and Ohio banking group making the offering exercised its option in the afternoon to purchase the balance, amounting to $1,200,000, of the city's total issue of $3,200,000.
After a stormy public hearing yesterday the Board of Estimate formally adopted a revised 1933 budget of $518,427,972.16, adding $62,178.17 to the totals submitted by Mayor O'Brien on Monday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 8 -- A constitutional amendment to bar is suance of tax-exempt securities by Federal, State or local governments was proposed in a joint resolution introduced by Senator Hull of Tennessee today. Under the amendment such issues hereafter would be completely forbidden, except that Congress might authorize taxexempt obligations in war-time.

A decision which, it was said, might have a far-reaching effect in litigation resulting from defaults on bonds, if upheld, was handed down yesterday by Judge Louis Goldstein in the City Court in Brooklyn. The court held that the right of a bondholder to sue on his bond could not be restricted by a mere reference in a bond to an indenture agreement containing greater restrictions than those printed on the face of the bond.

The morning newspaper membership in The Associated Press which Roy Howard acquired when he bought the "intangible assets" of The Morning, Sunday and Evening World in February, 1931, expired a few days ago when the ScrippsHoward organization ceased to publish The New York Repository.

All that war veterans want from the National Economy League in connection with its attacks on veterans' benefits is "a square deal," Rear Admiral Robert E. Coontz, U.S.N., retired, the national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, said yesterday on arriving in this city on his annual inspection trip.

While Supreme Court Justice Phoenix Ingraham listened to final testimony in a separation suit yesterday, the plaintiff, Mrs. Olive Rice, 45 years old, of 223 East Twenty-first Street, jumped to her death from the sixteen-story roof of the Gramercy Park Hotel, 52 Gramercy Place North.

William Church Osborn, lawyer, who has long taken a leading part in civic affairs, is to head the new corporation being formed by local banks and mortgage companies to assist in the refinancing of maturing guaranteed mortgages. Formal announcement of the details of the new organization was to have been made last night, but a delay developed over minor questions.

United States Army engineers inspected yesterday the $2,000,000 jetty which since March, 1931, has been extended out to sea from Rockaway Point and which is believed to have saved the Coney Island Boardwalk In the storm of Nov. 9 and 10.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Contractors and other large spenders of money would block ratification of a constitutional amendment permitting the taxing of tax-exempt securities, Secretary Mills declared today in commenting on a resolution introduced yesterday by Senator Hull.
SACRAMENTO, Cal., Feb. 9 -- More than $325,000 in currency and Bank of America bonds was stolen by three bandits in a daring holdup at the main postoffice here tonight.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I disagree with your editorial on procedural reform. I do not favor judges regulating procedure.

A syndicate headed by the Hongkong and Shanghai, Banking Corporation has underwritten 33,000,000 silver taels (about $9,405,000) of first mortgage 5 1/2 per cent bonds of the Shanghai Power Company, of which 15,000,000 silver taels were offered yesterday in Shanghai at a price of 96 and interest.

MADRID, Feb. 9 -- Spain will continue to buy oil in the United States despite non-renewal of the contract with the Petroleum Export Association, which expired at the beginning of the year, and regardless of current reports that a Mexican or Russian contract would replace it.
WASHINGTON. Feb. 9 (AP). -- A division of the estate of Mrs. Mary F. Henderson, long a leader of Washington Society, has been agreed upon by claimants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Charges that the treasury of the Mississippi Valley Utilities Investment Company was looted and its preferred stockholders and creditors were defrauded by its parent concern, the Middle West Utilities Company, were made by Eugene V.R. Thayer, receiver, in a report filed today in the Federal District Court.

OMAHA, Neb., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Seven firemen lost their lives and twenty-two others were injured in a $250,000 fire which early today swept the four-story brick Millard hotel, a historic landmark of this city. All of the forty-five guests were accounted for.

NATAL, Brazil, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press). -- Captain J. A. Mollison scored another victory over fatigue, mileage and time today when he brought his little four-cylinder plane down here in time for supper after a 1,885-mile hop across the South Atlantic Ocean, which was the last lap of a 4,800-mile journey from England.

Andrew Jackson Joyner, generally regarded as the dean of American trainers and employed by George D. Widener, was one of thirty-seven trainers to be granted licenses at the February meeting of the Jockey Club yesterday. In addition two jockeys, Robert Jones and Robert Merritt, were given riding licenses and the officials for the 1933 season were appointed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A special performance of Marc Connelly's "The Green Pastures" will be given Sunday night, Feb. 26, at the National Theatre, to give all ranks of Negroes in the capital an opportunity to see the play during its Washington engagement.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, has a reservation on the Majestic, sailing next Tuesday, which will get him back to America on Feb. 20, in ample time prior to March 4 to report to President-elect Roosevelt on the result of his conversations in London with the war debt committee of the British Cabinet.

Yesterday's statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the Reserve note circulation for the system as a whole to be at the highest figure of the present year to date. No other important item in the system reached a new high or low point for the year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Clark D. Shaughnessy of Loyola University, New Orleans, called the "greatest one-man coaching staff in football," is the successor to Amos Alonzo Stagg as head coach of the University of Chicago.

GENEVA, Feb. 9. -- A controversy over the meaning and authority of the Big Five agreement of Dec. 11 on the equality-security question broke out in the disarmament conference today between Germany and France.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The League of Nations Council's committee on Liberia has supported the position of the United States and the Finance Corporation of America, subsidiary of the Firestone interests, through a demand on Liberia to observe her contractual obligations with the Firestone company.

Great Britain will not be prepared, according to the recent statement of the Chancellor of the Exchequer, Mr. CHAMBERLAIN, to "swap" anything at Washington in return for debt reduction. Per haps, however, she will be read to do a little trading.
BERLIN, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange increased $538,591,137 In January, it was announced yesterday by the Exchange. On Feb. 1, 1,539 issues of bonds were listed. They had a par value of 541,172,601,809 and a total market value of $32,456,657,292.

Primo Camera faces an important test in his boxing career tonight when he opposes Ernie Schaaf, the Boston heavyweight who fights under the management of Champion Jack Sharkey and Johnny Buckley, in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden.

Clarence C. Pell, the national amateur racquets champion, will seek to win the Tuxedo Gold Racquet for the fourteenth time In the tournament which is scheduled to begin late this afternoon at Tuxedo Park, N.Y.

CHICAGO, Feb. 9. -- Bullish sentiment for wheat on the Board of Trade here was more in evidence early today than for some time, there being a continuation of the unfavorable reports of weather and crops. Commission house trade was larger, and with local buying the price was quickly rushed up about 1 cent a bushel from yesterday's close to the best figures since Jan. 13 for the May.

In the ever rekindled war between the Republican patriots who want to drive Mr. SAMUEL KOENIG from the county chairmanship, and the Republican patriots who want to keep him there, the ardor continues to be on the side' of the besiegers, but the victory thus far rests with the besieged.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Directors of the Reconstruction finance Corporation were told today by Alfred E. Smith and Senator Wagner that by adhering to their policy of high interest rates on loans for self-liquidating projects they were frustrating the purpose for which the emergency relief and construction act was passed last July.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Passage of the agriculture appropriation bill brightened prospects tonight for Senate consideration of some form of farm relief before the session is over.

An attempt to show through the testimony of a witness that Ernest Schoening, New Jersey rum-runner, had arranged his own "kidnapping," resulted yesterday in County Judge Nova's holding the witness in $50,000 bail for perjury. The witness was Michael Hanulak, who was expected to aid the State in the trial in the Kings County Court of five men charged with kidnapping Schoening for ransom.

Supreme Court Justice Gavegan handed down a decision yesterday in favor of Ralph Pulitzer and Joseph Pulitzer in their suit for the removal of restrictions and permitting them to erect an apartment house on their property on the north side of East Seventy-third Street, between Fifth and Madison Avenues.
No more discerning suggestion has been made regarding the cause of our troubled state than that of Dr. FRANCIS M. POTTENGER, president of the American College of Physicians:

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9 -- The possibility that Senator Glass might refuse to accept the post of Secretary of the Treasury and thus force a realignment of the Roosevelt Cabinet caused friends of the President-elect here some concern today.

Faced with an unseasonable rise of $53,000,000 in the amount of money in circulation and a fall of $13,000,000 in the monetary gold stocks of the country, both of which developments cut into member bank reserve balances, the Federal Reserve System purchased $20,297,000 of additional United States government securitie's in the week ended on Wednesday, It was disclosed in the weekly report of the system published last night.

By beating the Union League Club Class B squash racquets team yesterday afternoon in the play-off on the Harvard Club courts between, the New York division, Metropolitan League winners, the Princeton Club team not only won the sectional title but advanced to the final of the circuit.

ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- Heavy indebtedness of local governmental units was declared a distinct danger, which the State should not ignore, in a report on local taxation filed today in the Legislature by the Mastick Commission.

The twenty-three canvases, together with drawings and sculpture, by the late Arthur B. Davies, now on exhibition at the Ferargil Gallery, represent, with a few additions, what constituted one part of the American showing in last Summer's biennial at Venice.

General buying enthusiasm prevailed yesterday in the bond market on the Stock Exchange, and dealings amounted to $13,106,300, the largest for any day in approximately a month. Railroad bonds, particularly the more speculative issues, led the advance, many rising to more than 3 points.

LONDON, Feb. 9 -- Pacing up and down under guard beneath the grim walls of the Tower of London, an officer of the Seaforth Highlanders continued today to provide London with its strangest military mystery of years.
ALBANY, Feb. 9. -- A bill for the reapportionment of Congressional districts, long overdue in this State, was introduced today by Assemblyman Saul Streit, Democrat, of New York City.

The Fencers Club, national senior three-weapon team champion, successfully defended its honors last night at the Fencers Club by triumphing over the New York Athletic Club in the final of the titular elimination tournament.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange improved again yesterday and, after reaching the previous nigh quotations of the week, ended with gains of 3 to 6 points.
The fact that Mrs. Charming Pollock, wife of the playwright, is the daughter of the late Katherine Wilson Marble, actress, was revealed yesterday when Mrs. Marble's will was filed here.

The American Telephone and Telegraph Company reported yesterday a net income of $145,906,909 for 1932, equal to $7.82 a share earned on 18,661,623 average number of shares outstanding during the year, compared with $166,666,534, or $9.05 a share, on 18,419,461 shares in 1931.

Total assets of the Massachusetts Mutual Life Insurance Company increased in 1932 to $449,621,074 from the $426,899,037 reported at the end of 1931, according to the annual statement of operating results for the past year, mailed to participants yesterday.

GENEVA, Feb. 9 -- The League of Nations Committee of Nineteen demanded today a clear-cut written answer from Japan whether she accepted restoration of Chinese sovereignty in Manchuria, and added a verbal warning against any move toward Jehol Province.

Prices for commodities futures on local exchanges again moved irregularly yesterday, failing to break out of the relatively narrow ranges which have prevailed recently. Sugar and silver futures were lower, while coffee, cocoa, rubber, hides and silk closed with moderate gains.

New business leases announced yesterday toy brokers and renting agents of buildings in Manhattan were featured by the renting of loft and showroom space to firms in the clothing industry. Most of these tenants signed up for quarters in structures in the West Twenties.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 9. -- The resignation of William Z. Ripley as Nathaniel Ropes Professor of Political Economy at Harvard was announced today as effective March 1. Mr. Ripley will become professor emeritus.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The visit of Alfred E. Smith to Washington today was the occasion of another demonstration of his popularity in this politically-minded capital. Wherever the former Presidential candidate went during the day he was surrounded by enthusiastic admirers.

A new X-ray tube, made of laminated paper, which can withstand higher voltages than tubes made of glass, has been constructed at the Palmer Physical Laboratory, Princeton University, it is announced in the current issue of The Physical Review, publication of the American Institute of Physics.
ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 9 -- After a secret investigation lasting for two months, Roanoke police today captured two men, who they charged attempted to extort $50,000 from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.
The New York Public Library, which normally buys nearly 250,000 books every year, will buy only about 50,000 this year and most of those will be replacements of old popular titles.
LONDON, Feb. 9 -- The Admiralty announced today that its first contract for fuel oil extracted from British coal had been placed with a British company. The order was said to be 28,000 tons.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Acting on recommendations made by Dr. Alfred Hugenberg, Reich Minister of Economy and Agriculture, the government today decreed a 500 per cent Increase in the import duty on lard and an increase of about 100 per cent on live stock.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Copies of two letters sent to Chief of Police Manning of Roanoke and said by Colonel H. Norman Schwarzkopf, superintendent of the New Jersey State Police, to have been received by Colonel Lindbergh were made public here this evening.

Hope of an early Spring revival in business entered definitely yesterday into Wall Street's calculations as the security markets came to life with a progressive motion. The more active stocks advanced anywhere from a fraction to more than 3 points; the gains in domestic corporation bonds ran as high as 2, 3 and 4 points in many cases.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Money in circulation on Jan. 31 aggregated $5,644,652,165, compared with $5,674,941,484 at the end of December, a decrease of $30,289,319, according to the Treasury's circulation statement. The per capita for January was $45.06 on the basis of an estimated population of 125,261,000, against $45.33 in December on an estimated population of 125,198,000.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9. -- A new champion will be crowned in the sixth annual Winter tournament of the Artists and Writers Golf Association as a result of the semifinal matches played today at the Palm Beach Country Club. The perennial titleholder, Grantland Rice, who took the qualifying medal earlier in the week, was eliminated by Rex Beach, the novelist, who won by the slender margin of 1 up.

TOKYO, Friday, Feb. 10 (AP) -- Japan's reply to a League of Nations Committee's question about Japan's attitude toward discontinuance of the present Manchukuo regime will be emphatically in the negative, a government spokesman said today.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, IN THE PACIFIC, Feb. 9. -- With lights out and radios stilled, Blue men-of-war breasted the surging swells of the open ocean tonight, steaming silently beneath the moon like gray shadows across the dark sea.

A luncheon was given yesterday at the Ambassador by the flower show committee of the Garden Club of America for Mrs. Jonathan Bulkley, president of the club. After luncheon, the guests, mart of whom are representatives of garden clubs, discussed plans for the annunl flower show to be held in Grand Central Palace from March 20 to 25.

Thomas H. Beck, chairman of the Connecticut State Board of Fisheries and Game, yesterday made public the location of the trout stream which, he announced several months ago, would be used exclusively by women anglers.
The premiere of "One Sunday Afternoon," which had been previously announced for tonight at the Little Theatre, has been postponed until next Wednesday.

The corporation law of all States, under the authority of which securities are issued, should be carefully reviewed, in the opinion of William C. Breed of the law firm of Breed, Abbott Morgan, who addressed yesterday the forum of investment banking sponsored by the Investment Bankers Association and the Graduate School of Business of New York University.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9. -- A real blizzard that swept Hanover this afternoon, covering the Dartmouth College grounds hy nightfall, eased the minds of Dartmouth Outing Club men on the eve of the twenty-third annual Winter carnival.

Private Citizen Calls Up. Mr. ROOSEVELT, as our Washington correspondent is inclined to believe, has been in direct touch with Prime Minister MACDONALD by telephone, cable, wireless, the mails or all four methods of communication.
LONDON, Feb. 9. -- Sir Daniel Morris, one of the pioneers of research into empire resources, died at Bournemouth today at the age of 88.
A freak goal by Murray Murdoch In the third period enabled the New York Rangers to obtain a 3-to-3 tie with the Ottawa Senators in a National League hockey game at Madison Square Garden last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Some of you old New Yorkers journeying into the hinterlands may have noted strange building activities in our commuting centres. Men stringing barbed-wire, setting up searchlights, erecting block-houses.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 9 -- Charging that borough officials have entered into a conspiracy to develop a tract of land known as Palisades Gardens at the expense of and against the wishes of the taxpayers. Luke Flanagan, a taxpayer, petitioned the Court of Chancery today for a cancellation of $3,790,700 of improvement bonds issued by Fort Lee from 1928 to 1931.
Small flats and dwellings continued to furnish the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover in the deals reported yesterday.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported yesterday a loss of $15,999,900 gold through earmarking of that amount for foreign account. The operation, the largest of its kind since last Spring, was connected by the financial community with the return of Poland to the full gold standard instead of the gold-exchange standard, announced in Europe yesterday as effective on Wednesday.

Frank J. Taylor, Commissioner of Welfare, reported yesterday that the Department of Public Welfare spent $36,154,190.15 for the relief of 762,751 men, women and children in 1932, a 200 per cent increase in the number assisted over 1931 and a 100 per cent increase in expenditures.

The adjusted index of carded cotton cloth production shows a further increase to the highest level since early in December. The figure for the week ended Feb. 4 is 97.4, as against 96.5 for the preceding week and 94.1 for the corresponding week last year.

COPENHAGEN, Feb. 9 -- The telegram sent by Hermann Wilhelm Goering, German Cabinet Minister, to the editor of the Goteborgs Handels-och Sjofarts-Tidning, one of the most influential dailies in Northern Europe, protesting against references to Chancellor Hitler, has caused a furor throughout Scandinavia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- A decision to take no action against The New Outlook magazine for printing an article by David S. Barry, dismissed sergeant-at-arms of the Senate, which said some Congressmen took bribes was reached today by the Senate Judiciary Committee.

The "old guard" which has built its social season around the Metropolitan Opera for half a century announced last night that it was looking to the public to help New York's greatest musical institution weather the depression.

A large volume of holiday travel to New Jersey seashore resorts, also to the South and West, and a lighter volume to the Adirondacks and to points in New England, are expected over Lincoln's birthday by the railroad lines.
PARIS, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

THE HAGUE, Friday, Feb. 10 -- Reports reached here this morning that the battleship De Zeven Provincien, which was seized by a mutinous native crew, had been set afire by seaplanes that bombed her after her crew refused to surrender. Many of the crew were said to have left her in boats and to be surrendering to warships that intercepted her.

Miss Jean Shiley of Philadelphia, Olympic champion and world's record holder in the running high jump for women, has withdrawn from competition and will not defend her American indoor championship in Madison Square Garden on Feb. 25, it was announced yesterday by Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A.A.U.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 9 (AP) -- George T. Williams and the Commercial Steamship Company, a Delaware corporation, today asked that a receiver be appointed for the Williams Steamship Company, subsidiary of the American-Hawaiian Steamship Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Arthur A. Ballantine, Under Secretary of the Treasury, told a Senate committee today that it would be a tragic mistake to withdraw Federal aid now from the railroads, "a key-structure in the nation's financial system."

DETROIT, Feb. 9 -- About a half of the auto workers who walked out on strike at the Hudson Motor Car Company plants last Monday had returned to their jobs today, and production was resumed, but on a greatly decreased schedule, plant officials said.

Thursday, Feb. 9, 1933. Further relaxation in the street rate for call loans, with the return of funds recently dispatched to the interior to aid distressed banks, was in evidence with Federal funds offered, at 1/8, and trades made at that figured This compares with a high of 1/2, established last Monday.

The money market registered yesterday the first definite reaction to the unseasonable expansion in currency that has been going on in the last few weeks and the consequent shrinkage of Federal Reserve member bank reserves. Leading dealers in bankers' acceptances, faced with increased offerings from the banks, advanced discount rates one-eighth of 1 per cent to the levels which obtained prior to the last cut in rates on Jan. 23.

Bruno Walter made a welcome and interesting change in the customary character of programs of symphonic music last night in Carnegie Hall. He opened the program of the concert given by the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with two compositions by Americans, worth while as music, and as escape from convention.

TORONTO, Feb. 9 -- Progress in the treatment of a case of bone sarcoma, one of the most difficult forms of cancer, by the use of intravenous injections of a colloidal solution of metallic arsenic is reported today in the Canadian Medical Association Journal.

With good weather and a following wind, the new record for distance, 5,340 miles, made by GAYLORD and NICHOLETTS of the Royal Air Force, could be broken. Their achievement was made possible by elaborate tests of an improved single-motor machine designed to carry 1,000 gallons of gasoline in its 82-foot wings, With sleeping accommodations for one pilot while the other was at the controls.

Two changes in the cast of "Siegfried" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House did not rob the performance of a grand line and an eloquent interpretation. It is, furthermore, commentary upon the power of Wagner's music and the place that it retains in public estimation that even in these days the extra Wagner matinees bring large and very enthusiastic audiences to the Opera House.

Graham Court, an eight-story apartment building erected by William Waldorf Astor about thirty five years ago when Harlem was a high-class residential area, was reported sold yesterday by the Astor estate to Edward W. Browning, real estate operator.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending Feb. 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,069,000,000, a decrease of $10,000,000, compared with the preceding week and an increase of $262,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

The recent discovery by Professor Charles B. Lipman, internationally known bacteriologist of the University of California, that meteorites contain living micro-organisms of possible extraterrestrial origin does not necessarily mean that life on this planet had its beginning by the transportation of living matter from some other planet, it was declared here yesterday by Dr. Lipman In an interview at the Harvard Club.

Stuyvesant High School's basketball team yesterday took the lead in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division of the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship tournament, while James Madison High moved into a tie for first place with New Utrecht in the Brooklyn division.

WASHINGTON, Feb, 9. -- The same Senate which argued for days over air mail and ship subsidies and branch banking passed today, after only three hours of consideration, the $100,275,000 Department of Agriculture appropriation bill.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9.-- Three goals in the opening period enabled the Princeton hockey team to defeat Middlebury by 3-1 in Hobey Baker rink tonight. The visitors also tallied in the initial frame.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Charges that Senator Huey P. Long's political organization, supporting Representative John H. Overton in his election to the United States Senate, dealt in cash with no records kept were made today to the Senate subcommittee investigating claims of fraud in the election.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Mr. and Mrs. A. Atwater Kent entertained this afternoon with a tea at Ocean View Cottage. Their guests were:

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 9. -- Snow means a great many things in different sections of the land, but up here in this village of the New Hampshire hills it means broad grins on the faces of the officials of the Outing Club of Dartmouth College, busy tonight with final preparations for the twenty-third annual Winter carnival which starts tomorrow.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- The Cuban-American Friendship Council offered today to supply Dr. Orestes Ferrara, the Cuban Secretary of State, a photostat of the original copy of the confiscated edition of Dec. 31, 1932, of El Pais, the Havana newspaper, with a picture of a student reported to have been shot when trying to escape.

WALFISH BAY, South Africa, Feb. 9 (Canadian Press) -- The log of the Royal Air Force plane flown by Squadron Leader O.R. Gayford and Lieutenant G.E. Nicholetts to a new long-distance non-stop record revealed today only ten gallons of gasoline were left in the big machine's tanks when they brought it down here yesterday after their 5,341-mile flight from England.

MANILA, Feb. 9 -- A profound undercurrent of uneasiness throughout the three Moro Provinces of Lanao, Cotobato and Sulu has been secretly reported to Brig. Gen. Clarence Bowers, newly appointed chief of the Philippine Constabulary, by Colonel Luther Stevens, chief of the constabulary division of Mindanao and Sulu.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The letter "Psychology of Bankers," by Ranulph Kingsley, contains many incorrect and misleading statements.

PINEHURST, N.C. Feb. 9. -- The medalist and the runner-up for the medal, Miss Helen Waring of Pinehurst and Mrs. Sara Fownes Wadsworth of Pittsburgh, attained the final round today in the twentyeighth annual St. Valentine's golf tournament over the No. 1 course.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Bestowal on President-elect Roosevelt of practically dictatorial powers over the nation's purse strings for the first two years of his administration as the only way to insure drastic economies in governmental expenditures is proposed by Democratic leaders of the House.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 9. -- Mrs. Helen R. Leidy, ardent supporter of grand opera and widow of Dr. Joseph Leidy, eminent physician, died early today in the Chestnut Hill Hospital at the age of 62.

Blame for the attempted break in the Brooklyn city prison last November, which resulted in the fatal shooting of the head keeper and a convict, was laid to the "gross laxity" of Warden Harry C. Honeck in a presentment handed up yesterday to County Judge Franklin Taylor in Brooklyn by the Kings County December grand jury.

The teaching of science and engineering in technical schools as broad cultural subjects, with the aim to give the student not merely a technical knowledge but a comprehensive point of view of what science and technology mean to life and civilization, was urged last night at the round-table discussion of the American Institute of the City of New York, held at the Chemists' Club, 52 East Forty-first Street.
LONDON, Feb. 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes in pounds sterling:

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- A move to enlist Governor Lehman's aid in obtaining general postponement of farm mortgage foreclosures was begun at the sixtieih annual convention of the New York State Grange here today.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 9. -- A new treatment for alcoholic cases, under which a patient with delirium tremens became "normal" overnight, is described by three Ithaca scientists in a report of the proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 9. -- The Flying Ebony colt Coat Tails scored a length victory in the Avon Park Purse, feature today at Hialeah Park. Ebony Lady, a daughter of the same stallion, was first in the fourth race, secondary in importance.

Mrs. Auguste Noel gave a luncheon yesterday in the terraced restaurant of the Plaza. The guests, who were seated at a table decorated with Spring flowers, were Mrs. Ewing McAnerney, Mrs. Oliver De Lancey Coster, Mrs. John B. Ryan, Mrs. Sidney Harris, Mrs. Harry Van A. Brower, Mrs. Henry O. Tallmadge. Mrs. Reginald W. Rives, Mrs. Errol Kerr, and the Misses Marie La Montagne, Amelia Stevens, Josephine Noel and Edith Embree.

BERLIN, Feb. 9 -- Hermann Wilhelm Goering, National Socialist Minister without portfolio, has administered an official rebuke by telegram to the leading newspaper of Goteborg. Sweden, because of its attacks on Chancellor Adolf Hitler.

After considering a capital outlay budget for all departments totaling $254,464,890, the Board of Estimate decided yesterday to authorize, a number of projects carrying an estimated cost of $4,001,266 and deferred action on the $250,863,624 remainder.
TITLE SEATING PROGRAM. Today. Women's singles, school figures, at Ice Club, starting 9 A.M.

MONTREAL, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Latest results of experiments with an "icewater test" that may serve to detect a tendency toward high bloodpressure early in life were described today before the American College of Physicians.

Fourteen Manhattan and Bronx properties were offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Most of the defaulted properties were tenement houses and dwellings, and all were bought in by the plaintiffs who brought about the foreclosure actions.

The committee of Eastern, railroad presidents formed to curb competitive wastes plans to report next Thursday to the Eastern Presidents Conference on methods for reducing, losses from lighterage practices followed in New York harbor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 (AP) -- Regret was expressed by some members of the Senate Finance Committee today over Prime Minister MacDonald's statement that a number of economic and financial conditions stand in the way of the British returning to the gold standard at this time.

From the viewpoint of Wall Street, yesterday's share market was the best and most vigorous since early in January. Not only did the general list advance sharply in active dealings, but there was an animated spirit that had been lacking for several weeks.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. .1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday. 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

BELGRADE, Feb. 9 -- The Papal Nuncio to Belgrade, Mgr. Pellegrinetti, according to reports in diplomatic circles here, has protested on behalf of the Vatican against attacks on the Catholic Church and clergy in the Yugoslav press.
BRISBANE, Australia, Friday, Feb. 10. -- Australia had scored 153 runs for the loss of one wicket at the tea interval today in the first innings of the fourth cricket test match against England.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 9 -- News of the settlement of the extraterritorial court controversy without the customary Chinese verbal denunciations of imperialists is taken here as a typical example of China's changed diplomacy since the Japanese seized Mukden, Manchuria, in September, 1931.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Secretary Stimson spent considerable time today with, the House Foreign Affairs Committee, in executive session, pleading for the early adoption of the arms embargo resolution suggested by President Hoover.

Deems Taylor, composer and critic, offered a plan yesterday for a voluntary self-taxation of a penny a performance by radio listeners as his solution for the financial difficulties of the Metropolitan Opera Association. Addressing the League for Political Education at the Town Hall, he suggested an association of those who listen to radio broadcasts of opera, possibly functioning through the General Federation of Women's Clubs.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Edgar F. Luckenbach in a statement published in THE TIMES accuses railroad spokesmen, of pouring forth "venom" against the shipping using the Panama Canal. The facts do not support this charge.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9 (AP). -- After finishing second the last time out, following two successive victories, G. R. Yeargin's Predict came back today with an easy triumph in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

The severest cold spell of the Winter held almost the entire country in its grip yesterday, causing widespread suffering among the unemployed, ruining fruit and truck crops in many sections and bringing the toll of lives to at least sixty-five.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- Republican leaders are working out plans to reorganize the Republican. Congressional Committee into a progressive organization designed to take an active part in contests in all parts of the country.
Norman R. Collins, London publisher associated with Gollancz., Ltd., arrived yesterday on the White Star liner Georgic to seek American manuscripts for the British market.

In these days of mounting outcry against college professors meddling with politics it is well to recall the fine public service done by one of them. We refer to Professor THOMAS S. ADAMS of Yale, whose death on Wednesday brings a keen sense of loss not only to his many friends but to those who knew of his valuable work for the Government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9 -- Foes of prohibition scored another victory on Capitol Hill today when a subcommittee of the Senate Appropriations Committee applied another 10 per cent slash to the funds for enforcement during the 1933-34 fiscal year.

Consolidation of four local commodity exchanges into one, to be known as the Commodities Exchange, Inc., was assured yesterday when members of the fourth component, the National Raw Silk Exchange, approved the deal by an overwhelming majority, 204 to 15.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Gorell of London are visiting Mr. and Mrs. Henry Hill Pierce at 9 East Ninety-fourth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In common with many of your readers, my Sunday was saddened, a gloom pervaded the home, as I read the harrowing facts disclosed during the debate on reduction of Congressional salaries.

The day of the motion picture which devotes itself to mere diversion has passed and audiences are looking for adventure in reality rather than seeking escape from reality, in the opinion of Leroy E. Bowman of the Child Study Association, a speaker yesterday at the opening session of the ninth annual conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

LOW BRIDGE, a play in three acts, dramatized by Frank B. Elser from Walter D. Edmonds's novel, "Rome Haul," Staged by William J. O'Neill; produced by the Players Theatre. At the Fifty-seventh Street Playhouse. The performance will be repeated this evening.

John D. Rockefeller Jr., who announced last Summer his stand against prohibition, took a step yesterday designed to help the country achieve an adequate and socially desirable system of liquor control.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 9. -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., youthful holder of the New York State amateur title, advanced to the final of the South Florida championship at the Palm Beach Golf Club today. He defeated William B. Langford of Chicago, several times winner of the tournament.

The New York County grand jury, investigating ballot frauds, indicted sixteen more election inspectors on felony and misdemeanor charges yesterday, bringing the total number of persons indicted since the beginning of the county investigation four weeks ago to ninety-two.

Led by a woman, a group of fifteen labor agitators invaded a clothing manufactory on the seventh floor of 138 West Twenty-fifth Street yesterday morning and called on the sixty employes to strike and to join the Needle Trade Workers' Industrial Union, a leftwing Communist organization.

IT is the custom to give out the weights and scale measurements of pugilistic gladiators as they prepare to step into the arena. The surveyors have gone over Primo Carnera for the fifteenth or twentieth time, and the figures set down on the chart are calculated to scare off the stoutest citizen and send children screaming into the house.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 9. -- The Princeton basketball team, after a three-week layoff, resumed activities tonight and overwhelmed Cooper Union, 70 -- 20. Fairman and Seibert led the Tigers' attack with 12 points each. Larsen, Grebauskas and Fortune, the other regulars, contributed 11, 9 and 8 respectively.

Suspension of the ferry line between East Twenty-third Street, Manhattan, and Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was ordered yesterday by the Commissioners of the Sinking Fund. Peter J. McGuinness, Assistant Commissioner of Public Works of Brooklyn and defender of the interests of Greenpoint, his home community, made a final plea to save the line, but Mayor O'Brien insisted it must go as an economy measure.

In an impassioned speech before the Economic Club last night, Samuel Seabury called upon the members of that organization to demand that Governor Lehman take a definite stand upon charter revision for New York City.

The New York Stock Exchange has admitted to its list KelseyHayes Wheel Company new Class A $1 par value convertible stock, and Class B $1 par value stock, which were created in accordance with the reorganization of the old Kelsey-Hayes Wheel Corporation.

After the sort of victuals that have been served up in the theatre recently, "Before Morning," which was played at the Ritz last evening, seems at least to be intelligently written and acted. For that much relief this department gives due thanks.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 9. -- Miss Ruth Hall of Merion remains the only surviving American in the women's national squash racquets championship tournament at the Merion Cricket Club as the result of the quarter-final matches today, her path to the title barred by three British contenders.

The Merchants Association of New York lined up yesterday with other civic and shipping groups in the port district in opposing the proposed loan of $11,000,000 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to New Jersey interests who have announced plans for the building of a waterfront terminal in Bayonne.

More than 884,000 spindles were scrapped by the cotton textile industry during 1932, bringing the total dismantled since 1925, the peak year, to about 6,500,000 units, the Association of Cotton Textile Merchants of New York reported yesterday, in a ten-year survey of the industry.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 9 (AP). -- Clark D. Shaughnessy, who brought a lot of startling Big Ten ideas on football into the South when he swung down into these parts from Minnesota eighteen years ago, is going back to his old haunts this Fall with something to show the mid-West on how the South likes the game played.

HAVANA, Feb. 9 (AP). -- Lord Tournament, a speedy sprinter from C. L. Harris's barns, won his second successive race as he carried off the honors in the five-and-one-half-furlong feature at Oriental Park today.

Philip J. Roosevelt, chairman of the reorganization committee for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, announced yesterday that he had sent to the Interstate Commerce Commission a letter in which he opposed the granting, in the present circumstances, of a proposed loan of $1,027,174 by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to the company and asserted that unless the company's position was materially improved the road should cease operations.

The progress made by the International Schoolboy Fellowship, organized in 1927 to promote cooperation between the youth of the United States and other nations, was reviewed last night at the annual meeting of the group at the Harvard Club.

Seventy graduates, including sixty-four women and six men, received their diplomas last night at the fifty-eighth annual commencement exercises of the Belleveue Schools of Nursing, held in the auditorium of the Women Nurses Home, 440 East Twenty-sixth Street.

The rubber shoe, a humble item in the wardrobe of the tennis player and the office boy, has been made a symbol of the confusion of American economic policy under our present tariff. Footwear with rubber soles is being manufactured with increasing skill and on a large scale in Czechoslovakia and Japan.

Misconceptions of each other's traits by citizens of the United States and Latin America were deplored yesterday by Severo Mallet-Prevost, former president of the Pan-American Society, at a luncheon of the society in his honor attended by South American consular representatives at the Bankers Club, 120 Broadway, on the eve of his departure on a vacation trip to Rio de Janeiro and other southern capitals.

In opposing yesterday the application in behalf of Justice Lawrence T. Gresser of Queens and other Special Sessions justices to restrain the Board of Estimate from cutting their salaries of $17,500 a year more than 10 per cent, which they are willing to contribute, Corporation Counsel Hilly told Supreme Court Justice Levy that in the present emergency the judges should waive their constitutional rights.

BERLIN, Feb. 9. -- Stocks on the Boerse fluctuated in early trading today, finally settling at an average level slightly below that of yesterday. At the opening prices improved somewhat, but even then the volume of business was extremely small.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 9. -- An unusual demand that the Senate Banking and Currency subcommittee investigating the Stock Exchange be itself investigated by the Senatewas made today in letters to Senators from an organization styling itself the New York Stock Exchange reform committee of the Manhattan Board of Commerce.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Plans and Planners" will undoubtedly cause chagrin to many of your readers. The circumstances tempt one to rise in righteous indignation at even polite aspersion on those who have the mental vigor and stamina to try to think through the "mighty maze" and formulate their conclusions into a "plan."

Five 1932 fellows, who recently completed their three years' work at the American Academy in Rome, will open today a joint exhibition in the Grand Central Galleries. There are two landscape architects, Thomas Drees Price and Charles Reuel Button; Burton Kenneth Johnstone is an architect, Sidney Biehler Waugh a sculptor and John Melza Sitton a painter.

Friday, Feb. 10, 1933. The official marking up of bill rates, all maturities, by 1/3, provided the only development of importance in the day's money market. This action followed that taken by several dealers late on Thursday. It was the first change since Jan. 23, when there was a downward revision in rates from those which had been carried on from Dec. 5 last.

Auctioneers acting as the result of foreclosure proceedings against the owners of sixteen properties in Manhattan and the Bronx yesterday struck down all the defaulted holdings to the plaintiffs in the actions. Banks again played a prominent part in this form of liquidation by bidding in ten of the offerings.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The Far Eastern situation is causing increasing concern here as signs of coming events tend to convince officials that a crisis is approaching in the Chino-Japanese dispute.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- Ten commission merchants and companies were indicted today in the Federal court on charges of defrauding the Wabash Railway of about $1,000,000 through false claims on damaged goods. Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward, before whom the indictments were returned, fixed bond at $5,000 in each case.

The Metropolitan Opera Association will continue in its present home on Broadway between Thirty-ninth and Fortieth Streets or not at all, it was said yesterday in denial of the recurrent rumor that it would move to Rockefeller Center.

With only counsel for James J. Lanzetta, Tammany victor over Representative Fiorello H. LaGuardia, Republican, opposing, Supreme Court Justive Levy granted yesterday the application of the Board of Elections for permission to recount the entire city vote.

GENEVA, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Resolutions seeking to ease the expense burdens of counties, opposing tampering with the Eighteenth Amendment and calling for a national policy of disarmament were adopted by 31,000 delegates to the annual convention of the State Grange today in a final session prolonged well past darkness by 208 measures reported for consideration.

BATAVIA, Java, Saturday, Feb. 11 (AP). -- The Dutch destroyer Piethein arrived here early today, carrying the bodies of twenty-two men killed by an aerial bombing that ended the five-day mutiny of the native crew of the battleship Zeven Provincien.
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 10. -- Mrs. William Woods Plankinton entertained tonight with a dinner, followed by contract, at Casa de Los Ensuenos. Guests at the dinner included:
"Evensong," starring Edith Evans, will close its engagement at the Selwyn Theatre this evening.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Two men, believed to have aided in the kidnapping Sunday of Mrs. Mary B. Skeele, were sought on bench warrants tonight by detectives who said they had obtained full confessions from Luella Pearl Hammer, 36-year-old musician, and her household handy man, Frank Howard.
To the Editor of The New York Times: During this whole year, particularly at election and budget times next October, facts like these will be helpful for thinking about the budget for 1933:
Several New Yorkers were among the principals in the New Jersey realty deals reported yesterday.

DETROIT, Feb. 10. -- Prices of the new Ford V-8 cylinder cars, with 112-inch wheelbase, were announced by the Ford Motor Company Friday evening. The new price list shows reductions of from $5 to $35 on various types of closed cars under those of the former V-8.

Thomas Jefferson High School's basketball team defeated New Utrecht, 42 to 19, at the Jefferson gymnasium, in the feature contest of five Brooklyn division P.S.A.L. games played yesterday. The winners moved into a tie for first place with James Madison High in the Brooklyn standing.

That Philip J. Roosevelt, chairman of the reorganization committee for the Minneapolis St. Louis Railroad, did not have the full backing of interested security holders in his assertion that the Reconstruction Finance Corporation should refuse a proposed loan of $1,027,174 to the company unless it was accompanied by a reorganization, was disclosed yesterday when William P. Hawley, a member of the committee, issued a statement of disagreement.

Secretary of the Interior Ray Lyman Wilbur will be one of three speakers at the annual dinner of the Men's Class of the Riverside Church, popularly known as "the Rockefeller Bible Class," which will be held on Tuesday evening at the Hotel Commodore.

NEUNKIRCHEN, Saar Basin Territtory, Feb. 10. -- More than 100 persons are believed to have been killed and more than 1,000 were injured early this evening in an explosion of one of the biggest gas tanks in Europe in the plant of the Neunkirchen Iron Works.

After going through all its previous tests without once being upset, the Bayside Tennis Club squase finally was beaten last night when it met the Squash Club in the final matches of the season for the Metropolitan Leagrue Class B teams.

George Jean Nathan, who has been working steadily on a new book while engaged mornings as an editor of The American Spectator and evenings as a theatre reviewer, has completed the book and turned the manuscript over to his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- One of the most interesting developments resulting from the recent political overturn has teen the sudden and complete submergence of Lieut. Gen. Kurt von Schleicher, supposedly the strong man of German politics and the inheritor of the Bismarck tradition, whom popular estimation long credited with pulling the strings that moved officials more in the public view.

The December-January figures on State factory employment showed a 100 per cent increase in the normal seasonal decline for the month, according to a statement yesterday by Miss Frances Perkins, Industrial Commissioner.

ATLANTA, Ga., Feb. 10. -- Declaring that the newspaper had risen to a new power in world affairs, Dean Carl W. Ackerman of the Columbia University School of Journalism tonight urged that President-elect Roosevelt call an international press conference early in his administration to level "the walls of nationalistic opinion and preconceived prejudices."

One of the fruits of current municipal economy is the "capital outlay budget," in which various pending public improvements are listed in such a way as to enable the Board of Estimate to decide which shall be given priority. The days of lavish spending are over, at least for the present.

With the starting field cut down from eleven to seven by four defaults and with the postponing of the only other match scheduled for yesterday, the Tuxedo Gold Racquet tournament proper will get under way this morning at Tuxedo Park.

A comprehensive plan for restoring New York City real estate to a sound basis through the refinancing of mortgages and the reduction of mortgage interest charges was announced last night by Owen D. Young, chairman of the banking and industrial committee of the New York Federal Reserve District.

MONTREAL, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Hope is in sight, through new methods of surgery, of doing away with the severe pain suffered by most persons who have angina pectoris, the American College of Physicians was told at its closing session today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 10. -- Dr. Frederick C. de Sumichrast, Professor Emeritus of French Literature at Harvard University, taught at that institution for eleven years. He resigned from Harvard in 1911 to take up his residence in London, where he planned to devote much of his time to politics and lecturing.

Following a two-month investigation of six charges preferred against The New York University Daily News by Professor Philip O. Badger, chairman of the university's board of athletic control, the publication committee of the institution's student senate yesterday recommended that the paper be suspended from publication from Feb. 10 to Feb. 26, and that six of the eight members of its managing board be ousted.

Rutgers University scored two victories last night, in its Intercollegiate Swimming Association dual meet with City College at the C.C. N.Y. pool, winning the swimming meet, 44 -- 27, and triumphing in the water polo game, 33 -- 17.

Joseph Leblang, cut-rate theatre ticket operator, was insolvent at the time of his death, April 17. 1931, according to an accounting filed in Surrogate's Court yesterday by his widow, Mrs. Tillie Leblang Jasie, executrix of his estate. The report shows assets of $1,998,633.28 and debts of $2,983,610.40, or liabilities of $984,977.12 in excess of assets.

GENEVA, Feb. 10. -- A special Assembly will be called for next Friday to declare conciliation of the Chino-Japanese conflict hopeless and adopt a report condemning Japan and recommending means for solution of the dispute, according to the present plans of League of Nations leaders.

MOSCOW, Feb. 10. -- The only possible conclusions to be drawn from two long dispatches to the Izvestia, organ of the government, from its special correspondent at Rostov, the capital of the North Caucasus, is that whether or not there is grain for seeding in the region, the authorities will never be able to collect it.

TOKYO, Feb. 10. -- Count Uchida, the Foreign Minister, is carefully drafting Japan's rejection of the interpretation of the League of Nations Committee of Nineteen that Japan is agreeable to the Lytton report's seventh principle, which says the Manchurian regime must be modified to make it consistent with China's sovereignty, and the government has made it clear it considers conciliation efforts ended.
Henry P. Fletcher, former United States Ambassador to Italy, will sail today for a West Indies cruise on the Conte Grande of the Italian Line. Others sailing include:
HAMILTON, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- Eating a "right-handed" sugar will produce quicker and better muscular control in the hand one hour later than a "left-handed" sugar.

Trading in local commodities markets continued yesterday on a quiet scale in the absence of any marked trend. Price movements in futures trading were irregular and at the close only sugar showed a clear gain on the day. The movement of cash prices was also irregular.

Aside from irregularly lower prices for United States Government securities, bonds on the Stock Exchange generally gave a good account of themselves yesterday. Speculative rails continued higher, with the more seasoned issues of this group also making some gains.

Bonds issued in 1853 by the New York Erie Railroad, the predecessor of the present Erie Railroad, which have been extended from time to time since 1883, are to be subjected to a still further extension to 1938, according to an announcement issued yesterday.

The Supper Club held its inaugural supper and dance last night at the Savoy-Plaza. The club plans to give a series of entertainments, and at the end of its season the net profits will be given to charity.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Final action by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation on the $3,957,000 loan to the Hillside Housing Corporation for erection of model apartments in the Bronx has been indefinitely postponed following the conference yesterday between directors of the government agency and Governor Lehman's Emergency Public Works Commission.

PEIPING, Feb. 10. -- Acting Premier T.V. Soong arrived here by airplane today and went into conference with Marshal Chang Hsiaoliang regarding the latest developments in the Jehol situation and concerning the significance of events at Geneva.

Eighteen cash gifts aggregating $83,426.24 to Columbia University were announced yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler. The largest, $72,000, was donated by the Presbyterian Hospital to be applied toward the support of the department of ophthalmology during 1933.
EMPORIA, Kan., Feb. 10. -- Today I seem to be well planted in my middle sixties. I have definitely left the early sixties and in a few months will be well into the border-land of the late sixties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Socks and shoes for American soldiers was the theme of a debate between David A. Reed, former Major of the 311th Field Artillery, and Thomas Connally, ex-Captain of the Twenty-second Infantry Brigade, Eleventh Division, in the Senate this afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- When the House convened today Representative Arnold. Democrat, of Illinois, sought to get unanimous consent to send the $940,000,000 Treaaury-Postoffice bill to conference, but it was only after an hour of heated debate that the House voted to do so.

Condemnation of present-day movies by a guest speaker at a luncheon yesterday of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures in the Hotel Pennsylvania brought surprise to an audience which had taken a tolerant view of modern films, and which so expressed itself through a spokesman who quickly challenged the assertions of the visitor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Historic ground where George Washington camped with 10,000 soldiers 153 years ago would be converted into the Morristown National Historical Park, under a bill passed by the Senate today and sent to the House.

Exception to the annual financial statement of the General Outdoor Advertising Company has been taken by Price, Water-house Co. in their certification of the figures, it was revealed with the publication of the company's pamphlet report yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- A postmaster, a Sheriff, Coast Guardsmen and State troopers were among the New Jersey allies of the $5,000,000 Philadelphia rum ring which was smashed with a series of raids in October, 1931, according to testimony today at the trial of twelve of the ring's alleged members in Federal court.

La Salle Academy and Iona School of New Rochelle triumphed in games played yesterday in the Manhattan division of the C.H.S.A.A. championship basketball tournament. La Salle defeated De La Salle Institute, 16 to 15, at the West Twenty-eighth Street gymnasium and Iona won on its home court in New Rochelle from St. Ann's Academy, 22 to 12.

President COFFIN of the Metropolitan Museum of Art has said that it "started off as a rich "man's club, where art patrons "could keep their collection" hut that it is now doing its best to "serve the city." Increasingly it has become an educational institution.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10. -- Three of the famous dummy candidates of Louisiana appeared today before the Senate committee investigating the Overton-Broussard Senatorial primary. The solemn chairman, Senator Howell, Republican, of Nebraska, grinned broadly, and Senator Carey, Republican, of Wyoming, rolled in his chair.

CLEVELAND, Ohio, Feb. 10 (A.P). -- With iron ore stocks at Lake Erie docks and consuming furnaces nearly 7,000,000 tons lower than a year ago, an increase this year in ore movements from Lake Superior mines was forecast in the trade today.

TAMPA, Fla., Feb. 10. -- Wiffy Cox of Brooklyn was "right" today, the Palma Ceia golf course suited his mood and he shot a record-tying 32-33-65, live strokes under par, to lead the field of 105 contestants after 18 holes of the 72-hole Gasparilla open golf tournament.

Mrs. Curtis B. Dall, daughter of President-elect Roosevelt, will go on the radio as a commercial speaker if a "suitable" sponsor can be found who will present her in a broadcast that meets with Mrs. Dall's approval.

The presence in New York City yesterday of the two Republican legislative leaders, Joseph A. McGinnies, Speaker of the Assembly, and Senator George R. Fearon, supposedly to confer with Charles D. Hilles and H. Edmund Machold, lent color to the belief that a move by the Republican "Old Guard" to regain control of the party is under way.

New bonds offered this week for public subscription were the smallest in volume of any week since the end of December, amounting to only $4,450.000. Of this amount $4,036.000 represented municipal financing and $414,000 public utility issues.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 10 (AP) -- The Toledo American Association Baseball Club, in receivership for more than a year, today was sold to a group of Toledo men. Negotiations for the sale have been under way for several days by Al Reuben, receiver.

Pointing out that the declaration of principles announced recently by the American Petroleum Institute "is not an agreement in any sense," H.F. Sinclair, chairman of the executive committee of the Consolidated Oil Corporation, said yesterday that if proration of the production of crude oil could not be enforced and development of new pools and overdrilling could not be limited, "we shall be compelled to look elsewhere for corrective measures."

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- James F. Evans, 56 years old, was arrested as he asked for mail today at the general delivery window of the central postoffice here, on a charge attempting to extort money from the widow of Bradway Brown, executive of a printing concern in the city, who was found shot to dead at his home in Cinnaminson Township, N.J., on Jan. 16.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 10 (AP). -- The Shandon Farm's Ennis, second in the Jefferson Park Derby, outstepped a field of Louisiana Derby eligibles in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

THE football rules committee is now at work in the quiet city of Philadelphia with Waiter Okeson, successor to the late E.K. Hall, wielding the gavel as chairman at the three-day session. Like most of the members of the committee, "Okie" is a conservative and the chances are that the changes in the code will be few and minor.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10. -- James M. Cox, Democratic nominee for President in 1920, entered the political picture here today when James A. Farley, Democratic National Chair man, had luncheon with him at his home in Miami Beach.

Four Indictments charging theft of between $50,000 and $80,000 in securities from Dr. Mary Dunne Walsh of 65 East Fifty-fifth Street were found by the grand jury yesterday against Miss Edna V. O'Brien, 49 years old, director of an Investment and trading account concern on the thirty-fourth floor of 551 Fifth Avenue.

First Round. Schaaf twice tried a left hook but was blocked. Schaaf grazed the face with a left hook and Carnera put two rights to the body. Carnera jabbed a left to the face and then drove several rights to the heart.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to the United States, had another talk today with the Cabinet's debt committee. Now the matter will be allowed to simmer over the weekend until Monday, when the Ambassador will have one and possibly two more conversations with Prime Minister MacDonald, Stanley Baldwin, Neville Chamberlain, Walter Runciman and Sir John Simon.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- President Hoover spoke over a nationwide network of the Columbia Broadcasting System tonight, taking part in the dedication program of the new WCAU Building in this city.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

Next week is not expected to be an active one in the municipal bond field as far as new awards are concerned. Of the $10,343,028 of new issues scheduled for tender, one issue accounts for $6,657,000, that of the State of Mississippi refunding and hospital bonds, and it is not expected to interest New York bankers.

Use of the name of Acker Merrall Condit Company, for the last twenty-nine years dealers in groceries and fancy foodstuffs, has been sold by the Irving Trust Company, receiver, to the Romanoff Caviar Company, exclusive importers and packers of caviar, 247 Madison Avenue, it was learned yesterday.
