WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The recent discussion of the case of Sergeant-at-Arms Barry called sharp attention to the Senate in a light that is not exactly favorable, but which is easily understandable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Opponents of further government loans to the railroads tonight loaded their muskets with what they regarded as powerful ammunition taken from a Reconstruction Finance Corporation report showing that advances to the carriers in some cases far exceed the present market value of the collateral.

BRISBANE, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Australia's batting collapsed today in the first innings of the fourth cricket test match against England and the Antipodeans were all out for 340 runs.

Newark Metropolitan Airport maintained its leadership as the busiest flying field in the world in 1932, according to figures of the Port of New York Authority made public yesterday. During the year the major airlines which use Newark as their terminus carried in and out of the port 91,559 passengers on scheduled trips, nearly one-fifth of the total of 504,000 such passengers for the United States.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 69,496 tons in January to 1,898,644 tons at the end of the month, it was announced yesterday. The total established a new low record for the corporation, and compared with the previous low of 1,936.302 tons, established on July 31, 1931.

The New York Central Railroad reported yesterday for 1932 a net loss of $18,256,400 after taxes and charges, against a net income of $2,430,101, or 48 cents a share, in 1931. Net loss for December was $1,104,411, which was smaller than other monthly deficits reported last year.

District Attorney Grain sent a letter yesterday to R.E. McGahan, secretary of the Citizens Union, replying to one sent to the prosecutor three days before by Mr. McGahan demanding an immediate grand jury investigation of the vandalism of three gunmen who on Feb. 2 damaged twenty-seven automobiles in a garage in East Seventy-sixth Street.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10. -- Dominick (Duke) Bellizzi scored his seventeenth victory of the Hialeah Part meeting today, maintaining his place as the leading rider of the session, when he got home first with J.C. dark's Haggerson in the main event.

The "so-called banking system" of the country, the most important but "perhaps the most disorganized and uncoordinated of all businesses," should be turned over to "the unemployed engineering technologists at Columbia University and elsewhere for thoroughgoing reconstruction," Dr. Royal Meeker, president of the Index Number Institute of New Haven and former head of the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics, declared in a lecture last night at the New Yorker Theatre.

Roderick J. Kennedy, for thirty-one years chairman of the arrangements committee for the St. Patrick's Day parade, was elected grand marshal of this year's parade by acclamation last night at a meeting of 350 delegates in the Yorkville Casino, 210 East Eighty-sixth Street.

A plea of guilty on six forgery and grand larceny Indictments in the theft of about $30,000 in securities in May, 1931, from Mrs. Anne Crewe Kennedy, formerly of the St. George Hotel, Brooklyn, was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Harold C. Marsh, 50 years old, who formerly lived at the Barbizon-Plaza Hotel.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In reading THE NEW YORK TIMES I note a growing agitation for the reduction of the mortgage interest rate of from 6 to 4 1/2 per cent by real estate brokers, managers and operators in behalf of business property in New York City as the only solution to avoid complete catastrophe.

NEUNKIRCHEN, Feb. 10 (AP). -- The explosion of the gas tank of the Neunkirchen Iron Works tonight was heard through the Rhine Valley from Cologne. to Basel, Switzerland, a distance of 250 miles. Hardly a whole pane of glass remained within a radius of five miles of the city.

Inaction in the security markets yesterday reflected the caution that is customary in advance of an extended week-end. With Wall Street concentrating upon holiday plans, stocks were allowed to drift and the net results were negligible.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Disturbing reports circulated in Paris today, which appear only too well founded, that Henry de Jouvenel, who recently went to Rome to take the post of Ambassador, was received with ostentatious coldness by Premier Mussolini and the Italian press.

The injury done by unemployment to young women of the city was outlined yesterday to a group of supporters of the Church Mission of Help, at its headquarters at 27 West Twenty-fifth Street, by Miss Marguerite Marsh, executive secretary. The organization is under the auspices of the Protestant Episcopal Church but non-denominational in its service.

MUNICH, Feb. 10. -- Considerable excitement was caused here today by an article published in the Regensburger Anzeiger, the organ of Premier Heinrich Held of Bavaria, in which it was suggested that the unusual publicity recently given to the former German Crown Prince in the National Socialist press indicated that Chancellor Adolf Hitler seemed to be abandoning' his reserve over the idea of a Hohenzollern restoration.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Pope Pius XI and Senator Guglielmo Marconi will formally inaugurate the world's first ultra-short-wave radio telephone station tomorrow in celebration of the fourth anniversary of the Lateran Peace Treaty between the Vatican and Italy.

The New York University swimming team repulsed Fordham, 37 to 34, in the annual dual meet between the institutions in the London Terrace pool yesterday. Each team annexed four first places, but the Violet natators scored more consistently.
ALBANY, Feb. 10. -- A demand for greatly increased expenditures for unemployment relief was presented to Governor Lehman today by a delegation of New York City Socialists.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- Unmindful of all the speculation as to the outcome of the elections and what the government has in view, bonds continued to display remarkable strength today. Several Reich issues advanced materially as did Frankfurt and Cologne treasury notes.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 10. -- The Yale swimming team crushed Dartmouth under a 52-19 score in a meet which was attended by 1,500 spectators today. One Intercollegiate Swimming Association record was broken and two Spaulding Pool marks went by the boards.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 10. -- With further safety to the nation's football players and additional speed to the game as their aims, the sages of the gridiron gathered tonight to open their annual conclave.

Announcement by the Bank of England yesterday that it had purchased u3,000,562 in gold bars, equal at par to $14,602,235, was interpreted yesterday in Wall Street as discrediting the theory that Thursday's earmarking of $15,999,900 had been mostly for the account of the Bank of Poland.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10. -- Ambassador Reuben Clark was guest of honor tonight at a farewell dinner given by Mexican Government officials on the occasion of his retirement as the envoy of the United States here.

The Savage School girls basketball team triumphed over New York University's girls, 21 to 12, at the N.Y.U. School of Education gymnasium yesterday. The victors, in the van throughout, held an 11-to-5 advantage at the half.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Legislation revising Radio Commission procedure and making it unlawful for broadcasters to advertise lotteries neared Congressional approval tonight after passing the Senate.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 10 (AP). -- James Richardson, prominent Canadian grain shipper, of Winnipeg, in a statement prompted by the United Kingdom's grain preference ruling today, said it would appear as if Atlantic ports had permanently lost much shipping business to the Pacific.

The extreme cold wave receded from New York and the rest of the nation except in mountainous areas yesterday, but in the metropolitan district it was followed last night by a snowfall that began at midnight and was expected to continue today.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Our good Mayor was right when he informed us that "prosperity was just around the corner." It is I know it, for I saw it there this morning with my very own eyes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Although three more weeks must pass before the legislative and Executive arms of the government can function together once more, and there are acute economic situations here and there in the United States which are difficult to tide over the wait, it is increasingly made evident to observers that sound money policies and rigid Federal economy are the fixed objectives of Franklin D. Roosevelt and his advisory group.

Completing his two-day inspection trip with visits to government-operated and veteran-operated welfare institutions for ex-service men, Rear Admiral Robert E. Coontz, U.S.N., retired, national commander of the Veterans of Foreign Wars, expressed himself yesterday as well satisfied with what he had seen.

BUFFALO, Feb. 10. -- Simplification of local government to reduce expenses and increase efficiency was urged here today by Mark Graves, State Budget Director, in an address before the Buffalo Chamber of Commerce. He outlined the overlapping governmental functions in Erie County as an example.

A future without churches, Bibles or denominations of religion and with no weekly "holy" day as Sunday is predicted by John Haynes Holmes, pastor of the Community Church, in "Religion Today," a symposium edited by Arthur L. Swift Jr. of Union Theological Seminary, which has just been published by Whittlessey House, McGraw-Hill.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The business situation abroad has shown no marked change, the Department of Commerce revealed today in its weekly survey of world economic conditions.

The Board of Estimate committed itself yesterday to adding $1,584,000 to the city's expenses this year by appropriating part of that amount to pay salaries of engineers and technical men in the offices of the Borough Presidents for January and February.

Allegations that the Department of Hospitals had violated the law relating to the purchase of supplies and is giving the Eastman Kodak Company a monopoly in the sale of X-ray film, to the city in order to follow a "buy American" plan were made in the Supreme Court yesterday when the Gevaert Company of America, Inc., sued to halt an award to the Eastman company.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 -- Rejecting a subcommittee's further cut of 10 per cent in the 1933-34 prohibition enforcement fund, the full Senate Appropriations Committee today restored the original House appropriation of $8,440,000 by a vote of 12 to 9.

The National Transportation Committee plans to make public next Wednesday a report which, while recommending the regulation of competitive forms of transport, together with other measures urged by the railroads, will at the same time admonish the railroads for unnecessary duplication of service and other indications of failure to adjust themselves to changing conditions.

A further improvement in prices on the Cotton Exchange carried the May above 6 1/4 cents a pound yesterday, the highest quotation in two weeks, but there was scattered profit-taking in the last hour, and the list closed only 2 to 6 points higher than on Thursday.

WHITK PLAINS, N.Y. Feb. 10. -- The Metropolitan Opera Association closed its first subscription season at the County Centre here tonight, presenting "Lohengrin." The attendance was estimated at about 1,500.

WOOD-RIDGE, N.J., Feb. 10 -- A locomotive fireman was killed and a trainman seriously Injured near here today in the derailment of a locomotive and sixteen cars of two freight trains on a freight cut-off of the Erie Railroad, crossing the meadows from the main line at Rutherford to Ridgewood.

Harry Sherman, labor adjuster for Paramount-Publix, was elected president of Local 306 of the Moving Picture Machine Operators' Union yesterday to fill the post left vacant when the parent body removed Sam Kaplan on charges. Mr. Sherman received 530 votes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The 5 per cent economies proposed in the Bratton amendment would force the navy to reduce the number of its ships in commission to 66 per cent of the British vessels in commission and to 56 per cent of the Japanese, Secretary Adams wrote Senator Bingham today.
LONDON, Feb. 10. -- Cables and Wireless, Ltd., will occupy its new $5,000,000 building on the Thames Embankment after all.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Outspoken disapproval of the way in which they are handling farm relief legislation was expressed in letters sent tonight to all members of the Senate Agriculture and Banking Committees by Edward A. O'Neal, president of the American Farm Bureau Federation.

Although the advance on the Stock Exchange was halted yesterday, Wall Street continued to take an optimistic view of the markets. Transactions aggregated 724,000 shares, against 1,080,000 on the day before. No doubt the curtailment of speculative activity was due largely to the approach of the holiday week-end.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 10. -- Eighteen men were killed and a score wounded when a Dutch seaplane from the cruiser Java dropped a 100-pound bomb on the deck of the battleship De Zeven Provincien this morning while the vessel was in the hands of native mutineers.

The completion of fifty years of educational service within the boundaries of Manhattan will go uncelebrated as far as Dr. James M. Kieran, president of Hunter College since 1929, is concerned. Dr. Kieran, who will round out half a century of active work on Feb. 23, made it known yesterday that he would not permit any special dinner or social function to mark the anniversary.

The value of education in the work of conservation has been stressed at great length by almost every State official in the country, and efforts have been made throughout the United States to build a lasting foundation for wildlife conservation through schools and lectures.

The New York Athletic Club hockey team defeated the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club sextet in a New York Amateur Hockey League game at the New York Coliseum last night, 5 to 3. A crowd of 1,200 persons saw the battle.

In a letter to stockholders of the American Tobacco Company, George W. Hill, president of the company, defended yesterday the company's stock subscription plan for employes and announced that to uphold more vigorously the principle involved he had decided to decline the allotment to him of 13,440 shares of the stock.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA IN THE PACIFIC, Feb. 10. -- Long Pacific swells surged beneath the keels of 113 men-of-war tonight as the Blue fleet, defending the Western seaboard against a raid by a speedy Black force, steamed slowly over a calm sea.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 10. -- General Mario G. Menocal, former President of Cuba and leader of the attempted Cuban revolution in 1931, denied here tonight that a revolutionary movement has actually begun in Cuba for the overthrow of the government of President Machado.

One of the liveliest sessions in recent years is expected to develop today when delegates from the country over gather at the Hotel Vanderbilt for the fifty-second annual meeting of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

Several groups in the fight for Federal control of intercoastal ship lines found satisfaction in the report of the House Committee on Merchant Marine, Radio and Fisheries, filed on Thursday, in which approval is given to the proposal that rates must be published and open to public inspection.

A polo match between teams made up of Class D players of Squadron C, one designated the Blues and the other the Yellows, featured a program of military events at the 101st Cavalry Armory in Brooklyn last night, with the Blues carrying off the honors, 4 to 2 1/2.

Sensational performances by the Canadian entrants in the school figures of the women's singles featured the first day's competition in the North American figure-skating championships yesterday at the Ice Club.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt selected the gown she will wear at her husband's inauguration in less than thirty minutes, it became known yesterday. Visiting a Fifth Avenue department store on Thursday, she spent less times in making her selection than would the average woman when faced with the problem of appearing at her best for a bridge party.

It is not strange that Democratic Senators and even some Democratic Representatives are in revolt against the House leaders who would confer all power-including a quasi-power of legislation -- upon President ROOSEVELT. This would be the same thing as a confession of impotence on the part of Congress.

BERLIN, Feb. 10 (Jewish Telegraphic Agency). -- Herr Fuerstenberg left the Jewish Community in 1929 in protest of the refusal of the praesidium of the Kehillah to reduce his Kehillah tax, which was in the amount of 120,000 marks.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- Adolf Hitler, speaking at a huge National Socialist mass meeting in the Sportpalast tonight in his first public appearance since his appointment as Chancellor, declared war on the "parliamentary-democratic system."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- The St. Lawrence waterway and power development treaty with Canada was reported favorably today by the Borah subcommittee to the full Senate Foreign Relations Committee, with the recommendation that New York State pay $89,726,000 as its share of the cost.
HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 10. -- On the flashing steel blades of Jack Shea, Olympic champion, Dartmouth went to the lead today in the twenty-third annual Winter carnival of the Dartmouth Outing Club.

WESTPORT, Conn., Feb. 10. -- After drifting helplessly for thirty-six hours in rough seas and wintry weather, a party of eight men and two women aboard the thirty-foot auxiliary schooner Saugatuck were rescued early this morning by Louis Alien, keeper of the Middle Ground Light, which is in Long Island Sound nine miles off Bridge-port.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- A statement by the Anti-Saloon League today said John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s investigation of foreign liquor systems would reveal "that nowhere in the world is there now, or has there been, a system which, other things equal, reduces the evils of alcoholism as effectively as prohibition."

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected In the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- A new bankruptcy bill containing a section on railroads, which is said to have the approval of President-elect Roosevelt was presented by Senator Hastings today to his Judiciary subcommittee, which is considering bankruptcy legislation.

Emphatic refusal by the Socialists to join in any such fusion against Tammany Hall in the November municipal elections as is being planned by reform elements was expressed last night by Norman Thomas and Morris Hillquit, Socialist leaders, in a symposium on the question in Webster Hall, 119 East Eleventh Street, at the annual dinner of The New Leader, Socialist organ.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The Prince of Wales declared tonight he believed that through Anglo-Argentine cooperation Argentina a century hence would be "a great and leading nation, with a highly developed and original culture."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 10. -- A Brooklyn clothing salesman, found in an automobile whose license number, by mistake, had been sent out in an alarm for pay-roll robbers, was shot and killed by a police sergeant here tonight during a struggle with a plain-clothes patrolman in the street opposite the City Hall

Financial details of the consolidation of the National Raw Silk Exchange, the New York Hide Exchange, the Rubber Exchange of New York and the New York Metal Exchange into the Commodity Exchange, Inc., were disclosed yesterday when Supreme Court Justice Valente approved the merger.

The County Trust Co. of New York made a loan of $20,000, due Feb. 6, 1934, at 5 per cent, to the Independence Realty Corp., Mary A. Kehaya, president, on the sixteen-story apartment at the northeast corner of Bway, and 107th St., this loan being subordinate to a first mortgage for $1,600,000.

New York's Ferries. What was the particular Brooklyn ferry from which WALT WHITMAN poured out his affection for matchless Manahatta? Time, the bridges and the subway tunnels have taken toll of most of them.

A three-alarm fire yesterday morning at 173 Jefferson Street, Brooklyn, which caused two explosions injuring ten persons, seven of them firemen, was under investigation last night by Chief Fire Marshal Thomas P. Brophy.

A stormy session in the trial of five men charged with kidnapping Ernest Schoening, New Jersey rum runner, ended in Brooklyn yesterday with the disclosure that Schoening's wife has been in Canada since the arrest of two New York City policemen involved in the case.

LONDON, Feb. 10 (AP). -- Customs officials announced today that a second test shipment of wheat from Canada through the United States had been refused the British tariff preference of 6 cents a bushel.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10 (AP) -- A belief that the world soon will need something besides gold as a money basis was expressed today before the House Coinage Committee by Francis H. Brownell of New York, chairman of the American Smelting and Refining Company.
LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The sale has been completed of one of the biggest estates to change hands in the London area for some time. The price was approximately u1,000,000 [about $3,420,000].

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Acceptance by the Finance Commission of the Chamber of Deputies of the Socialist proposal to impose a surtax on incomes instead of reducing the scale of civil servants' pay has aroused a new storm of protest and has endangered the position of Edouard Daladier's Cabinet.

Frank Shields of New York, the ranking player of the Eastern asssociation and member of the 1932 Davis Cup team, led the field into the quarter-final round of the annual invitation indoor tennis tournament of the Heights Casino last night as play started on the club's courts on Montague Street in Brooklyn.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 10. -- The national women's golf champion went down in defeat in a blustery wind today when Mrs. L.D. Cheney of San Gabriel, Cal., won the annual midwinter Southern California title by defeating Miss Virginia Van Wie of Chicago, 3 and 2.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 10. -- Plutarco Elias Calles, the "strong man" of the Mexican Government, has turned over his beautiful Santa Barbara hacienda to the Agricultural Department to be used as an experimental station.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 10. -- Federal authorities today assumed charge of the investigation growing out of the arrest here yesterday of two young men and a woman in connection with an attempt to export $50,000 from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, on threat of kidnapping the flier's second child, Jon Morrow Lindbergh.
HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 10. -- For the first time in the history of the tournament the American women's national squash racquets title will go to England this year.

A grant of $50,000 from the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration for medical and nursing care in relief cases was made available by the Board of Estimate yesterday. Lawson Purdy, head of the work and relief administration, said that $29,000 would go for home relief and $21,000 for work relief cases.

Behind the incident of the Dutch naval mutiny in East Indian waters, partly comic in the overture but sternly realistic in the finale, is the general background of Asiatic unrest. This has manifested itself in the two chief theatres, India and China, with a dramatic intensity that has virtually monopolized outside attention.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 10 (AP). -- When Governor McNutt attends the conference of State executives called by President-elect Roosevelt he may have some counsel for him on governmental reorganization.

Impressionable playgoers who missed "The Monster" when it was stalking death in 1922 now have the privilege of shuddering before a revival. O.E. Wee and J.J. Leventhal mounted it at the Waldorf last evening at fire-sale prices with De Wolf Hopper carefully turning his R's into death rattles.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 10 (AP). -- The State Banking Department announced today that deposits in banks under its supervision had increased in the last quarter of 1932 by $23,846,545. Its report covered 206 institutions.

A complete miniature ultra-modern railroad, miniature yachts and sailing vessels, models of speed boats and ocean liners, airplanes and toy engines, the spare-time handiwork of millionaires, professional men and plain workingmen, employed and unemployed, were shown to the public yesterday at the opening of the fifth annual exhibition of the New York Society of Model Engineers at the Knickerbocker Building, Broadway and Forty-second Street.

Approval of the Board of Transportation's capital outlay budget of $32,300,640 for 1933 would make it possible to expedite construction so that all of the new city subway system, except the Sixth Avenue line, could be in operation late in 1934 or early in 1935, the Board of Estimate was told at an executive session yesterday.

The State Mediation Commission appointed by Frances Perkins, Industrial Commissioner, to investigate the stoppage of contractors In the dress industry held its first public session yesterday afternoon at the State Building, 80 Centre Street, took some testimony and adjourned for an executive session next Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Considerable opposition sprang up today to the proposal of House Democratic leaders to give President-elect Roosevelt dictatorial powers over Federal economies, and advisers of the incoming President are trying now to effect a compromise.

Congress is asked to make a small appropriation in aid of States organizing new gold-mining operations. Placer mining for gold is again attracting the man with the pick and the pan to abandoned gulches and to streams far in the hills of California, Nevada, Colorado and even North Carolina.

A budget representing curtailments of approximately $600,000 in the expenditures for missionary operations at home and abroad for the current year, which had been authorized by the General Convention of the Protestant Episcopal Church, was adopted yesterday by the National Council at the annual meeting in the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Protesting a cut by the House of 65 per cent in its requested appropriation for the fiscal year beginning July 1, the Federal Trade Commission notified the Senate today that such action would mean, "in effect, a scrapping of the commission."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 10. -- Charging that George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney at New York, had committed "Improper, reprehensible and unconscionable" acts in policing voting booths with Federal officers and in the subsequent investigation of election frauds in a few districts in New York City, Representative Dickstein of New York introduced a resolution today calling for a Congressional investigation of the official.
Primo Carnera, Italian giant, knocked out Ernie Schaaf of Boston in the thirteenth round of their bout at Madison Square Garden last night -- a bout which developed sensational aftermath.

The return of Poland to the gold standard was reported yesterday. That country has recently been on the "gold exchange" standard. That is, the Government's legal obligation has been to convert domestic currency not into gold but into foreign currencies exchangeable for gold.

Dr. Anselmo Alliegro Mila, vice president of the Cuban House of Representatives, who is stopping at the Hotel Plaza, proposed in an interview yesterday that American business men with interests in Cuba and American friends of Cuba form a committee to try to bring about a peaceful solution of the Cuban problem through negotiations between President Machado and the Opposition leaders.

CHICAGO, Feb. 10. -- After more than one burst of indignation that has flared and faded without result, it now looks as if the receivership and foreclosure situation in Chicago is likely to get thorough airing and drastic treatment.

Announcement was made last night of the death of Harris Mandelbaum of 12 West Eighty-seventh Street. He was president of the real estate firm of Harris and Maurice Mandelbaum, Inc., of 563 Fifth Avenue, of which his son, Maurice, is secretary and treasurer.

Growth of the city planning movement during the past three decades to the point where more than half of the States have enacted legislation to permit planning in their municipalities is described in the recent report of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Allow me to correct the estimate of the area of the Tennessee River basin, which has been given in recent articles as comprising 640,000 square miles -- about ten times too large.

A claim that retail distributers lost more than they gained when a manufacturer of a breakfast food reduced prices on his product and at the same time increased the distributers' markup was voiced by a Connecticut retail grocer in a letter to THE TIMES last week.

In order to raise funds for carrying on the charitable activities of the Kips Bay Neighborhood Association a subscription luncheon has been arranged for Thursday at Sherry's by a group headed by Mrs. Marscher J. Dunn and Mrs. Waldo Sawin.

BOGOTA, Feb. 6. -- The trouble with Peru has complicated the task of recovery and rehabilitation in Colombia. Thirty years of unbroken domestic peace and a century without a foreign war left this country unprepared to hold Leticla, its Amazon River port, against the small band of Peruvians from Iquitos, who captured it on Sept. 1, 1932.

Mrs. Ernest Schoening failed to appear in the Kings County Court yesterday to testify against the five men charged with kidnapping her husband, a New Jersey rum-runner, and the State finished its case with the testimony of a wire-tapping police detective.

WILLIAMSBURG in Virginia was a Colonial capital for fourscore years -- replacing Jamestown, the original English settlement, in 1699 and being retired in favor of Richmond in 1779, after the British colony bad become an independent American Commonwealth.

SO many grave questions have been poking their way up for discussion during the last few weeks that this column has had no time to celebrate the rowdiest comedy of the season. "Twentieth Century," written by those lusty lampooners Ben Hecht and Charles MacArthur, pitches its laughs in the diaphragm, where laughter is most weakening and enjoyable.

HONOLULU, Feb. 3. -- "Citizens of Hawaii welcome to official positions of trust those from the mainland who have been in the islands long enough to study and know local problems," according to Walter F. Dillingham, President of the Oahu Railway and Land Company and commander of the Hawaiian Department of the American Legion.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Empowering the President to declare an embargo on the export of arms to countries where hostilities threaten is not only practical but necessary to preserve the national dignity, in the opinion of the State Department, as expressed in a memorandum filed with the House Foreign Affairs Committee.

IF properly eager, you have very likely ere this visited the College Art Association's 1933 International at Rockefeller Center. In any event, inspection of these pictures should not be too long deferred, since the show remains in New York only through Monday, Feb. 27, after that resuming its travels about the country.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- In the files of the Quincy (Ill.) Whig of April 15, 1846, is a story of the Trailer murder mystery of 1841, alleged to have been written by Abraham Lincoln when he was a lawyer at Springfield, Ill., and played a leading role at the trial.

THE traditional weapon of disgruntled sailors -- mutiny -- was recently adopted by the native crew of the Dutch cruiser De Zeven Provincien; the crew ran away with their ship in protest against wage cuts. This incident finds several parallels in recent naval history and recalls some of the famous mutinies of the past.

A brisk rally in raw sugar was the feature of yesterday's trading on the local commodity exchanges. Hides also closed higher, while silk made irregular gains. Other commodities were quiet and slightly lower. The cash markets were featured by advances in grains.

Although snow handicapped the gunners of the New York Athletic Club at the Travers Island traps yesterday, excellent scores prevailed. The high scratch honors went to Z.G. Simmons, who broke 98 targets. J.H. Wantling captured the second cup with a card of 97.

The Merchants Association, in a report made public yesterday, criticized the State budget submitted to the Legislature by Governor Lehman and called for further reductions totaling $18,627,000 in State expenditures.

THE MYSTERY OF THE WAX MUSEUM," with Lionel Atwill as the man of mystery and Glenda Farrell sharing the feminine hysteria with Fay Wray, will bring its cargo of violence into the Strand on Wednesday night. The film, which has been photographed in Technicolor, was suggested by the burning of Mme.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Three new faces, two of them Republicans, will be seen at the directors' table of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation after March 4.

Berkeley Bell sprang another major upset yesterday. The fiery Texan, who very frequently comes through with a startling performance against highly ranked tennis stars, eliminated Francis X. Shields, fifth in the national rating, in a quarter-final round engagement in the Heights Casino invitation tournament.

A program of rehabilitation through country life is the latest venture of the Emergency Work and Relief Bureau in caring for unemployed single men of the "white-collar" class, Raymond W. Houston, assistant director, announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON. STRANGERS who travel to Washington after March 4 will see many new faces around the White House and hidden away in the offices about the city. The names of James A. Farley, Louis M. Howe, Steven Early, Marvin McIntyre, Bernard M. Baruch, Professor Moley and several others have become known in every corner of the land.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Currency expansion and creation of a "little socialistic State inside the capitalistic State," under which the government and States would put men to work at their old tasks and pay them in scrip, was advocated today by Professor Willford I. King of New York University.

WHEN Shirley Gratton of Ardenbridge was invited by her rich American friend, Mrs. Alice Macintosh, to be her guest on a West Indian tour, the Grattons (an upper-class English family) were both delighted and worried.

WHILE pleasure, not Science, as often before, is the objective of Vincent Astor's yacht Nourmahal, now cruising around the Bahamas, the fact that President-elect Roosevelt is on board with a party of friends lends special interest to the voyage of the vessel -- virtually a small liner.

JUST twenty-five years ago today, at 11 A.M., six automobiles left Times Square to attempt a feat that made the world of 1908 gasp -- a race from New York to Paris, westward. From New York they plunged almost at once into road conditions that sorely tried the courage and endurance of their drivers and tested to the limit the best mechanical products of the age.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- The increase in activity here, which annually begins in February and lasts until the end of April, has begun, and the coming weeks offer much for both the sportsmen and those socially inclined.

Being full of labor and lighterage troubles these days, the high dignitaries of the towboat industry resent intrusion. Managers of enterprising towing lines have "no statement to make" before the itinerant reporter has had time to frame a neighborly question. At the New York Towboat Exchange, which looks down the glittering noontime harbor from the eleventh floor of the Whitehall Building, the atmosphere is not convivial.

JUST as "Cavalcade" is an outstanding example of the value of clinging to the essentials of an author's work in filming a story, so "The Secret of Madame Blanche," an adaptation of sorts of Martin Brown's play "The Lady," which was at the Capitol last week, is the reverse.

Ice-bound in a city or seven million inhabitants: yet seeing no other human for ten whole days, and compelled to live for half that time on a diet of clams and coffee! It may sound like a fairy tale, but it's the experience of a New York watchman.
PARIS, Feb. 11. -- What is already being called in the French Right press "the new triple entente" of Germany, Italy and Hungary received wide discussion in Paris today.

THREE galleries at the Metropolitan Museum are given to the exhibition of prints acquired during the past two years. Apart from the intrinsic interest of each example, the exhibition as a whole has the great merit of showing prints of all periods, reflecting many temperaments, in close enough relation to let us gain something like a general idea of the field covered.

HAVANA. -- The amateur golf championship of Cuba, open to foreign amateurs as well as residents of the island, will be played on the links of the Country Club of Havana from Tuesday to Saturday of this week.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- The Suez Company has refused a request by British shippers to reduce the toll on ships passing through the Suez Canal, it was learned today. The Parisian financial world is particularly interested in the refusal because of its sharp tone and the reasons given.

A rattlesnake with only slight regard for tradition and science died yesterday at the Bronx Zoo at the age of a little more than two years. He had ten segments of rattlers. Tradition has it that he should have had only two -- one for each year. Science has it that he should have had about five or six -- two or three a year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Trade of the United States with the Far East last year declined $315,900,000 under the preceding twelve months to a combined value of $697,330,000, but compared with all American shipments the proportion destined for the Orient was larger than for any previous year, according to a survey by Janet H. Nunn, made public by the Commerce Department.

DOMESTIC service is the most promising field today for the girl seeking work, according to the experience of the Girls Service League of New York, and on the basis of that finding the league has turned one of its houses into a demonstration unit and is teaching housekeeping in all its most intricate phases.

Terriers of nine breeds were judged yesterday at the annual specialty shows of the Associated Terrier Clubs, which were held jointly in the Grand Central Palace. In all rings, save that of the American Sealyham Terrier Club, which confined its exhibition to American-breds, some of the greatest foreign and home-bred terriers were in the competitions.

THE red storm flag was flying its black spot, the other day, above Gloucester harbor, down on Cape Ann. A midwinter gale was coming, and weeks of savage weather were overdue. Yet a dozen fishing boats at the wharves were calmly fitting out for sea.

IN comparison with its size, less than forty lines, Lincoln's Gettysburg address has probably inspired more interest and more speculation than any other piece of literature of modern times. The reading public seems always ready to absorb whatever is written about it and to want, every few years, to have the story told anew.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Karl Larsen scored 21 points to lead the Princeton attack as the Tiger basketball team defeated Lafayette, 56 -- 18, tonight. The game marked the thirteenth victory for the Orange and Black court men in fourteen starts.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Although he nearly shot out of Shady Corner on his third heat, when one runner of the big sled went over the top of the twenty-two-foot curve, J. Hubert Stevens of Lake Placid righted his sled in time and went on to win first honors in the National A.A.U. senior two-man bob championship on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic slide today.

The example of honesty in business set by Abraham Lincoln was the keynote of speeches last night at the sixteenth annual Lincoln dinner of the Allied Organizations of the Grand Army of the Republic at the Hotel Somerset, 150 West Forty-seventh Street.

Presenting a defense which seemed virtually impregnable and coupling it with a sturdy offense, the City College basketball quintet vanquished Fordham University, 34 to 21, in the Maroon gymnasium last night.

THIS witty little sketch shows evidence of quite unusual humor, observation and insight, "Cheerful Weather for the Wedding" is very short -- too slight for a novel, too long for a short story, and, in fact, unfitted for the latter category by its lack of a definite plot.

A proposal to reduce the capital of the Goldman Sachs Trading Corporation by $23,060,324 will be presented to stockholders at the annual meeting to be held in Wilmington on March 15, according to the notice of the meeting mailed yesterday.

Renewed emphasis by retailers throughout the country upon the store-wide sales method of trade promotion in the department-store field was seen here yesterday as a probable development. Marked support for this view, it was held, is afforded by the launching tomorrow by R.H. Macy Co., Inc., of the largest store-wide sale in its history as a feature of its seventy-fifth anniversary.

DES MOINES. THE revolt of the farmers has borne fruit. Two months of minor rebellion in farmyards and on court house steps, first in the Middle West and then east as far as the Appalachians and west as far as the Rockies, have brought important concessions from those who hold the mortgages that are so heavy a burden on the farms.

IN studying the social aspects of their art the broadcasters give a modern interpretation to the thought of Cassius that the fault lies not in the stars -- but within the listeners, if they fail to glean the most from educational programs.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Behind all the bother that successive French Cabinets are having with the budget is far more than a question of francs and centimes. Fundamentally what is involved is a question of privilege. Old and new privileges are at stake.
SEVERAL new deals are foreseen for radio broadcasting soon after the new administration takes hold.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- A farewell luncheon was given today for Mrs. Herbert Hoover by the League of Republican Women. The guest of honor received the gift of an etching of the Washington Monument as seen from the windows of the White House.

BOSTON, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Federal Judge James A. Lowell today signed a decree authorizing the foreclosure sale of the Fisk Rubber Company of Chicopee with the exception of $7,000,000 in cash, bonds and certificates of deposit which will be turned over to the creditors.

NO less than six one-man shows by woman artists featured the week just ended in the New York galleries. Oils were in the ascendancy, with water-colors a close second in their work, and a few pastels for good measure. Subject matter ranged from roots in Winter and the South American Indian to interstellar space and New England landscape.

FOR the new season the Ford Motor Company is introducing fourteen models, different in appearance and with a number of new features. The cars are characterized by a 75-horsepower V-type eight-cylinder engine, which, it is claimed, will deliver a speed of eighty miles an hour.

MUNICH, Feb. 11. -- Baron Enoch von Guttenberg, leader of the Bavarian monarchists' association, told this correspondent tonight that even if the Hohenzollerns were restored to the throne in Berlin there could never be any question of seceding from the Reich as far as Bavaria and the Wittelsbachs its former ruling house, were con- cerned.

The lure of the show world's backstage artifices has been seized upon by the Emergency Exchange Association as the main attraction for an entertainment to be given at the original Roxy Theatre on Friday night in behalf of the work conducted by the association throughout the Eastern States.

THE regions served by the air lines of the United States are now connected for air express service with three continents of the Old World. Imperial Airways announced last week that regular weekly consignments were being shipped from and to the United States, with the Atlantic offering the only real delay.

DUBLIN, Feb. 10. -- With his government now safely launched on its second term in office, President Eamon de Valera must turn his immediate attention to framing the next budget, due for introduction in the Dail Eireann the end of March.

DOUBTLESS the identity of General William Eaton is a mystery to the average reader. But the General's story is well worth telling, mystery or no mystery. In the opening days of the last century he attempted an international coup d'etat with the Barbary States, only to meet his Waterloo through the chicanery and intrigue of the milder isolationists of that day, as others of Eaton's stripe have met defeat since then.

MOSCOW, Feb. 11. -- A projected Soviet exploration of the stratosphere was described to your corespondent today by M. Malinovski, secretary of the Soviet Air League, which has a membership of more than 14,000,000 persons.

PARIS, Feb. 9. -- The couturiers are inaugurating styles that give the figure freedom: tight-fitting lines are practically abolished. Bloused bodices, loose sleeves and flowing skirts create a new ideal of easy nonchalance.

ALBANY, Feb. 11 (AP) -- Hard pressed by relief-seeking constituents, the State's lawmakers find themselves floundering in an unprecedented flood of "depression bills" as the legislative session closes its sixth week.

VIENNA, Feb. 10. -- The 40-degree rise in temperature which in the past week has made rushing rivers of the fathom-deep snows left by Southeastern Europe's recent cold snap has had no such dissolving effect on the Winter of politico-economic discontent that lies heavy on this part of the world.

TORONTO, Feb. 11. -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight scored a 2 -- 1 triumph over Lester Patrick's New York Rangers in a close, ruggedly played game in the last appearance of the Blue Shirts in this city for the season.

BERLIN, Feb. 10. -- The day after the inauguration of the new American President a bored but determined German electorate will go to the polls for the sixth time within a year to decide the brand of government it wants.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Wheat did not meet the pressure today that traders on the Broad of Trade had expected, and prices moved up on cable messages indicating that definite proposals for reducing acreage of the four leading exporting countries had been made to delegates to the World's Economic Conference to be held next Summer, reports of a good export business in Manitoba and week-end evening up.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., Feb. 9. -- Whether the State of Virginia shall continue its present form of county government, in its essentials as old as the Commonwealth itself, or accept a modern commission plan, may rest upon the result of an experiment now being undertaken by Albemarle County.

NOMINATING himself as royal dictator of France, the Due de Guise, pretender to the French throne, recently entered actively into politics for the first time. It was a radical step for this conservative French claimant, who has hitherto devoted himself almost entirely to the career of a gentleman-farmer.
A high level of occupancy is being maintained in New York's model apartment houses, according to figures compiled last week by George Gove, secretary of the State Board of Housing.

Discussions in municipal bond circles on Senator Hull's proposal to amend the Federal Constitution to permit taxation of securities which at present are tax-exempt resulted generally last week in condemnation of the proposal on the ground that it would greatly disturb the existing market at a time when stability was urgently required.

WESTCHESTER: A new course in the construction and manipulation of marionettes, under the direction of Lillian Owen, has been inaugurated at the Westchester Work- shop, White Plains. Another addition to the staff of instructors is Edmund F. Ward, who will conduct weekly classes in drawing and painting.

The new Italian Ambassador to Washington, Augusto Rosso, will be the guest of honor at a dinner to be given on Saturday in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria by the Italy-America Society. In the absence of Henry Prather Fletcher, president of the society, who is now on a cruise, Henry Rogers Winthrop will preside.

BERLIN, Feb. 11. -- The Boerse was firm at the close of the week, although the public was hesitant in its investment buying. The stock market was supported by some large purchasing orders. Reichs-bank shares advanced 4 per cent and Stahlverein, Harpener and Phoenix were quoted considerably above yesterday's level.

A NOTEWORTHY novel, if only because in its realistic depiction of a French moving-picture organization Hollywood's vulgarity and debauchery are unpondered elements. The Paradore studio near Nogent, a few miles from Paris, is no convent, but the heterogeneous collection of men and women who work there is described as a group whose components think and behave like individuals.

Stephen Gallati of 249 East Sixtyfirst Street, who was associated with the firm of Munroe Co., which suspended in Paris in 1930, filed a petition in bankruptcy yesterday in United States District Court, listing liabilities of $2,284,983 and assets of $53.

MIAMI, Feb. 11. -- Confident of the overthrow of President Machado of Cuba, General Mario G. Menocal, former President, sat tonight on the porch of his Miami home discussing plans for the future of the island republic.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Medical Examiner Amos O. Squire of Westchester County announced today that he would hold an inquest at New Rochelle on Wednesday afternoon into the death of Harry Slavin, 38-year-old clothing salesman, of 853 Empire Boulevard, Brooklyn, who was shot and killed last night by Detective Sergeant Gerhardt Blume during an encounter which resulted from an erroneous police alarm.

Wholesale and retail prices of the four leading brands of cigarettes were cut yesterday to the lowest prices since 1918 as a result of the second general revision of manufacturers' prices since the beginning of the year.

LONDON, Feb. 11. -- Despite denials from the shipbuilders, David Kirkwood, member of Parliament for Clydebank, asserted today that the resumption of work on the 73,000-ton Cunarder would be an- nounced at the end of the month.

ALBANY. AN impression has been gaining ground since the first of the year among lawmakers, State officials and employes who foregather on Capitol Hill that Herbert H. Lehman is a "different" sort of Governor.

MORE than a half century after his death biographical and critical studies of Carlyle continue to appear. Evidently there is life in the old boy yet. Professor Cazamian's book appeared in French in 1913. His competence as a historian and a critic of English literature has been shown in his general and special works.

A determined New York University basketball team set a fast pace to repulse Manhattan, 37 to 30, in a hard-fought battle at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. The Violet had to turn back a closing rush by the Jaspers to annex its first victory over Manhattan since 1930.

Trading on the Cotton Exchang in yesterday's short session reached the largest proportions in some time, with prices changing irregularly in a range of $1 a bale. The report that the Senate Agricultural Committee had reported favorable on a bill to pool several million bales started a sharp rise which carried May to 6.30 cents a pound before heavy profit-taking wiped out all improvement and left quotations 4 to 8 points lower than on Friday.

THE various legislative proposals that have been made in the United States for the relief of unemployment are based on the principle that unemployment relief should be paid to the worker as a legal right for a limited period of time in definite weekly amounts.

Pleading for intelligent study of the many problems and burdens of real estate and for the need of unstinted cooperation between lender and borrower, Robert E. Simon, speaking over Station WRNY, said last week: "This is no time to lose hope.

LONDON, Feb. 9. -- Great Britain is again embarrassed by that awkward situation that inevitably arises whenever the white man makes the belated discovery that there is real value to the land that he has given to the natives of a primitive country.

Harold W. Hack, vice president of the Stewart Hartshorn Company of 250 Fifth Avenue, shade-roller manufacturers, and president of the Joanna Cotton Mills of Goldville, S.C., died yesterday at his country home. Oakridge, in Short Hills, N.J., after a short illness.

Returning to New York from a 10,500-mile trip through the principal farming areas of the nation, Horace Bowker, president of the American Agricultural Chemical Company, said yesterday that he had not found a single farmer or farm-supply dealer who was in favor of the domestic allotment plan of agricultural relief.

An address by President Hoover the valedictory address of his administration, at the annual Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club, which will be held in the Hotel Waldorf-Astoria, will feature the observance here tomorrow of the 124th anniversary of the birth of the Civil War President.

THE recent mutiny by native members of the navy in the Dutch East Indies focuses attention on those distant colonies of the Netherlands. Salary cuts are reported to have been the cause of unrest, the first in many years.
THIS is a story that comes from William Harris Jr. It is offered by this column with the usual bow and with the belief that it is new. If it is not, well -- see Mr. Harris.

Hunter College, the largest college for women in the world, will celebrate its sixty-third birthday at a formal chapel service on Wednesday. The program will include the president's address by Dr. James M. Kieran, and the annual presentation of gifts to the college.

NEUNKIRCHEN, Saar Basin Territory, Feb. 11 -- After a night of horror and utter confusion, dawn this morning brought some relief to the people of this town, who were driven out of their homes shortly before nightfall yesterday when a huge gas tank exploded, filling the air with a hail of big steel splinters that destroyed homes and factory buildings and killed and injured hundreds.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 11. -- The first telephone system utilizing ultra-short waves was inaugurated today when Marchese Guglielmo Marconi established a connection between two specially built stations, one of which was in the Vatican and the other at Castel Gandolfo, the Papal Summer residence, about fifteen miles south of Rome.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 11 (AP). -- Governor Pinchot charged today "adverse" bituminous freight rates were costing Pennsylvania an annual loss in sales of 60,000,000 tons of soft coal and the permanent unemployment of 42,000 miners.

SOME names are magic, serving the imaginative as veritable open sesames to the realm of dreams and visions. Cathay, Xanadu, Ispahan are of this enchanting company, to which already belong two of the "Caravan Cities" of Professor Rostovtzeff's fascinating book, Petra and Palmyra.

PARIS, Jan. 30, 1933. RAVEL has produced another "masterpiece," but this time an authentic work which, I believe is destined to live. It is a disconcerting composition, in that it presents aspects of his genius industriously effaced from other creations.

IT'S a man's world." Well, so it is, in so far as tailored fashions are concerned. The mannish type of suits seems to be cornering the market for early Spring. Neat and trim jackets and skirts are appearing on every side. The safest tip on this market is supplied by sailors and fedoras, which have a slight leaning toward the right eve.

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- One more effort was being made tonight to keep the Radical Socialist and Socialist ranks in agreement to support Premier Daladier's Cabinet and to hold a majority in the Chamber of Deputies. If that attempt fails, it is almost certain the government will be defeated tomorrow when a special session will be held.

As a contribution to the celebration of the 124th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln, an exhibition of important Lincoln material will be opened tomorrow at the galleries of the Rosenbach Company, 15 East Fifty-first Street, to continue all week.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11. -- An appeal to the public to support Franklin D. Roosevelt in putting through Congress his program for lifting the United States out of the economic depression was made tonight by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, and James M. Cox, former Governor of Ohio and Democratic nominee for President in 1920.

THIS posthumously published collection contains seven short stories, all the fiction, one understands, left behind by D.H. Lawrence. No story is very long, but the same degree of excellence is maintained throughout, so that, despite the brevity of the volume as a whole, a highly comprehensive view of the later Lawrence is obtainable.

THE final details of the arrangement whereby ownership of Ludington Air Lines passes to North American Aviation's operating subsidiary, Eastern Air Transport, are being ironed out over the week-end. The agreement to sell and buy was reached last week, but such things take time to conclude and a sale isn't a sale until the consideration has passed from one to the other party to the transaction.
To the Music Editor: The fiftieth anniversary of Wagner's death reminds me of an incident which occurred in Munich when his body was on the way to Baireuth from Venice.
This article is by on authority on Russian affairs. The larger part of the citations made are from writings and speeches of Russian Communists and the official Soviet newspapers.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 11. -- Harvard's basketball team bowed to the speedy Navy quintet, 48 to 26, at the new indoor athletic building tonight. The Midshipmen ran up a lead of 20 to 6 in the first half.

THE technique of playwriting for puppet actors presents a problem which the theorists of the theatre have ignored rather thoroughly. And yet, since it raises the whole question of the relative capabilities and limitations of the puppet as opposed to the human actor, it is an interesting one to consider.

Governmental "inconsistencies," in which worthwhile projects of one department are nullified by the efforts of another, were scored yesterday by Henry H. Heimann, executive manager of the National Association of Credit Men, in his monthly review of business.

To the Music Editor: The recent performance of the powerful Fifth symphony of Sibelius by Mr. Koussevitzky and the Boston Symphony Orchestra leaves one speculating again about a curious mystery. Here is an engrossing score, certainly one of the most important composed in the past quarter century.
To the Editor of The New York Times: It was by good fortune, this afternoon, that I heard, over the radio, the messages of the three Japanese good-will students to the youth of America.

The Fall buying season in the primary dry goods markets will get under way this week, as important cotton, wool and knit goods lines are scheduled to be priced. Heavyweight underwear and sweaters, blankets and outing flannels will be opened to buyers, with price reductions ranging from slight to substantial revisions.

Drastic readjustment of mortgage rates, banking, transportation and marketing is essential if the problem of farmers in the United States is to be successfully solved, according to three speakers who discussed "The Farmers' Holiday -- Direct Action for Famers' Relief," at a luncheon yesterday of The League for Industrial Democracy in the Hotel Woodstock, 127 West Fortythird Street.

THE group of eight volumes with which Appleton initiated last Fall its new series of biographies revealed compact, brief sketches, brilliantly written, of outstanding individuals in the world's history, distinctive and striking because of fresh viewpoints and unconventional treatment.

More than thirty commuters gathered in an office in Grand Central Terminal before catching the 12:45 train home yesterday afternoon to pay tribute to their old friend and conductor, Walter E. Spencer, who retired from the service of the New York, New Haven Hartford last October after fiftynine years with the railroad, more than half a century of which was in the passenger service.

IT seems the perversity of human nature to find content in one world yet to long for the uncertainty of another. Take myself, for example. Last Summer I sat in the garden of my Swiss home, terraced into the gray, ivyclad bastioned walls of a castle of long ago, among surroundings of marvelous variety and beauty, the heritage of undisturbed nature through long centuries of time.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 11. -- Reports today from the southern battle front in the Chaco say the Paraguayans have tried twice in the last week to break the Bolivian lines that dominate Nanawa, their chief stronghold in the south.

The Westminster Kennel Club will open its fifty-seventh annual dog show in Madison Square Garden tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock, the exhibition to continue through Wednesday evening with three judging sessions daily. Judging will start the first day at 10:30 A.M. and twelve rings will be in operation all day, the afternoon judging to start at 2 o'clock and the evening program at 8 o'clock.

BOONVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Farmers in Oneida and Lewis Counties, believing relief measures cannot become effective in time to save the dairy industry from disaster due to low prices, are considering plans for withholding their milk from market.

THE dovecotes of Downing Street have been stirred by a wholly unprecedented protest, officially presented by the Dominion of Australia. This newest of new diplomacy deals not with tariffs, not with disarmament, not with any of the topics usually associated with governments.

Irregularly higher prices characterized dealings in bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday during the two-hour trading peripd, but a total turnover of $4,758,900 made it the slowest day of the year to date. United States Government issues finished from 6-32 lower to 2-32 higher.

The volume of bonds called last week for redemption in February and future months before their maturity dates was the smallest for a week in more than a year. Those announced for February consisted of municipal securities, while those for later months comprised, principally, small lots of foreign issues called for sinking-fund purposes.

LIBERTY, N.Y. Feb. 11. -- Republican State Chairman W. Kingsland Macy, speaking tonight at the Lincoln dinner of the Sullivan County Republican organization, appealed for party harmony to aid in fighting the menace of Tammany.

MISKOLCZ, Hungary, Feb. 11. -- That the advent to power of Premier Goemboes has not changed Hungarian electoral methods was demonstrated this evening by the treatment received by the correspondent of THE NEW YORK TIMES and representatives of other foreign newspapers by the local authorities of the electoral district of Mezoekeresztes.

The motion picture as a valuable instrument for community use in deterring crime and dealing with the social maladjustment of a leisure class, born of the depression and technological unemployment, was described yesterday by Dr. Francis D. Tyson of the department of economics of the University of Pittsburgh at the closing session of the conference of the National Board of Review of Motion Pictures in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

Daniel Crawford, a Philadelphia builder of thirty years' experience, has recommended to United States Senator Robert F. Wagner that a change might be made in the Federal home loan bank act whereby two classes of loans would be provided for.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- When the Senate and House adjourned this afternoon, the final session of the Seventy-second Congress was sixty-eight days old. During that time, not one appropriation for the financing of the executive, legislative, judicial or independent estabishments of the government for the fiscal year 1934 has been sent to the White House.

The "new diplomacy" is as ill defined as the new morality, of which we hear so much and see a little in practice. Yet certain methods of international conduct are now regarded as correct, or at least admissible, which would have horrified the starched old school.

A SPECIAL Wagner performance by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra under Bruno Walter will take place this afternoon in Carnegie Hall to commemorate the fiftieth anniversary of Wagner's death -- Feb. 13, 1883.

ROME. ANY one interested in the national aspect of the talking picture can find an excellent field for study in Italy. However much Americans may feel, and desire, that their audible films should be as universally popular as the old silent films, the passage of the years is demonstrating that speech has brought to the screen the means of making the film industry national instead of international.
PALM BEACH. -- A fair division of honors between sports and cultural affairs is apparent for this week, when major golf tournaments will divide interest with artistic and musical ventures.

In commenting upon the various plans suggested for seeking new sources of State revenue William J. Hoppin, president of the First Avenue Association, states that the association has held that, before establishing new and increased tax imposts, every possible means of curtailing expenses of government should be exhausted.

The Manhattan Polo Club defeated the New York A.C. first team, 10 to 9, in a keenly fought game at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx last night. A backhand shot from the mallet of Dave Evans decided the issue after the score had been tied at 9 to 9 in the final period.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Launching a bid for his fourteenth gold racquet tournament triumph, Clarence C. Pell of New York, perennial winner of the national amateur squash racquets championship, today defeated his persistent foe of the last two decades, Stanley G. Mortimer, at the annual competition at the Tuxedo Club.

The ten-score or more veteran war fliers who are members of Aviators' Post, 743, American Legion, held the fourteenth annual Aviators' Ball last night in the Colonnade Room of Essex House, 160 Central Park South. Among the patronesses were Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt, Mrs. Frank M. Hawks, Mrs. Courtland Smith, Miss Ruth Nichols, Miss Laura Ingalls and Mrs. Clarence D. Chamberlin.
CLEVELAND, Feb. 11 (AP). -- Price in times of surplus supply, according to Paul Mazur, New York banker, is determined by "the fear of the last and most-harassed creditor."

LOUISVILLE, Feb. 9. -- With a State-wide battle in prospect over election of a Legislature favorable to resubmission of the prohibition question, Kentucky wets are beginning to realize the great difficulties in their path, due to the present gerrymander, which gives disproportionate strength to the small rural counties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Bank debits, outside New York City, were higher during the week ended Feb. 4, but the increase was not so large as in the corresponding week of 1932, the Department of Commerce stated today in its weekly survey of domestic business conditions.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 9. -- The run on two New Orleans banks resulting from statements of Representative Hamilton Fish of New York has demonstrated some of the reasons why Senator Huey P. Long is the "Kingfish of Louisiana." His manners may sometimes offend, but in emergencies such as this his actions make friends.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 11. -- Abandonment of the coming international conference on war debts and economic conditions would be far preferable to having the United States suffer another diplomatic defeat, Senator Lewis of Illinois told the Senate today.

SMART hostesses are using table settings of glass with an enthusiasm equaled only in the days when Venetian wars was a novelty in Europe. Entire services of glass are laid on tables with mirror tops; centrepieces of crystal glass are used, and even the floral ornamentation may be of glass.
BRONXVILLE, N.Y., Feb. 11. -- Many women in Westchester County will open their homes on St. Valentine's Day for bridge parties to aid the Westchester County Children's Association.

The reorganization plan of the Hotel Pierre was approved yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy, to whom it was submitted on Wednesday. The court also authorized the payment of $15,000 counsel fees to White Case, counsel to the committee, and $26,366 for other expenses.

THE fiftieth anniversary of the death of Richard Wagner will be observed by many musical organizations here, a special feature of the week being a benefit matinee performance of "Parsifal" for the Southern Women's Educational Alliance tomorrow afternoon at the Metropolitan.

IN the House of Commons Mr. Duff Cooper, Financial Secretary to the War Office and the soldier husband of Lady Diana Manners, is a man with a future. This biography proves that he is also a man with a background. He has absorbed the personality, the outlook and the career of the diplomatist in Europe who, above all others, is most instructive to the student of International affairs.

IPOH, Perak, Federated Malay States. BEFORE the Fox "Man Eater" company left New York to make an adventure film in the jungles of Malaya, a story requiring the services of three actors, two men and a girl, was prepared.

Plans for a $3,000,000 model housing development on the site of the old Bronx Bleachery at West Farms Road and East Tremont Avenue have been filed with the Bronx Bureau of Buildings as a preliminary step in an application for a $2,000,000 loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to provide the major financing.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 11. -- The winning streak of the B.B. Stable's Character was extended at Hialeah Park today to include the featured Bahamas Handicap, seven-furlong best, which had a value of $2,090 to he winner.

BOSTON, Feb. 9. -- The Republican party in Massachusetts is trying to get together and prepare to resume its habit of victory in the Bay State. It is not an easy task. For one thing, the party has endured a series of heavy defeats which have produced a few of the symptoms of demoralization.

VIENNA, Feb. 11. -- The British and French Ministers to Vienna today presented a second note to the Austrian Foreign Office regarding the shipment from Italy to the Hirtenberg cartridge factory near Vienna of military rifles, estimated to number between 65,000 and 180,000, for re-shipment to Hungary.

Gruenberg's "The Emperor Jones," after Eugene O'Neill's famous play, was performed at the Metropolitan last evening for the sixth and last time before a soldout house. According to well-informed talk in the lobbies, the work has "grossed" about $70,000 in New York alone.

LONDON, Feb. 2. SO accustomed has the theatre become to the superlatives of praise and attack that the word "interesting" has almost vanished from the vocabulary of criticism. Such tricks do habit and misuse play with valuable words! "Sincere" also has gone.

MADRID, Feb. 10. -- Spain's religious bill could scarcely have been introduced amid greater political turmoil in the Cortes, sandwiched as it was between attacks against the Azana government and heated counter-attacks from the government bench.

This department is designed to assist in the location of complete versions of poems and their sources, the names of authors, , which cannot be found through the usual channels of anthologies and books of reference.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 11. -- Plans for the annual Winter meeting of the National Alumni Association of Princeton University, to be held here on Washington's Birthday, were announced today by John Colt, 14, chairman of the Alumni Day committee.

ALBANY, Feb. 11. -- Criticism of the high cost of local government, contained in the report rendered this week by the Mastick commission has aroused a storm among Republican members of the Legislature, with the prospect that a bill to prolong the life of the commission for another year may be defeated in the Republican Assembly.

WILLIAMSTOWN, Mass., Feb. 11. -- With the arrival of about 500 alumni and the appearance of the Governors of Massachusetts, Rhode Island and New York, the annual mid-Winter homecoming of Williams College began today.

One angle of the current depreciation in the value of real estate receiving little consideration, points out Leroy M. Barkin of the law firm of Krellberg, Fitzsimons Barkin, is the position of individuals who, having purchased real estate, have executed bonds and mortgages which were later foreclosed.

THE sympathy, simplicity and kindliness which were so much a part of Lincoln, became manifest under tremendous emotional stress on that solemn Nov. 19, 1863, when he delivered the famous Gettysburg Address.

Because today is Lincoln's Birthlay, most of the Protestant churches will observe it as "Race Relations Sunday." In not a few churches the pastors of white and Negro churches will exchange pulpits. This is on recommendation of the Race Relations Department of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, of which Dr. George E. Haynes is executive secretary.

A decision of importance in the litigation between Joseph A. Broderick, State Superintendent of Banking, as liquidator of the Bank of United States, and the stockholders to recover an assessment of $25 a share on their stock, was made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Dore in striking out two defenses in answers by defendants in the suit filed last year, which is independent of the action brought last week against 15,000 others.

Demands for a "material" reduction in the sugar tariff will be made on behalf of United States producers of sugar in Cuba at the public hearings on the question before the United States Tariff Commission which will begin in Washington on Tuesday, according to H.H. Pile Jr., who last year was president of the New York Coffee and Sugar Exchange.

It is fifty years ago today since Frederick O'Byrne, Commissioner of Jurors for New York County, entered the office of which he has been the head since 1916, as an employe. Friends, present and former associates in the office and outside had planned a fiftieth jubilee celebration, but Mrs. O'Byrne was ill and the commissioner is spending much of his time at her bedside.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The annual hunter trials of the Middleburg Hunt will be held at the race track at Glenwood on Feb. 22. Robert B. Young, secretary, has announced that the entries will close on Wednesday.

Members of the emergency relief committee of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service, of which Miss Emie Sutton Day is chairman, have arranged an entertainment and fashion show for the afternoon of Feb. 27 in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

With trading sharply restricted in advance of the two-day pause occasioned by a Monday holiday, all of the markets displayed quiet strength yesterday. Speculators were disposed to mark time, and the dealings were of a perfunctory character.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA IN THE PACIFIC, Feb. 11. -- A brisk northwest breeze topped Pacific rollers with white caps today as the Blue fleet, guarding the western seaboard from the attack of the Black raiding force, continued its search for the "enemy."

PARIS, Feb. 11. -- The Societe Centrale de Banque de Province, capitalized at about $1,000,000, with 150 branch banks in French provincial towns and five branches in Paris, failed to open its doors this morning. This notice was posted on the doors of the Central Bank and all branches:

As the passage of the prohibition amendment and the enforcement of prohibition raised new and interesting problems in connection with the law of leases, Clarence M. Lewis, author of "The Law of Leases," points out that the anticipated repeal of the amendment and both Federal and State prohibition legislation on the subject will raise new questions, some of which may be avoided by consideration in advance.

Eighteen cash prizes have recently been awarded to unemployed architectural draftsmen competing in the latest of a series of prizedesign competitions conducted by the Architects' Emergency Committee. Besides the first, second and third prizes of $75, $50 and $35, respectively, fifteen fourth prizes of $25 each were awarded.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 11 (AP). -- Vigorous grilling of two men and a woman held in connection with a plot to extort $50,000 from Colonel Charles. A. Lindbergh was resumed tonight by Federal investigators, who announced that statements so far obtained from the trio were "conflicting" and contained some information they wanted to "keep confidential for the present."

THE sensational element in the Letter library is by no means exhausted by the extensive collection of Confederate broadsides and the spectacular Hartley papers described here last week. Other documents and tracts, equally thrilling and important in their own right, clamor for attention, and they will be described in brief outline now, before their sale at the American Art-Anderson Galleries next Wednesday and Thursday evenings.

The annual card party for the benefit of the girls' branch of the Public Schools Athletic League will be held on the afternoon of Feb. 25 in the main ballroom of the Plaza. The funds realized will further an extensive recreational program among girls of the public schools in the city.

Denying that the Brazilian Government has discriminated in any way against United States interests in granting exchange, V.F. Boucas, general technical director of the committee of State finances and economics of the Brazilian Government, in an interview with THE TIMES yesterday said that external debt obligations of Brazil were responsible for the scarcity of exchange.

The preliminary report of the New York State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Control Legislation will be submitted to Governor Lehman and the Legislature next Wednesday, the date specified in the act creating the commission, it was announced yesterday afternoon at the commission's headquarters, in the Park Lane, 299 Park Avenue.

YEOVIL, England, Feb. 11. -- Final tests have been made of the Houston-Westland biplane, one of the two machines to be used for the flight over Mount Everest, and, these having been successful, the machine was dismantled and packed for shipment to India.
OTTAWA, Feb. 11 (Canadian Press). -- Francis A. Anglin announced today his retirement as Chief Justice of Canada, the resignation to take effect Feb. 28.

LONDON. A NEW dog, Bob, has established himself as the companion of King George. Bob, a Cairn terrier, replaces Snip, whose death was keenly felt by the royal household and led to the report that the King would never have another dog.
FOR several months there has been proceeding a serious discussion of the Japanese mandate in the Pacific Ocean. Two questions have arisen, the one immediate and the other dependent on contingencies.

WARDEN LEWIS E. LAWES of Sing Sing, heard in the WJZ dramatization of his book, "20,000 Years in Sing Sing," on Sunday nights, has mastered the technique of broadcasting. The program script is well written and Mr. Lawes gives a natural portrayal of his role in life with no trace of micro-fright.
