Frederick Jagel, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera Company, gave an interestingly chosen and arranged program of songs yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall. Handel's recitative and aria "In Praise of Harmony" was succeeded by English songs not heard here often enough -- Vaughan Williams's "Silent Noon," Peter Warlock's "In an Arbor Green," Norman Peterkin's "The Fiddler" and two works of Delius, "The Nightingale Has a Lyre of Gold" and "I Arise from Dreams of Thee."
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 12. -- The National Football Rules Committee emerged from a three-day study of the playing code today and decided to make only two changes in the rules for 1933.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The rate of dollar exchange now precludes export of gold to America; in fact, the gold which left Paris during the week went principally to Belgium and England. The tendency of the pound sterling to go higher has been very strong, and the Bank of England has been, forced, in order to check the movement, to buy large amounts of dollars and francs.
LEIPZIG, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Official and cultural Germany paid homage today to Richard Wagner in the city of his birth one day before the world commemorates the fiftieth anniversary of his death.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- The speculative interest aroused on the Stock Exchange by the boom in Kaffir shares appeared to spread this week to other sections of the market. A minor boom is now in progress in tea-plantation shares, on the impending application of the restricting scheme.

DRAT these scientists! They come around with wonderful discoveries when it's too late to do anything about it. Here's Dr. Donald A. Laird, director of the Colgate Psychological Laboratory, coming out with a discovery that might have meant a pennant a world's championship for the round Robins of Flatbush if it had been made a few years ago or even a month ago.

Steel making operations barely held at 19 per cent of capacity last week, according to an estimate by the magazine Steel. The decline of 69,496 tons, or 3.5 per cent, in the unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation during January suggests to the publication that improvement in production in January may have overrun new business.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, in the Pacific, Feb. 12 -- Still groping for the "enemy," the Blue fleet, defending the Pacific Coast from the fast Black raiding force, saw little today besides the creamy curd of whitecaps, the sudden flash of seagulls in the sun and the clear far line of the ocean's rim.

Community trusts in the United States at the end of 1932 administered funds totaling $37,500,000 and pushed their annual aggregate distribution of funds to a new high level of 51,107,000, it was announced yesterday by the New York Community Trust.

To the Editor of The New York Times: To help prevent the necessity of giving is even more important than merely giving. To help men and women to help themselves, by securing employment for them, should be the general aim. Charity is a crutch, but work is a lever.

BERLIN, Feb. 10.-Improvement in German retail trade is progressing. While the department store turnover for the whole of 1932 was 18 per cent under 1931, the decline has about ceased. The steel trade also has somewhat improved. Unemployed workingmen in Germany as of Jan. 31, standing at 6,014,000, compared with 6,042,000 the same date in 1932.

The Kroner Grocery and Baking Company reports consolidated net earnings for 1932, after Federal taxes and preferred dividends, of $2,740,867, equivalent to $1.4758 a share on the common stock, compared with $2,731,128, or $1.463 a share in 1931.

ALBANY, N. Y., Feb. 12. -- Presentation of a preliminary report on beer control on Wednesday by the commission named to examine liquor sale and taxation will feature this week's session of the Legislature.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Records were thrown to the Adirondack winds today in the National A.A.U. senior four-man bob-sled championships on the Mount Van Hoevenberg slide. Five drivers broke the existing official A.A.U. figure for one heat down the run, 1:52, and in addition, Curtis P. Stevens twice shattered the course mark of 1:50.28 set last.

There has been an encouraging subscription for the special performance of "Parsifal," which will be sung this afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera House for the benefit of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance. All of the boxes and most of the seats have been purchased.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 2 -- While trading in the cotton market was not very active last week, there was generally a better undertone and prices were, for the greater part of the time, moderately on the upgrade. The more moderate volume of business was largely due to the subsidence of hedge selling which had been in evidence in previous weeks.

A pistol battle between two detectives and a group of five gunmen in an alleged speakeasy at 210 East 122d Street last night ended with the wounding -- probably mortally -- of one man, believed to have been an innocent victim, and the arrest of two suspects.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Unemployment in the United States reached in January an all-time peak of more than 12,000,000 wage earners out of work, according to the estimate issued today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor.

The seventy-fifth anniversary of R.H. Macy Co. will be celebrated with an anniversary sale featuring more than 1,500 special offerings and following many of the original policies laid down by the founder. The store's net sales on its opening day totaled 511.60. Last December a single day's net sales totaled more than $900,000.

Eamon de Valera, President of the Executive Council of the Irish Free State, spoke on "The Future of Ireland" yesterday in an international radio broadcast from Dublin, which was heard here over Station WABC and a nation-wide hookup.
The days of professional boxing and wrestling, on the comprehensive scale upon which these two sports have been promoted heretofore, are numbered in Madison Square Garden.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 12 (AP) -- Ely Culbertson and his bridge partner-wife are 5 up on Russia and engaged in a job proportionately prodigious in their ten-year plan of child-raising.

Last week's firmness on the stock and bond markets, combined as it was with inactivity, appeared to indicate little except a pause of expectancy pending further developments, and an equally apparent absence of acute uneasiness. Presumably the markets and the financial community are chiefly interested in the course of political events at home, and to that they have as yet little clue.

The "disarming" of school books that glorify war, the control by the people of all media of propaganda in order to prevent "war hysteria," and the inculcation among voters of the idea that war is a "stupid and suicidal anachronism," were remedies for militarism suggested by speakers yesterday at the opening sessions of the Young People's Peace Conference, held in the Friends' Meeting House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I hope you will find it possible again to bring before your reader the unique part played by the Welfare Council in the City of New York. THE NEW YORK TIMES, through its Hundred Neediest Cases Fund and its enlightened editorial comment, has always stood for unified social effort.
DETROIT, Feb. 12. -- Beekman Pool of New York, national squash racquets champion, and teams from Philadelphia and New York won their way to the finals in the national tournament today.

The correspondence between Judge SEABURY and the Appellate Division is creditable to both. That court had awarded Mr. SEABURY $75,000 as a proper fee for his services under appointment by it as counsel in investigating the Magistrates' Courts in this city.

Lincoln's Birthday inspired sermons by the clergy of virtually all faiths in the city yesterday. Ministers expressed the belief that the average citizen's attitude toward the State today was directly opposite to that of Lincoln's; that the direct action of a John Brown might be called forth if the depression continues, and that Germany in choosing Hitler had turned to the antithesis of Lincoln.

Connecticut must be an isle of bliss. Nothing troubles her. She has no "problems" that are not "political." The need for relief is slight. Nobody bothers about taxes. Therefore, the General Assembly can devote its best thought to distributive justice.

Mourned alike by the socially prominent and those who labored obscurely in the cause of freedom for women, Mrs. Oliver H. P. Belmont was laid to rest yesterday beside the body of her husband in a hilltop tomb in Woodlawn Cemetery.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- As a result of the pooling of all the operatic resources of Great Britain, Covent Garden will have a six weeks' season of international opera, beginning May 1. Sir Thomas Beecham is artistic director and chief conductor.

BEACON, N.Y., Feb. 12 -- Declaring that the assassin of James Husted Germond and three members of his family, who were slain Thanksgiving Eve in 1930 in Stanfordville. Dutchess County, was under surveillance. Sheriff Oakleigh Cookingham announced today that he hoped for a solution of the baffling case this week, with startling developments.

An appeal for action against lending libraries which, he charged, were engaged in the circulation of "filthy and prurient books" was made by the Rev. Francis X. Talbot, literary editor of "America the National Catholic Review of the Week," in a speech over radio station WINS last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Representative and Mrs. Bertrand H. Snell gave a reception this afternoon in the Chinese Room of the Mayflower Hotel, entertaining the Republican members of the House of Representatives and their wives.

To be Taken Calmly. It is obviously going to rain "dictators" in the United States for perhaps a fortnight. Therefore, it is imperative to warn the governments and peoples of Europe not to take us too seriously.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- One of those flurries of excitement to which the foreign, exchange market is growing accustomed and for which it looks with keen interest, occurred in sterling this week, when on Monday the dollar rate was allowed to rise suddenly from $3.40 to $3.45 1/4.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 12 -- Last week brought more interesting steel-trade news than usual, as production was found to have been running at a slightly higher rate than estimated, and in two branches of the finished steel trade, wire and sheets, efforts were started to advance prices.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 12 -- Ready to take up the details of his reconstruction program. President-elect Roosevelt will end his eleven-day cruise Wednesday evening at Miami and return immediately to New York.

OAXACA CITY, Mex., Feb. 8 (By Mail) -- Exploring the old graveyard of Monte Alban, Mexican archaeologists have struck upon the most important discovery of this season -- the tomb of a little girl of ancient America.
Tomorrow is St. Valentine's Day. Florists and telegraph operators are ready for it. Violets, it seems, will be the favorite flower for this year's corsages for lovers.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 12 (AP). -- Taking advantage of splendid weather, approximately 8,000 fans today attended the first Sunday racing of the Winter at the Fa Grounds for the benefit of the unemployed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- A new class of 175 students will begin training at the Army Air Corps primary flying school at Randolph Field Texas, on March 1, the War Department announced today. It will comprise one Air Corps officer, five officers of other branches of the regular army, eleven enlisted men of the Air Corps, five enlisted men of the other arms of the regular army and 143 civilians.
CHANGCHUN, Feb. 12 (AP) -- A threat to slam the Open Door in Manchuria in the world's face if the powers attempt to outlaw Japan was voiced today by a spokesman for Manchukuo.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The demands for inflation, mortgage moratoriums and reduced taxes, which have been made in Congress in recent weeks, have their strongest roots in the Middle and Far Western regions of the country. There is probably no more accurate mirror of the people's thought than mail received by Congressmen, and in the last two or three months the tone of these letters has changed radically.

"The Sophistocrats," a play by Kenneth Phillips, with Helen Brooks in the leading role, opens tonight at the Bijou Theatre. "Four o'clock," a melodrama by Nan O'Reilly and Rupert Darrell, opens at the Biltmore. The Morningside Players will present "The Fields Beyond," by Francis Bosworth, tonight at Earl Hall, Columbia University.

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Prices for hogs have astonished packers as well as raisers by their rapid fluctuations in the last several weeks. They have advanced 65 cents a hundredweight within about five weeks. The top figure last week was $4.15 and the high price yesterday was $3.90.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 12 (AP). -- A vigorous defense was mapped out today for Norman Harvey and his wife, accused as two of three principals in the $50,000 Roanoke extortion plot against Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh.

A campaign to enlist the support of all United States Senators and Representatives from States where cotton is a principal product was announced yesterday by the Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts, of 330 West Forty-second Street.

Arthur L. Clark, superintendent of the Fish and Game Commission of Connecticut, has come to the rescue of the sportsmen of that State who long have lamented the decrease in raccoons throughout the Commonwealth. Time was when the Connecticut woods were full of raccoons and coon hunting parties formed an interesting part of the Winter program of those who liked to indulge in outdoor sports.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The foreclosure sales in the West, where properties have been bid in for grotesquely less than market value, are undoubtedly voidable. Duress, physical or mental, restraining willing buyers, makes the sale repugnant to equity.

"Good" Catholic politicians who "attend mass every Sunday and wait on the devil the other six days of the week" were assailed yesterday by the Rev. Daniel Quin in his sermon at high mass in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Ignatius Loyola, Park Avenue and Eighty-fourth Street.

The strength of Christianity is in its appeal to loyalty, not in a command to submit, said the Rev. Dr. John McDowell, secretary of the Board of National Missions of the Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A., in his sermon as guest preacher at the North Presbyterian Church, 155th Street and Broadway, yesterday morning.
BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- The opera season in Berlin runs about eleven months, the municipal opera opening in mid-August and the State opera Sept. 1. Both give performances every night, including Sundays.

LONDON, Feb. 10. -- After its hectic experience of last week, the market for South African gold shares was this week more subdued. From the speculative viewpoint it needed relaxation, and dealers took steps, not unsuccessfully, to check the uprush of prices.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- Along the snow-piled shore of Milton Point, ice-fringed and bleak though sunlit, the order of Eskimos was formed today. It was at the sailing dinghy regatta of the Seahorse Yacht Club.

CHICAGO, Feb. 11. -- Extremely cold weather with heavy snows in parts of the Middle West affected business somewhat last week, but with a return to normal temperatures an increased activity is expected. There is uncertainty as to the effect which the changes in political leadership will have on business in general, but merchants and manufacturers are looking forward to a steady but slow expansion all over the country.
Berkeley Bell and Gregory Man-gin will meet this afternoon in the final of the Heights Casino invitation tennis tournament as the result of their victories in semi-final-round matches yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Last week headlines proclaimed that 12,000,000 people were out of employment. In today's news columns we read that "more than 5,000 persons are employed in multiple jobs in the school system of the City of New York."

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., Feb. 12. -- The will of James Nelson Gowenlock, retired manufacturer, who died last December at his home in Sutton, Surrey, England, leaves u10,000, which is to be distributed among some of his classmates and their widows, Union College and the Union Chapter of Delta Upsilon, it was announced today by Dr. Frank Parker Day, president of Union College.

The 226 Chinese who were brought to New York two weeks ago to join the crews of the Dollar liner President Johnson and the Panama Mailliner Santa Lucia but were barred by the Department of Labor on the ground that they had arrived here illegally as passengers, are now on their way home, it was disclosed yesterday.

Additional steps to detect and punish persons who call out fire apparatus by false alarms were urged yesterday by Fire Commissioner Dorman. His departmental report for 1932, the first of a major city department to be filed with Mayor O'Brien, expressed the hope that "the courts will be very severe in meting out punishment to those guilty of this practice."

MUNICH, Feb. 12 -- Despite the traditional dislike in Bavaria of quoted interviews and the delicacy of the present situation in the Statsrat, Fritz Schaeffer, leader of the Bavarian People's party, discussed with the writer today the present relation between Bavaria and the Reich and answered a number of questions concerning recent events and possible developments.

ALBANY, Feb. 12 -- There were 5,000 fewer marriages in New York State in 1932 than the year before, and the birth rate dropped 15.2 per 1,000 population, the total number of births being 8,000 below 1931, Dr. J.V. Deporte, Director of the Division of Vital Statistics of the State Department of Health, reported today.

The New York Athletic Club hockey team defeated the Philadelphia Comets in the feature game of the weekly amateur hockey double-header at Madison Square Garden yesterday afternoon by the score of 7 to 4. In the preliminary contest the Sands Point sextet turned back the New York Stock Exchange team, 4 to 2.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with, a great deal of interest the letter from E.B. Callahan, published under the heading "Troubles of Operagoers."

CHICAGO, Feb. 12 -- Trade sentiment in wheat is more in favor of the buying side than it has been for a considerable time. This change in sentiment has come in the face of political uncertainties, especially the near approach of a change in the Federal administration.

New York City today welcomes the leading representatives of the Western canine world, which will be in competition and on exhibition for three days in Madison Square Garden. The fifty-seventh annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club will open at 9 o'clock this morning, to continue through Wednesday evening.

Defeating the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club by a score of 3 to 1 at the New York Coliseum yesterday, the Bronx Hockey Club moved into a tie for first place in the New York Amateur League with the St. Nicholas team. A crowd of 4,000 watched a keen struggle.

SALISBURY, Conn., Feb. 12 -- Roy Mikkelsen, representing the California Sports Association, carried off the national amateur ski-jumping championship today in the thirtieth annual title tournament, on the Salisbury Outing Club's hill at the foot of the Berkshire Mountains.

Another attempt to bring something of the haut tan into the drinking, dining and dancing routine of New York ended early yesterday. Detectives, unimpressed by period furniture but certain that a horseshoe bar was out of place in Louis Quinze surroundings, induced and supervised the debacle at the Maison Royale, 6 East Fifty-second Street.

TORONTO, Ont., Feb. 11. -- Share-holders of Barry-Hollinger Gold Mines, Ltd., approved this week the plan for adding 1,000,000 shares to the capital. The Meeting was delayed while ballots were cast for new directors, including two from New York who are providing finances for required development.

Buyers visiting the wholesale apparel markets here last week divided attention between sales merchandise for immediate delivery and goods for Spring promotions. An active demand for Winter coats developed as a result of the cold spell, but manufacturers found it difficult to supply requirements.

A letter declaring that there is serious overcrowding in the maternity wards of the city hospitals, and urging the Board of Estimate to arrange for the extension of maternity care in private hospitals, was made public yesterday by the Women's City Club of New York, '22 Park Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12. -- Efforts by the administration to keep the deficit for the fiscal year 1933, ending June 30, close to the estimates made in submitting the budget to Congress last December are being embarrassed by the fact that many of the special taxes imposed by the so-called billion-dollar revenue law, passed in the last session, have fallen far short of expectations.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Has the Admiralty a secret plan for rehabilitation of the British fleet, to be put immediately into operation in the event of the failure of the Geneva arms conference to find some concrete scheme for a universal retrenchment?

"The world will little note nor long remember," said LINCOLN at Gettysburg, "what we say here." But the astonishing fact la that, except for what he said there, "what they did there" would not have been remembered around the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 12 -- The President and Mrs. Hoover attended Lincoln Day services at the New York Avenue Presbyterian Church, which Lincoln attended during his Presidency. They heard the pastor of the church, Dr. Joseph R. Sizoo, describe Lincoln as "the greatest figure of the nineteenth century, the kind of man God gives to the world once in 500 years."

Crete Wiesenthal, who bears one of the most distinguished names in modern dance history, gave her first New York concert last night at the Biltmore Theatre, assisted by Willy Franzl, premier danseur of the Vienna Opera. Frau Wiesen-tha1 played an important part in the establishment of the so-called "free" dance in that period when the revolutionary activity of Isidora Duncan had set in motion all sorts of creative innovations.

PARIS, Feb. 12 -- The news of the critical situation facing the Metropolitan Opera has led Parisians to wonder whether their National Opera is not in the same situation. Inquiries made today show, however, that though the future is somewhat uncertain present conditions are relatively sound.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 12 (AP). -- Charles Edward Patterson, retired vice president of the General Electric Company and former resident of New York, died here today after being ill for several months. His age was 66.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's program of foreign policies, as unfolded by him to a London newspaper and telegraphed back from there, has provoked comment and surprise in political quarters here because of the candor with which the Chancellor asserts that Germany will increase her armaments unless France disarms, and demands the return of the Polish Corridor.

The formation of a National Occupational Conference, to serve as a clearing house for information In the field of occupational education and adjustment, was announced yesterday by Morse A. Cartwright, director of the American Association for Adult Education.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 12 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55.3, which compares with 55.3 a week ago, 55.5 two weeks ago, 56.4 three weeks ago and 57.3 four weeks ago. The average of 57.4 in the first week of January was the highest of the year to date; this week's average, also reached last week, is the lowest.

Pleading for a continuance of Lincoln's program for the emancipation of the Negro, for tolerance and equality of opportunity for that race, Bishop Wilbur F. Thirkield, retired, of the Methodist Church, a member of the Department on Race Relations of the Federal Council of the Churches of Christ in America, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Metropolitan Methodist Episcopal Temple, Seventh Avenue and Thirteenth Street, denounced the perjudice which he said still persists.

A man was suffocated and seven firemen overcome by smoke early yesterday morning when fire swept a six-story apartment, housing eighty-four families, at 36-14 165th Street, in the Terrace Gardens section of Flushing. Four alarms were turned in for apparatus before the blaze was controlled.

HAVERFORD, Pa., Feb. 12. --- Continuing their brilliant play in this country, members of the women's British squash racquets team made a clean sweep against Philadelphia in an international match today on the Merlon Cricket Club courts, winning all seven matches before another big gallery.

LONDON, Feb. 12 -- Field Marshal Sir William Robertson, one of the outstanding figures of the World War, died suddenly today in his home here, at the age of 72. He collapsed while dressing for breakfast.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- The Index of wholesale prices In France during January, compiled by the Statistique Generale, stands at 390, the same as in December The separate Indices by groups of articles compare as follows with a year ago:

ALBANY, Feb. 12 (AP).-- Ninety thousand milk producers will turn their eyes toward Albany tomorrow to see what hope they can place in the emergency milk bill which is being whipped into its final form for presentation to the Legislature.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 12. -- The discovery of a mosaic pavement at Daphne, near Antioch, Syria, has been reported to Professor George W. Elderkin of the Department of Art and Archaeology of Princeton University, according to an article by Professor Elderkin appearing in The Princeton Alumni weekly.

The new Furness Bermuda Line flagship Queen of Bermuda, built at a cost of $8,000,000 for the New York-Bermuda trade, will start her official speed trials today on the Clyde, in preparation for her departure for New York later in the month.

BASEL, Switzerland, Feb. 13 -- The World Bank governors, who held their monthly meeting here today, decided, It is understood, for all practical purposes, in a special secret session, who will succeed Gates W. McGarrah as president at his expected, although not yet announced, retirement in May.

The Biological Survey of the Department of Agriculture yesterday announced that the danger which threatened the existence of hundreds of thousands of Canadian geese and brant because of virtually the total disappearance of eel grass, now has been alleviated to a great extent.

A large retrospective exhibition of work by Maurice Sterne, American, artist, opens at the Museum of Modern Art today with a reception and private view for members. Beginning tomorrow, the painting's, drawings and sculpture will be shown to the public, remaining until March 25.

Members of the social service department of the Stuyvesant Square Hospital, of which Mrs. Samuel Adams Clark is president, will hold their annual bridge and backgammon tournament in behalf of that organization on Thursday afternoon in the main ballroom of the Plaza.

After eighty-two years of service to ports in many parts of the world the Luckenbach Steamship Lines will use Manhattan, as a port of call next Wednesday when the freighter J.L. Luckenbach sails from Pier 71, North River, en route to Pacific Coast ports.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- The revival of the European steel cartel on a new basis seems assured today after negotiations held in Luxembourg over the week-end. There are still details to be arranged, but such progress has been made that steel interests in France now feel that success is virtually assured.

By anticipation, the President's speech to the National Republican Club in this city last evening was dubbed his "Farewell Address." It is not exactly that either in tone or substance Mr. HOOVER assured his hearers that the Republican party "will be recalled to power by the American people."

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 13 -- The assets of the John Hancock Mutual Life Insurance Company of Boston were increased to $639,455,691 in 1932, a gain of $18,177,558 over the preceding year, according to the report submitted by the president, Walton L. Crocker, at the seventieth annual policyholders meeting held today at the home office.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A bankruptcy bill stripped of all relief proposals for railroads and other corporations and applicable only to farmers and ordinary individual debtors, was reported out of the Senate Judiciary Committee today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The movement to extend wide powers of reorganization to the incoming President was in a state of confusion today as a conference neared on the Treasury-Postoffice appropriation bill, to which the reorganization authority is attached.

Reorganization of the Pennsylvania Dock and Warehouse Company is contemplated in a plan announced yesterday by Pierpont V. Davis, vice president of the National City Company, who heads the committee for holders of the company's $5,750,000 of leasehold mortgage 6 per cent bonds, due in 1949, on which the interest went into default on Aug. 1, 1931.

Ernie Schaaf, Boston heavyweight boxer, was in a critical condition last night at Polyclinic Hospital following a three-hour operation for the removal of a blood clot from his brain. Schaaf collapsed in the thirteenth round of his fight Friday night with Primo Camera and was taken to the hospital half an hour later.

College courses in marriage are recommended by Ernest R. Groves, Professor of Sociology at the University of North Carolina, in "Marriage," published today by Henry Holt Co. Such a course has been offered for eight years to senior class men at the University of North Carolina, he writes, and has been successful.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Alarm for the safety of the nation, voiced in both branches of Congress, led tonight to a fight for exemption of the military services from the 5 per cent cut below appropriations decreed in the pending economy bill.

Probably "The Sophistlcrats," which was acted at the Bijou last evening, is based on a set of real people. Probably some city of 75,000 or less population in the Connecticut valley does support a group of poets, columnists, dramatic critics and society leaders who clutch at smart phrases and literary celebrities quite as frantically as the provincial worldings of Kenneth Phillips Britton's play.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- British commercial aviation encircling the empire and the globe in the not distant future, with regular transatlantic air service started within the next two or three years, was envisaged today by Sir Eric Geddes of Imperial Airways, Ltd.

Holders of the first and refunding 4% per cent bonds of the Great Northern Railway Company have been requested by William P. Kenney, president, to assent to a plan for the extension for not more than fifteen years of the principal of $41,963,000 consolidated mortgage bonds of the St. Paul, Minneapolis Manitoba Railway, assumed by the Great Northern, and maturing on July 1 of this year.

After President Hoover had completed his address in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria last night and, accompanied Tjy Secretary Stimson, Secretary Hurley and Dudley Field Malone, had retired for a brief rest in his suite on the fourteenth floor of the hotel, a young man got out of the elevator and approached the door of the suite.

The cabled report from London, quoting a British tennis official as threatening any amateur taking part in the American open championship with disbarment from the Wimbledon tournament, failed to cause so much as a ripple of concern yesterday among local executives of the United States Lawn Tennis Association.

The French Government, through its Ministry of Fine Arts, has again offered the use of an entire wing of the Royal Palace of Fontainebleau as a Summer home and school of music for a limited number of American students, it was announced yesterday by Walter Damrosch, president of the American committee for the school and one of the founders of the conservatory.

Although she appeared somewhat weary upon her arrival from Washington, Mrs. Hoover was in holiday mood last night at the Lincoln dinner in the Waldorf-Astoria. She smiled graciously as she recognized friends at tables scattered throughout the ballroom and was engrossed in conversation with her companions on the dais throughout the dinner.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Proceedings in an investigation of production costs at home and abroad of fresh tomatoes, particularly in Mexico, requested by President Hoover were adjourned indefinitely late today by the Tariff Commission after a storm of protest by producers from Florida, Georgia, California and other States.

The refusal of youth "to be dragooned or conscripted into war against its own conviction" was hailed by Norman Thomas, Socialist leader, yesterday as one of the factors likely to avert war, in an address before almost 500 delegates at the Young People's Peace Conference, held in the Friends' Meetiing House, 221 East Fifteenth Street.

HONOLULU, Feb. 13 -- The Territory of Hawaii officially closed the so-called Ala Moana case today when Judge Charles S. Davis granted a motion to nolle prosse indictments against the surviving four of five men charged with assaulting Mrs. Thalia Massie a year ago last September.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Shepard Dillingham of 2 East Eighty-sixth Street are giving a dinner tonight for Lord Marley of London.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Despite a rising protest from merchants of the State against the retail sales tax proposed by Governor Lehman in his annual budget message. Republicans in the Legislature tonight are more strongly inclined than ever toward making the sales tax one of the principal revenue producers for the coming fiscal year.

To avoid the sales tax advocated by Governor Lehman and the Mastick commission, on the ground that it would be particularly Injurious to merchants of New York and other border communities by driving customers to New Jersey and Connecticut, the Merchants Association yesterday announced its advocacy of a proposed increase in the gasoline tax, and of the lowering of exemptions on both State and Federal Income taxes, besides a gross income tax.

A proposed change in the oral pleadings law that would make it impossible for those without means to hire a lawyer to appear in court and plead their own causes, as many do, is opposed along with nine other bills by the New York County Lawyers Association in another of its reports on pending legislation, made public yesterday.
MUNICH, Feb. 13 -- "Hitlerism has reached if it has not passed its zenith in Bavaria."

Formation of the Society for the Prevention of Asphyxial Death, Inc., to check what was termed an alarming and needless loss of life from submersion, gas inhalation, carbon monoxide from automobile exhaust, overdoses of anaesthesia, electric shock, asphyxia of stillborn children and other causes was announced last night by Dr. Paluel J. Flagg at a meeting of the Society of Medical Jurisprudence, at the New York Academy of Medicine.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 -- The cotton market here was rather quiet today as all the Northern and many of the Southern markets were closed for the Lincoln holiday, which prevented the usual interchange among the markets. Prices went forward slowly on moderate trade buying, which more than absorbed the little hedge selling in evidence.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13. -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Harold J. Bryant of Guilsborough, England, who are spending the Winter in their Lake Worth home, Mrs. Louis G. Kaufman entertained with a dinner tonight at the Colony Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your report that because of shortened funds the New York Public Library will be able to buy only 50,000 books this year, as against its usual annual purchase of 250,000 volumes, pictures a deplorable condition which, no doubt, reflects on a larger scale the same calamity befallen public libraries in every city and town in the country.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The domestic allotment plan is plain class legislation of the worst kind. It is "soaking the poor" that can afford it least. In the case of wheat, it means penalizing nineteen poor consuming Americans to place one farmer on "easy street."

Numerous candidates for the highest honor in American dogdom came to the fore in the first day of judging at the fifty-seventh annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which opened yesterday in Madison Square Garden and will be continued through tomorrow evening.
The President of the United States and Mrs. Hoover paid a hasty visit to New York last night in honor of the memory of Abraham Lincoln.

DENVER, Feb. 13. -- Distraught relatives of Charles Boettcher 2d, kidnapped scion of a wealthy Colorado family, awaited word from his abductors tonight after signifying willingness to comply with the $60,000 ransom demand.

PARIS, Feb. 13 -- That 1932 must nave been a profitable year in the French armaments industry is shown in detailed official trade statistics issued today. The value of exports in the classification of the customs list known as "arms, powder, munitions" jumped from 78,934,000 francs in 1931 to 243,150,000 francs (the franc is worth about 4 cents.) The quantity increased only from 34,589 metric quintals to 47,317.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 13 (AP) -- Winning a fight for reduction in the amount of their bail, the three young defendants charged with attempting to extort $50,000 from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh by threats to kidnap his second son had their hearing postponed today until Saturday.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- Beekman Pool, slightly built 23-year-old New York racquet star, today stroked his way to another national squash racquets championship and to revenge over another of the two players who have administered the only defeats he has experienced in recent months.
GENEVA, Feb. 13 -- The British are understood now to be making very discreet soundings among the great powers to ascertain how they would receive a proposal to abolish all war aviation.

Protesting against the Board of Aldermen's decision not to hold public hearings on the reopened 1933 city budget, the City Affairs Committee in a letter to the board yesterday described the procedure as "a star-chamber proceeding."

If the oil industry should fail in its cooperative efforts to enable all existing fields to supply as equitable portion of the market requirements, R.C. Holmes, president of the Texas Company, yesterday said, "The consequences would be the dissipation of all of the world's larger reserves of crude oil and the other assets of the industry at a tremendous cost of every one concerned."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- The Supreme Court today declined to reconsider its recent action in refusing to review the petition of the executors of the estate of John T. Dorrance, challenging a transfer inheritance tax of $17,437,655 imposed by Pennsylvania.

MONTREAL, Feb. 13 -- The financial statement of the Bell Telephone Company of Canada for 1932 shows operating revenues of $38,071,800, down 4.1 per cent from the $40,926,162 reported for 1931. Because of reduced miscellaneous income together with an increase in interest and other charges the amount applicable to common dividends was short of requirements by $836,868 for the year.

A decline of 4.6 per cent in the number of motor fatalities in New York State for 1932 as compared with 1931 is noted ii the annual report, made public yesterday, of Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, to Thomas M. Lynch, Commissioner of Taxation and Finance.

Although Val Riordan, Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School's star quarter-miler, retained his title and shattered his own record, Loughlin relinquished the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association senior indoor track and field team championship to its old rival, St. James of Brooklyn, 1931 winner, at the 245th Coast Defense Armory, Brooklyn, yesterday.
Substantial progress in clearing the week-end snowfall off the streets was made yesterday by a force of 31,500 men, 18,000 of them drawn from the unemployed.

HAVANA, Feb. 13 -- The police raided today the offices of Resales Lavedan, a prominent law firm, counsel for the National City Bank of New York, arresting Drs. Joaquin Martinez Saenz and Emilio Matin, members of the firm, and Ernesto Carcas, the office manager.

ASUNCION, Paraguay, Jan. 25 (AP by mail) -- Threatened migration of 5,000 Mennonites from farms in the Chaco to new and warless fields in Uruguay or Brazil will be averted if any concessions which Paraguay can make will induce the sturdy colonists to remain.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Responsibility of the medical profession for the prevention of mental diseases was stressed by Dr. Ray Lyman Wilbur, Secretary of the Interior, in an address here today at the opening session of the annual Congress on Medical Education and Licensure sponsored by the American Medical Association.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Curtis P. Stevens and his Lake Placid A.C. Blue Birds, Charles Divine, Robert Martin and E.H. Varno, smashed the A.A.U. record for total time of four heats and bettered their own record run of yesterday for one heat in annexing the national A.A.U. senior fourman bob sled championship on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run today.

DETROIT, Tuesday, Feb. 14 -- Governor William A. Comstock early today Issued a proclamation calling for an eight-day public holiday in Michigan, during which time "all banks, trust companies and other financial institutions conducting a banking or trust business within the State of Michigan shall not be opened for the transaction of banking or trust business."

New York City's commemoration of the 124th anniversary of the birth of Abraham Lincoln in Hardin County, Ky., on Feb. 12, 1809, ended yesterday with further tributes in which the nation was urged to follow the principles of its Civil War President in meeting the problems of a troubled epoch.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Five favorites and one joint choice scored at Hialeah Park today, and Mountain Elk, which won the featured Rock Ledge Purse, was one of the most heavily backed of the group at 17 to 20.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Samuel Insull Jr. has resigned as a director and a member of the executive committee and as vice chairman of the Peoples Gas Light and Coke Company, and has been made assistant to the chairman of the company, said the annual report, issued tonight.

In a struggle lasting close to three hours, Gregory Mangin of Newark, N.J., seventh in the tentative rankings for 1932, defeated Berkeley Bell of New York and Texas yesterday to win the annual invitation indoor tennis tournament of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

TOKYO, Feb. 13 -- Rejecting the demand that she withdraw her armies from Manchuria and restore China's sovereignty, Japan challenged today the legality of the negotiations committee proposed by the Committee of Nineteen of the League of Nations for settling her dispute with China.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- A move to throw all the resources of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation behind the cities of the country, many of which are facing financial collapse because taxpayers have been unable to pay their taxes, has been started by Mayor Frank Murphy of Detroit.

GENEVA, Feb. 13 -- The Japanese delegation received today Tokyo's reply to the Committee of Nineteen's question whether it would accept the sovereignty of China over Manchuria. Tokyo, according to the delegation, says "No" politely and in the same terms Yosuke Matsuoka recommended Chinese withdrawal from Jehol.

MONTREAL, Feb. 13 (Canadian Press) -- For the third successive week Bill Cook of the Rangers and Laurence Northcott, left wing of the Maroons, were deadlocked tonight for leadership in point-scoring in the National Hockey League. Each has 32 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The long-deferred showdown on prohibition repeal in the Senate was promised for tomorrow when Senator Blaine late today moved to take up his modified resolution, thereby placing the motion as the first order of business when the Senators reconvene.

In these days of uncertain and generally depressed stock markets, the rapid advance of South African gold-mine shares on the London market has stood almost alone. London itself describes the rise as the most spectacular since the "Kaffir boom"of 1895.

CHICAGO, Feb. 13 -- Grain exchanges in the United States were closed today in honor of Abraham Lincoln's Birthday. Liverpool and Winnipeg, which were open as usual, reported business good, the feature being the buying of 500,000 bushels of July wheat in Winnipeg by Jackson Brothers of Chicago and the selling of an equal amount of May at 7/8 cent difference to close spreads.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Credit has been too cheap in America, and it is not difficult to thumb-tack that as the cause of a great deal of our present economic distress. Back in the '90s it was thought to be more or less of a disgrace if one had a mortgage on his home, and everybody worked like blazes to liquidate them.

Columbia came back into the thick of the battle for the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League championship yesterday by defeating the University of Pennsylvania, in the Columbia gymnasium, 29-19, before an Alumni Day gathering of 2,000 persons.

With all the markets and banks in New York closed for the holiday, Wall Street marked time yesterday. Except for the New Orleans cotton market, where prices rose about 6 points, business was almost at a standstill in the principal domestic centres.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 13 -- The Paraguayan troops defending Fort Nanawa (Ayala) attached the trenches of the besieging Bolivians all along the line Saturday night, it was learned today, but were repulsed at every point.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Colombia invoked the Kellogg pact as a rebuke to Peru, and the action was not initiated by the United States, according to a statement issued tonight by the Colombian Legation.

The majority of women today do not know how to dress properly or how to get the greatest value and satisfaction from the money that they spend for clothing, according to Professor Lillian H. Locke of the department of household arts, Teachers College, Columbia University.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- The Boerse today developed an upward movement on more active business, with steels, coals, chemicals and electricals the centre of interest. Final prices near the day's highs. Siemens Halske closed 3 3/4, Schuckert 2 3/4, I.G. Farben 2 and Harpener 1 1/8 points above Saturday's levels.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Great Britain would be authorized to make the payment on her debt due in June in silver under the terms of a bill introduced today by Senator Key Pittman of Nevada.

MOSCOW, Feb. 13 -- The ancient city of Turtkul, the capital of the Kara Kalpak Autonomous Area of Kazakstan, Soviet Central Asia, is doomed by the encroachment of the Amu Darya, also known as the Oxus River.

Two Bishops, thirty-five clergy and 185 young men and boys took part yesterday morning in the annual festival service for acolytes in the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street.
COMMERCIAI PAPER. Yesterday..Legal holiday Friday.....1 1/4 per cent for the best names
PARIS, Feb. 13 -- Premier Daladier won a triumph tonight with the passage of his budget bill in the Chamber of Deputies by a vote of 359 to 253.

The classic authors were not always perfect grammarians, and even Noah Webster, author of the monumental dictionary, sometimes got himself hopelessly entangled in words, tenses and phrases of extraordinary ambiguity, Dr. Frank Vizetelly, lexicographer, told his audience last night in the Muhlenberg Branch Library, 209 West Twenty-third Street.
SOFIA, Feb. 13 -- More than 10,000 persons assembled at Gorna Djumaja in Bulgarian Macedonia for the national congress of Macedonian emigrants In Bulgaria, the first of its kind ever held.

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Picking their boats out of the ice and snow drifts along Milton Point, the enrolled Eskimos of the Frostbite Yacht Club renewed their adventures today, racing while dodging ice cakes off the American Yacht Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Feb. 8 show decreases for the week of $152,000,000 in loans and investments, $200,000,000 in net demand deposits, $22,000,000 in time deposits, $55,000,000 in government deposits and $11,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks.

A performance of "Parsifal" was given yesterday afternoon by the Metropolitan Opera Association, under the auspices and for the benefit of the Southern Women's Educational Alliance, in observance of the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Richard Wagner in Venice, Feb. 13, 1883.

LONDON, Feb. 13. -- Prime Minister MacDonald told the House of Commons today that the British Government had agreed to discuss with the United States Government, concurrently with the war debts, the whole gamut of world economic problems of mutual interest to both countries.

JAMESTOWN, Tenn., Feb. 13 (AP) -- After waiting vainly for two hours today for a judge to hear their habeas corpus petition. Colonel Luke Lea and Luke Lea Jr. announced the next step in their fight against extradition to North Carolina would be taken in near-by Crossville, where they obtained another writ in a surprise move.

Two protective committees for the holders, respectively, of the Celotex Company $869,500 first-mortage 6 1/2 per cent convertible bonds, due on Dec. 1, 1939, and $1,700,000 convertible 6 per cent debentures due on Nov. 1, 1936, issued a joint statement yesterday asking the holders to deposit tHeir holdings immediately.

DETROIT, Feb. 13 -- Striking workmen of the Hudson Motor Car Company returned today to the jobs they left a week ago, and the Connors Avenue body plant went back Into production. This followed assurances from foremen that wage difficulties would be ironed out by private negotiations to the complete satisfaction of the workmen.
DENVER, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Mayor George D. Begole in a proclamation today called upon "law-abiding citizens every where" to make a determined effort to apprehend the kidnappers of Charles Boettcher 2d.

In declaring that the principles of the Republican party which were upheld by 15,000,000 American citizens last November would remain a dominant factor in American politics, assuring the party's recall to power, President Hoover in his Lincoln Day speech uttered a hope that inspired his distinctly Republican audience.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 -- Senator Huey P. Long was sworn as a witness before the Senate Committee on Campaigns today in a hearing during which the tangled political alliances of Louisiana for the past ten years were reviewed and sixteen more dummy candidates questioned.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- The power of Federal courts to prevent New York State from collecting taxes from a bankrupt on a claim filed too late was unanimously upheld by the Supreme Court today in an opinion by Justice McReynolds.

President Hoover in his farewell address before leaving office, suggested here last night that some part of the debt payments due the United States from foreign nations might be set aside temporarily to stabilize the currencies of the world.

GROTON, Mass., Feb. 13 -- The Rev. William J. Farrell, pastor of the Church of the Sacred Heart here, an army chaplain in the World War, recipient of the Distinguished Service Cross and national chaplain of the Army and Navy Legion of Honor, died early today in the rectory at the age of 56.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., Feb. 13 -- Horace Roberts, real estate operator of this city, announced today that information had reached him which might lead him to demand the reopening of the investigation into the fatal shooting of his son, Horace Roberts Jr., and Miss Ruth Mowdray Wilson in June, 1929.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Acting on the recommendation of Governor Lehman in an emergency message, the Legislature tonight rushed through a bill extending the period for readjustment of the New York City budget until Feb. 25 to insure the validity of Mayor O'Brien's proposals for $40,000,000 in cuts.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- By a vote of 2 to 1, with Judge Frank Cooper dissenting, the Federal court ruled today that Charles H. Baldwin, Commissioner of Agriculture and Markets, could continue to prohibit the importation into this State of cattle afflicted with bang's disease.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- A relief effort designed to provide shelter for 88,000 youths cast adrift by the depression was voted in the War Department appropriation bill just before the $370,000,000 measure was passed by the Senate late today.

Tracy H. Lewis triumphed in the annual shoot for the Charles H. Winninger trophy over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He scored by breaking 98 out of 100 targets. Originally, the competition was scheduled for 200 targets, but the committee decided to cut the test and add distance and doubles events to the program.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- After a heated debate the Assembly tonight passed a bill sponsored by Assemblyman Alterman, Democrat, of New York, paving the way for a lawyer, disbarred by the Appellate Division, to carry his case to the Court of Appeals.

A resolution, calling for the establishment of a permanent commission on education and youth organization of the Zionist Organization of America to formulate an educational program of study and activity, conceived in the light of Palestine development for the guidance of schools, clubs, community centres and adult groups, was adopted yesterday at the closing session of the Zionist Organization, at the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Ninety-second Street and Lexington Avenue.

Dogs of lineage are "receiving" at Madison Square Garden for three days. Of all such exhibitions, the Westminster Kennel Club's show at New York is the largest and finest. Its awards are the most coveted. Entries come from as far West as California.

With only half their number signed and the training season barely two weeks away, the Yankees' management yesterday indicated that it means to besti itself very soon in a determined effort to bring the remaining half in line.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney and several of his deputies attended the annual memorial mass of the Holy Name Society of the Police Department yesterday in Holy Cross Church, Forty-second Street, between Eighth and Ninth Avenues. Members of the department and relatives of those who died during the last year filled the church.

ON BOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, in the Pacific, Feb. 13 -- Surging combers crashed against the sides of the Blue ships today, and a brisk northwest wind flung spray over their heaving decks as the 113 ships defending the Pacific Coast against the "enemy" raid steamed across the windswept ocean, searching for the Black Fleet.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, recognized by the New York State Athletio Commission as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, defeated Nick Lutze, speedy California challenger, in the feature exhibition. at the Seventy-first Regiment Armory last night.

The program given by the Beethoven Association last night in Town Hall was admirably representative of the traditions of this organization. The artists who performed were Mme. Ninon Vallin, soprano; Bruno Walter, conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, who was happy in giving his services as pianist in the performance of the Beethoven B flat trio, and the Roth Quartet.
Doubleday, Doran estimates sales of "Ann Vickers," by Sinclair Lewis, at about 4,000 copies a day.

A plan of reorganization affecting the Montague-Court Building in Brooklyn has been approved by the committee handling the matter and was mailed yesterday to all bondholders. The proposal contemplates the formation of a new company to acquire all mortgaged assets of the Court and Montague Street Realty Corporation, owner of the building and leasehold.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A good deal of propaganda has been put forward lately about economy, but even superficial consideration will show that prosperity in this country is based upon waste and extravagance. The doctrine of stopping all expenditures except for necessities would quickly bring most business activity to a standstill.
PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., Feb. 13 -- Long Island dinghy sailors gathered at the North Hempstead Yacht Club today and, braving ice and a chilling southwest breeze, sailed in five races.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Sandwrack, far back in his last two starts after a successful campaign at Jefferson Park, came through with a driving victory in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Vice President Curtis was the guest of honor and his slater, Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, headed the reception committee at the last Bachelors Cotillon of the season, given tonight at the Mayflower Hotel, with more than 400 members and friends in attendance.
The text of President Hoover's address at the Lincoln Day dinner of the National Republican Club here last night follows:
Business will be resumed in Wall Street this morning after having been suspended yesterday on account of the deferred observance of Lincoln's Birthday.

A Democratic Assemblyman from the Bronx named SMITH has introduced at Albany that hardy perennial, a bill to permit the removal of civil service employes only after a formal trial. The remarkable thing is not that this objectionable measure should have made its appearance again, but that it should actually have received a favorable report from a responsible committee in a year like this, when economy and efficiency are supposed to be guiding principles.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- The arrival here this morning of copies of The Sunday Express of London containing a report of an interview with Chancellor Hitler, wherein he is represented as giving his views with more than diplomatic candor on Germany's proper foreign policy, produced much hasty telephoning by the government to foreign capitals and the issuance of a statement of denial to foreign, correspondents.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 13 -- Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., one of America's "big four" in women's golf, won the medal today from a large and select field that included a group of British stars in the qualifying round for the championship of Florida over the Palm Beach Country Club course.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 13 -- Rear Admiral Harold Percival Norton, retired, died here Saturday night in the Naval Hospital, at the age of 77.

Legislation to prohibit public utility operating companies from using their credit to finance holding companies or affiliated operating units, except possibly with the commission's approval, is recommended in the annual report of the Public Service Commission to Governor Lehman and the Legislature, it was disclosed yesterday.

To combat illness and debilitation among the unemployed, the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration has established a program under which more than 150 jobless graduate nurses will be employed in a wide up-State area to give nursing and medical care for other unemployed, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State administration.

TUXEDO PARK, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- In a magnificent exhibition where every shot in his extensive repertoire responded perfectly to his call, Clarence C. Pell, the national champion, today registered his fourteenth Gold Racquet tournament triumph at the Tuxedo Club.

Dr. James M. Kieran, president of Hunter College, will "study and do a little writing" on the history and philosophy of the thirteenth and sixteenth centuries after his retirement next Summer, according to plans he revealed yesterday at a breakfast of the alumnae of the college in the Hotel Astor and in a conversation last night.

Negotiation and agreement must be the keynote in the solution of the Indian problem, not dictation, however benevolent or paternal, according to the Right Hon. William Wedgwood Benn, former Secretary of State for India, in an interview yesterday.

Increased participation in public affairs by scholars and universities is a hopeful sign that the world is emerging from its present "tangle," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday.
"Melody," George White's new musical production with music by Sigmund Romberg, book by Edward Childs Carpenter and lyrics by Irving Caesar, will open this evening at the Casino Theatre.

With more than 1,500 mill owners, executives and technical experts of the United States and Canada in attendance, the American Paper and Pulp Association and Affiliated Associations opened its four-day convention yesterday at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 13 -- Six new Cardinals will be created at a private consistory on March 13, whose principal object will be the appointment of three Cardinal Legates to open the holy doors of the basilicas of St. Mary Major, St. John Lateran and St. Paul's Outside the Wall, inaugurating the holy year.

Activity in the leasing of space in the Port Authority's inland freight terminal and commerce centre, occupying the block bounded by Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, Eighth and Ninth Avenues, was reported yesterday by officials of the Port Authority.

LONDON, Feb. 13 -- If the United States refused war debt revision and Great Britain continued to pay in gold, such payments could continue after the Bank of England's gold stocks of u120,000,000 had been exhausted, according to a review issued by J. Henry Schroeder Co.

BEAR MOUNTAIN, N.Y., Feb. 13 -- Twelve thousand persons, comprising one of the largest crowds ever to witness a ski jumping tournament in the East, turned out for the interstate meet today. Ideal weather conditions prevailed.

The country's football coaches and officials yesterday gave a prompt and sweeping vote of approval to the action of the national rules committee in making only two changes in the gridiron code for 1933, both calculated to improve the sport as well as further reduce possible causes of injury to the players.

College students of today no longer maintain the blase or indifferent attitude to life that they had a few years ago, Dean Virginia C. Gildersleeve of Barnard Coliege asserted yesterday in an address to 300 alumnae of the college at their annual reunion luncheon in Hewitt Hall.

Prime Minister MACDONALD speaks for the British Cabinet and obviously with more authority than has the Chancellor of the Exchequer. The latter had been rather brusquely ruling out of the coming discussions at Washington everything except the debt question pure and simple.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I am taking advantage of being in this country to ask those who possess letters from my husband, the late Israel Zangwill, whether they will be kind enough to lend them to me. I know he had a very large circle of friends and acquaintances in "The Great Republic which carries mankind and its fortunes," as he styled America in his play "The Melting Pot."

The musicians of the city and the general public joined in the observance of the fiftieth anniversary of Wagner's death yesterday. Besides the Metropolitan "Parsifal," there were Wagner concerts in several halls and all the leading broadcasting stations offered Wagner programs.

For the first time since 1917 Spring threatened to arrive this year unaccompanied by an exhibition of the Society of Independent Artists. Until recently it had appeared that the exhibition was as fixed a vernal phenomenon as the flowering of the cherry trees in Central Park, but now it is evident that April showers alone are not enough to make the exhibition bloom.

An article In The New York Law Journal, the official law paper for the Eirst Judicial Department of this State, points out today that the form of oath usually administered at Presidential inaugurations Is irregular and not in literal compliance with the Constitution of the United States.
MIAMI, Feb. 13. -- Good fishing will delay the arrival of President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt and his party at Miami later Wednesday evening than was intended originally.

The Summary, weekly newspaper published by inmates of Elmira Reformatory, urges the undergraduates of that institution to give a "chilling" reception to old grads returning to their alma mater not exactly for love of the place but for violation of parole.

BERLIN, Feb. 13 -- All Germany observed yesterday and today the fiftieth anniversary of the death of Richard Wagner. The commemoration chiefly took the form of operatic concerts and radio broadcasts, and addresses were delivered by conductors, critics and music teachers.
BOSTON, Feb. 13 (AP) -- Tragedy and heroism came into port today aboard the fire-ravaged and sea-beaten trawler Newton, home from the fishing banks of the North Atlantic.

Glenn Cunningham of the University of Kansas yesterday was voted the Rodman Wanamaker international trophy for the most meritorious performance at the Millrose Games. The Kansas athlete received 17 points, with Keith Brown, Yale pole vaulter, second with 13.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 13 -- Proposals for further reduction of army and navy appropriations, which, he said, were making the United States more dependent on the National Guard and civilian population than on the regular army as a medium of national defense, were attacked today by Louis A. Johnson, national commander of the American Legion, in a Lincoln Day address under the auspices of the national defense committee of the Legion in this city.

Rum Slays Fewer. Deaths from alcoholism last year In New York State showed the lowest rate in ten years. There are any number of reasons available. The depression seriously cut down the amount of liquor consumed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 13. -- By a vote of 212 to 174, the Democratic House today overrode the Republican proposal to discharge the Ways and Means Committee from further consideration of the Crowther bill to increase tariffs on imports from countries having depreciated currency, and thus killed all chances for such legislation at the present session.

Chairman FARLEY'S speech at Miami was so comprehensive that, even at the risk of injustice, only a few of its golden words can be picked out as specimens. It must suffice to say that with PARLEY as leader and under his auspices our institutions are to be "liberalized."

ALTOGETHER now, in a short cheer, "Sis-boom-bah, sis-boom-bah, Rules Committee, rah, rah, rah!" That was a practically perfect session the Football Rules Committee held on the outskirts of Philadelphia. All the members of the committee are entitled to stand up and take a deep bow. The gavel used by Chairman Walter Okeson at these meetings should be garlanded with myrtle and wild olive and preserved in some football shrine.

ALBANY, Feb. 13 -- Under the terms of a bill introduced tonight by Senator O'Brien of New York City and Assemblyman Garnjost of Westchester County, the State Superintendent of Insurance would be immune from civil liability or criminal prosecution on account of "any error in judgment or in exercise of discretion in any action taken by him" or on account of failure to exercise discretion or to act in his official capacity.

Warning that a repeal resolution may fail of adoption in the next Senate by a margin of eleven votes, Mrs. Charles H. Sabin, in an address broadcast last evening over WMCA, called upon the wets to "convince that august body that nothing short of repeal will be acceptable to the American people."

Musical romance being already in the air, George White has sent up a new strain under the title of "Melody," which was sung at his personal Casino last evening. It has all the virtues of the breed save inspiration. Mr. Romberg, veteran of some sixty scores, has set it to robust melodies and orchestrations after his thoroughly competent fashion.

LONDON. Feb. 14 -- The nations of the British Commonwealth took the first step today toward cutting the costs of their imperial research committees and economic organizations, which in recent years have reached millions of pounds annually.

The committee on national transportation, created at the request of seventy-two fiduciary and investing institutions and made up of BERNARD M. BARUCH, ex-Governor ALFRED E. SMITH, CLARK HOWELL, ALEXANDER LEGGE and, until his death, ex-President COOLIDGE, makes in its report an exceptionally thorough examination into conditions which have contributed, along with business reaction and shrinkage of traffic, to bringing the railways into their present difficult position.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- A report censurin Federal Judge Harold Louderback of California "for conduct prejudicial to the dignity of the judiciary" was agreed upon today by a Judiciary Committee majority and will be submitted to the House tomorrow.

Sophie Braslau, contralto, will sing tonight at Fuld Hall under the auspices of the local Y.M.H.A. and Y.W.H.A. Her program will include songs of Brahms, Bruch, Strauss, Schubert, Ravel, Massenet, Sadero, de Falla and Rachmaninoff.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Drastic economies In the operating costs of the New York Telephone Company are urged in the annual report of the Public Service Commission, which was filed with the Governor and the Legislature today.

As a consequence of Ernie Schaaf's death, the State Athletic Commission yesterday ruled against a proposed world's heavyweight title ring bout here between Jack Sharkey, the champion, and Primo Camera, Italian contender for the crown.

Four young men, three of them armed with pistols and the fourth with a sawed-off shotgun, held up the Hydrox Laundry and Dry Cleaning Company in Brooklyn yesterday afternoon, thus raiding an establishment in which Owen (Owney) Madden, Broadway racketeer now in Sing Sing for violation of parole, once claimed a partnership.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- If Prime Minister Ramsay MacDonald decides to come to Washington March 5 or soon thereafter as chief of arrangements, in the van of the other British economic negotiators, he will find a warm welcome awaiting him from those Republicans who take President Hoover as their guide in these matters.
NASSAU, Bahama, Feb. 14. -- Franklin Roosevelt returned to Nassau aboard Vincent Astor's yacht Nourmahal this morning after ten days' fishing in Bahama waters.

Once a year the American Woman's Association puts on a show of "major works" by artist-members. This, annual event opened yesterday afternoon with a tea in the third-floor gallery of the association's clubhouse 353 West Fifty-seventh Street, where it will remain until March 26.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 -- The Reichstag's committee for the defense of the people's Parliamentary rights, which was compelled to adjourn last week by the violent tactics of its National Socialist members, was definitely broken up today by similar methods and will cease to function.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -- While the relief action taken tonight by the Detroit Clearing House Association applies specifically to Detroit, relief was expressed that most of the out-State banks would adopt similar plans. The emergency measure made no reference to industrial payrolls, but most of the large corporations in the metropolitan area already have arranged to meet payrolls with cash brought from outside the State.

Heavy selling of bonds on the Stock Exchange resulted yesterday in the widest declines since May 31, 1932, which date was just prior to the announcement of the American Securities Investing Corporation, popularly referred to as the "bond pool."

The town of Leticia, the centre of the dispute between Colombia and Peru, is located in the vast jungle area around the headwaters of the Amazon. For nearly a hundred years this general area was claimed by Colombia, Ecuador and Peru.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Topics of The Times on New York ferries in yesterday's TIMES stirred recent memories. We spent two afternoons in January zigzagging back and forth on the ferries, getting changing perspectives of sky lines and scrapers, of river and harbor waters under Winter cloud-panoramas.

Francisco Castillo Najera, Mexican Ambassador to France, will sail tonight on the Cunarder Berengaria with Senora Najera, their daughter Emma and three sons. Miss Moya Beresford, daughter of Lord Decies, is also booked to sail for Cherbourg and Southampton.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The first goal of the Democratic party before Mr. Roosevelt enters upon his duties is the wiping out of the $750,000 deficit remaining after the last Presidential campaign, James A. Farley, chairman of the national committee, said today.

GENEVA, Feb. 14 -- The Disarmament Conference's political commission, established a year ago, held its first meeting this morning. After a long debate on where to begin, it agreed with Salvador de Madariaga of Spain and Joseph Paul-Boncour to begin tomorrow with the British proposal to amend the peace pact, as far as Europe is concerned, by replacing outlawry of war with outlawry of force.

Three one-man shows opened yesterday at the Grand Central Galleries -- sculpture by Brenda Putnam, block prints in color by Frances H. Gearhart and etchings, lithographs and drawings by Charles Z. Offin.

Declaring in his preface that "the present Wagner biographies are mostly, hindrances rather than helps toward the ideal end" of a truly definitive biography, Ernest Newman, English music critic and authority on Richard Wagner, has written his own "The Life of Richard Wagner," the first volume of which is published today by Knopf.

The Interborough Rapid Transit Company fell short of its full interest requirements by $83,856 in December and by $1,457,786 in the six months ended on Dec. 31, 1932, according to the report of Victor J. Dowling and Thomas E. Murray Jr., receivers of the company.

Joseph Stags Lawrence, vice president of the Bradstreet Company, declared last night that he did not believe inflation would raise prices because Federal inflation operations had aggregated $9,000,000,000 in the last three years without effect on prices.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 14 -- Since the burial of Louis Kossuth, Hungarian national hero, forty years ago, no such majestic funeral ceremony has been seen in Budapest as that which marked the burial in the Coronation Church of St. Matthew today of Count Albert Apponyi.

A tense banking situation in Michigan, for which Wall Street seemed unprepared, unsettled all markets yesterday. The selling converged upon stocks and bonds with damaging effect and there was an incidental decline in the principal agricultural staples.

Regional consolidations of the nation's railroads, "looking eventually to a single national system," should be hastened and, where necessary, enforced, the National Transportation Committee declared yesterday in its long-awaited report.

THERE are tragedies in all walks of life, but Ernie Schaaf died after engaging in a boxing bout, and fatalities in sport stand out in rather ghastly fashion because of the contrast between what is expected and what really happens.

Confidence that the world will eventually struggle free of its troubles was expressed last night by Governor Wilbur L. Cross of Connecticut and Ray Lyman Wilbur, Secretary of the Interior, in speeches at the thirty-sixth annual dinner of the Men's Class of the Riverside Church, in the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON. Feb 14 -- A protest against the Bratton 5 per cent economy amendment was made today by William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, just before the conferences on the Treasury-Postoffice bill adjourned without reaching any agreement over this feature.

HAVANA, Feb. 14 -- Fear by the government that an insurrection against the Machado regime is imminent brought about a series of raids yesterday and today in which hundreds of homes were searched for arms, and some seventy persons were arrested and lodged In Principe Fortress here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The War Department Issued these orders today:

The importance of continuing character education among public school children in the United States was emphasized yesterday by Dr. Francis W. Kirkham, educator and director of the National Child Welfare Association, at the annual meeting of the association at its headquarters, 70 Fifth Avenue.

Mayor O'Brien announced last night the appointment of an advisory committee on city planning headed by George McAneny, president of the Regional Plan Association, which is to cooperate with city engineers in laying out a master plan for the harmonious development of the city.

While I am in substantial agreement with the greater part of the committee's report, this supplementary memorandum states my conclusions in my own language, placing the emphasis where I think it belongs.

A Communist demonstration at the Emergency Home Relief Bureau in Public School 51. 519 West Forty-fourth Street, resulted yesterday in the early dismissal of 1.200 school children, the routing of 100 Communists, the arrest of five persons and injuries to two others.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla.. Feb. 14 (AP) -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, here seeking to break his own world land speed record of 253 miles an hour. flashed over the ocean beach at a speed of 212.63 miles an hour on a two-kSlometer route here late today on the first of a series of test runs in his Bluebird racing car.

The New York Central Lines were estimated unofficially yesterday to have incurred a deficit of about $2,500,000 after charges in January, against $1,564,707 deficit in January, 1931. Railroads which reported net losses for 1932 included the Delaware, Lackawanna Western; the Chicago, St. Paul, Minneapoils Omaha, Great Northern, Central of Georgia, Missouri Pacific, Northern Pacific and Western Pacific.

Only ten lines long was the item that recorded in yesterday's TIMES the successful towing of WILLY FARNER and 110 pounds of mail through the air over the Alps from Zurich to Milan. Yet it may mark another stage in the evolution of aerial transportation.

A curly-haired, chubby-faced policeman, Who admitted he was a grafter "like every other policeman," gave his explanation in Kings County Court yesterday of the shake-down methods which he said policemen used to extract tolls from beer-runners passing through their "beats."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President Hoover issued a proclamation today, calling the Senate of the Seventy-third Congress into special session to inaugurate the next Vice President, confirm President-elect Roosevelt's Cabinet and act on other nominations.
To the Editor of The New York Times : Accept my hearty congratulations on your editorial "Lincoln and the Veterans."

Investigations were begun yesterday by the District Attorney and the Commissioner of Correction to determine the responsibility for the outbreak at the Brooklyn City prison just before midnight Monday, which resulted in serious injury to one prisoner and in general disorder throughout the institution, involving more than 500 prisoners.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Any discrimination between aliens and citizens in the administration of home relief was opposed today by Miss Mary Gibbons, director of the Home Relief Bureau in New York, in testifying before the Senate Finance Committee.

WHITE PLAINS N.Y., Feb. 14 -- Historic St. Paul's Episcopal Church at East Chester, Mount Vernon, its vestry, rector and wardens, including Curtis B. Dall, son-in-law of President-elect Franklin D.
