Roosevelt, senior warden, were criticized in Supreme Court here this morning for their failure to permit modern tombstones in the old church graveyard, which dates from 1665, when the church was founded.

Unsettling developments which sent security prices lower also depressed prices in local commodity markets yesterday, abruptly terminating recent rallies in some of them. The one exception to the day's movements was silver, the futures contracts for which closed higher, in sympathy with the rally in the spot markets.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Japan's contention that her threatened resignation from the League of Nations would not affect her possession of the mandated Pacific islands north of the Equator Is considered in London as untenable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Cotton, consumed during January was reported today by the Census Bureau to have totaled 471,202 bales of lint and 48,412 of linters, compared with 440,062 and 44,275 in December last and 434,726 and 51,635 in January last year.

DETROIT, Feb. 14. -- With the exception of a few banks in the Upper Peninsula, all banks in Michigan were closed today following Governor William A. Comstock's early morning proclamation declaring an eight-day moratorium for the State's 550 financial institutions.
St. John's College registered its sixteenth victory of the season when it turned back the Canisius College quintet, 49 to 26, in the Degray gymnasium in Brooklyn last night.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Mrs. James P. Donahue entertained tonight with a St. Valentine's dinner at the penthouse at Whitehall which she is occupying this Winter, taking her guests later to the Colony Club for dancing.

Ernie Schaaf, the young Boston heavyweight who collapsed under the mighty blows of Primo Camera in a prizefight at Madison Square Garden Friday night before 20,000 fans, many shouting "faker," died yesterday in Polyclinic Hospital.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- Flashing over the rails at sixty-five miles an hour, the first Diesel electric train ever used on an English main line had a successful trial today on the 113-mile run from London to Birmingham.

PEIPING, Feb. 14 -- Learning that the disastrous earthquake in the Kaotai district of Kansu Province had also seriously affected Ansichow, 300 miles northwestward, as well as Kanchow, about 50 miles southeast of Kaotai, and other points, such as Yumen and Suchow, the China International Famine Relief Commission has initiated guryeys on the possibilities of extending relief.

LONDON, Feb. 14 -- The Coliseum Theatre's wonderful revolving stage, on which world-famous vaudeville performers have played for the last twenty-four years, will be hidden behind a movie screen after March 6, Sir Oswald Stoll announced tonight.

News that Michigan had entered upon an eight-day bank holiday had a depressing effect upon the security markets yesterday. Bonds lost from 1 to 6 points and stocks 1 to 4 3/4 points under moderately heavy liquidation.

The rather urgent business of affixing signatures to Yankee contracts became somewhat less acute yesterday when Secretary Ed Barrow announced that four members of the world's champions had come into the fold.

Leases by apparel retailers and wholesalers featured the Manhattan rentals reported yesterday. Most of the space taken is in the midtown area. Leases in the Bronx and other parts of the metropolitan zone also were reported.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, recognized as heavyweight wrestling champion in this State, successfully defended his title against Sammy Stein of Newark last night at the New York Coliseum. A crowd numbering 5,000 saw the Kentuckian pin his rival's shoulders with an arm scissors and wrist lock after 47:11.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday amounted to 1,542,000 shares, or more than twice those on the last five-hour day of the previous week. The turnover was the second largest of the year to date. The decline, measured by the price averages, was the widest since the third week in October.

After being adjudged "obscene" by United States Customs authorities and detained four days at the New York Custom House, a series of pictures of Michelangelo's frescoes on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican at Rome were released late yesterday afternoon by Assistant Customs Solicitor George N. Brewer and the consignees notified to come and get them.

With economy as a watchword, the elections of school officials and the adoption of school budgets were voted last night in towns and villages throughout New Jersey. The activities of civic associations and taxpayers, which had backed independent candidates in many instances, were felt in almost every community.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained at dinner tonight in honor of the Chief Justice of the Supreme Court and Mrs. Hughes and the associate justices and their wives, including Justice McReynolds, Justice and Mrs. Butler, Justice and Mrs. Stone, Justice and Mrs. Roberts and Justice Cardozo.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Indications pointed tonight to the employment of every available resource of the Federal Government to assist in meeting the Michigan banking situation.
Several flats and a meadow tract were included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The world champion Toronto Maple Leafs, playing their last game of the regular National League hockey season at the Boston Garden, tonight were overwhelmed, 7-2, by the Boston Bruins. It has been four years since the blue and white-shirted players have won a game on this surface.

The valuations upon which the Transit Commission based its tentative $474,500,000 unification plan of December, 1931, have been revised in accord with subsequent price declines, and a new revision is now being started to bring them down to June 30, 1932, the commission discloses in its annual report for 1932, submitted yesterday to Governor Lehman and the Legislature.

An attempt to revise the operating methods and price calculations of the knitted outerwear industry so that mills may operate at a profit under present conditions was started yesterday at the opening of the annual convention of the National Knitted Outerwear Association at the Grand Central Palace, when the executive committee decided to appoint a committee to prepare a broad program of revisions.

A statement by the prosecutor that he had found no evidence of fraud or deceit by Dr. William H. Walker, brother of the former Mayor, and four other physicians, accused of fee-splitting in compensation cases, threw their trial before a medical research grievance committee of the State Board of Regents yesterday into confusion and resulted in the exclusion of the physicians and the audience, including reporters.

ALBANY, Feb. 14. -- Governor Lehman's executive budget came to the fore today in developments at the Capitol. It furnished the topic of discussion, at a conference of the Republican Assemblymen which at some stages became stormy, as the members of the lower house, perturbed by pressure from the "folks at home," made insistent demands for further budget cuts.

BERLIN, Feb. 14 -- The Boerse was quiet today. Stocks fluctuated feebly on small transactions and the tendency, on the whole, was lower. Price changes generally were small and rather irregular. Harpener closed 1 point higher and Rheinbraunkohle 1 point lower than yesterday.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,025,000 barrels, compared with 2,028,250 in the preceding week, a decline of 3,250 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. An increase of 8,000 barrels daily in California and a decline of 13,050 in Oklahoma were among the most important changes of the week.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 14. -- A determined dry filibuster in the Senate against a vote even to take up the Blaine resolution for modified repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was checked late tonight after an eight-hour speech by Senator Sheppard on the League of Nations.

Federal Judge Knox decided yesterday to permit the taking of testimony from Francis C. Schwab, co-defendant with Cross Brown, New York real estate brokers, in a suit brought by the Newark Plaster Company for the recovery of commissions paid for the leasing of property owned by the plaintiff in Kearny, N.J.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Dr. Raymond Leslie Buell, research director of the Foreign Policy Association, declared that "so long as the United States continues its anti-French policy there is little hope of international economic recovery" in an address here tonight before the School of Public and International Affairs of Princeton University.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Favorable committee action on proposals for revision of the alimony laws was indicated tonight after a hearing on a series of measures before a joint session of the Senate and Assembly Codes Committee.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 -- With faces distorted with rage and voices hoarse, two of the Long brothers called each other "liar" today before the Senate committee investigating charges of fraud in the Overton-Broussard Senatorial primary.

MONTREAL, Que., Feb. 14 -- Nearly $3,000,000,000 of assurance in force at the end of last year and 95,122 new policies paid for during 1932 for a net amount of $284,098,930 were shown in the report of the Sun Life Assurance Company of Canada for 1932 presented today at the annual general meeting of the company.
ROCHESTER. N.Y.. Feb. 14 -- Max Morris, a physician of Irondequoit, filed a petition In bankruptcy today, listing liabilities at $298,616.44: assets, $250, and secured claims $284,300.

Recent archaeological discoveries in China definitely establish for the first time that the civilization of the Yellow River Valley is from 1,000 to 2,000 years later than the civilizations of the Nile, Euphrates and Indus Rivers, the Shanghai Tiffin Club was told yesterday by L.C. Goodrich, lecturer on Chinese language and history at Columbia University, at a meeting in the George Washington Hotel, Lexington Avenue and Twenty-third Street.

LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 14 (AP) -- Craig Wood's dazzling back-nine drive, four under par after he had needed one better than perfect figures to negotiate the first nine, today placed the Deal (N.J.) professional in the lead for the first round of the Orange Blossom open golf tournament.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Samuel A. Ettelson, former corporation counsel, won his fight today to have Calvin Fentress disqualified as trustee of the bankrupt Insull Utility Investments, Inc., on the ground that he was the nominee of Samuel Insull and his former bankers.

Mayor O'Brien took a flat stand against borrowing money from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to complete the Triborough Bridge or to finance any other city project when such loans were suggested yesterday at the meeting of the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate.

While the first trial growing out of charges of irregularities in the election last November got under way yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox, the Federal grand jury handed up another indictment, naming five more election officials, one of whom served as a Deputy State Attorney General, and two of whom are women.

BASLE, Feb. 14 -- The Bank for International Settlements announced today that the board had unanimously elected Leon Fraser of the United States to succeed Gates W. McGarrah as president, when the latter retires in May. Mr. McGarrah, who refused reelection, was named honorary president and remains a member of the board as long as he resides in Europe.

The Booth Theatre has been booked for "Our Wife," a comedy by Lyon Mearson and Lillian Day (Mr. and Mrs. Mearson), which will open Thursday evening. March 2. Among those in the cast will be June Walker, Humphrey Bogart, Rose Hobart, Miriam Battista, Flavia Arcaro and Edward Raquello.

To ihe Editor of The New York Times: A grave situation confronts retail stores in the State of New York. If the retail sales tax as suggested by the Mastick committee becomes a law, many stores will be forced to the wall. The taxation is class legislation, imposing a heavy burden upon these stores while laying no tax on other forms of financial, industrial and professional services.

TRENTON, N. J., Feb. 14. -- Following receipt of a letter from Mayor Frank Hague of New Jersey suggesting a two-year moratorium on mortgage foreclosures, Governor A. Harry Moore announced tonight that he would "shortly issue a plea to mortgage holders" to adopt the suggestion.

A move on the part of State and National Republican leaders apparently to force complete reorganization of the Republican organization in New York County became known yesterday. The movement, it is assumed, has as part of its purpose the ousting of Samuel S. Koenig as county leader, a post he has held for twenty-one years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Senator Thomas of Oklahoma, known as one of the severest critics of "Wall Street" and a strong supporter of inflation, turned his back on Congress today to seek the aid of "the Street" in checking deflation.
BOGOTA, Colombia (Wednesday) Feb. 15 (AP) -- The government today ordered Fablo Lozano Jr., the Colombian Minister at Lima, Peru, to demand passports for his departure from that country.

Elihu Root, dean of America's "elder statesmen," will be 88 years old today. He will observe his birthday quietly at his apartment at 998 Fifth Avenue. This evening there will be a small family gathering for dinner.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Don Leon, the 5-year-old son of Lee O. Cotner, trained and owned by R.W. Collins, scored a victory at Hialeah Park today which was almost as decisive as the one he chalked up in his previous start. The margin was four lengths as against five when he ran ten days ago.

GENEVA, Feb. 14 -- The Foreign Ministers of the Little Entente, after their first meeting here this evening, announced officially that they were engaged in "elaborating the pact of organization of the Littie Entente, allowing it to act as a unified International organ."

NEUNKIRCHEN, Saar Basin Territory, Feb. 14 -- The victims of the explosion of a gas tank last Friday were buried today. Thousands of persons slowly passed the long row of sixty-two coffins on fifteen black-draped carriages lined up at the lower market to pay their last tribute.

The Board of Estimate approved yesterday, in executive session, a subway construction program for 1933 calling, according to reliable reports, for the expenditure of approximately $9,500,000. Mayor O'Brien declined to discuss the board's action, but indicated that the details of the program would be revealed in an address which he would deliver today at a luncheon of the Merchants Association in the Hotel Astor.
Joseph P. Golden, Walter D. Maroney and F. Beal are with Appenzellar. Alien Hill.

Three women who have won national championships sent in their entries yesterday for the American track and field championships at Madison Square Garden Saturday, Feb. 25, in the afternoon prior to the men's title meet there at night. Two of them are present titleholders and one is a former ruler.

Funds handled by trust institutions during the depression have been better safeguarded and better conserved than most other investments, according to speakers at the opening yesterday in the Waldorf-Astoria of the fourteenth mid-winter trust conference of the American Bankers Association Trust Division.

With the announcement of approval of the Brooklyn-Staten Island bridge bill by the House Interstate Commerce Committee, officials of the Interborough Bridge Company were hopeful yesterday of being able to start work on the five-year-old project the latter part of this year.

OTTAWA, Feb. 14 -- The New York Rangers tied the Detroit Red Wings for first place in the American section of the National Hookey League by taking a 3-1 decision from the Ottawa Senators tonight. The loss pushed the Senators into a tie with the Canadiens for last place in the International section.

Snug-fitting high-back crowns with small brims in fabrics, shiny and dull straws and straw fabrics were featured at the Spring showing of hats held by the Retail Millinery Association of America last night at the Hotel Astor. About 800 persons attended.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 14 -- The Harvard Corporation has taken definite steps to end misunderstandings arising from the patenting of such inventions as the Drinker respirator, or "artificial lung," it was announced today.
Holders of mortgages on fifteen Manhattan and Bronx properties bought in the properties at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Most of the parcels were tenement houses. One sale was postponed.
The text of the report of the National Transportation Committee follows:

A plan now being considered In New Jersey by which a consolidation of the Fish and Game Commission with the State Conservation Department would be effected has aroused a great deal of interest. The Conservation Department in the past has not had any active part in the work of the Fish and Game Commission, though in most States the fish and game divisions are part of the Conservation Department.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 14 -- Yale increased its lead in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race tonight by defeating Princeton, 32 to 30. The score was tied seven times during the game.

Definite decisions on the appointments to be made by the Roosevelt administration have not yet been reached, James A. Farley, Democratic State and National Chairman, said yesterday upon his return here from a two-week stay in the South.

New York City's fiscal affairs seem to be getting the attention they deserve at Albany. Governor LEHMAN'S emergency message makes it certain that no shadow of doubt can be cast upon the legality of the efforts of city officials to "recall, reopen, reconsider and reduce " the budget.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- What is said to be one of the first serious attempts by medical men to peer into the mysteries of the ills of the ancient Egyptians through the use of the X-ray is being pursued in the museum of the University of Pennsylvania.
Dance of the Years. From the powers presding over A Century of Progress, which is the official name of the 1933 Chicago "World's Fair, comes a bulletin in which reminiscence is blended with promise.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 14 (AP) -- James H. Rand Jr. of New York, president of the Remington-Rand Corporation, advocated before a Senate committee today the setting up of a central industrial corporation to handle paper that could be rediscounted by the Federal Reserve Banks.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 14 (AP) -- W.T. Waggoner's Texas-owned Three D's Stock Farm, none too successful this Winter, sent out Trinchera, a gelded son of Eternal, and captured the 6-furlong St. Valentine's Handicap at the Fair Grounds today.

ALBANY, Feb. 14 -- Governor Lehrran today signed the bill passed by the Legislature last night, to insure the validity of Mayor O'Brien's budget cuts by extending, to Feb. 25. the period for readjustment of the budget.

Informed yesterday by Dr. William Scliroeder Jr., chairman of the Sanitary Commission, that the coat of removing the Jast snowfall was estimated at $2,089,995, the Board of Estimate in special meeting voted an appropriation of, $2,000,000 in special revenue bonds to meet the deficit in the snow-removal funds.

DETROIT, Feb. 14 (AP) -- The Detroit Free Press in a copyrighted article says that conflict between Senator James Couzens of Michigan and Henry Ford, former partners in the Ford Motor Company, is reflected in the difficulties which precipitated Michigan's banking holiday.

Despite declines in all other classifications, the number of retail failures showed an increase during the week ended Feb. 9, according to Bradstreet's. The store defaults totaled 376, against 353 in the preceding week. The total number of failures was 509, which compares with 567 in the previous week.

Three men were severely burned about their faces and necks when acid was hurled at them by an unidentified man in front of 252 West Thirty-eighth Street yesterday afternoon, in a fresh outbreak laid to ''racketeering" among the wholesale garment workers.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. .1 1/4 per cent for the best names Monday....Legal holiday The quotation is for three-four months' paper.

Developments in financial circles depressed prices on the Cotton Exchange yesterday. At one time July touched 6 cents a pound, or within 2 points of last week's low mark, and $2 a bale below the high figures of Saturday, but the market met resistance and a 15-point rally in the last hour left the list with losses of to 7 to 14 points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Rehabilitation of agriculture and labor through enactment of legislation declaring the existence of a national emergency was sought in a bill introduced in the House today by Representative Parsons of Illinois.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The chief danger in the clash between Colombia and Peru, as envisaged here, is that it might develop into larger operations and then spread by drawing in Ecuador and possibly Brazil, both of which have territorial interests in the region.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Emergency aid for the farmer and small home owner facing foreclosure reached the Senate calendar today while a renewed clamor for farm relief this session was heard in committee and on the floor.

GENEVA, Feb. 14 -- The League of Nations Committee of Nineteen unanimously approved tonight the report condemning Japan and recommending what the parties to the Manchurian dispute and the rest of the world, ought to do for solution of the Chino-Japanese conflict.

CHICAGO, Feb. 14 -- Weakness in stocks and the banking situation in Michigan were responsible today for a lower range of prices for wheat on the Board of Trade here. Despite buying by holders of bids and on resting orders by commission houses, the close was at the bottom, with net losses of 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel.

Preservation of the Times Square area, as the amusement centre of the city, through immediate lifting of traffic restrictions and future regulation of legal liquor sales, were discussed at a luncheon meeting of the directors of the Broadway Association yesterday in the Hotel Astor.

BRISBANE, Australia, Wednesday, Feb. 15 -- England started its second innings of the fourth cricket test match today needing only 160 runs to win, after taking Australia for a second innings total of 175. Victory in this game will give England the series.
HAVANA, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Gilbert Elston, twice injured last year, scored with Mose Goldblatt's Town Limit in the six-furlong feature at Oriental Park today.

ELIZABETH, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Simon Spitalny of 400 Linden Avenue, treasurer of the Superior Products Corporation of Linden, manufacturer of toilet accessories, died this morning at his home after an illness of three months. Mr. Spitalny was born in Russia seventy years ago.

General improvement in business and industrial conditions before the end of this year was predicted at yesterday's sessions of the conventions of the American Paper and Pulp Association and affiliated associations and the National Paper Trade Association of the United States at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

If friends and admirers the world over had not reminded her with their gifts and flowers, telegrams and cable messages, that began reaching the famous singer's home in New York last night, then Mme. Marcella Sembrich herself might have gone about her many musical activities, and especially her plans to assist in saving the Metropolitan Opera, on which she is eagerly engaged, without letting it be known that today is her birthday.

Far Eastern Developments. SHANGHAI -- Japan has drafted ultimatums demanding the withdrawal of Chinese troops from Jehol. Acting Premier Soong said China would reject them and defend her sovereignty. Opposition by the Chinese is expected to bring a speedy invasion.

Charles Miller, 45 years old, a tailor, of 412 East 143d Street, the Bronx, who the police say has been arrested eleven times for picking pockets, was held for a hearing Friday when arraigned yesterday before Magistrate Renaud in West Side Court charged with attempted grand larceny.
"One Sunday Afternoon," a new play by James Hagan, described as a romantic drama-comedy, will open tonight at the Little Theatre.

Jose Iturbi, who played last night in Carnegie Hall, pursued the interesting plan of offering in succession three sonatas and one sonatina, the sonatas by Mozart, Beethoven and Chopin successively, the sonatina the charming work of Ravel.

Members of the National Electric Light Association will meet at 10 A.M. today in the Hotel Biltmore to vote upon dissolution of the organization, as the Edison Electric Institute has been formed to take the place of other trade associations of the electric light and power industry.
TOKYO, Feb. 14 -- The present situation here is akin to that preceding recognition of Manchukuo last September, with the government's silence interpreted to mean uncertainty.

Weary members of the Board of Estimate who adjourned their meeting at 7 o'clock last night made no secret of their annoyance over Mayor O'Brien's lateness in starting the meetings and his apparent policy of holding the board in session until after the dinner hour.

"Democracy," said CHESTERTON, "does not champion educating a "man because he is miserable, but "because he is so sublime." It does not object so much to the ordinary man's" being a slave as to his not being a king." Democracy, is, indeed, ever " dreaming of a nation of kings" -- men capable of holding pre-eminent position or giving pre-eminent service.

After having written as many as a hundred letters to various government officials in Washington without receiving satisfaction regarding his claim for $30,382 for installing a lighting system on the Statue of Liberty, Joseph Schoenbach, an electrical contractor of 834 Sutter Avenue, Brooklyn, prepared yesterday to forward his bill to the White House.

The National Orchestral Association, Leon Barzin conductor, was assisted by Alfred Wallenstein, cellist, when it performed yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall. The occasion was also signalized by the first performance anywhere of Nicolai Berezowsky's "Fantasie" for two pianos and orchestra.

Between the final canvass of the Mayoralty election, completed on Nov. 30 and Jan. 30, the date the Board of Elections submitted its report for 1032 to Secretary of State Flynn. the vote shown for Joseph V. McKee for Mayor mounted once more, this time by 368, the board's report, made public yesterday, shows.

NASHVILLE. FEB. 14 Joseph I. Reece, former Commissioner of Insurence and Banking of Tennessee and one-time dean of Carson Newman college at Jofferson City. Tenn., pleaded not guilty on charges including grand lareeny at his preliminary hearing today, and was held in the Davidson county jail in default of $20.000 bond.

The plans of the Department of Labor to combat racketeers who are exploiting ignorant immigrants were put under, way yesterday when representatives of nine foreign groups, representing 2,000,000 persons, met with Immigration Commissioner Edward Corsi at his office on Ellis Island.

BERLIN, Feb. 14. -- President von Hindenburg signed today a decree suspending all enforced sales by court order of farms and personal property connected with them throughout Germany until Oct. 31. Only if a farmer brought about his financial difficulties through his own negligence may a creditor apply for permission to institute foreclosure or execution proceedings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Bear Admiral Hoogewerff, World War commander of the first battleship division of the Atlantic fleet, was born In Howard County, Md., on Nov. 27, 1860. and was appointed to the Naval Academy by President Hayes in 1877. During the Spanish-American War he served on the Cincinnati of the North Atlantic Squadron, engaged in blockading Cuban ports, and participated in the engagement at Matanzas, Cuba.

The committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate approved yesterday the allotment of $64,860 for emergency workers in the Hospital and Sanitation Departments for February. The money is to come from the city's share of the loan obtained by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Suggestions by President Hoover in his address in New York last night that part of the war-debt payments received by the United States from foreign nations might be used in international financial transactions that would assist countries with depreciated currencies to stabilize them attracted much attention here today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 14 -- Miss Diana Fishwick, former women's British golf champion, achieved the easiest victory of the first match round in the championship of Florida on the Palm Beach Country Club course today, defeating Mrs. H. C. Kersten of Richmond, the Virginia titleholder, 8 and 7.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- The entire credit structure of the country, including that of the National Government, will collapse unless the Federal budget is balanced to restore confidence and unless Federal aid to industry is continued and more money put into circulation through bimetallism, the Senate committee inquiring into economic conditions was told today by Dr. Herman F. Arendtz, Boston economist.

DENVER, Feb. 14 (AP) -- Police seeking the kidnappers of Charles Boettcher 2d reported tonight that another prominent man had been threatened and that a new ransom note had been received by Mr. Boettcher's father.

It is easy to understand why members of Congress, especially Senators, should wonder why such big waves of unpopularity are breaking over them. They admit the fact, but do not know how to explain, it. Are they not bearing themselves much as usual?
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 14 -- Three English players and one American are survivors tonight in the Atlantic Coast women's squash racquets championship tournament.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was made the target last night of good-natured gibes, in song and skit, by members of the Women's Trade Union League, In which she has been interested for the last ten years. As guest of honor at an entertainment in the league's headquarters, 247 Lexington Avenue, Mrs. Roosevelt seemed greatly amused as the entertainer burlesqued her pending career as the First Lady of the land.

Sallee Louise Dalton died last night. For more than a year and a half she had made as gallant a fight against infantile paralysis and resultant complications as had ever been seen by physicians and nurses of Kings County Hospital, Brooklyn.

Protection having failed so egregiously to produce the promised flood of prosperity, its devotees turn to it again as a breakwater against an imaginary flood of imports. Mr. ROBERT L. O'BRIEN, chairman of the Tariff Commission by Mr. HOOVER'S appointment, is a sound Republican and a sane protectionist.

While a number of last year's famous winners successfully defended their honors in the second day's judging at the Westminster Kennel Club Dog Show in Madison Square Garden yesterday, there were a number of notable upsets.

An educational Institution today must be just as willing to learn as an individual student or it is "doomed to die," Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, declared yesterday in his address opening the Spring session at Barnard College.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 14 -- President-elect Roosevelt will end his fishing cruise tomorrow and will leave here at night for New York to take up the many problems facing him, one of the most immediate in importance being a talk with Senator Carter Glass of Virginia, to whom he has offered the appointment of Secretary of the Treasury.

New York City banks took steps yesterday to avert a currency shortage in Detroit by shipping large amounts of money to their commercial customers in that city. Faced with the tying-up of their deposits by the eight-day banking "holiday" declared in Michigan, Detroit automobile companies and other business concerns drew upon their New York banking connections for currency with which to meet payroll requirements.

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., Feb. 14 -- Seven, airplanes, Including four amphibions, were wrecked by fire here this afternoon when a blaze destroyed one of the recently constructed brick hangars on the north side of the field. Damage was estimated at $500,000.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- President Hoover's New York speech last night and Prime Minister MacDonald's statement in the House of Commons that the British Government had assented to discussion of world economic problems in Washington side by side with debts have given a new angle to the debt problem, which as far as France is concerned, has been deadlocked since Premier Herriot's defeat on Dec. 13.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation apparently has failed to reconstruct business by large-scale lending of Federal funds, and now Fred I. Kent brings forth in THE TIMES a new plan for loaning and subsidizing back to normal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Questioning of Samuel Insull Jr. by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee tomorrow will open that committee's public study of the collapse of the Insull "utilities empire" as a new phase of the Senate stock market inquiry.

PARIS, Feb. 14 -- President Hoover's New York speech last night and Prime Minister MacDonald's statement in the House of Commons that the British Government had assented to discussion of world economic problems in Washington side by side with debts have given a new angle to the debt problem, which as far as France is concerned, has been deadlocked since Premier Herriot's defeat on Dec. 13.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 14 -- An aerial battle, presumably over Brazilian soil, took place near Leticia today in the first clash of military forces in the dispute between Colombia and Peru.

Foreign central banks earmarked yesterday $11,011,300 more gold at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, bringing to $79,273,200 the total since the first of the year. The identity of the bank or banks concerned in the "special transaction" was again not disclosed.

La Salle Academy and St. Ann's Academy triumphed in games played yesterday in the Manhattan division of the C.H.S.A.A. championship basketball tournament. La Salle conquered Iona School of New Rochelle, 31 to 15, at Goddard gymnasium and St. Ann's defeated All Hallows Institute, 21 to 8, at the East Fifty-fourth Street gymnasium.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Reconstruction Finance Corporation apparently has failed to reconstruct business by large-scale lending of Federal funds, and now Fred I. Kent brings forth in THE TIMES a new plan for loaning and subsidizing back to normal.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 14 -- Questioning of Samuel Insull Jr. by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee tomorrow will open that committee's public study of the collapse of the Insull "utilities empire" as a new phase of the Senate stock market inquiry.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The process of forcibly converting republican Germany through the coming election into a National Socialist State in which opposition will be eliminated as completely as it is in Fascist Italy is proceeding at a pace that leaves many onlookers amazed and aghast.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 15. -- Playing its best game of the season, Harvard's varsity basketball team upset a favored M.I.T. quintet, 28 -- 20, in the Tech hangar gymnasium tonight. It was Harvard's second victory of the campaign against five defeats.

Although eight of the nine regulars who are expected to be in the line-up when the Yankees open the championship season eight weeks hence have yet to sign their contracts. Secretary Ed Barrow yesterday indicated in a number of ways that the world's champions will not delay their program.

Although the usual result of inflation is to make prices rise, none of the projects that have so far been submitted in Washington would have that effect, according to Colonel Leonard P. Ayres, in the Cleveland Trust Company Bulletin. He lists, as follows, several reasons for the difficulties of evolving a plan that would lift prices:

The creative spirit in the education of the blind in America died with Samuel Gridley Howe in 1872, and if Howe could come back now "he would be the first to apply the torch to much of his own construction." Dr. Thomas Darl Cutsworth writes in "The Blind in School and Society," published this week by Appleton.

Morris Abrams, secretary of Representative Samuel Dickstein, who recently demanded a Congressional investigation of Federal Attorney Medalie's conduct of the election fraud inquiry, refused yesterday to answer questions before a Federal grand jury on the ground that to do so might "tend to incriminate" him, and was sentenced to serve sixty days in the Federal House of Detention for contempt of court.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., Feb. 15. -- An extortionist forced his way this afternoon into the home of R. Crosby Kemper, president of the City Bank and Trust Company, and under threat of killing Sally Ann Kemper, an 11-year-old daughter, demanded the payment of $15,000.

Minimum wage legislation will be the only effective means of maintaining industrial standards during economic depressions, Miss Nell Schwartz, member of the workmen's compensation board of the State Department of Labor, declared yesterday at the opening budget campaign luncheon of the League of Women Voters in the Fraternity Clubs Building, 22 East Thirty-eighth Street.

Foreign exchanges moved against the dollar yesterday as European centres reflected the news of the Michigan "bank holiday." Francs advanced 13/18 point to 3.91 5/8 cents, the best price since Jan. 4; guilders rallied 5 1/2 points to 40.14 cents, belgas were up 1 point to 13.93 cents and Swiss francs gained 1/2 point to 19.28 cents.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt was addressing 800 members and guests of the Warner Club, made up of employes of Warner Brothers Pictures, Inc., and affiliated companies, in the clubrooms at 321 West Forty-fourth Street last night when the President-elect was fired upon in Miami.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Charges that political pressure had been exerted to prevent a proper investigation of the Wilson-Roberts case in 1929 stirred Burlington County today and brought an announcement from Governor Moore at Trenton that he had received complaints from several persons interested in reopening the inquiry.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 15. -- Twenty-four persons were wounded, including fourteen women and an army Major, when troops used bayonets and rifle butts this evening to disperse a crowd trying to carry food to 4,000 striking railroad workers, barricaded in the workshops here.

TOLEDO, Feb. 15 (AP). -- The bill of complaint in the Willys-Overland receivership set up that the company had current obligations of $1,500,000 and funded debt of $2,000,000 of which $1,000,000 was in default as of last September.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- More than half of America's public debt of $20,907,000,000 matures or is callable this year and must be dealt with by the new administration. Figures at the Treasury today showed that $11,349,700,000 of the debt matures or may be called in the next eleven months.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Swimming without the services of Walter Spence, who is ill, Rutgers defeated New York University in a dual meet tonight, 43 to 28. The visitors took first places in three of the eight events, but were outclassed in the sprints and the relays.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- The Public Service Commission wants a law enacted which would require gas and electric companies, at stated intervals, to give credit to consumers on their bills for interest at 6 per cent on deposits they have made with the companies prior to the instalment of meters.

The American Railway Association announced yesterday that its members proposed to reduce the mileage rate paid on cars owned by private companies from 2 cents to 1 3/4 cents. The move was described as an attempt by the railroads to offset declines in income incurred in recent years.

Plans for reorganization of the Consolidated Investment Corporation of Canada will be presented to holders of its thirty-year first collateral trust 4 1/2 per cent gold bonds at a special meeting in Montreal on March 22. The corporation, a general management Investment trust, has assets of approximately $20,000,000, which are to be taken over by a company to be known as United Corporations, Ltd.

MIAMI, Feb. 15. -- Surrounded by detectives and high police officials, the man who shot at Presidentelect Roosevelt tonight gave his name as Joe Zingara of New York and related, in spasms of words during questioning at Police Headquarters, how "constant torment from a stomach operation" had impelled him to attempt the life of the President-elect.

THE Toronto Maple Leafs, holders of the Stanley Cup, will try to do some speedy and fancy skating at the Garden this evening. Lester Patrick's Rangers will appear in rebuttal. The Rangers are jammed with the astonishing Red Wings of Detroit in the lead in the American Group on ice, with the Boston Bruins, as Mr. Patrick puts it, "breathing on the back of our necks."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Urging an informal league in hockey among Princeton, Dartmouth, Harvard and Yale, because of the success achieved by the Eastern intercollegiate leagues in basketball and baseball, The Yale Daily News said editorially today:

Oscar Merrill Hartzell, former candidate for Sheriff of Des Moines, Iowa, who was deported from England on Feb. 7 as an undesirable alien, because he bad promoted a ten-year search for the mythical estate of Sir Francis Drake, is to be arrested when he arrives here today on the French liner Champlain.

The City Affairs Committee, in a letter addressed to Attorney General Bennett yesterday and signed by John Haynes Holmes, chairman, and Dr. Stephen S. Wise, vice chairman of the committee, asked the replacement of Sol Ullman, Assistant State Attorney General, as prosecutor in the trial of Dr. William H. Walker and others before a medical grievance committee of the State Board of Regents.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Mrs. Hoover was the honor guest today of the Women's National Press Club at a luncheon at the Willard. A leather writing case, bearing her monogram in gold, and a fountain pen were presented to her as a parting gift.

Stream pollution has become a vexing subject in many States and in several of them measures have been drafted to prevent a continuation of manufacturing enterprises along rivers from which conies a great deal of the contamination. This kills great numbers of fish and eventually ruins good fishing grounds.

The work of providing adequate health measures and medical care for the children in Palestine, which has been conducted by Hadassah, the Women's Zionist Organization of America, was brought to the attention of shoppers yesterday, who contributed to the welfare fund of the New York chapter of the organization by making purchases in Hearn's department store on Fourteenth Street.

Final adoption of the revised 1933 budget at a total of 18 per cent below that of the 1932 budget and announcement of a cut of $1,195,006,742 in assessed valuations of city real estate, personal property and franchises provided yesterday a substantial basis for belief that the basic tax rate this year will be appreciably lower than the 1932 rate of $2.59 per $100 of assessed valuation.

The first step to protect society against the tragedy arising from depressions is to place upon the statute books this 'Winter a compulsory unemployment insurance law, according to Howard S. Cullman, chairman of the New York Conference for Unemployment Insurance Legislation, in an address over station WEAF last night.

Completing his Journey from the mid-West to take up his new duties as head football coach at Fordham University, James H. Crowley arrived in New York yesterday from Lansing, Mich., where for the past four years he has directed the gridiron destinies of Michigan State College.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The nation's capital was deeply shocked tonight on hearing of the attempt on the life of President-elect Roosevelt.

MIAMI, Thursday, Feb. 16. -- Mayor Cermak was shot in the right side, just below the ribs, and was in a critical condition at Jackson Memorial Hospital. An X-ray showed the bullet lodged in the back of the abdomen.

News of the Miami shooting, spread by newspaper headlines, electric light bulletins and radio, created great excitement here. It provoked as much comment from the "forgotten man" who wandered through Times Square as from the leaders of the nation.

What is needed to stimulate business is expansion of credit and not inflation of currency, Representative Carroll L. Beedy of Maine told members of the National Paper Trade Association yesterday at the closing session of a three-day convention in the Hotel Pennsylvania.
Making its final home stand of the season, Fordham's basketball quintet gained a 27-26 triumph over Rider College of Trenton, N.J., in the Maroon gymnasium last night.

Owen R. Lovejoy, secretary of the Children's Aid Society, in a letter yesterday to Senators Costigan, La Follette and Cutting, expressed "amazement" the action of the Senate in deciding to care for transient boys now roaming the country by placing them in Citizens Military Training Camps, under the supervision of the War Department.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- A plan designed to restore beer at a nickel a glass, while continuing the banishment of the saloon and attendant evils, in the event that Congress modifies the Volstead act, was recommended today to Governor Lehman and the Legislature by the State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Control Legislation.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Holding on to an early lead, Cornell defeated Dartmouth, 38 to 35, in an Eastern intercollegiate basketball league game tonight. It was Cornell's first victory in six games. Ferraro led the Ithacans with five goals and three fouls for 13 points.

Except for the suggestion that a "single national" railroad system be formed, railroad officials found much of practical value yesterday in the report on railroads and transportation issued on Tuesday by the National Transportation Committee.

The New York University Student Senate ordered last night the suspension from further publication until March 6 of The New York University Daily News, student publication. The action was taken after four and a half hours' consideration of charges against the paper, which included those of "disloyalty to the university," "attacking a member of the faculty" and "deletion of vital points in a letter of a faculty member to the paper before publication."

A swift-moving New York University basketball team repulsed Rutgers, 34 -- 23, at the University Heights gym last night in a rough game. The Violet piled up a 22-9 lead at the half and although the losers waged a hard fight throughout the outcome was never in doubt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The domestic allotment plan for farm relief, revised so as to provide bonuses only to growers of wheat and cotton, was reported to the Senate by the Agriculture Committee today. Furthermore, all proposals for curtailing production of these commodities were eliminated.

The sudden death of a juror in the lobby of the Kings County Court building yesterday afternoon resulted in a mistrial in the cases of five men charged with kidnapping Ernest Schoening, leader of a New Jersey rum ring.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Holding that the State faces the possibility of a milk strike, Senator Perley A. Pitcher, chairman of a committee named to devise a program to ease the difficulties of the harassed farmers, introduced a bill today providing for a rigid State control over the dairy industry.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15. -- The combination of H.D. Cox's Capacity and Jockey Johnny Gilbert proved successful again at Hialeah Park today, the featured Miami Springs Purse falling to the pair. It was the fifth start at the meeting for the gelded son of Eternal -- Assembly, which has won four times with Gilbert up on each occasion.
ALBANY, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- A serious threat against the life of professional boxing in the State appeared in the Legislature today as an aftermath of the fatal Schaaf-Carnera bout.

With F.V. Brodil defeating F.M. Loughman in the deciding match the Columbia University Club players last night triumphed over the New York Athletic Club team, 4 to 1, to win the Metropolitan League Class A squash tennis championship on the former team's court.

For those who are weary of crime and infidelity there is "One Sunday Afternoon," which was put on at the Little last evening. It is a light and charming little fable by James Hagan, who once wrote a drama dubbed "Guns." Like Jacques's melancholy, it is "compounded of many simples."

DETROIT, Feb. 15. -- President Hoover is expected to go before Congress within a day or two and ask for the immediate enactment of legislation which not only is aimed to relieve the financial strain in Michigan produced by the closing of the banks under Governor Comstock's eight-day holiday order, but would be counted upon to relieve similar situations should they arise in other States.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 15 -- Although Yale tonight defeated Columbia, 41 to 30, marking the 107th consecutive victory for Yale swimming teams since 1924, and its third of the season in league competition, Eugene Jennings of the visitors furnished the thrills of the meet by creating two new pool records.

Thomas Mann's latest work, "Joseph and His Brethren," is stretching into a third volume, the Nobel Prize winner writes to his publisher, Alfred A. Knopf. He has been at work on this novel for several years and announcements that it would be a two-volume work have appeared frequently.
James A. Farley announced yesterday that Federal jobs in New York State will be apportioned by the Democratic State Committee.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Milder weather throughout the West increased the movement of hogs to leading markets, with the result that prices here declined today 5 to 15 cents a hundredweight, light and medium weight butchers showing the most weakness.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Two Army athletic teams broke even with invading squads today, the hockey sextet going down to an overwhelming defeat at Princeton's hands, 10 to 2, and the basketball quintet turning back the United States Coast Guard Academy, 37 to 23.

The General Realty and Utilities Corporation and subsidiary companies, exclusive of the Lefcourt Realty Corporation, report for 1932 a net loss of $535,031 after depreciation, interest and taxes but before net loss from disposition of real estate investments charged against a special reserve, or before giving effect to the reduction in the appraisal of properties as of Dec. 31, 1932.

Madison Square Garden will proceed with plans for a heavyweight championship bout next June between Jack Sharkey, the titleholder, and Primo Carnera, Italian ring giant, James J. Johnston, Garden boxing director, announced yesterday.

WRENTHAM, Mass., Feb. 15 (AP). -- A host of friends of the late Ernie Schaaf tonight visited the little rural home, purchased out of his first ring earnings, where lay the body of the fighter whose death followed a bout with Primo Carnera in New York last week.

A letter requesting that "The Green Pastures," the highly successful Negro drama, be withdrawn immediately from Washington, where it is now playing at the National Theatre, because of racial feeling and "prejudice" aroused by its presentation there, addressed yesterday to Marc Connelly and Rowland Stebbins, author and producer, respectively, from the local office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 15. -- A hurried putt on the eighteenth green, which missed the cup by inches, eliminated Miss Diana Fishwick, former British golf champion, from the championship of Florida in the second round at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

The cosmic rays, overflow from a mysterious, all-pervasive reservoir of cosmic energy, were trapped yesterday afternoon in a cunning net, devised by science, after they had penetrated a 360-ton steel vault forty feet underground beneath a thirty-six story skyscraper, and then made to "speak" over a Columbia network of seventy radio stations, with an audience of millions listening to them for the first time.

A concerted drive by railway unions supported by the American Federation of Labor to bring about Congressional action for the adoption of a six-hour day on the railroads will be undertaken after March 4 it was revealed yesterday by A.F. Whitney, president of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen and chairman of the Railway Labor Executives' Association.

DETROIT, Feb. 15 (AP). -- All Detroit banks remained closed today and prepared for opening on a 5 per cent withdrawal basis tomorrow. Some out-State banks were open a part of the day, caring for the needs of local business on a modified scale.

Thomas Jefferson's own copy of his "Notes on the State of Virginia," with autograph manuscript additions on the margins and inserted leaves, brought $6,800 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of rare Americana from the library of the late Levi Z. Leiter, Chicago merchant, associated at one time with Marshall Field.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- As fourteen measures, embodying Governor Lehman's tax program, were being introduced in the Senate and Assembly today spokesmen for upState retailers were telling the Governor that his proposed tax on retail sales "would leave a trail of bankruptcies from one end of the State to the other."

PEIPING, Feb. 15. -- If Japan pre- sents Nanking an ultimatum demanding the withdrawal of Chinese troops from Jehol Province, such action can be construed only as a declaration of war, declared Acting Premier T.V. Soong today following an announcement on behalf of the government expressing doubt that Tokyo would really carry out the threat.

LIMA, Feb. 15. -- The Minister of War left for Iquitos by special train tonight, presumably to take charge of military operations, after a special Cabinet meeting summoned to consider the conflict with Colombia.

AS a result of its drastic writing down of the value of its property during the year, the United Fruit Company was able to reduce its depreciation charges by $4,666,291, leaving that amount in its income account, according to the annual report made public yesterday.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Congress asked big business today how the balanced budget, for which business clamors, was to be obtained, and received no answer.

In his testimony before the Sen ate Finance Committee Mr. BA BUCH said that no other country has "dared to incur deficits" as large as those of the United States during the depression. While he did not cite figures, there is ample evidence to support his statement.

Mr. and Mrs. Linn M.A. Evans last night grave the first in a series of dinners at their home, 164 East Ninety-third Street. Among their guests were Mr. and Mrs. Robert Ogden Bacon, Mr. and Mrs. Nathaniel Berwin, Mr. and Mrs. Haliburton Fales, Mr. and Mrs. Homer Loomis, Miss Florence Van Rensselaer, Lawrence Smith Butler and Lawrence Atterbury.

HAVANA, Feb. 15 (AP). -- William H. Tutlow, 57 years old, of Belleville, N.J., was found dead today in the wash-room of a hotel where he registered Monday after his arrival on the Key West boat from Miami.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Airmail subsidies, eliminated from the Treasury-Postoffice appropriation bill by the Senate, threatened today to deadlock the important economy bill attached to the appropriation bill as an amendment.

LONDON, Thursday, Feb. 16. -- News of the shooting at Presidentelect Roosevelt was received in London about 3:30 A.M. It was immediately communicated by THE NEW YORK TIMES correspondent to the British Foreign Office for the information of Prime Minister MacDonald.

Mayor O'Brien, speaking yester- day at a luncheon meeting of the Merchants Association in the Hotel Astor, pledged his administration to a pay-as-you-go policy and to all possible further economies conso- nant with efficient government.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Samuel Insull Jr. today told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee how members of his family had made a paper profit, though it was never realized, he said, of $25,000,000, through a contract enabling them to buy stock in the Insull Utility Investment Company, Inc., at a price far below the market quotation.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- Prime Minis- ter MacDonald told the House of Commons today that no contradic- tion existed between what he had said and what Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, had said on the subject of the war debt to the United States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Testifying today before the Senate Finance Committee on family transactions in Insull Utility Investments, Inc., Samuel Insull Jr. said that on the day the stock was listed on the Chicago Stock Exchange a contract was signed giving to Samuel Insull Sr., his wife, his son and Martin Insull, a brother, 1,214,000 shares of the stock, or an option on them, for $11,730,000.

HACKENSACK, N.J., (Thursday), Feb. 16 -- Joe Zingara roomed here at 100 Green Street until September, 1931, Hugh McQuillen and George H. Crawford, special agents of the United States Treasury Department, learned early this morning.

YONKERS, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Interviewed on the eve of his ninety-second birthday, John E. Andrus, Yonkers capitalist, reputed to be one of the ten wealthiest men in America, exhibited a large gold watch, more than seventy years old, and declared that it had marked the starting point of his career.

Further reduction in State aid for education and a comprehensive study of educational costs and benefits by a body appointed by Governor Lehman will be recommended at the legislative hearing on the State budget in Albany today by the committee on commercial education of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, it was announced yesterday.

Mayor O'BRIEN has followed up his recent promises by appointing an advisory committee on city planning, headed by GEORGE MCANENY, As a former city official, now president of the Regional Plan Association, Mr. MCANENY is peculiarly well fitted to serve as a link between official and unofficial agencies interested in this movement.
HAVANA, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Starboard Light, a speedy 6-year-old gelding from H.C. Rumage's barns, galloped away from a field of high-class platers in the six-furlong feature at Oriental Park today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The as- sembling of the executive committee of the Republican National Committee, called today to meet here Feb. 27, will be made the occasion of an important address by President Hoover, according to his advisers, who said that his speech would deal with a party program and elaborate upon his New York Lincoln Day speech.

FAIRBANKS, Alaska, Feb. 15. -- A discovery which offers a new conception of the upper atmosphere, the mysteries of which have gradually been unfolding under intensive scientific study in the past few years, has been made here.

Mrs. A. Calles de Almada, daughter of former President Plutarco Calles of Mexico; Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons, American author and political economist; William M. Seabury, lawyer; Jules Henry, counselor of the French Embassy in Washington; Guy W. Ray, American Vice Consul in London, and Sergio Garcia Uriburu, Argentine Ambassador to Mexico, are among the passengers on the French liner Champlain, due today from Havre and Plymouth.

Repeal, straight or crooked, of the Eighteenth Amendment is still of low visibility. The first and preliminary report of the New York State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Legislation deals mainly with beer, a gentle variety of which awaits legalization at Washington.

The Atchison, Topeks, Santa Fe Railroad issued yesterday a preliminary statement for 1932 which was in contrast with the ones showing net losses for the year issued previously by other railroads. The Santa Fe had a net income of $7,545,008 in 1932, equal to 55 cents a share on its common stock, against $23,101,691, or $6.96 a share, in 1931.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- Substantial relief to delinquent debtors of Federal Farm Land Banks is provided in the Steagall bill, unanimously reported to the House today by the Banking and Currency Committee. The measure provides for extension of delinquent payments on mortgages, spreading them over a period of ten years, and would prevent the land banks from taking chattel mortgages as security.

The proclamation by the Governor of Michigan of an eight-day "bank holiday " in that State was avowedly issued " in view of the acute financial emergency," in Detroit particularly. The action appears to have been taken with the approval of the Detroit banks and of outside banking and governmental authorities in order to prevent a run on a single embarrassed bank which might have spread to other institutions.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- German ex- ports continued declining in January and reached the lowest mark recorded in many years. Compared with December, exports suffered a drop of 20 per cent, which is more than was expected to result from seasonal influences.

When Brothers Disagree. Senator LONG will not be injured with his public merely because two of his brothers are against him in the Louisiana primary fraud hearings. Fraternal salvos of "Liar!" only remind people that there are such things as family quarrels.

LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The stock markets generally were dull today, with weakness in foreign bonds outstanding, particularly Far Eastern. Chinese securities were down 1 to 7 points. Japanese bonds also were weak, and the German list was lower.
LAKELAND, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP). -- With a blazing round of 68, four strokes under par, to add to his round of 70 yesterday, Al Watrous of Detroit today won the Orange Blossom open golf tournament.

An exhibition of recent paintings by Raphael Soyer has opened at the Valentine Gallery, where the work will be shown until March 4. This young artist bad a one-man show of drawings, water-colors and oils a year ago at the L'Elan Galleries and his work has appeared with groups at the Daniel Gallery and elsewhere.

TOLEDO, Ohio, Feb. 15. -- The Willys - Overland company was placed in receivership late this afternoon and John N. Willys and L.A. Miller, chairman of the board and president, respectively, of the company, were appointed receivers.

Supreme Court Justice Peter A. Hatting granted yesterday a peremptory mandamus order requiring John G. Succa, who contends he is president of the Green Bus Lines, Inc., to turn over all of the corporation's papers, records and assets to John R. Thompson, a rival claimant.

After the reaction of the preceding day, a steadier tone was evident in local commodity markets yesterday. While again only silver futures showed a clear rise for the day, several other commodities closed higher in some of their contract positions, and losses in others were small.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15. -- Mrs. Lillian Cross, 48 years old, and weighing only 100 pounds, probably saved the life of the President-elect tonight when she forced the would-be assassin's shooting arm upward and caused the bullets to go high.

The volume of bankers' bills outstanding showed an unimportant decline of $2,325,268 in January to a total of $707,404,300 at the end of the month, according to the American Acceptance Council. Compared with the end of January of last year, the current volume is down $253,662,102, the major part of the decrease having been due to the contraction of bills drawn to finance imports and exports.
LONDON, Feb. 15. -- The Berlin correspondent of The London Times sent a dispatch to his newspaper tonight that said:

GENEVA, Feb. 15. -- The Foreign Ministers of the Little Entente completed today a convention trans- forming the entente, according to a communique, into a permanent "unified international organization open eventually to other States in conditions to be settled in each specific case."

Further transfers of currency to Detroit were made yesterday by New York banks for the account of their commercial clients, and arrangements were made for handling checks drawn on Detroit banks presented for payment here.

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reports for 1932 net income of $5,035,486, after taxes, charges and depreciation, equal to $6.79 a share earned on 741,480 no par common shares outstanding at the end of the year, and comparing with $5,664,802, or $7.64 a share, earned on 741,086 common shares in 1931.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt returned to her home at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street about 10:30 o'clock last night and found the household upset. The Negro butler's face betrayed his agitation as he admitted her.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not so many months ago a great deal was being said to the effect that education must be the last to suffer as result of the depression. We thought then -- we know now -- that the politicians were protesting too much.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- When the Democratic policy and steering committees of the Senate assembled today at the call of Senator Robinson, their members revealed a growing disposition in favor of two reforms which many experienced observers of Congress believe are prerequisite to the prompt enactment of the essentials of Franklin D. Roosevelt's program.

Eunice Norton, the young American pianist, graduate of the music department of the University of Minnesota, pupil of Tobias Mathay and Arthur Schnabel, and soloist in recent weeks with several of the leading American orchestras, gave a recital last night in Town Hall.

With the release of steel orders necessary to meet the requirements of 10,000 cars to be built by the Ford Motor Company and with the settlement of a strike at the Hudson Motor Car Company's body plant, the rate of operations in the steel industry has risen to 20 per cent of the national ingot capacity, according to the review of The Iron Age.

How nineteen members of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators' Union of Greater New York figuratively were "put on the spot" by Samuel Kaplan, its president, when they voted against the expulsion of another member, Alexander Polin, was related yesterday by Polin on the witness stand at the General Sessions trial of Kaplan and twenty-one other former officers and members of the local on a coercion indictment.

BELLEAIR, Fla., Feb. 15 (AP). -- Although a gallery of several millionaires and citrus farmers hunted among the palmettos for five minutes, the searchers were unable to locate Babe Ruth's golf ball on the sixteenth hole today, and the Babe lost to D.N. Tallman of Minneapolis, 3 and 2, in the second round of the Belleair amateur championship.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 15 (AP). -- J. J. Robinson's Eisenberg, a candidate for the Louisiana Derby, won his third successive race of the Winter season today, defeating a smart field of 3-year-olds in the six-furlong featured race at the Fair Grounds.

GENEVA, Feb. 15. -- Provision for invocation of the nine-power treaty guaranteeing the integrity of China is contained in the draft of the recommendation of the League of Nations on the Chino-Japanese situation. Also the way is paved for consultation with the United States as soon as the report is adopted.

The directors of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company voted yesterday to pay the regular quarterly dividend of $2.25 a share on April 15 to stockholders of record of March 14. This action had been fully anticipated and aroused little interest in stock market circles, the shares closing unchanged at 100 3/4.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 15. -- Public utilities and the railroads occupied the spotlight at Cornell's annual farm and home week today, with Maurice C. Burritt, State Public Service Commissioner, asserting that "the railroads themselves need to face the facts and to meet the new competition at or near its own level and standard of service, and to adjust themselves to new price levels."

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Increased alertness by social welfare agencies to deal with by-products of the depression, particularly among children of the distressed, was urged today by Governor Lehman. He spoke at the midwinter meeting of the State Association of the Commissioners of Public Welfare.

Elihu Root, former Secretary of State and dean of American statesmen, observed his eighty-eighth birthday yesterday quietly at his apartment at 998 Fifth Avenue. More than a hundred messages of congratulation from distinguished persons both in this country and in Europe, where his work for international amity has made him almost as widely known as he is in his native land, were received during the day.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, in the Pacific, Feb. 15. -- The slow glory of dawn spread over the Eastern Pacific this morning to find the 113 ships of the Blue Force still keeping their long vigil for an "enemy" that was fast becoming a phantom fleet.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- While there was considerable interest in official circles here today in the report of the National Transportation Committee, it was generally regarded as a reiteration of proposals made from time to time by the Interstate Commerce Commission and in Congress and as a valuable exposition of the problems confronting the railroad industry.

The list of forced sales conducted by auctioneers yesterday was featured by offerings of small dwellings and tenement houses in Manhattan and the Bronx. The process of liquidating these defaulted holdings involved twenty-four properties.

BRISBANE, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 16. -- England today won the fourth cricket test match against Australia by 6 wickets and regained the mythical "ashes," taken to the Antipodes at the end of the 1930 test series played in England.

William C. Bullitt, American writer, who has figured in the foreign press as visiting France and England to make unofficial inquiries on the war-debt question on behalf of President-elect Roosevelt, returned yesterday on the North German Lloyd liner Europa and denounced these reports as "ridiculous and sheer nonsense."

So far as the financial markets were concerned, the excitement caused by the announcement on Tuesday of an eight-day banking holiday in Michigan appeared yesterday to have subsided. The pressure against stocks was lifted and the bonds of domestic corporations regained their composure.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 15. -- Captain Jack Dayton lowered the Brokaw pool record for the 220-yard free style by two seconds as the Princeton swimmers defeated Rider College, 54 -- 17, tonight. Dayton was clocked in 2:20, breaking the record of 2:22 made by Joe Nicholson of Princeton last year.

The fourteenth week of the present Metropolitan Opera Company's season will bring the debut of Richard Crooks, American tenor, with the company. He will sing Des Grieux in "Manon" Saturday afternoon, Feb. 25, in a cast which will include Mmes. Bori, Doninelli, Falco and Flexer and Messrs. De Luca, Rothier, Bada, Altglass, Cehanovsky, Gabor and Ananian. Louis Hasselmans will conduct.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Feb. 11 there appeared an article which made it perfectly plain that the New York County Lawyers Association is altogether opposed to any and all State regulation of conventions to act on proposed Federal amendments, and desires that the Congress usurp these State powers and dictate to the States as to every detail of convention procedure.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- A Federal grand jury investigating the affairs of the Corporation Securities Company, in which indictments will be sought charging Samuel Insull Sr., Samuel Insull Jr., Martin J. Insull and probably nine others with using the mails to defraud, will be opened tomorrow.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 15. -- Senator Huey P. Long was held in contempt today by the Senate Committee on Campaign Expenditures after he had called a witness a "damned dirty liar and a lying thief." When sternly rebuked by Chairman Howell, the Louisiana "kingfish" apologized and asked the committee to "order the witness not to lean over and look at me when he's telling those lies."

NEW YORK. Mrs. Harold Benjamin Clark will give a tea on Feb. 22 at her home. 107 East 73d Street, for her cousin, Miss Mabel Schuyler Crane, daughter of the Rev. and Mrs. Louis Burton Crane of Elizabeth, N.J.

A plan of reorganization for the Shubert Theatre Corporation and certain of its subsidiary companies was proposed yesterday by a reorganization committee headed by Lee Shubert and including Robert C. Adams. Carl Ahlstrom, Edward A. Ducasse, Meyer Lesser, William P. Phillips, E. Clifford Potter and A.M. Wittenberg.

In Professor WILLIAM JAMES'S famous essay on "The Moral Equivalent of War," there is a suggestion of the value of such training as is now proposed for the youthful members of the Army of the Unemployed:
STUTTGART, Feb. 15. -- Opening the election campaign in South Germany tonight, Chancellor Hitler stated unequivocally that the forthcoming election would be the last one in Germany for four years.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced 4 to 6 points yesterday.
"The Lady Refuses," a new comedy by Saxon Kling, is announced for presentation next week at a theatre yet to be named. Lou Tellegen, Cecil Spooner and Charles Bryant are included in the cast.

Japanese and German bonds were about the weakest of the foreign loans on the Stock Exchange yesterday. The foreign issues, on the average, showed greater declines than did domestic corporation issues. The Japanese issues were adversely affected by news of the closing of the Tokyo Stock Exchange and the growing friction between the League of Nations and Japan.

Anton Joseph Cermak, the vigorous immigrant boy who capped his climb to policital power in his adopted land by overthrowing and succeeding Mayor William Hale Thompson in one of the outstanding political struggles of America's second city, will be 60 years old next May 9.

The Committee to Save Opera at the Metropolitan met yesterday in the office of Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the opera company's board of directors, elected an executive committee and renewed its appeal to the public to subscribe to its $300,000 fund to guarantee another operatic season.

The preliminary report of the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation and subsidiaries for 1932 shows a net income of $17,204,675 after taxes, charges, reserves, underlying dividends and minority interest, equivalent after preferred dividends to 96 cents a share on 11,608,150 no par common shares, comparing with $22,331,888, or $1.42 a share earned on 11,609,985 common shares in 1931.

In a proceeding by the Prudence Company, Inc., to determine its right to withdraw $889,551 in cash out of property pledged for an issue of $15,000,000 of guaranteed bonds, on the ground that the collateral on deposit was in excess of the amount required by the trust indenture to this extent, the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court decided yesterday that the deposit must remain intact.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Wagner bill proposing enlargement of the relief fund of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation by $300,000,000 to allow continued loans to States, cities and other political subdivisions, and the liberalization of the terms of such loans was reported from the Senate's Banking and Currency Committee today.

Gerald Campbell, British Consul General, expressed the opinion that a new era was at hand in an address yesterday afternoon on British Day at the international art exhibition arranged by the College Art Association on the twenty-seventh floor of the R.K.O. Building in Rockefeller Center.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Tuesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

Mme. Marcella Sembrich surrendered yesterday to the insistence of her friends after they had twice invaded her quiet home and singing studio on Central Park West to demand that she celebrate with them her "diamond jubilee" birthday.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 15. -- Colombian forces captured the town of Tarapaca, on the Putumayo River, from its Peruvian garrison today in the first real matching of strength over possession of the Leticia corridor.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Robert P. Gore, a friend of President-elect Roosevelt, who was standing by Mr. Roosevelt's automobile tonight when a would-be assassin started firing, told The Philadelphia Record over long-distance telephone that a woman threw her arms around the assailant's neck and tried to strangle him while he was still shooting.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The War Department released the following orders today:

Protesting the removal of bonds of the city and county of San Francisco from the list of securities eligible to secure postal savings deposits, a group of municipal bond houses in California has addressed itself to the office of the Postmaster General, asking for a new basis of determining municipal credit, according to word received yesterday by bankers here.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 15. -- The Senate today stripped the Blaine prohibition resolution to practically "naked" repeal and agreed to vote on the measure at 3 P.M. tomorrow.

The Public Service Commission began yesterday a bearing, on its own motion, on the provision in the New York Telephone Company's tariff schedule by which the subscriber assumes all risks relative to interruptions of service except under certain conditions under which the loss is divided on a pro rata basis.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Yosuke Matsuoka, who has served as Japan's special counsel during the long debate over the Manchu- rian problem at the League of Na- tions in Geneva, has cabled the For- eign Office for permission to return home soon by way of the United States.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 15. -- Browned by exposure to the tropical sun and invigorated by the salt air of the Southern seas, Franklin D. Roosevelt ended his eleven-day fishing cruise here tonight.

DENVER, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Investigation of the kidnapping of Charles Boettcher 2d, wealthy young Denver broker who is held for $60,000 ransom, encountered a setback today when Mrs. Anna Lou Boettcher failed to definitely identify N.W. (Red) Mitchell, reputed alcohol runner, as one of the men who abducted her husband Sunday night.

The members of the National Electric Light Association, in convention in the Hotel Biltmore, voted unanimously yesterday to dissolve the organization. A resolution was adopted appointing a liquidating committee to wind up the organization.

ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Thomas M. Lynch resigned today as president of the Tax Board and head of the Department of Taxation and Finance, his resignation to become effective on March 1. He will be succeeded, Governor Lehman announced, by Mark Graves, Director of the Budget.
Brokers and renting agents of Manhattan buildings yesterday announced a long list of new tenants for business occupancy. The leases follow:

To the Editor of The New York Times: In the welter of feverish political activity now afflicting Washington and filling the columns of our newspapers, may one raise a voice to ask that a little attention be directed to the Investment banking provisions of the Glass banking bill now under consideration in Congress?

Retailers of the country were urged to follow large industrial organizations by providing funds for research into consumer habits by F. Willett Walton Jr., advertising director of Arnold, Constable Co., in an address last evening in The Times Annex before the advertising class sponsored by THE NEW YORK TIMES.
