SANTIAGO, Feb. 15. -- The Central Bank of Chile, which is attending to the financial end of the liquidation of Cosach, the Chilean nitrate corporation, after the issuance of the decree ending its legal existence, now states that it cannot consider a loan contemplated for the payment of the company's former employes, since the statutes of the bank do not allow its funds to be used for operations of this nature.

The Seaglade of the St. Regis was transformed into a semblance of Monte Carlo last night when an entertainment was held there for the benefit of the Actors' Fund of America. Tall palms and large canvasses depicting beach and casino scenes were used in the decorations.

GENEVA, Feb. 15. -- Impressed by the effect on the Japanese Stock Exchanges of publication of unoffi- cial summaries of the League of Nations recommendation on the Manchurian issue, the Japanese delegation was understood to be swinging strongly today against withdrawal from the League.

The Miami incident recalls the shooting of Franklin D. Roosevelt's famous kinsman, Theodore Roosevelt, during a speaking tour as the Progressive party's candidate for President in 1912. The shooting occurred in Milwaukee on Oct. 14, while the candidate, who had finished out McKinley's term as President and served another term, was stumping the Middle West.

Bound, gagged and stabbed through the heart, the body of 12year-old William Bender, who disappeared Jan. 31, was found yesterday in a closet in one of a row of partly-built dwellings, less than two blocks from his home at 6 Bergen Landing Road, Richmond Hill Circle, Queens.
Babe Ruth and Bobby Jones have waged the battle of the decade!
ALBANY, Feb. 15. -- Following is the text of the first report of the State Commission on Alcoholic Beverage Control Legislation:
CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- News of the attempted assassination of the President-elect at Miami tonight and the resultant wounding of Mayor Cermak struck Chicago like a bombshell.

Warland Protector of Shelterock, an imported airedale terrier owned by S.M. Stewart of Montclair, N. J., was awarded the highest honors of the fifty-seventh annual dog show of the Westminster Kennel Club, which ended last night. The award came as the climax of the successful three-day exhibition in Madison Square Garden.

SAN JUAN, P.R., Feb. 15. -- John Dow, who sailed from New York last June in the schooner-rigged lifeboat Chance, for a 10,000-mile voyage, was towed into Mayaguez last night by the Coast Guard cutter Seneca. Officers of the Seneca, which returned here this afternoon, expressed high regard for Mr. Dow's seamanship.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 15 (AP). -- Port interests from the Atlantic and Pacific seaboards joined today before a subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee in urging the creation of "free port" trade zones.

CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Cross-currents continued today to dominate the wheat market on the Board of Trade here. There was no selling pressure, and scattered commission house and local buying lifted prices 1 3/8 cents from Tuesday's finish, only to react later from sales by houses that have been on that side on bulges for some time.

The squash racquets team of the Junior League won the honors in the New York group of the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association yesterday when it scored its fifth successive victory of the season through the default of the Rockaway Hunting Club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: For three years past it has been dinned into our ears that prosperity was just around the corner, though none of our leaders seemed familiar with the map, knew where the promised land was, which corner to turn, or how to get there.
The responsibility for guarding the President-elect night and day, at home or abroad, rests on the United States Secret Service, just as it is its duty to guard the President.

After the brisk selling movement of the day before, the trading pace on the Stock Exchange slackened yesterday. Transactions involved a total of 745,000 shares, or about half of the turnover of Tuesday. The general market was steadier and reactionary influences were brushed aside.

Charging that Congress had forgotten the electorate's mandate for prohibition reform as expressed in the last election, Dr. Nicholas Mur- ray Butler, president of Columbia University, issued yesterday a demand for "unconditional repeal" of the Eighteenth Amendment.
CHICAGO, Feb. 15. -- Mrs. Walter Wright, a former Chicago newspaper woman, gave by telephone the following eyewitness account of the attempted assassination of President-elect Roosevelt:

MIAMI, Feb. 15. -- An unsuccessful attempt was made to assassinate President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt just after he ended a speech in Bay Front Park here at 9:35 o'clock tonight, two hours after his return from an eleven-day fishing cruise on Vincent Astor's yacht Nourmahal.

The Brooklyn Tech and Manual Training hockey teams, champion and runner-up, respectively, in the P.S.A.L. tournament, triumphed last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace in non-league games. Brooklyn Tech defeating Lynbrook, 4 to 0, and Manual turning back St. Michael's, 2 to 0.

Creation of a municipal housing authority along the lines of the Port of New York Authority, with power to finance slum-clearance projects by issuing securities chargeable only against such projects, is urged in a plan sponsored by the State Housing Board, it was revealed yesterday.

AIBANY, Feb. 15. -- A bill carrying out recommendations for reform of procedure in the magistrates courts of New York City, as set forth by a committee named by Chief Magistrate McDonald, was introduced in the Senate today by Elmer F. Quinn, New York Democrat.

BERLIN, Feb. 15. -- The Boerse opened weak today, with a majority of the active stocks 1 to 2 points below yesterday's closing. Some fell more than 2 points. The depression generally was attributed to sympathy with the Michigan banking situation.

Acquisition of the assets of Ludington Airlines, Inc., by the Eastern Air Transport, Inc., wholly owned by North American Aviation, Inc., was announced yesterday. Terms of the deal were not announced, but it is understood that the sale was made for cash.

During the last forty years the stockholders of the Metropolitan Opera and Heal Estate Company have assessed themselves $4,522,000 to support the presentation of opera in New York City, R. Fulton Cutting, president of the company, revealed in a statement last night.

Oscar Merrill Hartzell, who was recently deported from England as an undesirable alien, because of his activities in drawing money by mail from his countrymen in Iowa, on the representation that he held an assigned claim on the mythical estate of Sir Francis Drake, was arrested yesterday when he arrived here on the French liner Champlain.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The action of the United States Senate in voting late today to submit the question of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to the States crowded out of the legislative limelight the preliminary report of Governor Lehman's Commission on Control of Alcoholic Beverages, which was filed today with the Senate and Assembly.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Commutation of the ten-year prison sentences imposed on the four defendants in Honolulu's sensational "honor slaying" case was the result, says Mrs. Thomas H. Massie, of a "deal" she made with authorities to leave the islands and drop the prosecution.

GENEVA, Feb. 16. -- The Japanese delegation to the League of Nations put on the record today a 2,000-word statement giving the Japanese version of the negotiations for conciliation. It amalgamates previous Japanese statements and lists effectively the concessions Japan has made, but adds nothing new of importance.

Average daily electric power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, amounted to 207,700,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended Feb. 11, as against 203,400,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 221,200,000 kilowatt-hours in the corresponding week last year.

PATERSON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Secret Service men left this city tonight apparently convinced that Joseph Zangara, the man who tried to kill President-elect Roosevelt, acted on his own volition and without the aid of any radical group or any other individuals.
LONG BEACH, Cal., Feb. 16 (AP). William James Guy, youthful Welsh adventurer, was acquitted tonight of a charge of murder in the slaying of Captain Walter Wanderwell on the yacht Carma Dec. 5.

Patrolman William J. Gaynor was shot and critically wounded last night after a struggle in a cordial shop in the Bronx with two assailants who took his pistol from him and escaped. He was hurried to Fordham Hospital, where it was said that his condition was serious.
The forty-eighth annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York will be opened to the public tomorrow in a setting that is perhaps the gayest ever arranged for one of the league's shows.
Police Commissioner Mulrooney has made unusual plans to guard President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt on and after his return to New York, he disclosed yesterday.

A black picture of the general European attitude toward the United States was given yesterday by Dr. Herbert Adams Gibbons, historian and economist, who returned on the French liner Champlain after completing two years of travel and study for a book on the French colonies.

Making their first appearance in this city in match play, the British women's squash racquets team defeated a New York combination representing the ablest players in the metropolitan area yesterday at the Heights Casino in Brooklyn.

Bank clearings underwent a severe reversal in trend in the week ended on Wednesday. After making the best comparative showing for thirty-one months in the first week of February, the total for the last week fell 25.1 per cent below that for the same week last year, according to reports received by R.G. Dun Co.
St. John's College of Brooklyn registered its seventeenth basketball victory of the season in Jersey City last night, overwhelming St. Peter's College five of Jersey City by the score of 43 to 16.

DETROIT, Feb. 16. -- Industrial leaders joined today with Detroit and New York bankers to devise a way out of the financial morass for Michigan, while the Federal Government at Washington, obviously concerned, kept in close telephonic touch.

By a vote of 5,007 to 1,960 Typographical Union 6 has adopted a referendum proposal to appropriate $250,000 from the union defense fund for unemployment relief, it was announced yesterday by President Austin Hewson.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16. -- In compliment to Dr. and Mrs. Martin E. Rehfuss of Philadelphia, who arrived last night to be their house guests, Mr. and Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury entertained with a luncheon today at El Mirasol.

Budgets down, assessments down, taxes down -- a prospect to delight the most jaded city taxpayer. The business of deflating extravagant municipal government should have been begun long ago, and might even now be carried further; but citizens should be grateful, nevertheless, for the substantial measure of relief now assured.
ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 16 (AP). -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt outlined her philosophy of calm in the face of such things as attempted assassinations today -- and then she put that philosophy into effect.

The possibility of national financing of education to relieve the "terrific distress in the school system of the country" was viewed as an "obvious" necessity yesterday at a conference of educators in Teachers College on plans for maintaining education during the depression.

Development of York Avenue and other parts of the upper east side of Manhattan near the East River into residential centres similar to Park Avenue was predicted yesterday by David V. Sutton after his election as president of the First Avenue Association at the annual meeting of that group in the Hotel Barclay.

What seemed the incredible has happened. The Senate yesterday by more than a two-thirds vote adopted a resolution for a constitutional amendment of which the first section declares, nakedly, that the Eighteenth Amendment "is hereby repealed."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The following Coast Guard changes for the week ended Feb. 15 were announced today:

DELHI, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- The joint legislative committee named to "investigate the causes of the decline of the dairy industry" has prepared a preliminary report which will be submitted to the Legislature presumably on Monday night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Members of Congress and diplomats hastened today to express their congratulations to Franklin D. Roosevelt for his escape at Miami last night. The State Department received messages from American representatives abroad conveying the good wishes of foreign governments.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES last Sunday, "Augur," writing from London, discussed disarmament in relation to Germany. The article, as many others before, is utterly unfair and misleading in regard to Germany.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- The operators of Briarcliff Lodge, a Winter and Summer resort since 1901, gave up their eighteen-month struggle with the depression and closed the 265-room hotel today. Mayor Henry H. Law of this village, who is head of the Briarcliff Lodge Association and the holding company that owns the estate, said that the continuance of prohibition had been a contributing factor in the failure of the inn.

HAVANA, Feb. 16. -- Small incendiary bombs caused the contents of fifty-nine mail boxes in the downtown district to burst into flames last night with an estimated loss of 500 letters and 2,000 others damaged, according to a check-up made today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Missouri Pacific Railroad filed-with the Interstate Commerce Commission today an application for a loan of $3,921,191 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, and also asked that $1,300,000 of a $4,300,000 loan previously requested, but which had not yet been authorized, be advanced.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Official circles were much relieved tonight when the Federal Secret Service, after a close investigation, decided that Joseph Zangara, who attempted to assassinate President-elect Roosevelt in Miami, had no connection with any political group or organization.

The Giants, who seem to have developed a penchant for doing things with a grand flourish in the Spring, come what may in the Fall, advanced to within one of having their entire roster signed yesterday when Secretary Jim Tierney announced the receipt of Harry Leiber's accepted contract.
WRENTHAM, Mass., Feb. 16 -- Although overwhelmed by her own grief, the mother of Ernie Schaaf today tried to send a ray of comfort to the man who fought her son in his fatal boxing match.

At a luncheon given by six west side mutual savings bankers to nearly 300 business and industrial leaders at the Hotel Astor yesterday, Thomas J. Watson, president of the Merchants Association of New York, declared that wage earners resented paternalism.
LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A gibe at the American merchant marine was delivered tonight by "Walter Runciman, President of the Board of Trade, speaking at the dinner of the Chamber of Shipping.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Blaine resolution to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment was adopted today in the Senate, which thus broke the grip which drys had held in that branch for fifteen years. The vote was 63 to 23, or five more than the two-thirds majority required.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- Supervisor Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale, new chairman of the Equalization Committee of the Westchester County Board of Supervisors, who resigned as Republican leader of the board two years ago to be at liberty to attack the methods then employed in preparing the equalization table, presented to the board today the fruits of his efforts as chairman of the committee.

Firmness in the Street rate for call loans was carried further when the supply at 3/4 was cleaned up in the last hour and 1 per cent ruled for closing trades. Federal funds stiffened to 3/4, from 1/4 @ 1/2, on Wednesday. The Stock Exchange rate remained at 1 per cent.

One of the few railroads to report a gain for 1932, the Reading Company, issued a statement yesterday showing that its net income last year was $4,228,789, or $1.02 a share on the $50 par common stock, against $3,314,928, or 37 cents a share in 1931.

Henry Ford still believes in high wages and that they must be raised swiftly when business volume picks up, he says in an interview with the editor of The Business Week in the current issue, out today.

WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT ROOSEVELT EN ROUTE TO NEW YORK -- JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 16. -- President-elect Roosevelt's personal account of the attempt to assassinate him and the shooting of Mayor Cermak of Chicago and four others at Miami last night is as follows:

PARIS, Feb. 16. -- The sufferings of the United States in the depression explains the American's attitude on war debts, Edouard Herriot, former Premier, declared tonight to a large audience attending the last of his series of lectures on foreign affairs.

The first step toward the restoration of world prosperity is an understanding between the United States and Great Britain, in the opinion of S.K. Ratcliffe, correspondent in America of The Spectator. London, who expressed that view yesterday at a luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York, 23 Park Avenue.

The volume of money in circulation in the United States rose $149,000,000 in the week ended on Wednesday to reach the highest total on record, $5,854,000,000, it was disclosed in yesterday's weekly report of the Federal Reserve System.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- When Samuel Insull began erecting the maze of utility holding companies and investment trusts for obtaining control of additional operating concerns he set in motion the forces that eventually brought about the collapse of that huge enterprise, Owen D. Young today told the Senate Banking and Currency Committee.

A loss of 0.2 point carried the Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices down to 81.0 on Tuesday from 81.2 (revised) the week before. Losses in steers, hogs and gasoline were largely responsible for the week's decline, offset in part by higher meat prices.

The Railroad Credit Corporation approved loans of $8,260,000 to five railroads yesterday, bringing the total of loans authorized since its formation a year ago to $61,519,918. The corporation was formed to distribute the proceeds of the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 2, 1932, in the form of advances to railroads to meet interest charges.

PARIS, Feb. 16. -- George W. Wickersham vigorously denounce raids on the public purse in the United States by the friends of war veterans in a speech delivered a the weekly luncheon of the American Club of Paris today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Congress alone cannot cure economic ills, but it can help by attempting to balance its budget and assuring investors that a stable currency will be maintained, E.D. Duffield, president of the Prudential Life Insurance Company, today told the Senate committee inquiring into economic conditions.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Miss Kathleen Garnham, the last British threat in the women's golf tournament for the championship of Florida in progress at the Palm Beach Country Club, was eliminated in the semi-finals today by Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, Mo., holder of the Western championship.
Mrs. William P. Hoffmann gave a luncheon yesterday at the Waldorf-Astoria for Mrs. Edward P. Mulrooney. The other guests were:
PARIS, Feb. 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16 (AP). -- L.M. Severson's Volta Maid was the even-money choice in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds today and she ran like a true favorite, galloping home six lengths in front of Frank Seremba's Anna L. The time was 1:13 2-5.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago, one of five victims of bullets intended for President-elect Roosevelt by Joseph Zangara, was still in critical condition tonight but resting more easily.
Former Governor Alfred E. Smith and other opponents of the Eighteenth Amendment greeted with satisfaction yesterday the passage by the Senate of the Blaine resolution for repeal of the amendment.

To avert a threatened money-market squeeze, growing out of Detroit's banking crisis, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York began yesterday to pump Federal funds into the market through purchases of United States Government securities and by reducing its bill-buying rate to one-half of 1 per cent.
PARIS, Feb. 16. -- Nearly 100 unemployed Poles attacked the Polish Consulate this morning, wounding two employes with knives and iron bars before the police could intervene.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- The Boerse opened irregular today, but the undertone was stronger than on yesterday. The initial buoyancy, however, petered out in the absence of buying orders and quotations tended to sag. Closing prices in general were not materially below yesterday's levels.
ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- The Senate passed today a bill designed to make it easier for New York City property owners to pay their taxes.

BATTLE CREEK, Mich., Feb. 16. -- Over the rusty rails of a Michigan Central branch line here this afternoon came a fish-shaped coach of bright red resembling tae passenger compartment of some large airplane. It was a demonstration model of the "autoram," a vehicle designed by automobile engineers to revolutionize main-line rail passenger service.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has turned over more than half of her book manuscript, "It's up to the Women," to her publishers, Frederick A. Stokes Company, and the volume will be published on March 16. The book, the publishers say, "will give women facts which prove their importance in modern progress" and offer practical answers to women who want to know how they may help recovery.

ABOARD U. S. S. PENNSYLVANIA IN THE PACIFIC, Feb. 16. -- Hemmed against the coast by Blue battleships, the Black raiding force was practically annihilated today when the "enemy" carriers attempted to launch air attacks just before dawn against important industrial and military centres of San Francisco and San Pedro.
LINCOLN, Neb., Feb. 16 (AP). -- Farmers marched to the Nebraska Capitol today, presented relief demands to the Legislature and then set out peacefully for home.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The shipping Board today approved the sale of fifty-two cargo steamships, to be used in the foreign trade, to be Lykes Brothers-Ripley Steamhip Company of New Orleans. These vessels will operate in a guaranteed service from New Oreans to the United Kingdom, European and Oriental ports.

By a margin so convincing that it leaves no room for the slightest doubt, Knute Kenneth Rockne stands out as the greatest of sports leaders over the past decade, in the opinion of those who have most closely scanned the whirl of events over the period of 1923 to 1933.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 16. -- Further details of the capture of the town of Tarapaca, north of Leticia, were received late last night from General Alfredo Vasquez Cobo, commander of the Colombian expedition.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 16. -- Making the annual Gubernatorial visit to the Farm Week celebration at Cornell University, Governor Lehman presented the Master Farmer awards at a dinner tonight at Willard Straight Hall. He is scheduled to deliver his main address on farm aid and State fiscal policy tomorrow afternoon.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Relief legislation became the pending business of the Senate late this afternoon on a motion by Senator La Follette, and the way was thus opened for settlement of the dispute as to whether the Federal Government will change the form of its assistance to States from loans to direct grants of money.

Yesterday's combined statement of the twelve Reserve banks showed the system's note circulation to be at a new high figure for the year to date, exceeding slightly the highest figure of 1932, reached in July, and overtopping the high mark reached in any other year since 1921.

HAVANA, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Dark Ayr, out of the money only once in five starts over the Cuban course, crashed through with bis second victory today when he scored by a nose over Prince Mexican in the six-furlong feature at Oriental Park.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Resources of national banks increased $744,979,000 between Sept. 30 and Dec. 31 last and amounted to $23,310,974,000 on the latter date, F.G. Await, Acting Controller of the Currency, announced today. This marked a decrease, however, of $1,351,312,000 in the year.

Prices of bonds of the city of Detroit made further recoveries yesterday, long-term issues being quoted at 57 bid and 60 asked. Although, because of the banking holiday in Michigan, the city was unable to transfer sufficient funds to meet payments on bonded debt service on Wednesday, bankers here received private advices yesterday quoting city officials as saying that no default existed.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The P. Lorillard Company reported yesterday for 1932 a net income of $4,556,051 after all charges and taxes, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $2.02 a share on the 1,889,775 shares of common stock outstanding. These figures, it was understood, were reached after setting up ample reserves to take care of price adjustments upon stocks in the hands of wholesale dealers at the close of the year.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- How stock was juggled back and forth among Insull investment trusts and subsidiaries, with an inflation of income on the books for each transaction, was disclosed by the Bureau of Investigation today as the Federal grand jury began hearing evidence concerning the defunct Corporation Securities Company.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16. -- The third successive victory of the Hialeah Park meeting was scored today by Stealingaway, the 3-year-old Ed Crump colt, which got home first in the featured De Soto Purse. Stealingaway apparently can win with various riders for H. Kneessi, Robby Robertson, and today Don Meade had the leg up, each scoring a victory.

APROPOS of Commission-William Muldoon's "dreadnaught" class in boxing, it might be recalled that Primo Carnera fought Billy the Kid Stribling, Jimmy Maloney, Paulino, Stanley Poreda, Jack Sharkey and others of that approximate size and weight and, until the recent bout at the Garden, the real damage done when Carnera was in the ring with another chap was that a sparring partner fractured two of Primo's ribs.

Eugene Hale Jr., a former member of the New York Stock Exchange, a brother of United States Senator Frederick Hale of Maine, died yesterday of cancer in St. Luke's Hospital, where he had been a patient since Jan. 10. He was born in Ellsworth, Me., fifty-seven years ago.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Blaine resolution, passed by the Senate today, goes to the House in this form:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The House Rules Committee agreed today to give legislative right of way to the Celler bill removing restrictions from physicians' liquor prescriptions, and a vote will be had in the House possibly late this week or early next week.

A tomb with pottery of Solomon's era and another containing burials of the Byzantine period have been discovered by a British-American archaeological expedition now exploring the Judean Hills in the southern part of Palestine in an effort to locate the site of the Biblical city of Lachish, according to a cablegram received here yesterday from H. Dunscombe Colt Jr., American director of the party.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith was the choice for Mayor in "a model municipal election by proportional representation" conducted under the joint auspices of the Women's City Club and the City Club of New York, at a luncheon held yesterday at the clubhouse of the latter organization at 55 West Forty-fourth Street.
Several flats taken over by mortgage holders were listed among the New Jersey realty conveyances yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Memorial services for two former Senators and nine members of the House who have died since the last annual services will be held in the House tomorrow, after which that body will adjourn in their memory.

The pamphlet report of the Pacific Telephone and Telegraph Company and subsidiaries for 1932 shows a net income of $16,217,207 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $6.26 a share earned on 1,805,000 common shares, against $18,807,575, or $7.69 a share, earned in 1931.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Governor Moore said today that President-elect Roosevelt was expected either to send a message or speak by radio to the conference here of Governors of Eastern States tomorrow and Saturday.

The Presidents' Traffic Committee of the Eastern Railroads decided yesterday to put into effect on April 1 a reduction in rates on the movement of anthracite westward from the Pittsburgh-Buffalo line to Chicago. The maximum reduction would be $1 a ton, applicable to Chicago shipments, with commensurate cuts for intermediates points.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- The great air adventure whose object is to fly over Mount Everest started officially today when three of the principal participants in the Houston Everest expedition left Heston Airport, twelve miles from London, in three light Moth planes.

James H. Crowley, Fordham's football coach, was welcomed formally to the East and his new position at a dinner in the college dining hall of Fordham University last night, attended by about eighty men, including many members of the press.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Detectives investigating the 1931 stay in Los Angeles of Joseph Zangara, who shot at President-elect Roosevelt, said tonight they had found records indicating he had registered here as a Republican voter.

People are writing letters to the newspapers to declare that they are "bored" by "Ann Vickers," Mr. SINCLAIR LEWIS'S latest novel. It is not disgust, which is a matter of taste, but boredom, which is a matter of experience. Similar laments have been heard in connection with the last fiction published by Mr. H.G. WELLS.

Featured by heavy trading and strength in sugar, prices on local commodity exchanges gave more favorable indications yesterday. Cocoa, silk, hides and silver also closed the day with gains. Prices in cash markets were fairly steady.

James H.R. Cromwell, step-son of E.T. Stotesbury, senior partner of J.P. Morgan Co., calls for government ownership of transportation and public utilities in "The Voice of Young America," a book published by the Scribners today.

The De Witt Clinton and James Monroe High School basketball teams continue to share first place in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P.S.A.L. as a result of yesterday's competition when each turned in its third victory in as many league tests.

GENEVA, Feb. 16. -- Adopting Great Britain's proposals today, the disarmament conference instructed a committee of eighteen countries, including all the great powers and Canada, to examine the possibility ot complete abolition of war aviation and air bombing combined with the establishment of effectual international control of civil aviation.

Into the lump of European troubles there has been put a bit of good-will that may be likened unto the leaven which was hidden in three measures of meal until all was leavened. What has been a mere entente and given the name "Little Entente" to Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania, is now to become, if the convention of yesterday is ratified, a "unified international organization" which will be open to other States.

The Association of Harlem and Bronx Property Owners. Inc., at a mass meeting held Wednesday evening at the Concourse Plaza Hotel to discuss realty market conditions, and especially prevailing interest rates, adopted resolutions asking mortgage holders to accept a reduction in rates.

Two bills designed to relieve the home owner of the 7 per cent interest on his delinquent taxes and to protect his property from tax sales will be introduced Monday in the New Jersey State Legislature, it was announced yesterday by Mayor Hague of Jersey City who, with the other Jersey City Commissioners, caused the measures to be drawn.

MUKDEN, Manchuria, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Along the frozen snow-banked roads which wind south and west from this city soldiers are moving day and night in loose marching order toward the borders of Jehol Province. Japan is getting ready to attack.
MEXICO CITY, Feb. 16. -- Dr. J. M. Puig-Cassauranc, Foreign Minister, sent the following telegram to President-elect Roosevelt tonight:

A difference of interpretation of the action taken by the Association of the Bar at its meeting on Feb. 14 on the recommendation of Samuel Seabury that appointment of magistrates be vested in the Appellate Division arose yesterday when Osmond K. Fraenkel, a member of the association, took exception to the published official version given out after the meeting.
Harvey D. Gibson, banker and chairman of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex with Mrs. Gibson from a trip abroad.

The highest recognition that Colombia College can bestow for non-athletic activities, the gold King's Crown, has been awarded to nineteen students, it was announced yesterday by The Columbia Spectator, student daily newspaper. Silver awards were given to fifty-eight students.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Representative Snell has promised more than 100 Republican votes for the repeal resolution and, if the Democratic caucus achieves its purpose, approval is virtually assured.

Changes in bankruptcy laws and establishment of a national system of debt commissions to facilitate readjustment and "protect property values against uncontrolled distress liquidation," were proposed yesterday by Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16 (AP) -- After being thrown into confusion by charges of Representative Dickstein of New York of corruption in the office of United States District Attorney George Z. Medalie of the Southern New York District, the House Rules Committee today deferred action on his resolution calling for an investigation.

Space for business use in many Manhattan buildings was taken yesterday. The day's leases included about one-fourth of the sixth floor in the new Port Authority Commerce Building, at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street. This space was taken by the National Card Mounting Company, Inc., through Brown, Wheelock, Harris Co.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 16 (AP). -- Miss Margaret Kruis, 23, a Winter visitor here from Newark, N.J., who suffered a scalp wound from a bullet fired by Joseph Zangara in an attempt upon the life of President-elect Roosevelt, told in the hospital today the following story of the shooting:

The Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra celebrated the one-hundredth anniversary of the birth of Johannes Brahms at Carnegie Hall last night. The observance was almost three months too early, if exact dates are to be honored in these matters, for Brahms was born on May 7, 1833.

The Indignation of the entire world has been heaped upon Joseph Zangara, according to The Associated Press. But for the President-elect there were messages of congratulation from the ends of the earth on his escape.

Charles S. Thide was called by Assistant District Attorney Gibbs yesterday as the second witness in the General Sessions trial of Sam Kaplan, former president, and twenty-one other officers and members of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Operators' Union on a coercion indictment.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- For the sixth time in the sixteen months of its existence the British Government was attacked today by a motion of censure from the Labor Opposition in the House of Commons and as usual the government won by an overwhelming majority.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (Canadian Press). -- His Majesty indicated today he was greatly interested in the cricket test series won from Australia by England today.

A new solution of the problem of borough automony under a revised charter for the city was evolved last night at a meeting of the Civic Conference, held in the Bar Association Building, 42 West Forty-fourth Street.

A defect in the so-called Rankin bill which would attempt to increase commodity prices through "conntrolled" inflation, is that it provides no workable method for safeguarding the national gold reserve. Thomas F. Woodlock, former member of the Interstate Commerce Commission said yesterday in an address at the Lawyers' Club, 115 Broadway.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Weakness in the stock markets today had little lasting effect on wheat on the Board of Trade here, a minor decline from yesterday's final prices developing fair buying to close spreads between this market and Winnipeg.

PARIS, Feb. 16. -- Former Premier Edouard Herriot today answered outbursts and accusations in the Italian press that the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Chamber of Deputies had been hearing charges regarding the reported treaty of alliance between Italy, Germany and Hungary by the statement that the question of Hungary had not been brought up.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The newly ratified Twentieth Amendment to the Constitution provides for the contingency which might have arisen last night had President-elect Roosevelt been killed at Miami.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Honors were even in official aeronautic records won by men and women last year, according to the list of new record-holders, announced today by the National Aeronautic Association. Five aviators and five women fliers are on the list.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 15, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,099,000,000, an increase of $30,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $304,000,000, compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

CHESTER, Pa., Feb. 16. -- A thrilling tale of the rescue at sea sixty miles off the coast of Florida of a commercial aviator who had been adrift for fifty-two hours with only an inner tube to keep him afloat was told here tonight when the Sun Oil Company tanker J.N. Pew docked.

Mrs. Cordelia Sinnott of 327 Euclid Avenue, Brooklyn, mother of Detective William Sinnott, who was wounded in the attempt to assassinate President-elect Roosevelt, expressed gratitude yesterday over her son's narrow escape from death by the gunman's bullet.

Three test cases to determine the right of the city to collect $500 each from theatres that gave Sunday performances "not of a sacred or educational nature" were filed in the Supreme Court yesterday. The suits are brought against the Madison Square Garden, the Dillingham Theatre Corporation, as owner of the Globe Theatre, and the Societies Realty Corporation, as owner of the Town Hall.

Public interest and a newly aroused concern for the future of the Metropolitan Opera was shown spontaneously when one of the season's largest audiences filled that theatre last evening for the fourth hearing of Delibes's "Lakme," with Lily Pons and Martinelll heading the cast of stars.

Proper relationship between advertising "pressure" and potential markets was urged yesterday by L.D.H. Weld, director of research of McCann-Erickson, Inc., addressing members of the Sales Executive Club at their weekly luncheon at the Hotel Roosevelt.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- A new theory of cosmic rays was put forward today by P.M.S. Blackett, young Cambridge physicist, who holds they consist, partly at least, of a new kind of particle, which he called a "positive electron."
PARIS, Feb. 16. -- Protesting new taxation and demanding "massive economies," shopkeepers all over Paris closed shop this afternoon.

Despite a drop in new insurance written and total policies outstanding, the total admitted assets and distributions to policy holders of the Equitable Life Assurance Society continued to increase in 1932, according to the annual report, issued yesterday.

Because of discussion of the possible consolidations of railroads into a national system caused by the report of the National Transportation Committee, issued on Tuesday, informal reassurance as to the relation of the proposal to employment among the approximately 1,000,000 of workers on the railroads was offered in management circles yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- President-elect Roosevelt is receiving the congratulations of the entire British press and public on his escape from assassination, and general sympathy is expressed for Mayor Cermak of Chicago, who was wounded at Miami last night.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Feb. 14:

NEW YORK. The last Friday Assembly of this season will take place tonight in the Crystal room of the Ritz-Carlton. Mrs. Hugh Campbell Wallace heads the committee in charge. Other members include Mr. Wallace, Mr. and Mrs. James Russell Lowell, Mr. and Mrs. Elisha Dyer, Mr. and Mrs. C. Peabody Mohun, Miss Virginia Cowperthwaite, Miss Edna Brokaw, Lawrence Morris, John W. Rosa and Edward Everett Watts Jr.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 16. -- Amid an uproar and over the protests of Senator Huey P. Long, his armed bodyguard was expelled this afternoon from the Senatorial hearing into the frauds alleged in the Broussard-Overton Senatorial primary.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 16. -- Repeating the splendid victories he had achieved in the specialty show of the Airedale Terrier Club of America and in the exhibition of the Westminster Kennel Club, the grand airedale terrier, Warland Protector of Shelterock, owned by S.M. Stewart of Montclair, N.J., gained the highest award tonight in the twentieth annual dog show of the Newark Kennel Club held in the 113th Regiment Armory.
The Toronto Maple Leafs overcame an early advantage gained by the New York Rangers to defeat the blue jerseyed sextet in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night, 5 to 2.

New York Athletic Club officials obtained record application blanks from the A.A.U. yesterday in the expectation that several world's records would be shattered in the annual Winged Foot track and field games at Madison Square Garden tomorrow night.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 16. -- Seven railroad workshop employes were killed and sixteen perhaps mortally wounded this morning when troops stormed buildings in which 4,000 strikers had barricaded themselves yesterday.

A committee of the House of Representatives has favorably reported a bill intended to deal with the farm-mortgage situation. Its scope is limited to mortgages held by the Federal Land Banks. Here it provides an extension of time for delinquent payments, spreading them over a period not to exceed ten years.

WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT ROOSEVELT, EN ROUTE TO NEW YORK; JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Expressions of gratitude that President-elect Roosevelt escaped from an assassin's bullet were conspicuous today in the hundreds of telegrams received by him on the train.

A policeman stationed outside the town house of Franklin D. Roosevelt at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street, and an almost uninterrupted arrival of messenger boys with telegrams were the only outward indications there yesterday of the dramatic incident in Miami, where the President-elect narrowly escaped assassination.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 16. -- Philadelphia detectives today cornered the Ferguson gang of bank bandits in their hide-away in Roxborough, at the northwest tip of the city, killed the leader, captured three of his band and recovered $37,000 which the four had stolen from the First National Bank of Ambier in a daring hold-up about an hour earlier.

Oceanographic work at this time of the year in Puerto Rican waters must be a joy to scientists -- especially when their mother-ship is Mr. ELDRIDGE R. JOHNSON'S steam yacht Caroline. She has begun to explore the Puerto Rico Deep, which, according to the United States Coast and Geodetic Survey, has been sounded to 4,662 fathoms (27,972 feet).

Jere F. Ryan, Democratic leader of Bayside and head of the Ryan Sales and Service Company, automobile dealer, was appointed Public Markets Commissioner yesterday by Mayor O'Brien to fill the vacancy caused last September when Acting Mayor McKee dismissed Thomas F. Dwyer.

ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Demands for a further reduction of at least $30,000,000 in Governor Lehman's $216,000,000 budget, including a 20 per cent cut in State aid for education, were made by representatives of civic and business organizations today at an unusual public hearing before the legislative fiscal committees.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 16. -- Brazilian residents of the Argentine Chaco contradict the Paraguayan Government's claim that Bolivian planes bombarded Concepcion, Paraguay, recently. A certified copy of a communication addressed to the Brazilian Minister in Buenos Aires by "the Brazilian colony in Formosa," Argentina, has been made public here. Dated Jan. 23, it says:

DENVER, Feb. 16 (AP). -- Search for Charles Boettcher 2d turned to isolated cabins and remote gulches of the Lookout Mountain country tonight, as the investigation of the kidnapping of the young broker reached the end of another blind trail here.
Approximately 1,250,000 persons without homes are wandering up and down the country, the National Committee on Care of the Transient and Homeless declared yesterday.

Affecting a cool indifference to the serious charge he faced, Harry Murch, 15 years old, of Richmond Hill Circle, Queens, the "gang" leader who is accused of murdering 12-year-old William Bender and hiding the body in an untenanted house, swaggered up to the bench before Magistrate Peter M. Daly in Jamaica Court yesterday.

Hunters who take pride in their ability to search out woodcock and then bag them, despite the fact that the woodcock is both scarce and hard to hit, will have more than passing interest in a bill which is to come before the New Jersey Legislature and by which the season on woodcock would be started on Nov. 10 instead of Oct. 15.

While the Michigan banking situation appeared yesterday to have shown further improvement as a result of the emergency measures that have been resorted to, the security markets were unsettled again by fresh liquidation supplemented, no doubt, by speculative selling for the fall.

Some of the arrivals today from Germany, France and England on the New York of the Hamburg-American Line are Senator Joseph Connolly, Minister of Land and Fisheries of the Irish Free State, and Dan J. McGrath, newly appointed Irish Free State Consul at Chicago. Others on the liner are:

State of Montana. The State of Montana has scheduled a new issue of $4,500,000 of funding bonds for award on Feb. 23. The bonds will mature serially from Jan. 1, 1934 to 1953, and the rate of interest is to be named by the bidders at not to exceed 4 per cent, according to word received here yesterday.

The New York Curb Exchange Announced yesterday the members of the standing committees for 1933. Two new members, Philip Cohen and Roy G. Vilas, were added to the board of governors. There were several changes in the personnel of the various committees:

A play by A.J. Minor, tentatively called "Masks and Faces," has been placed in rehearsal by Paul Martin, who also is staging the production. It is scheduled to open here about March 13, with a cast including Enid Romany, Gordon Richards, Donald Foster, Edgar Nelson, William Roselle, Kathleen Lowry and Edward Broadley.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 16. -- In a letter addressed to the Delaware River Joint Commission, Governor Moore suggested today that plans for a high-speed transit line over the Camden-Philadelphia Bridge be held in abeyance until the project has been investigated more thoroughly.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange held steady yesterday and closed with losses of 1 to 2 points.

BREMERHAVEN, Feb. 16. -- The Lufthansa's "floating airport," the steamship Westfalen, "which is to be stationed in the middle of the South Atlantic between Gambia, Africa, and Pernambuco, Brazil, as a refueling station for a proposed transooean air line, was demonstrated to a delegation of government officials in the North Sea this afternoon.

LONDON, Feb. 16. -- Field Marshal Sir William Robertson, who rose from the ranks to the highest place in the British Army, was buried as a simple civilian, in accordance with his wishes, in Brookwood Cemetery today.

LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP). -- A movement for Prime Minister MacDonald to reach Washington about March 15 for important personal talks with Mr. Roosevelt on the broad lines of the whole future of Anglo-American policy in the field of international affairs gained strength today.

BERLIN, Feb. 16. -- The committee of international bankers which has been considering since last month the extension of foreign short-term credits in Germany agreed tonight in principle to prolong the credits for another year.
The Rest Will Be Simple. It is no longer open to doubt that Mr. ROOSEVELT will bring with him to the White House the courage and fixity of purpose and swift decision that the times demand.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16. -- Scott S. Durand, head of the Chicago sugar brokerage concern, bearing his name, was named today as one of the leaders in a $9,500,000 alcohol conspiracy in an indictment returned before Federal Judge Charles E. Woodward.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The House Rules Committee, after listening to Representative Dickstein of New York plead for approval of his resolution for an investigation of the office and conduct of United States Attorney George Z. Medalie, declined to take action on the resolution at an executive session this morning.

The first concrete evidence of approval by the banking community of New York City's efforts at financial retrenchment was given yesterday when the city arranged to borrow $25,000,000 from the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank against 1933 taxes.

Federal regulation of intercoastal shipping was urged yesterday by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the Panama Pacific Line, and Edward P. Farley, chairman of the executive committee of the American Hawaiian Line, both of whom declared that the Copeland bill, which was passed last Summer by the Senate and recently reported by a House committee, provided the soluion of the intercoastal problem.

E. Ramey Donovan, captain of the Fordham University tennis team, was among the winners yesterday as play in the New YorK State intercollegiate indoor tennis championship got under way in the 102d Engineers' Armory. Donovan defeated Ralph Wolf of St. John's, 6 -- 4, 3 -- 6, 6 -- 2.

Some things cannot be put into words. One of them is the deep breath of relief and gratitude drawn by every American citizen on Wednesday night and yesterday morning when he learned that Mr. ROOSEVELT had escaped the bullets of a crack-brained assassin at Miami.

A letter by George Washington in which he laid down the maxim "founded on the universal experience of mankind, that no nation is to be trusted farther than it is bound by its interest; and no prudent statesman or politician will venture to depart from it," brought $3,750 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc.

In a closing address before about one thousand trust company executives of the United States, and directed at the public, Julius Klein, Assistant Secretary of Commerce, said at the dinner that ended the midwinter trust conference of the American Bankers Association in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel last night, that it was time to stop "the indiscriminate and reckless abuse of all banks and bankers."

Fourteen canvases by fourteen American artists were placed on view yesterday at the Kraushaar Galleries, where they will remain for six weeks. It is one of those peculiarly satisfying group shows such as Mr. Kraushaar, when the afflatus descends, can always be relied upon to produce.

The Woman's International League for Peace and Freedom honored Mrs. Israel Zangwill, English woman leader, and Lord Marley, Deputy Speaker in the British House of Lords, at its annual dinner last night in the Gotham Hotel. Both the visitors made pleas for an effective drive to prevent war and maintain international amity.

Hope that the newsprint industry might obtain tariff protection at the forthcoming special session of Congress was expressed yesterday by Selden E. Wardwell, chairman of the executive committee of the Great Northern Paper Company, at the annual meeting of the American Pulp and Paper Association at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- Should Speaker Garner be successful Monday in putting the Senate's prohibition repeal resolution through the House, as he is confident of doing, he will be the hero in the exciting legislative drama which began on the first day of this session.

DETROIT, Feb. 16 (AP) -- Detroit's Red Wings gained only a 2-2 tie in an exciting overtime National League hockey match with the Montreal Maroons tonight, but the single point gained in the standings, coupled with the defeat of the Rangers by Toronto, sent them into first place alone in the American division.

With a miniature rotogravure page for a cover, News-Week, a news magazine which hopes to strike between the circulations of Time and The Literary Digest and find a public, is issued for the first time today. More than 70,000 copies of the first issue are being printed and the thirty-six-page periodical, including covers, carries twenty-four and one-half columns of advertising.

With the release of fresh selling on the Stock Exchange yesterday. Wall Street searched vainly for an explanation. The actual happenings of the day were encouraging, so it was assumed -- but perhaps incorrectly -- that speculators for the decline were succeeding in an attempt to dislodge stock holdings.

WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT ROOSEVELT, EN ROUTE TO NEW YORK, SAVANNAH, Ga., Feb. 16. -- Unperturbed by his miraculous escape from a would-be assassin's bullet at Miami last night and concerned only for the two seriously wounded, President-elect Roosevelt sped north today, meeting with expressions of thankfulness for his safety from the crowds that gathered at the railroad stations and in hundreds of telegrams delivered to him on the train.

A Federal investigation of charges made yesterday by Representative Samuel Dickstein in Washington against a clerk in Federal court and against an assistant of George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, both unnamed, seemed likely as an aftermath to the Federal inquiry here into fraud at the November election, which has resulted to date in the indictment of thirty-seven persons, most of them election officials.

Federal regulation of intercoastal shipping was urged yesterday by P.A.S. Franklin, president of the Panama Pacific Line, and Edward P. Farley, chairman of the executive committee of the American Hawaiian Line, both of whom declared that the Copeland bill, which was passed last Summer by the Senate and recently reported by a House committee, provided the solution of the intercoastal problem.

As in her previous recitals of Spanish songs in costume, Conchita Supervia, Spanish soprano, last night revealed herself as past master -- or should one say past mistress? -- of the ability to convey by gesture, look, charming stage presence and voice the peculiar flavor of her country's songs; the juxta-position of acid, austere irony and voluptuousness which essentially distinguish the music of the Iberian peninsula from that of the rest of Europe.

The J.C. Penney Company announced yesterday that the directors had authorized the retirement of 96,000 shares of its 6 per cent preferred stock, representing at par value $9,600,000. On Jan. 12, the company asked for tenders of the stock at $103 a share up to $7,500,000 par value.

Bond prices sagged on the Stock Exchange yesterday, with leading issues of all groups averaging substantially lower for the day. Public utility bonds were about the weakest of the domestic corporation list, with rails and industrials next in the order named.
Most of yesterday's realty activity in Manhattan, the Bronx and Brooklyn was in housing properties. The trading included both sales and leases.
LONDON, Feb. 16 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:
Fillmore V.S. Hyde, the only player who has won four national squash tennis championships, gained the final round in the veterans' tourney at the Columbia University Club courts yesterday.

Former Deputy Chief Thomas J. Ahearn, one of the outstanding heroes in the history of the New York Fire Department, whom the late Chief Hugh Bonner called "the bravest of the brave," died yesterday morning at his home, 35-73 161st Street, Flushing, Queens, from a stroke of apoplexy suffered a few days ago.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Dispatches from Moscow speak of famine, but that does not lower the enthusiasm of our own after-luncheon orators who continue to laud the Five-Year Plan, and particularly the educational work of the Soviet State.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 16. -- The shipping Board today approved the sale of fifty-two cargo steamships, to be used in the foreign trade, to the Lykes Brothers-Ripley Steamship Company of New Orleans. These vessels will operate in a guaranteed service from New Orleans to the United Kingdom, European and Oriental ports.

Mayor O'Brien formally opened yesterday the new $697,000 Harway Avenue Bridge to Coney Island. At the end of the ceremony, which was attended by more than 2,000 persons, the Mayor stepped forward and cut the ribbon across the east span with a pair of silver shears.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Recent discussions in Congress of the salaries and retired allowances of army officers call to mind a debate last Spring, when a member of the lower house asked about the duties of officers in battle and whether there were casualties among the officers.

WITH PRESIDENT-ELECT ROOSEVELT, EN ROUTE TO NEW YORK, JACKSONVILLE, Fla., Feb. 16. -- Joseph Zangara, the diminutive would be assassin of President-elect Roosevelt, is more intelligent and has a better education than he would have the authorities believe.
ALBANY, Feb. 16. -- Senator Seabury C. Mastick, Republican, of Westchester, was challenged today on the seat in the upper house which the veteran tax expert has held for a decade.

In Brooklyn on Wednesday the death of a juryman in an important criminal case which had been going on for six days and would shortly have gone to the jury forced the judge to declare a mistrial. The proceedings so near completion must be begun again.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Reduction of 30 per cent in the acreage planted to cash crops will be required this year of farmers who procure crop-production loans, Secretary Hyde announced today in making public the regulations governing the loans for this year.

Plain-clothes policemen interrupted what they said was the opening of an exclusive gambling resort In a four-story private house at 216 East Sixty-first Street by raiding the place about 11 o'clock last night. In the establishment, which was known as the Junior Carlton Club, they found twenty-three patrons, all of whom were in evening attire.

TETERBORO, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Lincoln Ellsworth, the explorer, leader of the Ellsworth TransAntarctio Expedition, and his pilot for his great adventure in the Antarctic, Bernt Balchen, who flew Admiral Byrd on his transatlantic and South Pole expeditions, took off from Teterboro Airport this morning for Grand Forks, N.D., which will be their base during extended test flights under load over snow-clad Canadian terrain.
CHICAGO, Feb. 17. -- All hope of averting the bankruptcy of the Middle West Utilities Company has been abandoned, it was indicated today in proceedings before Federal Judge James H. Wilkerson.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 17. -- Lee "Wilson Dodd, playwright and author, will succeed George Pierce Baker in the playwriting courses in the yale Department of Drama next year when Professor Baker retires.

The Right Rev. James De Wolf Perry, Presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church and Bishop of Rhode Island, will leave today, accompanied by his wife, for Vancouver, B.C., to sail next Saturday on the liner Empress of China for a four months' official visitation of mission work of his communion in the Hawaiian Islands, the Philippines, China and Japan.

The Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church, Seventy-third Street and Madison Avenue, receives a bequest of $25,000 under the will of Henry I. Judson, husband of the late Frances Williams Judson, who died on Feb. 6, last, in his eighty-fourth year, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

The committee of Eastern railroad presidents formed to curb preventable wastes brought nearly to completion yesterday a report which is expected to go a long way toward meeting the criticisms of competitive excesses leveled at the railroads by the National Transportation Committee in a report issued on Tuesday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- An analysis of the Senate vote yesterday on the question of submitting flat repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to the people shows that the Senators who voted "aye" represent an overwhelming majority of citizens, taxpayers, supporters of the successful Presidential candidate of 1932 and members of the House of Representatives.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Governor Theodore F. Green of Rhode Island and officials of seven other Eastern States were present today for the opening sessions of the two-day conference called by Governor Moore to seek solutions to the common problems faced by State and local governments as a result of the economic situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Participation of the United States with a committee of the League of Nations in negotiations with China and Japan in an effort to settle the Manchurian dispute is a question for the Roosevelt administration to decide if the point ever arises concretely.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17. -- Plans for a more liberal lending policy by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, designed to expedite public works as a means of relieving unemployment, were approved by the Senate today in adopting Senator Wagner's amendment to remove the stipulation that public works built with corporation money must be self-liquidating.

A constant dread of war hangs over Russia, and the Kremlin Government is putting through immense defense plans in preparation for war, Elias Tobenkin writes in "Stalin's Ladder," just published by Minton, Balch Co.

The poetry, the patrician beauty and lyricism of Montemezzi's opera, "The Love of Three Kings," do not halt with the passing of the years. The revival of this work last night by the Metropolitan Opera Association returned to the repertory the most sincere and idealistic score which has come from Italy in the modern period -- in fact, since the period of Wagner and Verdi.

One of the pieces of sculpture which Roxy rejected from the Radio City Music Hall has become one of the honored exhibits at the forty-eighth annual exhibition of the Architectural League of New York, which opened yesterday at 215 West Fifty-seventh Street with a private showing for members.

The Prudence Company, Inc., has mailed to investors in mortgage securities guaranteed by the company a circular letter enclosing excerpts from the recent statement of Owen D. Young, chairman of the banking and industrial committee of the Second Federal Reserve District, regarding a comprehensive plan through which, it is believed, a general readjustment can be effected in the interests of both real estate owners and investors in mortgages.

After an early period of indecision, the share market pointed upward yesterday and retraced part of the ground lost on the previous day. The moderate improvement seemed to reflect reviving confidence at home, but the sharp rise of foreign currencies against the dollar indicated that financial judgment abroad had been influenced unfavorably by recent events in this country.

The Underwood Elliott Fisher Company reported yesterday for 1932 a net loss of $762,071 after depreciation, taxes and all other charges. This contrasted with a net profit of $1,401,060 in 1931, equivalent, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.79 a share on 674,648 common shares in that year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- "The old gray goose of traffic that lays the golden egg of railroad revenue is just about dead from the surcharge," former Commissioner Johnston B. Campbell warned the Interstate Commerce Commission today, in joining with shippers from all over the country in opposition to the railroads' petition for authority to continue collecting present emergency rates after March 31.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- John A.T. Carrougher, Assistant Postmaster at Brooklyn, was appointed today to succeed Albert B.W. Firmin, who resigned, effective Feb. 28.

Formation of Utilities, Inc., a new member of the Harrison Williams group of Investment trusts, was announced yesterday. Like its associates, it will specialize in the securities of public utility companies. Papers of incorporation were filed yesterday in Maryland.

By the act creating the Reconstruction Finance Corporation it is obliged to make monthly reports of its transactions to Congress. What there is in this requirement that directs, encourages or even suggests spreading these accounts over the country it is hard to see.

A first-degree murder indictment is to be sought against Harry Murch, 15-year-old Richmond Hill Circle boy, who, it is charged, stabbed to death his 12-year-old playmate, William Bender. The Bender boy's body was found in a vacant house in Richmond Hill Circle, Queens, last Wednesday.

With, four members of their ranks temporarily idle because of the strenuousness of the campaign they have waged, the British women's squash racquets team, as represented by the remaining three players, scored another victory yesterday on the courts of the Junior League.

Bronzed, vigorous and smiling, President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt returned home yesterday from his vacation in the South after his escape from the bullets of an assassin and was met by one of the most elaborate police guards ever accorded an individual.
Edward L. Kemble and Frank L. Giusti, members of the Bayside Tennis Club, advanced into the third round of the national Class C squash tennis championship yesterday at the City Athletic Club courts.

A proposal for revising the present law requiring all contractors performing public work for the State to furnish a completion bond is now before the committee on legislation of the New York Chapter of the American Institute of Architects for the committee's study and consideration with a view to enlisting the institute's support of the proposed change.

A student airplane pilot, practicing for his examination for a private pilot's license, startled the residents of Bensonhurst, Brooklyn, yesterday afternoon when the engine of his plane suddenly stopped 2,200 feet up and he dived at the peaked roofs.

RIDGEFIELD, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Almon L. Beall, 40 years old, of 456 Morse Place, this borough, was confined in the psychopathic ward of Bergen Pines Hospital at Oradell today following his action last night in attacking his wife in his home here and resisting capture by the police for more than two hours.
"Well, that's settled, and as I can't recall when it was ever done before I guess it should stand as a record, at least for the New York Giants."

The clothing distribution facilities of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee have been extended to home relief bureaus and public schools, which have been supplied with clothing, order blanks to supply the needy, it was announced yesterday by Frank Kidde, chairman of the Food and Clothing Division.

With his vacation over and unworried by the attempt to assassinate him in Miami, President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt turned yesterday to Cabinet making and conferred on the train speeding northward with three United States Senators to whom he had offered Cabinet appointments.
ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- Republicans in the Assembly prepared today to do some sharpshooting at Governor Lehman's executive budget.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- British trade is steady, but unemployment has increased, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly review of business conditions abroad. German foreign trade showed an encouraging increase in December.

Leaders in the steel industry are understood to be considering plans that it is hoped will bring firmer prices. Since the depression started, considerable shading of quotations has been done to attract business.

Pity the poor holding company, pride of the late '20s, built layer on layer like a birthday cake, with creamy stuff between the layers, and sugar and candles on top. The cream is now sour, the frosting is gone, and there is no one left to light the candles -- not even in the kitchens where it was cooked.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The objectives of the National Socialist actions in the present contest in Germany have now been frankly and unmistakably voiced by an authorized spokesman.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- League officials were expecting tonight to receive tomorrow an appeal from Colombia invoking the League Covenant against Peru. They tentatively called a special meeting of the Council on the subject for Monday afternoon and prepared to hold it tomorrow if need be.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The Earl of Lytton declared tonight that if either of the parties to the Chino-Japanese dispute refuses to accept the proffered assistance of the League and acts In a manner contravening the covenant, then the resources of the League are by no means exhausted.

Renewed efforts are being made by the League of New York Theatres, the managerial organization representing local theatrical producers and theatre operators, to bring about Sunday-night performances In the legitimate playhouses. The first move in this latest attempt has been the distribution to all members of the league, numbering about fifty, of a printed petition seeking signatures from players who favor Sunday shows.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Quentin Field Feitner, broker of Palm. Beach and New York and real estate dealer, died here at his home, Casa Invierno, early this morning after a short illness. He was 48 years old.

Two criticisms of modern education were made yesterday afternoon by Miss Fannie Hurst, writer, and Dr. Harry Dexter Kitson, Professor of Education at Teachers College, before the Panhellenic educational conference at the Panhellenic House, 3 Mitchell Place.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few days ago Congressman Crowther referred to the Democratic party as "demagoguing its way through the pages of history." This partisan heat was engendered by his inability to pass a higher tariff bill through a Democratic House.

ABOARD U.S.S. PENNSYLVANIA, SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 17 -- Fighting planes flashed against the dawn and the pounding screws of men-of-war thrashed trails of foam off the Golden Gate early this morning when the navy's annual mimic war ended in a scrambling melee on and above the sea.

DES MOINES, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Mid-Western farmers, seeking emergency mortgage relief measures and delinquent tax-sale postponements, counted tonight definite victories in three States and big strides toward succcess in several others.

WRENTHAM, Mass., Feb. 17 -- All the honors in the power of a community were paid to Ernie Schaaf today when the inhabitants of this, his town, joined hundreds of outsiders at his funeral. A cottege of automobiles two miles long escorted the body of the boxer from the Schaaf home to a country church and thence to the cemetery.

Radio operators of THE NEW YORK TIMES, who have established many records in long-distance reception of news, broke one of their records of another kind yesterday by copying the 15,000 words of the Manchurian report of the League's Committee of Nineteen.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Resolutions urging Congress immediately to enact legislation authorizing the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to make relief loans to municipalities, at par and secured by pledges of unpaid or delinquent taxes, and to purchase municipal tax-anticipation warrants with or without maturity date, were unanimously adopted at the Mayors' conference which met here today at the call of Mayor Frank Murphy of Detroit to devise means for providing financial relief to cities.

HAVANA, Feb. 17 (AP) -- South Seas, with a record of one victory, two seconds and two thirds in five starts this Winter, today won his second successive race at Oriental Park, leading a field of platers over a mile and fifty yards.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the Liquor Commission, to Governor Lehman, published this morning, is so sound and so realistic that it is startling to find in it a section that might well have been dictated by a syndicate of our leading illicit beer barons.

Friday, Feb. 17, 1933. Nothing happened in the day's money market to distinguish it from preceding sessions. Business was extremely light, and in the case of time money quotations these continued on a nominal basis. Stock Exchange call loans were 1 per cent, Federal checks 1/2 @ 3/4 and Street money 3/4.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17 -- Wheat traders construed developments in the world's situation today as indicative of higher prices. Early active buying of the July and September by strong commission houses sent prices about 5/8 cent above Thursday's' finish, but the upturn brought a return of the persistent selling of the May.

TOKYO, Feb. 17. -- The issue as to whether Japan shall withdraw from the League of Nations la reaching a crisis, with fairly authoritative indications at present that the Cabinet is divided, Premier Saito and Finance Minister Takahashi opposing Foreign Minister Uchida, War Minister Araki and Admiral Osumi, Minister of the Navy.

Jesse Baker of St. John's College won two matches yesterday in the New York State intercollegiate indoor tennis championship play which is in progress at the 102d Engineers Armory, and advanced to the semi-final with three seeded players.

Virtually all commodities fell into line yesterday with the upward trend evidenced by several earlier in the week. For the most part, however, trading was not so heavy as on the preceding day and many of the gains were the result of short-covering.

In line with a policy he formulated at the beginning of his term of office, Governor Joseph B. Ely of Massachusetts yesterday announced the creation of an advisory board for the division of fisheries and game of the State Conservation Department.
WASHINGTON, Sept. 17 -- The House of Representatives paid tribute today to the memories of two Senators and eight members of the House who have died in the last twelve months.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The foggy weather that has handicapped test flights at Billancourt, a suburb of Paris, throughout the Winter again prevented the Farman stratosphere plane today from invading the upper regions of rarefied air, according to Farman experts.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- Dollar exchange dropped heavily here today from 25.49 francs to 25.33 1/2, the lowest it has been since the critical period last June and within a slight margin of the sold export point. Taking advantage of the Michigan bank holiday and increasingly insistent reports from the United States regarding inflation or devaluation of the dollar, speculators reaped a harvest.

Low-price no-tipping dining cars will be placed in service on Monday for commuters on the Bankers Express of the New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad, it was announced yesterday. Similar service will be offered on the corresponding evening train from.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- Conclusion of the new standstill agreement permitting eventual investment of a part of the standstill funds in the security market stimulated stocks and bonds on the Boerse today. Advances in the stock market were almost general, public demand for Reich issues and short-term loans kept on increasing throughout the day.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Wholesale prices in January declined another 2.5 per cent below the preceding month, according to the index number of the Bureau of Labor Statistics, which stood at 61 for January, compared with 62.6 for December, and an average for 1926 equaling 100.

Evidence tending to confirm his original statement that Ernie Schaaf's death was not the result of injuries received in the battle with Prime Carnera was disclosed yesterday by Dr. Charles Norris chief medical examiner, following a microscopic examination of the brain of Schaaf.

The annual report of the Commonwealth Edison Company and its subsidiary, the Commonwealth Subsidiary Corporation, for 1932 shows a net income of $10,059,487 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal to $5.95 a share earned on 1,611,421 outstanding and 77,797 subscribed shares, compared with $16,322,542, or $10.40 a share earned on 1,569,420 common shares, in 1931.

ALBANY, Feb. 17 -- There will be little or no delay in this State in setting up machinery for action on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment if submitted by Congress, it was predicted today. The present Legislature before it adjourns plans to call a State convention to meet and act upon the question some time during the Summer months.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Special right of way for the Stewart bill to create the Morristown National Historical Park in New Jersey was agreed on today by the House Rules Committee, and plans were immediately laid to call the measure up for House consideration under suspension of the rules, probably Monday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 17 -- With Bradford Simmons, heavyweight, scoring his fifth straight first-round knockout victory, Harvard's boxing team defeated Penn State, 5 to 3, in the indoor athletic building tonight. The Crimson won four bouts and Penn State two, with the other two resulting in draw decisions.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 17 -- Martin Mulvey, 82 years old, a retired teacher of 272 North Seventh Street, died as the result of injuries be received in two automobile accidents this afternoon.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 15 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

A biography of Mustafa Kemal Pasha, who Is now engaged in forcing the religious in Turkey to say their prayers in Turkish rather than Arabic, has just been published by Minton, Balch. The title is "Gray Wolf" and the author is H.C. Armstrong.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Joseph Zangara, the man who tried to kill President-elect Roosevelt, was declared sane today by Dr. E.C. Thomas, county physician.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 17 -- Governor Lehman warned today against "destructive economy" in State fiscal policy which would cripple progressive government, and insisted that partisan politics should be barred in considering the budget.

Color is the keynote of the fourth annual show of the Lithuanian Arts Circle, which is being held on the mezzanine floor of the Hotel Victoria. Still-life and landscape predominate, water-colors being more numerous than oils. The still-life studies are the outstanding things in the show, among them two by J.F. Tamosaitis, excellent in their arrangement and delightful in their color.

Mary Pickford will sail on the Italian liner Rex today to join her husband, Douglas Fairbanks, on the Riviera. They expect to proceed east, stopping in China, and return to California on the Pacific.
