Other prominent passengers include Joseph P. Grace, steamship man, and George Doubleday, president of Ingersoll-Rand Company.

With the mystery surrounding him somewhat clarified by statements from his two alleged accomplices, Lou Douglas, described as "a Texas bad man" wanted for a double murder in Arizona, continued yesterday to elude detectives who are searching for him.
NEW YORK. Charles E.F. McCann and his daughter, Miss Helena McCann, have gone to Palm Beach where they will be at their Winter home.

Cooperation was offered as the way back to prosperity by Will H. Hays, president of the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America yesterday at a luncheon of the Association of New York Business Paper Editors, in the auditorium of the McGraw-Hill Building, 330 West Forty-second Street.

Michael Isaacs, a member of the Socialist party, who watched at the polls on Election Day last November, appeared In Federal Court yesterday and re-enacted for the benefit of Judge John C. Knox and a jury his description of the vote count in the Sixth Election District at Public School 10, Cannon and Broome Streets.

No one has been more widely known personally to the teachers of America than Dr. A.E. WINSHIP, for nearly fifty years editor of The Journal of Education. He was a Nestor in years, being 88, but so tie was also in his friendly counsels among the younger teachers, some of whom were as Diomeds who might be his youngest sons.

THE attempt to find somebody to discourse with authority on track athletics was a failure. Daniel J. Ferris, secretary-treasurer of the A. A.U., was in conference. Johnny McHugh, veteran starter and official of the P.S.A.L., was not at his desk in another part of the city. TL elevator runner ventured the opinion that Mr. McHugh might be off at some revolver range taking target practice.

To the Editor of The New York Times: So, the American customs officials banned Michelangelo as being obscene! This, of course, affords Europe and other enlightened parts of the world another laugh at our expense. No doubt the economic conditions have been mitigated considerably over there by continued laughter at the idiotic antics of our great country.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- After weeks of study and hearings on various plans to remonetize silver, a House Coinage, Weights and Measures subcommittee unanimously agreed late today to report a tentative bill to the full committee next Monday or Tuesday for action by the entire body.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Mrs. Samuel Valentine entertained at her villa tonight with a dinner and had as guests Mr. and Mrs. Emil J. Stehli, Captain and Mrs. John H. Gibbons, Major and Mrs. Elisha D. Hubbard, Mr. and Mrs. G. Horton Glover, Bishop and Mrs. Nathaniel Seymour Thomas and Theodore Clarence Hollander.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 (AP) -- Home Work, a 4-year-old son of Broomstick, with a reputation of being strictly a router, today started in a six-furlong sprint at the Fair Grounds and won his first race of the Winter season.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- The Italian press, printing the text of the second Franco-British note to Austria in connection with the discovery at Hirtenberg of arms shipped from Italy and destined for Hungary, comments in the severest manner today on its "violent terms" and the harshness of the conditions laid down.

Designs for costumes and murals, by Lillian Gaertner Palmedo, are being shown at the Marie Sterner Gallery until Feb. 25. Those who saw this season's production of Strauss's "Electra" at the Metropolitan Opera House were enabled to study actual costumes developed from Mrs. Palmedo's designs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Another advocate of a stronger banking system and a balanced budget appeared before the Senate Committee on Economic Conditions today when David F. Houston, former Secretary of the Treasury, and now president of the Mutual Life Insurance Company of New York, added his plea for stable currency.

The Citizens Committee in Aid of Stage Relief announced yesterday that it had opened offices at 515 Madison Avenue for the sale of tickets for its benefit to be held at the Metropolitan Opera House, March 26. It also announced the names of Its general committee, which will have charge of the benefit

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The last home railway dividend statement was issued today, that of the London North Eastern, which declared 1 per cent on the 4 per cent first preference and 1 1/4 per cent on the 5 per cent redeemable preference, against full dividends in 1931.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 17 -- Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, women's Western golf champion, defeated Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., in the eighteen-hole final for the championship of Florida at the Palm Beach Country Club today.

President-elect Roosevelt, in the regalia of a representative of the Grand Lodge of Masons of the State of Georgia, raised his son Elliott to the degree of Master Mason in Architect Lodge, 519 F. and A. M., at a communication of the lodge last night in the Grand Lodge Room of the Masonic Hall, 71 West Twenty-third Street.

Pennsylvania. Confirming estimates made with the recent declaration of its 50-cent dividend for 1933, the Pennsylvania Railroad in a preliminary statement issued yesterday showed a net income of $13,573,536, or $1.03 a share, for 1932, against $19,941,498, or $1.48 a share, in 1931.

Buying by commission houses increased yesterday on the Cotton Exchange, causing a 15-point advance at one time. March liquidation prior to notices next Thursday and scattered profit-taking closed the list 4 to 7 points higher than on Thursday.

BOSTON, Feb. 17 -- Harvard's hockey team turned back Dartmouth in an overtime game at the Boston Garden tonight by the score of 5 to 2. Two overtime sessions were required, with Harvard scoring three times in the second extra session.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 17 -- The first clashes after several days of rainy season inactivity were reported from the Chaco today.

The Thomas Jefferson and James Madison High School basketball teams remained tied for first place in the Brooklyn division of the P.S.A.L. tournament by triumphing in two of the five Brooklyn P.S.A.L. games contested yesterday. Both registered their fifth victories in as many league starts, Jefferson defeating Franklin K. Lane, 45 to 15, at Jefferson and Madison conquering Boys High, 38 to 29, at Boys High.

In 1932 the output per man-hour in manufacturing plants was about 20 per cent greater than in 1927 and 12 per cent greater than in 1929, Dr. Frederick C. Mills of Columbia University declared, in a study of changes between 1927 and 1932, made for the National Bureau of Economic Research and given out for publication yesterday.

A total of $10,768,300 of new State and municipal financing is scheduled for award next week, including some issues that are expected to attract lively competitive bidding. The amount compares with the revised figure for this week of $11,343,028, which, however, does not include the $25,000,000 of revenue bills sold by New York City through negotiation.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 17 -- With more than 2,000 pages and about 500,000 words of testimony in its record, the Senate's subcommittee on campaigns recessed today subject to call, after twelve days of inquiry into Louisiana politics and the Overton-Broussard Senatorial primary of 1932.
The text of the draft report of the League of Nations Committe of Nineteen on the Chino-Japanese dispute, as received by THE NEW YORK TIMES radio station direct from Geneva yesterday, is a follows:
Insull as Maestro. MARY GARDEN believes that If Chicago has no opera today it is SAMUEL INSULL'S fault. As head of the Chicago opera organization he set out to play the dictator and czar.

Another battle between Gene Venzke and Glenn Cunningham will be the feature offering at Madison Square Garden tonight when these two rivals clash in the Baxter Mile, one of the many attractions of the annual New York Athletic Club track and field games.
With the Tuxedo Gold Racquet in his possession, Clarence C. Pell will start today in quest of his twelfth national amateur racquets championship at the Racquet and Tennis Club, 370 Park Avenue.

City College and Yale divided their Intercollegiate Swimming Association dual meet at the C.C. N.Y. pool last night, the Elis gaining the swimming laurels by 40 -- 31 for their 108th consecutive collegiate dual-meet victory, and their sixty-third straight league triumph, and the Lavender capturing a hardfought water-polo contest, 17-13.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- The month-old mystery of the government's "secret prisoner," held in the Tower of London on charges of violating the official secrets act, was partly solved tonight when the War Office revealed his name. He was officially described as Lieutenant N. Baillie-Stewart of the Seaforth Highlanders.

LUCERNE, Que., Feb. 17 -- Eddie Blood of the University of New Hampshire today won the downhill skiing race as competition opened in the eighth annual International Intercollegiate Winter Sports Union championships. Stars from seven colleges and universities in Canada and the United States took part.
LOS ANGELES, Feb. 17 -- An astronomer at the Carnegie Institution's Mount Wilson Observatory has for the first time established the existence of ammonia gas on a planet.
The Citizens Budget Commission estimated last night that the basic tax rate for 1933 would be $2.28 per $100 of assessed valuation, a drop of thirty-one points from the $2.59 basic rate, for 1932.

MADRID, Feb. 17 -- With Important bills pending and the Cortes hopelessly deadlocked by radical fillbustering, the government today sought a solution, but after a meeting announced its decision to let things run. their course for the present.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- The League of Nations released in a ten-hour wireless broadcast to the world today its first report under Article XV, Paragraph 4 of the covenant, which requires it to lay down the law when its attempts to settle conflicts out of court fail.

The annual dinner dance of the North Carolina Society of New York was held last night in the Japanese Room of the St. Regis. A special entertainment program was featured by the Tom Fletcher Quartet and Zanett and Manon in dances. R. Means Brannon was chairman of the dance committee.

DENVER, Feb. 17 -- Working on what they say is the best clue they have had to date, two carloads of Denver police shifted the scene of activity from Denver to Northern Colorado as they started on the sixth day of their search for the kidnappers of Charles Boettcher 2d.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt spent a busy day following her return early yesterday morning from Ithaca, N.Y., where she spoke to 3,000 persons in connection with Farm and Home Week at Cornell University. Her arrival was quiet in comparison to the elaborate police protection given to her husband, the President-elect, on his return late in the afternoon.

Fordham Prep and Cathedral Boys High triumphed in Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. basketball games played yesterday. The former strengthened its hold on first place in the division race by defeating Iona School 16 to 14, on the latter's court in New Rochelle, while Cathedral Boys High, defending C.H.S.A.A. champion, conquered All Hallows, 34 to 18, at the East 54th Street gymnasium.

After ten years of delay the $30,000,000 Marine Park project got under way with formal ceremonies yesterday. Park Commissioner James J. Browne directed a huge machine which drove the first pile in a bulkhead that ultimately will mark the boundaries of a large lagoon.

Senator Joseph Connolly, Minister for Lands and Fisheries in the Irish Free State Government, arrived yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner New York with a program for refunding the unpaid balance of Republican loans obtained early in the last decade to finance the formation of the State.
COMMERCIAI PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Thursday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

Mrs. Sarah Settle Moise, 39 years old, a divorcee, who was accused of having defrauded Mrs. Clarence M. Woolley, wife of a director of the Federal Reserve Bank, numerous department stores and a woman relative of more than $60,000 through forgeries and thefts, was sentenced by Judge Koenig in General Sessions yesterday to fifteen to thirty months in the Bedford Hills Prison.

A charge that several "crooked" bus franchise contracts were nearly jammed through the Board of Estimate, before Mayor O'Brien took office, was made yesterday by Frank J. Prial, Deputy Controller, during a hearing on the proposed bus franchise grant to the East Side Omnibus Corporation to operate lines on the upper east side.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- The difficulty of finding American actors able to talk like real Germans, Frenchmen, Englishmen or Zulus was cited to a Senate committee today as famous theatrical figures pleaded that nothing be done to impair their right to hire foreign players.

In notifying the whole world yesterday that the League of Nations is certain to adopt the substance of the Lytton report on the controversy between China and Japan, the League did not bar the door to conciliation. That door, in fact, was thrown even wider open than it was in the Lytton report itself.

Because It afforded the most substantial basis for optimism, Wall Street professed yesterday to be more Interested in the share market than in bonds or foreign exchanges, where the day's results were less satisfactory. The advance on the Stock Exchange was slow and only 653,000 shares changed hands, but the reversal in the trend was encouraging.

The Bronx grand jury completed yesterday its investigation into the placing of a bomb in the Paradise Theatre, Grand Concourse and 188th Street, the Bronx, on Sept. 8, and, although it failed to return an indictment, it scathingly criticized Samuel Kaplan, former president of Local 306, Motion Picture Operators' Union, declaring that since he had been ousted, citizens might visit theatres without fear.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 17 -- The winning streak of General A., 13-20 favorite in the Brighton Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today, was snapped by the Coldstream Stud's 4-year-old colt Marmion, which triumphed by two lengths with speed in reserve.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 (AP) -- In direct opposition to Speaker Garner's ideas, the Democratic leader in the Senate. Senator Robinson of Arkansas today revived an issue supposedly settled by proposing repeal of the clause directing publicity for Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The time has come to consider the cessation of airmail subsidies and to give serious consideration to the question of putting the aviation industry on a self-sustaining basis, the Committee on Postoffices and Post Roads will recommend in a report to the House.

By the margin of three matches to two, the Princeton Club Class B squash racquets team last night defeated the Montclair A.C. on the courts of the Union League Club to win the metropolitan league championship.

Although it augmented non-operating income with a special dividend of $3,300,000 from the Pacific Fruit Express Company, the Southern Pacific Company reported yesterday for 1932 a net loss of $5,779,631, contrasted with a net income of $7,138,372, or $1.92 a share, in 1931.

Four issues of State and municipal bonds aggregating $26,863,000 comprised the new financing done publicly this week. In the corresponding week a year ago the new financing consisted of a single issue of public utility bonds, that of $25,000,000 Brooklyn Edison Company 5s due in 1952, priced at 97.

Last September Dr. CARL ANDERSON of Dr. MILLIKAN'S staff published in Science a note on a curious observation that he had made in the course of cosmic ray studies. He found tracks of positive particles. Protons are positive particles, but these were not made by protons.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- In a persuasive speech today the young French Minister Pierre Cot advanced the possibility of Europe accepting a uniform militia system on the general lines of the French plan. German and Italian opposition, although visibly shaken today, has by no means been removed, however, and the future of the plan remains to be settled Monday, when discussion continues.

The listed bond market failed yesterday to display the firmness shown by stocks, and the averages for all classifications of bonds on the Stock Exchange were lower. The United States Government group was particularly weak, losing 1-32 to 24-32 point, with resultant new lows for the year in the Liberty 3 1/2 s, Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s and Treasury 4 1/4 s, 4s, 3 3/4 s and 3s.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Preparations are being completed rapidly for the guarding of President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt at the inaugural ceremonies. The precautions to prevent any trouble will be more elaborate than have been taken at any inauguration, with Secret Service operatives augmented by agents of the Department of Justice.

William T. Hall, a retired city employe, who saved many lives in his long service along the waterfront as an engineer of the Department of Docks and Ferries, now the Department of Plant and Structures, died of heart disease early yesterday at his home at 1.353 East Fourteenth Street, Brooklyn.

GENEVA, Feb. 17 -- In a persuasive speech today the young French Minister Pierre Cot advanced the possibility of Europe accepting a uniform militia system on the general lines of the French plan. German and Italian opposition, although visibly shaken today, has by no means been removed, however, and the future of the plan remains to be settled Monday, when discussion continues.

The listed bond market failed yesterday to display the firmness shown by stocks, and the averages for all classifications of bonds on the Stock Exchange were lower. The United States Government group was particularly weak, losing 1-32 to 24-32 point, with resultant new lows for the year in the Liberty 3 1/2 s, Fourth Liberty 4 1/4 s and Treasury 4 1/4 s, 4s, 3 3/4 s and 3s.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Preparations are being completed rapidly for the guarding of President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt at the inaugural ceremonies. The precautions to prevent any trouble will be more elaborate than have been taken at any inauguration, with Secret Service operatives augmented by agents of the Department of Justice.

Enactment of the Bratton amendment to pending appropriation legislation will have disastrous effects on the navy, Rear Admiral William A. Moffett, chief of the navy bureau of aeronautics, warned last night at the eighth annual dinner of the Naval Academy Graduates Association of New York, at the Commodore Hotel.

HAVANA, Feb. 17 -- Four prominent Oppositionists, Colonels Carlos Mendieta, Roberto Mendez Penate and Aurelio Hevia, and Dr. Gabriel Landa, who sought refuge in the Mexican Embassy Jan. 6, will leave Cuba tomorrow as political exiles on the steamship Florida for Key West, Fla.

Prayers of thanksgiving for the deliverance of President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt from the hands of the would-be assassin and prayers of petition for the recovery of Mayor Cermak of Chicago will be offered at the altars of every one of the 452 churches in the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York at all masses tomorrow.

Heavy sentences imposed on three kidnappers were upheld yesterday by the Appellate Division of the Supreme Court in the case of Sidney Mann, 45 years old, a wholesale butcher, of 15 East Eightieth Street, who caused the arrest of his captors after they had obtained nearly $1,000 of $150,000 demanded.

Schuyler Neilson Warren, member of an old American family, who for many years was active on the New York Stock Exchange, died early yesterday morning in his home at 1,010 Fifth Avenue at the age of 75. He had been ill for more than two years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- The Democrats have on their hands a real battle for the Speakership of the next Congress. The leading candidates, Representative Rainey of Illinois, Byrns of Tennessee and McDuffie of Alabama, are "digging in," each asserting that he has the advantage.

To the Editor of The New york Times: More than usual Interest has been aroused by Russell Owen's article in THE TIMES summarizing the present sentiment among farmers as shown by their letters to Senators and Congressmen. This is Important because such letters show the real thoughts of real farmers.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y, Feb. 17 -- Three of the Stevens brothers, Lake Placid's ace bob sledders, monopolized the scoring honors m the North American championships on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run today. J. Hubert Stevens and Donald Deloria, riding the Adirondack Bob Sled Club's sled, won the title in 8:00.21 for the four race heats.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The negotiations for the prolongation of the "standstill" on German foreign short-term debts were concluded today with the ratification of the new agreement between the representatives of the foreign creditor banks and the committee acting for the German debtors.
HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Feb. 17 James Bernard Fagan, British playwright and motion-picture writer, died at his home here today of a heart attack subsequent to a relapse after influenza. He was 59 years old.

The statements of Walter Runciman, President of the British Board of Trade, before a meeting of the Chamber of Shipping Thursday night in London, in which he attacked the government subsidy of the American merchant marine, drew quick response yesterday from American shipping men.

An article in The National Municipal Review for February by F. L. BIRD, director of municipal research of the Bradstreet Company, deals with the depression problems of fifty cities in the United States. Some of them were caught napping in 1929 and have been struggling ever since to get into the solvent column; others have muddled along but have weathered the storm; a few have scarcely been touched by the depression.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 17 -- Passage Monday by the House of the Blaine resolution to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment was predicted today after House Democrats had voted in caucus to bind themselves to the measure.

DETROIT, Feb. 17. -- While Michigan bankers still struggled today to find a permanent solution of their problems, the Legislature at Lansing moved to endow Governor William A. Comstock with dictatorial powers over all banks in the State to prevent a crisis when the bank holiday which he proclaimed Tuesday morning expires Thursday.
A tragedy of the sea with a burlesque climax was written yesterday into the record of contemporary maritime history.

MADISON, Wis., Feb. 17 -- The Wisconsin Telephone Company was ordered today by the State Public Service Commission to show cause at a hearing March 20 why it should not be forbidden to carry out any further construction or installation of entensions, additions or improvements to the existing plant of the company.

Awards totaling $5,991,895.36 were made yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Leander B. Faber to owners of property the city seized for the construction of the Grand Central Parkway from Kew Gardens to the Nassau County line. Harry B. Mintz, Assistant Corporation Counsel, announced that he would protest two awards in which consequential damages were assessed against the city.

The United States Steel Corporation announced yesterday that under its annual employes' stock subscription plan, it was offering 200,000 of its common shares to its employes and those of its subsidiaries at $27 a share. This price, the lowest at which the stock ever has been sold to the workers, is an eighth of a point under yesterday's closing quotation of the shares on the Stock Exchange.

Historical data and records of the twenty-three oldest private family cemeteries in Queens, containing the graves of some of the forebears of prominent Manhattan families, have been compiled by surveyors of the Queens Topographical Bureau. Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens said yesterday this material would shortly be published in book form by the Queens Public Library Association under the direction of Owen J. Deyer.

HAVANA. -- Social events will hold a prominent place on the season's program during the coming week, in which the American holiday, Washington's Birthday, on Wednesday, and the Cuban national fiesta, "El Grito de Baire," on Friday, which marked the beginning of the last war of independence in the island, will be celebrated.

To the Editor of The New York Times: We have been advised by some papers and many people to "Buy America." It sounds patriotic and "100 per cent American." But is it? I believe a much better slogan would be "Sell America," and promote trade, industry and employment.

EVEN though "Topaze," the pictorial version of Marcel Pagnol's play, which was at the Radio City Music Hall last week, is not as satisfying as it was on the stage, it is a production fired with far greater intelligence than most Hollywood offerings.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 7 -- One of the agreements reached by the Foreign Ministers of Argentina and Chile at their meeting in Mendoza was to take steps toward the solution of the only unsettled question between the two countries -- the sovereignty of Picton, Lennox and New Island, three small islands in Beagle Channel between Tierra del Fuego and the island of Navarino.

THE debut of the American tenor, Richard Crooks, a second performance of "The Bartered Bride" and the fifth of the Wagner cycle series, "Tannhauser," are features of the fourteenth week of the opera season at the Metropolitan.

Dr. Miguel M. Gomez, former Mayor of Havana and a leader of the revolutionary movement against President Machado of Cuba, said yesterday that, if the Machado government is overthrown, the new government of Cuba will continue to repay the foreign debt.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Warrenton Junior Hunt, though no longer listed in the Virginia State Horse Show Association, will hold its annual show as usual, its secretary, Miss Mildred Fairfax Gaines, having announced the date for June 27.

John Pellicone, 8 years old, and his sister, Mary, 7, attended a showing of the motion picture "Orphan Annie" at the Gloria Theatre, at Carroll and Court Streets, Brooklyn yesterday afternoon. About 6:50 o'clock they started for their home at 359 Court Street, hand in hand.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 -- With a view to cutting off unfair competition and making the State Barge Canal and its branches produce enough revenue for the State to pay for upkeep, a constitutional amendment will be introduced in the Legislature on Monday night which would permit the State to charge tolls for vessels using the State's inland waterways.

The rapid spread throughout the East of "supermarkets" in which foodstuffs and household necessities are retailed strictly on a price basis was forecast yesterday by R.O. Dawson, directing head of the "Big Bear"supermarket now operating in an abandoned Elizabeth (N.J.) automobile factory.

Complaints that truckloads of butter and cheese in the Washington Market section were being destroyed by racketeers, who throw chemical bombs into the trucks because the drivers refuse to join "protective associations," resulted yesterday in an investigation by Assistant State Attorney General Edmund Collins, who predicted several arrests this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Mayors of great American cities begged the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today for an amendment giving the Reconstruction Finance Corporation power to lend money to the cities on the security of municipal bonds and tax-anticipation warrants.

ST. PAUL Feb. 18 (AP). -- A University of Minnesota survey indicates that speculative farm prices for farm lands in the 1917-1920 period of inflation, followed by a drastic decrease in income from farm produce, are the primary cause of farm foreclosures today.

THE effects of the world depression and of internal economic conditions upon the foreign trade turnover of Soviet Russia are discussed in a memorandum recently published in England by the University of Birmingham's Bureau of Research on Russian Economic Affairs.

In planning for retail dress business in March every garment bought should have a reason behind it for its purchase from the standpoint of promotional value, advertising or window display, Tobe, fashion and merchandise counselor to retail stores, says in the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES.

Criticism of the United States Tariff Commission for alleged failure to inquire into foreign production costs before recommending increased duties upon many products imported from countries where depreciated currencies or other factors make it possible for foreign makers to undersell domestic producers was voiced in import circles here last week.

PARIS, Feb. 8. -- That there is a wave of public opinion in Europe against what might be termed the annoyances of travel, such as customs and passport regulations, was clearly evidenced at the European Congress on the Economic Interests of Travel, just closed at Nice.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18. -- Frank Wykoff, holder of the world's 100-yard record, captured the 50-yard sprint handicap race, feature event of the annual James J. Cochran, Veterans of Foreign Wars, indoor track meet in Convention Hall tonight.

IN discussions of American banking practice it is frequently pointed out that, whereas four years of depression have brought the closing of a large number of banks in this country, just across our border Canada has passed through the same kind of crisis without a single bank failure or suspension.

WASHINGTON. THE capital's most celebrated residence is about to receive a new tenant. Leases on the mansion at 1.600 Pennsylvania Avenue, which for more than 130 years has housed a distinguished line of occupants, are written for terms of four years each, with options of renewal for four more years.

That the railroads are no longer the unrivaled agencies of passenger transportation in the United States, although they continue to exert a major influence on the social as well as the economic life of America, is a conclusion reached by investigators of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends, as announced in the first of the thirteen monographs to be published under the sponsorship of the committee.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- Great Britain is now approaching the difficult period of the year when all the spending departments of the government are making estimates of what their various experts think they must have for the coming twelve months.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- The final Paris showings restored practical styles without an effort at standardization. Looser lines dissemble super-feminine curves. However, intensely feminine effects are achieved and by a gay profusion of details.

The Seaboard-Great Lakes Corporation of 21 West Street has sent to shippers, receivers nad chambers of commerce a letter supporting the proposed Federal expenditure of 527,500,000 for the improvement of the New York State canal system, and urging all interested to write to the Board of Engineers for Rivers and Harbors in support of the proposed improvements.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18. -- The Chaco conflict threatens to take on new and more serious international complications of a continental character as a result of the probability that Paraguay will make a declaration of war next week in the face of Bolivia's preparations for a new general offensive along the entire Chaco front.

ROTHENBURG, Bavaria, THE Province of Franconia produces a special wine of its own -- a hard and strong beverage little known to the outside world and reminiscent of the soil that nurtures it rather than the grapes from which it is made.

THE most popular composer of opera in Germany has been Verdi, at least according to figures compiled for the period between August, 1931, and July, 1932. During this period, Verdi's operas had 1,420 performances throughout the theatres of Germany, and Wagner followed closely with 1,385.

ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 18. -- Brookline High School easily won the ninth Andover indoor track meet today with 29 points to its credit. Lynn English High was runner-up with 13. Medford and Lawrence scored 12 and 10 points respectively for third and fourth places.

HEADLINES in the newspapers took note recently of a pronouncement of Spectator, a publication of under graduates of Columbia University, that fraternities must be abolished on Morningside Heights. These "peculiar American institutions," with their Greek-letter labels so tempting to comic jokesmiths, must go, it was asserted, because, inter alia, they were not only morally delinquent and financially unsound but served as the machinery of corrupt college politics.

Two witnesses presented the views of mortgage bondholders to the Joint Legislative Banking Committee at a resumed hearing at the Hotel Roosevelt yesterday. One favored legislation which would authorize receivers or trustees in bankruptcy, under the direction of the court, to sell old stock of a bankrupt and buy new stock in a reorganized company.

Small lots of bonds of two municipalities were called last week for payment this month prior to maturity, and in addition payments at later dates were announced for one large real estate issue and for parts of several foreign issues. The total of bonds called for payment in February is now $59,794,000, compared with $44,613,700 in January, and $36,170,000 in February, 1932, for corresponding weeks.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Clinking milk bottles that awaken him daily before dawn have become so fixed in the life of the average city dweller that even on the brink of a possible milk strike he has given little thought to the prospect of suddenly being deprived of cream for his morning coffee.

MILAN, Feb. 5, 1933 FURTHER details are now available regarding the sixteenth-century Italian mystery play to be performed at the coming Florence Music Festival. It is an anonymous work, entitled "Santa Ullva," and is stated to be one of the most interesting sacred dramas written in Italy between the close of the Middle Ages and the dawn of the Renaissance.
PASADINA. THERE is no conflict between religion and science," the Abbe Lemaitre has been telling audiences over and over again in this country and then proving it by explaining the aims of both.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- Publication in France of the suggestion said to have been made by Professor Philip McMahon of the Fine Arts Department of New York University that European debtor nations might pay America with works of art has caused a storm of exasperated comment in the French press.

OMAHA, Feb. 16 -- Currency inflation may be to Bernard M. Baruch the road to ruin, but to many a corn belt farmer it still looks like the path to prosperity. If pride of opinion were not enough to confirm him in that view he would consider it a sufficient answer to Mr. Baruch to say that he reflects the Wall Street view.

Following is the statistical comparison of the Labor Bureau's general index of average wholesale prices in the United States for January, published yesterday. The calculation is based on 784 commodities since the end of 1931 and 550 for earlier dates.

Foreign exchanges continued yesterday to rally against the dollar. The gold standard currencies of France, Belgium, Switzerland and Holland made striking gains, the first three rising to prices above the gold export point. Sterling was held in check by the official control and closed at $3.44 1/4, down 1-16 cent net.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- In an effort to put money into circulation and relieve unemployment, the District of Columbia Bankers Association announced today that it had created a credit pool of $500,000, out of which loans, not in excess of $500, will be made to home owners for home improvement work.

When the St. Lawrence treaty came up in the Senate Foreign Relations Committee the other day, Senator WAGNER of New York voted " No," explaining that he was not quite clear what attitude he would ultimately take on the treaty. " I wish that the advantageous power features of the proposal could be separated from the objectionable navigation features," he remarked.

Under the auspices of the Emergency Relief Committee of the Churchwomen's League for Patriotic Service, of which Miss Emie Sutton Day is chairman, a fashion show and entertainment will take place on the afternoon of Feb. 27 in the ballroom of the Plaza.

ROME. IT is not perhaps so curious as it may seem at first sight that Italy, for thousands of years so rich in great men, should be so exceedingly and constantly poor in producing adequate biographies of them; so that from the Plutarch of antiquity to the Trevelyans and Thayers of today.

To the Dramatic Editor: In his interesting letter of defiance which you published last Sunday, Elmer Rice seems to take it for granted that the only reason why one could condemn his play, "We, the People," would be because it is written with the thought "that the theatre has the right to touch reality and to raise its voice in behalf of social idealism."

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Judge James A. Lowell, senior justice of the Massachusetts Federal District Court, will send no more liquor law violators to jail. On the contrary he will impose heavy fines, with suspended sentences and a long period of probation.

Just a "quiet day" at the office, motoring in the afternoon, and an evening at home with his wife, was all that Charles M. Schwab, veteran steel man, would allow yesterday to mark the attainment of his seventy-first birthday. The optimism that has marked him through life had not left him, and he looked forward with hope to some "unseen new development" to bring the country out of its depression.

HOLLYWOOD. IT is a very small world after all. Look at Joe E. Brown, for example. The first time I saw Joe Brown was a quarter of a century ago and Joe E. was playing second base for the St. Paul club of the American Association and I was writing baseball for The Kansas City Star.

RADIO'S imposing list of entertainers and speakers this week includes Efrem Zimbalist, violinist; Rosa Ponselle, soprano; Mario Chamlee, tenor; Josef Lhevinne, pianist; Roscoe Pound, dean of the Harvard Law School; Attorney General W.D. Mitchell, Amelia Earhart and Dr. E.F.W. Alexanderson of television fame.

An analysis by the Bureau of Investigation of the United States Department of Justice of fingerprint records representing 277,778 arrests by American policemen from Feb. 1 to Dec. 31, 1932, showed that 49 per cent of the arrests were for larceny, burglary, vagrancy, or else of persons held on suspicion or for investigation.

PARIS. WITH a suddenness that has dismayed not only French governmental circles but the other chancelleries of Europe, Franco-Italian relations have taken a turn for the worse. Only a month ago France sent a new Ambassador to Rome, Senator Henry de Jouvenel, and already reports which have been verified tell of his cold reception by Mussolini and the difficulties he is finding in making contacts.
The Hunter College basketball team turned back the Savage School girls', 21 to 20, on the latter's court yesterday. The Savage School men's varsity quintet defeated Columbia Teachers, 40 to 26.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Barring an unforeseen spurt of activity at the very end, the last "lame duck" session of Congress appears likely to leave some 45 per cent of its pressing routine business for the special session of the next Congress.

JOSEPH STALIN has informed the world that the Five-Year Plan has been completed in four years. For weeks before his appearance on Jan. 7 before a joint meeting of the Central Control Committee and Central Control Commission in Moscow, the Soviet press had been preparing the public for his announcement.

Last week's events at Washington should have given pause, if not deeper thought, to some of our impatient innovators. They have been lamenting the hopelessness of getting anything from this Congress or the next. Something though they don't know quite what, is wrong with the whole system.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- Friends close to President Hoover and in a position to know his mind made known tonight that they "felt certain" he intended to retire definitely into private life and not run for the Presidency again in 1936.

THE term North America -- to which the English imperialists take exception -- suggests a geographical entity, and also a distinct civilization, which embraces the Dominion of Canada and most of the United States.

The night of March 24 has been chosen as the date for the Rainbow Ball, an annual dance of the early Spring organized and directed by younger members of society for the benefit of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children. The event will take place in the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria and, as in past years, will be featured by a midnight entertainment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Republican wet bloc of the House, headed by Representative Beck of Pennsylvania, voted today to help Democratic leaders put over the Blaine prohibition repeal resolution on Monday.

THE town of Renwood, Ohio, which is already familiar to the readers of "Red-Headed Woman," forma the background for many of the stories and sketches in Katharine Brush's latest volume. Indeed, "Other Women" supplies a good many of the necessary omissions in its predecessor.

MOSCOW, Feb. 17 -- The all Union congress of the best collective farm shock-brigaders, which was held in Moscow this week, is an interesting and typically Bolshevist phenomenon. About 1,400 men and women, more than half of them non-members of the Communist party, have come to this capital from all sections to what is partly a glorified joy-ride and partly a revivalist meetings.

IF Crete Wiesenthal were anybody but Grete Wiesenthal would be kinder to allow her last week's debut concert to pass without further notice, but because she is an artist who has contributed largely to her particular type of art and because that art itself should not be dismissed with shrug of the shoulders, there are a few things that must be said.

ATER a quarter of a century of labor and meditation, of failure and success, writes Waldemar George, Derain experiences the superb solitude at which only very noble spirits can arrive. To that sentence we pin our faith, not so much to Derain as to Waldemar George.

LONDON. SURVEY operations of the air route between Calcutta and Singapore, conducted by the Royal Air Force with the cooperation of the Siamese Government, promise to simplify flying over country which is in many places hazardous terrain for the airman, but is important because of its location along the main air trunk line to the Far East and Australia.

Business is now in a position to increase employment and earnings rapidly if consumers are helped to pay their due and overdue bills faster, it was declared by David J. Woodlock, general manager of the National Retail Credit Association, in an analysis of the present economic situations made public in Chicago recently.

SUDDENLY every one appears to be writing a play about the Brontes. It is hard to imagine why, for the cheerless geniuses of Haworth parsonage are no more and no less vital today than they have been for a long time.

Good weather brought a field of thirty-one gunners to the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. J.H. Wantling won the High Scratch Cup by breaking 97 out of a possible 100 targets. The second scratch prize went to C.W. Phellis, who finished with 96.

Edward S. Greenbaum, member of the law firm of Greenbaum, Wolff Ernst of 285 Madison Avenue, was elected trustee in the American bankruptcy proceeding of the Kreuger Toll Company yesterday, to succeed Gordon Auchinclose, resigned.

Opera and Morale. Germany a dozen years ago was still in a daze of defeat and revolution. The country was impoverished. The people were underfed. Just around the corner was the catastrophe of money inflation and utter financial collapse.

PEIPING, Jan. 14. -- Marshal Feng Yu-hsiang, once popularly known las the "Christian General," now is described in Nortth China as "the great unwelcome guest." The leader of the defunct Kuomlnchun, once a politico-military party opposed to the Nationalist regime of the Kuomintang, is not desired as a resident even by his former subordinates, and great is the scheming to persuade him to leave North China, if he will not consent to travel abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- The Inaugural parade on March 4 will have more units in it than in many years, and it is expected that it will take more than three hours to pass the reviewing stand. The arrangement of the parade, giving all the organizations which will have places in the line and with the names of marshals and their staffs, was made public this afternoon.

LLOYD GEORGE once remarked that Poland had five Alsace-Lorraine problems: the Polish Corridor, Upper Silesia, Vilna, the Ukraine and White Russia. Mr. Lengyel's book goes far to convince one that Lloyd George was right.

THE thorough workmanship of Miss Ashton's novels makes them interesting even though they lack plot in the ordinarily accepted sense. "Doctor Serocold" was the account of a single day in the life of a country doctor; "Bricks and Mortar" told the life story of an architect.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Frequent references are being made in the public press to the possibility of inflation. The announcement of a bond issue by the government does not give rise to fears and apprehensions, provided the bond issue is well within the credit limits of the government.

Former Magistrate Jean H. Norris, who was removed by the Appellate Division as a result of the Seabury inquiry into the magistrates' courts, filed suit in the Supreme Court yesterday for $25,000 against the authors and producers of the play, "Four O'clock," which opened last Monday at the Biltmore Theatre, on the ground that her reputation was damaged because she was the "woman judge" referred to in the play.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Thomas Ewing Jr., president of the Alexander Smith Sons Carpet Company of Yonkers, who died in New York on Feb. 8 at the age of 35, left an estate of little more than $4,500,000, it became known today when his will was filed here for probate.

The eyes of the working people of the United States are on the New York State Legislature in the hope that at this session an unemployment insurance bill will be adopted, according to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, who was in New York last night to attend the Inner Circle dinner.
LONDON, Feb. 18 -- The Marquess of Lothian, who has recently returned from the United States, has an article in tomorrow's Sunday Observer entitled "American Realities."
LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Provided there are no unexpected delays in the delivery of aircraft or materials, the Mount Everest expedition may be ready to attempt the flight over the great peak by March 25.

NEW YORK. Miss Natalie Mae Coe gave a dinner last night at the Central Park Casino for the Marchese Pasquale Diana, Counselor of the Italian Embassy, and the Marchesa Diana, and for Lieut. Col. Marco Pennaroli, Military Attache of the Embassy.

PARIS. Feb. 10 -- Declaring that the needs of industry and commerce would eventually force peoples to drop their native languages and adopt a common tongue. Professor Ferdinand Brunot, newly elected president of the Academy of Inscriptions, spoke recently at the institute on what the world language would be.

Displaying a brand of horsemanship worthy of older competitors of the show ring. Miss Therese Murray, 14-year-old Brooklyn girl, captured the blue ribbon in the senior division event which featured the horsemanship competition for children of club members at the Riding and Driving Club of Brooklyn yesterday.
HANOVER, N. H., Feb. 18. -- Dartmouth's basketball team scored a 30-17 victory over Harvard tonight. Dartmouth started its veteran five and at half time had run up a 16-8 lead on the Crimson.

FACES which presume to grace the motion-picture screens of the nation must first pas the scrutiny of camera which are cruel and unsentimental in their power to reproduce the most minor blemishes. The process of deceiving the cinema cameras has been raised to a complicated art by Hollywood's make-up men.
LONDON, Feb. 16 -- To a close observer it seems evident that the system whereby naval armaments have been restricted since the Washington Conference is breaking down and must soon be discarded.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Leaders of the Senate and House were hearing an agreement today on the legislation to grant to Mr. Roosevelt when he becomes President unprecedented authority to reorganize the Federal Government in the interest of public economy.

SEVERAL years ago, we read much in current magazines regarding "square pegs and square holes; round pegs and round holes." The concept of vocational guidance that was popular at that time was that there was just one thing in whic han individual could succeed best.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Freight rates to and from New Jersey points were attacked on two fronts today in briefs filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission by the State Public Utilities Commission, the city of Newark and trunk line railroads.

The board of governors of the New York Curb Exchange yesterday expelled Stephen McDonald from regular membership in the Exchange and suspended William H. Fay and Herbert Carlton from regular membership for six months. All three are partners in Chater Edey and represented the firm on the floor of the Exchange.
With Vittono Podrecca as guest, Alberto Bimboni presents some of Italy's classics at the Casa Italiana this afternoon, assisted by Alma Michelini and Salvatore DeStefano.

H.C. Blackiston, director in the United States of the Furness-Bermuda Line, received a cablegram yesterday announcing the successful sea-trials of the new liner Queen of Bermuda, which will be in the New York-Bermuda run as a companion to the Monarch of Bermuda.

WASHINGTON. IN the period between the election and the inauguration of an American President one of the chief topics of discussion wherever two or more citizens gather is the probable personnel of his Cabinet. Soon after the list is announced, and those chosen take their oaths few persons can remember who occupy even half of the ten places.

DETROIT. THE possibility that the two most significant new car introductions of 1933 still remain to be made is quite widely recognized in this motor capital of the world. It is based on the fact that the smaller and less expensive Ford V-8 has yet to appear and that Chevrolet's Mercury models are being held in abeyance.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 18. -- A Peruvian communique today said that Peruvian airplanes had bombarded the Colombian naval squadron on the Putumayo River and had damaged the warships Barranquilla and Boyaca.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18 -- Attention will be called anew to the contributions of Dr. Joseph Leidy, famous American naturalist, to a half-dozen branches of science when at the annual meeting Tuesday marking the 121st year of the Academy of Natural Sciences of Philadelphia a group of Dr. Leidy's choice personal possessions will be presented to the academy as a bequest from his nephew, the late Dr. Joseph Leidy 2d of this city.

MOST writers sin by excess. On general grounds one might wish that a fat part of their collected works could be lost. As a rule, their reputations and the world suffer from the digging up of their forgotten early fragments, their 'prentice bands.

THE last week of Bruno Walter's engagement as guest conductor of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra will introduce two large choral works at next Thursday evening's concert in Carnegie Hall; the Brahms rhapsody for alto solo, male chorus and orchestra, wherein Sigrid Onegin and the Schola Cantorum chorus will sing with the orchestra, and Mahler's Second symphony, with Jeannette Vreeland, soprano, and Mme.

GENEVA, Feb. 18. -- The League of Nations announced today that Colombia, in invoking Article XV of the covenant against Peru, had requested an urgent meeting of the Council. The Council will meet Monday afternoon to hear both parties and accomplish at least the preliminaries that Article XV requires.

The Museum of Modern Art will open tomorrow its new permanent architecture room, installed and decorated as an example of modern interior architecture under the supervision of Phillip Johnson, director of the museum's department of architecture.

Yale's fencing team put on winning performances in the closing bouts to defeat Columbia, 9 -- 7, yesterday in the Columbia gymnasium. After the Lions had assumed a 6-3 lead with the foils, the Elis won three of the epee bouts and three of the saber events to emerge triumphant.

The New York University swimming team decisively outscored Manhattan, 41 -- 18, in a dual meet in the Jasper pool yesterday. The Violet won four of the seven events, and a majority of second and third places increased the winning margin.

For the second time within a month, Ed (Strangler) Lewis, Kentuckian, who is recognized here as the world's heavyweight wrestling champion, tomorrow night is scheduled to defend his crown against Jim Browning of Boston. They are to clash as the feature of a carnival at Madison Square Garden arranged in the interests of the New York Press Club.

Encouraged by the success of the Caribbean cruise of last season, which was organized to assist the Frontier Nursing Service, many women of society, including debutantes, not only from New York but several large cities of the East, have been interested in the forthcoming West Indies cruise.

DETROIT, Feb. 17. -- In his second month in office Governor William A. Comstock has had two unpleasant experiences in finance, one personal, the other more general. He has had his salary garnisheed, and he has had to close all the banks of the Southern Peninsula.

THIS biograpby was written for a collected edition of Henry Adams's works. The bitter times may long delay publication. To that delay we are indebted for this first life. The informed, discriminating and sympathetic article by Mr. Alien Johnsor in "The Dictionary of American Biography" will always be valuable, but he was necessarily restricted in matters of detail.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18. -- The thoroughbreds -will start galloping around the major tracks of Chicago on May 22, with the opening of Washington Park, but Sportsman's Park, the little half-mile oval, will have the honor of presenting the steeds for the first races of the season. May 1.

LONDON, Feb. 10 -- Sir Ronald Lindsay, Ambassador to the United States, reported to the Cabinet his conversation with Mr. Roosevelt and also discussed with members of the government the state of public opinion in America. Nothing could have been more timely.

"Since ancient times, towers have made a poetic appeal," the author tells us in her preface, "because towers will always stand midway between fact and poetry, the legends relating to them, more often than not, look in these two directions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 11 amounted to 501,320 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was an increase of 18,128 cars, or 3.8 per cent, over the preceding week, but 60,215 cars, or 10.7 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year, and 219,369 cars, or 30.4 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

LONDON, Feb. 8 A COUPLE of years ago I suggested in these columns that what ailed the theatre was the reluctance of writers of the front rank to give their time to it. It appeared to them, and with reason, that the stage, although it might be extravagantly profitable now and then, offered no assured and honorable outlet for their work.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The efforts of John D. Rockefeller Jr. to increase the national park areas will be scrutinized in a recently authorized inquiry by the Public Lands Committee of the Senate.

ROME, Feb. 17 -- As long ago as 1926 Premier Mussolini defined fascism as "Liberalism's grave-digger," meaning that fascism's political theories would kill and supersede the democratic ideals which had held undisputed sway in Europe for at least half a century.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- In the face of the Democratic ban against the confirmation of major nominations by President Hoover which would hold over into the new administrations, the Chief Executive today named one of his secretaries, Walter H. Newton, to be a Federal district judge in Minnesota.
Americana, autograph letters, first editions, original drawings, sporting books, sumptuous bindings, illuminated manuscripts and other literary treasures will be offered at auction here this week.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., Feb. 18. -- Ninety-three honor men of the three upper classes of Rutgera Universlty were announced today by Luther H. Martin, registrar. The senior class led all others with forty-three of its members receiving the designation of first honors students.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- Because it defied the British Broadcasting Corporation and sponsored commercial broadcasts from France, The Sunday Referee has been expelled from the Newspaper Proprietors Association here.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 18 -- It is learned in unofficial but well-informed circles close to Finance Minister Hueyo that Argentina has rejected an offer from Baring Bros., associated with, a group of other British bankers, for a five-year credit of u10,000,000 ($34,400,000) by which the bankers sought to release that quantity of British funds frozen here by the refusal of the Exchange Control Commission to issue remittance permits.

The Future of Democracy. Apropos a great many current political events, at home and abroad, the sage observations of the late Viscount Bryce seem timely. He wrote, in 1920: "Although democracy has spread, and although no country that has tried it shows any signs of forsaking it, we are not yet entitled to hold with the men of 1789 that it is the natural and therefore in the long run the inevitable form of covernment.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- This week in France has been one of those that might be cited as proving the need for adoption of some technocratic principles in government, while at the same time illustrating how terribly unscientific are the human heart and human character.

MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 18 -- The will of Leo M. Dunn, vice president of the Graybar Electric Company, Inc., who died on Jan. 20 at his home, 64 Washington Avenue, Garden City, was filed here for probate today. The estate is estimated nominally at "more than $10,000."

A MEMBER of the "Fighting Thirty-third" Infantry that chased Aguinaldo, away back at the turn of the century, as the elusive leader of the insurrection day after day slipped out of the hands of the American Army. Samuel E. Kane was so attracted by the wild mountainous region of Northern Luzon that when his battalion was demobilized he decided to stay in the island.

Contracts for supplying natural gas to companies providing gas service to a large section of Southeastern Pennsylvania adjacent to Philadelphia are expected to be signed soon by the Columbia Gas and Electric Corporation, which has three high-pressure pipe lines ready to furnish natural gas to the area, and by the United Gas Improvement Company, which controls the gas-distributing companies.

To the Ediior of The New York Times: The controversial problem of the handling of the war debts deserves all the thought that can be given to it in every circle. A rational conclusion can be reached only by taking into account not merely legal relationships or legalistic conceptions, but the indefinable and imponderable factors, and the psychology of the world's circumstances of today.

BOSTON, Feb. 18 -- A conference "to explore the possibilities" of our recognizing the Soviet Government of Russia was urged here tonight by Dewitte C. Poole, who, when attached to the State Department some years ago, had a large part in formulating the present policy of non-recognition.

Unscrupulous stock schemes and manipulation of shares have been all to prevalent in this nation in the last several years, Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate committee investigating the stock market, declared last night before a dinner of New York Lodge 1 of the Order of Eiks at the Hotel Commodore.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Seven of the nine Army athletic teams competing today in an extensive indoor sports program were victorious. The cadets won from Colgate at basketball, 40 to 36, defeated the Virginia Military Institute boxers, 6 1/2 to 1 1/2, and won from Princeton in a three-weapon fencing engagement, 11 to 6.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senator Couzens completed preparations today of a proposed joint resolution, which be may Introduce Monday, granting extreme authority to the Controller of the Currency to be used in such emergencies as that which brought about the one week "bank holiday" in Michigan.

The Transit Commission has no legal right to grant certificates of convenience and necessity to the bus companies which recently received one-year franchises in Manhattan and Queens from the Board of Estimate, Frank P. Walsh, counsel for Jamaica Buses, Inc., declared yesterday in an argument before the full commission.

Special promotions, including an anniversary sale by one large local store and a $1-day basement promotion, by another, brought an active consumer response on every variety of retail item, according to analyses by shoppers of the Meyer-Both Retail Reporting Bureau.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Fighting off a stirring closing rush, the Princeton hockey team defeated the Yale sextet tonight, 2 to 1. The flashy Tiger aggregation, after breaking a 1 to 1 tie late in the third session, was forced to bring all its defensive power into play to hold off the rugged Eli stick-wielders, who charged incessantly in a desperate bid for a deadlock.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The government today upset the plans of leaders of the Reichsbanner organization, which is holding its convention here, by refusing to permit the Republicans to use the Municipal Field in the suburb of Tegel for manoeuvres Sunday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Among American foreign service officers whose names are to be inscribed in bronze on a State Department roll of honor provided for in a bill sent to the House after passage by the Senate will be victims of revolution, war and religious uprisings.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The navy will acquire its first vessel designed and built as an airplane carrier when the Ranger takes the water at Newport News next Saturday. Mrs. Hoover will name the new vessel in honor of the ship of the same name commanded by John Paul Jones, the Navy Department announced today.

Owen D. Young's opinion that there should be a single holding company in each public utility group, expressed last week at the hearings on Insull affairs before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee in Washington, was said yesterday by officials in the Industry to represent the ideal toward which the principal utility systems of the country have been tending for several years.

Sentiment favoring establishment of a Federal bureau of business research, which would render more effective service to business in factfinding activities and operate at less expense than is involved in such work at this time, gained ground last week in business and trade association circles where a draft of the plan was circulated.

The American Red Cross will continue until midsummer to supply at full volume the food issued at the twenty stations set up in the five boroughs by the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was announced last night by General Robert C. Davis, executive director of the New York Chapter of the Red Cross, 315 Lexington Avenue.

A gala musical festival in the form of a Brahms centenary celebration has been chosen by a committee interested in the welfare of the Greenwich House Music School as the annual benefit for that institution which for two decades has occupied a unique position among the studios for musical instruction in this city.

TO the already extensive powers of the President it has recently been proposed that others be added, in order that the Executive may wage war on the depression more vigorously. Suggestions have been made to give Mr. Roosevelt powers like those exercised by President Wilson during the World War, though on a smaller scale.

THOSE wilderness areas which a benevolent povernment has turned into national parks for millions of Americans to frolic in in Summer would never be recognized if their friends saw them under the pall of their all-enveloping Winter snows.

OTTAWA. EIGHT of Canada's nine Provinces -- all save little Prince Edward Island -- are in the business of selling intoxicating liquors for beverage purposes. No two Provinces have precisely the same system.

In the Fourteenth Street Armory on Saturday night a street fair reminiscent of the gayety of Imperial Russia will be given in the interests of impoverished Russian exiles in this country. Under the auspices of the United Russian Committee, the event will assist the work of seven Russian philanthropic organizations here which have found their charitable work greatly increased during the recent lean years.

The Summit High School team of New Jersey and Roosevelt High School of Yonkers turned in victories, while the sextets representing Montclair Academy and Hackley School, played a 6-6 tie and Riverdale Country Day School and Morristown School battled to a 2-2 deadlock in four scholastic ice hockey games staged at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP) -- An assertion that the United States might suffer a serious sugar shortage in the event of a war which isolated the Philippines, Hawaii and Puerto Rico was made today to the Tariff Commission in an argument against raising the duty on the Cuban product.

James J. Corbett, who won the heavyweight championship of the world from John L. Sullivan and lost it to Bob Fitzsimmons before the turn of the century, died yesterday in the little stucco house at 221-04 Edgewater Avenue, Bayside, Queens, where he had lived for more than thirty years.

WHILE Poland's most Illustrious citizen is making a concert tour in this country. from abroad come rumors that his -- ive country, be set by political and economic difficulties. will again call upon him to leave his piano and take up the heavy duties of statemenship.

HAVANA, Feb. 18 -- The Bar Association of Cuba, fearing for the lives of Emilio Marrill and Joaquin Martinez Saenz, arrested Feb. 13, yesterday presented petitions to President Machado and Secretary of the Interior Zubizaretta, asking guarantees of the personal safety of these two lawyers.
LONDON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Leeds United, favorite to win the English Cup soccer competition, was unexpectedly eliminated today, falling before the flashy offense and stout defense of Everton, 2 to 0.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., Feb. 18. -- The Naval Academy had almost a perfect day in athletics so far as varsity events were concerned today, winning seven out of eight, mostly in decisive fashion. As to plebe sports, the showing was not nearly so good -- in fact, the first-year Middies lost four of the seven contests in which they engaged.

WHILE Congress has been discussing repeal of prohibition, bands, quartets and fiddlers have been given auditions in radio studios to determine what performance is most appropriate for John Barleycorn should the legislators sanction his appearance at the microphone.

AMERICAN institutions of higher learning are justly proud of the contributions which their laboratories have made to material progress. Now our colleges and universities are confronted with an opportunity to make an equally important contribution to social progress.
Prices on the Cotton Exchange strengthened again yesterday and closed with gains of 3 to 6 points after a considerable quantity of contracts had been taken from the market.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 18. -- A day of unusual activity in Princeton athletics was climaxed this afternoon with a Tiger victory over Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game by a score of 40-26. Princeton, by virtue of its triumph, regained undisputed possession of second place in the league standing.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- A warning against any steps that might lead to bureaucracy and political manipulation, was sounded by Governor Herbert H. Lehman of New York today during discussion at the conference of executives of Eastern States of a suggestion that departments of local governments be developed in State governments.

WASHINGTON. WHEN the banking bill was before the Senate recently much of the storm it evoked hovered around the gray head of a man whose pale face and slight physique were belied, when he was aroused, by the blazing fire of his eyes.

THE art world, more than ever grateful for a hearty laugh these days, got it last week through the United States Customs Department. The temporary withholding of permission to import photographic reproductions of Michelangelo's frescoes on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel in the Vatican lightened a stretch of very gloomy weather.

LONDON, Feb. 18. -- The Bishop of Liverpool, the Dean of Canterbury and the Moderator of the Church of Scotland are among a group of leading churchmen who have started a movement to reform the pictures of Christ.

IT is probably not overstating the matter to remark that no American, tenor making a debut at the Metropolitan Opera House ever approached that momentous event with a bigger popular public than Richard Crooks, who is scheduled to appear Saturday afternoon as Des Grieux in "Manon."
The Stamford Yacht Club's second annual Vineyard race is to be held this year on Sept. 1. Announcement to that effect was made yesterday by George F. Hubbard of the race committee.
Today. Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixtyfourth Street, 11 A.M. "The Undepressed Sides of Life." Dr. Horace J. Bridges.

WITHIN the month there have transpired two events of importance to air transport in the United States. The United States Senate has "washed out" the air mail appropriation for next year, the whole $19,000,000.

A second conference between President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt and Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, on the procedure to be followed in starting the negotiations for a revision of the British war debt is expected to be held tomorrow at Mr. Roosevelt's home, 49 East Sixty-fifth Street.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 2 -- To teach children to wash themselves and not to use bad language are the principal tasks of instructors at the only gypsy school in Hungray, at Diosgyor, a large gypsy settlement. Formerly parents refused to send their children to schools where gypsies were admitted for fear that they might acquire the habit of profanity as well as for fear of dirt and contagion.

IT is just three hundred years since there was born a curious fellow who for some reason, appeals to our modern instincts. For a century his name was buried in oblivion. But he refused to stay dead and suddenly emerged from the shades -- a miracle of resurrection.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Miss Kit Klein, national speed skating champion from Buffalo, N. Y., suffered a hip fracture in a spill during the Western indoor championships tonight at the Chicago Stadium.

WHILE the radio comedian is riding the crest of popularity, the comedienne is conspicuous by her absence from the microphone. The madcap Gracie Allen incidentally is the only feminine comic who has enjoyed any prolonged performance on the air.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The unprecedented drop in the price of silver is admittedly a material factor in the present world depression, and if its price could in some manner be stabilized the beneficial effect would be immediate.

Dr. TERROT REAVELEY GLOVER of St. John's College, Cambridge, is a protectionist. He is alarmed by the flood of imported American words that threatens to submerge the home vocabulary. In a letter to The London Times he reproaches STANLEY BALDWIN, Chancellor of his university, with using there that dire Americanism " to try out."

MADRID, Feb. 17 -- Seville Europe's newly nominated Zeppelin gateway, will begin construction of its dirigible airport early next month, and on May 5 Dr. Hugo Eckener is scheduled to leave there in the Graf Zeppelin for Rio de Janeiro.

Fourteen points are contained in a series of suggestions for dealing with the depression that has been forwarded by the committee on national affairs of the Brooklyn Union League Club to the Senate Committee on Finance, which recently invited all citizens to make such suggestions.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- England and Bermuda will meet in tennis competition, men's singles and doubles, on Thursday of this week at the tennis stadium, under the auspices of the Bermuda Lawn Tennis Association, as a prelude to the annual championships, play in which will begin the following day and is expected to reach the final rounds on Thursday, March 2.

Michael Karnilow's victory over Hugo Castello, winner of the city P. S. A. L. individual fencing title for the last two years, featured the triumph of Textile High, defending team champion, over George Washington High, 1931 winner, as the competition opened yesterday in the third annual city P. S. A. L. team championship fencing tourney at the Washington Irving High School.

IN this unusual and fascinating book Charles Francis Saunders gives not only an appreciative description of the principal flowers and shrubs of the Pacific Slope but the story of each plant, its literature, its place in the lore and traditions of Indians and early settlers and the part it has played in their lives.

A program for "deflation of government" to match deflation in business has been worked out by Governor David Sholtz of Florida for presentation to President-elect Roosevelt's Governors Conference at Washington March 6, it was made known here yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 9 -- The dowager Duchesse d'Uzes, who passed away within a week of her eighty-sixth birthday, was one of the most notable representatives of the old aristocracy in France and for many years was the leader in the effort to introduce woman suffrage.

JOE ZINGARA in his attempt to assassinate President-elect Roosevelt penetrated what is regarded as the most efficient protective system in the world -- the White House detail of the United States Secret Service. Headed by two men who have developed, through years of experience, a technique for anticipating hostile moves on the part of cranks, paranoics and persons with imagined grievances, this arm of the Secret Service overlooks nothing and prepares for everything.

EVER since the Institute of Politics began its discussions beneath the elms of Williamstown a dozen years ago, the Summer campus in more than one part of the country has served as an important forum of the American people.

Heavily guarded by police and Secret Service men, President-elect Roosevelt attended the annual dinner and show of the Inner Circle, an organization of New York City political reporters, in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor last night.

MONTREAL. -- This afternoon the final of the 150-mile snow-shoe marathon, which started from Hull last Sunday, will be run off at the Montreal Baseball Stadium. There will be races for girl speed skaters and a special race for snowshoe runners, as well as the race for the surviving runners in the marathon, the latter a fifteen-mile lap.

Los ANGELES, Feb. 17. AFTER a long period of somnolence this town's showshops are lifting their drooping heads, and once again the perennial Angelin claim to serious consideration as a theatrical centre is, to a mild degree, substantiated.

MISS BOWEN has certain unusual gifts for which the reader most always be in her debt. Gifted with keen perception into the nuances of sensibility, with sure knowledge of manners and conduct and with a sharp, agile wit, she is one of the most civilized of contemporary writers.

ALBANY, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The story of how nearly 40,000 New York State "city dwellers" have packed their possessions into automobiles, trucks and wagons and gone "back to the farm" since 1930 was told in records of the Department of Agriculture and Markets today.

YOU can always trust a Russian until he tucks his shirt in," said Kipling, attempting to generalize about the degree to which the European Russian is Asiatic. There have been many attempts to evaluate and to define the influence of a geographical fact on Russia: that Asia is only a continuation of the broad plains of Western Russia.

DALLAS, Feb. 16. -- The reorganization of the State Government proposed by the joint legislative committee on organization and economy is meeting with a rather lukewarm reception, at best. The separate bills to make it effective are just now making their way into the Legislature, so that advocates and enemies of the plan have not yet found themselves.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- Ralph Powers of the Harvard Club defeated Rowland B. Haines, former national squash tennis champion, in a second-round game in the first annual invitation squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Swimming Club today.

Editor The New York Times Book Review : In contrast to the prevailing excellence of the reviews in your section of the Sunday TIMES, which I regularly read, the review of Miss Angela Morgan's "Awful Rainbow" in last Sunday's issue (Jan. 22) seemed to me not only Inadequate but inexcusably flippant.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- After spending a day in debating details of relief legislation with the result that only four comparatively minor amendments were adopted, the Senate agreed just before recessing this evening to vote finally and definitely on the measure at 4:30 P.M. Monday.
Italy was depicted as a nation that has entered upon an era of modern expansion in two speeches made in New York yesterday by Augusto Rosso, Italian Ambassador to the United States.

LAKEVILLE, Conn., Feb. 18. -- The annual midwinter festivities at the Hotchkiss School came to an end tonight. The varied events were attended by many girls from out-of-town schools, who were guests at the homes of members of the faculty.

HISTORY is repeating itself in the Western States where, according to the recent report of a traveler the unemployed are building log cabins and dugouts in large numbers. These log cabins, unlike the ones in camps and Summer resorts, resemble the dwellings of the pioneers in more than externals.

For many months heads of various State conservation departments have been faced with a problem of deep concern to every sportsman in this country, which may do great harm to the conservation program. The problem has to do with the lack of finances, because of which work of fish and game commissions has been curtailed.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb 18 -- More than twenty-five Pulitzer prize winners will be the guests of the "Friends of the Princeton Library" at a dinner to be held in New York May 4.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 18. -- It is predicted here that the government commission headed by General Moura, appointed to determine whether Brazilian neutrality has been violated in the fighting between Colombia and Peru, will not be able to reach a verdict because of the nature of the region.

ONE of the more hilarious episodes in Mr. Wodehouses's new book of stories concerns an Anglican Bishop who was given a little of an amazing preparation called Mulliner's Buck-U-Uppo.
