This tonic was not often administered to human beings, having been "designed primarily to encourage elephants in India to conduct themselves with an easy nonchalance daring the tiger hunts which are so popular in that country."

A German Liberal has been giving a subtle reason for the appointment of HITLER as Chancellor of the Reich. It is that the rulers of Germany and the German people in general had come to be persuaded that " actual Hitlerism is preferable to the constant " menace of Hitlerism."

The pressing problem of the British war debt was settled last night for President-elect Roosevelt in the grand ball room, of the Hotel Astor, where the Inner Circle, an organization of political reporters, past and present, had its annual stunt dinner.

The New York A.C. polo team Was victorious over Governors Island, 7 1/2 to 5 1/2, last night as play started in the Winged Foot club's invitation indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx. In the other games played the 105th Field Artillery trio downed the Northport Polo Club, 7 to 6, and the Allenhurst Polo Club overwhelmed Triangle, 20 1/2 to 7.

LUCERNE, Que., Feb. 18 -- R.L. Denton of McGill University won the ski-jumping championship at the International Intercollegiate Winter Sports Union meet today, outpointing J.A. Trachier of the University of New Hampshire by a small margin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Senator Borah, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations, having been assured by his Democratic colleagues today that Senator Hull had accepted the portfolio of Secretary of State in the Roosevelt administration, expressed the general attitude of both parties in Congress toward the appointment.

With the completion of all except one match, the eight seeded players in the national squash tennis Class C championship tourney, in progress at the City Athletic Club, have advanced safely into the third round.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- A grizzled veteran of railroading, L.F. Loree, president of the Delaware Hudson, told the Senate Finance Committee today that if the government would let the railroads alone and take legal shackles off them, they could get along without help.
IT is generally said that this will be a good season for prints -- prints for morning, afternoon and evening -- and naturally that calls for a great variety of designs and fabrics.

IN "The Shadow on the Mesa" the deft hand of the prolific Jackson Gregory has lost none of Its cunning. This tale is quite as novel in plot and incident and fully as exciting as any of Its numerous predecessors dealing with happenings in the wild and lawless borderland of the Rio Grande.

If the United States Steel Corporation's annual offering of stock to employes, which was announced on Friday, is fully subscribed, the employes' holdings will total approximately 1,200,000 shares, or more than one-eighth of the present outstanding issue of 8,703,252 shares, it is estimated.

In one of the most unusual basketball carnivals ever arranged, fourteen college quintets will play seve games in Madison Square Garden on Wednesday, the entire receipt going to the Mayor's Official Committee for the Relief of the Unemployed and Needy.

BOSTON, Feb. 18. -- Harvard, the University of Maine and Bowdoin carried off the major share of prizes at the second annual New England indoor intercollegiate track and field meet sponsored by the University Club of Boston at the Boston Garden tonight.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 18. -- Champion Benson of Crombie, the white-and-liver pointer owned by the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N.J., and shown in the ring by McClure Halley, was declared best in show at the conclusion of the fourteenth annual exhibition of the Elm City Kennel Club tonight.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 18 -- At the conclusion of the first two heats of the North American fourman bob-sled championships on the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run today, the three Stevens brothers, who yesterday took one, two, three in the boblet races, were in the same positions in the big sled race.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Coleman, MaJ. Gen. F. W., Chief of Finance, 10 days furlough.

WITH astonishing rapidity the once Dark Continent of Rhodes, Livingstone and Stanley is being opened up by air. The trunk line service down the spine of Africa operated by Imperial Airways as one of Great Britain's empire links is now, of course, a matter of scheduled operation which has brought Cape Town and London within eleven days of each other with flights in each direction once a week.

PARIS, Feb. 18 -- While the Senate was beginning this afternoon its discussion of the government's financial proposals as considerably amended by the Senate Finance Commission, it received word that State employes of almost all categories had decided on a one-hour strike Monday "against the deliberate provocations of the Senate Finance Commission."

IT is not often that a detective is invited to witness a murder. but that is precisely what happens when Clay Harrison is engaged to go to Penstoke House to "keep an eye on things." Penstoke House is the residence of William Marston and his wife and daughter.

In a printed notice sent to members of the New York Club, 20 West Fortieth Street, Clarence G. Meeks, the president, disclosed yesterday that the directors of the club "are face to face with a situation meaning either disintegration of the club in an insolvent condition, or the carrying out of some alternative plan which will perpetuate the name of the organization."

EDGAR KENNEDY, the sadly abused hero of the "Mr. Average Man" comedies, will appear in support of Ely Culbertson in the series of six two-reelers which the bridge authority is making for RKO-Radio Pictures. Mr. Kennedy will provide the comic relief, committing such high crimes and misdemeanors as trumping his partner's ace and leading out of the wrong hand.

MR. MAURICE SACHS, whose great-grandfather, by the way, was Georges Bizet, gallops with such fury through a host of names in "The Decade of Illusion: Paris 1918-1928" that his book seems very much like a blurred motion-picture.

THE husband who despite a horde of mistresses remains faithful to his wife in his "own fashion," and is always true to her "in his heart," has long been familiar to all readers and theatregoers. Mr. Maxwell has chosen to reverse the roles.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is possible to sympathize with Senator Tydings in his recent defense of the present Congress, but it is most difficult to agree with him. I presume it is laudable for a member of any body to defend that body against attack, but unless such defense be made free of casuistry it were better not to defend.

IF you check through the roster of exhibits in the catalogue of Maurice Sterne's one-man retrospective show at the Museum of Modern Art, which opened a few days ago you will find that 118 of the 174 works listed have been borrowed from private collections or from museums.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 18. -- Harvard's varsity wrestling team today triumphed over the wrestlers of Princeton, 16-12, in the first Cambridge clash between the two teams in eight years.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 18 -- Breaking 48 out of 50 targets. R.H. Helsel annexed the High Scratch Cup in the regular shoot over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

The last speech by Calvin Cooidge -- and the only political speech made by him after he left the White House in 1929 -- was in advocacy of the re-election of President Hoover in Madison Square Garden, New Tork, on Oct. 11. It has an interesting and unusual history.

CHICAGO, Feb. 18 -- Further selling of May wheat, which the trade attributed to a resumption of liquidation of the Federal Farm Board's holdings, prevented today any demonstration on the bull side on the Board of Trade here, but at the same time failed to have the depressing effect that this class of selling had had in previous days.

CHICAGO, Feb. 17. THE CAT AND THE FIDDLE" will move out of town tomorrow to continue its tour and the new week will bring nothing in the way of first-night activity. Thus Chicago will enter the last phase of February with only four attractions, as follows:

DOORN, Holland, Feb. 10 (by mail) -- Wilhelm II, former Emperor of Germany, reflecting in the solitude of his banishment upon the American discussions concerning technocracy, has arrived at the conclusion that the technocrats are wrong in conceding the supremacy of the machine.

DENVER, Feb. 18. -- Two crimes, the slaying of the city's most notorious gangster and the kidnapping of one of its most reputable citizens, tonight challenged police as possible ramifications of the same plct.

Glenn Cunningham did it again last night. The burly Kansas youth vanquished Gene Venzke for the second successive time before a gathering of 12,000 at Madison Square Garden in the classsic Baxter Mile that featured the New York Athletic Club games.

The cold weather last week hindered haulings of produce from storage in the North and West, so that shipments of some products were greatly reduced, George G. Royce, director of the local office of the State Department of Agriculture and Markets, writes in his consumers' weekly review of local wholesale markets.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 -- Before a cheering throng of more than 10,000 persons, the Everglade Stable's Dartle, odds-on favorite at 4 to 5, galloped to a decisive victory in the Nursery Stakes, feature today at Hialeah Park.

PARIS, Feb. 10. -- Severe criticism of the trade policies of the United States and France is contained in the annual report of the committees on importation and exportation of the American Chamber of Commerce, which have just been issued here.

When Piccard made his first record-breaking ascent into the stratosphere physicists wondered whether his results would be worth the effort and the risk. Only a few weeks before, Regener had sent up unmanned balloons with automatio recording instruments and thus obtained measuremeats of the intensify of the cosmic rays at heights of about twenty miles-twice the altitude achieved by Piccard.

HOLLYWOOD. JOHN BARRYMORE returned to Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer this week for his part in "Reunion in Vienna," in which he is featured with Diana Wynyard. Regarded as one of the studio's more important productions of the year several lavish sets have been constructed, many of them involving the new types of buildings which have recently become popular abroad -- those with huge windows and of curved, modern design, while other sets portray the prewar era.

Prices of bonds were irregularly lower again yesterday on the New York Stock Exchange. Weakness in the Japanese group was viewed as reflecting uncertainty over the situation that is expected to follow Japan's reported move to quit the League of Nations.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Feb. 16 -- The Wyoming-Colorado controversy over the diversion of North Platte River water for irrigation purposes has resolved itself into a diversion-of-trade problem in form of a business boycott.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 16. -- Southern California is coming to the peak of the unemployment period and will get through, in all probability, without collapse of the relief program. A Reconstruction Finance Corporation loan to the county will give employment to 25,000 persons.

ROME, Feb. 18. -- The Italian press again dedicatee much space today to the Franco-British note to Austria over the Hirtenberg arms affair, especially emphasizing its "unnecessary harshness," which, the Italians declare, evidently aims at submitting Austria to stinging humiliation.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Throwing out a challenge for the Louisiana Derby, Col. Hatfield today won his third successive race as he defeated a classy field of 3-year-olds in the Derby Trial Handicap over one mile. The feature carried $1,500 in added money and C. Meyer had the mount.

Price movements in local commodity markets were irregular yesterday with trading quiet. Sugar reacted, as did cocoa, but silver continued its quiet upward trend, and coffee futures displayed strength. In the cash markets, prices held steady with changes scattered.

New Yorkers will have the privilege of witnessing on Saturday the first women's national indoor track and field championships ever held in this city. The games will be held during the afternoon at Madison Square Garden and some 200 entries have been received by the A.A.U., under whose auspices the meet is being staged.

RETAIL trade results of the week, except in special instances, suffered a further setback. Unsettled weather and renewed anxiety over financial and business conditions were given as reasons. Several days of exceptional volume, however, were reported for the largest store here, which is holding an anniversary sale.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- President and Mrs. Hoover held tonight the annual State reception in honor of the Senate and House of Representatives.

Because next Wednesday will be Washington's Birthday, many of the sermons preached this morning will be devoted in whole or in part to a review of lessons that can be drawn from the life of the first President. Some pastors will point out how in their opinion the Father of His Country would solve the depression were he living today.

THIS is a slight, unpretentions novel, pleasantry concerned with a group of Bostonians, centring around the figure of a brilliant young psychiatrist. Devotion to science and the cause of humanity had left Lewis Prynne little time for diversion, so that at 33 he was something of an ascetic, to spite of his attractive personality, and quite unversed in the ways of romance.

Contrary to the general Impression, holders of common stocks are subjected to almost as severe a loss of income from dividends as wage earners are through pay cuts in a major depression, according to a statistical survey of the subject just completed by the Standard Statistics Company, covering the period from 1914 to 1932 inclusive.

Six detectives with drawn revolvers broke into a room in 58 East 125th Street yesterday and captured Louis Sprague Douglass, wanted for the murder of John Hayden and Ralph Hart, near Bouse, Ariz., on Feb. 7.

BRONXVTLLE, N. T., Feb. 18. -- A. "hardly fair" party, including dancing, bridge and an entertainment by radio performers, was held tonight at the Hotel Gramatan here. Ronald McLeod served as general chairman. Part of the proceeds will be used for the Boy Scouts of Bronxville.

Conferences of bankers in New York and Chicago with officials of the City of Detroit are expected generally to take place as a result of the controversy concerning the renewal of $15,388,000 of bank loans of the city which will fall due a week from tomorrow.

THE most ambitious attempt to record the books printed from movable type in the fifteenth century is the German "Gesamtkatalog der Wiegendrucke." Leipzig, beginning 1925 and still in progress. It is estimated that this tremendous scholarly enterprise will be completed in another quarter of a century.

THE publishing firm of Coward-McCann has purchased the publishing division of Brentano's including all plates, manufactured stock and contracts for new books, excepting only the books of George Bernard Shaw, which have been sold separately to Dodd Mead Co.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- Yale's 109th consecutive college swimming victory was gained tonight over Brown, 47 to 24, before almost 1,000 spectators in the Payne VVhitney pool. Two pool records and one New England intercollegiate mark were broken and one tank standard equaled.

To the Dramatic Editor: Back in those mad November days your present Mayor dreamed a dream, about a city of homes, about Horace and the kiddies. Brooding comfortably amid the fields and fauna of Pennsylvania, I felt that by now you all would have settled down.

EVEN the name of the author of "Miss Mole" has some of the retiring and anonymous flavor of her books, the same combination of modesty and conscious worth which is to be found in the style of her writing and her characters.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 14. -- Spurred by the fact that many of the leaders of the government and of the Kuomintang party have acquired the habit of making public speeches and even radio broadcasts denouncing corruption in high places, a movement has been launched in Nanking for the establishment of a society the principal object of which will be "the improvement of public morals."

VIENNA, Feb. 17. -- How Austria can get herself out of the mess she got into when France, Britain and the Little Entente learned that she was acting as middleman for the illegal supply of rifles and machine guns to Hungary has become a life-and-death problem for the Dollfuss government.

When the League of Nations radio station broadcast to the four corners of the earth Friday the 15,000-word report of the Committee of Nineteen, constituting a condemnation of the methods used by Japan in her quarrel with China, it marked a new development in world diplomacy.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Five men learned today that jesting about the attempt to assassinate President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt was a serious matter to police and Secret Service officials pending the time the latter Were convinced it was a Joke.

A record entry list Is expected for the seventh annual Eastern bridge championships competition, which will take place at the Hotel Roosevelt during the week starting Monday, Feb. 27. Almost 350 persons are expected to take part in the pair event for the Julian Goldman trophy, the leading pair tournament of the year, and about thirty teams-of-four will take part in the competition for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy.

IT is worth, while to peruse the collection of criticisms of musical performances that Bernard Shaw wrote for The World in London during the years 1890-94. Of one, crime Shaw has seldom be guilty: the crime of dullness. He filled his column week in and week out with commentary that was always diverting and frequently more than that.

The younger generation of racquet players, which has its strongest representation in years on the courts today, stood to the fore yesterday as the national championship got under way at the Racquet and Tennis Club with Clarence C. Pell seeking his twelfth title.

GENEVA, Feb. 17. -- "Within six months we shall be applying the sanctions of Article XVI of the covenant against Japan," one of Europe's most experienced and farsighted Foreign Ministers predicted privately the other day. His opinion is not yet the general opinion in Geneva, although the trend is increasing toward it.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 (AP). -- Quick action by the people on prohibition repeal became a strong possibility today as State Legislatures awaited the predicted favorable House vote on the Senate repeal resolution.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Having noted in THE NEW YORK TIMES an article with reference to the article Stream, may I question the impression conveyed in this article -- that our mild Winters have no relation to the Gulf Stream. I purposely omit "recent mild Winters."

DESIGNERS of Station WCAU's new home at Philadelphia must have unearthed Aladdin's lamp and reverently rubbed its magic wick, and presto! -- appeared the answer to the broadcasters' dream. But it was not quite as simple as that.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Condemnation of Congress is general in this country. If times are good, business prays that Congress will "stop talking and go home," lest the balance of prosperity be upset. If times are bad, business demands that Congress "stop talking and do something."

With Continental currencies continuing their advance against the dollar and $12,353,800 additional gold earmarked for foreign account, the quiet and Irregular movement of stocks, bonds and commodities was more or less obscured yesterday.

A Washington's Birthday party, including bridge and an entertainment in which many well-known stars of the theatrical and musical worlds will take part, will be given on Tuesday afternoon at Essex House for the benefit of the Episcopal Actors Guild.

Most of the projects for the improvement of waterways in the New York port district which were carried on during 1932 have been completed or are nearing completion, according to the Port of New York Authority. The status of the work is reflected in the annual report of the chief of army engineers which estimates the expenditures for 1933 at $1,788,264 for this type of work, as against $4,859,146 expended In 1932.

BOOTH TARKINGTON possesses what might be described as the pioneer literary spirit. It was the opportunity of experimenting with a new medium of expression that induced this man from Indiana to direct his talents to the microphone.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 18 (AP). -- Joseph Zangara, the man who tried to kill President-elect Roosevelt, is a "psychopathic personality," one of those "whose pet schemes and morbid emotions run in conflict with the established order of society," a sanity commission reported tonight.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 14. -- The Chinese press is considerably wrought up over reports from Peiping and Jehol to the effect that when a band of raiding Mongols was recently killed to the last man on the Jehol border, it was discovered that the group was officered by a Japanese, Lieutenant Matsui, and that he carried orders for the formation of a new State to be known as "Tayuankuo."

Comparing the armies of today to museum effigies of prehistoric monsters which are horrifying but harmless, Captain B.H. Liddell Hart, British military critic and historian, predicts, in an article in March Current History entitled "New Armies for Old," that the great infantry armies maintained by the powers would sink into trenches within a week if hostilities should begin.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18 -- Hope for Senatorial action on bankruptcy legislation revived today when Republican leaders agreed to make this topic the pending business of the Senate following a final vote Monday on unemployment relief legislation.

The vanguard of reports on retail earnings for 1932 which made their appearance during the week showed foreign stores maintained their ability to achieve substantial net profits in the face of difficult economic conditions abroad. Their net-profit showing was remarked as calculated to stir envy among executives of stores on this side of the water, few of which will report net profits for last year.

IN 1849. at the peak of the goldrush fever. Matt and Jake, two green adventurers from Ohio, land in California, fired by ambition to dig their fortunes. But within three days they are robbed of their reserve funds and shanghaied aboard a sailing ship bound upon a raid of Russian sealers in the northern Pacific.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- Despite the week-end shrinkage in transactions on the Boerse today a firm tone was maintained. Conclusion of the new standstill agreement and hope that the Reichsbank would reduce its rediscount rate were cited as steadying factors.

IN 1928 the Academy of St. Cecilia in Rome decided to offer Ernest Bloch the title of Member of Honor of the academy. This year the academy, by special desire of its president, Count di San Martino, provided two concerts devoted to the works of the composer, who since last year has come several times to Italy and has become very popular there.

Sports followers who like to devote part of their Sundays to viewing athletic competitions no doubt will head in the direction of the Women's Swimming Association clubhouse on East Seventy-seventh Street this afternoon.

FROM time to time Equity has suggested certain courses of action which it felt the theatre might follow to its own advantage. There does not appear, at this time, any indication of a general plan of action from any other quarter in the theatre.

Sweeping changes in the methods used by the city to fix levies for local improvements were proposed yesterday by the Citizens Budget Commission as a means of overcoming the "growing evil practice of shifting the burden from the local areas of benefit and thus in effect setting up a 'second budget' against the city at large."

ANOTHER story of the little girl with an American artist father and a Scotch mother, whose life in Italy was described in the author's "Robin and Tito" and "Robin and Angus." In this third volume Robin goes to visit her Scotch grandfather, accompanied by Angus, her wirehaired terrier, who is as lively as ever and whose activities, though well meant, are occasionally devastating.

To the Music Editor: After much conversation and considerable listening-in, it is apparent that all music lovers or lovers of art in any form agree on one point -- that opera must not die in New York. What can be done to save it? Why not call for suggestions from the public?

BERLIN, Feb. 18 -- Germania, the principal Catholic newspaper in Germany, the official organ of the Centrist party and the personal mouthpiece of Dr. Heinrich Bruening during his Chancellorship, today was ordered suppressed for three days for printing the official party manifesto as the Socialist Vorwaerts was recently suppressed for printing the manifesto of its party.

A YEAR ago Miss Truax's first book, "Hospital," was given a warm reception by most reviewers, probably because of its unusual subject-matter, its three or four carefully drawn characters and the promise revealed by its best passages.

GENEVA, Feb. 18. -- Anxious interest in the attitude non-League nations, notably the United States, will take toward the report on Manchuria by the Committee of Nineteen of the League of Nations, broadcast yesterday, was shown today by League delegates and officials, particularly those who worked hardest to get it to include the Stimson doctrine of non-recognition.

The American Can Company reported for 1932 a net income of $10,957,295 after interest, depreciation and Federal taxes, equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $3.26 a share on the 2,473,998 shares of common stock outstanding. This compares with $15,529,579, or $5.11 a share, in 1931.

To assure continuance of the Salvation Army's emergency relief and institutional aid activities, $565,000 must be raised by public subscription by June 1, according to a survey of the advisory board of the organization. A campaign to obtain this fund will be started tomorrow from headquarters at 15 Nassau Street.

With one exception, transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday were the smallest of the year to date. The turnover barely passed the 300,000 share mark and trading took place in only about one-third of the listed issues. Some signs of strength were noted in the first hour, but the market drifted lower near the close, apparently because of speculative inertia.

Although it is understood that Alvin Webb never was a cowboy, he seems to know the ropes. At least that is what the police say, adding -- and this may account for his fancy tricks with hempen strands -- that he hails from Balinger, Texas. Webb now is under lock, key and bolt, charged with something new in burglary attempts, and the police are seeking a shoeless man as his accomplice.

BOGOTA, Feb. 13 -- A first edition of Miguel de Cervantes's "Novelas Ejemplares" (Exemplary Novels), published in 1613, has been found in the National Library here. It is said to be one of only seven examples of this work known to be in existence.

"Farm cooperatives in New York, in general, have probably withstood present economic difficulties better than most other forms of business organization," said F.A. Harper of the Department of Agricultural Economics and Farm Management at Cornell University in a "farm and home week" talk at Ithaca recently.

ONE of those plays about the Bronte Sisters finally appeared-although at a considerable distance from the home of Broadway's brave and fair. It was Dan Totheroh's "Moor Born," and what is called the world premiere took place Tuesday night at the University of Iowa, Iowa City, in Iowa.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 18. -- For the first time in China's modern history government leaders ventured, toward the front-line danger zones when Dr. T.V. Soong, Nanking Finance Minister, Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang and other officials and commanders arrived today at Chengteh (Jehol City), the capital of Jehol Province, from Peiping.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 18. -- Notre Dame's basketball team defeated Pennsylvania at the Palestra tonight, 36 to 24, before a crowd of 6,500 persons. The South friend passers were never beaded after the first few minutes.

MONTREAL, Feb. 18. -- The Canadiens could not cope with the rugged Ranger defense and lost a National Hockey League game to the New Yorkers, 3-1, tonight. The Rangers moved into first place in the American group, as Detroit lost at Toronto.

BALBOA, C.Z., Feb. 18 -- Ten huge bombing planes carrying an entire battalion of field artillery, escorted by twenty-one pursuit planes and twenty-nine observation and transport planes, flying at 100 miles an hour, closed the annual manoeuvres of the Canal department of the army today.

WASHINGTON. THE recent report of the secretary of the Senate, showing that the government spent about $8,000 for Senatorial shaves, haircuts, tonics, headache powders, , last year draws attention to the one-room barber shop on the ground floor of the Capitol, run for members of the upper house.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 18 -- The social festivities of Junior Week-End at Rutgers University were concluded tonight. Twenty fraternities held house parties at which 400 gruests were present. The Junior Promenade, the outstanding event of the week-end, was attended by more than 300 couples in the university gymnasium last night.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 18 -- The Times-Picayune is publishing in its Sunday editions the following editorial on "The Overton Election Inquiry," conducted by a Senate subcommittee here:

BUDAPEST, Feb. 4. -- A meeting unique in its character was recently convened by the school board of the Szemere Street Girls' High School of Budapest. Its only purpose was to find an e icient means to check the growing tendency among the school girls to lose weight.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The TIMES published a dispatch about the counterglow, or Gegenschein, in which it stated that Professor Elvey of the University of Chicago had recently measured the intensity of this light. The article states that the counterglow was first noted three-quarters of a century ago by Theodore Brorsen in Germany and was rediscovered twice-by T.W. Backhouse of England, in 1868.

ANTIQUE fabrics, difficult to find in a good state of presvation are much in demand among decorators. They are used to bestow distinction on old chairs or as wall hangings or bedspreads in period rooms. The artistic designs of many of these old pieces fragments though they may be, graphically recreate the decorative charm of an era.

RICHMOND, Feb. 16 -- Undeterred by the fact that his effort to deprive Communist agitators here of their constitutional rights has resulted in creating sympathy for them and in giving them a great deal of publicity, Mayor J. Fulmer Bright continues to harass them.

Eighty colts, thirty-three geldings and five fillies comprise the 118 thoroughbreds which have been nominated for the fifty-ninth Kentucky Derby, to be run May 6 at Churchill Downs, according to an announcement yesterday from M.J. Winn.

WEST LEBANON, N. Y., Feb. 18. -- Anton Lekang of the Norway Ski Club of New York carried off the New York State Class A ski jumping title with a total of 147.8 points in the championship tournament held today on the precipitous hill of the Norway Ski Club of New York.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 18. -- Appearing this week in the Yale Scientific Monthly is the first detailed description of the rowing tanks in the new Payne Whitney gymnasium at Yale. They have created an entirely new system of tank rowing and are calculated to give Eli crews a much bettor method of Winter training than those Which have been in force in the past.

BERLIN, Feb. 18 (AP) -- The news of James J. Corbett's death came as a surprise here today, since he had been reported dead on Feb. 9. The newspapers emphasized the gentlemanliness of the former champion and reported his career in detail, ranking him among the world's greatest boxers.

PARIS PLENTY has been said these last few seasons about cotton as a dressy fabric; the new cottons that look like wools and so on. Likewise, there has been much talk of woolens crashing into dressy circles.
PEIPING, Feb. 18. -- Manchukuo completed today preparations for the projected offensive of her forces, in conjunction with large Japanese contingents, to seize the Chinese Province of Jehol.

IT is poetry of a very special sort which is to be found between the covers of "Transvaluations," by J. Redwood Anderson; and although it also is poetry of a very high order, it is perhaps for the few rather than for the many. Of undoubted lyric genius and capacity, Mr. Anderson might be said in this volume to have done in verse, at least to some degree, what Blake did in his pictures.

DETROIT, Feb. 18 -- Inspired by local pride, the two great groups of national banks centring in Detroit have rejected overtures from New York bankers which they interpreted as intended virtually to take them over and have determined to work out their problems on their own, it was learned today from sources close to the Michigan bankers.

AL JOLSON, on one of last week's braw afternoons, expressed a fondness for one-syllable words and a distaste for motion-picture directors who require their stars to leap off bridges into cold water after sundown. Both opinions, which were by no means the only ones Mr. Jolson expressed, arose out of a discussion of his new picture, "Hallelujah, I'm a Bum."

A ARONS Freedley feel so low about it all that they propose forsaking the musical comedy. Or, at least, that was the way the party of the second part put it a day or so ago. They just cost too much. Mr. Freedley explained, further, that he is through for the season and added that next year he will produce some plays alone.

BOSTON, Feb. 16. -- Governor Stanley C. Wilson of Vermont, as head of a State which he believes is now recognized as the leader in the New England dairy industry, reviewed in a speech here a few days ago the record of the plan for the stabilization of that industry which began to function less than a year ago, and declared that the plan must not be allowed permanently to fail.

PITTSFIELD, Mass. SIMPLICITY in school life has a new example in the Lebanon School for Boys, which has recently been opened in the old Shaker village on the slopes of Mount Lebanon. The heritage of Shaker lore and accomplishment to which the school is heir, and the almost severely simple buildings of the sect which have been acquired, give the school an atmosphere and facilities for making a distinct contribution to secondary education.
To the Dramatic Editor: One would expect to grow callous to torn heart strings these days, but the passing of a gallant spirit like John Galsworthy gives a tug that cannot prevent a sigh of pain.

The Paderewski recital la like none other. It has a two-fold character. There is the atmosphere of an artistic rite; at the same time there is a singular sensation of spectacle and event. The proportions and the brilliancy of the audience that gathered yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall to hear the lord of his instrument reveal himself in discoursing the music of Chopin -- this audience was like none other of the season.

DETROIT. PROGRESS in metallurgy, according to the forecasts of automotive engineers, may soon bring important changes in manufacturing methods by which motor cars are produced. What the engineers are aiming at is a switch from forgings to castings in the production of camshafts, crankshafts and other important units, changing foundry practice In a way that would save the entire industry millions in cash over a year of operation.

In an effort to restore the knitted outerwear industry to a profit-making basis, the National Knitted Outerwear Association plans to offer to its members actual operating budgets taken from the experience of mills working at a profit, Harold R. Lhowe, counsel and executive director of the association, announced here yesterday.

Copyright, 1933, by NANA, Inc. "The finest city water supply in the world," is the challenge that Spokane, Wash., hurls to any one who wants to Dispute that statement. And the city is prepared to back up the claim.
DUBLIN, Feb. 17 -- Beyond the economic disturbance of the railway strike the Free State is enjoying a period of peace and quiet.

GLORIA SWANSON, producer as well as actress, will offer her latest film at the Rivoli on Wednesday night. It is called "Perfect Understanding" and was produced abroad. Miss Swanson, the daughter of an army officer, was born in Chicago and spent most of her early years in various army posts, picking up the odds and ends of an education when she could.

CONVINCED, obviously, that earlier accounts of the doings of Satan upon earth had failed to give the devil his dne, William Gernardi, assisted by Brian Lunn, has "collated" what must be regarded. If we are to enter into the spirit of the joke, as the first authentic publication of his true memoirs.

The formation under the Webb act of a cooperative organization to dispose of a large part of the huge surplus copper stocks in the United States in foreign markets is advocated by Kenneth S. Guiterman, formerly president of Henry Gardiner, Guiterman Co., copper exporters.

Maria Olszewska was a new princess of Egypt and Clara Jacobo a new bride of the Nile at the season's fifth performance of "Aida" at the opera last evening. Again the house was crowded, and a double day of Verdi was marked by popular enthusiasm such as has been noticeable since the Metropolitan's appeal for next year's needed guarantee.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., Feb. 16. -- The official announcement from Jackson last week that Mississippi wound up the year 1932 with a 9 per cent excess of receipts over disbursements, again directs attention to the sales tax in that State, an experiment which began last May and which, along with a rigid program of reduced expenditures, is largely responsible for the healthy condition of the Treasury.

The New York Music Week Association, which for ten years has endeavored to cultivate appreciation of good music, has evolved a project of "diminishing teas," in a search for a new name more expressive of the educational and cultural scope of the organization.

BERLIN, Feb. 4. AENGTHY man with a double portion of arms and legs and a very extensive nose suddenly leaps up from the orchestra pit, waving a baton in his hand. The drums and the brass begin to pound and blare.

In view of the demonstrated difficulty of balancing the national budget, it has been proposed that the Roosevelt Administration initiate a new system of Federal accounting. The plan would be to segregate in an " extraordinary budget" all outlays for so-called permanent improvements and to cover with current revenues only that part of the Government's expenditures which actually represent current costs.

The newspaper -was described as "the first article ever produced in the world by methods of quantity production" by Henry Wise Wood, inventor of the Wood high-speed printing press, in an address on Friday night before the Advertising Club of THE NEW YORK TIMES.

VIENNA, Feb. 18. -- The declaration by the Rome paper Giornale d'Italia that the British and French demanded a categorical promise from Austrian statesmen that the arms recently shipped to Austria for repair had not been sent to Hungary but had definitely been returned to Italy has revealed such a complete distrust of the explanations already offered by the Dollfuss Cabinet as to imperil its existence.

PARIS, Jan. 30, 1933 JULIEN KREIN, who surprised every one by his precocity in writing at the age of 13 or 14 compositions published by the Universal Edition, has now reached the mature stature of 20. One may judge his recent works by the remarkable concerto for 'cello, or, better, the ballade for orchestra.

SAN PEDRO, Cal., Feb. 16 -- What will undoubtedly be the most complete hydrographic and geodetic survey of the Aleutian Islands ever undertaken will be started by the navy in April when the officers and enlisted men of several naval vessels and two amphibian planes will start running base lines and taking aerial photographs of the rocky barren islets in the far north.

THE coal mining industry, says Malcolm Ross, "is a cantankerous industry, soured by the bile of insoluble difficulties." But in this book he makes a courageous and clear-sighted effort to understand some of its difficulties in one particular situation and by the light thus gained to illuminate the whole problem.

IN 1920 Van Wyck Brooks pubished "The Ordeal of Mark Twain." To many, the book was an astonishingly Interesting one, for it called attention -- and dramatically to what literary critics in America had more or less forgotten: that an artist's work is intimately bound up with the life of his times, and not to be explained with any adequacy by references to "wills to refrain" and the inner check."

Patrolman Thomas J. Fitzpatrick, 57 years old, plunged into the Icy waters of the Van Cortlandt Park lake, at the north end, near the city line, yesterday afternoon and rescued three boys who had crashed through the ice into six feet of water.

With only two business days left of Michigan's banking holiday. Wall Street is looking for relief this week from the severe strain under which the financial community has been working since last Tuesday. Bankers who have been in almost constant communication with Detroit are encouraged to believe that business may be resumed throughout the State as usual on Thursday morning without risk.

HARTFORD, Feb. 16 -- While the Connecticut Legislature, now approaching the end of the second month of its biennial session, is the centre of a furor over deals on the patronage in the minor courts of the State the representatives from the small towns are exerting their usual influence on legislative business.

Judging by the large subscription for the performance of "Alien Corn" on Tuesday night at the Belasco Theatre, which has been taken over by members of Neighborhood Playhouse Associates to aid the scholarship fund of the Neighborhood Playhouse Studios, the fund will be appreciably augmented.

FOR reasons best known to the companies, the digging out of a representative list of "Die Meistersinger" records is a comparatively laborious affair. Why no part of it has ever been taken for the purpose of making an album remains a mystery, and it leaves a collector to examine all catalogues and then be at a loss as to how to choose.

PARIS, Feb. 10 -- Plans for the creation of a cemetery in a beautiful park in the suburbs of Paris for the burial of American citizens have been submitted to the French Government by a group of prominent American bankers and business men of Paris.

ADMIRERS of Abraham Lincoln who have been brought up on Herndon, Miss.Tarbell, Dr. Barton, Beverldge and Carl Sandburg, not to mention that singularly juiceless series of heavy volumes which Nicolay and Hay produced nearly half a century ago, might at first thought wish that they could have been spared a Freudian biography.

Playing sensationally late in the second half, after having been held even for thirty minutes, City College's varsity basketball team brought its home season to a close at the C. C. N. Y. gymnasium last night by scoring 35-24 victory over Temple University of Philadelphia.

Silk Persian palace carpets and other antique Oriental rugs, tapestries, eighteenth century English furniture, early American furniture, glass and pewter, and etchings are among the objects which will be offered at auction here this week.

St. John's High School and Brooklyn Prep qualified to play for the C. H. S. A. A. hockey championship as a result of their victories last night at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, when the tournament schedule ended.

PINEHURST, N.C. -- Chief interest here this week will centre upon the traditional tournaments on Thursday of the Tin Whistles, the men's golfing society of Pinehurst, and the Silver Foils, a women's organization.

In commemoration of the birthday of Washington, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, is exhibiting a rare collection of Washington relics, including furniture, broadsides, prints, engravings and paintings. The collection deals principally with his inauguration and the events which followed it.

The annual Winter meeting of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers will begin a four-day session here tomorrow at the Engineering Societies Building, 29 West Thirtyninth Street. About 1,500 members from this country and abroad, including several distinguished foreign mining and metallurgical engineers, are expected to attend.

WE have often been accused of holding life cheap in America. Our record of homicides and accidents in a measure justifies this charge. But this is after all a narrow view. It gives an unfair valuation of the sacredness of life in America, for there are few countries in the world where life is so thoroughly safeguarded as here.

Designed to halt the average losses of $30,000,000 suffered yearly by the wool goods industry, a plan to establish a national wool acceptance bank, which would control the operations of the industry through credit, is now under way, Emanuel Kaplan of the Millbrook Woolen Mills and originator of the idea, said here yesterday.

IN these days of Tumultuous tought and economic distress, when man turns hither and thither in the hope of discovering some salvaging formula that will help him a short time longer to endure, comes a little book -- we might can it a breviary -- bearing a simple message that is like rain to a parched earth.

IT now is time to make a phonograph record of the mimeographed statements of returning Broadwayites who, it appears, suffer distressing exile while they bask in California sunshine and draw those checks from the film industry.

AUCKLAND, N.Z., Jan. 24. -- Political turmoil rules in this country today, and no one can see the outcome. The latest move of the farmer-led government, in hoisting the exchange rate to 25 per cent, has split the country wide open.

IRVINGTON, N.J., Feb. 18 -- Five-year-old Billy Brandstatter never wants to play "Cowboys and Indiana" again. As an "Indian" he was captured by three "cowboys" in a backyard yesterday and "lynched" on a picket fence.

The blue spread eagle of the American Merchant, United States and Panama Pacific lines, which flies on a white background at the masthead of their ships in the intercoastal and transatlantic trades, will complete forty years at sea next Wednesday.

ACCORDING to London dispatches last week, quoting Sir Eric Geddes after his return by air from Cape Town, the old maxim that the sun never sets on the British Empire will soon have to be changed to read airways for empire.
ISTANBUL, Feb. 16 -- Brusa, the best known Turkish spa, recently was the scene of a public protest against reading the Koran in Turkish.

The strongest field ever assembled for a national indoor championship meet will gather in Madison Square Garden on Saturday when the Amateur Athletic Union stages its forty-fifth annual track and field title games.

James J. Corbett, the first heavyweight boxing champion of the world under Marquess of Queensberry rules, was the ring's best and first really scientific fighter, a pioneer in the sport as it is regulated today. He introduced a new era in a sport that had been out-lawed in every State of the Union save Louisiana.

THE recent opening of a radio telephone service between the United States and Colombia marks another link in the vast chain of communications emanating from this city. Residents of New York can now reach 33,500,000 individual telephones, or 92 per cent of all those in the world, located in forty-six countries.

A high speed air race around the world is in the making in two hangars at Floyd Bennett Field. Wiley Post, who, with Harold Gatty as navigator, flew around the world in eight days two years ago, is grooming the Winnie Mae for an attempt to break his own record.

Total revenues of the electric light and power industry of the United States in 1932 were $1,832,595,900, comparing with $1,975,944,500 in 1931, a, decrease of 7.3 per cent, according to the report of the National Electric Light Association covering 100 per cent of the industry.

LAKE PLACID. -- Many of the finest ski jumpers from clubs in the United States, Canada, Norway and Finland have entered the Lake Placid Club's twelfth annual tournament, which is scheduled for Washington's Birthday.

A concert to celebrate the golden jubilee of Leon M. Kramer, composer of synagogue music, conductor and one of the musical pioneers of the lower east side, was given before a large audience last night in the Kaufmann auditorium of the Young Men's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and Ninety-second Street.

THE war cost the belligerents about 147 billion dollars -- but in the purchasing power of 1913, to which level the dollar has about returned, that cost would have been 46 billions. Thus, more than 100 billion dollars was pure "inflation," due to the destructive demands of war.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- To understand what is happening in Germany it will be useful to recall what William James recorded as the most philosophical remark that he had ever heard: "There is precious little difference between one man and another, but what little there is is of tremendous importance."

Legislation which would not only permit closed banks to reopen under safeguards limiting the withdrawal of deposits but which might also be used to check runs on banks through temporary "freezing" of part of their deposits is under consideration by several States as well as by the Federal banking authorities.

Elliot B. Wheaton's transcription of a six-voice Bach fugue was the first work on the New York Philharmonic-Symphony's program at its Student Concert in Carnegie Hall last night, receiving its first New York performance. One gleans from Mr. Wheaton's foreword to his score that the fugue was among other works sent as a "Musical Offering" to Frederick the Great after the visit of Bach the Great to Potsdam in 1747;

NEW LONDON, Wis., Feb. 18 (AP). -- Thousands of pounds of milk splashed on highways of Winnebago and Waupaca Counties and fists flew today as large groups of farmers participated in a milk sales strike.

NEW LONDON, Wis., Feb. 18 (AP). -- Thousands of pounds of milk splashed on highways of Winnebago and Waupaca Counties and fists flew today as large groups of farmers participated in a milk sales strike.

Dr. William T. Hornaday, militant wild-life conservationist, director of the Permanent Wild Life Protection Fund and former director of the New York Zoological Park, was decorated yesterday with the Outdoor Life gold medal for distinguished achievements in wild-life conservation, for 1932.

CHICAGO, Feb. 16 -- Back of the agitation that is disturbing the dairy farmers of Illinois, Wisconsin and neighboring States is the familiar story of declining prices and the absorption of all profitable return by the cost of marketing. The milch herd has ceased to be a source of livelihood and has become, so the farmers complain, a herd of sharp-pointed dilemmas on four legs.

SARATOGA SPRINGS, N. Y., Feb. 18 (AP). -- Leroy Funnell, speedy skater from East High School, Buffalo, finished first in two of the events he entered today in the third annual Winter carnival at Saratoga Springs.

An off-season that contributed more than its share of entertaining events having run its course, baseball will move directly into the open spaces this week when two of Greater New York's three major-league clubs embark upon their 1933 training campaign.

CHICAGO INSTEAD of "a century of progress" in painting, the Chicago world's fair is going to show visitors a century of progress in the collecting of paintings. For many months Robert B. Harshe, director of the Art Institute, which is to house the fair's official art show, toured Europe, visiting museums, great private collections and even painters' studios, and rumors drifted back to Chicago of plans for a most exceptional art exhibition in 1933.

With Lieut. Col. J.K. Brown playing his best polo of the season and young Billy Reynolds going well at No. 2, the Crusaders of Henry Lewis 3d won their first Metropolitan League polo match last night, turning back Squadron A, 10 1/2 to 6 1/2, at the loser's arena.

MIAMI. -- Probably no other single week of the season in the Miami area will exceed the present one in unique forms of entertainment. The annual chowder party of the Biscayne Bay Yacht Club, which will be part of the Washington Birthday observances, is an all-day outing combining features of the old-fashioned picnic and the modern afternoon tea with the delights of a cruise among the South Florida keys.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 18. -- Attended by a largo throng, the Tombola was given this afternoon in the Cluett Gardens by the Woman's Guild of Bethesda-by-the-Sea, as its annual benefit for the county's needy. Features were a dog show, fashion show, a midway for children, a Petit Bon Marche and many other attractions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 18. -- Bank debits outside New York City declined during the week ended Feb. 11 and were 16 per cent below a year ago, according to the weekly survey of current business made public today by the Department of Commerce.

TOKYO, Feb. 18. -- The cancellation of today's scheduled Cabinet meeting strengthens the belief that Premier Makoto Saito is winning the struggle to postpone a decision regarding withdrawal from the League of Nations, though the internal Cabinet developments continue hidden.
PALM BEACH. -- The week's calendar of activities is almost a surfeit of featured events, comprising a schedule which promises to eclipse that of any previous period this Winter.

The annual report of the Central Hudson Gas and Electric Corporation shows net income of $2,042,693 after all charges, taxes and reserves, equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.08 a share on 1,500,000 common shares, against $1,943,003, or $1.01 a share, in 1931.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 18. -- Steaming past the rugged headlands of the Golden Gate, vessels of the United States fleet stood into the broad reaches of San Francisco Harbor today to give their crews a Jew days of rest and recreation after a week of strenuous "war."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Under the impetus of non-partisan Senate leadership, an effort will be made in the next few days to pass the bankruptcy bill so as to get such legislation enacted in the short session expiring March 4.

To the Editor of The New York Timss: Where is "the man of yesteryear? And for that matter, where is the woman? These questions occurred to me after a glance at an advertisement of a suit for women which featured a tailored skirt and a pair of trousers!

Spasmodic recoveries in the latter part of the period helped to reduce what otherwise would have been substantial losses last week on local commodity exchanges. Some gains were made, notably in silver and sugar, with coffee also slightly higher.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- When the World War broke out in 1914, creating an unprecedented demand for ships to handle the movement of men and supplies, the United States, once preeminent as a maritime nation, had 112 ships of about 600,000 gross tons, trading to foreign and non-contiguous possessions.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is with pleasure that I avail myself of the opportunity granted by the Miami representative of THE NEW YORK TIMES to tender my best thanks to both that newspaper and its staff correspondent, Russell B. Porter, for the series of articles on conditions in Cuba iust published.

Sidney Howard's "Alien Corn," which forms Katharine Cornell's second production of the season, will open tonight at the Belasco Theatre with Miss Cornell in the leading role. Also opening tonight -- but for only a fortnight's run -- is "The Mighty Conlin." a play by Oliver White.

WHITE PLAINS. N. Y., Feb. 19. -- It is expected that when the Westchester County Board of Supervisors act on the new tax rating and equalization table tomorrow several Supervisors will oppose the schedules submitted last week.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Those of us who, during the past year or more, have personally known of the want and distress in the city that was not being met by any one of the many relief agencies, rejoiced in the news that Governor Lehman had the courage to make request for help from the Federal Treasury.

J.H. Wantling led a field of twenty-two gunners at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the High Scratch Cup for the second day in a row by breaking 96 out of 100 targets. The second trophy went to E.S.S. Carroll, who finished with 95.

BALTIMORE,- Feb. 19 -- Supported by Governor Albert C. Ritchie, plans were perfected today for prompt ratification by Maryland should Congress enact repeal of prohibition tomorrow. Maryland is one of the few States which did not choose to enact a State enforcement act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19. -- Publication by THE NEW YORK TIMES of the report of the League of Nations Committee of Nineteen on Manchuria yesterday morning within a few hours after the 15,000-word document had been received by wireless direct from Geneva brought commendation today from high officials and others in Washington.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 19 -- Manchukuo's "farewell statement" to the League of Nations is regarded by Chinese here as actually insulting and as accurately foreshadowing Japan's attitude toward the League. The message serves to stir deeply Shanghai's apprehensions as to the seemingly inevitable trend of events in Eastern Asia.

A resolution urging an immediate embargo upon, all arms shipments to Latin America and the Par East, to be supported in addition by a withdrawal of credit facilities, has been sent to President Hoover, to President-elect Roosevelt and to members of Congress by the League of Nations Association, Inc., that organization announced yesterday.

LONDON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- The report that President-elect Roosevelt had called in his economic advisers today for conferences on the eve of the meeting with Sir Ronald Lindsay wag received with an expression of interest in official quarters, but there -was no comment.

Despite an upturn in the production of automobiles, trucks and steel and in building and engineering construction, general business conditions declined in January from the prevailing level of the previous four months, according to the monthly report yesterday of the conference of statisticians in industry, operating under the auspices of the National Industrial Conference Board.

A considerable increase in unemployment relief work in Westchester County was made possible yesterday with the announcement by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration of a grant of $477,386 for relief wages this month in Mount Vernon, New Rochelle, White Plains and Yonkers and on State projects in the county.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Albert C. Middleton, State Treasurer of New Jersey, admitted today that he was the person described in reports during the last few days as "the big politician" who had sought to block a coroner's inquest into the deaths in June, 1929, of Horace Roberts Jr. and Ruth Mowdray Wilson of this town.

Although there were a number of buyers in the wholesale market here last week, activity showed signs of falling off. The leading consideration in the buying of merchandise last week was to obtain goods on which higher-up-than-usual mark-ups could be taken.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Answering promptly my query in THE TIMES of several days ago, Senator Fearon has given me a copy of the bill that would restore to mortgagors their former right to redeem property sold at foreclosure.

YOUNGSTOWN, Ohio, Feb. 19 -- Finishing mills of iron and steel companies in this district will continue to operate at 20 per cent this week, although steel ingot output will drop to 15 per cent, according to production schedules announced today.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 19 -- The recent war game between the Black and Blue forces of the United States Fleet did not reveal any startling weaknesses in the navy, nor did it emphasize the fleet's strength. It did not prove that the Pacific Coast was either invulnerable to attack or defenseless from attack.

Ernie Schaaf, the heavyweight boxer who died in Polyclinic Hospital last Tuesday, four days after being knocked out by Primo Carnera, the giant Italian, at Madison Square Garden, was suffering from an inflammation of the brain before he entered the ring, according to a report made public yesterday by Dr. Charles Norris, Chief Medical Examiner, and Dr. Benjamin Morgan Vance, Assistant Medical Examiner.

The American Veterans Association an organization of World War veterans fighting against misuse of public funds, proposes to find out why the Nelson report on veterans' relief was pigeonholed by the House Invalid Pensions Committee, Donald A. Hobart, national vice commander of the association, announced last night.

TRONDHJEM, Norway, Feb. 19 -- Hans Engnestangen of Norway captured the world's all-around amateur speed skating championship today, but the major share of the day's laurels went to Eddie Schroeder of Chicago.

RINGGOLD, La., Feb. 19 (AP). -- Less than fourteen hours after J.P. Batchelor, 51, cashier of the Ring gold Bank, was beaten to death by a Negro near here, Nelson Nash, 24, who, officers said, confessed to the slaying, was lynched by a group of several score men who hanged him from a tree.

The era of super-speed ships in transatlantic travel has ended, and it will be succeeded by a leadership of cabin ships of a type developed in the last two years, according to Adrian Gips of Rotterdam, managing director of the Holland-America Line, who is making a periodic visit to the offices of the company in New York.

SIDNEY, Neb., Feb. 19 (AP) -- A middle-aged farm woman, Mrs. L. A. Pearson, has become a storm centre of the Western Nebraska mortgage moratorium movement. Instrumental in stopping a foreclosure sale last week in Scott's Bluff County, Mrs. Pearson announced today that she would organize farm holiday associations until every move to dispossess farmer-debtors was halted.

A large audience is promised for the performance of "Alien Corn" next Wednesday night at the Belasco Theatre, which has been taken over in behalf of the Turtle Bay Music School, 317 East Fifty-third Street. The school offers an extensive musical program in a crowded district of the city.
Sales of houses featured realty deals announced in New Jersey over the week-end.

Passports are nothing new in connection with ship travelers, but it is probable that most racegoers would say they were unusual at a racetrack. Yet 2,283 "passports" were issued last year by the Jockey Club for the protection of the public and the betterment of the sport in this State.

Without any hullabaloo the American Arbitration Association has come to be recognized as the chief authority on the matters with which it deals. It has set the standards for forms and procedure. It is headquarters for information on the subject.

Extension of the probation system that now exists in forty-three counties of the State to the fourteen counties that are without paid probation officers and to five counties where probation is confined to offenders under 16, was recommended yesterday in a report of the Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction.

Faith in the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt to formulate a definite national program for both civil and military aviation is expressed in the Aircraft Year Book for 1933, which will be off the press in a few days. These annual summaries of every phase of aeronautic development have been issued by the Aeronautical Chamber of Commerce of America for the last fifteen years.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Communism is increasing in China, says a report by T.A. Bisson, issued by the Foreign Policy Association, and the struggle between opposing economic groups for control of the Kuomintang, or Nationalist party, and the expanding influence of communism in the interior must be viewed as "the key to political events in China" during the last decade.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Leading industries in this territory are reporting a few gains and others are holding their own in a way that creates a belief that, despite the unsettled conditions resulting from the bank trouble in Michigan and unrest in sections of the Middle West, the upward movement in trade and industry is being continued.

Clambering up a fire escape in flight from a hold-up man who had beaten and wounded him, Isidore Wall, 45 years old, proprietor of a tearoom at 1,784 Pitkin Avenue in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, was shot dead last night by the thug.

Since none of the playwrights is scribbling the sort of thing he likes, Arthur Hopkins has taken matters into his own hands and written "Conquest," which he mounted at the Plymouth Saturday evening. Although it falls a good bit short of being an exhilarating play, it is considerably superior to anything Mr. Hopkins has produced for a long time, and it is worthy of his incorrigible idealism.

The protective committees recently organized for holders of bonds and common stock of the Paramount Publix Corporation have sent out letters requesting the deposite of the various securities before the hearing in the United States District Court for the southern district of New York on March 17, at which it will be determined whether the receivership for the company will be made permanent.

Warfare between nations should be carried on exclusively with the "weapons of art," the brush, the chisel, musical Instruments and the pen, speakers declared yesterday afternoon at the celebration of Austrian Day in the galleries devoted to Austrian painting at the International Art Exhibition on the twenty-seventh floor of the R.K.O. Building, Rockefeller Center.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The second Sunday racing of the Winter at the Fair Grounds for the benefit of the unemployed drew an excellent crowd today as favorites claimed the majority of purses.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In addition to the efforts being made by our government and other agencies toward stabilizing conditions, serious consideration can well be given to the extension of bank credit direct to individuals and firms of good character and ability.

The week starts off busily, with no less than twenty exhibitions opening today. Derain paintings of the last decade are to be seen at the Durand-Ruel Galleries, which are also showing early African sculpture -- heads and statues from the Gabun Pahouin tribe.

Schemes for church union adopted hastily would unquestionably lead to misunderstandings more fundamental and widespread than those already dividing the Christian church, the Rev. Dr. Granville Mercer Williams, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mary the Virgin, 139 West Forty-sixth Street, said in his sermon yesterday morning.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Since the adoption, of the Senate's prohibition repeal resolution, by the House tomorrow was regarded by Democratic and Republican leaders as a certainty, steps were taken today to bring forward legislation paving the way for the machinery for ratification by State conventions.

Although returning from the "lame duck" session of the House of Representatives without relief in the form of any definite legislation, general and subcontractors arrived in this city last week hoping for the early passage of some law to prevent bid peddling on Federal building projects, writes Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

ATLANTIC CITT, N.J., Feb. 19 -- Although still convalescent from an attack of influenza and broncho-pneumonia, Senator Emerson L. Richards of this city, President of the State Senate, will visit Trenton for an hour tomorrow afternoon to present a non-partisan bill for a State convention to ratify the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 19 -- The Rev. Felix G. Robinson, pastor of St. John's Lutheran Church-by-the-Sea, and Charles W. Ackerman, vice president of the church board of trustees, were booked at the police station here this morning on charges of assault, following a row in the edifice.

MEXICO CITY, Feb. 19 -- Former President Calles today made public his second call for a return to silver coinage as the main road to recovery from the world economic and financial depression. He said in part:

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Although extreme economy is the watchword of the Lehman administration, Henry Morgenthau Jr., Conservation Commissioner, in his annual report, to be filed with the Governor and the Legislature tomorrow, strongly urges that the State carry on uncurtailed its program of reforestation.

VIENNA, Feb. 19 -- Vice Chancellor Winkler today indicated Austria had decided to reject the Anglo-French demands for statements on oath concerning the Italian shipment of 180,000 rifles and 200 machine guns to Hirtenberg, Austria, supposedly for arming Hungary, in violation of peace treaties.
Police alarms were broadcast yesterday for two young girls and a 32-year-old boy who disappeared from their homes over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Severe criticism of that part of the report of the Shannon committee, appointed by the House to Investigate government competition with business, which would restrict the benefits which agricultural cooperatives obtain from the Federal Farm Board, was made tonight in an open letter to Congress signed by representatives of fourteen farm organizations.

The New York American strengthened their hold on third place in the International Group of the National Hockey League by defeating the Ottawa Senators at Madison Square Garden last night. Taking the lead in the first period and adding one goal in each of the succeeding sessions, the spangled skaters turned back the Canadian sextet by the score of 3 to 1.

A record registration of 7,768 students in the City College day cession was reported yesterday by Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college. Yesterday's total represented an increase of 590 over the previous high mark set last semester.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria, Feb. 19 (AP) -- The most convincing indications were seen today that this week would witness the beginning of the long-heralded Japanese and Manchukuoan assault on the Chinese Province of Jehol and the opening of the most extensive international conflict the Orient has seen since the Russo-Japanese War of 1905.

Opposition to the proposed new building code is expressed by the Bronx Board of Trade in a letter just sent to Joseph V. McKee, President of the Board of Aldermen, before which the suggested changes in the city's building rules are pending.

The spread of atheism, skepticism and callous indifference to the church is little to be wondered at when it is realized that religion is no longer primarily concerned with the practical affairs of mankind, Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the New York Methodist area, former president of the Federal Council of Churches, declared yesterday morning at the Collegiate Reformed Church of St. Nicholas, Fifth Avenue and Forty-eighth Street.

In so far as current news affected financial markets, Tuesday's unexpected proclamation of an "eight-day bank holiday" in Michigan was last week's outstanding point of interest. To those in touch with the peculiar circumstances, this was considered a curious incident, not at all in the nature of a precedent and possibly, if judged in the light of the subsequent course of events, representing an unnecessary step.

Diluting the moral standard of the Golden Rule was likened to going off the gold standard by the Rev. Dr. Frank Wade Smith at St. Andrew's Methodist Episcopal Church, 122 West Seventy-sixth Street, yesterday morning. Dr. Smith is editor of the Methodist Year Book.
NEW YORK. The Albanian Minister, Faik Konitza, is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Although the Board of Estimate has approved the expenditure of about $9,500,000 for new subway construction in 1933, no progress in letting the necessary contracts and beginning actual work can be made until funds are made available through a long-term bond issue, it was indicated yesterday.

Compulsory unemployment insurance was urged as a social necessity and a stimulus to employment stabilization by Nathan Straus Jr. in a radio debate over Station WOR yesterday with Merwin K. Hart, president of the New York State Economic Council, who opposed unemployment insurance and argued for voluntary unemployment reserves.

It will be good news not only to Brooklyn tout to other neighboring boroughs in the Greater City, that work is to be pushed on the great Marine Park project. Its architect, Mr. CHARLES DOWNING LAY, has an exceptional opportunity in the development of this site.

LONDON. Feb. 19. -- Japanese diplomatic documents have just been brought to light in London proving that at the time of the Russo-Japanese War Japan insisted on keeping Manchuria "an integral part of China."

Much of the disaster that overtakes young people may be traced to lack of sympathy and understanding on the part of their elders, the Rev. Henry F. Hammer declared yesterday in his sermon at high mass in St. Patrick's Cathedral.
The golf "duffer" -- the man who shoots anywhere from 80 to 170 -- is to have his inning.

The International Exhibition of Contemporary Art under the auspices of the College Art Association, now in progress at Rockefeller Center, will be held today for the benefit of the Dega Shop. During the afternoon there will be an entertainment by well-known singers and actresses, who have volunteered their services.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 -- An individual sub-par afternoon round by Mike Turnesa of Elmsford, N.Y., in which he broke the course record, featured the first round of the annual international four-ball golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

WEST ORANGE, N. J., Feb. 19 -- George W. Merck, chairman for this State of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment, today telegraphed to President Richards of the Senate, praising him for his opposition, to the proposal of State Senator Wolber, that by legislative enactment the New Jersey Legislature constitute its present members as delegates to a convention to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will have to do a lot of figuring to reduce White House expenses 25 per cent as her husband has promised to do in general governmental costs. There are three distinct accounts to be kept in doing it, all of which will have to be considered in any plan to make so marked a slash.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- There was no bob racing at the Mount Van Hoevenberg Olympic run this morning, the warm February sun melting the ice surface on the slide and causing the officials to postpone the last two heats of the North American four-man championships until Wednesday morning.

A committee representing various producers and shippers of cotton has been organized in an effort to enlist support of Southern Senators and Representatives for reconsideration of the war debts. The plan is logical. Fully ten million people are dependent for employment and profits on the growth of cotton, its merchandising and its manufacture.
PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Real discouragement and some alarm is being felt in France just now for the first time over the problem of French relations with Italy.

There is too much stress on laughter and a sense of humor in Anglo-Saxon countries today, A.M. Ludovici, who was a Captain in the British Royal Field Artillery during the World War, and bas since devoted most of his time to writing, says in "The Secret of Laughter," published today by the Viking Press.

SHANGHAI, Monday, Feb. 20 -- Count Galeazzo Ciano, Italian Consul General here, has been commissioned by the diplomatic corps at Peiping to learn from the Japanese Minister here Japan's intentions regarding the safety of foreigners in the Peiping-Tientsin district in the event of the outbreak of war in North China.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 19 -- The cotton market here had periods of activity last week, mainly due to liquidation and some selling by ring traders, but generally it was extremely quiet. The main trend of prices was toward lower levels and the extreme spread of fluctuations was about $1.50 a bale.

BOSTON, Feb. 19. -- Upon the basis of indications from Washington that the House of Representatives will back the Senate In repealing the Eighteenth Amendment, Massachusetts is making ready to get the pole in the race among the States to be the first to ratify the act of Congress.

TOKYO, Monday, Feb. 20 -- Japan has decided to secede from the League of Nations if the League Assembly adopts its proposed condemnation of Japan's activities in Manchuria, it was learned today from a high official source. Foreign Minister Yasyua Uchida has cabled this decision to Japan's delegation at Geneva, it was stated.

After a police alarm had bean flashed throughout the city yesterday afternoon for a 9-year-old girl who had accepted a stranger's Invitation to go to the movies, and several theatres had been searched, the girl returned home.

With the absorption of Ludington Air Lines toy Eastern Air Transport an interesting experiment in air transport has come to a close. Two years ago NICHOLAS and TOWNSEND LUDINGTON of Philadelphia decided to start an air service between New York and Washington.
SOME irate correspondents are indignantly pausing for replies. It is high time to get at it.

The "ruthless slaying of policemen" cannot be checked until public opinion has been aroused to the danger of "certain legislative attempts" to weaken the Sullivan law, to grant more sweeping powers to the Parole Board, and to raise the age of criminal liability from 16 to 18 years, Commissioner Edward P. Mulrooney declared yesterday afternoon at a memorial service for forty policemen who were killed last year in the performance of their duty.
Henry Morgenthau Jr., Conservation Commissioner of New York State, in submitting his annual report to Governor Lehman and the Legislature, stresses one point very strongly.

The substance of the League of Nations message to the whole world last Friday was not so wonderful as the method of its transmission and reception. This gave a new meaning to the old saying about " securely judging the globe." On two sending machines at Geneva, one for the East and one for the West, 15,000 words in the International-Morse code were sped on their way through the air by wireless telegraphy.

The function of the church was defined by the Rev. Dr. A. Edwin Kelgwin, pastor of West End Presbyterian Church, Amsterdam Avenue and 105th Street, in his sermon yesterday, as the fostering of amity among neighbors and nations and not the encouragement of "bitterness, defamation and prejudice."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP). -- Organized drys are preparing to launch a nation-wide drive against approval of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.
