The Mayfair Theatre, on the northeast corner of Seventh Avenue and Forty-seventh Street, will go dark on March 1. After that date the Radio-Keith-Orpheum Corporation, which has operated the theatre since its opening night on Nov. 1, 1930, will confine its Broadway film activities to the Palace Theatre on the south side of the street, the company, announced yesterday.

Four Bishops, thirty-two other clergyman and twenty-nine laymen who are officially connected with the Protestant Episcopal communion participated yesterday morning in the service instituting the Rev. Dr. George Paull Torrence Sargent as rector of St. Bartholomew's Church, Park Avenue and Fiftieth Street.

When the Lake Shore Limited pulled out of Grand Central last night at 7:45 o'clock it carried the vanguard of the Giants westward for the training camp grind, which is scheduled to start in Los Angeles Thursday afternoon.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- With representatives of business and civic organizations demanding further reductions in Governor Lehman's $216,000,000 Executive budget, the showdown on the Governor's proposals for new and higher taxes of $84,000,000 has been postponed until next month.

A tangible indication that the world-wide depression has spent its force is seen by James A. Farrell, chairman of the National Foreign Trade Council and former head of the United States Steel Corporation, in the diminishing rate of decline in this country's foreign trade during the latter half of 1932.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Erratic prices of hogs, with a wider range than usual, combined with increased supplies of unfinished hogs, made an unsatisfactory market here last week. Unfinished light butcher hogs, second grade, were put up in the last three days of the week at prices that affected the general market, but the offerings were finally cleaned up by small city butchers at around $2.50 to $3.60 a hundredweight.

NASHVILLE, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Directors of the Southern Newspaper Publishers Association voted today to hold the annual convention at the Signal Mountain Hotel in Chattanooga June 26-28. Chattanooga was chosen because it is more centrally situated than Asheville, where fifteen of the last eighteen meetings have been held.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- The Committee of Fourteen appointed by Mayor Leslie V. Bateman last Fall to study local tax problems announced today that it had instructed its subcommittees on plan and scope to go before the Board of Aldermen at the board's meeting Thursday and recommend a scientific analysis of the governmental and school functions of this city by two Columbia University professors.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- There was less than the usual political disorder on Sunday throughout Germany today. A generous snowfall turned attention to Winter sports for one reason, but a stronger one was that the government's ruthless suppression of all anti-Nazi-Nationalist manifestations was having its effect.

The St. Nicholas Hockey Club team gained undisputed possession of first place in the New York Amateur League by defeating the New York A.C., 8 to 3, at the New York Coliseum yesterday before a crowd of 3,000.

SALISBURY MILLS, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Coming down the shortened inrun at a terrific speed and then soaring through the air for a distance of 154 feet on eacn of his two leaps, Harald Sorensen won the Class A championship in the eleventh annual ski jumping tournament of the United States Eastern Amateur Ski Association today on the Norsemen Ski Club hill.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- For more than a year, Lew Edwards, known as the "toughest guy" who ever served a term at Eastern State Penitentiary, has been leading a Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde existence, posing before the world as a desperado, jail-breaker and shrewd confidence man who "went straight" and to the underworld as a crafty genius who directed the activities of a bandit gang of ex-convicts, police said today.

Word was received here yesterday that the racing schooner Nina, which sailed from here Feb. 11 on a voyage to England, had met with an accident and put into Bermuda. The report stated that the yacht's keel had been damaged and the supposition is that she may have struck a reef.

Miss Janice Lifson, 14-year-old Women's Swimming Association star yesterday won the Metropolitan A.A.U. ten-foot springboard diving championship in the W.S. A. pool Victor in the outdoor title competition last Summer, Miss Lifson showed the way to five other competitors in adding the indoor crown to her other laurels.
LONDON, Feb. 19 -- Warm tributes were paid to THE NEW YORK TIMES in London tonight for having printed the full text of the League report on Manchuria, alone among the world's newspapers.
Samuel S. Koenig, veteran Republican leader of New York County, presented in a letter yesterday what amounted to a tentative Republican campaign platform for the next Mayoralty election.

A 5-year-old girl was rescued yesterday after she had fallen through the thin ice on the Morris Canal in Jersey City and had become lodged in the mud six feet beneath the surface of the water and about fifteen feet from where the ice bad broken.

A new $10,000 prize contest for a novel is announced today by the Atlantic Monthly Press and Little, Brown Co. of Boston. Of this amount $5,000 will be awarded as an outright prize and $5,000 in advance on royalties. The prize will be given for "the most interesting and distinctive" novel submitted before March 1, 1934.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Colonel Raymond Robins, prohibition advocate, who threw the nation into excitement when he disappeared more than five months ago while en route to visit President Hoover, finally completed his trip to the White House today.

Scoring twelve points in his team's dual meet with Yale at New Haven on Wednesday, Eugene Jennings, Columbia swimming star, took the lead in the Individual scoring in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association race with 37 points.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Edward S. Harkness of New York City has made gifts which will allow students working their way through the colleges at Yale University to comply with the regulations which require each member of a college to pay for at least ten meals a week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Louisiana's political turmoil echoed in the capital today, with counsel for the Senate committee investigating the State's 1932 primary issuing a statement assailing Senator Long and members disclaiming responsibility for it.

The fiftieth annual report of the New York Charity Organization Society, published yesterday, showed an expenditure of $1,806,195, the largest of any year in its history. Nearly 84 per cent of the relief expended was directly attributable to unemployment, as contrasted to 10.8 per cent in 1929.
BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The official weekly index of wholesale prices in Germany, as of Feb. 8, is placed at 90.5. This compares with 90.7 on Feb. 1, with 90.8 on Jan. 25 and with 90.9 a month ago.

Steel - making operations held barely steady last week at 19 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. Scheduled curtailment at Buffalo and Youngstown this week, the publication points out, promises to outweigh prospective expansion in Eastern Pennsylvania.

The fact that the American people are now looking to the future with hope and courage, despite the "cowardice" of their political leaders, shows conclusively that they have derived spiritual advantages from the depression, Dr. Horace J. Bridges of the Chicago Ethical Culture Society declared yesterday morning to the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 -- Outside official circles in Germany, in which the subject is taboo for journalistic purposes, certain apprehensions are beginning to be expressed regarding the continued good health of the venerable and respected President of the Reich.

A plea to cultivate friendly International relations as an interpretation of part of Washington's doctrines was made yesterday by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, in an address at the forty-third annual service of the Sons of the Revolution in the State of New York, commemorating the 201st anniversary of Washington's birth, in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 19 -- A denial that payment of the European war debts to this country would impede business recovery was contained in a letter sent today to President-elect Roosevelt by J.W. Van Dyke, chairman of the board of the Atlantic Refining Company, which has substantial investments in four overseas continents.
AIKEN, S.C., Feb. 19 (AP). -- George Jeter, Negro, died today from the effects of a beating administered by a group of white men last Tuesday and four men, his alleged assailants, were arrested.

BERLIN, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Two members of the republican Reichsbanner were killed and seven seriously injured and two Nazis were slightly hurt in a clash after a Reichsbanner meeting at Bad Doberan in Mecklenburg-Schwerin today.

LONDON, Feb. 17 -- During this week the London security markets have almost without exception been unsettled and depressed. The boom In Transvaal gold shares has subsided, owing to doubts concerning the future price of gold, aroused by the strong upward tendency of sterling, which it is feared may at any time break through official control.

The Merchants Association announced yesterday that it had adopted an eight-point plan for revision of the New York City charter and that it would make a determined fight for the adoption of its proposals.

Three persons, one of them a woman about 30 years old, were slain without warning at 2:45 o'clock this morning while they were standing about the bar of a resort known as "Porky Murray's Speakeasy" at 267 West Fifty-second Street, two doors west of the Guild Theatre, by gunmen who fired a fusillade of shots.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 19 -- Yale and Harvard have united in arranging a joint course to train men for the practice of law in fields involving business problems.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- In addition to twenty-three important Federal posts in New York State subject to appointment by President-elect Roosevelt, there are eighty-two New York postmasters who may be named immediately after he takes office.

PARIS, Feb. 17 -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France showed further loss of 313,000,000 francs gold, while foreign credit decreased only 29,000,000. Continuance of the outflow of gold from the Bank of France is expected here, but gold now leaving France does not go to America.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Quickaway won his sixth straight race today and set a new track record of 1:10 2-5 in winning an invitation handicap at six furlongs which matched him with Sundot, Lemon Hills and Tea Trader, the sprinter imported from New Zealand.

CLARKSVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Counsel for Colonel Luke Lea, Nashville publisher, and Luke Lea Jr., who are resisting removal to North Carolina, where they are under conviction of bank law violations, announced tonight that "the Leas are now in Clarksville available for the service of any legal process."

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 19 -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55.4, which compares with 55.3 a week ago, 55.3 two weeks ago, 55.5 three weeks ago and 56.4 four weeks ago. The average of 57.4 in the first week of January was the highest of the year to date; the average of one and two weeks ago was the lowest.
An international indoor tennis match between British and American players will be held on the courts of the Heights Casino in Brooklyn the afternoon of March 7.

Teams representing the Marshall Manhattan, Empire City and City College Chess Clubs were victorious yesterday in the third round of the annual championship series of die Metropolitan Chess League. Making a clean sweep against the Queens Chess Club, the Manhattan Chess Club retained first place by a margin of half a point in the game total.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Declaring that men and women past 40 present a "real industrial problem," the special committee of the State Commission on Old Age Security said in a report today that the State and private industry must develop more extensive and effective provisions for their economic security.
LIMA, Peru, Feb. 19 -- A decree forbidding Peruvians between the ages of 21 and 25 years to leave the country was published today. It was dated Feb. 17.

ALBANY, Feb. 19 -- Strong opposition to enactment of employment insurance at this session of the Legislature on the ground that it would result in dismissal of thousands of part-time workers and add greatly to the burden of unemployment relief is voiced in a report of the joint Legislative Committee on Unemployment to be filed with the Legislature tomorrow.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Steady improvement was displayed today by Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago and Mrs. Joe H. Gill, seriously wounded victims of Joseph Zangara, while secrecy veiled the plea which the gunman, who sought to kill President-elect Roosevelt, will make to the courts tomorrow.

PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Great Britain and France have turned back the diplomatic clock 156 years in sending an interpellation to Austria regarding a shipment of arms from Italy, supposedly to Hungary via Austria.

Clarence C. Pell of New York and Stanley G. Mortimer of Tuxedo, the two dominating figures in American amateur racquets since 1915, reached the semi-final round of the national championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The Berlin market was affected early in the week by the news of the American bank crisis at Detroit. The reaction was only moderate, however, and Wall Street's subsequent relative steadiness reassured the German market.

BERLIN, Feb. 17 -- The Berlin market was affected early in the week by the news of the American bank crisis at Detroit. The reaction was only moderate, however, and Wall Street's subsequent relative steadiness reassured the German market.

CAIRO, Feb. 19 -- An important discovery of medieval Moslem art in Egypt, consisting of several beautiful frescoes of the Fatimid period from the tenth to the eleventh century, has been made by Dr. G. Wiet, director of the Egyption Government's Arab Art Museum, near the famous Abul Saoud Mosque at Cairo, where many decorations in strong relief of the Tulunid period were unearthed several months ago.

HOUSTON, Tex., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Scientists here were considering today the possibility that a means of measuring the nucleus of an atom -- the smallest known particle of matter -- had been found by Tom Wilkerson Bonner, student-instructor at Rice Institute.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 -- Corn farmers in Illinois are more disposed than they were to part with their grain, despite low prices of 15 to 18 cents a bushel at country loading stations. They sold, within the last few weeks, more than 1,500,000 bushels of cash corn, mostly for shipment within five days, and a considerable part of it already has started marketward.

CEDARHURST, L.I., Feb. 19 -- Mrs. G. Bryans Wolfe, captain of the British women's squash racquets team which has been competing in the East, suffered a double fracture of her left ankle during the course of a semi-final match in the mixed doubles tournament at the Rockaway Hunting Club today.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 19. -- The award of forty-three scholarships and fellowships totaling $10,200 to students in Harvard University was announced tonight. The scholarship of the Harvard Club in Maine was awarded to Henry F. H. Sims of Portland, a freshman in Harvard College.

In preparation for another conference on war deists today with Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, President-elect Roosevelt conferred yesterday with his economic advisers at his home, 49 East Sixtyfifth Street.

PARIS, Feb. 19 -- Pleading that France's financial position was far from being as bad as that of other countries Premier Edouard Daladier appealed to the Senate today for coolness and discipline. He condemned the threat of state employes to strike for one hour tomorrow as a pay cut protest and condemned the shopkeepers' strike of last Thursday.
A warning that respiratory diseases and measles become more prevalent in the early Spring was given by Dr. Shirley Wynne, Commissioner of Health, in a radio address yesterday from station WINS.

NEW LONDON, Wis., Feb. 19 (AP) -- Much milk was dumped on Wisconsin highways again today as striking dairymen, formed tight picket lines in their campaign fop higher prices. The market blockade was concentrated around Waupaca County and little milk reached New London.

The recital given by Walter Gieseking, pianist, last night in Carnegie Hall, was a full and admirable display of those qualities which give Mr. Gieseking a place entirely his own among contemporary virtuosos. He continues to accomplish astonishing things, as an artist, and as a musician who attracts the public by the extraordinary sensitiveness and intimacy of his performances.

The J.C. Penney Company has reported for 1932 a consolidated net income of $5,002,672 after expenses, Federal income tax, depreciation, amortization and other charges. This was equal, after preferred dividend requirements, to $1.57 a share on 2,468,984 common shares.

A renewed effort to change the present jury system so as to provide for an extra juror to take the place of one disabled during a trial will be made in the State Legislature this week as the result of the mistrial in the Schoening kidnapping case.

The Negro is "overchurched," the teaching of religion in Negro churches is at a "low ebb." and the congregations are less responsive to emotional appeals, according to a report published today by the Institute of Social and Religious Research under the title, "The Negro's Church."

DENVER, Feb. 19 -- Claude K. Boettcher, father of Charles Boettcher 2d, kidnapped Denver broker, said tonight that he had received communications which he was satisfied were from the captors of his son. He added that they contained notes undoubtedly penned by the 31-year-old victim, who was kidnapped from the driveway of his home a week ago tonight as he and his wife returned from a party.

The first of a series of functions to further the Jewish National Fund's projected George Washington Memorial Forest in Palestine was held last night at the Hotel Astor. More than 500 persons attended, and each contributed at least $7.50, enough to pay for the planting of five trees.

A week ago Joe McCluskey of Fordham seemed well on his way to an unbeaten season. So did little Emmett Toppino. But at the New York A.C. games in the Garden on Saturday the two-year reigns of these two kings came to a sudden and totally unexpected termination.

Led by the sharpshooting Sam Foxworthy, who scored four goals, the Hershey hockey team of Hershey, Pa., overwhelmed the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club in the feature game of the weekly amateur doubleheader at Madison Square Garden yesterday, 10 to 2.

VIENNA, Feb. 17 -- Owing to decline in its note circulation to 800,000,000 schillings as against 992,000,000 a year ago and 914,000,000 at the beginning of the present year, the position of the Austrian National Bank has been further relieved.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 19 -- Factory employment remained at about the same level In January as in December, while seasonal influences resulted in a slight curtailment in many forms of outdoor work, including construction and agriculture, according to an analysis of reports received by the United States Employment Service which was made public today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 19 -- In honor of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph S. House, Mr. and Mrs. Cecil M. Singer gave a dinner tonight at the Everglades Club, where Lammot du Pont, Mr. and Mrs. James Bentley, Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence M. Lloyd and Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Paterno also were dinner hosts.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Renewing its sailing dinghy racing, Which was suspended before Christimas, the Larchmont Yacht Club held a regatta today that broke all records for the number of contests. In a program starting at 11 A.M. and winding up before the sun went down fourteen races were sailed.
President-elect Roosevelt sent a telegram of gratitude yesterday to Mrs. W.F. Cross of Miami, Fla., who on Wednesday night deflected Joseph's Zangara's five shots from Mr. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Wage increases, where they can be effected without imposing financial strain, will help clear the way to general business recovery, Philip K. Wrigley said today in announcing an increase in pay for factory workers here of the William Wrigley Jr. Company, founded by his late father.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 19 -- Renewing its sailing dinghy racing, Which was suspended before Christimas, the Larchmont Yacht Club held a regatta today that broke all records for the number of contests. In a program starting at 11 A.M. and winding up before the sun went down fourteen races were sailed.
President-elect Roosevelt sent a telegram of gratitude yesterday to Mrs. W.F. Cross of Miami, Fla., who on Wednesday night deflected Joseph's Zangara's five shots from Mr. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, Feb. 19 (AP) -- Wage increases, where they can be effected without imposing financial strain, will help clear the way to general business recovery, Philip K. Wrigley said today in announcing an increase in pay for factory workers here of the William Wrigley Jr. Company, founded by his late father.

A Joint statement signed by Frank O. Lowden, former Governor of Illinois, and Henry A. Wallace, Iowa publisher, urging reconsideration of intergovernmental debts was made public here yesterday by Alfred P. Sloan Jr., president of the General Motors Corporation and chairman of the Committee for the Consideration of Intergovernmental Debts.

Three young boys were drowned yesterday afternoon in the Bronx River, about four blocks north of the entrance to the Bronx Zoological Park, when the thin ice on which they were walking gave way beneath them. A fourth boy also plunged through the ice, but was rescued by an unidentified youth who dragged him ashore by the hair.

James Monroe assumed undisputed possession of first place in the upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the P.S.A.L. basketball tournament while Stuyvesant and Textile remained tied for first place in the lower Manhattan-Richmond division as a result of yesterday's games.

VIENNA, Feb. 20. -- Austria again is the centre of an international crisis which from insignificant beginnings is spreading rapidly out-ward, involving the whole European system. The Hirtenberg arms scandal is developing in a way to recall the upheavals following Austria's announcement in 1931 of her intention to form a customs union with Germany.
The powerful basketball team of Temple University submerged the Manhattan quintet under a hall of baskets to achieve a 45-31 triumph at the Jasper Gymnasium last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- By a vote of 289 to 121, being two-thirds with fifteen votes to spare, the House today adopted the Senate resolution proposing repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment and thus passed on to the States the question of ending national prohibition.

Looking out from a safe window on the turmoil, the spouting and the brickbatting in the Republican party of this town, one sees the self-announced virtue and excellence, the eminence, the purple mostly on one side. What is the lofty purpose of the noisy combatants ?

LONDON, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Miss Joyce Wethered, generally regarded as the world's greatest woman golfer, today went to work as an adviser of golf clothes and equipment and incidentally settled her status as an amateur.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- States in which wets plan immediate campaigns to ratify the amendment repealing the Eighteenth Amendment, looking to initiation of conventions before Legislatures adjourn, include:

Neither Sidney Howard nor Katharine Cornell Is one to take things easily. On the face of it "Alien Corn," in which they joined forces at the Belasco last evening, is only an excellent telling of the old story of the artist trapped in a Philistine's neighborhood.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 20 (AP). -- The Peruvian Legation issued a statement today saying that a crowd at Lima had stoned the Colombian Legation and that Fabio Lozano Jr., the Colombian Minister, had taken refuge at the Chilean Embassy.

E. Ramey Donovan, captain of the Fordham University tennis team, yesterday won the New York indoor intercollegiate tennis championship in the 102d Engineers Armory. He defeated Charles Marks of Long Island University, seeded No. 1 in the tournament.

George Washington's Birthday will be observed tomorrow in New York, as elsewhere in the United States, by patriotic, military, civic, fraternal, political and other groups at appropriate gatherings, including meetings, dinners, luncheons and religious services.

MANCHESTER, N.H., Feb. 20 (AP). -- Frank French, internationally known artist, author, illustrator, teacher of art and dean of American, wood engravers, died late last night at his home in Reed's Ferry, N.H., after a brief illness. He was 82 years old.

CAIRO, Feb. 20. -- The Egyptians outdid themselves today in welcoming with true Oriental hospitality King Victor Emmanuel of Italy, who arrived for a fortnight's visit in Cairo and the valley of the Nile.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The quick passage of the prohibition repeal resolution by the House today, following action by the Senate last week, took even the most ardent advocates of repeal by surprise. With this action the campaign for repeal is shifted to the States, where the influence of the wets will be directed toward Legislatures in an effort to have ratifying conventions appointed or elected as soon as possible.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (Canadian Press). -- Not only did Bill Cook of the Rangers break a tie for first place in the National Hockey League point-scoring race during the last week but his brother Bun took advantage of prolific Ranger scoring to assume second place.

Four signed contracts dropped out of Business Manager Ed Barrow's mail at the Yankee offices yesterday, bringing the number of Ruppert riflemen who are satisfied with the wage tendered them to considerably more than a two-thirds majority.

BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 20. -- A number of Peruvians were killed and one airplane was destroyed in an attempt by Peruvians to capture a Colombian island in the upper Putumayo River Saturday evening, according to a government bulletin published in El Espectador tonight.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 20. -- In celebration of their twentieth wedding anniversary, Dr. and Mrs. Edmund LeRoy Dow entertained seventy guests tonight with a dinner at Casa Pequeria. During din- ner the Roman Chorus gave a program of songs and dances, and later tables were placed for contract and backgammon.

American advertising policies should attain leadership in Europe in the next ten years, it was predicted yesterday by Dr. Edward Ewing Pratt, former director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce.

With the purchase of u3,665,079 ($17,836,107 at par) of bar gold, announced yesterday in London, the gold holdings of the Bank of England were lifted above the level at which they stood on Dec. 14, last, the day before Great Britan paid $95,550,000 of gold to the United States against the British war debt.

A large dinner dance was given last night in the Mirror Room of the Embassy Club for the benefit of the Yorkville Community Association. In the mirrored setting, decorated with festoons and clusters of electrically lighted opalescent balloons more than 200 members of society were in evidence at tables embellished with Spring flowers.

OTTAWA, Feb. 20. -- Canada is eagerly desirous of effecting a reciprocal trade treaty with the United States, but believes the government of President-elect Roosevelt should make the first approach to the Dominion, Premier Bennett told the House of Commons this afternoon.

HAVANA, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Ray Ruddy, which has the habit of winning at long odds, outran a large field of platers over a mile and one-sixteenth at Oriental Park today and paid 15 to 1. He returned $48.60 for $2 in the mutuels.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The United States intends to await action by the Assembly of the League of Nations on the Manchurian report of its Committee of Nineteen before making any move in the Far Eastern situation.

PARIS, Feb. 20. -- Without any disturbance but almost without exception in all departments, French Government employes ceased work today for periods varying from one hour to ten minutes as a protest against the reductions in their salaries and allowances proposed by the Senate Finance Commission.

All the security markets felt the impact yesterday of active liquidation. Stocks lost an average of 1 to 2 points and bonds, 1 to more than 4 points. In the latter market, the acute unsettlement in United States Government and German loans was the chief contributory factor in the general downward revision of values.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Senator Carter Glass has finally and definitely decided to decline the proffer of President-elect Roosevelt to be Secretary of the Treasury, a post which he occupied during the Wilson administration.

Gregor Piatigorsky, Russian 'cellist, gave what was announced as his only New York recital last night in Carnegie Hall. His program included Corelli's "Grave," Beethoven's variations on a theme by Mozart, Bach's suite in B major for cello alone; Weber's sonata in C major, Debussy's three-movement sonata, consisting of "Prologue," "Serenade" and "Finale," and a group of short pieces by Scriabin, Moussorgsky, Granados and De Falla.
Housing properties composed the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.
BOSTON, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Governor Joseph B. Ely today took quick action to place before the electorate of Massachusetts the amendment repealing prohibition.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The sanctity of international agreements was stressed by Secretary Stimson today in his last speech as chairman of the governing board of the Pan-American Union.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 20 (AP). -- F. Scott McBride, general superintendent of the Anti-Saloon League, said today that aggressive action "in every part of every State" would be taken by the league "against any liquor plan that the wets may put forward as a substitute for the Eighteenth Amendment."

Jesse Isidor Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., returned yesterday with Mrs. Straus from a three-month holiday motoring tour through England, France and Spain. The inclement weather caused them to cancel part of their projected tour through the last-named country.

Before a crowd of 800 which included Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey and Georges Carpentier, former heavyweight boxer, LeRoy Brown of the Salem-Crescent A.C. scored two knockouts in the 140-pound class of the semi-monthly amateur boxing show at the New York A.C. last night.

The Salle d'Armes Vince fencing team of Miss Dorothy Locke, Miss Molly Burnside and Miss Muriel Guggolz won two women's interclub foils matches at the Fencers Club last night, turning back the Fencers Club by 5 to 4 and the German-American A.C., 6 to 1.

Charles Krekey, 50 years old, of 1,559 Bushwick Avenue, Brooklyn, was killed instantly yesterday when he was catapulted from a horsedrawn truck on the Williamsburg Bridge and thrown over the rail to the pavement at Kent Avenue and South Sixth Street, more than 100 feet below.

The conferences between President-elect Roosevelt and Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador, begun nearly a month ago at Mr. Roosevelt's Winter home at Warm Springs, Ga., were resumed yesterday at his city home here, after Sir Ronald's return from London, where he consulted the heads of the British Government.

SCARBOROUGH, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- Miss Cicely Fenwick, a member of the British women's squash racquets team, forged ahead of the field in the New York State championship tournament, which got under way today on the Sleepy Hollow Country Club courts.

Though department chiefs had often advocated erection of an archive building and a site had once been selected, the real beginning of agitation for a proper building in which to house the older files of the Government was in 1908.

Supreme Court Justice John F. Carew heard argument and reserved decision yesterday on the application by Supreme Court Justice William Harman Black for an order restraining the Board of Estimate from deducting $2,500 from the $10,000 share of his salary of $25,000 payable by the city.

How the movies influence dress styles, etiquette, haircuts and house furnishings, and the "commercial mechanism" that has been developed to tell manufacturers and retailers what popular stars will wear, are dealt with in the newest monograph prepared by President Hoover's Research Committee on Social Trends.

An appraisal yesterday of the estate of Robert W. De Forest, lawyer, philanthropist and president of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, who died on May 16, 1931, showed that he left a gross estate of $6,970,719, of which $4,296,000 is taxable.

DENVER, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Mystery surrounding negotiations for the return of Charles Boettcher 2d deepened tonight as the family severed relations with outside agencies in the hunt for the abductors and the father, Claude K. Boettcher, denied that he had obtained $65,000 in cash for the ransom of his son.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The cornerstone of the great National Archives Building to be erected at Pennsylvania Avenue and Seventh Street, to house the valuable records of the government, was laid this afternoon by President Hoover at ceremonies attended by a small group of officials.

GUAYAQUIL, Ecuador, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Fabio Lozano Jr., Colombian Minister to Peru, arrived by airplane from Lima today with a story of how a mob of Peruvians broke into his Legation and ransacked the wine cellar, drinking what they could find, and causing considerable damage elsewhere in the building.

It has long been evident that no system of unemployment insurance which might be established at this time could serve to mitigate the suffering resulting from the present depression. Industry is incapable of building up now the necessary reserves, and there must be time for them to accumulate.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- Dr. Rudolph Nadolny, head of the German, delegation at the disarmament conference, conferred today with Foreign Minister von Neurath and Defense Minister von Blomberg. Later he was received by Chancellor Hitler.

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- The Prussian police were ordered today by Hermann Wilhelm Goering, federal commissioner, to use firearms ruthlessly against Communist acts of terrorism and to assist election campaign demonstrations of the government parties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP). -- The Supreme Court consented today to review the jurisdiction of the Federal courts in Chicago over bankruptcy proceedings involving the American Bond and Mortgage Company, a Maine corporation which was declared bankrupt with indebtedness in excess of $8,000,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The proposed Twenty-first Amendment to the Constitution as adopted by the Senate last Thursday and the House today reads:

TOKYO, Feb. 20 (AP). -- In addition to withdrawing her representative from the League itself, Japan will recall Vice Admiral Osami Nagano and Lieut. Gen. Yoshiji Tatekawa, her delegates to the disarmament conference.

The Merchants Association appealed yesterday to Mayor O'Brien and the members of the Board of Estimate and the Board of Aldermen to preserve the regulatory code prepared by the Board of Taxicab Control, even if the board itself is abolished.

After study of the difficult constitutional questions as to whether Congress or the State Legislatures should constitute the conventions in each State to which the proposed repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is to be submitted, the Voluntary Committee of Lawyers declared yesterday that each convention should be authorized both by the Legislature of its State and by Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Declaring that mortgagors who will not meet their obligations constitute a more alarming problem than those who cannot, Morton Bodfish, member of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, appealed tonight for consideration for those "thrifty citizens," whose savings were invested in home mortgage credits.

After conferring for more than two hours yesterday with Wall Street bankers and Controller Charles W. Berry, Mayor John P. O'Brien indicated that the city expected to issue short-term securities soon to finance its capital outlay program of $29,000,000 and to meet other obligations.

President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt was the guest of the Manhattan Club, the oldest national Democratic club in the "United States, last night at a dinner in his honor at the clubhouse, Madison Avenue and Twenty-sixth Street.
Same of the "high spots" in the history of national prohibition, in their chronological order, were:

BERLIN, Feb. 20. -- The Boerse opened buoyant and more active today. An upward trend was maintained until the closing hour, when some stock reacted moderately. Coals were the most favored issues, Rhein Braunkohle leading the group with an advance of 10 points at one time and closing 8 points above Saturday's price.

Three armed men entered the twelfth-floor offices of the Commercial Investment Trust Corporation at 1,860 Broadway yesterday, herded twelve employes, five of them women, into a small supply room in the rear and escaped with $1,000.

Walter S. Mack Jr., president of the fifteenth Assembly District Republican Club, announced last night that within a week or so a soup kitchen for the needy families in the Fifteenth Assembly District would be opened by the club.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The situation of the bar, so far as I am familiar with it, is an unhappy one. Many lawyers cannot make collections for past years and have practically no business for the present year. More fortunate lawyers are carrying an overhead which is ruinous.
Joseph P. Day, real estate auctioneer, was elected yesterday a trustee of the Consolidated Gas Company of New York at the annual meeting of stockholders at 4 Irving Place.

State of Montana. Bankers were advised here yesterday that legality of the issue of $4,500.000 of funding bonds, which the State of Montana has scheduled for award on Thursday, has been upheld by the State Supreme Court. The bonds were authorized recently by the State Legislature.

A hopeful outlook for a peaceful settlement of the Manchurian situation, with Japan ultimately adhering to her membership in the League of Nations, was seen yesterday by Sir Frederick Whyte, former adviser to the Chinese Government, at a luncheon of the American Woman's Association in the clubhouse at 353 West Fiftyseventh Street.

One Boxing Promoter. If JAMES J. CORBETT was a romantic figure with a firm hold on Popular affection and esteem, it may be that part of the credit belongs to an old and white-whiskered English gentleman now on a ship somewhere in the China seas and bound for his first visit to these shores.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The Navy Department appropriation bill, which, makes available for the fiscal year 1934 $4,591,389 more than was recommended by the Bureau of the Budget, was reported out of committee today and will come up for final passage in the House the latter part of the week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Efforts by a Senatorial bloc to switch the form of Federal unemployment relief from loans to direct grants to States failed decisively today when the Senate voted by 44 to 28 to perpetuate the present system.
BALTIMORE. Feb. 20. -- George W. Page, State Bank Commissioner, was named today receiver for the Title Guarantee and Trust Company by Judge Eugene O'Dunne, in Circuit Court 2.

The recital of Florence Page Kimball, soprano, which took place last night in Steinway Hall, deviated refreshingly from the usual vocalist's program. Songs of Torelli, Bononcini, Piaetti and Cimara formed the first group; Wolf's "Lebe Wohl" and "Auf dem grunen Balcon"; Mahler's "Ich atmet einen Linden duft" and Strauss's gay and vital "Schlechtes Wetter" constituted the second, and the last two, in French and English, were distinguished by Debussy, Faure, Loeffler, Quilter, Dougherty and Rachmaninoff.

A selling movement which enveloped all classifications of bonds on the Stock Exchange yesterday sent a long list of issues, domestic and foreign, into new low ground for the year. Leading foreign loans were hard hit. Many issues of the German group lost from 1 to 6 points for the day, the government 7s losing 4 points and the 5 1/2s, 2 3/4 points.

Jimmy Browning, husky Boston wrestler, gained recognition by the New York State Athletic Commission as world's heavyweight champion by pinning Ed (Strangler) Lewis, Kentucky veteran who was defending the crown, in Madison Square Garden last night.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been planning my budget to enable me to pay my State and Federal income taxes. I have not lost my position. My income has dropped about one-fourth and I suspect my salary will again be reduced.

Discussing motion pictures yesterday at the annual meeting of the alumni of Union Theological Seminary, Dr. George Reid Andrews again charged that the Motion Picture Producers and Distributors of America was formed, with Will Hays as its president, not to clean up the screen but to keep other people from doing so.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20. -- Two extrahole matches featured the second round of the annual international four-ball golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

"American Dream," a cycle of three one-act plays by George O'Neil, all of which have a connecting theme, wil open this evening at the Guild Theatre, being the third production this season of the Theatre Guild.

TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 21 (AP). -- Saying that Japan had decided to secede from the League of Nations, Admiral Minea Osumi, Japanese Naval Minister, today ordered the Japanese Navy to be prepared for any emergency.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- The bill authorizing the New York City Controller to sell bonds in $10 denominations in anticipation of taxes was passed in the Assembly tonight and now goes to Governor Lehman, who sent an emergency message to expedite the measure and is now expected to sign it.

Heavy selling of United States Government bonds, much of it from commercial banking sources, sent the entire list of eleven issues yesterday to new lows for the year on the Stock Exchange in the sharpest break in many weeks. With it went about the last hope that the Treasury would be able to do any longterm financing in connection with its requirements on March 15.

Squadron A and the Ridgewood Riding Club galloped into the semifinal round in the low-goal division of the seventh annual New York Athletic Club invitation indoor polo tournament at the 105th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx last night.

For the first time in twenty years the United States Circuit Court of Appeals yesterday, in an opinion written by Judge Martin T. Manton, reversed an order making permanent a consent receivership -- that of R. Hoe Co., Inc., manufacturers of printing presses.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 20 (AP). -- Dr. Daniel A. Poling, speaking as president of the World Christian Endeavor Union, and Philip R. Mather, National Commander of The Crusaders, national anti-prohibition organization, tonight commented that the prohibition fight henceforth would be waged in the fortyeight States instead of in Congress.

GENEVA, Feb. 20. -- On the eve of the special League of Nations Assembly the Japanese delegation late tonight was still decoding Tokyo's instructions regarding the report the Assembly will consider as the expression of the League's conclusions and recommendations on the Manchurian conflict.

What promises to be the best armory track meet of the season will be staged by the New York Curb Exchange tonight at the 106th Infantry Armory in Brooklyn with Glenn Cunningham, Leo Sexton, George Spitz, Frank Wykoff and Emmett Toppino heading a group of ten Olympians in the invitation events.

The manuscript of a new book by Herbert O. Yardley, author of "The American Black Chamber" and head of the secret American Cryptographic Bureau during the World War, was seized here yesterday and impounded by the Department of Justice under Section 32, Title 50, of the United States Code, which prohibits agents of the government from appropriating se-, cret documents.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- Colleagues of Senator Charles J. Hewitt, Republican, of Cayuga, who for a large part of his twenty-five years' service in the upper house has been chairman of its Finance Committee, became interested today in a report that a State pension had been awarded to him in excess of his present salary and that he might not wait until the end of his term to retire.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Senate has passed a bill designed to rescue 88,000 vagrant boys and young men from the highways, the byways and the "flop houses" of the land and place them, for care and instruction, with the army.

The American Metal Company, Ltd., reports for 1932, a consolidated net loss of $2,256,630 after all charges and reserves, but including discount earned of $1,034,040 on the purchase of some of its four-year 5 1/2 per cent notes, which it retired.

The Guaranty Trust Company, as trustee under two bond issues of the United States Bond and Mortgage Corporation, applied in the Supreme Court yesterday for the appointment of a receiver of more than 1,000 mortgages given by the mortgage company as security for the bonds, and for an order compelling the defendant to turn over to the receivers all books and records relating to the trust property.

Although actual steps toward the preparation of the 1933 Fordham football eleven will not begin for a fortnight, when Spring practice is inaugurated, Jim Crowley, new head football coach, yesterday made his first definite move in his official capacity.

DETROIT, Feb. 20. -- Officials of the two great groups of national banks in Michigan, who have been striving night and day for a week to devise a safe way for the re -sumption of normal banking when the holiday proclaimed by Governor Comstock expires next Thursday, left for Washington tonight to lay their plans before President Hoover, Secretary Mills and other officials who have been watching the Michigan situation.

The conservation committees of the Senate and Assembly will begin hearings today at Albany on the several measures which have been introduced in the Legislature in relation to the game laws of this State. The legislation consists of a number of changes in the present code governing hunting and fishing, as well as a bill to segregate license fee funds so that such fees will be spent exclusively for fish and game conservation work.

Heavy trading and sharply rising prices in silver to new highs for the year were the outstanding development in the local commodity markets yesterday. Other markets were quiet and irregular with lower price tendencies. Prices in the cash markets moved unevenly.

LONG BEACH, L.I., Feb. 20. -- Charges of assault resulting from a fist fight yesterday in the study of St. John's Lutheran Church after a discussion of church finances between the Rev. Felix G. Robinson, 34-year-old pastor, and Charles W. Ackerman, 68, vice president of the board of trustees, will not be pressed in City Court tomorrow by either Ackerman or the pastor, it became known today.

Early Spring Lull Continues. Orders reaching this market yesterday for both women's ready-to-wear and accessories were reported as reflecting the lull which featured the trades here last week. Some reorders are coming through, but the general activity has fallen off owing to the completion by many stores of their initial purchases for the season.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Maintenance of sound money and reduced government expenditures were urged before the Senate Finance Committee today by two of the nation's outstanding bankers as vital steps along the road to better times.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Investigation of the stock operations of the National City Bank and the National City Company will be started tomorrow by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee and eleven officials of the bank and the company have been subpoenaed to take the stand in a series of hearings.

The Rev. Arthur B. Kinsolving 2d, chaplain of the United States Military Academy at West Point, has been chosen by the Right Rev. Ernest M. Stires, Bishop of Long Island, as dean of the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City, L.I., it was learned here yesterday.

National prohibition, by far the most bitterly controverted issue to stir the American people since the days of slavery, has been the law of the land for thirteen years and a half, One of the most audacious and radical social experiments in history, the attempt to bring under legislative control the customs and habits of a large section of the population has been watched with world-wide interest.

The American Chain Company, Inc., a nounced yesterday a plan whereby holders, may exchange their $3,843,500 of ten-year 6 per cent sinking fund gold debentures due on April 1 for a new issue of $4,804,375 of five-year first mortgage and collateral trust company 6 per cent bonds.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria, Tuesday, Feb. 21. -- The Rengo (Japanese) News Agency correspondent here reported today that severe fighting between the Japanese and Chinese troops started at 10 o'clock Monday night at Chaoyangssu in the Province of Jehol.

Because of the apparent unwillingness of the executives of organizations of maritime employes to merge with the Neptune Association in a single organization of licensed officers, an attempt will be made to bring about an organization with the consent of the men regardless of the attitude of the officials of the existing unions, it was said yesterday.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 20. -- Jack Howard's Tryster filly, Miss Tulsa, which was a decisive winner in her previous start, made it two in a row in the Top Flight Purse at Hialeah Park today when she galloped in front from start to finish to win by a length and a half.
THE Giants are on their way to their Spring training camp and John McGraw is not with them. Nor will John meet them at Los Angeles and spur them, as of yore, through sprightly drills.

Supreme Court Justice Aaron J. Levy signed an order yesterday authorizing a recheck of ballots cast by more than 2,200,000 voters in New York City last election day. At the same time, letters were mailed from the Board of Elections notifying approximately 500 candidates of the time and places at which the votes would be recounted.

It has been rumored in Washington for several days that Mr. HOOVER was about to send a message to Congress reminding it of its various sins and shortcomings. But the one which he forwarded to the Capitol yesterday is not at all of that fault-finding or scolding nature.

Ethel Bartlett and Rae Robertson, who make up one of the finest two-piano ensembles appearing here, gave a concert at the Town Hall last night. The program began with a suite arranged by Cyril Scott from an invention, a sarabande and a gigue by Bach, which Mr. Scott has prefaced with a brief introduction based on the notes of the theme of the invention.

GENEVA, Feb. 20. -- The air committee of the disarmament conference agreed this afternoon that some international control of civil aviation was necessary for the abolition of war aviation and that mere regulations of civil aviation were inadequate as a safeguard.

Detectives worked all day yesterday without establishing a motive for the murder of a woman and two men in Michael (Porky) Murray's speakeasy in the musty old brownstone house at 267 West Fifty-second Street. The bodies were found on the barroom floor at 2:30 A.M. and were identified several hours later.

Mrs. John P. O'Brien, wife of the Mayor, took part in a charity sale to aid the New York City Cancer Committee and the social service of Memorial Hospital yesterday in Hearn's department store, 3 1/2 per cent of the gross receipts being donated to the cause.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- An analysis of the population of the States and their internal revenue payment statistics, as reflected in the House vote today on submitting prohibition repeal, shows a preponderant national sentiment in that direction even more overwhelming than was registered by a survey of the Senate vote last week.

MEDIA, Pa., Feb. 20. -- George Eyre Darlington, who had continued the practice of law after celebrating his 100th birthday on Aug. 20, died of an intestinal ailment today at his home here, after a brief illness.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 20. -- Governor A. Harry Moore sent to the Senate tonight the nomination of Supreme Court Justice Thomas J. Brogan, Democrat, of Jersey City, for appointment as Chief Justice to succeed Chief Justice William S. Gummere, a Republican, of Newark, who died several months ago.

MONTREAL, Feb. 20 (Canadian Press) -- The largest illicit still ever found in Montreal was seized by customs officers today. One man was caught, while three others escaped through a secret passage in the cellar. Officers found 15,000 gallons of mash ready for distillation and 2,500 gallons of alcohol put up in gallon tins ready for shipment.

While the House of Representatives In Washington was taking action yesterday with a view to altering the prohibition situation, the business of enforcement was going on here as usual. In the Brooklyn Federal Building twenty-five persons arrested Saturday evening in raids on Long Island were arraigned before United States Commissioner Edward E. Fay.

Transactions on the Stock Exchange yesterday totaled 860,000 shares, which compared with 653,000 shares on the final five-hour day of last week. After a fractionally lower opening, stocks drifted slowly lower. Prices at noon were heavy, with losses of 1 to 3 1/2 points.

MIAMI, Feb. 20. -- Pleading guilty to four charges of attempted murder, Joseph Zangara, who failed in his attempt to assassinate President-elect Roosevelt but wounded Mayor Cermak of Chicago and four others, was sentenced to eighty years in prison today.

The Phillips Petroleum Company reports for 1932 a consolidated net income of $775,766 after taxes, interest, inventory adjustment, depreciation, intangible drilling costs and depletion, equal to 18 cents a share on the 4,153.104 shares of no-par capital stock outstanding.

Nothing succeeds like repeal. After the Senate had got down to business, eliminated most of the equivocal and evasive clauses thrust into the resolution, and voted by more than a two-thirds majority for the straightforward words, "the Eighteenth Amendment is hereby repealed," it was certain that the House would go the same way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation authorized $143,393,847 in loans during January, and advanced $128,395,294 in cash, the corporation reported in a summary today covering its operations from Feb. 2, 1932, through January, 1933.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- Senator John J. Dunnigan introduced a bill tonight providing for a State convention late in April to pass upon the Congress resolution for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. If plans made by the legislative leadera this evening are carried out, the Dunnigan bill will become law before the week is over.

SUTTON COURTENAY, England, Feb. 20. -- The furniture and other belongings of the late Earl of Oxford and Asquith went under the auctioneer's hammer today at the country house here where he lived for more than twenty years and where he found rest and quiet during the years when he was Prime Minister.
Once again Clarence C. Pell of New York stands in the final round of the national amateur racquets championship, eighteen years after he won the first of his eleven triumphs in singles.
NEW YORK. The Earl and Countess of Moray are expected on the Majestic and will be at the Pierre. The Countess is the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. J. Archibald Murray.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- Movements of vessels follow, all dates are Feb. 18, unless otherwise specified:

GENEVA, Feb. 20. -- Satisfaction with THE NEW YORK TIMES and praise for its publication of the entire text of the Manchurian report on which the League of Nations Assembly will begin deliberation tomorrow were expressed today in those League quarters that were aware of the achievement.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The estimated cost of building construction for which, permits were issued in 351 cities during January amounted to $42,826,707, an increase of 39.6 per cent over December, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- Offering a strange contrast to conditions that prevailed in a bygone era, the Giants and Cubs, in the active days of John McGraw and Frank Chance baseball's most bitter rivals, marched off arm in arm today to their respective training camps in California.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- The Public Service Company of Northern Illinois, the third of the big Chicago utility companies to issue its annual report, earned its common stock dividends by a comfortable margin, according to the statement released today.

PARIS, Feb. 20 (AP) -- Ambassador Walter E. Edge, one of the twenty Senators who voted against the Eighteenth Amendment and the Volstead law, said in commenting tonight on the vote of the House of Representatives on the repeal resolution:

WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- President Hoover staged an eleventh-hour surprise for Congress by sending to the Senate and House late this afternoon a special message outlining proposals aimed chiefly at alleviation of economic distress, which he said seemed "possible for enactment during the present session."
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20. -- The text of President Hoover's special message to Congress today outlining measures he thinks are vital for adoption at the present session, was as follows:

VIENNA, Feb. 20. -- A letter full of fiery criticism and winding up with a challenge to fight a duel has been forwarded by Lieut. Gen. Konstantin Sakharoff, commander of the Kolchak White Russian forces that fought bolshevism from 1917 to 1920, to Major Gen. William S. Graves, retired, who was commander of the United States Siberian Expedition.

Advocates of unemployment insurance yesterday expressed surprise and regret at the "shocking somersault" of the Marcy committee in deciding not to recommend unemployment insurance legislation at this session of the Legislature after having given assurances that the committee would recommend a bill.

CHICAGO, Feb. 20. -- The wheat market on the Board of Trade was dull again today, but whenever liberal selling orders appeared, which the trade attributed to continued liquidation by the Federal Farm Board, buying orders were sufficient to absorb the offerings without the price being materially affected.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 20 -- A steady, orderly progressive building program designed to replace outworn and outmoded ships and to add new vessels as necessary to give the United States naval parity was urged today by Admiral Richard H. Leigh, commander-in-chief of the United States fleet.

It is strange that within a week of the attempted assassination of President-elect ROOSEVELT the New York Legislature should be seriously debating a bill which would weaken the Sullivan law and make it easier for criminals hereabouts to obtain firearms.

Jan Welzl, who created something of a stir early last Summer with some reversed facts in his "Thirty Years in the Golden North," is author of "The Quest for Polar Treasures," published today by the Macmillan Company. In this book he boasts of his skill in preparing bear-meat as food, saying that he "often ate a huge pot of bear-stew at one sitting" and that sometimes he "ate three bears in a month."

BUDAPEST, Hungary, Feb. 20 -- The trial of Frau Rose Littke, charged with the murder of Captain George de Ruttkay, began here today. Captain de Ruttkay, an officer in the bodyguard of the Regent, Admiral Horthy, was found dead with a revolver bullet through his heart in Frau Littke's room.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- New details of Japan's recent purchases of British liners were revealed tonight, and whether they are to be employed as troop ships or are to be scrapped for their metal and used in making shells their value will be large.
Special Washington's Birthday services, in which religious and patriotic organizations will join, will be held in churches throughout the city tomorrow.
Five Manhattan properties and two parcels in the Bronx went to plaintiffs in foreclosure at auction sales yesterday.
ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- A detailed check-up on the economic and social status of every employe of New York State with a view to "purging the payroll" has been begun by Controller Morris S. Tremaine.

ALBANY, Feb. 20. -- Submission tonight of the report of the special committee on unemployment, advising against enactment of unemployment insurance at the present session, brought a declaration from Assemblyman Steingut, the Democratic leader, that his party intended to support such legislation despite the report.
A dense fog, accompanied by heavy rain, came down shortly after 9 o'clock yesterday morning and held up the incoming liners.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 20. -- For the first time since 1911 the Westchester Board of Supervisors voted down today the recommendations of its committee on equalization and substituted a new equalization table for the one presented by the committee after seven weeks of study.

LONDON, Feb. 20. -- The British Government is faced with a new war debts problem. It is concerned now not with preventing the value of sterling from falling, but with stopping too rapid a rise because of the influx of "refugee money" from people nervous about their own currencies.

PARIS, Feb. 20 (AP). -- War-debt negotiations between France and the United States will be resumed after Franklin D. Roosevelt, has been inaugurated President March 4, Foreign Minister Joseph Paul-Boncour said today.

Monday, Feb. 20, 1933. A sharp run-up in Federal funds from 1/2 at the start to 1 1/4 per cent at the close, stood out as the most interesting development in the day's money market. This is the highest quotation for Federal checks in a long time, and compares with recent bids of 1/4@1/2.

A proposal that all industry be converted into the common stock type of financial set-up so that fixed interest charges and dividends would be paid only when and if earned was made last evening to a forum meeting of a group of members of the American Institute of Banking in the Hotel Lexington by Professor Walter Rautenstrauch of Columbia University.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 20 -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated Feb. 17:

Lying on the blue carpet of his two-room flat, where he had lived for fifteen years, Albert Schmidt, 80-year-old recluse, was found dead yesterday by the janitress of a tenement house at 531 East Fifth Street. A gas log burned brightly in the living-room fireplace; a window in the small kitchen was open a few inches.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 20. -- Whatever may have been the reasons for the delays in launching the Japanese drive against Jehol, the long period of anxiety and uncertainty has merely served to inflame the anger and hatred of the Chinese people, who have been gropingly attempting to find means of assisting the government's belated policy of resistance.

The 1933 exhibition of work by Negro artists, sponsored by the Harmon Foundation, opened yesterday at the Art Centre. It is the fifth exhibition of the sort put on here under these auspices. The first was held in 1928. There was no New York show last year, since the Harmon Foundation wished to stress its traveling exhibitions.

While advocates of repeal hailed as a victory the vote of the House submitting a repeal amendment to the States, and prohibition defenders accepted the result with caustic comment on the Congressional ac tion, both sides called the vote yesterday only a partial advance toward repeal, and girded themselves to carry the battle into the fortyeight States.

The development of an industrial democracy in the United States as the reply of capitalism to the menace of communism was urged yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Edmund A. Walsh, vice president of Georgetown University, at a luncheon of the New York and New Jersey section, women's department, of the National Civic Federation at the Hotel St. Regis.

Frederick J. Fuller, president of the New York Title and Mortgage Company, told the Management Division of the Real Estate Board of New York, at a dinner at the Hotel Astor last evening, that insurance company presidents with whom he had been in conference recently unanimously opposed a flat cut in interest rates.

WASHINCTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Currency inflationists were stirred to new activity today after Senator Fess of Ohio, veteran Republican whip, had urged in the Senate that President-elect Roosevelt immediately, as a reassurance to business, disavow any intention of "tampering with sound money."

VALLEY STREAM, L.I., Feb. 21 -- Convinced that many high school graduates who had been unable to find jobs were "wasting their time on post-graduate studies," W. Louis Buck, president of the Central High School District here, disclosed today that his board was considering a proposal requiring post-graduate students to post a bond, to be forfeited if they did not complete their studies.

A considerable number of women students spent their vacation last Summer digging gold in the numerous abandoned placer mines in California and other States in the Far West, but their efforts netted them an average yield of only 30 cents a day, the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers was told yesterday at their annual Winter convention by Charles W. Wright, chief of the Mining Division, United States Bureau of Mines.

Taxicab control in this city has come to be a veritable shuttlecock of local legislation. During the Walker administration a special committee appointed to study the subject recommended that taxicabs be declared a public utility under the jurisdiction of the Board of Transportation.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Let that mere man T.E. Duffy calm his disturbed mind. Despite his plaint, the real man of yesteryear is still just where he was in the estimation of mere woman.

The Gold Dust Corporation reported yesterday a net profit of 52.513,549 for 1932 after depreciation, Federal taxes and other charges, equivalent after dividend requirements on the S6 convertible preferred stock to S1.22 a share on 1,759,502 no-par shares of common stock, excluding 62,600 shares held in the company's treasury.

Larger bank clearings were shown again at several important cities for the five days ended yesterday. The total for leading centres in the United States, as reported to R.G. Dun Co., was $3,974,041,000, or 0.4 per cent larger than in the corresponding five days last year.

Jack Donahue, musical comedy star, who died Oct. 1, 1930, left an estate appraised yesterday at $533,441 gross and $441,346 net. The chief assets consisted of the real estate at 239-245 East Fifty-sixth Street, valued at $250,000, and two trust funds, executed in 1928, amounting to $240,493.

Arturo Toscaninl, the orchestra conductor, will arrive today on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen, accompanied by Mrs. Toscanini and their daughter, Wanda. Others on the ship are: Ira Nelson Morris, former United States Minister to 'Sweden; Paul Fuller, Consul General for Monaco in New York; Harold Lloyd, moving-picture actor; Erich Pommer, German moving-picture director, with Mrs. Pommer; Harry C. Black, Clive Currie, English actor; Mrs. Charles Swift, Louis Keidel and C.E.C. Freyvogel.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 21 -- It is learned unofficially in well-informed circles close to the Argentine Foreign Office that the ABC republics, Argentine, Brazil and Chile, have agreed to proceed with the Chaco peace negotiations without Peru, which has not replied to a joint note of the Argentine and Chilean Foreign Ministers after their Mendoza conference.

Silver and coffee futures were weak in yesterday's trading on local commodity exchanges. Otherwise the prices for staples moved in a narrow range, with sugar higher. Trading was generally active. Cash prices were irregular, with grains higher.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is discouraging to find, although fifteen years have elapsed since the World War, that the world is everywhere faced with problems of utmost difficulty and that in every nation are states of mind inimical to real peace.

The revision of municipal legislation affecting retail sales and advertising displays will be sought by the Fifth Avenue Association this year, according to announcements yesterday at the annual meeting of the association at the Hotel Roosevelt.

The Essex Troop of Newark played somewhat faster polo than it did several weeks ago when it fell before the Riding and Driving Club by a four-goal margin, and last night defeated the Brooklyn trio, 13 to 11, at the clubhouse of the losers.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 21 -- All over China the confusion and panic were increased today because the military had begun general commandeering of foodstuffs, coal and vehicles, and the impressment of laborers in preparation for the defense of Jehol.

Pity the sorrows of the poor old Republican party. Flat on its back and suffering from general debility, a new set of doctors descends upon it every week and orders it to take up its bed and walk. "Reorganization" is the healing word. The crowding "reorganizers" step on their own feet and are in a fair way to suffocate the patient.

TIME SCHEDULE. Afternoon Games. 2:00 P.M. -- Cathedral College vs. Brooklyn College. 3.00 P.M. -- Long Island University vs. St. Francis College. 4:00 P.M. -- Columbia University vs. Williams College. 5:00 P.M. -- Manhattan College vs. Villanova College.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- In the opinion of Senator Walsh of Montana, who has agreed to accept the post of Attorney General in the new administration, all connection which Congress has with prohibition repeal ended with submission yesterday of the new amendment.

President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt moved swiftly yesterday to take control of the foreign affairs of the United States twelve days in advance of his inauguration, to bring about the early convening of the World Economic Conference, in the hope that it might help toward a restoration of prosperity to all nations and to make an early start in negotiations for the revision of war debts owed to this country by foreign governments.

Keyes Winter, Republican leader of the Fifteenth Assembly district, took a stand yesterday in favor of drastic and sweeping reforms in the Republican organization in New York County and, by implication, for the unseating of Samuel S. Koenig as county chairman.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Brig. Gen. Samuel T. Ansell, retired, attorney for the Senate committee investigating the Louisiana Broussard-Overton contest, was called by Senator Long this afternoon in the Senate, a "scoundrel, rascal, liar, thief, crook and a counterpart of Benedict Arnold."

The annual Dixie dinner dance of the New York Southern Society took place last night In the grand ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. Several hundred members of the society, who include natives of Southern States now living in this city, were present.

NORWALK, Ohio, Feb. 21 (AP) -- How science is winning a battle to put coveted inches of stature on stunted boys and girls was described tonight by Dr. Theodore T. Zuck of the Brush Foundation of Cleveland.

Charges that former students in the discontinued teachers' training schools were forced to travel long distances to continue their studies in the three city colleges were denied yesterday by the heads of the city institutions, who appeared before the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate at Mayor O'Brien's direction.
Numerous business leases in Manhattan were reported yesterday, with a continuance of activity in the downtown and midtown areas

A suit to declare illegal an agreement between the cloth sponging and finishing companies of New York, organized as the Textile Finishers Association, Inc., comprising twenty-two members, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the New York Clothing Manufacturers Exchange, Inc., consisting of about twenty members who do the bulk of the manufacturing of men's, youths' and boys' clothing in the city.

All the domestic markets, for securities and commodities, will be closed today in observance of Washington's Birthday. The banks will also be closed, so that business generally will be at a standstill. Operations will be resumed as usual tomorrow morning.

A net loss of $12,720,600 gold was shown yesterday in the daily report of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York which revealed earmarking's of $13.997.800, exports of 51,475,500 and imports of $2,752,700. The large earmarking of gold reported brought the total amount set aside for foreign account since the first of the year to $136,585,900.
The International League will open its season on April 12 and close on Sept. 10, with each club again playing 168 games, according to the official schedule released today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Refusal to report out the Somers silver bill was voted, 7 to 5, by' the House Coinage, Weights and Measures Committee today, much to the disappointment of those who hoped for remonetization legislation at this session.
The Vanguard Press reported yesterday that 354,742 copies of books by Donald Henderson Clarke had been sold since 1929. Mr. Clarke's latest novel, "Female," will be published tomorrow.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Although Governor Lehman in a special message to the Legislature today sounded a note of caution against sacrificing soundness of procedure to mere speed in setting up machinery for ratification of the Congressional prohibition repeal resolution, the Legislature's leaders, including those of the Governor's party, appeared tonight to be virtually united in their determination to rush the Dunnigan-Sargent bill to passage before the end of the week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The House today voted to pass on to President-elect Roosevelt the responsibility for reorganizing the Federal Government in the interest of public economy, and approved a grant of broad and sweeping power to accomplish this end.
ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- The bank "resumption" bill backed by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks, was signed today by Governor Lehman.

Herbert J. Pennock, dean of the Yankee pitching staff, who rose to new fame as a relief hurler in the last two games of the world's series in Chicago last year, delivered his signed contract to Business Manager Ed Barrow in the club's Forty-second Street offices yesterday afternoon.

The American Federation of Labor will not alter its opposition to recognition of the Soviet Government and will fight any efforts to prevail upon the incoming Roosevelt administration to recognize the Moscow regime, it was announced yesterday by Matthew Woll, vice president of the federation.

Public utility bonds of all classifications on the Stock Exchange showed the only considerable resistance to the general decline in prices yesterday. United States Government bonds lost further ground, as did leading domestic corporation issues and foreign loans. The Federal issues were marked down 1-32 to 1 1-32 points to new lows for the year except the Liberty 3 1/2s, which touched par on Monday but held above that level throughout the day yesterday.

BOSTON, Feb. 21 -- With more than 1,100 dogs on the benches, a larger entry than a year ago, the Eastern Dog Club opened its twenty-first annual exhibition this morning in Mechanics Building. The judging program included three sessions today.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 21 -- The earliest Christian church paintings yet discovered will be exhibited publicly tomorrow for the first time when Yale graduates come here to attend the twentieth annual Alumni University Day.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., 19-year-old holder of the New York State championship, was forced to sink his last putt to win his quarter-final round match in the Everelades Club invitation golf tournament today.
TOKYO, Wednesday, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The important railroad town of Pehpiao in Jehol Province, China, was taken by Japanese troops at 2 P.M. Tuesday, dispatches reaching here today said.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Closely contested matches marked the semifinal round of the annual international four-ball golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today. Tommy Armour of Detroit, former United States and British open champion, and Olin Dutra of Los Angeles, P.G.A. champion, who have been installed as the favorites in the competition, eliminated Al Espinosa of Akron, Ohio, and Bill Mehlhorn of Chicago, 3 up and 2 to play.

Nearly 400 monkeys were brought here yesterday on the freighter City of Dalhart, of the American Pioneer Line, which docked from Indian ports. The monkeys were a part of a large shipment of animals, including snakes and birds, brought by Jan Mohamed Ismail, animal dealer of Karachi.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Little John Suvisakus started out today as just the 7-year-old "kid" brother of Anthony, 11, who had to be taken to Franklin Park because he tagged along anyway, but tonight he had behind him the man-like feat of having worsted a bear in single-handed combat and saved his older brother's life.

Nebulea and Nations Sir ARTHUR EDDINGTON'S new book, "The Expanding Universe," is peculiarly appropriate to the moment. This new universe, it may be recalled, was born out of the mathematical calculations of the Abbe LEMAITRE and the observations of our own California astronomers.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Feeling both for and against Japan was expressed in the House of Commons today, and a debate on the Far Eastern trouble was averted only by the refusal of the Speaker to entertain a motion to adjourn the House, on which the subject would have been discussed.

A comparison, of the votes on prohibition repeal in the Senate last Thursday and the House Monday with the results of The Literary Digest's nation-wide poll last Winter and Spring indicates that the residents of the States to which ratification of repeal must now be submitted are even wetter in sentiment than their representatives in Congress.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 21 -- The need for a five-day week and a six-hour day for a better life was stressed today by Dr. John H. Finley of THE NEW YORK TIMES at the Founders' Day exercises at Hollins College.

Accused of being one of a gang that swindled $60,000 out of John S. Wood of Exeter, N.H., retired capitalist and brother-in-law of Senator George H. Moses of New Hampshire, George S. Robb, a broker at 50 Broadway, was arrested last night as a fugitive from justice.

The railroads of the United States will "come back with a certainty" if Federal aid through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation is continued, Paul Shoup, vice chairman of the Southern Pacific Company, declared last night in an address at the twenty-sixth annual dinner of the Traffic Club of New York at the Hotel Commodore.

Count Boris Dobrynski, 45 years old, who said that his Russian title dates to 1012, and Arcady Szparkowski, 49, the jobless "industrialist," who are on trial in Judge Corrigan's part of General Sessions on a charge of stealing $25,000 from Valentine P. Greer, a speakeasy owner, took the witness stand in their own defense yesterday.
