Twenty-three talesmen said in Federal Court in Brooklyn yesterday that they could not serve as impartial jurors in a prohibition case as a result of the vote for repeal in Congress. This sentiment delayed trial of a case before Judge Grover Moscowitz, who found it necessary to excuse the group.

A letter of apology has been sent to President Hoover and a cataloguer at the National Art Galleries, Inc., has been discharged for a slur on President Hoover which appears in a catalogue description of a letter by George Washington to be sold at the galleries next Friday night.

CAMDEN, S. C., Feb. 21 -- Fully 2,000 horse lovers from the South and North assembled today to witness the annual hunter trials run off under the auspices of the Camden Hunt. There was an unusually large number of entries from the Rumson Club, New Jersey, and for the first time Monmouth County and the Fairfield and Westchester Hound Hunts teams were present.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Defeat in committee of the bill which would amend the State's libel law by prohibiting newspapers from disclosing the source of their information when sued for damages was predicted tonight following a brief hearing before the Assembly codes committee.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 21 -- Beginning next September, the head coaches of Harvard varsity sports teams will have year-round jobs. This move, one of the most revolutionary to date in the economy campaign of the Harvard Athletic Association, was announced today by Director of Athletics William J. Bingham.

Rupert Hughes, novelist and historian, who startled many persons a few years ago by declaring that George Washington had some of the vices of many of the gentlemen of his time mixed with uncommon virtues, told in an interview at the Ritz Towers yesterday of Washington's fight to right a national depression.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Senator Tydings, Maryland Democrat, was among the first here tonight to comment on Senator Hull's appointment, which he said "gratified him very much."

Welker Cochran, world's champion, increased his lead over Jay Bozeman, runner-up for the title, by winning both the third and fourth blocks of their special fourteen-block, 700-point three-cushion billiard match at the Strand Academy yesterday.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 21 -- Settlement of the American policy on foreign debts was termed the most important step in promoting economic recovery by Frank H. Simonds today when he testified before the Senate Finance Committee during its study into economic conditions.

A young man describing himself as Frederick Manthorp, 26 years old, a British actor living in a furnished room at 265 West Eighty-first Street, was held in $10.000 bail by Magistrate Walsh in Harlem court yesterday for a hearing tomorrow on a charge of attempting to extort under threat of death $2,000 from Mrs. John Sloane of 48 East Ninety-second Street, president of the Maternity Centre Association.

Dr. Wallace W. Atwood, president of Clark University, Worcester, Mass., who was an American delegate to the Pan American Institute of History and Geology, meeting in Rio de Janeiro, returned yesterday on the Grace liner Santa Barbara. After the convention of the institute, which ended early in January, Dr. Atwood went to Peru and Bolivia, where he studied the highland country for Incan and pre-Incan archaeological information.

Mrs. Adelaide Barnard says it is true and her daughter, Miss Hazel Doorty, confirms the account. Ornithologists have a word for it and pet-shop owners say it is not uncommon. Anyway, here is the story told yesterday by Mrs. Barnard and her daughter in their suite in the Hotel Claridgre.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Efforts by Senator Barkley to obtain consent of the Senate to an agreement to limit debate for the remainder of the session met with such a cool reception today as to make the plan appear hopeless.

A game habitat survey of New York State now is in progress under the auspices of the New York State Conservation Department. The active work is being conducted by the State Land Economic Survey of the State College of Agriculture at Cornell University.
Small housing properties continued to furnish the bulk of the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- A committee to represent New York State officially at the Roosevelt inaugural ceremonies was announced today by Admiral Cary T. Grayson. Large delegations are expected from various parts of the State.
MIAMI, Fla., Wednesday, Feb. 22 -- The crisis in the condition of Mayor Cermak of Chicago arrived late last night.

TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- Dr. Yukio Ozaki, a noted pacifist and former Minister of Justice, on landing at Kobe this morning from London narrowly escaped assault, policemen and friends grabbing two youths brandishing canes who broke through a police cordon shouting "Wait, Ozaki," as the statesmen was about to enter an automobile.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- The Boerse was weak today and business light throughout. It was the weakness on the international stock exchanges that subdued the spirit of brokers, and gallant attempts by some banks to inspire confidence remained unheeded. Not even the bond market offered resistance to the wave of pessimism that stopped activity and forced stocks and bonds down little by little.

DENVER, Feb. 21. -- A distracted father's statement that the kidnappers of his son, Charles Boettcher 2d, had refused to assure him against trickery in the payment of $60,000 was followed quickly today by announcement of a grand jury investigation of the abduction.
ALBANY, Feb. 21. -- Governor Lehman took action in two ways tonight to spur and broaden the unemployment relief program in the State for the coming months.
George Fissler of the New York A.C. retained the metropolitan 500-yard free-style championship in one of the feature events of the swimming meet staged at the New York A.C. pool last night.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The prohibition issue took temporary leave of the national Capitol today when official copies of the resolution repealing the Eighteenth Amendment were dispatched with all possible speed to Governors of the forty-eight States, within twenty-four hours after it had received the approval of Congress.

The trade practices of the Interborough Coat and Apron Supply Association, Inc., which is said to control 95 per cent of the coat and apron supply business in Greater New York, were condemned by Supreme Court Justice Charles C. Lockwood in Brooklyn yesterday in a decision vacating a temporary injunction obtained by the association.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- The Westchester Title and Trust Company of White Plains closed its banking department this afternoon and its directors announced that checks would be mailed tomorrow to about 8,000 depositors in payment of their deposits in full, plus interest until the closing of business today.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Something has gone wrong with the prophecies frequently heard early last December to the effect that, if Great Britain was obliged to pay her last war debt instalment to the United States due that month, the Pilgrim Society of London might as well abandon its dinners for the promotion of Anglo-American goodwill.

John Haynes Holmes, chairman of the City Affairs Committee, testified at the trial before the medical grievance committee of Dr. William H. Walker, brother of the former Mayor, and four other physicians on charges of fraud and deceit in the practice of medicine, that in his judgment Assistant Attorney General Sol tinman, conducting the prosecution, was "trying to defend the defendants" and that Mr. Ullman "has a very tender feeling for the defendants."

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- Reacting against the rebellious agitation recently developing among taxpayers, the French Senate today incorporated in the budget severe penalties against persons fostering the movement.
Tommy's favorite tree in Mrs. Katherine Jacobs's rear yard at 542 West 148th Street was ten feet shorter yesterday than it was last Wednesday, but Tommy wasn't around to notice it.

PARIS, Feb. 21 -- President-elect Roosevelt's reception of Ambassador Claudel today has broken, unofficially at least, a kind of diplomatic exclusion against France which has existed ever since Dec. 13, when the Chamber of Deputies refused permission to the Harriot government to pay the December debt instalment until and unless negotiations looking toward a reduction and rearrangement of the debt settlement were begun.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 21 -- After questioning sixteen persons at his office here today, Prosecutor Howard Eastwood of Burlington County announced that he had "uncovered new developments" which he believed would prove once for all whether Horace Roberts Jr. killed Ruth Mowdray Wilson and then ended his own life or whether both were slain by an unidentified third person.

The Philadelphia Orchestra, Issay Dobrowen conducting, gave Its seventh New York concert of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. The neatly balanced program began with a suite by Corelli, arranged for string orchestra by Ettore Pinelli; continued with Brahms'a Third Symphony and Strauss'6 "Don Juan" and ended with Rimsky-Korsakoff's Suite from his opera, "The Tale of the Tsar Saltan."

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- Enactment of the bill backed by the New York City administration to advance the date of tax payments in New York City to allow the city to pay $144,000,000 due the bankers on April 26, was urged today by Arthur J.W. Hilly, Corporation Counsel, before the Senate Committee on Cities.
BERLIN, Feb. 21. -- The intimidation and violence directed by the National Socialists against the Socialists and Communists has now for the first time been extended to the Centrists.

Gus Sonnenberg of Boston and Sammy Stein of Newark wrestled to a draw in the feature match at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 6,500 spectators saw the grapplers engage in an interesting tussle, but neither was able to pin the shoulders of his rival to the mat.

Manhattan Prep and Cathedral Boys High triumphed in Manhattan division C.H.S.A.A. basketball games yesterday, while Bishop Loughlin Memorial High and St. Francis Prep scored victories in the Brooklyn division.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- The petition of the Gulf Pacific Line and the Luckenbach Gulf Steamship Company, filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission, to investigate the lawfulness of proposed reduced rail rates on canned goods from Chicago territory to Western points, was endorsed in a resolution by the Shipping Board today.

DETROIT, Feb. 21 -- The writing down of millions of dollars in frozen assets carried on the books of Michigan banks began tonight as bankers started preparations to reopen for limited business Thursday under the terms of a new proclamation issued at Lansing this afternoon by Governor Comstock.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In 1901 the International Catalogue of the World's Scientific Literature began to be published by cooperation of some thirty-three bureaus representing the principal countries of the world. Each bureau furnished, at its own expense, to the central bureau in London classified references to the entire scientific literature of its region.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt recommended last night that the women of every community take a direct personal interest in the children of their neighborhood, seeing they are properly fed, clothed, housed and educated. Speaking at a reception in her honor in the Plaza, given by the Southern Women's National Democratic Organization, Mrs. Roosevelt said a "little personal interest" would be of more value than the work of any organization, however worthy.

Seventeen Manhattan and Bronx properties, most of them tenements and small houses, were taken over by plaintiffs at foreclosure auctions yesterday. The plaintiffs, as mortgagees, had instituted the foreclosure proceedings as the result of defaults.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Persons close to Senator Claude A. Swanson of Virginia said tonight he had been offered and had definitely accepted the post of Secretary of the Navy in the Roosevelt Cabinet.

The present market prices of the securities and real property held by Robert W. de Forest when he died on May 16, 1931, as listed in the official appraisal of his estate made public here yesterday, show that the net estate has shrunk during the last two years from $4,416,206 to about $164,000.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- When informed tonight of the announcement of his selection by President-elect Roosevelt to be Secretary of State, Senator Cordell Hull said:
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

Thomas Jefferson High School gained undisputed possession of first place in the Brooklyn division and Richmond Hill strengthened its lead in the Queens division as the result of two of the eight games played yesterday in the P.S.A.L. senior high school championship basketball tournament.

The annual report of the Ohio Bell Telephone Company shows net income of 56,150,464 for 1932, equal to $4.73 a share earned on 1,300,000 shares of stock, compared with $6,697.784, or $5.15 a. share, earned in 1931. The was a deficit of $24,536 after dividends, against one of $202,216 in 1931.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 21 -- Joseph E. Widener's Periodical was placed first in the featured Apalachicola Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today, as the result of the disqualification of Crap Shooter, even-money favorite, which finished first by a length over Periodical. Crap Shooter swerved in the last sixteenth and forced Buddy Hanford on Periodical to pull up.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained with dinner tonight in honor of Speaker and Mrs. Garner. A program of music was given afterward in the East Room for additional guests. Miss Margaret Halstead, soprano, and Albert Spalding, violinist, were the soloists.

Disapproval of a bill introduced into the State Legislature by Assemblyman Meyer Alterman of New York City, on the ground that its provisions, aside from the question of constitutionality, might tend to delay future removal proceedings against city magistrates, was contained yesterday in reports of the committees on legislation of the Association of the Bar of the City of New York and of the New York County Lawyers Association.

Back to the heights after his losing venture in the New York A.C. games on Saturday, Emmett Toppino of Loyola of the South equaled two world's records last night at the New York Curb Exchange games at the 106th Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

A new angle on the case of Charles Boettcher has developed here through the New York correspondent of the Springfield (Mass.) Republican, Neal W. Hopkins, to whom was handed a letter addressed to the victim's father by a stranger asking him to mail it.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Violent anti-Catholic attacks by brown-shirted followers of Chancellor Adolf Hitler, leaving in their wake a number of injuries to opponents, marked the election campaign in Germany today.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,082,660 barrels, compared with 2,025,000 barrels for the preceding week, an increase of 57,650 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A gain of 54,000 barrels in Oklahoma accounted almost entirely for the increase.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It is decidedly encouraging, at a time when so many public officials seem to have lost all sense of balance, to read the courageous and statesmanlike remarks regarding further cuts in the State budget which were made by Governor Lehman at Cornell yesterday.
William H. Woodin, president of the American Car and Foundry Company, made the following statement last night on his appointment as Secretary of the Treasury in President-elect Roosevelt's cabinet:

Cordell Hull, the tall, studious Tennessean whom President-elect Roosevelt has chosen as head of his Cabinet, is a Legislator-economist dedicated to the traditional Democratic policy of tariffs for revenue only.

Although fluctuations held within a 10-point range, the volume of trading was unusually large yesterday on the Cotton Exchange. Owing to today's holiday, final liquidation of March contracts prior to notices tomorrow furnished an abnormal amount of activity, and pressure on the near month closed quotations at the bottom at losses of 5 to 8 points.

Premier BENNETT'S statement in the Canadian House of Commons is of great significance. Despite his record as a high protectionist and his role as one of the principal authors of the recent Ottawa treaties surrounding the British Empire with new tariff walls, he declared that Canada "earnestly desires " a reciprocal tariff agreement with the United States.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Frenh opinion regarding Geneva's action in the Manchurian conflict is reflected by an editorial writer in Le Temps, who says: "The League of Nations finds itself at this moment confronted by a singularly ungrateful task."
LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Optimistic reports came today from the world oil conference, which assembled here secretly yesterday, in an attempt to standardize the prices of oil products.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- A program of legal reforms to aid the railroads was urged upon the committee by J.J. Pelley, president of the New York, New Haven Hartford, while a letter from 'William Randolph Hearst, the publisher, asserted that the government should operate the railroads.

Criticizing the proposed State retail sales, tax as bound to affect adversely the State's largest business division, Grover A. Whalen, president of the Advertising Club of New York and general manager of the John Wanamaker store, asserted last night that the tax would force thousands of stores out of business and reduce still further the already lowered level of retail trade.

A local law providing for abolition of the Board of Taxicab Control and the revesting of regulatory power in the Board of Aldermen and the Police Department was passed yesterday by the aldermanic branch of the Municipal Assembly.

DODGE CITY, Kan., Feb. 21 -- Considerably overshadowed by the more commanding presence of the Chicago Cubs, the Giants moved quietly and unpretentiously across the expansive mid-Western plains today on the second lap of their transcontinental jaunt to their Los Angeles training base.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 21. -- Matching her medal-winning score of a year ago. Miss Frances Williams, Allentown, Pa., playing in defense of her title, again topped the field in the qualifying round of the South Atlantic championship on the course of the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

RIO DE JANEIRO, Feb. 21 -- Brazil has ordered additional military and naval units to the Leticia frontier and has warned Colombia and Peru to respect Brazil's neutrality in the Upper Amazon war zone, it was learned today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Mrs. Hoover was the guest of honor today at the breakfast annually given for the President's wife by the Congressional Club, composed of wives and daughters of Senators and Representatives. The club entertained this year at the Shoreham Hotel.

BERLIN, Feb. 21 -- The physical improvement of communications between nations alone cannot produce happier international relations, but must be accompanied by the removal of other barriers to the free exchange of opinions, asserted Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology of Pittsburgh, at a luncheon of the American Chamber of Commerce of Berlin today.

New York City's first share of Federal loans for relief, made to the State by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was appropriated for use in March at a meeting of the committee of the whole of the Board of Estimate yesterday.

A mortgage on which $29,000 is due, covering 1,399 5th Av.. was extended to Feb. 1. 1936, at 5 per cent in an agreement between the Empire Trust Co., as trustee under the will of Benjamin Siegel, and the S.E. and M.E. Bernheimer Co., John L. Meyer. secretary.

Hartley W. Barclay, managing editor of Modern Brewery, telegraphed to Governor Lehman yesterday in protest against that part of the State Liquor Control Commission's report which recommends the prohibition of beer advertising. He characterized this as a "dangerous and uneconomic restraint of trade," which he said would do more harm than good.

Plans for a Spring fashion show, to be held at the Hotel Plaza March 21 for the benefit of the Woman's Auxiliary of the New York Infirmary for Women and Children, were announced yesterday by Mrs. George K. Weeks, chairman of the auxiliary at a luncheon of the sponsors in the Hotel Sherry-Netherland.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Green Wave, from the stable of A. B. Letellier, today made a show of the field in the fourth race, a sixfurlong claiming affair for older horses, to win by five lengths.
TOKYO, Feb. 21 -- Pending elucidation of the Cabinet's decision it is impossible to predict what form withdrawal from the League of Nations will take or when it will be effected.

On Monday the French Foreign Minister stated officially that France would resume debt negotiations with the United States after the fourth of March. This announcement by M. PAUL-BONCOUR was followed up by a call of the French Ambassador on Mr. ROOSEVELT yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 21 -- "No new taxes'' was the cry raised in the Assembly today when Republicans urged on the floor that the State budget be cut even more deeply than it was cut by Governor Lehman, in order to avert additional taxation of $84,000,000 he demanded to partly wipe out a deficit of $106,000,000 inherited from the preceding administration.

True "mechanization" the use of armored fighting vehicles to replace fighting men, is the subject of an article in March Current History by Captain LIDDELL HART. He is the inventor of the "Expanding Torrent" method of attack officially accepted by Great Britain.

Reactionary influences were again at work in the security markets yesterday. In bonds the downward movement matched that of the day before; in stocks, it was less aggressive. Sterling and francs lost ground in the foreign exchange market.

A 20 per cent increase in gross revenues from the 1932 level would give the Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad a comfortable profit, J.M. Davis, president, told stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday. He pointed out that the company's net deficit of $2,500,000 in 1932 included $2,600,000 charges for depreciation, so that had it not been for this bookkeeping the company would have shown a net income of $100,000.

A movement to introduce puzzles into the public school curriculum to make education a bit more palatable to young America was revealed last night at the monthly meeting of the Riddlers in the Hotel New Yorker.

CHICAGO, Feb. 21 -- There was a noticeable lack of pressure today on the wheat market on the Board of Trade, and comparatively little selling by houses which have been regarded as acting recently for the Federal Farm Board. A small early dip was laid to sympathy with Liverpool and to easiness in stocks, but the offerings were absorbed readily and prices moved up nearly a cent a bushel from the early low.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- The conferences on war debts and economic questions that President-elect Roosevelt is holding in New York have convinced Administration officials and experts that the groundwork is being surveyed with a view of reaching important decisions here on economic questions concurrently with the debt negotiations.

Mrs. Robert G. Mead was re-elected chairman of the Girl Scout Federation of Greater New York, Inc., at the annual meeting of its corporate members yesterday at the Chase National Bank, 18 Pine Street. It will be her third term as chairman since October, 1930, when the federation was organized to coordinate Girl Scout activities of the five boroughs.

The work done on behalf of expectant mothers in the isolated and virtually trackless areas of the mountain counties of Eastern Kentucky by a group of nurse-mid-wives carrying on in the face of handicaps imposed by nature and lack of funds was described yesterday by Mrs. Mary Breckinridge, director of the Frontier Nursing Service of Wendover, Ky., at a meeting in the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

With the purchase of u3,665,100 gold by the Bank of England on Monday the entire amount advanced by the Bank to the British Treasury to meet the $95,550,000 December instalment on the British war debt to America has been restored to the bank.

The directors of the New England Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday declared a quarterly dividend of $1-50 a share, compared with $2 previously paid quarterly. Four other associated companies and one affiliated company of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company had previously reduced their dividend payments.
HAVANA, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Monroe Goodpaster's 7-year-old gelding Meander today won the feature race, a six-furlong dash for older platers, at Oriental Park.

MONTREAL, Feb. 21 -- Untimely penalties proved the undoing of the New York Americans as the Montreal Maroons defeated Joe Simpson's team, 5-1 in a National Hockey League game tonight before a crowd of 7,000. The Maroons drove in two quick goals while Ayres was in the penalty box in the closing minutes of the opening period and another at the beginning of the second while Burke was serving time.

Chongo, a pickpocket taken into custody by the Long Beach, Cal. police in the investigation of the murder of Captain "Walter Wanderwell, and who escaped from Police Headquarters there during the questioning of suspects, is being sought in all seaports of the world, a general-alarm circular received in the metropolitan area revealed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Senator Glass settled a hundred rumors as to why he declined the Secretaryship of the Treasury under President-elect Roosevelt in a formal statement today, explaining that he simply did not wish to assume again the post he held under Woodrow Wilson.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21. -- Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank and its affiliate, the National City Company, both of New York, today told the Senate Banking Committee that in 1929 he sold to a member of his family 18,000 shares of National City Bank stock, the resulting loss of nearly 52,800,000 enabling him to avoid paying a Federal income tax last year.

Further pressure against bonds of the Japanese group yesterday causing losses of half a point to more than four points, in line with general weakness in the bond market, sent a number of these loans to new lows. The Japanese Government and government - guaranteed loans, rather than the corporation issues, showed the major declines.
Many of the Broadway attractions will give special holiday performances this afternoon.

GENEVA, Feb. 21 -- The special Assembly of the League of Nations met here this afternoon and heard from its president, Paul Hymans of Belgium, the strongest statement yet made by a League official on the Chino-Japanese conflict.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 21 -- Four members of the British women's squash racquets team, three players from Philadelphia and one from the metropolitan area had reached the quarter-final round of the New York State championship when play was completed today on the courts of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

When you find among those present students busy with notebook and pencil, then you may safely decide, upon at least one count, that you have entered the province of an "important" exhibition. Other factors no doubt conspire, but the student test is safe and sure.

THERE is a movement on foot now in this country which, if properly supported, will make the current Chino-Japanese disturbance look like a four-round preliminary bout. The reference is to the proposed national handicap golf championship to be held in this country. To encourage this is to "Cry 'Havoc' and let slip the dogs of war."

An application of the Freeport Texas Company to list 25,000 shares of its 6 per cent convertible preferred stock on the New York Stock Exchange reveals that the company agreed to pay Kidder Peabody Co. "$5 for each share for which purchasers are found."

Attendance throughout the country at superior films is greater than it was three years ago, but the motion picture industry is suffering from a bad case of overproduction, according to Samuel Goldwyn, film producer, who was interviewed in his suite at the Waldorf-Astoria yesterday.

VIENNA, Feb. 21 -- After the envoys of Great Britain and France had explained to the Austrian Chancellor that their joint note on illegal arms shipments was intended to save Austria from charges before the League of Nations Council, the Cabinet decided tonight to scrap its sharp reply and make no answer.

The work of the school relief committee in supplying free lunches to needy children in the public schools and their families will be extended to provide for destitute children in the parochial and other than, public schools through an arrangement approved yesterday by the Board of Education.

NEW YORK. Mrs. Robert Weekes Kelley will give a small reception for the Count and Countess de Comminges Friday afternoon at 510 Park Avenue. The Countess Is the former Miss Mary Porter Thayer, daughter of Mrs. S. Van Rensselaer Thayer of Paris and Boston.

Augmented by an increase of $4,747,423 in non-operating income, resulting chiefly from a special dividend declared by the Pacific Fruit Express Company, the Union Pacific system's net income for 1932 was $20,634,888, equal to $7.49 a share on common stock, against $26.057,312. or $9.93 a share, in 1931.

Rail, bus and air traffic was lighter yesterday than is usual before a holiday, officials attributing the condition to the fact that Washington's Birthday, today, falls in the middle of the week. Many celebrations of the day will be held in New York.

MOSCOW, Feb. 21 -- The Bolsheviki are really going out to solve the agrarian problem their way this year. Today they published two new decrees determining on a tax basis the peasant contributions of sunflower seed and potatoes after | the harvest, which will be approximately 10 to 15 per cent of the normal crop.

A sudden shift in the wind to the northwest yesterday morning was followed by snow flurries, rain and a freak gale that reached a maximum of sixty miles an hour. Widespread damage was done by the gale throughout the city. Plate-glass windows were blown in; signs, chimneys and cornices were ripped off and crashed into the streets; pushcarts were overturned, and in the tenement sections many clothes-lines, laden with wash, were deposited in the mud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Funds arising from gold imports, opens market operations, subscriptions for securities for the purpose of raising new capital and other investments, while largely concentrated at New York banks, are widely distributed throughout the country, the Federal Reserve Board announced in its monthly bulletin today.

The 400-meter relay race in the women's national championship meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday afternoon, prior to the men's title games at night, has attracted the entries of fourteen teams, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Several lively sallies between Senator Couzens of the Senate Finance and Banking Committees enlivened today's hearing, at which Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, was a witness

A sudden shift in the wind to the northwest yesterday morning was followed by snow flurries, rain and a freak gale that reached a maximum of sixty miles an hour. Widespread damage was done by the gale throughout the city. Plate-glass windows were blown in; signs, chimneys and cornices were ripped off and crashed into the streets; pushcarts were overturned, and in the tenement sections many clothes-lines, laden with wash, were deposited in the mud.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 -- Funds arising from gold imports, opens market operations, subscriptions for securities for the purpose of raising new capital and other investments, while largely concentrated at New York banks, are widely distributed throughout the country, the Federal Reserve Board announced in its monthly bulletin today.

The 400-meter relay race in the women's national championship meet at Madison Square Garden on Saturday afternoon, prior to the men's title games at night, has attracted the entries of fourteen teams, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 21 (AP) -- Several lively sallies between Senator Couzens of the Senate Finance and Banking Committees enlivened today's hearing, at which Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank, was a witness

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S motive in announcing at once his appointments of a Secretary of State and a Secretary of the Treasury is fairly obvious. It is a desire to speed the negotiations concerning the war debts and the coming World Economic Conference.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Prohibition enforcement will not be materially affected by the action of Congress in submitting a repeal amendment to the States, Amos W.W. Woodcock, director of the Prohibition Bureau, said today.

Bravery and quick thinking by Fireman John J. Crinnion saved the life early yesterday afternoon of Miss Maud Smithers, 64 years old, trapped by fire in her secondfloor room in a three-story rooming house at 55 West Ninth Street, her clothing ablaze.

The Columbia swimming team de feated Fordham, 45 -- 26, yesterday in the Morningside pool. Gene Jennings, the Blue and White's sophomore sprint ace, won the fifty-yard and the 100-yard free-style events, equaling the pool record of 0:24 1-5 for fifty yards.

LAKE PLACID, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- With a warm February sun making the Mount Van Hoevenberg bob track like polished, glass, J. Hubert Stevens of Lake Placid and his Adirondacks bobsled club crew took first honors in the North American, four-man bobsled championships today with total elapsed time for four heats of 7:12.51.

Teachers were hailed as "the real grand army of our Republic" yesterday by Charles H. Tuttle, chairman of the Interfaith Committee, while urging and commending efforts to promote tolerance and cooperation among various religious faiths as a means of solving the world's problems.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22. -- The Roberts prize for distinguished contribution to astronomy has been awarded to Dr. Bartholomeus Jan Bok of the Harvard Observatory, according to a letter received today from Dr. Hans Ludendorf, president of the Astronomical Society and director of the National Astronomical Observatory at Potsdam, Germany.

"For the overwhelming majority of the American people the fine arts of painting and sculpture, in their non-commercial, non-industrial forms, do not exist," according to assertions by Frederick P. Keppel and R.L. Duffus in their book, "The Arts in American Life," published today by the McGrawHill Book Company, Inc.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22. -- Princeton's unbeaten freshmen hockey sextet proved its superiority over the Yale freshmen, hitherto undefeated, by scoring a 3-to-1 victory in the New Haven arena today before an alumni day crowd of 800.

A dinner in honor of Maurice Schwartz, director and founder of the Yiddish Art Theatre, was given early this morning at the Hotel Edison. A committee of 100 men and women prominent in the thea tre and in social life sponsored the event, which began soon after midnight.

The William Lawrence Saunders Medal, given annually for distinguished achievement in mining engineering and awarded in 1928 to President Hoover, was presented last night to Walter Hull Aldridge, president of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Company, at the annual dinner of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers at the Hotel Commodore.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The Senate Foreign Relations Committee voted 15 to 5 today to report favorably the St. Lawrence waterway treaty. The favorable report is counted upon by friends of the treaty to smooth its course in the Senate, despite objections by Senator Wagner.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- A new royal honors sensatioa, according to The Dally Mail, is expected to follow the imprisonment of J. Maundy Gregory, who yesterday was jailed for two months and heavily fined for having attempted to obtain u10,000 from Lieut. Commander E.W. Leake on the promise that he would get him a knighthood.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Barney and Bridget, twin Russian wolfhounds, condemned to death by Recorder Joseph Altman tor biting Mrs. Elizabeth Marak of the Venice Park district, were in exile today in Absecon, just over the Atlantic City line.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Reversing its action of yesterday, when it voted against reporting out a silver remonetization bill, the House Coinage, Weights and Measures Committee voted 9 to 1 today to report the Somers bill favorably. Mr. Somers immediately prepared to go before the Rules Committee at the earliest possible time and ask for a special rule giving right of way to the measure, in order to obtain a vote during the next week.

Is Japan preparing to turn back the clock of her own progress ? This is a question which her best friends and admirers in the outside world are now asking with anxiety. Her recent course in Manchuria and at Geneva has troubled not only the repose of other nations but also their minds and consciences.

Senator GLASS has clearly stated the reasons why he declined Mr. ROOSEVELT'S offer of the Treasury. It is his desire to put himself in the best posture to fight unsound policies in Federal finance, especially to resist all plans for open inflation.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler, whom political opponents depict as a saber-rattling believer in big armies and navies, committed himself unequivocally today to a policy of universal and complete disarmament.
BOGOTA, Colombia, Feb. 22. -- Military conscription and new war taxes were decreed today as news came of another aerial clash with Peruvians in the Leticia area.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- One side of the Longworth-Curtis social dispute, which entertained Washington in the early days of the Hoover administration, will be told by Mrs. Edward E. Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, in a book of reminiscences soon to be published.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Two meetings of the British Cabinet were held today, which is always a sure indication of anxiety on the part of the Ministers. The subjects of the old war debts and the new war probabilities were both discussed, but for the moment the chief concern is about military developments in the Far, East.

Officers of the American Civil Liberties Union at 100 Fifth Avenue sent yesterday a letter to President-elect Roosevelt urging action by the Federal Government to promote freedom of speech, press and assembly through new administrative policies or legislation.
MIAMI, Fla., Thursday, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Two of Mayor Cermak's attending physicians elected to remain with him until after daybreak after an hour's conference ending at midnight.

Opposing views as to the influence of the radio and contemporary writing upon the study, appreciation and use of English were presented yesterday by educators to more than 600 teachers of English in secondary schools at the annual convention of the New York City Association of Teachers of English in the Textile High School, 351 West Eighteenth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- An emergency plan for helping the cotton-growing South tonight topped the heap of farm-aid bills which are piled up at the Capitol awaiting action before the March 4 deadline.
SEATTLE, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Murder and a broken romance were new theories studied today by police investigating the mysterious death of Miss Mary Fitzgerald, 27-year-old Tacoma society girl.
ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- The Republicans in the Legislature have their knives out in preparation for performing a major surgical operation on Governor Lehman's budget.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- John R. Fell, polo player and member of horse racing, yachting and club circles of this city and New York, was found dead today in his hotel room at Solo, Java, according to a cablegram received here today at the office of his stepfather, Alexander Van Rensselaer.

Both branches of Congress have agreed on a bill authorizing Mr. ROOSEVELT to reorganize the Federal Government. Democratic leaders in the House have abandoned the proposal to give him "dictatorial " power to withhold money that must be spent on account of laws which Congress itself lacks courage to repeal.

This is an age of literature high both in quality and quantity, Joseph W. Lippincott, president of J.B. Lippincott Company, publishers, said yesterday on his return from Europe on the French liner Lafayette, after six weeks of wandering among the literati of England and France.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Frederick Tremaine Billings Jr. of Pittsburgh, Pa., Princeton University senior, was the recipient of the Pyne Honor Prize at the annual Winter meeting of the Princeton National Alumni Association meeting in Nassau Hall here today.
DAYTONA BEACH. Feb. 22. -- It is true I have broken my own rec- ord of 253.968 miles an hour made on the sands of Daytona Beach Feb. 24 of last year with a new mark today of 272.108 miles an hour.

In a continuation of his magazine and radio attack against allegedly indecent books, the Rev. Francis X. Talbot writes that beneath the "art and literary pretensions" of Sinclair Lewis's "Ann Vickers," and of the novels of William Faulkner and Ernest Hemingway, are "crawling vermin."

BINGHAMTON, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Democrats of New York State were urged by Chairman James A. Farley in an address here tonight to strengthen their county organizations by taking the lead in a move for better county government.

Not the Zenith Model. Foreigners who have acquired their "knowledge of the American business man at the knee of SINCLAIR LEWIS may be somewhat puzzled by the man who will be Secretary of the Treasury in the Roosevelt Administration.

President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt asked Norman H. Davis yesterday to continue as chairman of the American delegation to the armament conference at Geneva and instructed him to carry on the American policy of trying to get an agreement for the limitation of offensive weapons.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- Presidentelect Roosevelt, who will be here tomorrow as a guest at the annual dinner of the Legislative Correspondents Association, is expected to back Governor Lehman in his plea to the leaders of his own party in the Legislature to go more deliberately in adopting their plan for the State's convention to pass on ratification of prohibition repeal.

FRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Harvard shattered Princeton's dream of a Big Three hockey championship by defeating the Orange and Black skaters in the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink tonight, 4 to 2. The game was the third and deciding one of the series.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 22. -- A return to the two-cent postage rate, beginning next July 1, was forecast here tonight by Representative James M. Mead, Democrat, of Buffalo, N.Y., chairman of the House Committee on the Postoffice and Post Roads.

The later operas of Richard Wagner, which excite the special admiration of the initiate, are not the only Wagner operas that draw the public. This was shown by the audience which gathered yesterday afternoon for the "Tannhauser" performance in the Metropolitan Opera House, given as one of the series of the special Wagner matinees.

An intimate study of George Washington, in which he was depicted as "a red-blooded, husky American youth," was presented yesterday by the Right Rev. William Hall Moreland, Protestant Episcopal Bishop of Sacramento to the members of the Brotherhood of St. Andrew.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 22. -- Declaring that what the United States now needed was leadership, not dictatorship, Bernard M. Baruch today called upon the nation's people to stop leaning on government and draw on their own courage to master the economic crisis.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Continuing the formidable play that has marked their appearances in this country, the women's British squash racquets players vanquished the United States team in the first international match of its kind by 4 to 1 at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club today.

High ranking army and navy officers pleaded, yesterday for adequate national defense at the annual luncheon of the Veteran Corps of Artillery, Military Society War of 1812, in honor of Washington's Birthday at the Hotel Savoy-Plaza.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Employment decreased 3.9 per cent and payrolls dropped 5 per cent in January, as compared with December. In seventeen major industrial groups embracing 69,392 establishments with 4,275,560 employes whose combined weekly earnings were 81,707,319, the Bureau of Labor Statistics announced today.

New York State's experiment in "emergency education" is to be extended to sixteen cities and counties outside of New York City, it was announced yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration, consisting of Harry L. Hopkins, Charles D. Osborne and John Sullivan.

ROME, Feb. 22. -- Washington's, Birthday was the occasion today of two brilliant functions in which not only the American colony but also many members of the Italian official world participated. Ambassador and Mrs. John W. Garrett threw the doors of their residence, Palazzo Rospigllosi, open this afternoon for a reception to which all Americans in Rome were invited.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 22. -- Breaking fifty straight targets, T.D. Carman won the holiday shoot at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Character and Royal Ruffin, both owned by the B.B. Stable, trained by Hirsch Jacobs and ridden by Buddy Hanford, maintained their winning streaks by victories at Hialeah Park today in the Stars and Stripes Purse and George Washington Handicap, respectively.

To a particular domain of music belong sonatas for violin and piano, such as Albert Spalding and Ossip Gabrilowitsch played last night in Town Hall. The medium, though it appears simple, is a very difficult one for composers and performers alike.

Serious harm to the morale of the unemployed and their families is the most insidious by-product of the present economic crisis, the Rev. C. Rankin Earnes, head of the national social service department of the Protestant Episcopal Church, said last night at a dinner of the National Council of the Church Mission of Help, at 99 Park Avenue.

New York joined yesterday with the rest of the nation in observing the 201st anniversary of the birth of George Washington. The day being a legal holiday, schools, banks and many stores were closed. There was no great exodus of pleasure-seekers from the city this year, however, and rail, bus and air traffic was considerably lighter than usual.

CHICAGO, Feb. 22. -- A movement for government-managed national self-liquidating certificates to end the depression has been started by the Evanston Independent Retail Merchants Association, originator of Eirma stamp money, with the support of Professor Irving Fisher of Yale University.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Trinchera, from the Three D's Stock Farm, proved his right to the outstanding favoritism accorded him in the Washington Birthday Handicap today, "by romping to a length victory over Mrs., A. Burkett's Making Bubbles.
NEW YORK. The Baroness Amaury de La Grange, who has been with Mrs. George D. Widener, is sailing on the Bremen today and will return to her home at 16 Rue St. Guillaume, Paris.
LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The House of Commons made it clear, after a three-hour debate tonight, that it would allow neither advertising nor political interference in British radio programs.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP) -- The question of limiting withdrawal of deposits from banks in distress, especially withdrawals by large depositors in a position to know conditions In advance, entered the Senate Finance Committee's Inquiry today.
Allenhurst and the 101st Cavalry of Brooklyn rode into the final round of the low-goal division of the seventh annual invitation polo tournament of the New York Athletic Club yesterday.

The Izaak Walton League of America, through its many local chapters, has been conducting an intensive campaign throughout the country for the past two or three months in an effort to obtain legislation in various States to stamp out commercial black bass fishing.

President-elect Roosevelt will have a Cabinet which will work with him, and will consist largely of personal appointments, if a list of his latest selections, which are believed to be final, undergoes no change. nor Harry F. Byrd for appointment as Senator to fill the vacancy which will be created by the resignation of Senator Swanson.

With business adjourned for the day, the financial community had opportunity yesterday for quiet reflection. The overnight announcement that Mr. Woodin had been chosen as the new Secretary of the Treasury was the holiday news of first importance; in the absence of a positive definition of the incoming administration's attitude with respect to the currency question this selection probably will be sufficiently reassuring.

Three men were trapped in an automobile submerged in twentyfive feet of water last night when the machine hurtled the Battery wall, near Marine Division Headquarters of the Police at the foot of Washington Street, and plunged into the upper bay.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 22. -- Pennsylvania won its Intercollegiate League swimming meet with City College of New York today, 47 to 24, and also took the water polo match, 27 to 9.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Sir Malcolm Campbell, English racing veteran, drove his 2.500horsepower Bluebird car over a dangerous beach to a new world's record of 272.108 miles an hour on the ocean speedway here today.

Within a few minutes after Lucrezia Bori had spoken to a radio audience from the stage where "Tannhauser" was broadcast at the opera house yesterday, her appeal for all interested in the Metropolitan's future to join in providing a guarantee fund for its continuance next season was met by an unexpected response.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The opinion gains strength in Congress that President-elect Roosevelt will not oppose a naval construction program providing for the gradual building up of the navy to meet the provisions of the London naval limitation treaty.

A suspension of express service on the city's independent subway system yesterday, coupled with a reduction of express service on the Manhattan lines of the B.M.T. and Interborough, brought complaints from many users of the rapid transit lines, who objected to the resulting traffic delays and overcrowding of subway cars.

A lively contrast, indeed, is furnished by two exhibitions at Knoedler's, separated in space only by the thickness of an ordinary partition wall and in time by centuries. The modern protagonist is Adele Herter, with two dozen paintings of flowers.
For the twelfth time since 1915 Clarence C. Pell, 47-year-old New York veteran, won the national amateur racquets championship yesterday at the Racquet and Tennis Club.

Every woman in the country is feeling the pressure of economy. From, the wealthiest to the poorest, none is exempt, though with some of the former the wish to be in the fashion of thrift may exert a certain influence. There is no nonsense of that kind about the 1933 management of the White House, however.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Dartmouth won a fast and hardfought basketball game from the Army five today, 43 to 30. A crowded gallery watched the Green quintet outplay the cadets after the first few minutes.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- Sterling continued to display weakness in erratic movements in the foreign exchange market today. The New York rate fell from $3.41 3/4, last night's closing level, to $3.41, subsequently rallying to $3.42 and then reacting to $3.40 7/8.

Edward Harper of 35 St. Mark's Place and Edward Marsh of 376 Bergen Street, both of Brooklyn and both members of the Brooklyn Council of Boy Scouts, were rescued yesterday from the icy waters of a pond on the Ernest Flagg estate at New Dorp, S.I., after they had struggled for more than thirty minutes to climb out on the crumbling ice.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The breakdown of International trade has brought us and every other country in the world to a point where only two courses are open, a shift from activities for export to activities for internal consumption, or the reduction of trade barriers and the restoration of foreign markets.
WINSLOW, Ariz., Feb. 22. -- Another tedious day of travel wore down upon the expeditionary forces of the Giants and Cubs in their transcontinental tour to the Pacific Coast today.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Eclipsing in brilliance similar performances of the last four Winters, "A Night in Old Madrid" was given tonight by the Romanies as their annual climax of the season. More than 400 persons were present.

GENEVA, Feb. 22. -- With the German delegate's attitude more Inflexible since his week-end visit to Berlin, the disarmament conference's general commission resumed work this afternoon in an atmosphere that steadily grew worse and made progress impossible.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Representative Tinkham of Massachusetts, Republican, today renewed his attack upon the administration's foreign policy. He told the House that "it is unthinkable that the Republican party can ever again obtain control of the government under such leadership as it has had during the past four years under Mr. Hoover, Mr. Stimson and Mr. Mills."

The fact that there are thousands of "designedly childless" marriages in America today was decried by the Very Rev. Aloysius J. Hogan, president of Fordham University, preaching in St. Patrick's Cathedral yesterday morning at the annual memorial mass of the New York Chapter Knights of Columbus.

ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- A threat to hale W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, before the bar of the Senate was made today by John J. Dunnigan, president pro tem, in a debate on proposed revisions of the State election law.

BERLIN, Feb. 22. -- Owing apparently to special upward movements in a small number of stocks, bonds on the Boerse displayed more strength today than yesterday, although business was quiet. A.E. G. advanced 2 per cent in heavy trading, estimated at 360,000 marks.

TORONTO, Feb. 22. -- Harold F. Ritchie, proprietary medicine manufacturer and merchant, who was president of Harold F. Ritchie Co., died suddenly in the Toronto General Hospital today He was 52 years old.

LA PAZ. Bolivia. Feb. 22. -- Reports to the general staff from the Bolivian high command in the disputed Chaco region tell a story of a siege at Fort Nanawa comparable with long struggle against odds of the Bolivians at Fort Boqueron last Summer, but with the Paraguayans now in the role of defenders.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 22. -- There is a marked increase in the severity of the fighting near the Jehol border, but both Chinese and Japanese sources of information agree that the actual Japanese offensive to subjugate Jehol is not yet under way. Since Manchukuo's ultimatum is expected hourly, however, a large-scale Japanese campaign is considered a certainty within forty-eight hours.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The Roosevelt Cabinet appointees, as announced here, are so much less known in this country than, it is expected, they will be a few months hence, that tomorrow's London papers are refraining from editorial comment. News dispatches on the subject hava scant information, which has been pieced out by reference to the American "Who's Who."

MIDDLEBURG, Va., Feb. 22. -- Mrs. John Hay Whitney's gray gelding, Bon Diable, with an almost faultless performance, won for her owner the handsome Middleburg Bowl, a $2,000 silver trophy at the annual hunter trials of the Middleburgr Hunt today.

Unsettlement resulting from a soft price situation and from the banking difficulties in Michigan accounted partly for the "flattening out" of demand for steel this week, according to The Iron Age which, in its weekly review, puts the estimated rate of production at a shede less than 19 per cent of ingot capacity, compared with 20 per cent in the previous week.

Prince Johannes of Lichtenstein will sail tonight for Europe on the North German Lloyd liner Bremen. Also on the ship will be Ernst Mentor, John Hay Whitney, who is going to Liverpool with Mrs. Whitney to see the Grand National Steeplechase; Baron George von Zedlitz, P. Herman Gade, Norwegian Minister to France, and Heinrich Schlusnuss, German concert tenor, and Mrs. Schlusnuss.

Declaring that at least half of Dreamland Park at Coney Island should be converted into a recreational area, Nathan Straus Jr., president of the Park Association of New York City, in a letter made public yesterday, asked Park Commissioner Browne of Brooklyn to postpone temporarily public bidding on the lease of the ten-acre tract for a parking space.

BUCHAREST, Feb. 22. -- Although outward peace in Rumania has been restored by the suppression of the strikes at Cluj, Bucharest and Ploesti, discontent over existing conditions is rife and the Communists are still diligently exploiting It.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The report of the national transportation committee and Mr. Smith's supplemental report, particularly the latter, do not give the Interstate Commerce Commission sufficient credit for the performance of a most difficult task since its organization in 1887.

Spectacular shot-making, hardfought contests and several upsets entertained a crowd of 20,000 at matinee and evening sessions of the annual charity basketball carnival at Madison Square Garden yesterday.

In the Senate on Monday Mr. LA FOLLETTE was talking about the Costigan-La Follette bill to grant $500,000,000 to aid the States in direct unemployment relief. Naturally, other Senators were talking, too, among themselves. Forgetting the insatiable passion of Senatorial organs of speech for utterance, loud or low, the Senator all too sourly asked that.

After having been closed yesterday in observance of Washington's Birthday, the markets as well as the banks and business organizations generally will reopen this morning. The holiday brought a complete cessation of activity in all financial centres in this country.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 22.- England made a clean sweep of its series with Bermuda at the tennis stadium today, taking all six matches in straight sets. Members of both teams will enter the championships starting Friday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Cordell Hull has decided that he will not resign as Senator from Tennessee to become Secretary of State until shortly before he takes his new office March 4, but between now and then will concentrate on the heavy duties to come.

Brenda Putnam, whose individual retrospective exhibition of sculpture is now at the Grand Central Galleries, will aid the fund for the benefit of needy artists by making a bust portrait of Arnold Genthe this evening at the Grand Central Galleries. Miss Putnam will undertake to do a life-size portrait within two hours, beginning of 8:30 P. M.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- The new Cabinet was studied with mingled feelings by Democrats in the capital when its hitherto missing items become known today. Enthusiasm was definitely lacking for the Cabinet as a whole, although certain appointments, notably that of Senator Hull for Secretary of State, were cordially greeted.

THE thin, mild-mannered, little man explained that he had been walking up Eighth Avenue the other night and had heard the cheers for Browning, and his heart rejoiced that at last a great poet was coming into his own. He stood aghast when he was disillusioned.

An action, for a declaratory judgment against Harry Whitney of 25 East End Avenue, an explorer and big game hunter and a distant cousin of Harry Payne Whitney, has been started here, it was learned last night, by George Gordon Battle, as counsel for Mrs. Marie Schuckofski Whitney, housekeeper for a Perry County, Pa., farmer.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22. -- In the most exciting game on the Harvard court this season, the Northeastern University basketball team of Boston registered a 29-28 victory over Harvard in the indoor athletic building today.

SYDNEY, Australia, Thursday, Feb. 23 (Canadian Press). -- Australia had scored 67 runs for the loss of three wickets in the fifth and final cricket test match against England today when the teams went to lunch. The Antipodeans started badly when V.Y. Richardson was caught out for a duck by D.R. Jardine off Harold Larwood's bowling.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., Feb. 22. -- "No body of men in the United States works harder than the Senate, or with more intelligence," said Felix Frankfurter, Professor of Law at Harvard Law School, who spoke at Smith College this morning in the annual Washington's Birthday celebration.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- After violent opposition of Nationalists predicting disaster from any weakening of France's military strength, the French Senate tonight refused the Chamber's military reductions, putting the Daladier Government in a minority of 133 to 170.

TOKYO, Thursday, Feb. 23. -- The British Ambassador, Sir Francis Lindley, asked Japan today what her intentions were in Jehol and requested further information on the nature of the government's decision to withdraw from the League of Nations.
HAVANA, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Reports of rebel activties in three interior provinces of Cuba today met vigorous denial in all official quarters.

LONDON, Feb. 22. -- J.H. Thomas, Secretary of State for the Dominions, announced tonight in the House of Commons that Lord Amulree had been made chairman of the Royal Commission to examine into the financial position of Newfoundland as a condition of granting a loan of u300,000.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- The renewal of Franco-American war debt conversations with Ambassador Paul Claudel's visit to President-elect Roosevelt yesterday brought a quick reaction here when United States Ambassador Walter E. Edge deleted from his Washington's Birthday address at the American Club tonight many blunt statements contained in the original draft.

Formal offering will be made today of a new issue of $4,950,000 State of Louisiana 5 1/2 per cent bonds, dated Jan. 1, 1933, and due from 1934 to 1953 at prices to yield 4 to 6 per cent. The offering group is headed by Halsey, Stuart Co., Inc., and includes six banking organizations: the Hibernia Securities Company.

Major Gen. James E. Fechet, retired, former Chief of the United States Army Air Corps, wrote a book called "Flying," which the Century Company publishes today. It has a foreword by Eddie Rickenbacker.

Leo J. Sexton of the New York Athletic Club, the Olympic shotputting champion, revealed yesterday that the national championship meet at the Garden on Saturday would bring his athletic career to a close.

MOUNT HOLLY, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Frank H. Miller, a private detective of Camden, was subpoenaed tonight for questioning here tomorrow by Prosecutor Howard Eastwood of Burlington County in connection with the renewed investigation into the deaths of Horace Roberts Jr. and Ruth Mowdray Wilson of Moorestown on the night of June 1, 1929.

DENVER, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Thwarted by police in bis first actual attempt to keep a rendezvous with, the kidnappers of his son, Charles Boettcher 2d, wealthy investment broker, Claude K. Boettcher moved more secretly tonight to avoid interference in case he is again summoned by the abductors.
DETROIT, Feb. 22 (AP). -- The question of how much money will be available to depositors in Michigan's banks tonight remained largely unsettled.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 22. -- Climaxing a three-year struggle to the top, Young Corbett of Fresno, Cal., was awarded the welterweight championship of the world today after his flying fists had thudded out a decisive victory over Jackie Fields in a bristling ten-round bout.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Senator Borah took a positive stand today against all proposals to confer "dictatorial" powers on the new President.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Fourth in the first of three special sprint races, Frank Wykoff, slim Southern California flier, came back to win both the remaining dashes tonight and tie Al Maskery of Penn for first place on points.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Secretary of the Treasury Mills today grave notice that tenders had been invited for $100,000,000 in 91-day Treasury bills to be sold on a discount basis to the highest bidders.

DUBLIN, Feb. 22. -- Following a meeting of the Executive Council of the Free State, an official announcement was issued tonight that General Owen O'Duffy, commissioner of the police force, had been removed from office by the de Valera government and that Colonel Edward Broy, recently made chief of the crimes branch, had been appointed to succeed him.

B.M. Higginson won the George Lyon Memorial Trophy at the Travers Island traps of the New York A.C. yesterday, breaking 192 out of a possible 200 targets. T.H. Lewis, who triumphed last year, returned a card of 189 to tie for the third scratch cup.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Following in full is the statement made before the Senate Finance Committee today by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the governing board and president of the Chase National Bank, on the causes of the present depression and possible remedies:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 22. -- Hop- ing to reach New York in fifteen hours, Colonel Roscoe Turner flew from United Airport at 1:23 P.M. this afternoon to take E.B. Hatrick, vice president and general manager of Cosmopolitan Movie Productions, to the bedside of his daughter, who was reported to be near death of injuries suffered in an automobile crash in New York.
LONDON, Feb. 22. -- The diehards in the House of Commons were overwhelmingly defeated today when they launched an attack on the Government's constitutional reforms for India.

BOSTON, Feb. 22. -- Champion Benson of Crombie, the winning pointer from the Giralda Farms of Mrs. M. Hartley Dodge of Madison, N.J., was named best in show tonight as the twenty-first annual exhibition of the Eastern Dog Club closed in Mechanics Building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- President-elect Roosevelt's announcement that Norman H. Davis would be retained as an American delegate to the world disarmament conference was welcome news to State Department officials and military and naval experts who are working on arms reduction problems.

An active campaign to place social legislation on Federal and State statute books was decided upon at the two-day conference of the Church League for Industrial Democracy, the Rev. Dr. J. Howard Melish, pastor of Holy Trinity Church, Brooklyn, yesterday told the members at a luncheon at the Hotel Brittany that followed the closing session of the conference at Grace Church.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 22. -- Alastair McGaw, Kearny High School star and holder of the New Jersey State indoor and outdoor Class A high school quarter-mile titles, broke a record and equaled another, to provide the chief feature of the twenty-third annual Dickinson High School Interscholastic track and field meet at the 113th Infantry Armory today.

DETROIT, Feb. 22. -- Steps were taken today to reorganize the two big groups of national banks in Michigan through the formation of new corporations with the aid of the large stockholders and a loan which it is hoped the Reconstruction Finance Corporation will make.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 22. -- The holiday peace of Harvard was disrupted this morning by the appearance of The Harvard Crimson, undergradute daily, announcing the appointment of Dr. Henry Eliot Clarke of Evanston, Ill., as the next president of the university.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Frank Bohn in a letter to THE TIMES advocates a bill recently passed by the Senate to care for 88,000 boys in army camps as a wise measure which will provide "the care and nurture which is due them at this time from the nation."

The last week but one of the Metropolitan Opera season will open on next Monday evening with a performance of Debussy's "Pelleas at Melisande." The cast will be headed by Mmes. Bori, Bourskaya and Dalossy and Messrs. Johnson, Pinza, Rothier and Ananian, with Mr. Hasselmans conducting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22. -- Premier Bennett'a suggestion that Canada is desirous of effecting a reciprocal trade treaty with the United States may have been the outgrowth of a visit which Henry Morgenthau Jr. recently made to Ottawa as an emissary of President-elect Roosevelt.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 22. -- The Princeton basketball team dealt the Yale five its second Eastern Intercollegiate League defeat in a brilliant game played before a capacity Alumni Day crowd of 2,500 in the university gymnasium today. The score was 46-26.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- More money for the Federal Trade Commission to continue its power and economic investigations was voted today by the Senate, which then sat back and listened to Senator Norris, Republican of Nebraska, light into what he termed "the power trust" and the Edison Electric Institute.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 22. -- Three birdies on the first four holes of the afternoon round enabled Paul Runyan, White Plains, N.Y., and his partner, Horton Smith of Oak Park, Ill., to win the annual international four-ball golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Now that Congress has submitted to the States the Twenty-first Amendment, providing for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment to be "ratified as an amendment to the Constitution by conventions in the several States, as provided in the Constitution," the States must zealously avoid any methods of procedure which will result in delay in securing ratification.
COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 22. -- Ignoring advice of Governor White, the Ohio Senate today voted, 22 to 9, to submit immediate repeal of State constitutional prohibition to a referendum in November.

SAN JUAN, P. R., Feb. 22. -- A new Atlantic depth of 44,000 feet just north of Puerto Rico has been discovered by a scientific expedition directed by Dr. Paul Bartsch, operating from Eldridge R. Johnson's yacht Caroline.

PARIS, Feb. 22. -- President-elect Roosevelt's action in receiving Ambassador Paul Claudel yesterday for a frank, unofficial talk on the debts situation has altered in a manner that cannot be exaggerated the whole attitude of France toward the United States that had developed during the stormy days of last December.

HARTFORD, Conn., Feb. 22. -- Following a vitriolic debate, the Legislature today hamstrung a district court bill, designed by the Governor's judicial council to consolidate the 135 local police courts and to have district judges appointed by the Governor, and then proceeded, with the aid of three Al Smith Democrats voting with Republicans, to elect Democratic and Republican judges in many towns, including Stamford, New Canaan, Westport and Norwalk.

PARIS, Feb. 22 (AP). -- Rapid settlement of the Franco-American debt question was predicted by former Premier Edouard Herriot in a warmly applauded address tonight at the annual Washington's birthday dinner at the American Club.

Purchases of American merchandise amounting to more than $2,000,000 have been made by the four stores of Gimbel Brothers, Inc., to be featured in a "no-profit" sale in the next twenty business days, it was announced yesterday by Kenneth Collins, assistant to Bernard Gimbel, president.

The utilization of energy from the cosmic ray was viewed as a possibility by Dr. Arthur H. Compton, Professor of Physics at the University of Chicago, in a lecture last night at the Brooklyn Academy of Music under the auspices of the Department of Physics and Proctor Foundation of the Brooklyn Institute of Arts and Sciences.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 22. -- Tax exemption of educational institutions as a national and State policy was urged by President Angell of Yale University in his annual address to the graduates here today. The occasion was the twentieth alumni-day program of the university.

A scathing attack upon the present leaders of the Republican party was made last night by Lloyd P. Stryker, an attorney and an organization Republican, at the annual Washington-Lincoln dinner of the Women's National Republican Club, 8 East Thirty-seventh Street.

The exhibition of paintings, sketches and drawings by Thomas Eakins, at the Milch Galleries, has been extended and will remain through the month. This showing, while not large or particularly representative, serves effectively enough as prelude to the publication, announced for March 1, of Lloyd Goodrich's definitive book on Eakins's life and work, brought out for the Whitney Museum of American Art by the Studio Publications, Inc.

Of the additional $50,453,239 of capital surplus to be created at the annual meeting of Drug, Inc., in Wilmington, Del., on March 14, the directors purpose to use at least $23,662,580 for writing down the book values of properties and leaseholds, mostly of the Louis K. Liggett Company, and $2,978,484 for writing off good-will.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., Feb. 22. -- Running through eleven races in close competition, the sailing dinghies of the Frostbite Yacht Club went to sea today off the Larchmont Yacht Club. The harbor provided sea enough for the cleven-foot craft with their seventytwo square feet of sail.

CAMDEN, S.C., Feb. 22. -- In a finish that thrilled a crowd of more than 5,000 cheering spectators, Hotscur, the durable and speedy chestnut gelding owned by Mrs. W. Austin Wadsworth of Geneseo, N.Y., for the second year in a row, outran a bunched field today in the Washington's Birthday Plate post and rail race of two miles over the stiff Springdale course.

Samuel S. Koenig, veteran New York County Republican leader, in two letters made public yesterday, moved to reassert his leadership, and extended the olive branch of cooperation to the leaders of the fusion movement for the next election.
LONDON, Feb. 22. -- An attack on what they considered the overriding powers of the Cabinet, and especially of the Foreign Minister, was made by Labor members of the House of Lords today.

Free port districts as a phase of freight transportation in the United States were attacked as impracticable yesterday by Irving T. Bush, chairman of the board of the Bush Terminal Company. Mr. Bush plans to submit his objections to the subcommittee of the House Ways and Means Committee which is considering legislation on the subject this week in Washington.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 22 (AP). -- In examining Gordon S. Rentschler, president of the National City Bank, today regarding its loans to officers to protect them in the 1929 market slump, Mr. Pecora asked:
Following are sketches of the public services of the nine men and one woman who are to constitute President Roosevelt's Cabinet, according to apparently authentic reports.

The Fencers Club A team, national epee champions, captured the Washington Square Fencers' trophy for the second consecutive year on the strips of the Fencers Club yesterday. Fencing in the continental fashion, the winners annexed 19 of their 24 bouts.

BUFFALO, Feb. 22. -- A plea for "morals in politics" was made here today by W. Kingsland Macy, chairman of the State Republican Committee, at the annual Washington's Birthday luncheon of the Martha Washington Republican Women's Club. Mr. Macy also advocated "buying American," and expressed the hope that President-elect Roosevelt would dedicate himself to a policy of "America first."
ALBANY, Feb. 22. -- A bill barring aliens from receiving any work relief whatever under the unemployment aid program of the State passed the Senate today by a vote of 29 to 15.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The British Government and the Roosevelt administration have not yet completed their plans for revising the war-debt settlement and for dealing with economic and related subjects, although progress is being made in the approach to the issues at stake.

The first New York performance of Monteverdi's opera "The Coronation of Poppea" took place yesterday afternoon at the Juilliard School of Music, almost 300 years after its premiere in Venice in 1642. The date was an important one in operatic history.

The announcement by President-elect Roosevelt that Representative Douglas will be Director of the Budget was described in banking circles yesterday as the most promising indication, of prospective governmental economies that has yet developed.

The American Civil Liberties Union announced yesterday that the State Department in Washington had taken "appropriate action" to prevent the Italian consular agent in Yonkers from "summoning any more American citizens of Italian birth for questioning on their attitude toward fascism."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- A twelve-year record for the passage of naval appropriation bills was broken today when the House passed the $315,419,000 naval appropriation bill in less than five hours. With the exception of a few changes, the most important of which involved the pay of aviation officers, the bill was passed in the form it came from the committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Testimony on the financial practices of the boom days of 1929 was put before the Senate Banking and Currency Committee today by Hugh B. Baker, president, and Harris F. Law, secretary, of the National City Company as the committee continued its general stock market investigation.

VIENNA, Feb. 23. -- Chancellor Dollfuss today suspended Egon See-fehlner, general director of the Austrian State railroads, on a charge of trying to have the Hirtenberg rifles smuggled into Hungary after the Chancellor had promised the British Government he would send them back to Italy.
ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Governor Lehman expressed approval today of a program calling for revision of the State Constitution to permit establishment of pari-mutuel betting on the New York tracks.

There will be a gathering of children as well as their elders this afternoon at the Plaza for the annual St. Valentine Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged. It will be held in the ballroom suite, where there will be booths for the sale of various kinds of articles, including the handiwork of the residents of the home.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- An international women's squash racquets trophy, to be played for by teams representing England and the United States, was offered in competition today by two members of the visiting British women's squash racquets team.

The committee on municipal securities of the Investment Bankers Association, headed by. E. F. Dunstan of the Bankers Trust Company, in response to requests of bankers for municipal issues, has taken up the question of the feasibility of recommending changes in laws governing eligibility of municipal bonds as security for postal savings.
The process of reading once more from the voting machines the totals recorded for candidates at the last election was begun yesterday in warehouses where the machines are stored in the five boroughs.

GENEVA, Feb. 23. -- It was decided at a secret meeting of leaders of the League of Nations this evening to propose to the Assembly tomorrow, after the adoption of the Manchurian report of the Committee of Nineteen, the establishment of a "consultative committee" to consider the "grave situation" which Japan's rejection of the report and her continued military operations have caused.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended Feb. 21, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,268,000,000, an increase of $169,000,000, compared with the preceding week and of $493,000.000 compared with, the corresponding week in 1932.
