The J. I. Case Company reports for 1932 a net loss of $2,611,081 after charges, taxes and provision for depreciation. For 1931, the company reported a deficit of $885,270. In the last year the company paid $1,500,000 of notes.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- A new leasing plan for farm relief, sponsored by the Northwest Agricultural Committee, which would attack the surplus problem by paying farmers from $1 to $8 an acre to take up to 25 per cent of their lands out of production, will be presented to Congress soon, in the hope of immediate action, or at least careful consideration by the present session looking to adoption in the special session.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Judge Robert W. Bingham, Louisvilla publisher, long has been one of the outstanding figures in Kentucky politics and a thorn in the side of his political enemies.

To the Editor of The New York Times: With the death of Frances Wolcott a very vital force passed from out midst. Born with a vigorous intelligence and an ardent and inquiring mind, the circumstances of her life combined to develop in her an unusual depth of human understanding.

SALT LAKE CITY, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Clubs, fists and tear gas bombs were weapons today in a clash between deputy sheriffs and a throng of several hundred persons who stormed the City-County Building in a successful effort to block tax foreclosure sales.

FARGO, N. D., Feb. 23. -- On the bleak, wind-driven plains of the Far Northwest, the Northrop plane which will be used for crossing the Antarctic Continent has received its baptism in below-zero weather.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Speculation, was concentrated today on the personnel of the future "Little Cabinet," that group of Under-secretaries, Assistant Secretaries and bureau heads who actually run the mechanics of the government, and on the identities of the envoys of the United States abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Bishop James Cannon Jr., opening a campaign against State ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, appealed to the people of the South today to help suppress "the wet rebellion" which he said was started by Alfred E. Smith in 1920.

Details of the capitalization of the Realty Stabilization Corporation of Delaware, the parent company of the New York corporation of the same name, were made public yesterday. Organization of the companies, whose purpose is to aid mortgage and title companies in close cooperation with the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, is rapidly nearing completion.

MOSCOW, Feb. 23. -- The Soviet Union today celebrated the fifteenth anniversary of the Red Army. Singularly enough, the day is not a holiday, and there have been no parades or display of military pomp. Instead, meetings are being held in factories, schools and clubs after working hours.

Executives of twenty-one railroad unions, representing the employes of all the principal lines of the country, made known here yesterday, after a conference designed to enlist the support of President elect Roosevelt, that they had united to obtain, through Congressional action, the wage and hour changes hitherto refused to them by the railway managements.
ROME, Feb. 23. -- The Duke of Spoleto, who ia a cousin of the King of Italy and who recently returned from America, was hailed today as the hero of an exciting rescue at sea of a Naval Lieutenant.

Income tax difficulties of Pola Negri, film actress, were said yesterday to have caused the cancellation of Miss Negri's departure on two liners, sailing within twenty-four hours of each other. Booked originally on the Manhattan, departing Wednesday midnight, Miss Negri cancelled her reservation, and again cancelled quarters yesterday on the Bremen, which left after last midnight.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- Beyond the continued reiteration of a vague promise of "work and bread," this election in Germany is being fought without any manifestation of a program, economic or political, on the part of the coalition now in control of the government.

NEWARK, N. J., Feb. 23. -- As predicted last Fall by Chester I. Barnard, director of the New Jersey Emergency Relief Administration, the number of persons on the relief roster will reach a peak of 500,000 individuals next month, according to the latest report of the administration, made public here.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23. -- In honor of her house guests, Mrs. R. Scott Lindsley and Miss Wilhelmina Kirby, Mrs. Jerome D. Gedney gave a luncheon for twenty guests today at Manalapan. Later today Mrs. Lindsley and Miss Kirby departed for Aiken, S.C.

Despite declines of 20 to 30 per cent in the packs of the principal foods, net earnings and the dollar volume of sales of the Continental Can Company, Inc., declined only 15 per cent last year, O. C. Huffman, president, reported in the company's annual statement, issued yesterday.

Mayor Frank Hague of Jersey City charged yesterday that the Hudson County Retail Druggists' Association was being used unknowingly by certain physicians and medical organizations in Jersey City in a "conspiracy to destroy the Jersey City Medical Centre," in defending the centre's practice of selling drugs at reduced prices to the poor.

Bruno Walter, for the last Thursday night program of his present season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, presented works for chorus soloist and orchestra, and he aroused keen anticipation on the part of disciples of Gustav Mahler by announcing the performance of that composer's Second Symphony.

Johnny Risko, Cleveland's veteran "rubber man," will oppose King Levinsky, hardhitting Chicago battler, in the feature bout often rounds at Madison Square Garden tonight. The battle will mark the third time these rivals have clashed.
BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- After a seven-day suspension by the police, Vorwarts, the official organ of the Social Democratic party, reappeared today. Under the heading At the Front Again," it says:

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23. -- A plan to put the National Government behind every dollar deposited in banks as a guarantee against losses is advanced by William Gibbs McAdoo, United States Senator-elect from California.

MUKDEN, Friday, Feb. 24. -- The entire Jehol frontier is snow-blanketed as a result of a blizzard and the temperature is dropping as Japan completes elaborate preparations for a smashing offensive for which the present battles are merely preludes.

GENEVA, Feb. 23. -- The Hitler government of Germany was completely isolated in the disarmament conference this afternoon when Arthur Henderson of Britain successively put to a vote in the general commission proposals on effectives by Germany, Italy and France.

Net income of the Pennsylvania Water and Power Company in 1932 amounted to $2,122,106, equal to $4.93 a share earned on 429,848 common shares, against $2,056,142, or $4.78 a share, earned In 1931. Gross revenue was $5,240,708, against $5,064,070, and net revenue $3,184,006, against $3,096,304, after expenses and depreciation.

A mother who goes to excesses to protect and indulge her child may well be suspected of secretly detesting it, according to a theory which engaged the tenth annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Rigorous rules regarding religious processions in the Rome diocese so that "abuses, if any, may be extirpated and the processions conducted in an orderly fashion with modesty and reverence," were issued today by Cardinal Marchetti-Selvaggiani, Pope Pius's Vicar General.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Before leaving his home at Hyde Park this afternoon to attend the legislative correspondents dinner here, President-elect Roosevelt announced that he had selected Representative Lewis W. Douglas of Arizona for Director of the Budget and confirmed the report that he had chosen former Governor George H. Dern of Utah for Secretary of War.

The opinion that crime will increase, rather than decrease, if the Prohibition Amendment is repealed, was expressed last night by Louis McHenry Howe, personal secretary to President-elect Roosevelt, in a radio interview broadcast from Station WEAF over an NBC network of stations.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The urgent need of bankruptcy legislation to permit reorganization of railroads was described to the Senate today by Senator Couzens, chairman of the Interstate Commerce Committee, who said that delay would mean "millions of losses through the Reconstruction Finance Corporation loans."

Foreign debts to the United States are "dead," Frank H. Simonds, writer on international affairs, said last night at a meeting of the Foreign Policy Association in Town Hall. Mr. Simonds reaffirmed his stand. Tuesday before the Senate Finance Committee in Washington that a settled American debt policy was the greatest essential in the promotion of recovery.

The reduction of the education budget by a "slide-rule calculation" rather than by study and consideration of the effect of education on social morale, was condemned yesterday by Howard W. Nudd, director of the Public Education Association, in a discussion before the committee on civic affairs of the parent-teacher group at the Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West Sixty-fourth Street.

Fluctuations on the Cotton Exchange yesterday were infiluenced more by the action of security markets than by March notices and after a 15-point advance prices broke $1 a bale to losses of 3 to 10 points on the day.

MOUNT HOLLY, N. J., Feb. 23. -- Discrepancies between the original death certificate for Horace Roberts Jr. of Moorestown, which was filed in Camden after his death on June 2, 1929, in the Cooper Hospital, and the copy of the certificate -- supposedly to be an exact one -- on file in Trenton, were revealed today.

BRIDGEPORT, Conn., Feb. 23. -- Cooperation of manufacturers in share-the-work and similar movements to relieve unemployment was urged by Frederick M. Feiker, director of the Bureau of Foreign and Domestic Commerce, in an address to the Connecticut Hardware Association today.

Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee, who resumed his duties at City Hall yesterday after an absence of six weeks, passed largely in Florida, denied a rumor that he would accept any Federal post in the Roosevelt administration.

SAVANNAH. Ga., Feb. 23. -- Jean Tillier of Greenwich, Conn., was wounded seriously yesterday afternoon when a gun in the hands of his host, Charles E. Height of New York City, was discharged accidently while the men were hunting on Mr. Height's preserve near Gillisonville, S. C.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The Boys Club has done a graceful thing in dedicating the fifty-sixth annual report number of its Quarterly to the memory of Mrs. E. H. Harriman, who was instrumental in building the club and supporting it after the death of her husband, who was its founder.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Acting under Instructions from the Japanese Foreign Office, Ambassador Katsuji Debuchi today called on Secretary Stimson to assure the United States that the Japanese military authorities intended to confine their present operations to Jehol Province.

Testifying yesterday in his own defense in the Richmond County Court at St. George, S. I., Harvey Parry, a warrant officer in the United States Coast Guard, who is being tried for the murder of Garnet Brotherton, 26-year-old riding master, on Jan. 31 last, described the events that led to the shooting.

A long friendship and business association ended, yesterday in a murder and suicide. Dominick J. Tierney killed James A. Walsh, wealthy Brooklyn manufacturer, and then committed suicide by cutting his own throat with a razor.

PEIPING, Friday, Feb. 24. -- Governor Tang Yu-lin of Jehol announced today that a Japanese force of 30,000 had launched a fierce onslaught on the city of Chaoyang last night after a three-day bombardment from the air.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 23. -- The spreading of news of the Jehol fighting has made Tientsin a danger centre. Thousands of Chinese, fearful lest defeated Chinese troops retire southward and loot the city, began swarming yesterday into the Japanese concession and other foreign-controlled areas.

A reorganization of the annual championships on a wider national basis was announced last night by the officials of the Indoor Polo Association of America. Under this reorganization, the finals will be played in Chicago late in April, but a comprehensive system of eliminations and sectional championships will precede them in the various centres of the game throughout the country.

At 8 o'clock last night Frances Perkins, State Industrial Commissioner, was still busy at her desk in the marble State Building at 80 Centre Street. With New England caution she refused to admit that she would be Secretary of Labor in the next Cabinet, but --
A net loss of $16,558,500 was shown yesterday in the dally gold

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The text of the Japanese ultimatum to China, handed to Dr. Lo Wen-kan, the Chinese Foreign Minister, by S. Uemura of the Japanese Consulate General in Nanking, and received by the Chinese Legation here, is as follows:

Supreme Court Justice Mitchell May in Brooklyn refused yesterday to enjoin four garment manufacturers and workers associations from, discontinuing business relations with Leonard Pace, a cloak and suit manufacturer, and the Brooklyn Ladies Garment Manufacturers Association, Inc.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 23 (AP). -- A reference to political campaign contributions was projected today into the proceedings involving the former Insurance Commissioner, Joseph I. Reece, accused by the Attorney General's office of stealing $100,000 in bonds from the Insurance Department.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23. -- Prices of wheat on the Board of Trade were slightly higher early today as a result of a sharp bulge in the price of silver and further unfavorable crop comments from the Winter wheat belt, but later they broke with stocks and at the lowest point were s cent a bushel below Tuesday's closing quotations.

While the Michigan banking situation showed some signs of improvement yesterday as business was resumed in that State under drastic restrictions, the security markets chose to reflect Wall Street's somber mood and there was a sharp downward revision of quoted values.

The Most Rev. Pietro Fumasoni-Biondi, who has been the Apostolic Delegate in the United States for the last ten years, arrived yesterday afternoon from Washington, D.C., en route to Rome to receive the red hat of a Cardinal.

This is the epilogue. The comedy was one in which Archibald Stanley Lord, tall West Indian Negro, cabin steward and ship's bugler of the Munson liner Munamar, played no part whatever, save as the dupe of a practical joker.

The wail of the siren and the howl of alarm signals mingling with static are not the only sounds which must be music to the ear of the radio patrolman, in the belief of Patrolmen Gerald O'Connell and William Seubert, crew of a radio car.
Orders Reflect Waiting Attitude.

NEW YORK. The second Knickerbocker Assembly for this season will be held tomorrow night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Many dinners will be given in advance. Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow heads the committee that includes also Mrs. F. Kingsbury Curtis, Mrs. I. N. Phelps Stokes, Mrs. Lyman Delano, Mrs. Adrian V. S. Lambert and Mrs. Thatcher Magoun Brown.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., Feb. 23. -- Death early today ended overtures for reconciliation between Mrs. Daisy Danziger Moreno and her husband, Antonio Moreno, the motion-picture star, when Mrs. Moreno's automobile plunged through the fog and down a 250-foot cliff, killing her instantly.

Thomas James Walsh, four times Senator from Montana and probable Attorney General in the Roosevelt Cabinet, left yesterday for Cuba. Senator Walsh is going to Havana, according to report, to marry Maria Nieves Truffin, known to her intimates as Mina, widow of a banker and sugar grower.

Tammany Hall is attempting to wreak vengeance upon Chief Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions for his independence in the last judiciary campaign, it was charged yesterday by leaders of the bar.

An ex-convict, who, the police say, has admitted making a living since his release from Sing Sing Prison two years ago by swindling newsboys under 12 years old of small sums, was arrested last night at Nostrand and Atlantic Avenues, Brooklyn, by a detective, who said he saw him obtain 53 cents from a 10-year-old newsboy by a ruse.

Dissension in the vestry of All Souls Protestant Episcopal Church, 88 St. Nicholas Avenue, over admitting Negroes to services on equal terms with white parishioners, which resulted in the locking of the church doors for three Sundays in September and October, reached the Supreme Court yesterday.

Although the duck-shooting season is a long way off, the hunter is always interested in conditions affecting wild waterfowl. The latest reports from a fairly wide range of territory indicate that ducks of almost all species have done remarkably well this Winter, thus assuring big flights northward when the Spring comes.

Yesterday's combined statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the system's note circulation to be at a new high figure for the year to date, exceeding the highest figure of 1932, reached last July, and overtopping the high mark reached in any other year since 1921.

It was almost a superhuman performance that Sir MALCOLM CAMPBELL gave when he made his world's record of 272.108 miles an hour. Fame or death was the reward of two runs of about thirteen seconds each. In the white mist that hung over the sands he could see but two seconds ahead.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- The Boerse continued firm today, especially the bond market, where business picked up somewhat. Stocks were quiet, with few exceptions. It is believed that the Reichsbank may lower its discount rate, but there is no certainty, which tended to increase the reserve of the public.

The New York Stock Exchange has received from the American lce Company a notice of a proposed decrease in its authorized preferred stock from 150,000 to 140,000 shares, in its common stock from 600,000 to 560,000, and in its capital represented by outstanding common stock from $25 to $5 a share.

A three-year lease on Dreamland Park, the city-owned ten-acre parking space on the boardwalk at Coney Island, was auctioned off at an annual rent of $23,150 yesterday morning by Park Commissioner Browne at his offices in Prospect Park.

Miss Martha Berry, head of the Berry Schools, Berry, Ga., received yesterday afternoon the Eleanor Van Rensselaer Fairfax Gold Medal for distinguished patriotic service from the National Society of Colonial Dames of the State of New York at exercises held in the society's headquarters, 215 East Seventy-first Street.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Considering we are citizens of a still nominally democratic country, we have recently been using the very undemocratic word "dictator" quite a lot.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Trading was extremely light on the Bourse today and confined almost entirely to speculators. Until the last hour stocks showed some resistance, but at the end general weakness set in, so that closing prices were the lowest of the day.
HAVANA, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Jaz Age, following two disappointing performances, came back today and merely toyed with a field of platers over six furlongs at Oriental Park.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 23. -- While Foreign Minister Koloman Kanya evaded discussion of Hungary's part in the Hirtenberg affair by saying the episode had been closed and that further references to it would therefore be improper, Premier Goemboes endeavored, by a statement to Parliament early this morning, to dispel recent alarming rumors of war dangers In South-east Europe.

Ware in CALVIN COOLIDGE'S county of Hampshire in Massachusetts had a town, meeting the other night. The hall was crammed. The majority of the citizens were bound to cut appropriations for everything except relief work. They got what they wanted.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Abandoning plans for further land speed trials this year, Sir Malcolm Campbell prepared tonight to return to England shortly with the expectation of coming back next Winter in an effort to boost his three newly established world automobile records higher.

Discussion of the proper method of acting on repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was renewed yesterday at Albany.The first plan, embodied in a bill introduced by Senator DUNNIGAN and Assemblyman SARGENT, called for a State convention of thirty delegates from each Senate district.

The origin of $100,000 in counterfeit $100 notes, many of which were successfully passed last month in Chicago, has been traced by Federal agents to Soviet Russia, it was disclosed yesterday at the Federal Building.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Seventy-second Congress is as little respected as any Congress in history, Representative Parks of Arkansas said today as a prelude to a fiery denunciation of the "tumble-bug speech" delivered recently before the Legislature of Missouri by Representative Shannon of that State.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23. -- Their transcontinental jaunt completed, the vanguard of the Giants who had left New York last Sunday and the Cubs who had been their traveling companions from Chicago parted company this morning to settle down to the business of performing their training chores for another pennant campaign.

LONG BEACH, L. I., Feb. 23. -- Wet, weary and cold after a night spent drifting on the Atlantic Ocean in an open boat, Theodore Olsen, 34 years old, a fisherman of Asbury Park, N. J., was picked up at noon today six miles off Long Beach by Coast Guardsmen of the Long Beach station.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Laying the cornerstone of the new Department of Justice Building with a trowel made from the wood and copper nails of the frigate Constitution. President Hoover in a brief speech today declared that "democracy can hope to endure only to the degree that it can find the means of enforcement of its own laws, even against the most entrenched of its own citizens."
CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Friday, Feb. 24 (AP). -- General Nobuyoshi Muto, the Japanese Generalissimo in Manchuria, has begun his long-heralded Jehol campaign.

In the course of his testimony before the Senate Finance Committee, Mr. ALDRICH of the Chase Bank touched upon the place and functions of the banks in helping the country out of the depression. They are to provide and safeguard credit.

Organized labor in New York rallied its forces last night and set up machinery by which it hopes to press through legislation providing State-wide unemployment insurance and establishing a thirty-hour week in industry. Three hundred delegates, representing 212 labor and Socialist units, met at the Rand School under the auspices of the Labor and Socialist Conference.

SCARBOROUGH-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 23. -- Following upon their victory in the international match yesterday the British women squash racquets players continued their sweeping success on American courts today by qualifying all four semifinalists in the New York State championship at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- President Hoover was the guest at dinner tonight of the members of his "Little Cabinet," made up of the Assistant Secretaries of the ten Federal departments, who entertained for him at the Mayflower Hotel and presented to him as a farewell gift the chair from his office in the White House which he has used througnout his administration.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I am chagrined for my own city when I find how splendidly run is another city, Binghamton, in the same State and therefore operating under the same general laws.

Of Senator BORAH it may be said, as we believe it was of CHARLES Fox, that he is often wrong, but when he is right he is incomparable. The Senator's letter denouncing and ridiculing the idea of a "dictatorship within the Constitution" is as fine a piece of political writing as one often sees.

Moving in direct contrast with other comodities, sugar and silver futures advanced sharply in broad markets yesterday on local exchanges. In other markets in the group, coffee was irregular and silk and hides slightly higher, while others followed the general trend into lower ground.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Alter conferring with Governor Lehman, John J. Dunnigan, Democratic leader in the Senate, announced today that he had agreed to make drastic amendments to his bill for setting up State machinery to pass on the repeal amendment to the United States Constitution.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Collections from twenty-nine sources of internal revenue in January were lower than in December, while there were increases in twenty-four items, according to figures issued today by the Internal Revenue Bureau.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Changes in tariff rates, announced by the British Government to become effective Feb. 28, will further restrict some United States exports but will promote the marketing of others in the United Kingdom, according to advices received today by the Department of Commerce from William L. Cooper, commercial attache at London.

Eighteen Manhattan, and Bronx properties were offered at foreclosure auctions yesterday following defaults in mortgage and tax payments. Two of the sales were adjourned, the remaining sixteen properties being struck down to the plaintiffs in the foreclosure actions.

Fixed assets of the U. S. Industrial Alcohol Company, which were carried in the balance sheet as of Dec. 31 last at a net valuation of $19,301,044, will be written down to $1 if stockholders at their meeting on April 20 approve a reduction in stated capital from $22,584,600 to $3,738,460, says the annual report for 1932.

BERLIN, Feb. 23. -- Accounts of the wounding of a man and the burning of an apartment house that left nine families homeless, allegedly by men in Nazi uniforms, appeared in two Berlin newspapers today.

A total of 279,473 families throughout New York State were receiving home and work relief in January, an increase of 33,651, or 13 per cent, over the previous month, it was announcad yesterday by the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

Stuyvesant High School's basketball team defeated Textile High, defending city P.S.A.L. champion, 23 to 19, at Textile yesterday to take the lead in the Lower Manhattan-Richmond division of the P.S.A.L. championship tournament.

BOSTON, Feb. 23. -- The trend among corporations during the last fifteen or eighteen months to write down assets of various kinds has almost approached the proportions of a mass movement, J.M.B. Hoxsey, executive assistant of the committee on stock list of the New York Stock Exchange, said today in an address to the Massachusetts Society of Public Accountants.

Mme. Elsa Scbiaparelli, one of the leading fashion designers in Europe, arrived yesterday from Paris on the Italian liner Conte di Savoia to see the season's fashions here and to visit friends. Mme. Schiaparelli has designed for this season a new dress with a cape effect.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 23. -- President Alessandri of Chile received a detailed statement today on the nitrate industry from the commission of three that is liquidating the Compania de Salitre de Chile (Cosach). World conditions for the sale of the natural nitrate, which Chile has in abundance, and the competition of synthetic nitrates were explained to the President.

Mrs. W. Granville Smith, musician and wife of an artist, died early yesterday morning in Knicker-bocker Hospital of injuries received two hours earlier when she plunged to the street from the fourth floor of an apartment house at 400 West 118th Street, where she had rented a room recently.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

DETROIT, Feb. 23. -- An exciting last period after two scoreless sessions brought the Detroit Red Wings a 3-to-0 victory over the New York Rangers and an undisputed hold on first place in the American division of the National Hockey League tonight.

There was no change in electric power production last week after allowance for the usual seasonal decline. The seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Feb. 18 was 207,700,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 218,300,000 kilowatt-hours in the corresponding week last year, when a sharp decline from the preceding week occurred.

HAVANA, Feb. 23. -- The interruption of telephone and government telegraph line, communication between Havana and widely separated districts of Cuba at about the same hour tonight leads to the belief here that new outbreaks are imminent.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. --After days of effort, Senate Democrats today accomplished a saving of 1 per cent in Senate expenditures -- then in a moment wiped it out by adding to its funds for 1934 more than the amount just lopped off.

Chairman FARLEY appeared at the Washington's Birthday dinner of the Broome County Democratic organization in the guise of a reformer. He urged his followers to seek simplification of county government, in the interest of economy.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The American press exposes with commendable zeal the oppressive methods of the Hitler-Hugenberg-Papen government against the Opposition. The flimsiest pretext serves as an excuse for the ruthless suppression of republican and labor newspapers, campaign activities are gagged, and only recently has there been a concerted attack on the Catholic trade unions, whose hostility the government views with increasing anxiety.

Large potash deposits in New Mexico recently discovered by United States geologists now have reached a stage of production which makes the United States completely independent of any foreign potash for the first time in its history, it was reported yesterday at the closing sessions of the Winter convention of the American Institute of Mining and Metallurgical Engineers by H. I. Smith of the United States Geological Survey.

Wall Street was in a pessimistic frame of mind yesterday as the reaction in security prices continued. Active pressure against the stock and bond markets reflected the prevalent nervousness, but it was apparent to brokers that liquidation was being augmented by speculative selling for the decline.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial comment on the limited appeal to students not only of the classics but also of the exact sciences takes no account of the fact that this limitation applies only proportionately to the total number of students in college.

All sections of the listed bond market were hard hit yesterday. Major losses in domestic corporation issues ranged from 1 to 6 points; in foreign loans, from 1 to more than 4 points, and in most of the United States Government bonds more than a full point.

READING, Pa., Feb. 23. -- Scoring 24 out of 25 flyers in a high wind, George W. Hansell, veteran Lebanon wing shot, today won the Grand American Amateur Flier Classic, featuring the second and final day's program of the mid-winter trap-shooting tournament of the South End Gun Club.

HYDE PARK, N. Y., Feb. 23 (AP). -- In the seclusion of the family estate on the Hudson River, President-elect Roosevelt is scanning the Democratic list for the multitude of men and women he must pick to take over key positions in the government on March 4.

The British Board of Trade's annual calculations of the balance of payments in Great Britain's foreign trade, visible and invisible, are always studied with interest. Circumstances make particularly significant the findings cabled yesterday, covering the account for 1932.
LONDON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

The efforts to reorganize and revive minor league baseball in the East are bearing fruit in three separate directions, George Weiss, general manager of the New York Yankees' fast-growing "farm" system, told The Associated Press yesterday.

With only twenty-nine seconds of the overtime session remaining, Nick Wasnie, the New York Americans busy right wing, sent a scorching high shot past Davey Kerr, goalkeeper for the Montreal Maroons, to give the star-spangled skaters a 2-1 victory over their adversaries in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Closing strongly in the stretch, the Warm Stable's Sabula, quoted at 9 to 2, romped home a half length in front of Marie Jean to win the six-furlong feature for 3-year-olds at the Fair Grounds today.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 23. -- Democratic leaders in the Senate turned their attention today from the Cabinet to the knotty problem of assigning honors when the Senate passes into their party control after March 4.

DENVER, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Claude K. Boettcher, father of kidnapped Charles Boettcher 2d, threw the power of his millions today behind his personal promise to pay the demanded $60,000 ransom on condition that his son be returned to him unharmed by midnight Saturday.

William H. Woodin, named by President-elect Roosevelt on Tuesday to be the next Secretary of the Treasury, embarked yesterday upon the task of familiarizing himself with his new duties by conferring with Ogden L. Mills, the present Secretary.
WITH Johnny Risko and King Levinsky coming up to what will be, if there are no serious objections, their third and last meeting, it may be in order to point out certain things in heavyweight history.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23 (AP). -- With long pointer in hand and a huge chart labeled the "Spider Web of Wall Street" as his subject. Senator Norris today lectured his colleagues on interlocking directorates.
PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 23. -- Relatives of John R. Fell declared today the theory that he committed suicide in a hotel room in Java, was wholly unconvincing to them.
Farewell Address Contents. What was the principal danger against which our first President warned his countrymen in the famous Farewell Address?

When resolutions were introduced at the annual meeting last night of the City College chapter of Phi Beta Kappa based on policies of the Board of Higher Education and of college authorities, Dr. Frederick B. Robinson, president of the college, officiating as president of the chapter, characterized the proceedings as "outrageous" and quit the chair.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- James C. Stone, who has been chairman of the Federal Farm Board since the resignation of Alexander Legge, today tendered his resignation to President Hoover, effective March 4. In his letter to the President he urged that the board should be allowed to continue its functions in building up cooperative marketing.

Thursday, Feb. 23, 1938. Money market developed no change in quotations or conditions over the holiday. Federal funds and outside trades on call loans were done at 1 per cent, which was also the Stock Exchange charge. Time money continued on a nominal basis so far as quotations were concerned, while business was extremely light.

To assist banks throughout the country to meet withdrawals of currency prompted by the banking difficulties in Michigan and elsewhere, the Federal Reserve System pumped out $215,000,000 of additional credit in the week ended on Tuesday, it was revealed in the weekly report, published yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- Francis P. Garvan, president of the Chemical Foundation, struck an international trade balance between the United States and the rest of the world to show the Senate economy inquiry committee today that this country, instead of having had a favorable trade balance for ten years has actually had an unfavorable balance, or been "in the red" to the sum $4,545,000,000.

Severe declines in United States Government bonds yesterday held the attention of the financial community far more than did the substantial losses in other departments of the securities markets. Specialists in the government's bonds reported that at times bids for them were utterly lacking.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 23 (AP). -- District Attorney Buron Fitts said today that a new investigation into the death of Paul Bern, film executive and husband of Jean Harlow, screen star, had been completed, and that he was convinced Mr. Bern had taken his own life.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 23. -- Miss Diana Fishwick, former British tltleholder, stands out as the lone survivor of the group of invading English players as the result of the second-round matches for the South Atlantic championship at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

GENEVA, Feb. 23. -- The League council's committee of three on South American wars began this morning its conciliatory efforts in the Leticia dispute between Colombia and Peru, under Article XV, paragraph 3 of the League Covenant. The committee intends to allow no delays as in the Manchurian clash between China and Japan, but swiftly to recommend strong action against Peru under paragraph 4, if her attitude made efforts fruitless.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- A favorite target for taxes, the motorist gets out from under part of the burden when he files his Federal income tax return.
"Hangman's Whip," a melodrama by Norman Reilly Raine and Frank Butler, will have its Broadway premiere this evening at the St. James Theatre.

Harry Schwartz, Republican inspector during the last election, took the witness stand yesterday in his own defense to deny before Federal Judge John C. Knox that he or Jack Pleva, Democratic inspector, indicted with him, had reached any agreement or had participated in any scheme to turn in a false count of votes in the Sixth Election District of the Fourth Assembly District.

ALBANY, Feb. 23. -- Governor Lehman submitted his supplemental budget of $373,567 to the Legislature today as the Senate Finance Committee reported favorably on a bill to impose a retail sales tax, as recommended by the Governor.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 23 (AP). -- Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago received intravenous injections of 10 per cent glucose, a food substance, today in an effort to build up his strength, sapped by an assassin's bullet and an attack of colitis. Three and one-half pints of glucose were injected in two treatments for nourishment, Dr. Karl Meyer, chief of the Mayor's medical staff, announced.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Prophets of evil have been flinging the word "revolution" at us a bit carelessly of late. Even members of the United States Senate are engaging in the pastime. One Of them, easily identified by his habit of wading against the stream in order to make a ripple, exclaimed, a few days ago: "Mr. President, there's already a revolution here."

MIAMA, Fla., Feb. 23. -- E. R. Bradley's Broad Meadows, 9-to-10 favorite in the Redland Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today, scored his third victory of the meeting when he was first past the judges at the end of the seven furlongs.

ALBANY, Feb. 23 (AP). -- Hilarious gibes which soared no one and found an especial target in President-elect Roosevelt and former Governor Alfred E. Smith, both of whom were present, were served up tonight at the annual dinner of the Albany Legislative Correspondents Association.

The transfer of three officers of the United States and American Merchant Lines, to become effective during the next three months, was announced yesterday by A. J. McCarthy, general manager of the Roosevelt Steamship Company, operator of the lines.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 23. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission was urged in an examiner's report today to dismiss the complaint of the Nassau County Village Association, which alleged that the refusal of the Pennsylvania Railroad to establish through passenger routes and reasonable joint fares between points on the Long Island Railroad and on lines of the Pennsylvania and its connecting lines in New England was unduly prejudicial to residents of Long Island and New England.

PARIS, Feb. 23. -- Premier Daladier, his principal collaborators and leaders of the French parties spent most of the day in negotiations to bring about a compromise between the Senate and Chamber of Deputies over the March budget, which the upper house returned with important alterations.

Members of the Imperial Russian nobility and other prominent Russians here have been lending their support to preparations for the second annual Russian Carnival, to be held tonight in the Fourteenth Street Armory. The event is under the auspices of the United Russian Committee and its proceeds will aid the philanthropic work of seven Russian charitable agencies.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- The process of enforcing silence upon opponents while the German people are bludgeoned into acceptance of National Socialist domination advanced another step today with the issuance of a formal order, forecast last week and then officially denied, authorizing the arming of Nazi storm troopers and Stahlhelm members and their use as "auxiliary police."

Central Illinois Public Service. The annual report of the Central Illinois Public Service Company for 1932 shows a net profit of $1,780,062 after depreciation, charges and ordinary taxes, subject to the adequacy of the provision for depreciation and to the fact that no provision has been made for Federal taxes, as the company will claim deductions additional to those shown in the report.

Although there were reactions in sugar and silver after the sharp rallies of the preceding day, the general tone of yesterday's local commodities markets was one of steadiness. The feature news of the day was the sale of Farm Board coffee.

Fortunate it is that the temple in Jehol built in commemoration of "three joyous happenings," one of which was the return of the Tartar tribe to the care of the Emperor (told to millions of school children by DE QUINCEY), has been preserved in an accurate reproduction.

WINNIPEG, Man., Feb. 24. -- Peeping out of the low green tent erected in a field near Fargo, N.D. Bernt Balchen, my pilot, and I watched the cold dawn this morning expand to daylight. We are making tests of the equipment to be used in the Antarctic next December, when we expect to fly from the Ross Sea to Weddell Sea and return, non-stop.

Pierre Gustave Toutant-Beaure-gard, who was known in the South for a little while after he had ordered the firing on Fort Sumter as "the great Creole," is the subject of a full-length biography by Hamilton Basso which has just been published by the Scribners under the title "Beauregard, the Great Creole.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- A movement to bar from committee assignments the four Republican Senators who supported Franklin D. Roosevelt in the last election was announced tonight by Senator Reed, who said that he would lay the proposal before the Republican caucus after March 4.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- Total gross revenues for motor-bus operations throughout the country during 1932 were only 5.7 per cent smaller than those in 1931, according to statistics compiled by the magazine "Bus Transportation." The amount for 1932 was $292,250,000, compared with $310,000,000 in 1931.

Dun's and Bradstreet's, the two most expensive credit-rating agencies in the world, are to be consolidated. Although Arthur Whiteside, president of R.G. Dun Co., who is expected to be president of the merged company, emphatically denied that he had confirmed reports to this effect current yesterday, it was learned that announcement of the deal would be made on Monday.

GLEN COVE, L.I., Feb. 24. -- Nicholas J. Tiffany, the son of Mr. and Mrs. George Tiffany of St. Louis, who broke his neck nearly two years ago when he dived into an empty swimming pool at night, died today in the house on the Pratt estate here where he had lived with his mother ever since the accident.

Mayor John P. O'Brien has served quiet notice on the employes not protected by civil service in his office that their tenure will expire on March 1, it was revealed yesterday. Since the new Mayor took office, his personal staff has had two changes.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 24. -- Visiting net stars from England and the United States went through their first-round matches without difficulty today as the annual championship of the Bermuda Lawn Tennis Club got under way.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- A measure setting up machinery for a special election on creation of a commission to revise the New York City charter and others amending present statutes were introduced today by Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, New York Republican.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Governor Lehman sent a special message to the Senate and Assembly today sounding a friendly warning against any attempt at dealing piecemeal with his executive budget and tax program and declaring that the whole picture must be considered in any changes that the Legislature may decide to make.

The Julien Levy Gallery at 602 Madison Avenue placed on view yesterday afternoon a group of drawings by the young Russian artist, Pavel Tchelitchew, which will be shown until March 18. Although virtually a newcomer, Tchelitchew is not entirely unknown here.

ROANOKE, Va., Feb. 24 (AP). -- Joe Bryant, 19, and Norman Harvey 26, obtained their liberty, under bond, and the government was given additional time for investigation by an agreement today deferring until July 3 the hearing of the two men and Harvey's wife Elsie on charges in connection with an attempt to extort $50,000 from Colonel Charles A. Lindbergh, by threats against his second son.

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- The stock market showed a little less pessimism today and prices improved slightly, with the exception of the South African gold mining shares, which PARIS, Feb. 24 declined as a result of concerted profit taking. Wall Street's weakness yesterday apparently had little influence on the Bourse.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 24. -- The Dartmouth chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, national scholastic society, initiated twenty-five seniors to membership today and conferred honorary memberships on five graduates of the college.

The Bowery Savings Bank, as plaintiff, bought in the vacant plot measuring 116 by 130 feet at the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Fortieth Street at foreclosure auction yesterday. The property was sold to satisfy a judgment of $1,058,779 obtained against Samuel D. Leidesdorf and others.

Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial has notified the Queens Sewer Bureau to discontinue the practice of "maintaining house-connection drains between curbs" and let plumbers do such work. Mr. Prial said yesterady that notification had followed investigation by engineers of the Bureau of Municipal Investigation and Statistics of the Controller's office into a complaint made by J.F. Harrington, field secretary of the Master Plumbers of the Rockaways.

LONDON. Feb. 24. -- The first question asked here following the Japanese withdrawal from the League of Nations Assembly today was: "Will the Japanese representatives continue to attend the disarmament conference?" It is reported in Tokyo they will, and this, in the opinion of London newspapers, is "most desirable."

Celebration on Feb. 12 of 100 years of British occupation of the Falkland Islands was not allowed to pass without retelling the story of the sea fight in which Admiral STURDEE sank all but one of the ships of Admiral VON SPEE. That naval action made the Falklands historically important as the "outpost colony."

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- Business on the Boerse was quiet today and prices declined slightly. A little ground was recovered in a late rally. Traders were watching with disappointment the developments in the business world. Weakness in dollar exchange inspired bears.

It is not surprising that the appointment of Representative DOUGLAS of Arizona to the important post of Director of the Budget in the Roosevelt Administration has been widely praised. No member of either branch of Congress has shown a keener understanding of the problems involved in balancing the national budget or greater insistence in demanding their solution.

While the Board of Elections continued yesterday its recanvass of the vote cast at the last election, the happenings at the polls that day were being described in indictments and the records of Federal court.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Attorney General Mitchell today began an investigation to determine if Federal statutes had been violated by certain operations, admitted in testimony at the inquiry of the Senate Banking and Currency Committee into stock-market trading and Insull utilities transactions, of banks, investment securities companies and utility corporations.
NEW YORK. Miss Marion Rumsey Cartier, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Pierre C. Cartier, will give a dinner tonight at the Embassy Club.

William Woodward, chairman of the stewards of the Jockey Club, governing body of the turf in this State, announced yesterday that all of the racing associations in New York will be closed if the Breitenbach bill, which proposes a tax of $1,000 per race, equaling $6,000 a day, is passed at Albany.

Jungle melodrama having been ordered, Norman Reilly Raine and Frank Butler have given their all in "Hangman's Whip," which was acted at the St. James last evening. From foul conversation to the ceremonial tom-tom it is all there in the proper order.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- President-elect Roosevelt will not present his program for economic recovery in his inaugural address except in the most general terms, it was learned today, but will reserve it for his message to the special session of Congress which he will call soon after his inauguration.

New York Central. The New York Central Railroad reported a profit and loss surplus of $238,624,521 on Dec. 31, against $267,691,835 a year previously. Unadjusted debits were $10,176,536, against $27,681,908. Total assets were $1,825,367,729, against $1,837,729,280.

The spread of knowledge and the development of individual beliefs have made virtually impossible for human beings to maintain the friendly intimacy that was common to past generations, according to Dr. Harry Stark Sullivan, who discussed maladjustment yesterday at the tenth annual meeting of the American Orthopsychiatric Association.

AMHERST, Mass., Feb. 24. -- The Massachusetts State College basketball team, displaying an accurate shooting attack and a well high impregnable defense, took the measure of the Harvard quintet tonight by 32 to 18. State led, 19 -- 13, at half time.
LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The worst blizzard in memory swept Western England today, adding fresh perils and discomforts to a country already snowbound in the north and southeast.

The basic tax rate for 1933 was announced yesterday as $2.33 per $100 of assessed valuation, twentysix points less than in 1932. Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial, who gave out the figure, said it was the lowest in the last thirteen years.

The conclusions and recommendations of the National Transportation Committee represented "a valuable and statesmanlike contribution toward the solution of a most important and difficult national problem," Henry Bruere, president of the Bowery Savings Bank and chairman of the railroad committee of the National Association of Mutual Savings Banks, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The Celler bill, removing restrictions from physicians' liquor prescriptions, was generally approved during discussion in the House late today, but a formal vote was delayed until tomorrow, when Representative Blanton of Texas, an ardent dry, demanded that the engrossed bill be read for final passage.

Official heads of both the Metropolitan Opera and Real Estate Company and the Metropolitan Opera Association made informal presentations to Giulio Gatti-Casazza yesterday of the first of many gifts and testimonials planned in honor of his twenty-fifth year as general manager of New York's opera.
GENEVA, Feb. 24. -- The text of the resolution adopted today by the League of Nations Assembly concerning the Chino-Japanese dispute is as follows:

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24. -- Climaxing ten months of cotroversy, Mayor Moore today summarily dismissed Kern Dodge from his post as Director of Public Safety following Mr. Dodge's refusal of a request to resign "for the good of the public service."

The annual St. Valentine Kettledrum in aid of the Samaritan Home for the Aged attracted many to the Plaza yesterday afternoon. It was held in the ballroom suite and there were attractions suitable for all ages, from young children to their grandmothers.

MANILA, Feb. 24. -- The tentative naming of the Roosevelt Cabinet creates a curious paradox In Philippine affairs since the three Senators included in it voted to override President Hoover's veto of the Hawes bill for Philippine freedom, while Daniel C. Roper testified at tariff hearings on behalf of Cuban sugar.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Assuming that the approaching Anglo-American debt negotiations depend largely on the trade between the two countries, The London Economist tomorrow will present statistics on these commercial transactions for the five-year period ending with December, 1932.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. , 24. -- Augeas, 5-year-old brown gelding owned by Mrs. H.M. Parks, paid the longest price of the Jockey Club meeting, $840 for $2, in the pari-mutuels today when he beat Tack by a nose at a mile and a sixteenth.

A sold-out house, the first this season for "Manon," will greet the American tenor, Richard Crooks, when he makes his debut this afternoon in Massenet's opera at the Metropolitan. A nation-wide radio audience, which has become acquainted with the tenor's singing in his frequent broadcasts, also will hear the entire opera.

The Bruckner Society's Mahler medal was presented to Bruno Walter yesterday after the conductor's repetition of Gustav Mahler's Second Symphony at the Philharmonic matinee. The medal bore a German inscription signifying "My time will yet come."

SHANGHAI, Feb. 24. -- The Chinese reluctantly made the belated official admission today that the NanlingPehpiao region of Jehol had been evacuated and also conceded that they had withdrawn from Chaoyang all except the rear guard of the 107th Brigade.

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- Japan's attitude toward Manchuria as "an integral part of Chinese territory," was, according to French diplomatic documents just published, one of the principal causes in the Japanese version of the Russo-Japanese War of 1904.

HAVANA, Feb. 24. -- Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana arrived here at 10:30 o'clock this morning aboard a Fan-American Airways plane to marry Senora Mina Perez Chautmont de Truffin, a prominent society woman, in Havana on Monday.
GENEVA, Feb. 24. -- The text of the statement made today before the Assembly of the League of Notions by Dr. V.K. Wellington Koo, a member of the Chinese delegation, follows:

Compacts for interstate regulation of the transmission of electricity and gas are being formulated for study and submission to New York and adjoining States, it was announced yesterday following the second meeting of the New York State Commission on Interstate Transmission of Power with representatives of Massachusetts, Connecticut, Vermont, Pennsylvania and New Jersey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Debate on the bankruptcy reform bill, a major measure urged by President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt, was finally begun in the Senate today, but without reference to relief for railroads and other corporations.

SCHENECTADY, Feb. 24. -- To the accompaniment of the clicks of cosmic rays, amplified to such a degree that they might be heard by radio listeners everywhere, Professor Arthur H. Compton of the University of Chicago summarized tonight the investigations carried on to date by Professor Robert Millikan, Sir James Jeans, Dauvillier, Abbe Lemaitre, himself and others.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- The Mayors or other representatives of the leading cities of the State gave a pledge today to Governor Lehman to support unemployment relief to the limit of the financial resources of their municipalities.

The Nashville, Chattanooga St. Louis Railway has leased new freight offices on the twenty-ninth floor of 500 Fifth Avenue at Forty-second Street, Albert B. Ashforth, Inc., the broker, reported yesterday. The lessee is now in 225 Broadway.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A former Attorney General has written a considered opinion to the effect that the machinery for the State conventions to be called to ratify the Twenty-first Amendment should be established by Congress. The Attorney General-about-to-be, according to press dispatches, has given as his informal opinion that the machinery must be set up by the several States.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Radio-telephone service was started today between the United States and Panama with talks between Secretary Stimson and Juan Demostenes Arosemena, the Foreign Minister of Panama.
UNIVERSITY, Va., Feb. 24 (AP). -- Seven technical knockouts were registered today at the opening session of the Southern Conference boxing tournament of the fourteen bouts fought.

The increase of public confidence in commercial night flying was described last night by aviation authorities who spoke at a dinner given by the Newark Junior Chamber of Commerce to promote the use by business executives of the Newark Metropolitan Airport, now the busiest air station in the world.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Dr. Sao-Ke Alfred Sze, the new Minister from China, presented his credentials to President Hoover today and stressed the importance of continued cordial relations between the two countries. He made no direct reference to the present controversy in Manchuria.

In anticipation of the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, the directors of Canada Dry Ginger Ale, Inc., one of the largest manufacturers of soft drinks in this country, have authorized the incorporation of a new subsidiary which will act as manufacturers' agent and wholesaler of ales, wines and hard liquors if the selling of these beverages is legalized.
New York University and City College were the scenes of insurgent activities by students yesterday in protest against administrative actions involving alleged infractions of students' rights.

A lens for concentrating cosmic ray electrons with energies of 100,000,000 volts by the application of electric current of only 100,000 volts and to "provide a source of radiation of convenient strength for use in experiments" was described yesterday before the meeting of the American Physical Society at Columbia University by Dr. W.F.G. Swann, director of the Bartol Research Foundation of the Franklin Institute, Swarthmore, Pa., and his associate Dr. W.E. Danforth Jr.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24. -- Harvard's varsity swimming team won its fifth straight dual meet in the indoor athletic building tonight, conquering Brown University, 47 to 24.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- An assertion that the Treasury is inconsistent in maintaining that the Liberty Loan act prevents the conversion of large bonds covering the war debts into small marketable bonds, was made by Francis P. Garvan, head of the Chemical Foundation, in a statement filed with the Senate Finance Committee today to support his testimony of the day before.

Federal Judge Francis G. Caffey dismissed yesterday a suit brought by the Middletown Combined Buildings Company, Inc., and Edward Quittner, owner and operator, respectively, of two theatres in Middletown, N.Y., against the Paramount Publix Corporation and other defendants to recover alleged damages of $5,130,000 sought under the anti-trust laws.

All classifications of bonds on the Stock Exchange won back yesterday in heavy trading part of the previous day's extreme losses. United States Government bonds led the recovery, with net gains for the day of 10-32 to 1 12-32 points. Two of the three issues of Treasury 3 3/8s closed exactly at par, the third issue, due in 1943, callable in 1941, finished at 99 22-32.

Strife among the members and officials of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers Local 3 broke out yesterday and two members of the union were shot down in the local headquarters at 130 East Twenty-fifth Street. A business agent of the union described as a "muscleman" is charged with the shooting and two others are being sought.

TUCSON, Ariz., Feb. 24. -- Mrs. John C. Greenway, 46, Democratic national committeewoman for Arizona, announced today her candidacy to succeed Representative Lewis W. Douglas, who will relinquish his post March 4 to become Director of the Budget.

D. Walker Wear, Binghamton Democrat, has been appointed to succeed James A. Farley on the State Athletic Commission governing professional boxing and wrestling in this State. For some time it has been understood in political circles that Mr. Wear would get the appointment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Senate investigators today heard evidence tending to show that the National City Bank of New York, forbidden by law to deal in its own securities, advanced credit for the purchase of its stock through a brokerage house.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Stimulants were administered tonight to Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago to sustain the action of his flagging heart, weakened by an assassin's bullet and the strain of a colitis attack.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- German business remains fairly stable at a low level, but unemployment is smaller than a year ago, the Department of Commerce said today in its weekly summary of business conditions abroad.

HACKENSACK, N.J., Feb. 24. -- Mrs. Ella A. Boole, president of the Women's Christian Temperance Union, denounced the passage of the prohibition repeal resolution by Congress at the Woman's Club auditorium here tonight under the protection of a police guard, headed by the city's chief.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- The text of the statement which Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's senior delegate, made before the Assembly of the League of Nations today immediately after the adoption of the report teas made public by the Japanese Embassy as follows:

To the Editor of The New York Times: The question of the so-called war debts has hitherto been discussed mainly from two standpoints: the effect of cancellation or reduction on trade, and international goodwill. I venture to submit that responsible statesmen in all countries have wholly or largely lost sight of another consideration to which public attention should be seriously directed.

A group of about eighteen students, reported to have been playing dice, were held up by four gunmen and forced to disrobe yesterday afternoon in a washroom of the Biology Building of Fordham University, 200 feet from the busy intersection of Fordham Road and Washington Avenue, the Bronx.

GENEVA, Feb. 24. -- The Assembly of the League of Nations in a solemn session this morning passed judgment unanimously against Japan in her conflict with China and at the same time made to Japan a standing offer for a peaceful solution.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The first of the departmental estimates on which the British budget for the year ending in March, 1934, will be based were presented in the House of Commons today. They fell far short of the desires and expectations of those Conservatives who have organized themselves into non-official committees for compelling economy.

WASHINGTON. Feb. 24. -- The attitude of the United States toward the action of the League of Nations in the Chino-Japanese controversy today is expected to become known after a conference at the State Department tomorrow between Secretary Stimson and Cordell Hull, Secretary of State-designate in the Roosevelt Cabinet.

The Association of the Bar of the City of New York acted quickly yesterday to file its protest against the so-called "ripper bill," which leading lawyers have charged is aimed at Presiding Justice Frederic Kernochan of the Court of Special Sessions.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Heads of the leading life insurance companies and savings banks in the State will attend a conference here tomorrow for discussion of the plight of the home owner and farmer hard pressed to meet mortgages.

An illuminated manuscript on vellum of "Tam o' Shanter and Other Poems," by Robert Burns, brought $2,500 last night at the National Art Galleries, Inc., at the auction of rare books from the library of Joseph William Walton, St. David's, Pa., and other collectors.
Johnny Risko, Cleveland's ring veteran, may be nearing the end of the fistic trail but he still has enough skill left to give some of the present-day boxers cards and spades and beat them.

Alexander F. Whitney, chairman of the Railway Labor Executives Association, conferred yesterday with William H. Woodin, the next Secretary of the Treasury, on various phases of the railroad situation.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Broadening of extradition treaties so that persons wanted in this country for use of the mails to defraud may be returned here for prosecution was sought today by Attorney General Mitchell. The Attorney General asked Secretary Stimson to make representations to foreign countries aiming to include fraudulent use of the mails among extraditable offenses.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 24. -- The Man o' War gelding Sea Fox, owned by J.F. Somerville, led from start to finish of the Panacea Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today, to score his third victory of the meeting. In seven starts since the beginning of the season the 5-year-old never has been out of the money.

In an effort to maintain their engineering staffs with funds set aside for unemployment relief, representatives of the various Borough Presidents conferred yesterday with Welfare Commissioner Frank J. Taylor and Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial on the possibility of paying their employes with unemployment relief money.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 24 (UP). -- The White Motor Company has withdrawn a plan of consolidation with the newly formed United Truck Corporation after a minority stockholder of White Motor had "threatened to tie up" the merger program by litigation.

ALBANY, Feb. 24. -- Governor Lehman transmitted to the Senate and Assembly today a communication, from Secretary Stimson giving notice that the Seventy-second Congress had adopted a joint resolution "relating to the Eighteenth Amendment."

Tallulah Bankhead's return to the New York stage has been postponed another two days. The office of Arch Selwyn announced yesterday that her play, "Forsaking All Others," would open at the Times Square Theatre next Wednesday night instead of Monday-evening, as earlier planned. Thomas Mitchell Is now redirecting the play.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "Whither Japan?" is perfect. It is fair and just and hits the nail on the head. What a pity it cannot be cabled to Tokyo and placed in the hands of every Cabinet Minister. It Is indeed regrettable to feel what a mistake Japan is making in not stopping for a moment to think.

The statement delivered yesterday to the League of Nations Assembly by Yosuke Matsuoka, Japanese delegate, before the report of the Committee of Nineteen was voted upon, was given out by the Japanese Consulate General hen as follows:

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 24. -- William Harold Terry, the man from Memphis, today officially inaugurated his first complete baseball campaign as pilot of the New York Giants with a workout that lasted three hours.

HAVANA, Feb. 24. -- Despite extra precautions taken by the military authorities, Cuba's national holiday, the Grito de Baire, the anniversary of the beginning of the War of Independence, was ushered in with the explosion of bombs in Havana which officials believe to indicate a renewal of Terroristic activities.

ROME, Feb. 24. -- The Chamber of Deputies today hailed Premier Mussolini as the victor over the combined forces of France, England and the Little Entente in the diplomatic battle precipitated by the shipment of Italian rifles to Hirtenberg, Austria.

TOKYO, Saturday, Feb. 25. -- The adoption by the League of Nations Assembly of the recommendations of the Committee of Nineteen has not created much of a sensation here, because it has long been rec- ognized as inevitable. Interest is now centring on how the government means to carry out its decision to quit the League.

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- The extreme gravity of the decision of the League of Nations Assembly against Japan was not minimized here today. There is deep regret in the comments that such a great power as Japan should have been forced to this pass and that the League, too, should have been inexorably driven to take the present stand.

Spring styles, created by French couturieres and brought here by the leading specialty houses and garment manufacturers to be copied for the new season, feature a number of new fabrics and details. These models were received on the Bremen, which arrived this week, and were viewed yesterday.

SYDNEY, Australia, Saturday, Feb. 25 (Canadian Press). -- England had scored 253 runs for the loss of three wickets by lunch time today in its first innings of the fifth and final cricket match against Australia. There is nothing at stake in this match as England won the "Ashes" last week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- On this day, which closes an era in the relationship of Japan with the machinery set up at Geneva by Western nations for preserving the peace of the world, there is not to be found in Washington one responsible public man who talks, thinks or even contemplates the possibility of war between the United States and Japan.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Rich in tradition, but stripped of the elaborate detail, furnishings and decorations which have made it nationally famous for nearly a century, the Yale junior promenade was danced tonight in Woolsey Hall by some 600 couples.

The purchase by Charles F. Williams of Cincinnati, president of the Western and Southern Life Insurance Company, of a "Portrait of a Young Girl," by Peter Paul Rubens was announced yesterday by the New house Galleries.

The proposal to give the President broad and extraordinary powers in the reorganization of the Federal Government for economy and efficiency was hailed yesterday as "highly desirable" by John Jay Hopkins, Assistant to the Secretary of the Treasury, in an address before the Women's National Republican Club in the clubhouse at 8 East Thirty-seventh Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 (AP). -- A campaign against the depression "as we fought the war" was urged upon the Senate Finance Committee today by J. David Stern, editor and publisher of The Philadelphia Record and The Camden (N.J.) Courier-Post.

The East Sixty-eighth Street German Reformed Evangelical Church, 355 East Sixty-eighth Street, of which the Rev. Julius Jaeger is the pastor, will celebrate its 175th birthday tomorrow. At a service at 3:30 P.M. a Bible from President von Hindenburg of Germany will be presented by Dr. Otto C. Kiep, the German Consul General in New York.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 24 (AP). -- Bobsled, one of E.R. Bradley's Kentucky Derby nominees, won the first victory of his career today when he defeated a field of maiden 3-year-olds over one mile at the Fair Grounds.

Gold transactions reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank consisted of an increase of $15,695,300 in earmarkings for foreign account, exports of $3,093,803, imports of $1,184,000 received at New York and an import of $494,000 from China received at San Francisco.

An investigation into the income for 1929 of Charles E. Mitchell, chairman of the board of the National City Bank and its affiliate, the National City Company, was begun here yesterday by George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney. The inquiry was ordered as a result of revelations before a Senate subcommittee on Banking and Currency in its investigation of stock market operations.

DENVER, Feb. 24 (AP). -- A tense atmosphere pervaded the home of Claude K. Boettcher, wealthy Coloradan, and police headquarters as the "zero hour" for the return of Charles Boettcher 2d by his kidnappers grew nearer tonight.

Guarded Senate Portals. What is the principal function of a doorkeeper in the United States Senate? In a mighty effort to cut expenses that august body has just reduced the number of doorkeepers from thirty-eight to thirty.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 24. -- Slight earth tremors continue to shake northern towns near Iquique and Arica, where an earthquake caused panic yesterday after prolonged underground rumbles and an unusual thunderous roar from the sea.

SCARBOROUGH - ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 24, -- For the third successive time. Miss Susan Noel. British and United States squash racquets champion, and Miss Cicely Fenwick, former English titleholder, will meet in the final round of an American tournament tomorrow.

Amendment of the multiple dwelling law to permit occupancy for rooming-house purposes of buildings of over six stories and more than fifteen rooms would create new construction and alteration work in this city, according to Morris Whinston, architect and engineer, who announced yesterday that he had suggested the proposed change in the law in letters to Governor Lehman and Assembly leaders.
John Masefield, poet laureate of England, and Mrs. Masefield will sail this evening for home on the White Star liner Majestic. Also on board will be Sir John Childs, Lady Gorrell and the following:

Another capacity crowd of 17,000 is expected at Madison Square Garden tonight when one of the finest fields ever assembled indoors gathers for the forty-fifth annual American track and field championships.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Edwin R. Hopkins Jr. of this city is to receive half of the $90,000 residuary estate of his mother, Mrs. Cornelia D. Hopkins, outright and the interest from the other half during his lifetime, the principal of the trust to go to the White Plains Lodge, F. and A.M., upon his death, according to a settlement of the Hopkins will controversy filed in Surrogate's Court here today.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Calling on the Roman Catholic Church in the United States to "contribute to the best ideals of this government," Archbishop Fumasoni-Biondi, retiring Apostolic Delegate here, bade farewell to Washington today.

ITHACA, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- Roger Butler Williams, president of the First National Bank of Ithaca and the Ithaca Savings Bank, died at his home here late this afternoon of heart disease. He had been in poor health for two weeks. He was in his eighty-fifth year.

Protests against enactment of a retail sales tax were received from merchants in thirty-two cities of the State at a meeting of the tax committee of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York held yesterday at Bloomingdale Brothers. Michael Schaap, president of Bloomingdale's, and chairman of the tax committee, presided.

Friday, Feb. 24, 1933. The money market was quiet and firm throughout the day. Federal checks and outside trades on call loans were arranged at 3/4 @1 percent, most of the business at the outside figure. The Stock Exchange rate remained at 1.

BROWNSVILLE, Texas, Feb. 24 (AP). -- A police theory that a young student flier had slain his instructor during a practice flight to obtain possession of an airplane for use by a gang of robbers led today to the detention of twelve men.
The Bronx Hockey Club went into a tie for first place in the New York Amateur League at the Coliseum last night when it overwhelmed the New York A.C. sextet, 9 to 2.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 24. -- Yale won from the Penn Military College basketball team tonight, 44 to 33, in a sensational game marked by many changes in the lead and five ties. Yale gradually went ahead late in the second half after the count had been tied at 29-all.

A fashion show, tea and entertainment, at which members of the Junior League and young matrons will be manikins, will be held at the Hotel Plaza Monday, it was announced yesterday by the New York Protestant Episcopal City Mission Society.

Money is still a convenience which the numerous managers of "swapping posts" scattered over the country would like to have in larger amounts. Their busy clients would prefer exchanging services for cash. Telephone companies and transportation lines have not come into the barter schemes yet, and still require nickels and dimes, while postage stamps have to be paid for in actual pennies.
Game conservation is big business. If the average sportsman does not believe that, a reading of the annual report of the Conservation Department of the State of New York will convince him.

The dispatch of Arizona justice was illustrated to the Queens police yesterday when Sheriff J.C. Hunter of Yuma County started back with three prospectors, two of them unemployed novices, accused of murdering two veteran prospectors in the wasteland goldfields outside Yuma.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Thirtyfive of the sixty-five commercially important nations increased barriers to international trade during 1932 apart from hindrances resulting from exchange control measures, according to a survey made public by the Commerce Department.

Stockholders of the Superior Oil Corporation approved yesterday in Wilmington, Del., a plan for readjustment of the company submitted to them last October by a committee headed by A.P. Osborn of Redmond Co. A new board of directors including Harry H. Rogers, John Rogers, N.A. Gibson, J.R. Hayden and John L. Essley of Tulsa, Okla.; F. A. Mayer of St. Louis and Mr. Osborn was elected.

With thirteen teams from the metropolitan area and three from Philadelphia among the contestants, play was inaugurated yesterday in the annual doubles squash racquets tourney at the University Club for the Lockett Trophy.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- About four hundred members of the Westchester County Federation of Women's Clubs were told this after-noon at a meeting in the County Centre that announcement probably would be made within the next few days of the establishment of a "university" in White Plains for the instruction of recent high school graduates in credited college courses, the classes to be taught by unemployed teachers.

WINSTON-SALEM, N.C., Feb. 24. -- A demand that the Federal Government institute sound public finance instead of resorting to inflation was voiced tonight by Francis H. Sisson of New York, vice president of the Guaranty Trust Company and president of the American Bankers Association, in an address at the membership dinner of the Chamber of Commerce.

Republicans who, jealous of CHARLES MICHELSON'S success as press agent for the Democratic party, are said to be contemplating a similar effort, will find the recent activities of the rival publicity bureau solemnly catalogued and appraised in a formal note in the current American Political Science Review.

Men's Wear Sales Improve. Further price reductions by specialty and department stores on men's clothing and furnishings brought out a fair consumer response during the week, retail executives reported yesterday. Suits priced around the $15 range were active, while the general run of furnishings also sold well.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- A fight that took four years to make ended with startling abruptness tonight when Otto von Porat, Norwegian heavy-weight, failed to come out for the eighth round, and Tuffy Griffiths of Sioux City, Iowa, was declared winner by a technical knockout at the Coliseum.

New issues in the amount of $7,413,597 compose the State and municipal financing scheduled for award next week. This week's revised total was $13,926,300, only a part of which attracted bids from municipal bankers. The weekly average for the year to date is $13,600,902, compared with $17,033,732 for the same period a year ago.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 24. -- The election of Charles C. Bell of Westfield, N.J., as first marshal of the senior class of Massachusetts Institute of Technology has been approved by the institute election committee, which has announced the results of the ballots on marshals and senior week committee.
