WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- Preparations for war debt conferences between the United States and debtor nations will be discussed in the next few days with the British and French Ambassadors by Senator Hull, the Roosevelt Secretary of State.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt plans to set aside a definite time each week, after she becomes mistress of the Presidential mansion, for press conferences, she said yesterday. She has agreed to see the Washington newspaper women for the first time on Friday, before the inauguration, when she will be staying at the Mayflower Hotel.

CHICAGO, Feb. 24. -- Depressing news again had little lasting effect today on wheat, on the Board of Trade here, and while the May dropped fractionally early to 47 1/2 cents a bushel, making the fourth straight day on which it has sold at that figure, the market rallied quickly on scattered buying and closed at the top with net gains of 1/2 to 3/8 cent, the May showing the most strength.

Word pictures of Franklin D. Roosevelt as he was when he was rebelling against wearing Scotch kilts and was afraid of the cook, are offered by his mother, Mrs. James Roosevelt, in "My Boy, Franklin," published today by Ray Long and Richard R. Smith. Mrs. Roosevelt told the story to Isabel Leighton and Gabrielle Forbush, who put it into book form.

With surprising suddenness, the markets turned sharply about yesterday and gave Wall Street a fresh viewpoint. The pessimism of the last week or so gave way to a hearty optimism. Whether the rally in the markets was "technical" or based upon a general revision of speculative and investment judgment, the results were impressive.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Winston Churchill, Member of Parliament, addressing his constituents at Epping tonight, discussed Great Britain's foreign policy in relation to the Chino-Japanese conflict. He declared British young men were arguing a great deal whether to fight for their own country if war came but that there was no likelihood of a war in which Britain would be involved.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Miss Diana Fishwick, former women's British golf champion, was beaten after a valiant fight in a nineteen-hole match with Mrs. Stewart Hanley of Detroit, in the semi-finals of the South Atlantic title tournament at the Ormond Beach Golf Club today.

With a victory over P.R. Lawson of the New York Athletic Club, scored at 15 -- 2 and 15 -- 6, W.E. Coyle of the Fraternity Club, topseeded man in the lower half of the draw, joined C.R. Ince of Columbia University Club in the second round of the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Squash Club last night.

The signed contract of Frank Crosetti, infielder, was received yesterday by the Yankees, reducing the club's list of holdouts to six, as the time approaches for the beginning of the Spring training campaign in St. Petersburg, Fla.
LONDON, Feb. 24. -- Sterling again was lower in the foreign exchange market today. From the overnight rate of $3.41 5/8, it opened at $3.41 1/4 and continued to weaken, closing at 53.41.

Mr. ROOSEVELT'S Administration is to have an auspicious beginning. He promises that the delivery of his inaugural address won't take more than eight minutes. There is good reason to be grateful for such restraint. Presidents, like too many other statesmen, are inclined to prolixity of speech.

SYRACUSE, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- The Sound and Honest Money Association, Inc., sponsored by leading agricultural organizations in New York State, was organized tonight with the object of seeking a flexible dollar of stabilized purchasing power.
Sales of small houses featured realty trading in New Jersey yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24. -- In a stormy session today the House refused to follow the recommendation of a majority of its Judiciary Committee and, by a vote of 183 to 142, impeached Judge Harold Louderback of the District Court for the Northern District of California.

NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 24. -- The City Commission approved today the municipal budget for 1933, carrying total appropriations of $20,936,384, or $521,004 under last year, and a net amount to be raised by taxation of $16,710,934, or $704,566 under last year.

PANAMA CITY, Feb. 24. -- Colombia's next move for the recovery of the Amazon river port of Leticia from its Peruvian occupants is uncertain, but it is believed there is a possibility of an air raid, with a land attack from the rear and river gunboats in support waiting to turn the tide of battle before venturing into shallow and probably mined waters close to the town.

The death in the Federal House of Detention on Jan. 23 last of Charles Meehan, a prisoner, who swallowed a liniment in the belief that it was medicine when it was handed to him on a tray in his cell, where he was undergoing a "cold turkey" treatment as a narcotic addict, has been made the subject of a Federal investigation, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, said yesterday.

Prices on the Cotton Exchange, after holding within a 4-point range for several hours yesterday, advanced in final dealings in sympathy with securities and ended 8 to 12 points higher than on Thursday.

The Flomar Realty Co., Inc., Henry J. Wiegand president gave a mortgage for $2,000 due June 30, 1936, with interest according to the bond, to Mary C. Flicker on 620 E. 17th St., subject to a mortgage for $8,000.

The National Vocational Guidance Association, now in session in Minneapolis, has assured the American Association of Adult Education, 60 East Forty-second Street, of its cooperation in the establishment of the National Occupational Conference, it was announced yesterday by Morse A. Cartright, director of the latter organization.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 24 (AP). -- A proclamation declaring tomorrow a legal holiday and a statement that daily proclamations would be given to make Monday and Tuesday legal holidays were issued late tonight by Governor Ritchie to close every bank and financial institution in Maryland until Wednesday morning.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt had her last fitting yesterday of the gown she will wear at her husband's inauguration on March 4. At the same time, it was announced that the color of the wrap she will wear will be known as "Anna Blue," in compliment to Mrs. Anna Roosevelt Dall, daughter of the President-elect.

To the accompaniment of wild cheers from a court room filled with men and women spectators, Harvey Parry, 30 years old, a warrant officer in the United States Coast Guard, was acquitted yesterday afternoon by a jury in the Supreme Court at St. George, S.I., of the murder of Garnet Brotherton, 26, a riding master of Port Richmond, S.I.

In the final note of the Japanese Government to the League of Nations, stress was laid upon the need of dealing with the "realities" of the situation in Manchuria. It was admitted that appearances were somewhat against Japan in the matter of treaties and of carrying on an undeclared war, but actual conditions were the determining thing.

With the return yesterday of Paul Hammond from Bermuda, a recent perilous adventure aboard the ocean-racing schooner-yacht Nina, which made port at Bermuda in what was described as next to a sinking condition, was revealed.

Owners of Class A boats of the North American Dinghy "Association met last night at 145 West Forty-fourth Street and drew up new rules designed to retain the usefulness of the small sailing craft that have been the backbone of the Winter sport in the Frostbite Yacht Club.

The approximate status of the municipal bond market is reflected in the following list of representative high-grade State, city and county bonds, legal for savings banks in this State, now offered by dealers:

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 24. -- Offering the most varied and comprehensive exhibits in five years, the annual flower show of the Garden Club of Palm Beach and the Palm Beach Gardeners Association opened this afternoon at the Royal Poinciana conservatories and will be continued through Sunday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 24. -- The board of directors of the Westchester County Taxpayers' Association, meeting tonight in the Peoples Bank Building, adopted a resolution condemning the method by which the Board of Supervisors on Monday had distributed the county tax among the twenty-two political subdivisions of the county as being on "a basis of political bargaining."

Scoring its twentieth victory of the season, the St. John's College basketball team turned back Columbus Council, K. of C., 20 to 16, in a hard-fought game before a capacity crowd in the Degray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night.

Partial recovery in United States Government issues had a tonic effect on all security markets yesterday. Foreign and domestic bonds retraced most of the ground lost on the day before and there was an equivalent rally in stocks. The principal commodities rose moderately.

Yesterday's classified statement of the Department of Commerce, on the source or destination by countries of the gold imported or exported during January shows that the month's total gold imports of $128,479,228 came from thirtyseven different countries, while gold exports, aggregating $14,280 went to only two.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., Feb. 24. -- Five miners and two deputy sheriffs were injured late today in a battle beween striking miners and working miners at the Capitol and Woodside mines in the outskirts of this city. One of the miners was shot.
ASUNCION, Paraguay, Feb. 24 (AP). -- President Eusebio Ayala sent a message to Congress today asking a declaration of war against Bolivia.

The schedule of play in the New York group of the team tournament conducted by the women's division of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association came to an end yesterday with a victory for the Nassau Country Club over the Rockaway Hunting Club.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 24. -- Colonel Anthony J. Drexel, an uncle of John R. Fell, sent a cablegram to this city today notifying relatives that he was investigating the fatal stabbing of the Philadelphia and New York sportsman in a hotel room in Surakarta [Solo], Java, Tuesday night.

In a move interpreted by the trade as an effort to help both cor- I porate chains and independent wholesale grocers fight the competition of "super-markets" which have sprung up in the last two years, the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, Inc., yesterday drew up a proposed model law for States which may seek to prevent the sale of standard grocery products at or below purchase i cost.

Of next Sunday's election in Germany it is significant that our Berlin correspondent should have felt entitled to speak so confidently. Nobody, he wrote on Friday, seriously expects HITLER'S own National Socialist party, "no matter under what favorable circumstances they contest this election,"

With Young Billy Reynolds and the veteran Lieut. Colonel J.K. Brown going very well, ably assisted by Henry Lewis at No. 1, the Crusaders polo team sprang one of the upsets of the season last night by toppling Los Nanduces, 13 to 5, at Squadron A Armory.
INDIANAPOLIS, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Repeal of Indiana's prohibition enforcement law will bring an early decrease in the population of the State's penal institutions.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Criticism of the League of Nations for adopting the Lytton report, a challenge of the findings of the report in virtually all its major premises, and repeated assurance that Japan has no "desire for territorial gains or commercial advantages" in any part of the world were contained in a statement of 5,000 words by the Japanese Government, issued through the Japanese Embassy here tonight.

THE feature at the RKO Roxy is "Rome Express," the British-produced film which has been talked of in the European film centres these last months. The action takes place on the Paris-Rome express, where a curious lot of characters have been collected by the author.

A Spring fashion carnival, instead of the spectacular charity carnival that has drawn many thousands to Madison Square Garden, in past seasons, is to be given this year for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre. Arrangements are now being made for this fete, which will take place on March 7 and 8 at Saks Fifth Avenue store.

Sales of several Westchester County homes have been made during the last few days, reports L. Ward Prince, president of Prince Ripley and chairman of the Westchester Committee of Fourteen. That committee is cooperating with the leading title and mortgage companies in Westchester in a campaign to sell the properties which the loaning companies have been compelled to take over.

DENVER, Sunday, Feb. 26 -- The hour of midnight, set by Claude K. Boettcher as the deadline for the ransoming of his son, Charles Boettcher 2d, had passed today with no sign of return of the kidnapped young clubman.

BUFFALO, Feb. 23 -- A desire to follow in the footsteps of her late husband as a member of the Democratic National Committee has been expressed by Mrs. Norman E. Mack, and she is an active candidate for the post on the committee made vacant by the recent death of Miss Elisabeth Marbury of New York.

Longshoremen on the Chelsea piers of the International Mercantile Marine Company, from Sixteenth to Twenty-second Street, succeeded yesterday in capturing one of two fugitive monkeys which had been playing hide and seek with pier employes since last Wednesday.
ANDOVER, Mass., Feb. 25 -- Andover lost a hard-fought basketball game to the Harvard junior varsity, 34 to 33, today. Fields's basket with a minute to play gave the visitors their triumph.
The performance of "The Late Christopher Bean" tomorrow night at the Henry Miller Theatre has been taken over in aid of the charitable enterprises of the Church Mission of Help in Long Island.

THE NEW YORK TIMES weekly business index shows a further increase to 54.4 for the week ended Feb. 18 from 53.7 for the preceding week. The main factor In the rise was again heavy shipments of coal, which caused a further advance in the adjusted index of freight carloadings to 57.3 from 54.8 for the preceding week.

VARIETY is the keynote in broadcasting this week. The Philadelphia Symphony will be on the air. The Metropolitan Opera presents "Tristan and Isolde." Bishop James E. Freeman will preach at the Ash Wednesday service at Washington Cathedral.

WASHINGTON. CONGRESS having stipulated ratification by the convention method in submitting to the States the proposal to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment, a grave constitutional question has arisen to confuse the issue between wets and drys.
LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The British Ministers are walking very warily this week-end, trying to find some way of imposing an arms embargo without being drawn further into the Far Eastern crisis.

FOURTEEN years ago yesterday -- that is, on Feb. 25, 1919 -- the tax on gasoline first became effective in this country, when Oregon levied a charge of 1 cent a gallon. Within one year it had been imposed in four States and had produced revenue exceeding 51,000,000. By 1929 every State in the Union taxed the motor fuel.

PRAGUE, Feb. 25 -- The new Little Entente pact, the text of which was published here tonight, contains the important clause that all political and economic agreements of the individual member States with third parties must in future receive the unanimous approval of all the Entente members, as expressed through a permanent council to be constituted.

GRAND opera stars representing in at least one rare instance the fifty years of the Metropolitan Opera House and, more generally, the twenty-five seasons of Giulio Gatti-Casazza as general manager, will take part in a testimonial concert arranged tonight in honor of Mr. Gatti's silver jubilee, the proceeds going at his wish to the Metropolitan's emergency fund.

OLYMPIA, Wash., Feb. 23 -- The attempted seizure of the Court House, the riotous protest against the "no work, no food" ultimatum of the Emergency Relief Commission and the demonstration in front of the Japanese Consulate in Seattle against "imperialistic war" have caused the Legislature and the State administration of Washington considerable concern.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Rufus Lusk of the Crusaders, an antiprohibition organization, said today that at least thirty-seven States were "reasonably certain" to vote for the repeal amendment.

LONDON. THE intervention of J.H. Thomas. Dominions Secretary in the "body-line" bowling controversy which has arisen out of the test matches in Australia, has revealed the meaning and function of cricket in the imperial scheme as nothing else could have done.
HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 25 The banking situation which has led the Governors of Michigan and Maryland to take protective action received the attention today of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

To the Editor of The New York Time: A dispatch from London to THE TIMES is headed "Modern Typewriter Dreamed of in 1857." The following appeared in "The Story of the Typewriter," published by the Herkimer County Historical Society:
SHANGHAI, Feb. 25 -- Chaoyang, the second largest city of Jehol Province, fell before the JapaneseManchukuoan offensive today.

Adventure on the high seas is something all men dream of, but it is a feature of life that Harry G. Gold. 16 years old. will avoid in the future. He returned yesterday on the Dollar liner President Wilson after an experience that was brief but packed with hard work, trouble and seasickness.

ST. LOUIS, Feb. 23 -- The question in Missouri is not whether the State will vote for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, but whether it will lead the repeal procession. Not many weeks ago it had the honor of casting the deciding vote that killed the "lame-duck" Congress.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- A decision as to what the New York Democratic delegation in the House will do when the party caucus is called to organize for the new Congress is expected to be determined this week-end in New York.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE TIMES of Feb. 9 there was an article concerning Nos. 14 and 15 Gramercy Park and also a marble bust dated 1876 by D.B. Sheahan, reputed to have been the property of Samuel J. Tilden. This bust never was the property of Mr. Tilden, nor did he authorize it.

The Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association, which is meeting in annual session this week in Minneapolis, has taken for its convention theme New Frontiers for American Life, the initial topic being the Relation of the Present Economic Crisis to the Future of Democracy.

The Symphony Society of Plainfield, N.J., under Louis J. Bostelmann will give its second concert of the season tomorrow night at the local high school. Louis Persinger, noted pedagogue and violinist, will be the soloist. He will play the Bruch concerto.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 23 -- Although Pennsylvania, Ohio and West Virginia moved promptly to prepare for conventions to pass upon the Eighteenth Amendment repeal proposal, they are not among the States racing to be first to ratify. In the national surveys of the wets Pennsylvania and Ohio are classed as certain to support repeal and this seems to be justified toy expressions in the States themselves.

Heaving the 12-pound shot 54 feet 9 inches on his final throw, Danny Taylor, New Utrecht High School sophomore, virtually won the team honors for his school and furnished the outstanding individual performance in the annual Manual Training High School interscholastic track and field meet yesterday at the Fourteenth Regiment Armory in Brooklyn.

BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- After apologizing to the Boston baseball public for his failure to achieve his ambitions for the Boston Red Sox, Bob Quinn today sold the club to Thomas A. Yawkey, 30-year-old New York millionaire and a son of a former owner of the Detroit Tigers.

Mme. Aino Malmberg of Finland, author, pacifist, feminist and patriot, who before the downfall of the last Czar aided in the struggle for Finnish freedom and helped Russian revolutionists, died on Feb. 3 in Helsingfors of heart disease, according to word received by friends in this country.

To the Dramatic Editor: I wonder whether you would grant space to an old man for a few words on a subject that is not of overwhelming importance. It but concerns Mr. Coward's "Design For Living." Everywhere, recently, and especially in Westchester, have I heard the play discussed, the emphasis being always on its moral timber.
A portrait by Gainsborough and other works of the British eighteenth century school and jeweler from various estates are among the objects which will be offered at auction here this week.

In a setting reproducing some of the characteristics of an oldfashioned Russian street fair during the Czarist regime, the second annual Russian Carnival took place last night at the 244th Coast Artillery Armory, West Fourteenth Street.

THE man whose autobiography this book is was born in Alsace something more than half a century ago. His lifespan, therefore, includes European happenings of world-shaking effect, but his own life - for Albert Schweitzer is a physician, philosopher and theologian, not a politician -- reflects these only indirectly.

Dividends to be paid by the Standard Oil group of companies for the first quarter of 1933 will approximate $32,795,029, compared with $44,112,501 in the last quarter of 1932 and $46,801,053 in the first quarter of that year, according to a compilation made by Carl H. Pforzheimer Co.

There is a certain justification for the rather vague and now less insistent demand that Mr. ROOSEVELT be granted something like dictatorial powers after he becomes President. It is supposed, as is probable and desirable, that he wall go into office with definite and large policies in mind.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Differences which have long been brewing between Republican factions in the Senate came into the open today when Senator Norris, on behalf of the "progressive" group, issued a "plan for progressive organization."

Promotion of cigarettes under private labels by wholesale grocern is under discussion among jobbers at the present time, it was learned yesterday. The jobbers are watching with interest the experience of a Philadelphia chain store group which started the sale of cigarettes under its private label recently.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Bank debits outside New York City declined during the week ended Feb. 18, the Department of Commerce stated today in its weekly review of domestic business conditions, but only part of the drop resulted from lack of figures from sis Michigan centres.

THE boy is father to the man When Sara Delano Roosevelt overheard her small son giving orders to another small boy as they dug industriously to make a fort, she told him it would be better to let his companion give the orders part of the time.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- With a vote of 168 to 160, the House today passed the Celler bill removing all restrictions from physicians' liquor prescriptions, and sent the bill to the Senate with an amendment authorizing physicians to prescribe malt liquors such as beer.

The following is the answer I give to your question: Are we to continue merely to improve the basis design of present-day aircraft as flown by the Wrights, or is it reasonable to expect some radically new principle at a not too distant date, which may make vertical ascent and hovering possible?
MEN'S INDOOR CHAMPIONS. 60-Meter Dash -- Ralph Metcalfe, Marquette. 65-Meter Hurdles -- Percy Beard, New York A.C.

BUDAPEST, Feb. 24 -- After sharply criticizing in Parliament the presence of foreign journalists at Hungarian by-elections, Premier Julius Goemboes won two such contests last Sunday, the agents of his candidate in Mezokeresztes adopting methods indicating that they were determined to get their man in, whatever the journalists might think and write about the means employed.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Sweeping power to protect deposits in national banks was given to the Controller of the Currency today, as the Couzens amendment to the national banking law was enacted by Congress and quickly signed into law by President Hoover.

To the Dramatic Editor: Otis Skinner wants to know if the youth of today, sophisticated, disillusioned, ripe too soon, can receive the thrill from the theatre which cheap provincial performances gave the youth of his day. Well, I am young -- 20 years of age -- and sophisticated, I think, in the usual sense of the word.

The principal barometers indicated a recession in trade activity in New York City last week. Bank clearing's were lower than in the preceding week and sales records compared unfavorably. Department stores did a light business on Washington's Birthday, but extensive advertising campaigns by several leading stores helped to bolster sales.

Thomas Watt Gregory, Attorney General of the United States during the administration of President Wilson, died at the Pennsylvania Hotel here at 2:25 o'clock this morning. Mr. Gregory, who was 72 years old, had been ill of pneumonia since last Friday. His wife, son and daughter were with him when death came.

AMONG the players who are assisting Gloria Swans on in "Perfect Understanding," which has arrived at the Rivoli, is that affable actor, John Halliday. Back in his younger days Mr. Halliday was a gold prospector and did well at it.

THE author is willing to vouch for the truth of this spectacular account of his adventures prospecting for gold i the hilts of Nevada. And if the events themselves are arranged in an order which admits of more drama and more irony than the events of actual life generally furnish, never-theless one cannot deny that they have the ring of veracity.

LITTLE change was noted in retail trade during the week, and the general tendency was still downward if anything. Exceptions to this trend were to be found, of course, in those instances where special sales drives of one kind or another were under way.
MINEOLA, L.I., Feb. 25 -- G.E. Mole won the High Scratch Cup at the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the shoot by breaking 48 out of 50 targets.

Two convicts, waiting in line to take a shower bath, quarreled over a 2-cent newspaper yesterday in the Federal House of Detention, West and Eleventh Streets. As a result one was killed, the other was held as the slayer, and the usually quiet waterfront neighborhood was thrown into excitement for a few moments by reports of a prison riot.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Captain. Ray Firestone registered nine goals as the Princeton indoor polo team overwhelmed the Harvard trio, 19 1/2 to 7, in the University Riding Hall tonight.

The debut of Richard Crooks as Des Grieux in Massenet's "Manon" yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House was the occasion of reverberating enthusiasm on the part of the audience, which inevitably contained many of the admirers whom this gifted tenor has won in his career as a concert artist.

Lotte Lehmann, accompanied by Erno Balogh, gave her third New York recital this season yesterday afternoon in Town Hall, which echoed to the applause of her large following. Of the early part of the performance account cannot be taken here.
PARIS, Feb. 23 -- Bronze is outmoding platinum as a smart color for hair, to match jewelry, fingernails and shoes.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Paris artists are congratulating themselves on the success this season of their second attempt to organize a barter fair. Pictures and sculpture exhibited in the Parc des Expositions at the Porte de Versailles are offered in exchange for whatever services or goods the buyers may incline to offer.

Two Roman Catholic Archbishops sailed yesterday on the Conte di Savoia of the Italian Line, from Pier 86 at the foot of West Fortysixth Street, en route to Vatican City to receive the red hat of a Cardinal from Pope Pius XI. The liner, which, had been due to leave at 11 A.M., did not go out of her pier until noon because of repairs being made in the engine room.

Governmental economy at the expense of the holders of useless jobs rather than at the expense of social agencies was called for yesterday by Aldermanic President Joseph V. McKee in an address at the forty-fourth annual luncheon of the Woman's Press Club in the Hotel Pennsylvania.

THE passion to collect unique things may be animated by nothing more than a selfish desire to possess what no one else can have. But its concomitant manifestations often wear a healthier aspect than just that. When a public institution reprints from its archives a hitherto unknown document or manuscript, we feel that to be proper evidence of a noble desire to share its treasures with the world.

T.H. Lawrence, C.W. Phellis and Z.G. Simmons Jr. tied for the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. Each finished the regular shoot with a card of 92. In the shoot-off, Lawrence won by breaking 24 out of 25 targets.

Surprise parties are in season and the audience of the Philharmonic children's concerts took Ernest Schelling off his feet with a presentation and shouting ovation midway in yesterday's morning hour of the great orchestra at Carnegie Hall. Conductor Schelling had just finished playing Chopin's E-minor concerto, applauded to the echo, when groups of the children edging excitedly down the aisles made a dash to surround him as he rose from the piano.
MOSCOW, Feb. 23 -- Next to food the passport system and its application form the main topic of discussion among the people of Moscow, Leningrad and other big cities of the Soviet Union.
The following statement of Peru's position in the dispute with Colombia over the possession of the Amazon port of Leticia was sent to THE NEW YORK TIMES by the Peruvian Embassy in Washington:

In another three days the month of March will appear, stepping gingerly like a smallish lion but better by far than a lamb. It brings to the theatre certain promises -- beyond that of Spring -- and some of these are duly set forth below.

A speedy City College basketball team unleashed a whirlwind attack in the second half to triumph over New York University, 38 to 23, at the 102d Engineers Armory last night. It was the final game of the season for both teams and the Lavender's third consecutive victory over the Violet in as many seasons.
THE earliest plan for the League of Nations in the burst of enthusiasm for the League Immediately after the World War included a radio station with power sufficient to girdle the earth.

Supervision of the wire plant of the American Steel and Wire Company at Fairfield. Ala., will be transferred on Wednesday to the Tennessee Coal, Iron and Railroad Company, it was announced yesterday. Both companies are subsidiaries of the United States Steel Corporation and operate plants at Fairfield in the Birmingham steel district.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- The Dundas Civic Centre, of which the Hon. Mrs. Charles Dundas is president, will hold a bazaar at Government House tomorrow, and on Tuesday will give a carnival costume ball at The Lighthouse, In the gardens of the New Colonial Hotel.

WEST POINT, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- An even dozen Army athletic teams were in action today, nine of them sweeping to victory and three losing in an afternoon of sports which included contests in basketball, boxing, swimming, wrestling, gymnastics, fencing, polo and rifle shooting.
A large subscription has been received for the recital by Roland Hayes, tenor, which will take place on the night of March 6 at the Town Hall for the benefit of the New York Urban League.

ALTHOUGH he is less in the public eye than are President von Hindenburg and Chancellor Hitler, Alfred Hugenberg may yet be known in history as the most powerful man in the Reich of this period. As Minister of Economy. Minister of Agriculture and Food and arbiter of wages In the Hitler Cabinet, he has been described as Germany's economic dictator.

Members of the Junior Branch of She New York Women's League for Animals are continuing this season their custom of presenting performances of Shakespeare's plays for the benefit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals. This year they have chosen as their annual production "The Merchant of Venice," which they will give on the night of March 8 at the headquarters of the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street.

PARIS. THE wheel of fashion has described a half turn in the past year. In fact, it looks as though we were returning, in spirit at least, to the early Louiseboulanger period of careless elegance that artfully just escapes being sloppy.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 25 -- Horace Leland Wigging, managing director of the Benjamin Franklin Hotel in this city since 1924 and a nationally known figure in the hotel business, died today at the Arnot-Ogden Memorial Hospital in Elmira, N.Y.

By coincidence, Premier BENNETT'S statement last week that Canada "earnestly desires" a reciprocal tariff agreement with the United States was timed with endorsement of such agreements by several witnesses appearing before the Senate Committee on Finance.

ST. PAUL, Feb. 23 -- The outlook for prohibition repeal in Minnesota and North and South Dakota may be stated in a very few words. In all probability the three States will ratify the repeal amendment. The time and method which will be designated for choosing the constitutional conventions affect the case somewhat, but there are no apparent circumstances which would alter the judgment that these States will vote for repeal.

CHICAGO, Feb. 23 -- Illinois, Indiana and Wisconsin are in a neighborly race to determine which of the three shall be first to ratify the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment. It is conceded by leading drys that small chance exists of preventing ratification in any of these States.

LET THE HURRICANE ROAR" is scarcely longer than a novelette, yet it has a scope which compels one to overlook its comparative brevity. Indeed, though the details of her story never trespass beyond the bounds of simple reality, there is something heroic in scale about Rose Wilder Lane's account of pioneering on the blizzardswept plains of the Dakotas.

THE furniture and other forms of the decorative arts from the collection of the late Michael Friedsam, which was placed on view yesterday at the Brooklyn Museum, are pieces so distinguished that they still influence the choice of antiques and the current styles of interior decoration.

LONDON, Feb. 13, 1933. SCHOENBERG, whose orchestral variations were given at a B.B. C. concert the other day, apparently has given up all thought of reaching port -- any port. He has come to London more frequently than any other modern composer, with the possible exception of Ravel.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 -- Eastern speculators who are credited with having been rather persistent buyers of wheat of late on the Board of Trade started to go out of their lines today and the heavy selling sent prices off 1 5/8 to 1 3/4 cents a bushel to the lowest levels since Feb. 6.

Building and loan associations should take the leadership in effecting a "new deal" in home building and should be ready to march in the front rank toward new developments in providing comfortable, durable and inexpensive dwellings for the average family, Bennett Chappie, vice president of the American Rolling Mills Company, told the conference of the American Savings, Building and Loan Institute in Washington, D.C., last week.

Predictions that the course of business may parallel that of last year, when an upturn was initiated at the beginning of August, were heard here yesterday in several quarters. The likelihood that several pressing problems will be disposed of before the usual mid-year lull encouraged the executives to look for an upward movement in August, even though the fillip provided in 1932 by the low cotton estimate may be lacking.

PARIS, Feb. 15 -- Recent experiments of the Paris police with the use of radio as an adjunct to the regular patrol and emergency call systems have been so successful that the wireless equipment will be increased.

WASHINGTON. ANATION of rugged Individualists, caught in a crisis in which individualism, rugged or otherwise, seems of small aval, looks toward the Federal capital for help and its eyes fall upon the 435 Representatives and the ninety-six Senators who compose the National Legislature.
LONDON, Feb. 24 -- British tariff experts have been racking their brains this week to discover what tariff concessions they can offer to the United States, and they find very few.
COMPACTNESS and simplicity of design are outstanding features of the prize-winning plans in the small-house architectural competition for 1932 sponsored by Better Homes in America.
STAATSBURG, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- President-elect Roosevelt announced tonight that the Summer capital of the United States during his term would be at Hyde Park.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- With President Hoover speaking from Washington over a national radio hook-up and representatives of all the Western States participating in a gala ceremony at the Presidio, the official start of work on the $35,000,000 Golden Gate Bridge, which will be the longest clear-span bridge in the world, will be celebrated here next Sunday with impressive and spectacular ground-breaking ceremonies.

THE chief characteristic of a political regime in Latin America is the predominating part played by the President. During election campaigns it is not the balloting for the Assemblies which arouses interest. Attention is entirely and passionately concentrated on the designation of the President, who is not to preside but to govern
PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 25.-- Mr. and Mrs. Henry Seligman entertained tonight with a dinner at Casa Mia, having the following guests:

By using what he terms as the golden rule, or percentage participating bond and mortgage plan, Frank Teets, a realty broker, of 551 Fifth Avenue, believes that many of the present realty problems might be satisfactorily solved.

COOPERATIVE enterprises are keeping the wolf away from students' doors on many a campus at present. Living costs are being pushed to Spectacular lows, once-clumsy male hands are becoming proficient with, pots and pans, and fraternity house round tables are resounding to a hitherto foreign language, that of rigorous bookkeeping and efficient methods of economizing.

Recognition of Soviet Russia was opposed yesterday as an "inflammatory proposal" that would only serve to antagonize Japan, and advocated as the only means of giving substance to the Stimson doctrine on non-recognition of Manchukuo, at the first Saturday discussion of the year at the National Republican Club, 54 West Fortieth Street.

CONTRIBUTIONS announced by the Stage Relief Fund during the past week totaled $4,413.44, which sum includes a total of $2,675.89 realized from the benefit performances of "Dinner at Eight" and "Autumn Crocus," given on Feb. 12 and Jan. 22, respectively.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- The expected happened at the capital of Maine when the Democrats sought once again to obtain a change in the election date so that the Pine Tree State no more would be hailed as the political barometer of the nation.

CHEYENNE, Wyo., Feb. 23 -- Because its Legislature anticipated by several days Congressional action on repeal, Wyoming could, if it so desired, be the first State to obtain a ratification or rejection expression of its citizenry. The Legislature, toward the end of its statutory forty-day session, had already provided the necessary authority for calling a State convention.

ALTHOUGH Mr. Lippmann's name alone appears on the title-page of this book, the actual work of preparation and writing, it is elsewhere indicated, has been shared by William O. Scroggs and Charles Merz. Like the companion volume for 1931 which preceded it, the book is offered as a contemporary record of events and not as a definitive history.

Taxable realty in the lower east side of Manhattan today shows a lower aggregate valuation on the city's assessment books than for three decades ago, although the total value of all property there, including exempted realty, is slightly higher than for the years just after 1900.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Edward Ford of the Boulder Brook Club carried off the first two places in the lightweight polo pony class, one of six events held at the Saxon Woods Hunt Club's horse show today.

The student organizations of Hunter College have elected 103 officers to guide the work of thirty clubs this semester. Five science clubs, five language clubs and four religious clubs are among those represented.
BERLIN, Fab. 25 -- A week from tomorrow Germany will go to the polls. If the count leaves the government in the minority it will not be due to the facilities extended by it to the Opposition.

WARREN EATON of Norwich, N.Y., an accomplished glider and soaring pilot, has been re-elected president of the Soaring Society of America, Inc. Dr. Wolfgang Klemperer was elected vice president and Arthur L. Lawrence of Providence, R.I., was re-elected secretary at the annual meeting.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., Feb. 25 -- Taking first place in every event except the 150-yard back-stroke, the Rutgers swimming team had little difficulty in defeating Fordham, 47 -- 24, today. The victory gave Rutgers a clean sweep over its metropolitan tank opponents, the other losers being Columbia, C. C.N.Y. and New York University.

The season's second and last performance of "Parsifal" will be presented Thursday afternoon, March 9. The hundreds of disappointed operagoers who were unable to obtain tickets for the first "Parsifal," Feb. 13, when the house was sold out, have requested the management to present a second performance.

Two 500-ton coal barges floated helplessly for two miles down the East River yesterday afternoon without even attracting the gaze of a busy midtown waterfront. Aboard each were a captain and his wife, who, as the minutes slipped by and their calls went unheeded, wondered whether they might float from the waters of a city of 6,000,000 residents into an unknown expanse of ocean.

INQUIRE in the Twickenham manner. "Ahoy! and Oho! and it's who's for the ferry?" and large numbers of people here-about will answer enthusiastically. "Hold it! Wait for us!" and come running Rumors persist that the ferryboat in these waters is, as it were, slipping, but the evil reports come all from Long Island, the free bridges across the East River having scotched, if not killed, the vogue of ferrying on that once-popular stream.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 25. -- With Governor A. Harry Moore of New Jersey and former Governor Alfred E. Smith of New York as guests of honor, the new cigar factory of Henry Clay and Bock Co., Ltd.. situated at Virginia Avenue and Grand Street here, was opened today.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- The serious situation caused by Germany's opposition to any reaffirmation of the Locarno treaties in the proposed pact outlawing force was made worse today when the Locarno signatories failed to break the deadlock in the disarmament conference.

A clash between two rival schools of business thought, one of which is composed of so-called conservative business men who are clinging to pre-depression principles and the other made up of those advocating "enlightened selfishness" in the belief that industry's best interests will be served by subordinating profits to the general welfare, is impending at the present time, George A. Renard, secretary-treasurer of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, said here yesterday.

J.F. Callanan of the Montclair Athletic Club, seeded No. 1, won his opening match yesterday in the Class B metropolitan squash racquets championship tourney which opened at the Harvard Club. He defeated A.L. Fincke of the Englewood Field Club by 15-12, 15-4 and 15-8.

ARE the recent stories of increases in delinquency and racketeering among adolescents greatly exaggerated? The researches of Dr. J.B. Maller of Teachers College, Columbia University, seem to show that they are. Even the statistics concerning the number of "nomad youth" are not altogether accurate, and the majority of them are in no sense to be considered delinquents, he told the Society for the Experimental Study of Education recently.

Life Imitates State The movie stars in their courses exercise a powerful compulsion on the daily habits and practices of the American people. The experts of Recent Social Trends report that there is at least one film queen who cannot put her best foot forward without creating serious problems for the shoe manufacturers of the United States.

The mid-week holiday caused a heavy supply of produce in the latter part of the week, resulting in a stagnated market with lower prices, George G. Royce, director of the New York office of the State Agriculture and Markets Department, reported yesterday in his consumers' weekly review of wholesale markets.

The New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition for the first time a rare collection of original caricatures of the War of the American Revolution, consisting of engravings and mezzotints belonging to R.T.H. Halsey, a member of the society and a trustee of the Metropolitan Museum of Art.

DETROIT, Feb. 25 -- The Detroit Clearing House Association plans to issue scrip in the form of its own certificates as a medium of exchange in Detroit and probably throughout Michigan during the banking emergency.

The fairly widespread expectancy in retail circles that the change to national administrations to occur within the next few days will lead to steps which, will improve trade lent a more optimistic tinge to views in retail quarters during the week.

Although the entry list is expected to be the largest on record, three stand-bys of contract-bridge competition will be absent when the Eastern bridge championship events open tomorrow afternoon at the Hotel Roosevelt. One of them, Ely Culbertson, has temporarily abandoned bridge in favor of a motion-picture career, and another, Sidney S. Lenz, has dropped competition for the time being.

Stores throughout the country have planned Intensive store-wide events to begin the first of next month, with the hope that March seasonal influences and the new administration will have a buoyant effect on retail trade, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer.

Miss Helen Stotesbury beads a committee of young women who are active in arrangements for a bridge and fashion show in behalf of the Briarcliff Holiday House to be held on Tuesday, afternoon at the Park Lane.

AS the publishers point out. this novel has the same setting as Thomas Mann's "The Magic Mountain" -- both are laid in a Swiss sanatorium. But as the publishers do not point out, no two novels could be more dissimilar in theme and treatment or, for that matter, in quality.

PARIS, Feb. 16 -- A wedding attended by a number of Americans, French and Belgians took place yesterday at the Church of St. Pierre de Chaillot, quite near the chancellery of the United States Embassy. The bride, Elizabeth Butler Frothingham, is the daughter of the late Joseph L. Frothingham of Boston and of Mrs. Edward Samuel, who, with Mr. Samuel, has a home here in the Avenue Montaigne.

PEIPING, Jan. 20 -- Although the coastal ports of China anticipate that 1933 will bring a conspicuous revival of Chino-Soviet trade as a result of the diplomatic rapprochement between Moscow and Nanking, the reconciliation already has resulted in the reopening of the ancient trade route between China and Sovietized Outer Mongolia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President Hoover signed "with, great satisfaction" today a bill authorizing the United States Supreme Court to prescribe rules and practices for expediting action in criminal cases where appeals are taken after verdicts in the lower Federal courts.

THE name of Charles Seignobos, Honorary Professor of the Sorbonne, is too well known to necessitate a long introduction. His works, from "L'histoire des anciens peuples de J'Orient" to the volumes which he contributed to the famous "Histoire de France contemporaine," edited by his friend E. Lavisse, have long since won for him the place of one of the most esteemed and authoritative of living French historians.

SYDNEY, Australia, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Featured by two brilliant batting displays, one just over the century mark and the other just under. England today scored 418 runs for the loss of eight wickets in the first innings of the fifth and final test cricket match with Australia.

Many younger married couples, debutantes of former years and single men are planning dinners to precede the final after-dinner dance of this season, which will take place on Saturday night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Ranking in popularity with other long-established subscription dances, this series is directed by a committee headed by Mrs. William Curtis Pierce and including Mrs. Frederic G. Hoppin, Mrs. Leighton H. Coleman.

Declaring that the city was "a long way short of bankruptcy," Professor Joseph D. McGoldrick of Columbia University defended public expenditures as a means of stimulating business and warned against curtailment in education yesterday at the annual luncheon of the Kindergarten-6B Teachers Association, attended by more than 600 members in the Hotel Astor.

ARCHITECTURE and its sundry correlatives climb into prominence that may be called both seasonal and supplementary. The seasonal aspect is taken care of, with unwonted splendor this year, by the Architectural League, whose annual exhibition at the American Fine Arts Building was duly described in the news columns.

DURING the World War sking was introduced into all the armies of the world as the most effective mode of travel and transport in the high mountain valleys.Today there are no more efficient military organizations than the fighting units on skis-the chasseurs alpins of France.

LONDON. ACCORDING to The Morning Post, those who conferred the Nobel Prize on Sinclair Lewis achieved a remarkable feat of prophecy. At the time be was only one of the most promising of the younger novelists, but he has now written in "Ann Vickers," the finest piece of imaginative literature produced in America this century.

BARCELONA, Feb. 10 -- Spain, the traditional land of the fiesta or holiday, is just now witnessing the spectacle of a serious strike in which one of the major issues is the workers' demand that holidays he abandoned. But this demand offends an old Spanish custom, and Spaniards who are regular are great sticklers for custom.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 25 -- Having marshaled his preliminary forces in something like world's record time. Memphis Bill Terry began today to map his plans for an intensive campaign which in the next six weeks is expected to yield a remodeled Giant team.
NEW YORK. Mr. and Mrs. Robert T. McKee of 136 East Seventy-ninth Street have left Summerville, N.C., for Sarasota, Fla., where they will remain for two months.

ARTURO TOSCANINI will return to the Philharmonic-Symphony Wednesday evening in Carnegie Hall. He will conduct the first New York performance of Howard Hanson's Second symphony, "Romantic." The work will be repeated Friday afternoon and next Sunday afternoon.

MILAN, Feb. 16, 1933. WERNER JANSSEN, the American composer whose "Louisiana" suite was produced at the Augusteo this season, recently conducted a program of modern American music at the Teatro di Torino, the aristocratic concert hall of Turin, used by the northern section of the Italian Broadcasting Corporation for its publicly attended radio transmissions.

Owners of tenement house properties generally are supporting the bill offered in Albany by Senator John J. Dunnigan to amend the multiple dwelling law. The amendments would include a provision for extending for one year, to April 18 1934, the time allowed for making structural changes required under the law, except in cases of "serious immediate hazards affecting life or health."

THlS novel is a plot story of the kind that had orthodox standing twenty-five and more years ago. Such novels are still written for popular consumption but now seldom achieve and rarely deserve critical consideration -- except in the pure field of detective fiction.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 25 -- In the next few months naval bands all over the world will blare out "The Admiral's March," saluting guns will spit their flaming wadding above the waters of many seas and Admirals' flags will flutter up and down from the main trucks of many men-of-war as the navy's highest commands change hands.

Mrs. Therese Schiff, widow of Jacob H. Schiff, the banker and philanthropist, died at her home at 965 Fifth Avenue early this morning. Mrs. Schiff, who was in her seventy-ninth year, had suffered a cerebral thrombosis. The funeral will be held at her late home Tuesday morning at 10 o'clock.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- International debts should be treated in the same way as private debts, by the best possible settlement made over the table, W.W. Atterbury, president of the Pennsylvania Railroad, today told the Senate committee inquiring into economic conditions.

Because Franklin D. Roosevelt will be inaugurated President of the United States next Saturday many pastors will devote their sermons this morning in part to a discussion of the responsibilities of that office. All will pray for a blessing upon the new administration.

WHEN President Franklin Delano Roosevelt, fresh from receiving the oath of his high office at the hands of Chief Justice Huches, leaves the East Portico of the Capitol and enters his car with Mrs. Roosevelt, he will head not only his own parade but a shadowy procession of marching men and women that stretches back to the very core and beginning of American life.

Supreme Court Justice Peter A. Hatting, who has been in the Post-Graduate Hospital for more than, a week suffering from a diabetic condition which developed into osteomyelitis, or inflammation of the bone and marrow, was forced to undergo the amputation of his left leg on Friday, it was learned yesterday.

Industry this month marked time, content to wait further developments and as a result, according to the monthly summary of national business conditions compiled by the business survey committee of the National Association of Purchasing Agents, the general level of activity was slightly below that of January.

The second of the Knickerbocker Assemblies for this season, took place last night in the main ballroom suite of the Ritz-Carlton. The subcrihers, who include debutantes of former years, were received by a committee headed by Mrs. Frederick W. Longfellow.

Widespread favorable response has greeted the plan suggested by Iser P. Cohen of the Cohen Brothers Corporation of this city for a national "recovery week," he reported yesterday. During the week, in the "manner of a Liberty Loan campaign," every man, woman and child in the country who can afford the expenditure is to be urged to spend 25 cents extra "as a moral and practical obligation to restore better days and conditions."

PINEHURST, N.C.-- Aa Pinehurst's most active part of the season opens, the twenty-ninth annual Spring golf tournament, which gets under way tomorrow, takes the spotlight in sports activity. This tourney, won in the past by such noted golfers as Eugene Homans and W.F. McPhail, again has attracted a large entry, the outstanding including Eric Thomson of St. Andrews, N.B., the defending titlenolder, and Halbert J. Blue of Pinehurst, the Carolina champion.

Some very clear-sighted remarks on present conditions in real estate were made by Lawrence B. Cummings, vice president of Douglas L. Elliman Co., at the management division meeting of the Real Estate Board of New York last week at the Hotel Astor.

The goal of the campaign to be started early in April by the Salvation Army was announced yesterday by James G. Blaine, executive chairman, as $1,110,000. The sum includes $565,000 for emergency relief and $545,000 for institutional aid.

THROUGH changes in their design, the majority of 1933 cars will necessitate stronger antifreeze solutions for the cooling system to function properly, it is indicated in an analysis just completed by the United States Industrial Alcohol Company.

Cardinal Hayes, District Attorney Grain and the Rev. Thaddeus Tieraey, pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of the Immaculate Conception, in Fourteenth Street, will not nave to appear as defendants in the $500,000 damage suit brought against them by Raymond J. Norman, a minister of the American Catholic Orthodox Church and treasurer of the Church of Contrology.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- Archery, the most popular Bermuda pastime of a half-century ago, before it was superseded by more vigorous sports, Is enjoying an enthusiastic revival here this Winter under the leadership of Mrs. Dorothy Campbell Hurd, Canadian woman golfer, who daily gathers a large group of disciples at the Belmont Manor and Golf Club's archery butts.

LONDON, Feb. 21 -- Before leaving London to join the remainder of the party which is to attempt to climb Mount Everest, Dr. C. Raymond Greene, medical officer of the expedition, who was accompanied by F.S. Smythe, gave some details about his plans for keeping his fellow climbers in good health.

BOSTON, Feb. 23 -- Three of the New England States will ratify the amendment for the repeal of prohibition without a doubt; five of the six States will probably ratify, and it is quite possible that New England will go unanimously for repeal.

The word "intoxicating" as applied to beverages is a very much abused word. If the framers of the Eighteenth Amendment had used their foresight instead of their hindsight the country would be very much richer and the people much happier during this long depression.

A clearly defined stage in the development of the modern woman is indicated by a little book of etiquettc, published in England in 1851. Recent rediscovery of this book has provoked the comment which appears below.

With the barter-scrip movement swinging rapidly into the Eastern section of the country, such centres as Syracuse, Rochester and Boston planning "self-help" exchanges, the number of units throughout the country has risen to about 400, according to estimates made here yesterday by authorities on the subject.

With the last of the great annual Eastern indoor exhibitions now canine history, American breeders and exhibitors have a breathing spell and an opportunity to take account of stock. The sweeping successes of recently imported animals in the important exhibitions have been spectacular.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Continuation after March 4 of the general stock market investigation by the Senate Banking and Currency Committee became almost certain today with the introduction of a resolution by Senator Fletcher prolonging the committee's investgating powers after that date.

THE art aspects of "the last monument to the spirit of 1929," the Radio City project, are considered in the February issue of The American Magazine of Art, by Philippa Gerry Whiting. The decorative developments in the theatres are discussed in detail and the article is illustrated with views of the interiors and reproductions of some of the murals.
ARTURO TOSCANINI, recently returned from Europe, will resume on Wednesday evening his leadership of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, in which capacity he continues until the end of the season.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The recent report from Harvard that the classics are not being Studied to the same extent as formerly deserves some comment. The reasons for this decline are fairly obvious.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The alleged frauds which marked last year's election in New York City, together with a renewal of efforts by the Democrats in the Legislature to bring about changes in the election law designed to give their candidates a better opportunity in elections up-State, have led to an unusual number of bills to amend that statute being dumped into the legislative hopper at the present session.
PRINCETON, N. J., Feb. 25 -- The Princeton hockey team matched Dartmouth's two goals in the final period to triumph over the Indians, 5-3, in the Hobey Baker Memorial Rink tonight.

Aircraft design at the present time is taking two definite trends, one the conservative trend toward the refinement of basic design, the other with the idea of experimenting with innovations. The net result of both developments will undoubtedly result in the airplane ten years from now being a composite picture of the refinements of the present design, with such of the innovations as have proved succesful being grafted' on to the main basic structure.

AND now for a footnote on animals, to complete the season's saga of Show Business. It will be, of necessity, in the nature of an elegy, the crying of many sibilants over the tragedy of the Worst Year of All. For the chariots of the Romans have been gathering dust these many months, the howdahs of the jungle muse have grown tarnished.

OTTAWA, Feb. 23 -- When the Canadian Parliament the other day voted down a private member's resolution which would have made exports of liquor to the United States legal again so far as this country is concerned, it was not an expression for prohibition or against the government control system which eight of the nine Canadian provinces have adopted.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- As forecast in dispatches to THE NEW YORK TIMES, the State Grange has called off its campaign for the recall of Governor Rolph. Opposition to the action was too strong among leaders of the anti-administration faction.

NEWPORT NEWS, Va., Feb. 25 (AP) -- America's first naval vessel designed as an aircraft carrier from the cradle, took to her element in the James River today. The vessel was christened "Ranger" by Mrs. Herbert Hoover in what probably was her last official act as First Lady outside the national capital.

For the second time this Winter, Madison Square Garden will be converted into a huge velodrome this week when, starting tonight, fifteen two-man teams compete in New York's fifty-fourth six-day bicycle race.

For the moment the neutron is the dark mystery of science. It has been changing disguises so rapidly since it was discovered that no one is quite sure what it is. Drs. BOTHE and BECKER were the first to detect it. Like COLUMBUS, they were unaware of the America they had discovered.

When Mrs. Catherine Casey awoke with a headache yesterday morning, shortly before 8 o'clock, she attributed it to a strong odor of gasoline which pervaded her sixroom apartment in a three-story frame house at 506 East 152d Street, the Bronx.

The veteran Walter Hagen has been named captain of the 1933 Ryder Cup team which will meet the British professionals at South-port, England, on June 26-27, it was announced yesterday by George Jacobus, president of the Professional Golfers Association of America.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In my opinion, the handling of the wandering boys is one of the most simple problems that confront our nation at this time; and at the same time these lads can be developed from menacing elements into most useful citizens. Briefly, I recommend Great Britain's method of saving and training wandering boys.

IRENE DUNNE was shifted into the part scheduled for Ann Harding in Sinclair Lewis's "Ann Vickers" last week, an event which caused Hollywood to conclude that Miss Harding's option would not be exercised by RKO-Radio.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- William E. Morton of Brooklyn, Vice Consul at Athens, has been appointed Vice Consul at Glasgow. Other changes in the foreign service the past week were announced by the State Department today as follows:

Even as the delegates to the Assembly of the League of Nations were approving the report of the Committee of Nineteen condemning the Japanese incursion into Northern China the armies of the Emperor were fighting their way westward into the Province of Jehol.

MONTCLAIR, N.J., Feb. 25 -- For the second year in succession, representatives of the Kimberley School captured the Hontclair Riding Club Trophy, donated by Colonel and Mrs. William H. Henderson. which is emblematic of victory in the horsemanship team competition which featured the annual midwinter horse show of the Montclair Riding Club today.

THE Cathedral of Exeter was consecrated in 1133 and will therefore celebrate this year the eight-hundredth anniversary of the consecration. Exeter's ecclesiastical history, however, goes back a long way before that, there being evidence of a church there as early as the seventh century.
PARIS, Sunday, Feb. 26 -- In a long and often uproarious debate tonight the Chamber of Deputies maintained its position on all the important matters of the March budget in dispute with the Senate.

DUBLIN, Feb. 24 -- As a first step toward creating what is referred to as a Christian social order in the Irish Free State, President Eamon de Valera's government is considering the establishment of an economic council.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Mr. Matthews's article, "France and Italy Widen the European Rift," overlooks certain considerations we might well ponder. He seems to think Franco-Italian entente or "detente" feasible. More likely would be a Franco-German alliance which the von Schleicher government suggested.

New York University's swimming team repulsed Cornell, 43 to 25, in the London Terrace pool yesterday. The Violet natators annexed six first places in the eight-event program. It was N.Y.U.'s fourth victory in eight meets this season and Cornell's third straight defeat.

LONDON, Feb. 15, 1933. WE have had recently a somewhat rare experience; we have heard no less than four new concertos in about seven days -- a Poulenc concerto for two pianofortes and orchestra played by the composer (aided by another French pianist); a violin concerto by Arthur Benjamin, with Antonio Brosa as chief soloist; Szymanowski's pianoforte concerto played by Smeterlin, and Vaughn Williams's pianoforte concerto played by Harriet Cohen.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- The recommendations of Governor Lehman for new and additional taxation will come up for a public hearing before a joint session of the Senate and Assembly taxation committees at the Capitol March 8.

FOR. the Inauguration of Franklin D. Roosevelt as President of the United States thousands of motorists from all sections of the country are expected to drive to "Washington to witness the ceremonies that will take place next Saturday.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- Neville Chamberlain, Chancellor of the Exchequer, delivered still another public warning today that Great Britain could not and would not return to the gold standard until the war debts had been cleared away.
BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Banks in the western tip of the State decided to remain open today.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The Bureau of Navigation Issued the following orders today, dated Feb. 23:

IN his introduction to this volume Ludwig Lewisohn pays homage to German literature and to the author. He finds that "today German prose in its higher and highest examplars is the best in the world." Mankind's renewed interest in the research of the soul has helped German literature to eater upon "a period of triumphant and universally valid expression.

LONDON, Feb. 25 -- The North German Lloyd liners Bremen, Europa and Columbus will dock at Southampton on their westbound voyages hereafter, instead of picking up passengers from a tender far down the Solent. Boat trains will take passengers from London direct to the gangplank.

LONDON. IT IS a common assumption, in Europe that Americans in general are lamentably ill-informed as to what takes place on this aide of the Atlantic. To this the more charitable Europeans are wont to attribute the often marked divergence of apparently characteristic American views from views which, predominate in the Europeans' own countries regarding the world problems that are now so superabundant.

THE vast cavern of the Shubert Theatre in Newark was dark except for the illumination which spread fanwise down and across the forward orchestra seats from a couple of flood-lights on the stage. Vague, shadowy forms of chorus girls and boys, waiting for an afternoon rehearsal, trooped up and down the aisles in the rear of the house or sat talking and laughing in strangely isolated groups, barely distinguishable.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- To strengthen its position in discussions expected to arise at the World Monetary and Economic Conference, the government has gone directly to the principal export associations of the United States with a request for "a confidential outline" at the obstacles in the way of increased exports and the countries most troublesome in that respect.

Displaying a diversified attack, Neil Sullivan and Ray Coffin of the Germantown Cricket Club, Philadelphia, who have carried off the honors for the last two years, gained the semi-final of the Lockett Trophy squash racquets doubles tourney at the University Club yesterday.

The steady stream of withdrawals of funds from New York by interior banks and the resultant need of New York banks to put themselves in a more liquid position caused heavy selling of United States Government obligations last week, and put the entire bond market to a severe test.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- President and Mrs. Hoover tonight held their last State reception, entertaining in honor of the army and navy and also in honor of the six government departments not previously honored owing to the interruption of the social program by the period of official mourning for former President Coolidge.

BERLIN, Feb. 25 -- Despite a shrinkage in the volume of transactions today, quotations on the Boerse took an upward turn. The day's feature was Accumulatoren. The stock opened 2 3/4 points below yesterday's closing level, then rapidly recovered and spurted to 197, or 6 1/2 point shigher than yesterday's final price.

THE Belgian girl who was Marthe Cnockaert and is now Mrs. Marthe McKenna, worked as a trained nurse in a German field hospital close behind the German lines in Belgium and at the same time served as a spy in the British Intelligence Service, collecting information that aided tremendously the British forces and the Allied cause.

WITH twenty-five young players advanced to the professional fold of the Chicago Symphony Orchestra, while others have found employment in the similar organizations of Philadelphia, St. Louis, Detroit, Minneapolis, Seattle and Portland, the promoters of the Chicago Civic Orchestra have called attention to the success of a training ground for native players in the West, as established fourteen years since by Frederick Stock.

GENEVA, Feb. 25 -- The League of Nations new advisory Committee of Twenty-one began this morning its task of concerting action behind the findings and recommendations on the Chino-Japanese dispute which the Assembly adopted yesterday.

Considering the devastating effect of the moratory fever which swept certain sections of the country last week, Wall Street is viewing critically the tendency to fall back upon arbitrary legal recourses to suspend bank payments where the action seems convenient.

IT was reported that during a receut lecture by Einstein at Pasadena on new aspects of relativity Dr. Richard Tolman of the California Institute of Technology, himself a mathematician of parts, rose to ask the meaning of a strange symbol and what it was doing in a particular expression.

BERLIN, Feb. 24 -- Two points are emerging pretty clearly with regard to the economic policy of the present German government that it will have a strong national bias and that it will be agrarian rather than industrial.

ROME, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A charge that France and the Little Entente are undermining Geneva peace efforts was made today by II Giornale d'Italia as the latest broadside from the Fascist press in denunciation of what the newspaper termed dangerous military preparations.

HOLLYWOOD. BILL WELLMAN, directing the production of the new Chatterton picture, "Lilly Turner," at the Warner Brothers' First National Studios, is rather in the predicament of the confiding person who was all run down and took every tonic recommended by his many friends and found himself filled with conflicting emulsions.
GENEVA, Feb. 24 -- With some hope and more dread Geneva seems to await the coming week.

To the Music Editor: I have read with great interest your article on Mme. Sembrich's plea to save the opera in yesterday's TIMES, as well as the various comments which have appeared in your columns to that effect, and I fully agree with them.

Flung from a second-floor window of her home by an explosion of suspicious origin that demolished an adjacent three-story frame and stucco dwelling at 262 Watkins Street, in the Brownsville section of Brooklyn, Mrs. Esther Storch, 54 years old, of 264 Watkins Street, was killed late last night.

Real estate transactions in Manhattan scored a new high mark during 1932, according to the number of realty parcels conveyed, but unfortunately it was the volume of foreclosed properties that had been taken back by mortgage holders which caused this abnormal in crease.

Practically 5,000,000 American families are able to own homes valued from $2,000 to $5,000, points out the home building and home owning committee of the United States Building and Loan League as the result of a survey on home-ownership possibilities.

IT is difficult to analyze this rather curious book and put it away into its own pigeonhole as one can do with most novels. THESE four attractive volumes increase to twenty-one the list of Whitney Museum monographs, the painters previously honored being George Bellows, Alexander Brook, Arthur B. Davies, Charles Demuth, Guy Pene du Bois, William Glackens, Robert Henri, Edward Hopper, Bernard Kurfiol, George Luks, Henry Lee McFee, Kenneth Hayes Miller, Maurice Prendergast, H.E. Schnekenberg, John Sloan, Eugene Speicher and John H. Twachtman.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- Coming from Geneva, where Japan met with defeat in the League of Nations, Yosuke Matsuoka, head of the Japanese delegation, arrived here tonight. He said his every thought now was for Japanese-American relations.

Unless it receives immediate assurance that it will not have to pay more than $184,000 of the $484,000 of overdue franchise taxes owed by the Second Avenue Railroad Company, the East Side Omnibus Corporation may not take advantage of the twenty-five-year bus franchise voted by the Board of Estimate on Friday, it was indicated last night.

LONDON, Feb. 16 -- Overnight, Europe has been presented with a political fact of first-class importance: A new great power has proclaimed its existence. The States forming the so-called Little Entente in Central Europe; that is, Czechoslovakia, Yugoslavia and Rumania, have announced that their somewhat loose alliance has been transformed into a fixed community of interests, which, according to details already published, comes quite near to federative organization.

VIENNA, Feb. 25 -- Count Clauzel, the French Minister to Vienna, called on Chancellor Dollfuss today and received confirmation of the promise already given by the Austrian Government that the return to Italy of the rifles recently shipped from that country to Austria, for repair at Hertenberg, with Hungary as their alleged destination, would be carried out.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, Feb. 25 -- The Foreign Office issued a. communique today stating that the Argentine and Chilean Ministers had visited Foreign Minister Canelas yesterday and presented an official plan for a solution of the Chaco conflict.

BOSTON, Feb. 24. BOSTON likes to be the exception that is said to prove the rule. In every other city the playgoing public has welcomed the fall in theatre prices. Here it remains indifferent or superior to the change.

The downward movement of prices of bonds on the Stock Exchange in yesterday's two-hour trading erased the gains made on the previous day in most groups. Liquidation was heavy for a Saturday, total transactions reaching $6,691,500, compared with $5,603,000 the previous Saturday.

THE melting-pot which, it would seem, should have been our national emblem, began to function before we were a nation even in the Western wilderness as well as in the cities of the eastern seaboard. This biography tells the story of one of its earliest Western products, that sturdy Italian wilderness statesman.

AFTER the ambitious blunder of "Lucrece" Miss Cornell has returned to practical playmaking in Sidney Howard's "Alien Corn." If it is not an occasion for purple panegyric, it is at least an occasion for wholesome satisfaction, for Mr. Howard is the actor's playwright.

Raising of requirements for admission to the School of Law of the University of Missouri to threefourths of the work toward a bachelor's degree, which is equivalent to three academic years of college work, has been postponed until September, 1934, it was announced recently by Dean J. L. Parks following a meeting of the faculty.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 25 -- After losing three straight league games, Dartmouth's five came back in sensational fashion tonight to crush Columbia, 45 -- 32, and tie the Lions for fourth place in the Eastern League. It was the first Green victory over Columbia since 1929.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria, Sunday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The hardy infantrymen from Northern Japan composing Major Gen. Heijiro Hattori's Fourteenth Brigade crossed the border into Jehol this morning and engaged a large Chinese force in what apparently was the most bitter fighting so far in the Japanese offensive to conquer the province of Jehol.

GENEVA, Feb. 13 -- The United States and Soviet Russia are now, with the exception of Japan and China, the two most important elements in the Far Eastern problem, according to Yosuke Matsuoka, chief of the delegation which for three months has been fighting Japan's case before the League of Nations.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25 (AP). -- An anxious city worried tonight over who would carry on its troubled civic affairs as it watched with mingled trepidation and hope for the reports from Mayor Cermak's bedside.

With messages of congratulation from President-elect Roosevelt and public officials, the new $16,000,000 Port Authority Commerce Building, covering the entire block between Eighth and Ninth Avenues, Fifteenth and Sixteenth Streets, was formally dedicated yesterday afternoon.

A NEW method of flood control involving the use of dynamite to blast channels and change the course of rivers and streams was suggested by recent operations conducted by United States Army officers in charge of flood control in the Atchafelaya section of Louisiana.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The largest crowd assembled in Washington since 1913 will be on hand next Saturday to participate in the last Springtime inauguration when the first Democratic President since Woodrow Wilson will take office.

ITHACA, N. Y., Feb. 25 -- Princeton rallied late in the second hall to break a 22-22 tie and defeat Cornell in an Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League game tonight, 41-32, and keep in the race with Yale for the title.

BERLIN. THE new book on Schleicher, until recently Chancellor of Germany, can hardly be called a biography of the man. Rather it tells the story of the German revolution and of the counter-revolution that rose simultaneously with it.
