WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- Matthew Woll, vice president of the American Federation of Labor, the last witness heard by the Senate committee as it concluded its second week of surveying the economic field in a search for curative steps, called for employment insurance, a five-day week and six-hour day, currency inflation by any one of several methods, heavy income, inheritance and excess profits taxes, and efforts to lift consumer buying power.

THE special Victor release of disks accumulated through the year, and for which no place has been found on monthly lists, consists of seven album sets and an assortment of forty-three loose red seals. These are of various vintages and vats.

With New York University slightly favored over Penn in the defense of its team crown, the twelfth annual intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships will be held at the 258th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx on Saturday.

Measures to increase taxes on motor vehicles and gasoline have been proposed in most of the forty-one State Legislatures now in session, according to a tabulation of such legislation made by the American Petroleum Industries Committee.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 (AP) -- After considering for two days the resignation of Joshua Reuben Clark as Ambassador to Mexico, President Hoover, without public comment, today accepted his retirement, effective immediately.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Describing the past four years as a period when "the consequences of past troubles were forever mixing with the premonition of new ones," Ambassador Paul Claudel of France, as dean of the diplomatic corps in Washington, today wished godspeed to Henry Lewis Stimson, retiring Secretary of State, and William R. Castle Jr., retiring Under-Secretary of State.
BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Major Gen. William A. Pew, Massachusetts Volunteer Militia, retired, veteran of two wars and lawyer, died today at his home in Salem at the age of 74.
BOSTON, Feb. 25 -- Harvard won its ninth straight triangular meet with Cornell and Dartmouth in the Boston Garden tonight. The final score was Harvard 50 1/2, Dartmouth 37 and Cornell 28 1/2.

One of the important philanthropic projects in the training of boys and youths, the Children's Village in Dobbs Ferry, N.Y., will be the beneficiary of the performance of "Design for Living" on Tuesday night at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre.

John F. Curry, Tammany leader, has been placed in the position of having to act as the final arbiter in a clash between W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, and John J. Knewitz, Republican leader of the Bronx, it was disclosed yesterday.

ROME, Feb. 24 -- The recent shipment of Italian rifles and machine guns to Hirtenberg, Austria, increased distrust and suspicion in Central Europe and harmed the cause of disarmament but the issue is considered here to be beneficial in some respects.
STATION WHAM, at Rochester, will Inaugurate its new 50,000-watt transmitter on Inauguration Day.
TORONTO, Feb. 25 -- The Toronto Maple Leafs tonight scored a 5-1 victory over the New York Americans in the fifth National Hockey League meeting of the season of the two sextets.

Fishermen are getting anxious. Flounders are beginning to come along in some favored spots on the Atlantic Coast, though not so abundantly as to indicate that they soon will be running heavily. The cod fishermen report getting some, and when they do it is the first sign that Spring is on its way and that the salt water angler is about to get busy.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is human life being lengthened or is its span becoming shorter? The answer is "yes" to each question. Such an answer seems impossible, but nevertheless it represents a condition that must be accented as a fact. The ailments that end human life may be placed broadly in two classes -- infectious diseases and "old age" ailments.

Conflicting views on the methods of selecting delegates to a State convention to act on the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment were reflected yesterday in three separate reports sent to Governor Lehman by his own liquor commission.

HOLLYWOOD. VOLTAIRE" may end George Arliss's association with Warner Brothers. Finding it increasingly difficult to secure stories for the star, the studio feels that there would be less risk and a greater profit if it secures the actor's services on those occasions when a suitable vehicle is found.

Roosevelt's contribution of $3,300 to the unemployed of the State from her earnings as a radio speaker will be spent in the employment of twenty jobless artists and craft workers in a pre posed "Home Crafts and Fireside Occupations" pro ram to be under taken by the State Department c Education, it was announced yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emegency Relief Administration.

Theobald, national director of education for the American Savings Building and Loan Institute, told the members at their midwinter conference in Washington last week that three research projects are now under way which are expected to have wide influence in the future financing of one-family homes.

Drys of the Extreme Left continue to show in adversity that same delightful genius of understatement which characterized them in the days when Congress ate out of the hand of the Anti-Saloon League. Our genial old friend, Bishop CANNON, calls on his sadly thinned band of followers to "suppress the Wet rebellion" begun in 1920 by ALFRED E. SMITH.

WOOL - GATHER to your hearts' content this Spring, ladies. At home or abroad you will want to wrap yourself in wool. You will be content to stay in it from daylight until dark, and maybe even later, for some of the woolens are so sheer and beautiful in texture that they are worthy of lavish after-dark entertainment.

A LISTENER in Tennessee who reminisces in a letter about the halcyon days of Tony Pastor's and recalls the Hammerstein Victoria Theatre in Times Square, says that he enjoys Amos 'n' Andy just as much as he delighted in the drolleries of Bert Williams in the days prior to the horseless carriage.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, Feb. 25 -- Berkeley Bell of New York recorded the first victory for the United States over England in the Bermuda Lawn Tennis Club's championship tournament today, turning back K.C. Gandar Dower, leader of the English team, 7 -- 5, 6 -- 4.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana and Senora Mina Perez Chaumont de Truffin were married at noon today at the home of the bride, Villa Mina, in Mariano, a suburb of Havana. The religious ceremony was performed by Mgr. Manuel Arteaga, the civil act required by Cuban law having taken place half an hour previously with Antonio Millas, a public notary, officiating.

For the second time in its career the Museum of Modern Art brings forward work by the famous nineteenth century French artist, Henri de Toulouse-Lautrec. In February, 1931, the museum combined in an exhibition his work and that of the strongly contrasting Redon.

The appointment of Captain Schuyler F. Cumings as master of the United States liner Manhattan added another to the many links which associate him with New York. The ancestors of Captain Cumings were among the Dutch settlers of Manhattan and his great-great-grandfather lies buried in St. Paul's churchyard, in Vesey Street.

Major Gen. Dennis E. Nolan, commander of the Second Corps Area, announced yesterday that, with an enrolment of 7,500 youths of New York State, New Jersey and Delaware authorized by the War Department, registration for the thirteenth annual Citizens' Military Training Camps would begin Wednesday.

AIKEN.-- The coming week will see the arrival of a large contingent of Winter visitors, not only from the North but from Florida, whence they will be en route to their homes above the Mason and Dixon Line.

Prices for all commodities traded on local exchanges declined in yesterday's trading in sympathy with weakness in outside markets and the unsettled state of economic conditions. For the most part trading was fairly quiet. Cash prices were also lower on the day.

FROM the start, American print-makers have fancied the arrangement of their work in series or "sets." Whistler in 1858 began his succession with the famous French set and followed in the '60s with the Thames set and later with the Venice sets, around which for many years circled a veritable hurricane of comment, contradiction, praise and prices.

FRANKLIN D. ROOSEVELT'S inauguration as President of the United States on March 4 will be described for an international audience. More than 150 radio stations, including several powerful short-wave transmitters, will flash a description of the scene and historic words from the lips of notable people to every quarter of the earth.

THE Austrian Tourist Information Office is again distracting us with beguiling leaflets, cunningly decked forth with photographs of fine old palaces and snowcapped mountains, concerning the musical and drama festivals to be given this Summer in Vienna and Salzburg, and there will doubtless be a great searching of pocketbooks and thumbing of sailing lists within the next two months.

Heavy liquidation on the Cotton Echange yesterday broke prices about $1 a bale to a final loss of 17 to 20 points. A closing figure of 5.94 cents a pound for the May delivery, compared with 6.18 cents on the previous Saturday, showed a loss of about a quarter cent during the week. The July sold within 7 points of this month's low quotations.

Spectacular baskets by Captain Bud Hassett and Fred Brunelli in an extra period of five minutes enabled the Manhattan basketball team to defeat Fordham, 35 -- 33, in a thrilling contest in the Manhattan gymnasium last night.
LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Snow-covered fields played havoc with the football schedule in the British Isles today. The results of games played follow:

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- After being closeted for several hours today with executives of the leading insurance companies and savings banks in the State, Governor Lehman announced this afternoon that he had received from them assurances that they would show the utmost leniency and consideration in dealing with borrowers on mortgages who, as the result of the economic depression, are finding it difficult to meet their obligations.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 -- Yale's indoor athletic season reached its height today with eighteen scheduled events, twelve at home and six away.

The library formed by the late Willis Vickery of Cleveland, who was a judge of the Supreme Court of Ohio, will be offered at auction at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries Inc., on Wednesday evening, Thursday afternoon and evening and Friday afternoon.

The movement in certain circles in Congress to abolish, the taxexemption privilege of State and municipal bonds by an amendment to the Constitution, if necessary, is not viewed with alarm in savings bank circles, according to the current bulletin of the Savings Bank Association of the State of New York.

A cloud hung over the second oldest drug store in the city yesterday. Time-honored since 1817, the Quackenbush Pharmacy, now at 703 Greenwich Street, survived all the wars and depressions for 116 years, but wholesale druggists filed petitions in bankruptcy on Friday to collect $557.

The results of the second day of the recanvass of the vote at the polls on Nov. 8, as announced yesterday by the Board of Elections, showed several errors in the Eleventh Assembly District in Manhattan, of which James J. Hines is the leader.
Mrs. Margaret Barrett Mulligan, formerly a prominent Democratic leader in Queens, died in St. John's Hospital, Long Island City, on Friday night of an intestinal malady.

The Columbia wrestling team won its eighth consecutive match of the year yesterday by defeating Rutgers, 28 1/2 to 1 1/2, in the Morningside gymnasium. The Lions swept through seven bouts without a setback before Frisco of Rutgers and Dudley of the Lions grappled to a draw after two extra sessions.

MONTREAL. -- The season's official curling competitions in the Province of Quebec come to a close here this week with the playing of the Elgin Trophy tournament at local rinks next Friday and Saturday.

PEIPING, Sunday, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The latest Chinese dispatches reaching here said that in the Kailu region in Northwestern Jehol a daylong engagement occurred yesterday between a Japanese regiment under the command of Major Gn. Kennosuke Mogi and a Chinese brigade commanded by Lieut. Gen. Thi Hsin-wu.

OMAHA, Feb. 23 -- Notwithstanding the certain knowledge that the question of prohibition repeal would eventually come up to them in substantially the form proposed in Congress, some of the farm States find themselves in a quandary over the matter of procedure, now that it is in their laps.

HERE is something new under the sun -- a textbook on marriage. During very recent years in two or three universities courses have been offered in preparation for family life or for marriage, and in various other institutions, educational and religious, there have been experimental attempts to organize instruction of similar sort.

INFREQUENTLY there appears a novel which is such a delightful surprise the, the reviewer longs to proclaim its merits with trumpets and kettledrums and paeans loud and clear. That is the way this reviewer feels about "The Enchanted Winter." which marks the debut in this country of Martin Hare.

BALTIMORE, Feb. 25 -- While Governor Ritchie and State and municipal officials conferred with bankers today in arranging legislation for the protection of depositors by limitations of withdrawals and other safeguards, the first of the three-day bank holiday declared by the Governor passed quietly.

Mrs. Rita C. McGoldrick, wife of Dr. Thomas A. McGoldrick, physician, of 294 Clinton Avenue, Brooklyn, has received from Pope Pius XI the Gold Cross of the Order Pro Ecclesia Pontifice in recognition of her philanthropic work "from the Catholic viewpoint."

OSCAR HAMMERSTEIN 2d departed yesterday on the Majestic, bound for London, Berlin, Vienna -- and almost anywhere else. He explained before he left that rehearsals for the English production of "Music in the Air" should begin in about a month, but the management has not as yet been decided.

The current decline in stocks is the tenth liquidating movement of the bear market which started in the Autumn of 1929. In previous depressions there were from five to seven distinct selling movements in securities.

Prohibition agents from Brooklyn went to Forest Hills. Queens, last night, and in a double raid based on a search warrant arrested a man and a woman and made one of the largest seizures of contraband in recent months.
CHANGCHUN, Manchuria, Jan. 27 -- Nearly a year has passed since the State of Manchukuo came into being.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 25 -- Springing into the lead when the game was less than two minutes old and holding their ravils scoreless until the last period, the Yale stick-wielders turned back Harvard's hockey team at the New Haven Arena tonight by the score of 4 to 1.

THOMAS MANN, Nobel Prize winner and author of "Buddenbrooks" and "The Magic Mountain," has just written to Alfred A. Knopf, his American publisher, that he is still hard at work on his long-awaited novel, "Joseph and His Brethren."

PALM BEACH. -- Following a precedent established two years ago when Winter residents first extended their Winter sojourns into late March and April -- many last Spring remaining until late May or June-- the first of March this year sees no hint of slowing down of activities.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 25 -- Declaring that education must concern itself with economic problems, the National Council of Education, a policy forming group of the National Education Association, went on record here today as calling upon President-elect Roosevelt to create a national council on social-economic planning, in which educators, along with representatives of labor, agriculture, industrial management and various professions, should have a part.

MADRID. I ONCE climbed Into the bull-ring with a bull. I was reminded all too vividly of the man who yelled down at the bullfighter. "Coward, and he such a little bull" The bullfighter called back: "He may look little to you. From here be looks like a rhinoceros!"

An optimistic future for the employment of trained women In finance, home economics, personnel work and art was described yesterday to a group of 165 women business executives and vocational guides who met at a round table luncheon in the American Woman's Association Clubhouse, 353 West Fifty-seventh Street.
ATLANTA, Feb. 23 -- The mixture of the repeal and beer problems has given Southern Jaw makers somewhat of a political headache already.

THIS is a challenging book. It throws down the gauntlet to those who have bad anything to do with Negro education, whether of white or black race, and it bids the Negro to come forward in pride of race and heritage and, standing on the basis of his own racial personality, demand an education that will develop that personality and its gifts rather than seek merely to Imitate the white man.

EXETER, N.H., Feb. 25 -- Exeter's basketball team scored a decisive victory over "Worcester Academy, 37 to 18, today. The New Hampshire players took an early lead and at one stage led their opponents 16 to 1, this being just before half-time.

LETTERS from Rhodeaia written by a young English woman to her mother and a friend in England supply the text of this delightfully human novel,which, despite a lack of drama and suspense, holds one's interest as a self-portrait and a vivid description of aspects of South African life.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Miss Susan Noel women's squash racquets chain pion of England and the United States, met with her first defeat on American courts today as the tour of the British team came to an end at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club Club.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 25 (AP) -- A test of whether it can prohibit use by radio broadcasting companies of the news which it and its members have gathered at a cost of millions of dollars annually was begun today by The Associated Press.

Another In the series of Sunday afternoon musicales by children, of the Music School Settlement will take place today in the auditorium of the Dalton School, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street, for the benefit of the settlement and the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

HAVANA, Feb. 25 -- Dynamite planted on the tracks of the United Railways at Kilometer 134, between Tosca and Jovellanos, in Matanzas Province, exploded at daybreak today just as Train 1, which left Havana at midnight last night for Santiago, reached Kilometer 134, derailing the engine and several cars and tearing up about 400 yards of tracks, according to information reaching here tonight.

NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 25 (AP) -- A.B. Lettellier's good campaigner Sazerao today won the $1,500 added Rex Handicap, feature event at the Fair Grounds, over the mile-and one-sixteenth route to pay $8.20 in the mutuels. The time was 1:47 2-5.

EXETER, N.H., Feb. 25 -- Exeter's basketball team scored a decisive victory over "Worcester Academy, 37 to 18, today. The New Hampshire players took an early lead and at one stage led their opponents 16 to 1, this being just before half-time.

SCARBOROUGH - ON - HUDSON N.Y., Feb. 25 -- Miss Susan Noel women's squash racquets chain pion of England and the United States, met with her first defeat on American courts today as the tour of the British team came to an end at the Sleepy Hollow Country Club Club.

SIOUX FALLS, S.D., Feb. 25 (AP) -- A test of whether it can prohibit use by radio broadcasting companies of the news which it and its members have gathered at a cost of millions of dollars annually was begun today by The Associated Press.

Another In the series of Sunday afternoon musicales by children, of the Music School Settlement will take place today in the auditorium of the Dalton School, 108 East Eighty-ninth Street, for the benefit of the settlement and the women's division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee.

Failure of the finance corporation organized in September by equipment companies to stimulate purchases by railroads has renewed discussion as to the outlook for this business should traffic increase by the 20 per cent figure that railroad officials believe would put them "in the black."

LIGHT and fluffy as is the story of the German - language musical film. "Ich Will Nicht Wissen Wer Du Bist" ("I Do Not Want to Know Who You Are"), this picture, which was directed by Geza von Bolvary, producer of "Zwei Herzen im Drieviertel Takt" and "Der Raub der Mona Lisa," is imbued with simple charm.

ALBANY, Feb. 25 -- Governor Lehman voiced the conviction tonight that the report of the Alcoholic Beverage Control Commission on proposals for holding a State convention to ratify the repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, as well as other recent events, guaranteed a program calling for a number of delegates at large.

BEAUFORT, S.C., Feb. 23 -- The lower end of Beaufort County is one part of the country where bread lines are unknown. It is a purely agricultural area, and the farmers have little money, but the thought of hunger does not bother them. Most of their houses need painting, and maybe they would like to trade in their old flivvers for new ones, but aside from that, the depression has passed them by.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Nine of the most formidable eligibles for the $50,000 Cuban Grand National Handicap ran at Hialeah Park today in the Jockey Club Handicap before more than 12,000 persons who were thrilled by a nose finish with a long shot the winner.

SAN FRANCISCO, Feb. 23 -- In five Pacific States -- California, Washington, Oregon, Nevada and Arizona -- ratification of the amendment repealing national prohibition is as certain as that the voters will get a chance to record their sentiment.

Action of the House committee on coinage, weights and measures in reporting for consideration by Congress the Somers bill for government purchase of silver recalled similar bills enacted in the past in the hope of stabilizing the price of silver.

THE administration record or the last four years is the record made by Herbert Hoover. He dominated his administration, its purposes, its methods, its mechanisms and its men. Some Presidents are shaped by the events of their times.

Thomas Austin Yawkey, new owner of the Boston Red Sox, after making a success in lumbering and mining as part of his plan to follow in the footsteps of his foster father, has further emulated the career of the man he admired by becoming the head of a baseball club.
KINGSTON, Ont., Feb. 25 -- The Royal Military College defeated West Point, 3 to 1, tonight in the annual international hockey feature played before a large crowd. Play was fast all the way.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The text of the invitation from Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary General of the League of Nations, for the United States to associate herself with the views of the League's report on the Manchurian dispute and Secretary Stimson's reply follow:...

Action of the House committee on coinage, weights and measures in reporting for consideration by Congress the Somers bill for government purchase of silver recalled similar bills enacted in the past in the hope of stabilizing the price of silver.

THE administration record or the last four years is the record made by Herbert Hoover. He dominated his administration, its purposes, its methods, its mechanisms and its men. Some Presidents are shaped by the events of their times.

Thomas Austin Yawkey, new owner of the Boston Red Sox, after making a success in lumbering and mining as part of his plan to follow in the footsteps of his foster father, has further emulated the career of the man he admired by becoming the head of a baseball club.

THERE are simple warmth and homely common sense about Helen Hull's writing that are set off no teas by the unornamented precision of her style than by the pleasant humanity of her character "Hardy Perennial." unlike some of Miss Hull's earlier books.

A new system of education which would reduce the time spent in elementary and secondary schools from sixteen to twelve years is suggested by Dr. Charles H. Judd, director of the School of Education at the University of Chicago, in a monograph to be published tomorrow under the auspices of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends.

IN overcoming objections of property owners to permit their land to be used as a location site for motion pictures, location managers often resort to strategy of the old barter-and-trade method. Some of those who accompanied Henry King on the location trip for scenes in "State Fair" recalled last week that the director did some expert bargaining to obtain rights to a farm for his picture.

A NEW low-cost housing plan for the development of the seven city-owned blocks bordered by Chrystie, Forsyth, Canal and Houston Streets has been drawn up by George A. Bagge Sons, architects, of 7 East Forty-fourth Street, and presented to Mayor O'Brien for his consideration.

A demand for a change in national economics to meet distress was voiced yesterday by Bishop Francis J. McConnell of the Methodist Episcopal Church at a Luncheon of the League for Industrial Democracy at the Hotel Woodstock.

THE election of a Democratic President is always an extraordinary event. It has been seventy-two years since the feeble and confused Buchanan surrendered his office to Lincoln and retired to his Pennsylvania estate of Wheatland. In that long period there have been only two Democratic Presidents. But it must be admitted by every one that they made their sixteen years count with remarkable power.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- Huron H. Smith, curator of botany at the Milwaukee Public Museum; Mrs. Smith, and her parents were killed tonight when their automobile was struck by a train at a crossing in Glenview, III.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 25 -- Oxygen and a blood transfusion strengthened Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago today and one of his physicians said at 8 P.M. that all indications then were that he will "live through the night."

GREENWICH, Conn., Feb. 25 -- The Knapp sisters, Phoebe and Jane, both students at the Rosemary Hall School of Greenwich, were the outstanding competitors at the midwinter junior riding competition conducted by the Round Hill Ciub in the club's indoor ring today.

Practically every leader and authority engaged in one form of business or another allied with real estate, and a considerable number of persons owning property rights to real estate whether it be in the form of mortgages or equities, are convinced that the rate of interest Should be reduced.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The following extracts are from a letter in THE TIMES of Jan. 15, signed E. Irvine Haynes:

RYE, N.Y., Feb. 25.-- A dance was held last night by the Harrison Community Service League at the Westchester Country Club. The proceeds will be used to provide milk for undernourished children of Harrison.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 24 -- Unless 531 leaderless individuals perform a well-nigh superhuman feat and band themselves together during the next few days for nothing but action, action, action, the Seventy-second Congress will pass into history next Saturday leaving a mess of mushroom legislation which even the inevitable special session of the new dispensation probably will find entirely too much to digest.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., Feb. 25 (AP). -- A suspected holdup man, armed with two pistols, a revolver and a sawed-off shotgun and wearing heavy armor crudely constructed of steel plate, was shot and killed by police today in a running gun battle.

PARIS, Feb. 24 -- President-elect Roosevelt's action in receiving Ambassador Paul Claudel and having a frank talk with him has been the central event of this week's French history. It was also almost the only cheering event in what has been a somewhat gloomy week.

A LOVE of science and of far places went into the making of this absorbing book. Dr. Andrews describes it as "an introduction to the scientific publications on the explorations of the Central Asiatic Expeditions in Mongolia and China from 1921 to 1930."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 18 amounted to 514,390 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was an increase of 13,070 cars, or 2.6 per cent, from the preceding week, but 57,875 cars, or 10.1 per cent, fewer than for the corresponding week last year and 198,766 cars, or 27.9 per cent, fewer than in the corresponding week two years ago.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- As soon as the present weary effort to get the March budget bill through Parliament has been completed, the French Government will seek at the earliest possible opportunity to bring before the Chamber again the question of the French debt to the United States and the payment of the debt instalment that was suspended by a vote of the Chamber last December.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- The United States formally associated herself with the views expressed in the report of the Committee of Nineteen on the Manchurian crisis, as adopted by the Assembly of the League of Nations, in a note dispatched by Secretary Stimson this afternoon to Sir Eric Drummond, Secretary General of the League of Nations, in response to an invitation to declare the American attitude toward the report.

A New Speed Record. THE thrilling dash of Sir Malcolm Campbell last "Wednesday at Daytona Beach must have left the common-run man-at-the-wheel with a feeling that he has been going at a snail's pace in comparison with the British speed demon's 272-mile-an-hour clip.

Confirmation of recent widespread reports of the asset write-off movement in industry was brought out yesterday when the National Association of Cost Accountants released to THE TIMES the results of a survey among 135 companies, which showed that 75 per cent were in favor of the plan and that 50 per cent had actually put into effect some form of reduction.

AUTOMOBILES in Great Britain, in the not very distant future, may be run with compressed coal gas as a fuel in place of gasoline. Already a number of experimental vehicles are being run on compressed coal gas and public demonstrations of the practicability and economy of this method of propulsion are a feature of the current British Industries Fair, it is reported from London.

At the close of a hard-fought match with R.W. Georgi of the New York Athletic Club, C.R. Ince, top seeded man of the draw, stood one round ahead of the rest of the field in the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Squash Club last night.

Japan's armies are on the offensive in Jehol, but there is a wider arena in which Japan today stands on the defensive, alone against a solid mobilization of world opinion. This has spoken out in the unanimous vote of forty-two nations in the Assembly of the League by which the conduct of the Tokyo Government in the Manchurian quarrel stands condemned.

PARIS, Feb. 12. ONE always looks forward with pleasure to a new play by Alfred Savoir, for one is at least certain of not spending a dull evening. It may not be an entirely satisfactory evening, but it will not be stupid.

The principal public utility companies controlled by the Mellon-Koppers interests of Pittsburgh along the Atlantic seaboard will be included in the $250,000,000 merger now in progress that will combine under the Koppers Coal and Transportation Company, a new corporation, all phases of the gas business from the mining of coal to the delivery of gag to homes.

In view of announcements both in the United States and in Germany of experiments with rotating wing or "paddle wheel" aircraft which, based upon results in the wind tunnel, appear to give promise, technical experts and designers in this country were asked whether radical departures from present design might be expected or whether, in their opinion, airplane progress would lie marked by further'refinement of existing types.

Brokers and other interests in charge of building maintenance have the opportunity at the present time of obtaining men of expert knowledge in practically every branch of the real estate and building management business, Robert E. Simon told the apartment house group of the management division of the Real Estate Board of New York at its recent meeting.

In line with the statements which have been frequently made that expert property management is essential to preserve its future sale and rental value, C.S. de Got, vice president of the Cross Brown Company, points out that the physical operation of property under present conditions is an important factor, just as giving the maximum amount of service for the least cost is the object of every owner or agent.

Just when it appeared that the destructive effect of the Michigan banking moratorium had been overcome, difficulties arose in another quarter yesterday. Maryland followed Michigan's example, with a three-day suspension of withdrawals of deposits from banks pending the enactment of safeguarding legislation.

After the lively recovery on Friday, the share market turned downward again yesterday as liquidation was resumed in bonds. As a result of the over-night developments, including announcement of a banking moratorium in Maryland, securities were unsettled generally, the most disturbing declines taking place in the bond market.
BERLIN, Feb. 25 (AP) -- The Reichsbank's statement as of Feb. 23 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

THE eighteenth biennial convention of the National Federation of Music Clubs will take place in Minneapolis from May 21 to 28 of this year. Among the events already listed are a concert for the first Sunday afternoon, May 21, by the Minneapolis Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Eugene Ormandy, and a concert on the evening of that day by the St. Olaf Lutheran Choir of Northfield, Minn., conducted by F. Melius Christiansen.

The annual awards of the Architectural League of New York in architecture, painting, sculpture and related arts were made yesterday at the forty-eighth annual exhibition of the league now in progress at the galleries of the American Fine Arts Society Building, 215 West Fifty-seventh Street.

LONDON, Feb. 25 (AP). -- Heavy snow was falling again tonight in Eastern Scotland, where the country already is blanketed a foot deep. From all parts of England, Ireland and Wales reports continued of damage caused by the worst blizzard in years.
Dean Franklin DeR. Furman of Stevens Institute of Technology at Hoboken announced yesterday that fifty-four students had won places on the dean's list for the second term of the college year.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 25 -- Debits to individual accounts, as reported to the Federal Reserve Board by banks in 252 leading cities, aggregated $5,283,000,000 during the week ended Feb. 22, or 7 per cent above the total for the preceding week and 7 per cent below the total for the corresponding week of last year.

Although complete statistics for 1932 are not yet available, the National Industrial Conference Board estimated yesterday that the national Income of the United States last year was approximately 53 per cent lower than, in 1929. The preliminary results for 1931, which are complete, show that the national income for that year was fifty-two seven-tenths billion dollars in actual dollars and thirty-seven nine-tenths billion dollars in "1913 dollars."

THE pre-Elizabethan tragedy of blood, whose convention demanded a round dozen of assorted deaths for the full satisfaction of the audience, has nothing on "This Bright Summer," a tale of incest, murder and bitter feud transplanted from the Hatfield-McCoy Appalachian country to the Vermont hills.

BY his title Mr. Devine means that conduct of life by the individual and the community, daily, practically, in general and in standards and Ideals, that will be social, aiming to promote not only the individual but the general welfare and, not satisfied with immediate results, aims to make such welfare progressively, increasingly better.

PARIS -- Experts of the International Chamber of Commerce, who have been preparing a report preparatory to the opening of the World Economic Conference, have reached virtually the same conclusions as the committee which recently met in Geneva, it has been announced here.

IN Cambridge, England, Dr. P. M.S. Blackett, working with G. Occhialni, has verified the discovery of a positive electron tentatively announced by Dr. Carl D. Anderson last September. "Posttron" is the name that Anderson would give to this new fundamental unit.

MIAMI -- Tomorrow is Charity Day at Hialeah race track. The proceeds at the gate,-the Miami Jockey Club's percentage of pari-mutuel receipts, the money from program sales and the salaries for that day of all Hialeah Park employes will go to swell the fund.

In placing restrictions upon the taking of certain species of wild ducks, the Biological Survey did so because it was apparent that these species needed special protection, having decreased more than other ducks.

The second-round victory of T. Davis Hall of the Harvard Club over John F. Callanan of the Montclair Athletic Club, seeded No. 1 player, provided an unset to feature yesterday's matches in the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association Class B championship singles tournament in progress on the courts of the Harvard Club.

PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 26. -- Speaking before a full congregation in the Princeton University Chapel, Norman Thomas advocated this morning a three-point code to relieve the world from its present depression.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria, Monday, Feb. 27. -- Stalwart Chinese resistance has been met by the Fourteenth Japanese Infantry Brigade on the road from Suichung [Southern Manchurian port] to Wukungfu in Jehol.

SYDNEY, Australia, Monday, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press) . -- England concluded its first innings of the fifth test cricket match with 454 runs today and the Australians had scored 32 for the loss of one wicket at lunch time.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 26. -- Having attained a considerable measure of success last year with a couple of young men, Johnny Salveson and Hank Leiber, who attached themselves to the Giants without having gone through the customary course of professional baseball apprenticeship, Manager Bill Terry is overlooking no bets along this line this Spring.

The Rev. Dr. George Paull T. Sargent, who was instituted as rector of St. Bartholomew's Protestant Episcopal Church on Feb. 19, preached his first sermon in his new office yesterday morning. Speaking on "The Days Ahead." he reviewed the "rich and remarkably inclusive heritage" of St. Bartholomew's.

BERLIN, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The deaths of three persons, the suspension of two more newspapers and a flood of oratory today marked the beginning of the final week before German citizens elect a new Reichstag and Prussian Diet.

No report that has to do with human affairs can ignore "the present economic situation." Dr. SUZZALO'S, as president of the Carnegie Foundation for the Advancement of Teaching, frankly faces it at the outset in his advice to colleges and universities.

Spokesmen for the Catholic, Jewish and Protestant faiths joined yesterday in a critical analysis of Hitlerism, in which they agreed that the lack of religious tolerance shown by the German Chancellor and his party doomed the movement to ultimate failure.

Marked irregularity characterized the price trends of local commodities markets last week. There were at times broad advances in sugar and silver, followed by reactions which substantially reduced the earlier gains. Other staples followed the trend in outside markets.
"Louisiana" is scheduled to open tonight at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre. It is a play by J. Augustus Smith, with an all-Negro cast.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Although industrial production increased in January, the gain was less than the usual seasonal amount and factory employment and payrolls continued to decline, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

Coincident with the approaching resignation of Chairman James A. Farley of the State Athletic Commission, and the appointment of D. Walker Wear as his successor, it was revealed yesterday that the commission has already launched a campaign to tighten the regulations on boxing in this State.

Nikolas Muray of the Fencers Club defeated his fellow Olympian and club-mate, Hugh Alessandroni, 5 to 1, In a fence-off and won the metropolitan foils championship and the Herbert Herkimer Trophy in the fencing tournament at the Salle d'Armes Vince yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP) -- The Roosevelt Secretary of State, Cordell Hull, turned tonight momentarily from the Chino-Japanese crisis to other thorny problems of America's foreign affairs, war debts and ways of reviving world trade.

The League of Nations acted promptly in requesting the United States Government to declare whether it wishes to "associate" itself with the action of the Assembly in the question between China and Japan. Secretary STIMSON'S reply is that the American Government has a "common objective" with the League in the policy of maintaining peace and the settlement of international disputes without resort to war.

CHENGTEH (Jehol City), Feb. 26. -- Thia city of 30,000 population, the capital of Jehol Province, is the scene of feverish military activity, as it is the point from which war supplies are being sent to many fronts. The military leaders here say they are prepared for a long siege and that they are ready to withstand the worst the enemy has to offer.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- With the official announcement of President-elect Roosevelt that he had chosen James A. Farley as Postmaster General, it became known today that the O'Connell brothers, Albany County Democratic leaders, had recognized Mr. Farley as State leader and repudiated, in this respect, John F. Curry, Tammany chief.
The text of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler's letter to Senator Reed Smoot follows:

Culture does not teach one to write novels, and "education in the technical sense serves rather to choke than to encourage the power of Imagination," John Galsworthy wrote in "Candelabra," a posthumous collection of his essays and speeches just published by the Scribners.

NEW HAVEN, Feb. 26. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55.1, which compares with 55.4 a week ago, 55.3 two weeks ago, 55.3 three weeks ago and 55.5 four weeks ago. The average of 57.4 in the first week of January was the highest of the year to date; this week's average is the lowest.

A survey by Captain HOOPER, in Naval Institute Proceedings, shows that while Great Britain controls 187,584 nautical miles of cable service and the United States 83,012 miles, the latter "has a leading "place in world rapid communication because of 'radio.'"

Germany has the will to pay off her entire private commercial indebtedness abroad, but she can not contribute more than her export surplus for interest and capital payments and the creditor countries must make this possible by adjustments. Dr. Alfred Hugenberg.

A realignment of the properties of the Pan American Petroleum and Transport Company, which entails the segregation of non-operaing properties in a new company and the consolidation of operating properties, will be proposed to stochholders at a special meeting to be called soon, according to an announcement by E.G. McKeever president.
HAVANA, Feb. 26. -- The magazine Plain Talk, published in New York, will be barred from sale in Cuba hereafter under a decision of the military censors, it was learned today.
Allied Metal Yards, Inc., George W. Files, president, gave a mortgage for $6,500, due Feb. 1, 1934. at 6 per cent, to Fred F. French Operators, Inc., on 174 South St.

At a meeting of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York at 65 Liberty Street on Thursday it is expected that action will be taken on a report of the executive committee that strongly endorses branch banking for New York State along lines recommended by Joseph A. Broderick, Superintendent of Banks.

Specifications for contract bids on about $4,900,000 of new subway construction work, to be started under the 1933 capital outlay budget recently approved by the Board of Estimate, will soon be prepared by the Board of Transportation, it was indicated yesterday.

Revision of the freight rates on lumber moving from Pacific Coast ports to piers on the Atlantic seaboard will be sought today when the member lines of the Inter-coastal Steamship Conference open their semi-annual meeting at Delmonte, Cal. Chairman Robert C. Thackara and representatives of the member lines left New York last week to attend the meeting.
MOSCOW, Feb. 26. -- Two decrees published today, one affecting agriculture, the other industry, give an idea of what is going on in the two realms of Soviet Russia.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- As the Seventy-second Congress approaches its end, with five and a half legislative days remaining, the leaders are giving chief concern to the enactment of three measures aimed to aid the economic situation -- amendment of the bankruptcy act, reduction of principal and interest of mortgages and the Glass banking bill.

CLEVELAND, Monday, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Seven member banks of the Cleveland Clearing House Association early today announced that, effective immediately, withdrawals by depositors would be limited temporarily to 5 per cent of net balances.

The control of crude oil production is declared by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey to be essential not only to the petroleum industry but also in the public interest in a statement outlining its position with respect to the main principles of the production program recently outlined by the directors of the American Petroleum Institute.

GENEVA, Feb. 26. -- Secretary Stimson's note giving the United States Government's approval of the Manchurian report which the League of Nations Assembly adopted Friday morning reached Sir Eric Drummond, the League's Secretary General, on the golf links this afternoon.

J.H. Wantling annexed the high scratch cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday, breaking 97 out of 100 targets. The second scratch cup went to E.S.S. Carroll, who finished with 94. In the handicap shoot the first cup went to J.P. Hennessy, who had a card of 81 -- 17 -- 98.

The East Sixty-eighth Street German Evangelical Reformed Church, 355 East Sixty-eighth Street, celebrated its 175th birthday yesterday with two special services. In the morning the Rev. Julius Jaeger, pastor, preached on the history of the church since pre-Revolutionary days.

A drive against the sale or renting of obscene books by book shops and circulating libraries will be carried on throughout Brooklyn, following a conference to be held in the District Attorney's office this morning, District Attorney Geoghan announced yesterday.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- The Chamber of Deputies and the Senate are both still fighting for every inch of ground in their clash over the financial reforms introduced by the government in the March credit and taxation bill and to be incorporated later in the budget.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial about the Nassau County charter was very gratifying to those who are interested in the movement for better government in that great suburban area. Speaking as one of the committee, I am glad that your editorial writer appreciated the fact that, though the charter comes from a partisan source, it is wholly nonpartisan in character.

The Adopt-a-Family committee of the Women's Division of the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee announced plans yesterday for what it expects to be the largest duplicate bridge tournament ever held. A substantial share of the proceeds will go to the relief committee.
NEW DELHI, Feb. 26. -- The government of India has proscribed the annual session of the All-India National Congress, which it was apparently proposed to hold in Calcutta at the end of March.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Gene Sarazen, United States and British open golf champion, gained commanding lead of 7 up over Olin Dutra, P.G.A. titleholder, in the first half of a 72-hole match for the "unofficial world's golf championship" at the Miami Biltmore Country Club today.

Parents of the village of Scarsdale, N.Y., are organized to battle the bedtime bogys that frighten their children almost nightly in juvenile radio programs, and they hope for the same success with which they vanquished the hot-dog and drove it off the streets of the village several years ago to preserve the regular eating hahits of their youngsters.

A colossal winged bull and a winged lion erected as guardians of a gateway in ancient Nimrud in Assyria nearly 3,000 years ago today stand conspicuously in the Fifth Avenue hall of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, marking the entrance to an exhibition of Assyrian art -- a field hitherto scarcely represented in the museum.
Princeton scored two brilliant victories to advance to a prominent position in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race last week.

NEW ORLEANS, La., Feb. 26. -- Trading in the cotton contract market here last week was far from active and price fluctuations were narrow and influenced largely by the liquidation of the March option. This was effected by switching from the near to the more distant months, but there was sufficient demand for March from spot interests to keep that month fairly steady.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Leaders in the grain trade are unusually nervous, and in wheat lean to the buying side on breaks on the old theory that wheat bought below 50 cents at this time of year will eventually pay a profit. Operators held at the close of the week that it was too early to place too much confidence in crop damage reports from the Southwest.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Business is reported to be moving in fair volume in all sections of this territory, or at about the same rate as in recent weeks, but trade leaders are disposed to take a conservative view and to await the change in the national government before they express themselves positively.

The annual report of Stone Webster, Inc., for 1932 shows a consolidated net income of $1,524,085 after charges, taxes and depreciation, equal to 72 cents a share earned on 2.104,500 shares of stock, without including net profit on sales of securities during the year.

The way out of the depression for the United States, Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler said yesterday, lies in rigid governmental economy and international cooperation on tariffs and war debts, rather than in higher taxes, inflation and "reactionary nationalism."

CHICAGO, Feb. 26. -- Effects of "doubling up" by families in single-family and apartment dwellings are shown in a new nation-wide analysis of housing supply and demand and consequent trends in rentals.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The labor question will never be settled until the last day's work is done. This is true, in large measure, because our solution -- if we could find one -- will be unsatisfactory to succeeding generations. Their ideals will be infinitely higher than ours.

Mrs. S. Hinman Bird is one of a group of prominent women who will assist today at the International Art Exhibition, held at Rockefeller Center under the auspices of the College Art Association. The proceeds of the day will be devoted to the New York City Visiting Committee of the State Charities Aid Association.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26. -- John A. Bell, formerly one of the leading bankers and coal operators of Western Pennsylvania, died last night in Hill View Sanitarium at Washington, Pa., where he had been under treatment for nearly three years.

SANTIAGO, Chile, Feb. 26. -- Differences between Chile and Bolivia as an out growth of Bolivia's undeclared war with Paraguay in the Chaco have been brought further forward by a note from La Paz insisting on the right to continue importing war materials through Chile.

University retrenchment along humane lines is necessitated by severe economic conditions, Dr. Henry Suzzallo declares in his annual report as president of the Carnegie Endowment for the Advancement of Teaching, made public yesterday.
Votes Badly Counted Corruption was not the sole motive for miscounted votes at the recent election in New York. Often it would seem that the purpose was error for error's sake.

Tammany Leader John F. Curry and Kings County Leader John H. McCooey conferred on Saturday on the choice of the New York City representatives in Congress for Speaker of the House. It was disclosed yesterday that they decided to put forward a member of the city's own Congressional delegation, Thomas H. Cullen of Brooklyn, as the candidate of the city bloc.

"Even Einstein has not made one change in the multiplication table," said the Rev. Dr. Arthur J. Brown, former secretary of the Board of Foreign Missions, in his sermon yesterday morning at the Fourth Presbyterian Church, Ninety-first Street and West End Avenue.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Another arm of the Federal Government -- the Internal Revenue Bureau -- reached out today to scrutinize Charles E. Mitchell's 1929 income tax return as the Senate Stock Market Investigating Committee prepared to resume tomorrow its inquiry into his National City Bank of New York, and its security affiliate.

PEIPING, Monday, Feb. 27. -- The Chinese who evacuated Nanling and Chaoyang have now taken UD a new front on a sixty-mile line which crosses the highway from Chaoyang to Lingyuan at Taiplngfang, about a third of the distance between the cities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In an article appearing in your Book Review of Feb. 19, under the title "New Biographies in Italy," your literary correspondent from Rome criticizes Alberto Cappa for having said in his new book, "Cavour," that "Count Sforza is the greatest Italian Foreign Minister since Cavour."

PARIS, Feb. 24. -- This week's statement of the Bank of France followed further decrease of 260,000,000 francs in its gold reserve, making 2,000,000,000 francs decrease, or about $78,000,000, in the eleven weeks since the opening of December.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Two large and important social events today were the reception with which Mrs. Edward T. Stotesbury entertained in honor of Mr. Stotesbury's eighty-fourth birthday, for which the grounds, residence and patio of El Mirasol were the setting, and the dinner given by Joseph E. Widener at his home in compliment to Governor Dave Sholtz, who passed the week-end with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Sholtz.

LAKE PLACID. N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Robert Martin, driving the Lake Placid Athletic Club four-man sled, finished first today in the Adirondack A.A.U. junior championship race on the Mount Van Hoevenberg run with a total elapsed time of 3:46.07 for the three heats.

Eugene Regard, a member of the French National Bondholders Protective Association, a semi-official body, has accepted membership on the Kreuger Toll secured debenture holders' protective committee headed by Grayson M.P. Murphy, according to cabled advices from Paris yesterday.
Preaching yesterday in the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, the Very Rev. Milo H. Gates, dean of the cathedral, said the Bible specifically commanded every Christian to support the government.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- The votes In the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week are given in the appended tabulation:

Bank officers who have failed to put the interests of their clients ahead of their own interests were denounced yesterday by the Rev. W. Russell Bowie in his sermon at Grace Protestant Episcopal Church, Broadway and Tenth Street.

A bill pending in Albany which seeks an amendment to the personal property law by adding a new section in relation to wage assignments is approved in principle but not in its present form by the New York County Lawyers Association, according to a report made public yesterday.

Mgr. Michael J. Lavelle, rector of St. Patrick's Cathedral, appealed to the congregation at high mass yesterday for "universality of contribution" to the annual collection for the support of the cathedral, which will be taken up next Sunday.

Rulers and high officials of foreign countries have cabled or written to Mrs. Carrie Chapman Catt, honorary president of the Conference on the Cause and Cure of War, in response to messages sent by Mrs. Catt and the executive committee of the organization at its recent convention in Washington, urging that they join in efforts to "wipe out war."

The Bronx Hockey Club made its best showing of the season in turning back the strong Boston team, 5 to 2, in an exhibition game at the New York Coliseum yesterday before a crowd of 6,000, the largest of the season.

Charges of "homicide by arson" were lodged against Aaron Schwartz, 51 years old, and his wife, Rachel, 45, yesterday after an investigation of the explosion Which razed the Schwartz home, 262 Watkins Street, Brooklyn, on Saturday night and in which Mrs. Celia Storch, next-door neighbor, was killed and at least twenty others injured.

The original manuscript of the famous inscription written by Benjamin Franklin for the cornerstone of the main building of the Pennsylvania Hospital at Ninth and Spruce Street, Philadelphia, has been discovered recently in Germany and just acquired by Dr. A. S. Rosenbach.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- In the opinion of national farm leaders, Henry A. Wallace of Iowa, whose appointment as Secretary of Agriculture was announced formally today by President-elect Roosevelt, faces the "biggest job in the history of American agriculture.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The figures of the Board of Trade on Great Britain's balance of foreign payments during 1932 are less favorable than some private estimates, but better than others. As a whole, they are regarded as conservative and give the general impression that, while there is doubtless still something of a balance against us in the payments of the year, there is nothing very unhealthy in the country's overseas trading position.

DETROIT, Feb. 26. -- Henry Ford, at a single stroke, has cut the Gordian knot of Detroit's confused and paralyzed banking situation by virtually taking over the two great groups of national banks here.

BOSTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Taking stock of their new property, Tom Yawkey, multi-millionaire purchaser of the Boston Red Sox, and Eddie Collins, his adviser-in-chief, today counted noses and discovered that they had about eight real major league ball players in the squad of thirty-three that will go south to Sarasota, Fla., on Wednesday.

PITTSBURGH, Feb. 26. -- Production of steel ingots last week was at approximately 18 per cent of capacity, or a point below the 19 per cent that had been maintained for three weeks. The official report for February is expected to show an average rate close to 19 per cent, against 17.78 per cent in January and 15.02 per cent in December.

CHICAGO, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Doing all their scoring in the last period, the New York Rangers tonight defeated the Chicago Black Hawks, 4 to 1, and approached to within a point of Detroit, first-place team in the American division of the National Hockey League.

The unsettlement of last week's stock market, the recurrent weakness In the bond market, and the indication that hoarding of currency had increased resulted partly from the not very skillfully handled Michigan episode, but they equally reflected the mental influence of the mischievous talk of experimenting with the currency.

President-elect Roosevelt, the Pope and the Mikado could end war and establish peace if they got together for this purpose, John Haynes Holmes declared in his sermon yesterday before the Community Church, meeting in the Town Hall.

Miss Lorna Whittelsey again displayed her prowess as a dinghy sailor yesterday by winning four of 'the six races held on Long Island Sound off City Island. Handling the tiller of Snow Bird, Miss Whittelsey sailed over the finish line first in all of the races held in the afternoon.

The last few weeks have been marked by a mixture of favorable and unfavorable events, in which superficially the preponderance seems to be on the unfavorable side, says the current issue of the Guaranty Survey published by the Guaranty Trust Company.

A score of exhibitions or more open today in the New York galleries. Paintings and prints by Chicago artists make up a large show at the Whitney Museum of Modern Art. The preview will be held from 11 A.M. to 2 P.M., and the show will open to the public tomorrow.

Charles E. Mitchell offered his resignation last night as chairman and director of the National City Bank and the National City Company, its subsidiary, and of all other National City subsidiaries, in a letter addressed to the directors of the bank, as the result of the recent testimony before the Senate Committee on Banking and Currency.

PORT WASHINGTON, L. I., Feb. 26. -- Defying a north-northwest blow that swept at twenty-five miles an hour-over Manhasset Bay, four dinghies were put under sail today In the regularly scheduled Frostbite Yacht Club regatta of the North Hempstead Yacht Club.

Eugene F. Saxton, editor-in-chief of Harper Brothers, has just returned after several weeks in England and France. He brought back the manuscript of a new novel by H.M. Tomlinson, "The Snows of Helicon," which will be published in May.
DENVER, Feb. 26 (AP). -- The "zero hour" fixed by Claude K. Boettcher as the deadline for the ransoming of his son, Charles Boettcher 2d, passed last midnight.

Athletes receive no academic preferment at Columbia University, but fare a little better than the average student in obtaining remunerative work and scholarships, President Nicholas Murray Butler was informed yesterday by the committee he appointed last October to investigate charges of favoritism made by Spectator, a student publication.

Steel operations declined last week 2 points to 17 per cent of capacity, according to the magazine Steel. The decline, the publication says, is traceable largely to the effects of the Michigan bank moratorium and numerous localized business disturbances.

An aftermath of one of the most sensational art scandals of recent years will take place here on the evening of March 9 when thirty-nine pieces of sculpture by Alceo Dossena will be offered at auction by the National Art Galleries, Inc., in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Plaza.

A new system of inmate education at Elmira Reformatory, designed to meet the special needs of the 1,200 youths confined there, was described yesterday in a preliminary report submitted to the Legislature by the State Commission to Investigate Prison Administration and Construction.

New York City is expected to obtain a short-term loan today or tomorrow from the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank, which institutions jointly lent the city $25,000,000 until Dec. 14, 1933, on Feb. 16. At that time it was indicated that the city would need about $20,000,000 more by the end of the month.

The State Senate Finance Committee's favorable report on a bill to impose a general tax on retail sales is attracting the attention of the building trades, especially of dealers in building materials and supplies whose responsibility in the matter of the tax payments is discussed by Allen E. Beals in the current Dow Service Daily Building Reports.

Authors of the chapter on Crime and Punishment of the President's Research Committee on Social Trends, made public yesterday at its headquarters at 230 Park Avenue, reach the conclusion that there is no crime wave of great size in the country, but that neither an increase nor a reduction in crime is to be expected in the immediate future.

HYDE PARK, Feb. 26 (AP). -- In the small white chapel in Hyde Park village the parish of St. James Episcopal Church bade godspeed today to its senior warden, Franklin D. Roosevelt, and the rector, reading from the Book of Proverbs, adjured him to:

On being told by newspaper men last night that his appointment to the Cabinet had been announced by President-elect Roosevelt, James A. Farley hurried to the telephone in his home and called his wife, who was visiting friends in Brooklyn.

LONDON, Feb. 24. -- The London stock markets are at present under the influence of foreign politics. Considerable decline occurred this week in all the leading foreign bonds, particularly those of China, Japan and Germany, the reasons for the weakness being obvious.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Charging that a new lobby of intimidation by powerful minority groups in Washington offers a serious threat to the American form of government, Representative Royal C. Johnson of South Dakota, in the current issue of the Nation's Business magazine, asserts that "any member of Congress who finds arrayed against him politically five major groups of organized minorities may as well not contine in politics.

Bruno Walter concluded his second season with the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra with the concert at the Metropolitan Opera House yesterday afternoon. The program was devoted to the classics: Bach's Fugue in C minor from the "Musikalisches Opfer" in Eliot B. Wheaton's transcription for orchestra; Brahms's Second Piano Concerto, in B flat, with Ossip Gabrilowitsch as soloist, and Schubert's C major symphony, No. 7.
NEW HAVEN, Feb. 26. -- Choices of new members of the Yale Chapter of Sigma Xi, announced today, included seventy-seven members and forty-eight associates.

The need for housing for families of limited income as well as the need for Reconstruction Finance Corporation aid to such selfliquidating projects as a means of unemployment relief, were emphasized yesterday at a housing rally in celebration of the second anniversary of the opening of Amalgamated Dwellings, a block bounded by Grand, Sheriff, Broome and Columbia Streets.

CHICAGO, Feb. 25. -- A rush of unfinished and undesirable steers, many of which had been overfed and were too weighty for the best trade, caused an unsatisfactory market here last week, some sales being around $4 to $4.50 a hundred-weight, but the poorest stock sellings as low as $3 and causing losses to shippers.

The first Yankee contingent leaves this city today on the Orange Blossom Special of the Seaboard Air Line for the St. Petersburg, Fla., training camp and what Colonel Jacob Ruppert and Business Manager Edward G. Barrow fondly hope will be the preliminary drive to another American League pennant.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., Feb. 26. -- Calling for a new deal in education and fresh cards for the forgotten rural school child, William J. Cooper, United States Commissioner of Education, in an interview here today discussed the serious problems which confront the annual convention of the department of superintendence of the National Education Association.
LONDON, Feb. 26. -- Residents along the upper reaches of the Thames prepared today to evacuate their homes as the stream, swollen by three days' heavy snowfall, rose menacingly.

Hans Wiener gave his first Broadway dance recital in three seasons at the Guild Theatre yesterday afternoon. Assisting him were his teaching associate, Otto Ashermann, the dance group from his Boston studio and a large "motion choir," or company of lay dancers from his New York studio.

An exhibition of German watercolors, drawings and prints opened Saturday afternoon at the Roerich Museum. It is presented by the German Roerich Association in co-operation with Die Freunde der Bildenden Kunst, E.V., of Munich, under whose auspices the work was collected.

PARIS, Feb. 26. -- Profoundly disturbed by Secretary Stimson's note to the League of Nations, Yosuke Matsuoka, speaking for the whole of Japan's Geneva delegation, which is now gathered in Paris, made an earnest plea to the people of the United States tonight "to think twice before they agree light heartedly to the recommen-dations by the League.

Giulio Gatti-Casazza, the silent man who came from Ferrara and Milan twenty-five years ago to take command of New York's opera, was honored last night by a vast audience that paid $16,000 for the jubilee stage show arranged by singing stars, past and present, in honor of their general manager.

BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 26. -- Despite low prices with, a continued lower tendency, grain shipments in the first two months of this year were 419,000 tons less than in the same months last year. With the old corn crop exhausted and flaxseed stocks 50 per cent lower than last year, cereal exports are certain to be much smaller than last year.

BERLIN, Feb. 24. -- The Berlin stock market began the week firm, with a number of advances. In the remainder of the week, however, prices gradually sagged off under the influence of the political unrest in Germany and the uncertainty of the American bank situation.

The Citizens Union announced yesterday that it was opposed to the passage in Albany of the QuinnMcCreery bill making it mandatory that back taxes be paid out of the proceeds of mortgage foreclosure sales. At present the payment or non-payment of taxes lies within the discretion of the judge ordering the foreclosure.

COLUMBUS. Ohio, Feb. 26 (AP).-- The five banks of Akron, agreed today to proceed with business tomorrow on a "restricted withdrawal basis" and the City Commission of Dayton, declared a three-day banking holiday for the three banks in that city.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The following statements displayed on the front page of THE TIMES Feb. 19 were read by thousands of persons: "Ex-Champion Succumbs Here to Cancer -- He Believed He Had Heart Disease." "He died in the belief that the pain that had wracked his body for the last few years of his life had been caused by heart disease."

ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- Assemblyman Abbot Low Moffat, New York City Republican, will present eight bills tomorrow evening based on recommendations of the late Hofstadter committee and designed to wipe out an annual six figure total of rich county patronage in the five New York City counties.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26 (AP). -- A call has been issued for the 127 new Democratic House members-elect to meet Wednesday night to formulate demands for recognition to be made of the old members at the party's organization caucus Thursday night.

Fifteen teams responded to the starter's gun as the fifty-fourth international six-day bicycle race got under way at Madison Square Garden at 9 o'clock last night. With the leading American and European pedal pushers entered, prospects for an entertaining week-long session loomed bright, and a large opening night crowd, numbering more than 15,000 persons, was on hand to witness the activity.

Glenn Cunningham did not run the extra 120 yards in an attempt to lower Gene Venzke's 4:10 mile record at the national indoor trackand field championships on Saturday. The timers were ready to clock the burly Kansan after he had defeated the Penn freshman in the 1,500-meter title test and set out after a new mark.
DES MOINES, Iowa, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Notified of his selection by President-elect Roosevelt as Secretary of Agriculture, Henry A. Wallace was reluctant today to discuss his plans.
The text of the findings and recommendations of the majority of the committee appointed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler to study football conditions at Columbia University follow:

In the farewell address in 1926 of Dr. McGlFFERT as president of Union Theological Seminary he urged the graduating class never to attempt to suppress free and honest inquiry into religion, never to be afraid to face criticism and never to use a negative instead of a positive religion.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., Feb. 26. -- The Litchfield School of Law, situated between Morristown and Bernardsville and named for the first law school in America, which was established at Litchfield, Conn., in 1784, will be opened to a limited number of women, law students next Fall.

Ample evidence that charity is being relied upon to pay the difference between wages and what it costs to keep alive has been found by the Consumers League of New York, 150 Fifth Avenue, in its examination of employers' applications for workers filed with the State Employment Service and with such private exchanges as the Young Women's Christian Association and the Girls Service League, it was announced by the league yesterday.

Increased activity was noted in the wholesale markets here last week, with better consumer response indicated by the large number of mail orders received by the leading buying offices here. A brisk demand was reported for coats and suits, especially fur-trimmed models.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Some business men believe that the present Senate banking investigation is untimely and that it is very likely to have a harmful effect on business.

HYDE PARK, N.Y., Feb. 26. -- Confirming previously published reports, President-elect Roosevelt formally announced today the selection of two more Cabinet members, Henry A. Wallace of Des Moines for Secretary of Agriculture and James A. Farley of New York City for Postmaster General.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 26. -- Apprehensive lest the Jehol hostilities Involve the Tientsin region, the Chinese are maintaining 30.000 soldiers alongth the eighteen-mile railway from plans already have been, formulated to block the river traffic by sinking two steamers if hostilities develop in the Tientsin area.
KNOXVILLE, Tenn., Feb. 26. -- The city of Knoxville is issuing scrip at the rate of more than $134,000 a month and merchants say it circulates faster than money.

Vocational training and education of the ordinary type have proved virtually worthless as preventives of juvenile delinquency among, the children of poverty-stricken families, Pauline Tripp, psychologist at the House of Refuge on Randall's Island, declared yesterday in the annual report of that institution.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- Mayor Anton Cermak developed pneumonia in one lung today and Dr. W.J. Snyder, one of the attending physicians, said the disease probably would spread rapidly.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 26. -- In heat approaching that of midsummer, the first contingent of the 1933 Dodgers checked into their quarters at Coral Gables today. The players will report to Manager Max Carey for their initial workout at Miami Field tomorrow morning at 10:30.

NEW YORK. The Hon. and Mrs. Bernard Clive Pearson of London, their daughter, Miss Veronica Mary Pearson, and their nephew, the Hon. John Pearson, son of Viscount Cowdray, are expected tomorrow at the St. Regis from Mexico City.
ALBANY, Feb. 26. -- A measure setting up machinery for a convention to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment by the State is expected to pass the Legislature this week.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- President and Mrs. Hoover gave a tea this afternoon for members of their household, including the military and naval aides and the secretaries to the President and their wives, Mrs. Hoover's three secretaries, and others of the White House staff.

LONDON, Feb. 26. -- The British House of Commons will debate the Far Eastern situation tomorrow but there are no indications that anything will be said by any member of the government or the dominant parliamentary group that will cause Japan alarm or hurt her feelings.

Among the lasting memorials to JOHN D. ROCKEFELLER Jr. will be the areas of park land, scattered the country over, which his generosity has preserved. The Yellowstone, the Yosemite and the Great Smokies have all seen how gold has been transmuted at his touch into the yet more precious metal of lake, forest and mountain protected from intrusion and dedicated in perpetuity to public use.

Speeches denouncing Hitlerism in Germany and Fascism in Italy yesterday afternoon at a Socialist mass meeting in Town Hall, 123 West Forty-third Street, were punctuated by blows and catcalls, and at one point were interrupted for terminutes while five or six Hitler sympathizers were ejected from the building with swollen lips and blackened eyes by a flying squad of Socialists in a welter of fluttering badges.

The flag of Hungary, a stranger to this port in recent years, flew above the freighter Puszta last night as she lay at Pier 7, Jersey City, after a crossing from Swan-sea, Wales. The ship docked unannounced on Saturday. When told last night of her arrival, George de Ghika, Consul General of Hungary, expressed surprise.

Without losing a game, Donald Strachan and Brendan D. Walsh of the Racquet and Tennis Club of Philadelphia smashed through, the final round of the Lockett trophy squash racquets doubles tourney at the University Club yesterday in an unexpected triumph over Neil Sullivan and Ray Coffin of the Germantown Cricket Club.

Like two or three other royal writers, Grand Duke Alexander had been both industrious and successful since the revolution turned him from his palace. His recent books, "Once a Grand Duke" and "Twilight of Royalty," have had many readers here and abroad.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- Reports from Detroit that Henry Ford had agreed to take over the First National Bank and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce and subscribe all the capital stock in the reorganization was officially confirmed here tonight and accepted by officials as a step which should lend great confidence in the banking situation.

DETROIT, Feb. 26. -- The New York Americans, doing their best work in the second period, played a 1-1 tie with the Detroit Red Wings in an overtime National Hockey League game tonight before 8,000 spectators.

VATICAN CITY, Feb. 26 (AP) -- Thrift was exalted today in an address by Pope Piua In which he expressed confidence this year would see the end of the universal crisis. Speaking to 600 clerks of savings banks in the Province of Lombavdy, he said:

There is no nonsense about Senator NORRIS and his fellow-Progressives at Washington. They do not propose to delude themselves. All this talk of their losing their identity and merging themselves in a great and happy Democratic family under ROOSEVELT does not appeal to them at all.

Henry Mattson of the Woodstock colony, whose first one-man show in five years now occupies the largest of the exhibition rooms at the Rehn Gallery, walks, like Kipling's cat, alone. His work in oil is unique and hard to classify. Certainly meriting the public's attention, it is not to be taken in at a glance nor fathomed without patience and an openminded approach.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, Feb. 26 (AP). -- Waylayer, 4-year-old brown gelding owned by A. A. Baroni, won the $2,000 added Phar Lap Memorial Handicap today by a scant nose from Prince Pest, 5-year-old gelding owned by Mrs. J.M. Irwin.

BOSTON, Mass., Feb. 26. -- The heaviest snow storm in several years, sweeping in unpredicted by the Weather Bureau before a strong northeast gale, blanketed much of New England under more than a foot of heavy wet snow last night and early today, indirectly causing four deaths, impeding highway traffic, delaying shipping and interrupting telephone, light and power service.
Housing properties constituted the bulk of the New Jersey realty trading reported over the week-end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 26. -- A veto of the independent offices appropriation bill was urged upon President Hoover today by the National Economy League because his recommendations for a reduction in the costs of the Veterans' Administration, were disregarded and nearly a billion dollars set aside for that branch of the government.
