The March 1 Monthly Review of Credit and Business Conditions by the Federal Reserve Agent at New York will say that sales of both the chain store systems and department stores for January were below those of January last year, the Federal Reserve Bank announces.

Three important paintings, one of which never has been exhibited in this country, will be lent by Duveen Brothers to the international exhibition of fine arts at the Chicago Art Institute which is being arranged in connection with the Century of Progress Exposition next Summer.

Since more American funds are invested in Canada than anywhere else outside of the United States, that country's balance of payments is of special interest. A review of the record for 1932, and a comparison with earlier years, is published in the current number of The Annalist.

The British, announcement yesterday of an arms embargo against Japan and China, pending the solution of the problem of exports and imports of arms and ammunition by the League of Nations, is expected by observers here to react to Japan's advantage.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The withdrawal of Japan from the League of Nations, following her refusal for nearly a year and a half to cease from military operations in Manchuria, has called forth great censure from other nations, especially from the United States and the smaller nations belonging to the League.

"Discovery," the second volume of John Drinkwater's biography, is published by Houghton Mifflinm today. It takes in the years 1897 to 1913. While John Galsworthy said, in a volume of essays just published here under the title "Candelabra," that it was necessary for him to forget what he had learned in schools before he became successful as a writer, Mr. Drinkwater regrets that he never went to a university.

Jan Smeterlin, here for his third American tour, gave his only New York recital of the season at Carnegie Hall last night. The program began with Bach-Busoni's Prelude and Triple Fugue in E flat and Mozart's Sonata in D major, K. 311.

Two restaurant managers accused by the police of violating Section 421 of the penal code, relating to misleading advertisements, pleaded not guilty when arraigned yesterday in magistrate's court. The arrests were the first in a drive by the Police Department to compel clubs and restaurants that advertise "no cover charge" to fulfill that pledge.

Several hundred engineers in the offices of the five borough presidents will experience their second payless payday of the month today, because the city's Finance Department cannot find funds with which to pay them. On Feb. 10 the Board of Estimate appropriated $264,000 in tax notes to meet their salaries for two months, but Controller Berry now holds it would be illegal to use tax note money for this purpose.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Additional cuts of $10,000,000 from the $216,000,000 budget submitted by Governor Lehman have been devised by the steering committee of Republican Assemblymen.

The discontinuance of all pensions to veterans not injured in war service and the readjustment of all other pensions "in accordance with the reduced cost of, living" are urged upon Congress in a report of the committee on Taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, which will be submitted to the chamber on Thursday.

There are 250,000 words in the English language, approximately three times as many as in any other tongue, Professor Robert L. Ramsey of the University of Missouri asserts in a survey appearing in the quarterly American Speech, just published by the Columbia University Press.

GENEVA, Feb. 27. -- Hope for the abolition of war aviation declined considerably here today when the Disarmament Conference's air committee, by an overwhelming majority, decided to explore the French plan for the internationalization of civil aviation.

Sergeant Edwin England, 53 years old, attached to the Wakefield police station, shot and critically wounded his wife and fatally wounded himself early yesterday morning in an argument in their home at 1,261 Stadium Avenue, the Bronx.

PARIS, Feb. 27. -- By putting a question of confidence and staking on it his Cabinet's life, Premier Daladier today obtained a reversal of the Senate's position on the cut of 500,000,000 francs [about $19,725,000 at the current rate] in national defense expenditure, which already had been passed by the Chamber of Deputies.
BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The next two months will witness the first round of what the Soviet leaders hope will be the final struggle to win the Russian peasants to bolshevism.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria (Japanese Field Headquarters), Feb. 27 (AP). -- The Chinese defense appeared to be stiffening today and there was no relaxation of the bitter weather along the entire front. The heaviest fighting In the campaign so far was reported.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -- John B. Ryerson of Cooperstown, N.Y., former Yale star, won the medal in the qualifying round for the Palm Beach golf championship at the Palm Beach Country Club today. He led the field by three strokes with a card of 34 -- 38 -- 72.
Fordham's baseball team launched its first step in preparation for the 1933 campaign yesterday, when fifteen candidates for battery positions reported in the college gymnasium to Coach Jack Coffey.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Democratic members of the House are having a hard time keeping their minds on pending business, due to the campaign now under way for the office of Speaker of the Seventy-third House of Representatives, which may be filled at the caucus of re-elected and new members Thursday night.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Declaring that short-sighted and selfish employers have used the economic depression as a pretext for lowering wages to levels entirely out of proportion to services rendered and below that of decent subsistence, Governor Lehman in a special message sent to the Legislature this evening urged prompt action looking to the establishment of a minimum wage for women and minors in industrial employment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Ambassador Paul Claudel today confirmed reports that he will soon be recalled to Europe. On leaving his conference with Senator Hull, incoming Secretary of State, the Ambassador told newspaper men that there "is something in the report" that Andre Lefebvre de la Boulaye will succeed him here.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Enthusiastically, a part of the 1933 pennant hopes of Flatbush launched their annual preparedness program at 11 o'clock this morning under the direction of Manager Max Carey and his first lieutenant, Casey Stengel.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 27. -- Admitting indebtedness of $13,000,000 to the Wesco Corporation of Delaware and more than $2,000,000 to the Fox Film Corporation of New York, the Fox West Coast Corporation filed a petition in voluntary bankruptcy today in United District Court here.

A rally in prices of United States Government bonds stood out yesterday against a background of general declines in domestic corporation and foreign loans. With New York City banks already in a liquid position and banks throughout the country now more nearly approximating that state than a few weeks ago, the pressure of government bonds on the market was relaxed.

SUMMIT, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Two men were killed and three injured today when a boiler exploded at the plant of the Berkeley Heights Brick Yards at Berkeley Hights, about five miles from here. The explosion was believed to have been caused by steam pressure within the boiler after it had been fired with the pipes frozen.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The Boerse was inactive, and prices were rather irregular today, but the market's undertone was steady. Stock fluctuations were fractional, with a few exceptions. Among the latter was Dortmund Union which finished 2 points above Saturday's closing and A.E.G. which rose 1 1/2 points, whereas Accumulatoren reacted from its recent spurts, losing 5 points.

If the voodoo gods looked after the welfare of Negro actors on Broadway such an artless drama as "Louisiana," which was acted at the Forty-eighth Street Theatre last evening, would be spared, the humiliation of a professional review.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Senator Glass, who declined the post of Secretary of the Treasury in the Roosevelt Cabinet, is slated to assume the chairmanship of the Appropriations Committee when the Democrats reorganize the Senate.
BERLIN, Tuesday, Feb. 28. -- An attempt was made last night to burn down the Reichstag building and it almost succeeded.

E.R. Bradley, who won the last Kentucky Derby with Burgoo King, is the leading nominator, with eighty-seven nominations, for the Saratoga stakes, entries for which closed recently, it was announced yesterday by Victor Schaumburg.

The Reading Company has made provision for the payment from 1932 earnings of the full annual dividends of $2 each on its first and second preferred stock this year, Charles H. Ewing, president, states in the report for last year, issued yesterday.

A report on the finances of the Hungarian Government made to American bankers by John Foster Dulles, of the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell, was issued to the public yesterday through the Institute of International Finance, which is conducted by the Investment Bankers Association in cooperation with New York University.

HYDE PARK, Feb. 27. -- The selection of two more members of his Cabinet, Harold Ickes of Chicago, for Secretary of the Interior and Senator Claude A. Swanson of Virginia, for Secretary of the Navy, was announced today by President-elect Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- President and Mrs. Hoover entertained the members of the "medicine-ball cabinet" and their wives at breakfast today, after a final "workout," in which the wives of twelve of the players joined their husbands, to their surprise, at the invitation of Mrs. Hoover.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- With the approval of President-elect Roosevelt, Major Gen. Blanton Winship, Judge Advocate General of the Army, will sail shortly for Monrovia, Liberia, as special American representative in an effort to straighten out tangled affairs between Liberia and the United States.

Trading on the Stock Exchange yesterday reflected the cautious attitude of the speculative fraternity. There was a fractional decline at the opening, followed by a feeble rally. Fresh weakness in the last hour coincided with a break in grain prices.

Lacking part of the funds for its March 1 payrolls and other obligations, the city borrowed yesterday $10,000,000 from the Chase National Bank und the National City Bank at an interest rate of 5 per cent, one-quarter of 1 per cent higher than the rate paid for $25,000,000 borrowed on Feb. 16.

Returning home late yesterday from the Cumberland Hospital In Brooklyn, where she and her eldest daughter, Selice, 15 years old, had waited in line to have the girl treated for a cold, Mrs. Selice Romak found all of her makeshift furniture and her five other young children in the street.

Benjamin Winter, real estate operator, whose transactions during the boom years amounted to millions of dollars and involved a number of the most valuable properties in the city, came back into the market yesterday with the purchase of a Bronx apartment house held at about $250,000.

Philip P. Jacobs, who will complete twenty-five years of continuous service with the National Tuberculosis Association of New York today, declared yesterday that one of the most remarkable developments in the field of public health was the awakening consciousness of the American people to public health.

Federal Judge John C. Knox in imposing sentence yesterday upon an income tax dodger, alluded to the statement of Charles E. Mitchell, former chairman of the board of the National City Bank, that he had sold stock to a relative in 1929 to avoid payment of an income tax.

The General Motors Acceptance Corporation, all of whose stock, except the qualifying shares of directors, is owned by the General Motors Corporation, reported yesterday a net profit of $6,266,102 for 1932, equivalent to $12.53 a share on 500,000 shares of capital stock.

Ethelbert silently paced the basement floor of the County Court House last night with a dejected droop of the head and a discouraged kink in his tail. Now and then he paused and mewed a puzzled and plaintive new.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., Feb. 27. -- With reported total operating revenues cut more than 50 per cent since 1929, consolidation of the Pennsylvania and Reading systems in South Jersey is mandatory if they are to continue adequate publice service, the New Jersey Board of Public Utility Commissioners was told by representatives of the two roads here today.

Huddie Johnson, pianist, who made her Hew York debut yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall as one of the winners of the Naumburg Foundation, which awards a number of recitals each season to promising young musicians, played with gratifying musicianship and sensitivity when she did not attempt works that are at present beyond her technique and her expressive powers.

While City College authorities continued yesterday to consider disciplinary action against participants in Friday's student strike, Dr. Morton Gottschall acting dean, congratulated the general student body on its "good sense" in refusing to join the strikers.

Fire destroyed a warehouse owned by Peter Cardinale Son, Inc., at Eleventh Street and the Hudson River, Hoboken, early last night, and spread to six barges of the Petterson Lighterage and Towing Company that were moored close by.

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 27. -- Pleas to American educational leadership to place a determined hand upon the reins of governmental budget-making and to guide the younger generation to a new understanding and control of our technological order were applauded today by thousands of educators from all parts of the country gathered here at the convention of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association.
SYDNEY, Australia, Tuesday, Feb. 28. -- England today won the fifth and last cricket test match from Australia by eight wickets, scoring 168 runs for two wickets.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Charges that the revolution, in Leticia was carried out, not by natives of the town itself, but by inhabitants of the neighboring Peruvian Province of Loreto, were included in a statement issued here tonight by the Colombian Legation.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Without comment, Governor Lehman dismissed today the charges against Borough President Harvey of Queens.

As an aid to municipalities in financing public improvements, special assessments are proper enough, provided they are not overdone. New York might be better able to cope with its financial difficulties today if from the beginning the principle of assessing part of the cost against property directly benefited had been applied to subway construction.

Emil Kissel, 20 years old, of 7,208 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, who was released from Brooklyn city prison last week where he had been held since November on a charge of patricide, was held without bail for a further hearing this morning, following his arraignment yesterday before Magistrate James A. Blanchfield, in the new Fourth Avenue court, on a charge of robbery.

Lady Lister Kaye will arrive from England today on the Cunarder Aquitania. She will pay social visits in New York and Washington. Others on the ship are Sir George Barnes, General Benavides, Peruvian Minister to London, and Jascha Heifetz, violinist.

TO avoid confusion, it is stated at the outset that this is a brief essay concerning Gene Venzke and Glenn Cunningham, two great runners who have been starring in a moving melodrama entitled "Afoot in America," but these fellows are fast and, from a standing start, it may take some time to catch up on them. Patienza, as the Italians say.

Orders Yesterday Showed Pick-Up A sharp pick-up in mail orders was reported here yesterday, marking what resident buyers and others believe to be the end of the lull which featured much of the last half month in the apparel trades. Retailers are now beginning to note increased consumer interest in Spring merchandise and strong promotions of the new garments are planned for the period directly ahead.
The Fish and Game Division of the New York State Conservation Department yesterday announced the inauguration of a survey of the fisheries problems of the famous Raquette River system.

An experiment in maritime construction will be completed today with the launching of an all-welded, steel cargo ship, built for the New Jersey Clay Products Company of South River, N.J., at the Staten Island plant of the United Dry Docks Company, Inc. It has been named the William F. Kenny, and will be sponsored by Mrs. William F. Kenny Jr., wife of the president of the Clay Products Company.
Reduction of housing costs outside of material and labor is necessary before home prices can be cut to any great extent, in the opinion of C.E. Close of the American Forest Products Industries.
BUENOS AIRES, Feb. 27. -- The Paraguayan Senate met in secret session for two hours tonight, according to Asuncion dispatches, debating the project to declare war against Bolivia.

WASHINGTON Feb. 27. -- The Federal Resprve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on Feb. 21 shows decreases for the week of $314,000,000 in loans and investments. $265,000,000 in net demand deposits.

Student controversy over the football situation at Columbia University was revived yesterday by the publication of the report of the special committee appointed by Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler last Fall to investigate the athletic situation at Columbia.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- The first indictment in the Federal Government's investigation of the Insull crash, accusing nineteen individuals of a gigantic mail fraud through the selling of Corporation Securities stock was returned today by the grand jury before Judge Charles E. Woodward.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Twin boys were born today to the Earl and Countess of Dumfries. The elder child is in direct succession to one of the greatest landed estates in the peerage.

Simon Liebovitz, president of S. Liebovitz Sons, shirt manufacturers, who died Oct. 24, 1930, left an estate valued yesterday at $1,177,803 gross and $693,382 net. The deduction was due largely to debts of $450,672, of which he owed $442,538 to his company.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, Feb. 27 (AP). -- In the space of thirty-eight minutes the Ohio Legislature tonight passed two emergency banking laws aimed at breaking the financial jam caused when fifty banks in the State restricted or stopped withdrawal of deposits.
ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The text of Governor Lehman's special message on wage legislation, read to the Legislature today, follows:

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- The Sargent bill amending the present drastic pistol law so that up-State applicants for pistol permits will not have to be fingerprinted and photographed was passed tonight by the Assembly, 78 to 62.

MIAMI, Fla., Tuesday, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Although the spread of pneumonia in the right lung of Mayor Anton Cermak doubled the affected area in twenty-four hours, it was checked during the night and his physicians, less pessimistic, expressed encouragement at his success in resisting the disease.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Miss Diana Fishwick, former British champion, paired with E.T. MacGovern of Great Barrington, Mass., won Iow gross honors today in the mixed foursome competition which annually precedes the Florida East Coast women's championship on the St. Augustine links.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- World economic conditions and their relation to a possible program of international cooperation for recovery from the depression were discussed today by Senator Hull, incoming Secretary of State, with Sir Ronald Lindsay, British Ambassador to Washington, and with Paul Claudel, French Ambassador.
NEW YORK. Lady Lister Kaye is arriving on the Aquitania and will be at the Ambassador.

Reorganization of the Bush Terminal Company with the return of Irving T. Bush, its founder, to the presidency will be sought at the annual meeting of the stockholders in April. Mr. Bush yesterday opened his fight to regain executive control with a statement to stockholders requesting them to place their proxies in his hands.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Not in years, if ever before in this country's history, have the words of a President's inaugural address been so prayfully awaited as those which Franklin D. Roosevelt will utter next Saturday. Never before perhaps, in the week before his inaugural, has a President-elect been under such pressure to anticipate the address he will make after taking the oath.

From 85,000 items of correspondence hidden for 140 years in seventeen chests in the cellar of a country house in Kent England, J.C. Long, an American biographer, has pieced out the story of the career of Lord Jeffery Amherst. The title of the biography, published today by Macmillan, is, perhaps in reminiscence of the Amherst College song, "Lord Jeffery Amherst, a Soldier of the King."

Gusty northwest winds which reached a velocity of 48 miles an hour whistled over the city all day yesterday, bringing a precipitate drop in temperature, injuring a woman pedestrian and causing slight property damage. The high wind, generated by a storm centring in the St. Lawrence region, threatened to continue through the night, but j the Weather Bureau expected it to diminish somewhat today.

The East Side Omnibus Corporation, to which the Board of Estimate voted a twenty-five-year franchise for east side Manhattan routes last Friday, announced yesterday its intention to tender the city today $184,000 in cash in settlement of all unpaid franchise taxes on the property of the Second Avenue Railroad Corporation.

A plea of guilty to forgery, covering also six grand larceny indictments, was entered in General Sessions yesterday by Alexander J. Whynman, 29 years old, former Deputy State's Attorney General in the Bank of United States Investigation, involving thefts of $10,000 from debtors of the defunct bank.

Led by the New York Central, nine railroads reported yesterday increased net operating incomes for January. The Eastern line increased its net income by $248,684, at the same time reducing its operating ratio from 80.5 in January, 1932, to 76.2.

GENEVA, Feb. 27. -- Colombia and Peru both notified the League of Nations today that they had ordered the immediate cessation of hostilities in the Upper Amazon basin, in accordance with recommendations made to them by their delegates here Saturday, with stimulation from the League.

Price trends were irregular in yesterday's local commodity trading, with generally lower tendencies. Trading was in moderate volume in most cases. A feature of the day's trading was the drop of cocoa prices to new lows, from which they later rebounded.

BERLIN, Feb. 27. -- The name plate of the German cruiser Emden, which was captured by the Australians in November, 1914, was presented today by Stanley M. Bruce, Australian High Commissioner in London, to President von Hindenburg as a gift from the Australian Commonwealth to the German republic.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Is it not high time that our security holders showed that they possess some resistance point in regard to security values? I was in England in 1926, when the general strike broke out, an event far more serious in its potentialities than anything likely to confront the United States at this time.

An improved demand for United States Government bonds developed yesterday with a resultant appreciation in values. Other sections of the bond market were depressed again. Stocks moved irregularly lower after a display of strength at midday.

GENEVA, Feb. 27. -- The League published today a British note dated Saturday asking, with the concurrence of France, that the Council "study measures which, in the application of Article XI of the covenant, might be proposed with a view to preventing the supply of arms and war material to Bolivia and Paraguay."

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., Feb. 27. -- Dr. Hans Zinsser, Harvard bacteriologist who announced two years ago the Isolation of the typhus fever germ which has taken a toll of millions of lives, has produced a serum which has immunized animals to the disease and is now being used on humans with the hope of ultimate control of the scourge.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Resentment among Southern Democrats against reported plans of National Chairman James A. Farley for handling Federal patronage came into the open today when Representative McMillan of South Carolina issued a condemnation of the whole project.

PEEPING, Feb. 27. -- Chihfeng has become the focus of attention on two fronts as the Japanese continue to sweep across the Northern Jehol deserts and through the mountains amidst alternating snow and duststorms, achieving points more than half way along the 172-mile stretch between Kailu and Chihfeng.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- President Hoover was acclaimed as national leader by the executive committee of the Republican National Committee in cession here today after he had outlined a program which he declared should command the respect of the entire people.

The Engineers Public Service Company and subsidiaries in their annual report for 1932 show cash of $5,344,389 at the end of the year, against $4,532,243 a year before, and notes payable of $6,470,181, against $11,736,846. Cash gained $812,146 despite a reduction of $5,266,665 in the notes payable.

The awarding of the Papal medal, Pro Ecclesia et Pontifice, to Miss Mary C. Duffy, Supreme Regent of the Catholic Daughters of America, for her leadership of the largest organization of Catholic women in America, was announced yesterday at the semi-annual meeting of the Board of National Directors of that organization, held at the headquarters, 10 West Seventy-first Street.

The James Monroe quintet maintained its lead in the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P.S. A.L. tournament by vanquishing Evander Childs, 21 -- 16, yesterday on the latter'a court for its fifth victory in a row.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- By a vote of 233 to 106 the House today passed the Senate bill creating the Morristown National Historical Park, and sent the measure to the White House for President Hoover's signature. The area was the home of General Washington and his troops.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Mr. and Mrs. Frank L. Crocker, who will leave tomorrow for New York after passing ten days a house guests of Richard B.W. Hall at Louwana, gave a dinner to thirty persons tonight at Patio Margery.
W.E. Coyle of the Fraternity Club, second seeded player, gained the third round of the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Squash Club last night.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Judge Kenesaw M. Landis today lost another fight in his long war against the baseball farm system when the minor leagues voted to accept the major league player transfer rule.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Grand Union, a speedy 4-year-old from the Blue Star Stable, galloped away from his opposition in the mile-and-fifty-yard feature at Oriental Park today.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- After asserting that more than $600,000,000 had been wasted in farm relief efforts and that the farmers had lost probably $1,000,000,000 more in taking "unwise advice" on holding their crops, Bernard W. Snow, statistician of the Board of Trade and chairman of the Business Men's Federation, proposed a new plan today for making the tariff effective for agriculture pending a government that will put the farmer on an equality with Industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The National City Company "only made an honest mistake" in helping to underwrite $90.000,000 of Peruvian Government bonds in 1927 and 1928, although advice to the contrary had repeatedly been given since 1921 by authorities on South American credit.
LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Beginning today, Great Britain is prohibiting exports of munitions both to Japan and China.

Dropping of Personal Property Levy Urged by Bronx Board. Repeal of the personal property tax is advocated by the Bronx Board of Trade in letters just sent to Governoi Lehman, members of the State Legislature, and the Mayor, Controller and other officials of this city.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 27. -- The Yale Swimming Association tonight announced that it would hold its first annual carnival on March 8 in the exhibition pool of the Payne Whitney gymnasium.

The Economic Forum, recently organized to examine current problems and promote improvements, met last night at the New School for Social Research, 66 West Twelfth Street, under the chairmanship of Frank Vanderlip, former president of the National City Bank.

Censorship, sedition bills and other repressive measures were condemned yesterday in discussions and resolutions at the annual meeting of the American Civil Liberties Union, held in the Henry Street Settlement building at 99 Park Avenue.

Bernard C. McGuire, promoter of chance enterprises, who was convicted and sentenced to serve a year and a day in Atlanta Penitentiary for violating the Federal lottery law in connection with drawings conducted by the Fraternal Order of Eagles, pleaded guilty yesterday to a similar charge relating to drawings conducted by the Loyal Order of Moose.

PEIPING, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Checkmated at the pass of Paishihtsumen, the Japanese drive in Central Jehol has suddenly changed its line of attack toward Tamiao, with the object of seizing Chienping, about half way between Chaoyang and Chihfeng.

DENVER, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Confident that he would receive another communication from the kidnappers of his son within the next twenty hours, Claude K. Boettcher, father of Charles Boettcher 2d, refused today to divulge to police contents of letters he received from the abductors containing instructions on bow to pay $60,000 ransom.

Fred W. Sargent, president of the Chicago North Western Railway, announced yesterday a plan to refund $6,355,000 of the road's 5 per cent sinking fund debentures due on May 1 through one-half cash and one-half from a loan from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

A legislative bill designed to eliminate multiple job holding in the city's public schools by empowering the Board of Education to grant leaves of absence without pay was approved last night at a joint meeting of the board and the Board of Superintendents in the office of Dr. George J. Ryan, president of the Board of Education.
Lean College Years. College athletics are today "more nearly in consonance with the educational process." So says the annual report of the Carnegie Endowment for the Advancement of Teaching.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith sent an appeal yesterday to 1,000 New Yorkers on behalf of the campaign of the Bowery Y.M.C.A., which is seeking to raise $67,000 before March 15 for immediate relief of homeless and unemployed men.

The board of directors of the National City Bank, meeting before the opening of regular banking hours yesterday morning, accepted the resignation of Charles E. Mitchell as chairman of the bank, abolished that position and chose James H. Ferkins, president of the City Bank Farmers Trust Company, a National City affiliate, to be chairman of the board.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., Feb. 27. -- Charles Arnwine, 25-year-old iron worker, was convicted by a jury of ten men and two women in the Bucks County Court today of murdering Frances Rempfer, a Newtown High School sophomore, at a tryst near her home on Nov. 13.

Morris Bier, a witness who testified last week that all had been quiet and orderly on election day at Public School 110, where he had served, he said, as a Communist watcher, was not near the polls between 4 and 7 P.M. that day, and he did not, as he testified, turn in a tally of the vote to Communist headquarters, according to testimony yesterday before Federal Judge John C. Knox.

A self-constituted advisory committee of Westchester County citizens was formed yesterday at a meeting in the Hotel Biltmore to enlist their cooperation with the National Probation Association organized by Charles E. Hughes Jr., its president.

MONTREAL, Feb. 27 (Canadian Press). -- The last full month of the National Hockey League campaign draws to a close with a new leader in point scoring in the International group, but with Bill Cook of the New York Rangers still the league leader and top man in the American section.

MOORESTOWN, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Apparently nearing the end of his personal inquiry to determine whether to reopen the investigation into the deaths by shooting in June, 1929, of Horace Roberts Jr. and Ruth Mowdray "Wilson, Prosecutor Howard Eastwood of Burlington County visited late today the Wilson home here with the announced intention of reconstructing the case.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 27. -- It has been learned definitely that despite the tremendous pressure of public opinion which bitterly criticizes his remaining at Nanchang engaged in a "side-show" anti-Communist campaign, General Chiang Kai-shek, Nanking Commander-in-Chief, will not proceed to Peiping and Jehol.

ALBANY, Feb. 27. -- Governor Lehman, at a conference during luncheon at the Executive Mansion today, told Senator, John J. Dunnigan and Assemblyman Irwin Steingut, legislative leaders of his party, that he would look for final action by the Legislature before the week is over on a bill setting up machinery for a convention to ratify or reject the resolution of Congress for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The United States Tariff Commission announced today that it had begun an investigation of competitive conditions as they relate to the wood pulp industry at home and abroad, under the provisions of a resolution passed by the Senate last week.
TOKYO, Tuesday, Feb. 28. -- Japanese armies are reported today to be slowly converging on Lingyuan and Chihfeng.

HANOVER, N.H., Feb. 27. -- Dartmouth's basketball team continued its winning ways in Eastern Intercollegiate League competition, downing Pennsylvania tonight, 29 to 19, and going into a tie for third place in the circuit.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Tuesday, Feb. 28. -- One minute after mid-night Governor Pinchot signed a resolution passed late at night by both branches of the Legislature giving individual banks in Pennsylvania the right to limit the withdrawal of deposits made up to and including yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Sears, Roebuck Co, mail-order and chainstore organization, operated at a loss last year for the first time since 1921. They made a moderate profit on their merchandising business, but this was wiped out by losses sustained in other activities and non-recurring charges.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today, with certain conditions, extension, by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation of a loan of $3,000,000 to the receivers of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railroad, of which $2,000,000 would be applied to the payment of taxes and $1,000,000 to payment of their equipment trust obligations.

LOS ANGELES, Feb. 27. -- An assertion that the bankers of the nation, who, he contended were led by J.P. Morgan Co., were blocking a solution of the railroad and other vital problems was made here today in an address before the University Club by Samuel Untermyer of New York.

Despite lowering standards "cutthroat" competition and cheapening of products with "price" as the only criterion, a spirit of "heads up" instead of "heads down," is likely to prove helpful in the present crisis, Leo A. Del Monte, president of the Industrial Council of Cloak.

Thirty candidates for the New York University baseball squad reported to Coach William V. McCarthy at the University Heights gym for the opening of pre-season practice yesterday. Most of the squad consisted of battery men.

The newly organized team of George Reith, Willard S. Karn, B. J. Becker and Charles Goren took the lead yesterday in the first event of the Eastern contract bridge championship tournament in the Hotel Roosevelt. Fourteen teams of four took part in the competition for the Curt H. Reisinger trophy, which will continue each afternoon this week.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 27. -- Governor A. Harry Moore and Senate President Emerson L. Richards tentatively approved today a proposal to set up a quasi-public corporation to borrow $50,000,000 or more from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to assist hard-pressed municipalities.

This season bids fair to make O'Keeffe a family name instead of an individual name in the New York galleries. An exhibition of flower paintings by Catherina Klenert, a younger sister of Georgia O'Keeffe and a newcomer to the local field, opened yesterday at the Delphic Studios.

The Yankee vanguard, only three strong but supported by five newspaper men, got away yesterday morning at 10:05 aboard the Orange Blossom Special for the Spring training period at St. Petersburg, Fla. The three players were Charles Devens, former Harvard star; Russell Van Atta and Pete Jablonowski, all pitchers.

Ash Wednesday will be widely observed tomorrow in Manhattan in the services by ritualistic churches and others. Good Friday will be April 14 and Easter will be April 16. Churches in the heart of the city, especially Protestant Episcopal, have arranged a multitude of services.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The attitude of President-elect Roosevelt toward the Somers bill to remonetize silver was said today to be the determining factor in whether a vote will be taken in the House before Congress adjourns Saturday.

The membership of the American Legion in New York State is 15,000 less than at this time last year, it was announced last night at a monthly meeting of the New York county committee of the Legion at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have just read your editorial of Feb. 23 regarding Japan. Having lived in Japan before, during and after the Russo-Japanese War, I have watched events leading to the present crisis with an interest and feeling quite different from that expressed in the popular condemnation of Japan.

Theologians and educators will act as Honorary pallpearers at the funeral of the Rev. Dr. Arthur Cushman McGiffert, president emeritus of Union Theological Seminary and its president from 1917 to 1926, which will be held this morning at 9:45 o'clock in the James Memorial Chapel of the Seminary, Broadway and 120th Street.

DETROIT, Feb. 27. -- Henry Ford, who became overnight one of the country's leading bankers, revealed today the first financial project he has in mind to carry out his principle that banks should be "service stations" for industry.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Announcements of the British embargo on arms to Japan and China and of French readiness to participate in any embargo in which Great Britain and the United States take part aroused no enthusiasm here today and were regarded as not having been made in any expectation that the United States would apply an embargo.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- Golden Miller, Miss Dorothy Paget'a 6-year-old gelding, which has been assigned 170 pounds for the Grand National, today was made a lukewarm favorite at 100 to 7 in the first call over of betting odds for the steeplechase classic, which will be run at Aintree March 24.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Andrew W. Mellon, Ambassador to Great Britain and former Secretary of the Treasury, and two former officials of the Internal Revenue Bureau today were named defendants in a $220,000,000 suit charging alleged connivance with officers of foreign steamship companies to evade just income taxes.

GENEVA, Feb. 27. -- The withdrawal of Japan from the League of Nations took a definite form tonight when her delegation's spokesman said instructions had been received no longer to attend meetings of the League Council. No instructions were received regarding the Disarmament Conference.

The new standardized score of "God Save the King," communicated in a British Army order to army and navy bands and civilian orchestras, has an interest for the United States, since the Rev. SAMUEL F. SMITH'S "America" was written in 1832 to fit the air.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Most of the States are having great difficulty in phrasing legislation for the nomination and election of the delegates to the conventions to be called in the various States in pursuance of the repeal resolution recently adopted by the Congress.

CHICAGO, Feb. 27. -- Sweeping reorganizations of the directorates of the Commonwealth Edison Company and the Public Service Company of Northern Illinois were voted today at the annual meetings of shareholders. The board of each company was reduced from thirteen to nine members and the "Insull" directors were displaced by outsiders not connected with the old regime.
COLUMBIA, S.C., Feb. 27. -- Preparations are practically complete for the execution on March 3 of Will Sanders, a Negro youth convicted of the murder of an aged white woman in York County.
CORAL GABLES, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Gene Sarazen, holder of the United States and British open titles, celebrated his thirty-first birthday by winning the "unofficial world's golf championship" today.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Strideaway, from W.T. Waggoner's Texas-owned Three D's Stock Farm, today made a successful debut as a 3-year-old, winning the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds.

The spread of banking restriction into Ohio and other sections, of the country yesterday brought a rapid tightening of the money market, which was met by a further release of credit by the Federal Reserve Bank through open-market operations in bankers' bills and United States Government securities.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Beating down a small but lively opposition, the Senate by a vote of 44 to 8 tonight passed and sent to conference the bankruptcy reform bill, allowing individuals, farmers and railroads to make voluntary readjustment of their debts without recourse to formal bankruptcy.

Prosecutors and police officials of New York City and adjoining counties met in the Wool Club, at 260 West Broadway, yesterday in the first of a series of round-table conferences to assist them in their war on criminals.

Two well-dressed young men walked into the branch store of the Adam Hat Company at 73 Flatbush Avenue, in a crowded section of the Brooklyn theatrical district, early last night and asked the clerk, Irving Goldberg, of 1,393 Lexington Avenue, Manhattan, to show them the new Spring styles.

LONDON, Feb. 27. -- The British Actors' Equity, which is trying to make a close organization of actors in this country in emulation of file Actors' Equity in the United States, won an important point tonight when George Rohey, noted comedian, gave it recognition in the face of a threatened strike by actors in the play in which he is due to appear Wednesday evening.

An exhibition of painting's and prints by Chicago artists opened privately yesterday afternoon at the Whitney Museum of American Art. Beginning today the pictures, arranged on two floors, may be viewed by the public. The show will continue until March 30.

The Reichstag building fronting on the Koenigsplatz, later renamed the Platz der Republik, was built between 1884 and 1894 at a cost of more than $5,000,000. It is in Italian Renaissance style and was designed by Paul Wallott. It was financed out of the 5,000,000,000-mark indemnity extracted from France after the Franco-Prussian War of 1870.

"A Saturday Night," the most recent drama from the pen of Owen Davis, will open this evening at the Playhouse under the management of William A. Brady. Peggy Wood, Hugh O'Connell and Arthur Margetson are included in the cast. "Caesar Julius," a puppet show, will also be given its initial performance by the Tale Puppeteers at their theatre in West Forty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- The bill to regulate intercoastal water traffic via the Panama Canal, which passed the Senate last June, was approved by the House today and now goes back to the Senate for concurrence on several amendments written into the measure by the House Committee on Merchant Marine, Radio and Fisheries.

The steamship Coamo arrived last night from Puerto Rico and Santo Domingo eleven hours late owing to stormy weather after rounding Cape Hatteras. Officials of the line said the ship would not have docked until this morning if it had not been necessary to land a woman passenger and send her to a hospital immediately.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 27. -- Training as thorough and methodical as ever prevailed in the days of the John McGraw regime began in earnest today as Manager Bill Terry settled down to the business of whipping his squad of Giants into shape for the opening exhibition clash against the Cubs Saturday.

VIENNA, Feb. 27. -- The publication by II Giornale d'Italia of alleged secret military treaties of the Little Entente promises to stir up as much excitement as the same newspaper's revelation of the stern character of the recent Anglo-French note to Austria over the Hirtenberg rifle shipment.

The complaint of Scarsdale mothers that children's programs broadcast nationally are making neurasthenics of their youngsters because of the emphasis placed on bogies and harrowing escapes was answered by two of the leading broadcasting companies here yesterday with the explanation that it was the first complaint of its kind in this part of the country.

Bursts of hard riding, interspersed with several spills, abounded at Madison Square Garden last night as the field in the fifty-fourth international six-day bicycle race turned into the second twenty-four hours of the grind.
The Intention of the Roosevelt administration to strengthen the newly acquired hold of the Democrats on the Western States was manifested In several appointments yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27. -- Some little optimism today penetrated the gloom which has overcast many days of testimony before the Senate inquiry into economic conditions, when Alexander D. Noyes, financial editor of THE NEW YORK TIMES, pointed out that in the past disastrous financial and industrial consequences had followed disastrous wars and that after they had run their course a new period of prosperity invariably followed.
Following heavy liquidation at the close of last week, only limited pressure appeared on the Cotton Exchange yesterday and a recovery left quotations with gains of 1 to 4 points.
Max Panteleieff, Russian baritone; Prince Irakli Orbeliani, pianist, and Consuelo Cloos, mezzo-soprano, will give a concert at the Grand Central Art Galleries tonight at 8:30.
HAVANA, Feb. 27 (AP). -- Week-end violence throughout Cuba had served tonight to stir anew rumors that something approximating rebellion exists in the interior.

The resignation of Mr. CHARLES E. MITCHELL was inevitable. No banking institution, not even the next to the largest in the world, could afford even to appear to approve or condone the transactions of which he was a guiding spirit and one of the beneficiaries.

Of a Christmas gift to humanity by Turkey little note has been taken in the midst of the ills that have befallen the world. On that day at the Cabinet meeting, presided over by President MUSTAPHA KEMAL, Turkey took her stand with the United States and eight other countries in ratifying the opium conventions of The Hague 1912 and 1914 and of Geneva 1925 and 1931.

BERLIN, Tuesday, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Minister Without Portfolio, ordered the arrest early today of the 100 Communist members of the Reichstag a few hours after the incendiary fire had swept the Reichstag Building.

Steamship agents in this city are much interested in the outcome of the meeting of the North Atlantic Conference Lines which is to be held in Brussels tomorrow, when the chief subject for discussion will be the attempt to have the new cabin steamships reclassified and designated first class.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Mrs. Ary Lamme of Apawamis and Miss Margaret Andersen of the Plainfield Country Club, Nos. 3 and 4, respectively, gained the quarter-finals, while the two other seeded players came through their second-round matches safely as play began today in the annual Racquet and Swimming Club women's invitation squash racquets tournament.

Bankers who engaged in speculative enterprises during the boom period were held responsible for "the damage to the reputation of the whole banking system" yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Philip J. McCook in an address before the Women's National Republican Club.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 27 -- Application was made by the Louisville Nashville Railroad to the Interstate Commerce Commission today for permission to establish, for a period of six months, reductions in passenger fares between all points on its lines.

PHILADELPHIA, Feb. 27. -- The Philadelphia Rapid Transit Company ended last year with a net loss of $583,050, contrasted with net earnings of $702,897 in 1931, the annual report today shows. Ralph T. Senter, president, asserted that reorganization of the whole "antiquated" corporate structure of the company was essential to prevent a wholesale destruction of values.

HEMPSTEAD, L.I., Feb. 27. -- A hit and-run driver was captured after a two-mile chase by an unemployed man in a commandeered automobile tonight after Mrs. Alice Smith, 73 years old, had been Knocked down and critically injured while crossing Main Street here.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., Feb. 27. -- Pliny W. Williamson of Scarsdale, whose work on the county equalization table was upset when the Supervisors adopted an alternative table last week, asked the legislative committee of the Board of Supervisors today to study plans for the revision of the county's equalization system.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 27. -- Mrs. Payne Whitney's Semaphore, second in his three previous starts at this meeting, scored decisively in the Harry Anna Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today. He was the 9 to 10 favorite and was going easily at the end of the mile, a length and a half before Scout Master, which led Haggerson by the same margin.

While all the markets pursued a vacillating course at one time or another yesterday, they gave a reasonably satisfactory conclusion to a month of unusual financial strain. The general share market ended the day with moderate gains after fluctuating nervously back and forth in the forenoon; bonds failed to mark out a definite trend, and agricultural staples as a rule moved forward.

Brig. Gen. John J. Phelan was elected yesterday to succeed James A. Farley as chairman of the New York State Athletic Commission at the weekly gathering of the board. Mr. Farley sat in at his last commission meeting and voted with Commissioner William H. Muldoon for General Phelan.

HYDE PARK, Feb. 28. -- The completion ot his Cabinet was announced today by President-elect Roosevelt when he named Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana as Attorney General, Daniel C. Roper of Washington as Secretary of Commerce and Frances Perkins, head of the State Labor Department, as Secretary of Labor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28.--All plans for receiving a British debt and economic mission in Washington immediately after March 4 have vanished from the scene here. With them has gone the frequent prophecy that "the British will be here March 5."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Mrs. Hoover received today the members of the Committee on Mobilization of Relief in Welfare and several small delegations, including a group of Congressional callers. Late in the afternoon she drove out for a farewell visit at the home of Mr. and Mrs. French Strother in Wesley Heights.

Showing no signs of weariness, the riders in the fifty-fourth international six-day bicycle race continued their pedaling at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 12,000 persons, the second largest so far, looked on as the cyclists started their third twenty-four-hour shift.

A number of substantial errors in the vote as reported for the November election were brought to light yesterday in the recanvass being conducted by the Board of Elections. The work of rechecking the voting machines is rapidly nearing completion, election officials said yesterday, and another week should bring the task to an end.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The personality of Alfred E. Smith was injected into the hearing of the Senate Committee on Economics today and roused that gathering to a greater attentiveness than any other man has been able to effect since it started.

Banks, churches and an insurance company were among lenders who bought in defaulted real estate in Manhattan and the Bronx at foreclosure auctions yesterday. Twenty properties were taken over by mortgagees in this manner, three scheduled sales having been adjourned.

Irvins Burkhardt, 2 years old, of 1,074 Gates Avenue, Brooklyn, may grow up to be a six-day champion. And in that event, he may give credit to the police department, personified by Detectives Klmer Barry and Louis Woelfel of the Gates Avenue station.

DENVER, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Leeway to deal with the kidnappers of Charles Boettcher 2d was given today to Claude K. Boettcher, father of the missing broker, by the withdrawal of policemen from his home and that of his son.

PARIS, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Andre Lefebvre de Laboulaye, who is expected to become the new Ambassador to the United States, represented his country as counselor to the embassy at Berlin in 1924 and in the same capacity at Washington in 1923.
The Princeton swimming team won seven out of eight events to defeat Columbia, 45 -- 26, last night in the Morningside Heights pool.

An audience in the Heckscher Theatre applauded last night as a woman "burned to death" before their eyes. They asked questions of a grisly skull and marched forward to have their pockets picked. One man even smiled as his new derby hat was used as a mixing bowl for pancake batter.

Definite evidences of better feeling came into the local commodity exchanges yesterday, with the result that the declining tendencies were halted and most staples closed higher on the day. Silk and cocoa were the only ones to close lower. Cash prices were generally better throughout the list.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Banks and trust companies in all parts of the State are up in arms against a measure sponsored by Assemblyman Edward S. Moran Jr., Democrat, of Brooklyn, which would prohibit any banking institution, insurance company or title company "to hold itself out to the public as being entitled to render or furnish legal services, or to advertise that it may act as executor, administrator, guardian, committee or trustee of any estate."

Continuance of the present rates of dividends by several leading companies, about which considerable uncertainty existed in the financial community, was the feature of the announcements made in February. Aside from that, the amount of payments last month compared unfavorably with previous years.
All classes of bonds were under renewed liquidation and prices and averages had the widest declines of any month since last May. They are now back to the levels of last July.

Declaring that the oil industry is "twice hurt" by heavy taxes on gasoline and by the limitation of the use of the highways by motor tracks and buses, J.W. Van Dyke, chairman of the Atlantic Refining Company, in his annual report, states that this "encroachment upon the economic freedom" of the oil and automotive industries "threatens to reduce the future profitability and worth of their assets."

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28. -- The names of officers of the seven colleges which will be opened at Yale next September, and two other colleges which will be opened soon afterward, inaugurating the college plan of residence, were made known today in statements addressed to the undergraduates.

Jim Browning, heavyweight champion, won from Mike Mazurki, former Manhattan College football player, in the feature wrestling bout at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of over 14,000, the largest of the season at that arena, saw the titleholder pin his rival in 23:40.

Congress having passed the Barbour-Stewart bill, the Morristown National Historical Park, including Washington's Headquarters, the Jockey Hollow camp site, Fort Nonsense, and other lands and buildings of Revolutionary interest, will soon come under the administration of the Department of the Interior.

The field of 587 student architects competing for the twenty-sixth annual Paris scholarship award of the Society of Beaux-Arts Architects was narrowed to eight last night at the Beaux-Arts Institute of Design, where the semi-final judgment took place.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Martin Coles Harman, popularly known as the "King of Lundy Island," who recently held control of companies worth L14,000,000, was arrested today. He was charged at Moor Lane police station, in the City of London, with three other financiers, with conspiracy to defraud.

The Queens police broadcast an alarm throughout five States yesterday for Margaret Lange, 11 years old, who disappeared Feb. 21 when she was sent on an errand by her sister, Mrs. Violet Vermilye of 9-08 Thirty-fourth Avenue, Long Island City.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- The Court of Appeals today blocked a plan of W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State chairman, for public improvements in Suffolk County, including the building of two bridges to Shelter Island, for which a bond issue of $5,000,000 had been voted by the supervisors.

No interference in the contest for the Speakership of the House of Representatives in the next Congress has been attempted or is contemplated by James A. Farley, Democratic State and National chairman, who as Postmaster General in the Roosevelt Cabinet will be the next administration's official patronage distributor, it was learned yesterday.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Election district boards in New York City are bipartisan in theory only, George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, told members of the Assembly Judiciary Committee at a public hearing this afternoon on a series of bills to amend the election law.

James Hendricks, a fireman employed by the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, is enjoying his first day off in almost forty years today, his ears still burning with the praise given to him yesterday by his superiors for what they consider a phenomenal record of service.

Ever since it became known that Senator HULL was to become Secretary of State, though he will not resign from the Senate before March 4, speculation in Tennessee has been active concerning his successor. Various names were urged upon the Governor for appointment, but he announced yesterday that his choice is Judge NATHAN L. BACHMAN, formerly of the Supreme Court of the State.

Harry E. Thompson, 58 years old, of West Orange, N.J., who up to a few months ago conducted a brokerage business under his own name, at 141 Broadway, was arrested on five grand larceny indictments last evening in front of his former office.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,192,600 barrels, compared with 2,082,650 barrels for the previous week, an increase of 109,950 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Increases of 93,550 barrels daily in the output of Oklahoma and 10,900 barrels in that of the Texas Panhandle accounted for most of the increase.

It is heartening to note that one of the most important measures of the present session of Congress has been approved in the Senate by a large majority. This is the bill to amend the national bankruptcy law, in order to conserve assets which might otherwise be lost through the process of forced receivership.

DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Ernest G. Liebold, Henry Ford's general secretary who suddenly dropped from sight thirty-six hours before, "found" himself tonight in a room in the Park Place Hotel in Traverse City, Mich., many miles away from the home for which he started at 11 A.M. yesterday and never reached.

Public offerings of new securities last month were the smallest in volume for a February in more than five years and for a month since October, 1931. They were all bonds, chiefly State and municipal issues. The total was $36,960,000, compared with $90,457,000 in January and $66,744,000 in February, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The D. M.W. Construction Company of Brooklyn today submitted the low bid for constructing an annex to the postoffice occupying the two-block fronts on the west side of Eighth Avenue, between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Street, opposite the Pennsylvania Railroad Station.

Oliver H.P. Belmont, former head of the National Woman's party, who died at her Paris home on Jan. 26, last, named her daughter, Mme. Jacques Balsan of Paris her chief beneficiary in wills filed for probate in Surrogate's Court yesterday.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Six new directors were elected today to the board of the Peoples Gas, Light and Coke Company at the annual meeting of stockholders. George F. Mitchell, president, was the only director re-elected. New directors are:

To the Editor of The New York Times: Into the Bowery Y.M.C.A. there came, about a month ago, a young man of 28, lean to the bone, with hollow cheeks and grim-set eyes. After eighteen wretched months of tramping about in search of work, he had come at last to "the one-way street."
ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Passage of Democratic program bills in the Senate today kept the upper house absorbed in heated debate for several hours.
American Equities Company -- Statement as of Dec. 31: Net asset value of common stock, $5.64 a share, comparing with $6.43 a share at end of 1931.

The pamphlet report of the Radio Corporation of America for 1932 shows a net loss of $1,133,586 before dividends, contrasted with a net income of $768,903 for 1931. After $343,019 dividends on the class A preferred stock, the deficit of $1,476,605 for the year reduced the surplus to $9,851,184 on Dec. 31.

The estate of Edward Dean Adams, engineer and financier, who died May 20, 1931, was appraised yesterday at $1,365,848 gross and $1,189,012 net, of which $1,108,021 was in securities and $256,125 was in mortgages, cash and insurance. He owned 2,689 shares of the Buffalo, Niagara and Eastern Power Company, worth $276,967, and 2,000 shares of New Jersey General Security Company, valued at $213,040.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

The General Electric Company had a profit of $14,404,110 available for dividends in 1932, according to a summary issued yesterday by Gerard Swope, president. After dividends on the special stock, this was equal to $11,829,078, or 41 cents a share on the common stock, against $38,381,990, or $1.33 a share in 1931.

The annual report of the North American Company for 1932 shows a consolidated net income of $16,415,751 after charges, taxes and depreciation, equal, after preferred dividends, to $2.01 a share earned on the average number of common shares outstanding during the year, comparing with $24,272,951, or $3.41 a share, earned in 1931.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- The February Federal grand jury, which indicted the Insulls and sixteen of their associates on mail fraud charges, will remain in session for two more months to investigate other Insull companies, United States Attorney Dwight H. Green said today.

SUICHUNG, Manchuria, Wednesday, March 1 (AP). -- Japan's Fourteenth Infantry Brigade, under Major Gen. Heijiro Hattori, was reported to have captured Pei Chang Yingtze, Jehol, fifteen miles northwest of Shamaoshan Pass, at 9 A. M. today.

Buyers' Arrivals Reduced The number of buyers registered in the market during the week ended yesterday showed a drop in comparison with the figures for the preceding week and were less than half the total of a year ago, according to the lists published in THE TIMES.

The town seems to be full of sculpture this week. From the beautiful Assyrian pieces at the Metropolitan Museum, the gift of John D. Rockefeller Jr., one turns to sculpture by moderns, one of whom, Marion Walton, exhibiting at the Weyhe Gallery, offer in her work certain arresting comparisons with the ancient carvings just installed at the museum.

"Of course, we don't want pants," was the prompt answer given by Mme. Elsa Schiaparelli, French couturiere, to a question put to her at the monthly luncheon meeting , of the Fashion Group held at the Hotel Ambassador yesterday. It was the first meeting at which the newly elected president of the organization, Miss Kathleen Howard, presided.

LONDON, Feb. 28. -- There is no disposition in responsible quarters here to regard the banking situation in the United States with great seriousness. In the first place, there is no sign of any really important institution getting into trouble, and the larger New York banks are considered extremely liquid.

PALM BEACH, Fla., Feb. 28. -- A large representation of colonists attended tonight the eighth annual Kiwanis benefit for under-privileged children at the Paramount Theatre. The benefit was under the direction of Arthur Hammerstein with Phil Baker and George Jessel as masters of ceremonies.

A report of the work of the breeding bureau of the Jockey Club, announced yesterday, shows that more than $250,000 has been expended by the governing body of the turf in this State in the maintenance of the bureau, which was established in 1906.
Numerous small housing properties in New Jersey were reported sold yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A new Treasury issue of $75,000,000 in ninety-three-day bills to be dated March 6 will push the public debt over the $21,000,000,000 mark. The issue was announced by Secretary Mills today. On March 6 there will be no maturity, this being the first issue for some time for purposes other than refinancing maturing obligations.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Primarily, this letter is an appeal to the citizens of New York to send used games, jig-saw puzzles and books to the Salvation Army's Cheer Lodge, 630 East Sixth Street, for the Use of unemployed men.

Increases in the amounts of foreign and industrial bonds called for redemption before their dates of maturity swelled the total of retirements in February to well above the previous month's figures and made it the largest sum for a month since January, 1932.

HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 28 (AP). -- The State today threw open the doors of its huge farm show building as headquarters for the "army of unemployed" converging on the capital. Hundreds of marchers arriving in trucks and automobiles, are expected late tonight and tomorrow.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Last night's fire, which rendered the Reichstag building untenable for at least a year, has provided the expected basis for measures of repression throughout the Reich unprecedented save in time of war or revolution.

Many March 4 Records. When Chief Justice HUGHES administers the oath of office to Mr. ROOSEVELT, some one has pointed out, it will be the first occasion on which a former Governor of a State has sworn in as President another former Governor of the same State.
MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28 (AP). -- Mayor Anton Cermak made sufficient progress today to warrant cessation of oxygen treatment and intravenous injections of glucose.

James A. Cahill, former patrolman, was identified by a witness yesterday as one of four hold-up men involved in the killing of Frederick Gillies in a reputed speak-easy at 268 Bergen Street, Brooklyn, on Sept. 3. Cahill, who was dismissed from the police force some time before the shooting, is being tried on an indictment charging first-degree murder before County Judge John J. Fitzgerald in Brooklyn.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., Feb. 28 (AP) -- Edward Bruce Williamson, banker and naturalist, died at his home today after a week's illness, following a stroke of apoplexy. He was 55 years old.

A sound and stable currency, a balanced Federal budget and governmental economy are essential to that feeling of confidence which will hasten the return of normal business conditions, says Howard C. Sykes, president of the New York Curb Exchange, in his annual report to members.

PANAMA, Feb. 28. -- The beginning of the end appeared to be in sight today for another Cocos Island treasure expedition with a report received here from the steamer Susan Luckenbach that the British auxiliary yawl Vigilante was in distress near Coiba Island, 200 miles from Panama.

The Amateur Athletic Union yesterday announced the result of an unusual experiment made at its national track and field championships at the Garden on Saturday. On each seat was a card bearing three questions, and on the answers to two of those queries probably hinged the fate of the metric system.

The Yale Puppeteers continued last night their genteel toying with the classical tradition. Or, presumably, it could all be called something along that line. For "Caesar Julius" deals -- at least in part -- with the arrival of three present-day worthies in the Temple of the Vestals.

The Waldensian Church of New York, which recently bought the four-story dwelling at 26 West Eighty-eighth Street, has leased the house to a client of Hattie M. Melhuish, broker, who negotiated the deal in conjunction with Irene Miller.

Sir Malcolm Campbell, who set a new automobile speed record at Daytona Beach last week, will sail tonight on the Cunarder Aquitania for England with his racing car, Bluebird II, and his six mechanicians.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- Reacting to nervousness caused by last night's blaze in the Reichstag building, stocks and bonds declined in the first hour today on the Boerse, but in anticipation of sweeping government measures to suppress all possible Communist terror, the downward movement soon was stopped and business became extremely quiet.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., Feb. 28. -- Yale's speedy basketball five was given a scare by Brown tonight for one half, but after recovering the form which has carried the team through one of the most successful seasons in years the Elis rallied to register a 44-to-20 victory.

MIAMI, Pla., Feb. 28. -- With the Dodgers in uniform for only the second time today, two husky youngsters already have caught the approving eye of Manager Max Carey and his battery coach, Otto Miller, who arrived this morning.
DETROIT, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Word that Hubert Scott-Paine had challenged for the Harmsworth Trophy was received with gratification in motor boating circles today.

In contributing his services to the cause of unemployed musicians by appearing as guest soloist at the Metropolitan Opera House last night with the Musicians Symphony Orchestra led by Sandor Harmati, Mischa Elman, violinist, put the public deeply in his debt for an evening of superb playing.

The response of the radio audience to the appeal made last week during broadcast performances of "Manon" and "Tannhauser" has been spontaneous and greatly encouraging, Lucrezia Bori, chairman of the Committee for Saving Metropolitan Opera, revealed yesterday.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., Feb. 28. -- The Tankee vanguard arrived today to begin training. With them out of the North there came a rainstorm that dampened the city as well as the enthusiasm of the new arrivals and weighted down palms that in song and story always wave in the breeze.

Tuesday, Feb. 28, 1933. Rates for several classes of accommodation were stirred about nervously, a sequel to restricted offerings in all departments. Street trades on call loans ranged from 1 @ 1 1/2 per cent, while Federal checks were done 2 1/4 @ 2 1/2 from a start around 1 1/2 @ 2 per cent.

GENEVA, Feb. 28. -- After the British had exerted strong pressure on Berlin, the disarmament conference's drafting committee, including all the great European powers, agreed today on the text of a declaration outlawing force in Europe.

Worry crowds on Chairman FARLEY before he presides at the board of patronage while deserving Democrats scramble for their rewards. On paper his plan of distribution looks fine. Candidates for office must be certified by State and local committees composed of right Rooseveltians.

Rising prices on the Stock Exchange yesterday seemed to Wall Street to reflect a growing belief that the worst phase of the banking difficulties had been passed. That, at least, was the construction which the commission houses placed upon the day's developments.

Story, the magazine which recently was imported from the island of Majorca to New York, is issued in America for the first time today. Its size has been increased by about twenty pages and its design and make-up have been altered under the supervision of Elmer Adler of the Pynson Printers.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- The Bolshevist drive to make collective farming successful operates on two principles -- positive action to conscript, support and organize, and negative action to destroy opposition, now called "measures of repression."

Among the policies which President HOOVER in his letter to the Republican National Committee declared should be nonpartisan, he enumerated "preservation of the "honor and integrity of the Government in respect to its obligations, its securities and sound "currency."

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., Feb. 28. -- Morning and afternoon play on the courts of the Racquet and Swimming Club today brought the field in the club's annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament to the semi-final round. Mrs. H.S. Green, Miss Edith Hahs, Miss Elizabeth Woolsey and Miss Marguerite Anderson were the players to survive a day of hard-fought matches.

"Forsaking All Others," in which Tallulah Bankhead will have the star billing, will open this evening at the Times Square Theatre. "Run, Little Chillun !" a Negro folk drama written by Hall Johnson, well-known Negro choir leader, and boasting a cast of 150 persona, will also have its premiere at the Lyric.

William James Keim walked out of City Hall postoffice at dusk yesterday. He headed for the bridge to take the Lexington Avenue elevated to his Bushwick home at 1,244 Jefferson Avenue, just as he had done every night for thirty-two years.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Urging the enactment of legislation to bar all except citizens from receiving public funds for work relief, the Senate Finance Committee called today for the setting up of a single agency in New York City to administer all official relief funds.

Earmarking of gold for foreign accounts, the largest amount for a month since September, 1931, sharply reduced the country's gold stock in February. This was an abrupt reversal of the movement of the metal in the previous month. The net loss of gold in February was $174,491,203, against a gain of $34,607,500 in January and a drop of $67,271,400 in February, 1932.

Baron Daniel Wigbold van Heeckeren of the Netherlands, recently appointed presiding arbitrator of the commission, for settlement of claims between the United States and Panama, arrived yesterday on the French liner Paris accompanied by the Baroness and their daughter, Cornelia Catherina.

While the second organization within a week was being formed in Jersey City last night to fight the contention of the Jersey City Taxpayers Association that reductions of $8,750,000 be made in the city budget, Warren E. Fairbanks, secretary of the association, made public a letter to the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in Washington in which he asked the Federal organization to refuse to lend any money for relieving the Jersey City budget.

Influences on the Cotton Exchange were virtually deadlocked, and prices at the close of trading were unchanged to 2 points lower than on Monday. The decision in the House of Representatives to dispose of the Smith bill encouraged scattered covering at one time, but uncertainty about the fate of farm-relief measures prevented confident buying and fluctuations held within a range of about 10 points, while the volume of business was the smallest this season.

The New York County grand jury which, since Jan. 11, has been investigating frauds and irregularities at the last election, in general sessions yesterday handed up to Judge Freschi four indictments against one man, accusing him of illegal registration and false voting.

GENEVA, Feb. 28.--The League of Nations moved a step nearer to proclaiming an arms embargo against Bolivia and Paraguay in a secret meeting of the Council this evening, called to discuss informally the Anglo-French proposals to this effect.
ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- A bill to create a compulsory reserve for building and loan associations was opposed and defended at a hearing before the Banking Committee of the Assembly today.

The action of the Louisville Nashville Railroad in asking permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission to reduce its coach fare from the standard 3.5 cents a mile to 2 cents was said yesterday to open the possibility of reductions throughout the country.

Governor LEHMAN bases his request for minimum-wage legislation on evidence which he describes as "overwhelming" that the depression is being exploited by selfish employers who are paying women and children starvation wages.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- Vigorous objection to the "model" pistol bill which would eliminate fingerprinting and photographing of up-State applicants for pistol permits, was voiced today by Police Commissioner Mulrooney at a joint hearing before the Senate and Assembly Codes Committee on this and a dozen other measures amending the penal law.

In view of the difficulties now developing in the banking system, Dean Wallace B. Donham of the Graduate School of Business Administration of Harvard University recommended last night in an address before the Town Hall Institute of Economics that Congress give to the President exceptional authority, not only to formulate a plan to stabilize the economic system, but "to carry it into effect."

Exports and imports into the United States by classifications during January, as given out by the Department of Commerce, compare as follows with the corresponding period of 1932 and 1931 (000 omitted):

Harold E. Wittemann, formerly well known as a real estate operator and now an inmate of the "alimony Jail" in Manhattan, was indicted by the Federal grand jury in Brooklyn yesterday on a charge of violating the national bankruptcy act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- By a vote of 188 to 183 the House late today passed the Smith bill, with amendments, providing for the relief of Southern cotton planters through the purchase by the government of all surplus cotton stocks now owned by government agencies, or upon which money has been loaned, and their resale to farmers who agree to reduce cotton acreage this year by at least 30 per cent.

NOGALES, Ariz., Feb. 28 (AP). -- The Nogales Herald said yesterday it had received reports that protests against alleged harsh treatment of Chinese residents of Sinaloa and some other west coast States of Mexico have been sent to President Rodriguez by Mexican citizens.

MIAMI, Fla., Feb. 28. -- The 6-year-old Luke McLuke gelding, Mr. Sponge, bred and owned by Joseph E. Widener, captured the Key West Purse, feature at Hialeah Park today. It was his first winning effort in six starts here, but he was made the favorite in a field of six despite his poor record, and led practically from start to finish.

In these days when "the hysterical are inviting us to leave the old landmarks of ordered freedom to wander in strange pastures and after false gods, we need nothing so much as a rededication to the principles and ideals of Jefferson," Claude G. Bowers, editor, author and orator, said last night at a dinner in his honor at the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- An additional loan of $2,234,800 to the Missouri Pacific by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation to help the railroad meet obligations pending completion of a program to handle heavy maturities was approved today by the Interstate Commerce Commission.
