The story of Los Angeles from the time of the Yangs, Indians left over from the Stone Age, to the present, is told in "Los Angeles, a History With Side-Shows," by Morrow Mayo, to be published today by Knopf.

The 1933 drive of the Joint Distribution Committee for the relief of millions of destitute Jews in Eastern Europe was opened last night at a meeting of campaign leaders at the home of Paul Baerwald, 9 East Eighty-eighth Street.

TOKYO, Wednesday, March 1.--Charges that the Chinese have been using poison gas in their battles against the Japanese in Jehol Province are made by the military authorities here. They reported that 170 Japanese soldiers suffering from...

The board of representatives of the High School Teachers Association, at a meeting yesterday afternoon at 88 Lexington Avenue, voted to oppose the Crawford legislative bill which would empower the Board of Education to abolish at its own discretion multiple-job holding in the New York City public school system.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., Feb. 28. -- Dr. John Belling, one of the leading geneticists and long associated at the biological laboratory here of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, working with Dr. Albert F. Blakeslee, died today at Berkeley, Cal.

GENEVA, Feb. 28. -- League of Nations officials announced today "that the United States Government has informed the Secretary General that, in identic notes to Peru and Colombia, it has given its fullest support to the action of the Committee of Three, which it feels is a most helpful one, offering a possibility of a peaceful solution honorable to both governments."

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- An ocean mail contract to be awarded at noon tomorrow to a new Philadelphia line held the attention of the Senate most of today while Senator Black of Alabama fought for passage of a resolution holding up the award.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Banking holidays alone will not be regarded as sufficient excuse for failure to file income tax returns due March 15, the Internal Revenue Bureau announced today.

A special term of the Supreme Court to hear the appeals of real estate owners from tax assessments for 1933 will be urged tomorrow by the committee on taxation of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York in a report to be presented at the chamber's regular monthly meeting.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- The $1,000,000,000 independent offices appropriation bill was thrown back into conference today by the Senate over an item of $300,000 for the Federal Trade Commission, the deletion of which, according to Senator Robinson of Arkansas would be tantamount to "wrecking the trade commission."

Having done nearly everything else, Owen Davis has made his contribution toward an era of good feeling in "A Saturday Night," which was acted at The Playhouse last evening. It is his answer to the tiresome old question, "Why doesn't some one write a play about decent people?"

TOKYO, Feb. 28.--The British embargo on arms sales to China and Japan "can only be intended as a rebuke to Japan and must change our long-standing friendship for Britain," said a spokesman for the War Office today.

TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- Senate President Emerson L. Richards said tonight that there would be a "new deal" in administration of the State Highway Department regardles of the fate of his bill to replace the four-member commission by a two-member board.

While the Board of Estimate debated yesterday over methods of providing the salaries of 800 technical men employed by the Borough Presidents, salary checks for other city employes went out from the Finance Department on schedule.

ALBANY, Feb. 28.--Further reductions in the salaries of State employes aggregating $4,100,000, in addition to salary cuts of $5,000,000 provided for in Governor Lehman's budget, were recommended today to a closed conference of Republican Assemblymen by the Republican steering committee.

DETROIT, Feb. 28. -- An unexpected complication arose in the local banking situation today and threatened the plan of Henry Ford and his son, Edsel Ford, to establish two national banks here to take the place of the First National Bank and the Guardian National Bank of Commerce, which are closed under Governor Comstock's banking holiday proclamation.

Consolidation of the various student publications at Columbia University to make possible the publication of a daily newspaper directed by the Columbia School of Journalism was urged yesterday by Dean Carl W. Ackerman.

The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said yesterday, through its assistant secretary, Roy Wilkins, that it had attempted to obtain executive clemency for Will Sanders, Negro youth sentenced to die at Columbia, S.C., on Friday for the murder of an aged white woman.
NEWARK, N.J., Feb. 28. -- This city probably will default tomorrow on its semi-monthly payroll of $1,150,000, according to an announcement made late today by Mayor Jerome T. Congleton.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A few months ago the Court of Appeals of Ohio enjoined three title companies in Cleveland from practicing law. Among the specific acts which they were enjoined from doing were:

Charges of police brutality were made yesterday by a witness for the prosecution at the arraignment of Emil Kissel, 20 years old, of 7,208 Sixth Avenue, Brooklyn, before Magistrate James A. Blanch-field in the Bay Ridge Court, on a charge of robbery.
PRINCETON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- The Princeton hockey team ran up its largest score of the season in overwhelming Brown, 12 -- 0, tonight at the Hobey Baker rink.

The Western Pacific Railroad will pay $1,293,339 of interest due today on first mortgage 5 per cent bonds and Series B 5 1/2 per cent certificates from a loan extended by the Railroad Credit Corporation.
The curriculum committee of the New York University Washington Square College announced yesterday that Bachelor of Arts would supersede Bachelor of Science as the major degree of that institution.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- Today's Manchester Guardian reprints on the main news page more than a column from Russell Owens's recent article in THE NEW YORK TIMES on the plight of American farmers.
TRENTON, N.J., Feb. 28. -- Governor Moore ordered today that Duane E. Minard of Rockaway Valley, First Assistant Attorney General at $7,500 a year, be suspended.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- With thousands of visitors arriving by every train, last-minute plans for the Roosevelt inauguration were undertaken today for the expansion of present arrangements which officials fear may fall far short of adequate provision for those attending the ceremonies.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 (AP). -- Tonight's emergency decree threatens imprisonment of not legs than a month and fines of 150 to 15,000 marks [the mark is worth, about 23.8 cents] for practiced or advocated resistance against the authorities.
HARRISBURG, Pa., Feb. 28. -- Emergency legislation to permit the limitation of withdrawals from bank accounts received the right of way in the Legislature today.

The campaign to clear Brooklyn book stores and circulating libraries of obscene literature was begun yesterday by District Attorney William F.X. Geoghan after a conference with police officials and Mrs. Thomas A. McGoldrick, head of the International Federation of Catholic Alumnae in Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Under the impetus of President-elect Roosevelt's influence, the House, it was confidently predicted tonight, will pass the bankruptcy bill as it passed the Senate, including protection for railroads and corporations under the amended act.

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- A warning to the United States not to join other powers in an arms embargo against Japan or China was uttered in a Senate speech today by Senator Lewis, as military events in Jehol convinced officials that two or three days would show how affairs would turn in the new Chino-Japanese crisis.

Frank E. Hopkins, widely known as a musician and as a printer of de luxe and special editions, died Sunday in Stormont Hospital, Topeka, Kan. Funeral services will be held tomorrow night at Jamaica Masonic Temple. His home was at 148-08 Eightieth Avenue, Jamaica.

THE HAGUE, Feb. 28. -- The Dutch Communist, van den Lubbe, arrested in Berlin in connection with the Reichstag fire, was born Jan. 13, 1909, in Leyden, the son of traveling street vendors. He was very well known to the Leyden police when he was a youth, making roads unsafe and destroying property.

A Brooklyn policeman who left his supper last night to look into the ransacking of a neighbor's home at 2,516 Cortelyou Road, Flatbush, critically wounded a burglar who was found later, through his fingerprints, to be Raymond Beck, "angel-faced choir singer" and second-story man extraordinary.

After deliberating for four hours and twenty minutes, the jury which has been hearing the first vote fraud trial in Federal Court in this district since 1870 sent out word at 11 o'clock last night that it had ben unable to reach a verdict. It was taken to a hotel for the night, and is to resume its deliberations at 9:30 this morning.

PARIS, Wednesday, March 1. -- With infinite patience and by incessant work, Premier Daladier has finally managed to get passed through both the Chamber and the Senate the March finance bill, which assures a reduction of the deficit in the French budget this year by nearly 5,000,000,000 francs ($196,000,000).

MINNEAPOLIS, Feb. 28. -- With the cry of "We are on the battle line," administrators of public education in America, assembled here in the convention of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association, defined today their enemy, their objectives, the concessions they are willing to make and their plan of campaign in their fight to preserve the integrity of the country's school system.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., Feb. 28. -- Displaying unfeigned satisfaction over the headway already made in conditioning his men with the aid of excellent climatic conditions. Manager Bill Terry paused in his labors long enough today to cast an appraising eye over his squad of Giants, which by tomorrow will be mustered to full war strength.

After one of the first loads of fill had been dumped yesterday in the area at Twelfth Avenue between Fortieth and Forty-first Streets reclaimed for the Miller Highway by a newly constructed sea wall, the body of a man was found in the water.

More than one-half the railway reports issued for January show improvements in net operating income compared with January, 1932. Roads which reported increases yesterday included the Atlantic Coast Line, Norfolk Western, Long Island and Virginian.

Trading on the New York Stock Exchange last month was slightly heavier than in January, but the slowest of any February since 1922. The heaviest day's trading was 1,542,400 shares, on Feb. 14, and the slowest, 584.845 shares, on Feb. 7. Sales for the month, as compiled by THE NEW YORK TIMES, amounted to 19,319,900 shares, compared with 18,719,502 shares in January, and 31,718,556 shares in February, 1932.

PEIPING, Feb. 28. -- Reports received here today said there had been a noticeable slackening in the Japanese attacks in Jehol Province, the Chinese denying abandonment of the important Paishihtsumen Pass. [On the Jehol-Manchurian border about fifty miles north of the Great Wall.]

WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Relief advances to five States aggregating $19,564,195, of which New York received $7,100,000, were announced today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation. Illinois got $6,245,143; Ohio, $2,257,569; Wisconsin, $3,608,222, and Iowa, $353,261.

Mail contracts which would make possible the operation of a transatlantic service with Boston as its American terminal port will be sought by a group of shipping men who have arranged to charter a fleet of ships and later replace them with new liners.
NEW ORLEANS, Feb. 28 (AP).-- Over a sloppy racing strip, A.B. Letellier's Sazerac today sped to his second successive victory in three starts, winning the Mardi Gras Handicap at the Fair Grounds.

Slightly firmer rates for funds available for call loans in the outside market and contraction in the amount of time loan funds, which resulted in the posting of nominal quotations after Feb. 13, marked the changes in the money market here last month.
New downtown quarters have been taken by several firms already in the area, according to leases reported yesterday. Numerous rentals in the midtown section of Manhattan also were listed.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- The British Government was distinctly pleased with itself today as it studied the world's reactions to its arms embargo against Japan and China.

Endorsement of Governor Lehman's proposal to establish a minimum wage for women and children was expressed yesterday by the New York State Labor Standards Committee, representing a group of industrial, welfare and religious organizations.

PARIS, Feb. 28. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's chief delegate to the League of Nations, put forward a suggestion in an interview with the writer today which, if adopted, might be expected to influence the friendly relations of France and Japan.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Representative Snell of Potsdam was unanimously nominated by the Republican House caucus tonight as the minority candidate for Speaker of the Seventy-third Congress.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., Feb. 28. -- A splendid outbound 38, only one shot over men's par, enabled Miss Kathleen Garnham of England to win the qualifying medal today on the St. Augustine links in the Florida East Coast championship for the Mrs. W.R. Kenan Jr. Cup.

Sam Howard, trustee in bankruptcy for the Corporation Securities Company of Chicago, began suit yesterday in the United States District Court against the Guaranty Trust Company, Central Hanover Bank and Trust Company and the Chase National Bank to recover blocks of securities which on April 16 last, when they were pledged, were worth approximately $360,000, $3,175,000 and $360,000 respectively.

The representatives of the Bayside Tennis Club are coming to be regarded as the nemeses of the City Athletic Club players in squash tennis and last night further fuel was added to the fire of their rivalry as Seymour Samuels of the City A.C. lost to William Hoffman in the national Class B championship play at the Squash Club.

Protest against measures now before the Legislature, which would create additional county court, city court and municipal court judges in the Bronx was voiced yesterday by Harold Riegelman, counsel to the Citizens Budget Commission, in a letter sent to the legislative leaders of both parties.

Ladenburg, Thalman Co., as fiscal agents for Paulista Railway Company (Brazil) first and refunding mortgage 7 per cent sinking fund bonds. Series A, announced yesterday that they were prepared to make part payment to holders of the Sept. 15, 1932, coupons at the rate of $17.50 for each $35 coupon and $8.75 for each $17.50 coupon on presentation.
NEW YORK. Mrs. A.J. Drexel Paul of Radnor, Pa., is expected at the Barclay today.

Touched by the appeal of John C. Mullins, 84-year-old Civil War veteran, that the city provide $32,000 to defray the cost of Memorial Day exercises, the Board of Estimate, meeting in committee of the whole yesterday, decided to consider the appropriation at an executive session today.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- James Truslow Adams, the American historian, has been elected a Fellow of the Royal Society of Literature.

BERLIN, Feb. 28. -- The Hitler Government's anti-Communist campaign was under way in earnest tonight with the publication of a Presidential emergency decree, based on Article XLVIII of the Constitution, whereby constitutional guarantees were suspended and the government of the Reich was authorized to seize executive power in any German State if its government failed to take "the necessary measures for the restoration of law and order."

To the Edtior of The New York Times: It the bill which Senator Crawford has introduced in the State Senate is passed, non-profit hospitals which conduct dispensaries for the benefit of the poor will have to choose between paying fines ranging for individual institutions from $100,000 to $4,000,000 yearly and the curtailment of their dispensary work.

DETROIT, Feb. 28. -- Mr. Liebold's association with Henry Ford began in 1910, when the man who later was a personage of great power in the motor organization was a young under-executive in the Highland Park State Bank.

On recommendation of Deputy Controller Frank J. Prial, the Board of Estimate accepted yesterday the offer of the East Side Omnibus Corporation, to which it voted a 25-year franchise for five east side bus routes last Friday, to pay $184,000 in full settlement of all claims and liens against the Second Avenue Railroad Corporation.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 28. -- Chinese leaders in Nanking, alarmed by the Tokyo War Office statement of the conditions which Japan would consider provocative and justifying military action south of the Great Wall, are now discussing a plan for formally proposing international control of all Manchuria and Jehol, in line with the Lytton commission's recommendations.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., Feb. 28. -- Judge Nathan L. Bachman of Chattanooga was named by Governor McAlister today to succeed Cordell Hull in the Senate when Senator Hull becomes Secretary of State Saturday.

The Majestic Apartments, the twenty-nine story structure at the southwest corner of Central Park West and Seventy-second Street, occupying the site of the old Majestic Hotel and adjacent parcels, was thrown into foreclosure in the Supreme Court yesterday.

Prices on the listed bond market moved irregularly yesterday, with domestic corporation issues slightly lower on the average and leading foreign loans slightly higher. United States Government bonds closed from 10-32 point higher to 16-32 point lower for the active issues.

The Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee will spend $1,100,000 for work relief for the unemployed in March, according to Harvey D. Gibson, chairman, who announced yesterday that the month's appropriation exceeded by $200,000 the original amount set aside.
LONDON, Feb. 28. -- A midget speed boat, the smallest ever entered in an international contest, will try to regain for England the Harmsworth Trophy next September.

Because of an eleventh-hour demand for accommodations to Washington for President-elect Roosevelt's inauguration, the plans made by Tammany Hall to transport its delegation of thousands to the capital must be amplified today and tomorrow.

CHICAGO, Feb. 28. -- Wheat continued today to show stubborn resistance to selling pressure on the Board of Trade here, and while suffering from scattered liquidation early, the market rallied 1 to 1 1/8 cents a bushel from the inside figures and closed 5/8 cent higher.
WASHINGTON, Feb. 28. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are Feb. 27, unless otherwise specified:

Colonel Arthur F. Foran, for the past two years the executive vice president of the More Game Birds Foundation, yesterday was elevated to the presidency at the annual meeting of the directors of the foundation at their offices, 500 Fifth Avenue.

ALBANY, Feb. 28. -- A conference hurriedly called this evening to prepare a final draft of a measure to govern the election of delegates and conduct of a State convention to pass upon repeal broke up without agreement on essential features of the bill.

CLEVELAND, Feb. 28. -- Uniform and sound laws governing corporations must be adopted if a recurrence of the security inflation of 1928 and 1929 is to be avoided, said Richard Whitney, president of the New York Stock Exchange, in an address today before the Cleveland Chamber of Commerce.

All the favorite teams successfully survived the final qualifying round in the team-of-four event of the Eastern contract bridge championships competition yesterday afternoon at the Hotel Roosevelt. At the end of the session the eight highest teams were selected from the field of fourteen which started on Monday and will engage in a series of knockout matches beginning this afternoon.

BERLIN, Feb. 28 (AP). -- A permanent ban on the entire German Communist and Socialist press was intimated today by the chief of the government press department, Walter Funk, at a meeting of foreign correspondents summoned to bear an explanation of President von Hindenburg's emergency decree.

The Young Judea Clubs held a festival concert of Jewish and Biblical music, representing many composers and a host of interpreters, at Carnegie Hall last night, the effort of the clubs and the contributions of a sympathetic audience being for the support of the Palestine Institute of Musical Sciences and the advancement of music in Palestine.

LOS ANGELES, March 1 -- Despite the sweeping changes which Manager Bill Terry has made in the personnel of his team since last Fall, the infield of the New York Giants for 1933 is not apt to differ greatly from that which set out with such high hopes a year ago.

Hall Johnson, the choir leader, brought down from Harlem last night some two hundred of his people and the play called "Run, Little Chillun!" Back of them lay many months of rehearsals in halls, in empty theatres, in out-of-the-way places where the cost was little.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 1 -- The Yale junior varsity basketball team and two Eli freshman swimming teams triumphed here today. The jayvee quintet defeated the Yale Divinity School, 35 to 16; the yearling A squad natators vanquished Canterbury School of New Milford, 87 to 18, and the freshman B team conquered the Roxbury School mermen of Cheshire, 56 to 13.

PEIPING, March 1 -- Following the lull In their attack yesterday, the Japanese launched a smashing drive today along a sixty-mile front from Chaoyang almost to the Great Wall, causing an extension of the Chinese front for almost twenty-five miles to the southward in an effort to meet a threat of a flanking movement directed at Yakow.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The scheduled signing today of an ocean mail contract for a projected line between Philadelphia and Liverpool brought a formal protest from the Senate through a resolution adopted by a vote of 45 to 28.

ALBANY, March 1. -- A bill to put interurban trucks and buses under the regulation of the Public Service Commission was assailed by trucking representatives today at a hearing before the joint Public Service Committees of the Senate and Assembly.

Reports from the teachers represented in convention at Minneapolis by their leaders make clear that they are ready to do their full part. When it becomes clear in any community, said the chairman of the Joint Commission on the Emergency in Education, that larger classes, administration economies and salary reductions are the only alternatives, but one choice is possible.

Eight members of the first ten, headed by Harry F. Wolf, the defending titleholder from the New York A.C., are included in the field of forty-four players who will start competition at 5 o'clock today in the national amateur squash tennis championship at the Harvard Club.

The question whether the Juilliard Foundation is fulfilling the intentions of the late Augustus Juilliard with regard to the Metropolitan Opera Company, as set forth in his will, was raised yesterday in a public statement by William Matheus Sullivan, lawyer and music patron.

Sam Kaplan, deposed president of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Union of Greater New York, took the witness stand yesterday in General Sessions where he and twenty-one other former officers and members of the local are being tried on a coercion indictment growing out of attacks on nine members of the local in 1931 and their expulsion, allegedly because they sought a Supreme Court order for an accounting of the local's funds.
SUICHUNG, Manchuria, March 1 -- The two great Chinese strongholds which blocked the path to Chengteh (Jehol City), capital of Jehol Province, fell to the Japanese invaders today.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt will wear a gown of silver lame in her favorite shade of blue at the inaugural ball. She had planned to wear an ivory white satin Chinese brocade, but at the final fitting of the misty blue and silver brocade "transformation" gown on Tuesday she was so pleased with it, it was disclosed yesterday, that she changed her mind.

SHANGHAI, Thursday, March 2 -- Although the Chinese officially deny the Japanese claims to have captured Chihfeng and Lingyuan. it is believed here that they are correct, for from the opening of the campaign the Chinese have consistently denied losses until three or four days after each event.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- With flags whipping in the wind along Pennsylvania Avenue, evergreens in place around the base of the reviewing stands in the Court of Honor and miles of bunting going up outside and in the hotels and public buildings, the capital today became a holiday city ready to welcome the greatest inaugural crowd in its history.

DETROIT, March 1 -- Senator James Couzens, once partner of Henry Ford and "former Mayor of Detroit, returned to his home town today with the avowed object of helping Michigan out of its financial chaos.

LONDON, March 1 -- Official notice of the disturbed conditions in Germany was taken today for the first time in the House of Commons, where questions were put to Foreign Minister Sir John Simon concerning the safety of British nationals in Germany and other phases of the situation brought about by the Hitler government.

NEW ORLEANS, March 1 (AP) -- J.T. Looney's Sweeprush, which has shown his best performances over heavy tracks, found today's conditions to his liking and romped home an easy victor in the six-furlong feature at the Fair Grounds. Mrs. A. Luzader's Miss Frisky took place honors from the early pacemaker, Prince Sulieman.

There was a time, as Albert Parry tells in "Garrets and Pretenders," published today by Covici, Friede, when American Bohemianism had not been split into cults with standards and no one made any money out of it or was self-conscious about it in any way.

A judgment for $13,506 was filed yesterday against former Mayor James J. Walker in the Supreme Court in favor of Hattie Carnegie, Inc., dealer in women's apparel, for the balance due on a bill of $20,059 for articles sold to his wife, Janet Allen Walker, between Sept. 7, 1928, and March 5, 1931.

ALBANY, March 1 -- The resignation of Henry Morgenthau Jr. as head of the State Conservation Department and chairman of the Governor's Advisory Agricultural Commission was received by Governor Lehman today.

The Borden Company reported yesterday for 1932 net income of $7,524,489, after all charges and taxes, which was 3.54 per cent of sales and equivalent to $1.71 a share on 4,396,754 shares of capital stock outstanding at the end of the year. In 1931, the net income, after ' provision for profit sharing, was $16,088,829, equivalent to $3.66.. a share on 4,395.281 shares.
A devastating second-half attack enabled Princeton's basketball team to defeat Columbia, 35-24, in an Eastern Intercollegiate League game last night in the Morningside gymnasium before 1,500 persons.

Wall Street gathered from yesterday's colorless stock market that the speculative element was finding some ground for confidence in spite of the apparently disturbing character of the financial news. Brokers insisted that their customers were more easily persuaded to buy than to sell.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Senate amendment to the bankruptcy act, urged by President Hoover and President-elect Roosevelt as vital to the safeguarding of billions of dollars of railroad, farm and Individual properties, was passed by the House today and goes to the President tomorrow for signature. The vote was 207 to 26.
ALBANY, March 1 -- The investigation of the death of Ernie Schaaf after his bout with Primo Camera was declared at an end today by Governor Lehman.

Penitentiary terms of not less than one year each were imposed by Judge Rosalsky in General Sessions yesterday on Charles T. Morgan, 43 years old, once called the "Boy Wizard of Wall Street," and Carmine Ucci, 53, of 58 Church Avenue, Brooklyn, admitted bootlegger and gambler and known in the underworld of the lower east side as "The Baron."

Caesar or Nerves? In Berlin grim conspiracies and revolutions may be brewing, but the dominant impression is one of jangled nerves all round, with the Hitlerite chieftains not better off than their opponents.

The Republic of Colombia will pay in full the semiannual interest due on May 1 on its American dollar 6 per cent bonds due Oct. 1, 1961, now outstanding in the principal amount of $30,612,000, and is prepared to take care of all arrears in sinking fund payments on both this loan and the 6 per cent dollar loan due on Jan. 1, 1931, now outstanding in the amount of $21,908,000.

ALBANY, March 1. -- Miss Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor designate in the Roosevelt Cabinet, made her final appearance before the Legislature today as State Industrial Commissioner and pleaded for a continuation of progressive labor legislation in the State.

LONDON, March 1 -- The burning of the Reichstag building in Berlin in the opinion of The London Times, came "at an opportune moment for the Nazi-Nationalist Gobernment" and it remarks that it is not clear how "the alleged incendiary's extensive preparations escaped the notice of the guards."

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 1 -- About 500 bedraggled members of an army of unemployed, recruited in all parts of the State, marched into the chamber of the House of Representatives today and, before a joint session of the House and Senate, cheered while their spokesmen presented a relief program calling for the immediate appropriation of $100,000,000 by the Legislature.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The text of the amendment to the bankruptcy bill as passed by the House today follows:

If Tallulah Bankhead had discovered something more brilliant than "Forsaking All Others" for her reappearence in America, doubtless she would have produced it at the Times Square last evening. But it will serve. For it is a cheerful little earful of bright retorts and verbal fencing numbers, written by Edward Roberts and Frank Cavett.
The Sinfonietta of New York, directed by Quinto Maganini, gave its last concert of the season last night in Town Hall. It will appear next season as the "Chamber Symphony."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Ferdinand Pecora, counsel for the Senate market inquiry, took his witnesses over a wide field of testimony today, ranging from a $10,020 loan from a National City Company bond syndicate fund for John Ramsey, general manager of the Port of New York Authority, to proposals for public regulation of the New York Stock Exchange.

As a result of the decision of the hockey committee of the metropolitan section of the Amateur Athletic Union to restrict the New York City contenders for the national hockey championship to one team, the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club sextet has been withdrawn from the A.A.U.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There has been much discussion of arterial highways and parkways being designed and built in New York City. In your issue of Feb. 19 was an elaborate analysis prepared by the Citizens Budget Commission which attempted to show that it is bad practice for the city to pay for these great physical improvements.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- With both branches of Congress joining in an unusual rush of activity, a wide range of remedial and emergency legislation, much of it of far reaching importance, was enacted or advanced today.
NEWARK, N.J., March 1 -- As predicted yesterday by Mayor Jerome T. Congleton, Newark failed today to meet its semi-monthly payroll and the monthly pension fund payroll, aggregating $1,160,000.

ALBANY, March 1 -- What was said to be a virtual agreement was reached tonight on a bill to govern the election of delegates and conduct of a convention to pass upon the resolution providing for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment submitted to the several States by Congress.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., March 1 (AP) -- The State prohibition law and enforcement legislation of Illinois were repealed, in effect, today by the lower house of the Legislature. Already passed by the State Senate, the repealer bills now go to Governor Horner for the signature he has announced he would affix as soon as the measures reached him.

Former Governor Alfred E. Smith demands that the Democratic party rid itself of "bigots, fanatics, populists, demagogues, mountebanks and crackpots," in his editorial article in the March issue of the New Outlook. He also, among other things, offers the Roosevelt administration a program for cutting the Federal payroll, urges that real estate be relieved of taxes for the support of education and advocates a temporary moratorium on foreclosures throughout the country.

The Emergency Work and Relief Bureau was compelled to lay off 3,200 workers yesterday and will reduce its staff of workers an additional 7,000 by April 1, it was announced yesterday by William H. Matthews, director.

A rumble which sounded as if the ceiling were going to cave in interrupted the presentation of the Noel Coward play, "Design for Living," at the Ethel Barrymore Theatre a few minutes before the final curtain at about 11:15 o'clock last night.
WARSAW, March 1 -- The first trainload of Polish Upper Silesian coal passed was shipped for Gdynia on the new Silesia-Baltic direct railroad which opened today.

COACH Lou Little of Columbia wandered into the Bronx the other evening to give a little talk on football. He said at the outset that he agreed with Bernard Shaw that public speaking should be made a capital offense, and added that he was there to prove it. The verdict later was "not proven." In fact, as he departed, he was being haled by some enthusiastic Bronx residents as "the Demosthenes of the gridiron."

The report of the Chicago, Rock Island Pacific Railway for 1932 shows that the company earned $1,000,000 from the freight surcharges that took effect Jan. 4, 1932, but that it did not borrow from the Railroad Credit Corporation, through which the surchages are distributed In the form of loans to needy railroads.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 1 -- The Spring training campaign of the Yankees got under way at Miller Hugging Field today promptly on schedule. The rays of the sun beat down upon a squad of nineteen athletes wearing baseball uniforms for the first time since the last world's series.

GENEVA, March 1 --The League of Nations has formally proposed that an international army under the authority of a League commission shall hold the Leticia territory in the Upper Amazon region pending negotiations between Colombia and Peru for a durable settlement of their dispute for its possession.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- A Florida downpour last night, followed by chilly winds and partly overcast skies, delayed for an hour the start of the Dodgers' third day of exercising today and sent a number of the boys on the field encased in rubber shirts.

A suit in behalf of stockholders of the National City Bank, accusing the directors of negligence and wrongful acts, which resulted in losses to the bank and a decrease in the value of its stock, was filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by Mrs. Anna Bashlow of Mount Vernon, who bought twenty shares in 1929.

WASHINGTON. March 1 -- Completion of the army air expansion program adopted in 1926, with respect to the number of fighting units, was announced today by F. Trubee Davison, the retiring Secretary of War for Air, with the approval of orders for the early organization of five additional pursuit squadrons.

Declaring that Russia was "an enemy State" and that "no nation has materially increased its trade with Russia as a result of recognition, nor has the United States suffered in the least by withholding it," Bainbridge Colby, Secretary of State in the 'Wilson administration, reiterated yesterday his opposition to recognition of the Soviet Government.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- Cuba's long-heralded rebellion has begun, according to revolutionists here who cannot be quoted. The revolt will continue for perhaps another week or ten days before it attracts widespread attention, it is declared, or is even recognized as a serious revolt, this despite the fact that it has been called the "best ballyhooed" of all risings.

Office, loft and showroom rentals continued to keep brokers and renting agents of Manhatttan buildings busy yesterday. This type of trading was most brisk in the midtown section, where several deals involving entire floors were announced.

PRAGUE, March 1 -- Foreign Minister Benes told the Foreign Affairs Committee of Parliament today that Czechoslovakia had no intention of tolerating another Hirtenberg rifle-smuggling affair. He indicated, however, that the matter would not now be brought before the League of Nations, as was at first threatened.

Wellesley College eventually will receive the residuary estate of Sara Teasdale, poet and author, who was found dead in her home on Jan. 29, it was disclosed yesterday when her will was offered for probate in Surrogates' Court.

A telegram pleading for commutation of the death sentence imposed on Will Sanders, 16-year-old Negro youth convicted on Feb. 2 in South Carolina of having clubbed a 59-year-old white woman to death, was sent yesterday to Governor Ibra C. Blackwood by the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, 69 Fifth Avenue.

On Saturday President HOOVER will conduct President-elect ROOSEVELT to the Capitol and will be present at the formal inauguration of his successor. The etiquette of the occasion is nowadays so definite and so familiar that the average citizen takes it as a matter of course.
CHICAGO, March 1 -- Wheat made a slow and easy start and a strong finish today on the Board of Trade. There was scattered selling early, but the pressure was not heavy.
BERLIN, March 1 (AP) -- President von Hindenburg greatly increased the powers of the government today by a decree raising the penalties for espionage, treason and subversive acts.

Lily Pons sang Gilda in the season's fifth and last "Rigoletto" at the opera last evening, to the delight of her admirers as expressed with thunderous applause after the "Caro Nome" aria and many curtain calls after each act. Miss Swarthout, Messrs. Laurl-Volpi, de Luca, Pasero and Gandolfi were others in the more dramatic roles.

Jack Pleva and Harry Schwartz, the first defendants to have been tried in this district for violation of the Federal election laws since 1870, were found guilty last night by a jury which had deliberated fifteen hours.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Seven relief advances to States totaling $7,370,484 and ten loans for small self-liquidating projects totaling $760,500 were made today by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.
Clinton prison at Dannemora, the "Siberia" of the underworld, is sending an art exhibition to New York.

A 10 per cent cut in the salary of every priest in the Roman Catholic Diocese of Brooklyn went into effect yesterday. Declining revenue, accompanied by greater demands on charitable institutions, had obliged Bishop Thomas E. Molloy to order the reduction, which applied to all ranks from the Bishop himself to the most recently appointed assistant pastor.

Jig-Saw Reorders Heavy. With the jig-saw puzzle now spreading to the Coast, reorders continue heavy and show no signs of diminution, it was reported hero yesterday. New types are being brought out, reflecting improvements in material and in the development of the jig-saw contest idea.

WASHINGTON, March 1. -- In the more than forty hours which Franklin D. Roosevelt intends to spend in Washington as President-elect he may have to set up a new record in the reiterated utterance of the word "no." This will depend on the number of persons he sees and talks with over the telephone.

Everywhere the moving pictures are creeping into houses originally designed for stage entertainment. Though the movies complain bitterly of their hard going financially, they still have enough money and enough confidence in their faithful public to press upon the old theatrical preserves.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Opposition to proposals for reductions in the salaries of State employes in the lower wage group developed at a conference of Republican Senators, called by Senator Fearon on the budget late today, and action on that phase of the Republican program was deferred for another conference next week.

A reflection of the transaction through which the Diamond Match Company repurchased 350,000 of its common shares for $5,162,000 at an auction in behalf of the creditors of the Kreuger Toll Company last June is seen in the preliminary balance sheet as of Dec. 31, just mailed to stockholders with an income account.

Five superior officers in the Fire Department were promoted yesterday after they had signed waivers of the salary increases they would normally receive, marking the first time in the department's history that promotions have been made without adding to the payroll.

A copy of the rare original edition of William Blake's "Songs of Innocence and of Experience" brought $6,000 last night at the American Art Association Anderson Galleries, Inc., at the auction of rare volumes from the library of the late Willis Vickery of Cleveland, one of the judges of the Supreme Court of Ohio.

NEW YORK. Mrs. John E. Berwind will give a large dinner tomorrow at the Central Park Casino for Mrs. Gwendda du Boulay of London, a member of the English Squash Racquets team, who is visiting her while in New York.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Despite the protest of President Hoover and the opposition of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, the report of that organization, showing the loans authorized to banks and trust companies and for other purposes during the month of January, was made public this evening by Congress.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The outer world is beginning to talk about a new Red terror in Russia, but, as explained in a previous dispatch, neither the Bolsheviki themselves nor leading sections of the Russian people consider it anything but "repressive measures" against class enemies and opponents of the socialization program.

BERLIN, March 1 -- Wholesale arrests of leading Communists throughout Germany and wholesale suppression of Communist newspapers, coupled with the suppression of Socialist newspapers and the mobilization of additional "auxiliary police" in many States, marked the second day of skillfully stimulated national hysteria following the incendiary fire in the Reichstag Building.

The Board of Aldermen formally fixed the 1933 tax rate at $2.33 per $100 of assessed valuation yesterday after Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin, only Republican member, had declared that the reduced rate had been accomplished almost entirely by abandonment of the Delaney plan of short-term subway financing.

A net loss of $36,827,900 of gold through further large earmarkings for foreign account and substantial exports of the metal was reported yesterday by the Federal Reserve Bank of New York. The decline through earmarking was $26,940,000, which brought total earmarkings since the first of the year to $235,301,200.
Banking holidays and legislative or Executive edicts authorizing restricted withdrawals operated In various States yesterday as follows:

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The Merchant Fleet Corporation was authorized today by the Shipping Board to advertise for bids for the leasing of the piers and properties of the board at Hoboken, N.J. The bids are to be transmitted to the board before final action is taken.

ALBANY, March 1 -- Opposition to the proposed reserve savings bank for the State, with compulsory participation, was voiced by spokesmen for savings banks today at a hearing before the Senate Committee on Banks.

Completion of Congressional action on the bankruptcy amendment met with approval in railroad, banking and legal circles yesterday. Officials of railroads not in need of using the bill's provisions hailed it as an aid to the credit of the industry generally.

Prizes were awarded to the winners of the fine arts exhibition of the New York Junior League coincident with its opening yesterday at the league's clubhouse, 221 East Seventy-first Street. The exhibit will end on March 15.

Some of the veteran captains who are members of the South Bay Boatmen's Association gathered yesterday at Lindenhurst, L.I., to celebrate the completion of their new fishing dock which they put together during the Winter.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 1. -- An order to show cause why the will of Florenz Ziegfeld, theatrical producer, who died last July in California, should not be probated and an administrator appointed was signed today by Surrogate George A. Slater, on the petition of Carl J. Austrian, attorney for the Bank of United States, now being liquidated.

Steinlen's poster in the window of the Ferargil Galleries prepares a visitor, to some extent, for what may be expected, though it can scarcely foreshadow such numbers. This is a major cat show. Cats in porcelain, wood, pewter, bronze and travertine; cats that are painted, carved, etched and drawn, even woven cats.

The pamphlet reports of the American Water Works and Electric Company, Inc., for 1932 shows a consolidated net income of $3,691,621 after taxes, charges, reserves, subsidiary preferred dividends and minority interests. This was equal, after preferred dividends, to $1.44 a share on 1,735,515 no par. common shares, against $6,399.166, or $2.97 a share, earned on 1,750,888 shares in 1931.

RED BANK, N.J., March 1 -- The body of Gilbert M. Keith, justice of the peace, missing since Monday from his office here and his home in Fair Haven, was found today in a woods near the roadside in Lakewood, a short distance from Paul Kimball Hospital there.
MIAMI, Fla., March 1 (AP) -- Mayor Anton Cermak's physicians said today their patient would live, "barring unforeseen circumstances."

Miss PERKINS is now officially open to congratulations on her appointment to the Cabinet. She deserves the tributes which are being laid at her feet. The women's organizations are making much of her appointment as the first representative of her sex in so exalted a post, but it is not merely as a woman that she has made a name for herself.

A suit to foreclose a mortgage on the Flatiron Building, for many years after its erection in 1902 one of the sights of New York, was filed in Supreme Court yesterday by the Equitable Life Assurance Society against the Flatiron Building Corporation, the United States Realty and Improvement Company, at one time interested in the building, and others.

Columbia launched nine crews yesterday on the Harlem River in the first outdoor practice session of the year for the Blue and White fleet. The flotilla included three varsity boats, two heavyweight freshman crews, two varsity 150-pound boats and two yearling lightweight eights.

DUBLIN, March 1. -- When the Dail Eireann reassembled today the government, on the initiative of Eamon de Valera, President of the Free State Executive Council, took the final step to remove the oath of allegiance to the King.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 1 -- Disregarding Governor McAlister's order for a six-day banking holiday in Tennessee, Chattanooga's three largest banks, the Hamilton National, the American Trust and Banking Company and the new Chattanooga National remained open today and issued statements indicating that they would do so tomorrow.

DENVER, March 1. -- Released after he had been kept blindfolded in a cellar for seventeen days by kidnappers who demanded $60,000 ransom, Charles Boettcher 2d, wealthy young investment broker and member of one of Colorado's best-known families, was returned to his home tonight, little the worse for his nerve-wracking experience.

With the testimony of ex-Governor SMITH, the Senate Committee on Finance has concluded the hearings which brought many witnesses to Washington to express their views. The object of this inquiry was stated in a resolution adopted on Jan. 26.

William Woodward, chairman of the stewards of the Jockey Club, left yesterday for Palm Beach, Fla., for a rest and to confer with Joseph E. Widener and George H. Bull. Mr. Bull is at Havana, but plans to meet Messrs. Widener and Woodward at Palm Beach.

VIENNA, March 1. -- The railroads of Australia were paralyzed from 9 o'clock to 11 o'clock this morning by a general strike. The trade unions of the Government party made common cause with the unions of the Hitlerites and Social Democrats to protest against the State, Railways' decision to pay the current month's wages in three instalments.

BOSTON, March 1 -- Calvin Coolidge's adopted State paid tribute to him today with simple exercises held before a joint convention of the Legislature in the historic chamber of the House of Representatives.

Wednesday, March 1, 1933. Continued demands upon this city by interior banks resulted in a general stiffening in all departments, with consequent rise in rates. Stock Exchange demand loans rose to 2 per cent at midday, after renewing at 1, the first variation from the latter figure since Oct. 13 last and the first upward revision since Dec. 30, 1931.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As far as the fantastic has elements of humor, the comment on "Women and Machines" in Topics of The Times was intended, I take, it, to be funny. Why not complete the humor of abolishing machines and women too by abolishing everything and everybody?

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 1 -- Three English players -- the Misses Diana Fishwick, Kathleen Garnham and Barbara Pyman -- were among the favorites who advanced in the first round of match play in the Florida East Coast championship for the Mrs. W.R. Kenan Jr. Cup on the St. Augustine links today.

Denying any present need for deposits by holders of long-term Hungarian dollar bonds, now in default, the American Committee on Long-Term Hungarian Dollar Debt, organized in June, 1932, following the Hungarian moratorium on foreign debt payments, issued a statement yesterday saying it had kept in active touch with the situation and had been recognized officially by the Hungarian Government.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Economic questions and disarmament were discussed by Secretary Stimson, Cordell Hull, the Secretary of State-designate, and Norman H. Davis at the State Department this afternoon.

RICHMOND, Va., March 1 (AP) -- Former Governor Harry Flood Byrd tonight accepted the appointment to the United States Senate succeeding Senator Claude A. Swanson, retiring to become Secretary of the Navy in the Roosevelt Cabinet.
CHENGTEH (Jehol City), March 1. -- West of the Chihfeng-Lingyuan defense line broken yesterday by the Japanese] is another and stronger one dominating roads from Lingyuan to the east and north.

BELGRADE, March 1 -- Before crowded galleries which included the diplomatic representatives of France, Czechoslovakia, Rumania and Poland, but not Italy, Hungary, Austria or Bulgaria, the new Little Entente pact was ratified today by the Skuptschina [Lower House].
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 1 -- Bolivia accepted "in principle" and with reservations today the proposals of the ABC-Peru group for renewing peace negotiations with Paraguay.

MIAMI, Fla., March 1 -- The seven race-winning streak of the B.B. Stable's Character was snapped at Hialeah Park today when the Coldstream Stud's Marmion wore him down and won by three-quarters of a length in the mile of the Fort Lauderdale Handicap.

BERLIN, March 1 -- The Boerse opened with more animation today and most of the active stocks rose. Later a recession set in and the day's highest levels were not generally maintained, although closing prices mostly were above yesterday's finals.

A group of 200 workers who lost their jobs because they were displaced by machinery received part of a dismissal wage yesterday, paid out of penalties imposed for the introduction of the labor-saving devices.

Decision on an application of the Irving Trust Company as trustee in bankruptcy of the International Match Corporation to expunge a claim of $112,000,000 filed against the corporation by the Swedish Match Company was held in abeyance yesterday by Oscar W. Ehrhorn, Federal referee, to give counsel for the claimant an opportunity to prepare "a proper and amended" claim.
Several taxpayer parcels were included in the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday, in addition to the usual housing deals.

Pressure against United States Government bonds and German loans, and irregularly lower prices for domestic corporation issues characterized dealings in bonds yesterday on the Stock Exchange. Tightening of money rates and extension of banking moratoriums to additional States operated to further liquidation in bonds, with United States Government issues forming the pivot.
Dishonesty in business was condemned yesterday by Bishop William T. Manning in an Ash Wednesday sermon at historic Trinity Church, which stands at the head of Wall Street.

MINNEAPOLIS, Minn., March 1 -- Warning that public education cannot be secure so long as its policies are dominated by great financial interests, Professor John Dewey of Columbia University, honorary president of the National Education Association, urged teachers here today to recognize their solidarity with farmers, factory workers, small merchants and "other classes of the underprivileged."

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Never before has there been a time when it has been so imperative for business men to rally their energies and brains behind united policies, Secretary Chapin declared in a statement today.

BERLIN, March 1 --In circumstances like those prevailing in Germany at present, it is the duty of conscientious correspondents, disregarding the superficial political turmoil, to seek beneath the confusion of today and the contradictions of yesterday some theory that may explain both and give promise of a hopeful tomorrow.

With legislative developments balanced against other news of a less reassuring character, the speculative markets chose yesterday to swing around to a cautiously optimistic viewpoint. Stocks extended their gains of the previous day and commodities were firm.

Fordham University opened a new chapter in its football history yesterday. Under the guidance of the new head coach, Sleepy Jim Crowley, the Rams launched the first steps of a transformation in style of play which next Fall will give New York its first major college to employ the Notre Dame system.

Breaking out of the narrow range in which they had moved since October, stocks, after making an effort in the early weeks of February to advance, declined sharply in the last half of the month. At the month-end they were below levels where, on four previous occasions, they had met support, and were back to where they were in the beginning of August.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with interest your editorial in opposition to the Hanley firearms bill, of which I have a companion bill in the Assembly.

PARIS, March 1 -- With growing anxiety the French are watching events across the Rhine and Chancellor Hitler's repressive measures, in which they see a determined intention to achieve a Fascist dictatorship.

More than 3,000 engineers, physicians, industrialists and public safety officials registered yesterday at the Greater New York Safety Conference at the Hotel Pennsylvania. The conference, which will close this evening with a dinner, is held under the auspices of the Metropolitan Chapter of the American Society of Safety Engineers, the Engineering Section of the National Safety Council, the New York Chapter of the American Red Cross and fifty-three cooperating organizations.

DETROIT, March 1 -- Ernest G. Liebold, confidential secretary to Henry Ford, was returning here tonight, accompanied by his son and two Ford Motor Company secret service men, after a mysterious disappearance Monday which started an extensive hunt for him.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 1 -- One of the largest social functions held here tonight was the dinner given by John Sanford and his daughter, Miss Sarah Jane Sanford, in the patio of Villa Marina.

The Guaranty Trust Companv is transfer agent for 10,000 $100 par preferred shares and 18,738 $100 par common shares of the International Time Recording Company of New York; 821 no par preferred and 5,000 no par common shares of the Tabulating Machine Company and 27,999,14 no par common shares of the Dayton Scale Company.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 1 -- Mrs. H. Stuart Green of Tarrytown and Miss Marguerite Anderson of Plainfield, N.J., will meet here tomorrow morning in the final round of the women's annual squash racquets tournament of the Racquet and Swimming Club.

The four seeded contract-bridge teams came through with victories yesterday afternoon in the first knockout round of the team-of-four event for the Curt H. Reisinger Trophy at the Hotel Roosevelt. Yesterday's play in the various events of the Eastern bridge championships resulted in the elimination of about half the players who had been playing in qualifying rounds since Monday and limited the field largely to the favorites.

PARIS, March 1 -- France will not immediately follow the example of Great Britain in declaring an embargo on shipments of arms and munitions to Japan and China, Joseph Paul-Boncour, the Foreign Minister, indicated today in an extensive statement Defore the Foreign Affairs Commission of the Chamber of Deputies.

Mr. Toscanini's return to the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra last night in Carnegie Hall was the occasion of a warm demonstration in his honor and of some very exceptional orchestral performances. The program contained a novelty in the form of Howard Hanson's "Romantic" Symphony No. 2.
KKOXVILLE, Tenn., March 1 -- Banks in Knoxville and most of East Tennessee will continue to do business as usual, it appeared tonight.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 1 -- Harvard's freshman basketball team won Its ninth game in eleven starts today, defeating Andover, 59 to 19, in the Indoor Athletic Building. The victors led at half time, 30 to 10, and at the end of the third quarter, 49 to 15.

Depression or no depression, passenger traffic from New York to Washington for the inauguration ceremonies will be the heaviest since the war, it was said yesterday at the offices of railroads, bus companies and air lines. Advance bookings indicated that more persons would leave New York to see Governor Roosevelt become President on Saturday than traveled from here to the inauguration of President Harding, President Coolidge or President Hoover.

The electric power index has dropped to a new low record. The seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Feb. 25 was 203,100,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 207,700,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 215,400,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year; and the adjusted index was 63.0, as against 64.5 for the preceding week and 71.5 for the corresponding week last year.

Depression or no depression, passenger traffic from New York to Washington for the inauguration ceremonies will be the heaviest since the war, it was said yesterday at the offices of railroads, bus companies and air lines. Advance bookings indicated that more persons would leave New York to see Governor Roosevelt become President on Saturday than traveled from here to the inauguration of President Harding, President Coolidge or President Hoover.

The electric power index has dropped to a new low record. The seasonally adjusted daily average for the week ended Feb. 25 was 203,100,000 kilowatt-hours, as against 207,700,000 kilowatt-hours for the preceding week and 215,400,000 kilowatt-hours for the corresponding week last year; and the adjusted index was 63.0, as against 64.5 for the preceding week and 71.5 for the corresponding week last year.

Franklin D. Roosevelt motored from his home at Hyde Park yesterday, passed the night at his city home at 49 East Sixty-fifth Street and will leave this afternoon for Washington where he will be inaugurated President of the United States on Saturday.

The courts and the legal profession, because of their importance in molding public opinion, have a great responsibility in helping the country to hold fast to its democratic principles in the midst of demands for their abandonment as a result of depression and unrest, Presiding Judge Martin T. Manton of the United States Circuit Court of Appeals declared yesterday afternoon at the laying of the cornerstone of the new United States court house.
WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Movements of vessels follow; all dates are Feb. 28, unless otherwise specified:

ALBANY, March 1. -- The Court of Appeals declared illegal today an agreement between the State Bank of Commerce of Brockport and Howard G. Stone, as treasurer of the farm department of the Monroe County Farm and Home Bureau Association, by which the bank pledged its assets for security of the association's deposit.

TOKYO, March 1 -- Evidence acc cumulates of Japanese irritation at Britain's arms embargo policy, though it is reliably reported that a military official said the army should welcome such pin pricks for their effect on public Opinion.

Price movements In local commodlty markets were more irregular yesterday, as profit-taking followed the rallies of the preceding day. Sugar, cocoa, silk, hides and several rubber contracts continued to advance, while coffee and silver slipped off.

With twelve teams remaining in the grind, the six-day bicycle race continued at Madison Square Garden last night. While a crowd of 11,000 persons looked on, the riders, showing no abatement of the strong pace they have been setting since Sunday, pedaled their way past the half-way mark with the lead still grimly fought for and changing regularly.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- Alleging that Senator Huey P. Long maliciously slandered him in a speech made on the floor of the Senate, Feb. 21, following his return from hearings held in New Orleans by the Senate committee investigating the election of Senator Overton, Brig. Gen. Samuel T. Ansell, counsel for the committee, today sued Senator Long for $500,000 damages.

The merits of traditional American individualism as against public enterprise were debated yesterday in addresses at a luncheon of the Advertising Club of New York by Dr. Virgil Jordan, president of the National Industrial Conference Board, and Professor Walter Rautenstrauch of the Department of Industrial Engineering of Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, March 1 -- The uncertainty overshadowing the next British move in the war debts situation has not discouraged hopeful speculation here as to the proposal which the Roosevelt administration expects the British to put forward soon.

PARIS, March 1 -- Premier Daladier as a mark of respect to the retiring United States Ambassador, Walter E. Edge, attended a farewell luncheon given to him today by the Anglo-American Newspaper Men's Association in Paris. Robert T. Pell, who has been press officer of the United States Embassy for the past three years, was also a guest.

A tentative schedule for the play-off dates of the National Hockey League was arranged at a meeting of the board of governors, held yesterday at the Hotel Lincoln. Because of the uncertainty that still exists concerning the ultimate winners of the play-off berths, few dates were decided upon definitely.

Paving the way for a judicial reform of alimony abuses, Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonynge in Brooklyn attacked yesterday the "petticoat justice" which permits "waspish" wives to imprison their husbands indefinitely for falling behind in alimony payments.

A reduction this week in the national average of steel operations to 17 per cent of capacity is ascribed by The Iron Age, in its midweek review, to banking difficulties which in some sections have tended to restrict business slightly. The rate last week was estimated at a shade less than 19 per cent.

Foundation work on the site of the annex to the Postoffice Building on Ninth Avenue between Thirty-first and Thirty-third Streets is nearing completion in anticipation of an early announcement of the awarding of the general contract for the $5,000,000 extension, it was revealed yesterday at the offices of McKim, Mead White, the architects, at 101 Park Avenue.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 1 -- Twenty-seven members of the senior class and nine juniors were elected to the Phi Beta Kappa Society at the meeting of the Princeton chapter here this afternoon. As six members of the class of 1933 were elected to the society last year, the total number of seniors admitted to membership is now thirty-three.
BERLIN, March 1 -- Soviet-German relations are not likely to be much affected by the Hitler regime's anti-Communist actions, however extreme.
WASHINGTON March 1 -- The War Department issued the following orders today:

C.H. Donner of the Princeton Club advanced to the quarter-final round of the national Class B squash tennis championship at the Squash Club last night. He drew up on even terms with H.A. Haines of the home club and T.H. Hendrickson of the Crescent Athletic Hamilton Club.

The index number of average commodity prices as of March 1, compiled and published by Dun's Review, indicates a decline during February of six-tenths of 1 per cent. This reduction, with the exception of last November, when the percentage decline was the same, is the smallest of any month since the consecutive three months' advance of July, August and September last year.
"Our Wife," a play by Lyon Mearson and Lillian Day, will have its premiere this evening at the Booth Theatre. June Walker, Humphrey Bogart and Rose Hobart are among those in the cast.

Out-of-town banks withdrew $500,000,000 of their deposits from New York banks to meet the crisis in Michigan and other interior States in the first three weeks of February, says the current monthly review of the Federal Preserve Bank of New York.

PARIS, March 1 -- For the first time in its recent history, the French Socialist party split last night on the question of the government's financial proposals. One hundred and four Socialist Deputies voted with the Government and twenty against it.

Progress of the Smith bill to pool all government-financed cotton that would be sold prior to March 1 next year caused an upturn yesterday in prices on the Cotton Exchange. After the opening trading had advanced prices about 10 points, scattered selling wiped out all improvement and quotations fell below the previous closing figures.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney issued orders yesterday for elaborate arrangements for safeguarding President-elect Roosevelt during his departure for Washington this afternoon. The plans call for the service of more than 2,000 uniformed patrolmen and some 200 plainclothes men, as well as the ranking heads of many of the department's branches.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 1 -- The largest crowd ever to witness an ice hockey game, 22,157 persons, saw the New York Rangers defeat the Atlantic City Sea Gulls by a 6-to-2 score at the Municipal Auditorium tonight.
LONDON, March 1 -- Ambassador Mellon expressed the hope and belief today that the present banking difficulties in the United States would result in a thoroughgoing reform of the banking system.

The rapid sweep of Japanese troops through the province of Jehol will probably make the Japanese Government still more indifferent to the British embargo on the shipment of arms and munitions to China and Japan. That measure itself has a curious look.

Yesterday's combined statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the system's note circulation to be at a new high figure for the year to date, and largest since 1919. Rediscounts of the system also reached a new high for the year, while total gold holdings and the ratio of reserve for the system as a whole and at New York also reached new minimums for the year to date.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The Reconstruction Finance Corporation announced today that a hearing will be given Monday morning by its engineers advisory board to representatives of the North River Bridge Company on the engineering features of the projected bridge across the Hudson River at Fifty-Seventh Street, New York.

An increase of 8 1/2 per cent in the number but a decrease of $15 in the average size of loans granted last year is reported by the Provident Loan Society of New York in its annual statement to members for 1932. Loans granted numbered 576,676, and the average size was $53, comparing with $68 in 1931 and $79 in 1930.

Some of the men who still are fighting the war -- patients in the hospitals for veterans here -- forgot their ills for a few hours last night at the fourth annual beefsteak dinner and entertainment provided by American Legion Post 1025, recruited from members of the Grand Street Boys Association.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Three more major financial operations of the National City Company before the market collapse of 1929 were described before the Senate's stock inquiry today as the committee concluded its Investigation for this session of Congress.

Jefferson De Angelis, well-known actor, who is remembered by older theatregoers for his light and comic operatic roles in such successes as "Fantana," "The Jolly Musketeers" and others, has been gravely ill at the Orange Memorial Hospital in Orange, N.J., since Feb. 22.
CHINCHOW, Manchuria, Friday, March 3. -- Japan's invading army has broken through the strongest Chinese defenses and today it was less than fifty miles from Chengteh (Jehol City).

PARIS, March 2 (AP). -- Ambassador and Mrs. Edge are planning a month's vacation in the Balkans before returning to the United States some time in April. Mr. Edge will retire as Ambassador Friday and on that night they will go to Switzerland with Robert I. Pell, press attache at the embassy, and Mrs. Pell.
The first seeded player of the tournament, James Jacobson, New York University freshman, was eliminated from the Eastern pingpong championship in progress at the Hotel New Yorker last night.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The arrival of President-elect Roosevelt from New York today was coincident with the beginning of the inaugural ceremonies, which will last for two more days. The city is decked with flags, the streets are filled with automobiles and sightseers, the hotels are jammed to overflowing, and there is all the usual excitement of inaugural affairs.

Aboard an "inauguration" special which left from Jersey City, President-elect Roosevelt and most of his family moved on toward Washington and the White House yesterday while a police band from New York sent the strains of "Happy Days Are Here Again" following them down the Baltimore Ohio station platform.

Democracy is on trial as to whether or not it can control its own duly elected representatives and force an end of wasteful governmental expenditures. Major Gen. John F. O'Ryan, wartime commander of the Twenty-seventh Division, declared yesterday afternoon at a meeting of more than 100 members of the Academy of Science at the academy, 2 East 103d Street.

SAN FRANCISCO, March 2. -- A fixed, definite government policy of prohibiting the sale or export of arms and munitions to any aggressor nation that prefers war to arbitration was urged here today by Newton D. Baker, Secretary of War in President Wilson's Cabinet.

NEW ORLEANS, March 2 (AP).--Miss Careful, which has shown her best performances over heavy tracks, today came from behind to earn a nose decision over four other 3-year-old fillies in the six-furlong featured race at the Fair Grounds.

Stockholders of Sears, Roebuck Co. will act on March 27 on an amendment to the employes' stock purchase plan of 1929, which would give to officers and employes rights to subscribe to a total of 150,000 shares of Sears, Roebuck stock at $25 a share until' Dec. 31, 1938.
DETROIT, March 2. -- Michigan's financiers have agreed at last on State legislation to permit the reopening of the banks, and this legislation is expected to be adopted next week.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- The Howard Savings Institution at 768 Broad Street, which is 75 years old and is considered one of the strongest saving's banks in the State, refused today to take advantage of the legal provision allowing it to withhold deposits for ninety days and announced it would pay out all deposits as requested.

LOS ANGELES, March 2. -- Having hastily drawn up his first-line defense, Manager Bill Terry set to work today arranging a secondary Giant infield and was more than agreeably surprised to find himself in possession of a third baseman of whose ability he had been totally unaware.

Trailing by two games, Willard K. Rice of the Harvard Club rallied to defeat W.W. Stokes Jr. of the Yale Club last night as the national amateur Class A squash tennis championship got under way on the Harvard courts. The score was 14 -- 18, 15 -- 18, 15 -- 7, 15 -- 1, 15 -- 10.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- Following a newly developed system of radio aids, a pilot flying in a snowstorm this morning located the Newark Metropolitan Airport, picked up the runway on which he was supposed to land and then following a curved radio beam brought his plane within five feet of the ground.

The Japan Advertiser of Feb. 4, received from Tokyo yesterday, gives details of a decree of absolute divorce granted by the Tokyo District Court on Jan. 30, 1933, to John Richard Geary, former president of the General Electric Company of Japan, against Mrs. Camilla McCallum Geary of Lockport, N.Y. The decree was granted on the ground of desertion.

MONTREAL, March 2 (AP). -- The Montreal Canadians upset the Toronto Maple Leafs, leaders of the National Hockey League's International Group, for the second straight time tonight, 4 to 3. The triumph, in a stormy game which produced five major penalties, gave the Canadians a tie with the New York Americans for third place.

Thursday, March 2, 1933. A stiffening money market bringing in its wake higher rates, featured business in the money market. The change of outstanding importance, announced after the close of business, was the advance in the Reserve Bank rediscount rate from 2 1/2 to 3 1/2 per cent, highest since Feb. 26, 1932.

The Lawyers Mortgage Company, of which Richard M. Hurd is president, has issued a letter to holders of its guaranteed mortgage certificates asking them to accept interest at the rate of 4 per cent from the date of the last interest payment and to agree to an extension of the time of payment of the principal of the certificates and mortgages covered.

A questionnaire to determine which of the country's current problems is most pressing has been mailed to a list of business and professional leaders by William C. Durant, automobile manufacturer. The replies will be made public. It was said yesterday at his office.

In recognition of their outstanding contributions to medicine, thirteen leading physicians and research workers from ten nations were elected last night to honorary fellowship in the New York Academy of Medicine.

The nine incumbent directors of the Brooklyn Union Gas Company were re-elected unanimously for 1933 at the annual meeting of the company's stockholders yesterday afternoon at the offices at 176 Remsen Street, Brooklyn. In a short talk to the stockholders, James H. Jourdan, president, said the company's business held up "remarkably well" in 1932 in spite of the pression.
A move toward a firmer steel price structure, which was made yesterday by the United States Steel Corporation, was immediately supported by all other leading manufacturers.

Mrs. Mabel Hunt Slater, who inherited a fortune from her husband, Horatio N. Slater, New England textile manufacturer, testified yesterday in Craig House, a sanitarium at Beacon, N.Y., to which she was committed in 1930, that she intended to create a trust fund for her nephew, William Hunt Slater, The Associated Press reported.

An automobile engine, adapted to burn fuel oil instead of gasoline, was demonstrated yesterday by officers of the Thurberator Corporation of 444 Madison Avenue. The appliance used to convert the engine into an oil-burner replaces the carburetor and may be affixed to any ordinary automobile engine, its maker said.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- When Franklin D. Roosevelt reached Washington tonight, to spend his last day and a half before becoming President, he found himself in an atmosphere of cooperation, and anticipation of the leadership for which the capital has been clamoring for two years.

Three women, a Boy Scout and fifty-four other persons received National Safety Council certificates for saving victims of gas, smoke, poison and submersion, at a banquet last night at the Hotel Pennsylvania, held at the close of the fourth annual Greater New York Safety Conference.

HARRISBURG, Pa., March 2.--Governor Pinchot today signed a certificate testifying to the re-election of Senator James J. Davis last November and sent it to Washington with Richard J. Beamish, Secretary of the Commonwealth.

The Corn Products Refining Company reported yesterday for 1932 a net income of $8,761,638, equivalent, after preferred dividends, to $2.77 a share on 2,530,000 shares of common stock. This compares with $10,709,775, or $3.54 a share in 1931. A net loss of $1,805,344 was charged on securities sold in 1932 to a reserve which had previously been established.

Seldom is death more importunate than when it came to Senate WALSH. Of private grief, of the strong all-pervading sense of public loss, of the new career that was not to be begun, it would be useless to speak. Regarded in it larger aspect, this seeming untimely end is no unfitting climax.
PARIS, March 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes, in francs:

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Secretary Adams's action in ordering the Marine and Navy Bands "off the air" caused a storm in the House of Representatives today. Representative Britten of Illinois, ranking Republican member of the Committee on Naval Affairs, urged Congress to take the action necessary to restore these famous service bands to the radio programs.

BERLIN, March 2. -- In the new Third Reich now so painfully being hammered out here, in which the utterly fantastic is attested by thousands of affivadits and Grimm's fairy tales by contrast with some official communiques become unquestionable facts, keen resentment that outside opinion is not reinforcing inside anti-Communist agitation is developing.

The Appellate Division reserved decision yesterday on an appeal by Charles A. Stoneham, president of the New York. Giants Baseball Club from a judgment by Supreme Court Justice McCook driecting the payment of $42,827 to former City Magistrate Francis X. McQuade as his salary as treasurer of the club from May 2, 1928, when McQuade was ousted by the club, to March 7, 1932.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- The play-off hopes of the New York Americans suffered a blow tonight when they lost to the Chicago Black Hawks, 3 to 2, while the Montreal Canadiens defeated Toronto and tied the Americans for third place in the international group of the National Hockey League.

AUSTIN, Texas, March 2. -- In a brief proclamation late today Governor Miriam A. Ferguson ordered all banks, trust companies, building and loan associations and other financial institutions in Texas to remain closed until the morning of March 8.

An order requiring the finger-prints of all aliens arriving in the United States for permanent residence, an unprecedented rule in the history of immigration, has been issued as a departmental order by the Immigration Bureau in Washington, it was revealed yesterday.
