Urge to Purge. Isn't it a bit early for the Democrats to start lighting each other as ALFRED E. SMITH would have them do? To be sure, his latest New Outlook editorial only restates views previously expressed by him on the subject of bigots, fanatics, Populists, demagogues, mountebanks and crackpots.

At the council meeting of the American Power Boat Association on Monday night a new device, calculated to time motor-boat races with greater accuracy, less work and less likelihood of human error, will be tested.

A five-story granite-faced dwelling at 119 East Sixty-fourth Street. a half block from Park Avenue, was raided as a Rambling house late yesterday afternoon by plainclothes patrolmen on the staff of Inspector Edward J. Lennon. Three men were, arrested, one as the operator of the resort, which was situated in the rear of the fourth floor.

Columbia's rowing squad was forced to abandon temporarily its outdoor training program yesterday because of the unfavorable weather. The Blue and White outfit took part in its first drill of the year on the Harlem River, on Wednesday and Coach Richard J. Gleudon plans to resume the outdoor sessions today if the weather permits.

DENVER, March 2 (AP). -- Law enforcement agencies, backed by the power and weight of the Boettcher name and fortune, swept tonight into a remorseless search for the men who kidnapped Charles Boettcher 2d on Feb. 12, and held him captive until last night.

A forecast that forty-six of the forty-eight States will vote to repeal the Eighteenth Amendment was made yesterday by The Literary Digest on the basis of the three prohibition polls it has conducted.
LONDON, March 2 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

When the State of New York in 1921 required all first voters to give proof of literacy, a list of 4,000 words was prepared by the State Education Department as a basis for the test. It was assumed that familiarity with these words, spoken and written, would enable one to qualify as a citizen.

HERKIMER, N.Y., March 2. -- The will of Corinne Roosevelt Robinson, sister of Theodore Roosevelt, former President, which was admitted to probate today, divides the residue of the estate, "exceeding $20,000," between her three children, Theodore D. Robinson, Corinne R. Alsop and Monroe D. Robinson.

A suit in behalf of stockholders of the United Founders Corporation for an accounting of a loss to the corporation, alleged to be $50,000,000, has been brought in the Supreme Court by Richard A. Rowland as owner of 2,210 shares of stock, and others, it was revealed yesterday as the result of a denial by Justice Hammer of an application in behalf of one of the defendants to transfer the case to the Federal court.

Grand opera at the Metropolitan next season was assured yesterday, after a month of suspense during which the Committee to Save Metropolitan Opera labored to raise a $300,000 guarantee fund, without which the Metropolitan Opera Association had announced it would have to yield to the depression.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra, Serge Koussevitzky, conductor, gave a concert of exemplary brilliancy last night in Carnegie Hall. The earlier part of the program was given to acknowledged masterpieces by Gluck and Schumann. The second part was a repetition, and the finest performance of a strange and formidable score that Mr. Koussevitzky, or probably any other conductor, has given in this city.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- After five starts In which he failed to earn brackets, Joseph E. Widener's The Pellcan got past the judges in first position today in the Winter Oasis Purse, feature at Hialeah Park.
ALBANY, March 2. -- Enactment of legislation creating a system of State employment Insurance will be sought by the Democrats at Albany, the party's legislative leaders announced today.
PEIPING, March 2 (AP). -- Throughout China there is bitter disappointment at the crumbling of the defense lines in Jehol.

Two homing pigeons winged over the edge of the Atlantic and across Sandy Hook Bay at dusk last evening carrying congratulatory messages to President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt on his administration, which begins tomorrow. The two pigeons, crack fliers of the Army Signal Corps, were released from the bridge of the new United Fruit liner Peten as it steamed out of New York Harbor on her maiden voyage to the Caribbean.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Saddened by the death of Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana, whom he had picked for his Attorney General, Franklin D. Roosevelt arrived tonight in Washington to prepare for his inauguration on Saturday as the thirty-second President of the United States.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 2. -- Im mediate aid for schools in the form of emergency loans from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation was asked here today by the convention of the Department of Superintendence of the Nations Education Association.

LONDON, March 2. -- The plight of Jews in Germany was emphasized tonight by Dr. Chaim Weizmann, presiding at a dinner to the "friends of Palestine in the British Parliament" given by the British section of the Jewish Agency.
HELENA, Mont., March 2 (AP). -- Senator Walsh was mourned in death today by Montanans of varied political affiliations.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 2. -- Startling upsets featured the second round of match play for the Florida Bast Coast women's championship and the Mrs. W.R. Kenan Jr. Cup today. The prime favorites to fall were Miss Maureen Orcutt of Englewood, N.J., the defending titleholder; Miss Diana Fishwick, former British champion, and Mrs. Opal S. Hill, recent winner of the Florida crown at Palm Beach.

Bank clearings last week were the highest for a week this year and only 3.5 per cent below those the corresponding week of last year, according to R.G. Dun Co., who note that no report was received from Detroit because of she banking disturbance.
POUGHKEEPSIE, March 2. -- Phi Beta Kappa honors were awarded to twenty-nine seniors and six juniors of Vassar College today. They were announced by President MacCracken, as follows:

Dr. William Briggs Tatum, senior assistant attending urologist it the Long Island College Hospital, was killed yesterday when he fell or jumped from the third floor of his home at 32 Pierrepont Street, Brooklyn. He had been suffering from a nervous ailment for about a year and was planning to leave shortly with his wife and child for a vacation in the South.
BERLIN, March 2 (AP). -- The foreign press was referred to by Captain Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Minister Without Portfolio, in an address tonight at a Nazi mass meeting.

ARDSLEY-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., March 2. -- Maintaining the brilliant pace she set in earlier matches, Mrs. H. Stuart Green of Tarrytown won the annual women's invitation squash racquets tournament at the Racquet and Swimming Club today by defeating Miss Marguerite Anderson of Plainfield, N.J., in the final.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Mrs. Edward Everett Gann, sister of Vice President Curtis, today urged all Republican women everywhere to work wholeheartedly with the incoming President and his administration for the restoration of prosperity.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt announced after her arrival here tonight that out of respect to the late Senator Walsh she and Mr. Roosevelt would cancel all purely social engagements in connection with the inauguration.

BERLIN, March 2. -- The Boerse was more active, with a decided upward tendency, today. Most of the active stocks rose, some of them making substantial gains. The best rise for the day was 4 1/2 points. Farben, potash stocks, coals and electricals were the centre of interest.

Steps to eliminate from the city the "invisible government" of the political machine were outlined yesterday by Dr. Luther Gulick, Eaton Professor of Municipal Science and Administration at Columbia University and director of the National Institute of Public Administration.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Warned that America's largest cities are on the verge of financial collapse, the Senate Judiciary Committee approved today a two-year bond moratorium bill to aid them. Members conceded, however, that there wag little likelihood of Senate action in the remaining few hours of this Congress.

What prisoners talk about, their ethics and etiquette, hopes and fears, are reported upon by Victor F. Nelson, who has spent more than twelve of his thirty-four years in prisons, in "Prison Days and Nights," published by Little, Brown.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., March 2. -- The Dartmouth swimming team scored a 41-to-30 victory over Brown University tonight, the winner being decided by the 400-yard relay, the final event. Dartmouth captured the relay by a margin of two yards, Crouse giving Banfield, the anchorman, this lead which Lewis, Brown's star, was unable to overcome.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The little band of conservatives whom Speaker Garner relied upon to carry on his leadership in the next Congress was unhorsed at the Democratic caucus tonight by a group of liberals, led by Representative Rainey of Illinois, Democratic leader in the present House, and Representative Byrns of Tennessee, chairman of the Appropriations Committee.
BERLIN, March 2 (AP).--The Reichsbank statement as of Feb. 28 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

At the opening session of the Greater New York Safety Conference yesterday, Mr. H.C. PARMELEE declared that " indus" trial safety pays in dollars and " cents." Aside from the humane aspects of the movement and the cost of paying damages for accidents, great financial loss in business is the consequence of neglect to adopt precautions.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., March 2. -- A chicken dinner at the Elks Club here means chicken hash and pickings for homeless men when they gather for dinner the next day in the new village jail. Officials of the police department announce that arrangements have been completed with the Elks, the committees of church socials and private hosts to collect food left over from parties for distribution to those unable to buy food.

ROCKY MOUNT, N.C., March 2. -- Senator Thomas J. Walsh, 73, of Montana, who was to have become Attorney General of the United States in the Roosevelt administration, died suddenly near here this morning while en route to Washington with his bride of five days, the former Senora Nieves Perze Chaumont de Truffin of Havana.

Funeral services for the Rev. Dr. David Davidson, educator, writer and early exponent in this country of the movement toward a liberal Jewry, were held at his home, 216 West Eighty-ninth Street, yesterday. In accordance with his wish, public announcement of his death on Tuesday was withheld by the family until after the funeral.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana, Attorney General-designate in the Roosevelt Cabinet, died of a sudden heart attack on a train early this morning as he was hurrying to Washington from Havana with his bride, whom he married in Havana last Saturday.

During the twenty years that he served in the United States Senate Thomas J. Walsh took a prominent part in all important matters to come before the upper house, but he was chiefly known to the public for his fearless and thorough expose of the Teapot Dome and Elk Hills oil scandals.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- President Hoover will not sail Saturday, inauguration day, from New York for California, as he had planned, but will stay in New York a week, one reason being a desire to be available if President Roosevelt should want information on any of the many complex problems with which he will be confronted immediately on taking office.

The New York Stock Exchange's monthly report on loans to member firms on securities shows an increase of $615,998 in February, or from $359,341,058 at the close of January to $359,957,056 at the close of business on Feb. 28. In the four weeks ended on Feb. 28, brokers' loans as reported by the Federal Reserve Bank declined $36,000,000, from $454,000,000 to $418,000,000.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- A man who isn't afraid to tell the House it is running wild -- Henry T. Rainey of Illinois -- is the man the Democrats tonight chose for Speaker in the Seventy-third Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ended March 1, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $2,585,000,000, an increase of $317,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $857,000,000 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

BALTIMORE, Md., March 2. -- Decisions favoring the Rustless Iron Corporation of America of Baltimore in a patent-infringement suit were handed down yesterday by Judge William C. Coleman in the United States District Court here. The suit was brought in 1929 by the Electro Metallurgical Company, a subsidiary of the Union Carbide and Carbon Corporation, and the American Stainless Steel Company of Pittsburgh.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 2. -- By starting his training campaign a week ahead of schedule, Sammy Byrd, Yankee outfielder, today became the team's first casualty.

NEWARK, N.J., March 2. -- School and municipal employes here remained unpaid today, but there were indications that collection of taxes and arrears would make it possible to meet the semi-monthly payroll, due yesterday, within a few days.

A liking for American popular songs was revealed yesterday by Miss Lily Pens, soprano of the Metropolitan Opera Association, at a private rehearsal of several of such selections in her apartment at Essex House, Central park South and Sixth Avenue.

In order to lessen the possibility of early elimination for some of the outstanding performers, the stars In the sprint and the hurdle race in the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. indoor track and field championships at the 258th Field Artillery Armory tomorrow night will be seeded in the heats, it was announced yesterday.

The Crockford's Club team of Oswald Jacoby, Louis Watson, Theodore A. Lightner and Michael T. Gottlieb and the team of David A. Burnstine, Howard Schenken, Charles Lochridge and Richard L. Frey defeated their opponents by narrow margins yesterday afternoon to enter the finals of the contract bridge event for teams of four at the Hotel Roosevelt.

Frances Perkins, Secretary of Labor - designate in the Roosevelt Cabinet, turned the other cheek to William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, yesterday. Replying to his statement that organized labor would "never become reconciled" to her appoint- ment, Miss Perkins, in a final "mass interview" before leaving for Washington today, said that Mr. Green's statement did not exclude cooperation between the federation and the United States Labor Department.

Minor Watson, Harry Worth and Fred Miller have been engaged to complete the cast of "Strange Gods," Jessica Ball's drama of life in Florida, which will go into rehearsal on Monday under the direction of Priestly Morrison and is scheduled to open here during the middle of April.

WASHINGTON, March 2.--Homer S. Cummings of Stamford, Conn., was picked tonight by Presidentelect Roosevelt as Attorney General in place of Senator Walsh of Montana, whose sudden death made a quick selection for that important post imperative.

Leonard Jacob, retired builder, whose firm, Jacob Young, helped erect the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, and who was well known years ago as a hunt follower and gentleman steeplechase rider, died yesterday at his estate, Chale, in Bedminster, N.J.

CHARLESTON, S.C., March 2. -- Merrill D. King, president of the Rex Paper Company, of Kalamazoo, Mich., jumped or fell from an Eastern Air Transport plane just before noon today while it was 800 feet over Edisto River rice fields, about thirty miles from here.

ALBANY, March 2. -- A bill providing a complete new charter for the City of New York, based on recommendations contained in the report of the Hofstadter committee, Will be introduced tomorrow by Assemblyman Moffat, Republican, representing the Fifteenth Assembly District in Manhattan.

SHANGHAI, March 2. -- A Chinese official who has just arrived in Shanghai by airplane from Jehol said the slaughter of the Chinese armies already was very great and explained that though the Chinese forces had constructed scores of miles of trenches, they were equipped with only occasional small dug-outs and the armies were not supplied with anti-aircraft guns.
NEW YORK. Sir Charles Gordon of Montreal is at the Ritz-Carlton.

Further liquidation in the listed bond market yesterday carried many issues in all groups to new tows for the year. Total transactions on the Stock Exchange reached $15,243,500, compared with $12,914,200 on the previous day. Of yesterday's total, dealings in United States Government bonds accounted for $5,844,500, the heaviest for a single day since June 29, 1932.

WASHINGTON, Friday, March 3.--Leaders of the Hoover administration and the new Roosevelt regime conferred last night and into the early morning hours today on the country's troubled banking situation, but with no tangible result.

The sales figures on Sinclair Lewis's new novel, "Ann Vickers," the national best seller since its publication late in January, have reached 96,314. Mr. Lewis is returning here from abroad on Monday aboard the American Farmer.

PARIS, March 2. -- Faced with the prospect of another bad year, the major lines of the North Atlantic shipping conference, meeting here today, began to reconsider the general 5 per cent increase in passenger fares which they agreed upon last November.

A decline of 0.1 point carried the Annalist Weekly Index of Wholesale Commodity Prices down to 79.9 on Tuesday, from 80.0 (revised) on the Tuesday previous, and 91.0 on March 1, 1932, the loss from a year ago amounting to 11.1 points, or 12.2 per cent.

S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of New York, dealing in real estate mortgage bonds, and S.W. Straus Co. of Delaware, a holding company, consented yesterday to the appointment of a receiver to conserve their assets, and to the issuance of an injunction prohibiting them from doing business in this State.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- As soon as President-elect Roosevelt stepped off the train here tonight, it stopped raining. Up to that time, for an hour or more it had been sleeting and raining.

TOKYO, Friday, March 3. -- Three hundred and seventy-two persons were killed today when a vast tidal wave submerged 300 miles of north-eastern coast of the main Japanese island. Hundreds more were missing. The authorities feared the death toll might run into thousands.

HAVANA, March 2. -- Reports of increasing disorders in the interior of Cuba, centring in the three lower provinces of Camaguey, Santa Clara and Oriente, filter into Havana daily, despite the strict military censorship.

The International Harvester Company reports for 1932 a net loss of $7,582,879 after all charges and reserves. This contrasts with a net income of $1,346,537 in 1931, or $1.64 a share on the 823,325 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock outstanding of $100 par value.

BERLIN, March 2. -- Former Chancellor Heinrich Bruening, who is stumping extensively for the Centrists in the closing days of the campaign, warned the government in a speech in Essen today that if it intended to overthrow the Constitution "the Centre will be there."

Returns to date indicate that net operating income of all Class 1 railroads in January was about $13,275,000, against $11,713,000 in January, 1932, an increase of 13.3 per cent, and against $34,341,000 in January, 1931, a drop of 61.3 per cent. Last month was the second consecutive one in which an increase was shown, the gain in December for all roads being 19 per cent.
BALTIMORE, March 2 -- Election of the following members of the class of 1933 of Goucher College to Phi Beta Kappa was announced today:

BERLIN, March 2. -- In previous dispatches the writer has given a gloomy picture of the situation in the North Caucasus, the Lower Volga region and the Ukraine, with their manifold difficulties of sabotage and peasant apathy and the harsh measures adopted to overcome them.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 2. -- The undeclared war in the Chaco jungles between Bolivia and Paraguay seems to be entering its final phase, in the opinion of diplomats who have seen Bolivia's reply to peace overtures of the ABC-Peru group.

Although a three-day holiday in Louisiana led yesterday to suspension of trading on the New Orleans Cotton Exchange, prices on the Cotton Exchange here displayed steadiness and resistance to pressure, closing a point higher to 2 points lower than on Wednesday.

The selection of 250 scientists, three of them women, who are regarded by their colleagues as among the leading workers in their fields in the United States, is announced in the March issue of Science, official organ of the American Association for the Advancement of Science, published today.

The Chrysler Corporation yesterday omitted the regular quarterly dividend of 25 cents a share on its common stock. It issued also its report for 1932, which showed a net loss of $11,254,232 after all charges and reserves, in contrast with a net profit of $1,468,935 in 1931, or 33 cents a share on the 4,408,609 common shares outstanding then.

GENEVA, March 2. -- The disarmament conference's political commission adopted a declaration this afternoon outlawing the resort to force among Europeans, but only on condition that the commission later discuss the extension of this engagement to all the world.

Confidence in the banking institutions of New York and the opinion that financial difficulties, similar to those of Detroit and other localities, would be averted here if business is conducted in "the usual way," was expressed yesterday by James Brown, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York and senior partner in the banking house of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co.

ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., March 2. -- A short-wave radio station which is alleged to have guided the operations of South Jersey's largest rum ring, whose business is said to net $200,000 a month, was silenced by Department of Justice agents this afternoon.

Among the passengers on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg, due today from Hamburg and channel ports, is Thomas Stockton Baker, president of Carnegie Institute of Technology, Pittsburgh, who has been lecturing in Germany under the auspices of the Carl Schurz Society.

The proceeds of the railroad freight surcharge that took effect on Jan. 2, 1932, were $61,625,000 in the first year of their operation, according to the monthly report of the Railroad Credit Corporation. In granting the surcharges, the Interstate Commerce Commission estimated the yield at $100,000,000 to $125,000,000 annually.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Louis A. Stone, in a letter to THE TIMES complaining about the practice of law by title and trust companies, seems to forget that these companies practice law only in the sense that they practice engineering and architecture and land surveying, professions just as much restricted to individuals as is that of the law.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In a letter to THE TIMES the American representative of the Social-Democratic Press Service of Germany regards it as "imperative to bring to the attention of the American public the scandalous and unfair methods" by which the Hitler-Hugenberg-Papen government is conducting the present election, campaign in Germany.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Herbert Hoover and Franklin D. Roosevelt will meet tomorrow for their third pre-inaugural meeting in a conference scheduled as a social affair. In reliable quarters, however, it was stated that the two men had several "personal matters" to talk over, and that the conversation might extend further.

GENEVA, Match 2. -- Members of the League Council unanimously but informally approved tonight the terms of a declaration drawn up by its committee on Latin-American conflicts for a world-wide embargo on arms shipments to Bolivia and Paraguay.

PARIS, March 2. -- General Anglo-French contact on the war debts negotiations with the United States may be expected within a short time. It is even probable that Premier Edouard Daladier himself will go to London to coordinate the Franco-British point of view.

While wishing HENRY MORGENTHAU Jr. well in whatever career may be in store for him at Washington, devotees of the forests and streams of New York State will regret that it is to lose his competent services as Conservation Commissioner.

WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- To the scene of his many legislative triumphs, Senator Thomas J. Walsh returned in death tonight, mourned by a great throng which had awaited the arrival of his body at the station.

An atmosphere of uncertainty surrounded the financial markets yesterday as the banking situation became more confused. There was a sharp but orderly decline in bonds, led by United States Government issues, but stocks gave ground more grudgingly under a limited volume of selling that seemed to reflect little apprehension.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Representative La Guardia's contribution, to the farm and home mortgage problem is a proposal for the creation of a new government mortgage bank with a capital of $200,000,000. In addition to its capital the bank may issue bonds up to $10,000,000,000. The holders of a farm mortgage may offer to trade it for a bond of the some and farm credit bank.

All of the political blueprints which Mr. HOOVER prepared in advance for his Presidency were drawn to the grand scale of prosperity. That he expected it to continue and even to swell into a greater diapason of complacent pride can hardly be doubted.

After a week of form reversals, the Class B championship of the Metropolitan Squash Racquets Association came down, to the final round at the Harvard Club last night with an unranked player and the No. 5 man in the seeded list left in the running.

James Monroe High School's basketball team, runner-up for the city P.S.A.L. senior high school championship last year, strengthened Its hold on first place In the upper Manhattan-Bronx division of the current title race by defeating George Washington, 23 to 20, on the latter's court yesterday.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Walter P. Plummer, editorial director of The Knickerbocker Press and The Albany Evening News, died of angina pectoris at his home here early this morning. He would have been 50 years old on March 27. He was president of the New York State Association of Newspaper Editors and a member of the American Society of Newspaper Editors.

Sam Kaplan, deposed president and chief organizer of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators' Protective Union of Greater New York, was cross-examined yesterday by Richard H. Gibbs. Assistant District Attorney, in General Sessions, where he and eighteen other members of the union are being tried on a coercion indictment.

The progress toward a sound policy of social legislation in New York State has been retarded in the last year, children's agents affiliated with the State Charities Aid Association were told yesterday afternoon at their annual conference in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, March 2. -- The assumption in State Department circles is that among the Ambassadors and Ministers who will be appointed by President Roosevelt will be Judge Robert W. Bingham of Kentucky, James M. Cox of Ohio, Jesse Isidor Straus of New York, Claude G. Bowers of New York and Sumner Welles of Maryland.

TOKYO, Friday, March 3.--An alarmingly prolonged earthquake shook Tokyo and all Northeastern Japan this morning beginning at 2:32 o'clock. Thousands of homes were destroyed in towns on the northeast coast by a tidal wave that followed the quake and by fires.

Murray C. Harwood, one of six men on trial before Federal Judge Hincks on a charge of using the mails to defraud, in connection with the alleged bucketshop business of D.V. Bennett Co., testified yesterday that he collected $600 from the concern for former Deputy Attorney General David Wohl who was attached to the State Bureau of Securities prior to the administration of Attorney General John J. Bennett.

Sharp advances in rubber and silver characterized the price movements in yesterday's local commodity markets. Coffee and hides also closed, with moderate gains, while sugar, cocoa and silk lost ground. Except for rubber, cash prices were lower.

TOKYO, March 2. -- Viscount Kikujiro Ishii, former Ambassador to the United States, in view of the developments at Geneva will visit the United States in May to promote in an unofficial capacity a more favorable impression of Japan's policies.
WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- Shock and surprise were expressed at the capital today as word came of the death of Senator Walsh.

IT was an "off hour" at the Garden, where the sixday merry-go-round Is in progress. The crowd had been cleared out for a brief interval. The sweepers and gleaners were moving slowly between the tiers of seats. The riders were rolling placidly around the track.

An undercurrent of nervousness in Wall Street failed yesterday to disturb the poise ou the share market. Trading on the Stock Exchange was somewhat more active than on the day before, but prices moved within narrow limits. There was a lively rally in several stocks shortly before the close, with the result that part of the earlier decline was canceled. The average of fifty selected stocks showed a net loss of 56 cents.

To the Editor of The New York Times: What would happen to the citrus industry it the United States Government should exact a tax of 60 per cent of the retail price of oranges, lemons and grapefruit? What would happen to he automobile industry if it should be taxed 60 per cent of the retail selling price of its cars?
CHICAGO, March 2 (AP).-- Persons looking for a nice, safe place to settle down should try Pittsburgh or Evaneton, 111.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 2 -- Mr. and Mrs. J. Gordon Douglas Jr. entertained tonight with a dinner dance at the Colony Club. Their guests included:

GOETTINGEN, Germany, March 2. -- Dr. Fritz Micheel, a young professor of Goettingen University, has discovered the chemical structure of vitamin C which prevents scurvy. As a result of his experiments he hopes to be able to produce it synthetically.

Fly fishermen will be more than mildly interested in an experiment which Springfield, Mass., is about to institute. In that city there is an area called Breckwood Park, and within it is a pond which in days of old was a noted trout fishing spot.

If comedy were just a matter of lines, things would be considerably easier for all of us. As authors of "Our Wife," which was acted at the Booth last evening, Lillian Day and Lyon Mearson show that they, too, have a flair for amusing dialogue.

William H. Woodin, who is to be the new Secretary of the Treasury, resigned as president of the American Car and Foundry Company yesterday and severed his official connections with the other corporations with which he has been associated for many years, the company announced.

Reuben Nakian, sculptor who is now holding a one-man show of portrait heads at the Downtown Gallery, has not always evinced so unmistakable an interest in realism. First he studied with Paul Manship, then with Gaston Lachaise, after that launching forth upon his own.

Thomas J. Watson, president of the Merchants Association and chairman of the Trade and Industry Division of the Salvation Army's united appeal, announced yesterday that twenty business and civic leaders had accepted chairmanships of groups that will organize firms and corporations for the appeal.

Maritime interests supporting the plan for the establishment of a ground base for the New York State Merchant Marine Academy at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, acted quickly yesterday when told that the Bronx Chamber of Commerce would ask Mayor O'Brien to use his influence toward having the site assigned for park purposes.
WASHINGTON, March 2. -- Eight months of the government's 1933 fiscal year ended Feb. 28 with a deficit of $1,360,279,739 and a public debt of $20,934,729,209, Treasury figures showed today.

Auctioneers put up eleven Manhattan and Bronx properties at foreclosure sales yesterday. All the holdings were bought in by plaintiffs, and two listed sales were adjourned. Four of the parcels bid in were taken over by banks.

Eleven teams, all closely grouped for first place, remained of the fifteen, original pairs that started, as the six-day bicycle race entered its fifth twenty-four-hour session at Madison Square Garden last night.

Mr. and Mrs. John S. Rogers gave a dinner last night at the Embassy Club. Their guests were Colonel and Mrs. C. Carroll Carpenter, Mrs. Hoppin Pool, Miss Alice Van Rensselaer, Harold Webster and Dudley Dupignac.

OTTAWA, March 2 (AP). -- The Detroit Red Wings, making their last appearance here of the National Hockey League season, defeated the Ottawa Senators by 3 to 2 tonight in a game marked by a small riot in the first period. The victory gave the Red Wings a three-point lead over the idle New York Rangers in the close American Division race.

ALBANY, March 2. -- Governor Lehman signed today the bill to permit New York City to issue bonds of small denominations in anticipation of tax revenue. The permission was sought by the city administration to escape "the tyranny of the bankers."

ATLANTA, Ga., March 2 (AP). -- Increases in textile activity and in building and construction awards were reported for the Southeast today in the monthly review of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.
MIAMI, Fla., March 2 (AP). -- Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago tonight was described by his physicians as "still a very sick man," but they added that "some hope of recovery may be offered."

The new Furness Bermuda liner, Queen of Bermuda, reached quarantine last night about 7 o'clock and prepared to remain there the rest of the night, while arrangements for her berthing today at Pier 95, North River, were hurried by the shore staff of the company.

The pamphlet report of the New York Telephone Company for 1932 shows net income of $27,671,139 after all charges, taxes and depreciation, equal after preferred dividends to $7.01 a share earned on 3,713,000 common shares, against $35,323,950, or $9.08 a share, earned in 1931.

MIAMI, Fla., March 2. -- Walter W. Beck, 27 -- year-old right-hander whose name leads all the rest on the Dodger roster and whose pitching record of twenty-seven victories against six defeats with Memphis last season attracted wide attention, has won the unqualified approval of Manager Max Carey.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The death of Theresa Schiff, the widow of Jacob Schiff, reminds us once again of what we owe to these two noble philanthropists. I recall that Mr, Schiff in his evening prayer at dinner was in the habit of asking that be might use for the benefit of others who were not so fortunate as he the wealth which had been given to him.

Miguel de Capriles of the University Fencers Club, a member of the American Olympic team last year, annexed the national individual three-weapon championship last night at the New York Athletic Club when he triumphed in the final round over Nikolas Muray of the Fencers Club, also an Olympic contestant last Summer.

Confronted with an unprecedented rise of $732,000,000 in money in circulation and a loss of $226,310,000 of gold reserves in the last week, the Federal Reserve authorities raised the rediscount rate of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York from 2 1/4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent yesterday.

Among other last-minute proposals submitted to Congress before its adjournment is a bill giving the Federal courts power in certain circumstances to authorize postponement of interest on municipal indebtedness. This plan has been put forward at the request of Mayor MURPHY of Detroit.

CHICAGO, March 2. -- Uneasiness ever the banking situation dominated grain trading today on the Board of Trade and more than offset the most sensational reports ever issued of damage to the prospective Winter wheat crop. Private returns suggested a yield as small as 370,000,000 bushels and figured the condition to be the poorest on record.

John Wanamaker is to ship his Gold Cup motor boat Louisa to Italy and drive her in the international regatta at Gardone, on Lake Garda, beginning May 25. Announcement of his decision was made yesterday, following the sending of the entry of the Louisa by cable.
Commercial Paper. Yesterday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names. Wednesday -- 1 1/4 per cent for the best names.

EN ROUTE TO WASHINGTON, March 2 (AP). -- The body of Senator Walsh was prepared for burial in the suit which the Senator wore when he took Senora Perez Chaumont, the widow of a wealthy Cuban business man, as his bride in Havana.

Having concluded the local showing of its 1933 International Exhibition at Rockefeller Center, the College Art Association has promptly opened what may be called a miniature International at the Howard Young Galleries, 677 Fifth Avenue. The motivating idea is, however, quite unlike that of the larger exhibition.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Seventy-second Congress virtually closed its work tonight with the exception of two small appropriation bills -- the second deficiency and that for the District of Columbia.
PHILADELPHIA, March 3 -- B. Dawson Coleman, banker and coal operator, died in his apartment at the Barclay here today after an illness of several months. He was in his sixty-eighth year.

The Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, Tenth Street, West of Second Avenue, has been lent to the Rev. Bronislaw Krupski, a priest of the Polish National Church and pastor of St. John's Polish Church, Yonkers, N. Y., to hold a service tomorrow morning at 11 o'clock.

Israel Grossman, who, as Al Gross, drew considerable attention in Republican politics here In 1928, when he had himself photographed with Vice President Curtis and announced he would organize "Curtis for President Clubs," was arrested yesterday in the Federal Building on an indictment by the New York County grand jury accusing him of the theft of $3,000 in money, and checks from a woman.

How the initiative and energy of two editors persuaded the undecided Woodrow Wilson to enter polltics is described by John K. Winkler in his new biography, "Woodrow Wilson: the "Man Who Lives On," published today by Vanguard.

TARRYTOWN, N.Y., March 3 -- The body of 8 woman found dead of carbon monoxide poisoning in a private garage on South Washington Street here last night was identified tonight as that of Mary L. Heidinger, 22 years old, formerly of Philadelphia.

GRAND JUNCTION, Tenn., March 3 (AP) -- A new champion came to rule the nation's bird dog world today, a comparative youngster packing fifty pounds of bone and muscle, to say nothing of brain and as keen a nose as any that ever sniffed the air of historic Ames Plantation.

To the Editor of The New York Times: That Bainbridge Colby has forgotten nothing and learned nothing since he was Secretary of State fifteen years ago is obvious from his letter opposing recognition of Soviet Russia. The fifteen years which have followed his outlining of the Wilson policy have clearly shown that his theory of Russia being an "enemy country" is wrong.

GLEN COVE, L.I., March 3 -- Mrs. Ruth Baker Pratt, Representative from New York, who will be free of political cares after tomorrow, will take advantage of that freedom to travel abroad, it became known here today through friends.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt assured the American people last night in her last radio broadcast before taking up residence in the White House that "your interests are my interests and I hope that in many ways we see eye to eye as to many of the questions that come up in our daily lives."

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Despite the depression, Franklin D. Roosevelt's inauguration is a "sellout" and a financial success. The anticipated profit of from $60,000 to $75,000 from the sale of tickets for grand stand seats, tonight's concert and tomorrow's inaugural ball will be turned over to charity.
WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- President Hoover today signed the bankruptcy bill, Intended to provide relief for individuals, farmers and railroads suffering from debt.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The appointment of Arthur D. Rooney Jr. of 459 Seventh Street, Brooklyn, as Special Deputy Superintendent of Banks hag been revoked, the weekly bulletin of the State Banking Department announced today, in connection with the liquidation of the Amherst Bank at Williamsville, the State Bank at Ransomville and the Wilson State Bank at Wilson.

SHANGHAI, Saturday, March 4 -- The puzzling situation at Chihfeng was clarified when the Japanese press revealed that the rumored treachery there did not involve Sun Tien-ying but a subordinate, Brig. Gen. Shih Wen-ha, to whom had been entrusted the defense of the mouth of the pass.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 3 -- Rutgers defeated Navy in an Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet tonight, 40-31. Although the Scarlet took five firsts in the seven individual events, the result was not determined until the 400-yard relay, when Walter Spence led Captain Ray Thompson by two yards in the final lap.

By a cleverly arranged combination and dicker carried out by a caucus of House Democrats, Mr. RAINEY was nominated for Speaker. Mr. BYRNS of Tennessee, in consideration of waiving his candidacy for that office, was selected to succeed Mr. RAINEY as floor leader.

WESTWOOD, N.J., March 3 -- Eleven of the fifteen members of the Paskack Chapter of the Daughters of the American Revolution including Mrs. Lillian M. Layman of Hackensack, who was appointed regent of the chapter three months ago, have resigned because of a controversy over the administration of the chapter, it became known here today.

LONDON, March 3 -- The Stock Exchange was dull today, with business on a very small scale, the market being depressed by the American situation. The rise in the New York bank rate had comparatively little effect here. A further sharp recovery in Japanese bonds indicated growing hope of possible early termination of hostilities in the Far East.

An aggressive Hunter College basketball team repulsed the New York University girls, 20 to 14, at the N.Y.U. School of Education gym yesterday. It was the winner's second triumph over the Violet this season and N.Y.U.'s final home game.

The annual report of the Public Service Corporation of New Jersey shows a consolidated net income in 1932 of $28,289,378, equal after preferred dividends to $3.35 a share earned on 5,503,193 no-par common shares, against $30,540,752, or $3.85 a share, in 1931.

The Macbeth Gallery, expanding in the midst of the financial depression, opened a new annex at 19 East Fifty-seventh Street with a reception last evening. This addition was made possible through the cooperation of a friend of the gallery and of American art, who modestly asks that his name be withheld.
The question perplexing the Greenwich Village Mutual Exchange is not "Which came first, the chicken or the egg?" but "Which came first, the chickens or the wheat?"

Students of Barnard College organized a miniature world economic conference yesterday and undertook the double task of first finding out for themselves "what's wrong with the world" by putting themselves in the position of representatives of the nations and then drawing up a plan for economic improvement.

GENEVA, March 3 -- The British announcement that Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon would return here soon to aid the disarmament conference to reach early decisions aroused much interest and speculation, especially regarding' the date when Norman H. Davis, United States delegate, will return.

The need for discrimination on the part of the Reconstruction Finance Corporation in order that it may supply fluids only for "economically sound" housing projects in New York was stressed by a special committee of the Real Estate Board of New York in a conference in Washington this week with officials of the Federal agency.
COLUMBUS, March 3 (AP) -- Issuance of State scrip probably will be

ROOSEVELT FIELD, L.I., March 3 -- A new Department of Commerce regulation requiring private pilots to have completed fifty hours' solo flying before taking passengers for flights was received here today. The regulation, dated March 1, was signed by Clarence M. Young, Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Aeronautics.

BERLIN, March 3 (AP) -- Dr. Heinrich Bruening, former Chancellor and a leader of the Catholic Centre Party, appealed to President von Hindenburg in a speech here tonight to intervene, "as father of the Fatherland, to protect the suppressed from their oppressors.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 3 -- Smith College will observe inauguration day tomorrow with many dances to be given by the college houses over the week-end. Many guests from Eastern colleges are arriving in Northampton for the festivities.
"Strike Me Pink," the Brown and Henderson revue, with Jimmie Durante, Hope Williams and Lupe Velez, opens tonight at the Majestic Theatre.

Representatives of the maritime interests of the port joined yesterday with the spokesmen of the Hungarian Government in greeting the freighter Puszta, the first Hungarian ship to enter the Port of New York since the World War, at a luncheon at the Hotel Sherry Netherland, at which the Hungarian American Chamber of Commerce was host.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Continuing his policy of refusing to accept responsibility without authority, Franklin D. Roosevelt on his last day before taking office as President resisted all attempts by members of the Hoover Administration to persuade him to join in some immediate statement or action designed to remedy the banking situation.

LONDON, March 3. -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, will go to Geneva soon to make a last desperate effort to save the disarmament conference from collapse. This action was decided upon today by the disarmament committee of the British Cabinet and it was its reaction to alarming reports of present conditions at Geneva, brought to London by Captain Anthony Eden, Under-Secretary for Foreign Affairs.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- The Senate said good-bye today to Vice President Charles Curtis. Although he will again preside, for the last time, tomorrow morning. The members presented him this afternoon with a large silver tray containing facsimiles of the signature of each member.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Impeachment charges against Federal judge Harold Louderback of California will be taken up the first day of the coming extra session, the Senate decided today when it temporarily resolved itself into a courtof justice.

Renewed hope for delinquent alimony payers serving prison sentences for contempt of court was extended yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Paul Bonyage in Brooklyn when he handed down his third decision in two days attacking the present alimony system and releasing incarcerated victims.
To the Editor of The New York Times: May I answer Dr. S.S. Goldwater's letter in reference to the Crawford bill?

Plans have been made by the broadcasters which are expected to enable many countries of the world to join with America today by short-wave radio for the inauguration of Franklin D. Roosevelt as President.

The "courageous stand" taken by foreign press correspondents in Germany in "exposing the vicious methods of the rulers of Germany" was praised yesterday by Dr. S. Lipschitz, American representative of the Social Democratic Press Service of Germany, who said the correspondents were to be commended for resisting the attempt "to make them tools in the Nazls's game of misleading the world."

Money rates were marked up again, following the advance in the rediscount rate late on Thursday. Stock Exchange standing loans went at 3 1/2 per cent, an advance of 1 per cent over the previous closing and highest for renewals since Jan. 5, 1932.

Americans are a people of invincible hope. Often they have given quadrennial proof of this. But seldom can their eagerness to see a new President inaugurated have equaled that of this year. It is a delayed realization of what they have been carrying in their hearts since last November.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 3 -- Under the patronage of a large group of colonists and the Palm Beach Parent-Teachers Association, Miss Katharine Homer, pianist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Homer, and Miss Sylvia Lent, violinist, gave a concert this afternoon at the Everglades Club.

CINCINNATI, March 3 -- The Rev. Dr. Henry. Coe Culbertson, at one time president of the College of Emporia, in Kansas, died at his home at Lorain, Ohio, today after a lingering illness. He was 59 years old. He leaves a wife and two sons.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The biennial "farewell" to retiring members of the House of Representatives was staged before crowded galleries this afternoon. At times it seemed to the spectators that the Democrats were so sorry over the retirement of their Republican colleagues they regretted winning the November election.

The United States Rubber Company reported yesterday a net loss, after depreciation but before inventory adjustments and other charges, of $9,617,646 for 1932. The deficit after these special charges was $10,358,373, against $13,074,362 in 1931.

Considerable excitement prevailed in Broadway between Forty-ninth and Fiftieth Streets just before 8 o'clock last night when a small fire coincided with the false report of a theatre hold-up which had been telephoned to Police Headquarters' detectives and the West Forty-seventh Street station at the same time.
TORONTO, March 3 -- Dr. Arthur Guy Ashton Fletcher, well-known physician here, died last night after a long illness in his sixty-fourth year.

Because of the widespread breakdown of standards the 115 candy manufacturers on the White List of the National Consumers League have been compelled "through the ruthless force of competition" to reduce wages below the $14-a-week minimum standard and therefore the White List will be discontinued it was announced by the league at its headquarters, 156 Fifth Avenue, yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: It happened that I was in Germany on several occasions from the early part of 1921 till the Fall of 1925, when that country was testing the method of issuing paper currency in ever-increasing amounts as a way out of her fiscal and financial troubles.

Evidences of strength in other markets spread yesterday to the local commodity markets. All staples closed higher, with notable advances in cocoa, sugar and hides. Cash prices, reflecting the general tone of the day, also moved higher.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The War Department today selected 113 army officers of highest efficiency rating to attend the two-year course of the Command and General Staff School at Fort Leavenworth, beginning next September. They were chosen from among those with a rating of 90 to 100 per cent in efficency and standing.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday. .3 per cent for the best names. Thursday. .3 per cent for the best names.

So far as Great South Bay is concerned tomorrow will mark the official opening of the flounder season, according to Captain Ray Snyder of Lindenhurst. The flounders have been running pretty well for a week, he says, and some big catches have been made.
BASLE, Switzerland, March 3 (AP) -- The German Reichsbank will repay $16,000,000 of a credit amounting to 536,000,000 due tomorrow, the Bank for International Settlements announced this afternoon.

More than $700,000 is left in specific bequests under the will of Anthony O'Boyle, who was the head of one of the largest lighterage businesses on the Atlantic coast. The will, filed in Brooklyn yesterday, disposes of $20,000 to two Roman Catholic institutions, and bequeaths the rest to members of the family.

The Bronx Hockey Club won the championship of the New York Amateur League and with it the right to play in the A.A.U. championship by routing the St. Nicks, 7 to 1, at the New York Coliseum last night before 3,000 persons.

LONDON, March 3 -- The Laborite Dally Herald, which has been publishing sensational stories of anti-Semitic plots by the Nazis, announced tonight that its Berlin corespondent, Victor Schiff, had been arrested on a charge of "plotting against the government" but that he had later been released.

HOLLYWOOD, March 3 (AP) -- Some well-paid movie stars found themselves little better off today than extras in the temporary, inconvenience of the State's hanking holiday, a check-up at the studios revealed.

Coordination of the official machinery of the State to meet the public welfare problems now confronting it was advocated yesterday by David C. Adie, Commissioner of the State Department of Social Welfare, at the twenty-third annual conference of the children's agents affiliated with the State Charities Aid Association, held in the Hotel McAlpin.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The Governors of twenty-seven States and representatives of six other Governors were received tonight by Mrs. Woodrow Wilson, Admiral and Mrs. Gary T. Grayson and Raymond T. Baker in the name of the inaugural committee at a picturesque reception at the Pan American Union.

To the Editor of The New York Times : In an editorial published Feb. 25 you refer to unanimous disapproval by the Assembly of the League of Nations of the action of the Japanese as a tangible "fact" and again as a "reality," and indicate your belief that the Japanese have underestimated the importance of this expression of opinion.

The two major events of the annual Eastern contract bridge championship, which has been going on all week at the Hotel Roosevelt, came to a close early this morning with Mrs, Grace E. Perpall and F. E. Bailey of the Cavendish Club winners of the pair championship and David Burnstine, Richard Frey, Howard Schenken and Charles Lochridge victors in the team-of-four competition.

CHICAGO, Saturday, March 4 -- Illinois banks this morning will begin a three-day moratorium on withdrawals, according to an announcement made at 2 o'clock this morning at the Chicago Clearing House, where members of the Clearing House Committee and representatives of the Chicago Federal Reserve Bank were meeting with Governor Henry Horner.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The inaugural program for tomorrow will be as follows:

The Treasury's Department's full monthly report of the stock of all kinds of money in the United States as of Feb. 1 shows the following principal changes during January. Gold earmarked for foreign banks is deducted, gold released from earmark is added:

Following an all-night conference with officials of The New York Clearing House and the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, Governor Lehman early this morning issued a statement from his home announcing a two-day legal holiday which will effect all banks in this State today and Monday.

Five miles above the mouth of the Connecticut River, where the down-current and the full-tide rush meet and open wide the stream's banks, there is to be a gathering of dinghy sailors today. It is at the little town of Essex, Conn.

Immigration men on Ellis Island said yesterday they did not view the prospect of a regulation requiring the fingerprints of allalien residents "with trepidation," as they expected the order to be rescinded as soon as Miss Frances Perkins, the new Secretary of Labor, took charge of the department.

BERLIN, March 3 -- Yesterday's upward movement on the Boerse continued today with increased momentum, with the result that all the active stocks netted more or less substantial gains. While the average rise was around 2 points, some issues went considerably higher, Including Rheinische Braunkohle.

SHANGHAI, March 3 -- A demand for the withdrawal of all the Chinese troops from Tientsin has been made by Japan and has been rejected by China in a sharp reply, the Foreign Office at Nanking revealed today.

NASHVILLE, Tenn., March 3 (AP) -- Lit J. Pardue of Ashland City, Tenn., tonight was appointed by Federal District Judge John J. Gore as a receiver for the Tennessee Publishing Company, publishers of The Nashville Tennessean and Evening Tennessean.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Max Carey may be a bit troubled about the condition of at least two of his infielders, but he is completely satisfied with the condition of the infield on which his Dodgers staged their fifth day of practice today.

Reggie McNamara was forced out of the fifty-fourth international six-day bicycle race at Madison Square Garden early this morning. He suffered a heavy fall while speeding around the Ninth Avenue curve and was knocked unconscious.

Under the rising pressure of banking moratoria, currency hoarding and foreign and domestic gold withdrawals, the money and exchange markets yesterday registered further sharp readjustments. Credit continued to tighten, the dollar cheapened in terms of foreign currencies and a record total of $116,439,600 of gold was withdrawn from the Federal Reserve Bank for foreign account.

Studies of Europe's vanishing ghettos make up an exhibition of oils, water-colors, drawings and etchings, the work of Lionel Reiss, which was formally opened yesterday in the south studio of the Students Activity Building of New York University at Washington Square.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Senator Cordell Hull's exaltation of the sanctity of treaties and international good faith marks him as a diplomat. Whatever a nation's practice, a lofty idealism must characterize its professions. A Secretary of State who must square our present policy in Asia with our past policy in America and its adjacent waters needs to be an acrobat as well as a diplomat.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Franklin Delano Roosevelt will be inaugurated tomorrow as the thirty-second President of the United States, the goal of efforts on his part as tremendous as those which he exerted to restore himself to health when he was stricken in the prime of his manhood.

While there were further reminders yesterday of the banking tension, speculative markets presented a cheerful front. In stocks there were advances of 1 to 4 points, with average net gains of about 1 1/2 points; wheat rose as much as 2 cents a bushel and cotton more than a dollar a bale.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- An extraordinary session of the new Congress to deal with the banking situation throughout the country is to be called by Mr. Roosevelt almost immediately upon his assumption of the Presidency.

While laboratory research carried on in all parts of the world has failed to find the cause of cancer, practical research among patients in the cancer clinics "is making rapid, substantial and effective progress," Dr. James Ewing, director of cancer research at Memorial Hospital and a leading authority on the disease, declared last night at the annual members' meeting of the American Society for the Control of Cancer, at the New York Academy of Medicine.

ALBANY, March 3 -- The appointment of District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin of the Bronx to the Supreme Court was announced today at the office of Governor Lehman. James C. Madigan, brother-in-law of Mayor O'Brien, was appointed as a justice of the City Court.

NEWARK, N.J., March 3 -- Large tax payments today made it possible for the city to meet its March payroll, unpaid so far because of lack of ready cash. Shortly before noon checks were issued for the $710,000 school salaries and the $400,000 municipal roll.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla. March 3 -- Sheer fighting spirit carried Miss Kathleen Garnham of England to victory over her countrywoman, Miss Barbara Pyman, in the semifinals of the Florida East Coast championship on St. Augustine links today.

New York's population was temporarily depleted by nearly 50,000 persons yesterday as enthusiastic Democrats boarded trains, automobiles, buses and airplanes in a migration to Washington to see a home State boy become President.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Following the announcement of his selection by President Roosevelt last night as chief administrator in the "new deal" for the farmer, Henry Morgenthau Jr. today forecast the end of the Federal Farm Board and its replacement by the "Farm Credit Administration," which he christened'the new farm relief set-up "for want of a better name."

A petition in bankruptcy against S.W. Straus Co., Inc., of 565 Fifth Avenue, one of the largest dealers in real estate mortgage bonds in the country, was filed yesterday in the Federal Court by three creditors whose claims aggregate $577.

DETROIT, March 3 -- Senator Couzens, departing today for the inauguration of Franklin D. Roosevelt at Washington, reviewed developments in the Michigan banking situation. He told of the manner in which Henry and Edsel Ford were brought to make their offer to organize new banks, and stressed the divided counsel that marked the struggle of the Detroit bankers with the problem.

NEW ORLEANS, March 3 (AP) -- E.R. Bradley'a 3-year-old Beef-steak, winner of his first start by eight lengths, scored another easy victory today, galloping home with three lengths to spare In the mile feature at the Fair Grounds. Ridden by Gilbert Elston. theg

Prices on the Cotton Exchange advanced more than a quarter cent a pound yesterday under the heaviest trading in several weeks. May rose above 6 1/4 cents to around the high level reached last month. In sympathy with stocks and grains, the market strengthened and closed around the top at gains of 20 to 23 points.

WASHINGTON, March 3. -- This was Herbert Hoover's last day in the White House, and he spent it fulfilling a thousand and one miscellaneous duties, official and social, which left him in the evening a tired and evidently much affected man.
Columbia closed its home swimming campaign last night by defeating New York University, 46 -- 25, in the Morningside Heights pool. The Lions won five of the eight events.

The publication of the statement yesterday morning that grand opera at the Metropolitan next season had been assured by the Juilliard Musical Foundation produced a series of statements from the Metropolitan, declaring that the public must not get the impression that there is no further need to contribute to the $300,000 guaranty fund which was launched a month ago by a committee to save Metropolitan opera.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, March 4 -- Advisers of the incoming administration expressed confidence early this morning that the plan now being evolved by President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt and his counselors, to relieve the banking deadlock which has been spreading in the United States, would be adequate to meet the situation and restore confidence.

BROOKLINE, Mass., March 3 -- The Country Club of Brookline first curling team and the Utica Country Club first team gained the third round of play as the twenty-second annual Stockton Cup Bonspiel opened at the Country Club Rink today.

The performance of Wagner's "Tristan and Isolde," given as part of the Wagner matinee cycle yesterday afternoon in the Metropolitan Opera House, was impressive testimony to the popularity of Wagner as he has been interpreted this season on New York's famous lyric stage.

Restoration of the German monarchy "might prove the medium through which the German people will achieve unity and order, which are needed in Germany more than anything else," James W. Gerard, American Ambassador to Germany from 1913 to 1918, declares in an article in the Freeson Magazine, a publication of the Free Sons of Israel.

A group of savings banks and insurance company officials is pressing the railroads to carry out there commendations as to consolidation and other means for reducing competitive costs made in the recent report of the National Transportation Committee.

Dr. Thomas S. Baker, president of the Carnegie Institute of Technology, Pittsburgh, returned yesterday on the Hamburg-American liner Hamburg convinced that "almost a reign of terror exists in Germany"; that Hitler has displayed few if any of the qualities of statesmanship and that if the present "repressive measures" continue, it will be surprising if a formidable resistance does not arise among the German people.
Several flats and a variety of one-family dwellings were Included in the New Jersey realty turnover reported yesterday.

As demand for municipal bonds was only about nominal in the last two days, municipal dealers are expected to welcome the small schedule of new issues up for award next week. Although thirty communities will seek bids on new issues of bonds and notes, the total will be only $4,555,732, against this week's revised total of $10,163,597 and a weekly average so far this year of $13,107,875.

WASHINGTON, March 3 (AP) -- Beneath the broad beams of the legislative hall in which he served with outstanding distinction for twenty years, the late Senator Thomas J. Walsh will lie in state Monday, mourned officially by his colleagues and friends in all walks of life.

Donizetti s "Lucia" was repeated at the Metropolitan last evening before a crowded house, that applauded many melodies in the earlier scenes of Scott's story, and grave the usual ovations for the mad scene and sextet. Lilly Pons sang the title role, Lauri-Volpi the lover and Bonelli the brother's role, to which the American baritone also gave artistic distinction.

LOS ANGELES, March 3 -- Although his squad is nursing more aches and pains than it cares to admit, Manager Bill Terry today put on the finishing touches to the hurry-up job he has had to perform to make his Giants presentable for the opening exhibition game of the season against the Cubs on Catalina Island tomorrow.

VIENNA, March 3 -- The German situation Is having more important repercussions in Austria. Victorious Hitlerism in Germany probably would mean the end of the Austro-German "anschluss" movement, but more immediately it has already produced the prospect of a coalition between the Christian Social and Socialist parties to ward off the threatened Nazi danger.

For Thursday's unfavorable statement of the Federal Reserve System, and for the advancing of the New York Reserve Bank's official rediscount rate from 2 1/2 per cent to 3 1/2, the course of the open money market and the movement of bank reserves were equally responsible.

Morris Silverstein's field goal in the last ten seconds of play enabled Thomas Jefferson High School's basketball team to defeat Alexander Hamilton High, 30 to 28, on the Jefferson court yesterday and to strengthen its lead in the Brooklyn division of the city P.S.A.L. championship tourney.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 3 -- The mystery surrounding the whereabouts of his two long-overdue pitchers lifted today for Joe McCarthy, the Yankee pilot. Vernon (Lefty) Gomez presented himself unannounced and, so far as is known, with no explanation.

There can be no doubt that the trustees of the Juilliard Foundation in offering to help the Metropolitan Opera avert closure are acting in accordance with the terms of Mr. JUILLIARD'S will. In making his princely and generous bequest, one of his purposes was stated explicitly as being to assist the Metropolitan Company in the production of operas.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The tribute of a State funeral will be paid on Monday to Senator Walsh of Montana, who died suddenly yesterday morning just two days before he was to have become Attorney General of the United States.

Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt has invited Mrs. Edwin Hughes, head of the music department of Todhunter School, of which Mrs. Roosevelt has long been an executive, to be her guest with Mr. Hughes in Washington today to view the inaugural parade.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's last "unofficial day, preceding her husband's Inauguration, began early this morning with a drive across the Rock Creek Bridge to call on a relative and to see again the Adams memorial monument, which she regards as the most beautiful in Washington, and ended with the delivery tonight of her last radio talk of a series begun in New York several weeks ago.

PARIS, March 3 -- Expressing the "earnest hope" that France would pay the deferred debt instalment, Ambassador Edge of the United States in a farewell interview with French newspaper men today said a number of things he had originally planned to say at the Washington's Birthday dinner here.

THIS has been a great season on the indoor tracks and the college gathering at the 258th Field Artillery Armory in the Bronx tonight undoubtedly will add another thrilling instalment. A few events are as good as settled now unless George Spitz of N.Y.U. breaks both legs on the way to the armory or Joe McCluskey is forced to run with a wardrobe trunk on his back.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 (AP) -- Mayor Anton Cermak, ill with complications following the wound from the gun of Joseph Zangara, had a sudden heart attack this afternoon, but quickly recovered and continues to improve, physicians announced tonight.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., March 3 -- An estate with a gross value of more than $500,000 was left by Georgia S. Peabody of New York, well-known Summer resident of Bolton Road, Lake George, who died on Nov. 21, 1931, a transfer tax appraisal filled today in Warren County Surrogate's Court shows.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Secretary Stimson said farewell today to the newspaper correspondents who have been stationed at the State Department the past four years with an expression of "real friendship" toward them.

The new Furness liner, Queen of Bermuda, steamed up the harbor yesterday morning abreast of her sister ship the Monarch of Bermuda, which acted as escort, to the company's pier at the foot of West Fifty-fifth Street.

Provisions regarding the treatment of railroad labor in the amendment to the bankruptcy law signed by President Hoover yesterday will create some unexpected problems, it was said in management circles of the carriers.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 3 -- Gratification is expressed by the newspapers here that the ABC-Peru group has found the Bolivi reply to Its peace proposals satisfactory. The press urges care to maintain the spirit of good-fellow-ship that has been demonstrated and warns against undue haste in negotiations that might lead to another failure.

ALBANY, March 3 -- A hitch in the plans for bipartisan agreement on a bill to create machinery for a State convention to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, appeared today as Speaker McGinnies announced his opposition to the proposed legislation.
LONDON, March 3 -- The disposition of the British fleet in Chinese waters, comprising twenty-one seagoing vessels, apart from submarines and gunboats, was officially revealed tonight.

Silas Williams, national commander of the American Veterans Association, announced yesterday a determined attack by his organization on "undeserved pensions, disability awards not connected with service and prepayment of the bonus.

Assemblyman MOFFAT, hard-working minority member from Manhattan and author of the majority report of the Hofstadter committee of city inquiry, has submitted for the consideration of his colleagues and others interested a new city charter for New York.
THE PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW York, by the grace of God, free and independent.

"The Enchanted Isle," a pageant of the south seas, was the feature event of the fifty-second annual "skelter" and ball of the Kit Kat Art Club at the Hotel Plaza last night. The proceeds will go to needy artists.

Stepping into his old post of Acting Mayor yesterday in the absence of Mayor O'Brien, Aldermanic President McKee blocked the attempt of Controller Berry to fix interest rates on new city revenue bills, and wound up a Board of Estimate calendar of 173 items in just twenty-eight minutes.

Tammany Likes Parades. Tammany Hall will be decidedly among those present in the Washington proceedings today. The Wigwam will march in the inaugural parade by Assembly districts and by battalions, with its sachems and its wiskinkies, its Phrygian liberty caps and its standards and its brass bands, thousands upon thousands strong, representing the cargo of dozens of special trains and the expenditure of heap big wampum.

Asserting that control of the production of crude oil is a basic step from which the correction of many uneconomic conditions in other branches of the oil industry may be expected to follow, The Lamp, published by the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, states that efforts to balance supply and demand should be extended to the refining end.
Thirteen Manhattan and Bronx properties went to plaintiffs, who bid them in at foreclosure sales yesterday. The results follow:

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 3 -- A fast Brown varsity basketball team inflicted a crushing 47-to-14 defeat on Harvard in the feature of a triple-header at the Harvard indoor athletic building tonight. It was the most decisive setback suffered by the Crimson in four years of play on the new Harvard court.

Nearly 2,500 unemployed teachers will receive jobs in the city's public school system if the Legislature enacts a bill drawn by the Board of Education and the Board of Superintendents and approved yesterday by virtually every teacher organization in the city.

DENVER, March 3 (AP) -- Ever widening in its scope, the search for the abductors of Charles Boettcher 2d spread tonight into North and South Dakota, where authorities, at the request of Denver police, sought a ranch house with "four steps leading to the front porch."

CHICAGO, March 3 -- A wave of buying jumped prices sharply in the wheat market today. Top figures were 2 1/2 to 2 3/4 cents above Thursday's finish and the highest since the middle of January. While general news gave no basis for the buying, sentiment was markedly changed in some quarters, and the belief was strong that liquidation of the Federal Farm Board holdings had been completed.

Making amends for his unexpected defeat In the national Class B championship at the hands of Edward Kemble of the Bayside Tennis Club, William E. Coyle Jr. of the Montclair A.C. furnished the finest grade of squash tennis seen in the national Class A tournament last night as a full round of competition was run off at the Harvard Club.
PROGRAM FOR TODAY. 10:00 A.M.-- Annual Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. convention at Columbia University Club, 4 West Forty-third street. Closed meeting.
BLOOMINGTON, Ind., March 3 -- A story of Senator Walsh, who but for his death day before yesterday would have become Attorney General of the United States:

Willem Van Hoogstraten, conductor of the Portland (Ore.) Symphony Orchestra, will sail today for Havre on the French liner Paris. Also on board will be Mme. Sigrid Onegin, Swedish operatic contralto; Dr. Fritz Penzoldt, her husband; Armand Tokatyan, tenor of the Metropolitan Opera House; James and Lucille Gleason, film stars; Guthrie McClintic and Commandant and Mrs. Henry Laraque.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Improvement was lacking in the general business situation abroad, according to reports to the Department of Commerce in the past week from its representatives. In South America January's up-swing in Brazilian trade was retarded in February by the exchange situation, Chile's trade volume showed a further decline and general business in Colombia fell to new low levels.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- While President-elect Roosevelt and Mrs. Roosevelt did not attend, all other members of their family were present tonight at the inaugural concert in Constitution Hall, where 4,000 persons packed the auditorium to capacity with applauding throngs waiting outside unable to obtain seats.

Correctly or not, yesterday's brisk rally on the Stock Exchange was attributed to anxiety among speculators for the decline. These traders, so the reasoning went, were afraid that any untoward development might drive them into an embarrassing position.

NEW YORK. The last of the season's Afternoon Dinner Dances, a subscription series for young married couples and former debutantes, will take place tonight in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. Several dinners will precede it.

Continued rental activity in the midtown garment-manufacturing area was reported yesterday. The Rosenberg-Murray Company, Inc., announced that a seventeen-story building at 347 West Thirty-sixth Street was about 95 per cent rented, though It had been about half vacant when the company assumed management last November.

BERLIN, March 3 -- Foreign Minister von Neurath's statement in today's issue of a political magazine that Germany "may soon be forced to indicate even more emphatically her claim for equal security" was interpreted here as a warning addressed to the Disarmament Conference, the course of which is watched with growing anxiety.
WASHINGTON, March 3 -- "Dignity, but great simplicity," will be the keynote of the social program of the next administration, according to Mrs. Roosevelt, wife of the President-elect.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria, March 3 (AP). -- Pressing westward in a blizzard after having captured Pingchuan, Major Gen. Tadashi Kawahara sent word back from the front today that within a few hours his Sixteenth Japanese Infantry Brigade would bring about the fall of Chengteh (Jehol City), capital of the province now almost completely overrun by the army of Japan.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- The cost of government ninety-three-day paper jumped to an equivalent of 4.26 per cent on the issue of 575,266,000 to be put-on the market March 6, Secretary Mills announced today.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- That sense of anticipatory tension which falls upon a city forewarned that it is to witness the turning of a page of history gripped crowded Washington tonight. Reminders that the morrow was to bring an end to twelve years of Republican rule were everywhere.

WASHINGTON, March 3 -- Approval by the Interstate Commerce Commission of a further loan of $7,000,000 from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to meet a May 1 maturity of the Boston Albany Railroad was asked by the New York Central Railroad today.

The New York Stock Exchange has received a letter from David Burnet, Commissioner of Internal Revenue, listing foreign bonds which are not subject to the Federal transfer tax. The following issues are exempt:

TOKYO, March 3 -- This morning's earthquake, which struck Tokyo lightly, took its heaviest toll of life and property in the fishing villages along a sixty-mile stretch of the northeast coast. Reports from this district repeat with pathetic monotony the story of a terror-stricken people fleeing only partly clothed in the darkness from their tottering cabins.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- Charley O., by Hourless from Clonakilty, a full brother to Mike Hall, won the featured Sunny Isle Purse at Hialeah Park today and encouraged those who fancy his chances in the $10,000 Florida Derby. The favorite at 9 to 10, Charley O. drove on gamely through the stretch and was just up to win by a nose at the end of the mile.

PARIS, March 3 -- Passenger fares on all lines operating between North America and Europe will remain unchanged until October, it was agreed at the regular Spring meeting of the North Atlantic Conference, which closed here today.

James Brown, president of the Chamber of Commerce of the State of New York, commented yesterday on the present situation of the New York Public library, with its cut appropriations and gains in circulation. He offers as "potent reasons why libraries should not be singled out now for severe economy" that "they have been operated without extravagance and with an intelligent regard to the public interest and the taxpayers' burden.
