The ideas of the various elections inspectors as to the total that the voting machines should have registered, instead of the totals actually recorded, appeared to govern some of the returns made to the Board of Elections on last election night, on the basis of the figures compiled yesterday in the recanvass being conducted by the board.

MIAMI, Fla., March 3 -- The six-inch putting cup, sponsored by Gene Sarazen, United States and British open golf champion, received its first test in major competition today in the opening round of the seventy-two-hole $5,000 open tournament over the Miami Biltmore course at Coral Gables.

The After-Dinner Dances were concluded for this season last night in the main ballroom of the Ritz-Carlton. The entertainments are arranged annually for younger married couples and debutantes of former years.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The banking stringency was brought home in a material way today to a large part of the multitude gathered here for the inauguration when hotels refused to honor out-of-town checks and telegraph money orders were limited to $100.

BOSTON, March 4 -- Breaking a 1-1 deadlock, with a pair of goals midway in the second period, Harvard's hockey team carried on to a 4-to-1 victory over Yale before 7,500 Spectators tonight in the Boston Garden.

One Corner Turned. One reason why President ROOSEVELT may be expected to act with swiftness and decision is that he has six weeks less time to make a record in than his predecessors. His term of office expires in January, 1937, instead of on March 4 of that year.

HAVANA, March 4 (AP) -- The Cuba and Chile Stables' consistent 5-year-old gelding, Monkey Shine, today led all the way to annex the fifth race at Oriental Park, a sixfurlong sprint for 4-year-olds and up, by two lengths. The time was 1:12 4-5.

ISTANBUL, March 2 -- Feb. 24 was celabrated throughout Turkey as the first anniversary of the foundation of what are known as the People's Houses. Every branch had its own festivities and the Premier broadcast a message to them all.

A description of the fashion centre of the World's Fair to be held in Chicago next Summer; the fashion "clinic" that will attempt to show how American women should dress in every detail, and the commercial possibilities of the centre were given here yesterday by Mrs. Ford Rodman Carter, Chicago social leader, who was recently appointed fashion director of the fair.

BUFFALO, March 2 -- A unique feature of the life of Buffalo is the annual bestowal of a medal on the citizen who is adjudged by the council of the University of Buffalo to have rendered exceptionally distinguished service in the community. This reward of honor was established by the will of the late Charles P. Norton, chancellor of the university and leader in the movement which produced its modern expansion.
PHILADELPHIA, March 4. -- Princeton's varsity swimming team won its seventh straight meet by defeating Pennsylvania in the Hutchinson pool today, 54 to 17. The Tigers carried off every first place.

A SECOND performance of "Parsifal" Thursday afternoon and a Saturday matinee performance of "Tristan und Isolde" will mark the final week of the Metropolitan Opera season. "Lucia di Lammermoor" will be the closing opera of the season Saturday evening, with Lily Pons and Lauri-Volpi in the leading roles.

THE man with the pair of skates under his arm said that he didn't know how the struggle for third place in the International Group would come out, but he felt reasonably sure that the Toronto Maple Leafs would edge into the heekey playoffs.
BASLE, March 4. -- The monthly balance statement of the Bank for International Settlements as of Feb. 28, In Swiss gold francs (19.295), is as follows:

THE author of "New England Holiday" (published in 1931) displays in his second novel a power of characterization well above the average of contemporary fiction. It is the love story of two very modern young New Yorkers, of a man whose first care is the preservation of his bachelor freedom at whatever cost, of a girl who for all her sophistication, like any daughter of Eve dreams of one man and a home.
The powerful St. John's quintet gained a victory over Manhattan, 37 to 29, last night on the Jaspers' court.

THE League of Nations' radio station's log at Geneva covering the complete record of the recent world-wide broadcast of the Chino-Japanese report discloses how the wireless flashed the 15,000 words around the globe, under varying conditions.

GUSTAV ECKSTEIN, scientist and author of "Noguchi" and "Lives," has delivered to Harper Brothers the manuscript of his first novel. "Kettle." which will be published late in April. Dr. Eckstein does all his writing at night in his laboratory at the University of Cincinnati.

The Hackley School team of Tarrytown, Roosevelt High School of Yonkers and Montclalr Academy were victorious in three of the four scheduled games in the weekly scholastic ice hockey series played at the New York Coliseum yesterday. The other match, listed between the Riverdale Country Day School and Millburn High School was postponed indefinitely.

The Savage School of Physical Education girls basketball team brought its campaign, to a close by defeating the William and Mary College sextet, 23 to 13, at the Savage gymnasium yesterday. The victory marked the eighth in ten engagements for the Savage girls.

PARIS, March 3 -- No President of the United States has ever assumed office with a heavier charge of other peoples hopes than will Franklin D. Roosevelt. It is no exaggeration to say that here in France especially that hope is poignant.

New York mortgage companies transacted business "as usual" yesterday despite the banking holiday, and the heads of several such institutions expressed the belief that Governor Lehman's order would have Blight direct effect on their operations.

John J. Berry of Newark, president of the New Jersey Association of Real Estate Boards, announces that New Jersey's "First Building Materials and Home Owners' Exposition" will be held under the auspices of the State association from May 13 to May 20, inclusive.

Opposition by the New York Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Children to bills pending before the Legislature which would open motion picture theatres to children unaccompanied by parents or guardians between 10 A.M. and 6 P.M. on days other than school days and Sundays, is announced by Ernest K. Coulter, general manager of the organization.

HAMILTON, Bermuda. -- Visiting owners of thoroughbred dogs, registered with recognized kennel clubs abroad, are being invited to enter their pets in the various competitions of the Bermuda Kennel Club's annual bench show, to be held here on Wednesday under the patronage of the Governor, Lieut. Gen. T. Astley Cubitt and Lady Cubitt, both of whom are enthusiastic dog fanciers.

PARIS, Feb. 22 -- Discovery near Clermont Ferrand of a vast fortified place, which constitutes one of the most important remains of ancient Gallic civilization, has set French archaeologists at work to determine whether they have not brought to light Gergovia, the scene of the memorable defeat of Caesar by the Gallic hero Vercingetorix.

WITHIN the last two years the suggestion has often been heard that partial relief from our educational tax burdens might be had if communities needing such relief were to impose a small tuition fee on high school students. Usually this is not possible; the Constitutions of most States guarantee to the people a free common school system, and the high school, by either express constitutional provision or judicial interpretation, is included within that system.
PARIS, March 3 -- There are two sides to every question, insists an American lawyer engaged to defend a compatriot who faces a charge of being a fashion pirate.

George Z. Medalie, United States Attorney, voided yesterday the indictment, returned on May 4, 1931, of James M. Hoyt, partner in the Stock Exchange house of Prince Whitely, which failed on Oct. 9 that year with liabilities of more than $20,000.000.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- The Wheatley Stable's Slapdash, daughter of Stimulus and Tetrarchy, today confirmed the claim that she is the best 2-year-old filly in training here when she won the featured Nursery Stakes No. 2 to maintain her perfect record at Hialeah Park. She has started and won three times.

THIS novel is out of the ordinary, first of all by reason of the fact that it has to do with a section of the country and a group of people new to fiction, namely, the Florida scrub and its "Cracker" inhabitants. These people -- outcasts, survivals, remnants, let one call them what one will -- are primitives when considered as individuals: tribal units when taken in their relation one to another.

For Lower Fees and Taxes. WITH automobile registrations decreasing at the rate of about 4,000 a day, gasoline consumption and the revenue from fuel taxes declining, it is no wonder that clamorous complaints are going up from other throats than the motorists'.

WAGNER'S "Tristan" at the opera next Saturday afternoon will be the 100th time this classic work has been sung at the Metropolitan in the quarter-century of Gatti-Casazza as general manager. "Tristan" likewise is the tenth among all the 172 operas and ballets in this period to pass the hundred mark.

LEE TRACY is headlined at the Capitol as the erratic newspaper correspondent of "Clear All Wires" in the Metro version of the stage comedy by Bella and Samuel Spewack. The action hops from Chicago to Paris, Moscow and China, and Morocco. Benita Hume, young English actress, plays the feminine lead, and the cast otherwise includes Una Merkel, James Gleason and C. Henry Gordon.

Mgr. John W. Hauptmann, who had been pastor of the Roman Catholic Church of St. Aloysius in Brooklyn since its foundation forty years ago, died Friday in his rectory, 382 Onderdonk Avenue, of diabetes. He was 72 years old. Surviving are a sister, Mrs. Frances Treubig, and several nieces and nephews, among them the Rev. John Treubig, S.J., and Sisters M. Aloysius and M. Marvella of the Order of St. Dominic.
HAVANA, March 4. -- An armed band attacked the Santiago-Havana express early this morning at Jicotea near Santa Clara.

IN his foreword Eddie Rickenbacker pays tribute to General Fechet's qualifications for telling "the airman's story" "He has taught fliers, flown flying machines and been intimately connected with the industry for fifteen of the most exciting and progressive years in air history.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Protesting the 12 per cent reduction in public relief for the idle recently ordered by the Cook County Bureau of Public Welfare, 12,000 to 15,000 unemployed persons marched through downtown streets today.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Franklin D. Roosevelt started his first day as President by attending divine services at St. John's Episcopal Church and hearing the prayer for his welfare by his old headmaster, the Rev. Endicott Peabody, rector of Groton, who also performed the marriage ceremony of Mr. and Mrs. Roosevelt.

CHICAGO, March 2 -- There are indications that when Mississippi adopted a general sales tax about a year ago it started something that is likely to develop widely. Indiana has followed suit; a salestax measure has passed the Illinoia Senate, and in Wisconsin the beginnings of an agitation in favor of similar action are already apparent.

Savings bank depositors throughout the city made little outward show yesterday of any feeling they may have had because of Governor Lehman's proclamation of a bank holiday. Small crowds which had collected before some downtown institutions moved away rapidly after the closing had been explained by bank guards or policemen stationed in the street.

PALM BEACH, Fla. -- Although the present calendar shows a slight decrease in major sports events, the many cultural and social affairs planned for March indicate no cessation of the swift pace established earlier, but rather a shifting of the centre of interest.

The Navy, making its first appearance in the City College pool, conquered the Lavender In both swimming and water polo last night in their Intercollegiate Swimming Association engagement, triumphing in swimming.

Regulations providing for the improvement of safety measures at sea, including the placing of lights on vessels in tow, construction of life floats for river steamers and detectors of fire in cargo holds have been approved by the Bureau of Navigation and Steamboat Inspection of the Department of Commerce, it was announced yesterday.

THOSE who are following the dispute between Colombia and Peru doubtless wonder why these two countries should fight over a small territory which is so generally described as being a fever-infested jungle swamp of no value.

SCOTSMEN throughout the world are following with interest a somewhat courageous proposal to add one more to the universities of their ever-famous country. It is to be the first university in the Highlands.

LONDON, too, is considering its grave problems in a detached fashion. It seems that Paul Roboson is now to start a two weeks" engagement in O'Neill's "All God's Chillun Got Wings." This would be March 13, for those who like their records clear.

More than 4,500 Columbia University students and their guests are expected to attend the three performances of the 1933 Columbia varsity show, "Home, James," to ba given Friday evening, March 10, and Saturday afternoon and evening, March 11, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

THEY are indeed "minute glimpses," but each one presents a striking view and a resume of the chief points of history and present consequence of some one well-known city of the United States or Canada. Seventy-five of these "glimpses" are contained in the book, which is a large octave volume, handsomely made and of ample page space.

Saturday night lured the usual crowd of merry-makers to Broadway last evening, bank holiday or no bank holiday. The entertainment seekers for whom Saturday night comes but once each week thronged the avenue from Times Square to Fifty-third Street crowded motion-picture houses and legitimate theatres and other amusement centres and seemed to have lost little, if any, of their gayety.

DALLAS, March 2 -- Texas, Oklahoma and Louisiana will join the big parade of States marching toward repeal, but it may take them a little time to fall in line. Louisiana is conceded to be wet, and ratification of the amendment is expected to be a mere formality.

Places where income tax advice may be obtained were announced yesterday by the Internal Revenue Department. Experts have Been assigned at each of the places to give information on the income tax requirements and to assist in the filling out of returns, which must be be filed by March 15.

PHILADELPHIA, March 4 -- Orders were sent out by Commander John D. Pennington, prohibition administrator for Pennsylvania, New Jersey and Delaware, to all deputy administrators and agents that they are to make no more purchases of liquor for evidence, and that no money is to be appropriated for wire tapping or used to pay informants.

THE Italian. Broadcasting Corporation is transmitting opera from La Scala, the Teatro Regio (Turin), the Carlo Felice (Genoa), the Royal Opera, the San Carlo, the Massimo (Palermo) and the Petruzzelli (Bari), usually in rotatlon, but at times simultaneously from two or more of these stages, also from the Politeama of Florence, during opera seasons.

GENEVA, March 4 -- President Roosevelt's inaugural address made a very good first impression internationally, according to the comment now available here. While many were disappointed by the brevity and generality and the secondary character of the passage concerning world affairs, they agreed that the best contribution the United States can make to the solution of the world's problems now is to put its own house in order.

IN his pictorial translation or W. Somerset Maugham's play, "Our Betters," which attracted thousands to the Radio City Music Hall last week, George Cukor, the director, wisely kept to the original work, instead of sacrificing the author's clever ideas and scintillating lines for the sake of a camera angle, a dissolve or some intrusive bit of symbolism.
WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Comment on President Roosevelt's speech by Congress members was generally favorable.

DR. McCARTAN was envoy of the Irish Republic to this country from 1917 to 1920, and in that capacity was in the thick of the dramatic and more or less bitter struggle to obtain American recognition for the revolutionary government which he represented.

Money transactions and transfers through postal saving's facilities and postoffice money orders and by telegraph over the wires of the Western Union and the Postal Telegraph Companies were uninterrupted yesterday, although limited to some extent by the banking situation, and neither the Postoffice Department nor the two telegraph companies contemplated suspension of such services.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT will broadcast from the White House tonight. Efrem Zimbalist, violinist, and Gladys Swarthout, soprano, share honors in a joint recital. The Italian maestro Arturo Toscanini returns to the microphone. There will be several international broadcasts this week, including German election bulletins.

WHEN those casual historians of Tin Pan Alley lift their mighty pens they come almost at once to the name of Sigmund Romberg. Just what to do with it then -- by way of a chapter heading -- is quite another matter.

PARIS, Feb. 21. -- Ambassador and Mrs. Walter Edge entered upon a final round of dinners and receptions before quitting the embassy here for good. On Friday, Feb. 24, they had M. Edouard Herrlot as their chief guest for luncheon at their official home in the Avenue d'Iena.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A roar ascended from the lower end of Pennsylvania Avenue. There was a rush to the spot. Some thought there was trouble, some thought there was a fire. A few even thought it might be a riot.

Herbert Hoover entered private life yesterday after a day of foreboding, in which his successor addressed the nation as though it were entering upon a war. With downcast eyes and a diffident manner, Mr. Hoover went to the Capitol to see Mr. Roosevelt inaugurated as President, and left hurriedly, as if glad to throw from his shoulders the mantle of responsibility for the affairs of a country desperately distressed.

FROM over the country last week came reports of the heavy toll taken of retail trade by banking troubles. The losses in some case ran as high as 75 per cent, while in other instances emergency measures of one kind or another held down the declines.

The Evander Childs High School fencing team gained undisputed possession of the lead in Division of the city P.S.A.L. championship by defeating the Textile High foilsmen, defending titleholders, 5 to 3, in one of eigrht tourney matches yesterday at the Washington Irving High School.

After a chase through downtown streets near the Bowery early this morning, a patrolman, riding on the running board of a taxicab he had commandeered, shot and killed one of three bandits who a few moments earlier had held up an establishment at 6 Stanton Street known as the "Whoopee" Clam and Oyster House.

HENRI MURGER is popularly supposed to have established Bohemia as a vagrant land of the spirit where happy-go-lucky, threadbare, artists lived, loved, drank and sometimes worked: but long before him Monsieur Francois Villon, together with such fellows as Guy Tabary.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4 -- Paul Runyan of White Plains, N.Y., co-winner of the recent international four-ball championship here, forged into the lead at the halfway mark in the seventy-two-hole $5,000 open tournament over the Miami-Biltmore links at Coral Gables today.

Because of the banking holiday all financial and commodity markets were closed yesterday, other exchanges having followed the lead of the New York Stock Exchange in suspending trading temporarily. Most of the important out-of-town markets also were closed.

GILBERT MILLER, far off there In Hollywood, seems to be making his plans, having his little triumphs. Rumors of them have been drifting around for days. In a melancholy moment this column set out to ask what he is about, what he hopes to do next season, what players he expects to have under the house flag of Miller.

THIS book is not nearly so formidable as one might fear from its title. Although "flaming youth" does not now send forth its pronouncements with the same self-assurance that braced its spinal column and shrilled its voice a few years ago, anything bearing the "youth" brand is still eyed askance by its elders.

BOSTON, March 1. -- "Winnipesaukee," please. Never mind what the encyclopedias say, or the histories, or the dictionaries, or the guide books, or any other works of reference. It is settled that henceforth and forever the correct spelling of the name of one of the most beautiful lakes in the United States shall be "Winnipesaukee," and that no more it shall be "Winnepesaukee."

WASHINGTON. March 4 (AP) -- In the big, high-ceilinged sitting room in the southwest corner of the White House that is to be her home for the next four years, Eleanor Roosevelt stood this afternoon, gazing soberly out the window as she drew off her gloves.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The quadrennial pageant which traditionally accompanies the inauguration of a new President was enacted here today with all the pomp and panoply of more prosperous years and with all solemnity.

WHAT with the departure of Uday Shan-kar and the final performance tonight of Mary Wigman, it is evident that the season has rolled around again to that annual period when foreign artists bid us farewell, leaving behind them the perennial discussion between the ardent nationalists and the more liberal elements in the dance field as to whether they have done us injury or brought us blessings.
Horace Mann School for Boys and Irving School of Tarrytown scored triumphs yesterday in the final two scheduled games of the Eastern Private Schools Basketball League's first season.

NEW YORKERS and suburbanites who work in the city travel daily in railroad trains, subways and other vehicles and are subjected to the devitalizing effects of vitiated and contaminated air. A movement to improve ventilation conditions in all forms of transportation got under way recently and resulted in the formation of the New York Committee for Better Transportation Ventilation.

THE English reviewers have seen fit to compare ''Appius and Virginia" with "Lady Into Fox," though any reasons for doing so must be startlingly unsound. The only thing the two books have in common is that each is a tour de force -- each a product, in the absence of pragmatic data, of the imagination.

BERLIN, Feb. 18, 1933. THE Ides of February have come and gone, Richard Wagner has been fifty years in some heaven or other, and all's more or less wrong with the world. Germany is still reverberating with the semi-centennial observances of the death in Venice and will continue so to reverberate (with an eye on tourists and other paying guests) for months to come.

As a result of the declaration of the two-day, bank holiday in this State, the New York Stock Exchange and all other security and commodity exchanges in New York City closed yesterday for the duration of the bank holiday. It was the third time in the history of the Stock Exchange that trading was suspended because of widespread unsettlement.

CARACAS, Feb. 22 -- The inauguration of public telephone service between Vene., ela and the United States, which was heralded by the recent conversation between Foreign Minister Chacin in Caracas and Secretary Stimson in Washington, marks the accomplishment in four years' time of the most radical revolution in its foreign communications system realized to any government.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- President Roosevelt's official famiy is one of vivid contrasts, its members differing greatly, not only from the Cabinet circle of the last administration, but from one another.
LONDON, Feb. 15 A FEW months ago Lionel Hale, who was then. I believe an undergraduate and is certainly very young., wrote a play called "Passing Through Lorraine" on a Joan of Arc theme.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 4 -- Ninety students from Rutgers and the New Jersey College for Women will participate in a model world economic conference, organized by the economics and political science departments of the university, here on March 23 and 24, it was announced today by Dr. Eugene E. Agger, head of the economics department.

The unsettled conditions throughout the country were reflected in the wholesale markets during the week, with a decline shown in the number of buyers here and in orders for merchandise, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by McGreevey, Werring Howell, Inc.

ST. AUGUSTINE, Fla., March 4. -- Miss. Kathleen Garnham of England capped a successful invasion of British women golfers today by winning the eighteen-hole final for the Florida East Coast Championship and the Mrs. W. R. Kenan Jr. Cup.

IT has taken Dard Hunter nearly six years to complete his latest contribution to the bibliography of papermaking. Although his list now shows thirteen titles, another ("Modern Handmade Papermaking in the Orient") is already in preparation. Six of these volumes were not only published by the author but also set in a type designed, cut and cast by him and printed on a paper made under his supervision.

CLEVELAND, March 2 -- Cleveland and most of Ohio had the manifestations of a bank holiday this week without all the demoralization which accompanied the outset of the State moratorium in Michigan. When Governor George White, late last week, stated that he would not declare a moratorium but would not through legislation enabling the banks individually, in the discretion of the State Banking Department, to limit their withdrawals, the air became clearer.

Asserting that the oil Industry Is "a seething caldron" of unknowns, The Lamp, official publication of the Standard Oil Company of New Jersey, outlines the whole economic picture of petroleum with the relations of problems in one field with those in another.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 4 (AP) -- John Macionis, Philadelphia Central High School student, set a new world's Interscholastic record of 2:181-5 for the 220-yard event at the annual Rutgers University swimming meet today. The previous record of 2:193-5 was held by Jimmie Gilhoula of Detroit.

BERLIN, Feb. 12 THE Berlin theatre is lying around in wreck and ruin. Beside it the Colosseum looks like a newly completed real estate development. The worldfamous Reinhardt Deutsches Theater is completely snuffed out by the management of Rudolph Beer pf Vienna.

PROVIDENCE, R. I., March 2. -- Block Island, famed for its sword fish, its deep-sea pilots and its vacation lures, and only to a slightly lesser extent for the bitter differences of opinion among its "islanders," is again torn by strife. This time, as frequently the case in the past, the presence of the "furriner" element has added spice to the battle.

As director for Fox's "Zoo in Budapest," Rowland V. Lee is master of all he surveys, the domain including 500 animals and about 1,000 birds, in addition to Gene Raymond, Loretta Young and other human actors. It is his belief, expressed on the "Zoo in Budapest" set recently, that the animals do not need as much coaxing as some actors before the camera and are not nearly so difficult to work with.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Quite as seriously as her predecessor four years ago took up the same responsibilities. Mrs. Franklin Roosevelt today exchanged roles with Mrs. Herbert Hoover, to the evident relief of the latter.

LOS ANGELES, March 2 -- Another man without a country -- one whose only reward for an 8,800-raile cruise in a 19-foot boat has been a short stay behind the bars of the immigration station in Los Angeles -- has turned up on the West Coast.

TRENTON, N.J., March 4 -- A telegram sent to all banks in New Jersey proclaiming a bank holiday for today and Monday was made public here today by the State Department of Banking and Insurance, following an order issued by Governor A. Harry Moore, who was in Washington attending the Inauguration.

A different entertainment is being arranged for the night of April 8 at the Ambassador under the auspices of the Prosperity Club, which has been, offering a series of Saturday night dances there throughout the winter. The event will be known as the Blue and White Supper Dance and the net proceeds will be given to a philanthropic organization.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4. -- Harvard was victorious in six of its eight Winter sport competition today, losing to the Yale varsity swimming and boxing teams while registering victories over the Yale freshman hockey team, the Yale varsity and freshman squash racquets teams, the Princeton varsity fencing team, the Choate School fencing team and the Yale sophomore class swimming team.

IT is the purpose of this excelently written novel to present impartially the effects produced in the lives of several mature married couples of love affairs pursued beyond the sanctions of their conjugal vows. These people are ultramoderns of gentle breeding, socialy prominent and wealthy, relatives by either blood or marriage, exponents of the right to follow their amorous inclinations wherever the fancy leads.

It is difficult to hand down a glib decision concerning George O'Neil's "American Dream," which the Theatre Guild has mounted as its third production of the season. For this Kansas poet and novelist has written a play on a theme that defies easy solutions.

OMAHA, March 2 -- Prairie eyes have turned alternately from Washington to local State capitals and back again during thess past few days. An air of hopeful interest in the new national administration is mingled with a disposition toward critical impatience with sweating legislative assemblies.

Closing of the banks yesterday by proclamation of the Governor was clearly a precautionary step. It will be so recognized. In the circumstances, with the strain steadily increasing, the emergency action supplies a necessary safeguard against public hysteria.

Faced by a nation-wide shutdown of banking facilities tomorrow and possibly for a good part of this week, manufacturers and wholesalers in the local markets indicated yesterday that they would attempt to continue business as usual, checking credits according to previous performances of customers.

FORM ruled the week in the New York galleries. An unusual crop of sculpture appeared, ranging from Assyrian works of an elder and simpler world to modern cats and portraits of living celebrities. These and the out-of-town visitor of the week -- the comprehensive exhibition of the work of Chicago artists -- are being entertained in another column on this page.

At the height of the World War the late Ellwood Hendrick was asked by Harpers to write a popular book on chemistry. There was good reason for the request. The war was decidedly a chemical war, not because poisonous gases had been introduced as weapons, but because the chemist dominated the steel mills, the munition factories and works where airplanes were made.

A report of great value has come from members of the Council of the Royal Institute of International Affairs, under the chairmanship of Viscount ASTOR, as the result of a survey of world agriculture. Its first sentence should be written today so large across the skies of our own nation that all who read may know where the revival must begin:
MIAMI, Fla., March 4 (AP) -- A gangrenous process is infecting Mayor Anton Cermak's right lung, his physicians announced tonight after they tapped the cavity of the organ.
WEST POINT, N.Y., March 4. -- Two indoor polo games, two wrestling matches, a gym meet and an indoor rifle match were on the program for Army teams todays.

Exchange of checks at 173 clearing houses throughout the country for February totaled $18,399,794,750. This was a loss of 8.6 per cent from the turnover In January, and the smallest since last November. Compared with February, 1932, there was a shrinkage of 13.8 per cent.
NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4 -- Yale's basketball team completed its regularly scheduled Eastern Intercollegiate League program tonight with a 46-22 victory over Cornell.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- President Roosevelt plunged immediately into the banking situation tonight by summoning members of his Cabinet and leaders of Congress to meet tomorrow afternoon to decide upon a program to deal with it.
PALM BEACH, March 4. -- Mr. and Mrs. Peter A.B. Widener 2d and Joseph E. Widener entertained with a dinner tonight at their villa.

ESSEX, Conn., March 4. -- In a current swift, deep and silent. Western Long Island Sound boats swept into the lead on the Connecticut River today in the first session of the inaugural Eastern Frostbite dinghy regatta.

The G.R.D. Studio, 9 East Fifty-seventh Street, is presenting (until March 11) the work of four artists: Frances Avery, Peggy Dodds, Dean Fausett and Dovv Ben Tzwee. This foursome has much to offer. An air of spirited give-and-take makes the walls alive with interest and occasionally the work rises to genuine distinction.

The application by Justice Lawrence Gresser, Queens member of the Court of Special Sessions, for an injunction restraining the Board of Estimate from cutting the $17,500 salary of Special Sessions judges 14 per cent and for a ruling that not more than 10 per cent should be deducted, was denied yesterday by Supreme Court Justice Levy.

MOSCOW, March 2 -- The Soviet attitude toward the Japanese adventure in Jehol is one of watchful waiting. No anxiety is shown in official quarters at present because the Japanese forces are not threatening the Soviet maritime provinces.

JAMES T. FARRELL may be roughly classed with the group of younger novelists who treat of proletarian characters and backgrounds in the spirit of sound realism. He gets down closer to bed-rock naturalism than any of them.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The Roosevelt administration made a successful bid for popularity this afternoon when it served tea and sandwiches at the White House to 2,500 out-of-town visitors, cold, tired and hungry from watching the inaugural, parade for four hours.

TRONDHJEM. IN his designs for the completion of the exterior of the Trondhjem Cathedral, the architect Helge Thiis, son of the well-known art critic Jens Thiis, has solved several problems by treating them as new problems of building.

After a week of concentrated contract bridge competition in several events, the Eastern championships tournament closed yesterday with the mixed team-of-four play for the Wilbur C. Whitehead memorial trophy at the Hotel Roosevelt. The event, one of the most popular of the tournament, brought a field of twenty-nine teams, each composed of two men and two women.

SCULPTURE -- relief, in the round and hybrid -- played a conspicuous part in the week's developments. On Monday the Metropolitan opened to the public what should really be called a new Assyrian department, containing superb pieces given to the museum by John D. Rockefeller Jr.

The Hudson Highlands, twenty miles and more of rugged hills, among which it has been said the great river plays hide-and-seek, needed a guide and interpreter. PHILADELPHIA, March 4 (AP) -- Mrs. Herbert Hoover, identifying herself as a "private citizen," started west from Philadelphia late today for her home in Palo Alto, Cal.

The problem of mortgage interest rates under present conditions seems to have created two distinct, schools of thought, points out Harry Hall of the firm of William A. White Sons, who is now engaged in liquidating the real estate assets of the Bank of United States.

ITHACA, N.Y., March 4 -- Anti-vivisectionists' activities are endangering the advance of science, Presdent Livington Ferrand of Cornell University declares in a letter to the Medical Society of the State of of New York.

THE recent Incident concerning a slur at Herbert Hoover contained in a book sales catalogue brings up the whole question of the function of such catalogues. It is not so ranch the aspersion cast by the remarks or the absurdity of their implications that concerns us now.

AVALON, Catalina Island, Cal., March 4 -- The Giants took to the open sea today as part of their conditioning exercises but met with disastrous results. For they not only experienced a rough voyage to this garden spot that juts out of the Pacific, but they suffered an even rougher landing, being upset by the Chicago Cubs, 10 to 2, in the opening exhibition game of the season.

HSINKING, Manchuria, Jan. 20 -- The only foreigners other than the Japanese who have displayed any great interest in investment opportunities in Manchuria since the birth of Manchukuo are the French. Several representatives of various French financial interests have passed through Manchuria in recent months.
WASHINGTON. March 4 (AP) -- Doffing his high silk hat to cheering throngs, Governor A. Harry Moore today led New Jersey's delegation in the inaugural parade to pay tribute to a new President.

SOUTHERN PINES, N. C. -- The tournament season, which has been under way for several weeks, will take on more color with the principal events of March. The women's fifth annual mid-South championship will be played on the two rolling courses at the Southern Pines Country Club.
Miss Ivy Maud Ross, who for thirty-two years was a member of the staff of The New York American, died on Friday afternoon in Alpine, N.J., after a long illness.
A 2 o'clock each Monday afternoon a music teacher at the University of Michigan steps to the microphone and lifts his baton.

VIENNA, March 2 -- The last fortnight has seen the creation of the third greatest military entity in Europe -- the Little Entente -- a fact whose importance is thoroughly appreciated in Rome and the capitals of Southeastern Europe though its significance is obscured for the rest of the world by more stirring events.

By defeating St. John's High, 2 to 0, last night in the second game of the play-off series at the Brooklyn Ice Palace, the Brooklyn Prep team won the hockey championship of the Catholic High Schools Athletic Association for the third year in succession.
DETROIT, March 4 -- Detroit turned definitely today to scrip as the one way to check the paralysis of business which is daily becoming more complete.

Viewing the bank situation as s national problem, Governor Lehman declared yesterday that further developments in the situation in New York would depend in a large measure upon expression of a Federal policy or line of action from Washington.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- Crowds of distinguished visitors thronged the nation's capital today, among them the Governors of twenty-eight States, all members of the Democratic National Committee, chairmen, and vice chairmen of State Democratic committees, chairmen of State inaugural committees, and all the members of the Electoral College who cast their votes for Roosevelt and Garner.
Praise for President Roosevelt's inauguration speech was expressed here last night by industrial and financial leaders, as quoted by The Associated Press.

KOENIGSBERG, East Prussia, March 4. -- Chancellor AdoLf Hitler, speaking tonight in this stronghold of National Socialism, was received with frenzied applause lasting almost ten minutes when he appeared before a crowded meeting after preceding orators had warned the audience that it was "not mere coincidence" that the Chancellor was making his final campaign speech in "this outpost of the Fatherland, severed from it by the disgraceful treaty of Versailles."

RICHMOND, March 2 -- Ratification of repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment is regarded as certain in Maryland and probably in Virginia and North Carolina, but no final action is expected in the last-named State before 1935, and there seems small likelihood that Virginia will settle the matter before 1934.

By way of gilding the pill of ultramodernism contained in the first performance here of Louis Gruenberg's First Symphony, Mr. Koussevitzky commenced his Boston Symphony Orchestra concert yesterday afternoon in Carnegie Hall with Mozart's "Kleine Nachtmusik," and this delicious music was played with fine taste and with the glorification of virtuosity by the strings.

The annual Rainbow Ball to be given on March 24 at the Waldorf-Astoria for the benefit of the Association for the Aid of Crippled Children has aroused the interest and cooperation of many younger members of society, including about 100 debutantes, who will participate in a fashion show presented by the American Creators Fashion group.

BERLIN, March 3. -- No stranger election has perhaps ever been held in a civilized country than that in which the German people will reluctantly be going to the polls again when this dispatch is being read.

PRINCETON, March 4 -- Fred Kammer led the Princeton hockey team to its second straight victory over Dantmouth in Hobey Baker Memorial Rink tonight, triumphing by the score of 2 -- 0.

MIAMI. -- Events of this week and some of those scheduled for the remainder of March in the Miami area promise to offer unusual features. One of the most colorful will be the fashion tea scheduled for this afternoon at the Miami Biltmore Country Club, whose members will entertain their friends on a float in the Spanish Pool.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney announced late yesterday afternoon, following a conference attended by commanders of all police divisions, that an emergency squad of ten to twelve patrolmen would be on duty in every precinct in the city ready to be rushed to the defense of cash held by theatres, business houses or other institutions during the period of the bank holiday.

If in the Inaugural Address of President ROOSEVELT anything is lacking, it is not courage. In the boldest and most resolute way he called upon the nation to join him in taking arms against a sea of troubles. Without a particle of blind optimism he recited the critical circumstances under which his Administration begins.

By appeals from the stage of the Metropolitan Opera House after each performance yesterday, and on special blanks to be enclosed in the programs at every performance until the season closes at the end of the coming week, the fund-raising committee representing the owners, producers and artists of the Metropolitan continued to solicit pledges of popular subscriptions to make up a $300.000 guarantee to assue opera next season.

The New York University swimming team triumphed over Carnegie Tech, 32-27, in the London Terrace seventy-five-foot pool yesterday. It was the final dual meet of the season for the Violet and the winner's record for the campaign was five victories in ten encounters.

At the March meeting of the board of directors of the American Kennel Club the question of granting dates for combined specialty shows will once more come up for discussion. There seems to be a considerable divergence of opinion on this matter.

THE International Exhibition of Art, organized by the College Art Association, has gone on from its temporary post at Rockefeller Center, and for New York that episode has ended. Looking back upon the several visits made to the galleries before they were dismantled, the general impression left in one mind at least is that there are fewer differences between the aims of one nation and those of another than formerly existed.

WINNIPEG, March 5 (Canadian Press) -- Scenes reminiscent of oldtime bull markets were enacted in today's short but violent session of the Winnipeg Grain Exchange. Wheat futures, propelled by buying from Chicago sources, moved as much as 2 cents higher.

NASSAU, Bahamas. -- Two ships of the Canadian fleet, the Saguenay and Champlain, are here for a visit and will remain until Tuesday. A combined team from the ships plan to play baseball with a team from the Nassau Baseball Association on the New Colonial Hotel diamond today and again tomorrow.

Inauguration Day having fallen this year on a Saturday, thousands of visitors will be making a week-end of it at the capital. On the side of weather, it is a rather risky business to travel to Washington these March days, as many found to their cost in years gone by, notably when Mr. TAFT made his historic journey up Pennsylvania Avenue in a blinding snowstorm.

A STUDY in frustration, Hamilton Basso might appropriately have sab-titled his book. For the life of the man whose story he narrates, Pierre Gustave Toutant Beauregard. General in the Confederate Army, for brief moments the favorite of fortune and then forgotten, presents a dramatic and tragic picture of ardent hopes, high ambitions, devouring thirst for fame, all coming to naught after one glimpse of the heights of glory.

Pound, Chief Judge of the Court of Appeals of the State, urged the members of the Columbia University Law School Alumni Association yesterday "to be good natured and calm" in the face of present conditions.

CHINCHOW, Manchuria, March 4 (AP). -- A handful of Japanese soldiers, pushing through a blizzard from Pingchuan, marched into Chengteh at 11:30 o'clock this morning and took it over without a struggle.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 4. -- The Princeton junior varsity indoor polo team scored three goals in the final chukker to hand the Yale Jayvees their first defeat of the season, 10 1/2 to 9 1/2, today. The Yale freshman riders downed the Princeton yearlings, 12 1/2 to 10 1/2.

CHAMBERSBtTRG, Pa., March 4 -- Penn Hall Junior College's swimming team accounted for a major upset today in defeating the New York University girls' squad, 32 to 21. This was the first setback in six years for the Violet naiads, who had won forty meets in succession.

Payments to policy holders in life insurance companies and their beneficiaries will not be interrupted by the banking holiday, it "was indicated at the offices of leading companies here yesterday. Inasmuch as the companies pay by check, however, there may be some delay before the checks may be cashed, depending on the length of the shut-down and the extent of the restrictions, if any, imposed when the banks reopen.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- About 400 persons from all parts of the country found the strain of waiting for the inauguration ceremonies and parade too much for them today and had to receive emergency medical treatment.

DR. KANY, Spanish professor at the University of California, has turned out a book on customs and manners in Madrid during the second half of the eighteenth century that will be a god-send to students of Spanish literature, history or social chronicles-- as well as to occasional novelists and playwrights -- for it is an encyclopedia of curious facts and practical details cozily assembled for the reader's convenience.

LOS ANGELES, March 2. -- The direct primary is in growing disfavor in California. Voters are, in large measure, disgusted with its intricacies and unhappy over the weird results it produces. The current Legislature may do something about it.

ONCE again events of historic importance are taking place alone the dragonlike, crenellated Great Wall of China. Fifteen centuries ago this amazing structure of defense, at that time already 700 years old. Influenced the whole trend of European history and the development of the white race when it deflected west-ward the general advance of Northern barbarians toward the warmer, richer regions of Eurasia and caused the overwhelming of Roman civilization.
PARIS, March 2. -- Fox skins draped to effect a jacket line, with the tails twisted to form a collar, are the smartest Spring furs shown with suits or coat frocks.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4. -- Yale varsity wrestlers today scored their first victory over Harvard in four years, but the Eli poloists met their most decisive defeat in years at the hands of Princeton.

Allenhurst scored an upset in the metropolitan Indoor polo circuit tourney at the Squadron C Armory. Brooklyn, last night, defeating the Cavalry team, 16 1/2 to 12 1/2, after receiving six goals handicap. While the handicap was a large one, considering the fact that Allenhurst has been playing above its rating all season, due in measure to its splendid mounting, the Cavalry had been expected to go much better.

The Soviet musical instrument industry has increased its output enormously in the past two years, but is still short of supplying the demands of the workers and peasants, according to a report published recently in the Moscow Daily News.

Persons who thought they had prepared for a banking emergency by placing cash in their safe deposit boxes found themselves in some instances no better off yesterday than the depositors whose funds were locked up for the duration of the bankers' holiday.

YESTERDAY, for the fourth time in our history, a Harvard graduate was inaugurated as President of the United States. Thus Harvard, breaking the three-to-three tie with her rival, the College of William and Mary in Virginia, and doubling the record of Princeton, outranks all other colleges as producer of Chief Executives.

BERLIN, March 4 -- President Roosevelt's inauguration fills the German press with hope for greater activity of the United States in foreign affairs, although it is realized the situation of the banks will monopolize the new President's efforts for some time.

To the Editor of The New York Times: A recent correspondent of THE TIMES has dealt very intelligently with the question of the classics and modern youth. He was quite right in blaming the cold and harsh realities of the present times for the unpopularity of the classics.

An expedition sailed on the S.S. Nerissa of the Furness Line the other day to obtain material in isolated parts of South America for a new series of FitzPatrick Traveltalks, thirteen of which are on this season's MGM program. The troupe includes Ralph Donaldson of Boston, aviator, explorer and a fellow of the National Geographic Society, and William Osgood Fields.

From the Royal Observatory of the University of Lund, Sweden, comes the cheerful news that it is about time the sun and with it the entire solar system blew up. The Cassandra who heralds our doom is Dr. CONRAD LONNQVIST. He finds that the average star explodes and becomes a nova or new star once every 400,000,000 years.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Immediate action through a special session of Congress to remedy the paralysis of the nation's banking system was pledged today by President Roosevelt in his inaugural address.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 4 -- To meet the demand for cooperative living arrangements at Smith College, two more dormitories will be opened next Fall where students will pay less than the regular rate for board and room and will do a small part of the housework.
BENITA HUME, who has been seen over here in British pictures as well as on the Broadway stage, makes her American screen debut with MGM in "Clear All Wires," which is at the Capitol.

ALBANY, March 4 -- Speaker McGinnies took issue today with the stand of Governor Lehman that New York should take steps to serve as a model for the rest of the country in setting up machinery for a State convention to ratify repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment.

GENEVA, March 4 -- The disarmament conference was the scene of a resounding joint demonstration by the European Continent's strongest capitalist and Communist powers today which struck many as especially significant on the eve of the German elections.

DUBLIN, March 3 -- With no immediate prospect of peace between Great Britain and the Irish Free State in sight, the government is going ahead with its plans to create a self-sufficient country. If even half of the de Valera administration's program of economic reform is achieved in the next five years a big expansion of native industry will have resulted.

TABLE settings of pertod inspiration, an important vogue, are being made more accurate through the study of old records, prints and paintings and by hints from collectors of antique tableware. Although some tables depend for their decorative effect chiefly on crystal glass, silver and white china, the prevailing trend is toward carefully worked-out color schemes.

ONE of the many definite indications that air transport has passed out of the experimental stage is forcefully summarized in a chapter of the new and excellent Aircraft Year Book for 1933, compiled by the Aeronautical Chambei of Commerce of America.

Wall Street veterans saw in conditions yesterday the elements of the situation that caused banks in 1907 in New York and other cities to supplement currency in circulation by the issuance of "clearing house loan certificates." This informal but valid form of currency found wide use in 1907.

Intensive outdoor sessions for the Columbia rowing squad will commence this week, it was announced yesterday by Coach Richard J. Glendon. The Lion flotilla started its activities on the Harlem River last week, but the first few days were spent in adjusting the practice schedules and again getting the oarsmen accustomed to rowing in a shell.

MERIAN C. COOPER, who went out into the wilds to film "Chang" and "Grass," remained at home in the studio to manufacture the bizarre adventures in "King Kong," which is at the Music Hall and RKO Roxy this week.

BERLIN, March 4. -- In a country-wide blaze of bonfires and torchlight parades the allied National Socialist and Nationalist parties tonight closed the electoral campaign, which tomorrow is expected to entrench them securely in power not only throughout Germany as a result of the Reichstag elections but throughout Prussia, where the electorate will vote simultaneously for a separate State ticket.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Members of the Cabinet and the "Little Cabinet" in the Hoover administration, the latter organization comprising Under-Secretaries and Assistant Secretaries, surrendered their jobs today to their successors.

American copper producers will fexert strong efforts to perpetuate the benefits they say the present tariff on copper temporarily gives them, according to Louis S. Cates, president of the Phelps Dodge Corporation, in answering widely quoted English reviews by Brandeis, Goldschmidt Co. and The Mining Journal of London, of the British attitude toward the American copper tariff.
Conway Hoffman of the Montclair A.C. is the new Class B Metropolitan squash racquets champion.

The metric system moved in on the Intercollegiate A.A.A.A. without a dissenting murmur yesterday, Although the advocates of the meter had prepared themselves for a battle with those favoring the retention of the yardage distances the matter I.C.A.A.A.A. convention at the Columbia Club, with the result that the meter is ready for installation at the outdoor championships in May.

Supermarkets selling groceries on a price basis have small chance of survival because they were born as a result of the depression and must disappear with a revival in business, V.H. Pelz of the staff of General Marketing Counselors, Inc., and recognized authority in that field, told THE TIMES yesterday.

TORONTO, Ont., March 4 -- The declaration of a dividend by Wright Hargreaves Mines, Ltd., of 5 cents a share In United States funds payable on April 1 to shareholders of record of March 15 is regarded as evidence that the company is on a regular annual dividend basis of 20 cents a share.

MR. MAIS means by his title the island that Includes Eugland, Scotland and Wales. He defends the use of "unknown" as a description of it by saying that the work is about parts of the country that are not so well known to book readers and travelers as are more famous regions, and that, anyway, it was unknown to him.

JAPAN moves into Jehol in opposition to the unanimous decision of the nations of the world. She is carrying out her policy in Manchuria regardless of the League's verdict and notwithstanding the risks involved.

ONE of the explosive moments in this exciting ironic novel about the welter of life around New York's "irregular" square occurs when Jason Wheeler, writer for tne sex story magazines, ex-poet, ex-Communist and ex-student of world affairs, turns on a gathering of "proletarian" poets to call them "barnacles on the bottom of a boat."

Relief work among Negroes, both in the South and in New York, will be assisted by two recitals to take place this week. A recital by Miss Leslie Frick, mezzo-soprano, and Mrs. John Bate, harpist, will be given on Friday afternoon at the Cosmopolitan Club for the benefit of three church schools for Negroes in the South.

The short interest on the New York Stock Exchange declined during February to the lowest figure since records of it were begun, amounting to 1,654,221 shares at the opening of business on Feb. 27, the latest date for which figures are available.

TORONTO. -- For the seventh year the annual battle for the Dominion Curling Championship and the 1933 possession of the Macdonald's Brier Tankard, emblematic of the highest curling honors in Canada, will start on Tuesday at the Granite Club, Toronto.

BARCELONA, Feb. 19 -- A strange tangle is presented by the question of the attributes and powers held by the President of the new Catalan Government. This tangle has Just resulted in the government's first crisis, precipitated by a disagreement between President Francesco Macia and the majority members of his Council, as to just where the President's powers should end and those of the chief Councilor, or head of the Cabinet, should begin.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., March 4 (AP) -- A complete survey of the Aleutian Islands and surrounding waters running west from Unimak Island to Attu Island, to study weather conditions and locate harbors valuable for naval operations and merchant vessels, is being undertaken by the navy, in conjunction with the Weather Bureau.

Advanced fellowships for study in Belgium for the year 1933-1934 have been announced by Perrin C. Galpin, secretary of the C.R.B. Educational Foundation, established by the Commission for Relief in Belgium. Fellows must be Americans on the faculty of a higher educational institution with knowledge of French or Flemish and with definite plans for work in Belgium.

Toby Cook, 7-year-old, Chula (Ga.) boy who rode ponies 811 miles to attend the inauguration at President Roosevelt's request, rode one in the inaugural parade and afterward told this story to an Associated Press staff writer.

The Art Directors Club announces its twelfth annual exhibition of advertising art, to open at the Art Centre on April 10. The show is open to any one who has directed or produced advertising art in America in the last year. About 5,000 pieces of work, originals and reproductions, will be included.

While he has suffered the effects of the depression in common with both chain and department stores, the smaller merchant now has the best comparative position in more than a decade, according to T.C. Cooper, general manager of Butler Brothers, wholesale distributers serving several hundred thousand retail stores throughout the country.

BERLIN, March 4 (AP). -- The latest compilation of reports from various parts of Germany showed that seven persons were killed in political disorders incident to the final day's campaign. There were fatal clashes in Essen, Homberg, Cologne and Diisseldorf, and the dead included National Socialists, Communists, one member of the Centrist party and a Reichsbanner man.

LONDON, March 4 -- There were no dealings in the foreign exchange market today following the declaration of the banking moratorium in New York. A hurriedly summoned meeting of a London bankers' committee took swift action after exchange dealers were uncertain what course to pursue.

To the Dramatic Editor: In your issue of Feb. 26 your Boston correspondent, "H.T.P.," writes: "The American Theatre Society, hard put for anything to fill its second series of subscription plays, picked up an English touring company in Western Canada and deposited it in the Plymouth."

THE Democratic party in the United States is probably the oldest political party in the world. It came into existence under the leadership of Thomas Jefferson in 1791 and won its first victory in 1792. when it secured control of the popular branch of Congress.

FEW Presidents in the history of the United States have been called upon to shoulder the heavy responsibilities which Franklin D. Roosevelt accepted yesterday. He enters the White House in a period of severe depression, with difficult decisions to be made at many points in the field of both domestic and foreign action.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A private service for the President-elect and Mrs. Roosevelt, members of the new Cabinet and their guests was held in St. John's Protestant Episcopal Church this morning before Mr. Roosevelt went to the Capitol for the inauguration.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The last "lame-duck" session of Congress passed into history today. The end of a long line of practically impotent legislative assemblages came to an end with the death of the Seventy-second Congress, whose second and final session piled up such a record for inaction and delay as to cause national leaders to rejoice at its passing.

THE two smallest private houses on Fifth Avenue are about to be altered so as to unite them as a single dwelling for the occupancy of Dr. Harry Woodburn Chase, now president of the University of Illinois, and who, on July 1, will take up his duties as the new chancellor of New York University, succeeding Dr. Elmer Ellsworth Brown, who has been chancellor of the university for twenty-two years.
Representatives of the International League teams were unable to unravel the complicated financial difficulties of the Jersey City Baseball Club yesterday at a meeting at the Hotel New Yorker.

OTTAWA, March 2 -- A movement has been undertaken by the Quebec Country Hotel Keepers Association through Rodrigue Langlois, its manager, to stop what he calls the "Americanization" of rural inns in the Province and restore an atmosphere more typically French.

LONDON, March 4. -- Financial London stubbornly refused today to take the American banking crisis tragically, although the initial shock was so severe that all dealings in foreign exchange were suspended.
The suggestion is made by John A. Ward, realty broker, that the rise and fall of the purchasing power of the dollar should be recognized in mortgage clauses.

Dollar transactions were suspended in the European capitals as a result of the American bank holidays, The Associated Press said yesterday. Tourists unable to cash checks were accommodated by hotels, travel agencies and some banks.

Death comes suddenly to two professors in Dunster College, a New England institution of learning which has recently added to its faculty a professor of criminal paychology in the person of Dick Wilson. Naturally enough, it falls to the lot of Wilson to investigate these deaths.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The Tammany Tiger, though somewhat hungry for Federal patronage, had no meal provided for it by James A. Farley, chairman of the Democratic National Committee, on Inauguration Day, and John F. Curry, the supreme Tammany chieftain, will have to wait, uncertain as to whether it ever will have such a repast.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 4. -- In an address tonight before the Wesleyan University chapter of Phi Beta Kappa, Dr. George E. Vincent of New York asserted that the problem in higher education was not to eliminate mediocrity to turn the colleges and universities into cloisters for an intellectual, fastidious and exclusive few, but to recognize the validity and value of both the elite and mediocre in an educational system modified to give them effect.

In a two-hour struggle that was marked by as fine a grade of squash tennis as has been seen all season, Frank R Hanson Jr. of the Columbia University Club defeated William E. Coyle Jr. of the Fraternity Club last night in the second round of the national Class A championship at the Harvard Club.

An unusual entertainment in behalf of the Stage Relief Fund has been planned by members of the Citizens' Committee, to take place on the night of March 26 at the Metropolitan Opera House. Many prominent men and women are working toward its success, and well-known stars of the theatrical, musical and radio worlds have volunteered their services.

ECONOMIC reaction of such scope and magnitude as has overtaken the world at large, and the United States in particular, must have had a cause of corresponding magnitude and scope. The usual explanations given for the great reaction are not sufficient.

THE Paramount Theatre announces its bookings for the remainder of March. Next Friday will usher in "The Woman Accused," a picturization of the story on which ten well-known writers collaborated. Nancy Carroll, Cary Grant and John Halliday are the principals.

THE rich cosmopolitan set satrized by Bourdet in his comedies appears almost respectable as depicted by Mr. Collins in this first novel. Its characters are for the most part frequenters of New York's night clubs and expensive speakeasies who are equally at home in Paris where they congregate about the Ritz bar.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- A vivid cross-section of the American people stood crowded shoulder to shoulder in the Washington Auditorium tonight watching the Governors of the States in jaunty processional up a lane of brilliantly clad soldiers, sailors and marines, while a gracious lady in blue, wearing orchids and a diamond necklace, smiled and bowed and rose to her feet as the marine hand played the State anthems.

In the light of the present critical emergency, a well-conceived and broad program of public works is necessary to start employment, restore purchasing power and help public confidence, Robert D. Kohn, New York architect and executive chairman of the National Committee for Trade Recovery, composed of fourteen associations in the construction field, said here yesterday.

DR. LAUGHLIN of the Carnegie Institution of Washington, with the assistance of Edith Banta, has conducted an investigation to determine what racial stocks are most inventive. Since pure races are virtually unknown today, Dr. Laughlin had difficulties that could be overcome only by inventing an ingenious method of selection.

FRINCETON, N.J., March 4. -- The Princeton basketball team remained in the race for the Eastern Intercollegiate League title as Johnny Seibert and Ken Fairman led the Tigers to a 39-35 victory over Dartmouth, tonight.

Dr. Bernard Iddings Bell, warden of St. Stephen's College, Annandale-on-Hudson, N. Y., announced yesterday that he would not consider any appointment in connection with the administration or teaching staff of the college after June 30, when his present contract expires.

Twenty Hunter College professors, out of a group of thirty questioned concerning their recreational and esthetic tastes last week, declared they did not care for bridge. Of these, fifteen said they "would not play it at all" and five others remarked, jestingly, "only under compulsion."

Degrees have been awarded to 500 City College students who completed required courses of study during the Fall semester, it was announced yesterday by Dr. Morton Gottschall, acting dean, after the degrees had been confirmed at a meeting of the faculty.

THE United States Navy and Marine band concerts have gone off the radio in accordance with an order issued by the Navy Department. These bands will broadcast only when performing at official functions. The broadcasters understand that the army band will not stop broadcasting.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- A prayer for Divine guidance of President Roosevelt and the new Congress was delivered by the Rev. ZeBarney T. Phillips, chaplain of the Senate, as the first words spoken in the first session of the Senate of the Seventy-third Congress.

In recounting some of the impressions of Brazil and its business possibilities, Charles F. Noyes, head of the real estate firm bearing his name, who recently returned from a trip to Rio de Janeiro, said that scores of American firms own their buildings there and that he came home feeling proud of the standard of American industrial activity in that city.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Washington was the centre of world-wide broadcasting for more than six hours today while a description of the inauguration of President Roosevelt was flashed around the earth by short-wave radio.

Closing time for entries for the seventeenth annual show of the Providence County Kennel Club, to be held in the State Armory on Cranston Street, Providence, R.I., on Saturday, March 18, has been extended and will be received by T.E.L. Kemp, superintendent, at Bridgewater, Mass., up to Saturday.

HOW old is the solar system and therefore the earth? How old are the stars? How old is the universe as a whole? The questions are more important than ever because of the recent theories and discoveries of the atomic physicists and the mathematical analyses of the relativitists.

The State Banking Board, of which Joseph A. Broderick, Super-intendent of Banks, is statutory chairman, is to meet at 10 o'clock tomorrow morning to consider what plans should be adopted so that depositors may obtain funds when the banks reopen on Tuesday, and at the same time protect the institutions so that they may continue to function.
NEW YORK. Charles Blair MacDonald has come from Bermuda to the Plaza.

It seems that New York began yesterday a two-day bank holiday. Union Square buzzed in the morning, but Father Knickerbocker still was doing business "at the same old stand" when night fell. Barring a few minor repercussions, the city went about its affairs much as usual.

WASHINGTON, March 4 -- The eligibility of Secretary of the Treasury Woodin, raised by Senator Couzens in the first session of the new Senate this afternoon and promptly disposed of by Mr. Woodin's confirmation, provided the only break in the otherwise routine process of confirming' President Roosevelt's new Cabinet.

BERLIN, March 4. -- Despite its being the pre-election opening, the Boerse today continued yesterday's rise, most of the active stocks gaining from a fraction to 2 points and more. Later the market sagged under week-end realization and the bank news from the United States.

SAN JUAN, P.R., March 4 -- A wall of water that swept down from the mountains on the city of Mayaguez caused the loss of at least twenty lives last night. Much of the city was inundated to a depth of seven feet, catching many persons in the streets.

The 60,000,000 of Germans go to the polls today in what is perhaps the most remarkable election ever held in a democracy. It may almost be said that it is a referendum on the republican form of government under which Germany has lived since the close of the World War brought the end of the rule of the Hohenzollerns. That is true because Adolf Hitler is the avowed foe of democracy.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Under the heading "Topics of The Times" in a recent issue there occurs the following:

Friendless and alone, Raymond Beck, 40 years old, known in crime annals as the "angel-faced choir singer," an ex-convict who had been a burglar from boyhood, died last night in Kings County Hospital. He succumbed to a bullet wound in the spine received several days ago when he attempted to escape from a policeman at the scene of his last burglary, 2,516 Cortelyou Road, Flatbush.

The appointment of a receiver for the property of Howard Scott, exponent and so-called "high priest" of technocracy, disclosed yesterday an unpaid judgment for $1,640 against him in favor of Carl V. Burger, filed in the City Court in 1923.

OTTAWA, March 2. -- Reciprocity is back in the news, and the Canadian papers are filled with comment and speculation on the prospect of this country working out with the new administration at Washington a plan of international trade mutually profitable and satisfactory.

CHICAGO, March 3. THIS is the most active week of the theatrical season in Chicago, thanks largely to the repertory of the Abbey Theatre Company of Dublin. First-nighters who are faithful to their duties must fare forth every night in the week to keep up with the procession of new bills.

LONDON. AN interesting feature of the program of the British Broadcasting Corporation is the occasional reading of poetical selections. It has thus been discovered that, while there is no special brand of microphone verse, some poems broadcast better than others.

PARIS, Feb. 25 -- French wine-growers and the special wine committee of the American Chamber of Commerce in France, whose efforts are directed toward facilitation of the entry of fine French wines in America when prohibition is modified, already are working closely together.

RED BANK. N. J., March 4. -- Miss Louise Finch, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Rufus C. Finch of Rumson, N. J., today added further honors to the long string she has gained in horsemanship competitions when she captured the Cedar Brook trophy, leading riding event in the mid-Winter horse show held for the benefit of the Monmouth County Chapter of the American Red Cross.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- With solemn mien, Franklin D. Roosevelt of New York took the oath of office and became the thirty-second President of the United States on the main steps of the Capitol at eight minutes after 1 o'clock this afternoon.

TOKYO, March 4 -- In milder weather, the work of providing relief for the injured and homeless and burying the dead proceeded steadily all day in the quake-stricken area, of Japan. Military relief parties reached the sufferers over the greater part of the region last night, bringing food, blankets, tents, clothing and medicines.

WHITE PLAINS, March 4. -- Voters in the twenty-four Westchester villages will go to the polls in March and April to register their approval or disapproval of leaders of the present village administrations. Twenty-one of the villages will hold elections on March 21, under the general election law, and three others on other dates under special charters. Ossining will vote first on March 14, Peekskill on April 11 and Port Chester on April 25.

ONE of the most interesting and important books on American folklore is George Pollen Jackson's study of certain aspects of religious songs among the rural people of the South. It deals mainly with the whites, but has also much that is significant to say about the folksongs of the Negroes and of the Indians in the section.

WITH repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment submitted to the States, the racketeers who won great wealth by violating the liquor law in the grand manner may have to apply their genius to new fields Or -- as seems most likely -- they may remain in the liquor business, become respectable distillers and drop their sidelines of mayhem, extortion and other skulduggery, and in most cases be glad of the chance.

NEW ORLEANS, March 4 (AP) -- The Audley Farm's Rocky News, ridden by Jockey Johnny Kacala, today won the $2,000 added New Orleans Handicap at the Fair Grounds by two lengths. El Puma was second and War Plane third over the mile and a furlong route.

TELEVISION broadcasters are beginning to wonder if it pays to pioneer. They find themselves in the same position as the pioneer sound broadcasters. Television has no source of revenue. The apparatus is quickly antiquated.
BOSTON, March 2. -- The question of the competition of the railroad and the highway in carrying goods for hire is a living issue today in all the New England States.

Modernization and rehabilitation of city properties promises to become an increasingly important part of construction activity, in the opinion of the Hegeman-Harris Company, builders of the seventy-story central skyscraper in Rockefeller Center and many other large buildings.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Two gaps in the Senatorial ranks and one in the House resulted from what legislators have facetiously termed President Roosevelt's "raid" on Congress in quest of personal aides.

THIS is a revolutionary book, from basic idea to last suggestions. The author challenges the whole system of educating the blind and the attitude of society toward them and toward their training. He does it in Judicial spirit, with due restraint and without heat or extravagance of statement.
The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, acquiescing in the two-day bank holiday proclaimed by Governor Lehman, closed its gold-paying windows yesterday and suspended banking transactions.

Suspension of all special State and mandatory laws preventing additional reductions in local budgets was proposed yesterday by the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards as a means of effecting further tax relief for real property.

LONDON, March 3 -- Diplomatic circles in London await with great interest the decision on the foreign policy of the Fascist Grand Council now meeting in Rome, which Ambassador Dino Grandi is also attending. On it hangs, perhaps, the fate of the peace of Europe, as here it is considered that the aggressiveness of the Nazi regime in Germany immediately will acquire the character of an international menace if it should receive Italian support.

In the interests of the musical festival to be given as a Brahms centenary celebration by the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra next Sunday night at the Waldorf-Astoria, Chalmers Clifton, conductor of the orchestra, will make an address on the concert program tomorrow afternoon at the home of Mrs. Henry Root Stern, 855 Fifth Avenue.

Many young women of society will take an active part in the Spring fashion carnival and tea to be held on Tuesday and Wednesday at the Saks Fifth Avenue store for the benefit of the Judson Health Centre. The fashion show, to be called "Petites Modernes," will enlist the participation of several debutantes and will be restricted to the showing of costumes well within the allowance of debutantes.

FAINTLY reminiscent of a mid-Vlctorian weeper, this naive story is concerned with the love and sorrow of an innocent, utterly simple-minded English girl who is led astray by a dashing army officer, on leave from service in India, then callously left by him in the lurch.

SALERNO, its quaint peasantry with its special customs and superstitions, lends a most colorful background to this story. Jenny Rorke, an English girl, finds in this setting escape from an early disillusionment. Miss Lyle, an American woman, the owner of a farm in the district, hires her aa her companion.

HERE is a book that challenges so much in the time-honored conception of Jesus that it is likely to attract attention and create discussion among not only those for whom religion is still a matter of consequence, but also among others who are interested only in His character and historical consequence.

MINNEAPOLIS WHETHER we wish it like it, we are on the battie line," wrote Ellwood P. Cubberley, veteran dean of the School of Education Stanford University, to the convention of the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association just closed here.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Solid masses at each Washington street intersection, sometimes as many as 100 deep, proved a problem for business men and strangers who had to walk a mile or more to find a way to "cut" back to their offices or hotels during the inauguration and after.
WHAT Mr. Benson calls his modern revue follows his Victorian Peep Show of "As We Were," considerably behind in wit and variety, intimacy and anecdote. It is a shorter book, though it has more pages.
