Flashing a superhuman burst of speed in the final hour, and pedaling so furiously in the closing sprints that none of the other teams could approach them, Alfred Letourner and Gerard Debaets, known as the Red Devil combination, won the fifty-fourth international six-day bicycle race, which came to a close in Madison Square Garden last night.

The announcement that the thoroughbreds of the C.V. Whitney racing string are to be trained in Kentucky after the coming season, and that the lease on Brookdale, the farm near Red Bank, K.J., will not be renewed portends a break in a turf tradition which stretches back for three-quarters of a century, and which links America, to France and England, and the present days to those of Lexington and Lecompte.

NOT many days ago a jaunty figure stepped off one of the Italian liners. Her silhouette was distinctive because of its resemblance to a capital "T," with square shoulders and narrow hips, and her perky hat was worn well over the right ear.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 4 -- Working as a soda clerk at a Hollywood Boulevard fountain for $18 a week, Raymond Haas, 29 years old, for ten years assistant cashier of the engineering firm of Ford, Bacon Davis, Inc., of 39 Broadway, New York City, was arrested today on a fugitive warrant charging him with the theft of $135,000 in cash from his former employers.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 4. -- Three days before his entire line of regulars is supposed to begin training and ten days before the Yankees are scheduled to battle the Boston Braves In their first Spring exhibition game. Manager Joe McCarthy finds himself in the unique position of being without the services of six hold-outs.

MEMPHIS, Tenn., March 2 -- With the repeal sentiment expressed last November holding firm and even showing slight growth the militant drys in Arkansas, Mississippi and Tennessee have abandoned all efforts to delay submission, which a month ago was seriously considered, and have turned their attention to the maintenance of the State prohibition laws.

HAVANA. -- The last week of the racing meet is at hand, and with hotels and tourist centres filled with guests the indications are that the Cuban Grand National Handicap next Sunday will draw an exceptionally large crowd.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- This date, which has meant so much in the history of the United States, will henceforth be an ordinary day in the calendar. The hopes, the fears, the triumph and bitterness which March 4 has represented will be the emotions of Jan. 20, 1936, and quadrennially thereafter unless Congress shall one day change the length of the Presidential term.

Twenty-five years ago was begun an experiment which has been characterized as a "new epoch in Protestant history." For nearly four hundred years the trend had been in the direction of multiplying denominations and accentuating differences in polity or creed.

CHARLESTON, S. C. -- The famous gardens of Charleston are just entering the height of the blossom season and from now until April 10 will be viewed in all their glory by thousands of visitors who come to see the annual display.

ROME, Feb. 20, 1933. THE twenty-fifth anniversary of the founding of symphony concerts at the Augusteo of Rome has just been celebrated with a double ceremony. The first was held Feb. 15 at the Augusteo before a gala audience including the King, Queen, royal Princesses, diplomatic corps and political authorities, as well as personalities of Italian music, art and letters.

Characterizing in discriminate price-cutting as the least effective form of selling and the most destructive force in business today, Kenneth M. Goode, advertising consultant to the Biow Company and author of several books, declared yesterday that a continuance of the practice will "bleod white" indiustry and trade and greatly retard recovery.
PARIS, Feb. 22 -- French photographers will this year observe the 100th anniversary of the death of Joseph Nicephore Niepce, whom they consider as one of the inventors of photography.

Urging immediate unification of commercial banks under the Federal Reserve Bank, a self-imposed insurance tax on deposits and anticipatory loans by Federal Reserve Banks on non-liquid assets of banks which would guarantee the depositors against losses, Paul P. Gourrich, economist, in a statement Issued yesterday on the banking crisis, suggests that Federal Reserve Banks be guaranteed in turn against possible losses on such anticipatory loans by the Reconstruction Finance Corporation.

AT the recent meeting of the American Institute of Electrical Engineers in New York Dr. Joseph Sleplan and Leon R. Ludwig of the Westinghouse laboratories told a remarkable story of how, with the aid of an ordinary lead pencil, they had solved a problem of long standing -- of starting and controlling electric arcs.

In a letter to executives of the American Wholesale Grocers Association, Paul S. Willis, president of the Associated Grocery Manufacturers of America, yesterday explained that his group is unwilling to support the proposed law advocated by jobbers which would prohibit either producers or distributers of grocery products from selling goods "below cost."

ATHENS, Feb. 16 -- In memory of Charles P. Howland, president of its board of American trustees who was killed in an automobile accident in Connecticut, Athens College has received from Stephen Deltas, Greek treasurer of the Greco-American preparatory school on the outskirts of Athens, the funded endowment of an annual prize.

THE little Tennessee mountain town of Glen Hazard needs no introduction by this time to the readers of Maristan Chapman. It is an Isolated and very small town, a scattering of gray bouses lying, like seed thrown by an idle wind, in a sharp valley, with Cragg Hill towering to the west and Red Hill to the east.

PARIS, March 4 -- The leading editorials in all Parisian newspapers today are devoted to President Roosevelt's Inauguration. No President has taken power amid such intense interest on the part of Europe generally, and France particularly, for France has a greater stake than any other country in what Mr. Roosevelt is going to do in the next few days.

A 300-YEAR-OLD school, the oldest private school on Manhattan Island, begins today a three-day celebration of its founding. Collegiate School, established in 1633, traces its history through the stirring days of New Amsterdam's early life when Wall Street was a wilderness and City Hall Park a "hide-out for Indians."

CHENGTEH (Jehol City), Manchuria, March 4 (AP). -- Early this morning, when it appeared inevitable that this city would fall into the hands of the Japanese within a few hours, hundreds of the people who live here were crowding through the southern gates headed for the Great Wall on the way to Peiping.

At a peaceful and orderly demonstration, about 10,000 Communists and sympathizers met in Union Square yesterday afternoon and listened to speakers who demanded unemployment insurance and more adequate relief from the city, State and Federal governments.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- The seventh Saturday in history on which the nation has inaugurated its President was chalked up in the books of time today, along with the notation that the second Roosevelt took the office on the same day of the week.

Thoroughbred horses that have never pawed the tanbark of Madison Square Garden or the turf of fashionable country estates mil be exhibited to the public gaze at the International Horse Show of Art to be held at the Knoedler Galleries, 14 East Fifty-seventh Street, from March 20 to April 1 for the benefit of the social service department of Memorial Hospital.

CHANGES more drastic than those that took place with the passage by Congress of the Watres act are foreseen if the new amendment to the airmail act, Introduced by Representative Clyde Kelly of Pennsylvania, becomes a law.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 4 -- From the large collection of Roosevelt silver which has been selected from the Mabel Brady Garvan Collections, the Yale Gallery of Fine Arts today opened an exhibition in honor of President Roosevelt.

THIS contribution to the literature of the depression first appeared serially in the pages of Life, and is now offered to the public in permanent form accompanied by embellishments from the hand of Soglow done in his wellknown rowdy manner.

THAT nobility of spirit which shone clearly through all the work at John Galsworthy and that wrote itself upon his face strikes the dominant note in this collection of essays and addresses. Such, in the phrase which he himself employs to describe that flavor of personality which informs the best work of every artist, was his own "flower of author."

A warning against fear resulting from the bank holiday was sounded yesterday by the Rev. Dr. Samuel Schulman in his sermon on "President and People" at Temple Emanu-El, Fifth Avenue and Sixty-fifth Street, in which he called for cooperation by all the people with President Roosevelt, adding that "the confidence which the people place in the new President is an expression of its own self-confidence."

GENEVA, March 3 -- There is an acute contrast between the methods the League of Nations powers and the United States are favoring in their joint efforts to achieve on both sides of the Pacific the same goal of enforcing the covenant and the Pact of Paris.

A NEW President of the United States - the thirty-first, so the inaugural invitations said -- has entered the White House. He occupies the most important elective office in the world. What view will he take of its duties and opportunities?

Calling attention to the various tax and financial problems of the State at the present time, the New York State Association of Real Estate Boards advocates, among other things, a sales tax as one method of relief to the overburdened realty owner.

The all-New York private schools' girls' basketball team was selected yesterday after a morning of strenuous tryouts. A second team was also chosen from the twenty-four girls who had been assigned to compete for positions. The tests were conducted at the American Woman's Association Building.

REPORTS have it that the "sunshine saloon," a type of car popular in England, may soon be introduced in this country. This is described as a closed model whose top may be rolled back in the manner of the old-fashioned roll-top desk.

IN its recent report the Joint Committee of Railroads and Highway Users laid down the following policy: "The apportionment of special taxes among motor vehicles of various types should be based upon use of facilities required, and should be sufficient to pay their fair share of total annual costs."

SEVERAL correspondents have written THE TIMES, asking whether rumors of extravagance in the management of the Metropolitan Opera Association, especially in the form of excessive salaries paid celebrated artists, were true.

ANOTHER of those charming, semi-travel, semi-short story volumes Mrs. Kelly does so delightfully. "Arabesque" will not disappoint those who have enjoyed its predecessors. Romantic, full of exotic sights and sounds as any one could wish, it is concerned with the adventures of various individuals.

SCOTTSBORO, Ala., March 4. -- Scottsboro's little brick court house where a, death sentence was pronounced less than two years age that brought protests from all over the world, is to see the beginning of a new phase in the famous "Scottsboro case" Monday.

ALBANY, March 4. -- Dr. Ernest H. Cole, Acting Commissioner of Education, today refused to call a district meeting to select a new name for what is now known locally as the Malverne High School in District 12, town of Hempstead, Nassau County.

Tracy H. Lewis triumphed in the seventh annual metropolitan all-around trapshooting championship over the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic Club yesterday. He took the shoot by breaking 181 out of a possible 200 targets.

Because of the wide interest manifested in the architectural competition for a unified program of development for Queens Boulevard the borough planning committee of the Queensboro Chamber of Commerce has extended the time for registration to March 15 and set March 30 as the closing date for submission of sketches.

CHICAGO, March 4 -- Closing of American grain exchanges on account of bank holidays in the leading States resulted In a heavy volume of business in Winnipeg today, the Canadian market as well as Liverpool being open as usual. Chicago and New York interests were reported as free buyers in Winnipeg and under talk of a large export business prices advanced rather sensationally, the October at the top showing 3 cents above Friday's finish.
Yours be the pathlesmess beyond the West;

PANAMA, Feb. 28 -- The agreement between President Sacasa of Nicaragua and General Cesar Augusto Sandino, by which the latter ends his revolutionary activities and, as he says, "becomes the rigrht-hand man of President Sacasa," will be a serious blow to professional anti-American agitators and propagandists in Latin America.

WASHINGTON, March 4 (AP) -- Left briefly in the White House after the Hoovers departed was the unpublicized but interesting woman who has been their housekeeper and custodian for four years, Mrs. Ava Long.

PEIPING, China, Jan. 22 -- The fact that the process of partitioning China is actually well under way becomes evident after a trip through Manchuria followed by a fortnight of observation of men and events in North China.

SHANGHAI, Jan. 31 -- In addition to the very considerable opposition existing within the Kuomintang party to the resumption of diplomatic relations between China and Soviet Russia, two large and important geographical areas have taken exception to this new development of the Nanking Government's diplomacy.

Despite several years' continuous decline in traffic, the New York Central Railroad maintained in 1932 its leadership in passenger revenue in the United States, L.W. Landman, general passenger traffic manager, said yesterday. Its passenger revenue, excluding the proceeds from mail, express and milk carriage, was $60,151,922, a decrease of $26,152,586, or 30.3 per cent, from 1931, and a decrease of 54.1 per cent from passenger revenue of $131,062,257 in 1929.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 4 -- Four gunmen held up a policeman and three employes in the offices of the A.R. Hyde Sons Company, shoe manufacturers, East Cambridge, today and escaped with the payroll of $13,000.

WHEN Governor Lehman asked the Legislature last week to provide for the setting up of "adequate machinery for the effective regulation and maintenance of minimum fair-wage standards" he was acting in line with a widespread movement to check the return of sweatshops in American industry.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- The White House was the scene tonight of a ceremony without precedent in the history of the nation. It was the swearing in of the nine men and one woman who comprise the Cabinet of President Roosevelt.

Though it is less than two weeks since Congress approved the resolution for repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment, several States have already started action. Either by one branch of the Legislature or both, bills providing for a constitutional convention have been adopted in Michigan, Indiana, Wisconsin, Wyoming, Montana, Arkansas and Idaho.

The shutters were closed yesterday on the big Wall Street banks and the banking department of the Federal Reserve Bank was locked and barred, but inside the banks there was no holiday for the financial leaders, although many of them were heavy-eyed from fortyeight hours of almost uninterrupted labor to stop the spreading banking crisis before it reached New York.

HOLLYWOOD. AFTER four years' absence from the screen. Colleen Moore has been engaged for the part of the wife in Preston Sturges's "The Power and the Glory," which went before the cameras this week at Fox.

ANNAPOLIS, Md., March 4 -- While 6,000 persons looked on, Navy's basketball team decisively defeated the Army quintet today, 51 to 24. The crowd, which included the regiment of midshipmen, was the largest ever to attend a basketball game in this section.

The pamphlet report of H.M. Byllesby Co. for 1932, which gives effect to a reduction in capital made last month, shows total assets of $12,228,566 at the close of the year. Assets include $6,600,000 investment in 330,000 shares of Standard Power and Light Corporation series B shares, pledged to secure notes payable in July, 1935, and $163,935 other investments.

WITH the full record for 1932 now available, air transportation has definitely established its position as the industry that ignored the depression. The staff of Aviation has just completed an elaborate survey of the current position of the aviation business, at home and abroad, with the ultimate object of preparing a pictorial presentation that would tell the whole story at a series of brief glances.

Several small lots of municipal bonds, for redemption this month, and entire issues of two public utility companies and one industrial concern, for payment in future months, constituted the principal additions made last week to the list of bonds called for payment before their dates of maturity.

TWO ocean currents profoundly affect the climates of Japan and Eastern Siberia. One, the warm Tsushima current, flows north through the Korea Strait into the Sea of Japan, washes the shores of the Japanese Islands Honshu and Hokkaido, and thus accounts for their agreeable climate.

ONCE royalty, always royalty. Even so, fourteen years after the World War's havoc among the crowns, one might paraphrase the ancient saying. "Once a Bourbon, always a Bourbon." For the Bourbon, as he was when the apothegm was coined, has disappeared from the face of the earth, but his spirit, somewhat paler and much chastened, still lives.

WARRENTON, Va. -- The Fauquier County Historical Society, of which H. C. Groome is president, has given a marker to be placed in the grounds of the Warren Green Hotel here. In style it is uniform with those used by the Virginia Road Commission.

LONDON, March 4. -- President Roosevelt cannot be too aggressive to satisfy British opinion, judging from the general comments on the inauguration available today. Editors here are unanimous in calling for instant action, and it matters comparatively little to them what that action is so long as it restores some measure of confidence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is nothing amazing in the statement recently made by Professor Robert L. Ramsay of the University of Missouri concerning the number of words in the English language. Professor Ramsay is of the type that excludes from the language as words what he is pleased to term "subordinate words, special combinations and obvious combinations."

THE Cabinet which takes office with President Roosevelt is the forty-third in the history of the Republic, counting as a distinct Cabinet each group of advisers called to serve with a President as he began a full or part term.
PEIPING, Sunday, March 5. -- Jehol is lost through treachery.

It is of great Importance that the public should understand not only what the unexpected application in New York of the banking moratorium means, but what it does not mean. One very unfortunate aspect of the moratorium expedient is that it gives opportunity for any inference, however alarming and however unfounded, as to the reason for adopting it.

"There are no miracles in fish and game propagation," according to William C. Adams, director of the Division of Fish and Game of the New York Conservation Department. Instead, he says, successful propagation comes from hard work and a first-class business administration.

WE of the twentieth century are fond of saying that we do not live in an age of faith. But when one visits Lourdes, that little, remote town in the foothills of the Pyrenees to which a million pious pilgrims from all parts of the Christian world flock every year, one begins to feel less sure.

DETROIT. THE automotive industry is getting ready for its annual Spring offensive. This year's sales drive, however, will lack the element of coordination which was so prominent in the effort which the industry made last year to break the buying deadlock.

More than 3,000,000 business calls and nearly 40,000 inquiries from persons seeking information, is the record of THB NEW YORK TIMES telephone department for 1932. This is disclosed in a report made yesterday by T. L. Jackson, traffic service representative of The New York Telephone Company, which calls attention to the high standards of service being maintained by THE TIMES private branch exchange.

Frederic G. Elton, district director of the Rehabilitation Bureau of the New York State Department of Education, will address the Men's League in Aid of Crippled Children on March 21 in the Hotel Marcy, 720 West End Avenue. The league, which was organized about ten years ago, offers vocational guidance and provides funds for subsidies and vocational training to orthopedically handicapped children.

THIS poet's novel tells the story of a young man who comes to New York as a drifter without money and without friends, and who, after many turns of fortune, ends as a young American composer of promise. Don is talented, has a fine voice and Is devoted to his music.
PIERRE, S.D., March 2. -- The revamping of the State tax system looms as the paramount issue in South Dakota's Democratic-controlled Legislature.

MONTREAL, March 4 -- Newsy Lalonde's Montreal Canadiens took undisputed possession of third place In the International group of the National Hockey League tonight, shutting out the New York Americans, 2-0, in a rough game before a near-capacity crowd of 11,500.

ASHEVILLE, N.C., March 4 (AP) -- Loser in a race with time, Cornelius McGillicuddy, veteran Philadelphia baseball pilot, was expected here today for the task of assisting in arranging the funeral of his daughter, Mrs. Margaret McCambridge.
Los Nanduces returned to winning ways in indoor polo at Squadron A Armory last night, winning a close, hard-fought game from the Crusaders, 12 1/2 to 10 1/2.

Marking the Salvation Army's eighteenth annual observance of "Prison Sunday," the organization is holding more than 200 special religious services today in penal institutions through its Eastern territory. They include addresses and musical selections by Salvation Army officers, with voluntary attendance and the privilege extended to prisoners of talking to officers after the services.

A survey of the activities of the American Bureau of Shipping in supervising ship repairs and construction in the last ten years shows that 966 vessels of 2,593,615 tons have been registered for classification under the direction of its engineers and technical experts.

THE Fox Film Corporation last week gave a private showing of a film made of a special stage performance of "Cavalcade" in the Drury Lane Theatre, London. This photograph of the Noel Coward play served the producers as a guide in making the actual picture, which is now on view at the Gaiety.

In order to raise funds for carrying on their many philanthropic enterprises, members of the Trinity College Alumnae Association will hold their annual bridge party and fashion show on Saturday afternoon at the St. Regis.

In France, as in other countries, somebody is always asking: Are people reading 1 a than they used to? What are people reading? Are there too many novels? The production of books has fallen less in the United States than in France. In the latter the number published in 1913 was 11,460; in 1931.

PHOENIX, Ariz., March 2. -- Arizona recently suddenly found itself confronted with a revival of the Colorado River argument, which has been quiescent since the United States Supreme Court decision authorizing construction of Hoover Dam.

WASHINGTON. March 4 -- John N. Garner became Vice President at 12:01 o'clock this afternoon in a brief and solemn ceremony which contrasted severely with the genial air that pervaded the House of Representatives thirty minutes before, when as Speaker of the House he adjourned that body sine die.

Conflicting rumors it proposed changes in the personnel of the United States Shipping Board, coincident with the change of the Federal administration, have flooded shipping circles in recent weeks. Nominees for the three places on the board have been advanced by their supporters and some embarrassment has resulted because of the unwillingness of some men to be considered for appointment.

KANSAS CITY, March 4 (AP) -- The Legislatures of Missouri, Kansas, Texas and Oklahoma moved swiftly today to cope with the financial situation in those States brought about by the declaration of banking moratoria.

WASHINGTON, March 4. -- Bank debits outside New York City increased during the week ended Feb. 25, but were 12 per cent under a year ago and had dropped 20 per cent since Jan. 1, according to the domestic business survey, made public today by the Commerce Department.

MIAMI, Fla., March 4. -- Sitting in the dugout at Miami Field today after motoring from Waycross, Ga., last night, Joseph A. Gilleaudeau, vice president and treasurer of the Brooklyn club, watched the athletes with generally approving eye and at the same time shed light on the hold-out situation.

BUENOS AIRES, March 4 -- "Few times in history has any change in government aroused a world-wide expectation approaching that caused by today's ceremonies in Washington," says the newspaper La Prensa today, striking the keynote of Argentine comment upon the accession of Franklin D. Roosevelt to the Presidency of the United States.

In connection with the inauguration of President Roosevelt, the New York Historical Society, 170 Central Park West, has placed on exhibition a selected collection of original books, printings and pictures dealing with the inauguration of George Washington as first President of the United States on April 30, 1789.

THROUGH the many biographies and autobiographies published during the past decade, even the most persistent adherent of the land has, almost in spite of himself, become at least passably acquainted with the sett and with ships.
WARSAW, March 3 -- The new Polish Foreign Minister, Colonel Joseph Beck, has been revealed during his four months in office as a realistic and cautious diplomat.
Franklin D. Roosevelt becomes the ninth President of the United States who has been a communicant of the Protestant Episcopal Church.

Closer cooperation among property owners, better management of buildings and standardization of rentals are needed to stabilize real estate values, in the opinion of Philip A. Benson, president of the Dime Savings Bank of Brooklyn.

LONDON, March 3. -- Britain's arms embargo against Japan and China was bitterly denounced today as a "silly and futile expedient" by General Sir Ian Hamilton, who was commander of the troops in the Dardanelles campaign and is one of the foremost pacifists in the British Army.
The Banking Situation. The New York Clearing House Association prepared to print and issue certificates to be used by the public as substitute money.

THERE having been no notable additions to the list of "Parsifal" disks since this was surveyed here about a year ago, there remains only "Tristan und Isolde" and a few recordings of non-operatic compositions to complete the review of Wagner for the gramophone as it is available today.

Two armed men walked yesterday afternoon into the establishment of S. Wyler, Inc., dealers in old English silver and jewelry, at 713 Madison Avenue, held up Sigmund Wyler, the proprietor, and his son Seymour and escaped with jewelry that the police tentatively estimated at between $25,000 and $50,000.

Quite independent of the rise an fall in the cost of living, an Industrial revolution has been going on in Greater London for the last ten years, with producers and merchants shifting their centres of gravity and thus indirectly altering the character of their environment.

Emphasis upon liberal extension of credit through charge accounts to assist customers in the emergency created by the closing of local banks was decided upon yesterday at a meeting of executives of leading local stores held at the Empire State Club under the auspices of the Retail Dry Goods Association of New York.

The leading women, squash racquets players of New York, New Jersey, Westcheater and Long Island will take part in the metropolitan singles championship to be held on the courts of the Junior League beginning Tuesday and in the team matches tomorrow.

LAKE PLACID. -- This week-end special trains are bringing many visitors from New York and other mid-State cities 40 Lake Placid for a ten-day ski party. Many are joining friends here for this month of "shirt-sleeve skiing," when the Season's deepest snows have covered the mountain sides and the penetrating sun's rays bestow a coat of tropical tan.

The Lenten sewing class that works in behalf of the New York Nursery and Child's Hospital will have its initial meeting for this season on Thursday morning at the home of Mrs. Frank S. Witherbee, the treasurer, 10 East Seventy-first Street.

The board of managers decided to close the Cotton Exchange during the New York State bank holiday and following the closing of the New Orleans Exchange on Thursday, there was no cotton trading in futures yesterday. The possibility of such action had been foreshadowed by the retreat of the floating short interest in the various speculative markets and the sharp rise in prices on Friday.

Among the operatic and theatrical leaders who sailed yesterday for Europe on the French liner Paris were Mme. Sigrid Onegin, Swedish contralto, and Armand Tokatyan, Armenian tenor, both of the Metropolitan Opera Association, and Guthrie McClintic, who recently produced Sidney Howard's "Alien Corn," in which his wife, Katharine Cornell, is starring.

Declines in the number of motor vehicles registered in New York State and in the amount of fees collected during 1932, as compared with 1931 are noted in the annual report of Charles A. Harnett, Commissioner of Motor Vehicles, made public yesterday.

AMONG the designs for modern housing projects displayed in the annual exhibition of the Architectural League now in progress in the American Fine Arts Building is one by George W. Sabiel, architect, showing sectional views of a 200-home suburban residential development project for a site in Westchester County.

TOLEDO, Ohio THE force which "credits" and the payment of fees exert toward keeping college students at their studies has been measured, in part at least, by attendance figures for the first semester of the "Opportunity College" of the University of Toledo, revealed in the report just made for the term.

IN choosing Mr. Strother to record the "performances" and "achievements" of his administration Mr. Hoover found an advocate exuberant and enthusiastic for his chief. The "record" as presented by Mr. Strother discloses a type of writing that is powerful in expression, gracious in phrase and highly interesting in what it does not say.

Breaking 93 out of 100 targets, F. Dufficy captured the High Scratch Cup at the Travers Island traps of the New York Athletic dub yesterday. It was the best score in a field of twenty-six gunners, who were handicapped by a high wind that sent the targets into difficult shooting angles.
Small dwellings and flats were sold over the week-end in New Jersey.

BUENOS AIRES, March 5. --- Wheat rose sharply the equivalent of 1 cent a bushel here Saturday morning in sympathy with Friday's strengthening in Chicago, and closed 5.10 pesos a quintal or 35 3/4 cents a bushel, compared with 5 pesos a quintal, or 34 3/4 cents a bushel on Friday, and 5.5 pesos a quintal, or 35 3/4 cents a bushel the previous Saturday.
HAVANA, March 5 -- (AP). -- Mrs. A.J. Pershall's Malolo defeated a small but select field to win the Grand Drawing Handicap, $2,500 added, at Oriental Park today.

PARIS, March 5. -- Frenchmen eagerly snatched the special editions of the Paris dailies from the hands of shouting news vendors late tonight, then in moat cases threw down the papers with expressions of disgust. It was obvious they expected or at least hoped for a popular electoral reaction against the Hitler dictatorship in Germany.
NEW YORK. The Hon. Mrs. lan Napier, daughter of Lord and Lady Essenden, is expected tomorrow on the Olympic and will be at the Madison.

Jehol has been overrun by the Japanese forces in ten days. It was less a campaign than a military procession. On the face of the news, Chinese resistance was of the very slightest. What is of more importance, there was no serious intention in high quarters, either at Peiping or at Nanking, to make a defense.

If ridicule can succeed where reason fails, the Committee for Modification of Veterans' Preference should have no difficulty in bringing about the desired change in the absurd system which now prevails, under which a veteran may enjoy all the benefits of ability and disability at the same time.

Mr. HOOVER'S last official act as President was to refuse to sign the largest appropriation bill voted by Congress. It was the measure making funds available for the various "independent" offices in Washington, including the most important single spending agency of the Government -- the Veterans' Administration.

To the Editor of The New York Times: The urgent need of the hour is to provoke thought toy the people of the United States on vital public issues. THE NEW YORK TIMES performed a great public service in devoting three columns to its special report of Mr. Untermyer's California address.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Today hope for America and for all the world lies in the ideals of Woodrow Wilson, Josephus Daniels declared in an address at memorial services for the wartime President held in Washington Cathedral this afternoon.

NO matter what the situation is elsewhere, there must have been considerable merriment in a certain section of Florida recently. Jolly Gene Sarazen was the cause of it. He is always doing something to attract attention.

LONDON, Monday, March 6. -- All England is ringing with applause of President Roosevelt's speech, finding it has the spirit of courage in the midst of depressing times. Judging from the enthusiasm of this morning's newspapers, the speech has appealed to the British public as has no utterance of any President since Woodrow Wilson.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 5. -- Bank holidays temporarily may tighten the money situation in New York and the country over, but they will not affect Babe Ruth's appraisal of his value to the Yankees or his negotiations with Colonel Jacob Ruppert, owner of the world's champions.

Launching a fast three-goal attack in the opening period and scoring 3 more points in the final session, the St. Nicks defeated the Philadelphia Comets, 6 to 1, at Madison Square Garden yesterday before a crowd of 4,000. This marked the final amateur hockey game at the Garden before the national championships start next Sunday.
LONDON, March 5. -- The financial markets of London are expected to be open as usual tomorrow, with banking leaders determined to keep cool in the face of the banking emergency in the United States.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- Tommy Goodwin of Monroe, N.Y., the 19-year-old New York State titleholder, successfully defended his Dixie golf championship over the Miami Country Club course today by defeating Lee Chase of Buffalo, N.Y., in the thirty-six-hole final round, 1 up.

ESSEX, Conn., March 5. -- Wind, that grand old harper, tuned its strings to high tension today in the final racing of the inaugural Eastern Frostbite dinghy regatta on the bulge of the Connecticut River here.

John E. Ramsey, general manager of the Port of New York Authority, who accepted a loan of $10,020 from an executive of the National City Company in June, 1931, about the time that company floated a loan of $66,000,000 for the Port Authority, has tendered his resignation, it was announced last night.

The American Smelting and Refining Company reports for 1932 a net loss of $4,506,175 after all charges and taxes and reserves for depreciation and depletion. This compares with a net profit of $874,976 or $1.75 a share on the 500,000 shares of 7 per cent cumulative preferred stock of $100 par value.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Participating in the American Legion national radio broadcast tonight, President Roosevelt, speaking from his library in the White House, in his first radio talk as Chief Executive, urged all American Legion men and all others to make the same sacrifice in the present emergency as in wartime.

Scoring an easy 46-to-22 victory over Cornell at New Haven on Saturday, Yale finished its season in the Eastern Intercollegiate Basketball League race with a record of eight games won and two lost and is now assured of at least a tie for the title.

Nine modern French artists are represented by water-colors, pastels or drawings in the current exhibition at the Pierre Matisse Gallery. Maillol, Rouault, Severini, Matisse, Dufy, Lurcat, Masson, Gromaire and Picasso are the companions in the show, and the works date from early in the century down to the present.

LONDON, March 4. -- This week's London stock markets were completely overshadowed by International affairs. The American financial situation, the upheaval in Germany, with the anxieties attached to the approaching election, and, in addition, the uncertainties of the Far Eastern conflict produced an atmosphere quite adverse to the security markets.

CHICAGO, March. 5. -- Unprecedented conditions in banking and business have caused uneasiness and a slowing down in some lines here, while others were little affected. The question of the ability of buyers to obtain money to pay off commitments, is uppermost in all lines of trade, and has made sellers indifferent about soliciting new business.
Governor Lehman received without comment just before last midnight the Presidential proclamation closing all banks until Thursday.

PEIPING, March 5 (AP) -- Japanese airplanes today bombed Chinese concentrations at several points in Jehol Province as the forces of Marshal Chang Hsiaoliang fell back to positions a few miles to the north of Koupei pass through the Great Wall leading to Northern China.

SHANGHAI, Monday, March 6. -- While members of the Nanking Government are expected to discuss a unified policy at Peiping this week, Jehol reports today tell of indescribable confusion among the Chinese forces there, with thousands killed, wounded and missing among the troops in Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's best brigades, which originally totaled 20,000.

BERLIN, March. 3. -- Industrial enterprise in Germany has been checked by the electoral campaign. The Institute for Studying Trade Fluctuations, in its quarterly report, says that since November there has been distinct reaction in consumption industries, buyers being evidently frightened at political developments.

Under the modified bonus plan, which was adopted at the last meeting of stockholders, no payments were made in 1932 to officers and heads of departments of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation, according to the annual report of the corporation, released for publication today.
Steel operations were reduced two more points last week to 15 per
Herbert Hoover spent his first day in four years away from the cares of official Washington yesterday and he apparently enjoyed it.

The volume and variety of traffic at the union inland freight terminal operated by the Eastern trunk line railroads at Eighth Avenue and Fifteenth Street reached a new high mark in February, according to the monthly bulletin of the Port of New York Authority, issued yesterday.

In the Bible from start to finish, religion is not man's quest for God, but man's response to God's search for him, the Rev. Dr. Henry Sloane Coffin, president of the Union Theological Seminary, said in his sermon yesterday at the James Memorial Chapel, 120th Street and Broadway.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Shippers of hogs are regulating supplies sent to packing points in a way that gives them a fairly good control of the market. With the competition between local packers and Eastern shippers, a few days' break was followed by an upturn in prices.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The Governors conference which President Roosevelt called nearly a month ago to discuss with him interlocking governmental problems will meet with him tomorrow morning in the White House at 11 o'clock.

HAVANA, March 5. -- A three-day bank holiday for all banks in Cuba, effective tomorrow morning and continuing through Wednesday, was decreed today by President Machado. It is understood the action was taken at the request of the Havana Clearing House as a result of similar holidays in the United States and especially in New York.

Praise for President Roosevelt's promised "new deal" and pleas for support of the new administration in its efforts to lift the nation out of the depression were voiced yesterday morning in many pulpits throughout the city. Many clergymen lauded the President's inaugural address and hailed him as a real leader in whom the people can safely repose full confidence.

TRENTON, N.J., March 5. -- An indefinite extension of the banking holiday in New Jersey was directed tonight by Governor A. Harry Moore. He indicated that the extension would last until the Federal Government has put into effect its program to meet the emergency.

AVALON, Catalina Island, Cal., March 5. -- Apparently it took the Giants only twenty-four hours of the exhibition-game schedule to regain their old form, for they dropped their second contest with the Cubs today, 3 to 2, in a manner strangely reminiscent of their fretful days of 1932.

DUBLIN, March 5. -- There was a riot today in the village of Drumsna in County Leitrim when an attempt was made to hold a meeting protesting against the Free State order for the deportation of James Gralton, a native of the district who now is an American citizen.

TOKYO, March 5. -- Rengo (Japanese) news agency dispatches from Chengteh (Jehol City) today said the final phase of the Japanese campaign in Jehol Province, a move to seize passes in the Great Wall north and northeast of Peiping, was producing some of the most bitter fighting of the whole drive.

Scoring fifteen, points in his team's two meets during the week, Ray Thompson, navy swimmer, went into a tie for first place with Eugene Jennings of Columbia in the individual standing in the Intercollegiate Swimming Association race. Both have thirty-seven points.

PEIPING, China, March 5. -- We drove today from Peiping through, the Antingmen "Gate of Ever Victorious Peace" and out the Jehol Road. The streets were empty of rickshaws. Camels and pony chairs are now being impressed for military transport, or hidden for fear they will be impressed.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt attended services this morning at St. Thomas's Episcopal Church, Eighteenth and Church Streets, Northwest, which will regularly be the President's place of worship.

Nine lines of verse on death and war are part of an unusual printed acknowledgment that friends who sent letters of condolence to the family of the late John Galsworthy. English novelist and playwright, who died on Jan. 31, are receiving from Mrs. John Galsworthy and Mr. and Mrs. R.H. Sauter, nephew and niece of the writer.

The Spectators Oxford correspondent writes that the hard times haven't thinned the number of undergraduates, but that they are less careless and more frugal than of old. Luncheon and dinner parties are rare. Short allowances make short commons.

Although Jimmy Durante has been in Hollywood, he retains enough of the old-time gusto to smash his way through "Strike Me Pink," which opened at the Majestic Saturday evening. Exibulant Jimmy still wears that broad grin and those shapeless hats, still stamps his foot excitedly and roars like a roisterous shipping clerk.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The text of President Roosevelt's proclamation on the banking situation, issued at the White House at 11 o'clock tonight, was as follows:

A cross-section analysis by questionnaire of the general building situation, with special reference to building financing and supply, has just been concluded by organized mill men of the lumber industry in the sixteen Northeastern States. The results of this survey as given to Allen E. Beals of the Dow Service Daily Building Reports Indicate that mortgage money in those States is not sufficient to take care of current building needs.

In a "salutation" to the new President, Aviation for March hails him as the first "ever to have" "flown either prior to or during" "his term of office." It deplores the fact that appropriations for "military" aviation have been reduced. This, of course, is leading up to an appeal to President ROOSEVELT to stand by army and navy aviation as a factor in the national defense.

MONTREAL, March 5. -- The 1932 financial statement of Frazer Companies, Ltd., mailed to shareholders at the week-end, reflects in the sharp decline in earnings continued extremely difficult conditions in the paper and lumber industry of Canada.

Mary Wigman in her farewell recital at the New Yorker Theatre last night made the prospect of her absence for two years seem doubly regrettable by giving a performance which, even judged by her own high standard, was of unusual brilliance.

BERLIN, Monday, March 6. -- With almost mathematical precision the results in yesterday's German elections for the Reichstag and the Prussian Diet bear out the predictions based on the pre-election campaign. Just as two and two make four, so suppression and intimidation have produced a Nazi-Nationalist triumph.

ALBANY, March 5. -- The banking situation occupied legislators' thoughts as they returned tonight for another week of sessions, and a possibility of rushing through special bills to relieve the stress was in prospect.

Maria Olszewska, a musician and singer superbly endowed by nature, and by nature a rarely gifted interpreter of poetical or dramatic texts, gave her first song recital in New York last night, in Carnegie Hall. Mme. Olszewaka's appearances in opera had given her a reputation which attracted a large audience.

The depression could be solved in twenty-four hours by a "good prayer meeting in Wall Street" at which the bankers and corporation heads would confess their sins, the Rev. Dr. Norman Vincent Peale, pastor of the Marble Collegiate Reformed Church, Fifth Avenue and Twenty-ninth Street, declared yesterday morning in his sermon there.

Bewildered but still cheerful, the city followed its usual routine yesterday, talked of the, possibility of using scrip instead of cash, but still patronized the movie theatres, restaurants and concert halls.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- Informed of President Roosevelt's declaration of a national banking holiday, Chicago financial leaders moved quickly during the night to provide in some fashion for the currency and credit needs of the community in the emergency.

A "Service of Thanksgiving" opening the celebration of the 300th anniversary of the Collegiate School of New York, the oldest school of its kind in the United States, the first sessions of which were held in the Battery, was held yesterday afternoon in the West End Collegiate Reformed Church, Seventy-seventh Street and West End Avenue.

PITTSBURGH, March 5. -- Demand for steel began to decrease nearly three weeks ago and the decrease has increased. After three weeks of production of ingots at about 19 per cent of capacity, production last week was not above 17 per cent.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One of the reasons for the financial crisis in the United States is the widespread hoarding, both of gold and of currency, which has been going on. Particularly has the withdrawal of gold, one of the bases of our currency, been a serious blow to the national credit.

When a sharp attack of disease occurs, the demand for prompt remedies arises. These the authorities at Washington are doing their best to supply. President ROOSEVELT could not have foreseen that the opening of his Administration would coincide with the closing of nearly all the banks in the country.

The Citizens Budget Commission made public yesterday summaries of its revised bills for consolidating the city's twelve pension systems. The commission has contended that reforms in the systems would save the pity $5,000,000 of the $29,000,000 it spends for pensions annually.

Faith in the ability of President Roosevelt to meet the problems of the present economic situation is expressed by Jesse Isidor Straus, president of R.H. Macy Co., in an advertisement published this morning.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- To prevent the export, hoarding or earmarking of gold or silver, coin or bullion or currency, President Roosevelt issued a proclamation at 11 o'clock tonight, in which he ordered a bank holiday from tomorrow through Thursday, March 9.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Mrs. Roosevelt motored to Mount Vernon this afternoon, taking a party that included nearly all the members of her family and a few friends, and on her return entertained at tea a group of women from the New York campaign headquarters.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 5. -- In compliment to Mr. and Mrs. Philip A.S. Franklin of New York, who are spending the Winter at the Boca Raton Club, Mr. and Mrs. Willard S. Brown entertained with a luncheon for forty persons today at the Club Beach.

BERLIN, March 5 (AP) -- Although Berlin was outwardly quiet throughout the voting hours today, there was considerable tenseness here. This was indicated in a measure by a widespread rumor to the effect that President von Hindenburg had spent the afternoon with troops of the Reichswehr at Doeberitz, outside Berlin, and that Lieut. Gen. Werner von Blomberg, the Minister of Defence, had taken a special oath.

Lieutenant Frank Toomey and Fireman Stephen McArdle etched their names yesterday morning on the Fire Department's roll of honor by rescuing eleven firemen, including the veteran Battalion Chief Michael F. Ruddy, after they had been trapped by flames and furnace-like heat in a tenth-floor apartment at 315 Central Park West.

The city's budget of $518,427,972 for 1933 was prepared almost exclusively by Mayor O'Brien although the Board of Estimate never rescinded its action of last October depriving the Mayor's office of the budget-making power, it was disclosed yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Secretary of the Treasury William H. Woodin declared tonight emphatically that the United States had not gone off the gold standard on account of the proclamation of the President. He was supported in this view by other high officials of the administration, both in the executive and legislative branches, among them Senator Key Pittman, chairman of the Committee on Foreign Relations.

CHICAGO, March 5. -- For the first time in its history on a regular business day, the Chicago Board of Trade held no session yesterday. Before it is reopened its officials hope to arrange with the banks a constructive policy. Men with $1,000 bills were there yesterday trying to get them exchanged for bills of smaller denominations.

The banking situation has created hesitancy on the part of the manufacturers and forced them to curtail operations almost to the point of producing only against actual orders. This development made it difficult last week to find desirable merchandise for prompt shipment in the wholesale markets.
NEW ORLEANS, March 5 (AP) -- A fair-sized crowd attended the fourth Sunday program of charity racing at the Fair Grounds track today as Le Ministre captured the feature event.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Berlin bankers expressed this week some apprehension that Thursday's advance in the New York Reserve Bank rate might precipitate a new wave of advances at the European central banks. They see no reason, however, why the Reichsbank should follow the movement, because the German rate in no way influences the international movement of funds, outflow of which is effectively prevented by the regulation of exchange.

Agreement seems to have been reached by the various sportsmen's organizations of the State regarding the conservation fund bill which was introduced some time ago in the Legislature at Albany. There were protests against the wording of the bill and because of this an amended form has been introduced by Assemblyman Steingut.

Among the exhibitions opening today in New York galleries is an exhibition of American water-colors at the Milch Galleries -- work of both the nineteenth and twentieth centuries. Sculpture in wood by Theodore Mistele is being shown by Cheshire House.

Abandoning the double standard of currency which it had attempted to establish in 1792 as a result of Alexander Hamilton's report to the Treasury, the "United States on Feb. 21, 1853, adopted the gold standard.
WASHINGTON, March 5. -- The votes in the Senate and House by the delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on important roll-calls last week were as follows:

DETROIT, March 5. -- Citizens of Detroit, entering upon their fourth bankless week, find just one satisfaction in their confused and uncertain financial situation. This comes to them as they see the other great cities of the nation embarking on bank holidays, and it is the same sort of satisfaction a sophomore feels as he watches a freshman diffidently seeking his way about a campus.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 5. -- L.A. Wilson, Assistant Commissioner, State Education Department, announced today that a meeting preparatory to the opening here of a free emergency day college would be held Wednesday evening at the White Plains Senior High School.

Only through organized good-will can the nations of the world attain real security and rid themselves of the fear which is one of the most significant factors of the depression, the Rev. Dr. Harry Emerson Fosdick declared yesterday morning in his sermon in the Riverside Church.

Police Commissioner Mulrooney sent an order yesterday to all precinct station houses restoring the old reserve system which was abolished with the introduction of police emergency crews in the five boroughs. The order takes effect this morning.

Clearing House certificates will be issued in New York, if needed, just as soon as they are printed, possibly today and probably not later than tomorrow, as a result of President Roosevelt's proclamation of last night.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- Four successive rounds under 70 enabled Paul Runyan of White Plains, N. Y., to win the 72-hole $5,000 open golf tournament at the Miami Biltmore Country Club at Coral Gables today, with a total of 266 strokes, to lead the field by en shots.

LONDON, Monday, March 6. -- The clear majority for Adolf Hitler's coalition government in the German election was just what had been expected and feared in England, especially in view of the ruthless intimidation of recent weeks.

BERLIN, March 3. -- Among the very numerous discussions of the American situation, the report of the Commerz und Privat Bank gives the judgment that Washington has seemed to be more interested in protecting the currency than in supporting weak banks.

Eviction proceedings against a huge grouper that weighs 350 pounds, has outgrown its tank, and is making it rather stuffy for two other groupers that occupy the same quarters, will be taken tomorrow morning by attendants of the New York City Aquarium, who look forward to a lively tussle.

The full story of the activities of Bernard Marcus and Saul Singer in expanding the Bank of United States in New York City, is told by M.R. Werner in "Little Napoleons and Dummy Directors," published today by Harpers.

Yale brought a team of opportunists to the Intercollegiate A.A. A.A. indoor track and field championships last Saturday. Capitalizing its potentialities to the fullest extent, the Eli combination dethroned a New York University team that was nowhere near as alert to seize its chances by the score of 32 points to 28.

ROME, March 5 (AP) -- The inaugural speech of President Roosevelt brought a decidedly favorable reaction in the Italian press, especially his declaration that he will seek extraordinary powers to deal with the situation if necessary.

ALBANY, March 5. -- With a virtual decision reached by the legislative leaders to defer consideration of the New York City charter legislation until after the budget and some pressing financial measures have been disposed of Senator Thomas C. Desmond of Orange, sponsor of the Seabury charter bill, announced today that he would take steps during the coming legislative week to bring that measure out of committee.

WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- From Henry T. Rainey, the next Speaker of the House, there came today positive assurances that "the Democratic party will make good its promises and legalize beer at the earliest possible moment." He added that it might be before April 1 and that, in any event, "it won't be many weeks."
MIAMI, Fla., Monday, March 6. -- Physicians of Mayor Anton Cermak early this morning relinquished hope for his life.

David Vardl and Eva Yoalit, who came here with the Moscow Habimah company and the former of whom also gained prominence for his direction of the English version of The Dybbuk at the Neighborhood Playhouse, presented a farewell program last night at the City College Auditorium before leaving for Europe.

The League of Composers' third concert of the season, which took place last night at the French Institute, presented compositions by graduates of the Curtis Institute of Philadelphia, the Eastman School of Music of Rochester and the Juilliard Graduate School of New York.

Grand opera at the Metropolitan "can no longer rely, as heretofore, upon a small group of rich men," Paul D. Cravath, chairman of the board of the Metropolitan Opera Association, declared yesterday in a broadcast from WJZ.

NEW ORLEANS, March 5. -- So many influences not directly connected with the cotton market combined to interfere with normal business here last week that trading was seriously restricted and finally discontinued at the end of the week by developments in the financial situation.

LONDON, March 2. -- It is long since the London foreign exchange market has witnessed activity comparable to that of the past week. The American banking situation, events in the Far East, and the confusing news from Germany, all of which started afresh an international movement of funds, have given rise to a feeling of uncertainty which was bound to find expression in the sterling exchange market.

The interborough soccer games which brought together the four major teams of Greater New York at Starlight Park yesterday both ended in 3 -- 3 ties. The Brooklyn Wanderers held the New York Field Club even and the New York Americans shared the honors with the Bohemian Queens.

The poor, who suffer most from its activities, often are led to support corrupt government by loyalty to some organization that gives a "random and well-advertised charity," the Rev. John C. Smyth declared at high mass yesterday morning in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Paul the Apostle, Columbus Avenue and Sixtieth Street.

NEW HAVEN, March 5. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55, which compares with 55.1 a week ago, 55.4 two weeks ago, 55.3 three weeks ago and 55.3 four weeks ago. The average of 57.4 in the first week of January was the highest of the year to date; this week's average is the lowest.

NEW HAVEN, March 5. -- Professor Irving Fisher's index number of commodity prices, based on 100 as the average for 1926, is 55, which compares with 55.1 a week ago, 55.4 two weeks ago, 55.3 three weeks ago and 55.3 four weeks ago. The average of 57.4 in the first week of January was the highest of the year to date; this week's average is the lowest.

It was a bright idea which inspired the Italy-America Society to cause the Teatro d'Arte to present a Goldoni comedy under its auspices at the Little Theatre last evening -- it registered a notable event in the history of the Italian theatre here and, consequently, in the career of the Teatro d'Arte; it provided for the actor-director of that excellent organization a new vehicle, unknown here before, for his versatile genius.

NEW HYDE PARK, L.I., March 5. -- Miss Rose Post, 18 years old, of North Merrick, L.I., was shot and killed today when a revolver was fired accidentally by Michael Grobeck Jr., 12, as he was showing it to her in the home of his parents here.

The bank holiday and the hoarding alleged to have been to a large degree responsible for it were discussed yesterday morning in several sermons delivered in the city's churches. Clergymen, in the main, accepted the holiday as a proper move.

GENEVA, March 5. -- Japan's expected formal withdrawal from the League of Nations raises the question in League circles whether she will not thereby sacrifice completely her right under Article IV of the covenant to a permanent seat in the Council.

AGUA CALIENTE, Mexico, March 5 (AP). -- Bahamas, 4-year-old Bon Homme gelding, won the $1,000 Man o' War Handicap today by a head from Pillow Fight, imported half brother of Phar Lap, at six furlongs.

Since early in the depression there has been a real back-to-the-farm movement, according to a monograph on rural social trends published today under the direction of former President Hoover's Research Committee on Social Trends.

Well-fed New Yorkers should profit from this Lenten season to experience some of the discomforts of other Americans "who need all they can possibly get to eat," the Rev. J.O.S. Huntingdon said in his sermon yesterday morning in the Protestant Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration, Twenty-ninth Street near Fifth Avenue.

WASHINGTON, March 5. -- Members of the Seventy-third Congress and the legislative representatives of the war veterans' organizations, who were happy last week in the thought that the veterans' problem was settled for the fiscal year 1934, awoke today to the fact that they had to do the work all over again.

It is not surprising that the sudden overnight news, that a two-day banking moratorium had been decreed for New York State, should have been read on Saturday morning with something like consternation. Possibly, however, the episode will be characterized hereafter as the inevitable result of the adoption of the moratorium recourse by other States and communities.

MIAMI, Fla., March 5. -- Max Carey and his first squad of Dodgers, with a week of intensive training behind them, enjoyed a full day of rest today, preparatory to starting move strenuous work tomorrow, when the squad is expected to be complete.

Mandatory laws providing for the payment of old-age pensions have been enacted in Indiana and Washington in the campaign to extend protective legislation for the aged poor to all parts of the country, according to The Old Age Security Herald of the American Association for Old Age Security for March, just out.

The need of America today is not a "new deal" but a new game with new rules, a drastic change in the systems of privilege which continue to corrupt their possessors, the Rev. Dr. Ralph W. Sockman, the pastor, asserted yesterday morning in his sermon in the Madison Avenue Methodist Church, at Sixtieth Street.

TOKYO, Monday, March 6. -- Every peasant in Japan is receiving a lesson in the economic inter-dependence of the world this morning from the instant repercussion here of America's financial troubles in the form of closed exchanges and suspension of all international money movements.

The Manufacturers' Export Association has urged President Roosevelt to appoint an experienced American business man as a member of the United States delegation to the coming international economic conference, it was announced yesterday at the association's headquarters, 401 Broadway.

The final card party in a series for the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Children will take place on the afternoon of March 14 at the home of Mrs. Arthur M. Anderson, 11 East Sixty-seventh Street.

Little Fellows' Innings. The department stores made an intelligent move in the direction of serving the public and also their own interests when they jointly offered a system of credit facilities during the banking emergency.

A plan to deal with the financial situation by abandoning the gold standard and changing the country's banking and monetary systems was announced here yesterday by representatives of industry and farm organizations as the first move of a campaign to obtain Federal action on their suggestions.

A questionnaire filled out recently by the 616 members of the freshman class at Hunter College disclosed that 51 per cent intended to train for the teaching profession, or 13 per cent less than in the previous semester. A growing tendency to enter professions, until recently reserved for men, was evidenced in the questionnaires.

Philip N. Krug, Democratic leader of Nassau County for the last eight years, is "out" in so far as influence in party affairs in the county is concerned, it was disclosed yesterday. His term as chairman of the executive committee of the party in the county, which carries with it the titular leadership, does not expire until September, however.

PHILADELPHIA, March 5. -- Clearing house certificates, to be used instead of cash, are being printed and will be available here by Wednesday, provided the banks are reopened by that date, it was said tonight after a meeting of prominent bankers lasting three and one-half hours.

NEWARK, N.J., March 5. -- An alarm was broadcast here tonight for two men, who, after imprisoning an East Orange taxi driver in his cab, drove in it to Clifton, N.J., where they held up a gas station and kidnapped the proprietor. After driving here, they pushed the gas station proprietor into the street.
WASHINGTON, March 5 (AP). -- Senate Democrats will caucus tomorrow to agree on an organization and will be ready for action Thursday when the special session is convened.

An American or an Englishman watches an exciting tennis match of mixed doubles, and his mind may wander from the game long enough to speculate on the gate receipts or the upkeep of the splendid courts. But a Frenchman contemplates the two agile young men, the two athletic young women, and thinks wistfully of VERLAINE'S blue-eyed maid with hair in braids, "killed by the blow of a tennis racket."

ATHENS, March 6 (AP). -- A crisis in the Greek Government resulting from yesterday's general election and the establishment of a military government was solved, at least temporarily, by the appointment tonight of a mixed administrative...

VIENNA, March 6. -- The first repercussion in Austria of Adolf Hitler's victory came today when Austrian Nazis met here and demanded the immediate resignation of the Dollfuss Cabinet, which they accused of selling Austria to France, and the formation of a nationist government in Austria.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The full texts of regulations issued late today by Secretary Woodin in connection with the national banking holiday follow:

After moving along with Dartmouth on practically even terms in the first half, Columbia's basketball team fell before the mercurial attack of the Hanover five in the second period and lost, 52 -- 26, in the Morningside Heights gymnasium last night.

Some readers may have noticed in Sunday's newspaper a brief Washington dispatch announcing that, "owing to the economic depression and recent developments "in the general banking situation," The United States Daily had been forced to suspend publication.

The Western Union Telegraph Company and the Postal Telegraph and Cable Corporation extended yesterday to money order service to and from Mexico and Canada the temporary suspension made effective with respect to Europe and other foreign points on Saturday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Six important aides in the Roosevelt administration were confirmed without a word of objection today as the Senate rushed through the last requested move to enable President-elect Roosevelt to swing his administration into action.

Italy Hails Our Dictator. It is estimated that there are 70,000 words in the Italian language, but they fail the Italian press in expressing joy at the magnificent tribute which President ROOSEVELT has paid to the Fascist idea by constituting himself a "dictator."

Miss Le Gallienne brought "The Cherry Orchard" up to Forty-second Street last night to brighten a square made more than a little sad by life -- and a blue Monday. It went into the New Amsterdam, to take its place beside "Alice" of the hallowed memory, and there it will remain for just four weeks.

ABOARD U.S.S. CALIFORNIA AT SEA, off San Clemente Island, March 6 (AP). -- A mock naval battle between two high sea fleets was staged today in the waters of the outer Santa Barbara Channel between Catalina Island and San Clemente Island.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Movements of vessels follow. All dates are March 3. unless otherwise specified:

George Banitch, who owns small drug store at 21-33 Thirty-first Avenue, Astoria, feels that there ought to be a holiday for holdup men. In support of this view he issued a proclamation early last night to two young men, one of whom he recognized as a former unwelcome visitor, when the pair, pistols in hand, stepped into his store.
TOKYO, March 6. -- Though normal exchange business has been suspended, the banks here are taking care of travelers by cashing checks not exceeding $50 at Saturday's rate.

Passenger traffic officials of the railroads serving New York will meet in the Trunk Line Association office at 143 Liberty Street today to devise means of accepting scrip as payment for fares. Meanwhile, the railroads were following a policy of accepting checks wherever possible.

PARIS, March 6. -- There have been no violent reactions in Paris to the suspension of banking operations in the United States. On the contrary, there has been quiet acceptance of a situation that had been expected in some form or other since March 1.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- S. Pinkey Tuck of New Brighton, N. Y., first secretary of the American Legation at Prague, Czechoslovakia, has been designated first secretary of the embassy at Paris.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- Several men nursed bruises and broken heads tonight and a score of others were in jail, the aftermath of an attempt by a corps of unemployed to stage a demonstration through Washington streets.

Housing properties in numerous communities of New Jersey were included in the realty conveyances reported yesterday. Most of the structures were one-family dwellings, though several flats also were among the properties transferred. Joe Tell of West New York sold to the Embro Realty Company of 921 Bergen Avenue, Jersey City, a four-story, sixteen-family brick apartment house at 323 Union Street, near West Side Avenue, Jersey City.

Decision was reserved by Justice Cropsey last evening in the special term of the Supreme Court in Queens at Jamaica, on the application of Herman Wollitzer of Jackson Heights, an attorney, to restrain seven title and mortgage companies in New York City from alleged illegal practice of the law.

The popular guarantee fund to assure the continuance of grand opera at the Metropolitan next season has risen to $125,000, according to an announcement made from the stage of the opera house last night by Lucrezia Bori, prima donna and chairman of the fund-raising committee.

Indications that the banking situation may rapidly crystallize into mild inflation were seen yesterday with a rise in the wholesale prices of foodstuffs, livestock, silver, cotton and other commodities. Retail prices of food were unchanged.

LOS ANGELES, March 6. -- Eating well but quite penniless, the Giants went back to intensive drilling behind closed gates at Wrigley Field today, to iron out the flaws that revealed themselves In the two defeats that were heaped upon them by the pubs on Catalina Island over the week-end.

Governor Herbert H. Lehman became a virtual dictator of the State's banks and insurance companies by reason of three emergency bills rushed through the Legislature at Albany last night. These measures gave him sweeping powers for the duration of the emergency caused by the national banking moratorium.

Quoting President Roosevelt's intimation in his inaugural address that fundamental social policies should not be dictated by "money changers," Dr. Harold G. Campbell, deputy and associate superintendent of schools, pleaded yesterday for parental cooperation in the maintenance of educational standards at a meeting under the auspices of the secondary schools council of the United Parents Association in the Russell Sage Foundation Building.

SCOTTSBORO, Ala., March 6. -- An unexpected defense motion to quash indictments against the nine Negroes in the "Scottsboro case," accused of attacking two white girls, delayed until tomorrow a decision on a motion for change of venue for seven of the Negroes whose cases were called here today in the Jackson County Circuit Court.

Biological authorities who assert that there are physiological ages which pay no attention to the calendar of days and years could find support for their theory in the person of President MASARYK, who today completes 83 years (though condemned to death seventeen years ago) and is in the fifteenth year of his Presidency and of the republic which he had so great a part in establishing.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- More than forty committee memberships were taken from Senate Republicans today at a conference among Senators Robinson of Arkansas, re-elected Democratic leader; McNary, Republican, of Oregon, and Reed, Republican, of Pennsylvania.

Jim Browning, the wrestling champion, successfully defended his title at Madison Square Garden last night by defeating Sammy Stein of New York before a crowd of 9,000 spectators. After a little more than three-quarters of an hour of wrestling, the champion lifted Stein above his head and slammed him to the mat.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP). -- Midwestern commodity markets wavered today as the full influence of the national bank holiday became effective. The Chicago Live Stock Exchange, centre of the nation's meat-packing industry, stumbled through a hectic day and announced the yards would be closed after tomorrow.

All markets were closed yesterday and business in Wall Street was to a large extent suspended. Banks and commission houses kept limited organizations at work conducting necessary business. The New York Stock Exchange and all other exchanges remained closed and will continue to do so until the banking holiday is called off.

The postal savings system, "the only bank in town now," will continue to operate "as usual" during the banking moratorium, according to instructions received at the general postoffice here yesterday from William T.S. Rollins, director of postal savings in Washington.
The national champion, Miss Dorothy Locke of the Salle d'Armed Vince, scored a sweeping victory in the women's open foils competition at the Fencers Club last night.

Measures now pending before the Legislature In New Jersey have aroused considerable interest among sportsmen. Five bills, all having to do with some phase of work which now falls under the supervision of the State Fish and Game Commission, have aroused some objection.
DETROIT, March 6. -- Plans for the issuance of a new form of commercial exchange in Detroit were not completed today because bankers were unable to agree upon the form of scrip.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- Buddy Hanford scored a triple at Hialeah Park today with Clean Play, Prince Drake and Action, the last named winning the featured race in the colors of N.E. Stanton. Action was next to the outsider in a field of five and caused something of a surprise when he won by two lengths after leading all the way.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Relative to THE TIMES'S comment on "Women and Machines," which Emilie J. Hutchinson takes to task, it seems to me Miss Hutchinson has overlooked at least a few items necessary to a fuller consideration of this topic.
CHICAGO, March 6. -- State and civic honors will mark the last rites for Mayor Anton J. Cermak, which will be held Friday in the Stadium.

For at least the third time in the memory of man, that unbridled younger generation which seemed, just a few years back, to have been the biggest problem facing mankind and with which Elmer Harris had so much fun in his play, "Young Sinners," returned to Broadway last evening in none other than Mr. Harris's play.

Of all the theatrical attacks upon the depravity of representative government Maxwell Anderson's "Both Your Houses" is the most stirring and direct. It is not only an angry crying of names and cases but an excellent play that will interest those whom it is convincing.

The new 2,200-ton twenty-knot Furness Liner Queen of Bermuda will leave at 3 P.M. today on her maiden voyage to Bermuda with 500 passengers. Among them are Lord Carew. aide to the Governor; Sir Henry W. Watlington, C. Ledyard Blair, Mrs. T. Suffern Tailer, Vernon C. Brown, Mrs. J.R. Roosevelt and Princess Braganza.

Belief that the United States Treasury will elect to do its financing for March 15 through the sale of very short-term obligations, in view of the expected high rate of interest that will have to be paid, was voiced generally throughout the financial district yesterday.

Anton Joseph Cermak, who fought his way up from the coal mines to be Mayor of America's second largest city, was a product of the peasant life of old Bohemia, transplanted to the Middle West of America. He was born on May 9, 1873, in a two-room cottage in a mining village fifty miles from Prague.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The War Department issued the following orders today: Frink. Maj. J.L., Q.M.C., to Washington, D.C., about June 30. Hickok. Maj. M.J., C.A.C., to Schenectady. N.Y. Bender, Capt. J.D., Inf., to Fort Sam Houston, Texas.

On the Winnipeg Grain Exchange wheat futures advanced yesterday in heavy trading. All three options -- May, July and October -- added about two cents a bushel to a similar gain achieved on Saturday. July wheat closed at 53 3/8 cents, compared with a recent "low" for the year of 44 1/2 cents in Chicago.

Charitable bequests totaling $605,000 were made by Mrs. Therese Schiff, widow of Jacob H. Schiff, banker and philanthropist, in her will, which was filed yesterday in Surrogates' Court. Seven organizations benefited.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- Farm leaders said today they are convinced that the domestic allotment plan, unless revived by President Roosevelt, is bound toward the scrap-heap on which now lie the export debenture, the equalization fee and other farm aid plans paraded before Congress in the last decade.

International motor boat racing was taken under discussion last night at the meeting of the council of the American Power Boat Association, held in the Hotel Lexington. Suggestion was made that the proposed regatta in Florida next Winter consist of three heats, one to be held at Palm Beach on Feb. 22.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The wife of the President of the United States received newspaper women today at the first White House press conference ever held by a first lady of the land.

BOSTON, March 6. -- Dr. Amos R. Wells, author of religious works, honorary editor of The Christian Endeavor World and a pioneer leader in the Christian. Endeavor movement, died today at his home in Auburndale after an emergency operation.
