ALBANY, March 6. -- A cordon of State Police was placed around the Capitol tonight as the Legislature reconvened, to prevent any disorder by a group of unemployed assembling in the city.

TORONTO, March 6 (Canadian Press). -- Despite the banking tie-up in the United States, the local stock exchange closed this afternoon with a buoyant tone. Stocks rallied in late dealings apparently on buying orders from New York and London and encouraged also by a vigorous advance in wheat at Winnipeg.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The Boerse showed increased activity and a pronounced bullish tone today. Practically the whole active list rose. Coals, electricals, steels and I.G. Farben were the centre of interest. The closing was strong. Bonds also were more in demand and firm.

Hunts Point, in the eastern part of the Bronx, hummed with activity yesterday as the presses of the American Bank Note Company, working at high speed twenty-four hours in the day, turned out certificates to be used shortly in New York City in lieu of paper money.

ROME, March 6. -- The Italian press, commenting today on President Roosevelt's inaugural address, emphasizes his statement that he is prepared under certain circumstances to ask Congress for wartime powers. This has aroused great interest here as perfectly in line with the Fascist mentality, which believes that in times of crises parliaments reveal their fatal weakness and that power must be concentrated in the fewest possible hands.

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- Instituting a policy of "open covenants openly arrived at," Joe Gilleaudeau, vice president and treasurer of the Dodgers, sat in the dugout during today's workout and frankly discussed contract troubles with two of the club's major holdouts.

MOSCOW, March 6. -- Fifty stores selling white and black bread at 20 per cent of the "free market" rates and twenty selling meat at a 50 per cent reduction have just opened in Moscow for all comers, irrespective of cards or passports. Their popularity was immediate.

Safe cracksmen, hoping to profit by the necessity of keeping cash in places of business, invaded four places in Harlem and the Bronx between Saturday night and yesterday morning. In the Bronx the safe of the Crescent Theatre at 1,175 Boston Road yielded $2,000 in cash.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The President, on learning of the death today of Mayor Cermak from the bullet of an assassin which was meant for Mr. Roosevelt, made the following statement:
ALBANY, N.Y., Tuesday, March 7. -- Following is the text of the bill giving broad powers to the banking board of the State during the present emergency:

To the Editor of The New York Times: To an American observing the mechanics of repeal from afar it seems that most of the proposals for the establishment of convention machinery exceed the necessities of the occasion and introduce difficulties, complexities and expenses unwarranted by the logic of the situation.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 2:
To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial "An Ineffective Embargo" Is comforting to those who look for a better understanding in the United States of the situation in the Far East.

The point of the national best-selling novel, "Ann Vickers," Sinclair Lewis, its author, explained yesterday, is that "women have almost caught up to men" and that they are "almost complete, full-sized human beings, with ideas, reasons, ambitions, force -- with virtues and faults."
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The administration set in motion today machinery which officials expected to go far to relieve the banking emergency in many States within another twenty-four hours.
To the Editor of The New York Times: The far-heralded and deeply annoying depression affects the rising generation in a curious way. I belong to that generation.

The James Monroe High basketball team crushed the Theodore Roosevelt High quintet, 24 -- 9, yesterday at the Monroe court for its seventh straight victory In the Upper Manhattan-Bronx Division of the P.S.A.L. tourney.

Bank holiday or no holiday, the lure of a bargain sale was so potent yesterday at a West Thirty-fourth Street store that a crowd of women, in their eagerness to enter, broke large plate glass windows on both sides of the entrance. Thirteen were injured.

MONTREAL, March 6 (Canadian Press). -- Bill Cook, Rangers veteran, still In the van or National Hockey League point-makers, is closely pressed by three International group challengers -- Paul Haynes and Laurence Northcott of the Maroons and Harvey Jackson of Toronto.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Regulations governing payment of freight charges during the banking holiday were issued today by the Interstate Commerce Commission. In general the regulations provided for delivery of freight with the carriers extending credit to the consignee.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 6. -- Nine Harvard crews made their first outdoor appearance of the season on the Charles River today.

President ROOSEVELT'S proclamation of a four-day nation-wide bank moratorium and of an embargo during that period on hoarding, export or earmarking of gold, is based on a wartime statute of 1917. That was designed solely to control export of gold and speculation in foreign exchange.

ABOARD CERMAK FUNERAL TRAIN, EN ROUTE TO CHICAGO, March 6 (AP). -- The special train bearing Mayor Anton J. Cermak's body back to Chicago sped northward along the Florida East Coast tonight on the first stage of its forty-hour journey.

To the Editor of The New York Times: In THE NEW YORK TIMES of March 1 here appeared a letter from Dr. S.S. Goldwater, wherein he begins by stating that if the Crawford bill is passed the hospitals will have to choose between paying fines ranging for individual institutions from $100,000 to $4,000,000 yearly,

(Hockey Harmony.) The fast right-winger, gaunt and grim, Came dashing down the ice. A big defense man greeted him And stopped him in a trice. The winger landed on his head, A much-disordered wreck. "My thanks to you," the hoister said,
WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- About a flower-banked bier in the Senate chamber, dignitaries of church and State bade a sorrowing farewell today to the late Senator Thomas J. Walsh of Montana.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- As Chicago struggled through the first day of the nation-wide bank holiday today on a cash basis, plans for the issuance of clearing-house certificates were completed by a special committee of the clearing house.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The Federal Reserve Board's condition statement of weekly reporting member banks in leading cities on March 1 shows decreases for the week of $434,000,000 in loans and investments, $693,000,000 in net demand deposits, $211,000,000 in time deposits and $215,000,000 in reserve balances with the Federal Reserve Banks, and increases of $358,000,000 in borrowings from Federal Reserve Banks and $106,000,000 in cash in vaults.

ROME, March 6. -- Don Marino Torlonia, member of the cadet branch of the famous princely family of Torlonia, is dead, the end coming suddenly from a heart attack. His estranged wife is the former Miss Elsie Moore of New York.
"The Lady Refuses," a comedy by Saxon Kling, will have its premiere this evening at the Bijou Theatre. Lou Tellegen, Cecil Spooner and Charles Bryant are featured players in the cast.

The readjustment managers of the St. Louis-San Francisco Railway conferred yesterday on the possibility of utilizing the amendment to the bankruptcy act made last week in speeding the reorganization of the company. In receivership for several months, the Frisco has assents to a plan of reorganization from about 70 per cent of the security holders involved.

The municipal bond market was at a complete standstill yesterday since, with the closing of the banks, dealers were unable to clear transactions in the usual way. Stock Exchange houses which maintain municipal bond departments were prohibited from transacting business under the rules of the Exchange, and independent houses found themselves unable to do any trading because of the tie-up.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Loadings of revenue freight for the week ended on Feb. 25 totaled 459,079 cars, the American Railway Association announced today. This was a decrease of 55,311 cars, of 10.7 per cent, from the preceding week; 76,419 cars, or 14.2 per cent from the corresponding week last year, and 222,142 cars, or 32.6 per cent from the corresponding week two years ago.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- When the White House currency embargo proclamation which took effect early this morning was originally drawn, its chief declaration read as follows:

CAIRO, March 6. -- Surrounded by somewhat disturbed American tourists, William M. Jardine, United States Minister to Egypt, sounded a high note of confidence in "the courageous leadership" of President Roosevelt in the banking crisis, the repercussions of which are extending as far as the Valley of the Nile.

The New York Stock Exchange will remain closed until further notice, it was announced yesterday The order closing the Exchange was issued by a special committee which was appointed to deal with all problems arising from the suspension of trading.
ALBANY, Tuesday, March 7. -- The following is the text of the special message of Governor Lehman read to the Legislature early this morning:

It was several seasons ago that Joseph Brummer put on his first Pierre Roy show. Now he has opened another, which, containing thirty-five canvases by this extraordinary Frenchman, fills all of the spacious top-lighted galleries at 55 East Fifty-seventh Street.

Thrifty school children, who have deposited more than $18,000,000 through the 525 school "banks" in the city, found their own banking facilities tied up yesterday and their financial operations restricted just as were those of adults by the bank holiday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President Roosevelt met Governors and their representatives at the White House today and discussed with them measures of relief and ways of meeting the banking situation. The President did not make any definite suggestions on national policies to be carried out in the States, or indicate what his recommendations would be to Congress when it meets on Thursday.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 6. -- The signing of Yankee hold-outs got under full headway today with surprising suddenness.

For the first time since the collection of gasoline taxes was begun in this country, gross receipts from that source last year were smaller than in the preceding year, according to the American Petroleum Institute. Gross collections for 1932 are estimated at $540,884,000, compared with actual gross collections of $569,789,232 in 1931, a decline of $28,905,232.

BASLE, March 6. -- Europe's central banks received the news of the dollar embargo fairly philosophically, judging from telephone calls received by the Bank for International Settlements today from virtually all of those banks.
CHICAGO, March 6. -- Oscar G. Foreman, retired banker, died today in his home here after an illness of several months with anemia. He was 69 years old.

MOSCOW, March 6. -- The Communist International has reversed its policy of Communist party exclusiveness of recent years and has reverted to a "united front" of all workers' parties under a manifesto issued Jan. 22 and published in the newspaper Pravda today.

Executives of twenty-nine leading local stores urged yesterday the immediate issuing of New York Clearing House certificates at a special meeting called by the Retail Dry Goods Association or New York and held in the offices of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, 270 Madison Avenue.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 6. -- Leaving an estate valued at more than $5,000,000, and bequeathing $89,000 to charity, the will of Patrick McGovern, head of Patrick McGovern, Inc., subway builders, was filed for probate here today with Surrogate Leone D. Howell. Mr. McGovern died at his home, Great Neck, L.I., on Feb. 22.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- A moratorium on patronage has been declared by the administration until the banking situation is solved. An announcement was made at the White House today that President Roosevelt would not concern himself with the distribution of places until such time as he had acted finally on the emergency banking legislation.

Roland Hayes's concert, given for the benefit of the New York Urban League last night in the Town Hall, was a rewarding experience, both as to program and performance. It is always a pleasure when a benefit concert (concerning which one's critical arrows are supposed to remain in their quiver) enables one to write without recourse to polite ambiguities.

ROME, March 6. -- Italian newspapers express deep satisfaction today with the result of the German election, which they believe places Chancellor Hitler in power for many years with sufficient strength in the Reichstag to give him a free hand in running affairs.

Representatives of more than fifteen clearing houses in various cities of this State, at a meeting held yesterday in the office of Superintendent Broderick, appointed a committee of State and national bankers to cooperate with Mr. Broderick, the Controller of the Currency, and the officials of the Federal Reserve Bank.

Dr. Alfred North Whitehead, Fellow in Trinity College In the University of Cambridge and Professor of Philosophy in Harvard University, traces the history of the human race through the story of mankind's changing ideas in "Adventures of Ideas," published today by Macmillan.

MOSCOW, March 6 (AP). -- Two bitter political antagonists, the Communists and the Social Democrats, have joined forces temporarily in an effort to present a united fighting front against their common Fascist enemy in Germany and throughout the world.

PARIS, March 6. -- Adolf Hitler's success in the elections yesterday was naturally bad news for France. Although it had been generally expected the French had hoped the popular expression of the German will might show some disagreement with the Nazi leader.

The International Clubs of Great Britain and the United States will meet on the indoor tennis courts of the Brooklyn Heights Casino this afternoon, with three members of the first ten and Manuel Alonso of the Spanish Davis Cup team playing for this country.

By defeating the Sleepy Hollow Country Club, Westchester division winner, and the Englewood Field Club, victor in New Jersey, the women's squash racquets team of the Junior League of New York captured the Metropolitan Intersectional Club team championship on the courts of the league yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- After seven years of existence, The United States Daily suspended publication with its issue of this morning. The paper was started March 4, 1926, under the presidency of David Lawrence of The Consolidated Press, who owned a controlling interest In the $1,000,000 corporation organized to launch the publication.

GENEVA, March 6. -- The League of Nations has confidence in the country of its founder. A large part of the League's funds are in dollars. Since more than a third of its members have defaulted in their League dues, its financial situation is such that the depreciation of the dollar would throw the League budget out of balance, but it is keeping its dollars.

It was learned yesterday that space had been engaged to ship $9,000,000 in gold out of the country on the Paris Saturday afternoon, and that Governor Lehman's banking moratorium shortly after 4 o'clock that morning caught the movement in process and stopped $6,000,000.

The aggregate market value of stocks listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $3,372,208,130 in February, or 14.6 per cent, according to the monthly report issued by the Exchange. The shrinkage was accompanied by a decline of 6,460,895 in the number of shares listed, or one-half of 1 per cent, as three issues were stricken from the list.

TIENTSIN, March 6. -- The Jehol warfare, which is lulling, is completely supplanted in public interest here by the American banking and monetary situation, which already is having a marked ill effect upon trade in the Far East.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- At a special meeting today the directors of the Chicago Live Stock Exchange decided to close the market at 3 P.M. tomorrow and to keep it closed until further notice. The action was taken after a joint meeting of officials of the Exchange, commission men and packers.

The State corporation suggested by Governor Lehman probably will resemble in some respects the National Credit Corporation, formed in October, 1931, at the suggestion of President Hoover to assist banks with sound but unliquid assets.

Although both the New York and New Orleans Cotton Exchanges remained closed yesterday, many brokers here assembled at the Exchange, owing to interest in the course of foreign markets. Operators here transacted business in Liverpool, where contract prices lost 12 to 16 English points, with spot quotations 14 points lower than on Saturday.

ALBANY, March 6 (AP). -- Preliminary plans and estimate sheets tell of huge construction jobs in New York State capable of Riving a year's work to perhaps 33,000 men if the Reconstruction Finance Corporation approves applications for $110,400,000 in loans.

LONDON, March 6. -- Sir William Henry Veno, whose name is known throughout the world in connection with a patent cough cure, was found shot dead tonight with a sporting gun beside him in a field adjoining his home, The Woodlands, at Altringham, Cheshire, where he had gone to shoot rabbits.

Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, announced yesterday, after the regular monthly meeting of the university board of trustees, that the Columbia University School of Law would raise the present tuition of $300 to $380 for the academic year 1933-34, in order that $68,000 might be appropriated for scholarships and loans to needy law students.

The Rev. Dr. William Norman Guthrie, rector of the Protestant Episcopal Church of St. Mark's-in-the-Bouwerie, celebrated the fortieth anniversary of his ordination last night. Twelve of his fellow-clergymen sat in the chancel last evening and participated in the service held in his honor.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- How oxygen regulates the protein-building process or body cells -- an important new aid in the study of cancer -- has been discovered by scientists of the Public Health Service.

The competition of the city's Eighth Avenue subway, according to a report filed with the United States District Court yesterday by the receivers for the Interborough, has cut into the company's passenger traffic at the rate of 28,000,000 riders a year on the subway lines and 13,000,000 a year on the elevated routes.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 6. -- Governor Cross today proclaimed an extension through Thursday of the Connecticut bank holiday, which was ordained Saturday by Roy L. Wilcox, Acting Governor In his absence. The Governor, who had hurried from the inauguration ceremonies in Washington, acted after conferring with bankers and G.J. Bassett, State Banking Commissioner, this forenoon.
CHICAGO, March 6 (AP). -- A young trio of America's Ryder Cup players are waging a stirring duel down the stretch in the big race for Winter golfing honors this year.

American good nature and cheerful optimism never showed to better advantage than amid this national moratorium for banks. Ways of doing business without money have been devised. Credit has been freely extended. Ingenious arrangements have sprung up on every hand to make things easier in the matter of payments due.

Mayor O'Brien issued a statement last night pledging his administration to continuation of its home relief and work relief programs without curtailment, and warned against any attempt to discount food orders or the pay checks of city employes under threat of reprisal from the municipal authorities.

Thomas Edmund Greacen, operator in real estate, with offices at 150 Nassau Street, and retired boot and shoe manufacturer, died on Sunday at his home, 1 Lexington Avenue, after a brief illness. His age was 86.

BERLIN, March 6. -- The National Socialist domination of Germany having become an accomplished fact, the effect of this development on German policies affecting the outside world becomes important, and it may be said that present indications on this point are reassuring.

So that the State of Pennsylvania might not be deprived of its full representation at the extraordinary session of Congress Thursday, Federal Judge Johnson Jay Haves consented yesterday to a further postponement until Monday of the trial of Senator James J. Davis from that State on charges of violating the Federal lottery laws.
LONDON, March 6. -- The Bank of England Intends to do everything in its power to keep sterling and dollar exchange at a rate of about $3.50, it was reported today.

Except for those men and women on emergency work payrolls of the city and the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee the work of unemployment relief continued normal yesterday. Grocers and storekeepers continued to accept orders for food issued by the Home Relief Bureau and said they would continue to cooperate until the bank holiday was over.

WASHINGTON, March 6 (AP). -- Representative Rainey, nominee for Speaker, told newspaper men today that "war debt negotiations will have to be delayed" pending the readjustment of the domestic financial situation.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 6. -- Seven members of Miss Diana Fishwick's group of invading English golfers qualified for the Belleair women's championship on the links of the Belleair Country Club today. It was the first time that foreign women players ever participated in a tournament on the Florida West Coast.

New York carried on without serious trouble yesterday and tried to do business as usual, except for the closing of the security and commodity markets, despite the national banking holiday decreed by President Roosevelt.

Despite the national bank holiday, which forced the closing of Agua Caliente and the Fair Grounds and caused an expected decrease in the wagering, Hialeah Park at Miami, Fla., and Oriental Park, Havana, opened their gates as usual yesterday for the final week of their Winter racing programs.

Spurred by the cheers of an overflow crowd of 5,000 persons, which filled the St. Nicholas Arena to capacity, the participants in the Golden Gloves amateur boxing tournament, conducted by the Daily News A.A. with the sanction of the Amateur Athletic Union, fought through the quarter-final and semi-final rounds of the competition last night.

Each of the 297 presbyteries that make up the General Assembly of the Presbyterian Church should elect in spite of the depression, the full number of commissioners to which it is entitled to the 145th annual meeting of that body, the Rev. Dr. Mark A. Matthews, pastor of the largest Presbyterian church in the world, the First, of Seattle, Wash., declared yesterday.

LONDON, March 6. -- There is every reason to believe the embargo on munitions shipments to Japan and China, which the British Government unexpectedly imposed a week ago today, will soon be rescinded and exports from this country will be resumed because no other country has followed the British example.
VIENNA, March 6. -- The American banking crisis and the consequent sagging of dollar prices had much the same effect in Southeastern Europe as abandonment of the gold standard by Great Britain.

CHICAGO, March 6 (AP). -- Chicago mourned today its second Mayor to fall a victim to an assassin, for the death of Mayor Cermak had a counterpart four decades ago in the assassination of Mayor Carter H. Harrison Sr. Like Mayor Cermak, Mayor Harrison was a national figure when he was slain Oct. 28, 1893, by Patrick Prendergast, a disappointed officeseeker.

The use of the boycott by one nation against another was declared "as damaging as actual warfare," by Kensuke Horinouchi, Consul General of Japan in New York yesterday at the meeting of the Government Club in the Hotel Astor.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Captain Albert W. Stevens, veteran photographer of the Army Air Corps, and his pilot, First Lieutenant Charles D. McAllister, experienced the coldest weather of their flight careers yesterday, during an experimental high-altitude photographic flight from here to New York City for testing latest aerial cameras.

The Southern Steamship Company and the Morgan and Clyde-Mallory steamship lines, operating in the Atlantic coastwise trade, have obtained permission of the Interstate Commerce Commission to intervene in the application of the Seatrain Lines for an order to force the railroads of the country to publish joint rates and through routes between the East and Southwest via the Seatrain ships, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Both houses of Congress, although not formally in session, laid unprecedented plans today for expediting emergency banking legislation that forecast completion of such laws within forty-eight hours after the special session convenes on Thursday.

DARJEELING, India, March 6 (By Wireless, N.Y.). -- An advance party from this expedition, which has come out from England to attempt to scale the summit of Mount Everest, a feat never yet accomplished, has gone to Kalimoong. Here its members will halt for a few days to repack stores before continuing on the tedious journey through Tibet by way of Gantok and Gautsa.

Erick Goldbeck, 135th Street Y.M. C.A., scored a pair of knockout victories at the semi-monthly amateur boxing show staged last night before 500 persons at the New York Athletic Club. Competing in the 165-pound class. Goldbeck stopped Vito Casucci, unattached, in the second round and then halted Edward Flynn, unattached, in the first round.

The right of the present Duchess of Manchester, who was Kathleen Ethel Dawes, an English actress, to use jewels, furs and laces left by Consuelo, Dowager Duchess of Manchester, her husband's mother, will be determined in a suit filed in the Supreme Court yesterday by the United States Trust Company and Thomas B. Gilchrist as trustee of the American estate of the Dowager Duchess.

Milton Baron of the Fraternity Club overcame the stubborn opposition of W.J. Hall of the Crescent Athletic-Hamilton Club last night to gain the quarter-final round of the national Class A squash tennis championship at the Harvard Club.

ATHENS, March 6. -- Learning that the Royalist opposition, headed by former Premier Panayoti Tsaldaris, had won an unexpected victory in yesterday's general election over the Venizelist Government, General Nicholas Plastiras, organizer of the military coup of 1922, proclaimed a military dictatorship today.

CHICAGO, March 6. -- Nothing appeared to halt the bull market in wheat that has developed in Winnipeg since the American markets Closed on Friday, and prices on the Canadian exchange soared 2 to 2 1/4 cents today and at the last were 4 cents higher than at the finish on March 3.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- The proclamation of President Roosevelt put into effect today is supposed to take care of the first two phases of a three-point program along which the President is proceeding. The first is to stop the panic so that a sane approach can be made to the banking problem.

Scrip-conscious New York went through the second day of the bank holiday yesterday orderly and optimistic. Trade fell off, but shopkeepers generally attributed the decline to lack of ready cash rather than to fear and predicted a swift pick-up when scrip is available.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- In addition to worrying about their personal finances, diplomats here were busy today surmising as to the effect the United States gold embargo would have on their own countries. At the British Embassy little comment was forthcoming, but officials expressed regret that the war debt negotiations, which were believed to be under way, would have to be postponed indefinitely until the domestic situation had cleared up.

H.M. Byllesby Co., Janney Co. and the Central Republic Company are forming a protective committee for the 6 and the 7 per cent convertible gold notes of the Shaffer Oil and Refining Company, now the Deep Rock Oil Company, according to a letter sent to bondholders.

Steel ingot production in the United States advanced in February for the second successive month, according to the monthly report of the American Iron and Steel Institute. As a result, February output was 20.39 per cent of capacity, against 17.78 per cent in January and 15.02 per cent in December, and was the highest since the 22.02 per cent rate reported in April, last year.

Former President Herbert Hoover broke the silence he has maintained since his retirement from the Presidency on Saturday to urge yesterday the "whole-hearted" support of his successor's banking proclamation.

ALBANY, Tuesday, March 7. -- Under an emergency message from Governor Lehman the Assembly early this morning by unanimous vote passed three bills vesting the Governor and the State Banking Board as well as the State Superintendent of Insurance with sweeping powers in relation to the conduct of banking and insurance business during the existing emergency.
WASHINGTON, March 6. -- President Roosevelt's speech at the Governors' conference today, as given out at the White House, was as follows:

WELLESEY, Mass., March 6. -- Two major fellowships were awarded at Wellesley College today. The Fanny Bullock Workman Scholarship goes to Virginia Corwin of New Haven, Conn., and the Alice Freeman Palmer Fellowship to Anne E. Litzinger of South Hadley.

BOSTON, March 6. -- The Executive and legislative machinery of Massachusetts moved with speed today in a series of efforts to minimize inconvenience attending the bank holiday and to resume normal business as soon as the Federal Government shapes its policy.
CHICAGO, March 6. -- The death today of Mayor Anton J. Cermak has created serious problems for Chicago.
NEW YORK. Lord Revelstoke and his son, the Hon. Rupert Baring, will arrive on the Olympic and will be at the Waldorf-Astoria.

Mayor CERMAK fought death with characteristic courage, vigor and tenacity. An innocent victim of fate at the moment when his political fortunes were highest, he has set an example of bravery and constancy to his countrymen. An immigrant child, born to poverty, he made his way from the smallest beginnings, got rich by industry and intelligence and became "the business man in politics."

MIAMI, Fla., March 6. -- Mayor Anton J. Cermak of Chicago died at 6:57 o'clock this morning from the effects of a bullet wound inflicted here on the night of Feb. 15 by Joseph Zangara in an attempt to assassinate Franklin D. Roosevelt.

GENEVA, March 6. -- Hope of Germany's recovering fairly soon a share in her former colonies was encouraged by Albert Sarraut, the French Minister of Colonies, in the disarmament conference this afternoon.

Lack of money failed to deter a good number of the 5,000 persons who filled the St. Nicholas Arena to capacity to view the quarter-final and semi-final rounds of the Golden Gloves boxing tournament last night.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 6. -- Mr. and Mrs. John Randolph Hopkins entertained today aboard their yacht, Veruselle, with a buffet luncheon, followed by a cruise on the lake and ocean. Their guests included:...
Real estate offices in this city were carrying on as usual yesterday, although the activities of the market in general were checked temporarily as a result of the banking holiday.

The total registration, rather than the vote recorded on the voting machines, guided some of the election inspectors in the Fourth Assembly District in reporting last election night the totals for their districts, it was indicated yesterday as the Board of Elections neared the end of the check on the voting machines.

Smudgy-nosed kittens mewing plaintively, great, sullen tabby-cats recruited from back alleys and fence tops, exuberant puppies of doubtful ancestry; turtles, pigeons, brook minnows in mayonnaise cans and small boys were features of the pet show inaugurating the annual open-house week of the Kips Bay Boys Club yesterday afternoon in its clubrooms at 301 East Fifty-second Street.

LONDON, March 6. -- At a meeting of the Clearing Bankers' Committee today it was decided to deal in all currencies except dollars and South American currencies. Dealing commenced very sluggishly and sometimes quotations mainly were nominal.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . . .Legal holiday Friday . . . . . . . 3 per cent for the best names.

WASHINGTON, March 6. -- Secretary Woodin told the press today that he would keep the public closely advised as to developments in the banking situation through two daily contacts with the press and declared that the Treasury was working with "might and main so that payrolls and necessary things may be taken care of" at the earliest possible time.

LONDON, March 6. -- Applauding President Roosevelt for his bold leadership, The London Times declares today that outright abandonment of the gold standard by the United States is "so unlikely it may almost be left out of account."

Ben Altheimer, founder of Bundle Day and originator of the religious and popular celebration of Flag Day, celebrated his eighty-third birthday yesterday at his home, 28 East Sixtly-third Street. Surrounded by scores of messages of felicitation from all parts of the country and flowers, Mr. Altheimer stressed the need of public confidence and patience during the present crisis.

The New York Stock Exchange and all other security and commodity markets in this city remained closed yesterday. Brokers said that there was no indication as to when a resumption of trading would be ordered, but that it was certain there would be no reopening until adequate banking facilities were available.

PEIPING, Wednesday, March 8 (AP) -- Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang, whose conduct of the Chinese defense against the Japanese invasion of Jebol Province has met with severe criticism, resigned today as military overlord of North China.
Maxwell R. Marston, former national amateur champion, has been elected president of the new Handicap Golfers Association of America, according to word sent out from the New York offices yesterday.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 7 -- A large tea was given today by Mr. and Mrs. John M.L. Rutherfurd and Mrs. Seymour Page at the Everglades Club. During the afternoon Ernest Charles gave a program of his own compositions.
A special exhibition of New York documents, manuscripts and silver is to be opened today at the Museum of the City of New York and will continue until April 10.

A wave of public buying and higher prices are likely to follow the financial crisis culminating in the bank holiday, Lew Hahn, president of the National Retail Dry Goods Association and chairman of the board of the Hahn Department Stores, Inc., predicted yesterday, following a meeting of the directors of the association, which has a membership of 3,800 department stores and specialty shops throughout the country.

HOLLYWOOD, March 7 (AP) -- The likelihood of a general shutdown in the film industry grew tonight as motion-picture producers assembled in conference to await word from New York headquarters on the course to be taken.

The extensive development on Brooklyn Heights projected by Ralph Jonas, former president of the Brooklyn Chamber of Commerce, has met with financial difficulties, it was indicated yesterday when plans were disclosed for the foreclosure of a $600,000 mortgage on the old B.M.T. building at Montague and Clinton Streets.

Believed by the police and the medical examiner to have become unsettled in his mind as a result of personal financial reverses. Louis Del Gatto, 48 years old, a cameo importer, killed his wife Columba, 47, and his 5-year-old son Ciro yesterday afternoon in their home at 1,129 East Forty-third Street, Brooklyn.

The difficulties experienced by newspapers in obtaining first hand and definite information from officials of the New York Clearing House Association regarding the efforts of bankers to meet the financial emergency prompted the suggestion yesterday that a spokesman be appointed to inform the public upon the progress of steps being taken to relieve the crisis.
NEW YORK. The Hon. Oliver M. Wallop, now at the Carlyle, will leave next week for Big Horn, Wyo.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 -- The New York, New Haven Hartford Railroad announced today the temporary discontinuance of a dozen trains, including the Yankee Clipper and the Merchants Limited, in each direction between New York and Boston, owing to the decline in business resulting from the bank holiday.

CHICAGO, March 7. -- As the result of the ruling by Secretary of the Treasury Woodin covering payments for perishable products, the Chicago Live Stock Exchange today rescinded its action regarding closing the stock yards, and the local yards will be open as usual.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, March 7 -- Indications that a drive to capture Puerto Casado, on the Paraguay River, are seen in reports of increased activity in Bolivia's undeclared war with Paraguay.

Miss Mary Murray Mahony, niece of Dr. Nicholas Murray Butler, president of Columbia University, is one of several young women who will take part in the performance of "The Merchant of Venice" tonight at the clubhouse of the MacDowell Club, 166 East Seventy-third Street, when members of the junior branch of the New York Women's League for Animals present their annual Shakespearean production for the benefit of the Ellin Prince Speyer Hospital for Animals.
CHENGTEH (Jehol City), China, March 7 (AP) -- Gen. Tadashi Kawahara with the Sixteenth Infantry brigade occupied the town of Sanchienfang at 4 o'clock this afternoon after heavy fighting.

The Robert Henri exhibition, which opened yesterday at the Macbeth Gallery, contains canvases both, early and late, several of which were included in the Henri memorial show at the Metropolitan Museum a few years ago. Among the earlier works are "New York Street Scene -- Fifty-seventh Street" (in Winter) and that sharply contrasting and lovely beach scene, "Far Rockaway."

Insurance companies in this State are making prompt payments of death claims and annuities, Superintendent of Insurance George S. Van Schaick announced yesterday in a statement in which he declared that every proper effort will be made to protect the rights of policy holders and to keep their contracts in force.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- With a nation crying for "scrip, scrip," the momentous problems which perplexed the capital until a few days ago have vanished like dreams into a forgotten past. The immediate need is for a dime with which to buy a sandwich, or the ingenuity to make $5 do what $20 would have done before.

MONTREAL, March 7 (Canadian Press). -- Interlisted issues dominated trading on the Montreal Stock Exchange today, accounting for 60 per cent of the slightly better than average turnover of 9,200 shares and recording advances extending to 3 points.

TRENTON, N.J., March 7 -- Meeting with William H. Kelly, State Banking Commissioner, here today at the call of Governor Moore, representative bankers approved a proposal that the Legislature be asked to authorize the establishment of a central clearing house for the purpose of issuing scrip to be used throughout New Jersey.

PARIS, March 7 -- The confidence felt in Paris in the real value of the dollar and in the steps being taken by the United States Government to deal with the banking situation was well indicated today when dollars were offered in unofficial trading at 23 to 24 francs.
HAVANA, March 7 (AP) -- Secretary of State Ferrara said today that $15,000,000 would reach Cuba tomorrow to bulwark reserves of banks here against their reopening set for Thursday.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Three separate meetings were held tonight at the Chicago Clearing House headquarters by bank officers who were putting the finishing touches to tentative plans for the issuance of clearing house certificates.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Postmasters in thirty-seven cities, including New York, having credits on money order account with the Treasurer of the United States were notified today by Postmaster General Farley that Secretary Woodin's ruling that all banking institutions are permitted to cash checks on the Treasurer should be utilized by offices in need of cash for the transaction of postal business.

TORONTO, March 7 (Canadian Press.) -- Prices were definitely buoyant and volume was much better than the average over recent months today on the Toronto Stock Exchange. Better prices in London for some of the interlisted stocks constituted the chief impetus, but a contributory incentive was the street report that New York is rapidly acquiring a bullish frame of mind which may produce some fireworks when the market there reopens.

Still operating on a cash or barter basis, the second night of The Daily News A.A. Golden Gloves semifinals again attracted to the St. Nicholas Arena last night a capacity crowd of 5,000, to say nothing of such unusual commodities as two live pigeons and a grandfather's clock.

DANZIG, March 7. -- The indignation of the Danzig Germans over the landing of 100 additional Polish policemen at the Polish ammunition depot at Westerplatte, within Danzig Harbor, in violation of existing agreements, reached such an extent today that the Senate of the Free City mobilized a citizens' guard to reinforce the local police in order to prevent outbreaks and clashes with the Poles.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The Republican Senatorial Committee on Committees decided today that Senator Norris should become ranking Republican on the Agriculture Committee with Senator McNary, former chairman, next.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- A sloppy track which prevailed at Hialeah Park today did not prevent Terrier, 1-to-2 favorite in the featured Cinderella Purse, from carrying the colors of the Miami Stable to victory. The veteran Laverne Fator rode the victor which had a length to spare at the end of the seven furlongs.

All the county bankers' associations in parts of New York State outside of New York City have been urged by the emergency committee of the New York State Bankers Association to create regional clearing houses. The recommendation is made with a view to facilitating more effective cooperation between the authorities and the banks in coping with the present situation.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, March 7 -- Although prize money for the tournament, totaling about $75,000, is tied up as a result of banking restrictions, the American Bowling Congress will open here on schedule Thursday, with entries from nineteen States and Canada booked for championship competition over a 31-day period.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- There were strong indications tonight that the idea of scrip was being abandoned in the administration's economic councils as a temporary means of commercial exchange, and that instead there was strong support for an Issue of new Federal Reserve currency, backed by the liquid assets of sound banks.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Secretary Woodin put in a day of continuous activity. He was at the White House this morning and again for a Cabinet meeting at 2 o'clock in the afternoon. At 4:30 o'clock he canceled a press conference to return to the White House with Under-Secretary Ballantine and upon leaving, after 6 o'clock, was smiling and said that he was "very happy."

ALBANY, March 7 -- Governor Lehman's plan for assumption by the State of sweeping powers to control the operations of banks and insurance corporations during the banking emergency was rounded out tonight by the Legislature through the passage of a bill providing for the creation of a corporation empowered to issue scrip, guaranteed by the sound assets of banks and affording a uniform medium of exchange throughout the State.

PARIS, March 7 -- Stock speculation, which was stimulated on the Bourse yesterday, was even, more evident today, and as a result the market was strong. Quotations generally closed at the highest points of the day. All categories shared in the advance.

LONDON, March 7 -- Confidence of financial London increased today as remedial measures continued to be taken in the United States. The foreign exchange market again dealt in all currencies except the dollar. The demand for sterling was sustained, but the effect was offset partly by continued buying of francs by British authorities.

It is desirable that the Legislature at this session should give earnest consideration to the series of bills, sponsored by the Citizens Budget Commission, designed to bring about a reform of New York City pensions. Senators and Assemblymen have been offered ample proof of the unsoundness of the present systems.

The John Day Company has decided to withhold publication, scheduled for tomorrow, of Joel Sayre's "Hizzoner the Mayor," until next Monday. By that time, the company hopes, people may be finding it easier to spend than they are just now.

The Manhattan Congregational Church at Broadway and Seventy-sixth Street has dismissed its pastor, the Rev. Dr. Edward Henry Emett, it became known yesterday. Members of the church's board of trustees declined to discuss the matter yesterday and would not explain Dr. Emett's dismissal other than that they had "good reasons."

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., March 7 -- Benjamin W. Wilson, a pioneer in engraving, who became nationally prominent in the industry, died here tonight at his home, 60 Elk Avenue, after an illness of two years. He was 78 years old.

Organization of an International society for the study of heart disease, the leading cause of death throughout the civilized world, was announced yesterday by Dr. Ernst Boas, chairman of the heart committee of the New York Tuberculosis and Health Association and associate physician at Mount Sinai Hospital.

Clerks of the Board of Elections, working with representatives of the Federal attorney, the Attorney General and the District Attorney, completed yesterday their recanvass of the vote cast on voting machines in Manhattan at the November election.
BERLIN, March 7. -- Hermann Wilhelm Goering, Minister without portfolio, has ordered the suppression of the nudist movement as constituting "one of the greatest dangers to German culture and morals."
While business opinion regarding inflation was divided, further price advances attributed directly to the bank holiday were registered yesterday in the commodities markets.
BERLIN, March 7. -- The latest Danzig incident has aroused considerable excitement in the Reich, where it is felt that the Free City is a dangerous corner in which a spark may easily cause a fire.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Between bites of a luncheon hastily served on the President's desk, Franklin D. Roosevelt and his new director of the budget, Lewis Douglas, today neared an agreement on a sweeping program to reorganize the government.

Leading throughout the encounter, the High School of Commerce basketball team defeated the previously unbeaten Stuyvesant High quintet, 11 to 4, yesterday in the Commerce gymnasium in their game postponed from Monday. Prior to yesterday, the Stuyvesant five, pace-setter in the lower Manhattan-Richmond division of the tourney, had won thirteen straight games, including eight in the P.S. A.L. competition.

Sir Philip Gibbs, who says that he would rather be "a one-dollar-a-day man in Munich or Avignon than a six-dollar-a-day man in Detroit or Pittsburgh," tells some of the joys of life without money in "The Way of Escape, A Challenge to the New Generation," published today by Harpers.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Former Governor Smith before the Senatorial committee showed his usual grasp of fundamentals on most of the issues he handled. But on one point he was not up to his par. That was when he said, "I believe we ought to recognize Russia."

ALBANY, March 7 -- Development of St. Lawrence hydroelectric power would pave the way for a general reduction in the cost of electricity to the domestic consumers through the State, according to the annual report of the Power Authority.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- Trading in wheat in Winnipeg by operators here is confined largely to interests that have been active in that market for some time and have ample funds there or have established credit sufficient to take care of their trades.

Ed (Strangler) Lewis, former world's heavyweight wrestling champion, was declared the victor over Sammy Stein of Newark in the feature finish exhibition at the New York Coliseum last night. A crowd of 7,000 saw Stein counted out in 46:32 after he had missed a flying tackle and landed outside the ring, too stunned to return before ten seconds had been tolled.

GENEVA, March 7 -- The continued passivity of the United States in the disarmament conference contributed directly today to the hardening of Europe into two camps that the conference has been almost steadily registering since Norman H. Davis left.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Checks on temporarily closed banks are being accepted for income tax payments provided a "diligent and conscientious effort" has been made to furnish either cash or a postoffice money order.

MIAMI, Fla., March 7 -- With thirty-three of the thirty-five listed Dodgers in uniform and in the midst of a snappy workout at 12:30 today, a tropical deluge, accompanied by high winds, cut short the exercising and sent the athletes scampering for the clubhouse.

The postal savings system continued to function normally here yesterday, and there was even less activity at the windows in the general postoffice than that observed during any Christmas period. Postmaster John J. Kiely said withdrawals on Monday had been larger than on any day since the bank holiday began, but still were less than deposits.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Senate Republicans formally selected Senator McNary as their leader today when they met to reorganize their forces into the "minority" of the new Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- A movement to reopen farm commodity markets was begun today by Henry Morgenthau Jr., new chairman of the Farm Board, who called heads of grain exchanges together for a conference tomorrow.

The leadership of President Thomas G. Masaryk of Czechoslovakia was praised last evening on his eighty-third birthday anniversary in broadcasts by the Czechoslovak envoy at Washington and the consul general here.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Mrs. Roosevelt spent another busy day in the unpacking and arrangement of household effects, and this afternoon, after taking Mrs. James D. Roosevelt, mother of the President, to the train to return to New York she attended the farewell concert in Washington of the New York Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra, conducted by Arturo Toscanini.

Society debutantes were the manikins yesterday afternoon at the opening of a Spring fashion show of "carefully budgeted" models at Saks. Fifth Avenue, held under the auspices of the Judson Health Centre, which does relief and welfare work on the lower west side.

The present week is proving to be one of the most prolific of the season in the field of art in Brooklyn, with a half-dozen shows on at once. The Brooklyn Museum has three; there is a double-barreled show on at the Towers Hotel, and a large and interesting exhibition at the Grant Studios opens the career of the newly organized Fine Arts Guild.

Resentful of the action of their depositors in withdrawing money from the banks on the eve of the nation-wide closing, many Wall Street bankers are advocating the imposition of punitive taxes upon all large amounts of cash and gold held by individuals.

In the stress of emergency the conference of Governors at the White House was confronted with questions of which there was no thought when it was called. Unemployment relief, however, seems to have been the main theme of discussion.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., March 7 -- Larkin G. Head, who was head of the bureau of information of the Association Against the Prohibition Amendment from the organization of the association in 1928 until three months ago, died today at his home here, 53 Park Avenue, of heart disease after a week's illness.
ALBANY, March 7 -- The text of the scrip act passed by the Legislature tonight was as follows:

ABOARD U.S.S. CALIFORNIA, at Sea off Lower California, March 7 (AP) -- A mighty high seas fleet moved on as a modern armada today for the third major engagement in the four days of thrilling tactical exercises in which 134 craft are engaged.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Major Gen. Samuel D. Sturgis, U.S.A., retired, died in Walter Reed General Hospital last night at the age of 71.
CANNES, France, March 7 -- The banking moratorium in the United States is causing no immediate concern to at least one prominent American Wintering on the Riviera.

To the Editor of The New York Times: There is a stiff controversy, principally among opponents of prohibition, concerning modes of ratifying the proposal recently submitted and relative powers and constitutional functions of Congress and State Legislatures.
To the Editor of The New York Times: I read with a great deal of interest and pleasure THE TIMES editorial "Roads to Recovery."

Contemplating the present state of the world, many are ready to say with OMAR KHAYYAM in the Fitz-Gerald rendering that if they could with Him conspire To grasp this sorry Scheme of Things entire, they would "shatter it to bits" and Remold it nearer to the Heart's desire.

Out of the confusion of opinion and practice which existed among the New York banks yesterday on the third day of the banking holiday there emerged a growing conviction that the national crisis would have to be settled by a thorough-going reorganization of the banking system.
PARIS, March 7 -- The French liner France has ended her career of nearly twenty-one years in the North Atlantic passenger service.

ALBANY, March 7 -- A bill adding two new members to the three now composing the temporary emergency relief administration and giving Chairman Hopkins a salary of $11,500 a year was passed by the Legislature late this afternoon.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 7 -- One hundred entries from five colleges have been received for the annual New England Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championship tournament which will start in the Harvard indoor athletic building Friday and finish the following day.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Increased naval construction to build the United States Navy up to the strength prescribed in the London Naval Treaty will be the policy of Secretary Swanson, he indicated today in his first press conference since assuming office.

The board of managers of the Cotton Exchange voted yesterday to continue the holiday until further notice, but developments in foreign markets attracted considerable attention in cotton circles. Following Monday's decline, an equally sharp recovery took place in Liverpool, where quotations rose nearly 20 English points and closed at grains of about 17 points oh the day.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Production of crude petroleum in the United States totaled 63,998,000 barrels in January, a daily average of 2,064,000 barrels, 192,000 above the preceding month but 94,000 under January of last year, the Commerce Department announced today.

ALBANY, March 7 -- Mrs. Emma T. Gary, widow of Elbert H. Gary, is not to be charged with the maintenance of the mansion at Jericho, L.I., which her husband left to her when he died in 1327, the Court of Appeals decided today.

LOS ANGELES, March 7 -- Among the manifold problems besetting Manager Bill Terry -- and that he has many Memphis Bill will not deny -- is one that right now seems to be perplexing him more than all others combined.

Miss Frances Perkins went to Washington early last week to become Secretary of Labor and a few days later -- Monday at 12:45 A.M., to be exact -- Balto, her reddish brown, stubby-tailed Irish terrier left home.

Salary reductions reaching 30 per cent for remuneration in excess of $5,000 a year were voted yesterday by the administrative committee of the national extension boards of the Congregational and Christian churches. The reductions are based on salaries as they were on Jan. 1, 1932, and supercede two previous cuts of smaller percentages.

Confusion which existed in banking circles yesterday was ended last night when the leading New York banks and trust companies decided to reopen today for the limited banking functions permitted by the regulations issued yesterday morning by Secretary of the Treasury Woodin.

The Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which has been closed since last Saturday in observance of the banking holiday, was authorized last night to reopen to make limited advances to member banks, pay out limited amounts of currency and effect transfers of member bank reserve balances.

Well rested and in fine spirits after two days as a private citizen, freed from the responsibilities of high office, Herbert Hoover arose early yesterday and left his thirty-third-floor suite in the Waldorf-Astoria Towers for a brisk forty-minute walk before starting a day occupied with private conferences and the reception of old friends.

WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- Officials of the Department of Commerce are awaiting reports from their foreign representatives before committing themselves as to the effect of the gold embargo and bank holiday on Latin-American trade.

Liberal wages and salaries and additional Investments in improving plants and facilities were offered by J. Howard Pew, president of the Sun Oil Company, in his report to stockholders, as a suggestion for rebuilding prosperity and making it permanent.

PARIS, March 7. -- In a single sitting today the Chamber of Deputies, by a majority of 360 to 185, approved the government's proposal to issue a 10,000,000,000 franc [$400,000,000 at par] bond issue to cover budget deficits of the past three years and to provide relief for the treasury.
Leases in the downtown industrial area featured the business rentals reported yesterday.

DENVER, March 7 -- The discovery in a wild, isolated region in South Dakota of a ranch house in which Charles Boettcher 2d, wealthy Denver broker, was held captive by kidnappers who obtained $60,000, and the arrest of two men accused in the abduction was announced today by Chief of Police Albert T. Clark

The Emergency Work and Relief Bureau, which has nearly 18,000 workers on its payrolls, obtained the release of $104,000 yesterday covering wage payments due Monday and yesterday, it was announced by Director W.H. Matthews.

Most Things Normal. Moderately diligent study of the morning paper will show that life has not entirely resolved itself into moratoria and scrip. The normal interests have not been slaughtered to make a bank holiday.

Sir George Barnes, former member of the Council for India and former Controller of the Department of Labor for the Board of Trade, will sail tonight for Southampton on the Leviathan of the United States Lines after spending ten days here.
The worried visitor knocked on the door and was admitted immediately. The great detective sat at his desk, placidly smoking his pipe.
WASHINGTON, March 7 (AP) -- The tremendous resources of the Federal Reserve System were employed tonight as the basis for an expansion of currency.

CHICAGO, March 7 -- The wholesale and retail prices of meats, particularly pork, soared today as food stores reported continued brisk buying of foodstuffs in Chicago and its suburbs. In spite of reduced shipments of perishable foods, retail prices of nearly all groceries remained unchanged.

The trial of Dr. William H. Walker, brother of the former Mayor, and four other physicians on charges of fraud and deceit in the practice of medicine, by the medical grievance committee of the State Board of Education, ended yesterday with motions by counsel for the physicians to dismiss the charges on the ground that no case had been established.

ATHENS, March 7. -- Constitutional rule was restored in Greece today. General Nicholas Plastiras, whose second dictatorship lasted only eighteen hours, was a fugitive tonight with a warrant out for his arrest. With martial law lifted, the people once more concerned themselves with their normal affairs.
The premiere of "Lone Valley, Sophie Treadwell's new play, which was scheduled for tonight at the Plymouth Theatre, has been postponed until Friday evening.
Eight Manhattan and Bronx properties were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure sales yesterday. Five sales scheduled for yesterday were adjourned and one property was withdrawn.
WASHINGTON, March 7 -- As soon as the banking situation has cleared President Roosevelt is expected to start putting Into effect the economy program authorized by the last Congress.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Although I was in accord with M. Herriot when he pleaded for the payment of the December debt instalment, there is a great deal to be said for the French point of view. From what I hear, this is totally ignored across the water by the man in the street.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The Interstate Commerce Commission made its second announcement today with respect to railroad practices during the bank holiday, in a public notice declaring such holidays and moratoriums to be "legal holidays" within the meaning of regulations pertaining to demurrage and storage charges.
LONDON, March 7. -- Chancellor Adolf Hitler's electoral triumph and the methods whereby it was accomplished have broken down almost all British sympathy for present-day Germany.

MINNEAPOLIS, March 7 -- The undersigned members of the University of Minnesota staff are of the opinion that drastic action on the part of the Federal Government is required in the present emergency to stop continued contraction of business.

The EAB Symphony Orchestra, which is sponsored by the "Alumni Club" of the Employment Assistance Bureau of 24 Broad Street, an organization cooperating with the Gibson committee in aiding men to find jobs, made its debut on the radio last night over WNYC.

Bartenders and proprietors of speakeasies throughout the nation sold liquor yesterday more openly than ever, after they had been informed of an order issued earlier in the day by Amos W.W. Woodcock, Director of Prohibition, which put into effect the restrictions recently imposed by Congress on the collection of evidence in prohibition cases.

KATONAH, N.Y., March 7 -- A disagreement over the administration of Brookwood Labor College, training school for labor leaders, was disclosed here today with the announcement that A.J. Muste, chairman of the college faculty. Thomas Tippett, a member of the faculty, five administrative officers and nineteen of the twenty-eight students enrolled, had severed their connection with the college.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Proclamations from virtually every Governor, calling upon the people of the States to urge their national representatives to work with President Roosevelt, will be issued tomorrow throughout the country, according to Rear Admiral Richard E. Byrd and others interested in national economy.

A dividend of 25 cents a share on the capital stock of the National City Bank of New York was declared yesterday at a meeting of the board of directors, payable on April 1 to shareholders of record of March 11. This compared with 50 cents recently paid quarterly.

LONDON, March 7. -- Eamon de Valera, President of the Irish Free State Council, has decided to spend the u2,910,000 of land annuities that the Free State refuses to pay Great Britain and which, in anticipation of arbitration, have thus far been retained in a suspense account in Dublin.

Two patients, one a 7-year-old boy, sitting in the reception room of the office of Dr. Louis Soscia at 705 East 187th Street, the Bronx, were slightly wounded last night by a hold-up man who was attempting to escape after being overpowered by the physician in a struggle in the examination room adjoining.
BERLIN, March 7 -- President von Hindenburg, who during the German pre-election campaign remained almost eclipsed, is now taking an active hand in the situation created by the election results.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 7 -- The arrival of three more athletes today boosted Manager Joe McCarthy's flock of Yankees to an even two dozen of the thirty-two players carried on the club's Spring roster.

Taxpayers who invest in the city's new "baby bonds" issued in multiples of $10 will receive interest at the rate of 4 3/4 per cent, the Board of Estimate decided yesterday at an executive meeting of its committee of the whole.

SCOTTSBORO, Ala., March 7 -- The new trial which the United States Supreme Court ordered for the eight Negroes sentenced to die after conviction of attacking two white girls nearly two years ago will not be held in Jackson County, still embittered, in which they were first convicted.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Regulations providing for the issuance of soundly backed clearing house scrip as a medium of temporary exchange, for the release of money from banks for the payment of usual salaries and wages and for absolute necessities, and for other details of the administration of the national bank holiday were issued today by Secretary Woodin of the Treasury Department.

Members of the City College varsity basketball squad were honored at a dinner given by alumni at the City College Club, 144 East Twenty-fourth Street, last night. Three hundred persons, including many alumni, City College athletes and officials, attended.

With all exchanges and banks closed as a result of the Governor's proclamation of a holiday which will last through tomorrow, little business was done in the financial district yesterday. No quotations for securities, foreign exchanges or money were available.

President ROOSEVELT declared in his frank and bold Inaugural Address that only a "foolish optimism" could overlook the "dark realities" of the country's present plight. But there is a kind of settled and obstinate pessimism which is even more foolish.

Passenger traffic officials of the Eastern railroads decided yesterday not to follow the Louisville Nashville Railroad's cut in coach fares to 2 cents a mile, but arranged to make drastic reductions in rates between New York and Chicago for the Century of Progress Exposition.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- Senate and House leaders argued today that President Roosevelt had authority to sign the Smith, cotton relief bill, which President Hoover refused to approve. A delegation made up of Senators Smith and Byrnes and Representatives Pou of North Carolina, Wood of Georgia and Cox of Georgia conferred with the President early today in an effort to persuade him to sign the measure.

Harry H. Galinger, 55 years old, of 200 West 108th Street, head of the Antwerp Realty Corporation at 32 Broadway, was arrested on suspicion of grand larceny yesterday, following questioning by Joseph Schottland, Assistant District Attorney.

BERLIN, March 7. -- While the funeral cortege of a recently killed Nazi storm trooper was on its way to a Dusseldorf cemetery today it was fired upon from housetops, suppossedly by Communists. The escorting police returned the fire, stormed several houses and seized fifty persons.

C. Harold Smith, vice president and chief stockholder of the Columbian Carbon Company, who offered a $1,000 prize several years before his death for the best advice as to disposing of $10,000,000 for the greatest good to humanity, left an estate appraised yesterday at $4,594,926 gross and $2,692,172 net, no part of which was left in public bequests.

Complications arising from the bank holiday and uncertainties as to future developments prompted the directors of several companies to defer action on the declaration of dividends yesterday until a more definite appraisal of conditions can be made.

Little change was noticeable yesterday in the city's reactions to the bank holiday. Big stores and small shops continued to invite credit and check accounts, foods and other necessities were still available to persons in almost every walk of life, while dealers in luxuries and theatre owners reported a steady decline.

Mrs. Martha Lauchran, wife of a veteran shipyard worker, who was robbed last Friday in Brooklyn of $10,180, all the money she and her husband had been able to amass in a lifetime of saving, was notified yesterday by the police that the two men who robbed her had been arrested in Camden, S.C., and $8,200 of her money recovered.
Alderman Joseph Clark Baldwin, Republican, and Controller Charles W. Berry, Democrat, put the personal touch in City Hall affairs yesterday by making pointed remarks about each other.
One of the largest leasing transactions in Brooklyn in several months, covering the property at 312-36 Flatbush Avenue, corner of Sterling Place, in the Park Slope section, was reported yesterday.

The concert of the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall yesterday afternoon, even though the or hestra is primarily a training ensemble, was its own excuse for being. With Georges Enesco as the distinguished violin soloist and Leon Barzin conducting the performances were evocative of the spirit of the composers represented and were maintained at a high level throughput the afternoon.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- The State Department has made formal inquiry of Spain as to whether Claude G. Bowers, New York editor, will be acceptable as Ambassador at Madrid, and has made similar inquiries of the British Government concerning Judge Robert W. Bingham, Louisville Courier Journal publisher, as Ambassador at London.

Opposition to the control of the shipment of plants, trees, shrubs and flowers into this State, as proposed in a bill now pending before the State Senate, was voiced yesterday by representatives of all branches of the florists and growers' industry at a public hearing held by the Merchants Association at its headquarters in the Woolworth Building.

The discovery this week of hundreds of dead or dying elder ducks on the beaches of Martha's Vineyard Island, off the Massachusetts coast, has aroused a good deal of alarm among conservationists in the Bay State and along the North Atlantic Coast.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,147,900 barrels, compared with 2,192,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 44,700 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 45,300 barrels in the daily average in Oklahoma was the most important change.

One of the most brilliant performances of chamber music of the season and in some aspects one of the most distinguished, took place yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, where the Budapest String Quartet gave its only recital of the year.

At a luncheon at India House, Hanover Square, the American Bureau of Shipping paid tribute yesterday, to Captain Giles Stedman, for his exploit in rescuing the crew of the British freighter Exeter City in January, and presented to him the Valor Medal of the bureau.

Daily average gross crude oil production in the United States last week was 2,147,900 barrels, compared with 2,192,600 in the preceding week, a decline of 44,700 barrels, according to the American Petroleum Institute. A decrease of 45,300 barrels in the daily average in Oklahoma was the most important change.

One of the most brilliant performances of chamber music of the season and in some aspects one of the most distinguished, took place yesterday afternoon in the Town Hall, where the Budapest String Quartet gave its only recital of the year.

At a luncheon at India House, Hanover Square, the American Bureau of Shipping paid tribute yesterday, to Captain Giles Stedman, for his exploit in rescuing the crew of the British freighter Exeter City in January, and presented to him the Valor Medal of the bureau.

Jacket dresses were outstanding in the Spring and Summer fashion showing of the Dress Creators League of America held yesterday afternoon in the grand ballroom of the Hotel Astor. The show was attended by more than 800 retailers from all parts of the country.

WASHINGTON, March 7 -- January exports from the United States declined to twenty-nine of the principal forty foreign markets and imports were less from twenty-two, according to detailed foreign trade figures made public today by the Commerce Department.

BOSTON, March 7 (AP) -- More than 12,000 rabid hockey followers tonight cheered the Boston Bruins as they climbed into second place in the National League's American division by outscoring the pace-setting Detroit Red Wings, 4 to 1, in a slam-bang battle at the Boston Garden.

"Between you and I," as the leading lady says in the first act, "The Lady Refuses" merely adds to the miseries of a wet night along Broadway. Many people came out of the rain into the Bijou last evening to take a peek at Saxon Kling's comedy, and many people gratefully hurried home.

The heads of New York City mutual savings banks decided yesterday to require depositors to give written notices sixty days in advance of withdrawing funds from their accounts when they are permitted to reopen their doors at the end of the banking holiday.

In nearly a score of countries alcohol is now mixed with gasoline. The object is not so much to benefit agriculture as to curtail importation of petroleum derivatives. German, Austrian, Hungarian motor trucks and automobiles run well enough on mixtures of alcohol and gasoline.

The Committee of the Whole of the Board of Estimate voted yesterday to summon the Tompkins Bus Company of Staten Island to appear on March 21 to show cause why its franchise should not be revoked for failure to make the payments required by its contract with the city.
MIAMI, Fla., March 7 (AP) -- Miami's tourist army, estimated 150,000 strong, halted to some extent today the scramble for cash which marked Monday's inauguration of the national bank holiday.

An appeal to members of the supervisory staff teachers and other employes of the Board of Education for contributions to the school relief fund, which has been depleted considerably by the financial stringency, was made yesterday by Dr. William J. O'Shea, Superintendent of Schools and chairman of the school relief committee.

Borough President George U. Harvey of Queens, in a letter to Controller Berry yesterday, requested the indefinite postponement of the tax sale on 2,697 parcels of land in Queens, which is scheduled to take place on May 4. The property, in the First Ward of the borough, includes churches, synagogues and other religious institutions as well as hundreds of small homes.

The National City Company, which has placed more securities with investors than any other banking institution in Wall Street history, will be divorced completely from its parent, the National City Bank, according to a statement made last night by James H. Ferkins, chairman of the board of directors of the bank.

Former Governor Smith was named last night as chairman of the Emergency Certificate Corporation which will undertake the issuance of a State scrip for New York in the event that the plan is finally authorized by Secretary of the Treasury Woodin.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday -- Bank holiday. Friday (last trading day) -- 3 per cent for the best names.

The New York Americans fought their way back into a tie for third place in the international division of the National Hockey League by defeating the Canadiens of Montreal at Madison Square Garden last night.

The Royal Commission, headed by Lord AMULREE, to inquire into the financial resources of Newfoundland, with a view to a loan of u300,000 by Great Britain, may help that Crown colony to emerge from something like disaster. To pay the interest on its debt due Jan. 3 Great Britain and Canada advanced the money needed, but something constructive must be done to put Newfoundland's house in order.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 7 -- Manhattan College put up stubborn resistance in a basketball game with Yale tonight, but was defeated, 31 to 25. The contest was replete with sensational shooting and was marked by keen defensive strategy on the part of both, teams.

The Elshuco Trio finished Its fifteenth season last night with a concert in the United Engineering Societies auditorium. The program was the second to be given by the ensemble celebrating the centenary of Brahms. The trio, comprising Karl Kraeuter, Willem Willeke and Aurelio Giorni, was augmented for the occasion by Conrad Held, violist, and the works played were the two Brahms piano quartets, in A major, Op. 26, and G minor, Op. 25.

LOS ANGELES, March 8. -- A tall, well-built blond young man has suddenly become the centre of attraction in the training camp of the Giants. His name is John Ryan and they call him Blondie. Among other things about him they say he may start at shortstop when the championship season begins.

The annual report of the Midland United Company for 1932 shows a consolidated deficit of $1,926,454 after charges, underlying dividends, depreciation and taxes, contrasting with a net income of $2,834,933 in 1931. Gross earnings last year were $38,302,097, against $46,018,323 the year before, and net earnings were $10,724,773, against $16,433,674.

MARE ISLAND, Cal., March 8 (AP). -- Ten thousand tons of concentrated fighting power will be launched here tomorrow when the new cruiser San Francisco slides down the ways to become the fifteenth ship of its class built by the United States under the limita- tions of the Washington Treaty of 1922.

LONDON, March 8. -- President Roosevelt's reported eight-point program headed by retention of the gold standard is held here chiefly responsible for the better tone of the British stock markets today.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The present banking difficulties in this country are not expected by Secretary of State Hull to affect the success of the coming World Monetary and Economic Conference or the part of the United States in that conference.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 8. -- Dr. Elston H. Bergen, dean of Princeton physicians, who had brought more than 3,500 Princeton babies into the world, died this afternoon at the age of 81, after a week's illness. Until his fatal illness he had continued his regular practice and had made visits to the Princeton Hospital as a member of its staff.
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 8. -- Babe Ruth came out for the Yankee practice today and dwarfed into insignificance every other development of an interesting day at Miller Huggins Memorial Field.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The action of the New York Legislature in passing an act enabling New York building and loan associations to affiliate themselves with the Home Loan Bank system was praised today by William T. Stevenson, chairman of the Home Loan Bank board.

BUENOS AIRES, March 8. -- The two branches here of United States banks were crowded today with people trying to reopen savings accounts they had closed Monday and Tuesday, but the banks refused to accept their deposits. Those who had closed their accounts in an American bank found it impossible to deposit others elsewhere.

A single banking system for the nation, was urged on President Roosevelt by Dr. John Dewey, educator, writing as national chairman of the League for Independent Political Action, in a letter made public yesterday.

PARIS, March 8. -- In the face of recent events in Germany and the continued coldness of Franco-Italian relations, the visit tomorrow of Prime Minister MacDonald and Sir John Simon to Paris on their way to Geneva is welcomed by the French Government.

Leading commodity exchanges throughout the city expect to open for trading, at least in spot if not in futures, just as soon as it may be legally and practically possible. In many quarters it is believed these exchanges will open before the securities exchanges.
