The Interborough, as was to be expected, is beginning to feel the competition of the new city subway. As more trunk lines are opened up by the latter the competition will be keener. The public will benefit to the extent that congestion on the old lines is relieved.

LONDON, March 8 -- Prime Minister MacDonald, accompanied by Sir John Simon, Foreign Secretary, is leaving tomorrow morning for Paris, where they will spend a day with Premier Daladier at the old game of hunting for a formula to save the Disarmament Conference. On Friday night they will proceed to Geneva.

Prices of American and foreigngrown cotton made more sharp advances yesterday in trading abroad. In Liverpool, contract quotations rose 10 English points, which made a gain of about 30 points in two days, while American middling advanced 20 and Indian 22 points.

Plans for cutting adrift the Chase Harris Forbes Corporation and its parent, the Chase Securities Corporation, which control the largest security distributing system in the world, from the Chase National Bank group of interest were announced last night by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank.

Dental laboratories and gold refiners for the Jewelry trade found their supply of raw twenty-fourcarat gold from the United States Assay Offices almost completely cut off yesterday, except for what might be obtained for deposits of sweepings and old or salvaged gold.

High praise for the prompt and intelligent way in which the Roosevelt Administration took hold of the banking situation continues to be heard. It is no doubt deserved. It helps to account for the remarkable calm and good cheer with which the people have submitted to their temporary embarrassments.

Patterned after the British charitable organization known as Ye Ancient Order of Froth Blowers, said to be third largest of the kind in England, the Society of Stoopnocracy was incorporated yesterday with the approval of Supreme Court Justice Carew to aid the destitute and unemployed.

A return to the decorative and truly feminine fashions was evident in the Spring and Summer style presentation of the Fashion Originators' Guild of America held last night in the Grand Ballroom of the Waldorf-Astoria. More than 700 executives, buyers and stylists of leading stores in all parts of the country attended to view the 140 models.

The English artist Harrington Mann opened yesterday at the Seligmann Galleries an exhibition of portraits, which is scheduled to continue until March 29. This is not the usual sort of slick "society" painting. Although it stresses the decorative aide and makes no bones about being intent upon producing a likeness, Mr. Mann's portrait work has a freshness of approach and an individuality in the matter of tone, texture and brushwork that make it ingratiating.

An interesting experiment took place last night in Carnegie Hall in the form of a recital by Julia Peters, lyric soprano, with "visual accompaniment" by Thomas Wilfred's clavilux, or color organ. By far the most interesting and beautiful portions of the performance were Mr. Wilfred's four solos upon his astonishing instrument.

LONDON, March 8 (AP). -- The domestic banking emergency in the United States has not changed Great Britain's policy so far as return to the gold standard is concerned, it was learned today from the highest financial quarters of the British Government.

Morning and afternoon play yesterday on the courts of the Junior League of New York brought the women's division of the metropolitan squash racquets championship to the semi-final round. The four survivors of the original field of fifty-five include in their ranks three of the four players seeded in the draw, the fourth, Mrs. E.T. Hill, being forced to default in her third-round match.

Mr. MELLON referred in his farewell address in London last month to the "appalling frequency" with which American Ambassadors come and go in Great Britain. His own term of service has been just short of a year. Before him we had DAWES and KELLOGG and HOUGHTON in swift succession.

Retailers Ordering Staples. A decidedly mixed situation has developed in buying by retailers here during the last two days, reports here yesterday indicated. While mail orders for ready-to-wear and allied merchandise have grown progressively smaller since Monday, there has been a rather noticeable tendency on the part of both small and large retailers to cover themselves on staple and semi-staple goods owing to the view that these goods are headed for an advance.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 8. -- George Fissler, former national record holder in the 440-yard backstroke event, triumphed in the feature of the first annual Yale swimming carnival tonight, winning the 440-yard free style race in 5 minutes 1 1-5 seconds.

For nearly six hours yesterday a jury in the trial on a coercion charge of Sam Kaplan, deposed president, and fourteen other former officials or members of Local 306 of the Motion Picture Machine Operators Protective Union of Greater New York listened to the defense counsel extol Kaplan and the prosecutor condemn him.
Opponents of the plan to convert Fort Sehuyler in the east Bronx into a park presented their arguments before Mayor O'Brien yesterday in a crowded meeting in City Hall.

Despite an order issued Tuesday by Amos W.W. Woodcock, Prohibition Director, putting into immediate effect restrictions to prevent Federal agents from purchasing liquor for use as evidence, agents under Andrew McCampbell, New York administrator, were able yesterday to raid twenty small speakeasies and cordial shops, making an arrest in each place.

Trailing one game down and with the score 11 -- 5 against him in the second, Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia Club, former titleholder, rallied to defeat Pat Cohalan of the New York A.C. in the national Class A squash tennis championship at the Harvard Club yesterday.

WASHINGTON, Thursday, March 9. -- A plan for new currency to be supplied to a large number of banks so that they may open for business Friday was outlined by President Roosevelt last night at the White House to a group of Congressional leaders.

Richard L. Simon, publisher, is returning today on the Italian liner Rex from a conference at Nice with former Mayor Walker and Frank Scully, who has helped him to write his memoirs of twenty-three years in politics in this city.

A British tennis team of either two or four players, to be headed in all likelihood by Frederick Perry, will come to the United States this Summer to play in the important grass court invitation and championship tournaments.

The directors of the Tide Water Associated Oil Company omitted yesterday the dividend of $1.50 a share on the 6 per cent cumulative preferred stock, which would be payable on April 1. Axtell J. Byles, president, in a letter to holders of the stock, explained that in 1932 dividends on the preferred shares had been earned by only a narrow margin, while now they were not being earned because of conditions in the oil industry.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Governor Ritchie of Maryland, aroused over the plight of small banks if scrip issued by clearing house associations were used largely during the banking emergency, called upon President Roosevelt today and urged that some program be devised to take care of the banks not members of a clearing house association.

For the second time within two months Judge Grover M. Moscowitz in the United States District Court in Brooklyn was compelled yesterday to declare a mistrial of an action before him because of the failure of a juror to appear on time.

Payrolls and Individual pay checks which were presented to banks open for the purpose throughout the city yesterday were paid only partly at the largest banks, except at the Irving Trust Company. The Irving Trust paid in full all day, basing its action on the permission granted by Secretary Woodin, among other items, "for the payment of usual salaries and wages."

The Board of Education, at its meeting yesterday, formally approved the proposed legislative bill, which it drafted at a joint session with the board of superintendents, to eliminate multiple job holding in the public school system by permitting leaves of absence without pay to teachers holding regular and non-regular positions.

Pleading for public support of President Roosevelt in the "national crisis," William Green, president of the American Federation of Labor, declared yesterday "the time has arrived when wage-cutting should end and when corporations and humane employers should boldly and courageously lead in announcing increases of wages to all employes."

LONDON, March 8. -- Foreign exchange quotations today reflected a more hopeful feeling regarding the outlook for the dollar. Unofficial dealings in dollars were done much nearer the last official rate of $3.44 3/4 than on Monday. Financial London is still talking of a rate of $3.50 or slightly more at the re-opening of American exchange.
Easing of the currency situation yesterday relieved the strain upon public and private agencies for the relief of New York's unemployed.

Several dinners were given last night in the Seaglade of the St. Regis, and another entertainment in the series for the benefit of philanthropic organizations of the city was held there in behalf of the Children's Clinic Welfare Club of New York University and Bellevue Hospital Medical College.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The House of Representatives is ready to proceed at top speed writing into law the recommendations President Roosevelt will submit to Congress to bulwark the banking structure of the country, and to enact such emergency legislation as may, in the opinion of the President, be necessary in weathering the financial crisis.

Legislation affecting conservation, and especially that branch of it relating to fish, game and wild life in general, is expected to come before the new Congress, and sportsmen the country over are awaiting the progress of the measures.

With the special session of Congress meeting today to enact emergency banking legislation, the New York commercial banks and trust companies prepared yesterday to reopen tomorrow on as close to a "normal" basis as Secretary of the Treasury Woodin will permit.

Issuance by the national government of $2,000,000,000 "recovery bonds" to be spent immediately on goods made and consumed in the United States would do much to reestablish employment and restore business, according to Dr. H.C. Dickinson, senior scientist of the United States Bureau of Standards and president of the Society of Automotive Engineers.

RONKONKOMA, L.I., March 8. -- Rumors heard in this village for two weeks that a "buried treasure" had been found near here were, confirmed today with the disclosure that four men employed by the Islip Emergency Relief Committee had found a gold mesh handbag filled with pieces of jewelry beneath the root of a tree they were preparing to cut down on Lakeland Avenue.

A $1,500,000 realty deal involving immediate improvement of the southwest corner of Park Avenue and Fortieth Street was announced yesterday, marking the largest Manhattan transaction outside of foreclosures this year and one of the few business-construction projects within recent years.

With the bulk of bank deposits still immobilized, business was conducted yesterday under emergency limitations, just as it has been since the close of last week. Funds were released for payrolls and for necessary purposes, but the banks generally were on a holiday basis.

The Carteret Academy sextet triumphed over Riverdale Country Day School, 3 to 2, and Summit High School and Morristown School battled to a 1-all deadlock in a five-minute overtime clash in a brace of scholastic hockey games played at the New York Coliseum yesterday.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- In addition to its other worries, the State Department now has before it complaints from diplomats who are unable to get any money out of their banks. Precedents are being patiently searched, but so far the department has been unable to find any hope for the indignant and hard-pressed envoys.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- President Roosevelt began his semi-weekly conferences with newspaper correspondents today, talking frankly and freely to them.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Proclamations were issued today by many Governors throughout the country calling on the people of their States for unified support of the government and on Congress for prompt action.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8. -- Hack Wilson, one of the two most stubborn holdouts of the Brooklyn club, arrived tonight, accompanied by his wife and small son. The other player still missing, Joe Stripp, has sent no direct word to the club in weeks.
BOSTON, March 8. -- Harvard's varsity hockey team defeated the Yale sextet, 4 to 3, in the Boston Garden tonight and won the annual series, two games to one.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The Seventy-third Congress, which will convene in special session tomorrow at noon, will have a Democratic majority of 22 in the Senate and 195 in the House. This will be the greatest Democratic majority, according to available records, since the Thirty-fourth Congress in 1855.
Dr. James Rowland Angell, President of Yale University, was elected yesterday to succeed the late Calvin Coolidge on the board of directors of the New York Life Insurance Company.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Not many persons realize that the Federal Government administers one Federal program of education -- namely, that of the Indian Bureau, which has the responsibility for the education, of thousands of Indian children scattered throughout the whole area of the United States.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Prohibition Bureau announced today that it had directed its forces throughout the country to specialize on eradication of the sources of liquor supply, leaving the handling of "speakeasies" to the States.

Mortgagees acting as plaintiffs in foreclosure proceedings bought in fourteen Manhattan and Bronx properties at auction sales yesterday. Tenement houses comprised by far the largest item on the list, which included only two Bronx parcels, one a vacant plot on Pelham Parkway North, at Eastchester Road.
CONCORD, N.H., March 8 (AP). -- The House of Representatives today passed the pari-mutuel race track bill by a vote of 273 to 109.

Aldous Huxley is recommending the coast towns of Portugal for writers with little money and much work to do. Harold Lamb is speaking well of Teheran, Persia, where a large room with magnificent carpets, three meals, a shower bath and unlimited service costs, he says $1.17 a day.

Plans for the formation of a self-liquidating corporation to borrow several million dollars from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation with which to finance reputable garment manufacturing concerns in New York, whose normal lines of credit have been curtailed or eliminated by recent banking difficulties, were mapped out yesterday by financial interests and business leaders of the district at a meeting of the directors of the Seventh Avenue Civic Association in the Hotel Astor.

President Roosevelt will again declare himself for "sound money" in his book, "Looking Forward," which the John Day Company will publish March 16. He will say also that "the day of the great promoter or financial titan, to whom we granted everything if only he would build or develop, is over."
KANSAS CITY, March 8. -- Two college teams remained in the A.A.U. national basketball title fight as favorites, although finding the going hard at times, moved into the quarter-finals tonight.

The St. Nick Hockey Club scored an impressive 6-to-1 victory over the Bronx H.C. at the New York Coliseum last night in an exhibition game before about 1,500 persons and gained some measure of revenge for its defeat last Sunday when the Bronx sextet won the championship of the New York Amateur League.

The protective committee for Kreuger Toll Company 5 per cent secured sinking fund gold debentures, headed by Grayson M.-P. Murphy, has supplied the New York Stock Exchange with information in regard to Class A and Class B certificates of deposit issued under the protective agreement.

GENEVA, March 8. -- Agreeing that Peru's attitude toward conciliation of the Leticia dispute with Colombia was unsatisfactory, the League of Nations Council this afternoon authorized the committee of three on Latin-American conflicts to prepare a report under Paragraph 4, Article XV of the League covenant for submission to the Council on March 15.

Plans of twelve new buildings to cost $1,558,900 were filed with the Manhattan Bureau of Buildings last month, against eighteen new structures to cost $1,733,700 projected in February, 1932, Samuel J. Fassler, superintendent of the bureau, reported yesterday.

Conditions under which the New York banks will be permitted to reopen tomorrow on a practically normal basis are virtually completed except for details in the government's national banking program at Washington, according to information in well-informed banking circles here last night.

WASHINGTON, March 8 -- The Federal Reserve Board tonight ordered all member banks to report the names of all persons who have withdrawn gold from member banks since Feb. 1. obviously in an effort to get a complete check on gold hoarders.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Alexander Dana Noyes's statement to the Senate Finance Committee, which was printed in THE TIMES of March 5, was most enlightening in regard to the clear demonstration he gave that the war, in the light of history, can be regarded as the sole cause of the depression.

Milton F. Baumann, industrial traffic manager of Jersey City, was re-elected chairman of the Shippers Conference of Greater New York yesterday at the fifteenth annual meeting of the conference at the rooms of the Merchants Association in the Woolworth Building.

Sales of the General Motors Corporation to consumers in the United States in February amounted to 42,280 cars, against 50,653 in January, and 46,855 in February, 1932, it was announced yesterday. In January sales to consumers were larger than in January, 1932.

BERLIN, March 8 -- The German Foreign Office authorized the statement today that the government deplored the three cases of molestation of Americans brought to its attention yesterday by the United States Embassy. Evidently unauthorized or self-appointed groups of Nazis were to blame in each case, it was said.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., March 8. -- A trust fund of $20,000, the income to be used for "the development of better understanding between the people of China and Japan and the people of the United States," is created in the will of the late William Morgan Savin, former member of the New York Stock Exchange, filed for probate here today.

DENVER, March 8 (AP). -- Centring in the Dakotas and bordering States, the hunt for two men Federal authorities charged with kidnapping Charles Boettcher 2d for $60,000 ransom was pushed vigorously tonight, while police here began building up cases against four other suspects held in jail.

BERLIN, March 8. -- The Boerse was a little less active today than yesterday, but the volume of business still exceeded the pre-election turnovers. Strength in both the stock and bond markets was still pronounced, although the advances today were not so general as recently.

The election of Professor Marston T. Bogert of the Department of Chemistry of Columbia University as president of the Columbia Chapter of Sigma Xi, national honorary science fraternity, was announced yesterday at the university. Professor Bogert, a past president of the American Chemical Society, succeeds Professor Donald E. Lancefield of the Department of Zoology.

When Sinclair Lewis is planning a novel, and he usually spends about a year planning each one, he talks at the rate of about 200 words a minute to his secretary, Louis Florey, and Mr. Florey makes notes. He does not put down all that the author says, but makes notes in outline form.
WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- Lights blaze from the Bureau of Engraving and Printing these nights as three shifts of workers hasten the printing of crisp Federal Reserve notes.

Although, the volume of retail trade yesterday continued to show the adverse effects of the banking moratorium, store executives here were inclined to regard improving sentiment as presaging a turn for the better. Payroll payments by banks and the ending of the confusion with regard to scrip were viewed as factors tending to stabilize consumers' purchasing.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- President and Mrs. Roosevelt paid a birthday call this afternoon on Oliver Wendell Holmes, retired Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, who is 92 years old today. They drove to the home of the aged jurist in K Street and spent some time with him in his library, where, surrounded by his favorite books which he now "has time to read," Mr. Holmes passes the greater part of his quiet days.

ALBANY, March 8. -- All day long members of the Senate and Assembly have been "standing by" on Capitol Hill, awaiting word from Governor Lehman in New York City to get into action at a moment's notice on more measures related to the banking emergency.

ATHENS, March 8. -- Panayoti Tsaldaris, leader of the Royalist party, which won in Sunday's election, was commissioned today by President Alexander Zaimis to form a new Cabinet and hopes to be able to announce its composition within a few days.

LONDON, March 8 -- "Buy British," the campaign that was expected to bring about a revival of British manufacturing by turning purchasers away from foreign goods to home products, is now doubted by one of its most powerful advocates.

NEWARK, N.J., March 8. -- A quiet soft-spoken man, who had registered at a hotel here as Edward E. Jackson of Baltimore, was arrested by the police today and held for the New York authorities as a fugitive from justice. The police said that he was Edward Jockin, an internationally known confidence man who had been accused of swindling $250,000 from wealthy residents of New York.

Average daily electric-power production, adjusted for seasonal variation, amounted to 201,100,000 kilowatt-hours in the week ended March 4, as against 203,100,000 kilowatt-hours in the preceding week and 214,700,000 kilowatt-hours in the corresponding week last year.

PHILADELPHIA, March 8. -- Walter Spence helped Rutgers defeat Pennsylvania, 41 to 30, in their Intercollegiate Swimming Association meet at the Hutchinson Pool tonight by winning two events and swimming anchor on the relay team that finished thirty yards ahead of the Red and Blue.

DUBLIN, March 8. -- An attack on the government wage-cutting policy led to stormy scenes in the Dail Eireann tonight and resulted in the withdrawal of a Labor deputy, Timothy Murphy of West Cork, from the Chamber.

Last year Mr. TURNER, Pepysian Librarian at Magdalene College, Cambridge, announced that a new edition of the Diary was in course of preparation. The tercentenary edition, its publishers have given notice, will be in seven or eight volumes, the first of which, it is hoped, will be issued next Fall.

More than 1,000 editors, staff members and faculty advisers of elementary and secondary school publications throughout the country are expected to attend the three-day sessions of the ninth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association, which opens today at Columbia University.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- To many of the President's closest advisers, the Aldrich-Vreeland act, repealed when the Federal Reserve act came into effect, provides the model scheme for the projected expansion of currency through Federal Reserve notes, not redeemable in gold, and on a ratio of 150 to the liquid assets of sound banks.

In spite of the unsettled conditions in the sugar industry, the American Sugar Refining Company was able to make a better showing in 1932 than in 1931. Net income after interest, depreciation and premium and discount on bonds was $4,327,986, equivalent after preferred dividends to $2.62 a share on the common stock.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- Heavy receipts by truck helped today to swell the movement of live stock to the local market, so that arrivals were far in excess of expectations. The 18,000 hogs received were 10,000 more than estimated early yesterday, when it was expected that the yards would be closed to open trading.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 8. -- Three English stars and one American internationalist, Mrs. Opal S. Hill of Kansas City, were successful in their quarter-final matches of the annual women's Belleair golf championship at the Belleair Country Club today.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., March 8. -- Mrs. Catherine Glen, descendant of early Dutch settlers in New Jersey, died yesterday at her home here in her ninetieth year. She was the widow of Charles T. Glen, a prominent Newark attorney. Mrs. Glen was born in Young's Mills, which was named after her father, the late Peter R. Young.
A new play by A.A. Milne, entitled "Sarah Simple," has been acquired by the Theatre Guild for future production. The play has been handled in this country through Curtis Browne, Ltd.

SHANGHAI, March 8. -- Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang's resignation as North China military leader and acceptance of blame for the loss of Jehol Province were hailed by officials in Nanking today as opening the way to extend Nanking's domination and make North China "really a part of China."

Macmillans are scouting for new American novels after several years during which most of the fiction published by that house has been English. Harold S. Latham, vice president of the Macmillan Company, said yesterday that he is particularly interested in new Southern writers.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Jesse Isidbr Straus of New York is understood to have been selected for appointment as Ambassador to France and the State Department is said to have made formal inquiry of the French Government as to his acceptability, preparatory to the sending of his nomination to the Senate by President Roosevelt.

Canadian business, with the exception of grain trading at Winnipeg, presented a cheerful picture yesterday as the United States strove to ease the financial situation resulting from the banking holiday.

MONTREAL, March 8 (AP). -- Volume expanded moderately on the Stock Exchange today as demand increased for base metal stocks and the utilities. Prices moved up firmly, but closed slightly below the best levels of the day. Transfers exceeded 11,000 shares.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The combined opposition of the railroads was thrown today against a petition of seven organizations asking the Interstate Commerce Commission to require the carriers to show cause why they should not make drastic reduction in freight rates.

General PLASTIRAS, who announced on Monday the setting up of a military government "to avoid the possibility of disorder" in Greece following the result of the elections on Sunday, thus played for a second time the role of dictator, but for a few hours only.

Declaring that this Is "a day of judgment," the Rev. Dr. Albert W. Beaven, as president of the Federal Council of Churches of Christ in America, issued a statement yesterday calling for "a time of united prayer" on the part of the Protestant people of America.

BERLIN, March 8.--The Reich Government tonight seized the police power in the States of Saxony, Baden, Wurttemberg1 and Schaumburg-Lippe under the emergency decree for the protection of the States. National Socialist police commissioners were appointed for these States by the Reich Minister of Interior, Dr. Wilhelm Frick.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Commenting on the upturn in farm and commodity prices, the Washington correspondent of The St. Paul Pioneer Press tonight prepared an analysis of the situation in relation to the administration's financial policy.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- Notified that the administration, at Washington had decided upon a plan of currency issuance and had frowned upon the putting out of scrip by local groups, Chicago Clearing House officials stopped work today on their certificate plans while they awaited more information.

Forty-one members of the class of 1933 in the Margaret Fahnestock Training School of the New York Post-Graduate Hospital received diplomas last night from Dr. Charles Gordon Heyd, retiring president of the New York State Medical Society, in exercises held in St. George's Church House at 207 East Sixteenth Street.

Plans for a revival of Channing Pollock's play "The Fool," which was first produced in 1922 at the Times Square Theatre with great success, under the sponsorship of the Greater New York Federation of Churches, were discussed yesterday afternoon at a meeting of the executive committee of that organization, held at 71 West Twenty-third Street.

THE report from Los Angeles is that Manager Bill Terry of the Giants doesn't know what to do about Sam Leslie. Sam plays first base when he gets a chance and hits heartily at every opportunity. But Manager Terry already has a regular first baseman for the Giants. His name is Bill Terry. That makes it a real problem.

HAVANA, March 8 (AP). -- With the Trial Handicap for the Cuban Grand National declared off, Mrs. F.A. Carreaud's Uma carried off the major honors at Oriental Park today, winning the six-furlong feature over a muddy racing strip. The time was 1:18 1-5.

The proposed issuance of State scrip was canceled last night when Governor Lehman announced that Secretary of the Treasury Woodin had revoked the permission granted Tuesday morning for the Emergency Certificate Corporation to issue a uniform temporary money for New York State.
HAVANA, March 8. -- The threeday banking holdiya which went into effect in Cuba on March 6 was extended to include March 9 by a decree signed by President Machado tonight.

Controller Berry began issuing salary checks yesterday to 52,000 city employes, Including 7,000 emergency workers, drawing on cash deposits of the city's money which were released by the Chase National Bank and the National City Bank through arrangements made with Secretary of the Treasury Woodin.

St. Michael's High School of Union City, defending champion in the fourth annual metropolitan Catholic Schools' basketball tournament under the auspices of the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, was eliminated in a second-round encounter at the K. of C. clubhouse in Brooklyn last night.
VIENNA, March 8 (AP). -- Alfred Frauenfeld, leader of the Austrian National Socialists, said today that his party was highly gratified at the assumption of dictatorial powers by Chancellor Dollfuss.

A resolution calling upon Governor Lehman and the Legislature to enact immediate legislation to set up unemployment reserve funds, to go into effect as soon as industrial conditions show a 20 per cent rise in the index of employment, was adopted unanimously last night at a meeting at the Women's City Club, held under the auspices of the club and the New York Conference for Unemployment Insurance Legislation.

The strongest array of American players to be drawn for an indoor tennis championship in years will start Saturday in the thirty-fourth annual national tournament at the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Assignment of committee chairmanships among Democratic Senators today resulted in a large number of new members receiving prized posts, with the consequent enhancement of prestige and the right to employ two or three extra clerks, according to the particular committee involved.

There will doubtless be much discussion whether the United States is "on" or "off" the gold standard. Responsible foreign comment on our existing situation rejects the idea of any abandonment of that standard here. The London Times remarks that "none of the compelling causes" which in 1931 drove England off the gold standard "is found in the United States today."

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 8. -- Problems, political and economic, which are besetting the world, will be taken up in realistic fashion by 350 students from twenty-seven institutions, who will meet at Smith College here tomorrow for the annual session of the Model League of Nations of the New England group of colleges and universities.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I have been privileged to read in the Congressional Record the letter addressed to you on Jan. 3 concerning a solution to the railroad problem, by George Foster Peabody.

Anxious buying pressure, which had forced spot prices to higher levels in the commodity markets, seemed to have subsided yesterday and prices were substantially steadier, with a few declines in price reported.

The Polish people are watching Hitler in Germany with unusual interest because they fear he will precipitate a war between Poland and Germany, a war which would embroil other European countries, according to M.F. Wegrzynek, publisher of The Polish Morning World in New York, who returned yesterday on the French liner Champlain.

ASHLAND, Wis., March 8 (AP). -- The Coast Guard cutter Crawford, moving cautiously in a blizzard, was cruising about Madeline Island tonight in search of a large ice floe on which an unknown number of men and dogs are believed to be drifting in Lake Superior.
DES MOINES, March 8 (AP). -- Acting Governor Kraschel announced this afternoon that all Iowa Slate and national banks were closed to conform with the State proclamation.

UNION CITY, N.J., March 8. -- Four persons and two policemen spent two hours raking through several tons of trash here today and finally recovered a cardboard box containing hoarded gold, which had been carried away in a garbage truck from a store here last night.

Brokers reported leaseholds on several Manhattan housing properties yesterday. Most of the day's activity was on the upper east side, where long-term contracts were negotiated on three apartment houses near Park Avenue.
The leasing of entire floors in Manhattan buildings yesterday indicated a good demand for large units of space.

A reform program, designed to purge the commercial banking business of all taint of speculative leadership and calculated to reduce the present overlords of the New York money market to a position of relative impotence, was proposed last night by Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank, in connection with an announcement that the bank had decided to divorce its security affiliate, the Chase Securities Corporation.

Herbert Hoover again took an early morning walk yesterday -- his second in four years without a Secret Service escort -- and then resumed his rounds of business conferences and talks with old friends, which have occupied most of his waking hours since Monday.

DARJEELING, India, March 8. -- The remaining members of the Mount Everest climbing party, in cluding Captain E. St. J. Birnie, F.S. Smythe, Dr. C.R. Greene one of the two medical officers of the expedition; E.O. Shebbeare of the Indian Forest Service and myself, are leaving here today for Kalimpong.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 8. -- The Princeton basketball team concluded its non-league schedule tonight with a 44-18 victory over the Rutgers five. Seibert continued his scoring streak to lead the Tigers' attack with 13 points as the Tigers registered their second victory of the season over the New Brunswick passers.

Keith S. Brown of Yale has entered both the pole vault and invitation high jump events to be contested at the fourteenth annual K. of C. indoor track and field meet to be held next Wednesday night at Madison Square Garden. Announcement of his entry was made yesterday, along with those of several other stars.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- Strong protests have been voiced to Secretary Woodin by New York bankers and others against the new Treasury regulation which provides for segregation in trust accounts of new deposits.

WASHINGTON, March 8. -- In the hope of finding some new plan of farm relief capable of being applied to this year's crops and "provide an orderly retreat for the overextended part of our agriculture," Secretary Wallace announced today that he had called a conference of representatives of the farm organizations and cooperative associations dealing in export commodities to meet here next Friday.

Mrs. Marjorie E. Woodhouse Leidy of Philadelphia and Rye, N.Y., was drowned and her husband, Carter Randolph Leidy, was painfully injured yesterday when their automobile plunged forty feet from an embankment into the Bronx River at Olinville Avenue, where the stream passes under the Gun Hill Road Bridge.

Climate in New York is unfavorable to outdoor bazaars, but a suggestion in this week's Publishers Weekly for open-air book stalls is practical enough to merit consideration. The idea behind the plan is to put more out-of-work booksellers back into business, even if only temporarily.

Younger American artists who have suffered from the depression are represented in the sizable exhibition of oils and water-colors at the Hotel Brevoort. Two large rooms on the first floor have been contributed as gallery space. This is a serious show of honest work.
TULSA, Okla., March 8 (AP). -- The midcontinent oil industry struggled along today, hopeful of an early flow of currency to prevent demoralization.

Max Lissberger, for many years a partner in the firm of B. Lissberger Co., 295 Madison Avenue, smelters and refiners of non-ferrous metals, and after that, until recently, an executive of its successor, the Federated Metals Corporation, died Monday at his residence in the Hotel Pierre of heart disease after an illness of several years.
ATLANTA, Ga., March 8 (AP). -- The South continued buying and selling cotton today at prices generally 30 to 50 points above the last quoted prices on the exchanges.
NEW YORK. Colonel and Mrs. Jacques Balsan have joined Brig. Gen. and Mrs. Cornelius Vanderbilt at 640 Fifth Avenue.

TRENTON, N.J., March 8. -- In a proclamation issued today, Governor Moore asked the people of New Jersey to give united and wholehearted support to President Roosevelt in "the grave task that confronts him." The text of the proclamation follows:

PARIS, March 8. -- News of President Roosevelt's eight-point program, which includes maintenance of the gold standard, reached Paris about noon today and immediately added to the cheerful feeling in the American colony as well as in financial circles.
WASHINGTON, March 8. -- The proposal to issue scrip for a national exchange medium was thrown into the discard today by Secretary Woodin.

TORONTO, March 8. -- The Rev. Canon Bernard Bryan, D.D., rector emeritus of the Church of the Epiphany, who entered Wycliffe College on its foundation in 1877 and was the first student of Wycliffe ordained and the last survivor of the first class ordained, died today at his home in his eighty-second year.

ALBANY, March 8. -- Department store owners and retail merchants from all over the State strongly protested today against the proposed three-quarters of 1 per cent sales tax, but at the public hearing on Governor Lehman's tax measures questions by legislators indicated a sentiment for raising it to 2 per cent.

TORONTO, March 8. -- The National Hockey League All-Stars had new faces in the line-up tonight and among the missing were Howie Morenz and Chuck Gardiner, who just a year ago were re-elected to The Canadian Press team by nearly unanimous balloting by sports writers in the circuit.

To the Editor of The New York Times: I did not experience the San Francisco earthquake, but I am going through the great New York bank eclipse. Crowded days, oblivion to impending events, failing to read the latest edition of THE TIMES on Saturday morning -- these were the reasons which brought me to Monday morning, March 6, with $1 in my pocketbook.

PALM BEACH, Fla., March 8. -- For the twenty-third successive year, colonists assembled this afternoon at the Poinciana diamond to witness the baseball game for the benefit of the Palm Beach Police Pension Fund in which a team composed of Winter residents played the team of the Palm Beach police.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP). -- A unified dry campaign to defeat repeal of the Eighteenth Amendment was voted today by 1,000 representatives of prohibition organizations and church groups, assembled here at the call of their leaders.

The New York Stock Exchange will reopen as soon as adequate banking facilities are provided for the consummation of transactions in securities, it was indicated yesterday in informed quarters. For this reason there is a possibility that the Exchange and other security and commodity markets in this city will reopen tomorrow or Saturday if the banks resume normal activities and are able to clear payments for stocks.

Fifth avenue Promenade. A tall, sturdy, well-groomed gentleman with a touch of gray at the temples left his hotel on Fiftieth Street early Tuesday morning for a stroll up Fifth Avenue to Central Park and back.

MIAMI, Fla., March 8. -- The Flying Ebony filly, Ebony Lady, owned by Mrs. Jack Howard and ridden by Silvio Coucci, was a decisive winner of the featured Anton J. Cermak Memorial Purse at Hialeah Park today. The favorite at 3 to 4, Ebony Lady made light of the feather of 100 pounds and sped the mile of the test in 1:37 1-5.

ALBANY, March 8. -- After Assembly Republicans had agreed to- day on a new schedule of salary cuts for State employes, ranging from 5 to 25 per cent, it was announced there would be a conference tomorrow of the legislative, leaders and the steering committees of the two houses on the budget.

WASHINGTON, March 8 (AP) -- Whimsically commenting that he had been warned that his new system would not work, President Roosevelt settled back in his chair and let the queries come thick and last today.

GENEVA, March 8. -- In a communication to the League of Nations, published today, the Japanese Government explains that, though it has been obliged to "withdraw its representatives from the League Assembly," it is continuing, because of its "unshaken determination to contribute to the establishment of universal peace," to participate in the disarmament conference.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 8. -- Attorneys defending the nine Negroes for whom the United States Supreme Court ordered new trials after they had been condemned to death for an attack on two white girls on a freight train passing through Jackson County, Ala., two years ago, met here today and planned their campaign of action.

CHICAGO, March 8. -- The American banking situation has thrown a pall over the world's grain trade and operators in all countries showed today a pronounced disposition to await a settlement of the difficulties. Winnipeg reported only a fair amount of business in wheat futures, partly in the way of evening up open commitments.

Justice Wenzel in Queens Supreme Court granted yesterday a temporary injunction to Charles Duveen, son of Lord Joseph Duveen, well-known English art expert, restraining S. Karpen Brothers, Inc., furniture manufacturers of Long Island City, from using the name "Charles of London" for their products.

State of Oregon. The State of Oregon plans to offer for sale on March 15 $1,500,000 of highway bonds originally scheduled for award on March 1. The issue will be dated April 1, 1933, and will mature $300,000 annually on April 1, 1934 to 1938.
Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt gives her idea of the "new deal" in an article, "What I Hope to Leave Behind," in the April issue of Pictorial Review, published today.

Prompt and final settlement or intergovernmental debts either by drastic downward adjustment or a long, flexible moratorium is favored by editors of ninety-two trade publications representing all of the nation's major business and industrial interests.

LOS ANGELES, March 8. -- The decision as to how long the Stock Exchange should remain closed should not rest with the members, but with some official authority specifically charged with such a decision, said Samuel Untermyer, speaking before the law alumni of the University of Southern California here today.

George W. Wickersham, chairman of the commission named by former President Hoover to study the prosecution of crime in the United States, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by his wife. He had been abroad to serve on an arbitration committee in a question of claims between Portugal and Germany.

LONDON, March 9. -- After cheerful early dealings today some sections of the Stock Exchange became dull in the afternoon on disturbing German news. The disquieting Continental reports, however, were denied officially and the market closed firm.

TOKYO, Friday, March 10. -- A spokesman for the Foreign Office this morning announced the possibility that a Japanese advance into North China had been made imminent by the Chinese resistance at Kupei Pass in the Great Wall and the large concentrations of Chinese troops at Miyun.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Josephus Daniels of North Carolina, Secretary of the Navy when President Roosevelt was Assistant Secretary, has been selected to head the new transportation agency which may take over the functions of the Shipping Board and the aeronautics division of the Commerce Department as well as some of the duties of the Interstate Commerce Commission.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- A record for Executive and legislative action was written today in the effort of the nation to end its banking difficulties, but progress was partly checked tonight by the inability of an administrative arm of the government to keep pace.

Prize awards, eagerly awaited by the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra's youngest audience each year, will be presented by Mary Garden as guest at the last of the elementary series of concerts for children tomorrow morning at Carnegie Hall.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Senate vote on passage of the emergency banking bill was as follows:
MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- Joseph Zangara, slayer of Mayor Cermak of Chicago, faced sentence to death or life imprisonment tomorrow still grinning and unrepentant as he sat in his cell here tonight.

Considerably more Federal Income tax returns have been filed In the offices of the four Internal revenue districts which take in the five boroughs of the city in advance of March 15, the final day for filing, than on the same date last year, it was learned yesterday.

To the Editor of The New York Times: THE TIMES published the obituary of a great man, Sir William J. Wanless, M.D., whose distinguished service to the missionary cause was no less than his service to India, for which the British Government conferred upon him the honor of knighthood and the Kaisar-i-Hind Medal.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- The six-furlong track record of 1:102-5 was equaled at Hialeah Park today when J.C. Ellis's Leros won the Biscayne Purse by a length and a half at the substantial odds of $17.70 for $2. Piloted by Johnny Gilbert, the gelded son of Nocturnal and Parley led practically from start to finish to gain his third victory of the meeting.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The time table of banking developments today was as follows:

HAMILTON Bermuda, March 9. -- Ten thousand persons greeted the new Furness flagship Queen of Bermuda as she steamed into Hamilton this morning three hours late on her maiden voyage from New York. Speed boats and other harbor craft, their occupants waving greetings, furnished an escort for the final mile, and watchers crowded the harbor wall and other points of vantage along the way.

ABERDEEN, S.D., March 9 (AP). -- The Daily News said today it had learned a roll of bills taken from Frank Sankey of Clark, S.D., brother of the hunted Verne Sankey, was part of the $60,000 paid for the release of Charle: Boettcher 2d.

Mrs. H. Stuart Green of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club and Miss Marguerite Anderson of Plainfield, N.J., stand as the survivors of the field of fifty-five players who started Tuesday in the women's metropolitan squash racquets championship.
PALM BEACH, Fla., March 9. -- Mrs. Earle Perry Charlton was a luncheon hostess today at the Semi nole Club, with bridge or golf afterward.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- Mrs. Janet Allen Walker, wife of former Mayor James J. Walker of New York City, filed suit for divorce today, charging "continuous" desertion for more than four years. She said that she had made "numerous requests for reconciliation," all of which were refused.

Theatrical men indicated last night that the legitimate theatres of New-York, suffering a loss of patronage as a result of the financial crisis, would be forced to close their doors soon unless members of the musicians' and stage hands' unions accepted a wage cut or cooperative wage basis in accordance with that already agreed to by members of the Actors' Equity Association.

Spurred by fear of public exposure and the threat of fines and imprisonment, gold hoarders scurried back to the Federal Reserve Bank and its member institutions yesterday to redeposit the yellow coins that they had lately stampeded to withdraw.

The market value of bonds listed on the New York Stock Exchange declined $1,671,486,285 in February to $30,785,171,007 at the end of the month, it was announced yesterday. At the beginning of February, all listed bonds had a market value of $32,456,657,292.

Men may make light of women's interest in changing styles, but there is a mystery about them worthy of the most profound philosopher's meditation. Entirely apart from the economic aspect and the more personal matter of paying for one woman's apparel -- both serious, though many more women yearly are buying their own clothes-there is a psychological problem involved.

Only $1 from each $5 ticket sold Recently for a proposed benefit theatrical performance to aid the Judea Convalescents Home at Saratoga Springs, N.Y., went to the home, Magistrate Jonah J. Goldstein brought out in Tombs Court yesterday at a hearing on allegations that Sam London, 23 years old, of 661 Saratoga Avenue, Brooklyn, had violated the law in selling some of the tickets without having a license.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- In its effort to learn the identity of the gold hoarders of the country the Federal Reserve Board today broadened the scope of its order for reports from member banks to cover withdrawals of sold in the past two years.
NEW YORK. Lord and Lady Plunkett of London are expected at the Savoy-Plaza today.

In a statement of earnings mailed yesterday to stockholders of the Western Union Telegraph Company, Newcomb Carlton, president, said: "The fact that the Western Union Telegraph serves practically every industry, and thus Is an indicator of general business, is reflected by the sharp decline of $25,723,000, or 23.7 percent, in operating revenues for 1932, compared with 1931."

Contrary to expectations, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday made no change in its rediscount rate. The charge for member bank borrowings, which had been raised from 2% per cent to 3 1/2 per cent last week was expected by the financial community to be advanced to a penalty rate, in view of the drain upon the facilities of the bank of issue that developed just before the banking holiday.

Among the prominent passengers expected today on the Hamburg-American liner Deutschland are Dr. Albrecht Mendelssohn - Bartholdy, professor at-the University of Hamburg and director of the Foreign Policy Institute; George Albrecht Fuerst, delegate of the Bremen Cotton Exchange to the annual cotton conference held under the auspices of the Department of Agriculture, and Mrs. Edith Reiner, American pianist, who has been giving concerts in Europe.

LONDON, March 9. -- The Bank of England purchased u2,012,000 more of bar gold today in pursuance of its policy of selling sterling to prevent a rise in the exchange rate. This makes a total of u42,172,000 bought since Jan. 24 and brings the bank's bullion stocks to u162,713,000.

Directors of the National Dairy Production Corporation voted yesterday to reduce the dividend from an annual basis of $2 to one of $1.20 a share. A quarterly dividend of 30 cents a share was declared, payable on April 1 to stockholders of record of March 17. The regular quarterly of $1.75 a share on preferred was declared.

Winthrop W. Aldrich, chairman of the governing board of the Chase National Bank, in putting forward his program for banking reform caused a sensation in Wall Street yesterday that nearly eclipsed the banking holiday as a topic of discussion and conjecture.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- It was a grim Congress which met today, the most momentous gathering of the country's legislators since war was declared in 1917.

Sam Kaplan, deposed president and chief organizer of Local 306 of the Motion-Picture Machine Operators Protective Union of Greater New York, and nine other former officers or members were found guilty of coercion yesterday by a jury in Judge Nott's part of General Sessions.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- Eight farm organizations today urged President Roosevelt to recommend action by Congress to guarantee in full all bank deposits in national banks and other banks which may place themselves under Federal supervision.

PEIPING, March 9. -- Launching of a vigorous counter-offensive against the Japanese in Jehol Province was ordered today by General Chiang Kai-shek, commander-in-chief of the Chinese National Armies, while Chinese forces in Jehol reported advances toward Chengteh (Jehol City).
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 9. -- Schedules for fourteen Harvard Spring sports outfits were announced today by the Harvard Athletic Association.

Fordham Prep defeated Bishop Loughlin Memorial High for the C.H.S.A.A. basketball championship last night, the Maroon youngsters winning a thrilling game, 20 to 19, in the De Gray Gymnasium. Four times the score was tied, and with the count deadlocked at 17-all, with three minutes to play, Creighton Drury, Fordham star, dropped in a field goal and a foul to clinch the victory.

Slow Music Indicated. Wherever the eye turns in the financial district it lights upon a heartrending scene from "East Lynne" or "Shore Acres" or "Way Down East." On every hand the fair but erring Affiliates are being turned out into the storm by stern parent banking institutions.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- The Dodgers doctor of bold-outs, Vice President Joe Gilleaudeau, who brought almost instant relief in the cases of Jack Quinn, Al Lopez and Danny Taylor, encountered one case today he could not cure.

"Three Novels of love," Which is made up of three novels written by the late John Galsworthy before he started his "The Forsyte Saga," is published by the Scribners today. The thick volume of 739 pages contains "The Dark Flower," which tells the experiences of a man in love and was written in 1912-13.

PARIS, March 9. -- Asked by a French journalist today whether France could not do something to shove her friendship for the United States in this period of difficulty, former Premier Edouard Herriot declared:

Never enough to be venerated is the rule of seniority, but the last election was cruel to some ancients of the Senate. Looking over the list of the committees, one almost rubs his eyes to find PAT HARRISON in REED SMOOT'S place as Chairman of the Committee on Finance, Mr. FLETCHER in WATSON'S shoes at the head of Banking and Currency, Mr. COPELAND ruling Rules in place of vanished GEORGE MOSES.

The current income of life insurance companies, despite the depression, was declared yesterday at the annual Congress of the Life Underwriters Association of the City of New York to be 50 per cent more than is needed to pay all death claims, maturing endowments and annuities, together with payment on a normal number of applications to the insuring companies for loans on policies or surrender for their cash value.

Main floor departments of several leading stores here experienced a pick-up in sales yesterday, marking the day as the best since Saturday. Trade was aided by improved weather conditions in comparison with the two days immediately preceding, with prospective reopening of the banks serving to develop a more optimistic attitude on the part of shoppers, retail executives said.

The important legislative measure submitted by the President to Congress is properly entitled "a bill to provide relief in the existing national emergency." It undertakes to deal, first, with the withdrawal of gold or currency from the banks for hoarding or for export; second, with the difficulties of the banks themselves; third, with such shortage of circulating medium as may exist through the extensive hoarding that has already been practiced.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- Legislation to hasten the realization of President Roosevelt's dream of converting the far-flung Tennessee valley into a giant industrial work-shop was introduced today in the Senate.

Private bankers interested in the marketing of railroad securities, savings bankers and insurance company officials conferred in the University Club last night with a committee of three railroad presidents appointed by the Association of Railway Executives on the recommendations as to railroad consolidation made by the National Transportation Committee.

HOLLYWOOD, March 9 (AP). -- Motion picture producers announced tonight that "97 per cent" of the contract film players had agreed to accept reduction of half their pay checks for an eight-week period.

High north-west winds, blowing sometimes at gals force of 56 miles an hour, played havoc here yesterday, causing the death of a man and injuries to nine persons, toppling trees, chimneys and flagpoles, loosening copings of buildings, tearing away heavy advertising signs and shattering store and apartment house windows all over the city.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Here are the emergency "banking bill's principal provisions:

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- In the economy bill to go before Congress at noon tomorrow the salary reductions for government workers and officers are to be based on the cost of living. The cuts may not exceed 15 per cent but that is to include the existing pay cut of about 8 1-3 per cent.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- President Roosevelt will submit to Congress tomorrow recommendations for reduction in the expenditures for war veterans and the civil list amounting to $500,000,000.

SOME learned naturalist, in his next volume on "Wild Animals I Have Known," should include a chapter on the care and feeding of that interesting species, the "Alumnus Vociferus." They are very difficult to handle.

BERLIN, March 9. -- The Boerse was considerably weaker today than in recent days. A decline in Reichsbank shares by 10 per cent upon rumors of the abolition of the autonomy of the institution started a series of lesser downward movements.

Awaiting legislative action in Pennsylvania and Illinois, Jack Dempsey is still undecided regarding a site for his heavyweight boxing match bet-ween Max Schmeling and Max Baer. Dempsey, who orignally favored Chicago for the battle, indicated yesterday that the fight probably will take place in New York, following a conference with Tim Mara, who has options on the local baseball parks for boxing matches.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The opening day of Congress was just another moving day for Mrs. John Nance Garner, who did not interrupt her own job of supertending the activities in progress in the Vice President's office to go to the Capitol to watch, even briefly, the ceremony in the Senate over which her hsuband was presiding.

Joe McCluskey and Paul Kanaly, who finished in a virtual dead heat in the two-mile run at the New York A.C. games, yesterday entered the two-mile invitation that will be one of the features of the Knights of Columbus track and field meet at Madison Square Garden on Wednesday.

Runaway horses dashed through two parts of the city yesterday, ripping loose from their wagons, snarling traffic, frightening pedestrians and causing injuries to a police sergeant, three patrolmen and a taxi driver before they were halted.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 9. -- Ten colleges of the Middle Atlantic States will be represented by 120 entrants in the annual Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association championships in the Rutgers pool Saturday, according to the entry lists announced today by P.J. Morrissey of Lehigh, secretary.

Pete Wagner of Boonton, N.J., veteran 190-pound oarsman of the Columbia varsity crew, has given up rowing for the year, it was announced yesterday on Morningside Heights. Wagner is a student In the School of Engineering and his studies and laboratory work necessitate his remaining on the campus until evening.

An investment purchase on Broadway was announced yesterday when Edward W. Browning sold the sixteen-story store, loft and office building at 693-697 Broadway and 2-6 West Fourth Street to a client of the Prudence Realty Company, Inc., broker in the transaction.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The daily average volume of Federal Reserve Bank credit outstanding during the week ending March 8, as reported by the Federal Reserve Banks, was $3,619,000,000, an incrase of $1,034,000,000 compared with the preceding week and of $1,891,000,090 compared with the corresponding week in 1932.

Yesterday's combined statement of the twelve Reserve Banks showed the system's note circulation to be the largest on record, being considerably in excess of the previous high established in 1919. Rediscounts of the system were the highest since 1921, while the total gold holdings reached a new low for the year. The ratio of reserve for the system as a whole and at New York reached new lows for the year.

A smiling battle of wits and words between Keyes Winter, veteran Republican leader, and Albert J. Berwin, Republican leader of the Seventh Assembly District, took place last night when Mr. Winter announced his support of a new political organization that is fighting Mr. Berwin for control of the district.

NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 9. -- Delegates from twenty-seven New England colleges and universities arrived here today for the annual session of the New England Model League of Nations. The attention of the delegates was somewhat divided between the world problems they are to discus and the "frozen" condition of their assets.

The Columbia baseball team will play twenty-one games this Spring, it was announced yesterday by Manager Kip Finch. Ten of the contests will be with teams in the Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League. Nine of the twenty-one games will be played at Baker Field.
The following films will be presented at Broadway houses today:

Judge Freschi in General Sessions imposed yesterday a sentence of three to six years in Sing Sing on William C. Head, 48 years old, formerly of 295 St. John's Place, Brooklyn, for thefts of $500,000 to $600,000 in the last seven years from the Standard-Vacuum Transportation Corporation, marine subsidiary of the Socony-Vacuum Corporation, of which he was paymaster.

An exhibition of oils, water-colors and drawings by Jean-Louis Forain opened yesterday at the Museum of French Art, to remain until April 1. The pictures have been lent by the following galleries: Durand-Ruel, Knoedler, Kraushaar, Scott Fowles and Wildenstein, and by these collectors: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph Kerrigan (who have contributed thirteen examples), Adolph Lewisohn, William F. LaPorte, Edwin D. Levinson, Dr. H. H.M. Lyle and M.A. McDonald.

POUGHKEEPSIE, March 9. -- Arthur J. Curry, 56, poultry farmer and roadhouse proprietor, of Stanfordville, was arrested tonight on a charge of first-degree murder, accused of slaying the four members of the farmer family of James Husted Germond in November, 1930.

The year opened auspiciously for the railroads in respect to net operating income, figures issued yesterday by the Bureau of Railway Economics showed. The 150 Class I railroads reporting, with a mileage of 241,399, showed an Increase of 18.6 per cent in net operating income for January, compared with January, 1932.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The chiefs of foreign diplomatic missions were formally received at the State Department in a body today by Secretary Hull and Under-Secretary Phillips in accordance with procedure customary when a new Secretary of State takes office.

BERLIN, March 9. -- Three more specific cases of molestation of American citizens by men wearing National Socialist uniforms were presented to the Berlin authorities today by George S. Messersmith, the United States Consul General, who in the name of the victims made a formal complaint and asked action on it.

BIRMINGHAM, Ala.. March 9. -- Roy Wright, 15-year-old Negro, who with eight others of his race Is awaiting trial for his life for an alleged attack on two white girls, denied his guilt today and made grave charges against mil men and deputy sheriffs in the first interview any of the prisoners has given since their arrest nearly two years ago.

OTTAWA, March 9 (AP) .-- Trailing by 3 -- 0 with only eleven minutes to play, the Chicago Black Hawks unleashed a terrific attack that brought them three goals in five minutes and a 3 -- 3 deadlock with the Ottawa Senators in an over-time National Hockey League fixture tonight.

HARTFORD, Conn., March 9 (AP). -- Proclaiming an emergency under the provisions of a newly enacted bill, Governor Cross cleared the way today for a reopening of State banks under rigid supervision of the State bank commissioners.

BOSTON, March 9. -- Brown and Boston University were the winners in the college hockey doubleheader played before 3,500 in the Arena tonight. Brown turned back Northeastern University of Boston, 3 to 2, and Boston University beat Boston College, 7 to 2.

Dr. Irving Langmuir, director of the General Electric Laboratories at Schenectady, N.Y., who received the Nobel Prize lor outstanding achievements in chemstry in 1932, returned yesterday on the Italian liner Rex, accompanied by his wife and their two children, Kenneth and Barbara.

Life insurance companies doing business in the State were ordered yesterday by George S. Van Schaick, Superintendent of Insurance, to suspend loans and payments of surrender values of life insurance policies during the period of the banking emergency.

HAVANA, March 9 (AP). -- Polar Sea, an 8-year-old gelding, today won his fifth successive race over the Oriental Park racing strip, defeating a field of platers in the mile-and-a-sixteenth feature at the Cuban course. Polar Sea finished third in his other start at this track.

Thirty-nine pieces of sculpture by Alceo Dossena brought $9,125 last night at an auction sale held by the National Art Galleries, Inc., in the ballroom of the Hotel Flaza. The highest price for a single object was 675, paid by W.E. Benjamin for a marble relief of the Madonna and Child in the manner of Mino da Fiesole, although three figures sold as a group for $750.

WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- Postal receipts throughout the country in February, as announced today by the Postoffice Department, declined 6.29 per cent in fifty selected postoffices and 6.10 per cent in fifty industrial postoffice cities, compared with February last year.

Gradings according to merit of 648 publications of elementary and secondary schools throughout the United States and its territorial posessions were announced in lists made public yesterday by the Columbia Scholastic Press Association at the opening of its ninth annual three-day convention at Columbia University.

LOS ANGELES, Cal., March 9. -- Considering himself far better prepared for the test than he was this time a week ago. Manager Bill Terry put his Giants through their final paces today for the resumption of their exhibition series with the Cubs tomorrow.

The "421 Street Special," a train carrying motion picture actors and chorus girls that left Hollywood on Feb. 21, arrived at Grand Central Terminal shortly before noon yesterday. The party was welcomed by members of the Forty-second Street Property Owners and Merchants Association, and attended a luncheon of the association at the Hotel Commodore, marking the 108th anniversary of the deeding of Forty-second Street to the city for $10 by J.L. and Sarah Norton.

Twenty-one speakeasies and cordial shops were raided yesterday by agents of Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator of this district, bringing to fifty-nine the number of such resorts raided since Tuesday when Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition director at Washington, ordered agents to turn their attention from speakeasies to distilleries and breweries.

With the prospect that the bank holiday in its more stringent features is near its end, tendencies toward further price advances in commodities and foods showed signs of disappearing yesterday throughout the city save in a few instances.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9. -- A bill creating a central clearing house association for issuance of uniform scrip throughout the State of New Jersey was passed tonight by the State Legislature. This action was taken after a long conference between Senate leaders and William H. Kelly, State Banking Commissioner.

Newspapers, magazines and annuals published by students in the public and private schools of the Jutted States, copies of which had been entered in the annual, contest directed by the Columbia Scholastic Press Association, received awards of merit as follows:

BOSTON, March 9. -- The Boston, Bruins tonight almost clinched a berth in the National Hockey League's play-offs by outscoring the New York Americans by a 4-2 margin before 8,000 persons, the smallest crowd of the Boston season.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- While no definite steps have been taken to reopen the grain exchanges, the trade expects operations to be resumed in a few days. Formal announcement of abandonment of the conference called by the Federal Farm Board in Washington between representatives of the exchanges and millers regarding reopening the exchanges increased the belief.

BERLIN, March 9. -- Bavaria, the last of the German States opposing National Socialist domination, surrendered today and accepted it, an from end to end of the Reich Nazi control is now absolute and con plete.

Geraldine Farrar returned yesterday afternoon to the stage from which she retired more than ten years ago to ask a large audience in the Metropolitan and the vast numbers listening to the performance of "Parsifal" over the air to help save the Metropolitan.

TRENTON, N.J., March 9. -- Charging that the Port of New York Authority is a "Tammany controlled body" that "has been operating in a high-handed manner," Senator Clifford R. Powell of Burlington County, floor leader of the Republican majority in the upper House, introduced tonight a joint resolution in the Legislature asking for a thorough investigation.

Fighting off a desperate closing rush which followed a neat goal by Cecil Dillon, the New York Rangers turned back the Detroit Red Wings in a National Hockey League game at Madison Square Garden last night. A crowd of 13,000 saw the blue-jerseyed sextet triumph over the American division leaders, 3 to 2.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 9. -- Two days before he is scheduled to put the Yankees through their first practice game, Manager Joe McCarthy has all except two of his athletes under control and only one who is unaccounted for.
Herbert Hoover paused briefly in a busy day yesterday to urge support of President Roosevelt's program for banking rehabilitation.

Within a relatively short period of time the administration has evolved banking legislation which is more comprehensive and far-reaching than anything that has ever been attempted in American financial history.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- President Roosevelt signed the emergency bank bill at 8:37 o'clock tonight in the oval room on the second floor of the White House Attending were Mrs. Roosevelt, Secretary Woodin and other officials.

To the Editor of The New York Times : I note with surprise in THE TIMES of March 6 a plan by the so-called Committee of the Nation, headed by Frank A. Vanderlip and endorsed by a large number of manufacturers, for a method of inflation by fluctuating the gold value of the dollar in accordance with price indexes of the Department of Commerce.

CLEVELAND, March 9 (AP). -- A note of optimism for the future, mingled with a desire to ease the difficulties or workers, has marked the reaction to the bank holiday among Ohio businesses and industries.
A radio broadcast of the hardships encountered in New York since last Fall by John S. O'Brien, 35-year-old engineer and surveyor, who also writes travel books and fiction stories, got him a job.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 9. -- An act creating a Felham-Port Chester parkway authority, with broad powers in connection with the construction of a toll parkway parallel to the Boston Post Road with $13,500,000, which it is hoped may be obtained from the Reconstruction Finance Corporation, was approved by the Westchester Board of Supervisors this afternoon with one dissenting vote.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Two plans for farm relief were rushed to completion today to be put before a conference of farm organization leaders called for tomorrow by Secretary Wallace. One proposal described as a compromise plan involves certain features of the domestic allotment and land rental ideas.
LONDON, March 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of England shows the following changes, in pounds sterling:

Samuel Untermyer, in a telegram sent yesterday to Governor Lehman from Mr. Untermyer's Winter home at Palm Springs, Cal., said he had been advised that the city administration had "smuggled through" the Legislature a bill stripping the Transit Commission of its power to unify the city's transit facilities and transferring those powers to the Board of Transportation.

Columbia and Tale will meet on the gridiron in 1934, it was learned yesterday. No official announcement has been made at either institution, but it was said at Columbia that negotiations have been under way for the last few months. The teams will thus resume football relations after a thirty-year lapse.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Working far into the night, Treasury and Federal Reserve officials were rapidly whipping into shape details of regulations pertaining to the operation of banks of the country.
Oregon yesterday joined Washington among the latest States turning to horse racing, with legalized betting systems as a new source of revenue. Both have taken legislative action within the past week.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Thousands of persons visited the City-County Building today and tonight to pay tribute at the bier of Mayor Anton J. Cermak, victim of an assassin's bullet in Miami, aimed at President Roosevelt.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- New York State's merchandise exports during the first nine months last year were valued at $190,119,423, or a loss of $151,574,890, compared with the $341,694,313 total in the corresponding period of the preceding year, according to Commerce Department figures made public today.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- The First National Bank of Chicago has taken over the banking business of its affiliate, the First Union Trust and Savings Bank, it was announced tonight by Melvin A. Traylor, president of both institutions, following a meeting of the boards of directors of the banks.

Five garbage-laden Department of Sanitation scows caught fire in the middle of the East River yesterday, and after being cut adrift two of them floated to the Brooklyn shore in the Greenpolnt section, where they set fire to two piers. A third drifted to the Long Island City shore, while the other two remained about 200 feet off shore.

The Delaware, Lackawanna Western Railroad is preparing to issue pay checks in multiple denominations to facilitate their acceptance among tradesmen, J.M. Davis, president, said yesterday. He added that a payment of $100 might be made through issuance of four $25 checks under this scheme, which would necessitate considerable extra bookkeeping, but that resumption of banking facilities by next week might greatly reduce the necessity for such procedure.

CHICAGO, March 9 (AP) -- Police squads started searching Chicago's underworld today in a hunt for Verne Sankey and Gordon Elkhorn, alias Gordon Best. Police said they were informed in telegrams from the Federal Bureau of Investigation and Denver police that the pair, wanted in the Boettcher kidnapping, were believed to be in Chicago.

ROME, Friday, March 10. -- After Premier Mussolini had spoken for more than two hours, fully laying bare his view of the international situation, the Fascist Grand Council, which held an extraordinary meeting lasting until the small hours of this morning, approved a "declaration" dwelling principally on three points.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Reflecting the then approaching banking crisis, money in circulation during February increased by $901,000000 to a total of $6,545,617,139 at the end of the month, the Treasury anounced today. That was a gain of $942,000,000 in a year.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 9. -- Ruling that "the death of the deceased was due to a series of blunders by police departments of several States and cities," Medical Examiner Squire of Westchester exonerated today Detective Sergeant Gerhard Blum of New Rochelle, who fatally shot Harry Slavin, Brooklyn clothing salesman, in New Rochelle last Feb. 10, mistaking him for a hold-up man.

ALBANY, March 9. -- Instructions to hold all members of the Senate in attendance until late Saturday were given by Governor Lehman today in a telephone message from New York City to John J. Dunnigan, temporary presiding officer of the Senate.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The extraordinary session of the Seventy-third Congress, its complexion overwhelmingly Democratic, started its journey swiftly today by rushing through the routine organization procedure to get at important legislation.
Twelve Manhattan properties were bid in by plaintiffs at foreclosure auction sales yesterday. One Bronx parcel also was sold. Three scheduled sales were postponed.

The American Bankers Association is proposing a plan to State bankers associations in every State to enable bankers to extend greater group "cooperation with the government along such lines as may prove desirable in dealing with the problems of the period of banking reconstruction that is at hand."

A downtown cast side street, laid out before 1797, was once called "Rough Street" and for a time after October, 1813, "Perry Street" in honor of Commodore PERRY, but is now known as Henry Street in every community where social work is carried on -- especially wherever trained woman's nursing has come to the home and hospital.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 9. -- An all-English, final for the women's Belleair golf championship, with Miss Diana Fishwick, 1930 British titleholder, opposing Miss Barbara Pyman, will be played as the result of the matches today on the course of the Belleair Country Club.
ALBANY, March 9. -- A bill to impose a, general retail sales tax of 2 per cent on all commodities was introduced today in the Assembly by Horace M. Stone, Republican, of Onondaga.

The New York Stock Exchange will remain closed until further proclamation from President Roosevelt terminates the banking holiday. Reopening of the Exchange is contingent largely upon the resumption of normal banking activities in the city, so that payments for stocks may be cleared.
BERLIN, March 9 (AP). -- The Reichsbank's statement as of March 7 shows the following changes in reichsmarks:

The new issue of The American Year Book, delving deeply and broadly Into the events of the momentous year 1932, has come from the press in its usual format but with an unusual wealth of material between its covers.
