Inevitably the current volume of this annual borrows significance from the transitional epoch which It reviews through the eyes of 200 writers selectively qualified to set down facts and expound their bearing.

WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Pausing in the midst of its strenuous work of financial legislation, the Senate resolved itself into a court today for the impeachment trial of Judge Harold Louderback of California, but postponed the issue until Monday because the House has not yet chosen its managers in the case.

MIAMI, Fla., March 9. -- The all-New York combination of Tommy Good-win of Monroe, N.Y., the 19-year-old Empire State tltleholder, and Albert R. Hakes of Dunkirk scored an overwhelming victory today in the first round of the amateur four-ball team golf championship over the Miami Biltmore Country Club course at Coral Gables.
COMMERCIAL PAPER. Yesterday-Bank holiday. Friday (last trading day) -- 3 per cent for the best names. The quotations are for three-four months' paper.

Maxie Rosenbloom will risk his world's light-heavyweight boxing championship tonight when he opposes Adolph Heuser of Germany in a fifteen-round bout at Madison Square Garden. The bout will mark Rosenbloom's first appearance as a defending champion at the Garden since the Fall of 1931, when he stopped Abie Bain of Newark in eleven rounds.

Leading bankers in this city expressed admiration yesterday for the courage and leadership shown by President Roosevelt and the new administration, for Congress for the speed with which the emergency banking measures were adopted and praised the tenor of the measures themselves.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The text of President Roosevelt's special message to Congress today, asking immediate enactment of emergency banking legislation, read as follows:

MONTREAL, March 9 (Canadian Press). -- Traders on the Montreal Stock Exchange decided today to await developments in the United States and prices of securities drifted slightly lower with a turnover of more than 7,000 shares in thirty-one issues.

John Nevins and Arthur Graef, suspended Brooklyn policemen charged with kidnapping Ernest Schoening, a New Jersey rum runner, pleaded guilty to reduced charges of attempted kidnapping and were sentenced to from five to twenty years in Sing Sing yesterday.

The State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration will contribute $3,995.696 to New York City for unemployment relief this month, according to an announcement yesterday by Harry L. Hopkins, chairman of the State Temporary Emergency Relief Administration.

ABOARD THE U.S.S. CALIFORNIA OFF SAN PEDRO, Cal., March 9 (AP). -- Four days of thrilling tests for sea fitness culminated this afternoon in a grand parade of 134 of the United States Navy's fighting ships down the Southern California coast, passing beach towns on the way to the naval bases.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- Japanese circles here regard the unification of Manchukuo as practically complete and look for little, if any, further military operations, inquiry today brought out.

Savings banks will be open today for small withdrawals to meet urgent needs of depositors, it was announced last night by Henry R. Kinsey, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York. Several savings banks did this yesterday, permitting withdrawals up to $10.

CAIRO, March 9. -- Many sensational discovereies have already been disclosed in connection with this season's excavations at Persepolis in Persia by the Oriental Institute of the University of Chicago, but more have Just been revealed.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The full text of the bin embodying President Roosevelt's emergency banking program, as passed by Congress and made law by the President's signature today, follows.
GENEVA, March 9. -- The Disarmament Conference took up the vital question of war material today and recorded immediately a change in American tactics and a tautening in the European deadlock.

With the time fast approaching for Secretary of the Treasury Woodin to make an announcement concerning his plans for the March 15 financing, specialists in United States Government obligations were still about as much at sea yesterday as to the exact terms of the new financing and the total amount as they were earlier in the week.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 7:

James Monroe High School's basketball team assured itself of at least a chance to play off for the upper Manhattan-Bronx division title in the current city P.S.A.L. championship basketball competition by defeating Morris, 45 to 9, at the Monroe gymnasium yesterday.

With the time fast approaching for Secretary of the Treasury Woodin to make an announcement concerning his plans for the March 15 financing, specialists in United States Government obligations were still about as much at sea yesterday as to the exact terms of the new financing and the total amount as they were earlier in the week.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The Bureau of Navigation issued the following orders today, dated March 7:

James Monroe High School's basketball team assured itself of at least a chance to play off for the upper Manhattan-Bronx division title in the current city P.S.A.L. championship basketball competition by defeating Morris, 45 to 9, at the Monroe gymnasium yesterday.

President Roosevelt's message to the new Congress and the emergency banking legislation recommended by him occupied the attention of Wall Street yesterday as preparations to reopen all sound institutions went forward. The plans to resume banking operations were necessarily attended by some confusion, but in the circumstances, with Congress still deliberating, the preliminaries were cleared away with surprising speed.

The second and last "Parsifal" performance of the present Metropolitan season was given yesterday afternoon, and the Interpretation of the opera, in its prevailing character and exalted atmosphere, was such as to communicate keen satisfaction to those who gathered for the occasion.
WASHINGTON, March 9 (AP). -- Committee assignments of new Democratic Senators were made public today by Senator Robinson, party leader. The assignments follow:

LONDON, March 9. -- On the very morning Prime Minister MacDonald left for the disarmament conference the British Government published naval estimates providing for a L3,093,700 (about $11,800,000) increase in expenditure over last year's total.

To the Editor of The New York Times: One important factor for future soundness is the adjustment of income taxes. For instance, it has always been realized in England that incidental profits and losses, such as from stock speculations, should not be taxable or reducible unless it is the individual's profession or business, but only the income derived from such speculations.
The postponed premiere of "Lone Valley" -- written, staged and produced by Sophie Treadwell -- will take place this evening at the Plymouth Theatre.

Opposition to the report of the Laymen's Foreign Mission Inquiry, stressing education rather than evangelism, which has been voiced in various quarters ever since it appearance last October, crystailized yesterday with the announcement of the formation of the Association for the Reemphasis of New Testament Missions.

Postal savings deposits, increased in the previous day by the release of hoarded gold, showed a further increase over withdrawals here yesterday, which indicated to Postmaster John J. Kiely a return of confidence in the stability of the country as well as response to President Roosevelt's efforts in the financial crisis.

The tragedy in the murder of James A. Walsh, Brooklyn cooperage dealer, was deepened Ironically yesterday when the filing of his will in Brooklyn revealed that he had bequeathed $5,000 to Dominick J. Tierney, the employe who killed him after a dispute over financial matters.

The Connecticut Fish and Game Commission yesterday announced a new policy in regard to the renewal of fishing and hunting license. Heretofore it has been necessary for sportsmen to procure renewals in person from town clerks but the annoyance that this has caused, which resulted in many protests, now has been done away with.

Miss Anne F. Sears, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taber Sears, gave a luncheon yesterday at her home, 1,060 Park Avenue, for her cousin, Mrs. Bradford Warner, the former Miss Nancy Hill, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Miner C. Hill. Her marriage to Mr. Warner, son of Mrs. Henry Wolcott Warner and the late Mr. Warner, took place last June.
PARIS, March 9 (AP). -- The weekly statement of the Bank of France shows the following changes in francs:

An inside story of a prosecutor at work stamping out rackets and convicting gangsters was related by District Attorney Charles B. McLaughlin of the Bronx yesterday at the Rotary Club's luncheon in the Hotel Commodore.

WATERTOWN, N.Y., March 9 (AP). -- Postmaster George A. Hager of Watertown said tonight a package containing a shotgun shell and "some writing" and addressed to President Roosevelt was intercepted in the Watertown postoffice Monday night.

PARIS, March 9. -- Faced with a European situation which is more complicated and even more dangerous for the future than that which they settled at Lausanne, Premier Ramsay MacDonald and Foreign Secretary Sir John Simon arrived in Paris today on the way to Geneva for a preliminary discussion of the arms situation in Europe with their French colleagues.

Declaring the proposed legislation to establish an inspection, quarantine and licensing system covering the shipments of florists and growers into New York State to be unnecessary and ineffective, the board of directors of the Merchants' Association of New York yesterday adopted a report con demning it on specific grounds.
WASHINGTON, March 9. -- The text of the proclamation issued by President Roosevelt tonight was as follows:

BALTIMORE, March 9. -- Priceless art objects, of which connoiseurs had lost trace and which had been sought all over the world in recent years, have been found among 243 crates that have lain in storage in the basement of the Walters Art Gallery, it was learned today.

Interest in local cotton circles yesterday was divided between the course of prices in foreign markets and developments in domestic spot cotton and dry goods circles. Contract quotations advanced 8 points more in Liverpool, but trading in American and Indian spot cotton quieted, with few changes in prices.

The Fencers Club retained Its national senior foils team championship last night when It won both of its matches in the final round-robin on its home strips Turning back the New York Athletic Club, 6 -- 3, and the P.S.A.L. team, 5 -- 0, the Fencers Club emerged victoriously for the second time in a row.

Restrictions governing disbursements of cash were further relaxed yesterday by some of the principal banks of the city to make possible more liberal financing of food shipments and an increase in the allowances for payrolls. At the same time, the limitations imposed on personal checks by the national holiday order were continued, save in emergency cases.

CHICAGO, March 9.-- Movement of hogs throughout the West continued heavy today and with a slow demand for fresh pork loins and other meats, prices in the stock yards here dropped 10 to 35 cents a hundredweight, making losses of 50 to 60 cents in two days.

VIENNA, March 9 (AP). -- Steel-helmeted army units aggregating two regiments were moved into Vienna tonight as Austria's new dictatorship armed itself to cope with the opposition, which centred in a special session of the Diet.

DENVER, March 9 (AP) -- A bulletriddled motor car believed by police to be the one in which the kidnappers of Charles Boettcher 2d fled after his release has been found, Police Chief A.T. Clark said today, near the ranch at Chamberlain, S.D., where Boettcher was held prisoner sixteen days.

Announcement by Prohibition Director WOODCOCK that the Federal Government will no longer harry proprietors of speakeasies, but will limit enforcement efforts" almost entirely" to large manufacturers and middlemen, is given the air of a new policy.

The present phase of our crisis is primarily one of government finance. For many months the government has been pumping its short-term certificates into the banks. The banks put their depositors' money into this government paper on the theory that this would promote liquidity. It was assumed that, in case of need, the Federal Reserve Banks would issue money to the banks for their short-term governments.

Pledging its support to President Roosevelt in any action for drastic reductions in the compensation paid veterans, which now cost the government more than $1,000,000,000 annually, the American Veterans Association ran full-page advertisements appearing in Washington newspapers yesterday, designed to draw the attention of the members of the new Congress.

PARIS, March 9. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, who has been Japan's chief delegate to the League of Nations, returned to Paris today after a busy week's trip, during which he visited big industrial plants and important industrialists of Germany, Holland and Belgium.

Mayor O'Brien reserved his decision yesterday on whether the army reservation at Fort Schuyler should be converted into a public park or a shore base for a merchant marine academy, after hearing the arguments of those in favor of the park.

An alarm for gems valued at about $5,000 was sent out last night by the police of the Stagg Street station in an effort to find a clue to the murderer of Morris Valenstein, 40 years old, a jewelry salesman, of 3,130 East Seventh Street, Brooklyn, who had offices at 62 West Forty-seventh Street, Manhattan.

For the fourth successive time Harry F. Wolf of the New York A. C. and Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club reached the final round of the national Class A squash tennis championship last night at the Harvard Club.

Three brothers, who said they were investment brokers with offices at 30 Bay Street, Tompkinsville, S.I., were arrested and locked up at Police Headquarters at St. George yesterday afternoon charged with obtaining money or valuable securities from clients and appropriating the funds to their own use.

The Travers, oldest race renewed annually in this country, had sixty-two thoroughbreds remaining eligible with the passing of the last declaration date, according to an announcement from Racing Secretary Victor Schaumburg yesterday. At the same time Mr. Schaumburg announced that the Alabama, famous test for fillies, had forty-seven racers remaining eligible.

A buoyant swing in the wheat market, on the Winnipeg Grain Exchange, strengthening of the Canadian dollar against the gold currency of France and rising prices among some hitherto dormant stocks on the Standard Mining Exchange in Toronto were woven yesterday into Canada's financial and economic fabric.
AKRON, Ohio, March 10 (AP). -- The giant 2RS-5, sister airship of the navy dirigible Akron, is ready in the Goodyear-Zeppelin hangar here for formal naming tomorrow as the U.S.S. Macon.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The veterans' lobby, taken by surprise, worked today as it never worked before in a desperate effort to defeat the President's program for drastic curtailment of veterans' pensions and other benefits.

Savings banks throughout the State, which today will ask the State Banking Board for permission to reopen when the banking holiday is over, yesterday began accepting funds from their depositors for safe-keeping, as the result of an announcement by Henry R. Kinsey, president of the Savings Banks Association of the State of New York and president of the Williamsburgh Savings Bank.

ORMOND BEACH, Fla., March 10. -- Henry L. Haynes of Lake Placid, N.Y., entered the final round for the Ormond Beach golf chamiponship by beating J.R. Gormley of Dedham, Mass., in the semi-finals today, 3 and 2. In the other match David N. tallman of Minneapolis disposed of C.P. Burgess of Dunkirk, N.Y., by the same score.
Knew or Guessed? Of the bank crisis of March 3 there seem to be many private persons who knew better what was coming than those who were in a position to know and whose business it was to know.

Children's "finger paintings" will be placed on view today at Nancy McClelland's, 15 East Fifty-seventh Street. The exhibition has heen arranged in the third-floor galleries and is being held for the benefit of unemployed artists, to whom will go proceeds from the admission fees.

Mrs. Outerbridge Appleby gave a luncheon at Sherry's yesterday for Mrs. Richard Reynolds, Mrs. George T. Brokaw, Mrs. John A. Mayer, Mrs. Robert Loree, Mrs. Chauncey Truax, Mrs. Broderick Markell and Miss Adelaide Kelly.
Payrolls were met in full, in cash, yesterday in many of the large enterprises in this city.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The Executive order issued by President Roosevelt directing, among other things, that all member banks of the Federal Reserve System which desire to resume normal banking functions, except as otherwise prohibited, shall apply for licenses, reads as follows:

MONTGOMERY, Ala., March 10. -- Holding that Alabama's jury system had been challenged by the motion to quash the indictments against nine Negroes accused of rape, on the ground that members of their race were excluded from the grand jury which indicted them, Thomas E. Knight Jr., Attorney General, said today that he was prepared to defend it before the United States Supreme Court if necessary.

In a final effort to avoid the general closing of all legitimate theatres in New York, which has appeared inevitable because of decreased box-office receipts in the face of continuing overhead expenses, representatives of the stagehands' and musicians' unions and the Actors Equity Association will meet this morning with a subcommittee of the League of New York Theatres, representing the managers, to seek some arrangement for continuing operation on a cooperative basis.

Andrew McCampbell, prohibition administrator, it was revealed yesterday, has disbanded his padlock squad, because of restrictions recently imposed by Amos W.W. Woodcock, prohibition director at Washington, prohibiting agents from buying liquor with expense money.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- Political leaders turned tonight to the question of who will become Mayor of Chicago to fill the vacancy caused by ths death of Anton J. Cermak. Several informal group conferences were held, and tomorrow the Democratic chieftains will begin formulating a program to filling the vacant chair.

Despite the rapid progress in unraveling the banking snarl, the New York Stock Exchange and all other commodity and security markets in this city will remain closed today. Officials of the Exchanges are hopeful, however, that trading will be resumed early next week.
Maxie Rosenbloom successfully defendend his world's light-heavy-weight championship by gaining the decision over Adolph Heuser of Germany in a fifteen-round bout at Jadison Square Garden last night.

ALBANY, March 10. -- State licensing and regulation of amateur, boxing and wrestling clubs passed the Senate today. The measure, sponsored by Senator Berg, Bronx Democrat, provides license fees ranging from $100 to $1,000, according to the size of the club and the size of the city.

Few of the issues of new municipal bonds scheduled for award this week in the aggregate amount of $4,530,732 attracted bids, because of the banking holiday and the virtually complete cessation of business in the municipal market. New issues for $7,288,404 will come up for competitive bids next week, the total comparing with the weekly average for the year to date of $12,250,160.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The text of the economy bill introduced in Congress, was as follows:
NORTHAMPTON, Mass., March 10. -- President Stanley King of Amherst College opened today at Smith College the first plenary session of the Assembly of the New England Model League of Nations.

As the result of inquiry made by the Right Rev. James de Wolf Perry, presiding Bishop of the Protestant Episcopal Church, a "Presiding Bishops' Relief Fund" has been established at the Church Missions House, 281 Fourth Avenue, it was announced there yesterday.

During the past week, while the interest of the country has been concentrated on the banking situation, a number of items of financial and industrial news have naturally received less attention than might otherwise have been given to them.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- One week from the day when Franklin D. Roosevelt assumed the office of President of the United States, he will have been invested by two acts of Congress as a Constitutional dictator. This will be accomplished when Congress has passed, and he has signed, the bill introduced today to effect government economies -- events firmly scheduled for tomorrow.

The heaviest rise in cotton prices since the closing of the exchanges here a week ago took place in Liverpool yesterday, where contract quotations advanced 20 English points and American middling 17 points. With Indian quotations gaining 16 points and Egyptian cotton in Alexandria marked up nearly a half cent, all growths commanded a sharply higher price level in world markets.

LOS ANGELES, March 10. -- Performing in a manner that offered a striking contrast to their work on Catalina Island over the last weekend, the Giants today resumed hostilities with the Cubs and forthwith flattened the National League champions, 5 to 3.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- A preponderance of national and State banks closed under Presidential and Gubernatorial proclamation since March 6 will be permitted to open, beginning Monday, under an Executive order issued today by President Roosevelt.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The text of President Roosevelt's economy message was as follows:

MIAMI, Fla., March 10. -- Hack Wilson's holdout shadow today was cast over the preparations for tomorrow's opening exhibition game between the Dodgers and the Athletics, but it was evident that the outfielder was the only person greatly concerned about it.

Lou Gehrig, first baseman of the New York Yankees and their leader for the last half-dozen years in hammering runs over the plate, surrendered in his hold-out battle with the club yesterday, signed his contract and will start this morning for St. Petersburg to report to Manager Joe McCarthy.

TORONTO, March 10 (Canadian Press). -- The outlook for higher prices for commodities supported today securities listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange and the market closed firm and with gains for most issues. Traders are waiting, however, for the markets in New York to reopen before assuming additional commitments, and the turnover consequently was small -- only 5,372 shares.

MONTREAL, March 10 (Canadian Press). -- Canadian dollars lost ground today in terms of both the pound sterling and the French franc. The pound was exceptionally strong, closing 5 cents higher at $4.18 in Canadian funds and gaming a half franc in French funds.

About 3,000 persons attended a farewell reception last night at the old Roxy Theatre in honor of Lord Marley of London, Deputy Speaker of the House of Lords, under the auspices of the People's Ort Federation and the Women's Association American Ort.
HAVANA, March 10 (AP). -- Chianti, a 7-year-old son of High Time which had been finishing second or third, was first today, winning the six-furlong claiming feature at Oriental Park.

High winds swept through the city yesterday for the second consecutive day, causing minor property damage and some accidents, and bringing a sharp drop in temperatures that sent the mercury tumbling to 20 degrees above zero at 8:30 yesterday morning.
SINCE mystery stories seem to be popular, a few short ones are herewith offered for critical inspection. The first one concerns a crime of omission.

LONG BEACH, Cal., Saturday, March 11. -- With sixty-five known dead and at least 1,000 persons injured in a devastating series of earthquakes, which began at 6 o'clock last evening and recurred at frequent intervals through the night, this city was still in terror early this morning at the greatest catastrophe in its history.

Seeking to extend the powers of the Mayor in formulating city budgets, Aldermanic President McKee introduced yesterday two amendments to his executive budget bill in the Board of Estimate branch of the Municipal Assembly and said he would move for adoption of the entire bill when it came up again two weeks hence.

To the Editor of The New York Times: As I read the discussion in THE TIMES of the Crawford bill which, would prohibit hospitals from collecting dispensary fees, and particularly the recent letters of Dr. Julius Ferber and Dr. A. Strachstein, I am impressed with the fact that while some of the contenders stress the needs of the indigent, others are especially concerned over the fact that doctors are not paid for their dispensary services.

The United States Treasury will do its March 15 financing through the Federal Reserve central banks instead of through the general market, according to opinion yesterday in generally well-informed financial quarters. It is believed the Treasury will sell its new obligations direct to the Reserve Banks or will obtain its money through overdraft on them which is tantamount to a promissory note renewable from day to day in the amounts found necessary.

PARIS, March 10. -- How to keep Germany from rearming openly in defiance of the Treaty of Versailles occupied most of a five-hour discussion today between the British Ministers, Ramsay MacDonald and Sir John Simon, and their French colleagues, Edouard Daladier and Joseph Paul-Boncour, before the Britons and the French Foreign Minister left for Geneva.

MIAMI, Fla., March 10 (AP). -- Boastfully shouting his unconcern and defying the court, Joseph Zangara, the assassin who tried to kill Franklin D. Roosevelt, today was sentenced to die in the electric chair for the murder of Mayor Cermak of Chicago.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Declining values in foreign-trade figures characterized the British business situation during January, the Department of Commerce said today in its review of world economic conditions. Optimism has increased somewhat in Australia, due to the recent strengthening of wool prices.

The typical classroom teacher is deprived today of vital social issues largely because of the nature of her training and because her thoughts and those of her pupils "pertain to the problems of yesteryear and seldom stimulate interest or challenge to the finality of the solution given in some archaic, theoretical textbook," according to Daniel P. Eginton, assistant supervisor of research and surveys, Connecticut State Board of Education.

Scholarship and intelligence, while of great importance, are only secondary to character and honor, Mrs. Theodore Roosevelt, widow of the late President, declared yesterday afternoon at a reception to more than 500 Roosevelt Honor Medallion winners in the city schools during 1932 at the Woman's Roosevelt Memorial Association, Roosevelt House, 28 East Twentieth Street.

All New York banks which are members of the Federal Reserve System filed applications with the Federal Reserve Bank of New York yesterday for permission to reopen immediately with full banking facilities.
LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP). -- The thirteenth strong earthquake shock, making a total of more than 130 including minor shocks, struck Southern California at 10:30 P.M. tonight.

GENEVA, March 10. -- International circles here tonight awaited the arrival of Ramsay MacDonald and Sir John Simon with much curiosity, little, faith and no enthusiasm. Nearly all agree the armament situation has reached the point where its discussion among the Premiers would be highly useful -- the more so in view of four developments today.

LIVERPOOL, March 10 (AP). -- Weekly cotton statistics are as follows: British stocks, 887,000 bales, against 890,000 a week ago, 893,000 two weeks ago, 892,000 three weeks ago and 851,000 a year ago, of which American 538,000 bales, against 530,000 a week ago, 520,000 two weeks ago, 518,000 three weeks ago and 412,000 a year ago.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The third piece ot emergency legislation to be sought by President Roosevelt to deal with the financial situation, authority for the Federal Government to begin extensive public improvements, has not been definitely formulated, and the administration recommendations probably will be delayed until Congress acts on the budget message, submitted today.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- After a day of debate behind closed doors, a group of fifty national farm leaders emerged from their conference with Secretary of Agriculture Wallace and Assistant Secretary Rexford Tugwell and announced that agreement on a plan of emergency relief had not been reached.

BERLIN, March 10. -- The National Government today was beginning to consider how to take up the task of repressing nationwide hooliganism, including that within the ranks of the National Socialist organization itself.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., March 10. -- Harold Frankel, Harvard's varsity 118-pound class entrant in the New England Intercollegiate Wrestling Association championships, sustained a broken fibula in the left leg in winning his semi-final bout at the Harvard Indoor Athletic Building tonight.

A dinner ending the six-day celebration of the 300th anniversary of the founding of the Collegiate School was held last night in the school building, 241 West Seventy-seventh Street. More than 350 men and women were present.

The New York, Ontario Western Railway earned $220,402 in. 1932 from the freight surcharges that took effect on Jan. 2 of that year, the annual report by Joseph H. Nuelle, president, and Edward G. Buckland, chairman, shows. The company's operating ratio was 71.15 in 1932, compared with 72.74 in 1931.
Small housing parcels continued to furnish the bulk of the New Jersey realty transactions reported yesterday.

In spite of the general strangulation of commerce resulting from the bank holiday, the undertone in the business world has remained firm this week, according to the weekly review by Dun Bradstreet, which says the value of credit received its most severe test.

Commercial banks in New York, awaiting the end of the bank holiday, continued in general yesterday to follow the policy of restrictions placed in force earlier in the week, although the rules were interpreted somewhat more liberally.

BERLIN, March 10. -- Frederic M. Sackett, who has been one of the most popular United States Ambassadors to Berlin, bade farewell tonight to his friends and the Americans he has protected and advised during his term in office here. He said good-bye at a dinner given for him by the American Club, the Chamber of Commerce and affiliated American societies.

Disappointment that the four-day banking moratorium should not have been ended definitely with Thursday, but was extended, failed to allow for the complexity of the arrangements necessary for resumption of banking business under the terms of Thursday's Congressional statute.

Delegates to the ninth annual convention of the Columbia Scholastic Press Association at Columbia University total 960 editors, staff members and faculty advisers of elementary and secondary school publications throughout the country, it was announced in lists made public yesterday by the association.

WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP). -- The assistance of the United States Fleet, whose battleships are lying off San Pedro, was asked and extended in the earthquake, Admiral Richard H. Leigh, the commander informed the Navy Department by radio.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Many measures familiar on the Senate calendar reappeared today when Senators introduced 238 bills, in addition to emergency bank measures. Reintroduction of the bills was necessitated by the fact that all legislation pending at the close of the Seventy-second Congress died with adjournment last Saturday.

BUENOS AIRES, March 10. -- Sir Otto Niemeyer, vice governor of the Bank of England, conferred for an hour with President Justo and Finance Minister Hueyo today. It was reported that they discussed the banking situation in the United States and its probable effects here.

BOSTON, March 10 (AP). -- The Commercial Bulletin will say tomorrow: "Trading along Summer Street has been more or less suspended during the week, pending the outcome of the new banking legislation and the ending of the bank moratorium.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: The bill to eliminate multiple teaching jobs, to employ a useful cliche, would be farcical if it were not so horribly tragic. Those who are not utterly blind cannot help but see that it is merely giving a piece of candy to a man who needs and asks for bread.
NEW YORK. Lord Revelstoke and the Hon. Rupert Baring are at the Jekyl Island Club, Brunswick, Ga., for a brief stay. They will return to the Waldorf-Astoria early next week.

DENVER, March 10 (AP). -- A new confession was made in the Boettcher kidnapping case today by Arthur Youngberg, police said, in which he further implicated Sankay and Elkhorn. Youngberg was arrested in the South Dakota ranch house where Mr. Boettcher said he had been held prisoner.

DANZIG, March 10. -- The Polish War Office informed the Danzig Government today that Westerplatte Basin in the harbor here, which normally is open to commercial traffic, will be held for the time being exclusively at the disposal of the Polish Government.

LONDON, March 10. -- The stock market again was cheerful today. Johannesburg gave renewed support to the Kaffir gold shares, German bonds recovered and a good showing was made by home industrials, motors being a feature, rising further on reports of a good export trade.

ALBANY, March 10. -- Despite the economic depression, savings banks in the State gained in both resources and deposits during 1932, according to a report of the State Superintendent of Banks, filed with the Governor and the Legislature today.

The credit policy of the Kelly-Springfield Tire Company in effect prior to March 4, will be continued, according to William H. Lalley, president, in commenting on the extension of credit by manufacturers to retailers under existing conditions.
Deals in housing properties in Manhattan and Brooklyn featured real estate trading in the metropolitan area yesterday.

LOS ANGELES, March 10. -- Three men, commissioned by the city of Santa Monica to fly over the Long Beach earthquake area and determine the amount of damage, met instant death here late tonight when the plane in which they were flying crashed into a hill near the intersection of La Brea and Slauson Avenues.
MIAMI, Fla., March 10. -- The pick of the 3-year-olds in training will go after one of the Winter turf's richest awards tomorrow in the renewal of the $10,000 Florida Derby at Hiaieah Park.

PEIPING, March 10. -- Climaxing days of confusion following the loss of Jehol Province by Marshal Chang Hsiao-liang, General Chiang Kaishek accepted his resignation today, arranged to merge the Marshal's sixteen divisions with the National Army and gave the North China command to his trusted aide, the War Minister, General Ho Yingching.
To the Editor of The New York Times: Two bills have been proposed by me and are pending in the Legislature:
ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 10. -- The thinning ranks of Yankee holdouts today were reduced to Babe Ruth, with the report from New York that Lou Gehrig had signed.

LOS ANGELES, March 10. -- Terror stalked a wide area tonight when the earth shuddered in Los Angeles and Orange Counties. Tall buildings tottered, with blinking lights recording their progress in space, while throngs below looked on breathlessly.

To the Editor of The New YorK Times: As the banking panic of 1907 led to the enactment of the Aldrich-Vreeland law of 1908, apparently now about to be re-enacted with modifications, and the appointment of the National Monetary Commission, which laid the foundations for the Federal Reserve Banking System, so it may reasonably be expected that the present banking panic will eventually lead to further strengthening of our banking system.

Although still under restraint as a result of the President's proclamation extending the holiday, banks began yesterday to show impatience by requesting permission, in increasing numbers, to resume business without further delay. The Secretary of the Treasury and the State banking authorities are sympathetic with them in their restiveness and, it was made plain yesterday, will assent to their requests as rapidly as seems advisable.

Magistrate Jonah J. Goldsteln in Tombs Court yesterday suspended sentence on John Imming, 36 years old, of 50-19 194th Street, Flushing, Queens, found guilty of violating a corporation ordinance in soliciting funds for an orphanage without a license.

LONDON, March 10. -- Tomorrow Economist compares the financial crash with a type of cyclonic storm which, after ravaging the region where it starts, leaves a track of destruction over a wide area and then returns to the place of its origin with unabated violence.

In 1925 Parliament passed the Honors or Prevention of Abuses act, punishing with fine and imprisonment the attempt to obtain money from a person for the alleged purpose of procuring for him a title of honor. The conviction of J. MAUNDY GREGORY the other day at Bow Street police court ended the first case under the act.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt established today another precedent by attending the tea given by the Congressional Club, made up of the wives and daughters of Senators and members of the House of Representatives, for the new Congressional hostesses of the Seventy-third Congress.

President ROOSEVELT'S first interview with the Washington correspondents this week was highly successful. The atmosphere of informality was consistent with his custom. At the very outset he abrogated one rule which had been in vogue since President HARDING got into difficulty with his own Secretary of State because of an offhand reply to a question regarding the arms conference.

Charles M. Kinsolving, commander of the New York Chapter of the American Veterans Association, which originated in Chattanooga, Tenn., last Summer to oppose payment of the bonus and non-service disability awards, appealed last night to the 4,000 members of the chapter in and around New York to telegraph President Roosevelt, assuring him of their support in his attitude with regard to veterans' appropriations.

MIAMA, Fla., March 10. -- The third victory of the meeting for the Brookmeade Stable's Jubilate was scored in the featured Henry L. Doherty purse at Hialeah Park today when the 5-year-old son of Lucky Hour and June Slower won by a length at the end of a mile.

While wheat and cotton prices continued to climb wholesale meat prices dropped to new lows yesterday, according to the Department of Public Markets, which credited the housewife with victory in the first round of her fight against soaring food prices.

PARIS, March 10. -- Criticizing the scope of the London Economic Conference as too ambitious, Daniel Serruys, former president of the League of Nations economic committee, addressing the International Diplomatic Academy here today, appealed to the nations to confine their efforts to less spectacular but practical remedies.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., March 10. -- Bill Foulke and Sheldon Stephens of Princeton, Gil Congdon of Yale and George Hartford of Harvard reached the semi-finals in the second annual intercollegiate squash racquets tournament in the Payne Whitney Gymnasium today.

To the Editor of The New York Times: Your editorial relating to the Hudson Highlands and William Thompson Howell awakens old memories. Mr. Howell and I were boys together in Newburgh, N.Y., and were members of the same class at the Newburgh Academy on Montgomery Street.

MOSCOW, March 10 (AP). -- The Soviet Government now is feeding some of the peasantry in the North Caucasus region, where the agrarian situation is acute because of failure of last year's crops due to reluctance of the farmers to produce.

Conferences between bankers and railroad officials on the report of the National Transportation Committee have progressed to the point at which there was said to be a likelihood of an early introduction in Congress of bills that would put into effect some of the committee's recommendations regarding consolidation and other points.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Hopes for the success of the General Disarmament Conference at Geneva dominated a discussion of more than an hour late this afternoon at the White House by President Roosevelt with Secretary Hull and Norman H. Davis, Chairman of the United States delegation to the conference.

BASLE, Switzerland, March 10. -- The telephone system of the Bank for International Settlements registered the disappointment in Europe today at the indefinite extension of the American banking holiday, off-setting the satisfaction felt at the full powers that President Roosevelt obtained.

SANTIAGO, Chile, March 10. -- Refuting arguments brought forward for government control of iodine production in Chile, El Mercurio points out editorially that the so-called world monopoly of iodine by Chile does not exist in a truly commercial sense.

With all the ranking players scheduled to put in an appearance during the afternoon, the thirty-fourth annual tournament for the national indoor tennis championship will get under way at 11 o'clock this morning on the board courts of the Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and Sixty-sixth Street.

Seeking to protect the interests and provide relief for the depositors in the State banks that are not members of the Federal Reserve System, Governor Lehman sent to Washington last night copies of a resolution adopted by the Legislature in Albany, asking for changes in the emergency banking laws.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP). -- Three bills designed to bring silver into wider use as money and to lift from the market the existing surplus were introduced today by Key Pittman of Nevada, Democratic President pro tempore of the Senate.

Philip Cohen, former governor of the New York Curb Exchange, who died of a heart attack in his home, 25 Central Park West, on Feb. 16 last, left $10,000 to his executors to distribute among charitable institutions, preferably those giving relief to the blind, it was disclosed yesterday when his will was offered for probate in Surrogate's Court.

ROCHESTER, N.Y., March 10. -- Methods and policies of the Public Employment Centre of Rochester are now becoming available for general use in other offices of the New York State Employment Service, according to the report of Director Jess T. Hopkins of the former organization.

The provisions in Title 3 of the new banking bill, providing for the issuance by national banks of 6 per cent preferred stock, were construed by bankers yesterday as designed to provide a means for repairing the capital structure of weakened banks and at the same time, possibly, to offer depositors in such a bank a chance to convert their deposits into stock.

Unfilled orders of the United States Steel Corporation decreased 44,444 tons in February to 1,854,200 tons, it was announced yesterday. This was a new low record for the corporation. It compared with 1,898,644 tons at the close of January, the previous bottom point.
LONDON, March 10. -- A drastic and unprecedented cut in fares as a means of regaining the large trade lost to bus lines was fixed tonight by the four leading railroads.

The Olympic point-scoring system will be the basis for determining the winner of the septathlon duel between Jim Bausch and Barney Berlinger, America's two greatest all-around athletes, at the Knights of Columbus track and field meet at the Garden on Wednesday, it was announced yesterday.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., March 10. -- A Supreme Court jury returned today a verdict of $1,000 for Mrs. Wilhelmina R. Kendrick, 63 years old, of Chappaqua, a piano teacher and choir leader, who contended her voice had been impaired as the result of an automobile accident in Scarsdale on Oct. 11, 1928.

The fresh water fisherman who intends to whip the streams of New York State this year will not lack for variety of species nor will the disciples of Izaak Walton who adhere to the art of trout fishing find themselves without fish to catch -- at least, if nature has cooperated to any extent with the work of the State's division of fish and game.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10. -- Ralph D. Trobridge left here on Feb. 6 after telling friends that he planned to go to Bermuda, according to officials of H.M. Voorhees Brother, a ladies' outfitting store, where Mr. Trobridge was employed as head of the jewelry department.

W. Kingsland Macy, Republican State Chairman, ordered the discontinuance yesterday of publication of The Woman Republican, the monthly organ sponsored by Mrs. Rosalie Loew Whitney, and at the same time dropped from the State Committee payroll the three women who have been engaged in editing the magazine.

BERLIN, March 10 (AP). -- The newspaper Boersen Zeitung today quoted the Oslo (Norway) journal Aftenposten, which carried a dispatch from Archangel, Russia, saying that a large lumber depot there had been afire for fourteen days and that thirty persons accused of being counter-revolutionaries had been shot.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- President Roosevelt sent to Congress today a request that the government's credit be further buttressed with a drastic reduction in expenditures, and followed it an hour later with a detailed plan to save more than $500,000,000 from veterans' compensation and Federal salaries.

TURIN, Italy, March 10 (AP). -- Production of the Fiat Company, Italy's largest automobile concern, was slightly greater in 1932 than in the previous year. Senator Giovanni Agnelli, its president, disclosed today at a meeting of stockholders.

PARIS, March 10. -- The hopes of nearly fifty claimants living in the United States to share in the estate of the late Charles Rubens received a serious setback today when a safety deposit box was opened by order of the Paris courts and was found to contain only a few defunct securities.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- A navy crew of thirteen officers and seventy-five men will man the new dirigible Macon during the airship's trial flights, the navy announced today. Weather permitting, the trials will begin March 30, and will last six weeks, it is believed, with six flights contemplated, one being an endurance cruise of fifty hours.
The New York Public Library has been experiencing recently something of a run on its facilities by assiduous readers intent on making the present crisis yield them knowledge and perhaps profit.

PARIS, March 10. -- Except for disappointment because the American banks could not open today as scheduled, French financial circles generally reacted very favorably to the vigorous action taken by President Roosevelt and Congress to solve the banking emergency.
WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP). -- British coal interests have a keen eye trained on the possibility of displacing from the Canadian market coal mined in the United States.

Samuel Rosoff, the subway contractor who virtually forced the Board of Estimate to grant to his East Side Omnibus Corporation a twenty-five-year franchise covering five important routes on the east side of Manhattan, moved yesterday to seek a ten-year grant covering the Manhattan and Queens routes named in the one-year franchises recently voted to the Green Bus Lines, Inc.

Moses W. Dykaar, well-known sculptor, who modeled a bust of Calvin Coolidgc and other noted Americans for the Senate Gallery, committed suicide yesterday afternoon by leaping in front of a Lexington Avenue express train at the elevated Jerome Avenue station at 167th Street, in the Bronx.

SAN DIEGO, Cal., March 10 (AP). -- An earthquake of jarring intensity rocked this city at 5:50 P.M. It lasted about half a minute, beginning with a series of tremors and increasing to a climax which was sufficient to rock buildings, but it did no apparent damage.

Mrs. August Belmont, who as Eleanor Robson used to slip out after performances at the Empire just across Broadway and buy admission at the Metropolitan to hear Calve, Ternina or Caruso, stood on the opera stage last night, introduced by Lucrezia Bori, to speak for the Metropolitan's $300,000 guarantee for next season.

ALBANY, March 10. -- The State Conference of Mayors, in a resolution, made public today, petitioned Governor Lehman and the Legislature to readjust distribution of gasoline tax receipts to the localities.

HOLLYWOOD, Cal., March 10. -- There is one sensation which makes one want to run for the middle of the street and duck his head. It comes when the floor of a building tilts one's chair upward, first to the right, then to the left, the ceiling curves in unison and everything in the world does a "shimmy."

OSSINING, N.Y., March 10. -- Within half an hour after he had been allowed to stroll in the yard at Sing Sing for the first time without the guard who accompanies new prisoners for two weeks, Joseph Filangeri, 20 years old, who had been sent to prison for a robbery in Brooklyn, walked up to Keeper Alfred Peffers on duty in the yard today and collapsed.

SOFIA, March 10. -- The relations of Bulgaria and Yugoslavia are not likely to be improved by the answer Bulgaria made today to Yugoslavia's recent protest at toleration of the great Macedonian irredentist congress.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The House of Representatives by an overwhelming majority after sharp debate voted today to seat Representative Francis H. Shoemaker, Farmer-Laborite, of Minnesota. Mr. Shoemaker only recently completed a term of a year and a day in the Federal Penitentiary at Leavenworth, following a plea of guilty to the charge of having transmitted "scurrilous, libelous and defamatory matter" through the United States mails.

The Gdynia-America Line, which was formed three years ago around the nucleus of the Baltic-American Line by the Polish Government, announced yesterday that the company would let contracts soon for two new liners to augment the fleet of three now serving the New York-Baltic trade.
WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The President has shown extraordinary courage in asking the Congress to give him the responsibility and authority to cut the cost of the Federal Government.

HAUPPAUGE, L.I., March 10. -- Seventeen brace and one bye dog were run today in the first two stakes of the annual field trials of the Hauppauge Gun Club under conditions that would daunt all save the hardiest of owners and handlers.

Wild animals seldom bunt down and kill human beings unless they are already criminals among their own kind, or else have made the accidental discovery that human quarry is easiest to waylay, Grace Thompson Seton writes in "Magic Waters: Through the Wilds of Matto Grosso and Beyond," published by Duttons.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Secretary of State Hull is planning to begin war debt discussions next week with Sir Ronald Lindsay, the British Ambassador, and T.K. Bewley, the British Treasury expert who is financial adviser to the Ambassador.

LOS ANGELES, March 10 (AP). -- A warning to Southern California architects and engineers that they should prepare for strong earthquakes was sounded in August, 1925, by Harry O. Wood, research associate in seismology of the Carnegie Institution of Washington and vice president of the Seismological Society of America, it was recalled tonight.

PARIS, March 10. -- Former Premier Paul Fainleve today added his voice to those of the French statesmen who have been trying to induce the French Parliament to reverse its stand and make the December war-debt payment to the United States.

BELLEAIR, Fla., March 10. Miss Diana Fishwick, former British women's golf champion, won her first American tourament today by defeating a fellow-country woman, Miss Barbara Pyman, is the eighteen-hole final for the Belleair title at the Belleair Country Club.

VATICAN CITY, March 10. -- Pope Pius is expected to leave Vatican City during the holy year beginning next month to climb the Holy Steps of St. John's Lateran on his knees. The steps are visited by nearly all pilgrims to Rome.

Gifts aggregating $10,967 have been presented to Columbia University, it was announced yesterday. A gift of $3,000 from Mrs. Eugene Meyer to support a research for sociological investigation in Westchester County was among the twenty-seven cash contributions announced.

Manhattan Prep. De Sa Salle, Brooklyn Prep and St. Francis Prep reached the semi-final round in the fourth annual metropolitan Catholic schools' invitation basketball tournament at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, Brooklyn gymnasium last night before a capacity crowd of 1,200.

YREKA, Cal., March 10. -- State Traffic Officer Steve Kent and Lester Quigley, a garage mechanic, were shot and killed here tonight by George Manning, suspected kidnapper of E.C. Ballinger, border customs guard, and believed involved in the recent abduction of Charles Boettcher 2d, wealthy Denver broker.
A gold stampede in reverse, unlike anything within the memory of the downtown financial community, developed yesterday as repentant hoarders swarmed into the Federal Reserve Bank.

WASHINGTON, March 10 (AP). -- Praise for President Roosevelt's request for authority to reduce veterans' payments was expressed by Henry H. Curran, director of the National Economy League, which has been fighting for such action.

TRENTON, N.J., March 10. -- A tentative draft of regulations, for the control of New Jersey State banks and trust companies when they are permitted to reopen, was issued today by William H. Kelly, State Commissioner of Banking and Insurance.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- The emergency banking law, enacted yesterday, will make possible a Federal guarantee of bank deposit on a selective basis, according to an interpretation of the measure today by some officials in one the government departments it concerns.

The list of the Italian liner Rex, leaving today for Mediterranean ports, includes Mr. and Mrs. Jacques Balsan, the former Duchess of Marlborough; Princess Alessandro Torlonia, George Davison, Harry B. Fowler, Dr. and Mrs. Philip G. Cole. Mr. and Mrs. Harry Lang, Mrs. Reginald de Koven, Mr. and Mrs. Walton Martin and Charles M. Graves.

Two leases in Rockefeller Center were announced yesterday, in addition to a variety of rentals in the midtown garment area. In Rockefeller Center tenth-floor space in the RCA Building at Sixth Avenue and Fiftieth Street was taken by the Davis Coal and Coke Company for occupancy next month.

To what extent is speed a factor in traffic accidents ? The latest contribution to this discussion is contained in the answers to a questionnaire sent out to the various State commissioners by the Institute of Traffic Engineers and published in The American City for February.

A survey of more than 100 industries by representatives of the City Free Employment Agency of the Department of Public Welfare "indicates a great spirit of optimism and many plants are already giving evidences of revival," according to Edward C. Rybicki, director of the agency, in a letter yesterday to President Roosevelt.

Employment in New York State factories rose 1.4 per cent during the January-February period, slightly more than ihe usual seasonal rise, according to Elmer F. Andrews, Deputy Industrial Commissioner, who said yesterday that it was encouraging.

Coming from behind in the second half, the Thomas Jefferson High School basketball team dedefeated Boys High, 30 to 14, in the Boys High gymnasuim yesterday for its tenth triumph in as many Brooklyn division P.S.A.L. games.

CHICAGO, March 10. -- Plans are being worked out for reopening the Chicago Board of Trade as quickly as adequate banking facilities are available. Peter B. Carey, president, and other officials of the Board returned today from Washington and threw themselves into the task of clearing away technical obstacles.

CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., March 10. -- A call for "every patriotic citizen" to support whole-heartedly President Roosevelt's proposal to eliminate veterans' benefits that are not connected with service disabilities was issued tonight by Silas Williams, National Commander of the American Veterans Association.

PRINCETON, N.J., March 10. -- Confronted with the necessity of cutting down expenses for all social functions, Dean Christian Gauss of Princeton University announced today that the Junior Promenade and the Upperclass Club house parties, the most prominent social events of the university each Spring, had been postponed indefinitely.

Heads of the large life insurance companies have received a request from George S. Van Schaick, State Superintendent of Insurance, for a list of names of persons who have recently borrowed on their policies, or obtained the cash surrender value, it was revealed yesterday.

ALBANY, March 10. -- There were no empty seats in the Senate today except those normally occupied by members who had been excused on account of illness or for good and sufficient cause. There were many absentees from the Assembly sessions, but not a sufficient number to prevent that body from acting on legislation which might be deemed necessary in the present banking emergency.

Out of the swiftly moving developments of the banking situation yesterday emerged a growing conviction among bankers that the emergency measures being taken by the Federal Government will mean the breaking down of clearing-house organizations and the unification of a national banking system under the protection of the Federal Reserve banks.

WASHINGTON, Saturday, March 11. -- President Roosevelt acted swiftly to place the entire available resources of the Federal Government at the disposal of the earthquake sufferers in Southern California.

Sophie Treadwell, who once wrote an original play entitled "Machinal," has renovated the legend of the scarlet sisterhood in "Lone Valley," which was acted at the Plymouth last evening. After serving the drama faithfully, man and boy, for nigh on to fifty year, that legend must be true.

In a fast, well-played five-game match at the Junior League of New York yesterday, Mrs. H. Stuart Green of the Sleepy Hollow Country Club won the women's metropolitan squash racquets championship, defeating Miss Marguerite Anderson of Plainfield in the final.

The President's message to Congress yesterday is the most direct and explicit demand for a cut in governmental expenses that ever came from the White House. We are not forgetting what Mr. HOOVER did or attempted in that line. But he did not, as Mr. ROOSEVELT has now done, take his courage in both hands and specifically propose to slice off nearly half of the pensions and veterans' benefits here-tofore voted by a lavish Congress.

WASHINGTON, March 10. -- Enthusiastic Democratic support generally, and slightly qualified Republican approval, greeted the message in which the President today asked for additional powers to deal with the problem of effecting economies in veterans' compensation.

Terminating a successful season, the St. John's College basketball team beat St. Thomas College of Scranton, Pa., 37 to 34, before a large crowd in the DeGray Gymnasium, Brooklyn, last night. The victory gave St. Johns a record of twenty-three triumphs and four defeats for the season.

THE life of Mrs. Franklin D. Roosevelt's father was too short -- he was born in 1860 and died in 1894 -- for him to have attained eminence or honors sufficient to inspire public interest in the publication of his letters. Mrs. Roosevelt understands this, although she rightly thinks that certain unusual experiences described in them may interest the general reader.

BY implication, and indeed in the words of one of the characters in the tale, God ("the God of our fathers -- the God of the Old Testament -- the God of wrath and vengeance") -- in utter disgust over the selfishness, stupidity and squalor of the human race, decrees the destruction of the world by a collision with a huge "planet" from outer space.

Three firemen and a woman were injured and fifty men, women and children were led or carried out of a five-story tenement at 1,525-27 Washington Avenue, the Bronx, yesterday afternoon, when a fire started in a ground floor apartment, making the stairway impassable.

DEERFIELD, Mass., March 11. -- Setting new marks in three events and capturing seven out of nine first places, the Brown swimming team far outdistanced its seven rivals to gain possession of the New England intercollegiate swimming crown in the Beech Memorial pool at Deerfield today.

Mary Garden, cuurtseying in fulllength red velvet, beamed on twenty prize-winning children yesterday morning at the close of the first or "elementary" series of the Philharmonic-Symphony Orchestra before the youngest audience regularly attending these concerts in Carnegie Hall.

WASHINGTON. DEPRESSION and unemployment have brought an increase in counterfeiting and led to greater vigilance on the part of the United States Secret Service. Descriptive warning circulars of seventeen examples of counterfeit notes have been broadcast during the last fiscal year and about seventy unidentified productions of varying types and denominations have been circulated in different sections of the country for short periods.

LOWELL SHERMAN, who directed the prosperous Mae West film "She Done Him Wrong," will return to the RKO-Radio studios to direct Katharine Hepburn in her next film, "Morning Glory." Mr. Sherman's last task for RKO was histrionic, with Constance Bennett in "What Price Hollywood."

OTTAWA, March 11. -- With two seconds to go In the overtime period, the Ottawa Senators defeated the New York American sextet tonight, 2-1. Earl Roche scored the winning goal while the spectators were leaving the auditorium, content that a tie was on the books.
Despite the inconvenience caused by the bank holidays a gratifying number of contributions were sent in during last week to the Emergency Unemployment Relief Committee, it was announced yesterday.

MINEOLA, L.I., March 11. -- R. H. Helsel won the first registered shoot of the year over the traps of the Nassau Trapshooting Club today. He took the trophy by breaking 97 out of 100 targets. Seven gunners tied for the Handicap Cup, each with a full card.

SUFFERN, N.Y., March 11. -- A cold snap here last night took every one unawares. But most of all, it surprised the four swans that decorate the lower end of Lake Antrim In the village park. Early morning motorists saw the birds seated regally, but motionless, in the ice on the lake about fifteen feet from shore.
At President Roosevelt's request, all review copies of his forthcoming book, "Looking Forward," have been called in by the John Day Company, publishers.

THE United States today has more gold than any other nation in the world, yet it has placed an embargo on shipments of this metal. It has a larger supply of money for domestic use than It has ever had on any earlier occasion in its history, yet the banks are operating on a restricted basis and the issuance of new money has been authorized by Congress.

JOHN McCORMACK, the Irish tenor, who received 6,000 letters as the result of his last broadcast; John Charles Thomas, baritone; Josef Lhevinne, pianist, and Harold Samuel, piano soloist with the Manhattan Symphony Orchestra.

ROME, Feb. 27. -- A plea was made today by Mrs. John W. Garrett, wife of the American Ambassador here, speaking at San Remo, for the formation in the world's great cities of "art patron galleries" by wealthy persons genuinely interested in advancing art, so that talented artists might display their works for sale independently of "the international clique of profiteering dealers."

LIGHT novels dealing with the enthusiasms and disillusionments of youth are so frequently sentimentalized or incredibly burlesqued that it is a pleasure to find 30 neat a balance of sympathy and humor as characterizes this airy story.

TO the modern reader -- for a number of reasons which are at once obvious and not here appropriate-the part called the "Inferno" is likely to be the most vivid, the most readable and the interesting division of that great sacred poem which has become known as "The Divine Comedy."

LET no one assume that "Adventures of Ideas" will prove a book easy to read. Professor Whitehead not only is a constructive thinker but he is enormously erudite as well. For the person who will, however, make up his mind to a considerable labor, the fruit thereof should more than recompense.

GENEVA, March 11. -- Prime Minister MacDonald and Foreign Secretary Simon of Great Britain spent their first day in Geneva in disarmament and Manchurian dialogues with seven visitors, which from all accounts, were of an exploratory character.
Poly Prep of Brooklyn regained The Athletic Association of Private Schools swimming championship at, he seventh annual title meet yesterday in the Brooklyn Central Y.M.C.A. pool.
MIAMI BEACH Notable costume events will make this a week of pay social activities. The climax will come in the twentieth annual regatta hall scheduled for Saturday night at the Roney Plaza Hotel.
PARIS, March 8. -- Vionnet's capes with a bust-length front, which droop to the floor in the back, strike a new note in Summer evening wraps. They are specially effective with a contrasting frock.

The Junior League Players, who already have produced two plays this Winter, are now rehearsing "Mr. Dooley Jr.," by Rose Franken and Jane Lewin, which will be their last production of the season. Performances will be given on March 31 and April 1 in the great hall of the league clubhouse at 221 East Seventy-first Street.

IN Oils sequel volume to The Village Book,'" says Mr. Williamson in his opening passage. "I set out to write the truth about one small community, Ham Village, as the truth of village life had never been written before." * * * "As man and writer," he goes on later, "I would like to be as the sun, which divines the true or inner nature of living things."
JERUSALEM. THE burst of building activity which an influx of capital is now producing in the towns of Palestine emphasizes the change which has overtaken Jerusalem since the war.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Business activity was retarded considerably during the week ended March 4, due to disturbed banking conditions throughout the country, according to the weekly survey made public today by the Commerce Department.

NO absent-minded professor but a "regular fellow," a home owner and a Rotarian is the Superintendent of Schools, who sets the pattern of learning and thinking for the children in American cities. Such at least is the portrait of him which emerges from the statistics in the new year book on educational leadership brought out by the Department of Superintendence of the National Education Association.

OMAHA, March 9. -- The Middle Western farm States have been taking their banking holiday complacently. Indeed there has been an air of jaunty good nature in the manner in which the inconvenience of being without ready cash or checking facilities has been accepted.

IN 1931 Drs. Urey and Murphy of Columbia University and Dr. F. G. Brickwede of the Bureau of Standards discovered what physical chemists had long suspected -- that hydrogen is not as "elemental" as the old books teach. Probably the same is true of all ninety-two elements.
LONDON, March 1. -- "President Wilson is coming into his own again!"

PRINCETON, N.J., March 11. -- Columbia's undefeated wrestlers scored their tenth victory by defeating the Princeton matmen, 14 -- 12, today in the final dual meet of the season for both teams. The victory gave Columbia its first undefeated wrestling team.

GENEVA, March 10. -- Although it is agreed here that in the American emergency the domestic problem comes first, yet there is a strong feeling that President Roosevelt could help world affairs greatly by sending to Geneva a lieutenant with broad powers to handle those foreign questions in which delay may bring about serious situations.

HAVANA -- Cuba's greatest racing event, the Cuban Grand National Handicap, for 3-year-olds and up, with $50,000 added, will be run this afternoon over a mile-and-one-quarter course and will mark the closing of the racing meet here.

THIS biographical and critical handbook on the works of John Masefield is especially useful in view of the very large output of poetry, plays and prose of the present laureate. One must not, of course, expect from Mr. Thomas an ultimate valuation of Masefield's literary achievement, for that Is virtually impossible in the case of any author still in the full tide of his work.
TOKYO, March 11. -- The Cabinet approved today the procedure to be followed in resigning from the League of Nations.

Among other interesting events in the Knights of Columbus track meet at the Garden on Wednesday night will be the decision as to whether George Spitz will be able to come back to something like his best high jumping form, after his excursion into the ranks of broad jumpers at the intercollegiates.
NEW YORK. The First Secretary of the Italian Embassy and Countess Roncalli di Montorio are at the Waldorf-Astoria.

The feeling is spreading in the chancelleries of the world powers that the accession to power of Adolf Hitler and fascism in Germany may lead to a new and sharper political alignment in the Old World -- an alignment which may make itself felt around the earth.

A triple deadlock for first place in Division 1 of the Public Schools Athletic League fencing championship resulted as George Washington repulsed Evander Childs. erstwhile group leader, 5 -- 3, and Textile routed Flushing, 5 -- 1, in two of the eight matches at Washington Irving High School yesterday morning.

Albert Spalding, the violinist, is to be a guest artist of the 1933 Westchester County Music Festival at the County Centre, White Plains, on Friday, May 19. Paderewski plays there March 24. while tonight there is a concert by the Aeolian String Quartet.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11 (AP). -- Thrills of the diamond paled into insignificance compared with those experienced during the earthquakes last night by Jimmy Dykes, former third baseman of the Athletics, now training with the Chicago White Sox at Pasadena.

MADRID, Feb. 28. -- Belief that the recent, presentation of the Sahagun tombstone to the National Archaeological Museum here by the Fogg Art Museum of Harvard University has paved the way for close relationship between Spanish museums and the principal museums of the United States was expressed by Francisco Alvarez Ossorio, director of the archaeological museum.

BOSTON, March 10. YET again Boston is the "different" town. While the bank holiday lies heavy on the whole country, the busiest theatre Monday of the season rises only a week away. On March 20, if present plans hold, four playhouses will be open, each with a new bill.

A desperate attempt by the League of New York Theatres to close all legitimate playhouses on Broadway as, a punitive measure against the stagehands' and musicians' unions, which had refused to accept a wage reduction or work on a cooperative basis, failed early this morning when certain producers who have "hit" attractions declined for one reason or another to follow the majority.

Declaring that agriculture engages the energies of about 35,000,000 persons in this country, who control one-half of our buying power, The New Mexico Extension News, publication of the New Mexico Agricultural College, expresses doubt as to technocracy's applicability to the nation's "most stable occupation and mode of life," and predicts that changes in agriculture will continue to come about gradually.

HAMILTON, Bermuda -- For this week, at any rate, Bermuda will be enthusiastically and even excitedly golf-conscious, for this is the week of the 1933 annual Bermuda amateur golf championship, and some of the most outstanding club players in the United States of America and the Dominion of Canada have entered the lists in an effort to add to their golfing laurels in top-notch competition.

NOW that the proved speed and reliability of air transport have demonstrated that passenger carrying by air could forge ahead despite depressed conditions of general business and register substantial gains in 1932 in contrast with substantial losses in all other forms of transportation, there is wide agreement among transport operators that the next step must be to increase passenger comfort by reducing both the vibration and the noise in cabin planes.

FIVE or six years ago the author of this book, university president, clergyman, eminent helper in many good causes, author of many volumes on educational, religious and social subjects, published a work entitles "Guides, Philosophers and Friends," which was a collection of biographical essays dealing with men who had been leaders of thought and for the most part, his personal friends.

Card parties continue to be at popular means of raising funds foil carrying on the philanthropio enterprises of various organizations maintained for the relief of the ill and needy. There has been an encouraging subscription for the final card party in a series arranged for, the benefit of the McMahon Memorial Temporary Shelter for Childdren which will take place on Tuesday afternoon at the home of Mrs. Arthur M. Anderson, 11 East Sixty-seventh Street.

WHAT should prove the least sundry of all the items this mad March morning concerns Eugene O'Neill. While the rest of the country has been taking holidays of one sort or another, not Mr. O'Neill. Brooding quietly down at Sea Island, Ga., he has written another play, which will be all ready for the Guild in the Fall.

BOSTON, March 9. -- Worthy of the best traditions of that New England of which her song have long been proud is the conduct of her people during the present banking crisis. They were amazed last Saturday morning to learn that their banks were closed.

COLUMBIA, Mo., March 11. -- "Immediate and vigorous action looking to an increase in the general price level" as the spearpoint of a drive to break the depression is urged upon President Roosevelt and members of Congress in a petition signed by 150 economists of colleges and universities in all sections of the country.

WHAT seems to be one of the most thorough and comprehensive studies yet made of the human results of the depression is reported in this harrowing book. Mr. Williams went about the task with the evident purpose of giving his account the broadest possible base and of viewing it under the light of wide horizons.

BERLIN, March 11. -- Tonight, on the eve of the communal elections, Chancellor Hitler reappeared on the stump for the first time since the Reichstag campaign, addressing a clamorously enthusiastic audience that packed the biggest hall in the Berlin fair grounds.

THIS novel depends for most of its effect upon plot, upon improbably romantic situations to which the author's skill lends a momentary plausibility, upon the elements of fictional exaggeration and suspense and surprise. The same might be said of many flimsy tales, but "The Auction." for all the obviously mechanical character of its construction.

LOS ANGELES, March 11. -- As if they had not suffered a sufficient amount of jolting experiences within the last twenty-four hours, the somewhat terror-stricken Giants sustained some more telling blows today.

Whatever the ultimate realignment of our commercial banks may be, the recent legislation and the events accompanying its enactment have combined to assign a national status to the entire banking system. This fact will be realized more and more as the purging process goes on.
HAVANA, March 11 (AP). -- Winning the first race of her career, O. F. Woodward's Sweepilla today came from behind to win the $2,500 Cuban Juvenile Stakes at Oriental Park.

A sum aggregating $52,000,000 was advanced by the building and loan associations of the country during 1932 for the construction of 19,370 single-family homes, reports the United States Building and Loan League. These were financed on the monthly instalment mortgage plan.

MILAN, Feb. 27, 1933. ATTILIO PARELLI'S symphonic poem, "The Chimera," at its first hearing in Milan under the baton of Max Reiter at the Conservatory revealed respectable descriptive faculties and the fluent melodic vein which has become familiar through this composer's comic opera "I Dispettosi Amanti," presented years ago by the former Chicago-Philadelphia Opera Company under his own conductorship and recently broadcast from Italian stations.
To the Music Editor: That the Metropolitan Opera Association In its present financial extremity appeals to the general public for aid in order to carry on is surprising presumption.

LONDON, Feb. 27. OUTSIDE one of the theatres in London is a placard containing quotations from published criticisms of the entertainment within. Special prominence is given to the words of a critic who has lavished praise upon the acting, and a phrase of his in which he describes it as "Better than in Paris, better than in Berlin" is particularly emphasized.

MIAMI, Fla., March 11. -- Ray Lucas, young right-handed pitcher who has three different styles of delivery, took the spotlight today when the Dodgers defeated Connie Mack's Athletics, 6 to 4, in the opening exhibition contest of the training season for both teams.

TO the list of statesmen who have also been known as musicians one more has recently been added -- William H, Woodin, the new Secretary of the Treasury. In time taken from business and politics he has written several symphonic compositions which have been performed by orchestras here and abroad.

With virtually no change in local food markets yesterday, retailers, particularly large chain stores, reported that buying of foods was almost normal in the metropolitan district and that customers were paying almost wholly with cash.

LONDON, March 11. -- Enthusiasm over President Roosevelt's first week in office leads J.L. Garvin to predict in The Observer that he will be re-elected and "play a principal part in the whole world's destinies, until the Spring of 1941."

Capturing hard-fought semi-final engagements, Brooklyn Prep and St. Francis Prep gained the final in the fourth annual metropolitan Catholic schools invitation basketball tournament yesterday at the Columbus Council, Knights of Columbus, Brooklyn gymnasium.
Flashes from Associated Press men working at teetering typewriters amid swaying walls recorded the chronology of death and destruction that hit southern California.

ARNOLD SCHOENBERG'S "Pierrot Lunaire" will have its New York stage premiere under the direction of Leopold Stokowski on the League of Composers' program of music, drama and films at the Town Hall on Sunday night. April 16.

WITH each succeeding season one notices Paris fashions taking on a more international character. I do not mean that they are losing one whit of that inspiration which makes, and keeps, Paris the style centre, in spite of many rivals, but collections no longer seem to be designed exclusively for the smart Parisienne -- the majority of clothes suit the smart woman of the world:

Organizations of veterans united yesterday with civics and business groups in urging upon Congress immediate passage of President Roosevelt's economy program, the principal feature of which is a plan for drastic cuts in veterans' compensation. Telegrams to this effect were sent by several organizations to members of Congress.
