PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- Some Philadelphia banks probably will be open for full banking operations on Monday, according to George W. Norris, Governor of the Federal Reserve Bank here.

The last regular performances of the Metropolitan Opera Association's present season took place yesterday amid demonstrations of enthusiasm and regret on the part of the huge audiences -- regret that the season had finished, and enthusiasm for the performances.

IF Zona Gale is regarded by most people as a "realist" it is because she came to write when there was both a vogue and a need in America for realism, and somewhat because she has over and over again described the front porches and hotel lobbies of her native Portage, Wis. -- and not because she is one.

JUST about as far from Broadway as it is from Vienna to Pressburg -- in other words, in Philadelphia -- the House of Shubert brought forth last Monday night that long-anticipated adaptation from the German of Leo Perutz which Is known as "A Trip to Pressburg."

AKRON, Ohio, March 11. -- Before a crowd of several thousand persons, the U.S.S. Macon, sister airship of the Akron, was christened In the huge Goodyear-Zeppelin hangar here this afternoon by Mrs. William A. Moffett, wife of Rear Admiral Moffett, chief of the Navy's Bureau of Aeronautics.

WITH the arrival of two H.M.V. records (DB178/9) Victor must be feeling that it was a trifle ahead of time complying with the demands to have something replacing the pre-electrical Kreisler-Zimbalist performance of the Bach D minor concerto for two violins.

A study of Mr. ROOSEVELT'S first week as President may hereafter be required of classes in government. It should yield much from several different points of view. One of them, and perhaps the most striking, has to do with the political mentality of the American people.

PHILADELPHIA, March 11. -- The Pennsylvania Railroad's West Philadelphia station, in use for thirty years, will be abandoned early tomorrow, its place to be taken, by the company's new $10,000,000 Philadelphia terminal at Thirtieth and Market Streets, now about three-fourths completed.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Eddie Savoy, the 77-year-old Negro who has served twenty-one Secretaries of State, first as page and then as messenger, since the days of Hamilton Fish, sixty-four years ago, retired from active service today with the congratulations of President Roosevelt.

THE second festival of contemporary music to be held under the auspices of the Corporation of Yaddo will take place this year at Yaddo, Saratoga Springs, from Saturday, Sept. 30, to Tuesday, Oct. 3. The first festival was held last Spring.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 11. -- Dr. and Mrs. Halford J. Morlan of Chicago and Fairfield, Ill., were two Lone Beach quake survivors who had thrilling experiences. Dr. Morlan, who is a surgeon and lecturer and a former president of the Illinois Izaak Walton League, described his experiences thus:

Racing's patrons are spread throughout the nation, according to officials of the Miami Jockey Club, who caused a count to be made on the thirty-ninth day of the meeting of the number of automobiles and the States from which they came. The track police found that 3,281 cars passed through the Hialeah Park gates and that license tags showed they came from thirty-eight States.

DETROIT, March 11. -- Hubert Scott-Paine, English challenger of Gar Wood for the Harmsworth Trophy, today announced through J. Lee Barrett, secretary of the Gold Cup committee, that he will not enter a craft in the race this Fall unless experiments this Summer prove to his satisfaction that he has a worthy challenger of Wood's boat.

"Buy a hat and help a baby!" is the slogan adopted by young matrons and debutantes who will take charge of the "Little Hat Bar" at Jay-Thorpe's throughout the week of March 20, when a percentage of all sales In that department will be devoted to the needs of the Child Adoption League of which Mrs. Charles Dana Gibson is chairman.

In a match filled with spectacular shotmaking and packed with excitement, Harry F. Wolf of the New York Athletic Club, defending titleholder, defeated Rowland B. Haines of the Columbia University Club yesterday in the final round of the national Class A squash tennis championship.

LONG BEACH, Cal., March 11. -- Colonel O.C. Wyman, commanding the 426th Field Artillery at Los Angeles, named relief and food administrator for the entire earthquake zone, conferred with State, county and city officials at Long Beach this afternoon and announced that he was prepared to provide all needed food, cots and blankets.

PRESIDENT ROOSEVELT'S announcement that he will make Hyde Park the Summer capital marks a deviation from the customs of the last few Chief Executives, who have not had estates of their own for such a purpose. While ex-President Hoover went regularly to the "Little White House." a camp on the Rapidan, other ex-Presidents -- notably Coolidge and Wilson -- spent Summer holidays at rented places, and as a rule changed plans each season.

MELBOURNE, Australia, March 9. -- Issues of vital importance to the Australian Commonwealth will be placed before the electors of two States soon in referenda. The people of Western Australia will be asked whether they wish to secede from the Federal Union.
NASSAU, Bahamas -- Preparations are being made for the celebration of St. Patrick's Day, an occasion which is eclipsed in Nassau only by the celebration of George Washington's Birthday.

THE tuberculosis survey by means of X-ray examinations, now being carried on in the Harlem section of Manhattan, and made possible by funds supplied by the State Emergency Relief Committee, has already disclosed a considerable number of unsuspected cases of tuberculosis in the first 600 individuals examined.

TO a million persons in more than 300 communities in almost forty States there was nothing disturbing about the "bank holidays." While everybody else was puzzling over what to use for money these people smiled knowingly.

A fight against the enactment of the so-called model game breeders bill has been, precipitated in Connecticut, where the North American Game Breeders Association, sponsors of the measure, hoped to make their first start in the East in the campaign to obtain more favorable laws relating to the breeding in captivity of game birds and game animals.

THE German elections last Sunday ended with an over-whelming victory for Adolf Hitler. In the new Reichstag his National Socialist party will have 288 seats out of 647. Together with his Nationalist allies, the followers of Alfred Hugenberg, he will control 340 seats, which is more than 52 per cent of the total.

The directors of the Central Mercantile Association have disapproved the Buckley bill, which carries out the recommendations made by Governor Lehman in his recent budget message to the Legislature imposing a retail sales tax of three-quarters of 1 per cent upon practically all commodities except foodstuffs.

ALBANY, N.Y., March 11. -- The Assembly passed today four bills to strengthen the banking structure of the State as the Legislature adjourned until Monday afternoon, for the first such session in many years.

RONALD COLMAN'S new picture, "The Masquerader," will be having its premiere at the Rivoli in a few weeks, probably, after the Mary Pickford film "Secrets" concludes its engagement at that theatre. The history of this particular story is a fairly complicated one.

IT would seem." says Dr. Worcester as he describes this present time, "as if God were mocking at his mockers." He thinks that "It is becoming evident to every discerning eye that a new Dark Age has made its appearance on earth."

All records for volume of communication between the Pacific and the Atlantic Coast terminals of the Western Union Telegraph Company were broken yesterday, primarily as a result of the California earthquake, officials estimated last night at the company's New York headquarters, 60 Hudson Street.
HARTFORD, Conn., March 11. -- Hartford fire insurance companies were unable today to estimate the losses in the California earthquake, but most of them were not expecting severe ones.
CHICAGO, March 11. -- A sharp advance has taken place in the price of cash grain since the American markets ceased official operations because of the banking holidays.

The ban which sent into the discard two nude statues designed for the Radio City Music Hall has been withdrawn and these modern sculptures have been placed on view so that the public may draw its own conclusions about their merits.

The increasing centralization of power and prestige of the Federal Government at the expense of the States is emphasized in "Trends in Public Administration," one of the thirteen supporting monographs published under the auspices of the Research Committee on Social Trends, which was appointed by former President Hoover.
HAVANA, March 11. -- Leopoldo Fernandez Ros, head of President Machado's strong-arm squad, known as "La Partida de la Porra" ("the Bludgeon party"), was shot and killed here this morning.

The annual exhibition of paintings at the Salmagundi Club covers the walls of the big gallery several rows deep and overflows into the hall with a profusion of color. Subject range from landscapes of New England to figure studies, from Oriental still-life to marines and New Mexican pueblos.

Many pastors will base their sermons today on the bank situation and draw moral lessons from the financial crisis. All will pray for a solution of the national difficulty and ask for a blessing upon President Roosevelt and his financial advisers.

WALTER C. KELLY made his debut in that field which thereto had been known to him rather vaguely as "legit" when, on Monday night last, at the Royale Theatre, the Theatre Guild lifted the curtain on "Both Your Houses" -- or just one of them.

To the Editor of The New York Times: May I add to your very interesting editorial regarding "God Save the Kings"? You say: "It has not been settled who composed the air of 'God Save the King.' John Bull (1563-1628) and Henry Carey (1696-1743) divide the honor."

ALBANY, March 11 (AP). -- Legalization of pari-mutuel betting on horse races in New York State during the present session of the Legislature is virtually assured, Assemblyman Charles H. Breitenbach, Brooklyn Democrat, said today.

Regaining the metropolitan gymnastics title which she held In 1931, Miss Adelaide Meyer, Brooklyn Eastern District Turn Verein star, won the women's metropolitan gymnastics championship for the fourth time last night.

BERLIN, March 11. -- The Boerse opened firm today, with all indications of another session of upward movements, but considerable realization sales modified the early enthusiasm and prices declined slightly. Reichsbank shares held fairly steady.

Thus far none of more than a dozen mechanical loose milk dispensers demonstrated before the Board of Health has measured up to the sanitary requirements, and unless an acceptable one is developed the counter sale of loose milk in New York City will be banned June 1, Health Commissioner Wynne announced yesterday.

Perhaps with an eye to the advent of Spring, the Museum of Modern Art will open to the public on Wednesday an exhibition of fruit and flower painting by modern artists. Early modern masters represented included Cezanne, Monet, Manet, Redon, van Gogh, Renoir, Rousseau and others.

EVER since the days of the silent films there hava been prophecies about the educational uses of the moving pictures, and with the advent of the talkiea it became a fixed article of faith with scores of teachers and students of education that sound films would work a revolutionary change in methods of Instruction in the schools.

IN these days when long novels are the fashion, and many of them grow up to be trilogies or sagas, "The Singers" is surprisingly short -- less than 300 pages. Its brevity la due to no shortage of material. The book is a fat, though compressed, slice of life in the town of Wurzburg on the Main In 1927.

ST. PETERSBURG, Fla., March 11. -- The Yankees staged their first intracamp exhibition game today when the Fletehers defeated the Burkes, 13 to 2. A crowd of about 700 went away disappointed when Babe Ruth failed to deliver one of his celebrated homers.

PHILADELPHIA, March 9. -- The drama of Pennsylvania politics entitled "Puddler Jim and the Pike County Forester" plays on and one Just as everybody starts predicting that it is about to be taken off the boards, the press agent works up a new stunt to attract attention and the S.R.O. sign is out once more.

"If mortgagor and mortgagee cannot bring the obligation into mesh with current conditions, they must both go down to destruction together," said Peter Grimm, president of Wm. A. White Sons and chairman of the Citizens Budget Commisson, yesterday, in pleading for a better understanding of the ills of real estate and the need for interest rate revision.

LONDON, March 11 (AP). -- Aston Villa crept up on Arsenal and Sheffield Wednesday in the first division play of the English League today, winning its match from West Bromwich Albion, 3-2, while Arsenal was being held to a 1-1 draw by Leicester City and the Wednesday was losing to Newcastle United, 3 to 1.

MOTOR accidents at night caused a "tremendous" personal and economic loss in New York State during 1932, it is pointed out by the Bureau of Motor Vehicles. While actual figures were not given, it was said that 50 per cent of mishaps resulting in death and 46 per cent in injuries occur after dark.

OTTAWA, March 9. -- No Canadian bank has closed its doors in the past ten years, and only two have been declared insolvent since 1910. The feature of Canadian banking formerly most subject to criticism -- the branch system -- in the past three years of extraordinary stress has proved its greatest strength.

ASHEVILLE, N.C. -- Visitors from all sections of the nation are expected to visit Asheville in the latter part of this month and during April to see the Spring flowers of the famous gardens surrounding Biltmore House when the display is usually at its best.
BOSTON, March 9. -- Maine continues to go Democratic. Every city in the State which held an election on Monday last chose a Democratic with a bang. Every candidate tically a Democratic sweep.

STILL far from being perfectly understood (we are too close) is the "modern movement." The phenomenon, at any rate may just as well be accepted as inevitable, after which it but remains to analyze and dissect, in our effort to separate wheat and chaff.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., March 11. -- Rutgers University won the thirteenth annual meet of the Eastern Collegiate Swimming Association tonight with a total of 41 points. University of Pittsburgh was second with 21 and Franklin and Marshall, third, with 11.

ONE hundred tons of silver are annually dissolved in America's photographic baths -- much of it in Hollywood. And so K. Hickman, W. Weyerts and O. Goehler, all of the Eastman Kodak Laboratories, have thought it worth the trouble to devise a way of recovering so rich a waste by new methods, which they describe in Industrial and Engineering Chemistry.

OUT in the University of California are the Lehmers, father and son, worrying far more about the theory of numbers than about the closing of the banks. Dr. Derrick N. Lehmer is Professor of Mathematic in the university and Research Associate of the Carnegie Institution of Washington; his son, Derrick H., is a National Research Fellow in mathematics.

Long Island covers will be the scene of numerous interesting competitions during the rather brief Spring field trial season, which opened last week-end with the meeting of the Hauppauge Gunning Club. This week's event is that of the North Shore Game Protective Association at Huntington, which will begin on Friday with the usual stakes en the program.

The wholesale markets here during the week definitely reflected banking conditions, according to the market report prepared especially for THE TIMES by Kirby, Block Fischer. Buyer arrivals noticeably decreased, but during the early part of the week mail and telegraph orders were in fairly good volume.
CHICAGO, March 11 (AP). -- Advances of $52,000,000 for construction of 19,370 one-family homes during 1932 are revealed in a summary of the building and loan industry's activities for last year.

Personal experiences connected with New York's worst snowstorm forty-five years ago, when drifts fifteen to twenty feet high clogged the streets and all business an traffic came to a standstill, were recounted yesterday at the annual luncheon of The Blizzard Men of '88 at the Hotel Pennsylvania.

BOTH the author and the publishers of this very Informative book about the Balearic Islands seem to have exaggerated notions as to dense ignorance concerning them in these United States until within the last two or three years. The general reading public and the resort-rusbers very likely did not know, in Mr. Waxman's picturesque phrase, "whether the Balearics were curb stocks, a college yell or something new in gents' underwear."

LONDON, March 11. -- Yosuke Matsuoka, Japan's chief delegate to the League of Nations, and Quo Tai-chi, the Chinese Ambassador to London, were kept in separate studios on opposite sides of a corridor tonight when they broadcast ten-minute statements on the Jehol dispute to the British public.
WASHINGTON, March 11 (AP). -- Uncle Sam's scientists set a trap a few months ago for an earthquake, and now a quake has come along and jumped into it.

THE faculty of philosophy and letters is now installed in the new University City of Madrid, the first faculty to begin its work in the great centre which is to be the chief university of Spain, the fountainhead and climax of the educational system of the country.

PARIS, March 10. -- In that medley of mixed emotions with which Jacques Bonhomme, France's "man in the street," regards the inhabitants of the United States there always has been in recent years something of that irritation with which the unfortunate look on those who are moneyed and consequently self-satisfied.

BARCELONA, Feb. 28. -- The granting of autonomy to Catalonia will have an increasingly important effect on the economic situation in Spain in general, notwith-standing the Catalan pose that the movement is a purely cultural one.

CHICAGO, March 11. -- Mrs. Jane Dowie, widow of John Alexander Dowie, founder of Zion City and the Christian Apostolic Church, died today at the home of Mrs. John Innes in Zion City, Ill., where she had lived since she was evicted a month ago from Shiloh House, the mansion erected by her husband.

Reflecting the unsettled condition of the country's finances, bonds called for payment last week, prior to their maturity dates, were the fewest for a week in many years Those announced for payment in March were nearly all municipals and, with the exception of an entire issue of industrial bonds and two small lots of foreign bonds, those for future months also were mainly municipals.

I think I can give an instance of a more complex problem put up to a postmaster than that noted in THE TIMES of March 5 about the letter addressed "To the colored man who always sings when ships pass the Panama Canal."
ATLANTA, March 9. -- The most apparent ray of hope in the present muddled economic situation is the faith of the people of this section in President Roosevelt.

A SPECIAL performance of "The Emperor Jones," with Lawrence Tibbett, and the second act of "Lakme," with Lily Pons, will be given by the Metropolitan Opera Company Saturday afternoon for the benefit of the Free Milk Fund for Babies.

Although it is generally expected that banking service will be resumed tomorrow on a basis sufficient to supply the ordinary demands of trade, plans for the reopening of the security and commodity exchanges remain uncertain. Present indications point to some further delay with respect to some of the markets.

TOKYO. WHEN Lieut. Gen. Sadao Arakl was summoned from a provincial command fifteen months ago to be Minister of War It was not the fighting in Manchuria which made his post the most Important In the administration.

Arthur Hollick, paleobotanist at the New York Botanical Garden, formerly one of the leading citizens of Staten Island, where he was president of the Richmond County Park Commission thirty years ago, died yesterday afternoon of pneumonia at his residence, 4,206 Carpenter Avenue, Bronx.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Mrs. Roosevelt attended this afternoon a party given in Continental Hall by the Girl Scouts of the District of Columbia to celebrate the twenty-first anniversary of Girl Scouting in this country.

Following a steady rise last week of 45 English points, contract quotations in Liverpool reacted 11 to 12 points yesterday. An advance of a point in American middling carried the premium over Indian to 58 points, which was a few points wider than the average differences prevailing for several months.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- The sensation in Washington for a week has been like that which a person, bent on a life-and-death errand thousands of miles away, would experience when he changed from an ox-cart to Frank Hawks's airplane.

A BENIGN Providence must have guarded these two babes in the woods during their wanderings among the pueblos and over the deserts of the Southwest, preserving them through all their amazing pilgrimage so that the author could write about it in this book, which most readers are likely to find enchanting as the author did the sand out of which it grew.

The indoor polo program at the Squadron C Armory, Brooklyn, last night was featured by two fast games in the metropolitan circuit. The first of these was a Class B affair in which the Crusaders conceded two goals to Fort Hamilton and triumphed, 10 1/2 to 9 1/2, on a goal by Lieut. Col. J.K. Brown.

SHANGHAI, Feb. 15. -- Szechwan Province once more comes into the limelight, with the news that a large force of the Communist troops which were driven from Hopeh into Shensi Province last Summer is operating in it.

LONDON, March 11 (AP). -- Following are the Board of Trade figures of Great Britain's foreign trade for the month of February, in pounds: Exports of British products, u27,920,000; re-exports, foreign goods, u4,480,000; total exports, u32,400,000; imports, u49,070,000; excess of imports, u16,670,000.

Gifts and bequests totaling $124,782,84 have been received by New York University in the last three months, William M. Kingsley, president of the United States Trust Company and treasurer of the university, announced yesterday.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., March 11. -- Amherst defeated Wesleyan, 63 to 50, today in a Little Three indoor track dual meet in the Alumni Athletic Building. Walsh, Haines and Van Schenk, all of Amherst, were tied for first place in the pole vault.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- President Roosevelt has virtually decided upon the main features of his unemployment relief program, but will delay its submission to Congress until the middle of next week to give that body an opportunity to pass finally upon his budget economy proposal.

WASHINGTON, March 11. -- Carrying the exceptionally higher interest rates of 4 and 4 1/4 per cent for short-term paper, the government on March 15 will issue $800,000,000 certificates of indebtedness to meet a maturity of $660,715,500 in 3 3/4 per cent, and $33,591,400 in 2 per cent anti-hoarding certificates falling due on that date and for other necessary expenditures, Secretary Woodin announced tonight.

Declaring that free public education has been threatened by budget cuts encouraged by bankers "who sold their stock short" and by "tax-dodger leagues," several speakers, at a joint luncheon of three teachers' organizations yesterday in the Biltmore, pleaded for "unity" among all teachers, parents and civic leaders to maintain the present high standards of secondary education.

Rear Admiral BYRD has been at the two points on the earth where all lines of longitude converge, where there is no latitude, where North suddenly becomes South, or where South becomes North, and where there is neither East nor West. He has again found such an ideal region this side of the two Poles.

CHICAGO, March 9. -- Full consciousness of the political implications involved in the tragic death of Mayor Anton Cermak has not yet come to the dazed minds of citizens. Other happenings of national importance have absorbed the anxious thought of the majority.

WEST PALM BEACH, Fla., March 11. -- America is "recovering from a wild debauch of frenzied finance, crazy speculation and insensate greed," but "never has the country had brighter prospects ahead than at present," Adolph S. Ochs, publisher of THE NEW YORK TIMES, said here today on the eve of his seventy-fifth birthday anniversary.

LONDON, March 11 (AP). -- Yosuke Matsuoka, who arrived here tonight, expressed outspoken personal opinions on Japanese-American relations and deplored Secretary of the Navy Swanson's announcement that the American fleet would be retained in the Pacific.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., March 11. -- Many women In Scarsdale will open their homes on Friday afternoon for bridge parties to aid the philanthropic work of the committee of 100 of the Scarsdale Woman's Club. The proceeds will be used for the following Westchester institutions: The Jennie Clarkson Home, Grasslands Hospital, the Cancer Hospital, Eastview and the Children's Village.
